column2: IF light can be controlled on the stage to create moods and atmosphere isn't it time that something were done with sound? Asking himself the question, Harold Burris-Mayer of Stevens Institute of Technology undertook research which may have a profound influence on composers of operas, dramatists and actors.

THE word "Spring" as part of a book's title leads one to expect something delicately imaginative. "The Enchanted Spring," however, is not, for instance, like Robert Nathan's delicious idyl, a work of imagination but of fancy; and some of one's disappointment is due to the inevitable contrast.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Revised in an effort to meet possible constitutional objections and carrying a provision designed to block suits to recover processing taxes, the AAA amendments bill today was ordered favorably reported by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- President Roosevelt's recent observation that "it is high time to deal with the nation's transportation as a single, unified problem" has again focused attention on chaotic conditions in the industry, viewed from the standpoint of a coordinated mechanism, and once more has reminded the country of the need for effective treatment of the question.

AUTEUIL, France, June 29 (AP). -- Empress Eugenie sunshades, black hats, lace mitts and ground-trailing frocks combined yesterday to make one of the most eccentric style displays ever seen at the running of the fashionable Prix des Drags race.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29. -- Overcrowded conditions in State institutions for the care of mental and nervous diseases resulting from the depression has brought an urgent need for 6,100 more beds for neuropsychiatric World War veterans, Watson B. Miller of Washington, national chairman of the American Legion rehabilitation committee, declared here today.

AN exhibition of photographs and renderings of interiors by members of the Decorators Club has opened in the club's gallery in the Squibb Building. It may be visited daily from 10:30 to 5, except Saturday and Sunday, until July 26.

NOT all ventures off the beaten track are as successful as Victor Album M-261, in which we have a first recording of Ernest Chausson's symphony in B flat, Op. 20, on three records, played by the orchestra of the Paris Conservatory under the direction of Piero Coppola.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 29. -- The Misses Cecilia M. and Marie I. vom Rath, twin daughters of Mr. and Mrs. William H. vom Rath of Pound Hollow in this community, were introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club.

The opening of a competition for the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Prize of $1,000 for a work of chamber music written for four string instruments without piano has been announced by the Division of Music in the Library of Congress. The award is made under the provisions of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation.

PROGRESSIVE BEQUEST: The will of the late Bronson M. Cutting, written in his own hand on Senate stationery, was filed last week. The estate, estimated at $4,000,000, was divided mainly among relatives and close friends living in his adopted State of New Mexico.

DALLAS, Texas, June 27. -- An interesting political drama is being enacted in the Southwest just now in the spectacle of the personal popularity of President Roosevelt holding loyal to the New Deal a section whose confidence in its policies is wavering perceptibly.

PARIS, June 29. -- A resolution calling on governments to undertake immediate stabilization of currencies was unanimously adopted today at the closing session of the International Chamber of Commerce congress.

A SIMPLE and sometimes lunatic avenue, Broadway adopts new heroes and heroines for notoriously odd reasons and sometimes for no reason at all. Some one once declared lyrically that, yes, he had no bananas, and that wrecked the first half of the Nineteen Twenties.

All the city's library buildings, including the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, are being renovated by about 225 relief workers, Francis Boardman, Director of the Works Division, reported yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, Director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

Julius Damato, 11 years old, arrested three weeks ago with his brother, Frank, 13, and Libson Lawrence, also 13, a Negro, for stealing a policeman's pistol and killing a man during a hold-up in a lot in Jamaica, Queens, faces amputation of the first and second fingers on his left hand.

A group representing the United Depositors Committee of the closed Bank of United States called at the offices of George W. Egbert, State Superintendent of Banks, at 80 Centre Street, yesterday morning and demanded that he confer with it in the presence of newspaper reporters.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 29. -- Preservation of the Constitution, a return to the gold standard, a protective tariff for industry, a revival of the anti-trust laws and the discontinuance of governmental monopolies and public ownership in any field that will interfere with private enterprises were among the planks offered to the New England Young Republican conference tonight by its resolutions committee as a platform of principles.

GENEVA. -- The prospect for preventing the Ethiopian question from developing into open conflict and a break between Italy and the League when the Council's time limit for arbitration ends on Aug. 25 seems no brighter now on the moral or diplomatic or legal side than on the military one.

THE season is at its height and musical events have been numerous and important. We have had international opera at Covent Garden and Mozart opera at Glyndebourne. The B.B.C. have given us a London music festival conducted, in turns, by Boult, Koussevitzky and Toscanini.

By way of a vacation while his new stratosphere ship is under construction, Wiley Post, who has flown twice around the world, will pilot his wife and Miss Fay Gillis, woman flier and writer, on a six-week flight through Siberia.

In the slowest trading in exactly, three months, the share market was steady during the half-day trading period yesterday. Transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 252,000 shares. Prices fluctuated within very narrow confines, and some of the issues usually termed active failed to sell at all, among them Allied Chemical, American Tobacco and Baltimore Ohio.

THE recent explosion of an armaments plant near Wittenberg recalls incidents in the life of Martin Luther, who for many years, first as an Augustinian monk, later as leader of the Reformation, made this ancient city on the Elbe his home.

A SOUTHERNER by birth and long tradition, Robert Rylee has written a dramatic and unusual first novel which is an uncompromising indictment of the White South, particularly Mississippi, in its relationship with the Negro.

BOTH Byron and Keats suffered the slings and arrows of outrageous criticism in their earliest ventures into print. Of Byron's "Fugitive Pieces," privately printed in 1806, all but four copies were destroyed by the author because one of the poems was scored severely for its viciousness.

The semi-annual awards of the Cooperation-in-Government movement to 275 members of the graduating classes in the city's high schools and to one graduate of the Sherburne (N.Y.) High School were announced yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., June 29 (AP). -- William Ellery Leonard, poet whose fear of distance keeps him always within a few blocks of the University of Wisconsin, where he teaches, took a young bride into his "prison" today.

NOT only has Alfredo Salmaggi announced a season of popular-priced opera to begin at the Hippodrome on Thursday evening, Sept. 12, but he has gone so far as to make public a full program of presentations for three subscription series.

ON a sunny afternoon at sea there comes the time when bellboys go about the decks ringing a bell in the manner of the old crier and carrying flat-sided horses cut and designed in wood. Soon the foyer resounds with the din of the racing master calling numbers that delay the animals or hurry them across the line.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- A resolution calling for a drive seeking Congressional action to provide employment and relief for "white collar" veterans was adopted this morning by the Yankee Division Veterans Association.

With the Olympic Club coming from San Francisco with what looks to be the strongest combination in its history, the New York Athletic Club is in for a bitter battle this week when it attempts to defend its national A.A.U. team championship at Lincoln, Neb.

At the dinner in Dublin in honor of the seventieth anniversary of WILLIAM BUTLER YEATS'S birthday. Mr. JOHN MASEFIELD called him "the greatest living poet." That honor can hardly be denied him. He "commenced poet" at 19. As Mr. SEAN O'FAOLAIN wrote in our Book Review the other day, he had already an absolute "command of verse."

Governor Lehman ended his day of activity in New York City yesterday with a tour of inspection of the Edenwald School, a branch of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, at Boston Road and 225th Street, the Bronx.

HOULTON, Me. -- Retarded by almost daily showers and heavy rains, farmers of Aroostook County, the world's greatest potato garden, have just finished planting their 1935 crop. This year's planting was late in the beginning because of lingering snows, and the unusual wetness of this season has put the farmer still more weeks behind in his work.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 29. -- Six first-round matches were played as the twenty-first annual invitation tennis singles tournament got under way on the grass courts of the Nassau Country Club today. Only two of the six seeded players saw action.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The first of the junior assemblies in the French Village grill of the Hotel Sagamore at Bolton Landing will be held on Tuesday. These assemblies, held weekly, attract many of the younger members of the Summer colony.

NEW flowering plants for Winter window gardens continue to appear in abundant variety, yet there is not a single one so far produced which can be considered as outrivaling the Geranium. With attractive, scented foliage and well-formed blossoms, rich in color, the Geranium still is one of the handsomest, as it is the most reliable, of our Winter-flowering plants.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 29. -- Indication that the State's appropriation for publicity would be continued on the present scale or a larger one was seen today as Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, addressed members of the State Hotel Association in the final session of its semi-annual meeting.

ANY one with a place in the country is popular in the good old Summer time, and city folk with "connections in the country" consider themselves lucky. As for the hostess, on occasions she finds that entertaining is arduous work; nevertheless, she is ever on the alert for new gadgets that will make her guests far more comfortable and add to their amusement.

The sports deck of the new Cunard-White Star liner Queen Mary will be covered by glass to protect passengers when the ship is proceeding in head winds, according to advices from Glasgow, where the ship is under construction. Passengers crossing on the French liner Normandie have commented on the need of such protection.
LEWES, Del., June 29. -- Three fishermen were rescued at sea today as flames swept the Helmi H., a 44-foot auxiliary fishing sloop, fifteen miles off the Delaware coast.

ROOSEVELT, man of many surprises, has suddenly thrown off the pale cast of thought which for the last few months appeared to becloud the Executive countenance, and with sudden and dramatic force has entered upon the third phase of his Presidential career, a phase which differs essentially from, but is not inconsistent with, his first two stages.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 29. -- Starting tomorrow a change in encampments at the two major State military training grounds will set in motion a total of 3,300 New York National Guardsmen. Included in the movement are three units from Manhattan.

SOJOURNERS to the distant and mystic isles of Far East seas tell salt-tinged yarns that may be fable, yet have the quality of truth. In the Dutch East Indies many seamen believe that if they are destined to die in the sea nothing can be done to stave it off.
DALLAS, Texas, June 29. -- The hopes of Texans for rain to halt mounting millions of dollars in dust storm damages were answered -- at a cost of $15,000,000 more, a check-up today showed.

THE full programs for the second annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which is to take place on Aug. 8, 10 and 11 in the amphitheatre of Hanna Farm outside of Stockbridge, Mass., have been completed. Henry Hadley is to be the director and the soloists will be Rudolph Ganz, pianist, and Richard Hale, baritone.

EVEN when he crosses the border for his material there is no mistaking that the author of these tales is a Scotsman. They have a folk rhythm, a distinctively Celtic quality -- akin to that of Ireland yet subtly different -- which marks them as purely and authentically Scotch.

A KIN to putting in the underpinning after the superstructure has been erected, or building the pedestal after the monument is in place, is Fred L. Pattee's bringing out "The First Century of American Literature" subsequently to and not prior to his several books on later American literary developments.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- As paymaster for the Works Progress Administration, the Treasury has taken on the biggest single disbursement job in its history, the distribution of the $4,000,000,000 through which President Roosevelt aims to create work for the 3,500,000 employables now on public relief rolls.

Harold Denny's story about the Soviet twins whose autonomic speech is being studied by psychologists of the Moscow Medico-Biological Research Institute stated that single children of autonomic speech have been known and studied since the time of Darwin.

BUDAPEST. -- Mihailoffists of the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization are, it appears, gradually creeping back to the position of dominance over Bulgarian affairs which they held until drastic measures were taken against them last year by the Gheorghieff Cabinet.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 29. -- Practically every dormitory and fraternity house at Middlebury College is filled as the Romance Language Schools open with the largest enrolment in their history.

Starting tomorrow what is generally considered to be the most widespread curtailment of operations since the depth of the depression, the cotton textile industry, in the coming two weeks, will face its most severe test since the demise of the NIRA.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., June 29. -- Forty-three yachts in five classes sailed through the densest fog seen on New Jersey waters in many years today in the opening championship contests of the season of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.
MOSCOW, June 29. -- Three Japanese incursions into Soviet territory -- two by Japanese troops and one by Japanese-Manchurian gunboats -- were reported today from Siberia.

WHEN Frederick Jackson Turner pointed to the influence exerted by the frontier throughout the formative years of the American nation he set the style for a whole generation of historians. Yet Turner, a great historian who founded a school of history, wrote but little himself and none of his works are set forth in a completely satisfactory fashion.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, in a statement just made public, asserted that any attempt to establish a Farm-Labor party would be successful only if the party was "avowedly anti-capitalist" and organized to campaign for State and local offices as well as national positions.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 29. -- Two teams were tied for first place at the end of the first round today in the Maplewood Country Club invitation best-ball golf tournament for the John F. Roche Trophy. The deadlocked pairs were F. Paul Anderson of Canoe Brook, thrice holder of the New Jersey amateur title, and Edward Schiener of Maplewood and Karl Kellerman, also of Canoe Brook, and his partner, A.B. Graham.

Thomas E. Dewey, young lawyer who made a pronounced success of convicting racketeers as an Assistant Federal Attorney in 1931, was nominated by Governor Lehman yesterday to conduct an inquiry into Manhattan racketeering, vice, crime and any improper connection of law-enforcement officials with such activities.

THE masses of mankind have probably never been well housed. Certainly they never have been by modern standards. A century ago "modern standards" might have meant almost anything, because they would have been largely a question of taste.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- The Connecticut Tercentenary track and field championship meet was won by the New Haven Harriers on the Yale track today. The victors outscored Yale and a sextet of other representative teams with 87 points.

Detectives under Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Ryan arrested thirteen men last night in Brooklyn for alleged participation in hi-jacking activities. Police said six of the men admitted hi-jacking a tobacco truck laden with $7,500 in merchandise April 22.

Ever so often we need to rekindle the fires of all true patriotism, for it is a virtue which has been and can be made productive of great good, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, pastor of the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street, asserted yesterday morning.
Roman Catholics are motivated by love, not fear, in the practice of their religion, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
An outdoor motor boat show, afloat, was established as an annual Summer fixture for the future as the result of action taken last night at City Island by the power boating interests of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Twelve additional registration statements, involving $33,942,515, have been filed under the Securities Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 30. -- Five crack shots from the Roseland Community Gun Club of New Jersey lived up to advance expectations by capturing the Great Eastern team championship as the seventh annual skeet shoot of the Remington Gun Club came to an end today at the Lordship Grounds.

The commodity futures markets were irregular last week in rather quiet trading. Coffee, rubber, silk and copper were lower, while cocoa, hides, wool tops, tin and zinc were higher. Sugar and cottonseed oil were irregular. In the cash markets, all the grains, cocoa, raw sugar, tin, cotton, silk, wool tops and hides were up, while lard, copper and rubber were down.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 30. -- Sailing in light airs, fog and a sprinkling of rain, Arthur Knapp skippered M.O. Griffiths's Kenboy to victory in the Interclub Class today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's special Sunday regatta.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association reports total deposits of $993,651,000 as of June 29, 1935, and total resources of $1,113,896,000. The Bank of America (California), the associated State bank, is not included in the published statement as herefore.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 30. -- Transportation of New York State National Guard units to and from the training camps in motor trucks is approved by the officers and guardsmen training here at Camp Smith, as their arrival at camp or the return to home is now about five hours quicker than before.

That George Washington considered the Constitution an imperfect document, but with "as few radical defects in it as could well be expected," is shown in one of his rare letters on the Constitution which has come to light here.

One of the disconcerting features of contemporary thinking is the easy assumption of premises based on a quantitative or static conception of economics or of civilized life. One man is very rich. Others are poor. Ergo, the former became rich by despoiling the others and, hence, income is unjustly distributed.
SPOKANE, Wash., June 30 (AP). -- Science now uses a bucket of ice water to determine whether a per son will develop high blood pressure years afterward.

A sharp drop in temperature in mid-afternoon, accompanied by a dense fog, drove thousands of persons from the beaches yesterday, causing traffic congestion on the highways equal to some of the worst days of Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- A rigid agreement that TVA critics shall dominate the House group that helps write the final draft of the administration's Tennessee Valley Bill was disclosed today to have been clamped on House leaders.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Full jurisdiction over loading perishable fruits and vegetables for railroad shipment has been assumed by the Freight Container Bureau of the Association of American Railroads, effective tomorrow. This was announced today by John J. Pelley, president of the association.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP). -- Four straight singles by Bob Johnson, Jimmy Foxx, Pinky Higgins and Eric McNair in the last of the ninth enabled the Athletics to defeat the Red Sox, 10 to 9, today.
BOSTON, June 30 (AP). -- In two one-sided games the Braves and Phillies split a double-header today, Boston taking the first, 9 to 3, and Philadelphia the second, 15 to 5.

Stock Exchange values having risen a week ago, measured by the "averges," to the highest level since the Autumn of 1931, and the course of general business not yet indicating whether hopes of a forward movement, after the mid-Summer halt, will be fulfilled, some reaction in stocks would not have been unnatural.

Loon, Alden Smith's 17-foot sloop-rigged decked-sailing canoe, won the first heat for the Elliott Trophy on the second day of Race Week for the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association on Eastchester Bay off City Island yesterday.

Since the Securities and Exchange Commission took over the administration of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, on Sept. 1, 1934, it has been winning the war against stock frauds, the Better Business Bureau says in its annual report issued yesterday.

Officials of the Furness, Anchor and other steamship lines docking their ships along the Hudson River front between Forty-eighth and Fifty-fourth Streets are contemplating a petition to Mayor La Guardia to have a bus service inaugurated for passengers and visitors.

Captain Bill Fagen returned to New York the other day from Bimini, chanting praises of the Bahaman resort as an angler's Eldorado and bringing new tales of the fishing prowess of Ernest Hemingway, the author.

MEXICO, D.F., June 30. -- The Mexican Government has inclined recently toward showing some tolerance toward Catholics, although there has been no official announcement concerning this. Semi-officially it has been announced that the government would welcome a more widespread reopening of private schools, conditional on a reasonable observance of the governmental program for socialistic education as outlined in President Lazaro Cardenas's six-year plan.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 30. --An array of present and former professional champions of Westchester, Long Island and Connecticut joined forces today to conquer the invading all-star Japanese golfers in a team match over the links of the Lawrence Farms Club, 8 1/2 to 1/2.

Southbound traffic on the New Haven Railroad was threatened in the Bronx shortly after 6 last night when a one-and-one-half-ton ice truck owned by Salvatore Curtez of 955 Woodlock Avenue, Bronx, rolled down a hill and lodged against a stone parapet of the railroad.
DUBLIN, June 30. -- Speaking in his own constituency of Clare this week-end President Eamon de Valera definitely set his face against all subversive armed movements.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30. -- The 50,000 Jews who were admitted to Palestine in the last year were merely the beginning of a mass immigration of sufficiently great numbers to remove hundreds of thousands of Jews from the economic and political danger points in Europe, according to Morris Rothenberg, president of the Zionist Organization of America.

PARIS, June 29. -- Confidence has not returned in France. An unfavorable impression was made by the attitude of the Chamber of Deputies, where a section of the Radical Socialists, who are the most widely represented party in the new government, joined with the Socialists and Communists in trying to create difficulties for the government.

Only upon the basis of friendliness and cooperation and with a devotion to interests higher than one's own immediate financial advantage can man build an ideal social order, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University, declared in a sermon at the Riverside Baptist Church yesterday morning.

MOSCOW, June 30. -- Preliminary data on the first half of this year, the third year of the second Five-Year Plan, indicate that heavy industry is operating more smoothly than ever before. The figures were made public today in the newspaper Pravda.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 30. -- Yale annexed the annual national intercollegiate outboard championship on Lake Quinsigamond for the second time today, beating Rutgers, victor for the past two years, 4,242 points to 4,084.
PARIS, June 30. -- With the running of the Grand Prix de Paris at Longchamp racetrack in the Bois de Boulogne, today, the "Grande Semaine" of the Paris season came to an end.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Weather conditions and crop reports are dominating factors in the grain markets, particularly wheat, the harvesting of which is said to have been about completed in the extreme South, with the work rapidly moving northward at a good rate.

The new all-steel Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild, which was dedicated recently at Pier 1, the Battery, will make its maiden voyage today, leaving the East Twenty-second Street pier to carry ill and crippled children to Sandy Hook and return.

One of the new industries which may be born out of the depression is that of the prefabricated house. Nearly every observer agrees that our standard of living in the last few decades has risen less in our housing than in almost any other sphere. One reason for this is that the productivity of labor in other industries has been increasing more rapidly than in residential construction.

DENVER, Col., June 30. -- In an attempt to scrap outmoded school subjects and methods and to give the pupils of 1936-40 training suited to modern-life needs, the executive committee of the National Education Association, on the eve of its annual convention here, voted to establish a new educational policies commission to draft a five-year plan for American education.

DETROIT, Mich., June 30. -- William Lee Ferris, also known as William Sweitzer, 26 years old, who has a record of numerous arrests for petty crimes, confessed to police today that he had shot and killed Howard Carter Dickinson, New York attorney and nephew of Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

PITTSBURGH, June 30. -- Steel producers endeavored to run their mills as fully as possible last week because of the holiday this week, but even at that production of ingots was only at the rate of the preceding week -- 38 per cent of capacity.

Long before the NRA or the Church League for Industrial Democracy, the Very Rev. James Otis Sargent Huntington, co-founder and Superior of the Order of the Holy Cross, oldest monastic order of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, was espousing the cause of social justice, said the Rev. Dr. Granville M. Williams, the rector, yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Contemplating a "health inventory" in fifty cities with special reference to chronic diseases and physical impairments such as infantile paralysis, arthritis, deafness, blindness, Bright's disease and other afflictions incapacitating persons for employment, the United States Public Health Service has asked the Division of Applications and Information of the Works Progress Administration for an allotment of $3,450,000.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 30. -- An appeal to the American Federation of Labor to join with progressives in Congress in the establishment of a third party was made here today by Representative Thomas R. Amlie of Wisconsin in an address before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30. -- Gregory Mangin triumphed in two matches to reach the quarter-final round as play in the twenty-first annual invitation singles tournament of the Nassau Country Club was continued on the club's grass courts today.
NEW ORLEANS, June 30. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week was rather limited most of the time, but developed a spurt and a decidedly firmer tone Friday,

Twenty-eight graduate students from twenty-four colleges and universities have received scholarships in the School of Journalism at Columbia University for the coming academic year, the first in which the school will be exclusively graduate, Dean Carl W. Ackerman announced yesterday.

BERLIN, June 29. -- Extension of the moratorium on the transfer of foreign bonds until July, 1936, has had no appreciable effect in the markets here. Indeed the group of certificated dollar bonds, which theoretically carry a gold liability, was firm on the Boerse.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- An estimated decrease of 20 per cent in the Spring crop of pigs for 1935, compared with the small showing a year ago, has suggested to the provision industry that consumers of dressed pork are likely to be forced to continue paying high prices for pork loins and bacon for the next year.

Offering will be made to the public today of $8,000,000 city of Indianapolis, Ind., gas plant revenue 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1938 to 1967, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Otis Co. The bonds are priced to yield 2.75 to 4 per cent.
TOKYO, June 30 (AP). -- Japan's foreign trade ledgers for the first half of 1935 closed today showing a gain of 17 per cent over the first six months of 1934.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- A second rebuff to pacifists marked the closing session today of the Central Conference of American Rabbis when the representatives of Reform Judaism refused to approve a resolution urging "all Jews" not to bear arms in time of war and absolving Germany and other belligerents of responsibility for the World War.

LONDON, June 29. -- The cotton trade is critical of the articles published in the United Kingdom by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace on the United States cotton policy, and his fears that an export bounty would draw retaliatory measures were said to be unfounded.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Spreading operations, buying December corn and selling December wheat, attracted attention last week on the Board of Trade, especially on the part of local professionals, who sold the wheat and bought the corn and were active in closing their commitments in the last few days, greatly enlivening trade.

IT was the pitching debut of Ralph Kress that brought this up. One day last week at the Yankee Stadium the hirelings of Marse Joe McCarthy were lathering the slants of Washington pitchers to a flourishing fare-thee-well.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 30. -- Continuing to play sub-par golf, Willie Turnesa, 20-year- old amateur star of the famous golfing family, vanquished Jimmy Loftus of Briar Hills by 5 and 4 in the final round of the second annual Briar Hills invitation tournament today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 30. -- Possibility that Soviet Russia will discard her anti-religious policy and come to some agreement with the Pope is said here to have been the subject of important conversations between Cardinal Verdier and Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, who has just returned from Moscow.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Harvesting of oats is under way in the Middle West, with returns fairly satisfactory, and there is a noticeable increase in offerings of new, as well as of old-crop oats for July-August-September shipment. The offerings are being bought by cash interests which hedge by sales of futures.
PEIPING, China, June 30 (AP). -- Martial law was proclaimed today in Tungchow, fifteen miles east of Peiping, upon reports that mutineers against the Chinese Army had taken refuge there.

Plans for the reorganization, administration, and expansion of white-collar and educational relief projects will be discussed at a city-wide conference of social scientists and workers in Harkness Hall, New Library, Columbia University, at 8 o'clock on the evening of July 10.
LONDON, June 30.-- Hundreds of thousands of government employes will receive higher pay beginning tomorrow when the government fulfills its promise to restore the salary cuts imposed in 1931.

KANSAS CITY, June 30. - Missouri's "Jim" Reed lashed out tonight at President Roosevelt's wealth-distributing tax program as "open to every criticism which can be levied against the burglar or highwayman."

Preparing for special sales events, retail buyers emphasized off-price Summer merchandise, especially in women's wear lines, in their purchasing activities in the wholesale market here last week. With many "bargains" available in the dress division of the market, buyers made fairly liberal purchases to fill in stocks, and substantial orders were also placed for women's Fall coats for early promotional events.

Noise abatement, for some time a dormant issue, has come to the fore again recently. Most of the comments, official and otherwise, have to do with mechanical noise of some sort. I should like to emphasize the terrific nervous strain and annoyance brought about by the human voice.

The much-heralded corn-eating contest that was to be the high spot of the annual dinner and outing of the Locality Mayors of Greater New York was suddenly called off after the dinner had begun last night because Chief Mayor Stitch McCarthy, on whom there was heavy preliminary betting, let it be known that he was a "dental cripple."

IT is an article of H.L. Mencken's own American credo that present-day native radicals, particularly of the Communist persuasion, are all solemn fellows, sadly different from George Bernard Shaw and the ebullient boys of the pre-war I.W.W., who had their ribald songs about the certainty of pie in the sky when you die. And, to be strictly honest, there was a time when Mr. Mencken's belief had a considerable measure of truth.

ROCKY POINT, L.I., June 30. -- The Nemo 3d, seventy-seven-foot houseboat cruiser owned by H.S. Malchow of Atlanta, Ga., floated off the shore rocks here which held her fast for more than eight hours. The craft had damaged two or three planks and was taking a little water as she pulled away at 10:45 tonight.

The charge that speculators who "either knew or sensed" President Roosevelt's intention to devalue the dollar made huge profits by shipping gold out of the country just before his inauguration and bringing it back later was voiced yesterday by Norman C. Norman, jeweler and dealer in gold, of 40 West Forty-eighth Street.

A free hand, sufficient appropriation by the city to finance a thorough-going inquiry, and complete cooperation by the La Guardia administration are the conditions Thomas E. Dewey will insist on if he is to become special prosecutor in the vice and crime investigation in New York County ordered by Governor Lehman.

BERLIN, June 30. -- The veil of mystery behind which Germany has accomplished her rearmament is about to be lifted. The world will be informed about her new army, navy and aviation corps to the same extent that other powers issue information on their armed forces, it is stated in informed circles.
Sinking-fund purchases amounting to $424,507 are being arranged on two loans in behalf of the government of the Argentine nation.

PARIS, June 30. -- What superficially might seem like a quiet European week-end, with Paris intent upon her Grand Prix, with Britain devoted to her own sports and with Germany engrossed in a celebration intended to veil and justify for all time the blood bath of last year, has been by no means as peaceful diplomatically.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- Death, racing against its record of 36,000 people killed in traffic accidents last year, was almost even at the 1935 half-way mark today.

Homes and building sites on Long Island and in Westchester and New Jersey were sold in large numbers in deals announced over the weekend. The deals indicate an improvement over recent week-end trading.

The Yanks fought to the last ditch against the Senators at the Stadium yesterday before 12,500 fans, but went down to defeat under protest in twelve innings. The count was 8 to 7 after 3 hours 14 minutes of mingled baseball, protests and arguments.

Governor LEHMAN finally yielded to the weight of argument and decided to urge, or direct, District Attorney DODGE to appoint as his assistant in charge of the racket inquiry and prosecution Mr. THOMAS DEWEY. It was at first objected that he is not well known.
SHANGHAI, June 30 (AP). -- Frank J. Raven, head of the now defunct Raven banking corporations, which closed on May 24, was placed under the custody of the United States Court in China today.

A new issue of $35,000,000 of Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., refunding mortgage gold bonds, Series B, 3 3/4, per cent, due in 1960, will be offered to the public today by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds are priced at 98 1/2 and accrued interest.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 30. -- Although never ahead until the final period, the Texas polo quartet recorded a well-earned 8-to-6 triumph over Aknusti on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today in a first-round match of the annual Meadow Brook Club Cups handicap tournament.

GENEVA. June 22. -- "Sympathetic support" for the work of the disarmament committee of the Women's International Organization is expressed in a letter from Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, accompanying a gift of $1,000 to it which the committee has made public.

Because of smaller payments in several groups, particularly in the bank, insurance, food and railroad classifications, which offset improvement in others, the aggregate of dividends declared in June was slightly less than a year ago and below the amount voted in May.

MOSCOW, June 30. -- A preparedness demonstration of a different sort was held in Red Square today. There were no thundering tanks, no clanking tractor-drawn field guns and no clouds of giant bombing planes as in the military shows that the Soviet Union has given so often since it began to feel itself threatened by war.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., June 30. -- Venturon, the Fishers Island sloop owned by William H. Young of Larchmont, won the 88-mile race from Norwalk to Duck Island and return today. She had elapsed time of 18:06:37 and corrected time of 17:00:19.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 30. -- Resolutions favoring a program of Americanism and urging the deportation of all aliens who have been in the United States ten years or more without signifying intention of becoming citizens were adopted at the annual State encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, which closed here tonight.
MEXICO, D.F., June 30. -- Unofficial sources said today that the government planned a general relaxation of its policies toward political enemies and toward the Catholic Church.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 30. -- An argument as to who should have had the family automobile over the week-end resulted late tonight in the shooting of John Smollen, 42 years old, by his wife, in the kitchen of their home at 139 Fourth Street, according to the police. Smollen, a fireman on the Central Railroad of New Jersey. was removed to the Alexian Brothers Hospital with bullets in his arm, neck and liver.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- While the collection machinery for New Jersey's 2 per cent sales tax, which goes into effect tomorrow, was being geared here today Governor Hoffman announced at Sea Girt that he would start negotiations immediately with the Federal Government to reduce the State's quota toward relief funds so a resultant surplus from sales tax receipts could be used to lower real estate taxes.

Some 90,000 public school children who daily received free lunches during the school term will continue to receive them through the Summer, it was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.
General Hugh S. Johnson will take over the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau here today as newly appointed Works Progress Administrator for New York City.

NEWPORT, June 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Washington Frazer have selected the evening of Aug. 12 for a dinner-dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Aerielle Frazer, to society. Mrs. Beverley Bogert, who introduced her daughter, Miss Lesley Bogert, last Summer at a ball, is planning a party here for three of this Summer debutantes, Miss Frazer, Miss Jane Pope, who will be introduced on Aug. 10, and Miss Virginia French.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., June 30. -- The influence of Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, coupled with the stand of Worcester delegates, resulted in a scrapping of both majority and minority reports of the resolutions committee by the New England Conference of Young Republicans today.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 30. -- The sylvan silence of Essex Fells has been preserved by the forethought of the City Fathers and by an ordinance duly passed and inscribed, the dogs and roosters and ducks of the community learned today.

The Student League for Industrial Democracy yesterday described the National Youth Administration's $50,000,000 project as "a peril to the freedom of thought and action of American students." At the same time the Works Division reported to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, that the basic data necessary to an effective handling of the youth program in New York City would be available when the project got under way.
One of the most valuable trophies in competition in the metropolitan area passed into the keeping of Berkeley Bell yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Demand for a tax bill which would broaden the base on income taxes and not be a measure designed as an "appeal to mass prejudice" nor "a mere sop to political prejudice" was voiced today by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, a potential candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

GREENVILLE, N.Y., June 30 (AP). -- A heavy guard was maintained today at the hospital bed of Alfred E. Volckmann, age 19, son of a local butcher, to forestall any new attempt at suicide following upon his reputed confession that he had criminally attacked and afterward slain Helen Glenn, aged 9.

A letter addressed to holders of Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation twenty-five-year collateral trust 5 per cent bonds by the bondholders' committee headed by Cecil P. Stewart asserts that the committee will "make impartial investigation of the management so as to assure the bondholders that, while the company is in receivership, no opportunities are being neglected to safeguard their investment and to improve the properties."

LONDON, June 30 (AP). -- Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Russia and others have speeded up their research on aviation and have expanded aerial programs in their race for aerial supremacy. They are turning out and testing scores of models of advanced planes of all sorts.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 30. -- One hundred and fifty men and women were plunged together amid broken timbers this afternoon when the centre section of the grandstand at Jaeger's Velodrome collapsed shortly after the place had been opened to the public for the first time.
SKYTOP, Pa., June 30 (AP). -- The American Whist League crowned two more bridge champions over the week-end in closing sessions of its forty-fifth annual congress.

Swarms of children shepherded by fluttery mothers and perspiring fathers kept the echoes rumbling in Grand Central Terminal last night in the greatest exodus to vacation camps that railroad officials have handled since 1931.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30. -- The odors of a hospital dispensary restored the memory of an amnesia victim here tonight. He is John Normington, 29 years old, of Marshfield, Wisconsin, son of a Waukesha laundry operator.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The promise of the opponents of prohibition that bootleggers, poison liquor and crime would disappear with the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment have not come true, the Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church asserted today.
Several mid-year changes in brokerage and other financial houses have been announced.

CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP). -- The White Sox closed a four-game series with the Indians with an 8 to 0 victory today after losing the first game of a double header, 3 to 2, their third loss of the series.

Cotton futures here touched the highest levels last week since the end of May just before the NRA code decision. Trading interest was. moderate most of the week, and with contracts scarce the market proved sensitive to adverse crop reports from private sources.
PARIS, June 30 (AP). -- Dueling masters today deplored the apparent preference for pistols instead of the time-honored sword in present-day duels.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., June 30 (AP). -- Fifty officials and experts in social planning met here today to give their advice to the Federal Government in its task of laying out new communities under the $500,000,000 resettlement program.
PARIS, June 30.-- Last week's rupture in the Franco-German commercial negotiations has revealed a strange situation, especially in view of the constant French denunciation of Germany's rearmament.

In a seldom frequented corner of the Bronx which was as green and peaceful as parts of the Dalmatian Coast 300 Yugoslavs spent yesterday afternoon celebrating a Summer holiday with national songs, folk-dances, barbecued lamb and kegs of foamy beer.

Miss Jay Boland, 19 years old, of 1,560 Inwood Avenue, the Bronx, was fatally injured at 6:15 o'clock last night when she was thrown from the rear seat of a motorcycle at 170th Street and Cromwell Avenue, the Bronx. She died of a fractured skull on her way to Morrisania Hospital.

More than 3,000 women active in the work of providing for the city's sick, were asked yesterday by Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the woman's division of the United Hospital Fund, to unite in a joint program for meeting the community's hospital needs.

BERLIN, June 29. -- The monthend demand for money has been greater this month than in May. As a contributory factor, the Gold Discount Bank continued to absorb cash by selling promissory notes, of which some 250,000,000 marks were marketed in the first three weeks of June.

BERLIN, June 30. -- About 1,000 "political prisoners" are believed to be still under detention in German concentration camps, while several thousand more are serving penal sentences for various minor offenses against the Third Reich.

The Wall Street pigeons appear to have joined the Wall Street wolves as members of a persecuted class. Until four weeks ago, when they were disfranchised, the birds in that section of the financial community enjoyed special privileges that put them in a pigeon class by themselves.

LONDON, June 29. -- The Paris discussions of stabilization of exchanges are considered here to be academic and not a prelude to any official move. They are helpful, however, in obtaining an exchange of views.

VIENNA, June 30. -- Increasing hostility between the Heimwehr-Fascists and their Clerical partners in the present Austrian regime (which rigid control of the press keeps out of the public view as far as possible) had a startling expression today.

" The church must stop supporting wars or go under; she must get out of the war business," warned Rev. Dr. Linley V. Gordon, secretary of the World Alliance for International Friendship, in a sermon yesterday morning at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.
DODGE CITY, Kan., June 30. -- Something unique in the way of a housing project which gives a new twist to farm life is well on the way to completion at Wilroads Gardens, five miles east of here.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) (By mail). -- An effort is being made by the Bank of England to stop speculation against gold currencies. In response to a circular it sent out meetings have been held with representatives of joint stock banks and bullion brokers at which they were requested to discourage forward dealings in gold.

ST. LOUIS, June 30. -- Glenn Cunningham, the Kansas flash, romped to an easy victory over Glen Dawson of Tulsa and Jack Wolff of Manhattan College, New York, in a special 1,000-meter race at the Ozark A.A.U. outdoor track carnival today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- The latest House payroll disclosed today that relatives are favorite employes of thirty-seven House members.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 30. -- Karl Kellerman, Rock Spring Country Club amateur, and A.B. Graham today collaborated in scoring a 68, which added to their 70 of yesterday won the annual Maplewood Country Club's invitation golf tournament. Their total of 138 was the lowest ever scored in the competition for the John F. Roche Trophy.

Mayor La Guardia again declined to disclose yesterday whether he would give his Park Commissioner, Robert Moses, the satisfaction of receiving from the Mayor's hands a formal reappointment to a three-year term as member of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 30. -- The junior set of the Westbury and Wheatley Hills colonies and the parents of some of them gathered today at the polo field of Old Acres, the estate of Mrs. Robert Bacon on the Jericho Turnpike, for the annual Westbury gymkhana in aid of the milk fund of the social service committee of Nassau Hospital at Mineola.
For years American observers have been describing Mexican politics with a naive simplicity, assuming that Mexico is and has been the typical example of one strong man's domination.

NEW HAVEN, June 29. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.6, which compares with 82 the week before, 82.3 two weeks before, 82.3 three weeks before and 82.3 four weeks before.

A call of $760,000 of the Erie Railroad Company's Pennsylvania fifty-year collateral trust 4 per cent gold bonds for redemption through the sinking fund, the first ever made in the thirty-four years that this issue has been outstanding, was announced yesterday by J.P. Morgan Co. as sinking fund trustees.

Continued pressure against the franc in the greater part of June caused larger importations of gold from France than in any previous month in nine years. These shipments, together with smaller amounts from several other countries, made a total of $235,779,200 in gold received at New York last month, the largest for one month since March, 1934, and in contrast with $131,831,600 in May and $61,682,700 in June, last year.

Almost every theatre planning on a Summer season is presenting an attraction of some kind this week. The holiday, of course, gives impetus to this dramatic flood, which includes several new productions. Among the latter (all opening this evening unless otherwise indicated) are:
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

PRINCETON, N. J., June 30. -- More than 1,000 persons attended the first annual Princeton Outdoor Horse Show today, which was dominated by the entries of Mrs. Helen R. Benson of Princeton. Mrs. Benson's horses took two championships, six blue ribbons and thirteen other awards.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 30. -- Religion, if it is to have any value and power, must be real, rational, personal and social; above all, it must be intensely and genuinely spiritual to meet the demands of modern life, the Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York declared tonight in an address at the University of Virginia.
BRAINE L'ALLEUD, Belgium, June 30. -- King Leopold III unveiled today a massive bronze statue erected as Belgium's memorial to her war hero, the late Cardinal Mercier.

Through the offering of one of the largest blocks of Federal Land Bank bonds in recent years, the aggregate face value of new securities publicly offered here in June was the largest for a month since April and well above the previous two years for the corresponding month.

The United States Rubber Company has sent to its stockholders a letter urging them to protest to their representatives in Congress against the proposed plan to tax corporations which operate as holding companies.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- A definite plan for blending NRA and the Federal Trade Commission through new legislation today was reported drafted by Secretary Roper's business division council.

HAMMONTON, N.J., June 30. -- A possibility of Federal aid for berry farmers of this area who are unable to get pickers to harvest the crops was seen here today. Edward J. Webster, official of the Department of Research, Statistics and Finance of the FERA, left here today after investigating farm conditions and indicated his report to the Relief Administration would be favorable to the growers' plea for aid.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Administration forces looked with many misgivings tonight toward the first test in the House tomorrow over the "death sentence" which President Roosevelt has vigorously insisted be retained in his Utility Holding Company Bill.

MERIDIAN, Miss., June 30 (AP). - The flying Keys, Fred and Al, with a world's endurance flight record already won, rode out another storm today as they sought to remain in the air longer than any other humans ever have.

News that Mr. HOOVER has informed certain Republican Senators that he will not seek a nomination for the Presidency next year will confirm belief in his good sense. It is said that before the Summer is over he will make a public statement, or write a letter, announcing his intention to remain in private life.

LONDON, June 29. -- While London at first welcomed President Roosevelt's tax plans as conforming to sound principles of finance and indicating that the manipulation of the currency had been abandoned as a quick road to prosperity, it now recognizes that the implications of the program are immense and that such taxation may be an anti-wealth weapon.

Passage through Congress of the bill to incorporate a National Theatre and Academy represents a worthy purpose and hope. To help bring about a better conception of the theatre as a means of popular recreation and instruction would be a fine thing.

LONDON, June 30. -- More than a hundred of England's most rabid tennis fans, packing camp chairs, had taken their places at Wimbledon's portals before dark tonight to assure themselves seats in the centre court for the matches tomorrow.

It is nonsense to contend that religion is an escape from life, the Rev. William V. Berg, pastor of the Reformed Church of Piermont, N.Y., said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 181st Street.

Returns from the city's 2 per cent sales tax received by the Finance Department total $8,276,452.89 for the second quarter, it was announced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor. The period for payment of the second instalment expired at midnight Saturday, but mail received today bearing a postmark before that time may increase the total slightly.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 30 (AP). -- Wilbur Hess of Rice Institute today captured the national intercollegiate singles tennis championship, defeating Leonard Patterson of California Tech in the final, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The price of the extension of the bituminous coal wage contract for a month was a White House undertaking that "full speed ahead" for the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill would be the order of the day, it was learned today as the full story of the "inside negotiations" yesterday afternoon and evening became available.
We read a lot these days about the government's colonization project in the Matanuska Valley, Alaska, and specifically about the discontent of some of the first settlers.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Five national farm organizations urged tonight a change by the Senate Banking Committee in the Omnious Banking Bill as passed by the House, in which, they asserted, there was "no limit to the powers delegated to the Federal Reserve Board to 'regulate the value of money.'"

Research that will lead to the formulation of sound economic policies in the present-day movement toward improvements in the nation's economic machinery is of great importance, according to the annual report of the Twentieth Century Fund, made public yesterday by Evans Clark, director of the fund.

BERLIN, June 29. -- Industry in May was 64.6 per cent occupied, comparing with 63.3 per cent in April, but the improvement was confined to the heavy-goods branches. Coal output for the first five months was 46,400,000 .tons, against 49,900,100 tons in the 1934 period.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- A seventeen-hit attack that routed three Cub pitchers salvaged a 9-to-7 triumph for the Pirates in the final game of their series before 10,400 today.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Business throughout the Middle West, Northwest and Southwest was interrupted to a moderate extent last week by rains, but the volume of trade, taken as a whole, was regarded as about the same as in the previous week and ahead of that of a year ago.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 30. -- Gerry Smith supplied a thrilling finish to a thrilling polo game at the Sands Point Club today as the Greentree four outscored Great Island, 9 -- 8, in a first-round match in the Meadow Brook Club Cups tournament.

Formal protests that the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church has been sending out official literature of late in which the word "protestant" is deleted have been made by three national organizations. The protests have been sent to the highest officials in the church, including the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop.

Foreign exchanges moved higher and against the dollar last week. In particular the gold currencies showed the best gains, the French franc, guilder and the Swiss unit selling up to the best levels since mid- March. The belga retraced all the ground lost in the last several weeks.

WARSAW, June 30. -- The nationwide collection of the 5,000,000-zloty Pilsudski fund for building Polish ships was the principal feature of a two-day "festival of the sea" celebrated throughout this country to commemorate the fifteenth anniversary of Poland's taking possession of a narrow strip of shore under the terms of the Versailles Treaty.
CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP). -- Behind the four-hit pitching of Tony Freitas the Reds defeated the Cardinals today, 5 to 2, to sweep the three-game series.

For more than two years the legislative has been, for the most part, the docile, if sometimes sullen, creature of the executive. It has yielded its will, it has surrendered its functions, to the President. At first this compliance might find excuse in the common pressure of national disaster and in the zeal for patriotic cooperation.
I would like to make a contribution to the store of information about the events leading up to the hank panic of 1933.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30. -- The Chaco peace conference will open here tomorrow in an atmosphere of optimism in marked contrast with the pessimism that characterized the protracted mediation that arranged the cessation of hostilities.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- Five years old today, 1930's famous infants, the leading characters in the "Bamberger-Watkins baby mix-up," went their separate ways again after their first reunion.
MEXICO, D.F., June 25 (By Mail). -- A new Federal Department of Tourism, to be an official part of the Mexican Government, is in process of organization and will begin functioning next year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 30. -- The terrain in and around Fort Knox, thirty-one miles south of here, is admirably suited to the Treasury Department's plan to cache there in underground vaults a good portion of the gold now stored in New York and Philadelphia.

The steady decline in the price of silver -- it has fallen 11 cents an ounce in less than as many weeks -- has aroused much indignation on the part of the inflation bloc in Congress. Why should a metal as valuable as these enthusiasts believe it to be sag so lamentably in the world's markets? Senator THOMAS of Oklahoma is certain of the answer.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- President Roosevelt will be asked by Representative William F. Brunner of Rockaway Park, N.Y., to give serious consideration to an allocation of work-relief funds to build a transcontinental super-express highway system, Mr. Brunner announced today.

BERGEN, Norway, June 30 (By Wireless). -- Here we are, and on the whole I must confess our trip was both easier and faster than I had anticipated. In 1933 I sailed Dorade over almost exactly the same course in twenty-six days. That was, I need scarcely add, a cruising passage during which Dorade was not driven hard.

No obstacles were placed in the way of the Giants' pennant drive at Ebbets Field yesterday. In fact, the Dodgers helped the Terrymen to increase their lead over the second-place Pirates to eight and a half games by dropping both ends of the double-header, 7 to 4 and 5 to 4.

The House Ways and Means Committee is about to hold hearings in reference to the establishment of a Federal lottery which, we are told, might produce a revenue of $1,000,000,000 a year. What a boon to this country such a lottery would be. Instead of millions of American dollars being sent abroad, we should keep them here.

A new type of national monument to be set aside for the advancement of science is being considered by the Federal Government. The proposal is to utilize the ancient ruins in different sections of the United States as research grounds for archaeologists, says a bulletin from the Department of the Interior.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $6,023,116,130. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

NANTICOKE, Pa., June 30 (AP). -- A story of horror was told today by more than 200 nerve-wracked men, women and children, who were plunged into a roaring stream yesterday by the collapse of a wooden dance pavilion in an amusement park.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- The Bears divided a double-header with Syracuse today before 5,600 persons By winning the nightcap, 3 to 2, Newark scored its first victory over Syracuse in eleven meetings this year. The Chiefs gained the verdict in the opener when Joe Cascarella pitched a 4-to-0 shut-out.

EN ROUTE TO LINCOLN, Neb., June 30. -- The New York Athletic Club track and field squad was humming over the rails tonight, bound for Lincoln and the defense of its National A.A.U. team title at the sixtieth annual American championships on the University of Nebraska cinders.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- Army and navy recruiting stations will be opened tomorrow for enlistment of 60,000 young Americans.
DETROIT, June 30 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin opened a State-wide campaign today to organize automobile plant workers in a plan to bring assurance of a $2,150 annual income.

The fourth and last day of the traffic survey conducted by the Triborough Bridge Authority to find out how many motorists cross the East River, when and for what purpose, ended last night after nearly 100,000 drivers had been questioned at the Queensborough Bridge and the Astoria and College Point ferries.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- The Rev. Dr. Robert Scott Inglis officiated for the last time as pastor today at the historic Third Presbyterian Church, 40 Abington Avenue, in the Forest Hill section of this city, closing a pastorate of thirty-four years.

Reports from business in June were reassuring, in view of previous fears that the invalidation of the NRA codes might lead to a period of disturbance in prices and wages, according to the National City Bank's monthly bulletin, published today.

BERLIN, June 30. -- A Sabbath radio broadcast to the youth of the nation, called the "Hitler Youth Hour," contained today perhaps the most outspoken declaration of scorn for the established church and assertion of the supremacy of Nazism to all religions and other doctrines that the Hitler youth leadership has yet promulgated.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 30. -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House, her home in Halsey's Neck Lane, for the Rev. Dr. Theodore Sedgwick, former rector of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church in Rome, Italy, who conducted the services this morning at St. Andrew's Dune Church, and Mrs. Sedgwick, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins at Pelham Farm.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 30. -- A disagreement over the value of fire protection supplied by the two engines and 110 volunteers of the Montrose Fire Company to the adjoining village of Buchanan was to end in suspension of service to Buchanan at midnight tonight.

Two books by Clarence Day have been named as the August selections of the Book-of-the-Month Club. They are "God and My Father," published several years ago, and "Life With Father," which will be published on Aug. 1 by Alfred A. Knopf.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP). -- The Tigers played havoc with Roger Hornsby's crumbling hurling talent today as they hammered six pitchers for victories in both ends of a Sunday double-header with the Browns. The Tigers took the first game, 18 to 1, and tapered off with an 11-to-6 triumph in the nightcap.

PARIS, June 30. -- Although the number of tourists sailing from New York is reported to have reached boom proportions American visitors in Paris are unusually few. Somewhere between Cherbourg and Paris several thousand American tourists have mysteriously disappeared despite the fact that the festival season here is at its height.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The status of major legislation in Congress is as follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30. -- Addressing delegates of the annual convention of Young Judea, which closed here today, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland urged Jewish youth to shy away from rabid forms of nationalism and fascism, which he declared are driving the nations to war.

A British flag tattooed on his left arm served yesterday to bring about a positive identification of the man whose body was found in Long Island Sound Saturday near Port Chester, N.Y., as Joseph Goodglass, former president of the Hydrox Linen Supply Company of 16 Hooper Street, Brooklyn.
Seventy lots in the Crestwood section of Yonkers brought a total $26,100 at an auction sale last Saturday by Joseph P. Day. The sale was to close the estate of Erne G. Hothorn.

BERLIN, July 1. -- The Boerse was quiet at the opening of the week today, but still firm. Heavy industrials were rather inactive; Vereinigtestahl gained 3/8 point. Potashes were strong, Salzdetfurth gaining 4 points. Machines were firm, Orenstein Koppel gaining 1 point. Electricals rose, Siemens Halske gaining 2 points.

MEXICO, D.F., July 1 (AP). -- Mexico's new Cabinet held its first session today, and a semi-official source said an order would be announced soon paving the way for scores of political and religious exiles to return to the country.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., July 1 (AP). -- Invited advisers to the resettlement and housing conference called by Rexford Guy Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, agreed today that more than one-third of the people of the country were inadequately housed and that the government was the only agency equipped to provide the cure.

The account given by Minister EDEN in the House of Commons yesterday of his recent futile negotiations at Rome was interesting in many ways. It showed, for one thing, that newspaper reports of secret interviews between statesmen are not always mere guess-work.

Thomas Brandon Boggs of 549 Riverside Drive was elected last night as Republican leader of the Thirteenth Manhattan Assembly District to succeed Fred D. Thompson, Y.M.C.A. director, who had resigned. The election was by the county committee members of the district, who met at the clubhouse, 537 West 125th Street.

An early court test of the constitutionality of the reciprocal trade agreements law appeared likely last night following a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday at which representatives of approximately fifteen industries discussed the possibilities of upsetting the law.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1. -- Fourth of July will be celebrated with a wide range of entertainments at clubs and homes here. The chief event will consist of the annual Cowal games of the Round Hill Scottish Association at the estate of Charles Arthur Moore in Round Hill.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 1. -- Two gigantic blasts of dynamite and black powder, witnessed by a crowd of 50,000 Dominion Day visitors, tore an 11,000-ton slice off Table Rock at the Canadian tip of Horseshoe Falls today and sent it crashing to the gorge below with a rumbling roar.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP). -- Arlington Park opened its $400,000 race meeting today, hoping to settle the 2-year-old handicap and 3-year-old championship for 1935. The meeting will run for thirty days.

PALMER, Alaska, July 1 (AP). -- A Federal investigator, apparently siding with complaining Matanuska Valley colonists on some points, discharged the commissary manager today and criticized the way houses are being built -- some without foundations.

DALLAS, Texas, July 1. -- This city received today the best bids in its history for its bonds when bids were opened on $3,500,000 of securities to provide funds for the Texas Centennial Central Exposition which will open here on June 6, 1936. Out of six bids, that of Brown Harriman Co. and associates appeared to be the best, R.V. Tompkins, city auditor, said.

Moderate gains in deposits and resources, together with a larger employment of previously idle funds, was shown in the semi-annual statements of condition published yesterday by several local banks and trust companies in anticipation of calls for reports by the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banking.
PARIS, July 1. -- Walter S. Adams of the Mount Wilson Observatory in California was elected today as a correspondent of the French Academy of Sciences.
The day's session in money witnessed no change from the dull state which has prevailed for many weeks. Inquiry for funds was small, and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

DETROIT, July 1. -- The Tigers moved within 4 points of second place in the American League standings when they defeated the Indians, 4 to 1, today behind the five-hit hurling of Elden Auker, their submarine pitcher.

The first of the eight performances scheduled to be given at the Lewisohn Stadium by the Fokine Ballet took place last night, with three ballets of Fokine's composition comprising the program. These included "Adventures of Harlequin," which received its first New York presentation on this occasion: "Le Spectre de la Rose," with Raul Haakon in the title role, and the Polovtsian dances from "Prince Igor."

Mayor La Guardia won yesterday in the Supreme Court the suit brought to cut off his pay on the ground that his acceptance of President Roosevelt's appointment as a member of the Advisory Committee on Allotments for the spending of the $4,000,000,000 Work Relief Fund automatically created a vacancy in the office of Mayor of New York City.

Before leaving for Washington yesterday morning Mayor La Guardia administered oaths of office to Chief City Magistrate James McDonald as justice of the Court of Special Sessions, Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to succeed Mr. MacDonald as chief city magistrate, and Miss May B. Upshaw, director of examinations in the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 1. -- Shad fishing, once carried on as an industry along this part of the Connecticut River, has come back as a sport, and today hundreds of persons are hooking the fish, which for the first time in many years are swimming up the river by the millions to spawn.

LONDON, July 1. -- An agreement reported to have been reached between the New York Yacht Club and the British Yacht Racing Association is hailed here as presaging a new British challenge for the America's Cup.
The season's first rod and reel catches of broadbill swordfish and the initial appearance of school tuna and bluefish were high lights of an eventful week-end on the offshore fishing grounds.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 1. -- Undoubtedly there are a few Japanese who believe Japan's destiny will take her south of China, but most well-informed Japanese declare the idea of a great extension of the empire is fantastic, according to Edward C. Carter, secretary-general of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

Yesterday's vote in the House on the proposal to restore the "death sentence" in the Administration's holding company bill was, first of all, a victory for rational industrial policy. Regulation is substituted for prohibition, control for outright destruction. That control, as written into the House bill, ought to be exacting enough to satisfy any sensible person.

MILAN, July 1. -- Two mountaineers, greatly fatigued and sunburned, arrived yesterday afternoon at the "House of the Alpinist" in the village of Entreves, near Courmayeur in the Aosta Valley. They gave the names Peters and Mayer. When asked where they came from, they answered, "From Grandes Jorasses. We have climbed the northern wall."

LONDON, July 1. -- A fine century by Bruce Mitchell, cautious Transvaal opening batsman, and clever bowling by Xenophen Balaskas, young Border Province Greek, gave England plenty of cause for worry today as the mother country and South Africa prepared for the third and final day's play tomorrow in the second test cricket match at Lord's.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- In sharp phrases Jouett Shouse told a radio audience tonight that the Roosevelt administration was displacing Democratic government with a "bureaucratic autocracy" and called the 1932 Democratic platform an "outmoded but sound document."

In the shallow of the United States Sub-Treasury Building, at Wall and Nassau Streets, where George Washington made his first inaugural address, the American Protestant Defense League held its first meeting at noon yesterday in a drive "to save the Constitution."

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had reappointed Park Commissioner Robert Moses a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority and has referred Mr. Moses' demand for a formal reappointment to the city's legal advisers as a matter of procedure.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows, Quotations are in cents:

DETROIT, July 1. -- The murder of Howard Carter Dickinson, New York attorney and nephew of Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, was solved today when William Lee Ferris, 26-year-old member of Detroit's underworld, confessed to Prosecuting Attorney Duncan McCrea that he did the killing in a robbery.

Manhattan realty activity was light yesterday, a feature of the sales being a modernization project for two flats in the Chelsea section. Eight properties bought in at foreclosure auction sales included a six-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Broadway and 161st Street.

Establishment of a system of joint action by apparel trade groups in any litigation which may arise with retailers on fair trade practice matters was voted yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives at the offices of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, 468 Fourth Avenue.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, beer racketeer of the prohibition era, owes New York State $36,937 in unpaid income taxes for 1929, 1930 and 1931, according to a tax warrant filed against him yesterday in the County Clerk's office. The warrant is the equivalent of a judgment and enables the Sheriff of New York County to levy on any real or personal property in the county belonging to Schultz.

WASHINGTON. July 1. -- The Milky Way galaxy, of which the sun with its planets constitutes only one of billions of stars, is a roughly circular disk about 200,000 light-years in diameter and 10,000 light-years in thickness, containing about 200,000,000,000 stars, of which the solar system may be a fair average.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A compromise banking bill, greatly changed from the measure which the House passed but still retaining in the Federal Reserve Board the control of credit, was reported by the Glass subcommittee today to the Senate Banking Committee, which, in turn, decided to report the bill to the Senate tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Reporters for Scripps-Howard newspapers watched from the House gallery while Representatives filed between two tellers today to vote on the "death sentence" provision in the Public Utilities Holding Company Bill.

Assured of a "free hand" and an "adequate appropriation," Thomas E. Dewey, a former United States Attorney, accepted an appointment yesterday from District Attorney William C. Dodge to conduct an investigation of vice and racketeering as a special deputy assistant before an extraordinary grand jury.

BALTIMORE, July 1. -- An agreement for the sale of the property and business of the Baltimore Tube Company to the Revere Copper and Brass Company, Inc., has been authorized by the directors of both companies, it was announced here today.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1. -- The 2 per cent sales tax which New Jersey placed in effect today, following in the footsteps of New York, was greeted with a combination of defiance, revolt and cooperation. There was considerable confusion on many fronts, although in most cases the tax was collected despite a sprinkling of "under protest" attitudes.

Largely because of credits from amounts set aside by some railroads to meet liabilities under the Railway Pension Law, recently held unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court, railway returns for May showed an improvement over April.

LONDON, July 1. -- Great Britain showed the world her latest wares in military and commercial aircraft at the Society of British Aircraft Constructors' fourth annual trade display at Hendon today. The exhibition was attended by more than 3,000 air experts representing fifty countries.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 (AP). -- His hair gleaming like a red fireman's helmet against Wimbledon's green turf, Donald Budge defeated Bunny Austin in a brilliant two-hour duel before 18,000 cheering fans to provide the all-England tennis championships with a stunning sensation in the quarter-final round today.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The text of the Wagner Labor Relations Bill as it will go to the President for signature is as follows:

A claim against the City of New York for an amount "in excess of $100,000" will be made by Mount Sinai Hospital, it was revealed yesterday in the institution's annual report. The claim is for losses sustained by the hospital as result of the flood which followed the bursting of a water main at Fifth Avenue and 100th Street on Dec. 28, 1933.

LET the little fellows go as they please in the international Golden Gloves tournament at the Yankee Stadium this evening. The interest in this corner is in Pat Floyd, the Battering Ram from Battersea and the 'eavyweight 'ope of all the King's men.
