WESTPORT, Conn., July 1. -- Lawrence Langner, who blandly is becoming one of the major deans of the Summer theatre, opened the fifth season of the Country Playhouse in Westport this evening. He gave Fairfield County -- and a good share of Broadway besides -- a taste of the restoration drama, Wycherly's "The Country Wife."

BERLIN, July 1. -- A bold challenge to the 'Hausfrau" idea set up for German women by the National Socialist movement and to the whole Nazi campaign for quick marriages and multitudinous childbearing for political reasons, has been issued by Mrs. Marie Joachimi-Dege and published in a periodical called New Literature.

BOSTON, July 1 (AP). -- With Wes Ferrell pitching effectively in the pinches for his eleventh victory of the season, the Red Sox turned back the Senators, 8 to 3, today and boosted their percentage to an even 500.

The task of work relief in this city was officially taken over by the Federal Government yesterday, with General Hugh S. Johnson in charge of a program that calls for the employment of 250,000 persons for the next twelve months at a cost estimated at more than $300,000,000.

VIENNA, July 1. -- Dr. Ernst Karl Winter, Vice Mayor of Vienna, whose newspaper The Aktion, which tried to effect a reconciliation-between Austrian workers and the present regime, has just been suppressed by the police, said today:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- Mrs. Olney B. Mairs was hostess at tea to about 100 members of the Village Improvement Society today at her Lee Avenue residence, Mrs. William R. Maloney presided at the meeting, which was devoted to making plans for the annual village fair, taking place at the Village Playground on Newton Lane Friday, afternoon, July 26.

Eli Baxter Springs, cotton broker, railroad executive, art collector and former Mayor of Charlotte, N.C., left an estate of $2,378,511 gross and $1,263,340 net when he died on April 14, 1933, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

Revealing a marked trend toward softer and more feminine treatment based on the princess silhouette and stressing wide use of drapes and pleats and full seleeves, initial showings of Fall dresses were made here yesterday. The new lines reveal a tendency toward shorter skirts and emphasize novelty fabrics.
Plans for a new and larger store in Chicago to take care of expanding business in that district were announced yesterday by Saks-Fifth Avenue.
That large portion of the city's younger set that is spending the Summer at home turned out en masse yesterday for the opening of the 392 supervised playgrounds conducted by the Board of Education.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 1. -- Gar Wood Jr. of Algonac High, Michigan, son of the famous speedboat racer, hung up his first world record in outboard racing this morning when he rode over the measured mile course on Lake Quinsigamond in his tiny Class C boat propelled by a 24-horsepower motor at an average speed of 54.804 miles an hour.

ARCOLA, N.J., July 1. -- A brilliant thirty-foot putt on the eighteenth green gave Miss Rosalie Knapp and Mrs. E.S. Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club the mother and daughter championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association for the second time today.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., July 1. -- Gloria Vanderbilt, the 11-year-old daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, arrived here today and will spend July with her mother on the William H. Hamilton estate at Nissequogue, overlooking Long Island Sound.

New York State's unemployment insurance law was officially put into effect yesterday. Its operation is expected to serve as a model and play an important part in the development of unemployment insurance systems in other States within the framework of the job insurance system embodied in the Federal Social Security Bill now pending in Congress.

It is a sensible and honest program that Senator VANDENBERG lays down in his discussion of the new taxes suggested by the Administration. If we are to have a new tax bill, he asks, let it be "a real tax bill and not a mere political appeal to mass prejudice." As "all the incomes of all 'the rich' will "not suffice to pay our mounting "deficit," this means that "the income-tax base must be broadened."

BUENOS AIRES, July 1. -- The Chaco peace conference was inaugurated this afternoon by President Agustin F. Justo of Argentina. It immediately prolonged the present truce until such time as the Bolivian and Paraguayan armies are reduced to a maximum strength of 5,000 effectives.
Dwellings in various towns were included among the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.
UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 1. -- The theft of jewelry valued at $60,000 from the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Santini, at Far Hill farm here, was reported to the Nassau County police today.

BERLIN, July 1 (AP). -- Captains of industry who balked at contributing their assessed share in Germany's billion-mark dumping pool to obtain raw materials for arms will be compelled to do so under a law made public today.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Under parliamentary rules a record vote is not in order while the House is sitting as the committee of the whole, as it was today on the Utilities Control Bill.

ATHENS, July 1. -- Shouts of "Hurrah for the King," by former members of the government and monarchists were feebly answered by scattered cries of "Hurrah for the republic!" from the galleries as 300 Deputies took the oath today in the newly elected Parliament sitting in the palace of Greece's banished King.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- About 1,000 members of the "Needy Veterans Bonus Army," probably half of the number actually encamped about Washington, laid plans tonight to "sound out" tomorrow every Senator at the Capitol on their plan to pay the bonus to every veteran who does not pay income taxes.

The eleventh arrest was made yesterday in the conspiracy by which John Flaherty, fake "fixer" of city and Federal jobs, obtained about $250,000 in the last five years from persons whose names he promised to have placed on civil service eligible lists. Flaherty was sentenced last Thursday by General Sessions Judge Collins to a Sing Sing term of four to eight years on guilty pleas to seven indictments.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 1. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors, with but one dissenting vote, endorsed this afternoon the Fearon amendment to the State Constitution which will be voted on a a State-wide referendum in the Fall.

The Treasury retired yesterday $600,000,000 in 2 per cent consols, the oldest outstanding issue of the United States. They were first offered in 1900, with no fixed maturity, but with the provision that they would become callable after April 1, 1930. Meantime, they bore the circulation privilege; that is, they could be used as the basis for issuing national banknotes.

The intervention of Mayor La Guardia in the threatened strike of building service employes in the Bronx, which has been set for Friday, was requested yesterday by Wendell P. Barker, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, which controls 800 buildings against which the strike is to be directed.

What with watching a weary Congress attempting to plow through the pile of "must" legislation and with examining the weekly reports on the seasonal decline in industry, traders in the security markets yesterday appeared unwilling to go very far in anticipating what is to come along these lines in the next few weeks.

Miss Carolyn King of Woodhaven and Miss Virginia Wandelt of Jackson Heights, second and fourth seeded players respectively, reached the semi-fined in the girls' metropolitan tennis tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- When an overwhelmingly Democratic House today smashed the Roosevelt objective of death for "unnecessary" utility holding companies the vote was taken in an atmosphere made electric by an intense cloakroom campaign, exceptional bitterness in debate, charges of lobbying hurled against both the White House and utility interests, and open warnings that Democrats crossing President Roosevelt's wishes would be called to account at the polls.
Governor Lehman issued at Albany yesterday a mediation proposal and a program of conditions for new collective agreements designed to avert the threatened strike of 40,000 garment workers here.

Operations of the International Shoe Company for the six months end on May 31 resulted in a consolidated net income of $3,568,105 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $1.06 a share on 3,338,300 no-par shares of common stock, excluding 11,700 shares held by the company.

On the strength of steamship sailings of Saturday when more than 14,000 passengers departed for foreign ports, and bookings and inquiries weeks in advance of sailing dates, shipping men expect this to be a record travel year since the depression.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Treasury began today to retire $599,724,000 of consols in connection with its program for the withdrawal from circulation of about the same amount of national banknotes issued against bonds.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 1 (AP). -- Receivers and lawyers for the bankrupt National Department Stores received an approved expense account today from Federal Judge John P. Nields with nearly three-fourths clipped from the original bill.

Taking a leaf out of the Hollywood book, an Argentinian film concern has fabricated a talking and singing picture which gives the Spanish-American radio public a chance to see a number of its "idols" in action.

Father Divine's entrance into the political world with his spiritual followers met its first repulse yesterday when the vanguard of his army of voters sought to register at the Board of Elections. Many of the Negro men and women gave their "Kingdom" names -- Joy Praise, Truth Delight, Sympathetic Heart, Blessed Virgin -- and these seemed "ridiculous" to Chief Clerk Edward J. McGowan, who ruled they must "give us their right names."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 1. -- A three-run rally in the ninth on a deluge of errors gave the Brooklyn Chapter the edge over the New York Chapter, 18 -- 15, in the annual outing baseball game of the Baseball Writers' Association today. Thirty-four hits and eleven errors were made in the contest at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club for the John J. McGraw Trophy.

A reduction in the average size of high school classes from the present level of thirty-one and a half pupils to twenty-eight pupils next year was asked yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, at a tentative budget hearing in the Board of Education Hall, 500 Park Avenue.

Paolo Aiello, who has lived thirty of his fifty-five years in this city but speaks only the language of his native Italy, pointed yesterday to an impressive gilt-framed painting that hangs on the wall of an apartment he maintains on city relief funds for his wife and 14-year-old step-daughter at 615 East 189th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Loans totaling $15,600,000, granted by the RFC to the New York Central Railroad and maturing between now and Aug. 1, have been extended until Oct. 1 in the expectation that in the Fall a conversion issue will be floated to absorb not only the RFC loans but also banking loans to the road.

Former Municipal Court Justice Harold L. Kunstler has returned to New York, it was learned yestorday, but he came back too late for interrogation at this time by the grievance committee of the City Bar Association.

Columbia Pictures will produce fifty-two feature-length pictures during the 1935-36 season, it was announced yesterday by Harry and Jack Cohn at the company's national sales convention in Chicago. Twenty-six two-reel and ten one-reel subjects will aso be released.

The gold stock of the United States has increased more than $2,000,000,000, or about 30 per cent, since the revaluation of gold in terms of dollars at the end of January, 1934, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in the current issue of its monthly review.

Otto Fukushima, 64 years old, who formerly conducted an art gallery at 18 East Fifty-seventh Street and is regarded as one of the foremost authorities on Oriental art, was arraigned in Yorkville Court yesterday charged with the larceny of $7,500, the proceeds of the sale of a 1,000-year-old Chinese painting.

Rumors have been current in Wall Street in the last few weeks that investigations were being conducted by the Stock Exchange or the Securities and Exchange Commission into trading activity in several listed issues. The rumors are generally true, for there is rarely a time when investigations are not being carried on.

MERIDIAN, Miss., July 1. -- Fred and Al Key brought their plane, Ole Miss, to a safe landing at 6:06 P.M. (Central standard time) today after breaking all existing endurance-flying records by spending almost a month in the air.
The maiden voyage of the St. John's Guild hospital ship, recently built to provide free excursion trips for mothers and children of the city's poorer districts, was made yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP). -- A revised White Sox line-up that didn't include Al Simmons, $27,500-a-year outfielder, who hasn't been hitting, turned back the Browns, 4 to 1, in the opening game of the series today.
SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 1. -- Many guests will arrive on Wednesday to pass the Fourth at various estates.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1. -- The leaders in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's 394-mile race for cruising craft around Nantucket Lightship were believed to be well along on the homeward leg up the Sound tonight. They are expected at the finish line off Hicks Ledge early tomorrow morning.

The Guaranty Trust Company filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday a contract for a $200,000 building loan to the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company. The loan will be used to complete the modernization of the Metropolitan Opera House, and will cover installation of air-conditioning equipment.

LONDON, July 1. -- Leaders of the Liberal and Labor parties appeared on the same platform today at the first meeting of the Council of Action for Peace and Reconstruction organized by David Lloyd George, Liberal party leader, for the double purpose of giving Great Britain a "new deal" in domestic and foreign policies.

I wish to call your attention to the extremely cumbersome method used by the immigration authorities in establishing the right of an alien residing in the United States to return to his residence after a visit abroad.

PARIS, July 1. -- Currency devaluation may or may not be long postponed in France. About that there are many opinions. But meantime economic revaluation, which in a limited way achieves similar ends, is being effected under the pressure of inexorable circumstances here as elsewhere.

Orrin G. Wood, a partner in Estabrook Co. of Boston, has been nominated for the presidency of the Investment Bankers Association by the board of governors, according to an announcement yesterday by Ralph T. Crane of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., president of the association.

BOSTON, July 1. -- The following story of the drowning of Robert R. Ames and his sons was told to The Boston Herald over the telephone from Sydney, N.S., tonight by Charles F. Tillinghast Jr., who was at the helm when Mr. Ames was washed overboard and who manoeuvred the boat in the attempt to save the father and the sons who had gone to his rescue:

CHICAGO, July 1. -- A marked change in sentiment has occurred in speculative grain circles in the last few days. While many in the trade have continued to maintain that the aggressive buying that has developed in wheat has been mainly in the way of short covering, the action of the market today indicated that the public had taken the buying side, induced by the continued reports of black rust, especially from Nebraska.
The President's recent message on new taxation and his more recent about-face as to the urgency of passing the suggested laws has brought forth much comment -- mostly unfavorable.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1. -- Some golfing fireworks flew from the clubs of Jack Sabol, rangy Westchester Hills pro and his partner, Dan Sullivan, as they won the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today with a best-ball score that left them nine strokes under par at the Wykagyl Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A difference of opinion between the President and the House of Representatives over whether all holding companies above the "first degree" should be abolished or harshly regulated would not ordinarily affect the prestige of the Chief Executive or the independence of the House.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- A new assault on the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, the second to be started in the Federal District Court here within three weeks, was begun today by two Philadelphia cigar manufacturers, Bayuk Cigars, Inc., and Bobrow Brothers, Inc.

Despite the protest of their counsel, who termed the proceeding an "indignity," George Watson, former director of the National City Bank of New Rochelle, and Leverett G. Gross, a former officer of the First Mortgage Guaranty and Title Company, were fingerprinted yesterday in the office of Raymond J. Mulligan, United States Marshal.

The Department of Commerce was urged yesterday publicly to identify and to prevent the operation of 120 merchant ships that it has adjudged firetraps, in resolutions adopted by the Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1. -- Arriving here from Jackson Heights, where he won the Eastern tennis championship on clay, Berkeley Bell joined Gregory Mangin of Newark and E.W. Feibleman of New York in the semi-final round of the invitation turf court fixture of the Nassau Country Club today.

Our Mayor is still with us, the courts having rejected a taxpayer's suit to declare the office vacant on the ground that Major LA GUARDIA forfeited it by accepting a place on the President's committee to apportion work-relief funds.

REGINA, Sask., July 1 (Canadian Press). -- Gun fire blazed out in riot-torn Regina tonight, leaving one policeman dead and a striker dying. Steel-helmeted Royal Canadian mounted police and city constables clashed with 3,000 relief camp deserters and sympathizers.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., July 1 (AP). -- A jury convicted Philip Bruno today of manslaughter in each of four slayings in the Kelayres political massacre and acquitted five of his kinsmen.

The monthly index number of commodity prices, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows a decline during June of 1 5/8 per cent, the index number being now the lowest since Dec. 1, 1934. It shows, however, an increase of 21-3 per cent, as compared with July 1, 1934, and is still 36 1/2 per cent below the index of July 1, 1932, which was the lowest of the period.

HAMMONTON, N.J., July 1. -- The New Jersey State Federation of Labor, in telegrams to Governor Hoffman and officials of the State and Atlantic County Emergency Relief Administration, requested today an investigation of wages paid to berry pickers by fruit growers in this area.

MOSCOW, July 1. -- An energetic protest declaring that the responsibility for the consequences of further trespassing in Soviet waters of the Far East by Japanese Manchukuoan river craft will fall on the shoulders of the Japanese Manchukuoan authorities was delivered in Tokyo today by the Soviet Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on June 26 shows increases for the week of $43,000,000 in total loans and investments, $70,000,000 in net demand deposits and $22,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

A Crowd of close to 50,000 amateur boxing enthusiasts is expected to gather at the Yankee Stadium tonight to witness the first International Golden Gloves contest, when the British team will meet a team selected from the best of the simon pures of New York. Gene Tunney, former heavyweight champion, will referee the championship bouts.

What light was found or diffused by the conference of Young Republicans of the New England States held at the Connecticut Eastern Point, a name auspicious of dawn and sunrise? Much inward illumination there may well have been, but the coarse outside world remains unenlightened.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A belief that farmers would not give up AAA benefits until they had found an export market at a fair price for surplus products was expressed today by Secretary Wallace to representatives of wheat farmers who began a study of a revised wheat-reduction plan to be incorporated in the 1936-39 contracts.
The passenger list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, due tonight from Southampton, via Cherbourg, includes:

After an early decline which carried late months off 10 points, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed unchanged to 4 points lower on the day. Rather favorable weather over most of the belt on Sunday and the elimination of the proposed amendment to use customs receipts in order to finance exports of surplus farm commodities, influenced morning trading.

Although the Federal work relief program, opened in this city yesterday, will remove about 300,000 families in the State from the home relief rolls, 200,000 families remain in the State for whom home relief will have to be provided, Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, declared last night.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1. -- Young Donald Budge of California, who had never played at Wimbledon before this year, defeated the great H.W. (Bunny) Austin of England in a grueling four-set match today and so made sure of one place for the United States in the semi-finals of the men's singles.

The strong demand for tax-exempt bonds, which in the last week has become something of a rush of capital to seek shelter from the possibility of large tax increases, resulted yesterday in attracting inquiries from another prospective borrower -- New York State -- which had not been expected to enter the market before next Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters won today a ten-year fight for union recognition by the Pullman Company, when the National Mediation Board of the Railway Industry certified that the porters affiliated with the American Federation of Labor had won elections for collective bargaining spokesmen by a vote of 5,931 against 1,422 for the company union.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- In the most decided legislative defeat dealt to President Roosevelt since he assumed office, the House today, by a vote of 216 to 146, rejected his repeated demand for inclusion of the "death sentence" in the Utilities Holding Company Bill, which would have required eventual dissolution of such concerns.

SYDNEY, N.S., July 1. -- Tragedy in an ocean yacht race was revealed today when the ketch Hamrah of Boston anchored here and her exhausted crew reported the loss of her owner and skipper, Robert R. Ames, a Boston real estate man, and his two sons, Richard G. and Henry R. Ames, who perished in trying to save him.

That Congress is approaching controverted measures with more reliance than heretofore on their individual judgment, was further shown yesterday by the Senate subcommittee's report on the Banking Bill. This subcommittee of eight comprises distinctly the strongest members of the full Banking and Currency Committee.

WARSAW, July 1. -- Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, will leave for Berlin tomorrow on an official visit, it was announced here late tonight. The news was unexpected, because nothing had been said about preparations for the trip.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A movement was started today among Senate Republicans for adjournment of Congress until Nov. 18, with a new session at that time devoted primarily to consideration of President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing tax program.

The New York United Cigar Store Corporation has leased the corner store at Forty-second Street and Seventh Avenue in the building to be erected on the Rialto Theatre site. The firm, which occupied the corner in the old building, will return from a temporary shop in the block below.

PARIS, July 1. -- Premier Laval's announcement yesterday in a speech that he intended to take exceptionally energetic measures to assure recovery in the financial situation, in addition to his statement that the actual deficit was more than 11,000,000,000 francs, gave rise today to many contrary rumors on the Bourse and led to a serious fall in rentes.

FORT LEE, N.J., July 1. -- A rapidly shifting fire, fanned by an off-river breeze, cut a path through Palisades Amusement Park at 4:45 P.M. today. It left in its wake the charred ruins of fifteen concessions along the Midway of the park and for a time threatened the entire amusement centre, where more than 2,200 persons, many of them children, were spending the afternoon.

Investigation would disclose grounds for more action by the Interstate Commerce Commission under the Elkins law, based on practices followed by the railroads at their New York terminals, Charles E. Coterill, counsel for several independent warehouses and terminals, charged yesterday at a hearing before William P. Bartel, director of the bureau of service of the commission, in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The most vigorous storm of boos which has greeted the judges all season was loosed at Aqueduct yesterday when they placed E.R. Bradley's Blossom Again first at the end of the featured Beldame Handicap. To many observers, the Belair Stud's Vicaress seemed to have a slight but definite margin at the finish.

Methods by which Esperanto, the international language, can be utilized to become a greater force in the advancement of literature, science and business were discussed yesterday at the opening of the annual congress of the Esperanto Association of North America in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, July 1. -- The juridical position of the recently concluded Anglo-German naval agreement was defined by Sir Samuel Hoare, Foreign Secretary, during questions in the House of Commons today as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Allocations of $316,278,881, including $142,245,275 to States and cities, an amount estimated to give employment to 169,900 persons for a year, were recommended to President Roosevelt today by his advisory committee on allotments.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Following is the text of Title 2 of the Banking Bill, as revised by the subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, and the part of Title 3 which deals with underwriting privileges:

Two plans of reorganization have been prepared for the American States Public Service Company. The first is a new plan submitted by J.B. Whitworth and F.D. Fenhagen, trustees, and is to be submitted to the Federal court in Baltimore on next Monday.

Marjorie Lawrence, a native of Melbourne, Australia, has been engaged for the Metropolitan Opera for next season, according to a cable received yesterday from General Manager Edward Johnson. Miss Lawrence is a dramatic soprano who has sung leading roles, including those in the Wagnerian repertoire, at the Paris Opera.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 1. -After winning both the qualifying round and the driving contest in the Westchester junior championship, young Charles Pettijohn Jr. was eliminated in the first round of the annual event at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

Changes in Field, Glore Co. which will take into that firm two men who were active in Wall Street a decade or more ago and had since retired, were announced yesterday. The new partners will be Halstead G. Freeman and Edward F. Hayes.

LONDON, July 1. -- Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, told Parliament today that Premier Benito Mussolini had rejected his proposal whereby the British Government had hoped to settle the Italo-Ethiopian dispute by giving Ethiopia a strip of British Somaliland to compensate the Africans for concessions to Italy.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1. -- The Summer theatrical season was inaugurated here this evening with the appearance of one of Broadway's brighter stars, Ernest Truex, in a fanciful presentation of Broadway's fanciful little comedy, "Prodigal Father," at the Havemeyer Auditorium, which is being used for the first time this year as a Summer playhouse.

Stanley R. Latshaw, president of the Butterick Company, took the stand yesterday before Peter B. Olney Jr., Special Master, to explain his company's plan for reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list the following:

Headed by Paul L. Guibord of Dartmouth, a field of fifty players from twenty-five colleges in the East and South started in quest of the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis singles title, left vacant by Jack Tidball of U.C.L.A., on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club in Dongan Hills, S.I., yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- While their athletes were interrupting the staid calm of Union Station tonight by racing up and down platforms like schoolboys on a lark, Manager Paul Pilgrim and Coach Bernie Wefers announced the composition of the four relay teams that will represent the New York A.C. in the sixtieth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships at Lincoln, Neb., on Wednesday and Thursday.

STONY BROOK, L.I., July 1. -Forty-three teams assembled today at the picturesque St. George's Golf and Country Club course and no less than fourteen posted best ball scores of less than par 70 in an amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

Public offering will be made today of $55,000,000 of Bethlehem Steel Corporation consolidated mortgage twenty-five year sinking fund 4 1/4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on July 1, 1960, at 98 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield about 4.35 per cent to maturity.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- Rear Admiral Walter R. Gherardi, U.S.N., commandant of the First Naval District, was the guest of honor today at a luncheon given at the Clambake Club by the club's president, Commander Marion Eppley, U.S.N., R.F.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1. -- Ninety-six players started play in the annual New Jersey centre junior and boys' tennis championships at the Montclair Athletic Club today. Sixty-four are seeking the junior crown, while thirty-two are entered in the boys' division.

DENVER, July 1. -- A bill providing that the Federal Government shall, as a permanent policy, pay at least a quarter of the nation's public school costs will be vigorously pushed in the next Congress, Willard E. Givens, secretary of the National Education Association, stated at its annual convention here today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1, -- Measures to repair the wreckage wrought by the World War without yielding to governments the independence of action prized by all free peoples were urged today as the only world reconstruction worth having, in the opening discussions of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Despite the tremendous advances made in military aircraft, the defending forces have made even greater strides in radio detection of attacking forces, it was said yesterday by an American engineer just returned from England.

According to a report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 25, mathematics, science and foreign languages are to be dropped from the regular list of studies required for graduation from the high schools of New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Norris Jr. of Haverford gave a dance at Green Hill Farms tonight in honor of their daughter, Miss Jane Norris, who will be a debutante of the 1936-37 season.

CINCINNATI Jul 1 (AP). -- Heavy and timely hitting, starting with a three-run spree in the first inning, gave Chicago an 8 to 4 victory over the Reds tonight, in the third night game in major league history.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP). -Senator Long put on a miniature filibuster today in the Senate, talking all day in an effort to prevent a vote to take up a bill giving shipping ports the right to appeal from discriminatory railroad rates. There was talk of a night session to wear him out, but he finally agreed to a vote tomorrow.

Patrolman Cecil F. Nelms of Traffic F reported to the East Sixty-seventh Street station at 6 o'clock last evening that he believed an automobile in which he had been a passenger struck and seriously injured a nurse as she was alighting from a Lexington Avenue surface car at Seventieth Street an hour earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- President Roosevelt extended the life of the National Labor Relations Board and the Steel and Textile Labor Boards. He met with the Work Relief Allotment Committee, received from coal operators assurances that they would extend the present wage contract for a month, under protest.

Prices of several commodity futures were higher here yesterday, but most staples were dull and easier. On the cash markets all the grains advanced except rye, which declined, as did dairy products, cocoa, tin and rubber.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Three executive orders continuing temporarily the work of the labor boards established under the authority of the National Recovery Act were issued by President Roosevelt today, pending his signing the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill.

Activity in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday was principally confined to the domestic corporate list, attention of individual investors apparently being diverted to the large offerings of new bonds scheduled for this week, while the banks and other institutions were only small buyers of United States Government loans.

Advertising linage used by Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores showed a rise of 4 per cent last month over 1934, according to figures issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The June total was 2,666,651 lines, which compared with 2,563,988 in the same month a year ago.

Underwriting houses reported yesterday brisk buying of two new public utility issues: $35,000,000 Southern California Edison 3 3/4 per cent bonds priced at 98 1/2 and $9,765,000 Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation 3 1/2s priced at par.
DETROIT, July 1. -- Joe Louis, the "Brown Bomber," who landed on Primo Camera in New York with an explosion that shook the heavyweight picture, slipped into his home town modestly and silently today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 1. -Danny Williams, Shackamaxon pro, today paired with Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, one of his proteges, to win the New Jersey P.G.A. Scotch foursome tournament. Danny and Miss Wild, playing alternate strokes from selected drives, scored a 75 over the par 72 Crestmont Golf Club course.
PARIS, July 1. -- For the first time since the World War groups of German war veterans arrived in France on a visit today.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 1. -- The first paid vacations for steel workers in this district started today, the beneficiaries being employs of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company. The vacation plan is due to efforts of employes' representatives in the plan of representation conducted by the company.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- President Roosevelt was notified today by the Pocahontas Operators Association that they would accept "under protest" the administration's request for extension of the present coal wage agreement until July 30. They urged that the contract be extended until April 1, 1936.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1. -The uniting of the progressive groups of general Zionism in a combined front against the forces of the right and left wings of the movement is mandatory for continuation of the work in Palestine, according to speakers at the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America.

Plank O'Day started in baseball as a pitcher for the Toledo team of the Western Association in 188. After three years in the minor leagues he went to Washington of the National League in 1887 and 1888.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 2. -- Ethel Barrymore received enthusiastic applause tonight from the first night audience of the New Rochelle Playhouse. She appeared in the role she created on Broadway in 1926 and 1927 in Somerset Maugham's "The Constant Wife."

Stockholders of the Swedish Match Company at a meeting on Saturday in Jonkoping, Sweden, gave a general authorization to the company's board of directors to proceed with a settlement of claims between this company, the International Match Corporation and the Kreuger Toll Company along the lines drafted in negotiations here between the affected interests in May.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- The youth of America was called upon tonight by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, president of the Internetional Society of Christian Endeavor, to participate in governmental affairs and make of its citizenship "something more than a seasonal celebration or a patriotic parade."

A rousing market for bank stocks which carried the shares of leading institutions up from 1 to 60 points and lifted five issues to new high prices for the year registered yesterday Wall Street's approval of the revisions in the Banking Act of 1935 proposed by the Senate Banking Subcommittee, particularly the amendment giving banks of deposit the right to participate in security underwritings.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- After receiving a report on the Kentucky Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Middle West Utilities Company, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson postponed today until Sept. 12 further hearings on a plan for reorganization of the major holding company of the former Insull properties.

MONSEY, N. Y., July 2. -- Tobias Wildstein, 109 years old, again stole the show at the annual outing today of the Home of the Sons and Daughters of Israel, 282 East Tenth Street, New York City. Last year Mr. Wildstein gave a swimming exhibition at Dover, N. J.

DETROIT, July 2 (AP). -- William Lee Ferris, alias Schweitzer, who has confessed that he slew Howard Carter Dickinson, a New York lawyer, here last Thursday in one of the most cold-blooded murders on record, will be arraigned, probably Thursday, on a charge of first-degree murder.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Gratification over the resolution for reducing trade barriers adopted by the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris was expressed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

The filly Below Zero, which figured in a dead heat last week, captured the featured race at Aqueduct yesterday with a show of courage few had credited her with possessing. At the end of a hard run six furlongs the daughter of Tryster was a head before the Arden Farms' Quel Jeu, which closed ground strongly but not fast enough to head the C.H. Knebelkamp color-bearer.

Ample funds seemed assured yesterday for the sweeping investigation into Manhattan's racketeering and vice planned by Thomas E. Dewey as Special Deputy Assistant District Attorney, despite protests in some quarters against the probable cost of the inquiry.

Bubbling mulligan enriched the stuffy air in the basement office of the Hobo College at 422 East Fifteenth Street yesterday as Ralph E. Dalton, head of the institution, flicked flies, discussed world problems and made mortar boards out of newspaper for the commencement on Friday.
The seemingly simple task of spread-eagling the field in the National League pennant chase was resumed yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where Bill Terry and his Giants routed the Phillies, 8 -- 4.
Mayor La Guardia became annoyed yesterday at persistent questioning on whether he had reappointed Park Commissioner Robert Moses as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

DENVER, Col., July 2. -- Insurgents in the National Education Association were defeated in the annual convention here today on two counts. They failed to force a strong resolution on the defense of academic freedom through the resolutions committee and their proposal to give more power to the rank and file of the organization was rejected.

A new and highly important interstate agency is about to be set up in the metropolitan region. Governor HOFFMAN has just signed two bills empowering the State of New Jersey to enter into a compact with the State of New York to control the pollution of the waters in and about the harbor which is their joint heritage.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals climbed back into third place in the National League today by blanking the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 to 0, in their first home game after an unsuccessful road tour.

From his haunt of ancient peace in New College, Oxford, Mr. STANLEY CASSON, archaeologist, looks upon us with that "cold and callous eye," peculiar to his profession, and tries to scare us with a piece in The Atlantic Monthly. For New York and London must some day be one with Nineveh and Tyre.

The prediction that Acting Deputy Chief Inspector Henry Bruckman, commanding Bronx detectives, will be promoted to assistant chief inspector in charge of the entire detective bureau was made yesterday by a high source at police headquarters.

Mary Pickford has written a novel which Bobbs-Merrill will publish early in August. The title is "The Demi-Widow." It is about an American girl who becomes a famous singer. The scene is Paris. The actress's first book, "Why Not Try God?" was a best seller for months.

A concerted effort by all branches of the liquor industry to obtain legislation to deprive returning tourists of the privilege of bringing liquor into this country duty-free will be sought in Washington next week by representatives of distillers, rectifiers, importers, wholesalers and retailers, it was decided yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
After the discomfiture they suffered at the hands of the league-leading Giants, the Dodgers yesterday found balm for their feelings in the meeting with the cellar-dwelling Braves at Ebbets Field.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 2. -- Camp Andree, the national Girl Scout camp here, opened for its fifteenth season today with an enrolment of 109 girls, including one Polynesian Girl Scout, Miss Stella Kaaua, from the Kamehameha School in Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Rev. Arthur A. O'Leary, a member of the faculty of Georgetown University since 1912, was elevated today to the presidency of the university and the chairmanship of the board of regents. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Coleman Nevils, who had been retained in the post for a year beyond the traditional six-year tenure.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2. -- A stunning upset on Wimbledon's centre court today toppled Miss Dorothy Round from the championship and paved the way for Mrs. Helen Wills Moody to regain the throne she held for so many years. Miss Round, sadly below her best form, went down to defeat under the merciless forehand drives of Miss Joan Hartigan, 22-year-old Australian champion, who reached the semi-finals last year in her first appearance at Wimbledon.
LATONIA, July 2 (AP). -- Returning to racing after a month's lay-off, Mrs. William Crump's Cherry Time captured today's feature attraction, the Ashland Handicap.

LONDON, July 2 (Canadian Press) -- South Africa defeated England by 157 runs at the historic Lord's Cricket Ground today, the victory being the first ever recorded by South Africa in a test match on English soil.

MEXICO, D.F., July 2 (AP). -- A clear indication that the government of President Lazaro Cardenas intends to continue its present program and policies came today from the first meeting of the newly installed Cabinet.

Jascha Heifetz will appear as soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium on Monday and Tuesday evenings, Aug. 5 and 6. Jose Iturbi will assume the dual role of conductor and piano soloist at the concert next Wednesday evening, July 10. George Dubrovsky, Russian baritone, who will arrive today on the Champlain, will appear in the title role of "Boris Godunoff" on Thursday and Friday nights, July 11 and 12.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday was generally quiet and prices were mixed. A sharp break in the bonds of Southern Railway influenced the rail section, particularly the second-grade issues, which, after advancing in the early trading, closed off.

Loans on securities to member firms increased $16,048,267 in June, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The total at the end of the month was $808,589,298, compared with $792,541,031 at the close of May.
Officers of the Italian liner Conte Grande reported when the liner docked here yesterday that on June 25, when the liner was a day out of Gibraltar, a passenger had disappeared mysteriously.

Louis Hassman, 44 years old, of 1,122 Avenue N. Brooklyn, for seventeen years a clerk in the Immigration Service at Ellis Island, was named in an indictment handed down yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn to Judge Robert A. Inch.

Public utility stocks were moderately firmer yesterday, thanks to the heavy majority piled up in the House of Representatives for the House's own version of the bill, much softer than the Senate version to which was accorded the full weight of Presidential preference.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Two Florida players scored victories in the women's Middle States tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

NORWALK, Conn., July 2. -- Mrs. Thomas Hucknall of Woodway today accounted for the low gross prize in the one-day Westchester-Fairfield golf tournament over the Shorehaven Golf Club course. Mrs. Hucknall returned a 91 to win and, in addition, was the only one of the fourteen players who returned cards to break 100.

Captain Sir Edgar T. Britten, master of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, reported on docking last night from Southampton that he had sighted a big iceberg directly in the path of the vessel on Sunday in Lat. 40.28 degrees N. and Long. 49.28 degrees W.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,689,850 barrels, compared with 2,728,300 in the previous week, a decrease of 38,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 53,000 barrels in the average daily output of California was the most important change.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Openly flaunting the wishes of President Roosevelt, the House, which yesterday only counted noses on the issue, went on record today by a vote of 258 to 147 to substitute its own modified version of the Public Utility Holding Company Bill for the more drastic measure passed by the Senate with its "death sentence" on all intermediate concerns by 1940.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 2. -- Miss Eline Neilsen of Arcola won her second net prize in two days when she posted a score of 89 -- 17 -- 72 today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Ridgewood Country Club.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore has called for redemption on Oct. 1, its 6 per cent series D and 5 1/2 per cent series E preferred stocks, of which there are outstanding $2,750,000 and $2,250,000, respectively, or a total of $5,000,000.

Pending delivery of new 4 per cent bonds of the Belgium National Railways Company, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, depository, is continuing to negotiate with the Belgian Government for "more equitable treatment" of holders of American shares representing participating preferred shares of the company, the bank notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

This being the travel season, the notes of today may be permitted a glance at the tourist trade. First of all, the Champlain will arrive this morning with Dwight Deere Wiman, who has been scouring London for talent on behalf of "Most of the Game" and "A Room in Red and White."
LONDON, July 2. -- Britain's rearmament was attacked today by David Lloyd George in a speech launching what he described as a non-partisan campaign for "peace and reconstruction."

ATLANTIC CITY, July 2. -- A move to coordinate and unify the activities of Zionist groups throughout the United States to broaden the scope of Palestine efforts and establishment of harmony between opposing groups was made today at the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- An administration spokesman was charged today by Representative Brewster of Maine with having used a threat in an effort to force him to vote in favor of the "death sentence" clause of the Utilities Holding Company Bill.

HUDSON, N.Y., July 2 (AP). -- Governor Lehman, in a speech made here tonight, declared that in the future the State could not expend for direct unemployment relief more than the approximately $4,500,000 a month appropriated in the last budget.

The first two sentences were imposed in General Sessions yesterday in District Attorney Dodge's own drive against vice conditions, started last May after his first clash with the recently dismissed March grand jury, which had already begun an investigation of vice and rackets.

A seven-year effort of property owners to have the surface cars on Eighth and Ninth Avenues replaced by buses at last is bearing fruit, with the prospect that motor transportation on these two thoroughfares will be started by Nov. 1, according to the West Side Association of Commerce.

Despite the depression, the health of the people of New York State has remained generally good in the last year, and the stability of family life has remained unshaken, according to the sixty-second annual report, made public yesterday, of the State Charities Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The special Senate committee investigation of Governor Paul M. Pearson's administration of the Virgin Islands got under way today with a fist fight. At the same time Secretary Harold L. Ickes, whose Interior Department has jurisdiction over the islands, drew from the committee a refusal to permit him to cross-examine witnesses.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- While two private detectives keep guard over Miss Rosamund Farrell Murray, 16 years old, after a threatening telephone call had been received six weeks ago at the Water Mill estate of her father, Joseph B. Murray, prominent Brooklyn churchman and radiator manufacturer, an intensive investigation is being conducted by the newly created "Scotland Yard" branch of the New York State police.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Treasury ended the fiscal year on June 30 in a much more favorable position than was forecast in estimates made in the budget message sent to Congress in January by President Roosevelt, according to an official accounting made by Secretary Morgenthau today.

Despite efforts of Japan to develop new sources of supply, maintenance of America's huge exports of cotton to that country appears assured for many years to come, according to the Far Eastern Survey of the American Council, Institute of Pacific Relations.

ONE of the sedentary sports these days is comparing Shufflin' Joe Louis with the powerful punchers of history. How would he look in there with the Tunney of Chicago? With the Dempsey of Toledo? Could he have traded blow for blow with John L. Sullivan, the Boston Strong Boy?

The 1934-35 undergraduate honor roll of Fordham University, containing 174 names, an increase over last year, when 161 students were honored, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. Deane, dean of Fordham College. The honor roll was announced in two lists.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 2. -- The Federal Government's antitrust action against the Radio Corporation of America and RCA Communications, Inc., ended today when Judge John P. Nields in Federal District Court issued a consent decree disposing of the communications agreements of the two companies with foreign countries, including China, Poland and Czechoslovakia.

What was referred to by Rockefeller Center officials as "the world's largest sculptural glass panel" has just been removed from the casting molds in the Corning Glass Works in preparation for its installation about July 15 as the chief decorative feature of the main entrance of the Palazzo d'Italia in Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, July 2. -- David Lloyd George, fiery wartime Prime Minister, today cited "powerful interests" fighting the Roosevelt New Deal as illustrative of the kind of opposition his own "New Deal" must face in Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- PWA will pay for a $4,700,000 slum-clearance and low-cost housing project in Harlem from work relief funds if New York City can obtain title to necessary land by condemnation within thirty days, Secretary Ickes today informed Mayor La Guardia and Langdon W. Post, New York Tenement House Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- President Roosevelt, at a White House conference, approved a plan whereby voluntary trade agreements without any labor provisions would be supervised by the Federal Trade Commission and the NRA would confine itself to liquidation, reviewing the past and keeping a record of "chiseling." The President also conferred with monetary and banking officials on the Banking Bill.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 2. -- Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion, and Manuel Alonso, formerly of the Spanish Davis Cup team, advanced, respectively, to the final and semi-final rounds of the invitation tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.

The State Hotel and Restaurant Wage Board submitted a report yesterday to Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, recommending minimum weekly wages from $6.64 to $14.40 for the 60,000 women and minors employed in hotels and restaurants in New York State.
TOKYO, July 2. -- The Soviet protest to Japan over Siberian-Manchurian border incidents cited eight recent cases of frontier violation by Japanese or Manchukuoan forces.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The demand for hogs was not active here today, and while some sales were regarded as steady, most of the business was done at prices 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower. The day's average price dropped 10 cents to $8.80, the lowest since March 21, and showed a loss of $1.10 in the past five weeks.
"The biggest opening day in history."
The Board of Estimate approved a revised July relief budget of $19,531,000 yesterday, cutting $1,000,000 from the original request of the Emergency Relief Bureau headed by Oswald W. Knauth

Refusing to pay about $400,000 in processing taxes due on July 1, four big milling companies filed suit in the United States District Court yesterday for a declaratory judgment that the AAA was unconstitutional. They also asked for an injunction to restrain Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District, from collecting the taxes.

Max Reinhardt's film version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" will have its world premiere in New York in October under a system of protected release hitherto untried in the film industry, it was announced yesterday by Warner Brothers.

A police drive started more than a year ago at the instigation of Mayor La Guardia to put an end to the Italian policy racket in his old Congressional district in Harlem received potential help yesterday when a woman and two men were found guilty in Special Sessions of operating a gambling establishment at 2,125 First Avenue.

LONDON, July 2. -- Mrs. Robert R. Ames, widow of the owner of the ketch Hamrah, is hurrying home tomorrow aboard the Aquitania from Southampton, heartbroken over the loss of her husband and two sons while they were racing their vessel across the Atlantic. She arrived in Liverpool Monday on the Laconia, accompanied by her sister, Miss Frances Glover, and William Wolbach, a classmate of one of her sons, Henry Ames, at Harvard.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- In a far-reaching decision, pending for more than five years, Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward today denied the petition of the government for an injunction restraining the Elgin, Joliet Eastern Railway from carrying the products of fellow subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

The Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, which will become law as soon as the President signs it, does not differ much from the measure in its first form. Following the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case a few changes in phraseology were made to make the bill seem more constitutional, but these phrases alter very little.
SHANGHAI, July 2. -- One of the secret clauses of the Chino-Japanese Tangku truce of 1933 was revealed today for the first time.

While forbidden firecrackers popped in the city's streets, thousands of New Yorkers commenced the annual Fourth of July exodus yesterday, traveling by rail and plane, automobile, bus and steamer to seashore and mountain, and to points as far west as California.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- Charles Curtis, Vice President in the Hoover administration, declared today for a change in the Republican national chairmanship.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP). -- The Tigers climbed over Cleveland into second place in the American League pennant race today by subduing the Tribe for the second time in as many days. The score was 8 to 3.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 2. -- A Midsummer dance was given tonight at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club, through the courtesy of Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of Roslyn, for the debutantes of this season, the sub-debutantes and young men home from school and college.
Professor Yandell Henderson in his letter to THE TIMES has taken the position that the existing competitive bootleg activities are not attributable to the government's high taxation of spirits.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Here is the breakdown by party affiliations on the three House votes of record on the Utility Holding Company Bill today:

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Grain markets developed a reactionary tendency today following the issuance of private crop estimates which suggested materially larger yields than last year when the harvest proved almost a failure over a wide section.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., July 2 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight urged that those who doubt the enormity of the social problems facing the government "get out and see the country" and then help by furnishing leadership in communities which need rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Applications for registration on Form 1-M by 4,006 brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities had been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission up to the close of the mails today, set as the deadline for the receiving of applications.

HAVANA, Wednesday, July 3. -- Fifteen members of a commission of American liberals, including Clifford Odets, playwright, and five women, were arrested here last night when they arrived on the liner Orients to investigate Cuban labor and social conditions.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 2. -- An almost complete about face on the part of the Bennett government with regard to its proposal to nationalize the storage and marketing of Canadian Western wheat is revealed by the amended bill which it will submit tomorrow to the House of Commons for third reading.

If the irregular movements of the share market yesterday proved much of anything, it was that security holders generally are not disposed to rush in to buy or sell as the political news changes with chameleonic rapidity. Utility stocks, naturally enough, pointed higher in recognition of the determined opposition of the House to the "holding-company'' section of the Utility Control Bill.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 2. -- Keeping his big shots close to the fairways and putting with faultless precision, Lloyd Ribner, a 19-year-old member of the Elmsford Country Club, today won the Westchester Junior Championship at Bonnie Briar by defeating John Thompson of Siwanoy, 4 and 2.

SEAL BEACH, Calif., July 2 (AP). -- More than twenty persons, including women and children, were cut off from shore and several lives were believed lost here tonight when a section of the pier collapsed under the battering of heavy waves.
BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP). -- The Orioles dropped an 11-to-10 decision to Newark tonight and lost undisputed possession of the league lead as Toronto defeated Buffalo to tie the Birds for first place.

The Guaranty Trust Company in its statement of June 30, published today, reports the largest total of deposits in its history, $1,412,601,414. This is a gain of $143,718,311 since March 31 and compares with total deposits of $1,260,064,445 last Dec. 31 and $1,203,475,411 a year ago.

Alfred Adams Wheat, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, and Mrs. Wheat are among those leaving today for Europe on the Washington of the United States Lines. Also on board are Dr. and Mrs. Frank Bohn, Leland Harrison, newly appointed United States Minister to Rumania; Earl Lewis, treasurer of the Metropolitan Opera Company, with Mrs. Lewis, and the following others:

An amended petition in the gold-clause litigation, involving the administration's gold policy and the constitutionality of abrogating the gold-payment clause in government bonds, will be filed today in the Court of Claims in Washington by John M. Perry, a senior member of the law firm of Larkin, Rathbone Perry of this city.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 2. -- "The track was never faster," said Meet Director Henry (Indian) Schulte today as he gazed on the sun-baked University of Nebraska cinder path, the scene tomorrow and Thursday of the sixtieth annual American track and field championships.

A public statement will be made within the next week or two regarding the amount of money raised to combat infantile paralysis by the nation-wide birthday balls in honor of President Roosevelt that were held on Jan. 30, it was announced yesterday at the office of Keith L. Morgan, treasurer of the national committee in charge, at 50 East Forty-second Street.

ROME, July 2. -- The only visible effect of the Rome visit of Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, has been to stiffen Italy's determination to rely on her own strength alone to see things in East Africa through to their logical conclusion.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2. -- By the slim margin of one goal, both the Aiken Knights and the Long Island polo quartets triumphed in thrilling second-round matches today at the Meadow Brook Club to gain the semi-finals of the annual Meadow Brook Club Cups handicap tournament.

In reading the confessions of the girls and the man who murdered a New York lawyer to rob him of what they could find on his clothes, which turned out to be just $134, it is hard to say whether one is more struck by the moral obtuseness or by the intellectual obtuseness of the act.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was lower than in the preceding week. However, the total was well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Retail failures increased during the week ended June 27, as com{ pared with the previous week, while in the manufacturing division there was a slight decline and in the wholesale branch the number was the same in both weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed summary is as follows.'

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- A verbal opinion that the question of free speech was not involved in the court fight of Father Charles E. Coughlin for the use of Soldier Field stadium was expressed today by Superior Judge James E. Kelly.

Commenting upon the defeat of President Roosevelt by the refusal of the House of Representatives to grant his repeated demands for inclusion of the "death sentence" in the Utilities Holding Company Bill, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, declared yesterday that the Representatives had let it be known that the day of White House intimidation had passed.

SYRACUSE, July 2 (AP). -- Pompey Hollow's militant schoolmarm, Esther De Lee, 21, who was dismissed last November by a trustee who said she had shown disrespect to the flag, tonight had only to sign a new contract offered by a new trustee to get her old job back next September.
A special performance of "Alda" will be presented at the Hippodrome tomorrow evening. The week-end operas will be "Faust," Saturday, night, and "Rigoletto," Sunday evening.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Jealous for the protection of the Federal Reserve System he helped create, Senator Carter Glass of Virginia today emerged smiling and happy over the outcome of his long fight to rewrite the administration's Banking Bill.

Despite the fact that since June 13 detectives have fairly swarmed through the two adjoining buildings at 580 Fifth Avenue and 1 West Forty-seventh Street, which house some of the leading diamond cutting firms, two gunmen at 5:30 P.M. yesterday made a daring raid on a tenth floor cutter's office in the latter building.

PAWTUCKT, R.I., July 2. -- F.A. Carreaud's Ajaccio, finishing with a game rush, breezed home two lengths in front of Mrs. Haughton's Bold Lover today in the featured six-furlong Moose Puree at Narragansett Park.

MOSCOW, July 2. -- The Soviet is rapidly increasing the strength of its Baltic fleet and improving the fortresses that guard the sea approach to Leningrad in the belief that Germany is preparing to attack in that region with some form of cooperation from Finland.

LONDON, July 2. -- The stock markets were irregular today. There was fresh support for British funds, which were in strong investment demand. The feature in the foreign market was a general rise in Russian bonds on a revival of the rumor that the Soviet Government may make some payment on the old imperial obligations in view of the improving credit of the present regime.

VIENNA, July 2. -- Hundreds of Austrian families who started for their annual holidays on the Dalmatian coast of Yugoslavia were victims today of the tourist traffic war that broke out yesterday between Austria and Yugoslavia.

PARIS, July 2. -- German war veterans stood at salute today before the tomb of the unknown poilu of France and afterward met in a conclave with ex-soldiers of former enemy nations. At this meeting resolutions were adopted for friendly intercourse between former fighters in the interest of world peace, but if echoes of discussions to which the meeting gave rise are confirmed, the veterans must go far before there is a general reconciliation.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday for the five months ended May 31 a net income of $242,511, after taxes, depreciation, depletion, leaseholds surrendered, abandoned, and other charges. This is equal to 13 cents a share on 1,843,872 shares of $10 par capital stock outstanding last Dec. 31.

Leonard Straus, seventh seeded player from Rutgers University, joined the ranks of the spectators as play in the thirteenth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship was continued on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club in Dongan Hills, Staten Island, yesterday.

A five-reel film of Admiral Byrd's most recent expedition to the Antarctic will be released shortly by Paramount under the title "Little America," A rough cut of the film, which was recently screened here before executives of the company, will be sent to Hollywood, where it will be edited and scored under the supervision of Dario Faralla.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- The Athletics gave our Yanks quite a tussle today in the opening clash of a two-game series. But in the end they bogged down, as they so frequently do, and to the Yanks went the ball game, 8 to 5.

Complaints from Westchester teachers and pupils that the recent regents' examinations were too severe drew the statement yesterday at White Plains from Dr. Thomas J. Wagner that they should be made more difficult, Dr. Wagner is county representative of the State Department of Education and member of the committee which prepares the examinations.

General JOHNSON has taken over responsibility for the administration of work relief in this city with a warning that "no miracles can be promised." None will be expected. Two years have passed since PWA embarked upon a work program which was widely heralded by its mere enthusiastic sponsors in Congress as certain to "prime the pump" of industry.
The city's 2 per cent sales tax, the most important of its relief levies, will raise at least $40,000,000 by the end of the year, Controller Frank J. Taylor predicted yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- Charles Blair MacDonald gave a luncheon today at the clubhouse of the National Golf Links of America for Lord Carew, aide-de-camp to Sir Astley Cubitt, Governor General of Bermuda, who has arrived to visit Mr. MacDonald at White House, his place in the Shinnecoek Hills.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July2 (AP). -- Fairfield County legislators have authorized the issuance of $15,000,000 in bonds for the immediate construction of the Merritt Parkway, and a committee of eleven was negotiating with the Federal Government today for the 45 per cent grant of funds to be used in the project.

HUDSON, N.Y., July 2. -- Describing the structure as one of the most important links in the State's system of roads and bridges and as offering the most direct route between picturesque New England and Western New York, Governor Lehman this afternoon officially dedicated the new $2,350,000 Rip Van Winkle Bridge, spanning the Hudson River midway between the city of Hudson and the village of Catskill.

CATSKILL, N.Y., July 2 (AP). -- Alfred E. Volckmann, confessed slayer of Helen Glenn, 9-year-old daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Ernest Glenn of Greenville, occupied a cell in Greene County jail tonight, the same lockup which on four occasions held the late Jack "Legs" Diamond, New York City gang leader.

With the double purpose of supplementing musical education in the public schools and of supporting the symphonic concerts in the Lewisohn Stadium at City College, the Board of Estimate authorized the Board of Education yesterday to spend $10,000 on the Summer concerts.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Hardly a day now but produces a Republican hope. The latest is the charge of Representative Brewster of Maine about the Passamaquoddy project. Consider how often the President has directed that there shall be no trace of politics in the expenditures for work-relief, and how often the Republicans have insisted his subordinates wouldn't keep politics out, and you can readily see how important the charge could become.

The reports issued yesterday by Second National Investors Corporation, Third National Investors Corporation, and Fourth National Investors Corporation for the six months ended on June 30 showed large increases in the net assets of each as a result of the appreciation in the market value of their investments. The reports follow:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2. -- In accord with a precedent established by Mrs. William S. Sims when her husband, Admiral Sims, was president of the Naval War College, Mrs. Edward C. Kalbfus, wife of Rear Admiral Kalbfus, was host to the wives and families of the new officers of the college this morning at the Art Association. Admiral and Mrs. Kalbfus were "at home" this afternoon.

ROME, July 2. -- Every day it becomes clearer that the result of the unsuccessful journey of Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, to Rome and Paris, was not wholly negative. It had certain indirect consequences of a positive if paradoxical character.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- A plan prepared jointly by the Federal Trade Commission and the NRA for dealing with voluntary codes and labor provisions under divided authority was demolished at a White House conference today as a result of an opinion by Attorney General Cummings, who opposed consideration of the labor provisions in connection with fair trade practices.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace today signed a proclamation establishing an AAA adjustment program for this year's rye crop, acting a few minutes after tentative approval of a flexible plan for the payment of benefits to wheat producers.

LONDON, July 2. -- The British Cabinet at tomorrow's meeting will face the question of whether this country can or will do anything to save the League of Nations from destruction by an Italian-Ethiopian war.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Lovely Girl from the Bomar Stable of Detroit, ridden by Jockey J. Bryson, won the feature at Arlington Park today over a muddy track in a spectacular stretch finish, conquering the Dixiana Farm's Rollin Home by a head.

The Union Jack fluttered oftener than Old Glory in the glare of powerful lamps at the Yankee Stadium last night, signifying a sweeping victory for a British amateur boxing team over New York's squad representing America, in the first international amateur Golden Gloves boxing tournament.

In what was said by T. Vincent Quinn, Assistant United States Attorney, as the first indictment ever returned by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn to charge conspiracy to commit subornation of perjury two Manhattan lawyers and a Baltimore woman were named yesterday.

PARIS, July 2. -- Premier Pierre Laval and his Finance Minister, Marcel Regnier, did everything possible to put a good front on France's financial situation when they appeared before the finance committee of the Chamber of Deputies today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 2. -- A protest against proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act affecting tobacco has been made to Washington by the United States Tobacco Association, meeting here in annual convention.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Almost two-thirds of the urban unemployed were disclosed today by figures from the Relief Administration to be concentrated in twenty-three cities.

Magistrate Adolph Stern was confronted with an unusual problem and a strange sight yesterday morning when he took his place on the bench of Yorkville Court. Among the prisoners sat Antonio Sclafani, dressed in a white knitted sleeveless sport shirt, gray flannel shorts that came just below his knees, rolled down silk socks and white tennis shoes.

NEWARE, N.J., July 2. -- Opposition to the New Jersey sales tax, which went into effect yesterday, began to assume the proportions of a State-wide revolt today, with merchants forming anti-sales-tax associations, new litigation being launched against the Sales Tax Act and a State Senator refusing to pay the tax on a restaurant check.

OSAKA, Japan, Wednesday, July 3. -- The Japanese cruise steamer Midori Maru, crowded with holiday passengers, collided with a freighter early today in Japan's Inland Sea and sank, with an estimated loss of 104 lives.

Honors in semi-final round play in the girls' metropolitan tennis tournament yesterday were monopolized by the King sisters, Carolyn and Justine, of Woodhaven. Both advanced to the final in singles and together they reached the last round of doubles at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Officially accepting a gift of Georgian Terrace, the $1,000,000 estate of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Tyler in Elkins Park, Temple University today announced plans for a Fine Arts College which, it said, would be "unique among art educational institutions in this country."

FLORHAM PARK, N. J., July 2. -- Calling the four licensed liquor sellers of this borough to his court, Recorder William A. Closter tried tonight the case of a drunken driver before them, then read an address on selling liquor to motorists.

In making public yesterday a reply from Governor Lehman to its protest that the Governor did not include an educator on his State Aid Commission, the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations again expressed regret that "some one familiar with educational finance" was not a member of the commission.

Asserting that Herbert Hoover had been defeated by "four years of vicious, dirty, low propaganda," John D.M. Hamilton, general counsel of the Republican National Committee and national committeeman from Kansas, yesterday advised members of the Women's National Republican Club that "you can't win the coming campaign by being nice."

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 2. -- The statement that President Roosevelt's "good neighbor" policy toward Latin-America has been successful, as reflected by conditions in Cuba, was made by Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, and disputed by Dr. Leland H. Jenks, Professor of History at Wellesley College, in addresses at the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs today.

The vital question of "on the palm" or "with the thumb" having been debated to an unsatisfactory conclusion, New York's first waiters' race was run in Paris style yesterday afternoon with a dismaying effect on midtown traffic.

ALTHOUGH Carl Van Doren's "An Anthology of World Prose" (Reynal Hitchcock, $3.50) contains only a few very recent things, such as the interview with Enver Pasha from Franz Werfel's "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" and Thomas Wolfe's "The Names of the Nation" (lifted from "Of Time and the River"), it could not have been compiled a decade ago.

Commodity futures were fairly steady yesterday in dull trading in anticipation of the holiday tomorrow. Coffee and copper were moderately firmer. On the cash markets, cotton, corn, flour and tin advanced, while wheat, rye, oats, printcloths and rubber declined.

The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society and American director of the National Committee for Mexican Relief, issued a statement yesterday in reference to an Associated Press dispatch from Mexico, D.F., published Monday in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

James C. Sheridan was ousted as Democratic leader and patronage dispenser of Queens by the executive committee of the county Democracy at a meeting yesterday afternoon in Democratic headquarters, 62-10 Woodside Avenue, Queens. He was permitted, however, to retain his position as chairman of the committee.

Public utility common stocks were only moderately firmer yesterday as a result of the preponderant vote in the House for the modified version of the Public Utility Bill. Preferred stocks advanced fairly briskly. The common shares of one leading utility, American Water Works and Electric, lost 1 3/4 points on the passing of the dividend and surpassed all other shares on the Stock Exchange in volume of trading with 52,600 shares changing hands.

Although President Roosevelt, in his recent order setting wage scales to be paid under the Federal Government's work relief program, failed to accept the principle of the prevailing rate as demanded by organized labor, indications yesterday were that in this city the relief wage schedules will be materially altered to meet in large measure the desires of the labor unions.

Members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., approved by a substantial majority vote yesterday two amendments to the by-laws which authorize the board of managers to set up a market-control committee in the event of emergencies such as that of last December, when a "squeeze" of shorts in sugar developed. The two sections added are 17a and 35d.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2. -- The sixth clause of the will of John E. Andrus, "millionaire straphanger" of Yonkers, who died Dec. 26, 1934, at the age of 93 years, was held invalid today in a fifty-nine-page precedent-setting decision by Judge George A. Slater, Surrogate of Westchester County.

One hundred and forty-eight Columbia athletes have been rewarded with insignia for participation in varsity and freshman sports last Spring, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson.

With an abundant supply of New Jersey raspberries at low prices in the market, the New York City Depart of Public Markets questioned yesterday the complaint of New Jersey berry growers that their crop was rotting because berry-pickers on relief refused to work for wages less than the dole.
