PARIS, July 2. -- A division within the Radical Socialist party and an acute antagonism between Left and Right parties in France may tomorrow lead to the resignation of Edouard Herriot, Minister of State in the Laval Cabinet, from the presidency of the Radical Socialist party.

Delegates to the annual Congress of the Esperanto Association of North America demonstrated the adaptability of this "international tongue" to verse forms yesterday at the invitation of the "Poetry Weeks" Fellowship in Rockefeller Center.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1 a bale yesterday and ended with net gains of 18 to 20 points. For the first time in several weeks, the July rose above 12 cents a pound and it closed at the even figure with the list in new high ground for the movement.

BOSTON, July 2. -- Miss Angie Eames of 149 Benvenue Street, Wellesley, a graduate of Wellesley College and a teacher in foreign schools, was a first cousin of Burton E. Eames, an attorney with an office in Boston.

A 16-year-old boy twisted awkwardly in the police line-up yesterday and blinked in the bright glare as he told detectives how he and two companions had deliberately set out to look for an easy "stick-up" and how their quest ended in the fatal shooting Monday night of an Amsterdam Avenue storekeeper.
I was very much interested in the letter of Ann Ward which you published, the essence of which was: Why not handle the relief problem through preventive rather than curative measures?

OTTAWA, July 2. -- Declaring that "we are faced with an organized attempt against the national life of Canada not only Dominion, but continent-wide," Prime Minister R.B. Bennett announced in Parliament today that his government would maintain its unyielding front against the relief camp strikers, despite last night's fatal rioting in Regina, in which a city policeman was beaten to death, two Dominion mounted police were mortally wounded and 100 strikers were injured.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Approved in its general principles by the administration, the omnibus Banking Bill drawn by the Glass subcommittee was unanimously reported today by the Senate Banking Committee under a program to pass it early next week.

Conceding that a majority of the Harborside Warehouse Company's management consisted of Pennsylvania Railroad officials, counsel for the railroad denied yesterday that it operated the company, at a hearing conducted William P. Bartel, director of the bureau of service of the Interstate Commerce Commission, at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., July 2 (AP). -- Six robbers, two of them armed with machine guns, sprayed the business section of this city with bullets late this afternoon before holding up the Merchants National Bank and escaping with $20,889 cash.

At the annual elections for employe representatives of operating subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation last month, more than 87 per cent of the workers voted, it was announced yesterday. The large vote was interpreted by the corporation as an indication of popularity of the employe representation plan, as opposed to the labor union method of representation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 2. -- By a margin of approximately nineteen minutes on corrected time after more than seventy-two hours of sailing, the schooner Teal, skippered by her charterer, George N. Wallace, returned victor today over Rudolph J. Schaefer's sloop Edlu in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's 394-mile ocean race to Nantucket Shoals Lightship and return.

From time to time distinguished members of the bar tell us that the bar of the State of New York is of inferior character and that a purge now and then would be a healthy thing. At the recent joint conference on legal education held at Albany, we were told that the bar is lacking in leadership and that better training should be required of law students.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 2. -- Twelve hundred young men in this year's Citizens Military Training Camp were under canvas here tonight. Most of them hail from the metropolitan area, although several hundred came from homes situated in the northern part of the State. About 900 arrived from New York City this evening.

What is the chief significance of the vote in the House against the President on the holding company issue? It was more decisive on the roll-call yesterday than on the vote by tellers on Monday. More than half of the Democrats in the House, when their names were called, went against the Administration.

Women were urged by speakers at a luncheon here yesterday to cap their victories in the fight for equal suffrage and repeal by taking the lead in a nation-wide "crusade" for legalized lotteries. The movement is designed to divert to charitable purposes in this country the flow of sums estimated at more than $3,000,000,000 annually to racketeers or to foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- After two days of debate involving the old and controversial question of long and short haul freight rates, the Senate today passed an amendment to the Interstate Commerce Act giving the Interstate Commerce Commission jurisdiction over rate-making to ports.

It was indicated yesterday that the threatened strike of 40,000 garment workers in this city would be averted on the basis of the proposals made by Governor Lehman to workers and employers. The Governor's proposals were made in a letter sent Monday to the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union and the employer associations involved.

BELGRADE, July 2. -- King Peter, accompanied by his mother, Dowager Queen Marie, left Belgrade today for the late King Alexander's favorite Summer palace on the lake at Bled. They will remain there for some time and will be joined soon by Prince Paul, head of the regency.

The International Longshoremen's Association, a subsidiary of the American Federation of Labor, threatened yesterday to tie up merchant shipping using the port of Lake Charles, La., as a move against the employment of non-union longshoremen at the port's piers.

ROME, July 3. -- Simultaneously with the arrival of a report that the British Cabinet was studying plans for an economic blockade to prevent Italy's threatened war against Ethiopia, the supreme council of the Italian Navy met in Rome today in response to an urgent call from Premier Benito Mussolini.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Mayor Clarence E.F. Hetrick and four Councilmen of Asbury Park, N.J., obtained from the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today a supersedeas which will save them from going to jail tomorrow under a contempt of court ruling of Judge Philip Forman of New Jersey.
Salt water fishing interests are enthusiastic over the project to construct an ocean sanctuary near North Wildwood, N.J., which was approved recently by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- When the Wheeler-Rayburn bill and the amendments broadening the scope of TVA are disposed of in one way or another, there will not be much left for a legislative death-grapple. No last-ditch instructions about the Glass Banking Bill have come from the White House.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP). -- Sparkdale, a 3-year-old gelding, led by a nose after a gruelling stretch battle with Marmion, the favorite, and Burning Up to capture the $1,000 Saint Clair Shores Handicap at one mile on the Detroit track today.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP). -- The Tigers, aided by four errors by Roy Hughes of Cleveland, took the Tribe into camp today, 11 -- 7. It was the Tigers' third straight victory over the erstwhile second-place holders.
A novel by Audrey Wurdemann, whose "Bright Ambush" won the Pulitzer Prize for verse this year, will be published in 1936 by Macmillan. The title will be "Mary Had a Son."
LATONIA, Ky., July 3 (AP). -- A dead heat was run at Latonia today, with J.F. Rector's Smooth and G.J. Mandle's Vesee finishing all square in the one and one-six, teenth miles of the eighth event.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,678,306,714 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange The average price per share of all listed stocks on July 1 was $27.78, compared with $26.50 at the beginning of June.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 3. -- A program of refinancing to put Monmouth County on a cash basis and provide budget relief from present debt service charges was take: under consideration by the County Board of Freeholders here today.

The detention by the Cuban Government of a Commission of fifteen American liberals, including Clifford Odets, playwright, in Havana Tuesday night as they arrived on the liner Oriente to study Cuban labor and social conditions caused a storm of protest here yesterday.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (AP). -- As a result of their victories today Fred Perry and Baron Gottfried von Cramm will meet in the final round of the Wimbledon men's singles championships on Friday.

A new counter-boycott league was launched here yesterday by the Friends of New Germany to combat the boycott of German goods organized by anti-Nazi societies in this country after Hitler's accession to power in Germany.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

NEWARK, N.J., July 3. -- Commenting on the State-wide attack on the New Jersey sales tax which became effective Monday, Governor Hoffman admitted today the levy, which was sponsored by his administration, was inequitable and unfair standing alone.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- In reply to criticisms in some quarters that the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program consists mainly of "boon-doggling," President Roosevelt today used almost half an hour of his press conference in reading to perspiring reporters a long list of approved projects of all sizes.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., July 3. -- Two persons, were killed age five injured, two of them critically, in a head-on automobile collision tonight on Route 29 near Centreville, about half way between Somerville and Flemington.

BOSTON, July 3. -- The Department of Public Utilities approved today the issuance by the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston of $53,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund bonds, to be dated July 1, 1935, and payable on July 1, 1965, and bear interest at a rate not to exceed 3 3/4 per cent.

On the ground that the gasoline sales tax prescribed by the city is a "tax upon a tax" because sellers are required to include in the sum collected from motorists a tax on the levy collected for the State tax, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and a dozen other of the largest gasoline concerns filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday asking the court to declare the requirement illegal.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A list of applications for registration on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, contained the names of sixty-five firms and corporations from New York City and vicinity, as follows:

Trading continued generally sluggish on the local commodity exchanges yesterday, owing to the pre-holiday influences, and price changes were small and in either direction. The markets will be closed today. On the cash markets, cocoa, tin and cotton advanced, while all the grains, lard and rubber declined.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Regulations governing free ports of entry, in accordance with the Celler Act of the Seventy-third Congress, were promulgated today by Secretary Roper, who designated Thomas E. Lyons, acting chief of the Foreign Trade Zones Board, which is composed of Secretaries Roper, Morgenthau and Dern.

Pig iron production in June, as estimated by The Iron Age, was 1,552,514 tons, or 51,750 tons a day, compared with 1,727,095 tons, or 55,713 tons daily, in May. The decline in terms of daily rate was 7.1 per cent. Furnaces in blast on July 1 numbered ninety-one, a loss of six since June 1.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Discovery, A. G. Vanderbilt's 4-year-old, will go after the $10,000 added prize over the mile and an eighth route in the Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park tomorrow. A crowd of 50,000 is expected to watch the race.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP). -- While acting as a liaison officer during some apparently fruitless dickering for the Boston Braves, Ford Frick, young National League president, today learned that a definite offer has yet to be made for the controlling interest in that financially distressed club.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- When the resolution by Senator Black for a lobby investigation was reported to the Senate today, Senator Long began a criticism of the House leadership for not allowing a record vote on the "death sentence" in the utility bill.

BELGRADE, July 3. -- Milan Stoyadinovitch, Yugoslavia's new Premier, intends to go to Paris to see Premier Pierre Laval the end of this month and will very probably combine this with an official visit to London. He would make the journey only after the budget and other urgent matters have been settled in Parliament.

BERLIN, July 3. -- Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, arrived in Berlin this morning for a two-day visit. His presence, the German press stresses, is wholly in the nature of a courtesy call, reciprocating the recent visits to Warsaw by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, and General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Air Minister.
Thin, silvery strains of music played by a thirty-four-piece Park Department band sounded the only note of harmony yesterday at the formal opening of the new $500,000 zoo in Prospect Park.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in the manner that frequently preceeds a holiday, price changes being erratic. Wheat averaged higher a good part of the day only to ease toward the last on evening-up by professional operators who had bought early, and the finish was 1/8 to 3/8 cent a bushel lower than yesterday's closing figures.

PLYMOUTH, England, July 3. -- Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee today really got into her stride for the first time since she has been racing against the British Class J yachts and scored a fine victory in the Port of Plymouth's annual regatta.

A similarity in the method he used to assault a Queens man on Monday night to that which was used in the murder of an elderly man in the Bronx last March led to the arrest yesterday of William Axons, homeless 27-year-old porter, on a charge of homicide.

The first step toward empaneling the special grand jury to investigate racketeering and vice in New York County was taken yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook after a conference with Thomas E. Dewey, Special Deputy Assistant District Attorney.

Dwight Deere Wiman arrived from London yesterday on the Champlain with some plans and contracts for "Most of the Game," but with none at all for "A Room in Red and White." For the former play, which he will present in association with Auriol Lee, he has engaged Robert Douglas and Dorothy Hyson.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Federal Work Relief Administrator for New York City, who says he is still very much confused as to what it is all about, had his first conflict with the city administration yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement on Work relief was as follows:

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 3. -- For the sixth successive year, the N.Y.A.C. won the national A.A.U. outdoor hard ball water polo championship tonight, defeating the Duquesne Library Club of Duquesne, Pa., 7 to 2, in the west bath house pool at Jones Beach State Park.
DENVER, July 3. -- Five thousand teachers were told today marriage opportunities for American girls are growing scarcer and that suicides and divorces are on the increase.

With a price of $2,000 on his head and with the police all over the world searching for him on the charge of murdering an 11-year-old Detroit girl last September, Merton Ward Goodrich, 27 years old and with prematurely gray hair, confessed the murder yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 30. -- A Woodbury County grand jury today indicted the State's Attorney General, Edward L. O'Connell, and his assistant, Walter Maley, on charges involving graft and corruption in public office.
BALTIMORE, July 3 (AP). -- Newark made it two straight over the Orioles today as Marvin Duke held the Flock to nine hits and enabled the Bears to register an 8 to 3 victory.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP). -- The Red Sox blasted three pitchers today while gaining their third straight victory over the Senators, 14 -- 7. Bosto made fifteen safeties and Washington got twelve off Johnny Welch. Buddy Myer, however, failed to get a hit in five attempts, breaking his consecutive-game hitting streak at twenty-one contests.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3. -- The estate of Mrs. Joseph Wilshire was the scene of a brilliant society event tonight, when a bridge party and dance for the benefit of the Madison Avenue Women's Exchange, New York, took place. More than 300 people from Greenwich, Mount Kisco, Rye, Bedford and other near-by towns and cities attended.

Rather than wait another day the Dodgers celebrated at Ebbets Field yesterday with plenty of fireworks, playing no favorites as they belabored three Boston hurlers with eighteen hits and sent the Braves home on the short end of a 13-6 count.

By all indications, the Banking Bill, as revised by Senator GLASS and his subcommittee, will be adopted by the Senate. In some of its provisions the bill thus formulated differs widely from the measure adopted by the House May 9, by a vote of 271 to 110. The important provisions, on which the two Banking Bills diverge, are three in number.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 3. -- Agreement that voluntary cooperation to bring about equality of economic opportunity among the nations is essential to reconstruction and the only hope of world peace, was reached today by three groups at the University of Virginia Institute.

The comic opera war between Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses over the latter's reappointment to the Tri-borough Bridge Authority reached a ludicrous point yesterday when the Mayor made fun of Mr. Moses's attitude and said he would reappoint him at 11 o'clock next Wednesday -- "if he will present himself."

LONDON, July 3. -- The Cabinet held today its first meeting since the return of Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, from Paris and Rome and with all the Ministers present devoted the session to discussion of the many diplomatic difficulties between this country and France and Italy that have grown out of the Anglo-German naval treaty and the Ethiopian question.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Stockholders of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois at a special meeting held today approved a proposal submitted by James Simpson, chairman, for the refunding of $15,650,000 of Series H 6 1/2 per cent bonds, maturing in 1952, which will result in an annual saving in interest charges of about $200,000.

TOKYO, July 3. -- Realism is to be introduced into Tokyo's annual air defense manoeuvres commencing Saturday by assuming that four large suburban railroad stations are being destroyed during the rush hour and by instructing passengers how to comport themselves in these circumstances.

A new coat and suit label, designated the "Consumers' Protection Label" and signifying that the merchandise is produced under "fair labor standards" was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board at its offices at 132 West Thirty-first Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3. -- Mrs. Moses Taylor has as guest at The Glen her son, Francis Taylor. Her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, will arrive tomorrow. Mrs. Taylor will give a dinner and an entertainment tomorrow evening. Mr. Taylor has arranged a display of fireworks.

Little progress was made yesterday by the markets as trading was almost entirely under the holiday influence. Prices, however, were generally steady at the closing. The share market idled most of the day, with a moderate increase in activity in the last hour which lifted the price average slightly; trading on the Stock Exchange totaled 720,000 shares, compared with the aggregate of the day before of 1,198,000.

VIENNA, July 3. -- An interesting account of the treatment of the Austrian Legion in Germany, which is composed of fugitive Austrian Nazis, is given by an Austrian Nazi who has just deserted the legion camp at Redtwitz, Upper Franconia, and escaped to Austria.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., July 3. -- The Board of Education of District 2, embracing this village, voted just after last midnight to renew a one-year contract with Frank M. Buckley as Superintendent of Schools here. His salary of $5,700 a year will he continued.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 3. -- The shortest-priced favorite of the current meeting, Miss Mary Hirsch's Captain Argo, bowed in defeat to Donald Christmas's Accolade in the second running of the Gaspee Claiming Stakes, six-furlong feature for 3-year-olds and upward, today at Narragansett Park.

The first high court ruling on the legality of the game of bagatelle, or the pin game, was handed down yesterday when the Appellate Division in Brooklyn held that a game of the type which ejects tokens is a gambling device and not a game of skill.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3. -- Argentina paid homage today to Samuel F.B. Morse, inventor of the telegraph. All telegraphic and wireless communication throughout the country was suspended for one minute, beginning at 6 P.M., the hour set for the unveiling of a monument to Morse in the general postoffice building here.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- A hail of Senate opposition beat today around the "Eastman" bill consolidating regulation of carriers under the Interstate Commerce Commission, but it emerged with all committee amendments intact and ready for renewed battle next week.

In his message to Congress recommending the passage of a law to insure the government against the possibility of righting the wrong perpetuated against the holders of its gold clause obligations, the President affects a virtue reminiscent of Pecksniff.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- At the end of a laborious task, Senator Glass smiled wearily but contentedly today at what he believes is a step toward a long-sought goal -- severance of the Federal Reserve Board from all connection with things political.

I wish to indorse the economic philosophy in your editorial "A Narrow Class Tax." Also to applaud Senator Vandenberg's constructive and courageous suggestion for a renaissance of our whole Federal tax system.
TRENTON, July 3. -- For the first time since 1930 New Jersey real estate valuations show an increase this year over last year.

Casually, almost as if the question had not really been discussed much before, General JOHNSON -- announces that he is for a "readjustment" in New York City of the scale for work-relief wages announced by the President six weeks ago. The unions, it appears, want "prevailing wages" to be paid, and the General announces that he will have a lot of headaches if he doesn't do it.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Exploration of "new fields" in business cooperation was planned by the Federal Trade Commission today in carrying out President Roosevelt's injunction to help create voluntary business codes.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE announces with a good deal of emphasis that he is in politics again. Most people in England will ask when he ever got out of politics. He has been out of office for some time. But his activity in public affairs has not ceased.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Although he prides himself on his sartorial appearance and his power of endurance in speech making, Senator Long concedes that his dancing might provoke a right to the jaw.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 3. -- "It takes years of experience for some men to make real fools of themselves," was the comment by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. today in a memorandum accompanying a decision setting aside a deed for two parcels of property conveyed by William H. Bauer, elderly farmer and widower off Manorville, to Mrs. Victoria Slesiona, who promised to be his housekeeper.

The rally in bank stocks, which was set in motion late last week by the news of the amendment to the Banking Act of 1935 giving banks the privilege of underwriting new security issues, was carried further yesterday. Shares of leading banks rose from a fraction to 35 points in dealings in the over-the-counter market, and seven issues reached new high prices for the year.

The correspondence of Clarence K. Streit which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday contained opinions and judgments which were a gratuitous outrage to the valor of the Italian Army, which only a few years ago was able to defeat the Austrian Army, one of the most powerful in the world.

Sam Parks Jr., the new open golf champion, and Jimmy Thomson, credited with being the world's longest hitter, arrived yesterday to join forces for a tour that will probably keep them going places from now until the time of the 1936 national open at Baltusrol.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- Joe Louis and King Levinsky signed articles today for a ten-round fight at Comiskey Park, home of the White Sox, on the night of Aug. 7.

The Treasury statement published yesterday dealt largely with changes in the national debt during the fiscal year just ended. It increased by $1,648,000,000 during the past twelve months, whereas the deficit for the year was the much larger sum of $3,575,000,000.

BERLIN, July 3. -- The Boerse opened unsteady today, with signs of weakness, but it became firm before it closed. Heavy industrial shares opened strong, but fell and became steady. Harpener, however, gained 2 points. Potash and electrical issues were firm throughout but not very active.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, will arrive today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others on board include H.B. Pierce, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Berlin, and Mrs. Pierce; Baron Kurt yon Tippelskirch, German Consul General at Boston, and:

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 3. -- One of the many Connecticut tercentenary celebration features was held last evening at the piano factory of the Pratt, Read Co. in Deep River when Miss Lotta Van Buren of New York City and five assistants gave a recital based on musical instruments tracing the evolution of the piano from the monochord of 600 B.C.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 3. -- Charles C. Pettijohn, senior and junior, turned in a score of 77 to win the tenth annual father-and-son championship of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- As an organization for handling labor provisions the NRA is virtually dead, according to indications conveyed at a press conference today by James L. O'Neill, Acting NRA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A new series of 2 1/4 per cent Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds, dated July 1, 1935, due July 1, 1944, and redeemable on or after July 1, 1942, was authorized by the corporation today to be used in obtaining funds or in exchange for home mortgages.

LONDON, July 3. -- The British Government's submarine policy was defended by Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, in the House of Commons today following the attack last night by former Prime Minister David Lloyd George.

VIENNA, July 3. -- The Austrian Government today summoned the State Council and laid before it a written proposal for cancellation of the laws of the Austrian republic that exiled the Hapsburgs who did not take the oath of allegiance to the Republic and for restoration to them of certain confiscated property.
Curt Davis took matters into his own hands yesterday at the Polo Grounds when the clash of the Giants and the Phillies threatened to drag out over a prolonged overtime session.

Steel operations declined sharply this week because of the July 4 suspension, the only holiday of year on which there is a 100 per cent cessation of production, aside from Christmas Day, according to the weekly summary of Iron Age.
ADDIS ABABA, July 3. -- I have been asked if I believe in war as the solution of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Miss Anne Page of Merton defending women's Middle States tennis champion, was extended by Miss Patty Kilmartin, 16-year-old Miami Beach girl today, but gained the quarter-final round at the Philadelphia Cricket Club by winning 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3.

TRIESTE, Italy, July 3 (AP). -- Thu 15,000-ton motorship Batory, destined for service on the Gdynia-American (Polish) Line, was launched at the Monfalcone Shipyards here today in the presence of the Polish Under-Secretaries of Commerce and Communication.

The three top-seeded players were joined by Gardner Mulloy, fifth seeded junior from Miami University, in an advance to the semi-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club on Staten Island yesterday.
The bohemians of Greenwich Village today will set about electing a mayor of their own choosing, who also will be a Maecenas.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The greatly changed Title II of the Omnibus Banking Bill unanimously reported from the Senate Banking Committee was "in its most vital respects a distinct advance in the direction of centralized responsibility and authority for the exercise of monetary powers," Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, declared in a statement today.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Charges that Governor Paul M. Pearson of the Virgin Islands had exceeded his authority under the law, was unpopular with a large section of the population and was not frank in his administration, were made before a Senate investigating committee today by Charles Henry Gibson, former United States Attorney for the islands.
RYE, N.Y., July 3. -- Mitena, the new Herreshoff international 12-meter yacht, appeared today in the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the American Yacht Club.

Three women and a man were injured, one of the women seriously, at Luna Park, Coney Island, at 12:20 A.M. today, when a two-car train of the "Grand Canyon" gravity ride on the west side of the park stuck on a curve near the bottom of the descent.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Arrangements were made today by Chairman Jones of the RFC for a meeting in New York Wednesday between John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, and O.P. Van Sweringen in an effort to compose their reorganization plans for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, now in receivership.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that he had asked the three employer members of the State Hotel and Restaurant Minimum Wage Board to file their reasons for dissenting from the report of the board recommending minimum wage rates of 18 cents an hour for table-service waitresses; 27 cents an hour for non-service food workers; 30 cents an hour for lodgings workers and $10 a week for resident employes.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- A bill to forbid American loans or extension of credit to the government or citizens of any warring nation was approved today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

The Supreme Court was called upon yesterday to decide whether the Four Aces team or Ely Culbertson's team comprises the "best bridge players in the world." The Four Aces carried their feud with Mr. Culbertson to the court by filing suit for damages for the publication of libelous articles about them and for an injunction to restrain future publication of similar statements.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A double-barreled investigation of lobbying in connection with the Utilities Holding Company Bill appeared likely today when the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee reported a resolution of inquiry.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Light weight hogs were in good demand here today and early sales showed advances of 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds, with those weighing less than 200 pounds showing the most strength. Local and Eastern packers competed for the desirable kinds, but heavy weights were dull and at the close were little better than steady.

Scores of motorists, many of them bound out of the city for the holiday, found themselves stranded high above the East River for a time last evening, when the police stopped all traffic on the Brooklyn- bound side of the Brooklyn Bridge, and by so doing captured two holdup suspects.

Although the race already has cost four lives, yachtsmen here felt no concern yesterday over the failure of the yawl Vagabond, owned by Roger G. Robinson of New Haven, Conn., and the German yawl, Stoertebeker, so far to reach the finish line in the transatlantic race from Newport. R.I., to Bergen, Norway, The Associated Press reports.

Although an advance above 12 cents a pound for the spot month attracted some selling yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, prices again reflected estimates of a disappointingly small crop and an increasing scarcity of supplies as a result of the virtual corner in the staple that has resulted from the Federal 12-cent loans to producers.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 3. -- Continued operation of the Willys-Overland plant was assured today when announcement was made that bondholders, creditors and the trustee, the National City Rank of New York, have reached agreement on a new request for permission to manufacture 10,000 Willys 77s and trucks.

Lights in some of the larger buildings in the vicinity of Times Square flickered for ten minutes at 9 o'clock last night, affecting the eyes of night workers slightly, but otherwise not seriously interfering with the normal life of the section.

Delegates to the annual congress of the Esperanto Association of North America adopted a resolution at the close of their meeting at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday to recommend to the Postoffice Department in Washington that a new stamp be issued in commemoration of their jubilee year.

The threatened strike of 40,000 garment workers in this city was definitely averted yesterday with the acceptance by the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, representing the jobbers, who are the key to the situation, of the mediation proposal and recommendations for new agreements submitted by Governor Lehman to the workers and employers.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 3. -- Play in the Wheatley Cups tournament, the annual nine-goal handicap event, will get under way at the Meadow Brook Club during the latter part of the week. The entries were announced today.

Confident that the city will have acquired by condemnation within a few weeks the four-block Harlem area approved by the PWA for lowrent housing, the New York City Housing Authority revealed yesterday details of what was described as "one of the most significant model housing projects ever planned for that district."

Cancellation of one of the terminal storage contracts here under investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission was announced by C.J. Brister, vice president in charge of freight traffic of the New York Central Railroad, at a continued hearing yesterday before William Bartel, director of the commission's bureau of service, in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Five more prisoners, arrested as a result of the fatal shooting of Simon Lieberman, 49 years old, during the hold-up of his candy store at 906 Amsterdam Avenue on Monday night were questioned in the police line-up yesterday morning.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3. -- America's last hope in the men's tennis singles went glimmering on the centre court today when young Donald Budge met defeat at the hands of Baron Gottfried yon Cramm, champion of Germany.

All during the time when the Utility Bill was pending in the House of Representatives there were insinuations and whisperings about a "vast corruption fund" which the companies involved were spending to influence legislation. It was no secret, in fact, that they did raise and lay out a good deal of money for printing advertisements and circular letters addressed to their stockholders.

In accordance with plans for gradual unification of the public relations activities of the New York Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, begun two months ago, the Exchange is preparing to take over the association's advisory council of 132 brokers in key cities of the United States and Canada.

LONDON, July 3. -- The Foreign Office's sudden intervention caused the withdrawal from Sotheby's salesroom today of century-old historical documents, including letters from Wellington and Nelson, and dispatches, all belonging to the Earl of Abingdon.

DENVER, July 3. -- A pressure group of a million teachers aligned with labor and "the millions of humble parents," as distinguished from the "vested interests," was demanded today by Professor John K. Norton of Teachers College, Columbia University, in presenting the final report of the joint commission on the emergency in education to teachers from all parts of the country at the annual convention of the National Education Association.

Guilty pleas to conducting disreputable apartments were entered in General Sessions yesterday by two women who had been indicted on charges of compulsory prostitution, which is a felony. Judge Cornelius F. Collins accepted the pleas covering misdemeanors on the recommendation of Assistant District Attorney Lyon Boston.

In observance of Independence Day all business in financial centres throughout the United States will be suspended today. The banks as well as markets generally will be closed. A few brokerage houses here will be open for transactions in connection with the Canadian grain, stock and silver markets. Business will be resumed tomorrow as usual.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP). -- Ernie Lombardi delivered a home run at the start of the last half of the tenth inning today to give the Reds a 4-to-3 decision over the Cubs. Bryant was the pitching victim of this blow.

By automobile, by train, by ship and plane, steady streams of humanity were pouring into and out of the city last night as New York prepared to celebrate today the nation's birthday -- the Fourth of July.

PARIS, July 3. -- A truce until October between the Right and Left wings of the Radical Socialist party, so as to permit Edouard Herriot to remain in the Cabinet and Premier Pierre Laval to do his best to help the country toward financial recovery, was arranged and approved tonight at a full meeting of the executive committee of the party in Paris.

Mrs. Marion C. Donnelly, 37 years old, wife of Police Sergeant Frank J. Donnelly, 46, from whom she was separated, was shot and killed at 11:30 A.M. yesterday in the living room of her apartment on the top floor of a four-story building at 10-60 Beach Twenty-second Street, Far Rockaway, Queens.

The body of Miss Mary Cunningham, 24-year-old actress known on Broadway as Irene Blair, who disappeared almost three weeks ago, was found yesterday in the morgue at Bellevue Hospital, just a few hours before it was to have been taken to Potter's Field.
Three juveniles from Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's string, coupled as an entry, loom as the choice in the Great American Stakes, feature of the final day's racing at Aqueduct this afternoon.

A tentative draft of a code of fair marketing practices for the oil industry has been completed at meetings here and in Washington and will be submitted to the American Petroleum Institute for approval, according to reports in the trade. If approved by the institute, the proposed code will be turned over to the industry so that all interested can voice their opinions before it is submitted to the Federal Trade Commission for approval.

Detectives learned yesterday the identities of the gang of five gunmen which, with a stock of uncut diamonds estimated by the police to be worth $500,000 as its objective, staged one of the most elaborately planned hold-ups in years late Tuesday afternoon, only to be balked by the quick-wittedness of their intended victim, Uscher Doppelt of 1 West Forty-seventh Street.

Among the thousands of persons receiving old-age relief in Manhattan are eight centenarians and fifteen nonogenarians, according to the records of the Old-Age Security Division of the city's Welfare Department, which is directed by Deputy Commissioner Ruth Hill at 20 East Twenty-first Street.

For the first time since her engagement at the Empire in "A Kiss for Cinderella" in the season of 1916-17, Maude Adams will appear on a Broadway stage next season, it was announced yesterday. John Golden will be her manager, and an as yet untitled play by Adelyn Bushnell will be her vehicle.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3. -- The unexpected defeat of Charles Mattman of Forest Hills, L.I., at the hands of Robert Kerdasha of Woodcliff, N.J., featured the quarterfinal round of the annual New Jersey Center junior singles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Yesterday's pre-holiday session of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was dull, with interest centred, as on Tuesday, in the railroad and utility issues. Transactions were $10,053,400, compared with $11,148,500 on the previous day.

Among the thousands of persons receiving old-age relief in Manhattan are eight centenarians and fifteen nonogenarians, according to the records of the Old-Age Security Division of the city's Welfare Department, which is directed by Deputy Commissioner Ruth Hill at 20 East Twenty-first Street.

For the first time since her engagement at the Empire in "A Kiss for Cinderella" in the season of 1916-17, Maude Adams will appear on a Broadway stage next season, it was announced yesterday. John Golden will be her manager, and an as yet untitled play by Adelyn Bushnell will be her vehicle.

Exonerating Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt of one of the more spectacular charges made against her, but finding her guilty of "persistent indifference" toward her child, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, the Appellate Division upheld yesterday Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew's decision awarding principal custody of the child to her paternal aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.
i The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
RENO, Nev., July 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Nina Gore Vidal obtained a divorce today from Eugene L. Vidal, director of the Bureau of Air Commerce. She refused to comment on reports she intends to remarry.

Decision to enlarge the group which is seeking passage of the Vandenberg amendment to the Duffy Copyright Revision Bill was taken at a meeting here yesterday, presided over by Herbert Gutterson of the Carpet and Rug Institute. It also was decided to draw up a definite plan of procedure to support the measure.

Hope that minimum hours and wages would be fixed by law for taxicab drivers in the not too distant future was voiced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in presenting certificates of merit and commendation bars to eighty-four taxicab drivers who have rendered "courageous and valuable assistance" to the Police Department since Jan. 1, 1934.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3. -- The unexpected defeat of Charles Mattman of Forest Hills, L.I., at the hands of Robert Kerdasha of Woodcliff, N.J., featured the quarterfinal round of the annual New Jersey Center junior singles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Yesterday's pre-holiday session of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was dull, with interest centred, as on Tuesday, in the railroad and utility issues. Transactions were $10,053,400, compared with $11,148,500 on the previous day.
BERLIN, July 3. -- The anti-Jewish campaign continues with renewed virulence throughout Germany.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The 40-hour, five-day week for all civil service Postoffice employes was endorsed tonight by Postmaster General Farley.

Five hundred men are being shipped "up the river" this week from the old penitentiary on Welfare Island to the new one on Riker's Island. Now practically completed, at a cost of nearly $9,000,000, it is said to be the latest word in prison construction. That means that it is designed not merely for security but for rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- Crude oil production in May was reported today by the Bureau of Mines at 82,454,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,659,000. This was an increase of 45,600 barrels over the April average and 84,000 over a year ago.

MARION, Mass., July 3. -- This harbor was a scene of unusual activity today as craft for the Eastern Yacht Club's cruise and the historic Puritan Cup race, which will be held tomorrow on Buzzards Bay, arrived for the rendezvous.

The Kashruth Association of Greater New York. Inc., answering yesterday a suit which challenges its right to supervise the kosher poultry industry in the city, declared that it was not only making no profit but was incurring a continual deficit.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3. -- Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close in a decision today dismissed a conspiracy suit against Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin of New York and Assistant District Attorney Martin Frank of the Bronx.

HAVANA, July 3. -- The fifteen American liberals who were arrested last night when they arrived here on the liner Oriente as a commission to investigate social and labor conditions were deported tonight by the Cuban Government on the same vessel.

OAK BLUFFS, Mass., July 3. -- Because her fiance complained she was "too popular," Miss Jean Pratt, 17, brunette daughter of Norman L. Pratt, Selectman, cut fifteen deep gashes in her face, arms and legs with a razor blade today in a secluded section of the East Chop Summer colony.

The State of Texas sold yesterday to a banking group headed by R.W. Pressprich Co. an issue of $2,000,000 of relief bonds dated April 1, 1935, and due on April 1, 1936 to 1943. The group paid 100.0601 for $1,450,500 as 2 1/2s and $549,500 as 2 1/4s.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 3. -- Sergeant Jaxon A. Kraemer of Asbury Park, a member of the Second Battalion Headquarters Company of the 114th Infantry, shot his way to victory today in the Governor's match here. He will receive a gold medal from Governor Hoffman which is emblematic of the championship of the New Jersey military forces.

Universal's screen production of Edgar Allan Poe's "The Raven" opens this morning at the Roxy. At the head of the cast are Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi, Irene Ware and Lester Matthews. Mr. Lugosi will appear in person tonight on the stage of the Roxy.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on May 31 a consolidated net income of $10,029,611 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.76 a share earned on 4,482,737 common shares.

ALBANY, July 3. -- The State of New York may not call its non-callable high interest rate bonds for refunding purposes before maturity, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today. The question had been submitted by Deputy Controller H. D. Yates.

BERLIN, July 3. -- In unconscious opposition to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economy, who sturdily affirms that Germany's mark is still stable at full value and who reproaches unwise, non-German currency juggling in the world, the Reichs-Kredit-Gesellschaft Bank publishes this week a paean in glorification of depreciated and unstable currencies.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Failure to prepare youth for the "hard realities of life" was charged to the American public school system at the International Christian Endeavor Convention here today by Miss Margaret Slattery of Boston, a former member of the Massachusetts Board of Education.

Gounod's "Faust" will be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight as the second in the series of operatic productions this season, with a repetition listed for tomorrow night. The principals will include Maria Kurenko as Marguerite, Armand Tokatyan as Faust, Leon Rothier as Mephistopheles and Joseph Royer as Valentin.

DETROIT, July 3. -- William Ferris, confessed murderer of Howard C. Dickinson of New York, was taken before Judge Christopher E. Stein of the Recorder's Court at noon today on a habeas-corpus hearing.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- The Yankees were in something of a stormy mood today and the result was a 2-to-0 whitewash for the Athletics.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 3. -- Presaging another set of remarkable performances when the senior meet is staged tomorrow, the junior athletes sent the sixtieth annual American track and field championships off to a flying start in the University of Nebraska Stadium today by setting six meet records.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3. -- Laying down an irresistible service barrage, Berkeley Bell, seventh ranking tennis player of the country, defeated Manuel Alonso today to reach the final of the invitation tournament of the Nassau Country Club.

LINDEN, N.J., July 3. -- Sudden wealth descended temporarily this afternoon on the household of Adolph Pakrul of 237 First Avenue here, when his 12-year-old son, Arthur, brought home an oil can he had found in a vacant lot.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3. -- Demobilization of the Bolivian and Paraguayan armies in the Chaco began this morning under the supervision of the neutral military mission. The peace protocol provides that within ninety days from today both armies shall be reduced to 5,000 effectives.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 3. -- Many guests arrived today to pass Independence Day at various estates of the colony.

TOKYO, July 3. -- Japanese military ambitions to gain important islands in the Amur River and Russia's determination to frustrate them were given today in a Soviet explanation as the reasons behind the latest episodes in the three-year Russo-Japanese dispute over the Siberian frontier.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- After spotting an old jinx, Dick Coffman, three runs in the first inning, the White Sox pounded him for ten hits in six innings and gained a 5-to-3 victory over the Browns in the finale of their abbreviated series today.

Visiting motorists will receive "special consideration, care and courtesy" from the police in this city, under an order issued yesterday to the entire force by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine. Out-of-city and out-of-State license plates will be privileged passports, and to occupants of such cars traffic officers are to act as "salesmen" for the city, stressing "service" and kindliness, the commissioner made it clear.

Bronx is still pre-eminent among the boroughs in the matter of zoos, but her sisters, in their unassuming way, are beginning to rival her. Central Park in Manhattan had a zoo for years, but what a collection of moth-eaten old yaks and other broken-down animals it was! Keepers fed and watered them, and then left them to their own devices.

New York tried hard to have a safe and sane Fourth of July and early reports indicated that this goal would be reached, but as the number of those injured directly or indirectly from exploding fireworks continued to mount after sundown, the total casualties in the city early today reached 2,640, which is forty more injuries than last year's 2,600.

The Empire City Summer meeting, which for the first time in its history has four richly endowed stakes, begins this afternoon at the Yonkers course with the Winsted Purse as the featured event of six races. James Butler, president of i the association, announced yesterday that many improvements had been made around the track and in the betting ring.

While beating down Long Island Sound before a stiff breeze at 4:45 P.M. yesterday, the two-masted schooner K-26965, owned and commanded by Manuel Brockman of 19 West 191st Street, the Bronx, went aground on submerged rocks off Rat Island, between Hart's and City Islands.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP). -- Despite the hundreds of millions of dollars put aside for work relief projects, officials disclosed today that only four of the new ones approved actually had been started.

The appointment of Ralph Dellevie of New York City as Tourist Commissioner for the Virgin Islands, was announced yesterday. The appointment was made by Secretary of the Interior Ickes upon Mr. Dellevie's return from a tour of inspection of the islands.

A new producing firm, a new play and a new playwright will come together next season when Robinson Smith and Frederick W. Ayer present "The Ugly Runts," by Robert Raynolds. The play, which deals with the mass suicide attempt of Hungarian miners last Fall, had its world premiere on June 10 last at Ann Arbor, Mich., as a feature of Robert Henderson's dramatic festival.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 4 (AP). -- Robert Robertson's colt Bright and Early equaled the track record for five furlongs when he raced to victory at Narragansett Park today in the Old Colony, the $5,000 added feature for 2-year-olds, in 0:59 3-5.
PARIS, July 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

DETROIT, July 4 (AP). -- Slapped, a long shot, came on fast in the stretch today to win the $3,000 added Liberty Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 2-5. He paid his backers among the crowd of 20,000 fans $60.40 for $2.

Running his gamest race before a crowd of 20,000 on the concluding day of the Aqueduct meeting, the Wheatley Stable's Snark yesterday captured the Great American Stakes, a speed test of five furlongs. With such stake winners as Maeriel and Delphinium behind him, Snark stepped the distance in the slow time of 1:00 1-5 over a track that could not have been faster.

NORWALK, Conn., July 4. -- Richard Birdsall, 40, of King Street, Port Chester. N. Y.. an explorer and writer, and Irwin Tyson, 18, of 23 Harvard Avenue, White Plains, were rushed to the Norwalk Hospital early this morning after a yacht on which they were cruising in Long Island Sound took fire and burned to the water's edge and sank.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- State, county and municipal law-enforcement officers will arrive here July 29 to attend a twelve-week course to be given by the training school of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Attorney General Cummings disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Tributes to the Constitution and American liberty, appeals to combat the forces of crime and of communism, and appreciation for the services of the veterans, living and dead, of America's wars, marked Fourth of July addresses in the local observance of the national holiday.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 4. -- Scoring a total of 287 out of a possible 300 on the 600-yard range, the rifle team of the 113th Infantry Regiment of New Jersey won the interstate regimental team match on the State ranges here today. The same team also took first place in the New Jersey regimental team event.

DENVER, July 4. -- Classroom teachers and other organization insurgents won a "revolution" of their own within the National Education Association today, carrying to victory at the convention here their demands for vigorous resolutions on academic freedom and tenure.

BELGRADE, July 4. -- Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch made his debut in Parliament today, stressing that the new government would continue its predecessor's foreign policy of intimate friendship with the other members of the Little Entente and France and would also endeavor to maintain cordial relations with an other States in the interest of general peace.

The importance of group insurance to the families of American employes and to the nation is cited in a statement by William J. Graham, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, based on the company's records for the first six months of 1935.
MOSCOW, July 4. -- A government inspired effort to put a stop to the abuse of the easy Soviet divorce laws was revealed today, following publication of figures showing an increase of divorces.

LA PAZ, July 4. --The Fourth of July was again celebrated here after a three years' lapse on account of the Chaco war. American business concerns were closed for the day. Their employes were entertained at luncheons or went to the country.

After booing and hissing at him during a patriotic speech in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, a crowd of about 150 radicals set upon Alderman Walter R. Hart, only to be chased away by policemen after the Alderman had knocked one of them down.

Is it possible that the robin needs defense? In a letter to THE TIMES an Indiana reader concedes that the robin is "one of the most beloved of birds," but complains that "its song is a monotonous troll." "We all love to hear it, of course," he goes on to say; "there is something extremely soothing and restful about it."

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Appeals for our active assistance in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis will be considered upon their merits when received. None has been received thus far, however, and in the meantime the State Department is maintaining silence.

CANTON, Ga., July 4. -- Governor Eugene Talmadge today termed the Roosevelt administration policies "pure communism" and predicted that the "real Americans" will rise up at the polls in 1936 against "bureaucratic control."

WINNIPEG, July 4 (AP). -- Tumbling prices at Liverpool, where the belief was held Canada's wheatholding policy was at an end, pulled down values here today. Futures closed 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel lower, with July at 80 1/4 cents and August at 81 1/4 cents.
HATFIELD, Pa., July 4. -- Two auto racers were killed today on the track of the Montgomery County Fair Grounds at Hatfield, while another was seriously injured.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP). -- Mrs. E.R. Thomas of Hollywood said today that Robert Thomas, 26-year-old screen player, who is her foster-son, was born in Portland, Ore., to May Yohe about a year before the once famous actress divorced in Portland. Ore., Captain Putnam Bradlee Strong, whom she had married in Yokohama in 1902.

ROUND HILL, Conn., July 4. -- The banks and braes o' bonnie Fairfield County resounded today with the music of the bagpipes and the cheers of a record gathering of Scottish-Americans and their friends.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 4. -- The funds of the Bank for International Settlements rose during June by 11,000,000 Swiss francs to a total on June 30 of 661,000,000, according to the monthly statement issued tonight.

TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- The industrial share section of the Toronto Exchange maintained a firm tone today, with the oils, some of the liquors and International Nickel higher. Consolidated Smelters was off about 3 points.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The emergence of the House of Representatives into the spotlight, after months of spear-bearing, has been one of the most interesting developments of recent political history. The hitherto predictable House has become unpredictable; the supposed repository of all radical ideas has proved itself conservative.

Your Correspondent "Political Observer'' and I appear to disagree on some points. He would combat bootlegging by lowering the taxes and duties on proof liquors. The line that I advocate is illustrated in two letters that I have recently sent. one to the chairman of the Liquor Control Commission of Michigan, the other to some members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives at Washington.

PLYMOUTH, Vt., July 4 (AP). -- For the rest of the country it was the 159th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence; for this little Green Mountain hamlet it was the sixty-third anniversary of the birth of its great citizen -- Calvin Coolidge.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP). -- The Athletics defeated the Senators in both games of a double-header today. The score of the first game was 6 to 3 and the second, which was a pitchers' duel between Earl Whitehill and Johnny Marcum, 2 to 1.
LONDON, July 4. -- The next move to restrain Italy from crushing Ethiopia is likely to be an Anglo-French effort. It will be made neither in Rome nor in Geneva, but in Addis Ababa.

LAWRENCE of Arabia begins his "Revolt in the Desert" with a chapter entitled "Storrs Goes to Jiddah." Had not STORRS (who later became Sir RONALD STORRS, Governor of Jerusalem) gone to Jiddah in October, 1916, and by his personal diplomacy got permission from the Grand Sherif, HUSSEIN, for LAWRENCE to visit the camp of FEISAL, probably there would have been no story of an Arabian adventure to tell.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 4. -- Thomas Rabbitt, 39 years old, resident manager for the Park Central Hotel in New York City, was drowned in the Hudson River this afternoon off North Tarrytown.

While bathing in the Marine Basin, at Whitney Beach in the Gerritsen Beach section of Brooklyn yesterday, James Cruickshanks, 61 years old, of 113 Dictum Court, near by, was stricken with a heart attack and was dead before aid reached him.

BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP). -- Baltimore won two extra-inning games from Newark today, taking the first, 11 to 10, in ten frames, and annexing the scheduled seven-ining nightcap, 5 to 4, with a two-run rally in the eighth after the Bears had broken a 3-3 tie with one run in their half.

BERLIN, July 4. -- The German Government has decreed that in future accused persons may be punished by courts even when there is no existing law that defines the charge against them as a criminal act.

TUSCUMBIA, Ala., July 4 (AP). -- With two Governors and a host of other notables attending, a throng estimated at more than 30,000 crowded the Muscle Shoals area today in observance of Tennessee Valley Appreciation Day, a tribute to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Along about the time that a "new" book by Mark Twain is due to appear this Fall on the Harper list, Longman, Green will publish a "first" by Robert Louis Stevenson. The title will be "Translation of Martial's Epigrams," and the contents will be made up from hitherto unpublished manuscripts, the result of Stevenson's labor to assimilate Martial's style and so improve his own craftsmanship.

The Continental Paper and Bag Corporation has forwarded to hol ders of first mortgage bonds issued by the Marinette, and Menominee Paper Company and assumed by Continental, a readjustment plan providing for extension of maturity of the bonds for twenty-five years with interest fixed at 5 per cent.

Warning against "the promises of demogogues and false prophets" of the present political stage, the Rev. Thomas Higgins of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in a sermon there yesterday at low mass, urged adherence to the principles embodied in the Declaration of Independence as the means of preserving the traditional ideals of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."

The municipal debt of the country was increased substantially in 1934 because of the necessity of financing for relief purposes, the distribution of PWA funds for local improvements and the plentiful supply of capital available for investment in municipal securities at low rates of interest, according to C.E. Rightor of the Municipal Service Department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in his annual compilation made for the National Municipal League.
BERLIN, July 4. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler sent a telegram carrying his Independence Day good wishes to President Roosevelt today.
Soaring over a hitherto unscaled "mathematical mountain-top," Dr. Albert Einstein, climber of "cosmic Alps," reports having sighted a new pattern in the structure of space and matter.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Secretary of the Interior Harold, L. Ickes, threatening criminal prosecution, demanded today that Charles H. Gibson, first witness before the special Senate committee investigating the administration of the Virgin Islands, return documents which, according to Mr. Ickes, he took from the files before he was discharged as Government Attorney of the islands.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP). -- Pittsburgh took advantage of loose Cincinnati pitching and fielding to take the first game of a double-header, 9 to 5, today, but lost the second, 5 to 4, as Billy Myers drove a homer in the seventh.

Three young white girls, a Chinese woman said to be the proprietor of a disorderly place, and two Chinese men were arrested early yesterday in what police said was the tenth raid on apartments operated by a large vice chain and frequented by Chinese. The raid was made by Patrolmen Arthur Brown and John D'Errico of the Sixth Division.

MARTINS FERRY, Ohio, July 4 (AP). -- Flood waters, driven by rains of cloudburst proportions, rushed through two widely separated counties of Ohio today. Sheriff Howard A. Duff of Belmont County said three children were reported missing there, and Sheriff F.D. Mason said that a heavy loss of live stock occurred in Knox County.

OTTAWA, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- A decrease of more than $4,285,000 was shown in the total deposits of the Bank of Canada in the week ended on July 3, according to the weekly statement issued today. The reserve in United States funds in the week increased by more than $1,000,000, while the reserve in sterling funds showed a decrease of more than $4,650,000.

More than 6,000 mothers and children were sent to vacation camps during the last week by charitable organizations, according to a report yesterday by the Children's Welfare Federation. In some cases lack of funds has caused an enforced curtailment of Summer activities by the organizations.

POTTSVILLE, , Pa., July 4. -- Wayne Schollenberger, auto racer, was killed today in a freak accident on the Cressona Fair Grounds race track. His car crashed through a board fence erected to prevent non-paying spectators from viewing the race. He was impaled on a board knocked loose from the fence.

The Capitol this morning will offer "Escapade." a Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer production ,featuring William Powell, Luise Rainer, a newcomer from Vienna; Frank Morgan, Virginia Bruce, Reginald 0wen and Mady Christians.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4. -- Girls in shorts or "slacks" are forbidden to enter the east end of Camp Smith, where the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment, New York National Guard, is in Summer training. The order was made public today by Colonel Walter Delamater, commanding the regiment, who feared the effect on his young men of women in such attire.
GRASS VALLEY, Calif., July 4. -- The text of Herbert Hoover's address here today was as follows:

The winners in the contest for the best essay on the motion picture "Sequoia," conducted during the last six months by the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, were announced yesterday. The winners and their alternates are:

PLYMOUTH, England, July 4. -- The American yacht Yankee won her second race in succession today beating T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour by one minute and thirty-three seconds over a thirty-six-mile course in the Royal Western Yacht Club's regatta.

The inclusion of Mark Twain in the Hall of Fame on the campus of New York University once was protested on the ground that Mr. Twain had confessed that, as a boy, he had taken a dime from a contribution plate at church, Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson reveals in a new volume, "Your Hall of Fame," published yesterday by New York University.

Cardinal Hayes has begun the assignment of priests as chaplains to care for the spiritual needs of the estimated 30,000 Roman Catholics who will be at non-sectarian camps in the Archdiocese of New York this Summer.

KANSAS CITY, July 4 (AP). -- All Miss Frances Elliott needed to cable to the Rev. David Thomas Wright, at Port Elizabeth, South Africa, was "Ruth 1, xvi," and the young minister knew that she was saying she would marry him. Ruth 1, xvi reads:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- Several Legion posts and other organizations of Suffolk County participated in an Independence Day parade here this morning, held under the auspices of the Malcolm R. White Post. Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin headed the committee of judges and awarded silver cups for the floats and their participants.

The season's second operatic presentation, Gounod's "Faust," was offered at the Lewisohn Stadium last night before a large and appreciative holiday audience. The performance will be repeated tonight if the weather is favorable; if it rains there will be a substitute orchestra program in the Great Hall and "Faust" will be sung tomorrow night.

SEATTLE, July 4. -- A sharp denunciation of the American Federation of Women's Clubs and the American Association of University Women for advocating birth control was issued today by the Catholic Daughters of America, in annual convention here.

The Associated Fellowship of Harlem announced yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had notified the organization that the Board of Education would provide playground facilities in all Harlem public schools in July and August. The information was in a letter to Colonel Leopold Philipp, chairman of the fellowship, an interracial group which had urged the playgrounds to reduce street accidents.

The Lehman Corporation, an Investment trust, reported yesterday that on June 20, the close of its fiscal year, the net value of its assets was $64,067,768, which was equivalent to $93.98 a share on 681,700 capital shares outstanding. This was after deducting the dividend payable today and after providing for taxes on unrealized appreciation on securities.

Attacking "wild-tuned pipers" who promise the people security and pampering. A. Harry Moore, Democratic Senator from New Jersey, defended the Supreme Court as the protector of the Constitution yesterday at the annual Independence Day celebration of the Society of Tammany, held in Tammany Hall.

SHANGHAI, July 4. -- "We fear an uprising of Japanese civilians in the Shanghai area if the requests incorporated in the recent Japanese protest against the printed insult to the Japanese Emperor are not immediately carried out," declared a spokesman of the Japanese Embassy today.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 4. -- With W. Averell Harriman and Earle W. Hopping leading the attack with three goals apiece, the Roslyn poloists conquered the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 9 to 5, in a high goal match at Roslyn Field today.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- After the first comprehensive investigation of methods and practices used by steamship companies engaged in intercoastal trade between Atlantic and Pacific ports, the Department of Commerce today condemned all tariffs filed by the water carriers as failing to comply with the requirements of the Intercoastal Shipping Act.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 4. -- The visiting team of Japanese golfing professionals scored a significant victory of two matches to one against a Westchester Professional Golfers Association team at the Grassy Sprain Golf Club today. It was their nineteenth triumph in thirty-one matches they have played on the tour and it was one of their most impressive.

EASTPORT, Me., July 4 (AP). -- Tons of earth, blown up by 600 pounds of dynamite touched off by Vice President Garner from Washington shot skyward today to signalize the beginning of work on the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project.

DETROIT, July 4. -- "My Old Kentucky Home" and other songs of Stephen Collins Foster lived again this afternoon when the restored home in which he was born and spent his childhood was dedicated in Henry Ford's Greenfield Village, whence it was moved by Mr. Ford from Pittsburgh.

The Wagner Labor Disputes Bill will become law as soon as the President signs it. It is only fair that union labor officials who make a bid for the favor of the government, employers and non-union employes, should at least do as much as industry must do in its own internal relations and in its dealings with labor -- namely, to come clean and undertake to stay clean when they come a-wooing for majority rule.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Omnibus Banking Bill, if it passes the Senate in the form in which it was reported by the Banking and Currency Committee, will encounter considerable opposition in the House, Chairman Steagall of its Banking and Currency Committee indicated today.
WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Representative Martin J. Kennedy of New York said today it was a "mystery to the country why President Roosevelt has ignored his loyal supporters in Tammany Hall."

ROME, July 4. -- Although official circles scout the very idea of an economic blockade of Italy, there is every reason to suppose that preparations are being made by Italy to meet such a contingency. This is proved by the extraordinary importance attached to the meeting of the committee of admirals in Rome now.

Some question regarding the constitutionality of the Lindbergh kidnapping law has arisen as the result of the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the Schechter case, The New York Law Journal declared editorially yesterday.
BERLIN, July 4. -- Colonel Joseph Beck formally concluded his conversations with German officials this afternoon. He took the night train for Bavaria for a brief holiday with his wife and daughter.

A sudden avalanche of lawsuits has begun, to test the constitutionality of AAA. Five actions of this sort have been started in New York during the last few days. Similar appeals to the courts, seeking an order to restrain the Government from collecting processing taxes on various farm commodities.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4. -- Mrs. Moses Taylor gave a dinner this evening at The Glen, her home in Portsmouth, for about thirty guests, including members of her family and her week-end visitors. Between 150 and 200 others arrived from other dinner parties to witness the fireworks display, arranged by Francis Taylor.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP). -- The White Sox took both games of today's doubleheader with the Browns. Les Tietje shut out St. Louis, 4 to 0, in the nightcap after Johnny Whitehead had ended his six-game losing streak by getting credit for victory in the first, 11 to 6, although he was relieved in the seventh.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4. -- Old age pensions -- the newest and one of the most difficult administrative problems of the Rhode Island State Government -- became a legal reality this week, and already several hundred persons, 65 or older, have applied to Dr. John A. Donley, Director of Public Welfare, for assistance.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 4. -- More than 900,000 acres in New Jersey, or nearly one-fifth of the rural area of the State, have been damaged by soil erosion, it was reported here today by Dr. Linwood Lee, New Jersey director of the Soil Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., July 4. -- With Buzzards Bay roughened by a brisk southwest breeze that reached a twenty-knot velocity toward the finish, Ray Hunt, one of Marblehead's leading skippers, won the historic Puritan Cup with the Q boat Hornet on time allowance today.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- When the Federal Government moves billions of dollars of its gold bullion from New York and Philadelphia to the new vault to be constructed at Fort Knox, Ky., extraordinary precautions will be taken to safeguard the valuable metal in transit.

JOHN KIERAN, who holds forth so learnedly in both prose and verse in the sports section of this paper, was once -- whisper it darkly -- a school teacher in a rural school. He was a kindly teacher, was John, and he disliked putting his pupils to any expense or trouble. No need to bribe good marks out of him with presents of apples and bouquets of daisies.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4. -- The history of so many recent tennis championships repeated itself on the centre court today when Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Helen Jacobs won their semi-finals matches and gave the British public the dubious pleasure, for them, of looking forward to another all-American final.

Tuesday was rather a filling day in the history of Republican medicine. Two eminent medicine men from the Kaw prescribed for the party. Dr. CHARLES CURTIS, about to subject the patient to rigid observation, was content for the present to advise the selection of a new national chairman and immediate exercise.

DUBLIN, July 4. -- Dublin celebrated Independence Day this year in a particularly striking way. American flags were flown not only on the United States Legation in Phoenix Park and the consulate in Merrion Square but also on many public buildings in the centre of the city.

RUMSON, N.J., July 4. -- Gaining a 5-1 lead in the first three periods, which the United States Army team was unable to overcome despite a second-half rally, Rumson triumphed in a twenty-goal team polo game today on Herbert Memorial Field.
CHICAGO, July 4. -- Thirty-eight thousand sweltering race fans today discovered why the flying hoofs of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery are no longer running second to any horse.

PARIS, July 4. -- Prospects for the Franco-American commercial treaty now being negotiated at Washington were frankly discussed by French and American officials at the Fourth of July dinner of the American Chamber of Commerce tonight.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold to a group headed by Arthur Cutler a nine-story apartment house at 227-29 West 109th Street, assessed at $180,000. The deal was for cash above a $137,500 first mortgage, according to Brooks, Harvey Co., Inc., the broker.

By some freak of definition, the President's plan to levy much higher rates on inheritances and legacies, while taxing more heavily corporations that do a large business, has been called "share the wealth taxes." They are nothing of the kind. Mr. ROOSEVELT himself plainly designated the use to which they are to be put.

PARIS, July 4. -- The French press has swung around to a strongly pro-Italian position not out of any conviction that the Italian case is any better than it was but with expressions of irritation against Britain -- in which may lie some explanation.

Some of the delegates to an Esperanto congress in this city have been composing verses in that language, and some were printed on Wednesday in our news columns. It was to the effect that the object of the happy circle at the congress was to spread Esperanto, the auxiliary language of the world, so that we might all one day live in harmony.

Thirteen persons were injured yesterday afternoon when the ferryboat Utica, of the West Shore Division of the New York Central Railroad, crashed into its docking pier at Forty-second Street and the Hudson River with about 200 holiday passengers aboard.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- Playing over the 6,639-yard course of the National Golf Links of America today in 75 strokes, two over par figures, Eugene V. Homans won the medal in the qualifying round of the fifth annual invitation tournament that attracted a record field of 106 starters.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 4. -- The 1,200 candidates in this year's Citizens Military Training Camp m took the prescribed "C.M.T.C. oath" here this morning in an impressive ceremony.

The classes of the adult education project of the Board of Education, which open for a six weeks' Summer session Monday, will have 50,000 enrolled students, according to an estimate made yesterday on the basis of 45,000 persons who registered in the week which closed Wednesday.

VIENNA, July 4. -- As was to have been expected, the Council of State duly approved today the Austrian Government's proposal for restoring Hapsburg property to the former ruling family and enabling the Hapsburgs to return to Austria, thus smoothing the path for a restoration when the government thinks fit and simultaneously increasing the suspicions of the anti-Hapsburg neighboring States.
W. Bernard Vause, former Kings County judge, who began serving a five-year sentence for mail fraud in Atlanta Penitentiary in 1932, is due to be released on parole tomorrow.

BOSTON, July 4. -- For the second time within two months, a serious accident to a member of Governor James M. Curley's motorcycle escort occurred today when a State trooper was spilled from his cycle on the Worcester Turnpike at Newton Highlands and severely injured.
