Among the passengers due here today on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg is a group of 180 German tourists consisting mainly of three groups. One group is composed of seventy physicians who are coming here at the invitation of the German Medical Society of Chicago to visit principal medical centres and hospitals of the country.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Church instruction for couples who plan to marry was urged at today's session of the International Christian Endeavor convention here.

Thomas Wolfe, called by critics one of the most promising young novelists of the day since his "Look Homeward, Angel," and "Of Time and the River" attracted wide attention, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, after a four-month tour of England, France, Germany and Scandinavia.
LONDON, July 4. -- Crack teams to contest for the Davis and Wightman Cups were named today by the British Lawn Tennis Association.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 4. -- "Sophomoric brain-trusters" of the Washington administration and "radio demagogues" were accused here today by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of encouraging the youth of the nation to accept idleness rather than work.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Definite plans to proceed with President Roosevelt's new tax program, even if it means "day and night sessions,'' were formed at a conference at the White House today. Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee, members of the taxation subcommittee and Treasury and Congressional tax experts discussed procedure with Mr. Roosevelt for nearly three hours.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 4. -- The town of Dalton and the various Berkshire Clubs had Independence Day celebrations. At the Lenox Club nearly 100 members and guests had luncheon. Tables were set on the lawn and verandas. Noticed in the party of sixteen with Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis were Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. Goode P. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. J. Paschall Davis.

LONDON, July 4. -- The stock markets here were quieter today under the influences of the end of account and the holiday in the United States. Profit-taking caused a setback in British funds. Brazilian bonds recovered in the foreign market on the Anglo-Brazilian trade agreement.

J.P. Morgan Co. and Drexel Co., the Philadelphia branch of the firm, in their combined report for June 29, published today, show moderate gains in deposits and resources compared with the amounts reported last March 4 and Dec. 31. Total deposits are $360,480,312, compared with $344,202,037 on March 4, and $338,026,690 at the end of last year.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4. -- For the second successive year Berkeley Bell won the invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today, thereby taking his place with R. Norris Williams 2d and Watson Washburn as the only players to establish two legs on the Nassau challenge trophy since 1913.

The Merchants' Association of New York made public yesterday a report of its convention bureau that showed in the twenty-two years-ended April 30 last 16,581 conventions and trade expositions were held in New York, bringing to the city 11,350,000 visitors.

A conference of workers and employers in the garment industry to discuss the basis of new collective agreements on principles embodied in the recommendations of Governor Lehman will be held today at the office of the impartial chairman for the industry, 132 West Thirty-first Street.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 4. -- Maryland's first contribution of native animals to the Prospect Park Zoo, Brooklyn, care Alfred E. Smith, will be a pair of Fiber zibeticus and a pair of Malacoclemmys palustris. That means two muskrats and two terrapins.

ST. CLAIR SHORES, Mich., July 4. -- Fred Cardoni, 30, of Detroit, mingling with a holiday crowd at Jefferson Beach, was snatched 2,000 feet into the air by the guide rope of a stunt balloon late today, and then dropped to his death after releasing his hold.

LONDON, July 4. -- Despite the declaration of Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, in the House of Commons yesterday that the report quoted by David Lloyd George to the effect that the British Government had refused a German offer to abolish submarines was "absolutely without foundation," Mr. Lloyd George, in a letter to The Times of London repeats his charge.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 (AP). -- In a wave of betting on Saturday's final the admirers of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Helen Jacobs were asking no odds. Mrs. Moody who has won the Wimbledon title six times, twice has defeated Miss Jacobs in the final round -- in 1929 and 1932.

Before a crowd of 5,000, the largest ever to witness an Independence Day polo game at Fort Hamilton, the First Division four conquered the West Point officers, 7-6, yesterday. The losers had an allowance of one goal.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- With a heavy demand for small coinage, credited to general business revival, the mints in the fiscal year ending June 30, had one of the busiest twelve-month periods in their history.

MOSCOW, July 4. -- Well-founded reports that new and stricter marriage and divorce laws will soon be promulgated in the Soviet Union are causing a bargain-counter rush of discontented husbands and wives to the "Zags" -- the marriage, divorce and birth registration bureaus -- to get rid of their old mates and get new ones while the getting is good.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- There was a round of entertainment for holiday guests today at estates throughout the colony.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 4. -- Two little boys who wanted to make a bonfire as big as their big brothers' nearly succeeded in burning down this town. Fire Departments from seven municipalities fought several hours to stop the blaze, which burned nine buildings.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday from the Paris meetings of the International Chamber, said he found the general trend among European business men was a resentment of government interference in business.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 4. -- Louisiana celebrated the end of Independence Day tonight with the convening of a special session of the Legislature, called by Governor O.K. Allen at the dictation of Senator Huey P. Long to further the control of the Senator over the people of the State.
LONDON, July 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling.
The following quotations from Montesquieu's "The Spirit of Laws" seem to be particularly pertinent at this time. They read as though they were just written:

Mayor La Guardia hailed yesterday the decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn holding bagatelle games which eject slugs or tokens to be gambling devices and therefore illegal as an effective blow to attempts to legalize the "big brothers of the slot machine."

HOHOKUS, N.J., July 4. -- Francis De Geyter, 12 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil De Geyter of 193 Pershing Avenue, Fair Lawn, N.J., was killed at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the Hohokus automobile race track when a wheel from one of the speeding cars left the axile, leaped a guard rail and struck him in the face.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 4. -- Losing control of his automobile as he was returning home from a dance at Bear Mountain at 4 A.M. today, Edwin C. McIntyre, 23 years old, of Valley Cottage, N.Y., was instantly killed when the car crashed into a telegraph pole.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 4. -- Showers of poison arrows shot into the Rio de Oro camp of the Gulf Oil Company at the Catatumbo concession yesterday resulted in the death of one Colombian worker, and another is dying of arrow wounds.
ROCKPORT, Ind., July 4. -- The Lincoln Pioneer Village was dedicated here today as Southern Indiana's celebration of Independence Day.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 4. -- A new Negro sensation came rocketing past the mighty Jesse Owens of Ohio State in the sun-drenched University of Nebraska Stadium today as Eulace Peacock, Temple University sophomore, twice beat the Brown Bombshell and twice shattered accepted world's records.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4. -- Mexico's design for living, as it appears to her own people and to an American economist, was presented to the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs today by Dr. Ramon Beteta, an official of the Mexican Government, and Dr. W.W. Cumberland of Wellington Co., New York.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- With an unaccustomed but complete absence of oratory, the Senate met today for a minute and a half. On the stroke of noon, Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, deposited his half-smoked cigar on his desk, arose and addressed Vice President Garner.

An all-Princeton final in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships was assured yesterday when Thomas D. Flynn staved off the challenge of Gardner Mulloy, Miami University junior, and Norcross S. Tilney won a straight-set victory from Paul Guibord, Dartmouth tennis and hockey star, at the Richmond County Country Club on Staten Island.

DENVER, July 4. -- A warning that the "malignant growth" of communism in this country has passed the incipient stage was sounded by Frank H. Belgrano Jr., National Commander of the American Legion, in a Fourth of July speech from Denver over the National Broadcasting System today.
Thousands of dogs, cats and other pets will be thrown on their own during the next few weeks. These animals will suffer through the selfishness of their pleasure-bound owners.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP). -- Administration confidence that its Utilities Bill would be written finally in a Senate-House conference was voiced today as the Capitol planned a double-headed investigation of lobbying for and against holding company abolition.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., July 4. -- A large gallery witnessed the opening game of the polo season today, when the Greenbrier Polo Club met the Fauquier-Loudoun Club of Middleburg, Va., on Greenbrier Field. Those having guests were:

Ten first-place performances and a generous sprinkling of second and third positions enabled the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York to total 70 points and retain its metropolitan canoeing team title yesterday on the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park.

HAVANA, July 4. -- Two New York school teachers, Mamie Keselenko and Regina T. Lazar, erroneously detained aboard the steamer Oriente Tuesday as members of Clifford Odets's expelled American inquiry commission, were released from the Tiscornia immigration station this morning.

THERE was a group in a room and the talk was on golf. Two in the group were Sam Parks Jr., national open champion, and Jimmy Thomson, the long-hitting, fair-haired husky young fellow from the Coast, who was runner-up in the Oakmont affair. They are teaming up for an exhibition tour of two months or so. But they were still talking of Oakmont.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 4. -- Making their debut as exhibition golfers, Sam Parks Jr., open golf champion, and Jimmy Thomson, long-hitting Californian, met defeat at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

Dr. Elmer D. Merrill has resigned as director of the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced there yesterday, to accept a newly created position as administrator of the botanical collections at Harvard University.

Returning to their home heath at the Stadium for what may be styled a one-day tournament with the Red Sox, the Yankees went down for a short count in the forepart of the afternoon's double-header yesterday and so brought considerable gloom to a holiday crowd of 47,000, the largest gathering to see Joe McCarthy's American League pace-setters perform this year.

BRISTOL, Va., July 4 (AP). -- Representative Wright Patman of Texas put blame today for the defeat of his bill for full payment of veterans' adjusted service certificates upon Frank N. Belgrano, national commander, and John Thomas Taylor, legislative, representative, of the American Legion.

Long-distance hitting by the Phillies, combined with good pitching when needed, proved insurmountable obstacles for the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field. They dropped both ends of a double-header, the first by 3 to 2 and the night-cap, a ten-inning affair, 8 to 7.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4. -- One hundred and thirty-four craft, a record for the season, set sail today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-fourth annual regatta. They included the two 12-meter yachts that were built to represent this country in the 12-meter international sloop racing next year, the first of that class built on this side of the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The Cardinals sped back into second place in the National League standing today, defeating the Cubs in both ends of the double-header, 5 to 3, in twelve innings, and 6 to 4, before 38,100, Wrigley Field's largest 1935 crowd.

The East Side celebrated Independence Day with a street parade and exercises at Tompkins Square Park. The events were calculated to arouse a stronger feeling of Americanism in a district inhabited largely by foreign-born. The parade formed at Marginal and Twentieth Streets at 12:30 o'clock and, after passing through the main thoroughfares, arrived at the park at 2:30 o'clock.

LONDON, July 4. -- Anglo-American friendship is the greatest thing in the world today, Sir Josiah Stamp, British financier, declared tonight at the American Society of London's Independence Day dinner, at which Ambassador Robert W. Bingham presided.

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, will play its 1,000th free concert in the course of its annual Summer series next Wednesday evening on the Mall in Central Park. This is the eighteenth season of concerts in various parts of the city.

Publications ranging in size from a printed page not much larger than a postage stamp to a finished sixteen-page booklet were exhibited yesterday by amateur journalists from various parts of the United States and abroad, attending the annual convention of the United Amateur Press Association of America at the Hotel Webster, 40 West Forty-fifth Street.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward O. Bogert entertained this afternoon at the Apaquogue Road residence of Mrs. Bogert's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Wood.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4. -- Before the largest crowd of spectators at the Meadow Brook Club this season, Thomas Hitchcock Jr., veteran internationalist, played some of his best polo in years in leading Greentree to a 10-to-4 triumph over Gulf Stream, winner of the third Westbury Challenge Cup last Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The New York A.C. captured the two feature eight-oared races in the annual People's Day regatta on the Schuylkill today before a crowd of 20,000.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The giant four-motored "mystery" bomber just completed for the Army Air Corps by the Boeing Aircraft factory at Seattle was designed to carry six tons of bombs for 6,000 miles without refueling and to have a top speed of 230 miles an hour.

GRASS VALLEY, Calif., July 4. -- Herbert Hoover came back to the gold country today to sound a Fourth-of-July call for the preservation of individual liberty, and was received with wild acclaim as he deviated from a prepared speech to use the vernacular of the mines.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 4. -- Tupelo, chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N.Y., and shown by Hubert Moseley, today was awarded the hunter championship of the horse show of the Westchester Riding and Driving Club, held on the grounds of the Hill and Dale Stock Farm.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 4. -- John M. McCloskey, 85 years old and demented, was found by police today to have been living alone in his home at 211 Atlantic Avenue, here, with the body of his sister, Miss Jennie A. McCloskey, 87, for at least a week. Dr. I.D. Patterson said the woman had died in bed of causes attributed to old age between seven and twenty days ago.

ADDIS ABABA, July 4. -- Ethiopia chose the United States Independence Day today to ask that nation to find some way to make Italy observe her obligations under the Kellogg-Briand pact, by which she renounced war as an instrument of national policy.
In New York, across the continent and in far corners of the world millions of Americans celebrated yesterday the 159th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
CLEVELAND, July 4. -- The Tigers had a glorious Fourth today at the expense of the Indians.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- "Third party" week in the preliminary manoeuvres for 1936 position opened today with arrivals of the first delegates to a two-day conference of "liberal" leaders here.

BOSTON, July 4. -- The crackle of home runs drowned the sound of exploding firecrackers today as the Giants submerged the hapless Braves in both ends of a double-header that attracted about 10,000 to Braves Field.

Thomas E. Dewey will go to Washington next week to enlist the aid of Federal agencies of law enforcement along with those of city and State in his drive against racketeering and vice in Manhattan, it became known last night on the eve of his conference with Governor Lehman on the plan and scope of his investigation.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Associated Telephone Company of Long Beach, Cal., has filed a registration statement with the SEC for an issue of $8,500,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, whose proceeds will be used to redeem first mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds series.
Henry Strater of Ogunquit, president of the Maine Tuna Club and well known as a big-game angler, forwards some information on fishing on the Maine coast which will be useful to prospective visitors.

Merton Ward Goodrich, who was arrested in Central Park for annoying children on Tuesday, and who confessed on Wednesday that he had killed an 11-year-old girl in Detroit last September, was questioned yesterday about numerous other unsolved crimes against children in and about Detroit.

FREDERICK the Great, friend of philosophers, believed in luck, and withdrew his favor from a young officer who had shown himself unlucky. To the unphilosophical, chance, fortune, luck must often seem the presiding deity over the affairs of men.

DARIEN, Conn., July 5. -- Mrs. S. Victor Weil of the Fair City Stables of Elberon, N.J., today won a leg on the Great Island Trophy, one of the most noted cups in competition at the Summer horse shows, with her chestnut gelding Lee Belle Sir Walter.

As a grandson of the late Roger A. Pryor, I was interested to read in your columns some days ago a report of Ambassador Dodd's Berlin speech, and his account of my grandfather's part in the firing of the first gun at Fort Sumter.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Bureau of the Budget, has written a book called "The Liberal Tradition: A Free People and a Free Economy," which D. Van Nostrand Company is publishing. He divides his discussion into four sections, "The Sins of the Past," "A Planned Economy and the Oppressive State," "Dictatorship and a Fiscal Policy," "A Free People and a Free Economy."
Sales of several building lots to buyers for improvement in the South Mountain Estates development in New Jersey were announced yesterday by Harry J. Stevens, broker.

LONDON, July 5. -- The French, it is learned on good authority, have declined to pledge themselves to immediate cooperation with Great Britain, either in framing a new naval conference program in the light of the Anglo-German accord or in bringing pressure to bear upon Italy to reach a peaceful agreement on Ethiopia.

VATICAN CITY, July 5. -- The Vatican placed on its index of forbidden books today Gabriele d'Annunzio's recently published work "A Hundred and a Hundred and a Hundred and a Hundred Pages From the Secret Book of Gabriele d'Annunzio, Tempted to Die."

Private industry made continually increasing demands for workers on the New York State Employment Service and the National Reemployment Service during the last ten months of 1984, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The Yale-Harvard track team, selected from the pick of the athletes in the two universities to compete against the Oxford-Cambridge team at White City, London, July 20 and 21, sailed for England yesterday on the French liner Champlain in charge of Charles B. Swope.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 5. -- James Heckscher of 8 Osceola Drive, Greenwich. Conn., former vice president of the Irving Trust Company, concealed $17,500 of his last salary in an effort to reduce alimony payments to his former wife, Mrs. Wary Fry Heckscher, Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr. said today in a memorandum decision.

Brock Pemberton has decided to close "Ceiling Zero" after tonight's performance at the Vanderbilt, and that brings this evening's mortality list to two. The other one, as already noted, is "Accent on Youth" at the Plymouth. And there may be at least one more.

TORONTO, July 5 (Canadian Press). -- Summer slackening of Canadian industry is less than usual this year, with distinct advances showing in mining, construction and leather footwear industries, according to the monthly commercial letter issued by the Bank of Commerce today.

Brenda Diana Duff Frazier, 14-year-old daughter of Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss of 7 East Seventy-fifth Street and the late Frank Duff Frazier, who died on June 21, 1933, will receive only $8.66 a month for spending money despite the fact that Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order permitting her mother to draw $45,750 for her maintenance and support for eighteen months.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 5. -- The Loyal Order of Moose today inducted its supreme officials into office on a platform in front of Plymouth Rock. The ceremonies marked the closing of the annual convention of the order in Boston.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., July 5. -- Miss Beatrix Hanson Moody, youngest of the four daughters of the late William Revell Moody, educator, and granddaughter of the late Dwight L. Moody, evangelist and founder of the Northfield Schools here, will be married to Charles Thomas Malbon of New York City at the home of her mother, Mrs. Mary Whittle Moody, next Wednesday at 4 P.M.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- In explanation of its recent decision forbidding ten prominent officials in the communications industry to hold plural directorate positions after Aug. 9, the Federal Communications Commission declared today that a director of two or more competing companies could not serve "adequately" the best interest of both.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 6. -- Eugene H. Rosenquest, president of the Westchester Lighting Company, announced today a new gas rate schedule had been filed with the Public Service Commission to reduce by $550,000 a year the rates to commercial and residential consumers.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Drastic liquidation by longs developed in North American wheat markets today as the result of fears that Canada would sacrifice its burdensome holding of wheat accumulated in several years of efforts to hold the price in that country at a level which would give farmers a satisfactory return.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A maximum eight-hour work day and 140-hour month, constituting in practical effect a thirty-hour week, was established today for the "light construction" part of the $4,000,000,000 work relief program being carried out by the Works Progress Administration under the direction of Harry L. Hopkins.

OTTAWA, July 5. -- Prime Minister R.B. Bennett told the House of l Commons before its prorogation this afternoon that there would be no unnecessary delay in the calling of a general election. He said that as soon as the revision of the voters' lists was complete and the necessary election machinery in order the date would be set.

Is it not time to call a halt on Senatorial investigations? Some of these, like the oil inquiry, may have served a useful purpose, but the practice has grown beyond all reason, and the expense involved is a serious menace at a time like this when every effort should be made to promote economy.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia. July 5. -- Premier Milan Stojadinovitch's declaration yesterday that he would enforce the 1931 Constitution has greatly disappointed the Croats. Dr. Vladimir Matchek gave a pessimistic interview to a Belgrade newspaper -- which the censor forbade it to print -- declaring the Stojadinovitch Cabinet was no better than its predecessors.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Plans for a wide and varied work relief program for every borough in New York City, embracing a list of seventy-two types of projects to cost $77,689,296, were made public by the Works Progress Administration today.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Stockholders of the Cudahy Packing Company will vote on July 15 on proposals designed to give to the directors full authority to negotiate the refunding of the company's entire funded debt, A.W. Anderson, secretary of the company, announced.
Before a ladies' day crowd of 7,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Bill Terry's Giants made the painful discovery that an under dog sometimes possesses a wicked bite.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP). -- Manager Frisch, on his arrival here tonight, said he still planned to use Dizzy Dean in the game at Cleveland, but did not say that the Cardinals' star pitcher would start the contest.

HEIDELBERG, July 5. -- Because they used frivolously the dread name of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and went roistering about town while one of his speeches was being broadcast, members of the Heidelberg chapter of the aristocratic Saxo Rorussia corps have been suspended for two years.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,475,000,000, a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $7,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., July 5. -- Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi arrived from Washington today.

William Goldberger, multigraph and letter writing, leased the Forty-second. Street wing in the Rogers Peet Building, 479 Fifth Avenue, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, as broker, and the Cross Brown Company, as agent.

The acquisition by the Lehigh Valley Railroad of an unprofitable commercial structure to protect a freight yard and adjoining property was described yesterday by Clayton E. Hildum, executive vice president of the company, at a hearing before William P. Bartel, director of the Bureau of Service of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

ST. PAUL, July 5. -- Elimination of Jerome (Dizzy) Dean as a starting pitcher in the all-star National and American League baseball game in Cleveland July 8 was virtually assured today by Manager Frankie Frisch of the Cardinals, who will pilot the National League team.

BERLIN, July 5. -- The officially recognized principle of the Nazi regime that wherever the interests of the State and those of the individual conflict the latter must be sacrificed appears to have found full expression in a long list of amendments to the code of criminal law issued today and commented upon at length by Minister of Justice Franz Guertner in a declaration to the press.
DETROIT, July 5. -- Hank Greenberg, the Tigers' first baseman, fired a couple of shots at the homerun record today when he collected two four-baggers and led Detroit in a 16-to-1 rout of the Browns.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, was advised yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, that $17,500,000 of Federal funds would be available for New York City for July.

LOS ANGELES, July 5. -- A form for the decree of foreclosure and sale of the Richfield Oil Company and the Pan American Petroleum Company properties was approved and signed today by Federal Judge James. No date was fixed for the sale.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Creation of a leadership for a national "third party," if the advisability of one should develop prior to the 1936 political campaign, was the goal of about 250 "native American radicals" who held today the first session of a two-day conference here.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Foreign governments and their political subdivisions were called upon by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to present for investors comprehensive information concerning their fiscal condition.

LONDON, July 5. -- T.O.M. Sop-with, chairman of the Hawker Aircraft Company, Ltd., has been nominated chairman of a new 2,750,000 company that is Being formed to bring under one control five British companies manufacturing fighting aircraft.

Philip Le Boutillier's yawl Stormy Weather, which won the transatlantic race to Norway, is to meet the famous Nova Scotia fishing schooner Bluenose, champion of the Grand Banks, in the Fastnet race in England next month. It is the first time one of the deep-sea fishing craft has been entered in a yacht race.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 5. -- Suit to compel the B.F. Goodrich Company, rubber manufacturer, to open its books for an inspection of earnings and balance sheet in advance of a stockholders' meeting on July 15 when authorization of a $45,000,000 first mortgage bond issue will be asked, was filed today in Common Pleas Court in Akron for Otis Co., investment bankers in this city.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- With substantial increases in all forms of currency except national bank notes, money circulation during the fiscal year ended June 30 rose to $5,567,988,498, as compared with $5,373,469,752 a year before.
MOSCOW, July 5 (AP). -- The widow of the founder of the Soviet State today told Russian women they "have not yet begun to probe the possibilities the Soviet regime has opened for them."

ROCHESTER, July 5 (AP). -- Newark clustered three hits and a base on balls in the thirteenth inning to defeat Rochester today, 7 to 4. The Bears tied the score in the ninth when Kleinke, who relieved Fisher, uncorked a wild pitch allowing McQuinn to tally from third base.

LONDON, July 5. -- The government's finance bill, which implements the budget presented in April, passed its third reading in the House of Commons today by 163 votes to 11 and was sent to the House of Lords. There was some amusement when the Opposition chided by Alfred Duff Cooper, Financial Secretary to the Treasury, decided at the last moment to challenge the bill and mustered eleven votes.
BOSTON, July 5 (AP). -- Captain John Smuts, husband of May Yohe, one-time bride of Lord Francis Hope, today described as "too silly to talk about" the assertion that a Hollywood actor was her son.

TRENTON, N.J., July 5. -- New Jersey was restrained temporarily today by Federal Judge Philip Forman from selling the property of railroads operating in the State for their failure to pay taxes for 1934 amounting to $6,700,000. The injunction will be in force "until further order of the court."

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5. -- A deeper depression at home under New Deal policies and another World War in which the United States would be involved were forecast as inevitable in addresses made today before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia by Colonel Henry Breckinridge and Dr. David I. Saposs, both of New York.

MADISON, Wis., July 5 (AP). -- Spurning entreaties and bananas, six Rhesus monkeys scampered in tree tops and on roofs just off the University of Wisconsin campus today, reveling in the freedom they declared for themselves on Independence Day.

The 1,513 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $43,511,242,590 par value as of July 1, had a total market value of $39,864,322,759, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of June 1, there were 1,520 issues, agregating $43,719,824,364 par value, which had a total market value of $39,617,835,876.

Mayor La Guardia's twice-beaten municipal power plant project received a new lease of life yesterday when Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch introduced a local law in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly calling for a referendum on the question at the November election.

NEWARK, N.J., July 5. -- The Federal Government has declined to allow the New Jersey State Department access to a survey of retail business made in the State for the Department of Commerce as an ERA project last Fall, George W. Grimm Jr., Deputy Tax Commissioner in the sales tax division, said today.

News of the prospective marriage of Miss Mary T. Barnes of this city to George Washington Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company, which has just been cabled from London, is of much interest here, although no details of the wedding plans have been disclosed.

A wide split between members of the Wall Street banking community has been caused by the amendment to the Banking Act of 1935 restoring to banks of deposit a part of the security business which was taken away from them by the Banking Reform Act of 1933.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson marked the eleventh anniversary of their wedding tonight by giving a costume supper dance at their country home at Greentree, adjoining the home of Mrs. Payson's mother, Mrs. Payne Whitney, in this community.

Abraham Cahan, author, political leader, critic and editor, sat in his office at 175 East Broadway yesterday, waiting for The Jewish Daily Forward to go to press and ready to celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday tomorrow. Posing for cameramen, giving interviews, reading the flood of congratulations that poured in and editing his newspaper, which he has served with distinction for more than a generation, was all in his day's work.

Strict discipline and promptness by the magistrates' court personnel will be the rule in the administration of Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., these requirements having been emphasized by him yesterday on a surprise visit to Yorkville Court.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Saturday, July 6. -- With the settlement of the Chino-Japanese border issues and extension of Japanese influence in North China, Japanese here anticipate closer commercial relations, amounting almost to inclusion of North China in the Japanese-Manchurian economic bloc.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5. -- Seven thousand miles away from England, here in the home sector of the two famous Helens of tennis, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody is favored to beat Helen Jacobs tomorrow at Wimbledon.

On allegations that the seeds of another race riot are being implanted in Harlem through the activities of the Negro Industrial Clerical Alliance and its president and organizer, Buff Abdul Hamid, known there as "The Black Hitler." Supreme Court Justice Cotillo granted yesterday an injunction restraining the organization, and its members from interfering with the women's apparel shop operated by the Lerner Company at 224 West 125th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, enacting into permanent law a Federal authorization for labor to organize for the purpose of collective bargaining, a definition of unfair practices, the creation of an organization to review disputes between employers and labor, was signed by President Roosevelt today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 5. -- Sanford T. Church, former Supreme Court Justice, died in his home here at 6:15 A.M. today of a heart attack. He had been ill for a week. His age was 67.

NEWPORT, July 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Pell entertained fifty guests at tea this afternoon in their Bellevue Avenue home after the christening of the infant daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Bartholomay Jelke, who have been making a holiday visit and will leave on Sunday.
Amid a setting of charm which few believed possible at Empire City, William Woodward's Sir Beverley yesterday won the featured Winsted Purse as the Summer meeting got under way at the Yonkers course.

Delegates of the Atlantic Coast district of the International Longshoremen's Association re-elected Joseph P. Ryan district president and voted confidence in his leadership as national president at the closing session at their annual convention yesterday at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

BERLIN, July 5. -- Gerhard Handrock, a Protestant deacon and candidate for the ministry, was sentenced to four months' imprisonment today as the first young German who has conscientious objections to serving in the new universal service army.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses will appear at Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall at 11 o'clock Wednesday morning to be reappointed as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority, it was announced yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 5. -- Senator Huey P. Long cracked the whip today and his followers in the Louisiana Legislature obediently pushed toward speedy passage a sweeping series of measures designed to rivet the Senator's control of all local government in the State.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 5. -- A belt of clouds with some scattered thunderstorms west of Rapid City this morning caused another postponement of the stratosphere flight, although conditions over a large part of the area are improving rapidly.

ALBANY, July 5. -- The personnel of sixteen legislative committees and seven temporary State commissions were announced tonight by Senator Dunnigan, majority leader, and Speaker Irwin Steingut of the Assembly.

Judge William F. Bleakley has signed the final order in his decision upholding the constitutionality of the State Mortgage Act, which it is expected the Court of Appeals at Albany will consider next Thursday, the State Mortgage Commission reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- David Lloyd George, England's war-time Prime Minister, appealed to the youth of the world for peace, in a special message read today at the International Christian Endeavor Convention.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5. -- Fred Perry proved today that he belongs to that little band of tennis immortals who will always be remembered in future years as the greatest champions the game has ever known.

LINDENHURST, L.I., July 5. -- A surprise raid on a low rambling bungalow at Copiague, near here, at dawn today, trapped four men and four women and uncovered, the police said, the headquarters of a policy ring that for more than a month had flourished in Suffolk County.

SHANGHAI, July 5. -- "This is a very grave case of lese-majeste and the Japanese people are very indignant and deeply insulted," said a Japanese Embassy spokesman today in referring to the insult to the Japanese Emperor in Hsinsen, Chinese weekly publication, under the title "Gossip About Emperors," which dwelt in detail on the political system of Japan, with emphasis on the imperial household.

PARIS, July 5. -- Stanley Dollar, speed-boat racer, arrived here today with only twenty-four hours in which to prepare for tomorrow's international competition for the Spreckels Trophy. He is the only American entry in the race, in which are listed three French, three Italian and two British boats.

Prices in the local commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday, with trading somewhat more active than on Wednesday. On the cash markets, lead rose 5 points to 4.05 cents, while declines occurred in all the grains, cotton and rubber.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- Efforts to enlist youth of all nations in a movement to abolish armed conflict will be made under provisions of a peace plan formulated today at sectional conferences of the International Christian Endeavor convention.

Indians in full regalia descended on New York yesterday for a two day stay. Their mission is a peaceful one, however, and tribal dances and ceremonials replace the warlike gestures of days long past. Dr. Harold Davis Emerson and fifteen of his braves and squaws from the United Indians of the Americas are guests of Hearn's Duty, Honor and Country Boys' Club, of which General Hugh S. Johnson is honorary president.

RENO, Nev., July 5. -- A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Theodora Boettger Topping from Daniel R. Topping. They were married in New York April 28, 1932. The ground for the divorce was cruelty. The couple reached an agreement on property matters.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The foreign trade of the United States in May showed practically no change from April, but imports exceeded exports for the second successive month, the excess amounting to $5,102,000, the Commerce Department reported today.

ROME, July 5. -- Italian circles note with considerable satisfaction that the British Government shows a tendency to abandon its energetic attitude toward the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, foreshadowed early this week.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Independence Day appeal of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia for the United States to invoke the Briand-Kellogg Pact against Italy in her threatened African war was promptly rejected by President Roosevelt today.

WARSAW, July 5. -- The Polish Government is satisfied with the results of the visit of Colonel Josef Beck, Foreign Minister, to Berlin. It is said to have proved that the Polish-German non-aggression declaration of Jan. 26, 1934, has stood the test of time and has continued to be a factor of great importance for the peace of Europe.

A new wage schedule providing $155 a month for the chief operator on Class A ships, an increase of $45 over previous rates, and the reduction of working hours from twelve to eight a day are included in the findings of Ben Golden, associate director for the Regional Labor Board, who was recently named arbitrator in the controversy between the International Mercantile Marine Company and the American Radio Telegraphists Association, Inc.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., July 5. -- The fire department of the village of North Great River was auctioned out of existence today. Its three fire trucks, crowbars, axes, shovels and other equipment brought a grand total of $53.50, but the fire alarm siren, which caused the department to go on the rocks, is still in the custody of the sheriff.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5. -- Eugene V. Homans, former metropolitan champion and medalist here yesterday with a 75, was one of those to gain the semi-final round of the fifth annual invitation tournament of the National Golf Links of America today.
LAKEPORT, Calif., July 5. -- Automobile loads of armed mountaineer ranchers were reported converging on the Lake County Jail here tonight for the purpose of "lynching that guy who drowned the girl."

ROME, July 5. -- The former King Alfonso of Spain narrowly escaped death today when a motor car he was driving overturned and hit a telegraph pole. Both he and his aide escaped with no bones broken and were able to resume their journey to Paris on a train.
Money market showed no change over the interval of the holiday. Business was small, and rates steady for all classifications.

The current number of The Annalist publishes a "thermometer" of silver. It shows the price per ounce at which the silver currencies of various countries become more valuable for the silver metal they contain than as tokens of monetary value. When and as silver rises to this point, coins tend to be withdrawn from circulation and melted down.

Patronage brokers in Congress are forever trying, first, to increase the offices at their disposal, and second, to strengthen their control over them. Not satisfied merely to take advantage of the early enthusiasm for the New Deal by throwing the various abecedarian agencies open to the spoilsmen, they have frequently sought to get their own thumbs as deep as possible in the pie.

DETROIT, July 5. -- Jack Medical husky swimmer from the Washington A.C. of Seattle, met defeat in national competition for the first time in two years tonight. He trailed ten yards in the wake of Ralph Flanagan, Miami (Fla.) schoolboy, in the mile swim that featured the opening program in the National A.A.U. outdoor championships.

The brewery business established by the late George Ehret in Yorkville in 1866 and discontinued in 1930 will be re-established in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday. A corporation for the manufacture of beer has been formed by the Ehret family which has just purchased the property of the Interboro Beverage Corporation, formerly known as the Leonard Eppig Brewery, at Melrose and George Streets.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5. -- Seldom has England been so excited over any sports event as it is over the renewal of the fued tomorrow between Miss Helen Jacobs, American titleholder, and her old nemesis, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, with the Wimbledon women's crown at stake.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- An intimation that if national banks were again permitted to underwrite issues of securities as proposed in the Banking Bill, now before the Senate, this authorization should be surrounded by strictest limitations as to the methods by which such securities are sold was given today by President Roosevelt.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 5. -- Mrs. Charles H. Sabin gave a luncheon today at Bayberry Land, her home in the Shinnecock Hills, for Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt of Beaulieu, Newport, who left later in the afternoon for Newport on their yacht, Winchester.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A division has arisen in the ranks in respect to the regional Republican conference to be held in Cleveland July 8-9 because of a feeling among "regulars" that the promoters of the meeting aim to stress the availability of Herbert Hoover as a candidate for the Presidential nomination.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman called upon "the racket-ridden and the exploited" yesterday to support Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of racketeering and vice as the Police Department took steps to carry out Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's promise to cooperate fully with the young special prosecutor.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- President Roosevelt signed the Wagner Labor Relations Bill, and the bill to incorporate a national theatre. He made known at a press conference that he was opposed to any provision in the banking bill allowing banks to underwrite security issues without proper safeguards for investors.

The bravery of a taxicab driver, who refused to drive three armed hold-up men, fleeing from Twenty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue at 3:15 P.M. yesterday with about $10,000 in cash and checks taken from a messenger for The Morning Telegraph, a theatrical and racing newspaper, resulted in the recovery of the money and slight injuries to the driver.

Perhaps, in some instances, the taxes on alcoholic beverages are excessive, but for the most part, so far as the hard liquors are concerned, the trouble is that the tax is written up so often that by the time the consumer gets it the cost is bordering on the prohibitive.

The home of the forgotten man has at last been discovered. It is Tammany Hall. A Representative from New York has been pleading with the President to do something for the disconsolate men who hang about the Wigwam waiting for Federal appointment to office.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The House in post-holiday mood tried today to outdo the Senate in brevity of session, but Speaker Byrns found the body's established procedure lacking in elasticity and members sat for a full twelve minutes, as compared with the Senate's record of ninety seconds in arranging for a holiday yesterday.

Definite but moderate gains in many directions were disclosed by reports of trade conditions during the six months' period just ended, with a gradual but irregular uptrend in practically all major lines, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The agency finds that more concerted efforts are being made to adjust operations to changing conditions.

Wilson Co. and subsidaries reported yesterday for the six months ended April 27 net income, after interest, depreciation, processing taxes, minority interest and Federal taxes, of $2,489,179. The earnings were equivalent after dividend requirements of the $6 preferred stock to 75 cents per share on the company's 2,001,163 no-par common shares outstanding.

Taken back to Detroit yesterday to stand trial for the murder of 11-year-old Lillian Gallaher, Merton Ward Goodrich admitted before leaving that he had attacked five other little girls in Detroit, but denied that he had ever killed any but the Gallaher child.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 5. -- The Art Masque Ball, sponsored by the Art Students Club of Interlaken and Asbury Park, was held in the high school auditorium here tonight and attracted a large contingent of the shore Summer colony.

The motives of the Butterick debentures committee, which is supporting a plan of reorganization proposed by the Butterick Company party under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, were questioned yesterday at a hearing on the reorganization plan before Peter B. Olney Jr., special master, to whom the plan was referred by Federal Judge Knox.

One of the season's outstanding polo matches is scheduled this afternoon on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L.I., when eight of the country's outstanding players will participate in a special encounter for the benefit of the Welfare Fund of the auxiliaries of the Nassau County Police Department.

Although new State and municipal financing will bulk slightly larger next week, only three issues will be for large amounts. The total for next week will amount to $15,206,494, as against this week's revised total of $11,043,062. The weekly average for the year thus far amounts to $23,498,046.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt will seek to earry her fight to win the custody of her 11-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, from the child's paternal aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, to the Court of Appeals, it was announced yesterday at the office of Mrs. Vanderbilt's attorney, Nathan Burkan.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- New list of applications to the SEC for registration by brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities contains the following firms from New York City and vicinity:

The expenditures of the Agricultural Adjustment Act have exceeded its collections, it was charged yesterday in suit brought by the Consolidated Cigar Corporation, 730 Fifth Avenue, to restrain the Collector of Internal Revenue from enforcing further processing taxes.

VIENNA, July 5. -- This afternoon the government's bill providing for the return of the exiled Hapsburgs and the restoration of the family's property was brought before the Federal Economic Council for approval and later it passed through the same formality with the Federal Cultural Council.

Leaders of business profess to believe that the manifest evils which were attacked and to a certain extent controlled by the NRA can be met just as well by business associations acting under the present law. This I do not believe.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP). -- The Pirates had a pleasant homecoming today after a long road trip, defeating the Cubs, 4 to 0, and chasing from the mound their leading pitching nemesis Roy Henshaw.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 5 (AP). -- Defendants in a suit filed by Christiane Yvonne Catherine Spoturno Seurin of Paris, administratrix of the estate of the late Francois Coty, founder of Coty, Inc., to acquire title to and obtain possession of 607,111 shares of stock in the corporation, are ordered to appear in Chancery Court Sept. 20 and show cause why an injunction should not be issued as asked by the complainant.
Oswald W. Knauth announced yesterday his resignation as director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, asking that it become effective on Aug. 1, or as much earlier as possible.

Higher prices for farm and food products are reflected in a rise of 1.1 points in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 122.8 on Tuesday from 121.7 (revised) for the preceding Tuesday. Beef prices again turned downward, however, and copper declined.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York: General Conditions.

Whidden Graham writes to your paper about high rentals and comments that in six years much has been promised and nothing has been done toward lowering them. He must be very much misinformed about the subject, as it is generally known that rentals have come down at least 30 per cent.

NORWALK, Conn., July 5. -- The disappearance of James W. Kelley, 39, paying teller at the Fairfield County Savings Bank, took on a melodramatic turn today when his younger brother, John Kelley, a member of the Norwalk Police Department, received a leave of absence from his regular duties with unofficial orders to "break the case."

NEW HAMBURG, N.Y., July 5. -- Visions of explorations in the Gobi Desert, the Rocky Mountains or some other haunt of the naturalist arose in the minds of a group of 200 boys and girls from New York at a camp along the Hudson here today when Henry Fairfield Osborn, former president of the American Museum of Natural History, told of his early experience in nature study in this vicinity.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line was a group of ninety-one German doctors. This is the first time since 1910 that a party of physicians and surgeons has come to the United States to visit the clinics in the principal cities.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 5. -- Former Senator George H. Moses and Mrs. Moses entertained at Crawford Notch today in honor of Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire and Mrs. Bridges. Their other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Gordon P. Eager, Mr. and Mrs. H. Stewart Bosston, Mrs. William E. Stoddard, Captain C.C. Way, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dreier and Mr. and Mrs. R.C. Maddux.
DETROIT, July 5. -- At the opening here today of the American Youth Congress business sessions "fight" songs were sung, with the emphasis on the urge to fight for peace.

TOKYO, July 5. -- The position of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and with it the future of the Nanking Government, is considered by the press here as endangered because of the incident arising from the insult to the Japanese Emperor published in a Chinese magazine.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The fight over control of forest lands, the United States Forest Service and the proposal to rename the Interior Department broke out anew today when Professor H.H. Chapman of Yale, president of the Society of American Foresters, made public a piquant exchange of letters between himself and Secretary Ickes.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 5. -- Apparently alarmed at the downward response in world markets to the amended wheat board legislation, which specifically directs a selling policy for the accumulated holdings of the government agency, the Federal Government immediately took two steps today toward assuring the world that no sacrifice sale was intended.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Influenced by improved weather over the holiday and a break of 5 cents a bushel in wheat, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke a quarter cent a pound or more yesterday and closed 20 to 28 points lower than on Wednesday. It was evident last week that 12 cents for the spot month was bringing actual cotton on the market.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP). -- Hi-Nelli, colorbearer from John Hartman's stable and ridden by Joseph Renick, reveled in the slow going at Arlington Park today and Won the featured Maywood Purse at five furlongs by two lengths and a half from H.P. Headley's Sparta.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 5. -- Because of their clandestine nature, the relations between Robert M. Miller, New York attorney, and two women are not cause for a separation to be granted to his wife, Mrs. Etta S. Miller, Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich ruled today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 5. -- The Vassar College experimental theatre opened its first Summer season tonight with "Ladies Are Made," a satiric comedy by Mary Morley Crapo, class of '34, based on the social obligations of a debutante.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 5. -- Champions of other years and ranking tennis players of the day gathered today for the annual invitation doubles tournament of the Piping Rock Club.

An ex-convict was shot dead and three other persons were struck by gunmen's bullets last night on New Utrecht Avenue near Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn. A few minutes after the body of the ex-convict, Girardo (Big Jerry) Mugavero, a racketeer recently released from Sing Sing Prison, slumped to the pavement, a policeman cornered two men who are believed to have been his assailants.
For the first time in 108 years the two branches in this city of the Religious Society of Friends, or Quakers, as they are commonly called, will hold a series of public meetings together.

As a means of simplifying procedure, a complete segregation of security and commodity margin accounts is being discussed by brokers with representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board. Under the present rule collateral for security account must be legally adequate not only for that account but also for any commodity transactions the customer may undertake on credit.

Six motor cruisers and eighteen sailing craft waited in readiness last night for the start today of the annual race to Block Island, one of the oldest classics among Sound sailors, held under the direction of the New York A.C. yachting department.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Wilson Co., Inc., of Chicago, filed with the SEC today a statement for the issue of $20,000,000 of bonds under the Securities Act of 1933. This brought the total filings since Jan. 1 to about $1,400,000,000, a record which surprised even officials of the commission.

New York State really ought not to have to advertise her own wares. However, it is perhaps as well that she should do so, not merely because her sister Commonwealths are bidding against her, but because by so doing she may be able to give their residents a better balanced picture of what she has to offer.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Declining to give an opinion one way or the other on the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Control Bill, Attorney General Cummings today advised the Ways and Means subcommittee handling the measure to push it through and leave the question to the courts.

CULBERTSON, Mont., July 5. -- Seventeen persons were injured, four seriously, when the westbound Empire Builder, crack Great Northern transcontinental train, plunged into a washout caused by a cloudburst four miles east of here early this morning.

Frank A. Flynn, Astoria taxicab executive, was found guilty of murder in the first degree last night in having drowned Margaret Parlato, 6 years old, in a bathtub at his home, 29-07 Thirty-first Street, Astoria, on April 30.
MANAGER JOE CRONIN of the Boston Red Sox sat in the visitors' dugout of the Yankee Stadium on the Fourth of July and gave his views on American League affairs.

BERLIN, July 5. -- Reports of better export trade in iron and tools strengthened the stock market here today. Vereinigtestahl, which is profiting from the armament program, gained 2 points; other heavy industrials were firm. Potashes were quiet and firm.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Having practically abandoned hope of passing any veterans' bonus legislation at this session of Congress, advocates of immediate cash payment began today to consider strategy for the American Legion annual convention starting in St. Louis Sept. 23.

OTTAWA, July 5. -- After a deadlock between the House and Senate over amendments to the trade and industry board, which kept the Governor General waiting nearly three hours, Parliament finally prorogued late this afternoon with the usual pomp and color.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Montgomery Ward Co. reported today that their sales in June were the best for that month since 1930 and surpassed trade in the corresponding month of 1929. The total was $23,822,297, which compares with $19,226,336 in June of last year, an increase of 23.65 per cent.

The sun was hot in Union Square yesterday afternoon, but it in no way stopped the flow of words or slowed up the proceedings at the outdoor commencement of the Hobo College, where six 'bos, past masters in the art of easy living, received their diplomas.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Leander Rowing Club, cup holder, will meet Pembroke College of Cambridge in the final for the Grand Challenge Cup, the leading event for eights, as the Royal Henley regatta winds up tomorrow.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 5. -- Success which has followed Adfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's horses this season was not long coming to the 3-year-old gelding, Erin Lad, recently bought by the young New York sportsman from Ed McGhee.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 5. -- Louis Hewlett, 71 years old, a retired coffee expert and buyer, was found dead in a small house on the Hewlett estate here this afternoon, a bullet hole in the middle of his forehead and a .32 calibre revolver at his side.
BERLIN, July 5 (AP). -- Another German, whom well-informed circles call a spy, soon will be beheaded, it was learned today.
BERLIN, July 5 (AP). -- Another German, whom well-informed circles call a spy, soon will be beheaded, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Eighteen railroads considered "fairly typical" of the railroad situation as a whole and the financial interests which have been associated with them were recommended for investigation by the special Senate Interstate Commerce Committee in a letter sent to Chairman Wheeler today by Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 5. -- Two years ag an unknown Negro lad won the national pentathlon championship. Today he is the most talked of youngster track and field has had in decades. When Eulace Peacock administered a startling double setback to the formerly invincible Jesse Owens in the American title tests here yesterday he made the long jump from obscurity to fame with unprecedented rapidity.

The threatened strike of 40,000 workers in the cloak and suit industry was definitely averted yesterday when union and employer representatives worked out the basis of a new contract along the lines suggested by Governor Lehman. The Governor had pledged the union at a hearing in Albany last week to defer strike action until he could submit recommendations which he believed would lead to a settlement of the controversy.

This week's Federal Reserve reports, published yesterday, showed strongly the effects of two developments in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by the reports. One of these developments was the retirement on last Monday of about $600,000,000 of 2 per cent consols, in connection with which the Treasury deposited with the Federal Reserve Banks gold certificates sufficient to increase their gold-certificate reserves $99,730,000 to a new high level of $6 226,221,000.

Special services for students in the Summer School of Columbia University, which opens Monday, will be conducted in churches on Morningside Heights, beginning tomorrow and continuing through the five Sundays the school is in session.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Advances of as much as 1 cent a pound in the price of fresh pork loins in the local market, despite hot weather, greatly stimulated the demand for hogs here today. While heavy-weight hogs were inclined to lag, desirable kinds were up 10 cents a hundred weight generally, with some late sales regarded as 25 cents higher than on Wednesday.

BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP). -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut confirmed today the amended plan for reorganization of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company under the Uniform Bankruptcy Act. Previously he had refused claims amounting to $83,000. Barring an appeal, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will take over Kelly-Springfield on Aug. 5.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 6. -- Ambassador Constantin Yureneff informed Foreign Minister Koki Hirota that the Soviet accepted the proposed tripartite frontier commission to regulate disputes arising over the Siberian-Manchurian boundaries.

The New York State Hotel and Restaurant Board has submitted a report to the Industrial Commissioner recommending minimum wages of 18 cents an hour for waitresses in hotels and restaurants, and 30 cents an hour for lodging workers. For a forty-eight-hour week, a longer hourly period than most of the 60,000 women and minors concerned actually work, this would mean minimum wages ranging from $8.64 to $14.40 weekly.
New municipal legislation designed to end lucrative racketeering in the fish industry is under consideration by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, it was learned yesterday.

The interposition of the holiday, while it did not materially increase the trading volume in the share market yesterday, did permit a little time for the going-over of the political situation as it relates to finance, and there was an outcropping of buying orders which moved prices steadily higher throughout the day.

Alone among the railroads, the Western lines reported an increase in net operating income in May, according to figures issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. The gain in the West was 40.2 per cent, but in the East there was a decline of 9.6 per cent and in the South one of 26.4 per cent.

JAMESBURG, N.J., July 5. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of the Rock Spring Country Club today added another competitive course record to her collection when she scored an 80 over the Forsgate course to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's one-day tournament.

Samuel Goldwyn announced yesterday that he had acquired the motion picture rights to Edna Ferber's novel, "Come and Get It," and that he also had signed Miss Ferber to prepare the screen script. Edward Chodorov, who will act as her technical assistant, will be responsible for the actual continuity.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 5. -- Hornet, Ray Hunt's Q boat; the gaff-rigged schooner Saraband, and the schooner Mandoo were victors today as a major yacht club cruise put into this picturesque island port for the first time since 1858.

Those dogged, deep-boring fighters of incredible strength -- the tuna -- are in our offshore waters. Although catches have not been numerous as yet, a survey over the holiday proved conclusively that the schools are here. Anglers planning week-end expeditions to New Jersey and Long Island resorts have reasonably good prospects of encountering the bulldogs of the sea.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in June aggregated $24,325,277,050. This was a loss of 2.4 per cent from the turnover in May, but 5.5 per cent greater than the total for June last year.

July retail trade got off to a good start in the metropolitan area, as notably active pre-holiday purchasing made for substantial gains in retail trade here during the week. Estimates indicated increases ranging up to 20 per cent were made by leading department stores here for the four-day selling period, as compared with the same days a year ago.

Those who stayed behind this week-end and did not join the exodus to the great open spaces experienced New York's hottest day of the year yesterday. The temperature rose to 87.2 degrees at 1:05 P.M. The previous high for the year was 86.7, June 13.

The heat wave joined forces with the usual holiday-week tempo yesterday to keep bonds on the Stock Exchange in a listless mood. Despite the moderate turnover domestic securities acted well with the exception of some rails, while a sudden break in Italian obligations featured the foreign group. Transactions were $9,841,000, compared with $10,053,400 on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Production of $47,311,243,640 in paper money and other negotiable securities at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing during the fiscal year ended June 30 was reported today by the Treasury. This compared with $42,113,520,120 in the previous year.

It took a General Sessions jury less than two minutes yesterday to return a verdict of guilty of forgery against Nicholas Kapp, a fourth offender, whose powerful build belied the 85 years he gave as his age. Kapp, who gave the address 153 East Twenty-third Street, is liable to a term of fifteen years to life when he is arraigned for sentence next Thursday before Judge John J. Freschi.

Modifications made by New Jersey in the proposed tri-State compact for abating pollution of the tidal waters of the metropolitan area will be accepted by the State of New York, it was indicated yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., July 5. -- Counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann today filed in the Court of Errors and Appeals a supplemental brief in support of the condemned prisoner's fight for a new trial on the charge of killing the Lindbergh baby.

TIRANA, Albania, July 5. -- Corruption in high places is not unknown in the Balkans, but Albania has just achieved the record either in Ministerial corruption, or perhaps in honesty in dealing firmly with it -- for such Balkan corruption generally continues till the government concerned goes out -- by the revelation that a Cabinet Minister headed a band of smugglers.

Police Commissioner Valentine ordered his department yesterday to make a check-up of persons conducting business during the Summer, to learn whether they had filed a bond with Controller Taylor covering their payment of the 2 per cent city sales tax.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Fewer than twenty-five requests to be heard in favor of or in opposition to the four-point Roosevelt program of Federal inheritance taxes, gift taxes, graduated corporation income taxes and individual income surtaxes had been received up to today by the Ways and Means Committee as leaders prepared to start hearings Monday.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. William S. Fitzpatrick gave a dinner for thirty-six at the Devon Yacht Club tonight in honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. H.C. Fitzpatrick, Mrs. James W. Simpson, Mrs. Thomas M. Gayley and Miss Virginia Evans. Mr. and Mrs. Zalmon G. Simmons Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., entertained at the club for their yachting party and for twenty East Hampton friends.

The amount of soot in the air over New York City during June averaged 1.30 tons a cubic mile, or .03 of a ton less than in May, it was said yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist of the Federal Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.
Norcross S. Tilney of Princeton won the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship yesterday, the first representative of Nassau to carry off the title since the tournament was inaugurated in 1923.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- From a sporting standpoint the Newport season is rapidly developing. Though no tournaments have yet been started at the Casino, the number of tennis players on the courts is increasing each day and it will not be long before there is a demand for weekend tourneys for women and for mixed doubles.

ATLANTA, July 6. -- Severe heat again forced retail sales down in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week, although a group of leading department stores reported sales nearly 10 per cent higher than the same period a year ago. Bank clearings were $3,000,000 higher than last week and $500,000 abow] those of ,reek before last.

HAMMONTON, N.J., July 6. -- That farm labor problems are rapidly assuming a position equal to the importance of taxes, weather and marketing for New Jersey horticulturists is one interpretation placed on difficulties raspberry growers have encountered in the last two weeks in obtaining sufficient pickers for a bumper crop.

THIS is that same chef-author whose "The Vicomte in the Kitchen" won much admiration and interest from connoisseurs but was found rather too much in the grand manner to appeal to apartment house hostesses. And so for their benefit he has written this little guidebook for the more informal cooking and serving in apartment homes.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Covering many elements bearing on safety at sea, Secretary Roper has approved a number of new rules and regulations recommended by the Board of Supervising Inspectors, Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection.
It must be six months at least since I wrote you about my sick uncle, the occasion being the assembling in Washington of the clinic which was then gathering from the various parts of our country.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Retail trade for the holiday week was ahead of last year's by a small margin, with preparations for the celebration a big factor in boosting sporting goods and other sales. The sale of household furnishings also continues at a most satisfactory pace.

Louis Revelia, 30 years old, a laborer, of 22 East 111th Street, was drowned last night in Central Park Lake, just off Fifth Avenue and 106th Street, when he attempted to swim diagonally across the lake to win a wager he had made with his cousin, Manuel Revelia, of 12 East 111th Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The latest technique of canine surgery, police work and the exploits of the Federal "G men," will be discussed at conventions in this city in the coming week.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4. -- Upton Sinclair's EPIC following has attracted politicians, reformers and cranks as honey attracts flies ever since Mr. Sinclair polled 850,000 votes for Governor last November.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and Mrs. Baldwin saw Cambridge University win the Grand Challenge Cup for the first time in history today.

THE easiest and most obvious way to pigeonhole this book is to stress its faint resemblance to "Outward Bound." Mr. Lohrke, however, has a more devious mind than Sutton Vane, and he is never half so explicit about his voyagers to eternity.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP). -- Wild Bill Hallahan, subbing for Paul Dean, turned in his second victory of the week today, holding the Reds to five hits, while his Cardinal teammates gained a 4-to-2 victory in a decisive sixth-inning rally.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 6. -- President Roosevelt and Senator Hiram Johnson of California fished this afternoon in the windswept waters of Chesapeake Bay under a July sun.

A VERY pointed comparison was drawn last week by Stephen S. Zand, sound-proofing specialist for aircraft, when he spoke before the Lions Club of New York. Mr. Zand read an excerpt from an aeronautical writer of 1925 who said that at that time there were no truly commercial airplanes in operation, passenger flights, if made at all, being taken in obsolete military machines.

CENTRAL CITY, Col., July 6 (AP). -- Central City's old Opera House tonight was the setting for an original musical extravaganza, a panorama of the mining community theatre's past, called "Central City Nights," and prepared by Robert Edmond Jones. It is the fourth festival sponsored by Denver University's Central City Opera House Association.

PARIS, July 6. -- Today for the second time this week Premier Pierre Laval received the British Ambassador, Sir George Clerk, seeking French support of British action to prevent an Italo-Ethiopian conflict.
MOSCOW, July 6 (AP). -- Independent Mongolia today formally accused the Japanese Army, already virtual master of Northern China, of plotting to seize Mongolian territory.

The proposed amendment to the Agricultural Adjustment Act to impose a compensatory processing tax upon rayon "represents the culmination of a two-year effort on the part of special groups to saddle on rayon a tax which the Department of Agriculture still says is unjustified by the facts."

ASBURY PARK, N.Y. -- Tennis enthusiasts of the North Jersey shore will see their favorites in action on the courts on Tuesday when the opening matches in the fourth annual invitation tournament of the Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club will be played.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6. -- A group of prominent educators and scientists will appear on the lecture program of Syracuse University's annual Summer sessions, the first six-week period of which opens Monday. Ernest Reed, director, predicts an attendance of about 1,400 students at the first session, more than half of whom will be secondary public school teachers.
The week brought to the President a resounding defeat, an assortment of work-relief headaches, a reminder of the writings of Robert Southey, but no July 4 holiday.

DALLAS, July 6. -- Although Independence Day brought a cessation of business- generally throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, improvement in retail trade and in most industrial activity is reported for the week. Retail sales in preparation for observance-of July 4 were larger than for several I years and brought the' volume of I sales for the week somewhat ahead of last week's volume.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 6 (AP). -- Nine North Carolina counties piled up huge majorities today for the opening of liquor stores. Six other counties had already voted strongly for legal sales.

WHEN the art world falls quiescent -- and the local scene is certainly slumberous these July days -- we may all find it agreeable to woo moments of meditation, considering now one aspect, now another, of those basic problems that can have so much to do with the spectacle we familiarly watch from day to day during an active season.

Side-stepping precariously on a parapet twenty-one stories above the street, an unemployed real estate salesman, intent on suicide, held the attention of several hundred nervous onlookers in East Forty-second Street yesterday at 1 P.M. until police strategy brought him to safety.

LONDON, July 6. -- The Royal Air Force of Great Britain paraded today before its King in the first formal air review ever held in England. It was inspected on the ground and then a large section flew past in the air 1,000 feet up, giving and receiving the salute just as marching troops salute and are saluted.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 6. -- Despite a heavy fog that enshrouded the fleet most of the way, all six of the motor boats participating in the twenty-sixth annual New York A.C. race from Execution Rock to Block Island, reached their goal tonight.

DO I like the films? You can say most emphatically that I do not." The speaker, says a Reuters dispatch from Hollywood, was Ramon Novarro, who has relinquished acting for a career as author and producer.

NEWTON, Mass., July 6 (AP). -- An official Newton police report tonight put Governor James M. Curley in his automobile at the time a State trooper, riding as escort, was thrown from his motorcycle and critically injured here on the Fourth of July.

ATHENS, July 6. -- As part of Greece's change from a republic to what is called a "democratic parliamentary government" which is believed to be the prelude to a return to a constitutional monarchy, a committee charged with constitutional changes has recommended control of the press and giving the right of suppression to the Cabinet and the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Contending that banks were using the Treasury's silver-buying machinery for their own profit, Senator Thomas of Oklahoma said today that a request for early stabilization of gold and silver, backed by forty Senators, would be served on President Roosevelt immediately.

THE human mind demands unity in nature. It is satisfied if the same laws -- if we can still speak of laws in these revolutionary times -- apply to the stars and the universe, and to atoms and the electrons of which they are composed.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- The text of the platform adopted today for the new third-party movement was as follows:
