WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Dissension among work relief chieftains was renewed today in contentions of PWA officials that Harry L. Hopkins's labor regulations would threaten damage to Secretary Ickes's low-cost housing program and possibly result in labor troubles.

OMAHA, Neb., July 5. -- Farmers have shown less concern over the avalanche of suits to enjoin collection of processing taxes than might have been expected from a region that has received such extensive benefits from them and in which support for AAA policies appears to have been consolidated.

NOW when certain garden flowers are producing their first display of blooms the experienced grower takes advantage of the interesting fact that most plants as soon as they produce a crop of seed, cease flowering -- realizing, apparently, that their purpose in life is accomplished.

BACON frying in the open sends up a welcome aroma, with the sizzle of grease dropping into the fire. Under the trees the feast is spread, sandwiches spilling from half-open boxes deviled eggs, dill pickles, and all sorts of eatables.

Emergency conservation work, as a complement to the normal maintenance and operation of Mount Rainier National Park in Washington, is a veritable trade school for many enrolles, giving them experience and training in radio research, telephone and power line repair, landscaping and office work, says a bulletin from the Department of Interior, National Park Service.

PEEKSKILL, July 6. -- Colonel Walter A. DeLamater of the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment of Manhattan, now in training at Camp Smith here, was elevated today to the rank of brigadier general of the line, to command the Fifty-third Infantry Brigade.

THE NRA is dead by Supreme Court edict. There are those who believe that it can be resuscitated to accomplish its main purpose by the pulmotor of eventual Congressional rewriting, meeting the objections raised by the court. Can this be done?

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 6. -- Heavy fog over Moriches Bay delayed the start of the week-end regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club for forty-five minutes today. A light southwest wind finally lifted some of the fog, and while it never was ideal for racing, thirty-two boats competed in the various events.

A REAL addition to our literature of immigrants and of pioneer days is made by this volume from the Caxton Printers. That literature, it is true, has grown already to voluminous proportions. But there will always be room on its shelves for any narrative as vital, real and different as this story of Elise Dubach.
BERLIN, July 6 (AP). -- Five great world powers knew tonight something that was being kept carefully from the people of Germany -- the Reich's detailed program of naval construction for 1935-36.

SEVEN hundred wooded acres along the crest of the Palisades, the recent gift of John D. Rockefeller Jr., give new scope to the Palisades Interstate Park, new vistas to the millions of New Yorkers whose only glimpse of country it is.

ALL along the Eastern coast these days, from the Chesapeake to Maine, yachts are putting off for week-end and longer cruises. They run from the little yawl and small motor cruiser to large schooners and stately power yachts, black and white and glittering with polished metal.

SEEKERS after thrills such as may be found in the works of the masters of detective fiction will perhaps be disappointed with this book. Here is no glamour and but very little excitement. Instead we have the straightforward narrative of a man who has spent forty years of his life in the pursuit of criminals.
ALBANY, July 6. -- State Tax Commissioner Mark Graves predicted today that the end of the downward trend of real estate values in the State would be reached during 1936.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Despite the July 4 holiday, privately financed construction insured by the Federal Housing Administration continued this week the spurt begun seven weeks ago. Applications for mortgage insurance for new buildings rose to $7,193,394 as compared with $6,266,624 in the previous week.

IT has been said that young novelists, instead of telling a story, too often content themselves with telling about a story. Faith Baldwin, who is by no means unskilled or unpracticed in her craft, has fallen into a similar error in "The Puritan Strain."

In general, the railroads have decreased the costs of conducting fiscal offices since 1929, a report by N.B. Haley of the staff of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, discloses. The report held that there were potential savings of not less than $750,000 annually in the consolidation of these offices.

OLD Man Coyote must surely, these days, be twisting his sly and evil visage into a sardonic grin when he sees how interesting and admirable the white people are finding the Indians, whom once they vied with him in harassing and maltreating.

Captain Reginald V. Peel, Royal Naval Reserve commodore and the Mauretania's last master, has been appointed to the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania in place of Captain Peter Vaughan, who has gone to The Homeric. The last-named vessel is on her series of annual Mediterranean cruises from Southampton.

Alderman Lambert Fairchild, who three weeks ago proposed an ordinance to forbid aliens from making soap-box speeches in the city, called yesterday upon patriotic and civic organizations to attend a mass meeting in support of the measure.

Sailing before a strong southerly breeze Adam Wahl's Centaur captured the decked-canoe class contest in the fourth day of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association's race week in East Chester Bay, off City Island, yesterday. The Centaur led William Lux's White Cap by more than eight minutes over the five-mile course.

Skippers of craft in the vicinity of Oyster Bay unquestionably will be amazed when they encounter Philip J. Roosevelt piloting his new thirty-one-foot flying proa, which was launched yesterday at his home, Yellow Banks.

Spaced just far enough to be convenient and accessible to motorboat owners of New York and New Jersey are the three yacht basins in the Palisades Interstate Park that sooner or later are going to be the pattern for municipal and park projects in most coastal cities of the country.

BECAUSE they meet at many points it might be a loose statement to say that geography and history are parallel subjects. Perhaps their relationship may be indicated more approximately by comparing it with the functions of an induction coil.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- Nearly 50,000 members of the Christian Endeavor Union, singing "Onward Christian Soldiers," "Hold the Fort" and "Jesus Never Fails," marched through central Philadelphia today in one of the largest and most impressive parades the city had seen since World War days.

AMHERST, Mass., July 6. -- Through cooperation with an institutional church in the near-by industrial city of Holyoke, Amherst College has developed over a period of years a unique laboratory for sociological research known as Amherst-in-Holyoke.

TORONTO, Ont., July 6. -- A barrage of inquiries greeted the directors of Eldorado Gold Mines, Ltd., at their annual meeting this week, as it did a year ago. The shareholders as a body were less critical, however, of the absence of detailed information in the annual report than they were then.

WHILE American travelers are going abroad in larger numbers this year, another tide of travel has set in the direction of America. Indeed, New York shipping men are convinced that the United States has become one of the important places on the European tourist's "must" list.

The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters won last week its ten-year fight for union recognition, and an air of quiet rejoicing pervades a three-story house at 105 West 136th Street. The house is headquarters for the brotherhood, and also for the Pullman Porters Athletic and Social Club, which has a practically identical membership.

LATONIA, Ky., July 6 (AP). -- Taking the lead soon after the start, H.G. Shoemaker's Wise Bessa easily won today the historic Latonia Oaks, closing day feature of the Latonia meeting, and a purse of $2,045.

LONDON is having her warm days, too, and the theatre is, as usual, the great sufferer. And just, observes the cable, whe Shaftesbury Avenue was emerging from the Jubilee slump. Sydney Carroll's Regent Park performances of Shakespeare are doing well, so are such hits as "Tovaritch," "Love on the Dole," "Lady Precious Stream." "Sweet Aloes," "Night Must Fall" and "Jill, Darling." The rest you can have for very little.

MR. SARGENT weighs the work of four independent thinkers with a certain high compassion which sets him aside as peculiarly fitted to interpret them for us. One of these men is a philosopher, Orestes Augustus Brownson, the other three are poets, Paul Claudel, Charles Peguy and Gerard Manley Hopkins.

Deaths from tuberculosis in the nation decreased in 1934, although the disease spread in sixteen of the larger cities, it was announced in a report issued last night by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- With the House Rules Committee scheduled to meet Monday to complete plans for its investigation of lobbying activities for and against the utility holding company "death sentence," a move was under way in Congress today to shift the burden of the inquiry to the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee instead of dividing responsibility with the House group.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 6. -- Eight the nation's leading polo figures played in the interest of charity on famous International Field at the Meadow Brook club today and the 20,000 spectators saw the Meadow Brook quartet, with Thomas Hitchcock Jr. and Winston Guest occupying the principal spotlight, defeat a 31-goal Sands Points combination., 6 to 4.

HAVING progressed through a state of resentment and finally resignation, the studios themselves now are taking an active part in censorship operations. On the lots where reform has been accepted without reservation the code is operating smoothly and with infrequent appeals to the Hays office.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 6. -- Driving through thick fog for par of the way on Nantucket Sound Ray Hunt and his Class Q sloop Hornet topped the fleet for the third time on corrected time in the Eastern Yacht Club's annual cruise today.

SEATTLE, July 6. -- Even its two-bed sickbay turned into a guest cabin, the Coast Guard cutter Shoshone of Oakland, Calif, sailed for Seward, Alaska, today with a Federal Relief Administration mission under instructions to put the Matanuska farm colony in running order.

PHINEAS TAYLOR BARNUM -- "P.T. Barnum" to the world -- born 125 years ago, on July 5, 1810, remains as steadfast in the American legend as he was in his long and stentorian lifetime. The echoes of his steam calliope die away but the name of Barnum resounds -- his reward for having been the world's greatest genius at publicity.

A boys' school in England is the scene of the murders described into this story, and it is fairly certain from the very beginning that the murderer is some person connected with the school. The murderer's first victim is a schoolboy named Wyvern-Wemyss.

AIR travel, having passed from the stage of somewhat hazardous adventure to that of a fast-growing standard medium of transportation, is entering more and more into the field of recreation. Flying for fun is gaining adherents all over the world.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 6. -- Work has been begun on the $4,000,000 plant here of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, which is to have a payroll of more than $1,000,000 a year, employing about 875 persons at the plant and 500 in the woods.

OTTAWA, July 6 -- Vehicular and pedestrian traffic between Canada and the United States across the Ontario boundary showed a considerable gain during 1934, compared with the previous year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today.

THREE hundred years ago sturdy band of hatchet-faced Puritans, roiled by religious controversies and too much squabbling with their neighbors over fences, set out from the little Colony of Massachusetts and headed their column south and west -- south and west to those tempting rolling hills which are now of the State of Connecticut.

Marked savings in interest costs are expected in the coming refunding operations of the Territory of Hawaii, according to C.J. Devine, president of C.J. Devine Co., Inc. It is likely that the forthcoming issue will set a new low rate in the territorial list, he says.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4. -- Incessant disputes and stoppages on the San Francisco waterfront are precipitating a crisis as Harry Bridges strengthens his control of marine unions through the recently organized Maritime Federation and ship owners threaten to abrogate the agreement which ended last Summer's strike.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- A draft of a new Federal Liquor Regulation Bill, tentatively agreed upon today by the House Ways and Means Committee Democrats, rejects the administration's proposal for a separate agency to succeed the Federal Alcohol Control Administration.
The complete records of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss. Helen Jacobs, the finalists, in the women's singles of the Wimbledon tennis championships follow:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6. -- Summer vacation travel along the Pacific Coast is now in full swing, with practically every vessel catering to this trade "sold out" as far as passenger accommodations are concerned. A new fad of presenting a "graduation tour" to youngsters finishing courses in college and even in high schools, has become the vogue at many coast ports.

BERLIN, July 6. -- The Boerse closed the week firm. Heavy industrial stocks, still supported by armament activity, were strong, Mannesmann gaining 1/2 point. Potash shares were stronger, Salzdetfurth gaining 2 points. Machinery issues were mixed and unsteady.

DETROIT, July 6. -- Frederick Walter attempted today to walk on the water with pontoons from Sarnia to Belle Isle, a stretch of fifty-five miles. He was picked up by a rescuing speedboat at 2 P.M. from an island at the foot of St. Clair flats, where he had been stranded.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6. -- With a burst of speed that her lines had shown was in her, Van S. Merle-Smith's new international 12-meter racer Seven Seas swept to the fore today in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- An application for $1,804,948 of work relief funds for preparation of an alphabetical index by families and geographical units of all individuals listed in the census of 1900 was received by the Division of Applications and Information today from the Census Bureau.

NOT much is known about the Negroes who lived in New England in the early part of the eighteenth century, but we have evidence that there was quite a colony of them in Boston by 1719. A contemporary manuscript records some sixty or seventy free colored folk in the city that year.

Attendance records for all previous housewares trade shows are expected to be shattered here this week when the annual Fall showing sponsored by the New York Housewares Manufacturers at the Hotel Pennsylvania opens Wednesday.

On the question of tax exemption of Federal, State and municipal bonds, more than the point of privilege should be considered. Such exemption is not a "privilege" in the sense that it is a gift; it is bought and paid for.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- John McDiarmid of Fort Worth, Texas, and Wilbur Coen Jr. of Kansas City will meet tomorrow for the men's western singles tennis title at the South Shore Country Club.

FOR a long time safety workers have been urging a sharp-shooting, rather than a broadside, attack on the accident problem. They have been saying, for example, that a large majority of accidents involve a small minority of drivers, and that special efforts to catch accident repeaters should therefore be made.

PARIS, July 5. -- The sight of any two Frenchmen having an argument always leaves an innocent Anglo-Saxon spectator with the impression that a fight is imminent. So he lingers around, but then nothing happens.

GENEVA, July 6. -- Italy was one of the original signers and Premier Benito Mussolini was one of the negotiators of the Briand-Kellogg pact. Ethiopia later accepted this renunciation of war. These facts are beginning to be recalled in League of Nations quarters as reports from these two countries tell now of more than 1,000,000 men on what the Indians had a name for the warpath.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Dr. W.E. Meanwell of the University of Wisconsin was elected chairman of the basketball committee and Dr. Frederick Hoffman of Cincinnati was named head of the baseball group today at the first Midwestern meeting of the American Olympic Committee.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, July 6. -- Jose Angel Ceniceros, Acting Foreign Minister, before an assembly of American intellectuals here today laid down a nine-point foreign policy for Mexico based, as he said, on "truth and sincerity."

Dr. EINSTEIN has made another attempt to formulate a theory which will embrace in a single comprehensive statement the wheelings of the stars, the speeding of light on its course, the attraction of the earth for falling bodies, the luster of the diamond, the lightness of hydrogen and the millions of manifestations of matter.

WITH the ratification of the Philippine Constitution in a national plebiscite, another important step toward eventual Philippine independence has been taken. A commonwealth government with a Filipino Chief Executive will soon be inaugurated and American supervision further restricted.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The constitutional formula to replace NRA, which the New Deal administration is seeking, may already have been found in the pending Guffey-Snyder bill to regulate the bituminous coal industry. At least a hope of this seems implied in the administration's determination that the bill be passed by Congress.

IN this book "eyes listen with clean intentness" and there are "dreaming mouths." A cheap East Side gangster, bent on revenging himself against a sleeping man, decides "the man was too resigned -- one could not touch him."

THE recent timely letter of the President to the Attorney General again calls attention to the importance of parole as an integral and necessary part of our American penal system. "Every decent citizen," the President wrote, "is interested in humane parole systems which seek rehabilitation of offenders; but at the same time we should seek to prevent abuses of paroles, especially in cases of habitual criminals."

OUT of the reorganization of the Harlow, McDonald firm, two new galleries have come. Arthur H. Harlow Co. opened last week in the British Building, Rockefeller Center, occupying the attractive and strategically located quarters that formerly housed the Empire Galleries.

ADDIS ABABA, July 6. -- Americans living in Ethiopia were advised today by their government to leave this war-threatened land. Diplomatic quarters took the action to mean that the United States, to which Emperor Haile Selassie appealed this week under the Briand-Kellogg pact outlawing war, had virtually given up hope that Italy and Ethiopia would settle their differences peacefully.
Joseph A. Lyons, Premier of the Commonwealth of Australia, arrived yesterday from Naples on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by Mrs. Lyons and his two secretaries, F.J. McKenna and J.A. Swanson.

WITH another and bigger public works program getting under way, a popular account of the original PWA is opportune, and Mr. Ickes, whose two jobs as Secretary of the Interior and Administrator of Public Works must have kept him as busy as the proverbial one-armed paperhanger with the hives, is, of course, the man to write it.

July retail trade in the metropolitan area got off to a good start last week, with sales increases ranging up to 20 per cent over a year ago estimated for department stores here for the four-day period. Pre-holiday purchasing was notably brisk and was well distributed over main floor accessories, sports and beach wear and vacation items.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's dream of winning another Wimbledon championship came true on the centre court today, but only after such a dramatic uphill struggle as she has not had to fight in many years.

LAST week the season began for one of New York's favorite vacation spots -- the New Jersey shore. Thousands of New Yorkers are weaving their design for summer living on a narrow strip of yellow carpet that stretches 125 miles from Atlantic Highlands to Cape May.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 6 (AP). -- After a heavy thunder shower had provided him with the mud he likes, J.W.Y. Martin's 6-year-old Dark Hope today led six rivals from start to finish in the $10,000 added Rhode Island Handicap, feature of Narragansett Park's closing program.

DARIEN, Conn., July 6. -- Frosty Fairy, smooth-going little gray mare owned by Dr. Walter H. Brundage of Pelham, N.Y., and shown in the ring to the best advantage by Mrs. Brundage, today won the championship in the smaller division of the saddle, horses at the final session of the ninth annual horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.
BOMBAY. -- A review of India's cotton imports and exports during the year 1934-35 reveals interesting figures.

Here is another Connington murder mystery with Chief Constable Sir Clinton Driffield doing the sleuthing. A man is found dead in an empty flat where decorators have been at work. One of the clues is an overturned paint pot, another is a gold cross shaped like the letter "T," and a third is a handkerchief soaked in blood.

PROBLEMS connected with high altitude flying as regards the physical condition of pilots and passengers are now under careful scrutiny by the Army Air Corps at Wright Field. The importance of a more detailed knowledge of this subject as it affects commercial aviation which is using higher levels was indicated recently by Professor Yandell Henderson, noted authority on asphyxia and head of the Department of Physiology at Yale University.

EVIDENCE that points toward continuance of unusual activity in automobile manufacturing into the Summer has come to light with completion of June and the first half of the year. With factory figures not all reported, estimates converge on a production and shipment volume that will be close to 400,000 for last month.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- President Roosevelt was believed at the Capitol today to be pointing the New Deal determinedly into an epochal political and constitutional struggle.

HOT weather and holiday requirements combined to push up retail sales in the week and for the first time this year large increases were reported from many sections of the country. In this area the gains ran as high as 20 per cent over a year ago, with sports wear and vacation goods particularly active.

A LARGE collection of prints by Hogarth, such as now inhabits the exhibition galleries at the Metropolitan Museum, is strong meat. It is well for those wishing to enter somewhat into his art that it is to last until the first of September, giving more than one chance to visit it.

CASSEL, Germany, July 6 (AP). -- Germany's old and new armies met today, for the first time since Adolf Hitler created the new one, in a mass demonstration in which 300,000 former soldiers participated.
RADIO has a new streamlined microphone. It looks like a billiard ball poised on the top of a metal pipe or rod.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Following Congressional authorization of an increase in its enlisted personnel from 118,750 to 165,000 the army on July 1 began its biggest peace-time recruiting drive. This represents an increase in enlisted personnel of 46,250 more men, by a good many thousands, than were on the rolls of the United States Army before the Spanish-American War.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- With more gold in the country than at any other time in history, the Federal Government is taking steps almost inconceivable twenty years ago to guard this precious store. The supply is valued at about $9,000,000,000.

DETROIT, July 6. -- Two young swimmers, John Macionis of Philadelphia and Adolph Kiefer of Chicago, eclipsed world records in the Detroit Boat Club pool tonight when they raced to championships in the National A.A.U. meet.

JAPAN has experienced some difficulties in spreading short-wave programs across the United States, but hopes to solve the problem by experimenting until a satisfactory wave and time is found, according to Sadao Iguchi, Consul General in New York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Lenox Civic Association is to be organized on a permanent basis at a meeting in Town Hall on Tuesday night. Its promoters include the Misses Kate Cary Mary Parsons and Heloise Meyer, Mrs. Samuel Frothingham, Otis P. and Ernest T. Curtis. At a preliminary meeting last Winter Prescott C. Buffum was elected temporary chairman.

On Jan. 29, 1935, according to spokesmen in Rome, Ethiopian warriors attacked Italian soldiers at Afdub, south of Ualual, a disputed spot on the Italian Somaliland-Ethiopian frontier in East Africa. At the time the clash over this barren spot seemed unimportant.

WORDSWORTH, who "wandered lonely as a cloud," would now be able to know to just what kind of cloud he was likening his wandering self, for the "International Atlas of Clouds and States of the Sky" has now been published, identifying by "family," "genus," "species" and "variety" every form of cloud.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Thousands of individuals are exempt in part or in whole from Federal income taxes, because of the character of their incomes, and seventeen classes of corporations are fully exempt, under internal revenue laws.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 6. -- For the second year in succession Eugene Homans today conquered the intricacies of the National Golf Links of America, one of the country's mightiest courses, and won the club's invitation tourney.

ALTHOUGH Shanghai has more schools in proportion to population than any city in China, even today 49 per cent of all children of school age are illiterate, and fully 25 per cent of adult Chinese there can neither read nor write.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 6. -- A traveling art library, containing modern paintings and reproductions of the best work of past and present masters, is being sent out from Brown University to tour Rhode Island this Summer for exhibition in various towns and villages. The experiment is believed to be unique among Eastern universities.

Sweeping in from the West with too much speed for the Eastern contingent to match, A.A. Baroni's Top Row yesterday drove his way to victory in the Empire City Handicap and tied the track mark for the mile and a furlong. A record crowd of 15,000 for the Yonkers course saw Jockey J. Longdon bring on the son of Peanuts from fifth position to score by a head at 6 to 1.

CALL FOR ROOKIES: For the fiscal year which started last Monday, the army and navy have $860,682,549 -- the largest total since the World War demobilization. More money means more men, and the recruiting stations were opened to raise the army from 118,000 to 165,o00, the navy from 82,500 to 93,500, and the marines from 14,900 to 16,000.

BERLIN, July 6 (AP). -- The Catholic Episcopal Office today was advised that Count Konrad von Preysing, Bishop of Eichstaett, had been appointed Bishop of Berlin to fill the vacancy created by the death March 1 of Bishop Nicholas Bares.

MARKED improvement in the take-off of passenger airplanes by the use of gasoline of ultra-high anti-knock quality is a probable development of the near future, according to Dr. Graham Edgar, vice president and director of research of the Ethyl Gasoline Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP). -- The Phillies divided a double-header with the Boston Braves before 8,000 fans today. Boston overcame a 4-0 lead piled up by the Phils to score a 10-5 triumph in the opener, but in the second the locals ran away with a 15-2 triumph.

Because the Summer sessions will begin tomorrow at Columbia University and other institutions of higher learning in the New York area special services will be held beginning today in various churches. To these services have been invited the thousands of students who will spend the next six weeks in the city.

DETROIT, Mich., July 4. -- The murder of Howard Carter Dickinson, New York attorney, in the remote Rouge Park section of Detroit, for a supposedly large sum of money he was believed to carry, has raised the question whether the "rolling" of rich men is a common practice in this city.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- With bankers split over the compromise Banking Bill's provisions permitting banks of deposit to go back into the securities underwriting business under strict limitations, Senator Glass's formal report on the measure was filed today in the Senate.
BETHEL, Ohio, July 6. -- Many of the 1,800 babies he brought into the world during seventy-five years of practice thronged Main Street today to celebrate Dr. William Eberle Thompson's 100th birthday.

An agreement on all disputed points was reached yesterday between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., representing the "inside" manufacturers of the industry.
HUNTINGTON, Ind., July 6 (AP). -- Mayor Clare W.H. Bangs, who went to jail in his fight to keep a campaign pledge, will wind up tomorrow his second month of directing city affairs from a cell.

SIR DONALD FRANCIS TOVEY is one of the most learned and versatile of musicians -- professor at the University of Edinburgh, a composer, pianist and conductor of the Reid Orchestra of Edinburgh, a theorist, a historian and a writer for whom none of the arcana of musical lore, history or practice are impenetrable.

ROME, July 6. -- The last contingents of the Sabauda Division left Cagliari, Sardinia, for East Africa yesterday. Today Premier Benito Mussolini made surprise visits to several points in the Province of Salerno, where he reviewed the January Third Division of Blackshirt volunteers, which will begin embarking within a few days.

IN a little restaurant in the Rue Boissy d'Anglas there were wild strawberries (fraises des bois) with cream; what is known in Paris as fresh cream, thick to the point of non-fluidity. This combination of delicacies is one of the delights of Paris in Summer. The strawberries, about half a pint of them, were brought upon a dish covered with strawberry leaves; the cream in a large crock, ice cold.

DETAILS of the new nine-lens aerial mapping camera which is being built for the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey were disclosed recently in a paper by Lieutenant O.S. Reading, chief of the section of aerial photographic topography of the survey.

In the Bay of Fundy the average difference between high tide and low tide is 18.6 feet. That is a lot of water. Engineers for a long time have itched to harness it to something; last week they started the construction task necessary, but the feat of engineering was lost sight of because the Passamaquoddy Project -- the name of the job -- had become involved in exciting doings in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Informal steps looking toward the evacuation of all American citizens who wish to leave Ethiopia were taken today by the United States Government, although officials here did not know officially whether actual instructions to that effect had been given at Addis Ababa.

PARIS, June 26. -- The height of the season in Paris, the Grande Semaine, is developing with even more than the traditional splendor. In addition to the crowded week of outstanding turf events and the usual distinguished public and private functions, the hospitality in connection with the International Congress of Chambers of Commerce is giving the Grande Semaine unusual social eclat.

VIENNA. -- Political prisoners confined in a Vienna police prison are responsible for the first recorded association of Socialists, Communists and Nazis in public action. A document has been issued purporting to be published in behalf of these political prisoners "without difference of party," demanding the restoration of the habeas corpus rights abolished by the Fascist counter-revolution.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- Chautauqua, first educational institution of its kind, was prepared tonight to open its annual season tomorrow with leaders optimistic after several lean years, brought to a climax by voluntary receivership in 1933.
A recent article in The Reader's Digest -- "People's Death Fight," by Paul de Kruif -- emphasized poignantly the need of government-owned sanatoria.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Greenbrier Polo Club will play the second match of the season today on Greenbrier field, again meeting the Fauquier-Loudon Polo Club of Middleburg, Va. Many spectators attended the first match on Independence Day.
Following Friday's sharp break in prices on the Cotton Exchange, the market steadied yesterday, recovered $1 a bale and closed with net gains of 10 to 14 points, or 50 to 70 cents a bale.

In an interview published in THE TIMES Magazine today HENRY FORD comments on the proposal that "wealth" be "shared." He is of course a highly interested party. Every one knows, he says, that the Ford Company is wealthy. But he asks, "What does its wealth consist of? "Money? Certainly not.
PARIS, July 6. -- In an overwhelming victory on the Seine today France captured the Spreckels Trophy for motor speedboats in the first international competition of its kind that Paris has witnessed.

INSTEAD of proposing the more or less irrelevant problems about papering a room and calculating the percentage of gain on a pound of tea, a Bronxville teacher for the past few years has been asking his junior high school pupils straight-from-the -- shoulder questions, such as: "How much do you cost your parents?"

Operations in 1934 of the American Commercial Alcohol Corporation and subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $930,937 after interest, provision for doubtful accounts, depreciation and Federal taxes, it was announced yesterday. This is equal to $3.57 a share on 260,899 $20 par shares of common stock, excluding stock in the treasury.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 61 (AP). -- A new page of history, casting light on the primitive characteristics and activities of early Indian inhabitants of the Susquehanna River Valley, has been opened by scientists excavating near Bainbridge, Dr. William A. Ritchie of the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences, which is sponsoring the work, stated today.

UXBRIDGE, Mass., July 6 (AP). -- A call for mass picketing at the plant of the Uxbridge Worsted Company Monday morning was issued at a meeting attended by 200 of the 800 striking United Textile Workers here this afternoon.

LARGE and unexpected increases in travel from New York to foreign ports astonish the steamship companies, tax their facilities and set economists in quest of reasons for this revival. On Saturday a week ago, for instance, some 14,000 passengers bound for many harbors left here on twenty-five liners as compared with the 9,075 for the corresponding day of last year -- a gain of 54 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- George F. Buchanan, 61 years old, a partner in the Franklin Composition Company, printers, was shot and clubbed to death this morning in his South Third Street apartment, evidently after a struggle.

The principal evidence -- in fact, all there was -- concerning the loss of the Blairgowrie, 3,259 tons, which went down with all hands in the North Atlantic on Feb. 27, was assembled the other day by Lord Merrivale, the British Wreck Commissioner.

TOKYO, July 6. -- Having received information that a hypothetical steamer with twelve "enemy" planes had been detected making for Tokyo, the commander of the Tokyo garrison at 11 A.M. today pressed a button, and the air defense organization came into action.

Since she won the national girls' championship in 1921, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody has gone on to capture nineteen more singles titles. Her exploits on the courts are without parallel in the history of tennis; she has taken the national girls' title twice, the national women's championship seven times, the English women's crown at Wimbledon seven times and four French women's championships.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Although Governor Homer has not made open announcement of his intention to seek re-election, reports from Springfield say that he is laying his plans to accomplish that ambition. Release from the immediate worries of a legislative session will further his efforts, but the record of that session, in which his party controlled both houses, will, in the opinion of many political observers, constitute a big handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Faced with a "tax strike" on a nationwide scale by processors of principal farm products against what they believe an unjust assessment of their operations for the benefit of producers, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration finds its permanence threatened for the first time since its creation at the height of an agrarian uprising two years ago.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP). -- The Tigers scored their ninth consecutive victory today, a 7-to-6 triumph at the expense of the Browns, and edged to within a few percentage points of the pace-setting Yankees.

BELLEPORT, L.I., July 6. -- Tom Whittelsey of Babylon, in Argo, defeated Langdon Thorne's champion international Star boat, Mist, in one of the feature contests at the opening invitation regatta of the Bellport Yacht Club of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association today.

WALLBURG, N.C., July 6 (AP). -- Making another attack on the Roosevelt administration, Governor Talmadge of Georgia said today that money was "choked off" from America's small business people in spite of the national emergency legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Postmaster General Farley will leave July 15 on a vacation of six weeks, a part of which will be devoted to a political survey. This survey is much desired by the President, who is reported to be concerned over the revolt in the House on the Holding Company and the TVA Bills.

IN the first place, Mary O'Toole fell asleep, and that was bad, because Mary was a nurse and should have stayed awake to give Mrs. Haughton her medicine at 1 o'clock. When Mary awoke at 2 o'clock Mrs. Haughton was dead. The doctor said that Mary had been negligent and that she was morally, although not legally, responsible for Mrs. Haughton's death.

NEW LONDON, Conn. -- A memorial service will be held at the newly dedicated statue of Nathan Hale, Connecticut's most distinguished soldier-hero, next Sunday in Williams Park, New London. This is to be part of the program of the fifteenth annual encampment of Connecticut Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States as its participation in the State's tercentenary celebration.

FOR so long a time has Theodore Dreiser occupied a prominent position in the field of American letters, anything from his pen is likely to arouse immediate curiosity, even when he chooses to exercise himself in something other than prose.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- New low prices for the season were established today for all deliveries of wheat, oats and rye on the Board of Trade. Liquidation developed and disclosed a lack of aggressive buying. Wheat dropped 2 7/8 to 3 3/8 cents a bushel below yesterday's closing quotation and 7 7/8 to 8 3/8 cents under the close on Thursday.

Anti-poliomyelitis vaccine, prepared by the New York City Health Department in its research laboratories at the foot of East Sixteenth Street, is being shipped to North Carolina, where an outbreak of infantile paralysis has become serious, it was learned yesterday.

WHILE it cannot truthfully be: said that "The Sea Is My Workshop" is precisely a weighty book, nevertheless, since the season is at hand when the "bronzed demigods" who sit up aloft at the beaches will have us in their safe-keeping, these memoirs by Frank E. Walton may be read with interest, and possible profit.

SOME people there are who seem born to injure all who come into any sort of close contact with them. Individuals of this kind are often charming, sometimes have many admirable characteristics; but with them they carry a blight which affects and not infrequently destroys other lives.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, July 7 (AP). -- Hankow advices from missionaries at Changteh, northwest Hunan Province, said today that the Yuen River had broken its dikes, flooding the city with a heavy loss of life.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 6. -- Nancy Geohringer, 9-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Geohringer of 90 Grand Avenue, North Hackensack, was killed this morning when she leaped from the rear of an ice truck directly in the path of a Garden State bus driven by Bernard May of Ridgefield Park.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Virginia's No. 1 amateur golfer is expected to emerge from the finals of the Virginia State amateur golf championship today on the Cascades course. Potential golf leaders have been falling by the wayside since Friday's first round of match play.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 6. -- Helpless anti-Long leaders today spoke bitter words and fought gamely, but Senator Huey P. Long's followers did his bidding, passed his twenty-six new bills in the House and rushed them to the Senate for final action.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Continued improvement in British industry and trade, with employment rising to a new high level and widespread activity in construction lines, was reported today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in our foreign markets.

Puck of the single eyeglass is gone from the Players. His wit is one of the traditions of Gramercy Park. He was not only witty himself, but the cause that the wit in other men should be laid to him. There is often too much barb and cruelty in wit. OLIVER HERFORD better deserves remembrance for his humor.

LONDON, July 6. -- If anybody had suggested six months ago that the first injury of any responsible European Foreign Minister at this time upon taking up his daily routine would probably be "What is happening in Ethiopia?" he would have been laughed at.

Lake Champlain, a yachting centre years ago but quiescent for two decades, is to have a renaissance of large proportions this season. The Lake Champlain Y.C. of Burlington, Vt., has been undergoing a reorganization in recent months and now is to cooperate with the Champlain Valley Council in some big doings on Aug. 1, 2 and 3 in a three-day regatta.

A change in the order of finish in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's 394-mile ocean race to Nantucket Shoals Lightship and return placed Rudolph J. Schaefer's sloop Edlu in first position on corrected time rather than the Teal, chartered by George N. Wallace, according to an announcement yesterday by William N. Bavier Jr., chairman of the race committee.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- The Florida citrus agreement and license, one of the Farm Administration's unsolved problems, was canceled today by Secretary Wallace, effective July 15.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 6. -- The Federal Government will take over the lease of the Jones Beach Bird Sanctuary at Gilgo Beach on Aug. 1 for a year as the result of a resolution adopted this week at a hearing conducted by the Oyster Bay Town Board on a proposal made by the Biological Survey of the Department of Agriculture to operate the refuge.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6 (AP). -- Complete overhauling of Oklahoma's government, called by Governor E.W. Marland a testing ground for the New Deal, was recommended today by the Brookings Institution.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, announced yesterday that Park Commissioner Robert Moses would continue in charge of the administration of works relief projects in the city's parks.
ATLANTA, July 6. -- W. Bernard Vause, former judge in Kings County, was paroled from the Federal penitentiary today and tonight was believed en route back to New York.

WITH the opening next Tuesday of fifty-eight play schools and day camps having facilities for 12,000 children, double the number who were accommodated last year, New York City's Summer activity program will be in full swing.
FISHERY inspection by airplane is the latest device adopted by the Canadian Department of Fisheries to detect poachers and enforce regulations for the protection of spawning Pacific salmon.

The appointment of Thomas E. Dewey, at the order of Governor Lehman, as Deputy Assistant District Attorney for New York County in an investigation into rackets and political alliances with crime, began to bear fruit last week in rapid action.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6. -- The San Francisco Bay area let out a Western war-whoop today as Mrs. Helen Wills Moody once more donned the regal robes of queen of tennis.

HARTFORD, July 5. -- The first New England conference of Young Republicans, held at Eastern Point, failed to discover any definite path by which the party as a whole can advance directly to victory next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5. -- Midway in the second year following repeal, California's $420,000,000 grape and wine industry still faces staggering problems, the hopeful factor being that its leaders, organized in the Wine Institute, are attacking these problems aggressively.

SYDNEY, Australia -- Two army airplanes will photographically map some 30,000 square miles of Australian hinterland during the next three years as part of Australia's attempt to regain the position once held among the world's gold-producing countries.

MANASQUAN, N.J., July 6. -- Playfully pushed into a deep hole which she and her companions had dug in the loose sands of the Manasquan beachfront this afternoon, Miss Doris Franzell, 22 years old, a trained nurse of 622 West 168th Street, New York, narrowly escaped death when the sands closed in over her, burying her completely.

The commission or fifteen liberals headed by Clifford Odets, 28-year-old playwright, who were deported from Cuba on Wednesday before they could begin a study of social, political and economic conditions there, arrived here on the steamship Oriente yesterday morning at 8:30 o'clock.

NO flowers in their season lend more beauty to the borders nor fit more graciously into the garden picture than do the aquilegias or columbines. A mass planting of these flowers, with their lovely blossoms lightly poised at the ends of tall, slender stems, swaying and nodding in the slightest breeze, is assuredly an enchanting sight.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 6. -- Marred by rain and rough water, the New York State outboard motor boat championship got under way today, with Gar Wood Jr. of Algonac, Mich., son of the famous speed boat king, assuming an early lead for the Governor Lehman trophy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 6. -- The problems of "Academic Freedom in the Public Schools" and "More Effective Expenditure of School Funds" will be discussed by nine leaders of American education this month at conferences under the auspices of the Harvard University Summer School of Arts and Sciences.

LONDON. -- In recent discussions of the new Banking Bill in Washington reference has been made, notably by Senator Glass, to the Bank of England, that venerable central bank whose status is unique, whose affairs are surrounded by a good deal of mystery, whose profit-and-loss account is never published, whose management of the currency and the banking system has been on the whole sagacious.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 6. Manuel Alonso, star of the Spanish Davis Cup forces of other years, and Guy Cheng, member of the 1933 Chinese Davis Cup team and No. 2 player in his country, failed to reach the semi-finals of the invitation doubles tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 6. -- The Louisiana House today passed quickly twenty-six of the bills introduced at the behest of Senator Huey P. Long when he summoned the Legislature to meet Thursday night and do his bidding.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 6. -- Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton showed her capable mounts, Danseuse and Stepaside, to excellent advantage and captured the first two awards in the Hunter Sweepstake Class, a feature event at the fifth annual Westhampton horse show today.

THE new LaFayettes for 1936 were placed on display last week at the showrooms of the Warren-Nash Motors Corporation and at dealers throughout the metropolitan territory. The new cars, introduced in the lowest price field, are available in six body types characterized by all-steel streamlined construction and redistribution of weight.

CLEVELAND, July 6. -- The greatest crowd that has ever paid to witness a baseball game, a capacity gathering of nearly 85,000, is expected to jam Cleveland's Municipal Stadium Monday for the big parade of the all-stars in the third annual game between hand-picked forces of the National and American Leagues.

The arrival by airplane this afternoon of Harry Bridges, San Francisco stevedore leader, will bring a tense situation to the opening of the annual convention of the International Longshoremen's Association tomorrow.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 6. -- Joseph F. Duffy of Scarsdale, N.Y., has arrived at the Mount Washington Hotel for his annual visit. He dined yesterday with Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sanderson and Miss Peggy Sanderson, after being entertained in their suite by Mr. and Mrs. George LaBranche and Mr. and Mrs. Enos Booth of New York.

Boy marbles players held their heads higher last night than they had for a year. For twelve months a girl had reigned as marbles champion of the city, but yesterday the honors were redeemed when Charles Seay, 13-year-old Negro boy of Brooklyn, took clear title to the city championship on the Mall in Central' Park.

A word of praise should be said for the bill introduced by Chairman Sheppard of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs. It would add five educators to the United States Military Academy Board of Visitors -- a much needed reform.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- An arson ring was reported smashed today by Detective Sergeant Thomas J. Holohan as he announced two alleged "torch men" of the gang had confessed a short time before the arraignment of a woman and her son on second-degree arson charges.

Public utility bond redemptions, of which there were six entire issues which totaled $78,245,000, featured last week's announcements of bonds called for payment before their dates of maturity. In addition, there were various industrial bonds in large amounts called for payment in future months and some small lots of municipal securities for retirement this month.

Early action on the Copeland measure known as Senate 5, to revise the Federal Food and Drugs Act, was indicated here yesterday when Charles Wesley Dunn, attorney for the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., received word from Washington that a subcommittee is expected to be appointed this week to consider the bill.
MURDER will out but wrestling will not down. That engaging entrepreneur, M'sieu Jacques Armand Curley, sent around one of his merry men to spread the great news.
BOMBAY. -- South India has been stirred to high expectations by the news of the possibility of gold mining in the Wynad planting area on the Nilgiris and at Shimoga, in Mysore State.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6. -- Among the young people at Bailey's Beach today was Miss Phyllis Gillespie, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie, who have just arrived from New York to occupy their Bellevue Avenue home.

Pinning their hopes of success on this country's reciprocal trade treaty policy, the largest contingent of export executives to go abroad since 1928 will start out in search of orders this month. Departing on trips ranging from three months to a year's duration, the exporters' first objective will be Europe, from which they will scatter to every important market in the world.

IN appraising "The Big Broadcast of 1985" one should touch on the happy selection of the title. Whenever the film reaches Ungava or Minsk, it can be brought as up-to-date as any lunch-room menu simply by pasting a new figure over the ultimate digit.

THE National Tourist Office of the French Ministry of Public Works at 610 Fifth Avenue in this city is now able to supply guaranteed hotel and restaurant rates in resorts, historic points, watering places and cities customarily visited by tourists in France.

SARANAC, N.Y. -- Reorganization of the Upper Saranac Yacht Club, which was founded in 1907 and was active until 1922, is to be effected at a meeting of camp owners as soon as a sufficient number have arrived at their Summer places here.

IN gardens where there were only a few blossoms but a great mass of leaves on daffodils this year it was not due to the weather. Beyond a doubt the bulbs had made many offsets and the food supply had run low. Such old plantings may be dug up carefully as the leaves begin to turn brown.

CRYSTAL BEACH, Ont., July 6. -- Eulace Peacock, Temple University Negro star who startled the track world with a double victory over Jesse Owens on Thursday, demonstrated today that it was no fluke when he flashed home in front of the Ohio State Negro in the 100-meter dash, feature of the Buffalo Police Club games.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Concerts by the North Carolina Symphony Orchestra, skeet shoots at the Asheville Skeet and Gun Club, and the veteran's golf tournament at the Biltmore Forest Country Club, will feature Asheville's social and sports calendar for this week.

THE visitor stood before Bela Lugosi's door and hesitated. He was not exactly frightened, but he was glad he had remembered to put on a stiffly starched collar to protect his throat, just in case Mr. Lugosi did turn out to be a real vampire.

BUENOS AIRES, July 5. -- The United States has taken an active and important part in terminating the Chaco war. Contrary to Washington's policy at European conferences, the United States delegates to the Chaco peace negotiations have not been mere observers.

MR. YATES, who is himself an inventor and is now patent editor of a popular scientific magazine, aims in this book to provide a guide "for practical, hardheaded men who are able to see some of the improvements" needing to be devised in articles already in use or to imagine and work out new aids to modern living.
BERLIN. THE marvelous variety which the German language can present is impressively brought out when it is used by three authors of totally different character, by each in his own individual manner.

PARIS, July 6. -- For the second time the Paris season this year culminated tonight in a magnificent spectacle of night racing at Longchamp with the whole track and paddock illuminated and converted into an elegant fairyland. Seven races were run between 9 P.M. and midnight, but the racing was only incidental to other attractions.

BOSTON, July 6. -- "The problem of the family in France is just the opposite of yours," said Mile, Therese Bieillot today. "We have to say to parents of juvenile offenders, 'You must let this boy go out in the evening or something worse will happen.'"

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- After a wild automobile ride about Westchester County, Ray A. Alberson, 32 years old, who said his home was at 38 Washington Avenue, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was arrested tonight as he sat in a beer garden and demanded that a man and his wife who accused him of abducting them order a glass of beer for him.

THERE is a tremendous task ahead of us. When the President said that "we must quit this business of relief," that no longer were able-bodied citizens to be allowed to deteriorate on relief but must be given jobs, he meant women as well as men.

BERLIN, July 6. -- If some militant matron or lonely spinster in this severely coordinated Third Reich feels it incumbent upon her to challenge the Nazi ideal of the "Hausfrau," it does not follow that the aforesaid ideal is threatened with fundamenal revision or that its implications are being freely contested.

Thomas E. Dewey, special racket prosecutor in New York County, will confer tomorrow with Mayor La Guardia. They plan to discuss the aid Mr. Dewey expects from the city administration, especially the Police Department. It is likely, too, that they will tentatively fix the amount the Board of Estimate will be asked to provide for the investigation, which may extend two years.

THEY rushed Professor Max Reinhardt and his bride overnight from coast to coast (via Reno) to have him here in time for a luncheon. The professor pleaded in vain to be left alone and argued that his arrival in New York some three hours before sailing time of the Ile de France would be sufficient for unavoidable publicity.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Latest State Department records show that of approximately 125 American citizens in Ethiopia, 113 are missionaries.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Business activity in June continued at about the May level, after allowance for the usual seasonal decline, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation.

ON almost every place, large or small, there is some "ugly duckling" spot which, with imagination and ingenuity, can be transformed into a bit of beauty. It may be a difficult fence corner, a huge rock too large to be moved, a low boghole too wet for ordinary planting or the unsightly hole left where some outbuilding has been torn down.

Going -- almost gone -- is that once great American institution, the rocking chair. Such is the sad tale told last week by Laurence H. Whiting. As he is the president of Chicago's Furniture Mart, where manufacturers from all over the country show their wares, he should be in a position to know whereof he speaks.

IN a quiet English village called Haileybury there is what has become a famous "college" for boys. Over here it would be known as a private or "country" school, and Mr. Jackson is a master who teaches history. It is a privilege that has left him with leisure, and an idea occurred to his mind.

NOT only the popular character of his music, as remarked in last Sunday's TIMES, but, above all, the fact that he was descended from a family of peasants stood Ippolitoff-Ivanoff in good stead when the Lenin revolution broke out.

Scoring 176 runs against its opponents' 57, the Brooklyn Cricket Club triumphed again in the championship competition of the New York and Metropolitan District Association, defeating the Veteran St. George team at Castle Point Field in Hoboken yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 4. -- The deliberate, though unexpected, disclosure this week of the strengthening of the Soviet navy's Baltic fleet in ships and airplanes while shore defenses also are being perfected has caused no surprise among foreign military observers here.

HOLLYWOOD is becoming a radio centre. Many of radio's star performers have wandered off to California to "vacation" on the movie lots. And further evidence that the broadcasters anticipate a closer alliance with the films is found in the announcement that the National Broadcasting Company is planning new studios on the West Coast.

The British aircraft industry looks forward to an intensive development of large flying boats, military as well as civil, to knit the empire by air, John Lord, veteran British aircraft industrialist, who is here on a visit to American aircraft factories, said yesterday.

BOYS in their natural, school and neighborhood gangs are being sent off together to the University of Michigan Camp for Boys this Summer as an initial experiment in a new delinquency-prevention program.

A Yale junior, Paul B.S. Sawyer Jr., last week was elected commodore for the next year of the Eastern Intercollegiate Outboard Association, succeeding Roger S. Firestone, who finished his course at Princeton last month. The new vice commodore is Crawford R. Ferguson of Dartmouth and Thomas Tyson of Stevens Tech is the new rear-commodore.

CALL it an illusion, but also there was some truth in it. In the days when Broadway was prosperous (pre-1929), aglow with $6.60 tickets and bull market foolishness -- in those days the musical shows were plentiful. They were synonymous somehow with light, laughter, the gold standard and prohibition champagne, and they cost a lot of money to produce.

THE TIMES printed a long letter from Arthur J. Brown, the general tenor of which seems to be summarized in the following sentence: "The Japanese press and Ministry of the Navy interpreted the manoeuvres as a war measure and assigned it as a reason for strengthening their navy."

ELIZA BIALK, native of Chicago, has written a first novel that is worthy of more than passing attention. It is written with the maturity of precocious youth, the spiritual and emotional clairvoyance that has understanding as well as rebellion, and ideals as well as brutality.

PALMER, Alaska, July 6. -- Postponement of virtually all colony construction, except cottages, has been announced by Eugene Carr, co-ordinator, and Don Irwin, director. This drastic change in government plans was made to insure shelters for settlers and livestock before Winter descends on the Matanuska Valley.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 6. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr., Lakewood's most famous resident, is planning no special observance of his ninety-sixth birthday on Monday, friends and members of his household here have revealed. Although it is expected that his son, John D. Rockefeller Jr., will be a house guest on the anniversary, no specific information could be obtained.

DON'T be put off by the McGuinness vocabulary. It is true that he writes rather more like an ink-stained wretch than like a "sailor, soldier, pearl-fisher, rum-runner, pirate and explorer." But Mr. McGuinness, in life as well as in this book, has a way with the language.

The contest between the trustee of the St. Louis Gas and Coke Corporation and the protective committee for the holders of first mortgage bonds over the plan of reorganization made public by the trustee has added another chapter to the bitter struggles of the utilities in the St. Louis area in the last ten years.

LAKE GEORGE. -- Mrs. James L. Hand of New York will entertain tomorrow afternoon at her Summer home when the committee will be organized for the fourth annual amateur Sagamore tennis tournament, Aug. 14-18, at the Hotel Sagamore.

The holiday tempo continued yesterday to be responsible for light trading in bonds listed on the Stock Exchange. News seemed to be almost no factor in the two-hour session in which transactions amounted to $4,556,000, compared with $4,675,000 on the preceding Saturday.

FLORENCE, June 15, 1935. ONE of the so-called marginal features of the Maggio Musicale -- an evening of classical dancing in the Florentine garden of Villa Acton -- has proved of such exceptional interest as to merit consideration with the other chief outdoor spectacles of the festival -- "Savonarola" and "Alceste."

LONDON, June 20. A PLAY that will run as a popular piece for the theatre and deserves to run on its merits as a work of art is a phenomenon rare enough to be in itself the subject of a week's commentary on the London stage.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- An Associated Press recapitulation today shows that this Congress has passed the following two dozen bills, classified by legislators as "major," and seen them signed by the President:

A VERY pleasing story of life in another country that boys and girls from 7 to 10 will enjoy and that beginners can easily read for themselves. The author thoroughly understands children's interests and Peter and Gretchen, who live in the city of Nuremberg, are real and engaging.

Charles H. Sabin Jr., one of the organizers of the Crusaders, anti-prohibition association, confirmed reports yesterday that he was organizing a group known as the Committee of Americans to campaign for a Federal sales tax and governmental economies and against higher income taxes and the present "nuisance taxes." He said the committee hopes to present a petition of 1,000,000 names to the President and Congress urging that the budget be balanced by such means.

BERLIN, July 6. -- Alfred Rosenberg, cultural director of the Nazi party and most widely known enemy of the Christian religion in Germany, read before an audience at Muenster today a letter from the Catholic Bishop of Muenster to the Governor of Westphalia requesting that he (Rosenberg) be prevented from speaking.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 6 (AP). -- Rescuers who broke a window to force entrance found 9-year-old Jess Tubbs, the physically handicapped son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Tubbs, asphyxiated and his mother near death beside him on a davenport bed in their gas-filled home today.

In general, the markets yesterday showed a little more activity than is usual on a warm July Saturday. Despite the absence of many traders, the share market held the gains of the day before and added to them somewhat, although irregularly so; trading on the Stock Exchange reached 515,000 shares, compared with 252,000 on the Saturday before when the volume was the smallest in three months.

Failure of the Callahan Zinc-Lead Company's plan to raise working capital by the sale of 748,592 shares of additional $1-par common stock to its stockholders was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, which ruled the scheme inoperative because a minimum of 250,000 shares of stock was not subscribed.

The ending of the NRA and the current desire of business men for self-government under voluntary codes afford the Federal Trade Commission the greatest opportunity for attaining first rank as an important government body it has had in a decade, association lawyers agreed here yesterday.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., July 6. -- Commuters from this village are congratulating Charles P. McClelland, Federal Customs judge, because the 80-year-old jurist bought his first commutation ticket from Dobbs Ferry to New York fifty-six years ago. He is Dobbs Ferry's oldest commuter.

More than seventy field trial meetings already have been scheduled for the Autumn season, while many more organizations have not as yet announced their fixtures. When the whole list is complete the total unquestionably will constitute another new record for such competitions.

Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim will receive from Mayor La Guardia a Certificate of Honor for Distinguished Service to the City of New York at the 1,000th performance of the Goldman Band on the Central Park Mall Wednesday night, beginning at 8:30 o'clock.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6. -- The administration's trade-agreement program was indorsed as sound in principle and effective in operation and President Roosevelt's Social Security Bill, now awaiting final action by Congress, was the subject of more praise than criticism in discussions today at the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 5. -- The end of the fiscal year just closed shows Kansas in such an enviable financial position, with such a record for efficient and economical government, that supporters of Governor Alf M. Landon are proposing to draft him as a candidate for a third term, despite Kansas's unwritten prohibition against Governors serving more than two terms.

BOSTON, July 6. -- Old Man East Wind dumped his oil on the heat wave along New England's coast tonight, while inland electrical storms eased the pressure on thermometers that had been overworked for the last two days.

ISTANBUL, July 6. -- General Ismet Inonu, the Prime Minister, recently informed the nation that Turkey's greatest danger lay in attack from the air. He appealed for a fund of 30,000,000 Turkish pounds for an adequate air force.

MANY persons who spend their Summers by the sea, and even some who live there the year round, go without the beauty of flowers and shrubs because of a mistaken idea that hardly anything can be grown near the seashore.

While activity in the wholesale markets here last week was slow, pre-holiday retail trade was brisk and resulted in increased volume for the period, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- A progress report outlining the major items of work accomplished by the Civilian Conservation Corps for the period from April 17, 1933, when the first camp was established, to April 1, 1935, was made public today by Robert Fechner, Director of Emergency Conservation Work.

A book loss of $1,391,170 was sustained by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad from its terminal warehouse in Jersey City from the time the eight-story structure was completed in April, 1930, until Sept. 30 last. This was disclosed yesterday at the final hearing conducted by the Interstate Commerce Commission here to determine whether warehouse rates charged by the railroads serving New York are compensatory or whether they are so small as to constitute rebates.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 6 (AP). -- Veterans of Foreign Wars of New York, at their closing session today, elected Earl Campbell of Niagara Falls, present senior vice commander, as commander for the coming year.

IT is difficult to see why Mr. Leonard called his book "Tools of Tomorrow." To be sure, he raises a corner of the curtain that conceals Utopia from us -- a very little corner -- but the Tools of Tomorrow are hardly disclosed. From first to last it is the Tools of Today that are Mr. Leonard's chief concern.

NEW YORK is rich this Summer in opportunities to study trends and practical details of home decoration. Supplementing the many displays of decorated rooms in stores are special exhibitions, including one at the Decorators Club of photographs and watercolor pictures of interiors.

SPEEDING rapidly on its way toward completion, this monumental work has reached its sixteenth volume and the letters R and S, completing the names to be included under the former and advancing perhaps a quarter of the way through the latter.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 6. -- Three armed and masked men made a daring invasion of the Ridgewood Country Club links here this afternoon, held up five golfers, wounded one after robbing them of about $235 and escaped in an automobile.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 6. -- Rear Admiral Ernest J. King, chief of the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics, and Colonel Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, were entertained at the sixth annual national soaring contest today by Lieut. Commander R.S. Barnaby of Pensacola, Fla., president of Soaring Society of America, Inc.

THE Atlantic non-fiction prize of $5,000 for "the most interesting and distinctive work of non-fiction" submitted in the 1935 contest sponsored by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co. has been awarded to Miss Mari Sandoz of Lincoln, Neb., for her manuscript entitled "Old Jules."

The Pact of Paris, otherwise known as the Treaty for the Renunciation of War, and popularly called the Kellogg pact, is the first major victim of the conflict between Italy and Ethiopia. It had been in a comatose state, which many thought indicated a condition of rigor mortis, since the assault and battery committed upon it by the Japanese when they took Manchuria from China. Now it is being buried, "unwept, unhonored and unsung."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6. -- Miss Molly Townsend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Townsend of Horse Island, Meads Point, Greenwich, gave a dinner at her parents' home tonight in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Terbell, who have just opened their residence here.

IN the annals of American diplomacy one might search in vain for a victory as triumphant as the one achieved by Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and their colleagues in the eight years that followed the uprising of the farmers at Lexington in 1775.

Chairman FARLEY does not make nearly so many political speeches as he used to, for which he ought to have a vote of public thanks. When he does speak now he serves a useful purpose as a sort of weathervane, showing which way the wind of politics is blowing. While the struggle between the President and the House was going on, Mr. FARLEY kept very quiet.

AMONG the 200 or more delegates to the North American Esperanto Congress who met last week at the Hotel New Yorker there were many who expected to go to the Esperanto World Congress in Rome. Aug. 3-10. Even in North America above the Rio Grande, with English prevailing from the palm-fronded Gulf to the frozen reaches of the Arctic, more and more people are learning the practical usefulness of Esperanto in foreign travel.
CAMP DIX, N.J., July 6. -- A much-improved Camp Dix will greet the officers of the 305th Infantry, the students of the Citizens Military Training Corps and CCC men when they arrive here next week.

A former physicist of the Naval Research Laboratory, Dr. F. Russell Bichowsky, has recently indicted the American Navy. He charges it is grossly inefficient, naval officers are badly trained, ships are obsolete in design and faulty in construction and that the navy is not prepared for war.

Concerted action to reinforce fair trade practices in the distribution of trade-marked merchandise in the drug industry was taken last week when model contract forms, suitable for use in New York and the other eight States which have passed laws similar to the Feld-Crawford measure recently enacted here, were adopted by representatives of all branches of the industry.
BROKEN BOW, Okla., July 6 (AP). -- William H. "Alfalfa Bill" Murray has gone native on his eighty-acre farm a half-mile west of this village.

THAT long-nosed, curve-lipped distressful mask which has been dragged across the cover of Punch for generations is an excellent caricature of Lord Brougham. This is the one direct reminder now of a man who was most famous in his generation.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell pitched his twelfth victory of the season today as the Red Sox, although outhit, 11 to 5, turned back the Athletics, 6 -- 4.

The well-stocked lakes and streams of Connecticut have provided existing sport for black bass enthusiasts since the opening of the season a week ago. With the trout seeking deep, cold pools as a result of the continued warm weather, many stream fishermen are turning their attention to the game bass.
The Department of Parks is placing on public exhibition at the Bronx County Court House, beginning tomorrow, a scale model showing the development at Orchard Beach.

SMART Frenchwomen are dressing up much more for afternoon this season than they have done for many a day. Leisurely looking ensembles quite outmode the businesslike tailleurs so much in evidence during the depression.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 5. -- Thirteen cities, all but one in the western part of the State, have organized the Home Rule Power League to acquire by purchase all the properties of private power companies operating in the area, these to be pooled with the properties already owned and operated by several of the cities, to form one huge reservoir of electric energy with facilities for distribution for the use of all.

ALBANY, July 6. -- A two-day program, replete with features depicting the various phases of conservation, will mark the State's second big celebration this year commemorating fifty years of the work. This is being arranged by the Central Adirondacks Association, in cooperation with the State Conservation Department, and will be held on July 20 and 21 along the Fulton chain of lakes in the Adirondacks, with Old Forge as headquarters.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- A call for a national convention in the Fall to create a new third party "based on the principle of production for use" was approved and a sweeping platform was adopted here today by about 300 representatives of virtually all shades of "native American radical" opinion.

The proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act are unconstitutional, the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America said yesterday in an analysis of the bill. Moreover, as an economic measure designed to insure the plentiful production and distribution of commodities, the measure is "preposterous," the association declared.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The Garden Club of Mount Desert, of which Mrs. Gilbert H. Montague is president, has planned an interesting program for its members at this week's meeting. They will drive from the island to Blue Hill, where they will be the guests at a buffet luncheon of Mrs. L. Dean Holden.

Although some branches of industry are being affected by the usual seasonal lull, reports from most of the leading cities throughout the country continue to indicate rising activity and improved economic conditions as the nation enters the second half of the year.

ACCESSORIES for the vacation constantly grow in number and ingenuity. Whether one's holiday consists of lazy hours on a beach or travel abroad, there is new equipment designed to add to one's pleasure. New offerings range from legless seats for beach lounging to electric connections which enable one to use American electric devices in foreign countries with different wiring systems.

WHITE MAN'S COUNTRY" is the biography of the late Lord Delamere. Mrs. Huxley explains the title as an expression of the ideal behind his efforts and those of his fellow-settlers to establish a permanent settlement in the highlands of East Africa.

TEACHERS as a class have lost less in dollars-and-cents income than most other professional people during the depression. Indeed, they are better off today on the average in purchasing power than they were in 1929, owing to the sharp drop in cost of living after that year and the slight drop in their salaries.

Characterizing the proposed $4,700,000 PWA low-cost housing project for the Macombs Place section of Harlem as "economically unsound," Frederick W. Wells, engineer and president of the Harlem Renters Association, attacked yesterday the condemnation feature of the plan as a "political gesture" impossible of achievement within the thirty-day period allotted.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 6. -- That there will be no dumping of Canada's large wheat surplus on the world's markets appeared today to be assured by conversations with leading grain men and high government officials handling sales of grain here. Premier Bennett's statement made in Parliament four weeks ago that "there will be no dumping of Canada's wheat" still stands as Canada's attitude.

The action of the House of Representatives, in rejecting the ultra-radical provisions of the Utilities Holding Company Bill, followed by signs of a conservative attitude on other contested measures, has evoked discussion of its political significance. No one can yet be sure just how much it means.

TRENTON, N.J., July 6. -- Residents of New Jersey had no more than made up their mind's this week to grin and bear the State's new 2 per cent sales tax, at least temporarily, when Governor Harold G. Hoffman, at whose instance the levy was adopted to raise $20,000,000 a year for emergency relief, reminded them that his complete legislative program included an income-tax proposal.
Homicide was charged against two men in Brooklyn yesterday as a result of the murder on Friday night of Gerard (Big Jerry) Maganero, 23-year-old ex-convict of 8,129 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn.

THE opening of the Shelley Skyway, which runs from Red Lodge, Mont., to the northeast boundary of Yellowstone National Park, a distance of sixty-eight and one-half miles, is reported by the Automobile Club of New York. It is said to be a spectacularly scenic road and connects with the recently completed U.S. 10, which was described on this page last Sunday.
