SAN JUAN P.R., July 6. -San Juan witnessed this morning the largest public demonstration in the history of Puerto Rtco when more than 20,000 men, women and children from every city on the island paraded from the Governor's palace to the Capitol, demanding that the -[,egis]ature pass bills to prepare Puerto lieo for permanent reconstruction. They urged the legislators to act immediately, warning that the people's patience was exhausted.

MOTORISTS touring in the Canadian Rockies will find the all-Canadian highway from Winnipeg to Vancouver practically completed this season. Only the strip between Golden and Revelstoke, B.C., remains unfinished. To accommodate automobilists a daily transport service between these points will carry cars and passengers from now until Sept. 15 across this portion of the Selkirk Mountain range, known as the "Big Bend."

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- In the first overt move to test the Supreme Court's "horse and buggy" definition of interstate commerce, President Roosevelt has asked a House subcomittee to overlook constitutional doubts and rush the Guffey-Snyder Coal Control Bill to early enactment, presumably to avoid a strike in the soft coal fields scheduled for July 31.

JED BURRIS ran the antique druggist's shop in Laurelton, a village fifteen miles from Chicago, ran it in the old-fashioned tradition passed on to him by the two preceding generations of his family, who had conducted the business with honor and modest pride.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The activities of lobbyists became a matter of unusual moment in Washington this week. The House instructed its Rules Committee to investigate the extent and manner by which friends and foes of the administration's Utilities Holding Company Bill brought pressure to bear upon Congressmen preceding a vote on the measure.

DICTATORS and depressions being timely subjects of vital interest, Anne Cameron has combined the two in "The House of Trujillo." Ruth Weir, the pretty, blond heroine, the daughter of the depression and the wife of the South American dictator.

While the so-called brain workers in the United States, especially those enjoying comparatively decent incomes, are receiving little consideration in the various schemes of social legislation being fought over in Congress, the little Baltic State of Estonia has recently issued regulations for the functioning of a special fund to provide old-age, invalidity and survivors' pensions for such professional workers as volunteer to join it.

THE third annual City of Sydney Eisteddfod and grand interstate choral championship will be held in the Australian city Aug. 21 and 22 and Aug. 26 to Sept. 7. In the foreword to the syllabus of the event a number of interesting items regarding music in Sydney are recorded, Excerpts follow:

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's victory today supplied all the vindication she ever will need for the incident in the American championship final of 1933 when, suffering from a back injury, she walked off the court in the third set with Miss Helen Jacobs leading, 3 -- 0. She was accused then of quitting, of depriving Miss Jacobs of a chance for a clean-cut, undisputed victory.

The President's prompt and proper reply to the communication of the Emperor of Ethiopia serves the useful purpose of calling fresh attention to the national obligations entered into and agencies established to assist in the peaceful settlement "of international controversies."

French officials have recently decided that members of the French artillery were proud figures but easy targets in sky-blue uniforms. But in the future they will march in khaki. A few blue uniforms, already made, will be utilized, but all new ones will be dust-colored, according to a bulletin from the National Geographic Society.
A visit for a night or a week-end to the new basin at Forked River, off Barnegat Bay, is a revelation to the cruising yachtsman who has been nearly everywhere and has seen most everything.

WITH a special body built by James Cunningham Son Co. of Rochester on a standard Ford V-8 chassis, the town car pictured above was announced last week by John G. Dale, New York sales manager. Production will be restricted at first, Mr. Dale said, and selling efforts will be concentrated in the Eastern States.

The disappearance of Albert Chiocca, 16 years old, of 215 East Twenty-ninth Street last Wednesday morning as he was delivering groceries for his father on Thirtieth Street near Madison Avenue, was reported yesterday by the police and agents of the Department of Justice.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- This week's reorganization of Pennsylvania's State Liquor Control Board carried out predictions made in February at the start of the legislative investigation into the board's activities, made at the demand of Governor Earle.

THE case of Luis Alberni illustrates two major laws of the picture business. One is that stars have much to fear from a good bit player but a good bit player has nothing to fear from stars; the second, that God proposes but the casting director disposes.

With the appointment on July 1 of Glenn A. Bowers as director of the Unemployment Insurance Division of its Department of Labor, New York State set in motion its program for unemployment insurance. One of the most important features of the program will be its dovetailing with the framework of the Federal social security plan.

BELGRADE, July 6 (AP). -- The Yugoslav Government, in what was regarded as an important stride toward unification of the nation, today authorized Minister of Justice Lyudevit Auey to sign a concordat with the Vatican.

MADRID, June 28. -- Dictatorship talk again is being heard in Spain -- so much that the energetic young War Minister, Jose Maria Gil Robles, leader of the powerful Catholic Popular Action party, has stated publicly that he would suppress rather than support a military coup d'etat intended to abolish democratic government in this country.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The present mood of Congress has put the administration more on guard than at any time since it came into power twenty-eight months ago.
LONDON. THE publication of the letters of Charles Dickens to his wife, now released by the death of their son Henry last December, has disappointed those who looked for sensational revelations.

A DISPASSIONATE view of the cinema, even from West Forty-third Street on a warm July evening, presents the familiar spectacle of a big fish gobbling up the little fishes. This is no time to attempt anything approaching a chronological survey of the development of the film industry.

Forced to jam through in a short space of time orders which would normally cover a period of months, dry-goods wholesalers, with only 45 to 50 per cent of their Fall business placed, expect to embark on a minor buying splurge within the next two weeks, they indicated here yesterday.

AFTER one of the most interesting and active seasons in recent years, the dance apparently finds it impossible to throw off its excitement and settle down for a Summer rest. Never before has there been such an extensive program for the vacation period as that which has already begun to get under way this year.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The fortunes of our Yankees came perilously close to falling upon an evil hour today as they grappled with the Senators in a doubleheader and a heat wave, amid a chortling crowd of 10,000.

With an enrolment 10 per cent higher than last year, the Columbia University Summer session will begin tomorrow. At the end of the regular registration period yesterday, the enrolment was 1,100 ahead of the total for 1934. Edward B. Fox, assistant registrar of the university predicted that the final figures for registration, which continues with half credit until July 12, will reach 11,600.
THIS is a bill of complaint. The complaint is several-fold, uttered in behalf of the motorist who for some good reason must keep up a fairly fast, steady pace on long jaunts.

I find myself in perfect agreement with the views expressed in Billy Artz's letter in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES. The dinner hour is not an appropriate time for dance music, melodramatic plays or juvenile "hair-raisers" on the radio. Dinner-concert music is certainly much more in harmony with one's mood while dining.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6. -- Sao Paulo industrialists are intensifying their campaign against the trade treaty with the United States. However, they have presented no data to show to what extent the treaty would hurt Sao Paulo industry.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today dropped intimations that they viewed the Canadian Government's steps for control of the wheat production and marketing as a potential stabilizer for the world market.
PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP). -- The Cubs ended a four-game losing streak today, beating the Pirates in thirteen innings, 10 to 8, after the losers had tied the count with a six-run drive in the ninth.

Dean John T. Madden yesterday announced the names of 124 students who attained the honor roll for the second semester of the academic year in the day division of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

Mr. McGOVERN was in his younger days a champion of the prize ring and when he quit that occupation he opened a gymnasium. But he soon discovered, he relates, that he was far too ignorant to carry on such work properly and so he took a long and intensive course in the Cornell Medical College, afterward becoming physical director there.

HEIDELBERG, July 6. -- The press and National Socialist party functionaries united today in a nation-wide attack on the Old Heidelberg romanticism and the singing, drinking, swashbuckling students of the famous dueling corps.
LONDON, July 6. -- The British public reaction to the foreign policy of the recently reorganized Tory government is divided and subdivided.

Benefits both to school children and relief workers on health and educational services of the Board of Education, in cooperation with the Works Division, were emphasized in a review of the projects made public yesterday by the Emergency Relief Bureau.

Interests connected with the Associated Gas and Electric Company expressed yesterday satisfaction with the New York Supreme Court's decision on June 27 annulling and remanding to the Pubic Service Commission the orders of the commission prescribing uniform systems of account for electric, gas and water utilities.

ASIDE from the events of the week at the Lewisohn Stadium, there are several items of news concerning forthcoming concerts. The first of these is that Jascha Heifetz will interrupt his first vacation in two years, which he is spending on the Pacific Coast, to fly to New York next month and appear as a soloist.

Strange things are happening at the Polo Grounds and Memphis Bill Terry last night was beginning to rock on his heels a trifle. Yesterday while 9,000 fans, the smallest Saturday crowd of the season, looked on in amazement, the Dodgers again trounced the Giants soundly by 12 to 7.

New corporate financing is coming once more into its own. It is quite true that it is largely a matter of refunding operations, but it still requires the usual origination, underwriting, wholesale and retail distribution. There is money to be made, prestige to be gained, and with the banks out of the bond business, competition is keen.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- Carl Fischer's effective relief pitching and a sixteen-hit bombardment that included Zeke Bonura's fifteenth homer of the season gave the White Sox a 7-to-6 victory over the Indians before 8,000 today. It was the White Sox's sixth straight triumph and Cleveland's seventh defeat in a row.

VIENNA, July 6. -- It is impossible to withhold admiration from the successful prosecution of the "cottonwool tactics" with which the ruling classes of pro-war Austria, have sought steadily since the revolution of 1918 to reverse the effects of the great upheaval which liberated all the non-Germanic peoples of the Hapsburg empire and enabled the Germanic inhabitants to replace the benevolent, fairly bureaucratic despotism by the ultra-democratic, self-governing republic.

WASHINGTON. IT is unusual for the President of the United States to urge a member of Congress to forego his personal plans for either advancement or retirement, and to remain at his Congressional post in Washington. When that occurs it is safe to assume that the President is in need of the member in question, that he has some particular legislative task he would entrust to that member and to him alone.
TOKYO. -- The recent Sakdalista rising provided a laboratory test of one of the favorite American illusions: that Japan is watching the Philippines as a cat watches a caged canary.

RADIO fits its speakers into a honeycomb of time. The stop-watch measures out the moments as the big red second hand of the clock on the studio wall paces the minute and hour hands around time's dial. To the broadcaster new to radio, the feverish race of the seconds signals for brevity; the old-timers instinctively adhere to it.

ROME, July 6. -- The Tribuna, in commenting on a recent session of the Committee of Admirals, the Italian Navy's supreme consultative organ, hints that among decisions reached was that in all future negotiations for limitation of naval armaments Italy would follow a policy similar to Japan's and accept only limitation of total tonnage, insisting on her right to decide herself how the total tonnage was to be distributed among the various classes.

OTTAWA, July 4. -- The sixth session of the seventeenth Parliament of Canada, the last before a general election is held in the Autumn, closed this week with a diminuendo passage in which the political ear discerned a note of discouragement for the government.

The formalities were completed last week and New York County -- the insular and sinful area bounded by the East and Hudson Rivers -- is to have its organized criminal activities scrutinized in an investigation that may last two years and cost a half million dollars.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP). -- Plunge Home led from start to finish in the $2,000 Juvenile Stakes, feature race of today's program at the Detroit track, by a length and a half. Be Big finished in second place, a head in front of Ste. Louise.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Exports of domestic products during May amounted to $2,628,000 more than in May, 1934, the latest Commerce Department figures reveal. The total of exports, not including re-exports, for May was $159,789,000, compared with $157,161,000 a year ago.

Leading banks in this city, as a whole, showed a slight decline in total resources and a small rise in deposits in the first half of this year, it was disclosed last week in their statements of condition on June 29, published in response to the orders of the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banks.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 6. -- Mrs. Nathaniel Landon of this place was in charge of a dance held here tonight at the Lawrence Farms Clubhouse. The proceeds will aid the Westchester County Children's Association. Mrs. Landon was assisted by Mrs. Charles Luckey, Mrs. Bertram Bell, Mrs. Fifield Workum, Mrs. Volney Righter, Mrs. Edwin Merrill, Mrs. Frederick Palmer and Mrs. Richard Woolworth.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- In one of the greatest races ever witnessed at Arlington Park, Coldstream won the seventh running of the $5,000 added Hyde Park Stakes today after being all but left at the post.

PARIS, July 4. -- The Grand Prix brought the season's biggest week to a close. Several interesting style notes were added to the new Summer fashions. A new silhouette appeared in slender, ankle-length shirtwaist dresses, emphasizing an elongated line.

The possibility of a new third-party movement in the national campaign next year is now being actively canvassed. Five Representatives in Congress conferred in Chicago with various other interested persons last week to study the situation and a "third-party convention" is to open in Omaha, Neb., tomorrow under the leadership of Roy M. Harrop, an Iowa lawyer.

SUMMER institutes are no novelty; for years the American scene has been dotted with such conferences. This season, however, a unique institute -- the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations -- will be held from Aug. 25 to 30, under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, at Williams College.

TACOMA, Wash., July 6 (AP). -- United States Marshal A.J. Chitty and Defense Attorney John F. Dore warred with words today over Chitty's charges that Pore handed Mrs. Margaret T. Waley, Weyerhaeuser kidnap defendant, a cheering letter from her husband, Harmon, in Federal court yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 6. -- Dizzy Dean, alternately baseball's bad boy and hero, is to go unpunished for his refusal to appear yesterday in an exhibition game at St. Paul.

The budgeting that is done for each of the Neediest Cases is illustrated by the following example. The case involved is Case 83 of the 1934 appeal; it was submitted by the Charity Organization Society and was published under the title "Pursued by Ill Fortune":

WHITE picket gates in the New England village called Storrowton, in Massachusetts near West Springfield, swing open this week to Summer tourists. In austerer style, this restoration is to the Old Colony what Williamsburg is to the Old Dominion.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP). -- Merton W. Goodrich, at the end of a long flight that began last September after the slaying of 11-year-old Lillian Gallaher, said today that he was "ready to get it over with," but would not plead until he knew the fate of his wife.

MOST properly "Journal Up the Straits" may be called an "item," as collectors like to do, for it is in fact a first edition, although Herman Melville has been dead these many years, and the journey of which this is his log was made between October, 1856, and May, 1857.

SOUTHAMPTON -- Southampton gardens, with all their infinite variety and charm, will claim the interest of the Summer colony here during the coming week. On Wednesday morning members of the Garden Club of Southampton will hold their second meeting for this season at Darena, the home of Mrs. George Barton French.

The possibility that Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Ryan, in command of Brooklyn detectives, will be made Assistant Chief Inspector commanding detectives in all boroughs instead of Acting Deputy Chief Inspector Henry E. Bruckman was seen at police headquarters yesterday with the designation of Ryan as Acting Assistant Chief Inspector.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 6. -- Ploughing through the ruffled waters of Zach's Bay with rhythmic power, Miss Elizabeth Kompa of the Womens Swimming Association thrashed her way to victory in the women's metropolitan 220-yard back stroke championship today and was timed in figures that have been beaten by only one dorsal performer, Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett.

THE mid-year report of The Hundred Neediest Cases Fund is presented on these pages today. The 100 simple stories that follow tell what six months of aid have meant to the 100 cases published by THE NEW YORK TIMES in its twenty-third annual appeal at last Christmas time.

With the passage of a bill to establish New Jersey's part of an Interstate Sanitation Commission, the New Jersey Legislature has brought the hope of cleaning up New York Harbor a step nearer realization. New York acted in 1931 and needs only to make minor changes to conform to the New Jersey provisions.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 6. -- A portrait of William III of England, Prince of the House of Orange-Nassau, from which Princeton takes both the name of Nassau Hall and the orange of its official colors, has been presented to the university by four alumni of the class of '94.

FOUR choice loaves from the Hollywood cinema ovens will be unloaded at theatres in and near the Times Square area this week. Both the Rivoli and the Strand will bring in their new tenants on Wednesday, while the Paramount and Roxy will -- as usual -- change their programs on Friday.

THIS is a handbook for use in such matters as improving one's standing in a community, making one's self popular, getting along comfortably and successfully with others, moving forward to a position of leadership. A great many books have been written on this very theme.
LONDON, July 6 (AP). -- Britain's government will try again next week to avert an Italo-Ethiopian war, but without much hope of success.

PRODUCTION and release of "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" by Metro may bring into the open as tense a situation as has existed between Hollywood and foreign countries in some years. Recently European, nations have found in the cinema an excellent football.

WASHINGTON July 6 (AP). -- Continuing differences over the scope of the President's wealth-tax program prompted predictions on one side tonight that it would be dropped temporarily, and on the other that it would hold Congress in session well into September.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- If the President continues to insist -- as he says he will -- that the Seventy-fourth Congress pass his wealth-tax program before adjournment of this session he may find himself embroiled in as dangerous a political situation as Mr. Hoover, in somewhat similar circumstances, brought upon himself in the Summer of 1929.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A wide-open contest for the Republican nomination for President is foreseen for next year following word from the West that ex-President Hoover will not demand "vindication" at the polls.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 6. -- Dr. Edward Robbins of Bay Shore, driving his bay mare Joy Lincoln, won the 2:12 trot today, lowering the season's track record to 2:09 3/4 in the second heat.

The high-water mark of the outdoor swimming season is fast approaching, and all the local stars are training assiduously for the national championships, which are to be held in Brooklyn for the first time on July 18-21. There will be new stands erected to accommodate the huge crowds expected at the Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, to see the leading swimmers of the country vie for honors and new records.

ROME, July 5. -- If any stimulus was required to solidify Italian public opinion behind Premier Benito Mussolini in his East African venture it was supplied by the trip to Rome of Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs.

LONDON, July 6. -- Heavy selling of bar silver from India and China threatened today to unsettle the silver market here but subsequent buying by the United States Government prevented a sharp break in prices. After an almost unprecedented delay of three hours the price finally was fixed at 30 11/16d an ounce for cash and 30 5/16d for two-month forward delivery -- declines of 3/5d and 5/16d an ounce, respectively.

Details of an operation under which that portion of the national and provincial foreign debt of Argentina which is in French francs wil be converted into Credito Argentino Interno 1934 bonds were made public yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau.

THE program in the opening week of the sixty-second annual Summer festival at Chautauqua, N.Y., will include organ recitals by George William Volkel and a sacred song service. The first of the concerts by the Chautauqua Little Symphony under the direction of Georges Barrere will take place July 17.

THE President's share-the-wealth message and the efforts of Congress to work out the plan whereby this scheme may be put into effect have caused no reverberations in this little city. Four miles away at the River Rouge plant eight silvery chimneys axe belching forth their accustomed volume of smoke.

There is much croaking about the instability of politicians. They flop over in the night. They take on almost instantaneous protective coloring. You never know exactly where they are at a given moment.

THE problems facing the voluntary hospitals of New York City -- problems largely arising from a sharp decrease in income during the depression years -- have been called to public attention by David McAlpin Pyle, the new president of the United Hospital Fund.

MR. CRONYN'S novel is in the hands of a consulting psychologist who has given up practice to write a thousand cases of "Variations From Normalcy in the Average Male." Lest this frighten the reader, we must add that the psychologist is no more than a stooge, that the characters are healthy, ordinary types and that there is no psychological vocabulary or theory to bother about.

OF all the woes that beset Benito Mussolini's path these days one is entirely personal. It takes the form of a little old man who sits high above a blue lake in Northern Italy and by his very existence disturbs the peace of mind of the dictator.

ANOTHER issue of Ars Islamica is at hand -- Vol. II, Part 1. This learned publication, to which reference has previously been made, is produced by the Research Seminary in Islamic Art, division of fine arts, at the Uni versity of Michigan.

BERLIN. -- It has now been decided that when the new German conscription system comes fully into operation the period of labor service will, after all, be six months and not a year, making a break in the careers of young men of only eighteen months in all.

TODAY clothes express one's mood. Does one feel sporting -- very well, then, one wears sports clothes. And by that it is not meant that one dons a bathing suit for a beach, or slacks for a boat -- that goes without saying, but one can be perfectly dressed in the sports type of evening dress at a country club if one feels so inclined.

New York delegates to the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women will leave for Seattle tomorrow morning. A group of national officers will accompany them. At Chicago they will board one or two special trains scheduled to arrive in Seattle on July 13. Meetings will continue through July 20.
So much has been in the press regarding the high cost of meats in the large cities that I, as a livestock producer, am tempted to write a short statement from the standpoint of the stockman.
The current heat wave continued unabated yesterday as sweltering millions in the city experienced the hottest day of the year.

DIEPPE, France, July 7. -- The citizens of this harbor town joined with the American colony in Paris today to honor a native of Dieppe, Jean Ribault, who earned his fame thousands of miles away in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP). -- The fans began with jeers and ended with cheers today as the surprising Deans, Dizzy and Paul, starred in a double-header triumph by the Cardinals over the Reds before 15,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 7. -- Courage as an imperative eligibility qualification for the famed special agents of the United States Department of Justice is gauged by their trainers' intuition and judgment during the training period, it was declared here tonight by J. Edgar Hoover, head of the department's Burea of Investigation.

After sounding a distress signal at 4:40 P.M. yesterday, the sightseeing boat Tourist, a 125-foot craft with 200 passengers aboard, floundered helplessly in the Hudson River just north of the George Washington Bridge, menacing other river traffic and drifting rapidly in a heavy current.

CHANGTEH, China, July 7 (AP). -The greatest disaster of recent years befell this prosperous inland city in Northwest Hunan Province today when dikes on the Yuen River collapsed and a wall of water engulfed the city and surrounding countryside. An undetermined number of persons were drowned.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 7. -Approximately thirty boats engaged either in racing or in following the Eastern Yacht Club's annual cruise were at anchor here today, waiting for the resumption of activities tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- While administration leaders laid their plans to start President Roosevelt's tax program through the Congressional machine tomorrow, Senator Vandenberg tonight denounced the Presidential plan as "not even a good soap-box formula," and demanded striking changes or else a few months' Congressional recess while a "real program is developed to fit our whole necessity."

OTTAWA, July 7 (Canadian Press). -- Hon. H.H. Stevens announced tonight that he had accepted the leadership of a new political party having for its object a "reconstruction and reform program" such as he has been advocating for the past eighteen months.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 7. -- The White Mountain resorts enjoyed the gayest week-end of this season, with many guests arriving to visit at cottages and a larger influx of early July arrivals at hotels than for some years.

Alden Smith's Loon won the Elliott Trophy series for decked-sailing canoes and Hans Waldinger's Spray took the Lady Bug Trophy in the open cruising class off the Island Canoe and Yacht Club in East Chester Bay yesterday.

A telegram from Columbus, Ohio, yesterday informed the New York police that the missing Albert Chiocca, 16-year-old son of Jerry Chiocca, 215 East Twenty-ninth Street, was safe in the workhouse in that city, serving out a sentence in lieu of a $15 fine imposed for trespassing on railroad property.

Following is the text of the forty-eight recommendations for bettering local relief administration made by Lloyd Paul Stryker in a report of the relief inquiry conducted by the Aldermanic committee Investigating Relief, of which he was counsel:
One of our local financial writers said in his column recently: "It is difficult for the average business man or banker to follow President Roosevelt, to understand what he is trying to do."

Interest generally in the wholesale markets was centred on Fall merchandise last week and large contingents of buyers are expected here this week. Many new and unusual style trends were noted in the dress lines opened, with indications that there will be an entire change of mode as compared with last year's fashions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 7 (AP). -- The Newark Bears reached a quartet of Red Wing pitchers for an 18-to-1 victory today for a clean sweep of the series. The Bears collected sixteen safe hits off Michaels, Cross, Harrell and Kleinke. The game was delayed until 5 o'clock because of rain.
NEW ORLEANS, July 7. -- Although far from active generally, trading on the Cotton Exchange here last week developed some busy periods.

An interesting transaction in which Harry F. Sinclair, oil operator, becomes a tenant of the Rockefeller interests was announced yesterday. Under the terms of a leasing contract the Consolidated Oil Corporation, holding company for all the Sinclair oil properties, takes seven entire floors in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, and as part of the same transaction a buyer has been found for the stock ownership of the thirty-story Sinclair Building at 45 Nassau Street.

Indications yesterday were that Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, again the world's tennis queen, would make her first appearance before a home audience since her comeback in the Wightman Cup competition at Forest Hills Aug. 16-17, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Putting perhaps a trifle more zeal into their work than circumstances may have demanded, the Yankees rode roughshod over the Senators today to win the odd game of the three-game set, 11 to 1. That enabled the McCarthy forces to return home with their one-game margin over the second-place Tigers still intact.

A series of police promotions resulting from the retirement of Vincent J. Sweeney, Second Deputy Police Commissioner, to become a city magistrate, will be made this morning at ceremonies at City Hall, when Mayor La Guardia will administer the oath of his new office to Mr. Sweeney.

BERLIN, July 7. -- Visions of an early return of the Hapsburg monarchy have thus far failed to arouse political circles here and comment on the Austrian Government's lifting of the ban against the former ruling house is confined to a few non-party organs.
ST. LOUIS, July 7. -- Reformers and saloonkeepers here joined today in a campaign to swat the feminine bar fly, newest product of the post-prohibition era.

SHANGHAI, Monday, July 8. -- A spokesman for the Japanese Embassy officially expressed pleasure this morning over a report from Nanking to the effect that the Kuomintang [Nationalist] party had finally officially endorsed a pro-Japanese policy on the part of the Chinese Government.

LONDON, July 6. -- British industry entered the second half of the year in an optimistic spirit with more workers employed than at any time since the war and with the prospect that the number of jobless may soon drop below 2,000,000. The present unemployment reflects the inactivity of certain trades due to reduced exports.

Sixty thousand shares of cumulative convertible participating preferred stock of the Froedtert Grain and Malting Company, Inc., will be placed on the market today by Hammons Co., Inc., at $15.75 a share. There are outstanding 80,000 shares, which are listed on the New York Curb Exchange.

In his letter to the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, the President admits that there are "reasonable" doubts of the constitutionality of the Guffey bill. Yet he urges that it be passed quickly nevertheless. It has been stated, and seems to be true, that the Attorney General of the United States flatly gave his opinion to Mr. ROOSEVELT that the bill is unconstitutional.

Great Britain and the United States, imperially disconnected by the Declaration of Independence, were never separated but have always been united by an indestructible bond -- the Evangelico Faith, the Rev. Dr. Albert D. Belden, superintendent-minister of Whitefield's Tabernacle, London, England, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Baptist Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

CLEVELAND, July 7. -- Despite former President Hoover's assurance to Republican Senate leaders that he would not seek the nomination for President next year, some promoters of the regional Republican conference opening here tomorrow originally planned to stress his availability as the most eligible man espousing safe and sound policies of government.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP). -- The American Commonwealth Political Federation was charged today with the task of completing the structure of a "third party" dedicated to a fight for a "new economic order."

Mary Pickford will turn film producer this season and produce two pictures for release by United Artists, the company announced yesterday on the eve of its national sales convention in Hollywood. The two will be part of the twenty-four feature films that United expects to receive from its eight member producers.

DETROIT, July 7. -- Ralph Flanagan, speedy young merman from Miami, Fla., completed his mastery of Jack Medica in the closing session of the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming championships at the Detroit Boat Club pool tonight by scoring a convincing victory over the Seattle youth in the 880-yard free-style.

ROME, July 6. -- Conditions in Italy, even in the present moment of international uncertainty, are, on the whole, satisfactory. Unemployment at the end of May amounted to 755,000, against 803,000 in April and 941,000 in March. The general production index stood at 107 in May, against 106 the month before.
Mary Roberts Rinehart, who is at her Summer home in Maine, has nearly finished the first draft of a new novel, which is to be called "The Doctor."

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 7 -- Another of the youthful prodigies of the Women's Swimming Association came smashing on to victory today as little Miss Anna Nerich thrashed through the dull grey waters of Zachs Bay to the national 100-meter breast-stroke crown amid the plaudits of a crowd of 20,000.

BERLIN, July 7. -- German political speculation on Premier Mussolini's adventure in Ethiopia is cautious and suggests that for the time being there is to be no reproof of the Italian Premier in German quarters.

MOSCOW, July 7 (AP). -- A charge that Japanese militarists were provoking "collision" in the Far East was made today by Vlas Chubar, Vice Premier and member of the Politbureau, in an address to a huge crowd in the Central Park of Culture and Rest.
With the exception of sugar and rubber futures, fair advances were scored by the leading commodity futures here last week, with trading small before the holiday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 7. -- Behind a sparkling exhibition of offensive and defensive play by Terence Preece, the Gulf Stream four triumphed over Roslyn, 11 -- 8, in an exhibition polo match at the Sands Point Club today.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that the organization's convention, the first in four years, will commence this morning at 10 o'clock at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

The legality of the slogan contest scheme by which the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is president, hopes to enroll 100,000 members, is under police scrutiny, it became known yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Little progress has been made in the national war on crime, and "the professional criminal, particularly, seems to be master of the situation," according to the annual report of the Prison Association of New York, made public yesterday.

The domestic cotton manufacturing industry found some indication last week that the bottom of the current recession may be near at hand, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. The service reports that buyers of cotton goods placed specifications and took shipments on old orders more freely.

CLEVELAND, July 7. -- Major league baseball will unfurl a record-smashing spectacle tomorrow in Cleveland's huge lakefront stadium, regardless of which "dream team" gets a rude awakening in the third annual battle between the all-stars of the National and American Leagues.

PARIS, July 6. -- With investors slow to deposit their semi-annual dividend receipts in the banks, money is not so abundant on the Paris market as in recent weeks. Loan rates have followed the downward movement of the discount rate, but borrowers are few.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare and former chairman and director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, yesterday characterized the report of Lloyd P. Stryker, counsel of the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief, as the statement of a prosecuting attorney addressing a jury.

NEWPORT, July 7. -- Newport is to have a repetition of the White Elephant dance held last Summer. The party is scheduled for Aug. 24 at the Newport Country Club. It will follow a dinner to be given by Miss Lucy T. Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurance Saunders of New York, one of the season's debutantes, and is being arranged by the group of young people who gave last year's event.

MOSCOW, July 7 (AP). -- The committee appointed to alter the Constitution to provide for the introduction of parliamentary practices in the Soviet form of government held its first meeting today under the chairmanship of Joseph Stalin.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Wheat markets of the world are for the most part in a demoralized condition, or nearly so, and no one is offering a solution that appears tenable in the way of a change for the better. It is a case of surplus of supplies over requirements, with good carryovers from the 1934-35 crop into that of the 1935-36 season.

Details of transactions in which thousands of holders of mortgage certificates here lost millions of dollars will be made public by the Congressional committee investigating real estate bondholders' reorganizations, representatives of the committee said yesterday.

Man's chief end in the modern world is the same as it was 300 years ago; to glorify God and to enjoy Him forever, the Rev. Dr. Milton J. Hoffman said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

Assumption of full control of work relief in the city by the Federal Government is the greatest single advance in local relief administration since the depression, Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel of the Aldermanic Relief Investigating Committee, declared yesterday in a report on his recently completed inquiry.

Clergy in the United States will observe Sunday, Aug. 18, as a day of prayer and protest against the declared intention of Italy to subjugate Ethiopia, the oldest Christian nation in the world, it was announced yesterday by the Committee for Ethiopia, 228 East Forty-fifth Street.

Charges that the cotton reduction policies of the AAA were steadily aggravating the plight of the tenant farmer and share cropper while enriching the landlords were made yesterday by the Methodist Federation for Social Service on the basis of a survey conducted in the cotton producing area.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7 (AP). -- A sudden, drenching rainstorm slashed into New York State near Rochester today and swept eastward, leaving in its wake flooded highways and farm lands, washed-out bridges and abandoned homes. The damage was estimated at hundreds of thousands of dollars.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
Except for an upturn in sterling and the Scandinavians, the trend in the other European exchanges was lower last week. Business was on a moderately heavy scale, allowing for our holiday on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The possibility of some compromise on the bitter religious controversy between the Mexican Government and the Catholic Church is seen in a report of the Foreign Policy Association, made public here today.

Publishers, members of trades unions and "all defenders of civil liberties" were called upon yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union to urge the House of Representatives to defeat the so-called "incitement to disaffection" bill, passed by the Senate June 24.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The Hitler regime and the Catholic Church appear to be drawing near an open break, with Nazi party functionaries and government officials broadcasting threats and fulminating against "black reaction."
MEXICO, D.F., July 7. -- All Catholic churches throughout Mexico where services were permitted today offered special prayers for religious liberty.
Brokers reported realty transactions in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn over the week-end:
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The threat of foreclosure by the Home Owners Loan Corporation has been heard by 568 persons who took advantage of government loans.

PARIS, July 7 (AP). -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque, chief of the national veterans' organization Croix de Feu, predicted today that the French Government was headed for a "fall," and that he would lead his forces to "power."

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the city had ready a sufficient number of work relief projects to put 250,000 persons in jobs. This, the Mayor said, could be done as soon as the Federal Works Administration was prepared to go into action.

Continuance of the established minimum wages of $14 in the North and $13 in the South, for a 40-hour week, and the maintenance of all wages above the minimum are provided for in new rules of business procedure for the wool textile industry which have been approved by the directors of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers to replace the NRA code, it was announced yesterday.

Perhaps no tennis match in years has had quite the dramatic quality and human appeal of the meeting of HELEN JACOBS and HELEN WILLS MOODY at Wimbledon. There would have been interest enough if the sole question to be decided was whether Mrs. MOODY, after a nearly two-year layoff from competitive play, could regain her supremacy.

OMAHA, Neb., July 7 (AP). -- An annual income of $2,500 for every American family will be demanded in the platform of the National Farmer-Labor party, Roy M. Harrop, chairman, predicted today. The convention of the party opens tomorrow.

BASLE, July 7. -- Plans to punish the speculators who almost broke the French franc and other gold currencies at the end of May, but were then caught short when the American equalization fund supported the franc were discussed this afternoon by the governors of the big European central banks, here for their monthly meeting at the Bank for International Settlements.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The recent strike of consumers against high-priced beef is reflected in a downward readjustment in cattle prices to the narrowest spread of the season, says The Chicago Drovers Journal in its summary of the meat situation.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 7. -Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion, and James H. Van Alen of Newport, former national court tennis titleholder, won the invitation doubles tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

The greatest struggle of the Christian Church today is against exaggerated nationalism, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, canon of St. John's Cathedral, Providence, R.I., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
BERLIN, July 7 (AP). -- Max Schmeling weighed 192 1/2 pounds and Paulino Uzcudun 203 for their twelve-round fight today.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Leaders in all lines of trade, particularly those affected by extremely hot weather, were well pleased with the volume of business done last week, as well as with that of the six months ended on June 30. On the whole, the volume exceeded that of 1934 by 5 to 10 per cent.
THE NEW YORK TIMES article "Tax Exempt Bonds a Growing Issue" contains the following paragraph:

The trend of the Summer theatres this week is in the general direction of revival. Only seven of them are taking the dubious July chance of trying out new shows, and the remainder are sticking to established successes. The seven full swings follow:

Mrs. Justine Wise Tulin will be sworn in today for a thirty-day term as a justice of the Domestic Relations Court and later will be appointed to succeed Justice Samuel D. Levy, who will retire shortly, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.

While his wife watched from the shore, a father, his 17-year-old son and a friend were drowned yesterday shortly after 4 P.M. in Jamaica Bay near Fresh Creek, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, as the result of a swift tide where they were bathing.
BOSTON, July 7 (AP). -- Northern New England was beset tonight by torrential rains that caused heavy damage.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President Roosevelt's fight with a strong Congressional group over his electric power policies will be renewed tomorrow in all of its fury when administration leaders seek to send his Utility Holding Company Bill to conference in thee Senate and amendments broadening the scope of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act are laid before the rebellious House.

A church that has no place for sinners has no place for Christ, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick Cathedral yesterday morning. He pointed to the "numbers of sinners in the Catholic Church" as one of its most conclusive proofs of being the true church of Christ.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 7. -- In the best sailing breeze of the season, a southerly that swept Long Island Sound into whitecaps, nineteen craft competed today in the special races of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. They led rails down against the wind, which puffed up to twenty-five knots at times.

STOCKHOLM, July 7. -- The three Scandinavian kingdoms, which have been called "the last outposts of sanity in Europe," are being driven to strengthen their defenses and join the world-wide rearmament race as a result of the Anglo-German naval agreement.

Several of the lawyers who are to aid Thomas E. Dewey, special New York County prosecutor, in running down rackets and organized crime, have been selected and have been in conference with him, it was reported yesterday. Their names, however, will not be made public until later in the week, Mr. Dewey adhering to his policy of silence until he has completed his outline of program and has proceeded further in organizing his staff.
" Political Observer," in his letter to THE TIMES, refers to "the cheap Australian and Algerian wines which are frequently fortified with methylated poisonous spirits."
BOSTON, July 7. -- In a heavily guarded downtown vault reposes a two-page document containing a provision of health and happiness for thousands of Boston's neediest more than a century hence.

ROSA E. KING'S "Tempest Over Mexico" (Little, Brown, $3) grows in the reading, starting small and finishing large. The beginning is nothing much. Comments on things seen are gadabout and almost chattery. The inconsequential is superficially observed and with no great care set down. The personality of the author seems unremarkable, her interests narrow and commonplace.

Recent newspaper descriptions tell us how Exterior Street changed its name to Marie Curie Street, with much ceremony under the Major's benediction. This especially interests us who live on Exterior -- a thousand pardons -- Marie Curie Street.

NEW HAVEN, July 6. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number on commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.7, which compares with 81.6 this week before, 82 two weeks before 82.3 three weeks before and 82.'3 four weeks before.

BOSTON, July 7 (AP). -- Sensational base-running by Bill Werber gave the Red Box a thirteen-inning 7-to-6 decision over the Athletics in the first game of a double-header today, but home runs by Higgins and Berry accounted for a 3-to-1 victory for the visitors in the eight-inning second game.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 7 (AP). -- The government's legal forces prepared today for one of the most important of the more than 100 suits aimed at the overthrow of the AAA.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7 (AP). -- Two youthful condemned murderers today made a futile break for liberty from Jefferson County's "escape proof" jail and, as it failed, the elder of the pair committed suicide with a pistol wrested from the warden.

Much of the legislation during the past year has been in the nature of a panacea and has been motivated by selfishness, the Rev. Herbert J. Glover, vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 7. -- This picturesque little village, most famous fishing resort on the Atlantic Coast, once again is the concentration point for the hardy clan of big-game anglers. With swordfish, marlin and tuna roaming the offshore waters, many prominent Eastern sportsmen and sportswomen have checked in at the Montauk Yacht Club, eager for another season of adventure on the high seas.

The depression has left its mark most deeply on the personalities of men, the Rev. Dr. Robbins W. Barstow, president of the Hartford Seminary Foundation, Hartford, Conn., said yesterday morning at the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue at 181st Street.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7. -- Faith in a God who guaranteed comfort is passing, but in the suffering of the depression men are finding "the real God," the Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown of the Union Theological Seminary, New York City, declared tonight at the vesper service inaugurating the second week of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

LIMA, Peru, July 7. -- Some 150 car owners left this morning for Oroya to inspect the new 111-mile central highway opened by President Oscar R. Benavides on July 1. The trip was organized by a touring club.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Security issues totaling $328,039,877.50 were registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week. Of this sum $320,925,147.50 represented new issues. The total is the largest ever filed in one week.

LIMA, Peru, July 7. -- Mrs. H. Gledhill, delicate-appearing 28-year-old English wife of a San Francisco business man, has arrived in Lima after having traversed a considerable part of the South American wilderness with two Indians as her only companions.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 7. -- A ball at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, last night climaxed Independence Week festivities in the Berkshire Hills. More than 200 were present. It had been arranged by the entertainment committee, of which Mrs. Frederick A. Pearson is chairman.

GENEVA, July 7. -- Washington's reply to Ethiopia seems to have made on the whole a rather discouraging impression in League of Nations circles. This is mostly not because of the note itself, but because it is reported to be interpreted in the United States as a refusal to act under the peace pact now or later.

The first all-metal vacuum tubes and all-wave radio receivers designed especially for the new "metallic bulbs" were demonstrated yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before a group of dealers and newspaper men by the General Electric Company.

W. Bernard Vause, former Kings County judge who was paroled Saturday morning from the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta, where he served three and a half years for conspiracy and use of the mails to defraud, returned here last night and said he hoped to obtain a Presidential pardon and resume the practice of law.

Playing errorless ball behind the first-rate hurling of Carl Hubbell, the Giants yesterday came near to convincing 12,000 Polo Grounds fans that their weird performances on Friday and Saturday were just a couple of bad dreams.

Allotment of Federal funds to return to their native lands aliens on the relief rolls who wish to leave the United States was urged by Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel to the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief, in a report on his recent investigation made public yesterday.

VIENNA, July 7. -- At Langenrohr near Tulln today the first monarchist demonstration since the announcement that the anti-Hapsburg laws would be repealed took place. It was held in connection with one of the usual Sunday readings of a letter of thanks from Archduke Otto for nomination as an honorary citizen.
In your editorial "Forty Hours in Production" you say that "if we could all work forty hours per week and still produce the same volume of goods and services as we could in forty-eight hours,"

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP). -- The Phillies today gained a 9-1 triumph over the Braves to win the rubber of a three-game series. It was the Phillies' eleventh triumph in their last fifteen games, and they moved past the Reds into sixth place.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The status of major legislation now before Congress is as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor, has announced that twenty insolvent national banks were liquidated in June and their receiverships closed, making a total of eighty-five receiverships finally closed or restored to solvency since his last annual report to Congress compiled as of Oct. 31, 1934.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 7. -- J.C. (Cab) Walier Jr. of Syracuse successfully defended his New York State outboard championship today and gained permanent possession of the Governor Lehman Trophy that went with the title. It was his third consecutive triumph.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- A petition to discharge the House Appropriations Committee of a joint resolution whereby the veterans' bonus would be paid immediately out of the $4,000,000,000 Work Relief Appropriation Bill will be started in the House tomorrow by Representative Fish of New York, he said in a statement today.

PARIS, July 7. -- Two long conferences this week between Premier Pierre Laval and the British Ambassador, Sir George Clerk, failed to produce any unity of views between Great Britain and France on the Ethiopian question.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 7. -- The powers of parish school boards, including the direct and immediate use of constitutionally dedicated funds from the State, were completely assumed by the State under amendments adopted in the Senate tonight as the upper house was preparing to give its approval shortly after midnight to Senator Huey P. Long's latest group of dictatorial bills.

Together Governor LEHMAN, Justice MCCOOK and Mr. DEWEY are setting the stage for the coming grand jury investigation in a way to command general approval. When the inquiry was first proposed there were some misgivings lest it should be centred on vice, after the fashion of the earlier ventures in Dr. PARKHURST'S day.

In its bearing both on political and financial sentiment, last week's outstanding event was the unexpectedly emphatic revolt of the House of Representatives against the indiscriminate pronouncing, by the Administration's bill, of "death sentence" on all utility holding companies.

Steel operations are expected to rebound to at least 35 per cent of capacity this week, following the drop to 31 per cent during the holiday suspension last week, the magazine Steel says in its weekly summary.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- A large group of Summer residents are interested in the annual fair for St. Philomena's Church, which takes place at Clinton Academy tomorrow afternoon and evening. Mrs. William R. Maloney is chairman.

Another fatality indirectly the result of Fourth of July celebrations was recorded last night when Paul Alesi, 21, of 439 Forbell Avenue, Brooklyn, died in Trinity Hospital of a bullet wound in the abdomen received near his home on the holiday.

Of the more than 11,000 students in the Columbia University Summer session, only 2,000 are enrolled from New York City. Among the remaining thousands practically every State in the Union is represented -- the Middle West by increasing numbers and the South by a large contingent.

In his dispatch about the change of the once conservative Senate into "sons of the wild jackass" and the once maverick House into what he calls "the more reliable and thoughtful branch," Arthur Krock dates, approximately, the time of the change.

Charging that there is a well defined movement to penalize big industrial units to a point which not only would prevent further growth, but also would break down their present corporate structures, The Lamp, official organ of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, says in its current issue that such a policy "is one of the least understandable of the cure-alls for the maladjustment of our economic position."

PARIS, July 6. -- Stiffening of the forward premium on pounds and dollar this week was caused by renewed anxiety over the domestic political situation when it became known that the Radical party had decided, with the approval of Edouard Herriot, to join with the Socialists and Communists on July 14 in a mass meeting to protest against the so-called Fascist danger to the republic.

Dan O'Mahoney will risk his recently acquired world's wrestling championship for the first time when he tackles Chief Little Wolf of Albuquerque, N. M., in a finish contest at the Yankee Stadium tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7. -- Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt was born a few years after her father, James Graham Fair, had become famous as one of the "Big Four" -- the discoverers of the Comstock Lode, which took a vast fortune in silver out of the Nevada mountains.

BERLIN, July 7. -- Max Schmeling, former world heavyweight champion, pounded his way through twelve rounds to a point victory over Paulino Uzcudun of Spain today in the Volksstadium before a crowd estimated at 50,000. It was the third time they had met.

ALL aboard for Cleveland and the big baseball party. It's the third carnival coming up and the National Leaguers are two down. Messrs. Frisch and Cochrane, the all-star pickers, are having a warm time dodging questions hurled in their direction. The all-star slate, as made up by the rival managers, has many fans filing vigorous minority reports.
BERLIN, July 6. -- The week's industrial reports and bank reviews serve to substantiate the belief that business recovery in Germany is continuing to slow down.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Black rust has appeared in parts of South Dakota and Eastern North Dakota, with some reported in the northwestern section of the latter State. It has been found also in Western Nebraska. The Spring wheat crop is from one to two weeks late in most sections and in some parts it is three weeks late.

The arrival from Europe today of Samuel Seabury, the city's chief transit adviser, is expected to result this week in the renewal of conferences between representatives of the city and of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in unification negotiations.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 7. -- Trailing, 8 to 6, early in the final period, the South Shore polo quartet staged a spectacular four-goal rally to defeat the Vipers, 10 to 8, today on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club in the opening match of the annual Wheatley Cups tourney for nine-goal teams.

Another third-party movement has got started and perhaps stymied at Chicago, all in a few days. A group of intellectuals and a scattering of practical office-holding politicians, supposed to come from more than thirty States, met, and the intellectuals got down to work with great ardor.
The first joint meeting in 108 years of the two branches of the Quaker Church in this city was held yesterday morning in the house of the Religious Society of Friends at 144 East Twentieth Street.

LONDON, July 5. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Wednesday at 67.5. This compares with 68.1 a fortnight before, 68.1 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

In a letter made public yesterday the Port of New York Authority and other port interests of the North Atlantic seaboard have pledged support to the Eastern railroads in the elimination of rate differentials to Southern ports. The letter, addressed to the Traffic Executives Association and sent to D.T. Lawrence, chairman, refers to the new tariffs recently filed on unboxed automobiles from Detroit, Pontiac, Flint and other points in Central Freight Association territory.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7. -- The observance of "Veterans' Day" by the Seventy-first Infantry and the 212th Coast Artillery, both of Manhattan, combined with a review of the provisional brigade by Brig. Gen. John J. Byrne, commander of the headquarters and headquarters detachment, coast artillery of Manhattan, attracted between 8,000 and 9,000 visitors to Camp Smith today.

HAVANA, July 7 (AP). -- The Cuban Navy announced today it had located the missing Canadian ketch Casarco, which has been drifting in distress for nine days with five persons aboard, including an ill mother and two children. All aboard the Casarco are alive, a navy vessel reported. It was found near Corrientes Point.

KASSEL, Germany, July 7 (AP). -Soldiers of the Kaiser's old army separated in a happy mood tonight after setting a new mark in German military history. But they went home making sly remarks about the antquity of the demonstration the new army put on for them.
Although finishing third in a race held yesterday by the Bayside Y.C: off Execution Light, Ace, sailed by Adrian Iselin 2d, clinched the championship of the Western Long Island Sound Star fleet.

The problems of those standing at the threshold of life are something that we must contend with at the present time, the Right Rev. Dr. Warren L. Rogers, Episcopal Bishop of Ohio, said yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 7. -- Steel producers regard demand as relatively well sustained, though this is by tradition the dullest period of the year. Because of the holiday production last week was not a measure of demand, since the break caused by the holiday raises costs and producers aimed to run as few units as possible.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Corn needs warm, dry weather to push it along more rapidly, as recent heavy rains and moderate temperatures have restricted growth. Corn specialists say that with good growing weather there is plenty of time to raise a large crop. There is a feeling in the trade that corn futures are a sale on sharp advances.
Unemployment has been virtually wiped out in the rural districts of Nova Scotia, A. Sterling MacMillan, the Province's Minister of Highways, reported yesterday on his arrival from Yarmouth.

New Yorkers received a slight respite yesterday in the heat wave that has gripped the city for three days. The high for the day, 82 degrees at 11:15 A.M., was made less oppressive by a fresh southerly wind that reached a velocity of thirty-four miles an hour at 4 P.M. Saturday's and Friday's highs were 87.7 degrees and 87.2, respectively.

DANBURY, Conn., July 7. -- Cervantes, Kentucky-bred thoroughbred by Spanish Prince II and out of Nona Marie, today gained his second hunter championship of the outdoor season for Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver of Westport, Conn.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 7. -- An early arrest of the three armed and masked thugs who held up five golfers on the Ridgewood Country Club links yesterday, wounding one player, was promised today by Harry B. Lockwood, chief of the detective bureau of the Bergen County Prosecutor's office.
BOSTON, July 7. -- Mrs. Helen Billings, 68, and her daughter, Miss Constance Billings, 40, who were killed in California today, lived at 23 Pond View Avenue, in the Jamaica Plain section.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Seabury are due today from Europe on the French liner Normandie. Others on board are Luigi Pirandello, Italian dramatist and novelist; Lammot du Pont, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Pendergast, Hassard Short, theatrical producer, and:

PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- The growing impermanence of the American home was ascribed here today at one of the closing sessions of the International Christian Endeavor Convention to the failure of youth to realize that "no home can survive on bread and cheese and kisses."

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP). -- Ted Lyons shut out the Indians, 2 -- 0, for Chicago's seventh straight victory and Cleveland's eighth defeat in a row today, but the Indians came back in the second game of the double-header before 30,000 and broke both streaks with a 7-6 triumph.
DETROIT, July 7 (AP). -- The Tigers conquered the Browns, 12 to 5, today to score a sweep in the St. Louis series and extending their consecutive victories to ten.

Three cumbersome meteorites that weigh about 108,000 pounds and are valued as museum specimens at $10,000,000 will be moved this week on steel trucks from the Seventy-seventh Street foyer of the American Museum of Natural History to the new Hayden Planetarium on Eighty-first Street near Central Park West.

LONDON, July 7. -- The British diplomatic position at this writing, some three weeks after the naval accord with Germany, is being likened to the case of the man who in state of exaltation jumped out of a second-story window. He was not killed, but later when an acquaintance met him in the street on crutches and his face wreathed in adhesive plaster he was a sad sight.

MOSCOW, July 7. -- Such favorable reports of this year's Russian grain crops continue to reach Moscow that qualified foreign observers now believe that the total harvest may be as much as 10,000,000 to 15,000,000 metric tons higher than last year's [a metric ton is the equivalent of 2,204.6 pounds].

A strike of elevator operators and other building service employes in the Bronx appeared likely this week as a result of the refusal yesterday of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League to abide by any agreement that may be reached between the Building Service Employes Union and real estate groups fn the Bronx.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 7. -- An aggressive Long Island polo team, which tallied in every period and led all the way, turned back Aknusti, composed of the four Gerry brothers, 12 to 7, before 1,000 spectators today in the weekly match at Bostwick Field.

The upward movement in cotton futures last week reached the highest level since the break on the NRA decision at the end of May. On Friday, however, they declined sharply, but in the closing session on Saturday they recovered part of this loss.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. John T. Smith gave a large buffet supper tonight at Certosa, their place in Ox Pasture

Fourteen Negro baseball players and two women accompanying them in a motor truck bound for Fair Haven, N.J., were injured at Eleventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street yesterday afternoon in a collision between the truck and a passenger car.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 (AP). -- The Cubs defeated the Pirates, 13 to 1, today to make it two out of three for the series. The Bruins made 14 hits, six of them doubles, off four Pirate hurlers.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 7. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. plans to spend his ninety-sixth birthday tomorrow quietly on his 500-acre estate on the Lakewood-Point Pleasant Highway surrounded only by his closest relatives.

When the Ways and Means Committee begins hearings today on a new tax bill it will of course invite Secretary MORGENTHAU to present the Treasury's point of view. This will give him an opportunity to amplify his last statement on the subject of taxation. It was made in April, when the fight over the soldiers' bonus was approaching its climax.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. John T. Smith gave a large buffet supper tonight at Certosa, their place in Ox Pasture

Fourteen Negro baseball players and two women accompanying them in a motor truck bound for Fair Haven, N.J., were injured at Eleventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street yesterday afternoon in a collision between the truck and a passenger car.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A request that he make representations to Mexico over the alleged persecution of Catholics in that country was put before President Roosevelt today by a delegation of prominent members of the Knights of Columbus.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- President Roosevelt approved work relief grants for eight projects for New York, conferred with Premier Lyons of Australia on a possible tariff treaty and proclaimed a trade agreement with Sweden. He was urged by a Knights of Columbus delegation to make representations to Mexico on the religious situation and accepted an invitation to address the Young Democratic Convention in Milwaukee in late August, if conditions here permitted.

Six Manhattan properties and three in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Six of the parcels were five-story flats. The tallest structure was a nine-story tenement in Eldridge Street, near Hester Street.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. is planning to oppose the city's plan to take over by condemnation four blocks of his property in Harlem for a $4,700,000 PWA housing project, it was reported yesterday.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 8. -- More than 500 striking employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation marched to the City Hall today and waited outside in a parking lot while their leaders conferred with W. Gentry Hodgson, Camden County relief director.

The Treasury announced yesterday its first financing of the new fiscal year. It consists of an offer of $500,000,000 in 1 3/8 per cent notes, maturing in 1939. The low rate of interest to be paid reflects the present ease of credit and continues the trend toward lower rates which has now been in progress for two years.

LONDON, July 8. -- The stock markets here were generally quiet today because of uncertainty on wheat and silver. British funds weakened because of lack of support. French and German issues were easier in the foreign market. Among industrials, Hawkers was easier on the formation of the new Hawker Siddeley Aircraft; other aircrafts were lower in sympathy.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., July 8. -- Mrs. H. Laurence Dowd heads a committee that is preparing for the Guild Hall Players benefit performance of Holbrook Blinn's, "The Bad Man," at Guild Hall Theatre, on Friday night. The other members are Mrs. Frank P. Shepard, Mrs. Victor Harris, Mrs. Shepard Krech, Miss Ruth B. Morna, Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey and Mrs. William R. Maloney.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Grants of $2,566,225 in work-relief funds for eight projects in New York were approved by President Roosevelt today, the grants representing 45 per cent of the total cost.

Prices of foods, clothing and coal declined sufficiently from May to the end of June to offset a rise in rents and sundry expenses, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board which will be issued today. The board estimated that the living cost of industrial wage-earners went down .2 per cent in June as compared with the May level.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
CLEVELAND, July 8. -- They were slapping backs in the American League dressing room after today's all-star game, but over in the National circuit's shower room they were slapping back.

Supreme Court Justice Schmuck denied yesterday an application by Frank C. Smith, a traffic policeman, to compel Police Commissioner Valentine to grant him leave of absence of sixteen days with pay because he is senior captain of Battery 305 of the Field Artillery of the State Militia and as a Reserve officer has been ordered to attend manoeuvres at Madison Barracks, N.Y., between July 27 and Aug. 9.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- An effort to reach an adjustment of reorganization plans for the Western Pacific Railroad will be made by Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at a conference in New York Wednesday with Thomas Schumacher, trustee of the road, and representatives of the bondholders.

England, still expecting every man to do his duty, has for the third time put her affairs in the hands of a party leader who likes to wear his old clothes. Mr. BALDWIN, who smokes a pipe and therefore thinks reasonably, wishes that he could change into an old suit and watch a cricket game.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Peter Grimm, president of William A. White Son of New York and an expert on real estate, will soon be named an assistant to Secretary Morgenthau, and will make a study of real estate loans in which the government has participated, it was reported today.
The city had another oppressive day yesterday as high humidity offset the cooling comfort of fresh southwest winds.

Track's newest and most sensational rivalry -- that between Eulace Peacock and Jesse Owens -- will be renewed at New York University's Ohio Field this evening when the country's leading athletes engage in an all-star meet patterned along the lines of the Princeton invitation affair.

Production of steel ingots in the United States in June amounted to 2,230,893 gross tons, or 404,964 tons less than in May and the lowest for any month this year it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. In June, 1934, the output was 3,059,483 tons.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8. -- The City Council was ordered today by President Judge Finletter of Common Pleas Court 4 to add $7,667,025.04 to the city budget for 1935 as an appropriation to the sinking funds for retirement of debt.
LONDON, July 8. -- Disappointed? Well, yes. Discouraged? Emphatically no.

An offering of $48,000,000 of first-mortgage twenty-year 4 per cent sinking-fund bonds of Armour Co. of Delaware, Series B, due on Aug. 1, 1955, will be made today at 98 1/4 and accrued interest by a syndicate consisting of Kuhn, Loeb Co., the First Boston Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., Blyth Co., Inc.; the Lee Higginson Corporation and associates.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- People from this city return from New York and Chicago, from Southampton, Newport, Lake Forest and Burlingame these days with their eyes bulging. It is the silly season for stories about the President. But it is notable that such stories are always brought from where the President does not live and work to where he does.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that the report of the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief sounded like history to him, though he had had no opportunity to read it fully.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 8. -- Dr. and Mrs. Frank A. Calderone of Westbury, with four guests and Captain John Hamilton, narrowly escaped death at 4:20 o'clock this morning when their fifty-eight-foot yacht Lorelei, a two-masted auxiliary schooner valued at more than $50,000, burst into flames and sank in Long Island Sound, seven miles from shore, northeast of Eaton's Neck Point.

The new French liner Normandie docked at 5:30 P.M. yesterday after her third westward voyage from Havre. The ship had anchored off Quarantine before noon, but the ebb tide and a strong southeasterly wind made Captain Rene Pugnet decide to delay the docking.

The list of the Italian liner Rex sailing today with 1,845 passengers for Mediterranean ports includes Mgr. Filippo Bernardini, Apostolic Delegate to Australia, Judge and Mrs. Hugh M. Morris, J. Robert Rubin, vice president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and Mrs. Rubin; Miss Amy E. du Pont and Mrs. Henry Clews.

PARIS, July 8. -- Elaborate preparations have been made and will be approved by the Cabinet tomorrow for the preservation of order in the streets of Paris next Sunday, July 14, when the Right and the Left political factions of the country will seek to turn the national holiday in celebration of the capture of the Bastile into a political demonstration to their advantage.

The names of 196 young men who have been selected to attend the Citizens' Military Training Camp at Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook, N.J., were announced yesterday by Major General Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area. The period of training will begin Aug. 1 and end Aug. 30.

VIENNA, July 8. -- Amalgamation of the Fascist Heimwehr and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's Clerical Ostmaerkischer Sturmscharen will be decreed within a few days, your correspondent learns, in an effort to end the rivalry between the organizations.
A suit on behalf of 23,000 Insull investors seeking to recover about $30,000,000 in the Federal court here was dismissed yesterday by Judge Julian W. Mack.

LONDON, July 8. -- Indications emerged in the House of Commons today that part of the alibi the British will offer if they abandon Ethiopia to Italian conquest will be that that country is, after all, only a barbarous, slavery-infested country unworthy of League of Nations membership and of support by other League members.
NEW ORLEANS, July 8. -- Senator Huey P. Long, in a radio speech here tonight, called President Roosevelt "a liar and a faker" and defied "them" to "indict me for that."

MOSCOW, July 8. -- The first half of 1935, the period in which the often postponed congress of the Communist International was at last scheduled to be held, is now passed. The congress has not been held. No reliable information is available when it will be held or even whether it will ever be held.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Supporting his argument with forty-five pounds of maps and detailed drawings and documents, Mayor La Guardia filed today with Secretary Roper the first application for permission to operate a "free port of entry."

While General Hugh S. Johnson, Federal Works Progress Administrator for New York City, continued to study the relief situation yesterday and pleaded for more time before proceeding to put 250,000 unemployed men and women to work under the new Federal program, Mayor La Guardia sent him seventy new work projects calling for an expenditure of $172,583,521.
