ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 8. -- A new scientific method for measuring the network of nerves in the human eye for positive identification of criminals who have their faces altered by plastic surgery and who destroy their fingerprints with third-degree burns is to be outlined here tomorrow by Dr. Carleton Simon before the convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police.

BERLIN, July 8. -- The Boerse was firm today, although not particularly active. The opening was weak, because of realization selling. Heavy industrials were mixed. Machines were mixed, with Orenstein Koppel gaining 1/2 point. Chemicals were quiet.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Conditional acceptance by President Roosevelt of an invitation to address the annual convention of the Young Democrats of America at Milwaukee on Aug. 23 was announced today.

Representative JOHN RANKIN of Tupelo, Miss., that paradise of municipal utilities, is not merely the hammer of holding companies. He marches down to posterity arm in arm with Senator NORRIS, TVA blazoned on each illustrious bosom. Night and day he shouts his beneficent slogan: "Let's light every farm home in America."

CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Before the largest crowd ever attracted to an all-star game, the American League today scored its easiest victory over the picked stars of the National League since the annual fixture was started in 1933.

In a letter to The Herald Tribune Senator BORAH utters a cry of alarm about next year's Presidential campaign. He has heard rumors -- as have others, for that matter -- that a Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States may be nominated for the Presidency in 1936.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 8. -- Miss Margaret Jordan, a 22-year-old domestic, committed suicide early this morning by shooting herself with the service revolver of a policeman after he informed her their friendship was over. A few hours before he had taken her to see the motion picture, "Love Me Forever."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The Park Department announced yesterday that its wheelchair service in the Central Park Zoo, by means of which crippled children may view the animals, is now in operation.

Dan O'Mahoney was successful in his first defense of the world's heavyweight wrestling championship. The 22-year-old Irishman defeated Little Wolf of Trinidad, Col., in 28 minutes 23 seconds at the Yankee Stadium last night while a crowd of 12,000 persons looked on.

LONDON, July 8. -- On the eve of the Labor party's vote to censure the government for its alleged failure to deal effectively with the problem of unemployment, it is officially announced that the total of Great Britain's jobless dropped yesterweek to the lowest level in five years.

The 102 properties in Series C-2 mortgage certificates guaranteed by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, representing $24,348,726.48, earned in twenty-one months ending April 30. $587,238.17 in excess of operating costs and taxes, or a yield of 1.385 per cent for the 7,496 certificate holders, according to testimony yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 8. -- With the business section of this city encrusted with an inch and a half layer of mud and debris, municipal officials and rescue agencies rushed efforts this afternoon to care for flood refugees driven from their homes by the worst inundation in the history of the area.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 8. -- Raging waters of the Tioughnioga and Chenango Rivers poured the worst flood since 1865 upon a wide area in the Southern Tier of New York counties today.

SKOWHEGAN, Me., July 8. -- The story of a schoolboy's devotion to his teacher is related in a prologue, three acts and an epilogue by Philo Higley and Philip Dunning in "Remember the Day," which the Lakewood players presented tonight for the first time anywhere.

Business men and corporations that, in the period of the unconstitutional NRA codes, were fined and imprisoned for so-called violations of the State Schackno Enabling Law can have the stigma removed merely by a motion in Special Sessions.
LONDON, July 8. -- Premier Mussolini of Italy is not afraid that any power or group of powers can prevent his carrying out his plan for the conquest of Ethiopia.

All seeded contestants progressed as play in the Greater New York junior and boys' net tournament opened at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. The starting field of ninety-one was greatly reduced.

Nothing in Secretary MORGENTHAU'S testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee helped to answer the question of why it has suddenly become so imperative that new tax schedules be rushed through in the present Summer session instead of being quietly studied and submitted to Congress in the Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Advances to the Commodity Credit Corporation of $97,157,503.25 for the regular June financing of loans on cotton accounted for the bulk of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's $119,399,445.77 authorizations and commitments in June, the corporation report showed today.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- Record-breaking attendance, surprisingly good first-day orders and firm prices characterized the opening of the two midsummer furniture exhibitions here today.

Sales of General Motors passenger and commercial cars to dealers and consumers increased sharply last month, following the decline in May caused by the strike at Toledo, according to figures issued yesterday. Sales in June to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 181,188 units, compared with 146,881 in June, 1934, and 134,597 in May, 1935.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Cooperating wheat producers will receive about $14,000,000 more under the 1935 AAA program than in 1934, getting benefit payments of at least 33 cents a bushel, as compared with 29 cents provided by the 1934 contracts under minimum adjustment returns established today by Secretary Wallace.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8. -- Without "substantial" financial relief, the internationally famous Westchester County recreation program, which includes operation of the County Centre here, will "disintegrate," E. Dana Caulkins, superintendent of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, declares in the commission's 1934 annual report.

The President's new Youth Project is interesting and commendable. The three last objectives appear fairly easy of attainment as long as the government has sufficient funds to pay for them. The question arises about the first objective: "To find employment in private industry for unemployed youth."

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- John Dickinson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce since April 15, and one of the early "Brain Trusters," will resign soon, according to reports, to become Assistant Attorney General in charge of the anti-trust division.

Nearly 3,000 children are expected to attend the fourteen Summer Play Schools conducted by the Child Study Association of America, which were opened yesterday in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. The schools will be in session every weekday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. for the next seven or eight weeks.

Sponsors Contend It Is a Game of Skill -- Inspector Seery Awaits McAuliffe Report. Injunction proceedings against the police were threatened yesterday by Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., the president of which is Mrs. Oliver Harriman.

In response to many requests Jose Iturbi will augment the pianistic part of his performance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra tomorrow night at the Lewisohn Stadium with three solos by Spanish composers. He also will be heard in Grieg's concerto, which he will conduct and play the piano part simultaneously.
NANKING, China, Tuesday, July 9 (AP). -- China's "Dragon River," the mighty Yangtse, ate a path of death and destruction today through a huge area, inhabited by many millions.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Oliver Buswell Jr., president of Wheaton (Ill.) College, won a victory today in his trial on charges of resisting Presbyterian Church authority when the Judicial Commission of the Chicago Presbytery dismissed a hearing on his case.

As chemical warfare goes, the new invention by the Italian Army for use against the Abyssinians is almost humane. It is a corrosive fluid for sprinkling on the ground over which the barefooted warriors of HAILE SELASSIE may be expected to charge.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 8. -- Debutantes of this and recent seasons as well as several young matrons in the Summer colony have entered the competition for the Babcock and Fox Cups in the annual Meadow Club tennis tournament, the draw for which was completed today.

More than 500 girls are expected to attend the three Summer day-camps which will be opened today by the Manhattan Council of Girl Scouts in cooperation with the Park Department and various welfare agencies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8. -- Surrogate George A. Slater of Westchester County, in a decision filed today, upholds the will of Miss Lillian Emma Kimball, formerly of New Rochelle, who left the residue of her $40,000 estate to Barnard College.

Floods from Sunday's unrelenting downpour swept through up-State New York counties yesterday. A toll of thirty-seven persons dead and seven missing, with damage to buildings and bridges, roads, highways and crops believed to exceed $10,000,000, was counted last night as aid for the stricken areas was mobilized.

LONDON, July 8. -- Apparent modification in the operation of the United States silver program in conjunction with sales on behalf of Indian and other Eastern speculators caused a further break in silver here today. It is believed the boom has collapsed temporarily, perhaps permanently.

Walter J.M. Donovan, broker and real estate owner, of Greenwich, Conn., who died Jan. 3, 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,675,729 gross. He owned real estate in the Bronx and Westchester County worth $3,492,600, against which there were mortgages of $2,521,450.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Secretary Morgenthau's statement prepared for the Ways and Means Committee's hearing on tax legislation was as follows:

HAWORTH, N.J., July 8. -- The two-year reign of the Orcutts in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association sister-brother championship was ended today at White Beeches, when Miss Alice and Hugo Rutherford of Baltusrol scored a 75 to win the title.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 8. -- Illumination of the ocean off Bermuda at a depth of half a mile is hoped for as the result of experiments with a beam of ultraviolet light which Dr. William Beebe is conducting at his laboratory here with Herbert Strong, New York color engineer.

Under the caption "Diluted Liquor" Professor Yandell Henderson of Yale University, describing himself as a "scientific expert," advocates the dilution of spirits from approximately 50 per cent to 16 per cent, as "an effective measure to combat bootlegging."

The congress of the International Chamber of Commerce ended its session in Paris last month and again the business leaders of the world agreed that in order to revive international trade it was essential, among other things, to lower tariff barriers.

Father Knickerbocker gave more than 700 mothers and their children from the tenement districts of the East Side and the West Side a special treat yesterday when the municipal ferryboat Queens took them on the first of a series of Summer excursion trips up the Hudson and around New York Harbor for five hours.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 9. -- The decision by central bank governors during their monthly meeting at Basle to act in common if there should be the slightest sign of a new attack on the currency of any country represented in the Bank for International Settlements has caused considerable discussion here.

Consumers of steel in Toledo, Ohio, have issued a protest through the Toledo Chamber of Commerce against alleged discrimination of manufacturers in Pittsburgh against their city and in favor of Detroit in the price of steel. The protest has been filed in the form of a brief with the producers.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 8. -- "Swordfish to port!" cries Captain Owen Duffy.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP). -- Mid Victorian, a speedy daughter of Victorian from Mrs. Silas Mason's barns, left six other 3-year-old fillies far behind in the Oakton Purse at Arlington Park today.

It is difficult for any one who watched Mr. STRYKER conduct the aldermanic relief inquiry to comment impartially on his report. It was not a spectacle to edify the community. "Our sole function," he now declares, "was "to present the facts in so far as we "could ascertain them."

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 8. -- For the first time since the Eastern Yacht Club cruise started, the two Class M boats carried off the honors today on corrected time, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Prestige winning and Waiter K. Shaw's Andiamo placing second.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The acreage of cotton under cultivation on July 1 was 29,166,000 as compared with 27,883,000 a year ago, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today.

Railroad offices here reported yesterday an almost complete stoppage of service in the area north and west of Elmira, where the up-State storm was most severe. The main lines of the Erie and Lehigh Valley and the Lackawanna's main line to Buffalo were closed to traffic all day yesterday because of washouts.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Possibilities of negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement with Australia were uppermost as President Roosevelt conferred today with J.A. Lyons, Prime Minister of that Commonwealth, who arrived from New York with Mrs. Lyons this afternoon on his way home from the Silver Jubilee in London.

Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes charged yesterday the American-La France Fire Engine Company with maintaining a lobby which had exercised influence on public officials in an effort to have the company's fire apparatus bought by the city.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A confused picture of division of authority, jealousies and administrative cross-purposes was unfolded today by two witnesses before the special Senate committee investigating charges of maladministration in the Virgin Islands.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 8. -- Europe's principal central bankers take a serious view of the effects of Premier Mussolini's Ethiopian policy on the rest of the world politically and especially economically and monetarily. Their informal exchanges of news and views while they were here today for the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements left no doubt of this.

An expedition to study the Asabela Indians in the Upper Amazon Valley and to bring back ethnological specimens to the Museum of the American Indian (Heye Foundation), will leave New York in early August to be gone for a year or more, it was announced yesterday.

Net profit of the New York Hanseatic Corporation for the first half of 1935 amounted to $75,590. After paying $40,000 in dividends, the surplus stood at $639,800 on June 30, comparing with $604,209 on Dec. 31, 1934.

Jockey Robert Jones, the lad who was so seriously injured at Saratoga a year ago that some thought he might not ride again, scored a double at the Empire City meeting yesterday when he was first with Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Gleeman, and then topped matters with a score on Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment in the feature.

The residuary estate of the late Joseph Pulitzer, newspaper publisher, held in trust for his seventeen grandchildren, was valued at $5,585,729.39 as of May 31, 1934, in an accounting filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court by the trustees.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A reference by Senator Schall, Republican, of Minnesota, to President Roosevelt as "this megalomaniac President" was stricken from the Congressional record today by Senate leaders.

Continued hot weather spurred turnover of Summer merchandise in local stores yesterday, continuing the sharp increase in volume noted last week. Business in main floor, sports and beach wear and vacation item departments was excellent. Re-orders reaching manufacturers from out-of-town stores indicated that substantial gains were made by most retailers last week and that retail stocks of seasonal goods are at a low point.

Reorganization proceedings that followed defaults of Commonwealth Bond Corporation securities resulted in the loss of equities to thousands of investors, the Congressional committee investigating real estate reorganizations was told yesterday at the resumption of its public hearings in the County Court House.

GARNERVILLE, N.Y., July 8. -- Every road leading into this village is picketed tonight by outposts of an army of more than 500 local residents, who have announced they will prevent union workers from New York City from entering the Hirsam knit and sportswear factory located in the Haverstraw industrial terminal.

The Fokine Ballet opened its second pair of performances at the Stadium last night with a program of three ballets composed by Michel Fokine. They were the "Scheherazade" of Imperial Ballet fame; "The Sorcerer's Apprentice," to the well-known tone-poem of Dukas, and "The Elves," set to Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream" overture and the Andante and Allegro from his violin concerto.

MOSCOW, July 8. -- The government of the Mongolian People's Republic (Outer Mongolia) has sent a conciliatory reply to Japanese-Manchukuoan demands in an obvious effort to avoid a crisis threatening as a result of the arrest of a Japanese Army officer and a White Russian who was in his company near the Mongolian-Manchukuoan frontier on June 23.

CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Worried by his responsibility, Manager Mickey Cochrane of the American League All Stars went into conference with a retired planet just before the battle. Said Manager Mickey to Babe Ruth, "Do you think it will rain?" Said Babe Ruth, "By golly, I hope not." "Thanks," said Manager Cochrane.

BERLIN, July 8. -- Walter Rothenburg, the Hamburg boxing promoter who staged the Max Schmeling-Steve Hamas fight and hopes to become the Tex Rickard of Europe and possibly his successor in world boxing affairs, is in Amsterdam trying to arrange a Schmeling-Baer fight there.

ATLANTA, July 8. -- Indictments will be sought before a grand jury based on the story of an 11-year-old Rossville, Ga., girl who said in the juvenile court today that her father sold her into marriage for $125.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The "rough rider" cavalry tests of three decades ago were ordered applied in modern fashion today to the Army Air Corps.
CLEVELAND, July 8. -- The play-by-play description of the all-star game at the Municipal Stadium today follows:

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 8. -- Headed by Frank Parker, fourth ranking player of the country and the defending cup holder, a field of sixty will start out tomorrow in the annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 3 shows decreases for the week of $160,000,000 in total loans and investments, $42,000,000 in time deposits, $302,000,000 in government deposits and $193,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and an increase of $91,000,000 in net demand deposits.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 8. -- Darwin's sophistication proceeds apace. The tropical capital of Northern Territory now has a golf course. The course was cut out of the jungle by aboriginal prisoners.

The titles of the first eight pictures to be produced this season by the newly formed Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation were announced here yesterday just before the departure for the Coast of Sidney R. Kent, president of the corporation; Joseph M. Schenck, chairman; Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president, and William Goetz, member-producer.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A further extension until July 20 for the filing of financial statements by corporations, for securities registered on the Stock Exchanges under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, in cases where a previous extension had been accorded, was announced today by the SEC.

Otto Wallace Walter, 42 years old, of 24 Buena Vista Drive, Hastings-on-Hudson, an Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering at City College, was injured fatally in an automobile accident early Sunday evening on the Saw Mill River Road between Briarcliff and Hawthorne, it was learned yesterday.

Apparently the Shuberts are going heavy for musical shows this coming season. Latest reports are that J.J. Shubert of the firm, who already is down on the lists for considerable activity in that line, has acquired through the office of Laura D. Wilck yet another -- this one called "The Splendid Hour," with book by Houston Branch and score by Charles Wakefield Cadman.

A small, brown Rhesus monkey, apparently trying to escape the confusion, heat and humidity of the midtown area yesterday after-further harassed yesterday afternoon when it entered the window of the Terminal Beauty Salon on the mezzanine floor of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 8. -- Under the headline. "Russia's new seafront," Admiral von Schoultz, who for many years was in charge of Finland's naval defense and regarded as a great expert on North European maritime affairs, has published an article dealing on the new Russian naval establishments in the Arctic Ocean and the White Sea, and the large canal connections with the Baltic and the Arctic.

The development of aeronautics has completely reversed conditions necessary to foment war, it was declared yesterday by Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, World War flier and head of Eastern Air Lines, before more than 150 members of the Sales Executive Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The share market yesterday appeared to throw off some of the restraint under which it labored during most of last week; trading on the Stock Exchange, totaling 1,309,000, was the heaviest since June 21, and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks advanced a little more than a point to within 30 cents of the high point for the year thus far established on June 24.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 (AP). -- Twelve women of the San Francisco Bay region who have been taking dinitrophenol, the newly developed anti-fat drug, have been stricken with temporary blindness in recent months, it was disclosed here today by Dr. Loren Chandler, dean of the Stanford University Medical School.

CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Opening the Republican Crusaders' conference today, George H. Bender, as permanent chairman, denounced the regulars for refusing to cooperate in reviving the party, declared in that the organization opposed advancing Mr. Hoover's candidacy and condemned Roosevelt policies.

BATH, N.Y., July 8. -- Twenty hours of rain ended here at 4 P.M. today, leaving this community of 5,000 persons and other parts of Steuben County paralyzed after causing a heavy loss of livestock and considerable damage to crops and property.

Following the publication of my letter protesting against the excessively high dwelling rentals charged the 300,000 families on relief rolls, I have received a letter from the owner of a tenement house offering to give me the building if I will pay off the mortgage and back taxes.

A sudden tightening helped the bond market on the Stock Exchange throw off some of its earlier trading losses yesterday and prices rallied from the low levels of the day. Closing prices, however, were irregular. Trading continued on a somewhat limited scale, with transactions amounting to $9,272,900 as compared with $9,841,000 on last Friday.
BERLIN, July 8. -- The German Admiralty announced tonight a total naval construction program for this year of two 26,000-ton battleships, two 10,000-ton cruisers and twenty-eight submarines.

Trading on the local commodity future markets was mixed and generally dull yesterday. Sugars were sharply lower, while most other leading staples were slightly firmer. On the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, lead and tin advanced, the least to the year's high point, while corn, cotton and rubber declined.

But for a certain difference in the pictures displayed, it might have seemed yesterday that Greenwich Village had moved one of its periodical outdoor art exhibits right up to the Bronx. Tacked along a fence opposite Public School 55, at St. Paul's Place and Washington Avenue, were dozens of paintings and crayon sketches showing all the variety of a grown-ups' art show, though they had been done by children.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 8. -- Samuel Reshevsky of New York, winner of the international tournaments at Syracuse and Margate, triumphed today in his first match in the major open tournament at the annual congress of the British Chess Federation.

LONDON, July 8 (AP). -- A team comparatively inexperienced in international competition but captained by the veteran, Charley Whitcombe, was selected today to represent Great Britain against the United States in the Ryder Cup golf matches at Ridgewood, N.J., Sept. 28 and 29.
The opening sentence of a news item which appeared in your paper on July 4 read:

The Home Owners' Loan Corporation is preparing to take over in foreclosure a number of dwellings in New York State because of delinquencies in payments on refinanced mortgages, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Declaring that the worst of the depression was past and that the time had come to consider curtailment of government borrowing and reduction of the public debt, Secretary Morgenthau expressed before the Ways and Means Committee today a firm conviction that the new Roosevelt tax plans would not impose burdens that would retard business revival.
Money market was colorless. Despite increased activity in stocks, demand for new funds was light and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP). -- Fifteen swimming and diving stars, the cream of the contestants in the national A.A.U. championships which close last night, began training today under Coach Robert Kiphuth of Yale University to represent the United States in a three-day international match with the best natators of Japan.
Liberalization of its policy in regard to earnings of any member of a household other than the head of the family was announced yesterday by the Home Relief division of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8. -- By disposing of an issue of $75,000,000 of short-term State notes today at a net interest rate of 35-100 of 1 per cent, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, again broke his own financing record for New York State.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8. -- Engaging in 347 contests during the past college year, fifty-three different Princeton athletic teams won 219 times for a percentage of .631, it was announced today by the university athletic association. Losses were sustained 122 times and tie games resulted on six occasions.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP). -- Imperial Betsy was first in the featured fifth race at the Detroit track today as the fans celebrated Getaway Day. The victor returned $54.60 for $2 to win, $20.20 to place and $10.80 to show. Rizla was second and Kyso third.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 8. -- Secluded behind the high iron fence of his estate on Ocean Avenue, John D. Rockefeller passed his ninety-sixth birthday today with no evidence to the outside world that the occasion was being marked by a celebration of any kind.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Officials of the National Gypsum Company and the Universal Gypsum and Lime Company continued today to maintain silence on reports of agreement on a plan to effect a merger through an exchange of stock. It was believed, however, that Universal may make a statement late this week, when a report of earnings will be forwarded to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The House vested broadened inquisitorial powers in its Rules Committee today on the eve of its investigation into alleged attempts of administration and power company representatives improperly to influence votes for and against the "death sentence" clause in the Utility Holding Company Bill.

ALBANY, July 8. -- Governor Lehman directed the Conservation Department, State Troopers, National Guard and Highway Division to give any aid required today to the territory in the regions devastated by floods in yesterday's downpour.

BUFFALO, July 8 (AP) -- Senator joint legislative committee to in-joint legislative committee to investigate public utilities, conferred today with officials here on a proposed investigation of light and power rates in the Buffalo district.

When the French liner Normandie docked here at 5:30 o'clock last night there were several Italian and American friends of Luigi Pirandello, Italian dramatist and novelist who won the Nobel Prize in 1934, waiting to greet him at the pier.
Conveyance of a postoffice site in West New York featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Following publication of President Roosevelt's letter urging passage of the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill, advocates and foes of the measure swung into increased activity today.

Twelve members of the Maccabi motor cycle team of Palestine washed the accumulated grime of 15,000 miles of mud and highway from their faces yesterday morning and went to the offices of the Zionist Organization of America, 111 Fifth Avenue, for an official reception.
YONKERS, N.Y., July 8. -- The Eastern Sectional Girls Centre tennis championships started at the Amackassin Tennis Club today with thirty-two players competing.

The detective division of the Police Department will be completely reorganized in the near future, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine revealed yesterday. His announcement followed ceremonies in City Hall at which Mayor La Guardia proposed a city investigation bureau and demanded full cooperation of the police and magistrates with Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets and organized crime in New York County.

DELHI, N.Y., July 8. -- The valley of the west branch of the Delaware River was devastated last night when several cloudbursts punctuated a heavy rainfall, 8.2 inches of rain falling in twelve hours, according to the record of the Weather Bureau station here.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 9. -- Japan's slow motion preparation of methods of retaliation against Canada's restriction on Japanese goods advanced another stage yesterday when the Tariff Commission adopted a plan for tariff increases on selected Canadian products.

Peter Donahue, Democratic Committeeman of Orange County, who has gone to jail three times since 1932 rather than talk about Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, former beer runner for whom he worked, won a respite yesterday from the Federal House of Detention, where he has been since May 27 as a result of his latest tangle with the government.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 8. -- Scoring his fifth goal of the match three minutes after the start of the "sudden death" period, Thomas Hitchcock Jr. today gave Greentree a 7-to-6 polo victory over the Meadow Brook Ramblers on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook club.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Larger receipts of hogs failed to have any material effect on the market here today. A weak opening was followed by aggressive buying by city butchers and smaller packers and the loss was soon recovered. In the late trading sales of some heavy butcher hogs were regarded as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, the firmness in lard being a factor.

AS Don Quixote said: "What a fine life will be ours, Sancho, my friend!" The mental picture of that speaker and of his audience is sharp after reading J. Hampden Jackson's "The Post-War World" (Little, Brown, $2.50).

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Secretary Morgenthau, in presenting to the Ways and Means Committee today estimates on twenty-eight different combinations of inheritance, gift, corporation and individual income taxes, aimed to demonstrate how amounts varying from $118,000,000 to $901,500,000 might be returned to the Treasury annually through President Roosevelt's new tax plans.

ROME, July 8. -- An attempt by the American and French delegates representing Ethiopia to wreck the Italo-Ethiopian conciliation commission now sitting in Scheveningen, The Netherlands, is charged in Italian circles. The extreme slowness with which the commission's work has proceeded so far is attributed to repeated attempts by the delegates of Ethiopia to drag the question of the boundary between Ethiopia and Italian Somaliland into the discussion.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- After a conference with Federal Relief Administrator Harry L. Hopkins late today, Governor Harold Hoffman said that New Jersey's share of direct relief contributions would be reduced about $500,000 a month, beginning probably with October.

A strong bid for Senate support of the Jones amendment to the AAA allocating $100,000,000 for the stimulation of export trade, especially in textiles, will be made by the Cotton Textile Export Association and the Cotton-Textile Institute, it was stated yesterday by Samuel W. Lamport, chairman of the cotton tolerance committee of the former group, following a meeting here.

Painstaking burglars, whose equipment included two large acetylene gas tanks, looted the safe of Richters Jewelers, Inc., 583 Fifth Avenue, just north of Forty-seventh Street, over the week-end and obtained about $18,000 worth of merchandise.
The erection of the intricate projection machine that will create an "artificial firmament" in the new Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History will begin today.

Although negotiations are progressing for a new agreement between employes and employers in the garment industry on the basis of Governor Lehman's recent recommendations, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union ordered yesterday a stoppage in the shops of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, the "inside" employers, pending official conclusion of the agreement.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 8. -- Although sixty-five combinations competed in the amateur-pro tournament at the Engineers Club today, not one succeeded in breaking par of the layout on which Chick Evans and Francis Ouimet waged their famous duel in the 1920 National Amateur.
TOKYO, July 8. -- Premier Keisuke Okada's Cabinet, which when appointed was thought too weak to survive, celebrated its first birthday with a luncheon today.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- With subscriptions totaling more than three times the $500,000,000 asked, Secretary Morgenthau today closed the books on the offering of 1 3/8 per cent Treasury notes made this morning. Subscriptions placed in the mails by midnight tonight will receive consideration in making allotments.

LONG BEACH, Calif., July 8 (AP). -- Five black-hooded pirates, carrying chains and leg irons to fasten their victims, raided a gambling barge, the Monte Carlo, today and escaped with loot estimated at $32,000 in cash and jewelry.

CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Rallying under a clever drive by the Canadian reinsman, Vic Fleming, Miss Ontario, bay daughter of Grattan Direct, won the third and fourth heats of the $1,000 2:15 pace, feature of the opening day's grand circuit events at North Randall track today.

" Noise," that pressing problem of American cities, has been made the subject of a book by N.W. McLachlan, to be published this month by the Oxford University Press. This is said to be the first book to deal with virtually all aspects of the subject -- its causes, its measurement and the remedies which exist, with tables of noise-intensities in America and England.

The recent heavy selling of the securities of the Southern Railway is somewhat of a mystery to the financial community. In spite of the reassuring statement a few days ago from Fairfax Harrison, president of that road, the selling has continued and most of the securities have established new low levels for the year.

HANKOW, China, Tuesday, July 9. -- If the Yangtse River, already overflowing in many localities, rises another few feet, there will be a flood inundating about 50,000 square miles of the nation's richest land.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 8. -- Important decisions regarding the long-standing feud between the radio industry and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, and on other problems, are due at the thirteenth annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters, which opened here today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8. -- The gap between the Occident and the Orient was bridged today for the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs by Pearl S. Buck, Chinese-born American novelist, who declared that while differing logically they are emotionally similar, and that "of all peoples, Americans and Chinese should best understand each other because we are extraordinarily alike."

MOSCOW, July 8. -- Systematic evasion by industrial executives, eager to show a profit, of one of the most enlightened provisions of the Soviet system -- vacations with pay for mothers -- was exposed and officially denounced today.

PARIS, July 8. -- Vigorous inter vention a few minutes before closing time today prevented a further serious fall in French rentes and other securities on the Bourse. During the early part of the session the tendency was steadily downward, some rentes showing a loss of almost 1 franc.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 8. -- With the known death toll increased from eight to twelve and many persons unaccounted for, Ithaca's anxious citizens tonight looked forlornly at darkened skies which still continued to pour a deluge on the community.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 8. -- James Dale has one of the theatre's most ambitious split personalities. Two years back and as the Mr. Dulcimer of "The Green Bay Tree" he oozed decadence up and down the length of West Forty-eighth Street.

Rumblings of an impending fight for leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association, whose members are employed on the piers in every port of the country, were heard yesterday morning when the quadrennial meeting of national delegates opened at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

Mayor La Guardia and Thomas E. Dewey, who as Special Deputy District Attorney is about to open an investigation of Manhattan's rackets and organized crime, discussed the probable costs and other matters in an automobile yesterday and parted at Newark Airport, apparently in complete accord.

Controller Frank J. Taylor may announce today the terms of the planned issue of $38,000,000 New York City bonds and corporate stock. Interested bankers indicated yesterday that they believed that $25,000,000 might be offered with a 1945 maturity, the remainder maturing serially in from one to ten or one to twenty years.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 8. -- Donna Fox, who will pilot Uncle Sam's bobsled four in the 1936 Olympics, helped to steer a Grassy Sprain golf team home a winner in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur tourney today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 8. -- "Lawyer-criminals" drew bitter reproach today from United States Attorney General Homer S. Cummings in his address at the opening of the forty-second annual convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police in the Hotel Ambassador.
BALTIMORE, July 8. -- Hearings on the reorganization plan worked out by committees for holders of bonds of the Consolidation Coal Company, now in receivership, opened today in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A registration statement for the issuance of $12,500,000 first mortgage 4 per cent twenty-year bonds, due Aug. 1, 1955, whose proceeds will be used chiefly to refund outstanding bonds carrying a higher interest rate, was filed with the SEC today by Libby, McNeill Libby of Chicago.
A few casual strollers in Central Park were surprised about 11 A.M. yesterday to see a Stinson cabin monoplane land in the old dirt-filled reservoir near Eighty-second Street.
ALBANY N.Y., July 9. -- The text of Governor Lehman's address tonight over the radio on flood conditions in the State was as follows:
MOSCOW, July 9. -- For the first time since the revolution, Moscow gave itself over wholly to gayety last night in a carnival lasting into the early hours of this morning.

Summer leasing of apartments in various Manhattan neighborhoods have been active in recent weeks, judging from the long lists of rentals which have been reported by brokers specializing in this type of realty business.

Plans for a large formal flower garden on the site of the old Central Park greenhouses, at 105th Street and Fifth Avenue, have been completed by the Park Department, it became known yesterday. Construction of the garden as a work-relief project is expected to start in a few days.

SCHEVENINGEN, The Netherlands, July 9. -- With an official announcement that the Italo-Ethiopian Conciliation Commission had decided today indefinitely to adjourn its sessions after it had sat here for the last two weeks, the task of striving to settle the dispute between Italy and Ethiopia came to a Sudden end.

Peace in the cloak and suit industry became assured yesterday when 1,300 shop chairmen, at a meeting in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, ratified the new collective agreements made last week between the Joint Board of the Cloak Makers' Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, and the three employers' associations.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 9. -- The declaration of principles adopted by the Republican Crusaders' conference today reads as follows:

Rain and lowering clouds could not dampen the enthusiasm of 1,200 excited boys who left their tenement homes yesterday for an all-day outing to Hook Mountain aboard the steamer Rensselaer as guests of Samuel R. Rosoff, owner of the Hudson River Night Line.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- On recommendation of Representative Bert Lord of New York, whose home district around Binghamton was one of those hardest hit, the Rural Resettlement Administration began working today on the problems of loans for seed, feed and housing in areas where plantings and crops were washed out by floods, and barns and homes wrecked.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 9. -- Apparently despondent over his work as a scenario editor, Ray Long, 57 years old, nationally known writer, magazine editor and publisher, who started many others along the path to pen success, died tonight from a bullet wound, declared by the police to have been self-inflicted.

Dr. Mark Graubard, geneticist, who is doing research in inheritance of skin pigments, has completed a manuscript entitled, "Genetics and the Social Order," which Tomorrow, publishers, will issue shortly.

A pageant of the skies observable in the United States will take place next Monday night, when the earth, the moon and the sun will combine to stage a total lunar eclipse. Weather permitting, New Yorkers will be able to watch the stellar drama beginning at 10:15 P.M., Eastern daylight-saving time.

After a stormy debate on the report of the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief, the Board of Aldermen voted yesterday to adopt the report, which was written by Lloyd Paul Stryker, the committee counsel.
Fifteen properties were sold at foreclosure auction sales in Manhattan yesterday. Two scheduled sales were adjourned.

Lewis E. Lawes, warden of Sing Sing prison, will be among the 600 passengers sailing for Europe tomorrow on the French liner Normandie with Mrs. Lawes. Others leaving in the ship for Havre, via Plymouth, include:

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 9. -- The Yale Forty-Niners opened their third season in the White Mountains with "Coquette" here tonight at the Chase Barn Playhouse. Marie Brown had the leading role of Norma Besant. Beatrice Beach, the founder of the company, was the director.

Plans for placing the unfinished Hampshire House in Central Park South and the site of the Consumers' Brewery in Sutton Place on an income-producing basis were suggested by members of the advisory council of the State Mortgage Commission at the hearing yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler on plans proposed by the commission for the reorganization of Series C-2 guaranteed mortgage certificates.

Crown Prince Olaf of Norway, who is commodore of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club, is expected to send a challenge for the Seawanhaka Cup for a match in the Fall. The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay is eagerly anticipating it.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Investment housing purchases and business property leases featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

Objections to turning over the common-stock control of the Butterick Company to its largest general creditors, the Oxford Paper Company and the Cuneo Printing Company, were voiced last night at a hearing before Peter B. Olney Jr., special master, on a plan of reorganization proposed by the company under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

AKRON, Ohio, July 9. -- The actions brought last week by Otis Co. of Cleveland, a brokerage house, to force the B.F. Goodrich Company to permit an examination of its financial records, ended today in Common Pleas Court when Judge Arthur W. Doyle, with consent of the management of the rubber company, granted the demand.

A strong recovery in issues of Southern Railway and a continued downward trend in Italian obligations were featured in an otherwise steady bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Total transactions were $10,854,400, compared with $9,272,900 on Monday.

A census of the unemployed in New York City to serve as a guide in the application of the new Federal work relief program was urged yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, works progress administrator. He said he would recommend such a census to Washington and that he favored a similar procedure for the rest of the country.
TACOMA, Wash., July 9 (AP). -- The government opened its fight today to convict Margaret Waley of the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping by charging that she participated in the plot from its inception.

Arthur S. Draper announced yesterday that he was quitting on Monday next as editor of The Literary Digest, which position he has held for the last two years. Mr. Draper said his resignation was due to "differences of opinion as to matters of policy."

LONDON, July 9. -- After further exceptionally large quantities of silver, offered by speculators in all directions, had been taken up by the United States Treasury, India appeared as buyer at an enhanced price today, and at the close of business the market was held to be steadier than for some time.

Your editorial on Oliver Herford must have given pleasure to his many friends and admirers. An incident in my experience illustrates his charming courtesy to other artists and writers. Some years ago I sent some verses to Life. Instead of the usual acceptance or rejection, the very morning that my verses were delivered I was called to the telephone.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9. -- Open warfare over the New Deal policies of the Roosevelt administration broke out today and raged for more than three hours in the round-table conference sponsored by the American Liberty League at the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.
Following the lull of the Independence Day holidays, business leasing in Manhattan, and particularly in the midtown district, has taken on new life.

Advances were the rule on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with the exception of coffee and hides, and trading broadened in most of the staples. On the cash markets, gains appeared in all the grains, cotton, cocoa, lard, rubber and lead.
BERLIN, July 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 6 shows the following changes, in terms of the reichsmark:
Dwellings, flats and business parcels were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Eric Cleugh, vice consul in New York of the British Government, made a plea for reciprocal amicability among English-speaking nations last night at a dinner of the New York State Grand Lodge, American Order, of the Sons of St. George, at the George Washington Hotel.

If conspiracy in the distribution and sale of narcotics were made an extraditable crime it would be "of the greatest possible benefit" in suppressing illicit drug traffic, Colonel C.H.L. Sharman, Canadian Commissioner of Narcotics, said yesterday.

Eighteen Jewish institutions here and abroad receive bequests totaling more than $50,000, while other institutions may share the residuary estate of Leo Lesser, hat manufacturer, who died at Long Beach, L.I., on June 30. This was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A drive was started in the House today to alter the bill to amend the TVA act, as reported by the Military Affairs Committee, so as to make it conform to the measure passed by the Senate, which is more in line with administration desires. Test votes on administration strength are slated for tomorrow, when House leaders hope to obtain passage of the TVA legislation.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson told attorneys today that he will refuse to hear "lengthy objections to every administrative matter" after lawyers had engaged in a sharp clash over application of the trustee of the Middle West Utilities Company for approval of a settlement agreement involving a $21,000,000 claim against the Mississippi Valley Utilities Investment Company, a subsidiary of the former Insull master holding company.
The police recovered in a vacant store at 1,728 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon hijacked drugs, mostly patent medicines, valued at $12,000.

BATON ROUGE, July 9. -- Martial law ordered by Senator Huey P. Long on Jan. 25, on the eve of the beginning of his open hearing into charges that two attempts had been made on his life, was lifted today.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 9. -- Fifteen hundred youths from New York City, Newark and Jersey City arrived here this afternoon at the Citizens Military Training Camp for the annual thirty-day period of Summer training.

ALBANY, July 9. -- All agencies of the State combined today, under the direction of Governor Lehman, to alleviate the suffering and to repair the damage caused by floods in the southwestern tier of counties.

With little to go on so far as any new influences were concerned, the share market went its separate way yesterday, oblivious to the Congress engrossed in tax, utility and banking matters, and to the commodity markets which advanced briskly under the leadership of wheat.

Samuel Seabury appeared before the Congressional committee investigating real estate reorganizations yesterday afternoon and characterized as "raw and outrageous" the operations of S.W. Straus Co., which collapsed after selling more than $1,000,000,000 real estate securities to the public.

A hearing will be held in the Federal court in Chicago today on a plan of reorganization of the Mid-West States Utilities Company contemplating the acquisition of the business and assets of the company and its subsidiary, the American Union Telephone Company, by a new company.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 9. -- Five of the twelve competitors in the international tournament of the British Chess Federation had clean scores at the end of the second round today.

NORWALK, Conn., July 9. -- James W. Kelley Jr., teller at the Fairfield County Savings Bank, who disappeared June 27 a few hours before bank examiners discovered a $20,000 shortage in his accounts, went to the police headquarters today and surrendered himself.

Usually the Bronx is a matter-of-fact, peaceful place, where the voices of banshees are never heard. Yesterday, however, it seemed for a time that one of the wailing creatures had made its way into the place and was prepared to keep up a strong and steady wail indefinitely.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 9. -- The worst of the flood conditions in the Binghamton district was believed to be over tonight, although apprehension was felt because of the steadily rising Susquehanna.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 9. -- With the official flood death total fixed at eleven in Tompkins County and several persons still missing, this community turned its attention today to relief and reconstruction efforts, the State and Federal Governments collaborating.
The whereabouts of three huge turtles destined for the Bronx Zoo was a mystery last night.

LONDON, July 9. -- The stock markets remained quiet today although there was a feature at the start in dealings at a premium in the New Zealand 3 per cent loan, the issuance of which was a big success. Keen interest was shown in the pending 10,000,000 Indian loan which is to be offered at 98.

BOSTON, July 9. -- Less than ten weeks after breaking ground on a reclaimed East Boston dump, contractors turned over the completed Suffolk Downs, one of the largest and finest race tracks in the world, to the Eastern Racing Association tonight on the eve of its 28-day inaugural meeting.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 9 (AP). -- Richard Earl Walker, editor of The Chattanooga Times, was found dead in his office this afternoon from a bullet wound in the head which Police Commissioner Eugene Bryan said was self-inflicted.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Prices of hogs moved upward again today with broad shipping demand a factor. In the past two days approximately 6,000 head have been purchased here for shipment to the East. This is the largest business in a number of weeks.

GLASGOW, Mont., July 9 (AP). -- Two thousand homeless sought refuge tonight from the desolation wrought in the Fort Peck Dam area last night by tornadoes which lashed little "pasteboard towns," killed two persons, injured thirteen seriously and put the mushroom villages in shambles.

EASTON, Pa., July 9. -- Two youths rode a log down the raging flood waters of the Lehigh River and over a dam into the Delaware today. It is believed that they are drowned, but searching parties are scanning the Delaware for sight of them. The log ride started off Turkey Island.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Sharp opposition to the Roosevelt tax program was put before the Ways and Means Committee today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 9 (by wireless). -- In her secluded pink villa on Victoria Street, Princess Elizabeth, the former Queen of Greece, talked as a disillusioned woman about her divorce from ex-King George, granted last Saturday in the Bucharest Appeal Court.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- On his word as a physician, Senator Copeland now says that members of the Congress -- particularly those over 58 years old -- after their grueling year, "are in no position to legislate wisely or sensibly." The Senator's practice of late years has been largely by fiat.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9. -- Flay continued in the Wheatley Cups annual nine-goal handicap tourna-[ sent at the Meadow Brook Club today with the South Shore Club of Woodmere and Great Island registering victories in the two matches contested.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Red Cross was asked by President Roosevelt today to take all measures within its power to alleviate the suffering caused by floods in New York State.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 9. -- Yale athletic teams during the past school year competed in 346 events, one less than a year ago, statistics released by the Yale Athletic Association disclosed tonight. They won 213 events, lost 127 and tied 6. Against their Big Three rivals, the Elis won from Harvard in four of five major sports and from Princeton in three of four.

ALBANY, July 9. -- After taking stock of the damage to State property by flood waters, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, said today the State parks in the Finger Lakes region in Central New York had been especially hard hit.

The city is counting on being allowed to exempt from its constitutional debt limit the $100,000,000 in city bonds that it will issue in financing its transit unification plan, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- President Roosevelt held a night conference on legislation with House leaders and influential committee members. He ordered Red Cross aid to flood areas in New York State, talked to PWA State directors and received a request from the New Jersey Congressional delegation that he intervene in the strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation plant at Camden.

Dr. Frederick Tilney, Professor of Neurology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, was elected medical director of the Neurological Institute yesterday by the board of trustees, it was announced by Floyd B. Odlum, president of the board. Dr. Tilney, who will occupy a newly created office, has been chairman of the institute's committee on medical research.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 30 appeared correspondence from Budapest under the caption: "Bulgaria Fears New Terror."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 9. -- Six hundred police chiefs from as many American towns and cities listened spellbound in the convention hall of the Hotel Ambassador here today as J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, delivered what was probably the bluntest talk on crime ever uttered by a public official.
A news item from Hammonton, N.J., is headed, "Investigator from Washington Cheers Jersey Farmers as Their Losses Mount."

Justice Justine Wise Tulin, first woman in New York to hold a juridical position higher than that of magistrate, will share the bench in Domestic Relations Court in the Bronx today with Presiding Justice John Warren Hill. A week of such tutoring will precede her assignment to similar work.

The latest changes in the Police Department are well timed. Mr. DEWEY is about to begin his grand jury investigation of racketeering and crime. Mayor LA GUARDIA and Commissioner VALENTINE have promised their full collaboration; simultaneously they announce an impending reorganization of the Detective Bureau, with Inspector BRUCKMAN in command.
CLEVELAND, July 9. -- "Save the Constitution," was the chief note of a declaration of principles adopted today by the Republican Crusaders Conference at the close of its two days' session.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A warning that 1,500,000 Negro workers might move in the direction of left and radical unions, organized mainly by Communists and others seeking to rival the American Federation of Labor, if federation unions continued to discriminate against Negroes, was conveyed in testimony presented today before a special committee at federation headquarters.

In their recent monthly conference at Basle the governors of European central banks appeared to reach a more or less formal agreement to go to the relief of any country where the currency is threatened. This was, however, merely to reaffirm the purposes which had already been indicated by the larger banks.

PATERSON, N.J., July 9. -- Four men of the eight men seized when police raided a Mountain View bungalow June 23, and confiscated a supply of weapons and ammunition, went on trial today before Judge Joseph A. Delaney in the Court of Quarter Sessions, under a public enemy indictment.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday a "gratifying" decrease in the number of auto fatalities and accidents for the first six months of 1935 as compared to the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A call for speed to displace the dole with jobs for all employable unemployed persons within the calendar year 1935 was voiced today by President Roosevelt to State directors of the Public Works Administration.

In yesterday's news there was a dispatch reporting that European bankers, international and other, are fearful that the financial strain of a war with Ethiopia will be very hard for Italy to endure. The preliminary costs of the military expedition to Abyssinia must already be high.

The quota of $25,000 set for the clothing industry and allied trades of Greater New York in the United Jewish Appeal for the Jews of Germany and Eastern Europe was oversubscribed last night at a dinner attended by more than seventy-five members of the industry at the Metropolis Club, 105 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- With rivers and streams in Eastern Pennsylvania swollen by the heavy rains and cloudbursts of last night and early this morning, flood waters blocked highways, crippled railway service, destroyed buildings, flooded homes and factories and caused hundreds of thousands of dollars' damage.

Following a statement from the manager of the government's cotton pool that future contracts for more than 800,000 bales of cotton are held here and in New Orleans now, prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 15 points yesterday and closed 11 to 13 points higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Five States, New York, Illinois, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and California in that order paid more than half of the internal revenue taxes during the fiscal year ending June 10, according to an analysis issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The issue on the "death sentence" for public utility holding corporations be drawn in the Senate at 2 P.M. tomorrow when a vote will be taken by agreement on a motion by Senator Dieterich to instruct the Senate conferees not to insist on the drastic clause.

The haste with which officials selected talesmen for the special grand jury to investigate Manhattan's rackets and racketeers drew an expression of surprise yesterday from Thomas E. Dewey, Special Deputy Assistant District Attorney. He made it clear, however, that he was not yet annoyed.

Hot weather makes hot words. These are of no moment. They are to be taken in a Pickwickian sense. A statesman who calls another statesman a liar in July is translating into the mid-summerian dialect the Winter phrase, "I disagree with you." No malice, no willfulness is imputed.

GARNERVILLE, N.Y., July 9. -- Well supplied with brickbats and clubs, the 142 non-union residents of the Haverstraw area, who were locked out of the Hirsam Knit Sportswear plant here because of a Supreme Court order requiring the employment of union workers, waited in vain today for the union recruits who were expected to be sent here to take their places.

Public offering of $5,437,000 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds of the city of Boston will be made today through a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers. The syndicate won the bonds yesterday on a bid of 100.10, representing an interest cost basis of 2.489 per cent, against a basis of 2.570 per cent on the next highest bid.

BOSTON, Mass., July 9. -- A rain-soaked band of 125 New York City employes and officials, led by Lewis J. Valentine, Police Commissioner, left for home tonight after playing the major part in earning $25,000 for Boston's unemployed at the charity carnival at Fenway Park this afternoon.

The contest for leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association, with Harry Bridges of San Francisco seeking to supplant Joseph P. Ryan of New York, remained dormant yesterday at the second meeting of national delegates at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

BERLIN, July 9. -- The Boerse was stronger today, but not particularly active. Heavy tndustrials showed some selling to take profits, but no noticeable losses. Machinery shares were stronger, Schubert-Salzer gaining a half point.
CHANGTEH, Hunan Province, China, July 9. -- Fire followed flood s Central China's rain-swollen riv-{ rs raged down to the sea today, i nd famine stalked after, sure to! iaim its share of the dead.

A probable lowering of humidity here was predicted last night by the United States Weather Bureau. Issuing a forecast of generally fair with moderate temperature for today, the bureau made known that much of the city's discomfort was due paradoxically to "cooling" sea breezes.

TRENTON, July 9. -- Decision was reserved today by Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan on a petition for a temporary injunction to restrain collection of the sales tax pending determination of the constitutionality of the law under which it is being levied.

DETROIT, July 9 (AP). -- Merton Ward Goodrich mumbled a plea of not guilty in Recorder's Court today to the murder of 11-year-old Lillian Gallaher and completely upset prosecution plans for swift disposition of the case.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Appointment of Peter Grimm, New York authority on real estate and municipal finance, as Assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.
LONDON, July 9. -- The last hope of averting a military attack by Italy upon Ethiopia faded out today.

Floods that take heavy toll of life and property are something we are accustomed to associate with the turbulent Mississippi and its tributaries or the partially subjugated areas of the Far West. But here at home in the southern tier of our own New York State, almost at the metropolitan doorsteps, storms have wrought greater and more sudden havoc than within any comparable area beyond the Alleghanies.

UTICA, N.Y., July 9. -- Harold W. Main of Malone, as special master, recommended that a claim for $3,777,679 by the General Finance Corporation against the United Traction Company of Albany be disallowed in a report filed in Federal court here today.

ROME, July 9. -- Italy's attention is concentrated at present exclusively on London, where the Ethiopian question will be debated in the House of Commons Thursday. But the uneasiness with which every British move was watched a fortnight ago has given way to confidence that the British Cabinet will not do much beyond registering protests against Italy's African plans.

According to an announcement which I saw in the June 9 issue of THE TIMES, the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York has taken steps to solve one of the greatest problems facing the single woman in New York City at the present time.

Chairman FARLEY, it was quietly stated in a Washington dispatch a few days ago, is about to start on a tour of political exploration. It will cover several States and occupy him for six weeks or so. This will not be the familiar case of a master politician going back home to "mend his fences."

CHICAGO, July 9. -- A flood of reports of black rust from the American and Canadian Northwest, continued lack of hedging pressure in the Southwest, and a violent upturn in Liverpool swept American wheat markets sharply higher today.
BOSTON, July 9. -- The United Fruit Company issued today a statement in which it said:

A check for $15,150, representing American contributions to the special emergency ORT campaign, was turned over yesterday to Dr. David Lvovitch of Paris, vice president of the World ORT Union. The presentation was made by B. Charney Vladeck, president of the People's ORT Federation, at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, at its regular meeting today, is expected to consider the appointment of members of its advisory council of ten "outsiders," the term of the present group having expired on July 1.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9 (AP). -- After bowing by 9 to 5 in the seven-inning twilight portion of a double-header with Newark, the Bisons captured tonight's contest, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- President Roosevelt was warned tonight by House leaders, fourteen of whom met with him at the White House for two and one-half hours, that continued insistence upon adoption of the full administration program regardless of the delay that would ensue would endanger his whole legislative program.

Argument on the two conflicting plans for reorganization of the Ambassador Hotels in New York and Atlantic City became so heated at a hearing yesterday that Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe was forced to warn lawyers and spectators against further demonstrations.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 9. -- Harold S. Vanderbilt's Prestige triumphed again over Andiamo in Class M, while the Q boat Lively Lady, owned by Malcolm W. Greenough, had the best corrected time in the fleet today as the Eastern Yacht Club's annual cruise disbanded a day ahead of schedule.
DELHI, N.Y., July 9. -- Since the crest of the flood passed yesterday forenoon the Delaware River here has fallen about eighteen feet despite recurring heavy showers.

The largest entry list that the junior championship has seen in a great many years, nine teams, has entered for the first of the polo season's national championships, which starts at the Burnt Mills Polo Club, Bedminster, N.J., on Sunday.

The luck of Jockey Robert Jones, who did so well on Monday, carried him onward at Empire City yesterday to a sensational victory aboard My Purchase at the expense of one of the most heavily played favorites of the meeting. At the end of the mile and a sixteenth of the Briarcliff Handicap, Jones had his mount, a 7-to-1 shot, three-quarters of a length ahead of Golden Way, the 3-to-5 odds-on choice.

An optional loading and unloadlng service will be started Aug. 8 by the New York, New Haven PIartford Railroad at its various freight stations, it was announced yesterday. A similar system was put into affect July i by all other railroads entering the port district of New York.

Three members of one of the most desperate gangs of hi-jacking bandits with which the police of this and the New England States have had to cope in recent years were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions.

AAA announced yesterday that it has boosted to 33 cents a bushel the bounty to be paid to farmers who contract with it to curtail the 1935 wheat crop. Hitherto, 29 cents a bushel has been paid. The higher figure has presumably been set in order to compensate in part for the recent decline in market prices.

With an attendance of close to 250 buyers representing stores all over the country, the annual convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association began yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Marked optimism was shown on Fall prospects by eighty manufacturers who are staging exhibits at the convention, which continues today and tomorrow.
Relief and railroad headquarters in New York City concentrated efforts yesterday to alleviate the flood distress up-State.

Disease and fire threatened up-State communities yesterday in the wake of disastrous flood waters which swept on southward into Pennsylvania. The death toll in the State increased to forty-one, while five persons died in Pennsylvania and the drowning of two others was feared.

Alderman Lambert Fairchild drew a crowd of about 250 to City Hall yesterday by sounding the tocsin for an anti-Red rally, but failed to persuade his Aldermanic colleagues to pass an ordinance requiring street speakers to identify themselves as citizens.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 9. -- Two persons are dead and 200 injured, many seriously, as a result of a terrific gale that swept this city last night causing property damage estimated at several million dollars.

While wholesale and retail failures for the five days ended July 4 showed a decline as compared with the previous week, there was a slight increase in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Huge balls of fire rolled across the waters of the Kill van Kull at its junction with Newark Bay, and great tongues of flame leaped skyward as a fuel barge with 75,000 gallons of gasoline aboard took fire early yesterday after a collision.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 9. -- Making his first appearance of the season in an Eastern senior event Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School, fourth ranking player of the country, defeated Armand L. Bruneau of Brooklyn today as the annual invitation Spring Lake tennis tournament started at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

BATH, N.Y., July 9. -- Receding waters in the Steuben County flood area today prompted hope that danger was past, although threatened rain caused apprehension. In all parts of the flood district water was receding except on Lake Keuka.

Mayflower Associates, an Investment trust, reported yesterday that on June 29 the net asset value of its 224,458 shares outstanding was $53.10 a share, after $1 dividend paid and allowances made for potential income taxes and other charges for the first half of this year.

Warner Brothers announced yesterday their intention of bringing, a Shakespearean cycle to the screen. With Max Reinhardt's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" completed, the company now is considering film versions of "Twelfth Night," "As You Like It," "A Comedy of Errors" and "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,677,400 barrels, compared with 2,689,850 in the previous week, a decline of 12,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 29,600 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma and a gain of 18,200 in California were the most important changes.
THE halt in the big league firing provided a chance to look over the field and weigh the chances of a world series on a five-cent fare. Even in the rain they looked pretty good.

Racketeers, night-life characters and high police officials crowded the West Side Court yesterday afternoon at the opening session of the trial of Salvatore Spitale, one of the underworld intermediaries in the Lindbergh case, and Salvatore Arcidiaco, also known as Dannie Brocco, under the Brownell section of the Public Enemy Law.

Despite the intervening holiday more buyers were reported in the week ended yesterday than during the previous period. However, the number did not exceed the total for the same period a year ago. For the week, 765 buyers were reported, as against 536 the previous week and 895 in the same period last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

An episode believed to be without precedent in the history of American fishing -- the hooking of a broadbill swordfish in the surf -- was related yesterday by A.F. Miller of 142-02 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, L.I.

Dean Milton E. Loomis, New York University Washington Square College, announced yesterday that 184 students had been commended for high scholarship during the second semester of the 1934-1935 academic year. A minimum average of 90 per cent is required for recognition on the commended list.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during May, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.
CLEVELAND, July 9. -- The baseball clans evacuated this city today after the third all-star game, leaving behind a substantial addition to the fund for baseball's needy.

SHANGHAI, July 9. -- Two hundred Chinese students, rioting in a court room here over the conviction of the publisher Tu Chung-yuan, greeted the announcement of the verdict with cries of "Down with Japanese imperialism."

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J. July 9. -- For the second consecutive year A.F. Kammer and his youngest son, Lowery, today won the New Jersey State father-son golf championship, defeating, among others, the combination of Sheppard and Eugene Homans, three-time winners of the event.
MOSCOW, July 9. -- Moscow's subway excavators announced today they had discovered the underground chamber where Ivan the Terrible was said to have tortured his victims nearly four centuries ago.

GENEVA, July 9. -- The International Red Cross Committee has written to Ethiopia urging that that country adhere to the Geneva Red Cross convention of 1929. It has made clear that unless this is done it will be difficult, if not virtually impossible, for any Red Cross work to be done for the sick and the wounded in the event of war in Ethiopia.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 9. -- The Red Cross stepped into a scene of chaos and threatened disease in this city today, forming a disaster relief committee to care for hundreds of refugees who were forced to abandon their homes in a flood that has cost the lives of three persons and caused $2,000,000 property damage.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The House committee investigating alleged administration and power company lobbying on the Public Utility Holding Company Bill heard Thomas G. Corcoran deny today as "baseless" the charges of Representative Brewster, Republican, of Maine, that he had threatened to halt work on the Passamaquoddy Bay project.

The assigning of young married policemen to vice work is discussed "calmly and straight from the shoulder" by Mayor La Guardia in an open letter in the July issue of "Spring 3100," written in answer to an anonymous letter signed "Heartbroken Mothers."
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A basis for negotiation of a reciprocal tariff agreement with Australia was laid today in a discussion between J. A. Lyons, Prime Minister of Australia, and Secretary Hull.

A dividend of 25 cents was declared yesterday on the stock of Allied Mills, Inc. This is the first disbursement since 15 cents declared on July 1, 1930. Further dividends this year, it was said, will be contingent upon earnings.

E.B. Derr, former president of Pathe Exchange, Inc., applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Valente to direct an examination of the records of the corporation, which Mr. Derr alleges is under the control of "corporation manipulators." The court reserved decision.

Lightning could not strike twice again last night and the attempt of Eulace Peacock to score another double of the same magnificent proportions as that he registered at the national championships met with only half success. On the rain-soaked Ohio Field track the Temple sophomore turned back Jesse Owens of Ohio State in the 100-yard dash, but bowed to him in the broad jump.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A demand that Judge T. Webber Wilson be removed as United States district judge in the Virgin Islands for "judicial misconduct" was made today by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes.

PRAGUE, July 9. -- The nearest approach to an official statement of the Little Entente view of Hapsburg restoration rumors was published in today's Prager Presse, the organ of the Czechoslovak Foreign Office.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9. -- Playing over the rain-soaked course of the Southamption Golf Club today in the amateur one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association, Alick Gerard Jr. turned in the best card when he finished with a gross score of par 71 for the eighteen holes.

Two employes of S. Rauh Co., manufacturers of spats, were robbed of a $1,591 payroll as they were about to enter the concern's office on the third floor of 642 Sixth Avenue, near Nineteenth Street, at 10:15 A.M. yesterday.

LONDON, July 9. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, defending his government today against the first motion of censure offered by the Opposition since he resumed the Premiership, made a disparaging remark about America's attempt to cure unemployment by lavish public expenditure.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Representative Blanton of Texas came forward today as the champion of the nursing mothers of this country. He sought to have the House adopt a resolution setting forth what he described as the true version of the incident of two weeks ago when Joseph Sinnott, House doorkeeper, was said to have escorted from the gallery a woman who was nursing her baby in the old-fashioned manner.
