Alderman Lester Baum introduced in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday a bill calling for a referendum on the municipal power system planned by Mayor La Guardia. The measure was referred to the local laws committee. Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch has introduced companion legislation in the Board of Estimate.

Assemblage of an apartment house site in the Bronx was reported yesterday. The prospective builder, Samuel Rubin, acquired a plot 53 by 135 feet at the northwest corner of Gun Hill Road and Kings College Place from Murray Maran and Samuel Stein, operators, who recently bought the plot.
The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed sole transfer agent and scrip agent for the first preferred stock of $100 par value of Paramount Pictures, Inc.

CLEVELAND, July 9. -- For the eighth time in fifteen years, an entry from the stable of Ben White captured the Rainy Day Sweepstakes, feature attraction for 2-year-old trotters in the Grand Circuit program today at the North Randall track.

New York City securities amounting to $38,000,000 and maturing in from ten to forty years will be offered for sale next Tuesday, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. The offering will consist of $25,000,000 of corporate stock maturing July 1, 1975, and $13,000,000 of serial bonds, with terms of from ten to thirty years.

J. Andre Fouilhoux, architect, of 40 East Fortieth Street, has received first prize in a competition conducted by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects for the design of a small dwelling within reach of American families of modest income.

Provision in the 1936 public school budget for an extension of evening sessions in the high and elementary divisions was recommended yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to the finance and budget committee of the Board of Estimate.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 9. -- The wind and the rain were only minor obstacles in the way of Mrs. Madeline Chandler of the Lakeville Country Club of Great Neck, L.I., as she carded an 85 over the Bonnie Briar Club links today to win by a wide margin in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 9. -- Chemung County escaped serious damage in the series of cloudbursts surrounding this city, although for a time early this morning there was serious concern that the dam in the Chemung River, in the centre of the city, might give way and send water running even with the top of the dikes into the south side residential section.

" Doubting Thomas," a Fox Film' production based on George Kelly's old stage success, "The Torch Bearers," will be presented this morning at the Rivoli. Will Rogers has the starring role, assisted by Billie Burke, Alison Skipworth, Sterling Holloway and Gail Patrick.
CHICAGO, July 9. -- The Utilities Power and Light Corporation made public today its annual report for 1934, which had been delayed some time.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Cornelius Van H. Engert, outstanding specialist in the foreign service on Near Eastern affairs and modern Oriental languages, was assigned by the State Department today Charge d'Affaires and Consul General at Addis Ababa because of the growing tenseness of the Italo-Ethiopian situation.

The seasonal slump in business during July and August should be considerably less noticeable than usual, and the Fall upturn should show marked improvement over the corresponding period of 1934, James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting of the company's stockholders.

DUE, perhaps, to a light-hearted conviction that life is merely a flagrant copy of fiction -- and not the best fiction, either -- Gerald Bullett offers in his new novel, "The Jury" (Knopf, $2.50), what at times seems almost a synthesis of the most wearable English fiction of the last decade. The book spread-eagles from a fringe of the best to a fringe of the most popular, a very omnibus volume of fiction appeals.

Goeta Ljungberg, who sang Strauss's "Salome" at the Metropolitan Opera House, will appear in the title role of Puccini's "La Tosca" at the Lewisohn Stadium on Thursday and Friday evenings, Aug. 1 and 2.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 9. -- About 300 homes and stores were flooded, trucks and automobiles were stalled for hours and there was much property damage in Northeastern Maryland from cloudbursts of early today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 9. -- Charged with having tortured Ruth Fahey, 9 years old, of 67 West Post Road, White Plains, "because she was too fresh," two White Plains boys, 12 and 13 years old, were held by the police today for the Children's Court on charges of juvenile delinquency.

CINCINNATI, July 10. -- Casey Stengel's Dodgers made their major league night game debut tonight, and they did not like it. But 12,000 fans, who had assembled early in Crosley Field for the gala evening of "fireworks 'n' everything," had a joyful time, indeed.

As a holder of 100 shares of Paramount Publix Corporation stock, I have received from the United States District Court a statement of claims made by various individuals and firms for services in connection with the reorganization of this company extending over the past two years.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 10 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, aimed a new blast at the national and State administrations today by asserting that Governor Lehman "took a leaf from the Roosevelt book in his extravagance and reckless spending."

United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on April 30 a net income of $60,791 after expenses, depreciation, Federal taxes, interest, amortization and other charges. This was equal, after 6 per cent prior preference dividend requirements, to 51 cents a share on 37,000 $7 preferred shares.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 10. -- Replying to a Finnish diplomatic demarche relating to the fate of Finns living in Russian districts adjacent to the frontier, where wholesale deportations are reported to have occurred recently, the Soviet Government briefly declares its treatment of its own subjects is emphatically an internal Russian matter on which it is not obliged to render an account to a foreign State.

The sloping greensward on the estate of Charles M. Schwab, the steel man, at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street, overlooking the Hudson, will be dotted Monday afternoon with contrasting colors such as have never been seen there before.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 10. -- heart-breaking task faced hundreds of residents of Binghamton's First Ward tonight as they set out in rowboats, under the direction of militiamen, to make their mud-coated homes habitable. Scenes of desolution confronted residents of this section and relief workers as the work of rehabilitation got under way.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- A new chairman for every D.A.R. committee was announced today by Mrs. William A. Becker, President General.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty granted permission yesterday to Mrs. Emma Calhoun to have a search made of the homes of Mrs. Charles L. Tiffany, wife of the Fifth Avenue jeweler; Mrs. Maude Wolfe Cameron, sister of Mrs. Calhoun, and the home of Mrs. Henry L. MeVicker for valuable silver plate alleged to have been removed from the home of her mother, the late Emma Wolfe.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Hundreds of applications for loans for rural electrification projects, already approved by the engineering and legal divisions of the Rural Electrification Administration, will be brought before the Advisory Committee on Allotments soon, Morris L. Cooke, REA director, stated today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Appearing to be bent on distancing the House in its investigation of lobbying, the Senate is expected to start tomorrow upon an inquiry into "pressure" exerted in behalf of and against all legislation, either pending or disposed of at the present session of Congress.

Characterizing the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act as a new charter of liberties for workmen, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday that Communists and industrial leaders had joined in an attempt to defeat the law.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- Combining a late-inning attack on Fred Frankhouse with Charley Root's shutout relief pitching, the Cubs today wiped out an early deficit and defeated the Braves, 6 to 4, in the opening game of the series. It was the Cubs' ninth triumph over Boston in eleven meetings this season.
GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 10. -- Two of the leaders in the British Chess Federation's annual tournament met reverses today in the third round.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Just how bees happen to be designated as basic commodities in the amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the problem of controlling the love life of the queen bee under the proposed enlargement of the law were problems enlivening an otherwise dull debate as the Senate started work today on the amendments.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 10. -- Members of the Summer colony filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players opened their ninth season here with the presentation of "How Like a God," a new comedy by Willard Starks.

THE glossary of Will Durant's "The Story of Civilization: Our Oriental Heritage" (Simon Schuster, $5), extends from Page 939 to 944. It is made up of foreign terms which are used in the text, but not immediately defined. Among the words and phrases translated are "esprit," "en masse," "dramatis personae," "nom de plume," "protege," "raconteurs," "objets d'art," and "savant."

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Six violations of Commerce Department flying regulations were charged today to Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., in connection with the crash in Missouri on May 6 in which Senator Cutting and four other persons were killed. The charges were listed by Secretary Roper in a final report of the case.

BERLIN, July 10. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, struck another blow at the Catholic clergy yesterday by issuing a decree providing for prosecution of any one opposing enforcement of the sterilization laws.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- A stop order was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission suspending under the Securities Act of 1933 the registration statement of securities of the Wee Investors Royalty Company of Tulsa, which included a plan for chain distribution of the shares by the investors themselves.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 10. -- About 150 crippled children from Middlesex County were brought to the "Little White House" as the guests of Governor Hoffman here today for an outing. The children saw a review of the 102d Cavalry Regiment of Essex County at the National Guard camp near by.

Benjamin Wood, financier and son of Fernando Wood, who was Mayor of New York City for two terms between 1855 and 1861, left an estate appraised yesterday at $719,677 gross and $610,162 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $677,126.

The Union Oil Company of California reports for the three months ended on June 30 a net income of $1,600,000 after expenses, taxes, interest charges, expenses incurred in connection with refinancing part of the company's debt and provisions for depreciation, depletion and estimated Federal income taxes.

LONDON, July 10. -- The military correspondent of The Times of London, estimating how the Italian forces may strike Ethiopia, says that Italy's present attitude and the tone of her spokesmen suggest that an unlimited aim -- the definite subjugation of the whole country -- rather than a limited aim, such as biting off a fresh slice of the country, is governing her policy and consequently her strategy.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 10 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie's government, blaming Italy for the breakdown of efforts to arbitrate Italo-Ethiopian differences, demanded today the immediate convocation of the League of Nations Council.
DELHI, N.Y., July 10. -- Despite continuing heavy showers, the Delaware River and its feeders have dropped to nearly normal levels today, but watchers are alert lest weakened dams should go out.

Amid the cheers of his confreres and in a scene of revelry and wassail Robert Clairmont was inducted into the office of Poet Laureate of Greenwich Village last night at a meeting in the Village Vanguard, a resort in the basement of a building at 178 Seventh Avenue South.

TACOMA, Wash., July 10 (AP). -- Evidence aiming to show that Mrs. Margaret Waley was an active participant in the $200,000 kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser was brought into her trial by the government today.
With promises of lower humidity only partly fulfilled, the city sweltered yesterday under another day of mugginess. The Weather Bureau, however, predicted that it would moderate today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10. -- While emulating a Federal agent last night at 56 Ferris Avenue, this city, a local boy was shot in the hand. The players of the police game were Fred Vaccaro, 15 years old, of 60 Ferris Avenue, the victim, and Joseph Dura, 16, of 56 Ferris Avenue, where the game was played.

Early sale of a new $4,430,000 bond issue is included in plans for a refunding operation by the Territory of Hawaii, according to W.C. McGonagle, Treasurer of the Territory, who is here to arrange for the first major Hawaiian financing since 1929. Proceeds of the offering will be used to refund three issues of callable 4 per cent bonds, involving a substantial saving in interest.

Treasury figures published yesterday show in detail the impressive gains made in the Government's chief source of income -- its collections of internal revenue. They amounted during the fiscal year just ended to $3,297,000,000. Only four times in the country's history has this figure been exceeded.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10. -- Young women of the Summer colony will act as ushers at the annual benefit concert at the Art Association next Monday night, when Fernanda Doria will sing. The ushers will be the Misses Lesley Bogert, Virginia M. French, Jane Pope, Aerielle Frazer and Betty Brooke and Mrs. Thomas Clark Howard.

TRENTON, July 10. -- Six girls and two boys, marooned in a camp on a small island near Frenchtown as the Delaware River became swollen from the floods in New York and Pennsylvania, were rescued early today.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- A hearty laugh backed by his robust appearance was President Roosevelt's reply at a press conference today to a question as to the state of his health.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 10. -- At Egremont Inn, South Egremont, is a group of Boston Horticultural Club members who are visiting gardens in Western Massachusetts. This afternoon they were guests of Professor and Mrs. Walter Prichard Eaton at Twin Fires, Sheffield.

With traders unimpressed by the tenor of the politico-financial news yesterday, but influenced a little by the continued optimism reflected by the mid-week reviews of industry, the share market made a creeping advance. Transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to 1,150,000 shares, or about 200,000 less than on the day before.
New York City is in no danger of a milk shortage despite the serious damage to the dairy business caused by the flood, according to leading milk distributors.

Errol Flynn, Irish actor who was brought to Hollywood from England by Warner Brothers about six months ago, will play the title role in the screen version of Rafael Sabatini's novel, "Captain Blood." Opposite him in the leading feminine role will be Olivia de Havilland. Michael Curitz will be the director.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- Flood waters which roared down from New York State through Eastern Pennsylvania to the Delaware and Chesapeake Bay were subsiding today after taking twelve lives in this State and doing property damage which may reach several million dollars.

Broad smiles and hearty handshakes replaced the recent harsh words between Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses as Mr. Moses was sworn in yesterday for a full three-year term as executive officer of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

With more than 1,000 entries and 250 horses in the stalls, the fifth annual Country Club Horse Show will open at 9 o'clock this morning in the ring on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club at Rye, N.Y. The exhibition, with morning and afternoon sessions, will continue through Sunday afternoon.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 10. -- This city organized a disaster relief committee of the Red Cross today as one of the first reconstruction steps after the flood.

Twenty-nine districts, five more than last year, will hold qualifying rounds for the national amateur championship, it was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association. The title competition itself is listed for The Country Club, Cleveland, Sept. 9-14.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Roaming through eastern Long Island and pausing to chat with fishing folk, one picks up a miscellany of angling items.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 10. -- The first-round match of the Wheatley Cups polo tournament today saw the Rockaway quartet triumph over the Houston team by a score of 9 to 7.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 10. -- Demands for special State aid totaling $308,000 were placed before David Noonan, Assistant State Highway Commissioner and Governor Lehman's personal representative, here at a meeting of the Disaster Relief Committee of this city tonight.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 10. -- Bobby Jacobson, defending champion, not only won the qualifying medal today in the annual New Jersey State junior golf championship, but advanced to the semi-final by overwhelming Donald Spicer of Baltusrol, 8 and 6, in the opening round of match play.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The present system of marketing wheat, oats, corn and other grains through exchanges was approved in findings of a special commission of the Farmers National Grain Dealers Association in a report made public tonight.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, accused the New Dealers in two speeches today of attempting to change the Constitution by subterfuge, and drew comparisons between Republican and Democratic programs for recovery to the detriment of the latter's "costly experiments."

ELMIRA, July 10. -- Surveys of flooded sections in this area were begun this afternoon when Robert E. Bundy, national director of disaster relief for the American Red Cross, made a flight over territory west of Elmira checking up on damage to towns and villages as well as farmlands.

After an all-day session during which the names of prominent persons and gangsters were bandied, the trial of Salvatore Spitale, underworld intermediary in the Lindbergh case, and Salvatore Arcidiaco under the Brownell Public Enemy Law was postponed yesterday until Saturday.

WARSAW, July 10. -- The Polish Parliament was dissolved today by President Ignaz Moscicki in a decree declaring that its dissolution was necessitated by the fact that the new constitution now comes into force. Under the new law the Sejm and the Senate are to be formed on a different basis than they have been.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- June imports of liquors and cordials for immediate consumption, plus withdrawals from bonded warehouses, were 439,046 proof gallons, valued at $2,049,577, as against 517,122 gallons, valued at $2,318,249 in May.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- The Senators shattered Detroit's ten-game winning streak today as the Tigers opened their Eastern tour, but they won only after one of the season's heaviest hitting battles, 12 to 11.

Vocational preferences among Manhattan and Bronx boys interviewed by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor show a trend away from "business" as an occupation, the association announced yesterday. William H. Matthews, its director of family welfare, said that of 300 boys who had applied for vacations at association camps this year only 4 per cent wanted to be business men.

PITTSBURGH, July 10. -- His efficiency as an All-Star game performer established, Hal Schumacher today returned to the serious business of helping the Giants win a pennant. Under the encouraging influence of Hank Leiber's heavy hitting, the young hurler from Dolgeville, N.Y., let down the Pirates with five blows at Forbes Field, scored his thirteenth conquest of the season and his eleventh straight victory.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10. -- Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., scored an 88 to triumph in the first annual women's invitation golf tournament of the Gedney Farm Golf Club today.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that William Church Osborn, attorney, had been elected chairman of its board to succeed Peter Grimm, named earlier this week as special assistant to Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury Department.

After a survey of roads blocked and bridges washed away by the up-State flood, Ernest B. Bearnarth, travel director of the Automobile Club of New York, recommended yesterday that motorists who have planned vacation trips in or through the Catskill Mountains and the Finger Lakes region postpone their departures for at least a week.

OTTAWA, July 10 (Canadian Press). -- The condition of Canada's Spring wheat crop as of June 30 was put as one point lower than at the end of May in a crop report issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The condition was 96 per cent of the long-time average.

MOSCOW, July 10. -- An all-inclusive plan for rebuilding Moscow in ten years into a completely modern metropolis, covering more than three times the area of the present city and providing comfortably and spaciously for a 5,000,000 population, was adopted today jointly by the Council of People's Commissars and the central committee of the Communist party.

ROME, July 10. -- No particular surprise was created here by the breaking up of the Italo-Ethiopian commission at Scheveningen, The Netherlands, since it had been expected from the day the Ethiopian delegates began injecting the delimitation of frontiers and the interpretation of border treaties into the discussion.

Dr. Herbert Spencer Gasser, Professor of Physiology and director of the Physiological Laboratories of the Cornell University Medical College, has been appointed director of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, succeeding Dr. Simon Flexner, who is retiring, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Federal aid in conducting the inquiry into vice, rackets and other crimes in New York County was pledged today to Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, and other high officials.

Herbert Gordon, 40 years old, an accountant, who has an office at 1,457 Broadway, was arrested in District Attorney Dodge's office late yesterday afternoon on complaint of a woman school teacher, who charged he had taken $390 from her on his promise to obtain an appointment for her as a truant officer in the Education Department.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 10 (Canadian Press). -- Four American clubs were eliminated from the international Junior yachting contest today, leaving six crews to race tomorrow and Friday for the Prince of Wales Trophy.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine conferred with Mayor La Guardia yesterday about the details of establishing a separate bureau of investigation within the department as Thomas E. Dewey obtained promises of help from Federal officials in Washington for his inquiry into Manhattan's rackets.

A Board of Education resolution, prompted by Mayor La Guardia and adopted by the board at its meeting last night in a split vote, requires custodians of school buildings used as voting places to serve without additional pay on primary, registration and election days this Fall.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Roosevelt at his press conference laughed aside inquiries as to his health. He appointed John Dickinson Assistant Attorney General.
TOKYO, July 10. -- Rumors originating abroad that Japan intends to intervene in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute were officially declared today to be utterly unfounded.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10. -- Two men were arrested by a score of detectives and patrolmen firing revolvers and swinging nightsticks at 4 o'clock this morning at the entrance to the Hudson-Manhattan tubes here, and a truckload of stolen electric motors and radio tubes worth $75,000 was recovered.

In discussing the subject of taxicab rates you overlooked one very important point -- no sane business man will sell an article or service for less than cost. To merely advocate a reduction in price on the theory that lower prices mean greater sales is a hazardous proposition.

Offering an assortment of home furnishings ranging from canary birds to air conditioning apparatus and other major electrical appliances, more than 500 manufacturers of homewares opened Fall lines of merchandise yesterday at the annual New York Housefurnishings Show at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Arturo de Filippi, tenor, will sing Nathan Novick's "Post-Impressions of the New Year," with Mr. Novick conducting, at a concert by the Bronx Symphony at Forest Park tonight. Franco Autori will conduct other works.

Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Martin and Sir Mark Young are among the passengers sailing tonight for France and England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, for Cherbourg and Southampton. Others on board include:

ALBANY, July 10. -- Regional "was boards" were set up tonight by Governor Lehman to cooperate with State authorities in ascertaining the full extent of the flood damage wrought this week and to report such needs as the State can supply.

In a recent issue you published a story about the proposed ban on women drinkers urged by reformers in St. Louis. It seems to me that such a step would be far more dangerous than the present system of admitting feminine drinkers to our nicest places.
Erskine Caldwell will discuss his recent observations in the South, the drought area, and Detroit in a non-fiction book which Robert M. McBride will issue next Fall.

PARIS, July 10. -- Twenty-five nations are represented by about 300 astronomers at the fifth congress of the International Astronomical Union, which began here today under the presidency of Professor Frank Schlesinger of Yale University.

LONDON, July 10. -- The stock markets were again quiet today but firmer in underton in some sections. The best showing was in British funds, which were in moderate investment demand. Foreign bonds were steady, except Brazilian issues.

Dr. Ralph S. Muckenfuss, a bacteriologist of Washington University, St. Louis, Mo., was appointed yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice as temporary assistant director of the city's Bureau of Laboratories, a $6,000-a-year post.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Committee Against the Guffey Coal Bill declared in a letter today to Chairman Hill of the Ways and Means subcommittee that operators representing 60.1 per cent of the total 1934 production, or 215,515,466 tons, were opposed to the stabilization measure.

Three of the recent acquisitions of the newly formed Museum of Modern Art Film Library, 485 Madison Avenue, were exhibited privately there yesterday afternoon. Chief among them was the fifty-foot movie of the May Irwin-John C. Rice "kiss," a bit of pictorial osculation which was frowned upon by the moral uplift societies of the Nineties, but which left yesterday's mixed audience more amused than inspired.
Quotations for money, all classifications, were carried forward without change. Business was light.

In his talk at Washington to the Public Works Administrators of several States the President emphasized the need of speed in getting their projects started. This applies to public works in States and municipalities as well as to those which the Federal Government is undertaking.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 10. -- Without yielding so much as a set, the favored array came through two rounds of play to gain the quarter-finals today in the invitation Spring Lake tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

All eyes will turn, in a way of speaking, to the Chanin Auditorium this evening, when George K. Arthur unfolds his three "Grand Guignol Horror Plays." It isn't often July has an opening, certainly not one of pure melodrama. The works that make up the program are "The Old Woman," by Andre de Lorde; "Something More Important," by H.F. Maltby, and "E. and O.E." (which means "errors and omissions excepted"), by H. Crawshay Williams.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 10. -- Yale's baseball delegation of fifteen players, together with Coach Joe Wood, Manager Howard K. Brown Jr. and Andrew Barr Jr., representing the faculty, will leave tomorrow morning on the first leg of its journey to Japan, where a twelve-game series will be played with Japanese university nines.

That the majority of women who send their former husbands to jail for non-payment of alimony are psychopathic cases is the primary conclusion drawn from a three-year survey made among divorced couples, the results of which were made public yesterday by the Alimony Reform League of New York State.

Although they came into the country as heroes, two young New Zealanders, members of the Byrd expedition to Little America, may be deported as aliens unless the British Consul, the Byrd expedition headquarters or the Brooklyn Young Men's Chamber of Commerce can succeed in arranging passage home for them.

The corporate trustee plan favored by the State Mortgage Commission for the reorganization of the defaulted $24,000,000 C-2 guaranteed mortgage issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was assailed by attorneys for owners of more than $10,000,000 of the certificates while Mortgage Commissioner Louis S. Posner testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

CLEVELAND, July 10. -- A daughter of the bluegrass, Hollyrood Phyllis, owned by the amateur reinsman, John L. Dodge of Lexington, Ky., captured the $1,000 Governor's purse for 2:17 trotters today in the Grand Circuit meet at North Randall.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 10. -- Guy Cheng, top-seeded Chinese Davis Cup player, and Gilbert Hunt of Washington advanced before the rest of the field to the quarterfinal round of the forty-third annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament as play in the first and second rounds was completed.

PARIS, June 10. -- Stabilization and monetary security through close financial cooperation among London, New York and Paris constitute the aim of the Bank of France's present policy as it was explained today by the bank's governor, Jean Tannery, speaking before the American Club of Paris.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, the Red Sex ace right-hander, turned in one of his most brilliant pitching performances today as he shut out the White Sox with two singles and won his thirteenth game, 7 to 0. He also walloped a home run and a single to drive home two of his mates.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Some phases of the Kreuger-Toll reorganization are being examined by the Protective Committee Study of the SEC, but the proceedings will be behind closed doors, since representatives of protective committees and the Kreuger-Toll trustee in bankruptcy have insisted that a public hearing would be harmful to the interest of American investors.

MOSCOW, July 10. -- The first clear indication of the Soviet Union's readiness to resist if Japan should make serious encroachments on the territory of Outer Mongolia was given today in an editorial in Pravda, chief Communist party organ, denouncing the "robber policy" of Japan on the Asiatic mainland.

Your correspondent Whidden Graham touches on a matter of great interest and importance to many of us. My own philosophy on the problems of values, real estate and otherwise, has been of great consolation to me since the depression, and I pass it on for the comfort of Mr. Graham and others.
NORWICH, N.Y, July 10. -- Chenango County's Red Cross chapter put its resources at the disposal of flood victims today. Contributions of money and clothing were sought to aid sufferers.

An amusing illustration of the trickiness of international comparisons occurred in the House of Commons on Tuesday when ARTHUR GREENWOOD, member of the last Socialist Cabinet, moved a vote of censure of the Baldwin government. Whatever improvement in economic conditions had taken place in Britain, he said, was mainly owing to its departure from the gold standard, which came about because the Government could not help it.

Nikola Tesla, the man with seven hundred basic patents to his credit who startled the world on a number of occasions in the past by achieving what others had regarded as impossible, including the large-scale generation and distribution of alternating current, yesterday treated the combined metropolitan press to a personally conducted tour of the labyrinthine laboratory of his fertile mind.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 10. -- Joe Gerlak, recent graduate from East Chester High School, near by, played in his first tournament today and celebrated the occasion by winning the medal.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Prices of hogs soared 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight here today, the top of $10.10 for full-load lots coming within 10 cents of the high point of the season. Small lots sold at $10.15, or 15 cents above the prices paid yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 10 (AP). -- With only two days of rest Ken Ash and Bill Harris came back today to pitch the Bisons to two victories over Newark. Buffalo won the afternoon game, 4 to 2, and triumphed under lights tonight, 5 to 4.

Moderate trading continued to rule the bond market of the Stock Exchange yesterday, with outside influences a negligible factor in price trends. Decisions in several matters likely to affect movements in various groups were still too distant to command the attention of security holders and traders.

Miss Doris Crandall of Mayfair House gave a dinner last night in the Pierre Roof Garden for Mr. and Mrs. Judson Shaffer, who were married recently. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Evans Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Noel Leggett, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard P. Tamerling, Mrs. Charles F. Shelden, Miss Mary Jane Moore, Alan Laidlaw, Randolph Hall and John Barker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 10. -- Athletic insignia in nine branches of sport have been awarded to 196 men, the Yale Athletic Association board of control announced tonight. Twenty-eight major Y's are listed, five going to members of the Eli outdoor polo team which won the intercollegiate championship and twenty-three to track men.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 10. -- Miss Ruth Adel of Queens Valley and Mrs. Henry March of North Shore scored 85s today over the links of the Deepdale Golf Club to take the lead at the end of the first round of the annual fifty-four-hole medal championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association.

BOSTON, July 10. -- A crowd of 25.000, hardly noticeable in the immense and lavish $2,000,000 Suffolk Downs track, today roared a lusty welcome as thoroughbred running horses returned to Boston after a quarter-century lapse.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 10. -- Winthrop D. Lane, director of the division of parole of the Department of Institutions and Agencies in New Jersey, defended the parole system today in an address before the convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police at the Hotel Ambassador.
The original letters which passed between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr preceding their historic duel have been acquired by Thomas F. Madigan, dealer in autographs, 2 East Fifty-fourth Street.

A suit for $175,000 damages was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court against Samuel Knighton, president of the New York Produce Exchange; Harold L. Bache, John L. Julian and five other members of the Exchange by Harry B. Brockhurst and Edward A. Brown on the grounds that the plaintiffs originated the idea of dealings in tobacco futures that were carried on by the Produce Exchange and that they received nothing for the idea.
Boondoggling will be continued in the administration of work relief projects by General Hugh S. Johnson, at least for a while, he indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Rumors that Secretary Roper's Business Advisory Council would resign in a body when it met here tomorrow were denied today by Mr. Roper, who declared that five vacancies would be filled and a new chairman chosen to succeed Harry P. Kendall.

PARIS, July 10. -- Prices settled down on the Bourse today after a somewhat spectacular rise of rentes in the last few days. There was, however, considerable fluctuation during the day, prices dropping, rising and dropping again in a manner somewhat disconcerting to the market, while the amount of business done actually was very small.

As Director of the Bureau of Investigation in the Department of Justice, J. EDGAR HOOVER heads the Federal forces in the war against kidnapping and other less spectacular crimes. Many times his men have had to deal with desperate criminals released from prisons on parole only to turn again to their former savage ways.

In recognition of his contributions to paleontological, geographical and archaeological science, Dr. Barnum Brown, curator of fossil reptiles at the American Museum of Natural History, has been elected a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society at London, England, it was learned yesterday.

WHERE there is so much smoke, there must be some fire. But apparently the National Leaguers didn't start to burn up over the all-star game in Cleveland until the last man had been put out. Perhaps they became heated because they were laid out cold. At the dinner table later they refused to pass anything except recriminations. There were double orders of these tidbits all over the board.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 10. -Otis Co., investment bankers, issued tonight an appeal to holders of stock in the B.F. Goodrich Company for proxies to be voted on the rubber company's plan to borrow $45,000,000. Having obtained judicial authority to investigate the Goodrich Company's records, the bankers again assailed the plan as stockholders and also as underwriters of previous issues of debentures and distributers of the company's preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Senate today sent the Utility Holding Company Bill to conference and the struggle over retention of the "death sentence" clause insisted on by President Roosevelt thus enters another phase. All but one of the conferees representing the Senate have voted for the abolition of holding companies.

Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, announced yesterday that a first allotment of more than $200,000 had been sent to the flood-devastated districts up-State for the relief of those in distress.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- President Roosevelt's New Deal policies were defended here today by official representatives of his administration for the first time since the attack upon them by the American Liberty League Monday at the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The first official move toward resumption of American battleship construction was revealed in an announcement by Secretary Swanson today that the Navy Department was thinking of asking the next Congress to authorize one dreadnought as part of the shipbuilding program of the 1936-37 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- Four times in a row the House voted smashing victories today for the administration on the Tennessee Valley bill.

A team of ten of America's star athletes, including Eulace Peacock, the new sprint sensation and national 100-meter champion, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday. The men will compete in France, Belgium and Switzerland in a series of nine or ten meets against some of the best athletes in Europe.

Taking advantage of a door that had been left open as a means of fighting the heat, two robbers stole $170 and a $600 emerald ring from Mrs. Edna Bleigh in her ninth-floor apartment at 17 West Sixty-seventh Street at 3 P.M. yesterday, according to a report to the police.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 10. -- The question of disposal of Canada's wheat surplus as well as freer Canadian-Australian trade formed the subject of conferences today between Prime Minister R.B. Bennett and J.A. Lyons, the Australian Prime Minister.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, at its regular meeting yesterday, accepted with regret the resignation of Robert A. Lovett of Brown Brothers Harriman Co. as a member of the Exchange's advisory council of ten "outsiders" and reappointed for one year the remaining eight councilors.

James C. Sheridan, chairman of the Democratic Executive Committee of Queens and former county leader, was exonerated yesterday by the Queens grand jury of charges alleging the sale of political jobs. The grand jury handed its report to County Judge Thomas Downs in Long Island City at the end of three weeks' investigation into the charges.

A prospectus has been mailed to holders of Standard Gas and Electric Company $14,823,000 twenty-year 6 per cent notes and $9,826,500 convertible 6 per cent notes, both due on Oct. 1 next, outlining a plan for the extension of the time for payment of the principal of these notes to Oct. 1, 1940, with interest at 6 per cent.

A ten-year term in Sing Sing was imposed yesterday by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions upon Albert Brescia, 27 years old, an ex-convict and leader of three gunmen who specialized in hold-ups of Yorkville and Harlem dental establishments.

With the cessation of Treasury purchases of silver abroad yesterday the dollar rebounded in the foreign exchange market. The pound sterling, which on Tuesday had been forced up to $4.98 1/2 by the silver-buying activities of our government in the London market, fell yesterday to $4.95 3/8 and closed at $4.96 1/4, off 3/5 cent from Tuesday's final price.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP). -- The Browns broke a nine-game losing streak when they defeated the Athletics today, 7 to 2, in the first game of the series.

Most of us never heard of the Republican Crusaders until they had their conference at Cleveland. Out of the air of six States -- Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia -- they were summoned and appeared. Chairman FLETCHER gave them his blessing. Some of the State chairmen were absent or hostile.

Max Baer, former heavyweight boxing champion, paid a flying visit to the Johns Hopkins Hospital at Baltimore yesterday. Dr. William F. Reinhoff, after an X-ray examination, reported that no bones were broken in his hands, as he had feared, and that he would be able to fight in September.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- A list of applications for registration on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission contained the names of these firms from New York City and vicinity:
LONDON, July 10. -- The United States New Deal is not ended but is growing, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, told the American Chamber of Commerce of London today.

BATH, N.Y., July 10. -- Heavy rains in several localities added to the suffering of residents in the flooded Steuben County area last night. Water is today lowering except on Lake Keuka, where it is six feet above the level a week ago.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- In sharp contrast to the forecast of July 1, 1934, when one of the smallest crops in the nation's history was predicted, the Crop Reporting Board predicted today a wheat production this year of 731,045,000 bushels, about 17,000,000 bushels more than was expected a month ago. This compares with last year's production of 496,929,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- A bitter personal attack on President Roosevelt, which brought an abrupt silencing of the offending witness, and a brisk exchange accompanying an expression of scathing criticism of New Deal policies from other quarters, enlivened the hearing today on President Roosevelt's new tax program before the House Ways and Means Committee.
BATAVIA, Java, July 10 (AP). -- The volcano Krakatoa, which exploded in 1883, killing 36,000 persons, began a series of eruptions today.

LONDON, July 10 (Canadian Press). -- Cambridge defeated Oxford by 195 runs in the annual three-day varsity cricket match concluded today at Lord's. It was the first decisive game in four years and the first Cambridge victory since 1930.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Apprentice, now a selling plater but formerly the smart James Butler colt, ran to victory through deep mud over his home track, Empire City, yesterday, to vindicate the faith of thousands who made him the public choice in the featured fourth event on the assumption that he would do well on his old stamping ground.

BERLIN, July 10. -- The government claims through a report issued by its statistical bureau today to have reduced unemployment by July 1 below the 2,000,000 mark, making a total of 4,000,000 reemployed since Adolf Hitler took office.

Two additional teams listed yesterday brought the total entry for the national junior polo championship to eleven teams, a new record for the event. The competition, scheduled at the Burnt Mills Polo Club, Bedminster, N.J., will get under way on Sunday.

With the up-State flood waters receding and the worst of the damage believed to be over after three days of destruction from torrential rains centring in the Finger Lakes and Catskill Mountain regions, State and local authorities began yesterday a campaign of rehabilitation and reconstruction.

Under light trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 2 to 4 points yesterday and made the highest closing since May 25. Strength in outside markets kept professional operators on the buying side while dearth of contracts imparted a strong undertone.

GENEVA, July 10. -- Professor Gaston Jeze, Ethiopia's representative before the Scheveningen Conciliation Commission, delivered in person to the League of Nations Secretariat today its decision along with a brief covering letter on behalf of Ethiopia, suggesting that "urgent" League intervention is necessary.

Asserting that equal pay for married and unmarried teachers is "unsound," Professor Willard S. Elsbree of Teachers College, Columbia University, advocated yesterday a system of "family allowances,'' based upon the number of children of the teachers.

GENEVA, July 10. -- Despite all the efforts of the last year the core of more than 20,000,000 unemployed persists virtually unaltered in mid-1935 in the twenty-nine principal industrial countries for which the International Labor Office gives quarterly figures.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- No reasonable man would expect the Senate to forego the wonderful opportunity offered by the Black resolution to investigate lobbying. Consequently every one believes the Senate will pass the resolution, and soon again treat the nation to that mixture of useful revelation, unpardonable snoopery, petty revenge, bullying and political manoeuvring which is called a Senate investigation.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10. -- Richard Weir, 35-year-old soda dispenser, at 10:15 o'clock tonight walked up to Patrolman William Lozier on traffic duty at Broad Street and Branford Place and calmly said, "I've just cut my sweetheart's throat."

Four incendiary bullets from an army rifle were fired from a range of twenty-five feet into a five-gallon can of solidified gasoline yesterday afternoon by Clyde Pangborn, round-the-world flier. It did not explode. Indeed, it was not until the fourth shot, when some of the substance had been liquified by pressure and spilled on the ground, that it even ignited.

Times Square was thrown into an uproar about 6 P.M. yesterday when two armed thugs entered the offices of Clark's Tours, on the fourth floor of the Times Building, robbed the manager of $50 and his coat and trousers, and fled after tying up their victim with picture wire.

LONDON, July 10. -- George Lansbury, Labor party leader, hurled the charge of "corruption" at the government today for permitting Ramsay MacDonald to hold the sinecure post of Lord President of the Council at a salary of 2,000 a year while his son Malcolm held the Colonial Secretaryship at a salary of 5,000.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 10. -- 'Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy is preparing to foment rebellion among Ethiopia's feudal Lords by giving large sums to various chieftains, especially those who are Moslems, to revolt against Emperor Haile Selassie, according to rumors circulating here following the monthly exchange of news among the governors of the central banks in connection with the meeting of the Bank for International Settlement.

For two years agents of the Treasury Department tried unsuccessfully to find the group they said was smuggling small Swiss watch movements into this country and was thereby defrauding the government of hundreds of thousands of dollars in duties.

The disasters which have suddenly descended upon scores of communities in New York and neighboring States have mounted to a national calamity. No planning of man could have averted it. All that can be done by mortals is to be ready to apply their ingenuity, their sympathy and substance in alleviation of the suffering and the loss from acts which are beyond their control and for that reason called "acts of GOD."
LONDON, July 10. -- New proposals for settling the Italo-Ethopian quarrel are under consideration in London tonight. They are generally attributed to Dino Grandi, the Italian Ambassador.

NEW ORLEANS, July 10 (AP). -- The city administration of Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, swaying under drastic legislative burdens, was considering today offering the palm leaf to Senator Long to end their political strife.

Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim received from Mayor La Guardia a Certificate of Honor for Distinguished Service to the City of New York at the 1,000th performance of the Goldman Band on the Central Park Mall last night. The presentation was part of the New York Summer festival activities arranged by the Municipal Art Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- A move to sweep away "red tape" and speed reconstruction in the flood-stricken areas of up-State New York with the aid of emergency work relief funds was undertaken today by up-State members of Congress.

Though clearing skies made it unnecessary to transfer the event to the Great Hall of the City College, as had been planned late in the afternoon, an orchestral concert was substituted at the Lewisohn Stadium last night for the scheduled repetition of the Fokine ballets given in the Stadium last Monday night.

The Second National Investors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the $5 prefered stock to apply against arrearages. On May 14 it paid $1.25 on account of accumulations. The Third National Investors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock, against 50 cents paid on May 14.

VIENNA, July 10. -- The clock of Austrian history was put back a little further toward 1918 this afternoon when the government put through the Federal Chamber its bill for abolition of the anti-Hapsburg laws of that year.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Educational institutions and their products were indicted today by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, in an address before the Institute for Administrative Officers of Higher Institutions.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- Sun Captor, owned and trained by Jake Lowenstein of Chicago, reeled off the fastest mile that has been run on American tracks this year to defeat E.F. Seagram's favored Stand Pat in the feature race today at Arlington Park.

ROME, July 10 (AP). -- Premier Bonito Mussolini called 120 generals and other high officers of his army into council tonight as an official spokesman termed Ethiopia's latest appeal to the League of Nations another "useless attempt" to prolong League influence over the Italo-Ethiopian controversy.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The investigation of the troubles of the inhabitants of the Virgin Islands developed today into a political duel between Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, chairman of the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs.

A willingness to cover requirements up to the middle of November has been disclosed by numerous furniture buyers attending the Fall showing in progress at Chicago, according to word telegraphed here yesterday by representatives of Eastern factories.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, it was remarked yesterday in Wall Street, is proceeding in much the same manner in shaping up its regulations against market rigging and price pegging of new issues as it did in the case of its floor-trading rules.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- Attorney General Cummings told the House Banking Committee today that unless a resolution was passed barring damage suits against the government to collect losses arising from dollar devaluation, "an international agreement to establish a gold standard would be almost impossible."
Applications to list additional securities of four companies and a new listing by a fifth were approved yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

Excessive advertising by stores of promotional merchandise, with neglect of regular lines and insufficient emphasis on furnishings, were cited as outstanding reasons why boys' wear department are "backward," by William Howard, publicity director of Gimbel Brothers, at the annual convention yesterday of the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association at the Hotel Astor.

Germany's naval plans for this year include two battleships of 26,000 tons each. This is rather surprising in view of the enormous reputation hitherto enjoyed by the German "pocket battleship" of 10,000 tons. In these small ships Berlin was thought to have developed a weapon of such terrifying potency that the other nations seemed at times to be quite outdated with their clumsy monsters of three times the size.

Prices of commodity futures were slightly easier yesterday in dull trading, with the exception of copper, cocoa, cottonseed oil and silk, which advanced. On the cash markets wheat, cotton, lard and silk advanced while corn, rye, oats and rubber declined.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- A bearish construction was placed by wheat traders on the government's estimate of 731,000,000 bushels for this year's harvest, as it showed 24,000,000 bushels in excess of the recent private returns. The report was made public after the close of the market here.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- After a late rally had tied the score, the Tigers tallied a run in the tenth inning today to defeat the Senators, 7 -- 6.
Brokers reported transactions yesterday involving flats and taxpayers in the Bronx.

One more Broadway fugitive, who has been flourishing in Hollywood exile for the last few seasons, will return to her native heath this Fall. Mary Boland is the name and the show which she will come back in that most widely proclaimed of all the coming season's prospects -- the Cole Porter-Moss Hart "Jubilee!"

Executive officers of seven major associations of advertisers and publishers joined tonight in a statement, issued through The Associated Press, terming proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act "an open challenge to the economic recovery of this country; an inevitable obstruction to recovery."

Representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission who are conducting a study of corporate reorganizations completed their hearings in the matter of Paramount Pictures, Inc., on Wednesday evening at the local offices of the commission without gathering a great deal of new data.

Joseph Schwartz, who escaped from the Tombs prison with two other men in 1933, was caught, an ex-convict facing life imprisonment killed himself when capture was imminent and their two companions were wounded and arrested in a one-sided shooting affray that stirred Park Avenue at Eighty-fifth Street, yesterday at 1 P.M.

Several considerations arise from the harvest prospects indicated by the Government's monthly estimates. Except for the corn crop, with which this month is sometimes a critical period, the "July crop report," based on conditions as of July 1, may usually be depended on to foreshadow actual results.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,475,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and $7,000,000 above the corresponding week in 1934.
ALBANY, July 11. -- The Court of Appeals decided today that it was proper for the Commissioner of Welfare in New York City to use persons on relief to supplement the regular staff of investigators.

A preview of Interborough Parkway, the new express highway linking Brooklyn with the Long Island parkway system, which will be opened as far as Metropolitan Avenue on July 27, was held yesterday for officials of the Park Department and the Triboro Bridge Authority and a group of newspaper reporters and photographers.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Schofield, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Gouverneur. N.Y., resigned yesterday from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions, asking that the resignation take effect at once, because the board refused to reorganize.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 11 (AP). -- Joseph Indoratto of Passaic, N.J., who, according to police, was the leader of a gang responsible for many hold-ups in and near that city, was shot to death in the street here today by Passaic detectives.

Harold Zamo, who, the police say, occasionally uses the alias Harry J. Samurian, was arrested in District Attorney Dodge's office late yesterday afternoon. Morris Pickar of 1,152 Croes Avenue, the Bronx, accused Zamo of defrauding him of $300 on June 14 in offices Zamo then operated as the Zamo Corporation at 500 Fifth Avenue.
PITTSBURGH, July 11. -- Manager Bill Terry and his rampaging Giants today at Forbes Field showed two former heads of the National League and President Ford Frick how they take the close ones.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Wholesale wage reductions, a lengthening of working hours, and a breakdown of labor standards and fair trade practices on a nationwide scale are some of the results of the Supreme Court decision invalidating the NRA, according to reports made to the NRA by its field staff, by trade unions and by individuals affected by the changes.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 11. -- After waiting for weather more than a month, Captains Orvil A. Anderson, pilot, and Albert W. Stevens, commander, ordered the inflation of the stratosphere balloon this afternoon.

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, was elected president of the National Grain Yeast Corporation of Belleville, N.J., at a meeting of the board of directors on July 1 and assumed his new duties this week, it was announced yesterday by officials of the company.

Douglas Fairbanks arrived here yesterday by airplane from the Coast and divided his time with a dentist and executives of United Artists, of which he is one-fourth owner with his former wife, Mary Pickford, with Charlie Chaplin and with Samuel Goldwyn.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Wholesale commodity prices rose a bit during the week ended July 6, the composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics standing at 79.1 as compared with 78.9 for the preceding week and 74.7 a year ago.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Dense fog rolled over Lake Milo tonight and delayed the finish of the semi-final round of the international junior yachting contest for the Prince of Wales Trophy.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- A bearish construction placed on the government's report on wheat, which was issued after the close of trading yesterday, led to free selling of futures early today on the Board of Trade and prices had a maximum decline of 3 3/8 cents a bushel.

Polly Adler, who recently served a thirty-day term on a vice conviction, was arrested at 6 o'clock last night by detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street station, acting on the request of the Chicago police.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 11. -- Organized work for reconstruction of this flooded area got under way today when 500 men equipped with 150 trucks started to clean debris from the streets and the Red Cross opened permanent headquarters to relieve stricken families.

PARIS, July 11. -- American astronomers were prominent today in commission discussions planning the work for the next three years of the International Astronomical Union, which is holding its convention here.

A complete survey of the functioning of the committee system of the New York Stock Exchange is being made by Dean K. Worcester, executive vice president, and Olin F. McCormick, manager of the personnel department, it was disclosed yesterday by Charles R. Gay, who assumed the presidency of the Exchange in May.

LONDON, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Two county cricket fixtures were concluded today, one day ahead of schedule. Nottinghamshire scored a fine victory over Northamptonshire, winning by an innings and 45 runs, while the champion Lancashire eleven beat Essex by an innings and 54 runs.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the purchase of dwellings for altering into small apartments.

CLEVELAND, July 11. -- A liberal saving in dividend charges will result from the refinancing by the M.A. Hanna Company of its $7 cumulative preferred stock with a $5 issue bearing substantially the same conditions. This appeared today when the company filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933.

The new labor agreement in the coat and suit industry insuring peace for two years was signed yesterday in the office of the impartial chairman, George W. Alger, 132 West Thirty-first Street. The agreement terminated the controversy which had threatened a strike of 40,000 workers.

The Ukrainian Catholic Youth League will hold its second congress tomorrow and Sunday at the Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. More than 250 delegates, representing clubs of Ukrainian Catholic youths in the United States and Canada, are expected.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the first time formally listed stock "rights" when it approved 650,000 privileges to subscribe to new common stock of the Glidden Company at $22 a share on the basis of sixteen new shares for each 100 shares held.
Railroad and telephone companies reported yesterday that they were making good progress in restoring normal transportation and communication facilities to the flood area up-State.

OFF they go to Europe, amateur athletes of the U.S.A., Outward bound. Nice time for an ocean trip and a foreign tour. Many hardworking citizens would like to trade places with the agile jumpers, sprinters, distance runners, pole vaulters and hurdlers, and assorted performers in an amateur way.

ALBANY, July 11. -- The legality of Chapter 282 of the Laws of 1934, which directed that the cost of rate investigations of public utilities should be paid by the concerns under investigation, was upheld today by the Court of Appeals in the case of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company, which sought an order against the Public Service Commission.

A new issue of $2,000,000 State of Connecticut revenue anticipation notes, due in six months, was awarded yesterday to Day, Stoddard Williams of New Haven and associates. The bankers bid a 0.1475 per cent basis, a record low interest cost for the State.
PARIS, July 11 (AP). -- Miss Joan Warner, who started life in the nude in Narbeth, Pa., will find out next week just what the French law thinks of her continuing in the nude when she dances in Paris.

ONE pre-election promise which Adolf Hitler has tried faithfully to keep is that of making good jobs for his true-blue supporters. He has gone at the business on the practical principle that you can't make an omelette without breaking some eggs. One of his first steps on coming into office was to provide new opportunities for his friends on the newspapers published by the once potent firm of Knorr Hirth of Munich.

Those traders in stocks who talk in terms of technical reactions after periods of advancing prices can readily explain yesterday's recessions in the share market, which ranged from fractions to 2 points; some may be inclined to interpret the market's action in the light of the heavy vote in the House in favor of the controversial TVA Bill, as it may be argued that the administration once more has a firm hold on Congress.

Two new films are on today's schedule. They are "Paris in Spring," with Mary Ellis, Tullio Carminati and Ida Lupino, which opens at the Paramount, and "Hooray for Love," featuring Gene Raymond, Any Sothern, Bill Robinson and Maria Gombarelli the ballerina, which will be at the l@oxy.

Bank clearings were reduced last week because of the Independence Day holiday. Twenty-two leading cities in the United States reported a total of $4,327,604,000 for the five business days ended on Wednesday, last, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., off 8.1 per cent from the total of $4,709,621,000 for the corresponding week last year, which had six business days.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 11. -- Alfred Otto Wagner, 38 years old, of 1,368 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, a family man on home relief, was in the custody of J. Edgar Hoover's Federal agents in New York tonight after he had confessed the authorship of seven extortion letters in which he had demanded a total of $465,000 from the families of kidnap and murder victims within the last year.

The $28,000,000 series of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates known as F-1, sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, for which Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler appointed trustees in May, will be the first of the defaulted issues to pay an interest dividend as a result of their operation since they were taken from the State Insurance Department.
LONDON, July 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 11. -- Jack Creavy, former Westchester caddie and a brother of Tom Creavy, ex-P.G.A. champion, made short work of his opponents in the first two rounds of the fifth annual New York State junior golf championship at the Siwanoy Country Club today.
In a letter to this column, Thomas Aitken, big-game fishing editor of Outdoor Life, comments on the hooking of a swordfish in the surf near Quogue, L.I., last Sunday.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Prices of hogs rose 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight today to $10.25, exclusive of the processing tax of $2.25, the highest mark since October, 1930, and 5 cents above the best level paid on May 27. Numerous loads of selected 190 to 220 pounds hogs brought the top price.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- President Roosevelt approved allotments of more than $41,000,000 for works relief projects in New York City. He intervened in the quarrel between Secretary Ickes and Senator Tydings over the Virgin Islands investigation.

In his first set speech as Foreign Secretary, Sir SAMUEL HOARE did not hesitate to use plain language. He said that he believed in "realism" as affects foreign relations. Let each country say frankly what it thinks and proposes to do. To a considerable extent Sir SAMUEL sought to do this for Great Britain.

More than 1,000 articles of clothing were shipped yesterday by the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross to Hornell. The shipment was part of a reserve supply of clothing held ready for emergencies.

Begun without the aid or need of footlights and continued under the friendly beam of a moon that was steadily reassuring for those who doubted the good intentions of a sultry night, Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" held the interest and enlisted the applause of an audience of about 2,500 at the Lewisohn Stadium last evening.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S decision to do a little touring in America this Summer must have been made before the rumors about his health drifted back to the White House. The stories are an added reason why the President may be expected to go traveling soon.

WASHINGTON, July 11. --- Vigorous attacks were made in the Senate today on the proposal in the Agricultural Adjustment Act amendments which would prevent suits against the government for return of processing taxes levied on commodities. Senators Borah, Dickinson and Vandenberg questioned this proposal as debate proceeded on the measure.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- In another modifying amendment to Form A-2 for the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933, the SEC has provided that under certain conditions an enumeration need not be made of subsidiaries which constitute retail outlets for the registrant.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 11. -- Indisposition on the part of Samuel Reshevsky of New York caused the postponement of his adjourned game in today's fourth round of the international tournament at the congress of the British Chess Federation in the Town Hall and enabled B.H. Wood of Birmingham to take the lead with a clean score of four straight victories.

LONDON, July 11. -- In an exposition of British foreign policy covering its every field, Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare in the House of Commons today questioned whether Italy was justified in "plunging into war" against Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A banking bill which would permit commercial banks to participate in the underwriting of securities would be opposed by the American Bankers Association unless it specifically prohibited the banks from originating or distributing securities, Rudolf S. Hecht, president of the association, declared today.

BURBANK, Calif., July 11 (AP). -- Miss Laura Ingalls tonight became the first woman to fly the East-West transcontinental route non-stop when she guided her speedy monoplane to a landing here at 7:51 P.M., (Pacific standard time).
CORTLAND, N.Y., July 11. -- State, county and local forces continued today their efforts to repair the damage wrought by the most disastrous flood in local history.

PARIS, July 11. -- Hundreds of thousands of Phrygian bonnets such as were worn by revolutionaries in the days of the first French revolution -- but this time made of paper -- seem likely to be a feature of Bastile Day on Sunday, which is being feverishly awaited in Paris.

HAMMONDSPORT, N.Y., July 11 (AP). -- With floor damage estimated at $1,000,000, Hammondsport was declared today the worst hit section in the entire up-State flood area in proportion to its population of 1,300 persons.
The Tri-Continental Corporation and its affiliated investment trusts reported yesterday sharp increases in the net assets of the group for the six months ended on June 30.

AMSTERDAM, July 11. -- The most ambitious trip ever undertaken by a submarine ended this morning when The Netherland Navy's K18 arrived at Surabaya in the East Indies, having left Helder, Holland, last Nov. 14 and having covered more than 25,000 miles.
New York sweltered yesterday in the hottest weather thus far this year, with the mercury soaring to 90 degrees at 4 P.M. The heat was expected to continue today.

Maurice Lefcourt may perhaps be the one motorist in ten who comes to New Jersey, drives like a gentleman, and gets treated as if he were one of the overwhelming majority of the New York State drivers who behave like hoodlums when they come to New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A determination of the United States to exercise her influence for peace between Italy and Ethiopia developed today through conversations Secretary of State Hull conducted with representatives of powers that signed the Briand-Kellogg Pact for outlawing war.

Plans for the new $1,000,000 municipal stadium on Randall's Island were made public yesterday by the Park Department coincident with an announcement that a contract had been let for demolition of the old House of Refuge buildings now occupying the site of the sports centre.

VIENNA, July 11. -- A hunger strike that broke out simultaneously yesterday morning among the Socialist political prisoners, both men and women, in every part of Austria, whether in prisons or concentration camps, has furnished startling evidence of the complete communication that apparently exists from prison to prison.

Fees and charges amounting to $3,222,315 are being claimed from the Paramount Publix Corporation by lawyers, accountants, receivers and members of stockholders' and bondholders' committees, according to schedules that have been filed in the United States District Court in the last week.
PARIS, July 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
BERLIN, July 11. --Germany will have good crops this year and will be virtually self-sustaining as far as grains are concerned, requiring only a small import of oats.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 11. -- Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing Prison and other critics of his recent speech on the "national scandal" of the parole system were bitterly assailed tonight by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, in a speech at the annual dinner of the Association of Chiefs of Police at the Hotel Ambassador.

Apparently George K. Arthur figured that if the blood ran cold enough it would be the answer to the season's hottest night. He was only partly right. In his program of three "Grand Guignol" plays, set last evening upon the stage at the Chanin Auditorium. there is one of unquestioned horror

With speakers indicating that efforts should be made at once to carry out a policy of education and not legislation as a solution of unfair trade practices, representatives of thirty-six branches of the grocery and allied manufacturing industries, at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, decided to organize an advisory committee to map a program of procedure.

For several days fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange have followed the course of the wheat market closely, and when grains were set back sharply yesterday cotton declined 15 points. Final quotations were 9 to 11 points lower than on Wednesday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Daniel G. Condon, a member of Richard Whitney Co., would be permitted to transact business on the floor of the Exchange as a substitute for Mr. Whitney, who is devoting much of his time to the chairmanship of the Exchange's committee on bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A belief seems to be growing in the President's inner circle that he will not resist adjournment of this session of Congress without passage of the Wealth-Tax Bill. One of Mr. Roosevelt's most trusted representatives said at the Capitol today that, when the other important pending measures are out of the way, somewhere between Aug. 3 and 10, he looked for a demand for adjournment and acquiescence by the President.
BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP). -- Drownings and traffic accidents had left a toll of five dead here today as stricken sections from subsiding flood waters.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- Ferdinand Pecora was reported authoritatively today to have been requested by President Roosevelt to become chief counsel for the Federal Communications Commission's investigation into the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Launching the long home stand upon which, it is conceded, their pennant hopes rest, the Yankees got off to a flying start by turning back Walter Johnson's retreating Indians, 8 -- 1, before 8,000 persons at the Stadium yesterday, at the same time protecting their game-and-a-half advantage over the Tigers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11. -- As Eastern Pennsylvania streams dropped to normal levels today after their ravages of Tuesday, urgent demands for flood control expenditures were heard both in this city and in Washington.
TOKYO, Friday, July 12. -- Katsuji Debuchi, former Ambassador to the United States, sails Tuesday as this government's good-will envoy to South Pacific countries.
LONDON, July 11. -- Following are textual extracts, giving the most important points of the speech by Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today:

In proposing a graduated income tax for corporations, the Federal Government is making an attack on "business bigness" which would lower the standard of living in this country, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, declared yesterday in a letter to its stockholders.

With sugar and copper futures stronger, other staples generally were soft yesterday with trading only moderate in volume. On the cash markets, silk advanced while declines appeared in all the grains, cotton, rubber and coffee.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- After Bob (Lefty) Grove gained his tenth victory of the season by pitching a 4 -- 3 triumph over Chicago, the White Sox fell on four Red Sox hurlers to capture the other half of today's double-header, 10-2.

A temporary stay against eviction of two non-rent paying families who moved into the building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-third Street before its erection was completed was granted yesterday by the owners of the building.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July ll. -Minnesota millers fighting the Federal processing tax on wheat won the first round this afternoon when the Federal District Court issued a temporary injunction to prevent collection of the tax until such time as the question is finally decided on its merits.
GENEVA, July 11. -- The League of Nations published today the three awards of the Italo-Ethiopian arbitral commission and the accompanying letter from the Ethiopian agent, Professor Gaston Jeze.

After causing considerable crowding at the first turn which played hob with the favorite, the Starmount Stable's Brown Bud filly, Brindle, went on to win the featured Rhinebeck Handicap at Empire City yesterday to the consternation of most observers.

The searcher may be seeking what is already known by others, but the researcher is a seeker after what has not been known to any -- a pioneer who tents on the verge of the known, facing always the unknown. His is the immense service rendered at an early stage by the "cultivation of every field by simple discriminations."

ALBANY, July 11. -- The legality of New York City's past and present emergency tax program to raise funds for unemployment relief was upheld unanimously today by the Court of Appeals in two decisions.

TACOMA, Wash., July 11 (AP). -- After the government rested late today in the trial of Mrs. Margaret Thulin Waley, charged with conspiring to kidnap 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser, Federal Judge Edward E. Cushman refused a defense motion for dismissal of the charge and a directed verdict of acquittal.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A portrait of King George by Frank Salisbury was presented to President Roosevelt today for the American people by Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, "in the hope that it may further strengthen one of the many and important bonds of sympathy between the United States and Great Britain."

CHICAGO, July 11. --Details of a plan by which the Universal Gypsum and Lime Company will be merged with the National Gypsum Company were outlined today in a letter mailed to stockholders of the former company.
