ALBANY, July 11. -- The authority of Attorney General John J. Bennett to subpoena the books and records of Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the Niagara-Hudson Power Company, in his investigation of the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland was upheld by the Court of Appeals today.

The Chancery Court in Jersey City recovered $18,450 yesterday for Charles Benson, 59 years old, a marine engineer, who had complained his wife had been taking his pay checks for twenty-five years, allowing him only trifling sums for carfare and lunches and hoarding the rest, in cash, in a locked suitcase.

The B.F. Goodrich Company issued yesterday, through J.D. Tew, president, an analysis of its plan for financing, calling for the issuance of $28,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent bonds, in reply to the criticism of the plan by Otis Co. of Cleveland, who have asked for proxies to be voted in opposition to the plan.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 11. -- Hundreds of Summer residents attended this afternoon the annual lawn fete for the benefit of Emanuel Episcopal Church at Harborcourt, the estate of Mrs. Nicholas Brown.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports. On the liner is Justice Harlan Fiske Stone, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, returning from a vacation abroad with Mrs. Stone.

LONDON, July 11. -- The stock markets here were still quiet today but brighter. There was renewed support for British funds on early closing of the lists for the India loan. Foreign bonds were steady. Domestic rails were dull, and the foreign rails weakened. International issues were better, under the influence of Wall Street, particularly nickels.
The Sanitation Department's endeavors to keep the city clean cost $28,773,053.35, according to the annual report for 1934 submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond.

Oblivious to the oppressive heat 10,000 boisterous youngsters from Harlem, munching popcorn and ice cream, spent yesterday picnicking, singing, laughing .and running with wild abandon over the green slopes of the East Meadow in Central Park.

The management and bondholders of the Denver Rio Grande Western are still far apart in their ideas as to the reorganization of that road and it likely will be four or five weeks before an agreement can be reached, Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, said yesterday following a meeting with representatives of both groups.

With State and municipal, Federal and private awards falling behind last week, engineering construction contracts for this week total $17,913,000, according to The Engineering News-Record, which reports that of this total $12,332,000 is for State and municipal projects, $1,351,000 for Federal and $4,230,000,000 for private jobs.

The right-wing forces of the International Longshoremen's Association, headed by Joseph P. Ryan of New York, swept the quadrennial convention yesterday morning at the Hotel Governor Clinton, although an occasional gesture of the opposition was made, with little effect.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A fiscal policy avoiding as far as possible the sale of large issues for cash and abrupt increases in the public debt is being shaped by the Treasury.

The Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council notified employers of the State yesterday that in investigating the operation of the Unemployment Insurance Law with a view to the feasibility of grouping and rating employers by plants, occupations or industries, the council will examine employers' employment records before as well as after enactment of the law.

BRUSSELS, July 11. -- Because of the opposition of the British and the French, the International Congress of Antique and Art Dealers has been obliged to drop temporarily the proposal for a permanent international office for the organization in Rome.

The National City Bank and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company yesterday made known their intention to sell at public auction certain blocks of stock of utilities companies, formerly controlled by Samuel Insull, which had been pledged with them in 1931 as collateral for loans which were subsequently defaulted.

LONDON, July 11. -- The only development today in the many conferences here on the Ethiopian situation was the issuance of an authoritative statement that applications for the export of arms and ammunition from Great Britain to Ethiopia were still being considered "in the usual manner."

Thomas E. Dewey is scanning the country to find the best man available for the post of chief investigator in his inquiry into rackets in New York County, the special prosecutor announced yesterday. He also disclosed the names of the first three selections for his legal staff, which may eventually number a score or more.

The Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, which recently filed a petition for reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, will remain in control of its affairs, at least for the time being, it was decided yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Tilly Tonka, black filly, owned by C.W. Phellis of New York and driven by Fred Egan, boosted her stock for the $40,000 Hambletonian Stake by sweeping to a straight-heat victory in the $1,000 Cleveland News 3-year-old trot at the Grand Circuit meeting at the North Randall track today.
LONDON, July ll. --"Fred Perry vs. Ellsworth Vines for the world tennis championship. Vines serving. Quiet please."

Continuing its advance, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 123.4 on Tuesday from 122.9 (revised) the Tuesday previous. Prices were higher for hogs and the meats, potatoes, fruits, cotton and wool, hides, tin and lead. The grains were the only commodities to show important losses.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July ll. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes have arrived to spend their fourth season at the Mount Washington Hotel, Bretton Woods, after a motor trip through New England.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 11. -- After touring about one-third of the New York area affected by floods, Governor Lehman declared tonight that he was pleased by the cheerful spirit of the disaster-ridden people and the efforts to rehabilitate a wrecked countryside.

Seeking means of employing 450 attorneys, the Lawyers' Security League of 152 West Forty-Second Street announced yesterday that it had obtained Mayor La Guardia's approval of six white-collar projects in the legal field.

The Federal Home Loan Bank serving the New York district will move its headquarters from Newark, N.J., to New York City within a short time, George MacDonald, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Dr. Sneddon's surprising announcement of his disapproval of the kindergarten, as recently delivered before Summer session students at Columbia University, makes it appear worth while to mention that more than a thousand letters written by college presidents, deans and faculty members, testifying to the value of kindergarten education are now on file at the office of the National Kindergarten Association.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July ll. -Overcoming deficits of 1-3 in the first set and 3-5 in the second chapter, Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School, fourth in the national ranking, defeated Hal Surface of Kansas City, Mo., 7-5, 8-6, today to gain the semi-final round of the invitation Spring Lake tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 11. -- Men and women who have slept but little during the last seventy-two hours were busy cleaning up their homes today as powerful resources of the State were placed at the disposal of those in charge of rehabilitation work.

Dr. William B. Peck, managing director of the Post-Graduate Medical Association of North America, returned yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan with fifty-two doctors who made a two-month tour of European medical centres. Dr. Peck, who is a physician of Freeport, Ill., said the association's membership was 50,000 in the United States and Canada.

The three suits brought here recently by Mrs. Muriel Sisman Dodge against her husband, Horace E. Dodge, Detroit speed-boat manufacturer, involve about $500,000 in property and the custody of their two children, David Elgin Dodge, 5 years old, and Diana, 3, it was learned yesterday.

Conferences are being held in Washington on proposed legislation which would restore to banks, under certain restrictions, the privilege of underwriting securities. Before 1933 such underwriting was unrestricted, and the decade of the Twenties witnessed a large amount of it. The practice was popular enough at the time.

With a marked increase in transactions in United States Government issues, bonds on the Stock Exchange moved fractionally lower yesterday. Sales amounted to $12,215,100, compared with $10,678,200 on Wednesday. Of this total, domestic corporation obligations accounted for $8,205,000, against $8,789,000 on the previous day.
TORONTO, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- The Maple Leafs defeated Newark, 11 -- 8, under the floodlights tonight.

John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, returned on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday after spending a month in Germany in a study of religious and political conditions under the Nazi regime. He said he had interviewed every one he could reach, attended meetings and visited private homes, doing everything "in my power to find the truth."
ROME, July 11 (AP). -- Commingled relief and caution marked the official Italian frame of mind tonight as news of Sir Samuel Hoare's declarations in the British House of Commons was published.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A list of applications for registration on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission contained the names of these firms from New York City and the immediate vicinity:

The report of the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company for the fiscal year ended on April 30 shows a net profit of $743,509 after depreciation, provision for losses in disposing of capital assets, Federal taxes and other charges. It was the largest profit in the company's history and compares with one of $458,460 in the preceding year.

CINCINNATI, July 11. -- Billy Sullivan's two-base wallop to the right-field corner off Dazzy Vance in the eighth inning, driving in two runs, upset the Dodgers again today and kept the Dazzler from scoring his 198th major league triumph.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11. -- The terrific power of Thomas Hitchcock Jr. finally enabled the Greentree team to gain an up-hill victory in the Meadow Brook Club Cups final on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

In Tulsa, Wonder City of Oklahoma, navel of the oil industry, and in the thought-parlors of its independent Tribune, a moral election is in progress. In 1932 Mr. HOOVER was that Tribune's man of men. He knew what not to do but not what to do. He mustn't be renominated. That would be the worst blunder the Republicans could make.

The steel industry is still adhering to wages, hours of work and principles of fair competition outlined in the old Steel Code which was scrapped by the United States Supreme Court's ruling in the Schechter case, leaders of the steel industry said yesterday.

After spending last Autumn and Spring in New York, Ford Madox Ford has returned to Southern France, where he will spend the remainder of the Summer. Before sailing, Mr. Ford turned over the manuscript of his new novel to his publishers, J.B. Lippincott Company, who expect to issue it next Spring.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., July 11. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of the Greenwich Country Club became the winner of the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today after matching cards with Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden, metropolitan titleholder.

Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post split openly yesterday with the leadership of the Knickerbocker Democrats in the Tenth Assembly District. The leaders there responded by asserting that Mr. Post was not much of an asset anyway and that it was inevitable that they must part company.

A trial which had been in progress in the Federal Building since last June 3 came to an end yesterday, when Judge Robert P. Patterson was informed of the conduct of James J. Owens, a juror, last Wednesday evening.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 11 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian Treasury profited approximately $63,000,000 by the revaluing of gold and the chartered banks gained about $10,500,000. The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today, showed the effect of the revaluation under the Exchange Fund Act which received royal assent on last Friday.

Without attempting to ascertain to what extent the city's history is being neglected in and out of the schools, it should seemingly go on record that the historians have not failed to supply adequate historic material. Herewith a partial list of books dealing with the historic happenings and historic landmarks of New York:

Led, according to a relief official, by a woman, about forty persons stormed the new West Side relief bureau for single men at 552 West Fifty-third Street about 2 P.M. yesterday and created such a disturbance the police were called. Twenty-five were arrested.

Mrs. Oscar Lewisohn of London, the former Edna May Petrie of Syracuse and the idolized Edna May of international stage fame in the gay Nineties and the early years of the twentieth century, sailed on the liner Aquitania last night for Europe after a stay of seven months in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The hundreds of thousands of investors in utilities whose letters and telegrams did most to turn the public against the holding company abolition clause in the Wheeler-Rayburn bill should not be losing sleep because of the administration's triumph with the TVA amendments.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP). -- A delayed ninth-inning attack, featured by a two-base hit by Pinch Hitter Virgil Davis, today gave the Cardinals a 5-to-4 decision over the Phillies and Dizzy Dean his fourteenth victory of the season.

Inasmuch as further discontent with the Constitution can be foreseen if the Supreme Court is forced to void more of the administration's program, ought not this program be given fuller consideration than has been the recent practice? The following questions suggest themselves:

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A nation-wide campaign against President Roosevelt's "tax the wealthy" program was announced today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which on Saturday is scheduled to lay its case before the Ways and Means Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's request for legislative outlawry of gold-clause suits ran into difficulties in a Senate committee hearing today.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11. -- A controversy of several months between Newark and the State Relief Administration over relief allotments to this city was intensified today when the State Relief Council warned the Newark City Commission to pay its relief assessment due so far this year by July 20 or the ERA would cease paying rents for families on relief here.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 11. -- Six of the seeded eight players are in a position to add their names to the historic Longwood Bowl tennis trophy, as all except one favorite joined Guy Cheng and Gilbert Hunt in the quarter-final bracket at the Longwood Cricket Club today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A campaign of nation-wide scope against communism was begun yesterday by the Catholic War Veterans Association with the return from Europe of Father E.J. Higgins, pastor of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Astoria, Queens.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 11. -- Bobby Jacobson, 17-year-old Hollywood Golf Club star, today won his second consecutive New Jersey State junior Championship by defeating James McMillen of the Essex County Country Club, 8 and 6, in a one-sided final.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July ll. -- A great sensation has been caused here by the arrest by the Finnish General Staff of Major Onni Kohonen, 38 years old, a member of the coast defense and the general staff, who, it is suspected, has long had connections with a Soviet espionage organization.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- President Roosevelt's power development program emerged triumphant today from a welter of vitiating committee changes when the House, 277 to 100, passed the administration's own amendments to the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, designed to enable the TVA to proceed with non-profit safe of electric current and circumvent the recent adverse ruling of Federal Judge Grubb of Alabama.
TOKYO, July 11. -- Nine persons were killed and 101 injured by a sharp earthquake early this morning in Shizuoka Prefecture.

Another operation designed to reduce fixed charges was made known yesterday by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore with the announcement of the refunding plans for the Series H 4 1/2 per cent bonds.

FONTHILL, Ont., July 11. -- Clipping one stroke from regulation figures, tall Ray Mangrum, who learned his golf on the Pacific Coast and now is registered from Pittsburgh, toured the Lookout Point course in 69 today to take the lead at the end of the first round in the $5,600 seventy-two-hole General Brock Hotel golf tournament.
GREAT NECK, L.I, July 11. -- Two golfers were still tied for the lead at the end of the second round in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's medal play tourney today at the Deepdale Golf Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11. -- Mrs. Charles H. Sabin will give a large luncheon tomorrow at Bayberry Land, her place in the Shinnecock Hills, for members of the committees representing towns and villages in this end of Long Island who are aiding in plans for the Southampton Hospital Week to be held from July 21 to July 28 to raise $18,000 for the free service of the Southampton Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A movement to ascertain from all available sources how much was expended by opponents of the utility holding company "death sentence" to bring about its defeat was projected today by the House committee investigating lobbying for and against the bill.

After dominating the Public Utilities Securities Corporation, owner of control of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, for nearly four months, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation disposed yesterday of all its holdings in the Harley L. Clarke finance company to the Atlas Corporation and caused the resignation of all the directors whom it had elected to the Public Utilities Securities Corporation's board.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A total of $41,571,090 was made available for 104 New York City projects today by President Roosevelt, assuring that the city's work relief program would get under way in a short time. About 45,000 persons will be put to work with the funds authorized.

A woman and a small boy were seriously injured about 9 o'clock last night when the driver of an automobile on Prospect Avenue, near 150th Street, lost control of the car and ran over them. The boy, whose right leg was amputated and whose left leg was broken, was pinned against a stoop after the car had leaped the curbing.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A major change in the administrative personnel of the Virgin Islands was expected to follow after President Roosevelt had intervened today in the growing controversy over the government of the tiny island possession.

Mrs. Hoppin Pool gave a luncheon yesterday at the St. Regis for Mrs. John Aspegren, Mrs. Osborn Wyckoff Bright, Mrs. John B. Aspegren, Mrs. John E. Berwind and Miss Amy Aspegren. A dinner was given at that hotel by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Mackenzie to celebrate the birthday of Mrs. John A. Kerr.

PATERSON, N.J., July 11. -- James Bell, 29 years old, of 426 Hudson Street; Arthur Gaynor, 31, of the Embassy Hotel, and Frank Foy, 26, of 417 Central Park West, all of New York City, who were among eight men seized in a secluded bungalow in Mountain View, N.J., last June 23, were convicted by a jury in Quarter Sessions Court here today under this State's new "public enemy law."

An appropriation increase of more than $225,000 in the 1936 budget, to enable the city to care adequately for various types of handicapped and underprivileged children and to eliminate many waiting lists, was recommended yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, at a preliminary meeting on the budget at the Board of Education Building, 500 Park Avenue.

RYE, N.Y., July 11. -- A combination of a brilliant youthful rider and an outstanding little pony proved unbeatable today in the Albee Cup competition, the leading trophy event on the first day's card of the fifth annual Country Club Horse Show held at the Westchester Country Club.

Retail deliveries made by the United Parcel Service increased 28 per cent for the week ended July 6, surpassing the previous peak gain since Easter of 19 per cent noted for the week ended June 22. The rise last week compared with one of 17 per cent for the week ended June 29.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 (AP). -- The Cudahy Brothers Company, packers, today was cited to the Federal Labor Board at Washington for "refusing to obey the law," paving the way to a possible test of the new Wagner Labor Relations Act.

BELGRADE, July 11. -- Prince Paul, head of the Yugoslav Regency, left yesterday on a special royal train for his meeting with King Carol of Rumania at Sinaia. Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch met him en route, accompanying him to the frontier station of Subotica.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP). -- The Athletics and Browns divided a double header today, the Athletics winning the first game, 7 to 3, and the Browns the second, 9 to 6.

A group of members of the National Peace Conference met yesterday at the League of Nations Association, 8 West Fortieth Street, and drafted a telegram to be sent to Secretary of State Hull supporting his expressed hope for Italo-Ethiopian peace.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July ll. -- The relative rights and powers of Congress and the Supreme Court with special reference to New Deal legislation were discussed today before the Virginia University's institute of public affairs by Senator Barkley of Kentucky and Representative David J. Lewis of Maryland, and by Raoul E. Desvernine, chairman of the national lawyers committee of the American Liberty League and a member of its advisory council.

One thing the Treasury estimates of yields from the proposed new income taxes reveal unmistakably is that whatever may be the political merits of still higher rates on the very high incomes, they would be negligible from the revenue-raising standpoint. When the President originally proposed the new taxes on June 19 he directly suggested merely an increase in the rates on incomes above $1,000,000.
NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (AP). -- District Attorney Eugene Stanley of New Orleans, bitter foe of Senator Long, tonight announced his resignation.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 11. -- Miss Jane Alcott won the flag tournament on the Maidstone Club links. Among the many entries were Mrs. James B. Skidmore, Mrs. H.J. Robertson Jr., Mrs. Irving H. Taylor, Mrs. Harbeck Halsted, Mrs. Paul Scheerer, Mrs. Alfred V. Leaman 3d, Mrs. Charles F. Kiely, Mrs. Thomas Aquin Kelly and Miss Lucie Alcott.

The Public Service Commission of New York yesterday ordered the Associated Electric Companies, Inc., and the Associated Gas and Electric Company to file with it "a full and true statement" of all transactions with the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation in relation to the purchase or acquisition by the latter company of the Shandakin Tunnel transmission line.

Louis Weiner, 60 years old, who is the father of five children and lived at 1,845 Phelan Place, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to a five to ten year Sing Sing term in General Sessions on his recent guilty plea on a compulsory prostitution charge.

BERLIN, July 11. -- The Boerse opened weak today, showing considerable losses. Shipping shares were particularly weak. Various specialties that had risen rapidly fell quite as rapidly under the influence of yesterday's pessimistic declaration by the directors of the Boerse.

ALBANY, July 11. -- Reports of flood damage brought to Albany today by Conservation Bureau officials said the worst destruction in any of the State parks was at Enfield Glen, between Elmira and Ithaca.

Wilson Rood, former Poly Prep performer, supplied the first upset in the Greater New York junior singles tennis tournament by eliminating Morton I. Davis, third rated Choate School star, at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. The third-round encounter was decided in straight sets, 7-5, 6-3.

Two groups of American track and field athletes sailed last night on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania to compete this Summer against some of Europe's leading stars. There were fourteen men in the party, twelve contestants and two coaches.

Three robbers operating at high speed yesterday bound a lone clerk in the office of John Schumacher, a wholesale jeweler, at 607 Fifth Avenue and then looted the showcases of sterling silverware. They were unable to get into the safe, which contained about $20,000 worth of jewelry.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed unanimously yesterday Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey's sweeping injunction restraining transportation unions and steamship companies from refusing to handle freight hauled by non-union teamsters.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- A careful study of the ripped stratosphere balloon will be made by the special advisory committee of scientists for the flight, to determine whether another attempt is to be made.

ROME, July 12. -- A government communique this evening recounts several minor incidents involving Italians in Ethiopia. These incidents receive official mention only because they give a picture of Ethiopia seething with anti-Italian sentiment, which suits the Italian Government's purposes.

Alterations converting the six-story apartment house at 519 East Thirteenth Street into a neighborhood settlement house will be made in connection with the sale of the house yesterday by the Protective Security Corporation to the Don Bosco Community House, Inc.

Works Progress Administration projects in New York State can be manned with 600,000 unemployed as rapidly as the new projects are put into operation, it was announced yesterday. William H. Lange, State director of the National Re-employment Service, said the entire employable relief population outside New York City had been registered and occupationally classified, and that the rolls totaled 300,000.

Two of the men arrested at Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street Thursday afternoon, after one of their companions committed suicide and another had been wounded by detectives, were arraigned yesterday in the Yorkville Court before Magistrate William A. Farrell on charges of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.

THOMAS JEFFERSON PENDERGAST, master Democratic statesman of Kansas City and Missouri, has come back from Europe to give a needed, if severe, lesson to the Tammany Hall amateurs. TOM is a professional. He has been a boss for twenty-five years. He scorns the piddling word "leader," a term accepted by the soft-boiled political managers of today.
Two Coney Island physicians have been suspended from the medical panel of the Medical and Nursing Service of the Emergency Relief Bureau following their protests against the tactics of the service.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Despite the fact that wage reductions have followed the Supreme Court's NRA decision, the nation is in the midst of a readjustment that will be completed in the Fall when business will be ready for another move forward, the American Federation of Labor declared today in its monthly survey of business.

The share market appeared to move forward with a little more assurance yesterday, canceling part of the losses of the day before and making the best gains, on the average, since last Monday. The automotive, aviation, alcohol and railway-equipment issues assumed leadership, moving up 5/8 to 2 3/4 points, many to new high marks for the year.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The administration won a victory today when the House Interstate Commerce Committee rejected its subcommittee's proposed substitute for the bill passed by the Senate to regulate motor bus and truck transportation through the Interstate Commerce Commission.
VIENNA, July 12. -- The government announced today an elaborate mourning program for July 25, the first anniversary of the assassination of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss.

PATERSON, N.J., July 12. -- Eight gangsters captured in a Summer bungalow at Mountain View, N.J., on June 23 were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from an indeterminate period in Rahway (N.J.) Reformatory to twenty-nine years in the State prison.

Peter the Great, the staid hippopotamus, has lived for twenty-seven years in the elephant house of the Bronx Zoo, and it looks as if the elephants have taught him something. It seems, as a hardworking photographer learned yesterday, that a hippopotamus never forgets.

LONDON, July 12. -- A step toward the reorganization of Great Britain's greatest exporting industry on the basis of permanently lowered production may be taken by Parliament if efforts made today succeed in insuring the passage of a bill for scrapping 13,000,000 cotton spindles, about one-third of the present number.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- President Roosevelt, in approving a set of rules today for the $200,000,000 work relief road program, ordered that at least 25 per cent of money thus allotted be used for streets in metropolitan areas and an equal percentage for farm-to-market roads.

BERLIN, July 12. -- The German reaction to Sir Samuel Hoare's elucidation of British foreign policy chiefly takes into account the fact that its presentation occurred under circumstances that could scarcely be designated as favorable to Britain's foreign relations generally.

An invasion of New York State by representatives of the Townsend Plan to enlist voters in support of the old-age revolving pensions was officially started yesterday with the announcement by Max Loewenthal, State area manager, of the opening of headquarters in the Gregorian Hotel, 42 West Thirty-fifth Street.

For the first half of this year the preliminary report of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company and consolidated subsidiaries showed a net income of $1,469,900 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The Roosevelt "tax the wealthy" program was the subject of another attack today when the National Association of Manufacturers, the Ohio State Chamber of Commerce, and the American Mining Congress joined in denunciation of the plan as one which would prolong the depression; as economically unsound, from whatever angle studied, and as harmful to millions of investors in American industries.

Miss Agnes Schmidt, 22 years old, of 2,292 Ryder Street, Brooklyn, saved a 4 1/2-year-old child from drowning last night in Kimball Basin, Jamaica Bay, and Patrolman Jeremiah C. Dempsey of the Fourth Avenue Station, Brooklyn, who was off duty at the time, after assisting Miss Schmidt in bringing the child ashore, completed the rescue by reviving the child by artificial respiration.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -Faced with mounting litigation and unfavorable court decisions, farm officials disclosed today that processing-tax collections dropped more than $4,600,000 during May.

Brooklyn bested Manhattan almost 2 to 1 in the ten-week diphtheria immunization contest, staged by the Department of Health and ending June 25, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday. In Brooklyn 14,591 children under the age of 6 years received the protective treatment and in Manhattan the total was 7,346.
RAPID CITY, S.D., July 12. -The stratosphere balloon collapsed at 3 A.M. [6 A.M. New York time] today as it was ready for its ascent.

A copy of the late Colonel T.E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom," which was published originally at $20,000 a copy, is to be exhibited beginning Monday in the Doubleday, Doran Book Shop at the Lord Taylor store. By agreement with the executors of the estate of Colonel Lawrence, who died as the result of a motor accident in England, Doubleday, Doran will publish two new editions of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" next Fall.
LONDON, July 12. -- The salvage ship Artiglio is due today at Plymouth, where she will land gold bars and sovereigns valued at 45,000 recovered from the wreck of the liner Egypt off Ushant.

LONDON, July 12 (AP). -- Fifteen Americans, former sightseers but now scattered to their homes from New York to California, and their former guide, an Englishman, were victorious today in their court action arising from the collision of a sightseeing bus and an automobile on Aug. 25, 1930.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Melvin H. Purvis, the head of the Chicago Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice who led the hunt that ended in the shooting of John Dillinger, announced his resignation today. The place, which Mr. Purvis has held since Dec. 17, 1932, will be filled temporarily by Daniel M. Ladd, an agent during Mr. Purvis's directorship.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP). -- Fourteen of the fleetest 2-year-old fillies in America were named tonight to go to the post in the Lassie Stakes, world's richest race exclusively for juvenile misses at Arlington Park tomorrow. If all start, the event will have a value of $35,120.

CANNES, France, July 12. -- Formation of an American volunteer flying squadron which will offer its services to the Ethiopian Government if war breaks out with Italy was announced today by the well-known American stunt flier Hal F. Duberrier.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Along two routes, the administration moved today toward doubling the man-power of the army and giving more rapid and certain promotion to its officers.

The Capitol has changed its plans for next Friday. Instead of bringing in a revival of "Smilin' Through," as reported earlier, it will show a new Warner film, "Don't Bet on Blondes," with Warren William, Claire Dodd and Guy Kibbee.

The Manhattan auction mart was the scene of auction sales involving a loft building, dwellings and multi-family structures yesterday. Auctioneers asked for bids on eight properties, all of which were bought in by the plaintiffs who brought about the foreclosure proceedings.
ALBANY, July 12. -- Canal navigation, interrupted by the floods earlier in the week, would be resumed tomorrow or Sunday, Leroy C. Hubbard, Assistant Canal Commissioner, said today.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, appealed yesterday to the International Longshoremen's Association to permit the loading of 2,400 bales of cotton stored at Gulfport, Miss., for export to Russia. A strike of long-shoremen is in effect at the port.

The fingerprints of a Brooklyn man arrested last Saturday in connection with a lottery led to his being held yesterday for having escaped from a detention cell in the Coney Island Court twenty-three years ago while awaiting action by a grand jury on a charge of robbery in the first degree.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, July 12. -- More than 100,000 Orangemen took part in today's celebrations throughout Northern Ireland of the anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne. Free State Orangemen from Dublin, Wicklow, Monaghan and Cavan made a trek across the border to the beat of the traditional Orange drums.
GRENOBLE, France, July 12. -- A new phenomenon has appeared in France -- the young zealot restive for political action.

BERLIN, July 12. -- The Boerse weakened again today in response to steady official pressure. It is now evident that the experiment by the Ministry of Economics and the Reichsbank is working. Despite the armament boom, the government has succeeded in checking the tendency toward a boom market.

BUCHAREST, July 12. -- Prince Paul, head of the Yugoslav Regency, reached Sinaia this morning on a special royal train, to be greeted by King Carol, Crown Prince Michael and the entire Rumanian Cabinet.

OVERBOARD with a splash. This is just the weather for it. Usually the swimming arguments in this corner are started by a visit from one of the aquatic Spence family. But with the mercury away up yonder in the thermometer tube, apparently the sensible Spences are staying right in the water all the time, and not seeking heated arguments in the sweltering city.
Police Commissioner Valentine issued an order yesterday requiring all precinct detective bureaus in the city to keep an up-to-date record of all known criminals.

Rather reluctantly the Yankees bade adieu to the Indians yesterday, a bit sorry that the schedule compelled Walter Johnson's crew to depart after Charley (Red) Ruffing had hurled the McCarthymen to a well-earned 5-2 decision before 6,000 persons at the Stadium.
Alfred L. Breor, who has been Richmond County Republican leader for five years, announced yesterday that he had resigned. He attributed "poor health" as the reason.

RYE, N.Y., July 12. -- A sawed-off putter helped 16-year-old Charles Pettijohn Jr. to obtain the lead in the first round of the Sweetser Victory Cup tourney with a par-equaling 72 over the Westchester Country Club links today.

PITTSBURGH, July 12. -- Government attorneys argued in Federal court today that the Union Trust Company should be compelled to produce records in connection with stock deals involved in the Andrew W. Mellon income tax case.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 12. -- Dr. William Beebe announced today the discovery of the second specimen found in 300 years of the pterodrama cahow bird. This species was found in millions by the first settlers of this colony but was supposed to have become extinct about 1630.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 12. -- Nemesis in the form of a chess-timing clock today overtook Samuel Reshevsky of New York, representing America in the international tournament at the annual congress of the British Chess Federation in session at the Town Hall.

PITTSBURGH, July 12. -- This was an off day on the schedule for the Giants, a day of rest for the heat-ridden athletes who are charging on the National League pennant. Notwithstanding, the Bill Terry machine was thrown slightly out of gear by the incapacitation of Clydell Castleman, one of the famous Big Five pitching staff.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Although the total dollar value of our exports increased in May over a year ago, shipments to the great markets of Europe, Northern North America and South America all declined, an analysis by the Commerce Department showed today.

The Bronx again was a centre of realty activity yesterday when brokers reported several deals involving dwellings and apartment houses. Purchases of sites for improvement with houses also were announced.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 12. -- Discussion of the New Deal and the Constitution at the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs reached a climax tonight when the issue presented by the American Liberty League was debated by Representative Wadsworth of New York and General Hugh S. Johnson before a record crowd in the amphitheatre.

PRAGUE, July 12. -- Germany's Davis Cup tennis team, led by Baron Gottfried von Cramm, became a heavy favorite to beat Czechoslovakia in the European zone final after the first two singles matches had been divided today.

TENAFLY, N.J., July 12. -- Mrs. Eugene Homans of the Knickerbocker Country Club and Mrs. George K. Scribner of Rockaway River tied for low gross honors over the Knickerbocker course today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day golf tournament.

Construction contracts in the thirty-seven States east of the Rockies last month totaled $148,005,200, a gain of almost 18 per cent over the May total and almost 17 per cent above the June, 1934, aggregate, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

State Controller Morris S. Tremaine made public yesterday a letter of congratulation to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. on the recent opinion rendered by Mr. Bennett holding that the State of New York has no power to call outstanding bonds for refunding purposes before maturity.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 12.-Miss Judith Hamlin, Miss Constance Roberts and Miss Rosemary Ward are the committee arranging for the gymkhana to be held Sunday afternoon, beginning at 3:30 o'clock at the East Hampton Riding Club. A large number of East Hampton's and Southampton's Summer colonists have been invited for the tea which will follow in the clubhouse.

Cecil Melrose and Francis W. Smoothy, young New Zealanders who have been something of a thorn in the side of the Byrd Antarctic expedition because of their inability to return home without funds, will sail July 30 on the Anglo Canadian for Dunedin, N.Z., it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Commander George O. Noville, executive officer.

TACOMA, Wash., July 12 (AP). -The government accused Mrs. Margaret Waley today of attempting to hide behind the Mormon religion in her fight to escape punishment for the kidnapping of 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser.

PARIS, July 12. -- In view of the political and financial uncertainties in the coming days, the Bourse closed this week with remarkable firmness. Rentes especially were in demand in today's session and showed gains ranging from 1 franc to 1 franc 50 centimes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12. -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, said tonight that there was no disharmony between the department and Melvin Purvis, head of the Chicago office.

LONDON, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Canadian schoolboy cricketers could not fathom Uppingham College bowlers, being held to 24 runs all out, land lost by 269 runs at Uppingham today. J.R. McCosh and A.V. Spencer were the marksmen taking five wickets for nine runs and four for two, respectively.

The Right Rev. Thomas Henry McLaughlin, Vicar-General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, N.J., and rector of the Immaculate Conception Theological Seminary, Darlington, N.J., will be consecrated as Titular Bishop of Nisa and Auxiliary to the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of Newark, on Thursday, July 25, at 10:30 A.M. in the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart, Newark.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 12. -- Miss Mariette Arguimbau and Miss Elsie Link today won the doubles title in the Eastern sectional girls' tennis tournament at the Amackassin Club by defeating Miss Eleanor Gates and Miss Patricia Cumming in the final, 6-2, 2-6, 6-1.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 12. -- The two youngsters who finished one-two in the qualifying round, Joe Gerlak and Jack Creavy, both former caddies, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final round of the New York State Junior Championship at the Siwanoy Country Club tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- An estimate that the nation's railroads could save more than $56,000,000 annually through consolidation and coordination of freight and passenger terminal facilities was put before Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, today in a report by V.V. Boatner of the coordinator's investigating staff.

A shower that fell over New York a few minutes after midnight this morning drove the mercury down 10 degrees in less than an hour, according to unofficial readings at Times Square, thus ending for the time being, at least, the hottest two days the city has experienced this year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP). -- The Athletics gained an even break in the four-game series with the Browns by scoring a 9-to-0 shutout victory today.

Business men whose route to work takes them down upper Broadway were surprised yesterday morning to find themselves passing under a new bridge between 253d and 254th Streets. There had been no bridge there when they went home Thursday night.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP). -Peter Expert, owned by K.M. Brewer of Urhana, Ill., and driven by Homer Walton, won the Cleveland Press $1,000, 2:19 pace in straight heats at the fifth day of Grand Circuit racing at the North Randall track today.
PARIS, July 12. -- Both officially and in the entire press France has received the declaration of British policy by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare in the House of Commons with great satisfaction.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July -- Governor Lehman drove tonight through a flood-devastated area in which a heavy rainfall threatened to add to the damage already suffered. Heavy rains were reported from Binghamton to Hornell, which is roughly the limits of the area already affected.

PARIS, July 12. -- Lieut. Col. Alfred Dreyfus, the principal figure in one of the most passionately disputed political controversies in French history, died peacefully in his Paris residence today. He was in his seventy-sixth year.

BOSTON, July 12. -- Two odds-on favorites, Teralice and Sgt. Byrne, captured the co-features, the South Shore and the Winchester Purses, today at Suffolk Downs. Charlie Stevenson completed a triple when he booted in Sgt. Byrne under the wire in the Winchester. His other triumphs were on Songstone in the first race and Teralice in the fourth.

The lake fisherman who hopes to take black bass with top-water or near-surface lures on blistering hot days is an optimist indeed. In the heat of midday, when the shallows are fairly cooking, the most likely looking patch of lily-pads or weeds often will be bare of fish.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Work on the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project will be halted if the Maine Legislature at its next session does not set up an Authority for administering the Quoddy after it has been completed, officials here have decided.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- While a few hogs sold in the early trading today at $10.25 to equal the best figure of the previous day, the practical top was $10.20 and the market closed weak to as much as 25 cents a hundredweight lower with hogs weighing over 250 pounds leading the decline.

After this evening, Clifford Odets will be represented on Broadway by only one play, for his double bill -- ''Waiting For Lefty" and "Till the Day I Die" -- will depart tonight from the Longacre. There has been talk of a reprieve, but the Group Theatre finally said "no" yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, July 12. -- The feeling is growing in London, apparently without any more visible or substantial foundation than the optimism radiated by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the House of Commons yesterday, that some solution of the Ethiopian problem will be found to avert an Italian war upon the little African empire.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- A proposal for dissolution of the Advance Rumely Corporation and distribution of its assets will be submitted to stockholders on Sept. 30 in La Porte. Ind. Under Indiana law a two-thirds vote of the shareholders will be necessary for approval of the plan.

The Brownell Public Enemy Law makes it illegal for any person "who bears an evil reputation" to consort with "persons of like evil reputation, thieves or criminals." It further provides that when any such person is found consorting this shall be "prima "facie evidence that such consorting "was for an unlawful purpose."

LONDON, July 12. -- The stock markets here were quieter today, apart from a revival of support for Kaffir Mines and improvement in irons and steels. British funds were dull, with demand slackening. Foreign bonds were quiet and quotations were steady. Domestic rails were steady and foreign issues slightly weaker.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Twelve building trades unions claiming to be the bona fide Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor have decided to ignore the invitation of President William Green of the federation to attend a convention of building unions in this city on Aug. 1 to reorganize the department.
There was never a particle of genuine evidence against Captain Alfred Dreyfus. Nevertheless, he was twice convicted of high treason.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 12 (Canadian Press). -- The Vineyard Haven Yacht Club was 2 up tonight when darkness prevented completion of the three-out-of-five final race series with the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., for the Prince of Wales trophy, North America's junior yachting award.

Your editorial "Guffey Mysteries" should command the attention of every thoughtful American. The act of President Roosevelt in addressing a letter to the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee in charge of the Guffey bill urging him to press for enactment a proposed law which the President himself concedes may be of doubtful legality is not only unprecedented but also a serious threat against a constitutional democracy.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Congestion in July wheat in the Kansas City market which had prevailed for some time was relieved today. It was reported that cash interests which had the July delivery sold as a hedge against the cash grain were permitted to change over the latter into the September contract at a discount of around 3 3/8 cents a bushel under the July.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's foreign department has been informed by the German Film Board of Censors and Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Education and Propaganda, that photoplays written by Herman J. Mankiewicz -- one of Metro's staff script writers -- cannot be exhibited in Germany unless Mr. Mankiewicz's name is removed from the screen credits, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- President Roosevelt will leave tomorrow to spend a week-end at the Jefferson Island Club, situated in Chesapeake Bay, where a handful of Democratic Senators will be his hosts and the list of his fellow guests will include most of the administration leaders in Washington.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., July 12. -- R.A. Hoeffner of Montgomery, N.Y., who breeds, trains and drives his own horses, scored three victories in the Yankee Circuit harness racing at Cedar Lake Park today. He won twice with Highland Bob in classified trotting events and once with Highland Worthy in a classified pace.
GRANADA., Col., July 12 (AP). -Caught in their sleep, nine persons were drowned early today by flood waters which rushed down upon Granada and near-by farms. Property damage was put at $200,000.

HANKOW, China, Saturday, July 13 (AP). -- Hankow's famous Changkung dike, the sole remaining barrier between this city's million people and the surging Yangtse River, cannot stand up more than another day against the ceaseless pounding of the flood waters, officials were warned tonight.

TORONTO, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- The Maple Leafs eked out a 1-0 decision over Newark under the arc lights tonight, to make the game a gala occasion for Manager Ike Boone, in whose honor a special program was staged. About 12,000 attended.

TORONTO, July 12. -- Harry M. Stevens officially launched his new Reconstruction party today with a 4,000-word manifesto to the electors of Canada setting forth a "reform" program designed to appeal to all classes in the community with the exception of "big business."

Alfred Otto Wagner, 38 years old, of 1,368 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, ex-convict, was held yesterday in $50,000 bail for a further hearing next Thursday by United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn, on a complaint of Department of Justice agents that he had attempted to extort $465,000 from relatives of kidnapped persons.

Organized labor in New York City decided yesterday not to permit union men to work on relief projects for less than the prevailing wage. It reached its decision at a conference called by George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, and Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- President Roosevelt stated today that he hoped to name within a week the three members of the statutory National Labor Relations Board created under the Wagner-Lewis law.

LONDON, July 12. -- Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, told a British audience over the radio tonight that whatever it might think about the League "it remains the only actual expression of the practical need for States to seek together on a common basis sane and safer ways of international adjustment."

Long Island Sound's banner event of the year, the Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-seventh annual Race Week, will get under way at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and for eight consecutive days the waters stretching to the Long Island shore and as far east as Greenwich Point will be dotted with racing sails. The competition will be carried on through next Saturday.

Here are the expressions of one citizen who was in sympathy with President Roosevelt at the time of his inauguration, but, in view of the administration's record to date, is now quite solidly opposed to its policies as they have been revealed.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12. -- With two points standing between him and defeat in the third set, Charles Harris of West Palm Beach, Fla., rallied to defeat J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., today in the semi-final round of the invitation Spring Lake tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.
PARIS, July 12. -- Plans for the observation of future solar, eclipses occupied several commissions of the International Astronomical Union here today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 12. -- Staging a strong finish today at the Deepdale Golf Club, Mrs. Robert C. Lake of Plandome, the former Marion Turpie, captured the annual fifty-four-hole medal championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association with a total of 254 strokes.

In spite of their reputation for lifelessness, statistics are sometimes eloquent. When Commissioner HAMMOND reports that the Department of Sanitation cleaned the city's streets and removed garbage and waste at a cost of $3.53 per capita last year, as compared with $5.33 in 1932, when Tammany was in flower, he speaks volumes for Fusion efficiency and economy.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 12. -- An unforeseen development in the Longwood Bowl tennis matches today placed Norcross Tilney, recent Princeton graduate and winner of the Eastern intercollegiate title, in the semi-final round instead of Guy Cheng, second ranking player of China.

LONDON, July 12. -- King George, accompanied by the Queen and their four sons, will review a section of the British Army tomorrow in the Rushmore Arena, famous as the scene of the annual tattoo performances at Aldershot. Last week it was the air force that "flew" past the King in review.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12. -- Serious rioting broke out in York and Lancaster Streets in Belfast tonight while parties of Orangemen were returning to the city following celebration of the anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne, and three were killed, with forty wounded.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- The Tigers again came from behind to victory today as they rallied after a bad start to turn back the Senators, 2 to 1, and hold their place in the American League race a game and a half behind the Yankees. It was Detroit's twelfth victory in the last thirteen games and gave the Tigers the series, two to one.

With the thermometer touching the season's high during the past week and business in the local night resorts generally touching the season's low, according to assembled reports, interest logically finds itself wandering to the star-canopied suburban spots.

The Federal Government in June made the smallest allotment of surplus foods for distribution among Home Relief families in New York City since surplus foods were made available in October, 1933, it was reported yesterday by the Commodities Distribution Division to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP). -- The White Sox shelled four Boston pitchers for a 13-2 triumph today to square the four-game series. They made a total of seventeen hits but clinched the game in the opening frame, when they reached Joe Scarella for three runs.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows.

ROME, July 12. -- Only by the exercise of conscious and almost visible effort at self-control did the Italian press today refrain from crowing too blatantly over that part of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the British House of Commons yesterday dealing with the Ethiopian question.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Expenditures by the electric power industry of $301,865 on activities by which defeat of the administration's Utility Holding Company Bill was sought were spread on the record today at the Senate lobby investigation as the opening hearing got under way with such dramatic suddenness that it proceded through most of the day without an audience.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 12. -- Harvey Shaffer of the Meadow Brook Club and Jarvis S. Hicks Jr. of Seawane tied for the qualifying medal in the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tourney today, each registering a par 72.

The earth trembled in far-off Copiapo, Chile, yesterday, not once, but sixty-four times, as if in response to the bidding of a man in a Greenwich Village apartment. On last Wednesday the time and place of this earthquake was forecast by Reuben Greenspan, 31-year-old teacher of mathematics and navigation at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and a geophysicist and seismologist in his spare time.

Prospects that the Senate might act next Monday on AAA amendments putting a processing tax on both rayon and silk dismayed the trade here yesterday. The rayon amendment, proposed by Senator Smith, would tax the coarser deniers of rayon, exempting those above 100 denier.

Routine price fixing based on the July delivery steadied prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and the list closed with gains of 5 to 8 points. Further selling of October against purchases of May was a feature of the trading, but as July contracts were in demand and being supplied against purchases of October 33 points lower, selling pressure had little effect on near deliveries.

With the world record holder, Discovery, certain to rule a short priced favorite despite top weight of 132 pounds, the $10,000 added Butler Handicap will be run today at Empire City. The Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt star, which set the universal figures for a mile and a furlong in the Brooklyn Handicap, will be running again at that distance and will be opposed by five others.

The Scots have a special name for those who are about to receive honorary degrees from their universities: "honorary graduands." The word derives from the gerundive of the Latin verb graduare and from a time when all university men knew that the gerund was a form of the verb "capable of "being construed as a substantive but "still retaining the regimen of the "verb," and when teachers of a certain type were called "gerund-grinders."

I should like to protest against the methods that the State Highway Department is pursuing in putting State roads through some of the most beautiful regions of the Adirondacks, such, for example, as the road through Chapel Pond, and the road at present being made through Keene Valley.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Newspaper and magazine publishers were virtually assured today that their proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act would be included in the omnibus amending measure now pending before the Senate.

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, yesterday denied a report that Irving Wexler, alias Waxey Gordon, the racketeer now in a Federal penitentiary, was part owner of the National Grain Yeast Corporation of Belleville, N.J., of which Mr. Roosevelt recently was elected president.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 12. -The Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club gymkhana is to be held here tomorrow afternoon at Holmesdale. Twenty-one persons will take part in twelve junior and senior events. Charles H. Wilson will be judge. Mrs. Maurice Woolverton of New Lebanon, N.Y., is general chairman.

All the available spheres of interest on the terrestrial globe being exhausted, with the exception of Ethiopia, people are turning their attention to the skies. An international congress of astronomers is meeting in Paris.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- To avoid confusion in connection with its efforts for regulation of oil and gas interests, under the Securities Act of 1933, the SEC today made public a compilation of all rules, regulations, forms and opinions which have been issued.

QUEBEC, July 12. -- Douglas Fair-banks and Sylvia, Lady Ashley, sailed from Quebec this afternoon, bound for England and Japan. No marriage ceremony had been performed in Quebec up to the time the boat sailed.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- A protest against Secretary Morgenthau's appointment of Peter Grimm as his adviser on Federal real estate financing was sent to President Roosevelt today by the special committee investigating the New Yorker's connection with real estate bondholders' reorganizations.

TRENTON, July 12. -- The State Board of Bar Examiners announced today that of the 574 persons who took the April examinations for attorneys and counselors, 220 were successful. In both tests those who failed exceeded the number of those who passed.

BERLIN, July 12 (AP). -- Joe Jacobs, American manager of Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion, tonight said the German slugger had agreed to fight Joe Louis, Detroit Negro, in New York in September.
Money market showed no change. Demand for funds was light and quotations unchanged for all classes.

The International Longshoremen's Association refused yesterday to record itself in favor of a thirtyhour week for waterfront employes, the use of "hiring halls" supervised by the men, formation of a national labor political party and the formation of a maritime federation.

The so-called "loop" plan for a highway approach in New Jersey to the Midtown Tunnel under the Hudson River was approved last night by the Weehawken (N.J.) Township Committee at a meeting in the Town Hall in Weehawken.

With $43,339,945 of new State and municipal bonds to be sold through competitive bidding next week, interest will centre chiefly in the $38,000,000 New York City corporate stock and serial bonds to be sold on Tuesday. The revised total of new bonds which came up for award this week is $17,706,494.

A wide search is being made by the police for John C. Jerome, 35-year-old fireman attached to Engine Company 26, at 220 West Thirty-seventh Street, who failed to report for duty on June 22 after leaving his apartment at 245 East Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- New York City became the focal point of a nation-wide search for Mrs. Evelyn Smith, 35-year-old former burlesque chorus girl, and her Chinese friend, Harry Jung, following an alleged confession by Mrs. Blanche Dunkel that her son-in-law, Ervin Lang, was murdered for hire and that the killing was accomplished unaided by Mrs. Smith.

Italian public sentiment -- or at least official sentiment -- seems to face both ways. It resents Secretary HULL'S statement to the Italian Ambassador in Washington that the United States viewed with deep concern the possibility of a war between Italy and Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The underwriting section of the Omnibus Banking Bill was sharply criticized today by President Roosevelt. His comment increased the probability that the section, which would permit banks to participate to a limited extent in underwriting, would be eliminated in the Senate debate or in conference.

RYE, N.Y., July 12. -- Splendidly jumped by Miss Phoebe Warren, the upstanding chestnut gelding Double Entry, owned by the Morelands Stables of Miss Elmina and William Brewster of Durham, Conn., today gained the first leg on the new Page Trophy, leading prize competition of the second day of the fifth annual Country Club Horse Show on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.

Drifting lazily through the entire trading session yesterday, the bond market was inclined to mark time, with disturbances of slight proportions in the utilities section. Transactions for the day on the Stock Exchange were $10,107,200, a drop of $2,107,900 from the sales on Thursday.

Several fundamental differences remain to be ironed out before any agreement can be reached as to a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, said yesterday after meeting representatives of bondholders and the management of that road.

NEW ORLEANS, July 12 (AP). -Senator Huey P. Long told a committee of Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley's "old regular" organization today that "it must be the people who put him (the Mayor) out." The Senator said he, would call a session of the State Legislature to act to remove Walmsley from office within twenty-four hours after the "old regulars" obtained approval of a majority of the city's voters for a petition requesting the Mayor's removal.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12. -- The voters' ball, given at Providence tonight under the direction of the Rhode Island League of Women Voters, was of special interest to many of the Newport colony because Mrs. Dan W. Jones was general chairman and Mrs. Walter Gurnee Dyer chairman of the beauty contest.

Under the caption "The Price of Liquor," Edward Hunter complains "the trouble is that the tax is written up so often that by the time the consumer gets it the cost is bordering on the prohibitive." To remedy this, he suggests "that the government forbid the multiplying of the tax by the various middlemen between the distillery and the consumer."

HARWICH, Mass., July 12. -- Traffic was tied in a knot and several hundred Cape Codders were turned away from district court today as Mrs. Sadie M. Shaughnessy of Somerville was convicted of threatening her Summer neighbor in the "battle of Creosote Beach."

Trading in commodity futures here yesterday was light and erratic as a rule, with cocoa, silk and hides firmer and sugar steady. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, tin, silk and rubber declined, while lard and cocoa advanced.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 12. -Appropriating $84,500 for flood relief purposes, the Binghamton City Council made formal application today for the assistance of Federal engineers in rehabilitation plans, which call for a new city river bridge and development of a flood-control system.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- A sweeping declaration in support of the Briand-Kellogg pact outlawing war as an instrument of national policy was issued by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in terms that were tantamount to a reminder to Italy in her dispute with Ethiopia that she had given her word by treaty never to seek the solution of controversies with another nation except by pacific means.

Retail distribution last week exceeded the sales figures of a year ago by unexpectedly large percentages, while the recovery in wholesale markets was marked, as Fall buying made an auspicious start, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

According to a cable dispatch received yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the convention of Brazilian coffee growers on Thursday approved the following suggestions to the Federal Government, together with measures to remain in force until Dec. 31, 1937:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- After much dissension in committee, the bill for which President Roosevelt asked to forbid suits against the government by holders of gold-clause securities was reported favorably today by the House Committee on Banking and Currency.

The first obstacle was thrown yesterday in the path of the impending racket investigation in New York County for which Thomas E. Dewey has been appointed special prosecutor. It came in the form of a taxpayer's suit to restrain the city from appropriating money for such an inquiry.

Torrid and rainy weather took its toll of retail trade in the metropolitan area this week, with the result that sales of leading department stores here fell under the figures for the same week a year ago, according to reports by retail executives.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 12. -- Torrential rains descended on this flood-stricken city, for the second time within a week, today and threw a momentary scare into thousands who are suffering from the effects of the first inundation.

The Guaranty Trust Company will join other banks next week in putting collateral of the Insull utility groups on the auction block. On Wednesday it will offer at 2:30 P.M. the collateral securing its loans to Insull Utility Investments, Inc.

Although new bond financing this week was considerably below the totals for the three weeks immediately preceding, the aggregate this week of $61,376,000 was far above that of the corresponding period last year when new issues amounting to $38,355,000 were marketed.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Anxiety over inflation and the nation's credit today deferred a Senate committee decision on administration legislation to protect the revamped monetary system from legal attacks.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12. -- Ulster's gay celebration today of the 245th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne became riotous after sundown, when three persons were shot dead and forty were wounded.

Henry H. Daniels of Choate School, seeded second, was eliminated by Aloysius Doyle of Woodhaven, ranked eighth, in a major upset in the Greater New York junior and boys' tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. Doyle took the quarter-final encounter in straight sets, 6-2, 6-2.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12. -- Pete Bostwick's Aiken Cyclones scored a one-sided victory over Roslyn, and the Meadow Larks defeated Rockaway at the Meadow Brook Club today in second-round Wheatley Cups tournament games. The Cyclones had things very much their own way to defeat Roslyn, 22 to 4, and the young team of Meadow Larks took a hard game from Rockaway, 9 to 4.

The Roosevelt Medal for 1935 will be bestowed upon Dr. William H. Park, director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Health Department, at a dinner in Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth, on Oct. 27, it was announced last night by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

For several days the Senate has been engaged in sharp controversy over a bill proposing to increase the present authority of AAA. Its enactment has been urged by officials of that agency, who insist that they must have the powers it proposes to confer if they are to carry out the mandate of Congress to restore "parity" to agriculture.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Anxiety over inflation and the nation's credit today deferred a Senate committee decision on administration legislation to protect the revamped monetary system from legal attacks.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12. -- Ulster's gay celebration today of the 245th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne became riotous after sundown, when three persons were shot dead and forty were wounded.

Henry H. Daniels of Choate School, seeded second, was eliminated by Aloysius Doyle of Woodhaven, ranked eighth, in a major upset in the Greater New York junior and boys' tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. Doyle took the quarter-final encounter in straight sets, 6-2, 6-2.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12. -- Pete Bostwick's Aiken Cyclones scored a one-sided victory over Roslyn, and the Meadow Larks defeated Rockaway at the Meadow Brook Club today in second-round Wheatley Cups tournament games. The Cyclones had things very much their own way to defeat Roslyn, 22 to 4, and the young team of Meadow Larks took a hard game from Rockaway, 9 to 4.

The Roosevelt Medal for 1935 will be bestowed upon Dr. William H. Park, director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Health Department, at a dinner in Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth, on Oct. 27, it was announced last night by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

For several days the Senate has been engaged in sharp controversy over a bill proposing to increase the present authority of AAA. Its enactment has been urged by officials of that agency, who insist that they must have the powers it proposes to confer if they are to carry out the mandate of Congress to restore "parity" to agriculture.

ADDRESSING the International Association of Chiefs of Police at Atlantic City last Wednesday, Sidney J. Williams, director of the Public Safety Division of the National Safety Council, again presented the case for uniformity in traffic regulations.

TRADE results varied in the week over various sections of the country. In this area the hot spell reduced volume to a point where it was running only about even with a year ago. Storms and floods in other districts affected sales adversely.

BECAUSE of public apathy and severe critical treatment, Warner Brothers are abandoning the vast and lush musicals that have been indigenous to the studio and, at least for the time being, will confine themselves to the less pretentious and more intimate form of tune film.

Active negotiations are expected to begin this week between investment bankers and brokers and the Securities and Exchange Commission relative to the regulations governing price-pegging and other stabilizing market operations which the SEC is empowered to draft by Section 9 (6) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

During the past fortnight skippers of two clubs of the metropolitan area led interesting cruises to ports on Long Island Sound. Many other clubs have ambitious runs scheduled and several more are planning to revive annual cruises that were abandoned in recent years.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- With the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee operating under an involuntary moratorium on testimony, a move was under way in the House today to combine the House inquiry with thane of the Senate to avoid duplication and save one of the $50,000 appropriations.

Melvin Lapman of the Bronx and Aloysius Doyle of Woodhaven gained the final of the junior singles and Joseph Fishbach of De Witt Clinton High School became the boys' champion yesterday in the Greater New York junior and boys' tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
RUMSON, N.J., July 13. -- Rumson defeated the United States Army four, 12 to 9, today on Herbert Memorial Field in their third match in three weeks.

THERE was a bit of a laugh enjoyed locally last week at the revelation that Brooklyn, the borough of churches, was the scene of one of the Warner musical films. The merriment had to be tempered, somewhat, by the discovery it was just a little musical film, a Vitaphone two-reeler in fact, and that the Busby Berkeley Beauties were not to be used.

QUAKERS and pirates and ladies in linsey-woolsey are strolling through Boston Common; also gentlemen in powdered wigs and lovely satin breeches; a milk-maid with shining pails and ruffled pantalettes; Indians and Puritans and swaggering sea captains. Past the pillories and along to the ducking stool they wander back and forth the whole day through.

A SHALLOW but vociferous set of young people have the principal and supplementary parts in this story of a budding jazz musician's disturbed first year of married life. Paul is 25, swell-headed and unstable, banjoist and crooner of a popular dance orchestra playing hotel, amusement-park and cabaret engagements in the more flourishing sections of the Southwest.

ASSUMING that judges in this State agree with Federal District Judge James C. Michael of the Second Judicial District in Minnesota, anybody can fly, anywhere in New York State, without Federal license or identification for plane, or pilot license, provided the pilot stays within the borders of the State and, presumably, whether he flies for pleasure or for profit.

MONTREAL. -- Visitors here this week will have an opportunity to go aboard a British warship, as H.M.S. York -- flagship of the America and West Indies Squadron -- is due to arrive up the St. Lawrence River on Wednesday and will remain in the port of Montreal for several days.

TOMORROW night, between 12:09 and 1:50 A.M., Eastern daylight-saving time, a total eclipse of the moon will be visible in most parts of the United States, for the first time since Nov. 27, 1928. The moon will not completely vanish from sight, but will shine with a peculiar copper-red color, an effect due to the earth's atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Railroads serving the Texas Company and Western Paving Company plants were ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to cease by Sept. 3 the practice of allowing compensation for switching of cars within the property of the shipping companies.

Two armed thugs who apparently believe that tourist agencies hold large cash sums in their offices donned white gloves yesterday morning and raided the safe of William L. Strauss Son, 640 Madison Avenue, after corralling three employes and a window cleaner in a closet.

A new flaming red day lily is in bloom in the experimental beds at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. The new flower was originated by Dr. A. B. Stout, director of the laboratories at the Botanical Garden, and is as yet unnamed.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 13 (AP). -- Two persons were killed and twenty injured in a second night of rioting that began yesterday with the celebration of the 245th anniversary of the battle of the Boyne. In two days of fighting between Catholics and Protestant Orangemen four have been killed and sixty-six injured.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 12 unless specified:

WESTBURY, L.I., July 13. -- The Fox Hunters, composed of three young players who have been well trained in polo, with a fourth who has had a bit more experience, galloped into the final round of the Wheatley Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Steadily Chicago is gaining ground in its war on crime. The record for the first six months of 1935, as compared with that for the same period a year ago, shows a reduction of 20 per cent in all forms of commercial offenses.
DES MOINES, July 13 (AP). -- A strike of 250 union bakers tonight threatened a "breadless Sunday" for the families of many housewives who scorned mixing and baking their own dough.

Intensive pressure upon the Senate to ratify the sanitary convention between this country and Argentina will be brought by foreign trade interests this week. Approval of the measure, it was pointed out, will lift the ban on imports of Argentine meats, particularly mutton from Patagonia, and end a rift which has existed between business interests in the two countries for more than six years.

Now that we are going through such a disquieting stage of pro and anti radical fervor, it Seems to me that there are two constructive things we might do which I feel sure would be of great value in awakening in our young people an appreciation of citizenship and a proper recognition and valuation of our outstanding men and women.
