IN the dual role of pianist and conductor, Jose Iturbi will give Grieg's piano concerto the place of honor on tonight's program at the Lewisohn Stadium, inaugurating another week of symphony, ballet and opera. He also will play a group of piano compositions by Spanish composers, including Albeniz's "Sevilla," No. 3, Granados's "Goyescas," No. 4, and the Ritual Dance of Fire from de Falla's "El Amor Brujo.

With advance boom buying conspicuous by its absence, but with prices firm and confidence shown that sales gains of 10 per cent or more will feature retail trade this Fall, initial purchasing activity for next season in major lines got off to a good start last week, according to the consensus of buyers and manufacturers here.

BRUSSELS, July 13. -- Newspapers here print little comment on Belgium's recognition of the Soviet Union concluded at Paris after long negotiations between the Belgian and Soviet Ambassadors, but it is pointed out that Antwerp suffered greatly from non-recognition that Belgium's trade balance is unfavorable.

THE Whiteface Mountain Memorial Highway, which will be opened next Saturday, reveals a world of scenic wonder and engineering skill that make it one of the most interesting eight-mile stretches of roadway in existence.
LONDON, July 13. -- Jack Lovelock, New Zealand's great miler, was beaten at his specialty today by an English club runner, Stanley Wooderson, unknown outside his native land.

MORE than a mile above the sea level, on a plateau of the American Southwest, two hundred and fifty men are building a new capitol. It is not the capitol of a State. Its stone walls rise in shapes that are strange to most Americans; its name -- Nee Alneeng -- falls with a strange accent.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Merchants Association of New York formally asked Congress today to refuse to enact at this session the legislation recently proposed by President Roosevelt for higher taxes on large incomes of corporations and individuals, and on large estates.

EIFFEL TOWER, Paris, has been heard several times recently, particularly on Sunday nights, testing for the benefit of radio amateur operators. The call letters are FLE and the transmissions are on two waves simultaneously, about 9,370 kilocycles (32 m.) and 4,000 kilocycles (75 m.).

Walker Buckner, vice president and chairman of the executive committee of the New York Life Insurance Company, will complete fifty years of service with that company tomorrow. At the age of 14 he began working for the company as an office boy.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 13. -- A summary of conditions of highways in the counties affected by the recent flood was issued today by the Division of Highways on advices from district engineers. The report covers conditions for tomorrow and Monday.

PARIS, July 11. -- The night racing at Longchamps was the crowing event of the social season; it came to a grand finale with an apotheosis of lights and fashions. All of smart Paris was in gala evening dress.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 13. -- Samuel Reshevsky of New York today regained an undisputed lead in the international tournament at the annual congress of the British Chess Federation in session at the Town Hall. He defeated B.H. Wood of Birmingham, who had been tied for first place with Reshevsky and Miss Vera Menchik, with a king's Indian defense after twenty-eight moves.
Preparations for war in East Africa continued to be pushed last week in Signor Mussolini's and Haile Selassie's camps.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- House leaders arranged today to bring up Thursday the bill to bulwark the administration's monetary by forbidding gold clause program suits. The legislation, requested by President Roosevelt, is expected to go through in one day with little trouble.

A detailed report of the activities of the Pacific Coast Secretariat, an organization said to be the agent of the Central Communist party in the United States in the spread of propaganda among workingmen in Western ports, was read into the records of the quadrennial convention of the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the association.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The texts of the State Department's announcement of the trade agreement with the Soviet Union, of the identical notes exchanged by Ambassador Bullitt and Foreign Commissar Litvinoff, and of the statement issued by Mr. Bullitt in Moscow follow:
Current reports that the Italian Government would soon enter the international market for a loan sufficient to finance its Ethiopian campaign was discounted in New York financial circles yesterday.
A large black spider attempted to demonstrate yesterday in the Bronx that it could overcome a seven-inch garter snake.

With the composer conducting, a novelty was performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony at last night's orchestral concert in the Lewisohn Stadium, the new work being "The Lido," a symphonic sketch by Theodore Cella.

THE overnight tourist cottage, which began as a humble roadside shack a few years ago, is growing civilized -- becoming more attractive in looks and more complete and modern in equipment. Along the nation's highways hundreds of bright new shelters are opening their doors to the motoring guest this season.
Magistrate Frank Oliver approves of people singing in their backyards these hot evenings and disapproves of "cranks who run the Police Department."

PHILADELPHIA, July 12. -- Voters lost count this week of the number of candidates willing to be headlined in November when an answer is recorded to the question, "Is Philadelphia to have its first Democratic Mayor in more than a half century?"
LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP). -- A distinct earthquake shook parts of Southern California early today, but no damage was reported.

FOR many years chemists and fuel engineers in many lands have tried to develop a process for converting the highly inflammable liquid gasoline into a non-explosive solid form. The extent of the research is indicated by the fact that more than 200 patents have been granted for solid fuels.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 13 (AP). -Luke Lea, former United States Senator from Tennessee, failed today in his move to obtain a pardon from the North Carolina State prison. The pardon was denied by Governor Ehringhaus.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 13.--Ending a tour of the flood-stricken area with an estimate of public and private damage of $25,000,000, Governor Lehman today appealed to President Roosevelt for Federal aid.

THE author of "The Scarlet Pimpernel," which has recently taken a new lease on life in the movies, has devoted her latest historical romance to the missing Dauphin of France. The mystery of the little son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette has provided a theme for many writers.

VICTOR has managed to anticipate Edward Johnson's latest dispatch from Europe by the release of two disks by Marjorie Lawrence which carry passages that should have been recorded long since -- the whole of the final scene, the climax of Strauss's "Salome."

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 13. -- With the end of the first week's training of the largest group ever to assemble at Camp Dix for the Citizens Military Training Camp, the schedule for next week's training has been tightend materially.
BERLIN, July 13. -- German ardor for union with Austria is undergoing a significant chilling. Nazi championing of an Austro-German racial community more recently has also become less vociferous.

What the critics call boondoggling, and what the Emergency Relief Bureau call craft work, is to continue in New York with the sanction of General Hugh S. Johnson. The relief authorities are still to provide social agencies and settlement houses with teachers who will direct children in recreational activities that include various handicrafts and the making of numerous objects ranging from flower boxes to airplane models.

Edward Corsi, director of the Home Relief Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau, will be sworn in as Second Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare either tomorrow or on Wednesday, it was announced last night by a representative of the Mayor's office.

TO the dictum that truth is stranger than fiction one might add after reading this book that it is not nearly so interesting. Mr. MacClure has told the stories, from the records, of several women who were accused of various crimes, chiefly murder.

DALLAS, July 13. -- Excessively warm weather has prevailed over the Eleventh Federal Reserve District for the last week, with only occasional and scattered showers. The weather has been favorable for cotton, but has not served to stimulate business.

CENTRAL CITY, Col. THE person whose hobby is noting automobile license plates from various States would have a fertile field at Central City these first weeks of July. Up through winding canyons and along the zigzag mountain switch-backs, caravans of cars are moving to a common destination -the Old Opera House at Central City. For the fame of its Play Festivals, now in the fourth annual edition, is becoming nation-wide.

A SET of four sixteenth century Tournai tapestries depicting incidents in the life of Hercules has just been given to the Metropolitan Museum by Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim in memory of her husband. The tapestries hung for several years in the Armor Court and, having entered the museum's permanent collection, will be on public view for the remainder of this month in the Room of Recent Accessions.

THE war was the dominating experience in Arnold Zweig's life. Its recollection has such a hold upan him that it colors his psychology, his Weltanschauung. the very figures of speech in his writing. His two great novels, "The Case of Sergeant Grischa" and "Young Woman of 1914," sprang directly from his need to probe for the origins of this blight upon mankind.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., July 13. -- More than 500 men, women and children were frightened here today when a shark appeared in the midst of swimmers a few hundred feet from shore. Killed later by Coast Guardsmen, the shark was found to be nine and a half feet long and embedded in its jaw was a twelve-inch section of the cutlass of a swordfish, apparently the victim of a deep-sea battle.
A motley collection of 800 animals arrived at Staten Island yesterday on the Isthmian freighter Steel Traveler from the Malay Peninsula, where they were collected by Frank Buck, big-game hunter.

IN a foreword to this book, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, says that the council "has, as one of its purposes, the dissemination of information concerning American shipping conditions."

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, was asked yesterday by John H. Baker, executive secretary of the National Association of Audubon Societies, at 1,775 Broadway, to urge President Roosevelt to issue an executive order imposing a closed season of one year on migratory waterfowl.

The United States is showing an increasing interest in Russia, as is made evident by a 50 per cent increase in four years in the number of college students studying the Russian language, Professor George Z. Patrick of the University of California asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The silly season has flowered again with the ripening of a new crop of rumors, obviously without foundation, to the effect that President Roosevelt's health is not all that it might be.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- William P. Lambertson, Republican Representative from Kansas, says golf is twice as much fun if played barefooted. And, he insists, it is healthful.

LONDON. THE centenary of the death of William Cobbett has just been celebrated by a large number of highly appreciative articles in the British press. That he should thus be remembered 100 years later would scarcely have surprised Cobbett himself, for he was not overmodest in his estimate of his own merits, but he would never have anticipated the line that these tributes would take.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP). -- The Cubs ran a winning streak to six games today by turning back the Braves, 10 to 2 and 3 to 1, in both ends of a double-header before 11,500.
It might be just as well not to judge too harshly the Congressional antics of last week. Washington was no place for human beings. Witness:
ANNAPOLIS, July 13 (AP). -- President Roosevelt left the capital today for a week-end with Democratic political leaders of all schools of thought at the Jefferson Island Club in Chesapeake Bay.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP). -- Scoring all their runs in the second inning, the Indians defeated the Red Sox today, 4 to 2, in the opening contest of their four-game battle for a berth in the first division. Willis I-Iudlin pitched steadily, holding the Red Sox to seven hits.
BISMARCK, N.D., July 13 (AP). -Friends and foes of North Dakota's new 2 per cent sales tax closed their campaigns today to await the will of the voters in a special referendum Monday.

This little volume proves to be, as its time indicates, nothing more ambitious than a note. And it covers ground that has now become very familiar. But Mr. Wackrill, Roger Fry remarks, is "a writer who can be sympathetic to new manifestations" and who is "ready to welcome the possibility of new developments," without foolishly turning his back on general art principles that exert their sovereignty through the ages.

HAVING been expelled from the United States Marines (on a charge that later proved to be false) and disowned by his father, young Cleve Carroll of Tennessee set out for California's goldfields, but became stranded in Nicaragua and joined the filibusters of William Walker, that strange little lawyer-doctor-editor and rare combination of dreamer and man of action who made himself president of Nicaragua -- only to be carried off ignominiously on an American warship.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Art patron as well as relief expert, Harry L. Hopkins today finished handing out CWA paintings, sculpture and etchings and called them so good that there would be more where they came from, created by artists who still haven't jobs.

RENO, Nev., July 13. -- Solution of the mysterious disappearance nearly sixteen months ago of Roy J. Frisch, Reno banker, appeared nearer tonight as authorities investigated the story Frisch was slain by Baby Face Nelson.

Heretofore the Tennessee Valley Authority has had three broad functions: to furnish cheap light and power to the humble valley housewife and make the economic wilderness round about her blossom like the rose, to furnish Senator NORRIS, Senator WHEELER and their friends a club with which to belabor the "Power Trust," and to supply a "yardstick" for electric rates by which to measure those of private companies.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Out of the confusion and political bickerings of the Tydings committee's investigation of conditions in the Virgin Islands, only one indisputable fact has thus far been established -- indeed, conceded by all hands.

A second World War, more widespread, more devastating and of greater duration than the 1914-18 conflict, was envisaged as a possible result of the impending Italo-Ethiopian war in an interview here yesterday by Rassarl Heshla Tamanya, a Falasha princess of Ethiopia, and first cousin to Emperor Haile Selassie of that nation.

SINCE this is to all intents and purposes Fokine month in New York, it is entirely appropriate that Cyril W. Beaumont's new book called "Michel Fokine and His Ballets" should have made its appearance at this time.

LOUISVILLE, July 12. -- There is a reason for the optimistic commercial agency reports on Kentucky agriculture. It lies largely in the $15,000,000 which a beneficent Federal Government has poured into the farmers' hitherto practically empty purses.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during June was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 385,946 bales of lint, and 61,905 bales of linters, compared with 469,250 and 65,501 in May this year, and 363,262 and 54,587 during June last year.

WHEN the faculty of the University of Mexico was planning its Summer courses for this year, one young Professor of Literature proposed a course in books about Mexico written by foreigners. But he gave up the idea, he says, because he came to the conclusion that the field was too vast to be covered in six weeks; the American authors alone would take a full semester.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 13. -- An insect bite and complications proved fatal today to John Tomashunas, 48, a Shickshinny miner here, who survived entombment for five days and six nights in the colliery of the Westend Coal Company in 1931.

AFTER six years on the WJZ network, Amos 'n' Andy move across the dial to WEAF's hook-up tomorrow night at 7 o'clock. Advocates of such program rotation contend a new audience is found to supplement the faithful followers who may tune in the new wave.

THE fourth annual music festival at Massanetta Springs, Va., on the Spottswood Trail, four miles east of Harrisonburg, scheduled for Thursday and Friday, will be preceded on Tuesday night by a hymn-singing program under the leadership of Dr. John Finley Williamson, head of the Westminster Choir School and musical director of the festival.

Support of pending amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act providing for regulation of milk shipments in interstate commerce was urged yesterday upon the Senators of the seven States represented on the Governor's committee to control milk traffic between these States.

THE thing one notes most quickly on glancing at this book is that American literary prizes far exceed in number all the rest together. More than sixty famous prizes, British, Continental and American, are listed and described, and over two-thirds of these are American, while of the book's fifty-seven pages it has needed only twenty-one to list and tell the story of those offered across the Atlantic.

Fifty Women will tee off tomorrow morning in the Fairfield and Westchester open golf championship at the Wee Burn Club in Noroton, Conn., in the annual tournament, which will continue through Wednesday.

RYE, N.Y., July 13. -- Golf's most sensational shot, a hole in one, enabled Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot to add the Sweetser Victory Cup tourney to his list of golf triumphs in a grand closing round of 69 at the Westchester Country Club today.

AT last year's meeting of the American Chemical Society, Thomas Midgley Jr., who produced knockless gasoline by the use of tetraethyl lead, predicted the tapping on a commercial scale of the estimated three-quadrillion-dollar treasure in pure gold known to exist in very dilute form in the waters of the seven seas.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Contributions of $78,169 for the relief of New York flood victims were reported by the American Red Cross today. It was estimated by Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, retired, chairman of the organization, that $350,000 would be required to aid about 3,000 families.

After an exchange of cablegrams with Joe Jacobs, who is in Germany with Max Schmeling, Mike Jacobs, secretary of the Twentieth Century Sports Club, announced yeesterday that he will stage a fifteen-round bout between Schmeling and Joe Louis at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 17 or 18.

SOME day Herbert Hoover may be regarded as one of this generation's strongest influences for peace. He has built a monument to the greatest catastrophe of the modern world. The monument bears his name -- the Hoover War Library.

RADIO'S epidemic of amateur hours, in which a wrestler faces the microphone to mimic barnyard noises, while dog catchers and barbers turn singers, is not likely to spread across the sea, in the opinion of John Watt, producer of the British Broadcasting Corporation, a recent visitor in New York.

BOSTON, July 11. -- Uncertainty pervades the New England textile industry in both its branches. In woolen the volume of production is high, but labor is making demands which the operators state they cannot accept.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 13. -- Connected informally with the theatre during his entire career through his friendships with actors, playwrights and stage authorities, Dr. Charles L. Safford, music director of the Mohawk Drama Festival, has at last achieved a long-cherished ambition -- to take part in an important enterprise in the drama.

STUDENTS of folklore have turned their attention toward the International Folk Dance Festival, to be held in London, England, July 15 to 20, under the auspices of the English Folk Dance and Song Society and the British National Committee on Folk Arts.

Broadly speaking, I suppose every one reacted favorably toward President Roosevelt's latest expressed desire to build a better social order. But the nearsighted idea that it can be accomplished by increasing taxation must, if carried too far, force the nation into social demoralization.

BERLIN, July 13. -- Signing of the Soviet-United States trade agreement is a blow to German hopes and possibly to some of the Reichs-bank's well-laid plans. Despite their opposition to everything communistic, the heads of the Nazi regime are anxious to win as much Soviet trade as possible.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 13. -- Lord and Lady Baden-Powell, Chief Scout and Chief Girl Guide of the world, were greeted by 1,500 Girl Scouts here today when they visited Camp Edith Macy, national Girl Scout leaders' training camp, and the adjoining Camp Andrea, national Girl Scout camp.
CLEVELAND, July 12. -- Liberal Republicanism, breaking away from the Old Guard leaders, stated its case in the regional conference held here this week under the auspices of the Republican Crusaders.

DRIVING through the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, winding up into the Berkshires or the Catskills, following the shore route north to Maine, or rolling over the Poconos headed for the Middle West, the tourist motorist keeps a weather eye out for eating places along the road.

Robert Aitken, well-known American sculptor, and his wife, Mrs. Joan Aitken, were severely injured early yesterday morning when their automobile skidded on a wet street and crashed into an elevated pillar at Flatbush and Fifth Avenues, Brooklyn.

LISBON. -- Once again the Portuguese are perturbed about their African colonies. They get the "jitters" every time some article is published abroad which even insinuates that their colonies might be in better hands or endeavors to develop the idea that at least one or two countries in Europe desire African territory which they do not possess.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A movement to win delegates for former President Hoover in the Ohio Presidential primaries through a favorite-son "stalking horse" has gained such headway as to arouse the opposition of the anti-Hoover forces here and in Ohio.

Play starts today in the first of the season's national polo championships, the Junior, with two games at the Burnt Hills Polo Club, Bedminster, N.J., at 4 P.M. The Aiken Knights of Long Island clash with Monmouth County, one of the New Jersey teams in the draw, and at 5 o'clock Long Island meets Burnt Mills, the defending champion, and representative of the club that is host to ten other teams in this tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- If Congress were in fact as in theory an independent, coordinate branch of the government, it could, and probably would, complete all essential legislation now pending and adjourn the present session before another week-end.

The N.E.A. convention in Denver is doubtless right in its feeling that America is far from what it should be from an educational standpoint. It is doubtful, however, if, in stressing the need for increased educational facilities, it has placed its finger upon the chief source of difficulty.

Relief from the heat wave, broken after last midnight by showers, held generally throughout yesterday. A prediction that the torrid weather would not return for another day at least was contained in the official forecast for today -- fair with moderate temperatures.
In the editorial introduction to "The Modern Movement in Painting" we are told that.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published recently a dispatch from Washington concerning the restoration of a theatre in Charleston, S.C., with a grant of PWA funds. The item referred to a theatre "built in 1735 and said to be the first theatre in this country."
If all goes well the Triborough Bridge, which has been described as the greatest improvement in New York City this generation has seen, will be opened to traffic just about one year from today.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP). -- Wild Bill Hallahan, celebrating a return to his old hurling form, held the Phillies to two scratch hits today as the world champion Cardinals earned their eighth consecutive victory, 4 to 0. Hallahan's third straight triumph in two weeks still left St. Louis seven and a half games behind the league-leading Giants.

Political bedfellows are here defined as "those who like the same bunk." A committee is "a group of men who keep minutes and waste hours." Alimony is "a fine levied on a man guilty of matrimony." These diverting notations from this collection of "definitions not found in dictionaries" were written by John Garland Pollard, former Governor of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- A move to push the Farm Adjustment Bill through the Senate early next week and get it into conference was started today by Senator Smith of South Carolina, who has charge of the bill.

Sixteen bond issues in which trading was to have been suspended at the close of business tomorrow by the New York Stock Exchange will be retained on the list as the result of a ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday extending the time for permanently registering them until Nov. 5.

PRAGUE, July 5, 1935. NOT in some time has the operatic work of a native composer attracted in Czechslovakia as much attention as Otakar Ostrcil's "Honzovo kralovstvi" ("Hans's Kingdom"), produced in Prague recently after previous hearings in Bruenn and in Maerisch-Ostrau.

After nearly two weeks of supreme Summer weather here on the Maine coast, a northeaster descended upon us, and now the third day of its gray dictatorship still holds us incommunicado from all that splendor of blue and gold.

WHEN the family migrates to the seashore, the mountains or the woods for a few weeks of change and relaxation, simple living conditions, to provide the maximum of rest and the minimum of household care, are usually in order.

Macmillan's new "Modern Readers' Series" makes a fine beginning here. It is astonishing to see how handsomely got out these books are -- they are bound in cloth, printed on the sort of paper and in the general size you associate with a good novel -- at the price of 90 cents.
The city has no right to charge rent to electric companies for manholes sunk in city streets for the installation of electrical transformers, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn decided yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- The flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society, to be held on July 25 and 26 in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street, gives every indication of being the most colorful and imposing one in many years.

With an excellent Fall season anticipated, arrivals of out-of-town buyers here last week were even more numerous than anticipated, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
RAPID CITY, S.D., July 13. -- The exodus from the stratosphere camp started today, but there remains a possibility of a flight this year -- from another base.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 13. -- The reported investigation by Federal agents of a murder mystery in which President Roosevelt was said to be interested because of important political figures involved was verified here today by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

THIS is the season of the year when blatant radio loud-speakers are condemned as a nuisance by disturbed neighbors. Especially in apartment centres complaints are heard that thoughtless neighbors operate their radios too loudly, while open windows facilitate the "broadcast," and agitate nerves on a hot day or night.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13. -The opening of the thirty-seventh race week of the Larchmont Yacht Club was celebrated tonight with the flag officers' ball.

The Police Department is going through another of those recurrent upheavals which have marked its spectacular history for many years. Again the department is being shaken up and, as usual, most of the shake-up centres around the Detective Bureau.

MAYBE it was because he had grown extremely fond of America. Maybe a tempting invitation to visit the mountains of West Virginia had been too strong. Or maybe the dangling bait of a Hollywood film engagement had been flashed before his roguish eyes.

RYE, N.Y., July 13. -- Repeating his brilliant victory in the Page Trophy event, the superb chestnut gelding Double Entry, owned by the Morelands Stables of Miss Elaine and William Brewster of Durham, Conn., and once more jumped in faultless fashion by Miss Phoebe Warren, today won the Albee Trophy for hunters in the third day of the fifth annual Country Club Horse Show on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club.
HERE is a lively and engrossing tale of further adventures of young Chip Bennett, cowboy of the Flying U, whose quick thinking and rapid action have been celebrated in other novels by the author.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad announced yesterday that its lines to Syracuse and Ithaca, which have been blocked by flood conditions, were reopened during the afternoon, that the Buffalo line was expected to resume service some time last night, and that the Utica line probably would be opened today.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, B.W.I. -American big-time gangsterism and the much-criticized American parole system figure in the most sensational double murder in this island's history, for which two Cuban drug traders are now in Spanishtown prison awaiting the gallows.

TWENTY French college students will leave Paris this week for an eighteen-day tour of Brittany in two de luxe freight cars. This is the first of a series of vacation trips planned by the French University Tourist Bureau in cooperation with the French League of Youth Hostels, and will be followed in August by larger groups, including an American contingent in three box cars.

PROFESSOR BERTAUX, on the evidence of this book, is one of those historians who believe that proper labeling suffices to explain literary phenomena. He examines literature always for its intellectual tendencies, and never for its representation of life.

DODGE CITY, Kan., July 11. -July is budget-making time for Kansas counties and towns, and this year, in spite of improved prospects and increased tax income, the pay-as-you-go policy will be adhered to.

HONOLULU, July 13 (AP). -- Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum commander of the Army's Hawaiian Department, announced today formation of a service command to coordinate military and civilian activities if Hawaii is blockaded in an emergency.

TWELVE prize pigs from Lloyd George's Surrey estate are bound for Labrador, gift to the International Grenfell Association. Eight Scottish engineers, paying all their own expenses, are building a road from St. Anthony to Hare Bay -- only a mile, but an important mile when snow piles high in Winter time.

There are only a handful of native Ethiopians in Harlem. There are not many American Negroes known to be in Ethiopia. Nevertheless, Harlem's quarter-million inhabitants are deeply concerned with the fate of that country which, except for Liberia, is the last independent stronghold of the black man on earth.

GOING into action without preliminaries, this exciting tale of mystery and adventure in the Canadian Northwest opens with the arrest of young Laramie at an isolated trading post for a murder committed there four days preceding, of which he now hears his first news.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 13. -- The championship talent in the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tourney, notably Eddie Driggs Jr. and T. Suffern (Tommy) Taller Jr., today had considerable more difficulty than either Jarvis S. (Chubby) Hicks Jr. or John F. Riddell Jr. in gaining the semi-finals.

SETTLED: A precedent in etiquette was set at the White House last week. At a state, dinner in honor of Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons of Australia, Mrs. Woodrow Wilson was placed just below the honor guests and just above the Cabinet members. Previously there had been no rule of precedence for Presidential widows.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP). -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Gallant Mac and Identify ran one-two today in the $7,500 added Massasoit Handicap over the mile and a sixteenth route at Suffolk Downs. It was Gallant Mac's first victory in six starts this year.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The New York Chinatown slaying of Elsie Sigel twenty-six years ago was linked to developments today in the hunt for Mrs. Evelyn Smith, key figure in the murder of Ervin Lang. Mrs. Smith and her Chinese friend, Harry Jung, are hiding in Chicago's Oriental quarter, police now believe.

PITTSBURGH, July 11. -- Whatever form the plan may take finally, a soft coal regulatory measure that will go to the limit of constitutional authority is expected from this session of Congress by the principal authorities on the industry here.

Denying that operations of the Tennessee Valley Authority are a fair "yardstick" for public-utility operations, Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, declared in a statement issued yesterday that those in charge of the project realized that they could not survive if they subjected their operations to requirements binding private utilities.

THE great exhibition of Italian art from Cimabue to Tiepolo is housed in the little Palace of the City of Paris. It contains 240 drawings, 150 engravings, 110 pieces of sculpture, 300 curiosities, 100 textiles and tapestries, 100 illuminated manuscripts and 490 pictures carefully selected by a council of famous experts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 13. -- A motion by counsel for dismissal of the charges against the Rev. Carl C. McIntire, pastor of the Collinswood (N.J.) Presbyterian Church, who is on trial here for alleged rebellion against the authority of the General Assembly of the church, was denied today.

In a second open letter to Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas, Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, urged yesterday that the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations or Senator Capper as a member of that committee, invite a group of prominent Americans to tell what they know of Communist activities in this country.

THE main exhibition at Mystic, Conn. this Summer will be divided into two sections. Watercolors, pastels, small oils and craft work are on view at the gallery of the Mystic Art Association and will remain until Aug. 6. After that the show, composed of largo oil paintings, work in black and white, and crafts, will be current from Aug. 10 to Sept. 15.

THE bigger home defense air force on which the British Government has decided may be considered not merely as a response to the multiplication of aircraft in other countries but as a token of the changing views of the strategy and tactics.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13. -Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a luncheon today at the Meadow Club for Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Tuckerman of Washington, D.C., who are spending several days here at their home in the Shinnecock Hills. Among other

EUROPE'S Summer playgrounds are just now at the height of the best season they have known since the crash of 1929. Beaches, mountains, lakes and spas all tell of crowds as numerous as any of the pre-depression crowds, although averaging out a bit younger and perhaps a bit more frugal.

Acting on a tip that they might find firearms, detectives raided early yesterday the five-room apartment of George Langhorne, 76, who for twenty-two years has operated an elevator at 14 Maiden Lane. They said they found four loaded pistols, and arrested Langhorne for violation of the Sullivan Law.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Federal Reserve Board issued today an interpretation of its margin requirements for securities Exchanges, stating the conditions by which, under certain circumstances, a bona fide cash transaction may be transferred from a customer's special cash account to his margin account. The text of the ruling follows:

How will American naiads fare at next year's Olympiad in Berlin? Will they prove capable of retaining the international leadership conclusively established at Antwerp in 1920 and brilliantly maintained at the games of 1924, '28 and '32?

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 13. -While relief agencies were mobilizing to rehabilitate sufferers in Southern New York's worst flood disaster, George F. Johnson, 78-year-old chairman of the board of the Endicott-Johnson Corporation, donned rubber boots and literally waded into the thick of things.

MANILA. -- Governor General Frank Murphy's return to the Philippine Islands crystallized more clearly than anything else has done in recent months the conflict between economics and politics in Philippine affairs.

THE first-run cinema temples in the midtown area are sure of at least three new films this week. This number may be augmented by the time Friday rolls around, but that does not seem likely at the moment. Anyway, here are the new ones: "Broadway Gondolier," with Dick Powell, Joan Blondell and Adolphe Menjou, is scheduled to arrive on Wednesday at the Strand;

A NEW rocket, which is expected to reach an altitude of forty miles into the stratosphere, has been invented recently in the Soviet Union by L. Korneyev, engineer for the Stratosphere Committee of the All-Union Scientific Aviation Engineering and Technical Society, according to a report in The Moscow News.

ALIMONY: The Alimony Reform League of New York State conducted a survey of divorced women who have sent their husbands to jail for non-payment of alimony. Each of the women was asked how long she wished to keep her husband behind bars. Forty-nine per cent answered: "Until he rots to death."

AS one looks at the array of nighties that lie on the counters they are irresistible. What to choose? Shall it be the flowered one (design as dainty as any ever painted on Dresden china), a combination of crepe and chiffon, the gown being of the former and the puffed sleeves and ruffles at the hem of the latter?

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- A full program of events will be held during the coming week at the White Mountain resorts, where the Summer stock companies provide entertainment and interest for many colonies.

General James G. Harbord, chairman of the New York chapter, and Douglas Gibbons, chairman of the disaster relief committee of the National Red Cross, issued an appeal to the citizens of Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday for funds to relieve the distress caused by last week's floods up-State.

An original plaster medallion of Admiral Byrd by the New York sculptor and artist, Vincent Schofield Wickham, has been forwarded to Washington for inclusion in President Roosevelt's private collection. The artist, whose work was done from a photographic study, was informed by the White House that the President would be glad to own the medallion.

Improvement in credit and collection conditions in the various wholesale markets throughout the country during the latter part of this year, after the usual Summer let-down, was predicted here yesterday by the National Association of Credit Men.

NANKING. -- Decreasing monetary contributions from Europe and America and an increasing assumption of the burden of leadership by Chinese laymen and clergy have resulted in a definite numerical decline in Protestant missionary representation in China.

THESE recent publications of the Modern Library constitute a rich and varied shelf of reading worth any one's time. To have put the whole of Symonds's "Renaissance in Italy" in two volumes of clear type and sound binding is a publishing achievement.

Some 8,000 home-relief subsistence gardens in New York City are yielding their first crops, and growers, notably in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Richmond, reported yesterday that they were gathering bumper harvests.

DANBURY, Conn., July 13. -- After fifteen years of extensive campaigning, William C. Capewell, veteran gunner of the home club, finally achieved his first major trapshooting championship by capturing the Connecticut State singles 200-target event at the thirty-fifth annual competition today.

Weather played an important part in determining business trends last week, the extreme heat stimulating the demand for merchandise at retail in some sections of the country, while in other areas high temperatures had a tendency to curtail purchases.

WASHINGTON and Los Angeles today are America's pre-eminent capitals of display. From these two cities come the political drama and the film drama of the nation. Both are centres of the same basic and altogether human industry -- that industry which combines art and science to enable man to rise by self-promotion and live by glamour.

THE "adventures" which Mr. Hambidge mentions in his subtitle are quite as much in spiritual as in material things. They, and, in fact, the whole book and the "Sunstead Series," to which it belongs, have a certain kinship with those "adventures" that lured and so richly repaid the army of David Grayson readers through his long list of books.

ALL-METAL vacuum tubes, small black cylinders, less than the size of their equivalents in glass bulbs, feature the new line of 1935-36 radios, demonstrated for the first time during the past week in New York by engineers from General Electric's "House of Magic."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 13. -- Mrs. Mae Stauf, 35 years old, the widowed mother of two children, was charged here today with being "culpably negligent" in the death of two persons whom she is alleged to have run down June 25 on Jericho Turnpike at South Huntington, L.I.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., July 13. -- Resentment aroused here by the new State sales tax has driven some retail buyers, particularly of provisions, to make their purchases across the Delaware River in Easton, Pa., where there is no sales tax.

FOR the first time in ten year King George is to hold a naval review at Spithead this week. The spectacle, magnificent in itself, will have a double significance for Britain's ruler. It will bring forth memories of his early youth spent as a cadet and later as an officer in the navy.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Work relief officials were worried today by the decision of organized labor in New York City not to accept jobs on work relief projects unless union wage scales were adopted. They refused, however, to make any official comment in the absence of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, who is a member of President Roosevelt's week-end party at the Jefferson Island Club.

HISTORY becomes reality for air tourists in Michigan. In two hours flying time from Detroit -- two ad one-half hours from Chicago -- the aerial voyager can turn back three centuries to the land of the French voyageur; to Jean Nicolet, the first white man to pass through the Straits of Mackinac.

LONDON. A NEW picture directed by Alfred Hitchcock is always an event in British filmdom; and his latest production, "The Thirty-nine Steps," is reckoned among his best. It is breaking records of several years standing at the New Gallery in Regent Street, and it Is sanguinely expected that, when shown in New York, it will have an equally good reception there.

CERTAIN minds are acrobatic. They observe normalcies but from abnormal points of view. Gulliver saw people too large or too small. Alice through her looking-glass saw them the wrong way round. So has it been with Capek.

LONDON, July 13. -- To understand present tendencies in British foreign policy, which suddenly seem to have become so cautious, so non-committal and so eager to grasp the advantages of friendship with everybody, while taking sides with nobody, certain pertinent factors must be borne in mind. Together they explain much which is outwardly not easy of comprehension.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The annual Lenox flower show is to be held at Lenox Town Hall on Thursday and Friday. The Lenox Horticultural Society, under the leadership of Otis Phelps Curtis and Ernest T. Curtis, is the sponsor.
MONTREAL, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- The sturdy little Hudson's Bay Company supply ship Nascopie steamed out of Montreal harbor today on her annual 10,000-mile cruise to the Arctic.

VIENNA, July 13. -- Almost a year after Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss's assassination, his successor, Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, narrowly escaped death and Dr. Schuschnigg's wife was killed when their automobile crashed into a tree beside a road near Linz, in Upper Austria, at noon today.

THOUGH midsummer is usually the season when it is most difficult to transplant successfully, it often happens that certain plants must be shifted at this time. When such is the case experienced gardeners use every precaution to avoid the losses that might otherwise occur.

THE Supreme Law of which Maeterlinck writes with poetic fervor is Newton's law of gravitation -- "the greatest law of earth and heaven," "the essential law which governs the motion of all things," "the law of laws, which manifests the will par excellence of the great All," "the soul of the universe."

You can teach an old dog new tricks, according to results of a survey announced by the Adult Education Project of the Board of Education and the Federal Government which show that grown-ups make better students than children.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The advice of the President to Congress not to "permit doubts as to constitutionality, however reasonable," to block the enactment of pending legislation, if accepted, foreshadows a busy year or two and a difficult task ahead for the Supreme Court of the United States in determining the constitutionality of the legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- An analysis of the effect of present and proposed tax levies on the estate of a citizen of New York [understood to be the estate of Harry Payne Whitney] who died in October, 1930, was included in the statement of Roy C. Osgood, vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, made before the Ways and Means Committee of the House today.

In your editorial "'Prevailing Wage' Again" you assert: "The argument made to General Johnson that failure of the government to pay prevailing wage rates would tend to break down wage standards in industry is without substance." I contend that this assertion is without substance.

An anxious mother's fear that her child at play was imperiled by a man practicing rifle fire from a window resulted early yesterday in a spectacular gun battle in the streets of Jamaica, Queens, in the arrest of five suspects and, the police announced, in the disruption of the notorious and elusive "rifle gang," to which about 400 store hold-ups in eight months were attributed.
GENEVA, July 12. -- The outlook for the League of Nations in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict is at best undoubtedly bad, but at worst it is not tragic.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The $4,000,000,000 work relief program, upon which President Roosevelt has declared he will stand or fall, has finally taken definite shape and should be well under way on a nation-wide scale by Aug. 1.

WARSAW, July 18. -- The new Constitution supplants the word of Marshal Josef Pilsudski as Poland's supreme law, according to Premier Walery Slawek. No man will attempt to step into the shoes of the dictator who guided Poland through her struggle for independence and through the turbulent period of reformation of the imperfect institutions of the early days of the resurrected republic.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP). -- An all-American swimming relay quartet today bettered the United States team record for 800 meters at the Southern Pacific A.A.U. aquatic meet at Los Angeles Swimming Stadium. The time was 9 minutes 22-10 seconds.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 13. -Showing vastly improved form over his tennis of the preliminary rounds, Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School today scored a crushing victory over Wilbur Hess of Rice Institute, national intercollegiate champion, to gain the final of the Spring Lake invitation tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.
LONDON, July 13 (AP). -- Following are the foreign trade figures of the Board of Trade for June:

Changes in the investment portfolios of the principal investment trusts during the first half of this year, as shown in reports issued last week, indicate that the managements of these companies look for an orthodox recovery in business and have little fear at the moment of currency inflation.

Faced with the possibility that further delay in placing Fall commitments would result in delivery difficulties later, dry goods wholesalers placed an exceptionally heavy volume of orders in the markets here last week. The buyers began arriving Wednesday and by Friday were actively engaged in covering initial requirements on a wide variety of products.

Since London signed the naval agreement with Berlin about a month ago Paris and many other capitals in Europe have been asking "Whither Britain ?" Last week in Parliament Sir Samuel Hoare tried to give an answer.

Definite dates for redemption of several large industrial and public utility bond issues, following successful flotation of other issues of lower coupon rates so as to raise funds necessary for the retirements, featured last week's announcements of payments of bonds before their maturity dates.

Equipped with a generous supply of placards and banners and accompanied by a number of bands, 15,000 men and women workers representing 302 organizations paraded yesterday noon from Union Square to Foley Square in a mass protest against relief and wage conditions.

OPENINGS in the galleries were very scarce last week. On Thursday a group of etchings and lithographs by Walt Kuhn -- part of a recent gift -- was placed on view for two weeks at the New York Public Library. Other exhibitions at the library to which public attention is called are a large group of modern prints and the annual show of recent accessions.

There is no denying that the government of the cities is the one most conspicuous failure of the United States. * * * The faults of the State governments are insignificant compared with the extravagance, corruption, and mismanagement which have marked the administrations of most of the great cities * * *

THEATRICAL troupes playing in ye old barn on a score of countrysides this Summer have begun to have rivals on the campus. In New York state at least two campus companies are playing under distinguished auspices.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The wheat markets were on the down grade today from start to finish and showed little disposition to rally. The finish was about the bottom. Weather conditions in the Southwest were favorable for harvesting Winter wheat, and the trade is looking for much larger receipts there next week in consequence.

Yachtsmen will have an opportunity on July 30 to join forces with the mariners of commerce to argue before Federal authorities that boating has become so congested in the region of Greenport and Shelter Island as to warrant dredging of famous old Sterling Basin.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13. -- The volume of Summer tourist business along the Pacific Coast has suddenly reached such proportions that it is amazing officials of all shipping lines. They had made provision for accommodations which they thought would leave ample margin for a substantial increase over last year's movement of passengers, but the arrangements now appear far from adequate.

INLAND points of South America, formerly inaccessible to the tourist because of inadequate transportation facilities, have been opened by the development of air and rail lines linked to the ports of call of modern liners. The Grace Line, the Santa ships of which operate weekly to Panama, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Chile, has arranged a variety of itineraries that include remote areas.
TOKYO. -- While other countries have been fighting the depression by trying to create a scarcity and raise prices, Japan has fought it by creating abundance and reducing prices.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The matches between the polo team of the War Department, Washington, and the Greenbrier Polo Club, to be played on the field here on Friday and Sunday, and the West Virginia open tennis championships, to be held on the clay courts at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club commencing tomorrow, are the outstanding sports events of the coming week at this spa.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- One of the most ambitious programs of rapid-transit development ever undertaken by a city of comparable size is before the people of San Francisco for their approval.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The conclusion today at Moscow of a trade agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States came as a complete surprise here because the agreement had been brought to a satisfactory conclusion without observers either here or in Moscow having received an inkling of such a plan.
PARIS, July 13. -- The International Astronomical Union at today's sessions took up the question of standardization of instruments and methods in world observatories.
In a special bulletin to affiliated groups and game administrators, the American Game Association reviews the latest developments in conservation.

TACOMA, Wash., July 13. -- Nineteen-year-old Margaret Waley was convicted swiftly of both "Lindbergh Law" and conspiracy charges by a Federal jury here today in the $200,000 kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP). -The Tigers and Athletics split a double-header today, the Mackmen taking the first, 18 to 5, in a hitting barrage and dropping the second, 6 to 3, after announcing they would protest the battle. Thus the Tigers climbed to within a game of the league-leading Yankees.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -The Senators won their first double-header of the season today, defeating the Browns, 11 to 7 and 10 to 4.

PITTSBURGH, July 13. -- The Giant steam-roller flattened the Pirate crew in a knockdown-and-dragout skirmish on Forbes Field today to give Carl Hubbell his eleventh triumph and the league leaders three straight here to the dismay of about 10,000 fans. The count was 7 to 6.

There will be visiting preachers today in almost all the Protestant pulpits in mid-Manhattan, as with few exceptions the pastors have gone on their Summer vacations. Of the visitors, several are from Great Britain, two from Scotland and the others from England.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 13. -- Honors were well divided today in the Buffalo Launch Club's annual international outboard regatta on the Niagara River. Fred Chase of Northampton, Mass., and Fred Jacoby, Jr., North Bergen, N.J., triumphed in the professional division, and Gar Wood Jr. of Algonac, Mich., and Sammy Crooks, Hudson, N.J., shared the amateur laurels.

THE chief contest and the greatest achievement at the recent meeting of the National Education Association in Denver had to do with freedom of teaching. Three measures that may well prove epoch-making for American democracy were there undertaken.

IT will be interesting to see whether anything really new and really worth while is done in the scenic and dramatic investiture of operas next season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Much has been said by the prophets of the new regime on this score.

Somewhere in the furthest reaches of the Bronx or along the nearest sandy strip of New Jersey a more or less mysterious gentleman described only as a "veteran enthusiast" may at this minute be engaged in burrowing into a scrapheap and pouncing upon a treasure for the evolving Museum of Modern Art Film Library at 485 Madison Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, July 13. -- Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Dall Boettiger, daughter of President Roosevelt, is among the defendants named in a mortgage foreclosure suit filed in Supreme Court here today. Curtis B. Dall, her former husband, is another defendant.

BUCHAREST. -- Carol II, royal playboy of Europe, has settled down to the serious business of being a King. The handsome heir to the Rumanian branch of the House of Hohenzollern, who was recalled five years ago to the throne he renounced for the carefree life of a commoner, employs his time and energies now in ruling one of the wealthiest and most politically strategic countries of Eastern Europe.
A complete guide on where to bathe and where not to bathe within the city limits was made public yesterday by the Health Department to prevent illnesses caused by swimming in polluted waters.

PARIS, July 13. -- All is quiet in Paris this evening and the general anticipation now is that tomorrow's monster parades in celebration of Bastile Day will be kept from degenerating into a disturbance of the public peace.

Under the influence of continued favorable weather for the growing crop and easier wheat and silver markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 10 to 13 points yesterday, carrying October back to 11.65 cents a pound, the same close as on the previous Saturday. Scattered

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 13. -- Setting a new record for the course, Jack Rutherfurd of Port Washington, L.I., driving his new Gold Cup boat Duster, captured the free-for-all race of five miles, the feature event of the Cape May regatta today.

LONDON. -- The problem of China, temporarily obscured by topical developments in Europe, is always in the minds of the directors of British policy in Asia, for Japan unceasingly is hammering at the structure of Chinese independence in the execution of a far-seeing plan of economic and military penetration.

No two persons see a thing the same way. That weathered bromide was aptly applied yesterday to the thirty-second birthday party of Peter the Great, the hefty hippo, in his outdoor quarters at Bronx Park.

ASBURY PARIS, N.J. -- Ross-Fenton Farms, a rendezvous on picturesque Deal Lake, will be the scene of one of the main social events of the North Jersey shore season on Wednesday when a luncheon and bridge will be held for the benefit of the Association for Catholic Action Among Boys.
CHICAGO, July 13. -- Forever Yours -- for $25,790 -- was the way they filled out the big check at the swanky debutante party for 2-year-old misses at Arlington Park today.

Criticism directed at the mark deals by which Germany acquired large quantities of coffee and other "cash" crops of Latin-American republics has resulted in action which will put a permanent end to such transactions in at least three countries, according to information received here by interested exporters last week.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 13 (AP). -- Two women glider pilots staged a keen duel in the air just west of this city today, in a duration contest which ended after one had been aloft for 5 hours 31 minutes.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 (AP). -- Big Mose Kelsch was killed today in an automobile wreck and the thousands who saw him rise to athletic fame because he could kick a football with uncanny accuracy mourn the loss.

A one-legged Negro, who bit the hand of the man he robbed, slashed his face with a knife, bit the leg of a detective and finally was felled by a blow on the head from his own crutch, was arraigned yesterday in Tombs Court with another Negro on a charge of robbery.

BRUSSELS. THE introduction of a system of licenses for importing certain parts of automobiles into Belgium is intended as a checkup on these imports. Further legislation is expected that will enable the Belgian Government to limit the benefits of the Belgo-American trade treaty to importers who have assemblage works in Belgium.
" Ship ahoy!" piped four youths at 6 o'clock last night as they shoved off from the pier at Ninety-sixth Street and the Hudson River on a crude homemade raft they had just put together.

FOR the first time in its eight years of existence Random House is about to publish a novel. The author is Morley Callaghan, and the title of his novel is "They Shall Inherit the Earth." It will be published about Sept. 1. This is by far the longest book Mr. Callaghan has written, and Random House considers it his most important book to date.

Trading in the security and commodity markets during the half-day period yesterday amounted to little more than what is considered routine. Stocks moved within a narrow price range and closed steady, a trifle higher on the average; bonds, too, showed but small fluctuations, evidencing firmness throughout.

Thousands of skippers have passed close to Sebonac Creek on the southeast side of Great Peconic without knowing that one of the best harbors on the cruise to the end of Long Island existed there. It is amazingly well hidden. Even with a chart one has to look twice, at least, to find its entrance and without one nobody would casually suspect an anchorage.

THE scontinent of Shvambrania discovered by two small Russian boys, Lyolya, who now tells the story after he has grown up, and his younger brother, Oska, in the momentous year of 1914. Their father, the Doctor, punished them when they lost the queen from his new and highly prized chess set by making them sit in a gloomy place called "The Pharmacy" in that medical household.

THIS work will prove especially serviceable to students. The main body of Vol. I is devoted to a scholarly cataloguing of the marvelous collection at Windsor Castle, with an introduction by the author. This is valuable and very interesting material, though it is strictly of a documentary and fact-sifting nature.

DUBLIN. -- A scathing denunciation of past and present Free State Governments for their neglect of art was delivered by Dr. Thomas Bodkin in the course of a recent lecture at Trinity College. Until very recently Dr. Bodkin was director of the National Gallery.
BUCHAREST, July 13 (AP). -- The Hapsburg family was warned today by a powerful combination of Austria's neighbors to stay away from the non-existent throne of Austria.

OFF with the sticky dress that has been worn at golf or through a series of business conferences. Take a tub, refreshingly scented with a salts whose aromatic perfume rises like incense from the water, shake a cooling bath powder over your glowing skin, and then -- slip on a negligee.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 13. -- With its clock stopped at midnight last Monday, the Legislature is continuing in special session to reconsider reconstruction measures drafted in Washington and amended here to provide for greater local control over Federal projects for Puerto Rico.

TORONTO, Ont., July 13. -- The mining industry of British Columbia continues to show progress, figures of the first six months of the current year show. In this period the gross value of the mineral production for the Province is estimated at $21,672,674.

IN answer to a departmental query regarding her plans -- if any -- for the immediate future, Mary Pickford sent the following message speeding across the continent from Hollywood via the telegraph wires.

Those singular White Sox, who continue to tread on the heels of the leaders when, according to the outstanding critics of the land, they ought by now to be stamping all over their own feet well down in the second division, trampled all over the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday, to the consternation of a crowd of 12,000.

On the basis of their latest published statements, the thirty-two commercial banks and trust companies in this city had earnings of $93,612,600 for the year ended on June 29, equal to about 14 per cent on their combined capital of $648,169,300, according to a study prepared by The Financial Age.
The President of the United States has a hearty laugh. He used it last week to answer a whispering campaign.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 13. -- Norcross Tilney will meet Wilmer Hines in the men's singles final of the Longwood Bowl tomorrow, right after Miss Helen Pedersen finishes playing Mrs. John Van Ryn for the honors in the women's invitation event.

Although California, curiously enough, is the only place in the United States that has a full Summer skating season comparable to that in England, the East for the last three years has had its own short hot-weather session.

SUITABLE clothing for those who go down to the sea -- or Sound -- in ships is becoming increasingly easy in direct ratio to the mounting popularity of boating. Leaving out of consideration the rigid yachting etiquette that demands white trousers and the properly braided double-breasted blue coat for a yachts afterguard in its more formal moments, almost all of the men's shops have stocks of merchandise peculiarly adapted to the playtime requirements of Corinthians.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 13. -- Bolivia does not know who will be her President after Aug. 15, but fears that a struggle for control might develop have been quieted by Acting President Sorzano Tejada, who recently returned from conferences with military leaders in the Chaco.

Brooklyn authorities were trying to learn yesterday whether John Moody, who lived at 239 Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, twenty-three years ago, is still alive and whether he desires to press the robbery charge he made in 1912 against Edward Hughes, 50-year-old printer, who was arrested in Brooklyn a week ago on a lottery charge.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Both wholesale and retail trade are a little ahead of last year, gains with the larger department stores running as high as 10 per cent, with the average about 5 per cent. Merchants profess themselves most gratified with the showing, as last year's totals reflected the buying of out-of-town exposition visitors.

An exchange of charges yesterday marked the latest phase of the conflict between rival factions of the Knickerbocker Democrats which began a few days ago when one group formally ousted Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post. Mr. Post, prime mover in the organization of the Knickerbockers, was suspected of treating with Tammany.

On the eve of Bastile Day, which has been awaited with some trepidation in foreign-exchange circles as a possible occasion for disturbances in France which might affect the political situation there, the franc yesterday rallied 1/2 point to 6.62 1/4 cents.
ROME, July 13. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's East African venture comes at a time when the Italian financial situation is beginning to show improvement after the depression years.
GORHAM, N.H., July 13. -- Seven automobile race amateurs will participate tomorrow in a road race to the top of Mount Washington.

The discretionary power of the New York State Liquor Authority to issue or refuse licenses has resulted in more effective control over liquor than existed in pre-prohibition days, Commissioner John Sullivan of the State Liquor Authority asserted yesterday in the current issue of the A.B.C. News, the official bulletin of the Authority.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 13. -The stratosphere camp near here was filled again today with the pungent, clean smell of new rubber exposed to the sun, just as it was Thursday afternoon when the big balloon for the National Geographic-army stratosphere flight was taken out of the box for inflation.

UP in Massachusetts this morning Sidney Howard is working on what will unquestionably be one of 1935's important theatrical events. It is the dramatization of Humphrey Cobb's novel of the war, "Paths of Glory."

Kenji Toda, an artist who for many years has been connected with the University of Chicago, tells us that his work on the Japanese illustrated books in the Ryerson collection of the Chicago Art Institute turned his attention to old scroll paintings, from which he believes the main line of Japanese book illustration stems.

David K.E. Bruce, son-in-law of Andrew W. Mellon, said yesterday that he had sold his entire stock interest in the National Grain Yeast Corporation of Belleville, N.J., and now had no affiliation with the concern. This is the organization of which James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, recently was elected president after having acquired a stock interest.

CINCINNATI, July 13. -- Ample evidence was given today that the disintegration of the Dodgers is practically complete. With big George Earnshaw trying hard for his second victory in seven starts, the Stengelmen booted away their third straight to the Reds, 5 to 2.
ADEN, Arabia, July 13. -- At the seaport of Massaua, in Eritrea, the chief landing station for the Italian expedition to conquer Ethiopia, the heat is intense, sometimes 122 degrees in the shade.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- If the Seventy-fourth Congress were a man of great affairs, his staff and family would call in physicians, and the physicians would send him on a holiday in the interest of his own welfare and the safety of those dependent on his management. For it is Congress, not the President, which is exhausted, irritable, nervous and uncertain to function wisely.

Salvatore Spitale, golfer and "layer of odds," often arrested but only once convicted, testified he was appointed an intermediary in the Lihdbergh case because he was "a square shooter and I give anybody a square deal" when he took the stand yesterday to deny he was a public enemy under the Brownell law.

ST. LOUIS, July 13. -- Hot weather, an unusually heavy vacation movement and a marked increase in weddings have served to increase retail sales in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. The gain is estimated at 15 per cent ahead of last year, though some of the big stores have shown better figures.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- Petromite, 2-year-old bay pacing colt owned and driven by Edward Conord of Glen Ridge, turned in the outstanding performance of the regular matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

PARIS, July 13. -- The Grande Semaine, the big week of the Paris season, and its immediate aftermath have made the last few days the most brilliant socially of the high season and have even surpassed similar periods here in recent years.

SWAN LAKE, N.Y., July 13. -Miss Erna Kompa, swimming star from Sheepshead Bay, established a new American record of 2 minutes 55 8-10 seconds in the 220-yard backstroke competition over a sixty-foot course at the new President Pool today.

Manufacturers in the rug industry yesterday were appraising results of the first week of their showing of Fall lines in Chicago, still unconvinced of the advisability of holding a similar exhibition there next Winter. Buying reaction at the Chicago showing was fair, but did not meet the expectations of many of the mills represented.

Thomas E. Dewey was reported yesterday to have requested between $60,000 and $80,000 for the first five months of the investigation Governor Herbert H. Lehman has directed him to make into organized crime and racketeering in Manhattan.

BUCHAREST, July 13. -- Dr. Nicolas Titulescu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, had an audience of two and a half hours with Prince Paul, head of the Yugoslav Regency, at Sinaia this afternoon in the presence of King Carol.
TORONTO, July 13 (AP). -- The Maple Leafs swept their closing double-header with Newark today to stretch the Bears' losing streak to seven straight games. The scores of 8 to 1 and 6 to 3.

HANKOW, China, Sunday, July 14. -- Ten thousand troops and coolies, working day and night, are believed to have strengthened and heightened this city's dikes sufficiently to withstand the flood waters of the Yangtse River, unless further rains swell the torrent.

PRAGUE, July 13. -- Taking no chances, Germany's Davis Cup tennis team called on Baron Gottfried von Cramm for doubles duty today and earned the point that may prove decisive in the European zone final against Czechoslovakia.
CHICAGO, July 11. -- Two ingenious crooks who are still at large put over a predatory scheme the other day that surprised the Chicago police.

LONDON. -- Though the British Government had been notified some weeks ago as to what naval tonnage Germany proposed to build this year under its new 35:100 ratio agreement with this country, the publication of the official German program has administered a distinct shock to the man in the street.

PUBLIC speeches by the Prince of Wales lately have attracted wide attention, both in Britain and abroad, and aroused some criticism. This is a rare experience for a royal person in these days when the addresses delivered by royalty usually are prepared by cautious secretaries and advisers and are formal, perfunctory and full of pleasant sentiments rather than of arresting ideas.

ALDERSHOT, England, July 13. -- For the first time in ten years Great Britain's King reviewed his army today -- not the entire home forces but a microcosmic assembly of some 9,000 officers and men in which every branch of the service, with the army's very latest in mechanical equipment, was represented.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- A more than seasonal decline in the June relief population of 140 of the larger cities today cheered the men in charge of President Roosevelt's long-delayed $4,000,0001000 work program.

The debate in the Senate last week on whether bees should be basic farm commodities under amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act directs attention to the fact that about 250,000,000,000 bees in some 4,000,000 colonies are at work in the United States, with a total production of some 150,000,000 pounds of honey.

CLEVELAND, July 13. -- The black pacing cyclone, Calumet Evelyn, with Vic Fleming in the sulky, recorded her twelfth straight Grand Circuit victory in the George H. Tipling free-for-all pace on North Randall's closing program today.

ALTHOUGH the book department of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries fell short of the interesting objective of a million dollars this season, it made a highly impressive showing with a total of $838.827.

Every yachtsman on a cruise to strange harbors knows that his best friends are the Coast and Geodetic Survey people. For 75 cents, or a half dollar, or even occasionally for 25 cents, they have sold him a chart that keeps him safely in deep water.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -Charging Immigration Commissioner MacCormack with "conflicting statements" on the alien situation, Representative Dies, Democrat, of Texas, today demanded that the commissioner explain his attacks on the Dies Alien Deportation Bill.

ON the jacket this book is described as one "of vital interest and startling disclosures," which in a way it is. That is to say, it is neither so vital nor so startling as a similarly well-informed discussion of unemployment, flood prevention, erosion, or the relations between capital and labor might be, but it is important enough if we think of a navy as something we have to have.

Chanting a demand for the reinstatement of six Brooklyn Edison Company employes who, the Brotherhood of Utility Employes maintains, were discharged last February because of their union activities, a crowd carrying the banners of the Brooklyn Neighborhood Consumers and the Unemployed Council yesterday picketed the company's Brownsville district offices at Chester Street and Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn.

In view of recent statements in the American press with regard to the treatment accorded American artists in the Soviet Union, perhaps my experiences will be of interest to your readers. Under the terms of my contract with the Soviet Bureau I was given the best hotel accommodation and service from the day of my arrival -- in spite of the fact that for about eight weeks I was preparing for my first concert.

ONE rarely associates hats with the business of government, but in France, where Cabinets are formed, perhaps to last only a few days -- witness the recent Bouisson Ministry -- the hat has a definite place in the national scheme.

WITH no statistics available, it is hard to say who are the most prolific light fiction novelists. But surely Maysie Greig must come in the first flight of fast writers. Before you have a chance to forget her last bit of flashy, frothy romance, a new one appears.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 13. -- Under no circumstances will we accept a railway or other zone in or through Ethiopia administered or policed by Italy, because history teaches that the creation of such zones inevitably is followed by annexation.

WHEN the British Television Committee this year recommended television be presented for public reception it created "a scientific sensation which would have dwarfed the story of catching the Loch Ness monster on a bent pin," according to A.W. Cruse's international television inspection report made to the National Association of Broadcasters.

Chinese art is a big subject, and, as compared with much that has been written about it, the present is a small and unambitious work. However, Dagny Carter proceeds with so much fresh enthusiasm and real understanding, and presents her material so simply, directly and clearly, that the book should prove interesting not alone to the student or specialist but also to the general reader who is interested in the great culture of China.

During the last six years, taxes paid by the steel industry have amounted to 66.4 cents of every dollar of net income available for the payment of taxes and for dividends to stockholders, according to an analysis prepared by he American Iron and Steel Institute on the basis of returns of twenty-six steel companies representing more than 93 per cent of the steel capacity of the country.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Musically there will be plenty to interest the Summer sojourners this week. Tomorrow night at the Art Association the annual benefit concert for the association will be given under the direction of the entertainment committee, which is presenting as guest artist Miss Fernanda Doria.

CRISES in soft coal mining are of two types. One is marked by violent fights in the fields, with the miners taking direction into their own hands. The other type appears when the coal diggers are knit together into a union so powerful that its leaders can carry on the battle in Washington, using economic pressure instead of brickbats.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 13. -Michael J. Collins Jr., 54, business and political leader of Glens Falls, was drowned or died of heart failure early today in Lake George when the automobile in which he and J. William Singleton of Horicon Avenue were riding ran off the Lake George steamboat dock into eight feet of water.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13. -- Italian troops numbering 81,500 passed through the Suez Canal on their way to the East African colonies from March to the end of June, according to available statistics. Nearly 15,000 more have passed on the same route during July.

NO matter how hot and humid the weather may be, there is one pastime that is effortless and cooling. That is smoking. There are some new smoking things that should amuse those who sink into a state of apathy as soon as the sun shines hot through the haze, and don't recover until the breezes blow cool again.

With his courage tested as it has not been since he engaged Cavalcade, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery scored yesterday at Empire City in the inaugural of the Butler Handicap, run before 15,000 at the Yonkers course.
VIENNA, July 13. -- The Social Democratic political prisoners' hunger strike for better food and proper exercise periods was admitted today in a government communique.
