Under his constitutional power to "recommend" legislation to Congress, the President of the United States may proceed in two ways. He may urge specific measures. Indeed, he may have Administration bills prepared and submitted to appropriate committees of House and Senate.

There is one side of tuberculosis, usually unthought of, which is beginning to receive its due consideration. The rehabilitation committee of the National Tuberculosis Association at its annual convention at Saranac Lake recommended the placement of adult education in sanatoria.

Possibilities of a complete change in buyer-seller relationships and for the stabilization of both employment and production are seen by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in the social security and high-tax programs of the administration.

Leonard Hartman, former Columbia basketball captain and tennis ace, began the defense of his Richmond County clay court tennis championship by winning two matches at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I., yesterday.
Francis McGowan, 4 years old, of 63 La Salle Street was injured fatally late yesterday afternoon when he was struck by an automobile as he played in front of his home.

The first scriptural fable was one having to do with trees. The trees were tired of judges as rulers and wanted a king -- a dictator. The choice fell successively on the olive, the fig and the vine, all of whom declined. Then said all the trees unto the bramble, "Come thou and reign over us."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a dinner at Nid de Papillon tonight for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace of New York, and for Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth, Mr. and Mrs. Grantland Rice and Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Brown.

ARTHUR HORNBLOW Jr., associate producer at Paramount, was in town last week with what is probably the most valuable screen script in the world. It is Sidney Howard's adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's novel, "The Light That Failed," with notes and corrections made by Kipling himself.

In the Fall of the year 1918 in Moscow little Ivan, aged 12, was being taught in school that respect for the opinion of his elders was an outworn bourgeois, notion. It was a year after the Bolshevist revolution and little Ivan's elders, including his father, mother, brothers, uncles, , were of middle-class origin.

In the last two weeks of debate on the question of restoring to banks of deposit the privilege of underwriting new issues of securities, the banking community has clarified its point of view and appears to be reaching a fairly uniform opinion about midway between the two extremes that were expressed when the proposal first at appeared.

What the Weather Bureau soothsayers describe as the drought cycle seems to have completed its course in all parts of the country. Floods last month in the West and this month in New York State testify to the truth of the old saying that it never rains but it pours.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The resignation of Richard Strauss as president of the Reich Music Chamber and as chairman of the League of German Composers was announced today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and president of the Reich Kultur Chamber.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The Bar Harbor Drama Festival, under the direction of Leighton Rollins, will present its first performance next Saturday at the outdoor theatre of the Building of Arts with a new arrangement of "The Birds" of Aristophanes.

GLOUCESTER, Mass. -- Mid-July finds a full schedule of activities arranged for the Summer folk in the North Shore sector, including Manchester and Cape Ann. Principal attention is focused on the annual ladies' invitation tennis tournament opening tomorrow at the Essex Country Club in Manchester and continuing on following days.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -After clarifying the United States' policy with regard to the threatening war clouds in Africa by emphasizing American interest in the world-wide preservation of peace, Secretary of State Hull left today for a brief vacation in Virginia.
CAMDEN, Me., July 13. -- From Aug. 11 to Aug. 18 Camden will be the gathering place for private collectors and those interested in early American antiques of the period from 1650 to 1850.

When one gets accustomed to the graceful, antique spelling, it is a pleasure to read this lyrical poetry of the Elizabethan age as it was written for the Elizabethans. "England's Helicon," an anthology of poems by Marlow, Sidney, Spenser, Raleigh, Drayton and others, was first printed in 1600.

MR. READ is a distinguished scholar in art and literature, and his criticism has been an indispensable instrument in re-creating the energy of past masters. He has also written poems, and they have a similar exact and appreciative sense of what his contemporaries are doing in poetry, in introspection and outlook, in style and rhyme and imagery.

ONE of the more caustic witticisms circulating in National Socialist Germany concerns Adolf Hitler. "Fuehrer" to all Germans and "Herr German Reich Chancellor" to the diplomatic corps, who arrived at the Pearly Gates, demanding admittance.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Sharp curtailment of production in nearly all fields occurred in the week ended July 6, due to the Independence Day holiday, which resulted in a three-day suspension in many plants, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

WITH the ever increasing difficulty of obtaining that old garden stand-by -- "good, thoroughly decomposed Barnyard manure" -- gardener are Becoming more and more intensely interested in discovering what may Best Be employed as a really satisfactory substitute for it.

BOMBAY. -- An India-EnglandUnited States organization is likely to be formed for lac research and is declared to have prospects of an important future. The Indian Lac Research Institute at Ranchi seeks to bring about this research combine.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 13. -- In conjunction with the oarsmen's competition the national regatta of the American Canoe Association will be staged on Sunday.

OMAHA, Neb., July 11. -- When Relief Director Cameron of Harrison County, Iowa, suspended the entire relief roll in his jurisdiction and notified more than 300 beneficiaries to find jobs for themselves, he took a rather dramatic way of dealing with a situation becoming general in the Corn Belt.

LONDON, July 13 (AP). -- Great Britain, anxiously watching the development of the crisis between Italy and Ethiopia, received today with intense interest Secretary of State Hull's declaration in support of the Kellogg-Briand pact.

NOVEMBER of this year, and not January of next year, is going to be automobile introduction month for 1936. New York, restored to its former position as centre for a national show, will dominate the situation.

Extremely hot and rainy weather affected retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Against the sharp increases of the preceding week, declines under a year ago were reported for a number of department stores here. As a consequence, executives estimated that average sales figures for the month thus far show only a slight increase over the corresponding period of 1934.

AN electrical device to be installed beneath the kitchen sink for the purpose of grinding the waste food and quickly disposing of it through the drain pipe into the sewer has been developed by engineers of the General Electric Company.

FROM his point of vantage as a stowaway aboard the lugger which left Annapolis for some Point in Chesapeake Bay with Dick Powell and a supplementary party of six other fishermen, the reporter decided that the omens presaged poor fishing and good interviewing conditions.

THOUSANDS of pathetically stimulating letters have passed across the desk of Miss Josephine Roche since President Roosevelt named her as executive chairman of the National Youth Administration. To the blueeyed, prematurely gray-haired Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who is economist, philanthropist and coal magnate, these letters epitomize the yearning of youth for half a chance at happiness.

MRS. WYMAN is the sponsor of the Students Association in the William Penn High School for Girls, Philadelphia, and therefore has been and still is behind the scenes and in constant intimate touch with the development of the project and speaks with authority not only on its success in this specific instance but of its theory, principles and methods, and also, to a certain extent, of how they have worked out elsewhere.

WITH significance beyond a mere airplane outing, the fourth annual good-will cruise from Roosevelt Field to Montreal will get under way at the historic Long Island field next Saturday. From fifty to eighty planes have taken part in the trip in other years, and a very large entry is indicated this year, George Orr, president of the field, said last week.

A textbook on Japan prepared primarily for the use of Hawaiian public schools but used experimentally at the Lincoln High School, Teachers College, Columbia University, will be completely revised and rewritten, partly because of criticism of the book as "Japanese propaganda," it was learned yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 13. -- Troop movements involving about 4,500 New York National Guardsmen will take place tomorrow, as the various units move out of Camp Smith and Pine Camp, the two major training camps, to make way for the replacement troops.
FONTHILL, Ont., July 13 (AP). -- Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., won the General Brock Hotel open golf tournament today, posting a 291 for the seventy-two-hole medal play.

LEEDS, England, July 1 (Canadian Press). -- South Africa scored 26 runs for one wicket in the third test cricket match with England today after 25,000 watched the English eleven tally 216 runs in its first innings.

HALIFAX, N.S. -- Numerous visitors from all sections of the continent are arriving at Nova Scotia's capital for the annual gala week which will be launched tomorrow with the opening of the Deep Sea Rodeo and Aquatic Carnival.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 13. -Picked as the winner from the very beginning, 19-year-old Jack Creavy of Tuckahoe lived up to expectations by winning the fifth annual New York State junior golf championship over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.
ALBANY, July 13. -- Forty-one persons were killed and damage amounting to millions of dollars was caused by floods in the southern tier of New York counties this week.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 13. -- Representative W. Sterling Cole visited this city today and conferred with the industrial rehabilitation committee formed to apply for a grant of $1,000,000 from the Federal Government to reopen ruined plants which normally employ a thousand workers.

MRS. HILL always offers wholesome romance for the pure in heart, with enough of a look-in at the naughty didoes of utter worldlings for salutary contrast. "White Orchids" details the bumpy course of a true-love story, with a poor and virtuous girl and a tremendously rich and moderately good young man playing the leading roles.

WOODBURY, Conn., July 13. -- A special service will be held tomorrow afternoon by the Rev. Floyd Appleton, rector since 1930 and twenty-eighth in the history of the church, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the building of historic St. Paul's Church by its first rector, the Rev. John Rutgers Marshall.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 13. -- When her husband began broadcasting from a radio station that he installed in their Tuckahoe home eighteen months ago all marital happiness ended for Mrs. Esmeralda Jensen, she said in separation suit papers filed in Supreme Court today.

The report of the committee of inquiry made public yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist party said that the party differences were not sufficiently fundamental to justify either faction in precipitating a crisis.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 13. -- Islamic art treasures, borrowed from four of the prominent collections of the country, were placed on exhibition in the library of Princeton University today. Although the display has been arranged primarily for the students in the Summer seminar in Arabic and Islamic studies, it may be inspected by the public for the rest of this month.

THAT word modern -- what does it mean? A question often launched with an accent of challenge by a bewildered public. And how can you wonder? Some six years ago, when the Museum of Modern Art was very young, we hopefully shifted the responsibility for definition.

Extensive improvements on the new clubhouse of the Columbia Y.C. on the former estate of Percy R. Pyne, 247th Street, in Riverdale, were completed last week, according to an announcement by John McKinlay Wight, secretary, and the formal opening will be conducted next Saturday.

The threat of hostilities between Italy and Ethiopia has again provoked discussion of our position in the event of war, particularly with respect to the question whether we should permit our nationals to furnish munitions to combatants on either side. The present limit of the Government's authority in the matter of arms shipments is set by a joint resolution of Congress adopted in 1922.

It took Sears before the restaurants of New York realized how profitable the Continental habit of outdoor dining could be. How long will it take those who would like to see midsummer lucky Yorkers forsake the blare of their radios for good music, to realize how profitable a "pop" concert could be?

VIENNA, July 1, 1935. THE "Festwochen" are over. In a few days one Commendatore Castelletti is bringing to Vienna an Italian organization including Elisabeth Rethberg, Aureliano Pertile, Armando Borgioli, Galliano Massini, Ezio Pinza, Norbert Ardelli, "horses, oxen, camels, dromedaries and sheasses," which will spend several weeks giving "Aida," "Cavelleria" and "Pagliacci" in the open air on the Hohe Warte at Doebling.

THE question, of course, is whether there should be any melodramas in the Summer. It seems a basic weakness of the cinema that it turns out its product without regard for the passing seasons. True, football films come out in the Fall and "Gentlemen Are Born" emerges in the Spring.

A resolution criticizing what was termed Soviet Russia's attempt to prevent the rise of a strong Ukrainian separatist movement by keeping the Ukrainian people in a state of starvation was adopted yesterday at the second annual congress of the Ukrainian Catholic Youth League.

Visitors at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today will find displayed in the room of recent accessions four rare sixteenth century Tournal tapestries presented by Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim in memory of her husband.

With a total of twenty-seven events to be decided and with athletes from Philadelphia, Baltimore, Detroit, Chicago, St. Louis, Toronto and New York among the entrants, the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen will be held on Princeton's intercollegiate course on Lake Carnegie.

PARIS. WHITE wraps hang in the very topmost branches of the Paris style tree this Summer. They are to be worn at all hours of the day or night, over dresses of any color. And, as there are just about as many new shades of white as there are of colors, a woman has no longer any excuse for saying: "I don't look well in white."

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP). -Topics ranging from ethics of criminal law to Federal taxation will be considered at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association opening here Monday. About 3,000 lawyers from Maine to California are expected to attend.
ROME, July 13 (AP). -- Italy will attend a meeting of the council of the League of Nations if one is called shortly on her dispute with Ethiopia, it was said today in authoritative circles.

MOSCOW, July 13. -- The long deadlock on Soviet-United States trade was broken today with the signing by William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, of a one-year trade agreement that is capable of being renewed indefinitely.

Four Philadelphians, two of them policemen, were rescued yesterday by Coast Guard Patrol Boat 183 of the Cape May station when their outboard motor boat capsized in Delaware Bay near Cape May, N.J. They were taken to the Coast Guard Hospital at Cape May, where their conditions were reported as not serious.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 13. -- Production of steel will rise next week 2 points in this district to an average of 43 per cent of capacity. Operations will be 13 points higher than a year ago.

THIS is the season when the latest styles of furniture, on which designers and manufacturers have worked for months, are released to the trade, hence in the retail shop displays new trends are evident. Previews of the styles are to be had at the great furniture trade expositions, such as the one now being held at Grand Rapids.

DUBLIN, July 13. -- The statement by J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, in the House of Commons this week has narrowed down the Anglo-Irish dispute to the issue of whether the Free State elects to remain within the British Commonwealth or secede.

Two important changes in the new French liner Normandie will be made during her Winter lay-up with a view to reducing the vibration that has been remarked by passengers when at sea. In the main salon of the ship, pillars will be erected to provide a greater stability, and her four three-blade propellers will be replaced by four-blade propellers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13. -- While doleful residents of Larchmont Manor stood by workmen began this afternoon to destroy an elm tree of fifteen-foot circumference on the lawn of Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Stevens, 65 Beach Avenue.

WHEN wreckers recently pulled down the Rialto Theatre and disclosed parts of what had been Hammerstein's Victoria in the gay, glad days before the war they found an old north wall and a rear wall of undeniable antiquity.

LILIES, though distinguished denizens of the garden, are frequently omitted because they are considered either expensive or difficult to grow. Raising them from seed, however, makes the cost almost negligible. Today this method is available to impatient gardeners who seek quick, easy results.

PARIS, July 12. -- Everybody in Paris has been asking everybody else all this week "What is going to happen on Sunday?" and then, of course, in the way people do, has gone on to reply to his own question in his own way.

A FRENCH air mission, one of many missions from Paris currently converging on Rome, assembles in the lobby of a Roman hotel. In this Latin setting the Latins from the North look very French -- a little tired, cynical and stiff, as young in years but subtly older in spirit than the lustrous youths who come to greet them.

The account in THE TIMES recently of the use of the Bible as a cable code in the betrothal of the Kansas City girl to the minister in Port Elizabeth, Cape of Good Hope, gives occasion to mention earlier uses of this same device. It dates back almost to the beginning of telegraphy, for we find it used in 1846.

THIS pageant was designed, as is usual in pageantry, for a specific purpose -- in this case to forward in England the cause of Christianity. It is a very living exercise of faith and conviction. There was, indeed, an effort under way in behalf of the "Forty-five Churches Fund" of the diocese of London.

Net profit of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 amounted to $7,157,767 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday. This is equivalent to $5.96 a share on 1,200,000 shares of $25 par common stock. In the preceding twelve months the net profit was $5,854,212, or $4.88 a share.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- Chief among the social events here tonight was a dinner for sixty given by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince at Marble House in honor of their guest, Marquis Guadelmina, who recently arrived from Europe.

The two-hour trading session on the bond market yesterday was a dull affair, with all classes of bonds maintaining a firm tone and moving within narrow limits. Closing quotations were irregular. Transactions for the day on the Stock Exchange were about even with a week ago and amounted to $4,580,800, compared with $4,556,000 on the preceding Saturday.

SILVIO PELLICO'S "Le mie Prigioni," published in 1832, measurably aided the realization of the United Italy visioned by Count Cavour. It is quite possible that Stefan Lorant's "I Was Hitler's Prisoner," published 103 years later, may help Germans to realize Das Viertereieh prophesied by Prince Hubertus Loewenstein in "After Hitler's Fall."

WESTPORT. THE Whiteface Mountain Memorial Highway, a new automobile road constructed by the State of New York for eight miles between the town of Wilmington and the summit of the fourth highest peak in the Adirondacks, will open to the public next Saturday.

Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday the names of 158 students who attained the honor roll for the second semester of the academic year in the evening division of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

In his earlier days Patrolman Arthur Fidgeon of the West Forty-seventh Street station was a mighty good middle distance runner for the New York Athletic Club. But last night on West Forty-eighth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, the former athlete staged his most spectacular race, pitting his speed against that of a runaway horse.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., July 13. -Seventy-three yachts raced in the annual Mantoloking Yacht Club regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association today in a light and fluky westerly breeze. Sue, Star Class boat, sailed by F. Thompson Brooks, and Eel, piloted by Mrs. Charles E. Lucke Jr., sailed to the second dead heat in the history of the association.

Probably no phase of American penal practice has been so consistently and thoroughly criticized, in recent years, as the parole system. J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reopened the issue last week when he described the system as a "national scandal."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13. -All yachting records for a single fleet were broken today in the opening regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-seventh annual race week. Two hundred and eighty-five craft competed, and with the number of large sloops, the total tonnage far surpassed any previous mark.

WITH what eagerness would not one seize the opportunity, had one the money, to purchase a first folio Shakespeare! Or with what envious eyes gaze at a quarto sage within some closely guarded library! Yet to William Jaggard, printer of London, what are now a collector's treasures represent a best but the opportunities of a business year.

THE Professor of Sociology in the University of North Carolina here adds another to the list of his many books wherein he has offered wise counsel on those problems of marriage, the home, parenthood, children, sex, the family, that bedevil human beings into unhappy and frustrated living.

NEW ORLEANS, July 11. -- On previous occasions called the dictator of Louisiana, Senator Long now is accused by his enemies of having done away with all democratic government in this State and of having set about a role of dictatorship in real earnest.

If it were customary to celebrate the centenary of a great man's death rather than that of his birth, we should this month have been paying our national tribute to JOHN MARSHALL'S career, and there are circumstances of the present day which would have made the occasion doubly appropriate.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 13. -- Attorney General Homer S. Cummings will head the list of lecturers at the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations at Williams College from Aug. 25 to 30. He is to speak on "Organized Religion and Crime Prevention."
NEW ORLEANS, July 13 (AP). -- Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, his back to the wall, denounced his former associates today for deserting him for "Dictator" Huey P. Long and reiterated his refusal to resign.

ABLE trencherman as well as gourmet the author of this book surely is. For all through his pages are strung not only recipes but selected breakfast, lunch and dinner menus that he has carefully worked out and presents with pride as meals which, as he phrases it, give him pleasure to tuck into.

CHARLOTTESVILLE., Va., July 13. -- President Roosevelt and his New Deal policies were attacked and defended and "understanding" of the Hitler regime in Germany was urged once more at the concluding sessions today of the University of Virginia's ninth Institute of Public Affairs.

IT is said that since Mark Twain died romance has been missing from the American pilot service. Be that as it may, we who served aboard the Mauretania saw it flourish again when Jim McCarthy, doyen of the New York pilots, deliberately gave up a holiday in order to take the "Old Lady of the Sea" down the Narrows of the Hudson River on her farewell voyage.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., July 13. -- All work on the gigantic Boulder Dam project came to a halt today as truck and transport drivers joined the strike of carpenters and steel workers for restoration of the seven and one-half-hour workday. The shutdown involved about 4,000 men.

TOMORROW will see the dedication of the two new bridges that now loom as the glittertering hope for economic revival of Grand Island, situated in the Niagara River between Canada and the United States and extending virtually from the north end of Buffalo to Niagara Falls.

Praising the progress achieved by leading newspapers in various parts of the country in censoring advertising copy and barring dishonest and misleading representations from their columns, Paul E. Murphy, chairman of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in a statement issued yesterday, declared the time is ripe for a movement to "clean up advertising, national as well as local, through means of a voluntary censorship."

SEATTLE, July 13 (AP). -- Women will leave the Presidency of the United States to men, Mrs. Celine MacDonald Bowman of Richmond, Va., president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, said here today on the eve of her organization's annual convention.
RENO, July 13. -- A divorce was granted here today to Robert E. Mebel of Brooklyn from Mrs. Mildred Mebel on grounds of dessertion.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 13. -- Four unknown soldiers will be buried with appropriate ceremony on Sept. 8 in the Lake George Battleground Park on the 180th anniversary of the date of the battle in which they lost their lives, the Bloody Morning Scout.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Business, as represented by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, the Illinois Manufacturers Association and the Merchants' Association of New York, joined today in attacking President Roosevelt's new tax program as a menace to the return of prosperity and as a plan that would lead to the confiscation of many large estates.

Donations to philanthropic enterprises in the six leading cities of the United States for the first six months of this year totaled $28,133,226, an increase of 104.64 per cent in the last two years, according to an announcement yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, fundraising consultants.
WASHINGTON, July 14. -- A unique government publication dealing with the navy -- a favorite study of President Roosevelt -- has come from the presses of the Government Printing Office.

Through the intervention of a Bronx dressmaker, who was bitten twice by a five-foot rattlesnake in the hills of Kentucky forty years ago, a seven-inch garter snake that was waging a losing battle with a large black spider in the rear yard of the home of Mrs. Winifred Bligh at 2,448 Young Avenue, the Bronx, was released from the spider's web yesterday morning.

MOSCOW, July 14. -- From both the American and Soviet viewpoints the chief gain seen in the trade agreement signed here yesterday by William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, is its stabilization of the commercial relations between the two countries.

ALBANY, July 14. -- Infant and maternal mortality dropped sharp-up in May, the State Department of Health reported today. A new low was recorded in still births and in deaths from tuberculosis, influenza and diphtheria.
Seven persons were injured, two of them seriously, in an automobile collision at New York and Baisley Boulevards, Baisley Park, Queens, at 12:45 P.M. yesterday.
PARIS, July 14. -- Hundreds of thousands of people crowded into the Champs Elysees this morning to see the biggest military procession organized in Paris since the victory parade of 1919.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,473,249,080. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

World industrial production continued to advance during May, while prices of important raw materials averaged 3 per cent higher than in the preceding month and 7 per cent above those in May, 1934, according to the monthly report on economic conditions issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP). -- Failure of an attempt to pool the terminal resources of twelve railroads at Kansas City for a test of the benefits to be derived from terminal coordination was reported to Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, by V.V. Boatner, chairman of his section of regional coordination.

A warning against belief in "that insidious devil, magic," was offered by the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, pastor of the Westbourne Presbyterian Church of Glasgow, Scotland, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

A return to the cooperation and the community spirit of the early Christians was urged by Dr. Robert E. Speer, senior secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.

The church "will get nowhere until it recognizes that most of the people round about us are no longer Christian in belief and motivation, because they think that modern knowledge has done us in," the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, canon of St. John's Cathedral, Providence, said yesterday in a sermon at the 11 A.M. service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP). -- A War Department request for $2,000,000 to map areas along the coasts and borders "which will become of high strategic importance in war" was announced today by the works applications division.

A unique volume, "American Big Game Fishing," was published recently by the Derrydale Press of this city. It is an invaluable addition to the literature of this comparatively new and rapidly growing sport.

Business in New York City faces additional local taxes as well as whatever levies may be added by the tax program under discussion in Washington, the Merchants Association warned in a statement issued yesterday.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 14. -- Two Long Island teams scored the opening victories in the national junior championship at the Burnt Mills Polo Club today. The Aiken Knights just managed to stand off the determined bid of Monmouth County to triumph, 10 -- 8, on Schley Field, and Long Island won a hard fought game from Burnt Mills, 9 -- 7, on one of the club fields.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 14. -- While a last systematic effort was made to find the third of her drowned children, Mrs. Edwin Landon of Trumansburg was taken to a hospital tonight to give birth to another baby. The 23-year-old woman barely escaped with her own life when the flood swept away the family's creekside camp, drowning her three young children.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Further consideration of President Roosevelt's wealth-tax plan is to be postponed for the time being to give Congressional leaders an opportunity to clear away the remainder of the essential legislative program.

Mussolini's failure to settle the Italian-Ethiopian dispute through peaceful arbitration would imperil the peace of all nations as well as destroy the independence of Ethiopia, according to three speakers who broadcast yesterday afternoon over Station WOR.

BERLIN, July 14 (AP). -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, keeping a sharp eye on Germany's rearmament progress, is making a series of troop and factory inspections. He spent the week-end in Bavaria, after a busy week with General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Air Minister; General Werner von Blomberg, War Minister, and General Staff officers.
Thomas C. Dalton, police fingerprint expert, was named for official recognition yesterday by Inspector Joseph Donovan, head of the Bureau of Criminal Identification.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 14. -- Summer residents of Whitefield, Jefferson and surrounding towns filled the Chase Barn Theatre at 4 P.M. today, when the Yale Forty Niners sponsored the first of a series of Sunday musicales. The guest artist, Miss Winifred Merrill, came from her Summer home in the Blue Hill (Me.) music colony and was accompanied by John Quincy Bass, pianist, a member of the Mountain View ensemble from the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.

A seventy-five-gallon naphtha drum was blown 250 feet across heavily traveled Jersey Avenue, Jersey City, a Holland Tunnel and Pulaski Skyway route, by an explosion in a fire last night in the one-story frame factory of the Excelsior Hat Company at Fifteenth and Coles Streets.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14. -- There were seventy-six craft in the special Larchmont Yacht Club regatta today, a big fleet normally but small in comparison to the record gathering of 285 yesterday.

LONDON, July 13. -- The disequilibrium of the European gold bloc remains a menace to the stability of the foreign exchanges, according to observers here, and the decision of the central banks to support gold currencies is construed mainly as a move to check speculation in guilders.
Eight new plays are being tried out in Summer theatres of the East during the current week. They are:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 14. -- Archer Gibson played the organ at a small musicale which Mrs. E. Prentice gave yesterday afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown. Later tea was served in the garden by Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs and Mrs. Vanderpool Adriance.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 14. -- Traveling by motor truck with a police motor-cycle escort through Manhattan and Yonkers to facilitate the movement, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin and his command of 1,075 guardsmen of the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment, arrived at Camp Smith today at 10:15 A.M.

CINCINNATI, July 14. -- Shifting his line-up twice from top to bottom only gave Manager Casey Stengel more headaches today, and his Dodgers crept out of town tonight for Pittsburgh in sixth place after losing both ends of a double-header to the Reds, who supplanted Brooklyn in fifth position.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14. -- This city, decked in royal purple and white, the official colors of Elkdom, is eagerly awaiting thousands of visitors and their guests who are coming to attend the 71st national Grand Lodge convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (AP). -- Criticism of the conduct of the Bruno Hauptmann trial is contained in a report to be presented tomorrow to the American Bar Association by its committee on cooperation between the press and the bar.

The Weather Bureau, aware of the fact that today would be St. Swithin's Day and that New Yorkers might have to endure for forty days whatever weather it predicted, took things phlegmatically last evening.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 14. -- A threefold celebration will be held in the Niagara area tomorrow. Governor Lehman will dedicate the two new Grand Island bridges and the fiftieth anniversaries of the beginning of conservation in New York and of the State reservation at Niagara will be observed.

LOS ANGELES, July 14. -- Through deals reported closed within the last few days or to be closed within the next few days, John J. Raskob, former Democratic chairman; Bernard Baruch, Senator Key Pittman and others are expected to undertake soon the revival of the old Comstock and the Silverado silver mines.

Two persons were burned about the face yesterday afternoon when the engine of a 32-foot speedboat, operated by Murray Simon of the Hotel Newton, 2,528 Broadway, backfired and burst into flame as the boat was passing Stepping Stone Light, off City Island.

The "prelude" to a "gigantic" meeting at which Harlemites will have their chance to pledge their lives in the service of Emperor Haile Sellassie I of Ethiopia was held yesterday afternoon in the Trade and Commerce Building, 2,370 Seventh Avenue, near 138th Street.

The difference of opinion between Mr. THOMAS GARDINER CORCORAN, the young Justinian of the Harvard Law School, and Representative RALPH BREWSTER of the Third Maine District has stirred particular interest among the Dirigos. The controversy rose over the Quoddy project, tide-harnessing to the tune of some $36,000,000.

Fourteen recommendations to save the taxpayers of New York City a least $2,712,181 a year, simplify court procedure and increase the efficiency of the courts were proposed yesterday in a report urging the reorganization of the city's judicial system under a central administrative body.

BERLIN, July 14. -- A series of Sunday morning national radio services for German youth, conducted by Nazi spokesmen, revealed today the new doctrine of what appears to be a new synthetic national religion.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 14. -- Fred Jacoby Jr., North Bergen, N.J., the nation's leading professional outboard driver, added the Buffalo Launch Club's international highpoint trophy to his long string of accomplishments today in the closing events of the two-day championship regatta on the Niagara River.
LONDON, July 14. -- A careful analysis of reports that the Ethiopian situation may be cleared up without Italy's resorting to war has revealed no single fact in substantiation.

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands, July 14. -- Six men were killed today when a Fokker liner of the Royal Dutch Airlines was wrecked in attempting a forced landing. The accident occurred at the principal air field, a mile and one-half from this city.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Discussions of British foreign policy as applied to the task of fortifying European peace have become more frank in the German press since the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons Thursday and all contend that the collectivism championed by Britain has not demonstrated its superiority over the bilateral procedure favored by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -- Winning twelve first places in the eighteen-event program, the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York successfully defended its Atlantic division canoeing team title on the Weequahic Park Lake 800-meter course today.

ROME, July 14. -- Mgr. Eugene S. Burke, who for ten years has been rector of the North American College in Rome, has resigned to return to his home diocese in Newark, N.J. The Bishop of Newark, Mgr. Thomas J. Walsh, has appointed him rector of Holy Trinity Church in Hackensack, N.J., and dean of Bergen County.

MIAMI, Fla., July 14 (AP). -- Two boys and a girl were rescued by a Coast Guard seaplane this afternoon after they had been adrift in an overturned sailboat for thirteen and one-half hours in the Atlantic, five miles east of here.
I read with great interest the article in THE TIMES real estate section last Sunday concerning the date of the law affecting the old-law tenement houses.

NO indictment either way is intended. But it is a plain fact that Arnold Zweig, one of Central Europe's favorite story tellers, would not have landed in the contents columns of either the pulp paper magazines or the "slicks" of this country with any of the short stories which make up his new book, "Playthings of Time" (Viking, $2.50).

Although plentifully supplied with species of jungle, desert and mountain mammals, the American Museum of Natural History has discovered it is greatly lacking in specimens of American wild life, it was announced yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 14. -- Analyzing recent European events that have tended to shake the world's faith in the League of Nations, the newspaper Mercurio says that the League's lack of success has been due not so much to the faults of the organization as to a lack of moral preparation by a majority of nations to fulfill the ideals entertained when Woodrow Wilson laid the foundations for the cooperative experiment.

The Mercury Athletic Club, by piling up second and third places, won the second annual track and field games sponsored by its organization yesterday at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx. The Harlem athletes won only two of the eight events for men, but their point total of 18 surpassed the efforts of the Jersey City Field Club and Trenton Times A.A., both of which finished with 10.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Hot weather so stimulated buying of lightweight goods last week, giving retailers in this territory an opportunity to reduce their stocks, that the volume of business ran considerably ahead of recent weeks and also that of a year ago.

SEATTLE, July 14 (AP). -- Delegates and visitors were arriving today for the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs. An attendance of 15,000 is expected.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP). -- Jack Medica, University of Washington swimming star, partially squared accounts for recent defeats with his greatest rival, Ralph Flanagan, today when he defeated the 17-year-old Miami, Fla., ace by a foot in a 1,500-meter free-style race at Fleishacker Pool.
BATH, N.Y., July 14. -- It will be a long time before the farm land of this region recovers fully from the damage caused by last Monday's flood.

Depicting vividly conditions in his diocese of 80,000 square miles in the Rocky Mountains, the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of Salt Lake City, Utah, appealed yesterday at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral for funds to assist the priests and nuns who are laboring there.
PARIS, July 13. -- The wholesale price index for France for the month of June was 344, compared with 353 in May and with 363 in June, 1934.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Registration statements for a total of $57,494,377 in securities issues were filed with the Securities Exchange Commission during the week ended July 10, the commission announced today.

Charles R. Marks, captain of the University of Glasgow team and Scottish interuniversity champion, and William Thompson, last year's runner-up, were beaten in the second round of the eighth annual men's Richmond County clay court championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I., yesterday.

The executive board of the International Longshoremen's Union, composed of the president, secretary and fourteen vice-presidents, met yesterday afternoon at 420 West Eighteenth Street to discuss minor matters as the final work of the convention here.

LONDON, July 13. -- President Roosevelt's silver statement was considered of negative value here, because his attitude toward the world silver situation was not clear, but the continuance of United States purchases of domestic silver had a steadying effect on the market, where weak speculators reduced their commitments.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 14. -- Several hundred persons watched the jumping contests and gymkhana which marked today's formal opening of the Riding Club of East Hampton for the season. Miss Ann Wright won the potato race, Shepard Krech Jr. being second.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 14 (AP). -- The police arrested an English Pied Piper today as he prepared to lead a children's crusade for gold and diamonds into the wilds of Brazil's Matto Grosso.
PARIS, July 14. -- Hundreds of thousands of men, women and children in rival political camps disputing a "dictatorship" paraded today in huge Bastile Day demonstrations.

Harry Vincent Bove, member of a well-known East Side Italian family, leaped to his death at 4 o'clock yesterday morning from the stern of the ferryboat Catskill into the Hudson River shortly after the boat had left her slip at Weehawken bound for New York.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Stocks of meat in cold storage are the smallest in recent years, but heavy imports from other countries have helped take up some of the slack in the supply in this country, says The Chicago Daily Drovers Journal.

CORRY, Pa., July 14 (AP). -- An angry mob carrying tar and feathers wrecked the home of Julius F. Sweitzer, 68, and his 86-year-old bride early today, but the couple was saved by police and firemen, who whisked them away.

WASHINGTON, July 14. (AP). -- Senator Arthur Capper, Republican of Kansas, one-time printer's devil who rose to eminence in journalism and politics, observed his seventieth birthday anniversary today, confident that the future "has greater things in store than we have dreamed of."

MONTAUK, L.I., July 14. -- The oil tanker Raritan Sun, carrying a cargo of several hundred thousand gallons of petroleum, went on the rocks in a dense fog early tonight half way between the Montauk Light and the Ditch Plains Coast Guard station on the south shore of Long Island.

A marked illustration of the steadily increasing tendency in acquiring real estate for investment is presented by the sale just announced by the firm of Riker Co. of the six-story elevator apartment house at 2,118 Ditmas Avenue, in the Flatbush residential area of Brooklyn.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 14. -- Christ Protestant Episcopal Church of this city can never have as its rector a member of the Anglo-Catholic group in that communion, according to legislation just enacted by the official boards of the parish.

Nearly 2,000,000 men, women and children fled from the heat of the city yesterday in search of cooling breezes at beaches and resorts. A bright, sunny sky and a mild southerly breeze gave them all the pleasures and all the tribulations common to a Sunday in midsummer.

None of last week's markets gave very clear expression of judgment on the general situation; on the Stock Exchange as on the Chicago Board of Trade, such movement as occurred was conflicting. It is worth observing, however, that with all of the week's vacillation, stock market "averages" went above the previous high level of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Rural sections in all States are leading the towns and cities in the purchase of United States saving bonds, with about as many women as men purchasing them, the Treasury Department announced today. Present sales, it was added, were showing a marked tendency upward.

Hot weather has become inconceivable without a revival of "The Mikado." Age cannot wither nor custom stale the infinite variety of GILBERT and SULLIVAN'S inspired muse. Neither can all the contemporary news dispatches from the Far East make the Japan of Manchukuo and Peiping more real than KoKo's and Pooh-Bah's countrymen.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 14. -- Stock incorporations numbered 1,535 in June and brought the six-month total to 9,842, the Secretary of State's office announced today.

The Yankees and White Sox fought each other for four hours and twenty minutes at the stadium yesterday, and at the end, having dropped one game of the double-header and taken the other, the New Yorkers had increased their slim lead in the pennant race to a game and a half.

ROME, July 14. -- Negotiations are understood to be in progress by the Italian, British and French Foreign Ministers to discover a way out of the difficulties in which the great powers and the League of Nations have been placed by the Italo-Ethiopian controversy.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 14. -- The resignation of John H. Jeffries Jr. as head coach of the varsity baseball and basketball teams of Princeton and the appointment to the respective positions of William J. Clarke and R. Kenneth Fairman were announced today by Professor Burnham Dell, chairman of the university council on athletics.

A tentative agreement to end the strife between the National Socialist party and its New York State branch was reported reached yesterday at an all-day conference between a subcommittee representing the national executive committee and representatives of the State committee.

A fast-moving baseball game held 1,000 spectators in rapt enthusiasm at Marine Park, Great Kills, S.I., late yesterday afternoon when the Flat Tires won the championship of the United States World War Amputations Post 116 of the American Legion from the Broken Wings for the first time in five years.

ALBANY, July 14. -- Income tax collections this year by the State totaled in round figures $58,000,000, including the 1 per cent emergency income tax. Advancement of the second instalment date on income taxes from July 15 to June 15, provided by the Legislature on Governor Lehman's recommendation, increased collections $4,500,000.

HANKOW, China, Monday, July 15. -- Although the Yangtse River flood at Hankow is remaining stationary at a level of more than fifty-one feet and all ports above this city of 1,600,000 are reporting that the water is receding, frantic efforts are being made to combat an expected rise that will arrive in about two weeks.

The investigation of racketeering and crime in Manhattan by a special grand jury convoked upon orders of Governor Herbert H. Lehman faces its first legal test today in Part I of the Supreme Court, where the right of the city to appropriate funds requested by Thomas E. Dewey, the special prosecutor, will be challenged.

The Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works is ready to absorb immediately 100,000 of the State's 600,000 employables now on relief rolls, it was announced yesterday by Acting State PWA Director Arthur S. Tuttle at 2 Lafayette Street.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- All officers and members of all organizations affiliated with the American Federation of Labor were called upon today "to defend and protect" the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act "against all opposition and all attacks which may be made upon it" in letters sent by William Green, president of the federation, to national and international unions, State Federations of Labor, city central bodies, Federal labor unions and American Federation of Labor organizers.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., July 14. -- A bus loaded with thirty-two residents of Jersey City, returning from an outing at Greenwood Lake, N.J., crashed through a fence and plunged over a six-foot embankment tonight at 10:30 o'clock.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- The growing corn crop made progress last week, and considerable cultivation was done, except in Oklahoma and areas where rain retarded work. In the southern counties of Iowa the condition is unsatisfactory, with corn drowned or choked by weeds.

At 10:15:18 o'clock tonight the full moon will lose its glow and will take on a dull color as the first stages of eclipse set in. The moon will turn from silver to brass and from brass to red, according to Dr. Clyde Fisher, curator of astronomy at the Museum of Natural History.

RYE, N.Y., July 14. -- In a flashing finale that had the spectators almost bewildered by the rapidity of the final awards, the fifth annual Country Club Horse Show came to a colorful close today on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP). -- Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, economist and statistician, pointed today to what he termed "the failure of the combination of great accumulated shortages of goods and great accumulated surpluses of capital to stimulate new business activity."

SHREWSBURY, N.J., July 14. -- State troopers, game wardens and local police joined today in a hunt for a pack of wild dogs which last night attacked a 7-year-old girl here and which is believed responsible for the killing of chickens valued at more than $450 in the last three days.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14. -- Mrs. Charles H. Sabin gave a luncheon today at Bayberry Land, her place in the Shinnecock Hills, for members of her Sunday house party, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. Woodward Babcock and Oliver Hoare of London, brother of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (AP). -- Twenty-three thousand fans -- the largest home crowd of the season -- watched the world champion Cardinals sweep their four-game series with the Phillies today, taking both ends of a double-header. Paul Dean scored his ninth victory in the opener, 5 to 1, and Bill Walker stretched the Cardinals' victory string to ten in the nightcap, 10 to 1.

Mr. Witherspoon's letter, with its timely reminder of the "ignorance of the average business man," is a refreshing confession which many could take to heart. I, among the many, stand admittedly guilty of his criticism.

Discussing the present status of construction costs and labor prices, Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports states that the cubic foot composite index compiled by that firm shows a reduction from 82 in January this year, to 80 at the present time.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 14. -- Wilmer Hines today crowned his first American tournament appearance of the season with a double success by winning both the singles and doubles finals of the forty-third Longwood Bowl tennis competition.
GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 14. -- After six days of play competitors in the tournaments of the British Chess Federation's annual congress rested today.
The consumption of Indian cotton by mills of that country and exports of cotton by India were larger in May than in any previous May, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14. -- Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen gave a largely attended tea at her home, Wakehurst, this afternoon in honor of her daughter, Princess Louise Mdivani, who is spending the Summer with her.

With the grim pronouncement that they were prepared to "fight it out all Summer," the 225 registered caddies at the Dyker Beach Park municipal golf course in Brooklyn went on strike yesterday morning at 5 o'clock, demanding an increase of 25 cents over the present 75-cent caddy fee.

PARIS, July 13. -- Considered in the light of the celerity with which about 10,000,000,000 francs in gold were withdrawn from France in the last crisis, the rate at which the gold has been returning appears slow, and it is obvious that fears of devaluation of the franc are not entirely removed, especially abroad.

PITTSBURGH, July 14. -- The Giants avoided the ignominy of a shut-out at Forbes Field today with a desperate last-minute rally, but that's the only consolation they got out of their final game with the Pirates before a crowd of about 12,000.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., July 14 (AP). -- Although fifty more workmen at the Boulder Dam project went on strike today, bringing the total of idle men to about 400, the likelihood of complete paralysis of work was lessened when the truck drivers' union voted to remain on the job.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Relief "white-collar" workers who are investigating and collecting internal revenue taxes through checking over old lists have thus far paid for their services through additional collections seventeen times the cost of their salaries, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, stated today.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 14. -- State police turned hundreds of Sunday sight-seers away from this city today as the American Legion, 1,200 strong, made a wartime encampment for the day and moved mud and debris from the streets on a wholesale scale.

This evening will be the witness of one of July's vagrant events -- the opening of the Civic Light Opera Company's series of Gilbert and Sullivan revivals. First in the series will be "The Mikado," to continue for the remainder of this week, and the theatre is the seldom frequented Adelphi, on West Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP). -Rexford G. Tugwell's new rural resettlement administration was disclosed in official quarters today to have 6,090 employes on its payroll.
The annual festival of Our Lady of Mount Carmel (Monte Carmelo) began yesterday on the upper East Side.

BERLIN, July 13. -- Money is abundant here, with day loans at times under 3 per cent. In the first six days of July, 52 per cent of the Reichsbank's month-end credits for June was repaid. Savings banks' deposits are still increasing, and were 13,200,000,000 marks at the end of May.

Notwithstanding favorable crop developments and adverse conditions in the domestic textile industry, cotton futures held steady last week and at the close on Saturday prices were virtually the same as at the close of the preceding week. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices were unchanged to 3 points down for the week.
THE following report from an all-agog tourist below the Rio Grande has been received and is herewith placed on file:

Unable to resist an impulse to taunt the police about "how slick we fooled you," one of the five men arrested as members of the Brooklyn "rifle gang" of burglars and hold-up men told yesterday so detailed and vivid a narrative that the authorities believe they now can clear up perhaps 400 store robberies.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., N.Y., July 14. -- C.S. Ogilvy's Jay led a fleet of eighteen boats across the finish line today in the last of the Star Class elimination series conducted under the burgee of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 14. -- In the presence of a capacity crowd, Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School received the massive Clifford Hemphill Challenge Trophy in perpetuity from the hands of the donor today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The prohibition propaganda that legal beer and repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment caused an increase in automobile accidents was answered today by Captain William H. Stayton, chairman of Repeal Associates, with official police statistics from forty-three New York cities.

TACOMA, Wash., July 14 (AP). -- Reports that the government was closing in on William Dainard, fugitive "brains" of the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping, continued to circulate here today while Mrs. Margaret Waley awaited in jail the pronouncement of sentence for her part in the crime.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 14. -- New York City girls apparently have discovered a method of circumventing Yonkers' new ordinance prohibiting shorts, bathing suits and so-called sun suits from being worn on public streets.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 14. -- The national gliding championship was awarded tonight to Richard C. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., for the second year. J.K. O'Meara of New York City won second place.

Last year available camp facilities were used to less than 70 per cent of capacity because of lack of funds. It is not only deplorable from a sentimental point of view but it is unsound from a practical standpoint.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP). -- A claim that the relief population is as well off physically as the rest of the country was advanced today by Harry L. Hopkins.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Television will be put on a long-distance telephone hookup early in 1936, if the Federal Communications Commission approves a plan by the Bell Telephone laboratories to install a "coaxial" cable between New York and Philadelphia.

VIENNA, July 14. -- Viennese musical circles are speculating on whether the resignation of Dr. Richard Strauss from his official post in the Third Reich portends his return to Vienna to reoccupy the house that was presented to him by the Austrian Government when he was director of the Vienna Staatsoper.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The principal financial event this week was the official warning against an exaggerated advance in the stock market. Although ostensibly issued by the Boerse committee, the warning really emanated from Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, with the purpose of influencing the securities markets in the interest of the government's future economic policy.
WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The status of major legislation now before Congress is as follows:

All accounts agree that Congress is now in a very bad temper. Publicly this is shown by angry clashes in committees and upon the floor. Heated language provokes outbursts still more fiery. Members of both houses are touchy, irritable, nervous, suspicious, ready to believe the worst of any man or measure.

About two weeks ago the Research and Planning Division of the NRA, under the direction of LEON HENDERSON, released a report analyzing what has happened during the last ten or a dozen years to interest and dividend payments when compared with national income and labor income.

Increasing imports of steel in the first five months of this year deprived 3,900 workmen in the United States of full-time jobs, according to a survey by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The report reads in part:

VIENNA, Austria, July 14. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, although injured yesterday near Linz in an automobile accident in which his wife was killed, made clear today he is determined to continue active leadership of Austria's Fascist Government.

Activity turned sharply upward in the wholesale markets last week as a large number of out-of-town buyers arrived here to purchase Fall merchandise and to carry out their plans for August promotions. Although many of the retail representatives were content to study the new lines of apparel and accessories offered for the new season, wholesalers expressed themselves as being satisfied with the volume of orders placed for both staple merchandise and fashion items.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe's momentary letdown in the tenth gave the Athletics a 4-to-3 triumph over Detroit today.

MELBOURNE, July 14. -- The famous Swedish grain racing barque C.B. Pedersen, which left Australia a month ago in ballast, carrying eight passengers who wished to "round the Horn in sail," is experiencing one of the most adventurous voyages of her long career.

SWAN LAKE, N.Y., July 14. -- Miss Erna Kompa of the Women's Swimming Association of New York was the star of the two-day invitation swimming meet concluded at the President Pool today. The elder of the Kompa sisters continued her attack on American back-stroke marks by breaking three records to add to the one she established yesterday for 220 yards.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Germany has discovered on the basis of this year's good crops the possibilities and the limitations of its effort to make itself independent of the outer world in the matter of foodstuffs.

BERLIN, July 14. -- A delegation of British ex-service men, composed chiefly of former colonels, representing the British Legion, arrived here today to be the guests of the German Veterans League. They were greeted at the station by delegates of the Stahlhelm and the Kyffhauser League as well as by a deputy for Joachim yon Ribbentrop.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Preliminary steps looking to the negotiation of trade agreements or the holding of trade practice conferences under the sponsorship of the Federal Trade Commission have been taken by representatives of about 100 industries, the commission stated tonight.

VIENNA, July 14. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg returned to Vienna this afternoon on the train bringing the body of his wife from Linz. He was met at Penzing station by all the members of the government headed by Vice Chancellor Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, who arrived from Venice by airplane shortly before.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and chairman of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, returns today from Paris where he has been attending the annual conferences of the association. He and Mrs. Butler are on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.
I appeal to you because the national forests are again in serious danger.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 14. -- Cecil Smith, one of the country's trio of nine-goal players, gave one of his outstanding performances today in leading the Texas polo quartet to a 16-to-5 triumph over a Westbury four on Bostwick Field.

The decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, voiding the injunction against ship lines and longshoremen who have refused to handle freight transported in trucks manned by non-union employes, was accepted by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, as a move to improve waterfront trucking service.

NEW ORLEANS, July 14. -- The cotton market here was rather quiet last week. There was no disposition to speculate and business in future contracts on the Cotton Exchange was light. Scalping operations were restricted by a scarcity of contracts.

An audience of about 9,000, the largest since the opening night of this Summer's Stadium concerts, vigorously applauded Jose Iturbi in the double role of soloist and conductor last night, when he led an orchestra of Philharmonic-Symphony players from his place at the keyboard in a performance of the Grieg piano concerto.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14. -- Destruction of an ancient and historic elm tree on the lawn of Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Stevens at 65 Beach Avenue is unnecessary, the owners were told this afternoon in a telegram signed by John F. Schenck, Mayor of Flemington, N.J. Mayor Schenck suggested that a tree expert on Staten Island be consulted.

PANAMA, R.P., July 14. -- President Harmodio Arias assumed personal charge of the National Police today when a controversy between Galileo Solis, Minister of Government, and Chief of Police Aurelio Guardia reached a crisis over control of the model jail where the government's arms are stored.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 14. -- As a permanent memorial to Meyer London, who came to the lower East Side of New York City from Russia when he was 20 years old, became widely known as a labor lawyer and leader and served three terms in Congress, an auditorium seating 3,000 was dedicated today at the Workmen's Circle Camp, near here.

Fay Wray is due to arrive from Hollywood at the Newark Airport this morning, and will sail on the Europa tomorrow night for England to play the leading role in "His Majesty's Pajamas," a Gaumont-British film.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 14. -- Tommy Hitchcock led the Sands Point four to a 10-4 victory over Great Island today in the weekly high-goal polo match at the Sands Point Club. The veteran internationalist was all over the field and gave one of the best exhibitions of the season as he recorded four times for his team.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP). -- The Massachusetts 6:30 Sunday Sports Law today halted the second game of a double-header between the Red Sox and Indians in the tenth inning with the score at 2-all, after the home team had defeated the visitors, 14 to 3, in the first game.

A man described by the police as an ace of the German air force during the World War was arrested early yesterday morning as an automobile thief after the car he was driving had crashed into a radio patrol car parked at 196th Street and the Harlem River Drive.
A flood control survey will be made of the rivers and their principal tributaries through the southern tier area of New York State which was flooded last week, Governor Lehman said yesterday.

Fruitful religious experience must, in the absence of narrowing dogma, be directed by intelligence in the application of good-will, William J. Reagan, principal of the Oakwood Friends School at Poughkeepsie, said yesterday in the principal address at the Religious Society of Friends meeting house, 144 East Twentieth Street.
PRAGUE, July 14. -- Germany swept Czechoslovakia aside in the Davis Cup European zone final today to earn the right to oppose the United States in the interzone final at Wimbledon next week-end.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 14. -- Sustaining its first defeat of the season in the championship series of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lost today to the Union County Cricket Club of Elizabeth, N.J., 140 to 113.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 14. -- By winning three of the last four holes, Johnny Riddell of the Garden City Golf Club scored a thrilling 1-up victory over T. Suffern Tailer Jr. of Piping Rock in the eighteen-hole final-round match of the Rockaway Hunting Club's invitation golf tournament today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 14. -- With rehabilitation work in full swing in the flood-stricken villages in the Binghamton area, sight-seers by the thousands, ignoring published warnings barring from the district all visitors who had no business there, tried to drive into the damaged zone all day today, keeping a large detachment of State troopers and the Broome County Sheriff's deputies busy.

The new trade agreement between Soviet Russia and the United States is more significant in what it implies than in what it actually does. Under it only a trifling increase -- $16,000,000 or $18,000,000 -- in our exports to Russia can be expected. The total will be only about a quarter of what we used to sell to Russia, and will represent a very small fraction in our foreign commerce.

In his review of the American scene in yesterday's TIMES, Sir JOSIAH STAMP put his finger on one of our weaknesses which has been clearly exposed to the eye of the discerning observer by the rapid expansion of public services to cope with the depression. We have, he declares, no adequate appreciation of what a skilled administration means.

The Congressional committee sitting in New York at present, which is invesigating real estate reorganizations, has brought to light some interesting facts. During the past three years considerable publicity has been given to protective and reorganization committees. Their weak points have been dilated on at length, as well as the effects on bondholders.

A display of Ethiopian material form the collection of Gordon MacCreagh is being shown at Putnam's Book Store and at Brentano's in connection with the publication of the new second edition of Mr. MacCreagh's book, "The Last of Free Africa." The book has been brought up to date.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
Staging a powerful closing drive, the First Division riders of Fort Hamilton conquered the Governors Island four, 12 -- 7, at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 14. -- The race for the "Forgotten Yachtsmen" was won today by H.M. Devereaux's cutter Pendragon from the City Island Yacht Club.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 14 (AP). -- Looting and incendiarism marked the third day of Protestant-Catholic disorders today, but at curfew time tonight (10 o'clock) police reported quiet had been restored.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The Treasury announced today an offering of $100,000,000 in 2 7/8 per cent bonds to be sold to the highest bidders, as part of the new fiscal program by which it is intended as far as possible to avoid very large offerings for cash on regular quarterly tax payment dates.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- The annual black rust scare is on in the Spring wheat territory of the Northwest, in the United States and Canada. In Canada the black rust has been only moderate so far, while in the United States it has been found mostly in the Dakotas and parts of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Republican women are looking to Virginia Bacon in the coming campaign. They are keeping their eye on the energetic wife of Robert Low Bacon, Republican Representative from New York's "fashionable First," on Long Island, because she is keeping her eye on the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Business activity in June was steady, with production resisting the seasonal decline, retail sales improving and freight car loadings expanding, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey.

It is the duty of the church to act as a friend to the bewildered people of Africa, "that the world may be a safer place to live in," Dr. Emory Ross, secretary of the Committee on African Welfare of the Federal Council of Churches, said yesterday morning at the Central Church of the Disciples of Christ at 142 West Eighty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- More than $200,000,000 of private capital for the modernization and repair of all types of buildings, for construction of new homes and for the refinancing of existing mortgages has been released through insured loans under operation of the National Housing Act since last Fall, according to Stewart McDonald, acting Federal Housing Administrator, today.

MONTREAL, July 14 (AP). -- The Royals swept a double-header with Newark today to stretch their winning streak to eight straight and increase their lead in the International League. The scores were 4 to 2 and 4 to 0, giving Newark a string of nine straight losses.

Commodity futures markets here were irregular last week in quiet trading. Rubber, hides and coffee were lower, while sugar, after a sharp break at the beginning of the week, was slightly higher, and silk, copper and coca advanced. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, cocoa, lard, lead, tin and silk moved up, while flour and rubber declined.

NEW HAVEN, July 13. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.6, which compares with 81.7 the week before, 81.6 two weeks before, 82 three weeks before and 82.3 four weeks before.

While a substantial number of retail buyers visited the local market yesterday, they continued to operate with a certain degree of caution. At present stores are primarily interested in cleaning up their Summer stocks, and, accordingly, little business of a fill-in nature appeared.

Trading was mixed and generally dull yesterday on the local commodity futures markets. Copper, rubber and cocoa were firm. In the cash markets, gains occurred in all the grains, lard, rubber and tin, while cocoa and cotton declined.

HANKOW, July 15. -- The Yangtse River dropped a half inch today from the level that has imperiled this great city, partially as a result of the dynamiting of the railway embankment, which afforded a new outlet.

Flowers discarded by exhibitors in Horticulture Hall of Rockefeller Center after they had been judged unworthy of exhibition but salvaged by a porter who restored them to bloom and beauty by careful nurturing in his Bronx backyard won a first prize yesterday for Peter Podneek, the porter, in the first annual flower show for employes and tenants.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- Almost all of the Summer colony turned out tonight for the annual benefit concert of the Art Association, at which the music and entertainment committee, headed by Carroll W.J. Ball, presented as the artist Fernanda Doria, contralto soloist.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer reserved decision yesterday on a taxpayer's petition to restrain the city from providing funds for the special investigation of organized crime ordered by Governor Lehman. In so doing he left the Board of Estimate free to appropriate the funds that Thomas E. Dewey, Special Deputy Assistant District Attorney, has requested.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Registration on the country's twenty national Exchanges of securities of corporations was effected today under regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission with a minimum disturbance of trading. Virtually every prominent corporation had met the requirements which permit trading in their securities to continue.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 15. -- Pat Hurley called me up last night. Remember Pat, Secretary of War during the time when we had no trouble with the Constitution but had it with everything else.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15. -- Sweeping down on the finish line in a spectacle seldom witnessed before in a yacht race, the fleet in the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week provided a succession of thrills today. H.S. Vanderbilt's Class M sloop Prestige and W.J. Strawbridge's international twelve-meter Mitena showed the way among the large racers, but their victories were overshadowed momentarily by the closeness of the competition in the various divisions.
The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday received the following cable from Rio de Janeiro regarding work by the convention of Brazilian coffee growers:

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Opposition to the construction between New York and Philadelphia of a coaxial cable, over which telephone messages, telegraph and television could be transmitted simultaneously was withdrawn suddenly today by the Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company.

The close-clipped lawns surrounding the sedate chateau of Charles M. Schwab, steel man, at Seventy-third Street and Riverside Drive, were gay with laughter and merriment for the first time in a decade yesterday afternoon.
ROME, July 15. -- If there are any who still think war in East Africa can be avoided, Premier Benito Mussolini made it clear today he is not one of them.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 15 (AP). -- A political row over Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, neared a climax tonight with both sides predicting victory in a new attempt to oust him as executive vice president of Texas Young Democrats.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Only trivial progress was made on the AAA bill today during a Senate debate featured by a heated attack and defense of its price-fixing provisions.

Under an extremely light volume of business, price movements on the Cotton Exchange yesterday held within narrow limits, ending 5 points higher to 1 point lower. There was scattered pressure in evidence on the March position and, with houses doing government business buyers of several blocks of May, the differences shifted until October sold at a 6-point premium over March as well as above both December and January.

LONDON, July 15. -- Without showing a trace of over-confidence despite the fact that they are the unanimous choice of British experts and betting commissioners to defeat Germany in the Davis Cup interzone final this week-end, the members of the American international tennis squad put in two hours of hard practice today under a scorching sun at Wimbledon.

The Bell System reports a consolidated net income of $56,545,535 for the five months ended on May 31, compared with $55,902,642 for the same period last year. Of the total, after providing for amounts applicable to stocks of associated companies held by the public, a balance of $50,770,112 was applicable to stock of American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., July 15. -- The arrival from India of a shipment of animals for the private "jungle" maintained here by Frank Buck, trapper of specimens for zoos and circuses, resulted early today and last night in the injury of two attendants.

Opening his speaking drive last night against political foes seeking to depose him as Republican County Chairman, Chase Mellen Jr. challenged his rivals to come forward with the name of the person they wanted to succeed him.
ROME, July 15 (AP). -- Italian authorities opened an investigation today of the strange deaths in a bathing resort of an American art teacher and a Briton who was in a party of her friends.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 15. -- The Misses Kathleen and Myrtle Buckner of Riverdale-on-Hudson, who are with their grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Buckner, at the Mount Washington Hotel, entertained there at dinner for Miss Mimi Vanderbilt and Master Peter Vanderbilt, who came with their mother, Mrs. A.R. Vanderbilt of New York, who occupies the Irwin H. Cornell cottage at Sugar Hill this season.
