The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the purchase of 500 new subway cars for the Independent City Subway at a cost of $19,288,026, and also authorized construction of the fourth section of the Ward's Island sewage disposal plant at a cost of $7,479,000.

Some fishing boat captains always have a supply of stories ready to keep any tired members aboard from growing too drowsy, but Captain Howard Lance will be able to cheer the discouraged sword fisherman with an experience that cannot easily be duplicated (truthfully).

In response to the demand of the Socialist State organization, the national executive committee of the party voted at the final session of its quarterly meeting here yesterday a clear-cut repudiation of communism and Communist methods and adopted a program that was characterized as paving the road for a restoration of party harmony.

BOSTON, July 15. -- Lawyers in Federal District Court here were startled today when Judge E.H. Brewster predicted that the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals tomorrow would rule against the AAA processing tax law. Judge Brewster, who is not a member of the Circuit Court bench, on Oct. 19 had upheld the same law.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 15. -- Mrs. Frederick J. Davis of Providence, R.I., today led a field of 86 women golfers through the qualifying round of the seventeenth annual Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournment for the Griswould Cup to become medalist with a score of 79.

The population of one-half the earth, including every one in the United States, had the rare opportunity last night of witnessing the longest eclipse of the moon in fifty years. The lunar pageant here lasted five hours and 28 minutes.
" Schmeling! Schmeling! Who's got Max Schmeling?"
Administration of the new relief program in New York State probably will become a leading issue in the Assembly election this year.

The Committee for Ethiopia, recently formed by friends of that nation to place Ethiopia's case before American public opinion, announced yesterday that it had started circulation of a peace petition asking President Roosevelt to invoke the Kellogg-Briand peace pact in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute.

A plea of guilty to the charge of possessing a pistol, a misdemeanor, was entered in Special Sessions yesterday by Francesco Pardo de Zela, 19 years old, whose father, of the same name, is the Peruvian Consul General in this city, and lives at 510 West 110th Street.
" Alibi Ike," a First National production based on a story by the late Ring Lardner and featuring Joe E. Brown, Olivia de Havilland, Ruth Donnelly and Roscoe Karns, opens today at the Cameo.

Opposition of employers to the efforts of workers in organizing for collective bargaining constituted the most serious menace to the advancement of civil liberties during the past year, according to the conclusions drawn in "Land of the Free," the annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union, which was made public yesterday.

The situation of Italy, Germany and Japan in the family of great powers is developing to a point where the problems of these nations will "tax the world's wisdom and the world's statesmanship to the utmost," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared in a statement upon returning yesterday from Europe.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, witnessed yesterday a near-riot among factions of the chicken slaughterers' union in a crowded room in Clinton Hall, in the heart of the lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The House today put its own "Brain Trust" at work drafting the President's Tax Bill. The Ways and Means Committee asked Lovell H. Parker, chief of staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue, and Middleton Boaman, House legislative counsel, to try to shape up a tentative bill.

Louis Cohen, who has been a fugitive since 1933 when he and two other men were indicted for helping Irving Wexler, better known as Waxey Gordon, in concealing the latter's income, surrendered yesterday to Francis W.H. Adams, United States Attorney.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MEXICO, D.F., July 15. -- A burst of machine gun fire from an automobile on the principal street of Villa Hermosa, Tabasco, ended today a student campaign against Tomas Garrido y Canabal, radical former Cabinet member and ruler of the State of Tabasco.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- The outstanding wedding of France and the oldest inhabited Norman castle in England are next on the program for Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth and her daughter Paulina, aged 10. They will sail Wednesday on the Manhattan for a six-weeks European stay.
Rare mammals, birds, reptiles and fish from East Africa arrived yesterday on the American-South African liner City of New York, which docked at Pier 7, Brooklyn.

The Midtown Hudson Tunnel, which has been burrowing like a huge mole beneath the bed of the river since last December; will be "holed through" within the next two or three weeks, it became known yesterday during an inspection of the $37,000,000 project by a group of PWA officials.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 10 shows decreases for the week of $94,000,000 in total loans and investments and $35,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $66,000,000 in net demand deposits, $11,000,000 in time deposits and $160,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Secretary Morgenthau can see "no possible objection from the point of view of Treasury finance or government credit" to the passage of the resolution outlawing suits on the gold clause.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Hoffman Philip, Minister to Norway and a veteran career, diplomat, was promoted today by President Roosevelt to be Ambassador to Chile.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 15. -- Professor Hoskins, who was automatically retired last month under the age rule, was born in Rockdale, Delaware County, Pa., on Jan. 16, 1867. He received his preparatory education at the Rugby Academy in Philadelphia, and was graduated cum laude from Princeton University in 1891.

The intervention of Governor Lehman in the strife between citizens of Haverstraw, N.Y., and members of the Knit Goods Workers Union, Local 155, its affiliate, was requested yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 15 (AP). -- Sixteen survivors, including five of the nation's first fifteen ranking women tennis players, were left in the annual Essex County Club's invitation tournament tonight after completion of the first two rounds.

SEATTLE, July 15. -- Feminine political ambitions stand a better chance of realization in Georgia and Maryland than in any other State, it was indicated in an address by Mrs. Geline MacDonald Bogyman of Richmond at the first mass meeting of the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

Several kinds of witnesses have appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee to testify on the proposed new taxes. One group has contributed mainly indignation and an abuse of the sponsors of the new schedules that has not helped its case. Another has contented itself with a sober analysis of the principles involved.
With a passenger list of 1,600, the North German Lloyd liner Europa will sail tonight for the Channel ports on the second half of her ninety-ninth trip.

JAMES HANLEY is a writer of high talent and serious purpose. These qualities are plain in "The Furys" (Macmillan, $2.50), his most ambitious work so far. Hard and sustained effort went into the book. It is built on careful detail, the scope is wide, the material is handled with complete honesty. I was not in the least stirred by it and believe that it will be a rare reader who is.

" Reader" writes to say that he and his friends voted for Roosevelt supporters in November last year not because they liked the New Deal but because they feared it, and Roosevelt was their only hope for protection against a radical Congress.

General James G. Harbord, chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, renewed yesterday his appeal for contributions to the Red Cross relief fund of $350,000 for the aid of victims of the recent up-State flood.

The directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., have retained Thomas D. Thacher, of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, to represent the company at the hearing to be held on Thursday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the United States District Court on the fees and allowances amounting to $3,222,315 claimed by lawyers, accountants, receivers and others from Paramount Publix Corporation, predecessor of Paramount Pictures.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Appropriations for several veterans hospitals, further dam construction in the Tennessee Valley and a long list of other projects were added to the second Deficiency Appropriation Bill today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 15. -- The immediate exchange with Paraguay of all students held as war prisoners, so that they may resume their studies without further delay, is suggested by President Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano and Minister of the Interior Enrique Baldivieso.

When a possum in quest of food happens to step across the invisible boundary line between the sovereign States of Georgia and Alabama does he thereby enter into the stream of interstate commerce and become subject to the recent Supreme Court decision?

HAVANA, July 15. -- The death penalty was imposed today on Ramon Suarez, Elizardo Salabarria, Gregorio Martin and Jose Diaz by the Urgency Court, which found them guilty of kidnapping Antonio San Miguel, wealthy president of the Guantanamo Western Railway, and four servants on June 5.

Teachers who are overweight are not "acceptable hygienic models" for their pupils and do not stand the strain of teaching, in the opinion of the board of examiners of the city schools. But Miss Rose Freistater, thirty pounds overweight according to the board's standards, thinks otherwise, and has carried to the State Commissioner of Education her fight to obtain a regular license as a laboratory assistant.
LEEDS, England, July 15. -- Ahead by 222 runs, England tonight was in a fortified position to defeat South Africa in the third test cricket match finishing tomorrow.

Secret Service agents of the Treasury Department revealed yesterday how they trapped Nicholas Triola, dealer in counterfeit banknotes, after three months of patient old-fashioned detective work, one of their number posing part of the time as an ex-convict in order to get in with the counterfeit-passing gang.

Although public opinion appraises a man by "the company he keeps," he is not to be presumed to have knowledge of the fact that in a remote past an associate of later years was convicted of a crime, and the State bears the burden of establishing by direct evidence that he had such knowledge, Magistrate Nathan D. Perlman decided yesterday afternoon.

MIDWAY ISLAND, July 15 (By Wireless). -- Exactly three months after she first anchored off this low-lying atoll, in the same alternating spine-chilling showers and blazing sunshine, the steamer North Haven has completed her mission of laying stepping-stones for the Clipper plane service that will span the Pacific.

Bus service for handicapped children attending parochial schools is provided in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It directs the Board of Education to supply such service in September.

GREAT YARMOUTH, July 15. -- There was no change in the relative positions of the leaders in the international tournament of the British Chess Federation today as a result of the play in the seventh round.

NOROTON, Conn., July 15. -- Miss Betty Pietsch of Lawrence Farms led a field of forty-nine at the end of the first eighteen holes of the women's Fairfield and Westchester open golf championship for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy at the Wee Burn Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Leading House backers of the "death sentence" in the Utility Holding Company Bill today upset the House Rules Committee's procedure for investigating lobbying activities of the utility companies by demanding that they be heard when the committee resumes its investigation tomorrow morning.
Bob Moses had to bring a whole live barnyard to Central Park so our New York City children would know a goose from a guinea hen.

In your editorial of July 14 you pointed out that in John Marshall's day the important constitutional decisions of the United States Supreme Court were handed down by the justices of that court without consideration of how these decisions would affect the fortunes of the political parties with which they were affiliated in private life.

In the House yesterday the Hon. BRASWELL DRUE DEEN, Representative of the Eighth Georgia District, made a speech that touched the hearts of all his homesick colleagues. He said in effect that he was far frae his hame an' weary aften whiles. The brethren, all gnawed by the same irresistible longing for their homesteads and their fences, rose up and yelled and cheered for the usual three minutes by the clock.

ALBANY, July 15 (AP). -- Governor Lehman tonight was prepared to confer with Federal representatives in a new step to coordinate State and Federal relief work in the flood-stricken areas of the State.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- A determined drive to adjourn Congress was started in the House today, following representations from some of President Roosevelt's associates on his weekend fishing trip to Jefferson Island that he was willing for the session to end if a date and "formula" for quitting could be agreed upon.

LONDON, July 15. -- While official quarters here insisted that Great Britain was still determined to "uphold the League of Nations," emphasis continued to shift today from the sins of the Italians to the sins of the Ethiopians.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Broadening its war against "stock racketeers" the Securities and Exchange Commission was disclosed today to have created a clearing house for collecting and diseminating information on operations of get-rich-quick promoters.

RENO, July 15. -- A decree of divorce from Joseph Larocque Jr. was granted today to Louise Y. Larocque of New York on grounds of cruelty. The couple were married on April 22, 1924, and have one child.

Despite the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the right of the NRA to act, several hundred New York City employers have cooperated voluntarily with the local office of the NRA and have authorized it to distribute to their employes nearly $20,000 collected under NRA rulings for non-compliance with codes before the Supreme Court had handed down its decision.
GUADALAJARA, Mexico, July 15. -- President Lazaro Cardenas, in the last twenty-four hours, has been testing his popular support.

VIENNA, July 15. -- Less than a week since the repeal of anti- Hapsburg laws of the Austrian Republic by the present government, a sharp answer has come from the Little Entente in the shape of an authoritative front page editorial in the Prager Presse, organ of the Czechoslovak foreign office, which finances the publication and controls its entire contents.

The new issue of $40,000,000 of Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company 3 3/4 per cent bonds met a ready market yesterday. The bonds in over-the-counter trading quickly went to a premium of 2 to 2 1/2 points over the offering price of 102 1/2.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Senator Borah, who is in some quarters mentioned as Republican candidate for President, declined today to attend a Republican conference of representatives of eleven Western States, which is to be held at Yellowstone National Park Aug. 23-24.
A young woman was fatally stabbed and her escort was injured at about 2:15 A.M. yesterday by a Negro in Morningside Park at 120th Street as they were returning from a dance.

BERLIN, July 15. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler received five of the British Legion's delegates today. He was assisted in welcoming them by his deputy leader of the Nazi party, Rudolf Hess. Later, representatives of the British War Veterans Association laid a wreath on the war memorial which is Germany's equivalent for the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
BERLIN, July 15. -- The Boerse opened on a note of inactivity and failed to develop any tendency today. Toward the close certain specialties registered gains from a quarter to a half point.

BELGRADE, July 15. -- Although no official information is forthcoming concerning the long conference Prince Regent Paul had with King Carol of Rumania, it is believed in well-informed circles the question of the attempted restora tion of the Hapsburgs in Austria, following the Schuschnigg's government's recent repealing of the republican laws against the Hapsburgs, was the principal subject discussed.

Many windows in the three-story plant Of the Spring Products Corporation, at Walnut Avenue and 135th Street, the Bronx, were broken and five automobiles belonging to employes of the concern were overturned yesterday when a group of strikers rushed the place at about 9 A.M.

The New York State Association of Cemeteries believes a single day is too short for the full expression of the sentiment implicit in Memorial Day. Accordingly, at the opening of its seventh annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, the association called on organizations "interested in memorializing the dead and honoring our national heroes, both military and civic," to join it in seeking the establishment of National Memorial Week.

TACOMA, July 15. -- A bank bandit reported to resemble scarfaced William Mahan, fugitive "brains" of the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping, shot and killed two police officers near here today and escaped with scores of officers in pursuit.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 15 (AP). -- Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and a group of State and national officials came to the Niagara frontier today for two ceremonies -- the dedication of the new Grand Island Bridges over the Niagara River and the observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the State Reservation at Niagara Falls.

LONDON, July 15. -- Ten miles of iron-gray warships rode at anchor this evening in the quiet, sunlit waters between Portsmouth and the Isle of Wight in readiness for the mightiest demonstration of British naval power since the surrender of the German fleet at Scapa Flow.

LOS ANGELES, July 15. -- Elimination of private defense counsel in all criminal cases and substitution of a public defender would "strike at the very root of our crime problem," Mayer C. Goldman of New York City, said in an address prepared for delivery before the American Bar Association tonight.
MOSCOW, July 15. -- Another drive against the relatively few remaining traders -- this time against traders in living quarters -- was forecast today in complaints of profiteering by petty landlords.

HARRISON, N.J., July 15. -- Mrs. Ruth Kohler Glynn, 28 years old, was shot and killed in her home here today by her 26-year- old husband, Thomas Glynn, following several arguments over the recent loss of his job.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 15. -- Recently named members of the New Jersey Interstate Sanitation Commission, which will represent this State in the Tri-State Anti-Pollution Commission for the regulation of pollution in the waters of New York harbor, organized here at the "Little White House" this afternoon after being sworn into office.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters acted yesterday to force employes of all trucking concerns serving the New York port district to join unions as a means of insuring the movement of freight to and from waterfront piers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15. -- Many reservations have been reserved for the first dinner and supper dance in a series of parties on Saturday night at the clubhouse of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and in which prominent members of the Summer colony are interested.
CINCINNATI, July 15. -- A Giant pitching star went into eclipse at Crosley Field this afternoon, long before the moon went into its lunar fade-out.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP). -- Frank Frisch's climbing Cardinals won their eleventh consecutive game today, defeating the Braves, 13 to 6, in the first of a four-game series and crept to within five games of the league-leading Giants.

Cloudy skies and a humid atmosphere intensified a day of heat in which the mercury rose to a high of 80 yesterday, holding temperatures above normal for the eleventh consecutive day. Some hope of relief was seen in a forecast of moderate temperatures and fair skies for today.

A threat yesterday to replace 215 striking caddies at the Dyker Beach Park municipal golf course in Brooklyn with strikebreakers unless they returned to the links at 6 A.M. today left them unmoved. The caddies contended that every youngster in the Bath Beach and Bensonhurst sections, surrounding the course, who is capable of caddying was already enrolled in their ranks.

The third bill of the Fokine Ballet at the Stadium opened its scheduled pair of performances last night, with "Cleopatra" as its chief novelty, "Russian Toys" as a lesser novelty and "Les Sylphides" as its only old familiar item.
Esar Levine, a publisher, was held in $500 bail yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey on an indictment charging that he had sent obscene circulars through the mails to advertise his books.

DETROIT, July 15. -- Net profits of about $1,400,000 will be shown by the Packard Motor Car Company for the three months ended on June 30, it was announced today by Alvan Macauley, president Exact figures will not be available for several days.
BERLIN, July 15. -- Terror spread along Berlin's fashionable Kurfuerstendamm tonight as Jews, with blood pouring down their faces, fled along the street.

COLUMBUS, Miss., July 15 (AP). -- Bert Moore and Dooley Morton, Negro farmers, about 26 years old, were lynched today eight miles south of Columbus. A mob of white citizens took the prisoners from Deputy Sheriff Parker Harris of Lowndes County and hanged them to an oak tree.

PARIS, July 15. -- Making good his promise when he accepted office and asked Parliament for power to proceed by decree to save the franc, Premier Pierre Laval, with his Finance Minister, Marcel Regnier, will submit tomorrow to the Cabinet and for the signature of President Albert Lebrun twenty-three decrees which are expected to balance the budget.

For years the fabulous entrance of Ko-Ko Moulan brought New York her first hint of Spring. "The Mikado" could always be counted upon in late April or early May, either under the banner of the late Milton Aborn or that of his successors.

Supreme Court Justice Cotillo said yesterday he would confirm the findings of Referee Ralph O.F. Fay in favor of Clendenin Ryan Jr. to annul Mr. Ryan's marriage to the 19-year-old Countess Marie Ann von Wurmbrand-Stuppach on the ground of misrepresentations.
Rewards of $10 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons abandoning cats or kittens were announced yesterday by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

" Invincible Louisa: The Story of the Author of 'Little Women'" by Cornelia Meigs, which last year won the Newbery Prize Medal for the most distinguished book for children, has just been published in England under the title "The Story of Louisa M. Alcott." English reviewers point out that "Little Women," written by an author born 103 years ago, is a continuous best seller in England.

Advertising is in grave danger of losing its important place in the field of business as a result of unfair attacks and impending legislation against it, George J. Auer, advertising manager of The New York Herald Tribune, told members of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion yesterday at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- Melvin H. Purvis settled some speculation as to his future activities today by announcing that he planned to write a series of magazine articles on his eight years in the war on criminals. Concerning his purpose he said:

Several writers of letters to THE TIMES seem to think government ownership of the gas and electric business is all of a piece with government ownership of all business. I beg to disagree. There is a great difference in principle between those who wish the government to run a few exceptional businesses for exceptional reasons and those who seek general socialism.

Interest in the municipal bond filed today will centre in the sale at noon of $38,000,000 of New York City corporate stock and serial bonds. Two all-or-none bids for the securities are expected to be made, one by a group headed by the Chase National Bank and the other by a syndicate headed by the National City Bank.

The Hungarian Government has announced plans for the transfer in foreign exchange of 50 per cent of the interest service due from Aug. 2, 1935 to Aug. 1, 1936, on the State loan of the Kingdom of Hungary of 1924, according to a communication from the League Loans Committee in London received here by Speyer Co., as United States fiscal agents for the loan.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 15. -- An interview with Spruille Braden, United States delegate to the recent Pan-American commercial conference at Buenos Aires, occupies today a full page in the local press and receives favorable editorial comment because of his frank discussion of many South American problems, particularly foreign policy.

The application by Joseph P. Moran, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, to direct the Board of Estimate to restore his salary to the level of Dec. 17, 1932, when the pay cut became effective, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Dore.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The controversy between Chairman Kennedy of the Securities and Exchange Commission and Representative Pettengill, Democrat, of Indiana, over the merits of the House bill to regulate utility holding companies blazed anew today when the Representative, having received detailed objections from Mr. Kennedy, invited him to be "constructive in his criticism," and to "put up or shut up."
LYON, France, July 15. -- Perspiring Lyon continues to celebrate today the most republican July 14 France has seen since the war.
Business in the money market continued small, while quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Advancing prices for fresh pork stimulated today buying of hogs and while the local market for the latter was steady to 10 cents a hundred pounds lower early, the loss was recovered later, with the finish in line with the close on Friday.

Following a meeting of broad silk weavers, throwsters, raw silk dealers and hosiery manufacturers at the offices of the National Federation of Textiles, Peter Van Horn, president of the group, left for Washington yesterday afternoon to carry to Congress the industry's emphatic protests against a compensating tax on rayon and silk.

The first effort of the 1935 season was a winning one at Empire City yesterday for the Sickle colt, Cycle, which carries the colors of the Howe Stable. Tossed into the second division of the Briarwood Handicap, a sprint which had the place of honor on the card, the 4-year-old had the fleetness to outrun such a keen racer as Polycletus.

TEANECK, N.J., July 15. -- A 22-year-old youth, Albert Koury of 258 Wadsworth Avenue, New York City, was shot and killed instantly here early this morning by a Bergen County policeman after a nine-mile automobile chase from Ridgewood, N.J.

ROME, July 15. -- The inevitability of war with Ethiopia was viewed here today as emphasized by Emperor Haile Sellassie's statement that Ethiopia would not accept an Italian zone of influence or construction of a railroad through Ethiopia.

TRENTON, N.J., July 15. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz replied today to criticism of the conduct of the Hauptmann trial, declaring it was "unfair, unwarranted and without basis in truth or fact." The criticism was contained in a report to the American Bar Association by its committee on cooperation between bar and press.

The two 16-inch guns at Fort Tilden, near Jacob Riis Park, Rockaway Beach, Queens, will be fired next week for the first time in twelve years, according to tentative army plans, it was learned yesterday.

Sheriff Daniel E. Finn resigned last night as Tammany leader of the First Assembly District, west, and immediately his son, Daniel E. Jr., was elected to fill out his term. Thus the rule of the Finns, which began more than half a century ago with the noted "Battery Dan," continued in Greenwich Village.

After a conference at City Hall yesterday with Mayor Daniel Hoan of Milwaukee, Mayor La Guardia said he would seek to correct the manner in which work-relief funds are given to cities. He will visit Federal officials in Washington today.

Under the sign of the horseshoe, Which has now nearly entered into the oblivion of the cigar store Indian, John Riley, one of the last of the old order of blacksmith philosophers, plies his ancient trade in his small smithy in West Thirteenth Street.

With Eddie Driggs Jr. of Garden City defending for the second straight year, a field of 100 will start in quest of the New York State amateur golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club tomorrow. Play in the thirteenth annual tournament will continue until Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Despite the fact that a large amount of July wheat which had been sold by cash handlers as a hedge against cash grain was changed over to the September delivery last week the near-by delivery at Kansas City continues to show congestion and at one time today advanced 5 cents a bushel above the close on Saturday, the limit permitted under Exchange regulations.

The Coast Guard headquarters here was informed last night that the captain and crew of the Raritan Sun, oil tanker aground near Montauk, L.I., had been rescued at 8 P.M. by a breeches buoy rigged by men of the Ditch Plains Coast Guard station, under the direction of Commander E.T. Osborne.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- President Roosevelt was understood today virtually to have decided to return the administration of the Virgin Islands to the Navy Department, from which it was transferred to the Department of the Interior during the Hoover administration.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Lyn Lary, the shortstop Washington traded to St. Louis a few weeks ago, came through with a double in the eleventh inning today that drove in the deciding run in a 3-2 victory of the Browns over the Senators.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Sharp improvement in the earnings of the Cudahy Packing Company in the first four months of the current fiscal year was disclosed today in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its proposed refunding program.

Although new life insurance production last month fell 8.5 per cent below the total for June, 1934, the volume for the first half of this year was six-tenths of 1 per cent greater than the amount for the corresponding period of last year, it was announced yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- A new admission by Mrs. Blanche Dunkel, that she was present when her son-in-law, Ervin Lang, was strangled, was announced tonight by Police Lieutenant Tom Kelly.

Jerome Wolf, 33 years old, who said he lived at 479 Audubon Avenue, arrested on complaint of Milton Gotlieb of 65 Clifton Avenue, the Bronx, who said he had paid $500 to Wolf after the latter promised him an investigator's job in the Income Tax Division at Washington, took the stand yesterday at his trial in General Sessions.
THERE were a couple of stout fellows watching the Yankees and White Sox indulge in that bargain bill in the Bronx on Sunday. Reading across, they were Freddy Fitzsimmons and G. Herman Ruth.

With the beginning of the new fiscal year the Roosevelt Administration has changed its system of bookkeeping. Hitherto its expenditures have been listed under two main divisions: "general" and "emergency," the latter including all outlays not of a routine character.

BOSTON, July 15. -- Confessing that he hurled his blind sweetheart to her death from the third floor of a South End hotel as "an act of mercy" to save her from want, Forest R. Wells, 30-year-old itinerant blind musician, was held in jail tonight awaiting grand jury action on a charge of first-degree murder.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- A list of applications for registrations on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission contained the names of these firms from New York City and the immediate vicinity:

YONKERS, N.Y., July 15 (AP). -- A woman and a guide were drowned today, according to a telephone message received here, in a futile attempt to save a 7-year-old boy who fell from a rowboat at Ultowanna Lake, near Old Forge, N.Y., close to the Summer home of Dr. Leo H. Baekeland, the inventor, a resident of this city.

Two teams finished in a tie for first place in the amateur-professional best ball tournament, which served as a preliminary to the Long Island open golf championship test yesterday over the tricky Fresh Meadow Country Club course in Flushing, but it was Herman Rama, youthful assistant pro of the home club, who loomed as a threat to the contenders for the Long Island crown.

The "clan" of which Lord BADEN-POWELL is the chief carries the word into the wider horizon which it had in its original Gaelic significance. It embraces not only those of a common ancestor and associated together, but youth and men of different countries and ancestral traditions.

LOS ANGELES, July 15. -- Protection of States' autonomy and preservation of individuals' constitutional rights were urged at the opening of preliminary conferences today in advance of the annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 15. -- A dance for Summer colony juniors will be given at the Maidstone Club on Wednesday evening. Mrs. Clifford H. McCall, Mrs. S. Kip Farrington and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop Jr. are in charge. Similar entertainments for sub-debutantes and their brothers will be given weekly by the committee.

LELAND OLDS has an article in the Summer Yale Review on "The Public Utility Issue." He speaks from the viewpoint of the New York State Power Authority, headed by FRANK P. WALSH, of which he is executive secretary. The reader may be pardoned if he nods now and then over the article, as a man might in whose nostrils rested the heavy scent of old straw much threshed.

NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP). -- Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley scored a point in his fight with Senator Long over the control of New Orleans today, as his revolting ward leaders changed their minds and abandoned plans to oust the Mayor from office.

Eleven players, headed by Melvin Lapman of the Bronx, first seeded entry, reached the fourth round as play started yesterday in the Eastern junior tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP). -- The top-weighted Maeriel, winner of the Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park, made an auspicious start in New England racing today by capturing the $2,500-added Mayflower Stakes for 2-year-olds over the six-furlong route at Suffolk Downs.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., Tuesday, July 16. -- A woman was washed off the jetty at Silver Point Beach, near here, about 8:30 o'clock last night and lost in the heavy seas, while her husband clung to the rocks under the pounding waves for more than four hours until Coast Guards, who had been unable to reach him, managed to rescue him.

Prices on Fall curtains, drapes and curtain hardware showed no change from Spring levels at the New York Curtain and Drapery Show which opened in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. The 300 buyers who registered on the opening day commented chiefly on the stability of prices and the variety of novelty products offered by the seventy producers taking part in the exhibit.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 15. -- New York State's Republican leaders will gather here tomorrow to outline major issues for the campaign to regain control of the State Assembly in the Fall election.

A plan providing for bonuses to officers and some employes of the First Boston Corporation in profitable years without committing the company to such increased expenses in lean years has been presented to the stockholders for a vote at a special meeting on Aug. 13.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 15. -- Having declared that the Mortimer L. Schiff Boy Scout reservation near here "knocks the spots off all other Scout training centres in the world," Lord and Lady Baden-Powell motored back to New York today after an overnight visit to the 480-acre reservation which was dedicated about three years ago.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 (AP). -- The career of Julia Graham, Sisterville, W. Va., choir singer who "crashed" the movies by twice attempting suicide, has been ended by death.
CINCINNATI, July 15. -- The government has no power to condemn land for low-cost housing projects, the Sixth District United States Court of Appeals ruled here today in a two-to-one decision.

Continued strength in second-grade railroad liens were a feature yesterday of an otherwise dull and listless trading session on the Stock Exchange. The turnover was the smallest for any full five-hour trading period since June 3. Total transactions were $7,931,400, compared with $10,107,200 on last Friday.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 15. -- The first American performance of H.R. Lenormand's "The Coward" brought a host of celebrities and a theatrically important evening to the Westport Country Playhouse last night. The evening turned out to be memorable for presenting one of the most ambitious productions ever to grace the stage of a Summer theatre. "

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Queen bees zoomed swiftly out of the amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration Bill in the Senate today after Senator Glass had objected to forcing birth control upon them. He refused to "deprive them of the more abundant life that Professor Tugwell has contrived for human beings."

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 15. -- The New Jersey sales tax continued today to be the paramount interest of Governor Hoffman, who this afternoon "accepted" the often denied "challenge" of the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, Speaker of the Assembly, to a debate on the tax.

" Bastile Day" had been looked forward to as a signal for rioting and terror and possible revolution. But in Paris, where it was said that a great many tourists had feared to go on the Fourteenth of July, it passed as quietly as a Summer breeze. In some of the interior cities there were clashes between paraders and police.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 15. -- Application for approval of a merger of the Essex County Trust Company of East Orange and the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark has been filed with the Federal Reserve Bank, it was announced here today by officials of the East Orange institution.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 15. -- Major Gen. George E. Leach of Washington, Chief of the Militia Bureau of the War Department, made a parachute jump from an army plane somewhere near Holbrook, Ariz., late today and has not been heard from since, March Field army flying base here was informed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Army, navy or marine officers would have to obtain approval of their Cabinet officer before making any public statements affecting foreign relations under a bill introduced today by Senators Clark and Nye of the Senate Munitions Committee.

The late Mrs. Ida E. Wood, widow of Benjamin Wood, former Representative and publisher, was the sole legatee in the estate of her sister, Mary E. Mayfield, who died March 5, 1931, the appraisal showed yesterday. Mrs. Wood, who died March 12, 1932, left an estate of nearly $1,000,000, much of which was in hoarded funds.

Price movements in the share market yesterday were inconclusive. Steadiness was generally maintained until toward the closing when the selling increased a little and stocks ruled irregular at the last. Steel issues were favored throughout, and to a lesser extent many of the railway equipments.

Representatives of conflicting views on monetary policies will be brought together on Thursday and Friday at Ithaca, N.Y., when Cornell University joins with the American Institute of Cooperation as sponsors of a series of conferences on governmental policies with respect to money.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Whatever his reasons, and despite the supporting background from March, 1933, to July, 1934, the President dislikes to be represented as the "dictator" or master of Congress. He deplores the use of the expression, "the must legislative program."

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- The Cubs scored their eight straight victory today but they were carried to ten innings by the Phillies before Bill Herman's double with two out sent Augie Galan home with the run that gave them a 2-1 decision.

A new independent common stockholders' protective committee has been formed by McCrory Stores Corporation shareholders to support the plan of reorganization for the company sponsored by the preferred stockholders' protective committee. The new committee consists of J.L. Merrill of E.A. Pierce Co., chairman; William Ferguson of Kidder, Peabody . Co., and Otis A. Glazebrook Jr. of G.M.P. Murphy Co.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Acting on statements by members of the so-called Brooklyn "rifle gang" of bandits as to disposition of their loot, the police yesterday took into custody seven storekeepers for interrogation. They were later booked as receivers of stolen goods.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- An estimate that 1,127,000 persons will be put to work soon with the $1,499,992,805 allotted by President Roosevelt for work relief projects up to July 9, was made today by the Works Progress Administration.
LONDON, July 15. -- David Lloyd George sang today what was undoubtedly the swan song of his much heralded plan for "organizing British prosperity," but not of his own political career.

ALBANY, July 15 (AP). -- Employment in New York State's construction industry advanced 1.1 per cent last month with a similar increase fn payrolls, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15. -- A charge that "Wall Street and management" were conspiring to get Congress out of Washington was made today by Francis J. Gorman, vice president of the United Textile Workers of America, at the opening of the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- Penncote, racing for L.E. Komouris of Chicago and ridden by Jockey F. Ritz, galloped to a surprise victory today at Arlington Park. In previous races Penncote had been stopping but this time the 4-year-old daughter of Pennant and Cherrycote led the field from start to finish in the mile race.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 15. -- The Ramblers reached the semi-final round and Roslyn completed the first round with a 6-to-4 victory, over Aknusti today in the national junior polo championship at the Burnt Mills Club. The Ramblers edged out the Army in the closest sort of a fight, 7 to 6, while Roslyn showed enough strength to finish in front at the close.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 15. -- Fay Bainter tried her hand tonight at a new play by a new playwright, much to the approval of her first-night audience.

A gas explosion caused by a woman preparing to end her life on the seventh floor of the sixteen-story apartment house at 2 Horatio Street shook Greenwich Village at 3:05 P.M. yesterday and rained plaster dust, shattered furniture and broken glass into the streets.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15. -- James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President appealed to the Port Washington Democratic Club here tonight to "make a real effort to change the psychology of our fellow-countrymen and convince them that they should vote the Democratic ticket in 1936."

Apparently Broadway is not interested in vicarious horror with the thermometer at 90 degrees in the shade. The three Grand Guignol plays which began an engagement last Wednesday evening at the Chanin Auditorium under the direction of George K. Arthur will call it a full week tomorrow evening -- and the end of a courageous venture.

WASHINGTON, July 15 . -- Non-Federal work relief projects for New York City totalling $13,975,756 were approved today by President Roosevelt. He also approved projects for Georgia, Indiana and Alabama, the total being $48,265,258.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A new Federal Alcohol Administration Bill setting up permanent government control of the liquor traffic within limits laid down by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case, but breaking with the administration on two major points, was ordered to the House today by this Ways and Means Committee and placed in position to be acted on before the end of the week.
Anthony Sclafani, 62 years old, lost his second clash yesterday with the Park Department over the matter of diet for the Central Park Zoo animals.

Mayor La Guardia is expected to call the Board of Estimate into special session today or tomorrow and ask its members by unanimous consent to provide Thomas E. Dewey with about $115,000 with which to open his war on organized crime in Manhattan.

An appeal for a proposed salt water fish sanctuary was forwarded yesterday to the Bureau of Fisheries and the United States War Department in behalf of the Sheepshead Bay Boat Owners Association, by Anthony Klaer, president of the organization.

Max Strahl, 32 years old, of 327 Central Park West, a stock salesman, who is alleged to have defrauded clients, including a friend of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, of more than $250,000, was arrested yesterday in the offices of Attorney General Bennett, 80 Centre Street.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 16. -- Many members of the Bretton Woods colony gave late parties in the Dutch Room of the Mount Washington Hotel last evening while a waiting the moon's eclipse, which most colonists went out to watch.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 16. -- Showing the golf that once made her a perennial winner of the tournament, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare swept through her first-round match today in the seventeenth annual Shenecossett women's invitation tournament for the Griswold Cup. Mrs. Vare played only ten holes to defeat Mrs. Charles J. Downey of Springfield, Mass., 9 and 8, and advance into the quarterfinals.

WASHINGTON, July 16. --In a session lasting nearly six hours today, the House accomplished exactly nothing. During three hours and twenty minutes of that time the members sat listening to their names being called as Republicans forced five separate roll-calls.
BERLIN, July 16 (AP). -- Varian Fry, editor of The Living Age, issued today the following statement in connection with last night's anti-Jewish rioting:

Label sales of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board since Monday, when distribution began, totaled 120,000, it was announced yesterday by F. Nathan Wolf, secretary of the board. Under the board's regulations, all members, which comprise more than 90 per cent of the firms in the industry, are required to use the labels, which are known as the "Consumers" Protective Label."

The $16,181.41 that Polly Adler is alleged to owe the United States Government for failing to pay income taxes from 1927 through 1930 prevented her yesterday from retrieving $1,250 the police seized when they arrested her on July 11.

IT was at the Empire City race track. Six men seated around a table in the clubhouse dining room. Five listening. One spinning tales of the turf. The lone talker to the willing listeners was a sturdy, genial, white-haired and ruddy-faced gentleman who is "rising 74" and still going strong. It was Colonel Matt Winn, the Caliph of Churchill Downs and Grand Mogul of other racing acres such as Latonia and Lincoln Fields.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman, president of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., at 551 Fifth Avenue, was questioned yesterday behind closed doors in District Attorney Dodge's office in an inquiry to determine whether it is legal for the organization to offer sixty-eight prizes of from $10,000 to $40 for a slogan for its campaign.

Seeondary railroad liens and a few selected industrial issues led yesterday the domestic corporate bond section to moderately higher levels on the New York Stock Exchange. Sales expanded slightly, amounting to $10,230,400, compared with $7,931,400 the day before.
CINCINNATI, July 16. -- The victory spurt of the Reds has now attained sizable proportions. They took the league-leading Giants into camp today at Crosley Field for the second successive time.

You did well in Sunday's editorial by calling attention to certain beneficial -- one might almost say humanitarian -- values in the large surpluses of some of the great corporations. In them has resided, during the depression, a huge fund not for unemployment insurance but for employment assurance.

Jockey Kempton Knott, the young apprentice who was unknown in the metropolitan area before the current racing at Empire City, scored the first triple of the meeting yesterday when he was first with Exeter, Gentle Tryst and Drusus. In addition, he landed second with Mad Beth and was fifth aboard Playfole.
Gum opium, reported to have a value of between $150,000 and $200,000 to sellers after cutting, was seized at 4 P.M. yesterday at the French Line pier at West Fifteenth Street.

VIENNA, July 16. -Mrs. Herma Schuschnigg, victim of the automobile tragedy Saturday in which her husband, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, barely escaped death, was buried this afternoon in the hillside cemetery in Hietzing, a suburb of Vienna, ball a mile from the Hietzing church, where her body had lain since it was brought back to Vienna Sunday.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 16. -- "It is probable that the volume of building construction will rise from about 1936 to 1942 and that the value of gold will fall. If these two events should occur, business will be very active and real estate will be a prize possession -- not a drug on the market, as is now the case."

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A petition for an inquiry by the United States into the religious status of American citizens resident in Mexico was presented to President Roosevelt today by a delegation representing 242 members of the House of Representatives.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP). -- The New England traditions of scholarship and thoroughness are apparent in each of the judges of the United States Circuit Court which today handed down a majority decision here finding the processing and floor taxes of the AAA unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- President Roosevelt received a petition, signed by 242 House members, asking him to institute an inquiry into the religious status of American citizens in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Preliminary conversations have been held between this government and Germany that hold some promise of negotiation of a reciprocal trade pact, the State Department made known today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 16. -- The bodies of Mrs. Sylvia E. Clifton, 27 years old, and her 7-year-old daughter, Gay, were found side by side here today in the gas-filled bedroom of their home at 322 East Fulton Street. The police found the gas turned on both in the oven and in a hot-water heater in the adjoining kitchen.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Relief projects totaling $58,685,809, to provide work for about 52,000 persons, were approved today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments. The President must now-pass upon them.

The volume of commercial ton-age under construction in the yards of the world rose to 1,282,531 tons during the last three months, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday. This represents a gain of 12,997 tons for the quarter.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- In an effort to adapt the requirements for domestic issuers to peculiar circumstances of private foreign issues, the SEC today promulgated three new forms to be used for permanent registration on national securities exchanges.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

COLUMBUS, July 16. -- Judge James T. Hallinan of the New York Supreme Court and a member of Queens Borough (N.Y.) Lodge, was unanimously elected Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks at the opening of the Grand Lodge meeting here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP). -- The Athletics jolted the Detroit Tigers further back into second place in the American League standing today by bombarding Alvin Crowder and Elon Hogsett for an 8-to-2 victory.

The Southern Pacific Company is negotiating with a group of New York banks for a loan of about $30,000,000 to pay off its loan of about $22,000,000 to the RFC and to improve its working capital position, it is reported in banking circles.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 16. -- The council of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange called a meeting for this afternoon in the hope that its members would be in a position to announce that the pegged price of wheat was about to be removed, but when the members gathered the chairman said the government had taken no step yet to effect that advantageous position.

Yesterday's decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals at Boston makes it certain that the whole question of the constitutionality of processing taxes imposed by AAA will be brought before the Supreme Court when it reconvenes. These taxes have been the backbone of the Administration's farm program.

The problem was whether the Board of Education had done right by the children of New York in denying a teacher's license to Miss Rose Freistater because she weighs too much. Miss Freistater, 26 years old, is 5 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 180 pounds.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16. -- Billy Nicholls, former Pennsylvania Military College player, scored all his team's goals in leading the Reds to victory in the members' polo round-robin on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 16 (AP). -- John Cobb, London fur broker, and his British racing crew, T.E. Rose-Richards and C.J.P. Dodson, bettered seventy-four automobile speed records in a twenty-four-hour test over the salt flats ending today.

These are not good days for Nazi Germany. From the Vatican the German Government gets a diplomatic note accusing it of violating the agreement which it had made with the Holy See, and treating German Catholics in ways that are not merely anti-religious but cruel and scandalous. At the same time the Nazis themselves were displaying to the world a new outburst of anti-Semitic fury in its most bestial and disgusting form.
MEXICO, D.F., July 16. -- A statement by the Ministry of War this evening said all was quiet in the State of Tabasco.

Alexander Papanastasiou, who served as first Premier of the Greek Republic from 1922 to 1926, and now is the leader of the Opposition party, arrived last night on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic on his first visit to the United States.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Germany's imports and exports balanced in June for the first time on record. Whereas May showed the small export surplus of 4,000,000 marks, a larger decline in June in exports than in imports brought an exact equilibrium.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 16. -- Major Gen. George E. Leach, the War Department's newest member of the Caterpillar Club, flew into March Field today and was more interested in a shave than treatment for an arm injured when he parachuted from a blazing airplane in Arizona yesterday.

New York City held its most successful bond sale in more than thirty years yesterday, selling a $38,000,000 issue of long-term serial bonds and corporate stock to a syndicate headed by the National City Bank at an interest cost basis of 3.47 per cent.

The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston awarded yesterday an issue of $53,000,000 first mortgage bonds to a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation at a bid of 101.913 for 3 1/2 per cent coupons. Proceeds from the sale of the bonds, which will mature in 1965, will be used to redeem $55,000,000 in notes due in 1937.

I believe the remarks made by Professor Willard S. Elsbree of Teachers College, Columbia University, in an address before Columbia Summer session students and quoted in your paper yesterday need some comment and analysis.

The American public spent $2,243,-$35,000 for general merchandise in department stores, mail order, general and variety stores during the first six months of this year as compared with $2,138,209,000 during the corresponding period of 1934, according to figures issued yesterday by A.W. Zelomek, director and economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Payment of the British debt to the United States through transfer to us of the Bahamas, Jamaica, the Bermudas and other islands as well as abandonment of all British claims to construction of a Nicaraguan canal was proposed to the Senate today by Senator Lewis of Illinois.

Italy will experience no difficulty in raising funds in the European money market to finance a conflict in Ethiopia, Commander Luigi Criscuolo, investment banker, told NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. Coincident with a further break in Italian dollar bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. Criscuolo, who has been identified with Italo-American finances for twenty years, denied emphatically that the Banca d'Italia has been selling dollar bonds in the New York market.

Policemen in radio patrol cars in New York City will be able to carry on two-way conversations with headquarters if present tests of a new ultra-short-wave system are successful, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.

Failures in the retail and wholesale divisions increased in the week ended July 11, as compared with the five days ended July 4, while the manufacturing branch showed a decline, according to the report issued by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed summary is as follows:

BORDENTOWN, N.J., July 15. -- Despite a warning that a jail break would be attempted, a 61-year-old one-armed felon escaped today from the State prison farm here while extra guards and three State troopers were on duty.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 16. -- Frances Start appeared tonight in the new play, "Stardust," by Robert and Sally Wilder, which runs for the rest of the week at the New Rochelle Playhouse in the clubhouse of the New Rochelle Woman's Club.

NEW ORLEANS, July 16 (AP).--Senator Huey P. Long has apparently decided upon a recall election to remove Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley from office. After one plan to oust the Mayor had failed and another had been discarded, the Senator announced his newest threat against the Mayor in a printed circular laid on the door steps of thousands of New Orleans homes today.

Joe McCarthy, manager of the New York Yankees will remain as leader of the team at least until the completion of the 1937 campaign, it was announced by Colonel Jacob Ruppert, club owner, shortly before game time yesterday at the Stadium. McCarthy's present contract with the club, for three years, was to have expired at the end of the current race.

With more than 200 executives of large business enterprises present, the American Management Association held a private meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria to discuss the Wagner Trade Disputes Act recently signed by President Roosevelt.

TIVOLI, Italy, July 16 (AP). --An autopsy was performed today on the bodies of Mrs. May Katherine Thompson, 40 years old, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and H.N. Scott, found dead Sunday in a cabin in the fashionable sulphur bath at Acque Albule.

BERLIN, July 16. -- The Bourse was firm today, although virtually inactive. Some realization selling appeared at the close. Heavy industrials were quiet. Potashes were slightly stronger, Salzdetfurth gaining 2 points. Machines were slightly stronger, Schwarzkopf gaining 2 points.

Seven separate sales of Insull collateral held by New York banks to guarantee loans made to Insull Utility Investments and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, are scheduled for today, with the probability that all but three recently advertised offerings of collateral will be adjourned until early next week.

The police began a search in Harlem yesterday for a young Negro purse-snatcher, charged with stealing a handbag containing more than $4,000 in jewelry from an automobile near 132d Street and Park Avenue.

The decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals holding the processing tax unconstitutional, while not unexpected in cotton textile centres yesterday, effectively choked the buying movement which started last week in the primary market and broadened Monday and yesterday morning.

All commodity futures except coffee and cocoa were lower in price in yesterday's active market. The weakness was attributed as a rule to the court decision holding the AAA processing taxes unconstitutional. On the cash markets corn, flour, cocoa and tin advanced, while cotton, dairy products and rubber eased.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- Knocking young Roy Henshaw out of the Box with a four-run blast in the second inning, the Phillies defeated the Cubs, 7 to 5, today to end their five-game losing streak and at the same time snap the Chicagoan's ring of eight straight victories.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 16 (AP). -- Plans for the construction of the Merritt Parkway, now being perfected by State Highway Commissioner John A. MacDonald, are expected to call for the expenditure of a sum much larger than the $15,000,000 estimate originally made, it was disclosed today.

KANSAS CITY, July 16 (AP). -- Inheritance and estate tax statutes of the forty-eight States disclose that opinions of lawmakers differ chiefly in fixing the amount government may take from the wealth men accumulate.

BOSTON, July 16. -- The processing tax levied by the Secretary of Agriculture under the Agricultural Adjustment Act is unconstitutional and constitutes an improper delegation of power, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled here today in the case of the Hoosac Mills Corporation against the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- President Roosevelt's Social Security Bill, a major measure in his general program of social and economic reform, was moved a step toward final completion today when Senate and House conferees reached agreements on all but one of the amendments in disagreement between the two bodies.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16 (AP). -- A dime-store clerk who returned a lost purse to the son of China's President will soon become his bride.

LOS ANGELES, July 16. -- The statement that an independent judiciary and the "sanctity" of the Supreme Court are essential to the liberty of the people and the "very existence of the country" was made today by President Scott M. Loftin of Jacksonville, Fla., in opening the first general session of the American Bar Association's convention.
BOSTON, July 16. -- Here are some of the highlights of the decision rendered today by the Federal Circuit Court on AAA processing taxes:

The story of two former honor students at Yale University, one of whom studied higher economics under Professor Irving Fisher and persuaded the latter to invest some of his savings in a financial venture, which has come under the scrutiny of the United States Attorney's office, was related yesterday in Federal court.

TAIHOKU, Formosa, Wednesday, July 17 (AP). -- The Japanese Empire's third death-dealing earthquake in three months and the second of the week heaved along the west coast of Formosa shortly after midnight today. It repeated on a smaller scale the havoc wrought April 21, when nearly 3,000 persons were killed in the same area.
PHILADELPHIA, July 16. -- Formation by labor of its own political party was urged by speakers before the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers today.

NOROTON, Conn., July 16. -- Miss Betty Pietsch of Lawrence Farms was nine strokes ahead of her nearest competitor after scoring a sterling 82 on the second day of the Fairfield and Westchester open medal play golf championship at the Wee Burn Country Club today.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Governor Lehman today asked for Federal aid to prevent floods like those that damaged Central and Southern New York last week. He telegraphed to Frank H. Walker, chairman of the National Emergency Council, to ask him to assign army engineers to make a survey.

Officials of the Dyker Beach Park municipal golf course in Brooklyn failed yesterday to carry out a threat to replace 215 striking caddies with strikebreakers unless the caddies returned at 6 A.M. Whether this was due to their inability to obtain other caddies -the strikers contend that all available caddies in the neighborhood are enrolled in their ranks -- or was due to a sit-and-wait policy, could not be learned.
George Palmer Putnam has written a novel of the bootleg petroleum industry in collaboration with Nell Shipman. Under the title "Hot Oil," the book will be published by Greenberg early next month.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- Mrs. Henry Austin Clark gave a luncheon today at Four Acres for Mrs. William Crawford, who is passing the season at the Meadow Club. The other guests included Mrs. Tillman Martin, Mrs. Ancell H. Ball, Mrs. Walter N. Stillman, Mrs. George Bird Grinnell, Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn and Mrs. Grosvenor Atterbury.

Among the passengers who arrived last night from England and France on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic were Jane Cowl, American actress; Cicely Courtneidge, British actress, and John Van Druten, English actor and playwright.

Dr. Aaron N. McMillan, surgeon and missionary in Angola, West Africa, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France with Mrs. McMillan to spend a twelve-month leave continuing his medical studies, Dr. McMillan, who is a Negro, studied in medical schools in Portugal prior to going to Africa in 1931, where he and his wife remained in the mission maintained at Galangue by the Congregational Church.

The police administration of Commissioner Valentine in relation to civil liberties was praised and the attitude of Board of Education officials toward academic freedom was condemned in a report issued yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Committee.

NEWARK, July 16. -- Federal Judge Guy Le Fake began hearings today in suits brought by five concerns to restrain the Collector of Internal Revenue from collecting processing taxes under the AAA, totaling $817,848, on the ground that the processing tax is unconstitutional.

Narrow price movements again characterized trading yesterday in the share market. The Circuit Court's ruling that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's processing tax is unconstitutional was of interest to followers of stocks, but scarcely found any reflection in the action of the market yesterday; it was in commodities, notably in cotton, that the decision operated as a factor.

PARIS, Wednesday, July 17. -President Albert Lebrun at 1:30 this morning signed twenty-three decrees initiating measures by which the Laval Cabinet estimates that it will find almost 11,000,000,000 francs [the franc closed yesterday at 6.63 3/8 cents] to cover the budgetary deficit.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Beinecke gave a farewell dinner last night at the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Herman Cron, who are sailing today on the Manhattan to go to their hunting lodge in the Black Forest of Germany, where they will be joined by the host and hostess in September.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- Rallying in the late innings, the Browns won their second straight game from Washington today by a score of 6 -- 4 to square their current series.
The Economic Intelligence Service of the League of Nations has published a study on recent developments in banking, under the title "Commercial Banks, 1929-1934."

The Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, the Paulist Fathers, 415 West Fifty-ninth Street, is principal beneficiary in the will of Miss Margaret J. Brown, daughter of Thomas and Julia Brown, who died on May 26, it was revealed yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

The fine old custom of running away from home and being picked up by kind-hearted policemen with a ready supply of candy and ice cream seems to be deteriorating. Danny Keyes, who is 7 years old, tried it, and all he got yesterday was a glass of water.
After a day and evening of processions in which more than 20,000 persons were estimated to have taken part, the annual festival of Our Lady of Mount Carmel ended last night on the upper East Side.

Donald O. Newman, 22 years old, son of Raymond Newman, executive vice president of the Corporation Trust Company, shot and fatally wounded himself yesterday on the roof of the Commercial Trust Company Building, at 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City.

FORTE DEI MARMI, Italy, July 16 (AP). -- Mme. Sigrid Onegin, Swedish opera singer, has filed suit against the German tenor, Kuppinger, for injuries she suffered when the tenor grew overly dramatic in the role of Don Jose in "Carmen" last April, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A Federal charter was approved today for the Railroad Cooperative Building and Loan Association of New York City, third largest building and loan association in the country, the Home Loan Bank Board announced.

A further allotment of $142,500 was made yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration for care of those left homeless by last week's up-State floods and for emergency repairs to public property. The $142,500 makes about $375,000 allotted as a direct grant from State and Federal funds.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 16 (AP). -- Although enjoined by a Supreme Court order from employing any but union labor, the Hirsam Knit Sportswear Company rehired its 142 unaffiliated employes and was running full blast today after a two-week shutdown.

PORTSMOUTH, England, July 16. -- Gorge V. who was a sailor before he was a King, reviewed his fleet today while thousands of his loyal subjects congregated in a second great array of surrounding merchant vessels and hundreds of thousands more crowding the green shores of Spithead watched the spectacle.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The "Toledo plan" to adjudicate labor disputes, now being considered by employers and labor at the request of the Department of Labor, is "unworkable and impracticable," according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- Backed by the army high command, the House Military Committee today set out to obtain $40,000,000 to expand the combat strength of the army air corps.

In recent months bankers, individually and through their organizations, have been giving most of the attention they could spare from their official duties to questions of Federal and State legislation. With the passage of the Banking Act of 1935, which is not confidently looked for at this session of Congress, it is expected that banking organizations will turn to problems closer to home.

PITTSBURGH, July 16. -- Casey Stengel can use several more pitchers named Tom Zachary. Today the veteran southpaw presented the Brooklyn pilot with his first triumph of the Western invasion and ended the Brooklyn losing streak at six games.

PATERSON, N.J., July 16. -- Charles "Mickey" Norman 3d, West Paterson 3-year-old, is not the inveterate smoker he used to be. Since his third birthday last July 28 he has given up cigarettes. He uses his corn-cob pipe as a "revolver" most of the time and he smokes cigars only on week-ends and special occasions.

ROME, July 16. -- Newspapers here published long front-page editorials today emphasizing in vigorous language what they described as the "inevitability" of war with Ethiopia. The Giornale d'Italia, often officially inspired, attacked the efficacy of diplomatic efforts to halt hostilities.

The local premiere of "Broadway Gondolier," a Warner Brothers musical, with Dick Powell, Joan Blondell, Adolphe Menjou and Louise Fazenda, will take place tonight at the Strand, after the last showing of "Front Page Woman."

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16. -- The destruction of the whole excess coffee crops has been banned by the coffee convention. A bulletin issued tonight after the afternoon session states that hereafter one part, unspecified, of the coffee purchased by the National Coffee Department for destruction shall be eliminated by direct destruction or even by use for industrial purposes after denaturization.

So many people are buying new cars that it is no wonder the City of New York has caught the fever. In fact, we are going to have no less than 500 new cars and they average about $40,000 apiece. They are the kind that run in the Independent subway.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Administration leaders crushed today the adjournment movement in the House and re-announced their purpose to enact President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing tax program before the end of this session.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Senate today heard a strongly phrased denunciation by Senator Robinson, Democratic leader, of Senator Schall, whom he accused of "moral obliquity" and of "shielding himself behind the unfortunate affliction" of blindness to break the Senate rules with attacks upon the President of the United States.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 16. -- Two more places were filled in the semi-final bracket of the national junior polo championship at the Burnt Mills Polo Club today. The Aiken Knights won their second victory of the tournament, turning back Rumson, 10 to 5, and Great Island made its debut in the tourney by defeating Long Island, 10 to 3.

For some years it has been the fashion, even among officials who should know better, to decry excessive speed as a determining factor in the mounting toll of traffic fatalities. They insist that reckless driving, not speed per se, is the cause of the lengthening list of serious injuries and deaths.

MONTREAL, Wednesday, July 17 (Canadian Press). -- A fortune of $17,000,000 has just caught up with its inheritors and will be shared by six Montreal families and one New Yorker, according to an article in The Montreal Gazette today. It was made in diamonds by Harry Lozack, who left Bialostock, Poland, twenty years ago for South Africa.

LEEDS, England, July 16 (Canadian Press). -- By careful batting South Africa today succeeded in drawing the third test cricket match with England before a crowd of 10,000. As in the first test, South Africa was lucky to get a draw, stonewalling the English bowlers until the time limit expired.
The world's most famous golfer came home yesterday to an empty house.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16. -- The average department store in the Pacific Coast States in 1934 showed some tendency toward higher margins, expenses and profits, in percentage of sales, than the average store elsewhere in the United States, according to a report issued today by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School.
Conditions in the money money market remained unchanged. Business was light and quotations steady for all classes.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Charges involving the burning of telegrams, the signatures to which were in hundreds of cases alleged to be unauthorized and picked at random from the city directory of Warren, Pa., and all urging defeat of the "death clause" in the Wheeler-Rayburn Utilities Holding Company Bill, were developed today at a surprise hearing of the Senate lobby investigating committee.

LONDON, July 16. -- Big Bill Tilden and Ellsworth Vines sat around their hotel lobby today, as expectant as ambulance drivers awaiting a call to action, but the summons never came. America's two foremost professionals had been assured indirectly that their services were desired to help whip the United States Davis Cup team in trim for the interzone matches with Germany at Wimbledon this week-end.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Prices of hogs advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight here today with the top up 10 cents to $10.30, a new high since October, 1930. Small receipts and light packer reserves of both lard and meats are the dominating influence in the advance, according to stock yards interests.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 16. -- Jack Sabol and Jay S. Jones, Westchester Hills pair, collaborated on a sparkling 36, 29 -- 65 to win the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Grassy Sprain links today. Twenty-three teams started in the competition.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 16. -Although slightly shocked by the restoration ribaldry of "The Beaux' Stratagem," which was revived here last night by the Forty Niners at the Chase Barn Playhouse, the fight night audience was enthusiastic in its acclaim of this eighteenth century comedy classic.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Compensation of $2,020,034.50 was paid by General Motors Corporation in its last fiscal year to directors, some of whom are officers of the parent company or subsidiaries, according to an amendment filed with the SEC to the corporation's application on Form 10 for permanent registration on the Stock Exchanges.

LONDON, July 16. -- The controversy over the government's purchase of the Codex Sinaiticus, ancient Bible from Russia, for the British Museum during the black days of Britain's financial crisis in 1933 by means of an advance of 93,000 from the Civil Contingencies Fund is revived by a report of the Committee of Public Accounts, which hotly criticizes the transaction.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 16. -- New Jersey and New York City will witness a demonstration tomorrow of the mobility of the United States Army when infantrymen here will be rushed to New York and to Fort Monmouth in trucks. After a quick dash over New Jersey roads and through the Holland Tunnel those sent to New York will parade through Manhattan.

Yesterday in the House a motion for adjournment on July 23 was badly beaten formally and informally, but that defeat indicated nothing. The date set was premature. The disgust of the House at the prospect of a long imprisonment in Washington is notorious. There will be constant pressure for adjournment.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16. -The elm tree in Beach Avenue here which had often been admired by the late Joyce Kilmer, author of "Trees," fell to earth a few minutes before 7 o'clock tonight by order of the Federal Government's Dutch elm disease sanitation forces.
The Park Department reached far back into the album yesterday for a new idea in public entertainment and came up with a contest for barber-shop quartets.

SHANGHAI, July 16. -- "I cannot give definite details, but under the terms of the Tangku truce, Japan has the right to establish not only civil aviation in China, but also several other enterprises, such as radio, telegraphs, railroads and other things," said a Japanese Embassy spokesman today.
All utility reports are consolidated returns, including subsidiaries, unless otherwise specified.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP). -- Pennant hopes of the world champion Cardinals were boosted today as Jess Haines pitched the Red Birds to a 2-to-1 conquest over the Braves and the St. Louisans crept to within four games of the league-leading Giants.
