Elizabeth Hawes, one of the leading designers of women's clothes in New York, returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday after a visit to Russia, where, at the invitation of Soviet officials, she gave a fashion show for the benefit of Russian women.

DETROIT, July 16. -- Rewards totaling $3,000, offered for information leading to the arrest of Merton Ward Goodrich, will be paid to Thomas J. Harris, New York patrolman, whose arrest of a man he found loitering near the children's wading pool in Central Park, July 3, brought to an end the search for the slayer of Lillian Gallaher of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- A bitter controversy between Secretaries Wallace and Ickes was headed toward the Senate floor today with committee approval of a bill seeking to transfer all Federal conservation activities to a newly named Interior Department.
GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 16. -- E. Klein of Hungary and Samuel Reshevsky of New York, who drew in a long 90-move game at Margate, met again today in the British chess congress.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A final arrangement to construct the proposed municipal stadium on Randall's Island has been made between the government and New York City, Mayor La Guardia revealed today.

Jimmy Hines of the Garden City Country Club, who trailed Joe Turnesa, the champion, by four strokes with a total of 289 last season, set the pace for a field of 147 contestants with a card of 71 in the first round of the fourteenth annual open championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday.
Tammany leaders flocked to the Wigwam at Seventeenth Street and Fourth Avenue yesterday to greet James J. Dooling on the first anniversary of is election as the chieftain of Tammany Hall.

An offering of $32,000,000 Pure Oil Company fifteen-year 4 1/4 per cent sinking-fund notes, carrying non-detachable common stock purchase warrants, will be made today at 100 and accrued interest by a banking group comprising Edward B. Smith Co., the First Boston Corporation, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Field, Glore Co., Kidder, Peabody Co. and the Central Republic Company.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- The Elks Club of Dallas, Texas, has decided that William Parks, Chicago organist, is good enough for their talented adopted daughter, Miss Aloah Dallas Elk, and the two will be married here Friday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16 (AP). -- The solution of one of the great problems of science and industry, how to "see" sulphur and poisonous selenium with the spectroscopic eye, was reported to the conference on spectroscopy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that 923 of the 1,000 men on the patrolmen's eligible list who had been invited to take a preliminary course of training while waiting to be appointed had accepted.
MARLBORO, N.Y., July 16 (AP). -- Bobby Linsig, only child in recent medical history to live without an esophagus, had a birthday today and celebrated by chewing on a new "pacifier."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16. -- Another fleet topping all past-year records took part today in the race week regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Two hundred and sixty-eight craft were out, only seventeen less than the all-time mark of last Saturday. Of the number, Prestige, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Class M sloop, and Van S. Merle-Smith's new international 12-meter Seven Seas came through to victory.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 16. -- The rioting which has turned Belfast into a city of turmoil and terror since last Friday flared up again this afternoon. While the funeral procession for William Lyttle, one of the victims of the disorders, was passing along York Street with thousands of persons in the cortege, it was fired upon as it reached Donegal Street.
BERLIN, July 16. -- The anti-Jewish rioting last night brought forth a "warning to elements inimical to the State" by the State police today.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 16. -- The examination before trial of William Fox of Woodmere, former head of the film and theatre interests which bear his name, ran into a snag today when he testified that his personal financial records from 1925 to 1929 had disappeared.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 6. -- The statement that women are taking over more and more of the important jobs in this country by proving their ability was made by speakers at the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs today.

For the first active week of the Fall buying period, buyers' registrations in this market were slightly ahead of a year ago. Arrivals listed in THE TIMES for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,063 as against 1,061 for the corresponding week last year.
Golfers from all points of the Empire State are to tee off today at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck for the qualifying round of the thirteenth annual New York State amateur championship.

The favored array in the Eastern junior tennis singles championship swept its opposition aside to gain the quarter-final round yesterday on the play courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A registration statement has been filed with the SEC by the Cudahy Packing Company of Chicago for the issuance of $20,000,000 first mortgage sinking fund bonds, series A 3 3/4 per cent, due Sept. 1, 1955, and $5,000,000 convertible sinking fund 4 per cent debentures, due Sept. 1, 1950. Both issues are to be dated Sept. 1, 1935.

Small steel companies with a total investment of less than $1,000,000 each earned a greater return on invested capital in 1988 and 1984 than the larger companies, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

With the arrival of Miss Anne Govednik of the Chisholm A.A. of Minnesota and Miss Alice Bridges, Whitin Community Association, Whitinsville, Mass., at Manhattan Beach yesterday, the list of defending titleholders on hand for the women's national swimming championships rose to five.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A slim margin of two votes today saved a major phase of the New Deal's farm program, price-fixing, from destruction by the Senate.

Supreme Court Justice Cotillo yesterday granted the plea of Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., heir to part of the wealth of his grandfather, Thomas Fortune Ryan, to confirm the findings of Referee Ralph O.L. Fay, who took testimony in his annulment suit against the former Countess Marie Anne von Wurmbrand-Stuppach, daughter of the former court chamberlain to the Emperor of Austria.

THERE is a curious simplicity about many of the patriotic utterances of Charles D'Ydewalle, the Belgian aristocrat whose "Albert and the Belgians" has just been published here by Morrow ($3). "The Belgian troops appeared in Ghent on the very day of the armistice," he notes enthusiastically, "driving the enemy out of the city at the point of the bayonet."

Sergeant John A. Johanson, a soldier of the "old army," who enlisted in the days when the blue uniform of the Federal Army was still being worn, probably holds a record for short-time enlistment. The 62-year-old soldier signed up for twenty days on July 11 to complete thirty years of service for retirement.

MOSCOW, July 16. -- The oft-postponed seventh congress of the Communist International will definitely be held in the near future. it was announced today by A. Lozovsky, head of the Red Trade Union International and also a member of the presidium of the Comintern and of the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Government.

The hearing being conducted before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe on two conflicting plans for reorganization of the Ambassador Hotels in New York and Atlantic City was resumed yesterday in the Woolworth Building.

TOKYO, July 16. -- General Jinzaburo Mazaki, Director General of Military Education and popularly known as one of the army's "big three," has been ordered relieved of his post, to which General Jotaro Watanabe has been appointed.

An optimistic picture of the potentialities of Chinese-American economic relations was painted yesterday by W. Cameron Forbes, chairman of the American Economic Mission to the Far East, for the benefit of 150 leaders in the export field at a luncheon given by the National Foreign Trade Council at India House, 1 Hanover Square, to welcome home the mission.

Ignazio Lupo, 58 years old, organizer of the "Italian Bakers Association" and known to the police as "Lupo the Wolf," was arrested with his son, Rocco, 35, at 2 A.M. yesterday on a charge of conspiracy in an attempt to extort "protection money" from a retail baker in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, July 16. -- General Jinzaburo Mazaki, Director General of Military Education and popularly known as one of the army's "big three," has been ordered relieved of his post, to which General Jotaro Watanabe has been appointed.

An optimistic picture of the potentialities of Chinese-American economic relations was painted yesterday by W. Cameron Forbes, chairman of the American Economic Mission to the Far East, for the benefit of 150 leaders in the export field at a luncheon given by the National Foreign Trade Council at India House, 1 Hanover Square, to welcome home the mission.

Ignazio Lupo, 58 years old, organizer of the "Italian Bakers Association" and known to the police as "Lupo the Wolf," was arrested with his son, Rocco, 35, at 2 A.M. yesterday on a charge of conspiracy in an attempt to extort "protection money" from a retail baker in Brooklyn.

The producing firm of Pearson Baruch, in association with William Brady Jr., have acquired a new play entitled "Snatch Away Girl," by Frank J. Collins and Olga Lee, which they will try out during the week of Aug. 5 at the Casino Theatre, Deal, N.J. . . .

Hoit, Rose Troster are distributing their current edition of "Facts and Figures." which contains a survey of New York City bank statements as of June 29, and data on insurance company stocks and other over-the-counter securities.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 16. -- In prime condition after a brief ocean voyage, three days of rest and an afternoon's practice here, the cricketers of the Bermuda Athletic Association opened their North American tour with a match on the grounds of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 2,715,100 barrels daily, compared with 2,677,400 in the previous week, an increase of 37,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 29,800 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and of 18,000 in California were the important changes.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- In the face of the Boston court decision holding sections of the Agricultural Adjustment Act unconstitutional, AAA and Treasury officials nevertheless went ahead today with plans to carry out the provisions of the act until a final decision is had from the Supreme Court itself.

After all operating and maintenance employes of the I.R.T. subway had been pressed into service as lookouts, a Negro sought as a suspect in the murder of Miss Leonora Rivera, 22 years old, stabbed early Monday in Morningside Park, was taken into custody last night in the Bergen Street, Brooklyn, station.

It may appear too early to make plans for the election of judges in this city next November. But it is not. While the primaries and nominating conventions are still two months away, that interval is always marked by great activity on the part of politicians and party machines. This is perhaps especially the case with coming judicial elections.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 16. -- Nickel-in-the-slot parking was introduced in Oklahoma City today and promptly precipitated an uproar.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Except for the presence of uniformed Storm Troop patrols, there were no external reminders along the Kurfuerstendamm tonight of last night's attacks on Jews. Nevertheless, the baiting continued in the city during the day.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Charging that the Democrats design to hold the Assembly by "pouring Federal funds into doubtful counties," Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, said at a conference of his party today that the use of Public Works money threatened success of the Republican campaign this year.

LONDON, July 16. -- Members of the Council on the Interchange of Preachers Between the Churches of Great Britain and America were guests at a luncheon given by Viscount Leverhulme yesterday to meet the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo of Washington and other preachers from the United States.

LANSING, Mich., July 16. -- Michigan industries and their employes have been definitely benefited by the United States Supreme Court's annulment of the National Industrial Recovery Act, according to the State Department of Labor and Industry.

By way of celebrating the fact that their manager had been retained for two more years, the Yankees overcame the White Sox yesterday at the Stadium, sending way the troublesome Chicago team under a 2-0 shutout before 1,000 fans.

Commendation and congratulation from Lord and Lady Robert S.S. Baden-Powell, world heads respectively of the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, on progress made in those movements in the United States during the last five years featured the luncheon in their honor yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Several hundred guests attended.

Growing interest in water-going aircraft and marked improvement in performance of both seaplanes and amphibians, large and small, have led to a nation-wide cooperative movement launched yesterday by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America to establish proper docking and handling facilities in many American cities.
BOSTON, July 16. -- Following is the text of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals decision holding the AAA processing and floor taxes illegal:

In a decision worded more sharply than any ruling issued by the United States Customs Court in years, Judge William J. Tilson yesterday ordered the Collector of Customs at Los Angeles to liquidate an entry of wearing apparel imported by Bullocks, Inc.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 16. -- Leading her two nearest rivals by a margin of six strokes, Miss Rosalie Knapp of the home club captured low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day handicap tournament over the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course today.

Seven storekeepers who had been arrested Monday on charges of receiving stolen goods from the "rifle gang," which terrorized Brooklyn and Queens with a series of robberies, were held in bail yesterday for hearings later.

A decision by the Massachusetts Circuit Court of Appeals declaring the Agricultural Adjustment Act unconstitutional had an unsettling effect on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, and prices declined $1 a bale to close at net losses of 11 to 13 points.

The unusual spectacle was presented yesterday of an Assistant District Attorney virtually asking the acquittal of defendants whom another prosecutor for several days had been trying to place in jail. It was in the case of Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco, on trial under the Brownell law.

Net income of the Schenley is-tillers Corporation and subsidiaries in the second quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $1,443,030, after provisions for interest, depreciation, contingencies, Federal income and capital-stock taxes and other charges.

Extension by the Securities and Exchange Commission of a sixty-day exemption from permanent registration to securities of Canadian companies prevented the suspension of trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday in stocks of three unregistered companies.
The city of Worcester, Mass., will receive tenders today on a new issue of $500,000 of notes, dated July 1, 1935, and maturing on July 15, 1936. The notes will be issued in anticipation of revenues.

ALBANY, July 16. -- The route conditions on highways in Southern New York inundated or washed out by the flood of last week were announced today by Governor Lehman, who received the information from the division of highways.

Eston A. Young, 63 years old, retired principal of a Brooklyn business training school, hanged himself last night, according to the police, in the cellar of his home at 1,243 East Twenty-ninth Street, near Avenue M, in the residential Madison Park district of Flatbush, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- A hope in some administration quarters that proposed legislation will lay the groundwork for future effective control of arms exports from the United States was conveyed today to Congress.
The money market was featureless. No increase in the demand for funds was noted despite heavier turnover on the Stock Exchange, and quotations remained steady for all classifications.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The first bonus march of 1935, complete with sound effects, was encouraged as to the justice of its cause by Representative Fish of New York today. He is the author of a bill to pay the veterans' bonus at once out of the $4,000,000,000 works relief fund Congress voted at the beginning of the present session.

GENEVA, July 17. -- There is reason to believe the Secretariat of the League of Nations is warning Council members tonight that a meeting of the Council on the Italo-Ethiopian conflict seems imminent and is sounding them regarding what day between July 25 and 31 the meeting shall begin.

Experienced steamship managers in the North Atlantic trade, when informed last night of the announcement from t3erlin that the 1NTorth German Lloyd and the -Tamburg American Lines had now become, for practical purposes, government undertakings, said they were not surprised.

The multitudinous children of Columbia, Goerck and Ridge Streets splashed furiously in their fire-hydrant showers yesterday afternoon while the usual massive trucks rumbled overhead on Williamsburg Bridge.

DETROIT, July 17. -- Elmer B. O'Hara, State chairman of the Democratic party; State Senator A.J. Wilkowski, secretary of the Democratic party in Wayne County, and fifty-two other Democrats were accused today of a conspiracy to "steal" the 1934 election for Secretary of State and Attorney General.

Spokesmen of organized labor in New York City announce after a conference that "under no circumstances "are any of our organizations to per-"mit their members to work on relief "work at less than the prevailing "wage." This is a remarkable decision. Its implications can be better appreciated when we recall the history of relief and examine the probable long-run effects of the policy announced.

A report from Larchmont, N.Y., in your issue of July 14, under the heading, "Old Tree Felled as Town Mourns," concerns the destruction of a beautiful old elm tree and concludes with the accusation "that the disease was first brought to this country from the Netherlands."

When the Wheeler-Rayburn bill first made its appearance members of the utility industry, regarding it as a destructive measure -- as indeed it was -- felt called upon to fight it with every legitimate weapon at their command. A number of utility executives banded together and set up a lobby at Washington, quite openly.

CRAWFORD NOTCH, N.H., July 17 (AP). -- Anton Von Bernuth of Whitestone, L.I. seeking his third White Mountains tennis championship, today gained the semi-final round by defeating Earl Goldthorp of Paterson, N.J., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

One hour after taking off from Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon on the first leg of a proposed flight to Bergen, Norway, Thor Solberg, Brooklyn picture-frame manufacturer, and Paul Oscanyan, his radio operator, returned to the field because their Loening amphibian was "tail-heavy.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A list of applications for registration on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, contained the names of these firms from New York City and the immediate vicinity:

BERLIN, July 17. -The Boerse was weaker today. Heavy industrials fell slightly, both Mansfeld and Stahlwerke losing 1 3/4. Potashes stayed at yesterday's levels after early advances. The machine list was notably weaker, SchubertSalzer losing point and Schwarzkopf 2.1/2 points.

An unnamed Board of Education official surmises that the bill passed by the Board of Estimate, to convey physically handicapped childdren to religious public schools, may be illegal. He also cites something about public funds being forbidden to "private schools." May I submit two rulings on the matter?

BERLIN, July 17. -- Nazis today continued their anti-Semitic campaign despite warnings from higher-ups and pushed their sterilization program despite Catholic protests, while the controlled press cried out bitterly against "atrocity reports" abroad.

NOROTON, Conn., July 17. -- Having established a comfortable and commanding lead during the first two days of the tournament, Miss Betty Pietsch coasted through the final eighteen holes today at the Wee Burn Club to annex the Fairfield and Westchester open medal play championship with the low total of 258 strokes for the fifty-four-hole test.

A bill authorizing the erection of a suitable memorial to Major Gen. GOETHALS within the Canal Zone has been passed by the United States Senate and is now on the House calendar awaiting final action. If there could be objection to its enactment by any one, it would be solely on the ground that he needs no new monument.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 17. -- Sing Sing officials were informed that Walter Taber, 29 years old, who had been released from this prison recently after serving four years for stealing the automobile of George C. Stone of Pawling, N.Y., was sentenced today in Poughkeepsie to ten years in Sing Sing for robbing Mr. Stone's house.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 17. -- Pennsylvania will advertise soon for bids for all or part of the $50,000,000 loan authorized by the recent tax-anticipation notes law. Governor George H. Earle, Charles A. Waters, State Treasurer, and Frank E. Baldwin, Auditor General, form the board that will float the loan.

The young woman who has been refused a permanent teacher's license because she is too fat has already had a year's training in the class room, and her superiors say her work was excellent. That is a point not to be overlooked.

HALIFAX July 17 (Canadian Press). -- Smooth-stroking oarsmen from Buffalo's West Side Athletic Club carried off the honors in today's rodeo week regatta, winning an international eight-oared race and qualifying for Saturday's final of the four-oared event with coxswain.

The Loose Wiles Biscuit Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 1 to authorize the issuance of a new class of 5 per cent preferred stock. If the issue is approved, the corporation's 7 per cent first preferred stock will be retired at the call price of $120 a share on Oct. 1. Arrangements have been made for a banker to underwrite the issue.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17 (AP). -- Meteor, Rochester Yacht Club entry, annexed the Silas George International Cup for six-meter sloops today in the third and final race against Jack, Watertown Yacht Club craft, and Mist, entered by the Royal Canadian Club of Toronto.

ROME, July 17. -- The question of postponement of the League of Nations Council meeting that should be held next week is still an object of intense negotiations between the Italian, French and British Foreign Offices.

William Charles Wentworth, secretary to the Legislative Council in the upper house at Sydney, Australia, and Mrs. Wentworth, who are at the Waldorf-Astoria, gave a tea yesterday at that hotel. Their guests were Dr. and Mrs. Russell Cecil, Mrs. Maxwell Cumming, Mrs. F.W. Edlin, Miss Rose Cumming, Miss Levina Fairlie, Colonel Philipoff, E.T. Fisk and David Clarkson. Mr. and Mrs. Wentworth are sailing next Wednesday on the Mariposa for their home in Sydney.

LOS ANGELES, July 17. -- Coordination of all law-enforcement agencies, regardless of State lines, was urged by members of the American Bar Association today as the association concentrated on its nationwide war on crime.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL TRAIN, GUADALAJARA, Mexico, July 17. -- In a speech delivered yesterday before an audience of 5,000 to 6,000 Indian farm workers President Lazare Cardenas said he proposed to organize all agrarians into reserves for the Federal Army.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The House action today in refusing to accept the Clark amendment to the Social Security Bill and forcing it back to conference with the Senate, elated experts who worked on the original bill, and others interested in it, but it served to renew their determination to defeat the amendment by bringing pressure to bear on Senators.

The report of James G. McDonald, High Commissioner for Refugees Coming From Germany, as published here yesterday revealed the organization in the United States of a Refugee Economic Corporation, with a capital of $10,000,000. IIe stated that "at present the capital subscribed amounts to $1,250,000, of which part is being called up with a view to immediate assistance of settlement schemes."

Retail collections on charge accounts increased 0.28 per cent during June as compared with the same month last year, according to the twenty-key-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. With nineteen stores reporting, the percentage last month showed an average of 48.01.

The National Biscuit Company reported yesterday for the quarter ended on June 30 a net profit of $2,385,318 after taxes and other deductions. It is equivalent after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to 31 cents a share on 6,289,448 shares of $10 par common stock.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

JERUSALEM, July 17. -- All efforts by Italy to disseminate propaganda among the Arabs of the Near and Middle East for the purpose of enlisting Moslem support in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute are proving futile.

An addition of more than 2,000 persons and families on relief in June over May was reported yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and director of the Emergency Relief Bureau. Although more than 12,000 families were dropped from the June rolls, more than 14,000 new cases appeared, he said.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Final approval by President Roosevelt of an allotment of $20,642,700 to be used by the Works Progress Administration for carrying out 136 non-Federal projects in New York City was announced today and the proposed activities described in a statement made public by the Division of Applications and Information.

Ship lines were notified yesterday of an order issued by Secretary Roper requiring common carriers engaged in the foreign trade of the United States to file all rates and charges on freight shipments from this country to foreign ports within thirty days of their effective date.

A further fractional gain was the response of the franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday to the publication of the plans of the French Government for covering its budgetary deficit of about 11,000,000,000 francs. The franc rose to 6.63 1/2 cents, a gain of 1/8% point, and closed at that price.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 27, -- Princess Irbain Khan Kaplanoff gave a luncheon today at the Meadow Club for Princess Alexis Obolensky, who has joined her and Prince Kaplanoff at Sunnycroft for a visit. Among the other guests were Mrs. Leland Eggleston Coffer, Mrs. John Thomas Smith, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, Mrs. Fenton Taylor and Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP). -- Before a mid-week crowd of 20,000, Mrs. J. Chesney's 4-year-old brown filly, Incandescent, came from behind in the stretch to capture the Plymouth Rock, the mile and 70-yard feature for 3-year-olds and upward today, at Suffolk Downs.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 17. -- The press and public were barred this morning from the examination before trial of William Fox of Woodmere, former moving picture executive, before official referee Elvin N. Edwards in the Nassau Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- While the Senate and House prepared for a conference battle of their own over new TVA legislation, a mingling of praise and criticism tonight greeted the action of the Court of Appeals in New Orleans in declaring the vast project constitutional.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 17. -- Of two games in which he participated today in the international tournament of the British Chess Federation, Samuel Reshevsky of New York won one and adjourned the other in a satisfactory position, thereby regaining the lead from Dr. Adolf Seitz of Germany.

A chanting, placard-waving group of fifty-one youthful pickets, including Representative Michael B. Smith of the Washington State Legislature, were arrested yesterday as they were staging a demonstration in front of the offices of The American Mercury at 730 Fifth Avenue.

The contest between ports on the Atlantic seaboard and the Gulf for the traffic in automobiles shipped from factories in the Middle West for export markets was advanced yesterday when New Orleans interests filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for suspension of rates published by Eastern railroads effective Aug. 1.
PARIS, July 17. -- Premier Pierre Laval's courage in taking such drastic measures as he has done to remedy the budget situation has won everybody's commendation.

Completion of the consolidation of the public relations activities of the New York Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms was signalized yesterday by the announcement of the Exchange that it had taken over the association's national advisory council, consisting of brokers in 140 principal cities of the United States and Canada.

The new issue of $38,000,000 New York City serial bonds and corporate stock offered to the public yesterday was more than 75 per cent sold, according to an estimate by the syndicate managers at the close of business yesterday. From the standpoint of the city, the sale was the most successful in more than thirty years, while the bankers expressed satisfaction over the manner in which the bonds were taken in the market.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 17. -- Chancellor A.E. Mitchell today upheld the legal right of the Tennessee Public Service Company, local utility, to a temporary injunction restraining the city of Knoxville from building a municipal electric power distribution system using Tennessee Valley Authority power.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, July 18 (AP). -- Disorders spread into widely separated parts of riot-torn Belfast early today, although heavy forces of troops earlier had appeared to have the situation under control.

With Jose Iturbi conducting and Leroy Anspach, a young Philadelphia pianist, making his New York debut as soloist, last night's orchestral concert at the Lewisohn Stadium was devoted about equally to the music of Franz Liszt and Igor Stravinsky.

If Washington weather were not so sultry, and tempers were not so frayed, and the pressure to hurry into legislation merely for the sake of being done with it were not so strong, Congress might put aside the new AAA Bill long enough to study carefully the decision of the Circuit Court at Boston on the basic act creating this agency of the New Deal.

Auctioneers offered nine properties in Manhattan at foreclosure sales yesterday. Two scheduled sales were adjourned. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs, consisting largely of savings banks holding mortgages on the defaulted realty.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 17. -- The will of Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt, who died July 7 at her town home, 60 East Ninety-third Street, Manhattan, was filed for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today. It provided for the distribution of several millions of dollars in cash and trust funds among relatives, employes and friends.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Marjorie Gladman Van Ryn of Philadelphia and Miss Helen Pederson, Stamford (Conn.) star, respective victor and runner-up at Longwood last week, today were eliminated from the eleventh annual Essex Country Club invitation tennis tournament by unseeded third-round opponents.

Upholding the constitutionality of the Brownell "Public Enemy" Law, Magistrate Nathan D. Perlman found Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco guilty yesterday morning of disorderly conduct and sentenced them to three months each in the workhouse.

LOS ANGELES, July 17. -- Mrs. Mae Elizabeth Keaton today sued Buster Keaton, screen comedian, for divorce, naming as corespondent Mrs. Leah Clampitt Sewell. In another suit, Mrs. Keaton asked $200,000 damages from Mrs. Sewell for alleged theft of the actor's affections.

Lower-priced poultry for consumers is the aim of a drive started yesterday by the Department of Markets to abolish the practice of commission merchants of overfeeding chickens to increase profits. A raid in West Washington Market by department officials resulted in the seizure of eighty-eight over-cropped fowls, which were slaughtered and sent to Bellevue Hospital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 17. -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines promised disabled American veterans in convention here today a new construction program which will provide for an additional 1,333 hospital beds in different sections of the country.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Red Sex regained a first-division berth at the Indians' expense today by turning back Cleveland twice, 13 -- 5 and 3 -- 1, before a delighted crowd of 16,000.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Curt Davis's five-hit pitching and a barrage of four consecutive hits by Moore, Camilli, Vergez and Haslin that scored all their runs at the start of the fourth today gave the Phillies a 3-to-2 victory over the Cubs, their second in a row.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Senators amassed an even dozen hits today to defeat the Browns, 8 to 4. Ed Linke was victor on the mound.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 17. -- Texas, playing its first game in the national junior polo championship on Schley Field at the Burnt Mills Club this evening, eliminated Roslyn by the surprising score of 7 to 2 and went into the semi-finals. Texas drew a bye in the opening round.

Steps to bring about consultation by the United States with the League of Nations and signatories of the Kellogg Pact to find a peaceful solution of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute were urged last night in a statement of policy adopted by the National Peace Conference.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Out of the confusion following the Circuit Court of Appeals decision at Boston holding AAA processing taxes unconstitutional, there emerged today a plan to practically ignore, the decision and to carry on "full speed" under the amended measure expected to be passed by Congress and approved by President Roosevelt possibly next week.

Increased returns in the insurance field for the current year and an optimistic outlook in other industries were reported yesterday by Carl Heye, president of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, at the opening of the convention of leading members of the sales force of that organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With traders in securities and commodities of a mind to ignore, or to relegate to a minor position of importance, the political news of the day, the markets yesterday appeared to move forward from "natural" causes. The optimistic tone of the midweek industrial reviews and the generally favorable corporation earnings statements for the second quarter, found reflection in the share market from the outset.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17. -- Junior day of race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club was just about spoiled this afternoon because of lack of wind. It was the day on which the youngsters have a chance to sail the larger boats, even up to the Interclubs, Victorys and Atlantic sloops.

The following letter from Thomas E. Dewey to District Attorney William C. Dodge, declaring that $253,095 a year was the minimum requirement for an effective investigation of "important crime" in Manhattan, was made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, along with the special prosecutor's itemized budget:

Jouett Shouse, former chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, who has been a severe critic of the Roosevelt administration, declared yesterday that "an administration which passes unconstitutional acts is bound to bear the brunt of its course." Mr. Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, sailed on the United States liner Manhattan with Mrs. Shouse to pass several months in France, Switzerland and England.

The new film opening this morning at the Radio City Music Hall is "Ginger," a Fox production featuring Jane Withers and Jackie Searl. On the stage will be "Mid-summer Divertissement," a revue in six scenes, staged by Russell Markert.

The first double of the season for the George D. Widener establishment was recorded yesterday when Go Quick and Chicstraw won the third and fourth races, respectively, at Empire City. Chicstraw annexed the Larchmont Handicap, the featured event, and it marked the first successful effort of the year for the 4-year-old son of Chicle and Last Straw.

Jimmy Hines of the Garden City Country Club yesterday added a fine 73 to his pace-setting 71 for the first round at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing to take a firmer hold on the lead at the half-way mark of the fourteenth annual open championship of the Long Island Golf Association.

LONDON, July 17. -- Within sixty-five minutes today a sum exceeding 32,000,000, the amount required, was subscribed for an issue of 2 1/2 per cent guaranteed debenture stock of the London Electric Transport Finance Corporation at a price of 97.

Houghton Mifflin are wondering just what Adolf Hitler expects to learn from Walter Millis's "Road to War." The company reports that it has just forwarded a "desk copy" to Berlin at the earnest request of Ernst Hanfstaengl, personal friend of Hitler and in charge of Germany's public relations with the foreign press.

With grain and stock markets strong and cotton contracts scarce again, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly higher yesterday. Price-fixing operations based on near months carried July above the 12-cent mark, while October moved to a 12-point premium over May, compared with a discount of 10 points two weeks ago.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 17. -- The Youngstown Steel Company was reorganized today at a stockholders' meeting, when preferred shareholders received equal voting power with common stockholders. P.G. Dalton of Cleveland, chairman of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, and C.N. Osborne of Cleveland, secretary-treasurer of the M.A. Hanna Company, were added to the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The War Department said today a report was due here tomorrow on how many army engineers would be necessary for a flood-prevention survey authorized by President Roosevelt in up-State New York.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 17. -- Rallying on two occasions when she seemed beaten, Miss Virginia Bascom, 19-year-old player from Worcester, Mass., eliminated Mrs. Frederick J. Davis of Providence, R.I., 1 up, at the nineteenth hole in the quarter-finals of the seventeenth annual Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup today.

Yielding to what he considered the immutable influence exerted over his wife by Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, Samuel N. Green Jr., a Negro postoffice clerk, asked Justice Jacob Panken in Children's Court yesterday to send his seven children to an orphan asylum.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- A new bill to put industry on a thirty-hour work week was facing Congress today.

Three of the four Federal judges in the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals are Democrats and the fourth is a Republican. The members of the court who are Democrats are: Presiding Judge Nathan P. Bryan of Jacksonville, Fla.; Samuel H. Sibley of Atlanta, Ga., and Joseph C. Hutcheson Jr. of Houston, Texas.
Among those booked to depart today for California via Havana and the Panama Canal on the Dollar liner President Taft are:

A committee of five representing the 215 striking caddies at Dyker Beach Park golf course in Brooklyn were told yesterday at a conference at the Arsenal in Central Park that two of their three demands would be granted, but despite these concessions there were no indications last night that the strike would be called off.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 17. -- Leading oarsmen from the United States and Canada began gathering here this evening for the sixty-third annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which will start tomorrow and continue through Saturday on Lake Carnegie.

Every competitor who takes to the water today in the first events of the national A.A.U. women's outdoor swimming and diving championships at the Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, should turn in a star performance if diligent practice and serious training decide the results.

The course of domestic corporate bond prices continued yesterday toward moderately higher levels on the New York Stock Exchange, under the fresh leadership of a few selected public utility and industrial issues. Railroad liens, as a group, also extended their advances, with several noteworthy gains recorded in that section.

LONDON, July 17 (AP). -- Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary for Colonies, told the House of Commons today that Britain's military forces in Kenya, bordering Ethiopia and Italian Somaliland, had been "partially redistributed" -- although it was "considered unnecessary to reinforce them" -- in view of "possible contingencies on that frontier."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17. -- The calendar prevented at least one youngster from competing in Larchmont's junior regatta today. The age limit for juniors is 18 years and one of the leading skippers just turned the corner.
The question of the ownership of moneys saved by a wife out of funds given to her by her husband has recently come up in New Jersey.

Among new singers engaged for performances of open-air opera at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium by Salmaggi's Chicago Opera Company are Enzo Giannini, Giuseppe Del Credo and Pietro Lagana. The first-named will appear in "Cavalleria Rusticana" on Saturday evening, July 27, the cast also to include Elda Ercole, Florence Wylde, Carlotta Bruno and Edward Lugano.
PARIS, July 17. -- France has not abandoned hope of inducing Italy to accept a procedure in the African affair that will accord with the workings of the League of Nations.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- The bid of the Cargill Grain Company of Minneapolis for the North Western Grain Elevator in South Chicago, now controlled under lease from the Chicago North Western Railway by the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation, was turned down today by Federal Judge William H. Holly, before whom plans for the Rosenbaum reorganization are pending.

TACOMA, Wash., July 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Margaret Waley, who preferred life behind bars to freedom without her kidnapper husband, was sentenced today to twenty years' imprisonment for her part in the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping.

ALBANY, July 17 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, State Works Progress Administrator, warned municipalities today to speed up submission of Works Progress Administration projects as he forwarded applications for $6,000,000 to the Allocations Board in Washington.
The American Child Health Association, one of the leading health research organizations, will probably disband and discontinue its activities soon, it was indicated yesterday.

Not the corporations, but the public, would pay the proposed graduated corporate income tax, C.M. Chester, president of General Foods Corporation, said yesterday before sailing on the Manhattan for a few weeks' visit to England.
A new heat wave sent the mercury up to 86 at 6 o'clock last evening, bringing another day of above-normal temperatures after a relapse Tuesday to the first normal day since July 4.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17. -- Winfield R. Sheehan resigned today as vice president and production chief of Fox Film Corporation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 17. -- Discovery that sugar can take on a mysterious form of "tan" from ultra-violet light and thereby prevent germs from growing caused a stir among biologists at the Conference on Spectroscopy at Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- A difference of opinion on the advisability of calling a general strike of hosiery workers on Sept. 1 was recorded here today in a three-hour discussion at the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.

The State Attorney General's office obtained yesterday an order temporarily restraining Carl H. Phillips of 122 East Forty-second Street, a dealer in oil royalties, from carrying on his business pending an investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -The property of blocking all gold clause damage suits today was heatedly argued by Senator Glass, Democrat, of Virginia, and Attorney General Cummings.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Talk of early adjournment was laid by President Roosevelt today to propaganda by those who would like to see Congress adjourn without acting on the proposed bill to levy taxes on inheritances and increase income taxes in the higher brackets.

An accounting filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Aaron Rabinowitz, Lawrence L. Martin and James L. Clare, the trustees appointed by Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to reorganize the $27,910,000 F-1 issue of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, disclosed that the certificate holders would receive $279,000 on Aug. 15 next with another payment of an equal sum likely to be made on Dec. 15.

Joseph Toplinsky, alias "Yosky Nigger," a veteran racketeer who headed an East Side gang of extortionists and horse poisoners as long ago as 1902, according to the police, appeared in the police line-up yesterday charged with having "hijacked" a truck in Sullivan County May 23, kidnapping the driver and his helper and escaping with $8,000 worth of drugs.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- President Roosevelt at his press conference laid the movement for early adjournment to opponents of tax legislation. He approved a number of work relief allotments and said that the AAA would continue operating as usual until the Supreme Court had passed on its constitutionality.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Again showing itself responsive to demands of the silver bloc, the Senate Agriculture Committee reported favorably today the proposals of Senator McCarran to repeal some sections of the Silver Purchase Act of 1934, which placed the fate of the metal in President Roosevelt's hands.

TOKYO, July 17. -- The War Minister, General Senjuro Hayashi, followed up his dismissal of General Jinzaburo Mazaki as Director General of Military Education by calling a meeting of the Supreme Military Council today, at which both sides got an opportunity to express their views with the greatest frankness.

The special investigation into organized crime in Manhattan, ordered by Governor Lehman, encountered political headwinds for the first time yesterday, after Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer had removed the only legal obstacle placed in its path thus far.
MONTREAL, July 17 (AP). -- Montreal defeated Newark today, 9 to 4, and stretched its International League lead to 3 1/2 games. It was Newark's eleventh consecutive loss.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 17. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club went around the wind-swept course of the Lido Country Club in 88 today to capture low gross honors in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day handicap tournament.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 17 (AP). -- Rodney Bliss of Omaha won the medal honors in the Western amateur golf tournament at Broad-moor today by posting a par 70 for a thirty-six-hole total of 142. A thunderstorm delayed play and sent scores soaring.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 17. -- Westchester golfers dominated the qualifying round of the thirteenth annual New York State amateur championship on the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today, two of them tying for the medal and seven of them finishing among the first eight.

Investigators for the Bureau of Internal Revenue have been going over the books of several local banks in recent weeks, gathering information on stock transactions carried out in the name of nominees with a view to levying assessments for additional stamp taxes on such transactions.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- President Roosevelt's far-reaching program of social and economic security for the masses was deadlocked today over the question whether private company pension systems were to be permitted under the plan.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Reversing its action of yesterday, the Senate voted today, 44 to 41, to remove important price-fixing provisions from the amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration Act.
NEW ORLEANS, July 17. -- The text of the decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today on the Tennessee Valley Authority Act was as follows:

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 17 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Sellassie's fighting men, clad in new uniforms, sharpened their shooting eyes and drilled interminably today as Ethiopia's preparations for possible war with Italy continued.

ROME, July 17. -- The world's seaplane non-stop distance record, which Italy held from October, 1934, to June, 1935, and then lost to France, was recaptured by Italians today on completion of a flight of 3,086 miles from Monfalcone, near Trieste, to Berbera, British Somaliland.

Production of steel ingots this week made one of the most spectacular gains aver shown in midsummer, rising 4 points to 40 1/2 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age said yesterday in its summary of operations. The 11 per cent advance followed a rise of 14 per cent in the preceding week, the magazine pointed out, but the earlier increase represented normal recovery from a holiday period.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP). -- Bill Hallaban, moving rapidly along the come-back trail, won his fifth straight game today, 2 to 1, but a home run in the ninth inning by Terry Moore was necessary before the champion Cardinals succeeded in turning back the Braves.
The weekly weather report was issued yesterday by the government as follows:

The stock market has responded quickly to earnings reports for the second quarter which have been appearing in large numbers this week. In some cases the reports have been disappointing, and the stock of the company affected has declined promptly and emphatically.

A SUITABLE dedication for Phil Stong's "The Farmer in the Dell" (Harcourt, Brace, $2) would be "With love and kisses for Will Rogers." As a scenario for Mr. Rogers this light, pleasantly readable novel falls short of perfection on only one point. That is that there is no clearly marked opportunity to do rope tricks. But there are compensations for this lack.

NEW ORLEANS, July 17. -- The constitutional right of the Tennessee Valley Authority to sell in competition with private utilities all surplus power generated by hydroelectric plants on the Tennessee River was upheld in an opinion handed down here today by the Federal Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.

Brighter shades in Fall wool and silk dresses will be popular this year, the color coordination committee of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association forecast yesterday in a report intended to guide buyers in selecting popular price dresses for Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Triple A's legal downfall in a second-tier Federal court, amid the attendant cheers of anti-New Dealers, calls once more for the reminder that, politically, the cheers may be unsoundly based. For there is a definite wish in a high and shrewd administration quarter that the Supreme Court will throw the Wagner bill, the Guffey bill and the AAA into the discard with the NIRA.

For the first five months of this year the Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $7,421,128 after taxes and other charges. This is equal to 56 cents a share on 13,167,696 shares of $50 par capital stock. In the corresponding period of 1934, the revised net income was $8,599,584 or 65 cents a share. Comparisons follow:

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher in quiet trading yesterday. Sugar futures again lost ground. In the cash markets all the grains, lard, cocoa, tin, cotton, silk and rubber were higher, while eggs were lower.

A definite buying policy on wash goods for Spring of next year, embracing three points, was adopted unanimously by 100 dry goods wholesalers, meeting yesterday under the auspices of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

Your issue of today devotes nearly a column to a letter from Luke W. Finlay reciting the circumstances in the case of Senator Rush D. Holt of West Virginia. Mr. Holt was not of the constitutional age of 30 years when he was elected, so he waited until he reached that birthday, presented his credentials, and was admitted to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The administration intends to adhere to its reciprocal trade agreements program, undeterred by attacks in Congress.

Theatrical gleaning this Summer morning reveals but a few kernels, to wit: Eugene Snyder and Harry Losee will direct the dances and ballets for "At Home Abroad," the Shuberts' forthcoming "musical holiday," which is scheduled to go into rehearsals in about ten days.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 17. -- Winners in the 1935 publicity contest were announced. Awards were made to the club obtaining the best editorial in a local newspaper, daily or weekly, and to the State that published the best news publicity story between June 1, 1934, and June 1, 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17. -- A suit brought by a woman to establish the legality of her marriage after her husband died on their wedding night was revealed in Supreme Court today when counsel for Mrs. Clara Goldstein Levin, 48 years old, of 10 St. Andrew's Place, Yonkers, filed a judgment for $101,437 against the estate of her husband.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Reductions of all railroad passenger fares to 2 cents a mile for coach patrons and three cents for Pullman cars, with elimination of the surcharge on Pullman fares, were recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Irving L. Koch, examiner.

PORTSMOUTH, England, July 17. -- Over a steel gray sea and under a dull gray sky King George led his fleet to sea today and watched it in a mimic battle against floating targets and an air attack. In the Channel, the scene of countless English battles against real foes, he left it and returned to London. Tonight he is sleeping peacefully in Buckingham Palace, the final pageant of his year of jubilee ended.

Douglas Fairbanks will produce two pictures a year for release by United Artists, the company announced yesterday. Now in England and soon to travel to Japan, Mr. Fairbanks will return to Hollywood early next year and plans to begin his first picture in February.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Reports of black rust in the Northwest, with some damage indicated in the Eastern Dakotas and in Western Minnesota and increasing reports of disappointing yields of Winter wheat, changed trade sentiment today and sent wheat prices soaring on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Arnold C. Mason, one of two former honor students at Yale University, for whose arrest warrants charging mail fraud were issued two weeks ago, was brought here yesterday from Camp Devens, Mass., where he was serving as a first lieutenant in an R.O.T.C. camp.

The report made by Mr. MCDONALD at London yesterday on two years' work of the commission for German refugees is a calm and concrete document without a sign of heat or color. It is all the more effective for that. The statistical details tell their own story of hardship and heartbreak.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Following further disclosures involving the destruction of messages opposing the abolition of holding companies sent to members of Congress from the Western Union office at Warren, Pa., the Senate committee investigating lobbying on the utility bill announced today that, if necessary, it was going into the records of every telegraph office, big and small, in the United States.

Surrogate Delehanty in a decision yesterday admitted the will of Edward West Browning, real estate operator, which established the Edward W. Browning Foundation for improving the welfare of humanity, with the codicil which cut off his former wife, Dorothy (Peaches) Heenan Browning, and denied probate to a second codicil that bequeathed about $300,000 of his $7,000,000 estate to relatives, hospital attaches and employes.
I Coach Tom Clarke held up a pacifying hand at the height of the bottle-throwing, but he might just as well have been waving to an Astoria trolley on a no-stop corner, or all the influence he had.

With the discussion continuing relating to the scarcity of ducks and unfavorable conditions in nesting areas, More Game Birds Foundation is at present contemplating an extensive survey that would entail an investigation similar to the one conducted in the Summer of 1933.

LONDON, July 17. -- Again it must be recorded that there is a strong feeling in diplomatic circles in London and seemingly echoed from Paris with less positive conviction that the Italo-Ethiopian dispute will be adjusted before actual hostilities begin.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Prices of hogs here were on the upgrade again today. Small receipts here and at other Western markets more than offset the decline of 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents a pound in fresh loins, largely in the East as the result of consumer resistance.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Elmer Danielson, the Western Union messenger who had charge of the stove in the Western Union cellar, was a star witness before the Senate Power Lobby Investigating Committee today.

Determined to enforce a court decree ordering the Hirsam Knit Sportswear Company at Garnerville, near Haverstraw, N.Y., to employ only union workers, in accordance with an agreement with the Knit Goods Workers Union of this city, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers, the joint council of the union announced yesterday that it would make a test of its rights in the situation.

SEATTLE, July 17. -- Large expenditures in peace time for armament were denounced as leading toward war in a report submitted to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs today.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 17. -- Agricultural cooperatives were upheld as the farmer's only safeguard against regimentation, in an address at the American Institute of Cooperation here today by H.E. Babcock of Ithaca, general manager of the G.L.F. Exchange.

LONDON, July 17. -- Cheering and depressing pictures of British life were given to Members of Parliament today in two important reports by public men. Sir Kingsley Wood, the new Minister of Health, in reviewing the country's rapid advance during the King's reign in the war on illness, declared:

A new idea in picketing, consisting in having the whole family of the picket on the line, attracted attention between noon and 2 P.M. yesterday as Herbert Holmstrom, a discharged Interborough Rapid Transit Company painter, paraded up and down before 165 Broadway, where the company has its offices.

The self-styled "Rassari Heshla Tamanya, Falasha Princess of Ethiopia," who issued statements last week predicting that a world war would develop out of the Italian-Ethiopian dispute, is not a first-cousin of Emperor Haile Sellassie I, it developed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Federal deficit and debt got off to a flying start in the first two weeks of the new financial year. The Treasury's July 15 statement today showed the national debt had jumped about $500,000,000 to a new peak at $29,177,786,318.

BERLIN, July 17. -- The North German Lloyd and Hamburg American Lines announced today that they would no longer operate their North Atlantic services, but would place their North Atlantic fleets in the hands of newly created operating companies.

LONDON, July 17 (AP). -- Wilmer Allison and Donald Budge, expected to be the American team's singles representatives in the inter-zone Davis Cup matches with Germany, got in an hour's hard practice against each other on the No. 1 court at Wimbledon today.

Public offering is being made today of a new issue of $70,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1965, of the Duquesne Light Company at a price of 101 1/2. The new issue will replace two issues of 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the company aggregating the same amount.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Mahnkey of Oasis, Mo., has been selected as "the best country newspaper correspondent in the United States," it was announced yesterday by The Country Home, a national farm magazine. Her prize, offered by Wheeler McMillen, editor of the magazine, will comprise a silver trophy, $50 and a trip to New York.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was confined largely to leasing contracts involving private homes on the East and West Sides.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Mahnkey of Oasis, Mo., has been selected as "the best country newspaper correspondent in the United States," it was announced yesterday by The Country Home, a national farm magazine. Her prize, offered by Wheeler McMillen, editor of the magazine, will comprise a silver trophy, $50 and a trip to New York.

A comparative unknown in the East, Edgar Weller of Austin, Texas, registered an upset when he eliminated Charles T. Mattmann of Forest Hills by 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, in the quarter-final round of the Eastern Junior singles tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Yesterday Mr. ROOSEVELT showed again his sensitiveness in the matter of maintaining correct relations with Congress and his rigid abstention from even the appearance of anything that could be construed as an effort or intention of seeking to enforce his will upon a body whose independence he so scrupulously respects.

The broad variety of Fall merchandise placed on display in the past week by manufacturers has attracted the greatest number of wholesale and retail buyers to the local markets since pre-depression days, a survey revealed yesterday.
LONDON, Judy 17. -- The end of James G. McDonald's work as High Commissioner for Refugees Coming from Germany was foreshadowed in the report that Mr. McDonald submitted to his governing body today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- Senator Long was put on notice today by the President that he would have no influence over Federal relief expenditures.
BERLIN, July 17 (AP). -The Reichsbank's statement as of July 15 shows the following changes, in reichsmark:

LONDON, July 17. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, announced in the House of Commons today that he would head the British delegation to the League of Nations Assembly in September, when important matters, including the Abyssinian question, probably will come up.
LONDON, Judy 17. -- The end of James G. McDonald's work as High Commissioner for Refugees Coming from Germany was foreshadowed in the report that Mr. McDonald submitted to his governing body today.
LONDON, July 17. -- The British Labor Ministry ended today the invasion of London by American chorus girls with an order for twenty-six to cease dancing here.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was confined largely to leasing contracts involving private homes on the East and West Sides.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -Historical studies of code administration in twelve industries will be started at once by the NRA's Review Division. The recovery, agency made known at the same time today that five industry sections had been created in the Division of Business Cooperation under the direction of Prentiss L. Coonley.

VAN LEAR, Ky., July 17 (AP). -- Rock and burning coal blocked the path of rescue workers tonight as hope waned for the lives of nine coal miners, entombed about two miles from the mine entrance by a gas explosion.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, was notified yesterday of the approval by the PWA of a $605,000 loan to the city to be used for the repair and alteration of the mechanical plants of nine city hospitals. According to Dr. Goldwater, the repair work at the various hospitals has been needed for many months. The loan will supplement a work relief grant of $495,000 to cover 45 per cent of the cost.

PITTSBURGH, July 17. -- Truth may be stranger than fiction, but the truth about the Dodgers' feats today is a challenge even to that adage. After breaking their sixgame losing streak yesterday they turned on the Pirates today to win both ends of a double-header 5 to 4 and 5 to 0.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Back Log, running for L.E. Komorous, outlasted Thomas Donley's Arson in a spectacular stretch duel today to annex the one-mile top event at Arlington Park by a neck.

PARIS, July 17. -- On the Bourse today the reaction to the government's financial decrees was on the whole extremely favorable. There is apparent confidence that the sacrifices the government has demanded will be accepted by the country.
" Just like a kid," sighed Jimmy Hines as he wearily closed the hole with wire. "Anyway, they can get into trouble and they're sure to find it."

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- The processing tax of the Agricultural Adjustment Act was declared unconstitutional today by Judge William H. Kirkpatrick in Federal District court here in an appeal taken by F.G. Vogt Sons, Inc., pork packers, against collection of $378,127.95 out of a total of about $1,500,000 levied against the company since November, 1933.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that he would not permit taxicab rates to be lowered in the city unless the courts compelled a reduced rate.

RENO, Nev., July 17 (AP). -- Sale of a "large share interest" in the Consolidated Virginia Mining Company at Virginia City, to John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was confirmed here today by Zeb Kendall, president of the company.

LONDON, July 17. -- The Royal Commission, which is Britain's feeble counterpart of the Nye committee in Washington, heard today that British aircraft concerns were helping Germany to rearm in the air.

The approval of Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe of fees and charges amounting to $3,222,315 for services in the receivership, bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings through which the Paramount Publix Corporation has gone since January, 1933, will be sought today by lawyers, receivers, trustees, accountants, banks, stock and bond holders' committees and experts of various sorts.
Apartment houses and a theatre building will be erected in the Bronx as the result of sales of sites yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17. -- In response to the request of Governor Lehman, army engineers will start at once a survey of the flood-stricken territory in Southern New York to ascertain what method of flood control would be best to prevent a recurrence of the floods of last week.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 17. -- Emperor Haile Sellassie in a statement to this correspondent said today that Ethiopia desires the League to discuss her dispute with Italy by July 25, and awaits its decision without taking any diplomatic steps.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- With Clark Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, acting as intermediary, President Roosevelt today received Governor Talmadge of Georgia for a talk about difficulties surrounding the administration of an allotment of $19,000,000 of Federal highway funds to Georgia.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Railroad executives here declined to comment yesterday on the probable influence on earnings of the proposal made by Irving L. Koch, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, for a reduction in railroad passenger fares to 2 cents a mile in coaches and 3 cents in Pullman cars.

A public offering of $53,000,000 of Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund Series A bonds due 1965 is being made today at a price of 103.79 and accrued interest, to yield 3.30 per cent, by the banking syndicate which successfully bid for the issue at a competitive sale.

The rising tide of nationalism now washes over the footlights. The British Labor Ministry has sternly ordered twenty-six American chorus girls employed in London to leave the country. Britons can now breathe easier; another threat to recovery has been scotched.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Senator Borah is 70 years old, though his physical and mental energies are those of a younger man. He comes from a Far Western State with a thimbleful of electoral votes. He is a Republican only during national campaigns or on election day.

BOSTON, July 18. -- Senators Walsh and Coolidge and Massachusetts members of the House at Washington were asked today by M.D. Liming, general secretary of the Boston Chamber of Commerce, to oppose President Roosevelt's new tax measure.

GENEVA, July 18. -- The Ethiopian Legation in Paris has informed the Swiss Government that Ethiopia is ready to adhere to the Red Cross convention of 1929, which provides for humane treatment of sick and wounded soldiers. The Swiss Government has replied that such notice is not enough, adherence to the formal document being required.

Some New Dealers are finding a partisan significance in the decisions of the Federal courts against a few of their measures. They point to the fact that the Circuit Court at Boston decided two to one against the constitutionality of AAA, and that the two judges of the majority were both Republicans.

A dividend of $3 on the first preferred stock on account of accumulated dividends was declared yesterday by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. On June 1 and March 1, this year, similar payments were made. The arrears after this distribution will amount to $10.50.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Wholesale commodity prices rose slightly in the week ended July 13. The composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics standing at 79.2 as compared with 79.1 the preceding week and 74.5 a year ago.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 18 (AP). -- Policemen armed with rifles patrolled the tense West Belfast section today as the Lord Mayor, Sir Crawford McCullagh, made a public appeal to the citizenry to end the rioting that has claimed seven lives here.

Last night I visited Central Park for the purpose of seeing the "sky-dancing" and was enthralled by the wonderful scene -- thousands of young people rhythmically swaying to pleasant music, most of the couples dignified, even elegant, while others more vividly interpreted the livelier tunes, but all of it decorous.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- The Athletics climbed to within three and one-half games of fifth place by defeating the Indians, 7 to 5, in the opening clash of a four-game series today.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Plans for the International Jamboree of Boy Scouts, assembling 30,000 boys here Aug. 21-31, were discussed Over a White House luncheon table today by President Roosevelt and Lord Robert Baden-Powell, founder of the Boy Scout movement.

Carloadings figures for this week, which will be announced next Friday, will start a period in which substantial increases will be shown over the corresponding weeks of last year, according to estimates in some quarters of the transportation field.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 18. -- The downfall of Eddie Driggs Jr., defending champion, and Tommy Goodwin, titleholder in 1932, and the rise of a newcomer, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, were the sensational developments of the opening day's matches in the thirteenth annual New York State amateur championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

PITTSBURGH, July 18. -- Casey Stengel was rubbing his eyes and pinching himself to make sure he was awake as he and his Dodgers entrained for St. Louis tonight. He had just watched the same team that dropped five straight to the Reds win its fourth in a row from the Pirates for a clean sweep here.

GEORGE RUSSELL was so multiplex a personality, he worked with such eagerness, energy, compelling serene intelligence and geniality in so many fields, that he seems almost incredible. It was right that so true a Platonist should be a great citizen as well as a great poet and writer of prose.
VATICAN CITY, July 18 (AP). -- Pope Pius today named Mgr. James B. O'Reilly of New York as Consultor of the Congregation for the Oriental Church.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Recalling that "a statute of long standing provides that no injunction shall be granted to restrain the collection of any tax," Attorney General Cummings stated today that the government would fight all efforts to block collection of processing taxes.

SEATTLE, July 18. -- Denying that the AAA and the farmers of America had used governmental powers to curtail food supplies for the nation's own consumers, Secretary Wallace declared in an address here tonight that agriculture never had adopted a policy of food scarcity.

Luigi Pirandello, Nobel Prize Winner of Literature for 1934, who arrives tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia, will be guest of honor at Sunday's Stadium concert. Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi will represent Mayor La Guardia. The honor guest will be received by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium concerts, and Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman of the Mayor's municipal art committee.

The need for a definition oil "mass picketing" and a definite police policy toward such demonstrations was emphasized by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in West Side Court yesterday as she dismissed charges of disorderly conduct against fifty-two students arrested late Wednesday afternoon for picketing in front of the offices of The American Mercury, 730 Fifth Avenue.

ROME, July 18. -- The authoritative review, Affari Esteri (Foreign Affairs), today said Italy's aims in Ethiopia were absolute control of Ethiopia's military forces and the right to settle Italians in the African empire.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18. -- An unnamed, far-off star, whose surface temperature is 180,000 degrees Fahrenheit, the highest heat ever measured anywhere, was described to the conference on spectroscopy today at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- With sharp competition evident in the investment market, the offering of $100,000,000 of 2 7/8 per cent Treasury bonds, on which bids were opened Wednesday, was subscribed more than five times at virtually the price at which similar bonds of an earlier issue had been quoted on the Stock Exchanges.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- Hurrying home "because Freddie will be furious," Mrs. Helen Wills Moody sailed for home on the George Washington today still undecided whether she will compete in the Wightman Cup matches and national championships at Forest Hills, N.Y., next month.

The share market again moved to a higher closing, with trading on the Stock Exchange reaching 1,495,000 shares yesterday, compared with 1,357,000 the day before, and with a total of 790 issues dealt, the largest number since May 24. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks crossed 100 for the first time since Nov. 7, 1931; on the day, leading industrial issues were up 1 to 2 1/2 points.

PARIS, July 18. -- Steady improvement in all sectors of the Bourse marked the reaction today to the energetic measures taken by the government to reduce expenditure and the cost of living in France. There is apparent confidence that by their severity the government decrees will be sufficient to prevent any necessity for devaluating the franc and will restore public credit.

ROME, July 18. -- Despite reports current abroad that Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General, has already informed member States that the League of Nations Council will take up the Italo-Ethiopian question this month-end, the current opinion here continues emphatically to be that the meeting will be postponed to some later unspecified date.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Mrs. Irving H. Taylor gave a dinner at the Maidstone Club for her daughter, Miss Irene Taylor, and for thirty of the latter's young friends before the weekly junior dance at the club.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18. -- Scoring a 41 on the outgoing nine and coming home in 42 for a total of 83, Mrs. Edward Stevens of the Greenwich Country Club won the low-gross prize in the women's Westchester-Fairfield golf tournament today on her home course.

The promotion being conducted by the Associated Wool Industries will make a particular bid for a greater portion of the Summer trade, particularly in men's clothing, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, stated here yesterday.
There will be a Seawanhaka Cup match off Oyster Bay next September with six-meter sloops. Crown Prince Olaf of Norway is the challenger.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $6,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

LONDON, July 18. -- Securities were quiet and dull today on the London Stock Exchange. British Government stocks weakened slightly after an almost continuous rise of several days. Aviation, motors and armament issues suffered from profit-taking.

An improvement of several years' duration in residential building reasonably may be expected, the rise in recent months apparently having definitely reversed a downtrend which started in 1928, Moody's Investor's Service declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- A barrage of extra base hits that included homers by Chuck Klein, Frank Demaree and Stan Hack gave the Cubs an 11-to-3 victory over the Phillies today and an even break in the four-game series.

Ernest Sturm, chairman of the boards of the America Fore group of insurance companies, made public yesterday business records of the group for the first half of 1935 showing a gain of $16,184,274 in combined assets to $219,708,490, with securities valued at June 30 market levels, and an increase of $16,017,195 in combined net surplus, to $111,972,475.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, withheld an endorsement of Chase Mellen Jr. for re-election as New York County chairman at a testimonial dinner to Mr. Mellen last night. The State chairman criticized Mayor La Guardia for keeping back patronage from the Republicans and allying himself closely with the Roosevelt administration at Washington.
Ten Manhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at forecloslure auctions yesterday. The results were as follows:

NEWPORT, July 18. -- Mrs. Walter Belknap James opened her home, Rockhurst, on Bellevue Avenue tonight for the second in the series of chamber music concerts given under the direction of Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead. As at the first concert a week ago, there was a very large assemblage of members of the Summer colony, a majority of whom were on the list of patrons and patronesses.

Reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York showed a rise of $193,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments for the week ended on Wednesday, according to their weekly statement of condition, published yesterday.

Beneficiaries of the late Percy A. Rockefeller, industrialist and financier, who died Sept. 25, 1934, received $3,124,773 in life insurance, the largest individual amount left by any person who died in 1934, according to an article in the current issue of The National Underwriter.
