Edgar Weller of Austin, Texas, and David Corson, Roselle, N.J., gained the title bracket of the Eastern junior tennis singles championship on the clay courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Central bank advocates in Congress opened fire on the omnibus Banking Bill today, with Senator Nye introducing an amendment to strike out all of Title II and insert his Central Bank Bill as a substitute.

J.D. Tew, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, last night mailed a letter to stockholders indicating that about 74 per cent of the stock had consented to the financing plan of the company. The company's charter requires 75 per cent.
Four men were under arrest yesterday charged with looting the office of the American Optical Company at 215 East 149th Street, the Bronx, early yesterday morning.
BOSTON, July 18 (AP). -- Percy Pike's Ebony Lady, the 5-year-old daughter of Flying Ebony, today captured the Westport Purse, the mile-and-seventy-yard feature at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Morgenthau and Perkins and Harry L. Hopkins on future relief needs, entertained Lord Baden-Powell at luncheon and appointed five Hawaiian judges.

Current reports from two important industries offer a remarkable contrast. Railway freight carloadings for the week ended on July 13 are estimated at about 565,000. This is some 40,000 cars below the figure for the corresponding week last year and some 80,000 below the figure for the same week in 1933.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18. -- Samuel Goldwyn of New York today became the dominating influence in the Pickford-Fairbanks-Chaplin-Selznick United Artists Film combination. For a payment of $250,000 he bought out the half interest in the physical property of United Artists Studio which had formerly been owned by the Joseph Schenck-Darryl Zanuck producing team.

Though their efforts to appear half-frozen in the first and third acts may not have been completely convincing for a mid-July audience, a cast that was about nine-tenths American sang its way into favor at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, with the first of this week's two performances of Puccini's "La Boheme."

BERLIN, July 18. -- Stocks of the Lloyd and Hapag Companies were removed from the list of the Berlin Boerse today, after about 500,000 marks in selling orders had appeared at the opening, only to find no takers. There had been considerable buying of Lloyd and Hapag recently and the condition of each company, as revealed by the necessity of such striking reorganizations as were announced yesterday, came as a surprise to outsiders.

To the views of Maurice Lefcourt and Stephen G. Rich on the attitude of the police of New Jersey toward New York drivers I should like to add those of one who can see, from broad driving experience, both sides of the question.
LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

BERLIN, July 18 (AP). -- Rival New York fight promoters, frenziedly bidding for the services of Max Schmeling, German heavyweight, must wait at least another week before they know for whom he will fight.

A test of the constitutionality of the Brownell Public Enemy Act under which Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco were convicted Wednesday before Magistrate Pearlman, will be delayed as a result of the withdrawal yesterday of writs of habeas corpus sued out before Supreme Court Justice Valente.
An early improvement carried prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday $1 a bale above Wednesday's low levels when the list fell back 15 points and ended with a gain of 1 to a loss of 4 points.

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 18. -- Winning two additional games, first the one scheduled in today's tenth round and then his adjourned match from the ninth, Samuel Reshevsky of New York held his lead in the international tournament of the British Chess, Federation at the Town Hall and will enter tomorrow's final a prime favorite.

A new edifice, estimated to cost $280,000, will be erected by the Church of the Good Shepherd on Broadway near 207th Street, according to plans filed yesterday by Paul Monaghan, architect. The structure will occupy a plot 68 by 192 feet and will consist of a main church and basement, or crypt church.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 18. -- Sharp differences of opinion as to the course the country should pursue in its monetary policy marked the opening of the monetary conference today in connection with the session of the American Institute of Cooperation at Cornell University.
Police Commissioner Valentine addressed a general appeal to lawyers yesterday to bring forward complainants who have been victimized by racketeers.

The Virginia Press Association selected a cruise this year for its forty-seventh annual convention, and 174 of its members, many accompanied by their families, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Robert E. Lee for a two-day sightseeing tour of the city.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 18. -- More than 300 guests of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Cox of Melrose, Mass., arrived today at the Mount Washington for a two-day outing. They attended the opening of the Cave Grill at tonight's supper dance and took part in various sports, riding and mountain climbing, a large dinner and a special cinema showing at the Hall in the Pines.

A tie vote by members of the Board of Education, at a special meeting last night, killed a resolution that would have authorized an appropriation of $10,000 to help maintain the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concerts in the Lewisohn Stadium.

IT appears to me that Somerset Maugham is now convinced -- whether consciously or not -- that nothing except writing is entirely worth writing about. His new book, "Don Fernando" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50), on the surface an informal study of Spain in its Golden Age, is in reality a long essay on the art and practice of writing.

The Annalist Index of Business Activity is 79.1 (preliminary) for June, as compared with 79 for May, 80.6 for April and 83.6 for January, the high for the year to date. On the basis of the amount of time that elapsed during the completion of minor cycles in 1933 and 1934, last month's slight rise should mark the beginning of another substantial upturn.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CINCINNATI, July 18. -- The Giants picked the hottest day of their visit here to play their longest game of the series, but they finally downed the Reds. With the thermometer hovering around 100, the Terrymen went twelve innings before they corralled a decision over Cincinnati, 5 to 3.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses moved yesterday in characteristic fashion to end the caddy strike which has been in effect since Sunday at the Dyker Beach Park golf course in Brooklyn.

Some idea of the progress being made in salvaging trout, following the destrucution caused by storms and floods at the up-State fish hatchery at Bath, was received by State officials at Albany yesterday.

H.M.S. Dundee of the British West Indies Squadron will arrive in New York Harbor today and will receive a twenty-one-gun salute as she passes Governors Island. The guns of Fort Jay will boom the salute in return for a twenty-one-gun salute from the cruiser.

MEXICO, D.F., July 18. -- Five thousand students, accompanied by members of the faculty of the National University of Mexico and headed by the rector, Dr. Fernando Ocaranza, paraded through the principal avenues of the capital this morning as a protest against the killing of three students who recently went to Villa Hermosa in the State of Tabasco to participate in the local elections.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18. -- A bronze tablet bearing the names of the first settlers of Greenwich and twenty-seven of the original landowners was dedicated this afternoon on the memorial site, Maple and East Putnam Avenues, by Anfell Husted Chapter, Daughters of the American Colonists.

In an initial report to the New York Stock Exchange on its reacquired stock holdings, the Marlin-Rockwell Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had purchased 24,900 shares of its stock in the open market. The Kresge Department Stores, Inc., reported the acquisition of 7,095 shares of its preferred stock for retirement.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Prices of wheat receded today on the Chicago Board of Trade under pressure of hedging sales against purchases of cash grain and a small overbought pit condition. Upturns ran into selling orders, with the end at the bottom, at net losses of 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents.

ALBANY, July 18. -- Governor Lehman said today that he has no intention of asking for an apology from the Canadian Government because of an alleged discourtesy last Monday night, when he and members of his party, including State police, went into Ontario to view the illumination of Niagara Falls.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- A nation-wide drive against automobile fatalities, calling for establishment of 15.000 roadside first aid stations throughout the country, is being planned by the Red Cross.

Excessive humidity and temperatures that ranged from a low of 71 degrees to a high of 87 stifled the city's millions yesterday, caused one death in Newark, N.J., and forced hundreds of thousands to flee to the nearby beaches in search of relief. There were two drownings.

IT appears that a couple of modest men are responsible for the pleasant surroundings and the general jollity at the Empire City race track these Summer days. Young James Butler says that General Manager Frank Brady deserves the credit, and Frank Brady passes it all back to young James Butler, with compound interest.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 18. -- The South African government buildings here were invaded today by 400 unemployed men from Johannesburg, headed by Major Frank Roberts, a member of Parliament, who protested against "hunger wages" at State relief works and demanded a minimum wage of 10s daily.

BERLIN, July 18 (AP). -- M.C. Harbeck, American editor of the German edition of the magazine Golden Age, published in Berne, Switzerland, by the International Bible Students Society, was arrested today by Berlin secret police. He was permitted to communicate with the United States Consulate General.

To establish confidence in the cotton textile markets and to prevent hand-to-mouth purchasing as a result of the Hoosac decision against the processing tax, a proposed provision to be incorporated in orders was submitted yesterday by retailers to textile executives.

Quiet strength in United States Government issues was the feature of an otherwise listless day in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Domestic corporation bonds maintained a strong undertone, but with only a few exceptions price changes were confined to small fractions in light trading.

TOKYO, July 18 (AP). -- A new crisis was reached today in negotiations for settlement of border disputes between Manchukuo, Japanese-dominated empire, and Outer Mongolia, Rengo News Agency reported, with the possibility that Manchukuo might demand demilitarization of part of Mongolia.

A new marine terminal covering 257 acres on the southwestern end of Staten Island was dedicated yesterday by the Socony Vacuum Oil Company in the presence of officials of the company and of Staten Island and Brooklyn. The new terminal, which will serve as the central point of the company's marine operations on the Atlantic seaboard, is considered one of the most modern in the world.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18 (AP). -- Troubles piled up today on K.M. James Lin, son of China's President, and his bride, a former clerk in a Columbus dime store.
None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year.
CHICAGO, July 18. -- Underworld executioners, after waiting ten days in ambush, today shot and killed Louis (Two-Gun) Alterie, union head, prohibition gangster, gambler and "dude" rancher.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The influence of the United States in behalf of peace between Italy and Ethiopia was again exerted today under circumstances that clearly meant giving moral support for a projected meeting of the League of Nations Council to consider means for furthering a solution of the crisis and to other peace efforts made in Europe.
In teeming Lewis Street yesterday the Starts still dreamed of the millions left by Uncle Harry Koslak and the whole neighborhood bubbled with the excitement of it.

NEW ORLEANS, July 18. -- Senator Huey P. Long's idea of "democratic government" in new Orleans, where his forces are facing stubborn opposition, is "just about complete," the Senator said today after he had annexed 4,000 Sewerage and Water Board employes to his political machine.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Representatives of the management and of the bondholders of the Western Pacific Railroad will meet in New York tomorrow in another effort to compose their differences over a reorganization plan. Chairman Jones of the RFC announced today.

The change of management of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg American Steamship Lines, which was reported Wednesday night in cable dispatches from Berlin, will not involve a change of ownership, it was announced here yesterday. The ships will continue to sail under the house flags of the two lines and their organization in the United States and Canada will remain unchanged.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The I Latest available information shows1 I that no American lives have been! i lost in the Chinese floods, the State I [ Department was informed in a re-j port dated yesterday from Nelson T. Johnson, Ambassador to China.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Federal Government moved on four fronts today toward helping flood sufferers in up-State New York and Northern Pennsylvania get back to normal and to prevent a recurrence of last week's disaster, which took heavy toll of lives and property.

The Cunard White Star liner Majestic will sail tonight for Channel ports. Lord Robert Baden-Powell, founder of the Boy Scout movement and Chief Scout and Chief Guide of the world, will depart on the liner, accompanied by Lady Baden-Powell and their daughters, Heather and Betty.

In "Europe Groping for a Course," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of July 14, Anne O'Hare McCormick, not once but several times, calls in question the courage of the British Foreign Office in seeking an amicable solution of certain vexed matters now threatening the peace of Europe.

Pedestrians around Times Square at noon yesterday witnessed the start of the final leg of a push-cart trek from Litchfield, Conn., to Washington, D.C., by way of Los Angeles, when Emanuel Jonidas set out along Seventh Avenue to the West Twenty-third Street ferry.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 18 (AP). -- Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Brookline, ranked just below Champion Helen Jacobs in the national tennis list, appeared back on top of her game today when she gained the semi-final round of the women's Essex Country Club's invitation tourney by defeating Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., 9 -- 7, 6 -- 1.
Mayor La Guardia and some 6,000 others among his constituents invaded the Stadium yesterday, doubtless in the hope of getting some relief from the heat.
Virtually nothing is happening in the local theatre these warm days; the few minor nuggets that can be culled from Broadway had best be jet down in the following order:

Retail deliveries made by the United Parcel Service, Inc., increased T per cent for the week ended July 13, it was announced here yesterday. The rise of last week compared with an increase of 28 per cent for the week ended July 6.

Bank clearings for the twenty-two principal cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,863,223,000, against $5,159,827,000 for the corresponding week last year, an increase of 13.6 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MONTREAL, July 18 (Canadian Press). -- Unexpected by airport officials, Thor Solberg, Norwegian-American flier who hopes to fly in easy stages across the Atlantic to Bergen, landed his amphibian biplane at Fairchild Airport late today after a quick trip from New York.

Member bank reserves, which had advanced to a new high level last week, declined $128,000,000 this week, according to the Federal Reserve report as of Wednesday, published yesterday. The decline, it was estimated, reduced the excess of member bank reserves over requirements to about $2,375,000,000, compared with close to $2,500,000,000 last week.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Beaten in efforts to forbid suits for recovery of any illegally collected processing taxes, administration leaders in the Senate on the AAA amendments were forced today to withdraw this drastic proposal and accept a substitute permitting suits for tax refunds where the claimant could prove he had not passed the levies on to the consumer.

The report of the Gillette Safety Razor Company for the first half of this year, including certain foreign subsidiaries for the six months ended May 31, showed a net profit of $2,171,375 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- A national railroad lobby, which "divides up" Congress members among railroads, is using rail officials as "key men" in "lining up" prominent citizens in every county to bring pressure to bear "whenever the lobby chieftains in Washington give the signal," according to statements made to the Senate Lobby Committee by the editor of Labor, organ of the standard railway labor unions.

Vigorous opposition to the proposed new food and drug law sponsored by Senator Royal S. Copeland was expressed yesterday in a telegram sent to Representative Rayburn of Texas, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee of the House of Representatives, by Dr. Norman W. Burritt of Summit, N.J., on behalf of the New Jersey Medical Society.
Can you not see your way to devoting one small paragraph to the efforts of the Tabasco students in fighting the Garrido political machine?

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Bank suspensions have ebbed this year to a mere trickle, leaving government agencies free to concentrate on clearing away the remaining depression wreckage in the banking field.

Captain Albert F. Hegenberger of the United States Army Air Corps won the Collier Trophy for 1935 for "the greatest achievement in aviation in America during the past year," it was disclosed yesterday. The presentation of the trophy is expected to be made by President Roosevelt in Washington next week.

George B. Cortelyou has become a member of the board of directors of D. Appleton-Century Co., taking the place of the late Ira Brainard. Mr. Cortelyou was formerly president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York. Earlier he served as the first secretary of the United States Department of Commerce and Labor, Postmaster General, and Secretary of the Treasury in the Cabinet of President Theodore Roosevelt.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals ran their winning streak to fourteen consecutive victories today, crushing the Braves, 13 to 3. The Red Birds peppered Danny MacFayden and Bob Smith for eighteen hits, including two home runs, in the last of a four-game series.

The French franc rose to a premium above the dollar yesterday as the foreign exchange market, on further consideration of the French Government's economy program, indicated its belief that the drastic measures proposed would strengthen the country's currency.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the sale of a loft building and several apartment houses.

PEIPING, China, Friday, July 19. -- Every additional detail of the Yellow River (Hwang Ho) floods received by the United States Embassy from Tsinan, Shantung Province, gives emphasis to the magnitude of the disaster.

Alfred Otto Wagner, the ex-convict who is accused of sending threatening letters in a number of prominent kidnapping cases, was held in $100,000 bail for trial on July 24 when he was arraigned yesterday before Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Mrs. Marion Firth Geer gave a reception this afternoon at Red Brook, her home on Nyack Road, for Miss Helen N. Trotter, who, with her mother, Mrs. Theodore V.A. Trotter, is passing the Summer at Woodhull House.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Light-weight hogs were in good demand again today with receipts here equaling the smallest arrivals for a Thursday in recent years. At some of the Western markets the offerings were said to be too small to establish quotations on all grades.

After setting the pace for three rounds, Jimmy Hines, professional at the Garden City Country Club, yesterday captured the fourteenth annual open championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing with an aggregate of 297 for the seventy-two hole test.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 18. -- More than 10,000 Republicans from north of the Raritan River came here today to shake hands with Governor Hoffman at his first "Governor's Day" reception of the season at the Summer Executive Mansion here. Some delegations brought bands and drum and bugle corps.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The New York City work-relief program can get under way at once, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced today, in revealing that "at least $40,000,000 was available for WPA projects in New York.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday that the liquidating value of its shares increased from $18.07 on March 31 to $20.42 on June 29. Securities owned, carried at cost of $44,884,856, had a net market value, less reserve for possible taxes, of $48,834,173, indicating an unrealized appreciation of $3,949,317.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- Hazleton Mirkil, 44, a Philadelphia attorney, was found shot to death this afternoon after he had been missing nearly a day.
The police of the East Sixty-seventh Street station revealed last night that they were searching for Dr. Leopold Bernstein, Yorkville steamship agent, on a warrant charging him with grand larceny.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Under cover of a sweeping police edict specifically directed against "political Catholicism," the Hitler government, through General Hermann Goering, head of the Secret State Police, informed the Catholic clergy of Germany today that attacks on the new German State from pulpit or parish house would be dealt with as assaults on the government's authority.

The need for interfaith cooperation in a spiritual as well as economic recovery of the country was emphasized by speakers yesterday at a joint luncheon meeting of the executive committee and the metropolitan committee of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery in the Lawyers Club.

Married women may teach in the London County Council schools; over here we call them public schools. It is not the conquest of a new right but the restoration of a right which the married women lost a dozen years ago.

LOS ANGELES, July 18. -- Scaling down on debt superstructures without currency inflation was urged as a basis for further planned recovery in the annual report of the American Bar Association's committee on commercial law and bankruptcy today.

LONDON, July 18. -- Donald Budge, red-headed Californian who, within a busy month since reaching England, sky-rocketed from comparative obscurity as a singles player to become the ace of the American Davis Cup team, will be entrusted with the opening singles assignment in the interzone matches with Germany starting Saturday.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 18. -- Two Canadian oarsmen sounded warning today to American scullers that the world championship is in danger of going back across the St. Lawrence for the first time since 1927.

District Attorney Dodge issued a statement yesterday on an investigation by one of his aides into the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., at 551 Fifth Avenue, of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is the president.

John H. Shaw, importer and exporter, of 78 Water Street, has been named as Ethiopia's first Consul-General and only diplomatic representative here, it was disclosed yesterday. The State Department in Washington would not comment on the appointment, but it was understood that official announcement awaited only the receipt in Addis Ababa of a communication from this government that the appointment would be acceptable.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18. -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr. played his usual strong game in leading the White polo combination to a 10-to-8 victory over the Blues on Whitney Field today at the Meadow Brook Club.

LONDON, July 18 (Canadian Press). -- Replying to the Gentlemen's first innings of 218 runs, the Players today declared at 251 for nine wickets at the oval. When stumps were drawn at the conclusion of the second day's play, the Gentlemen had scored twenty-seven for two.

The new films opening today are "Shanghai," with Charles Boyer and Loretta Young, at the Paramount; "Don't Bet on Blondes," with Warren William, Claire Dodd and Guy Kibbe, at the Capitol, and "Lady Tubbs," with Alice Brady, Douglas Montgomery, Anita Louise and Alan Mobray, at the Roxy.

A barge and a motor boat carrying 600 cases of Holland alcohol were seized early yesterday off Duck Island, near Saybrook, Conn., after Coast Guard craft had become suspicious of a speedboat which had attempted to reach the barge. After following the speedster in a futile chase on Long Island Sound the Coast Guards returned to the barge and motor boat, which was tied alongside.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Carl Reutershan, 44 years old, a clerk of the East Hampton Board of Education, and a friend, John Grant, 39, were swept out toward the open sea while swimming off a private beach near the Maidstone Club late this afternoon and brought safely to shore after three boats had moved to their rescue.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Mellon chain of banks, controlled by former Secretary of the Treasury Andrew W. Mellon and his family, today attacked the constitutionality of the government's attempt to tax corporation surpluses.

Nathan Straus, president of the Hillside Housing Corporation in the Bronx, was designated by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to report upon municipal housing in European cities which he will visit this Summer.

The commodity future markets continued unsettled yesterday, with gains appearing in coffee, silk and some metals, while other staples pursued a reactionary course. On the cash markets, flour, lard and silk gained, while all the grains and rubber declined.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- An officer of a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company at Ithaca, N.Y., immediately after it became evident that an investigation was coming, ordered destruction of records that bore any relation to the utility holding company legislation, it was brought out today by the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee.

The outsider, the 25-to-1 shot Legionary, upset the form in the featured Irvington Handicap at Empire City yesterday. With B. Wimmer in the saddle, Legionary receded steadily in the betting, but led from start to finish to land the victory by a nose and give Mrs. L.H. Nimkoff her initial score of the meeting.
BERLIN, July 18. -- The apartment house districts in West Berlin showed today that Julius Streicher's Jewish boycott had been at work.

Tenders will be received by Monroe County, N.Y., on Wednesday for an issue of $1,000,000 tax anticipation notes, dated July 15 and maturing Jan. 15, 1936. Bankers are asked to name an interest rate not to exceed 6 per cent.

John Haynes Holmes, who pictured Hitler's sweeping control of Germany and a revival of confidence on the part of the German people in an interview given when he returned from Europe last week, issued a statement yesterday answering many letters of criticism of the attitude he expressed in the interview.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 18. -- At 11:55 this morning a pink silk veil dropped from the Emperor's box in the Parliament House opposite the great palace. Emperor Haile Sellassie, in khaki field uniform, rose from his throne and without further ceremony read his speech, which had been postponed a week because of the diplomatic situation.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- Anthony Eden, Secretary for League Affairs, who will head the British delegation to Geneva when the Italo-Ethiopian dispute is taken up, today assured Geoffrey Le M. Mander of the Liberal Opposition in the House of Commons that Britain would not Join Italy in exerting pressure on Ethiopia but would have "full regard for the rights and obligations of State members of the League during the present negotiations."
A suit growing out of the devaluation of the American dollar when the United States went off the gold standard was decided yesterday in favor of a foreign bondholder.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- An officer of a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company at Ithaca, N.Y., immediately after it became evident that an investigation was coming, ordered destruction of records that bore any relation to the utility holding company legislation, it was brought out today by the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee.

John Haynes Holmes, who pictured Hitler's sweeping control of Germany and a revival of confidence on the part of the German people in an interview given when he returned from Europe last week, issued a statement yesterday answering many letters of criticism of the attitude he expressed in the interview.

A ten-day period, during which the State Liquor Authority again will receive applications for on-premise liquor licenses, will begin on Aug. 1, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the authority, announced yesterday. No new licenses for liquor stores will be received, he said.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18. -- Under the first real breeze of Larchmont race week, a steady southwester which reached 12 knots in strength, 285 craft had a genuine test today. The number just equaled the record one of last Saturday and made 1,101 starters in the four days of the series competition so far.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18. -- Five additional companies today joined the five already in court in the suits now being heard by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake seeking to restrain New Jersey District Collectors of Internal Revenue from collecting processing taxes, under the AAA, on the ground that the tax is unconstitutional.

Trouble that had been brewing all day at a Home Relief station at 285-287 Powell Street, between Sutter and Blake Avenues, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, flared into open warfare shortly after 7 o'clock last evening when seventy-five men and women barricaded themselves in the station, fought it out with fifty policemen and finally were forced to give way before tear gas.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- The projected non-stop flight of a Soviet airplane from Moscow over the North Pole to San Francisco is to begin in strict secrecy, according to orders that became known tonight. The plane and its crew were reported in readiness and waiting only for favorable weather reports to take off.

From time to time an interesting little letter by Ralph N. Taylor appears in this column, lamenting the sad fate of a taxi driver. Mr. Taylor would do right by our forgotten chauffeurs. His method is so simple -- limit the number of cabs.

The half-billion-dollar Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, which operates the largest pipe-line system in the United States, supplying natural gas to the Eastern part of the nation, was named a defendant yesterday in a suit for $180,000,000 filed in Federal court by attorneys for the receivers of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 18. -- Chief Abram W. Skidmore of the Nassau County Police Department approved today the issuance to violators of minor traffic laws illustrated warning cards.
BOSTON, July 18 (AP). -- Only one of the Red Sox reached second base today as Schoolboy Rowe pitched and batted the Tigers to an 8-0 shutout.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- In his article in the periodical Communist International, William Z. Foster, once Communist candidate for President of the United States, said conditions there had finally reached a point where a united workers' party, embracing all industrial workers arid farmers desiring to break with the two major political parties, was an absolute necessity.

LONDON, July 18. -- Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, reviewing Great Britain's trade position in the House of Commons tonight, admitted that he had been wrong when he declared last year that the home market was reaching the saturation point.

TORONTO, July 18 (AP). -- Angel Child, a bay daughter of Guy Richard, owned by Dr. A.O. Taylor of Maysville and driven by Spec Erskin, Dayton, Ohio, set a new Canadian three-heat record today in winning the first division of the Progressive trot, which featured the opening of the Grand Circuit at Thorncliffe Park.

The three Jamaica, Queens, boys who stole a policeman's revolver and then shot a man who refused to be held up by them were sentenced to reformatory terms yesterday by Judge Jacob Panken in Queens Children's Court at Jamaica.

Some of the leading corporation lawyers in New York argued at a hearing before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday in support of claims for fees and disbursements totaling $3,222,315 on account of their own firms, other law firms, trustees, accountants and others in connection with the receivership, bankruptcy and reorganization of the Paramount Pictures Corporation.
BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 18. -- The Aiken Knights moved into the final round of the junior polo championship at the Burnt Mills Club today with a defeat of the Ramblers, 9 to 4.

The Bronx, which in recent weeks has provided the market with many housing deals, was the scene of a business property sale yesterday when the five-story factory and two-story annex at 220 Southern Boulevard, northeast corner of 137th Street, were sold by the Isabelle Realty Corporation, Charles Jacobs, president, to H. Hertzberg Son, Inc., a brush manufacturing concern.

The Prussian Minister-President and Chief of the Secret Political Police, General Goering, in instructions to provincial superior presidents and presidents, has dealt with the negative attitude of certain groups within the body of the Catholic clergy toward National Socialism and its institutions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 18 (AP). -- Disabled American veterans, described by President Roosevelt as "a living example of the sacrifices made by our citizens during the World War," were assured tonight in a message from the Chief Executive that "there never can be any question but that the war disabled should be adequately compensated."

DETROIT, July 18. -- The State's case in the trial of Merton W. Goodrich, confessed murderer of 11-year-old Lillian Gallaher, was completed today. Tomorrow Goodrich will take the stand to defend himself.

Ichthyological and invertebrate circles here were thrown into a state of considerable excitement yesterday when the news leaked out that an octopus was in town. It arrived Wednesday by boat from Key West and is now recuperating from its trip north in a glass tank in the showrooms of the Aquarium Stock Company, 66 West Broadway.

TOKYO, Friday, July 19. -- Inspired articles in the newspapers accuse Ambassador Yotaro Sugimura of having exceeded his instructions when he informed Premier Benito Mussolini that Japan was not interested in the political aspects of the Ethiopian question and would not interfere in any circumstances.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- After a partisan wrangle over the merits of the New Deal, the House adopted today by a vote of 258 to 88 the administration bill prohibiting suits against the government for damages growing out of abrogation of gold clauses in contracts. The action was taken in connection with devaluation of the dollar.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Louisiana will not take part in the new PWA program, and funds for projects already undertaken in that State have been cut off, Secretary Ickes announced today.

After a prolonged executive session in which Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, was reported to have threatened to quit if the budget he sought for his inquiry into rackets in New York County were reduced, the Board of Estimate in a brief open meeting yesterday appropriated $122,000 to finance the investigation from July 29 to the close of the year.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 18. -- A promising seabass and lobster fishing season ended disastrously today on the eastern end of Long Island as a blight of oil, leaking from eleven tanks in the hull of the Sun Oil tanker Raritan Sun, aground on the rocks 200 yards off shore between Montauk Point and the Ditch Plains Coast Guard Station, spread a sheen over the neighboring waters.

To the full-throated cheers of the 5,000 fans who packed every available inch of space at the Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, yesterday, an 11-year-old diving wonder became the women's senior national A.A.U. diving champion.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- The task of the forthcoming congress of the Communist International will be to enlist the world proletariat into active behind-the-line allies of the Red Army in the event of an expected war, it was announced authoritatively here today in the Communist International, the organ of the executive committee of the Comintern.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- A tale of huge spending to promote business with the War Department and of attempts to sell army equipment to Ethiopia was unfolded today before the House Military Committee.
PARIS, July 18. -- The reception of Premier Pierre Laval's decree laws for defense of the franc has been generally favorable in financial circles and in all political circles but the extreme Left.
PARIS, July 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Study of relief demands in prospect a year hence was ordered by President Roosevelt today as the first step in drafting the Federal Budget for the financial year beginning July 1, 1936.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Congressional movement to tax corporations' excess profits instead of their incomes today attained swelling proportions.

CHESTER, Pa., July 19. -- Four bandits, disguised with colored glasses and hankerchiefs, held up a branch of the Delaware County National Bank at Third Street and Highland Avenue, here, today and escaped with $48,000 in paper currency, $25,000 of which was the weekly payroll of the Philadelphia Electric Company in this place. Left in plain sight on the bank trays was $15,000 in silver coins.

TORONTO, July 19 (Canadian Press). -- A new Canadian record over a mile track was set today as Jack Orr, pacer owned by G. White, Lexington, Ky., and driven by Tom Berry, won the feature event of the Grand Circuit racing at Thorncliffe Park.

PARIS, July 19. -- The Travelers Bank, an American institution, which closed its doors without explanation Thursday, remained closed today. The same notice, saying the bank would be reopened "tomorrow," hung there all day.

Important researches in the effects of various foods on epilepsy being carried on at the New York State Psychiatric Institute, 168th Street and Haven Avenue, were stopped yesterday because the neighbors complained about barking dogs.

Richard Young, former Representative in Congress and member of the Board of Education, known as the "Grand Old Man of Flatbush," left more than $60,000 to employes of his leather company and bequeathed more than $200,000 in specific legacies to relatives, friends and charities, it was disclosed yesterday.
John Longobardo, the "cat burglar," was arrested for the seventh time yesterday after robbing a Bronx home while out of jail on parole.

RENO, Nev., July 19 (AP). -- Mining fever ran high in Nevada again today. Hopes for a revival of activity were stirred by plans of John J. Raskob and others to operate the once fabulously rich gold and silver properties in the historic Comstock Lode.

PARIS, July 19. -- Solid ranks of the Mobile Guard, with rifles slung across their shoulders, closed every entrance to the Place de l'Opera this evening from 5:30 until after 8 o'clock to prevent objectors to Premier Pierre Laval's salary cuts from assembling and holding a demonstration they had threatened.
SAVANNAH, Ga., July 19. -- A number of men interested in the cotton business were called into session today by the ringing of the "first bale hell" at the Savannah Cotton Exchange.
PARIS, July 19 (AP). -- An overdose of narcotics, taken in her jail cell, ended today the spectacular financial career of Mrs. Marthe Hanau, "financial wizard" of Paris.

LONDON, July 19. -- The Parliamentary Labor Opposition will move another vote of censure against the government next Tuesday in connection with debate on the depressed industrial areas of Northern England and Wales.

TOKYO, July 19. -- Ambassador Giacinto Auriti of Italy called on Foreign Minister Koki Hirota today to request more information on Japan's stand regarding Italy's dispute with Ethiopia. According to the press, Mr. Hirota said that Japan had commercial but not political interests in Ethiopia.

The National City Bank yesterday bought in for $2,174,115 the greater part of the collateral it received to secure an indirect loan of $5,000,000 to Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, one of the Insull group of companies, at a public auction held in Jersey City shortly afternoon.

ALBANY, July 19. -- Governor Lehman urged all financial institutions in the State today to cooperate with the State aides of the Federal Housing Administration, especially in the area where floods have destroyed property.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., July 19. -After placing seventh in the first race at Cedar Lake Park today Miss Uhleen Volo, owned by J.R. Sullivan of Whitneyville, Me., and driven by Bill Crozier, won the third trot and paid $167.40 for a $2 ticket. Mary Volo Hanover, owned by Thomas Ashworth, paid $47.60 to show in the first race.
A bull whose ride to the slaughter house had become irksome broke loose on Delancey Street yesterday and for twenty minutes scattered a deal of fright among the pushcart peddlers of the neighborhood.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The State Mortgage Commission has created a division of research to study all phases of the mortgage situation and necessary remedial legislation. Maurice Finkelstein, a member of the commission staff, has been named director of the division, with LeRoy B. Iserman as counsel.

Edward Corsi, director of the Home Relief Division, was appointed Second Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner. Coincidentally, Miss Charlotte Carr, assistant to Mr. Corsi in the Home Relief Bureau, was appointed to succeed him by Oswald K. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau. Mr. Corsi and Miss Carr will assume their new duties on Monday.

SHERMAN, Texas, July 19. -- Judge Randolph Bryant of the Federal District Court granted a temporary restraining order today against the collection of the cotton processing tax levied against cotton gins.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -Behind the five-hit pitching of Vernon Kennedy the White Sox today collected thirteen hits to defeat the Senators, 7 to 2. The attack was featured by a two-run barrage in the seventh.

While a group of several patrolmen was approaching four robbers held up the occupant of an automobile parked at Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and escaped with jewelry valued at nearly $10,000.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- President Roosevelt urged adoption of provisions in AAA amendments denying the right to sue for return of taxes already collected, and took issue with Senator Borah on the right to sue the government.

To a chorus of approval from hundreds of throats, Harvey and William Mandell, curly-haired twin sons of an unemployed war veteran, were elected yesterday as the champion babies of the lower East Side. They scored their triumph by popular acclaim, on the roof of the Educational Alliance, in the twentieth annual baby beauty contest under those auspices.

New bond financing this week amounted to $234,148,000, of which $195,000,000 represented corporation issues. Except for the weeks when large offerings of Federal Land Bank bonds were made, the week was the most active since that ended on April 10, 1931, when new bonds in the amount of $296,275,000 were marketed, of which $241,440,000 were corporate issues.
CHICAGO, July 19. -- Before a ladies' day gathering of 26,700 today at Wrigley Field, Lon Warneke avenged some of the indignities the Giants have heaped upon him this season, Chicago winning, 9 to 3.

LONDON, July 19. -- Addressing the Association of Foreign Correspondents who entertained him at luncheon at the Hotel Savoy yesterday, Sir Samuel Hoare, Foreign Secretary, outlined his personal policy as he had maintained it in the India Office and as he intended to carry it out at the Foreign Office.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 19. -- Ray Billows, 21-year-old shipping clerk in a Poughkeepsie printing establishment, and Jack Creavy, 19-year-old ex-caddie who recently won the State junior title, will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the thirteenth annual New York State amateur golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

DETROIT, Mich., July 19. -- Soon after court opened today, Merton Ward Goodrich pleaded guilty to the murder of 11-year-old Lillian Gallaher and was immediately sentenced to life imprisonment at Marquette. The sentence was imposed by Judge Henry S. Sweeny in Recorder's Court.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The detailed Senate vote on the compromise amendment to the AAA bill was as follows:

GREAT YARMOUTH, England, July 19. -- Winning his tenth game in the eleventh and final round of the international tournament at the annual congress of the British Chess Federation, which has been in progress at the Town Hall since July 8, Samuel Reshevsky of New York today captured the first prize, adding to the international laurels he gained at Syracuse and Margate, where he also took the highest honors.

The report of United Founders Corporation for the six months ended on May 31 shows a net write-down of $53,634,643 of holdings in subsidiary companies, charged to surplus; a write-down of miscellaneous holdings, including holdings in affiliates, of $9,098,832, also charged to surplus; a write-down of miscellaneous securities of $62,430,702, charged to investment reserve accounts, and charging to that account of $4,407,626 net losses on sales of securities during the period.

Respite from the heat wave in which New York had sweltered for three days came just before 9 o'clock last night when a severe thunderstorm swept over the city, dropping the temperature 7 degrees in less than half an hour.

Sixty-nine men and women school-teachers from Germany, most coming from Saxony, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin. They are all members of the National Association of Teachers and none has been to the United States before.

TRENTON, July 19. -- In contrast with a national tendency toward population stabilization, New Jersey is maintaining, and is likely to continue to maintain for a number of years, a larger increase in population than the country as a whole.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Marked benefits to commerce between the United States and Cuba have resulted from the reciprocal trade agreement that has been in effect since Sept. 3, according to a report by the American Chamber of Commerce of Cuba, based on a canvass of its members.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Requirements for filing on Form A-2 used by seasoned corporations for registration of issues under the Securities Act of 1933 was further modified today by the Securities and Exchange Commission so that subsidiaries which are not of material significance to the total enterprise represented by the registrant need not be named.
CINCINNATI, July 19 (AP). -Young Emmett Nelson pitched the Reds to a 3-to-0 shutout over the Phillies today.

Here, it appears, are the toothmarks of a man in the hide of a dog! While other less formidable resorts are attracting attention to themselves by billing ambitious debutantes, society matrons and caroling blue-bloods as stars of their entertainment, it has remained for the Rockefeller Rainbow Room, the top-hattest spot of them all, to make a gesture toward Cinderella! . . .

GREENWICH, Conn., July 19. -More than 400 members of the younger set from Greenwich, Rye, Stamford and other near-by places attended a junior dance at the Greenwich Country Club this evening. A buffet supper was served.

Influenced by hundreds of complaints made to them by bus riders, the Transit Commission and the Board of Health have renewed their efforts to reduce to a minimum the emission of noxious and annoying fumes from buses operating in the streets under city franchises.

Luscious red apples growing in the city dweller's own back yard is more than a possibility for the near future, if the horticultural success of the Better Homes in America movement in New York City becomes widespread. About three dozen apples -- still small, green and sour -- have made their appearance on four trees standing in the garden of America's Little House at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Indications that the administration Tax Bill may contain a tax on excess corporate profits instead of the graduated levy by President Roosevelt were seen today when Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee intimated that his colleagues, who will start writing the bill Tuesday, appeared to favor such a change.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, July 19 (AP). -- Violence from the Omaha street-car strike dispute crossed the Missouri River today and brought injury to five persons here.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The application of Eastern railroads to reduce freight rates in the Eastern territory to meet competition of truck and water carriers was denied by the Interstate Commerce Commission today for the second time within a year.

Having followed the case of Senator Holt fairly closely, I could hardly be as unaware of the case of Henry Clay as Mr. Thompson assumes in his letter of July 16. From the beginning the supporters of Senator Holt have stressed to the utmost Clay's admission to the Senate at the age of 29 years 8 months.

The fourth annual Summer school for church workers under the auspices of the United Lutheran Synod of New York will be held as in previous years, at Silver Bay, Lake George, N.Y., beginning today and continuing trough Friday. The director will-be the Rev. Paul C. White of this city, secretary for religious education of the Synod.

Fairly good shopping weather this week brought sales in local department stores up to a point equal to or slightly ahead of those of the corresponding week of last year, retail executives reported here yesterday. Specials and lower-price goods received chief interest from the public.

A reactionary trend predominated in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Sales amounted to $9,203,100, compared with $9,361,200 on the previous day. Domestic corporate issues of the more speculative class proved particularly vulnerable to the selling pressure, with some good-sized declines scored among the second-grade rail liens and the more sensitive utility issues.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 20 (AP). -- Between 180 and 200 warships, almost the entire fighting strength of the Japanese Navy, mobilized today in the southern bays and harbors of Japan for annual manoeuvres.

GULFPORT, Miss., July 19 (AP). -- Walter Wedell, brother of James Wedell, New Orleans speed pilot, and his passenger, Howard L. Sanders, 22-year-old traveler from Anderson, S.C., were killed today when Wedell's plane fell into the Gulf of Mexico thirty miles out from Gulfport.

Weakness persisted in the commodity futures markets yesterday, with the exception of sugar and metals, and trading generally was restricted in volume. On the cash markets lard, tin and silk made new highs and wheat also advanced.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- New York County (Manhattan Island) had only one farm of record on Jan 1, according to the farm enumeration of the Census Bureau.

MOSCOW, July 19. -- The Anglo-American Institute of Moscow University was dissolved today just as more than 200 teachers, students and sociologically minded travelers arrived here to begin their Summer course.

LONDON, July 19 (AP). -- Many observers said today that, while the Ethiopian terrain was decidedly rough in many places, it would not hamper greatly a modern invading army. They pointed out, for one thing, that the Ethiopians had almost completely deforested their country for kindling wood.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- While President Roosevelt was asserting today the right of the government to bar suits against itself, Senate Democrats voted nearly two to one to allow citizens access to the courts for suits to recover illegally collected processing taxes on agricultural commodities where they could prove conclusively that the tax had not been passed on either to the consumer or the farmer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 19. -- Representative Wright Patman, Bonus Bill author, assured three thousand cheering members of the Disabled American Veterans Association at their annual convention here today that before Congress adjourns another chance will be given to its members to vote on the bonus question.

More than eighty airplanes are entered for the fourth annual goodwill cruise today from Roosevelt Field to Montreal. Led by Major Alford J. (Al) William, flight commander, they will leave in the reverse order of speed, beginning at 9 A.M.

Flashing marked superiority for the greater part of the match, Edgar Weller of Austin, Texas, completed his first quest for the Eastern junior tennis singles championship in successful fashion yesterday on the clay courts at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

Reports that a settlement had been made on a line of 30,000 bales of July cotton in Liverpool unsettled trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. Efforts of a foreign short interest to extricate itself from a squeeze in near months, resulting from government control of virtually the entire domestic supply, had carried the July in Liverpool to 191 points above New York.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Bullish talk from the Winter and Spring wheat belts continues to be received here in volume, but in the face of what some traders regard as sensational reports of damage there is little or no evidence of expanding outside interest.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 19. -About 300 persons from Huntington, Cold Spring Harbor, Northport, Greenlawn, Centerport, Halesito, Oyster Bay and other North Shore communities attended the annual benefit bridge and dance given by the ladies auxiliary of the Huntington Hospital at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club this evening.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 19. -Mrs. Ryle Smith, who has the Dippel cottage on Meadow Way this season, gave a dinner for thirty tonight at the Maidstone Club. It was followed by bridge.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Any program for work relief, to follow the present $4,000,000,000 plan, will depend on data on the situation to be supplied by December, President Roosevelt said at a press conference today. The data will be used for his message to Congress Jan. 3, the President said, and the problem of getting such information was discussed at a White House meeting yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 19. -- Formulation of a program to guide the future destinies of the Baltimore Transit Company began here today as stockholders, voting by proxy through the voting-trust committee, elected a new board of directors.
LONDON, July 19. -- The fatalistic spirit pervading Ethiopia was described today by a high Ethiopian official who recently revisited his country.

Robert B. Roberts asks in a recent letter to THE TIMES: "Is it not possible to celebrate the Fourth without endangering lives? It's a long time since 1776, but did the Colonials of that period celebrate in such fashion? If not, why do we?"
LONDON, July 19 (Canadian Press). -Aided by splendid bowling, The Players defeated The Gentlemen by nine wickets in the three-day cricket fixture concluded today at the Oval.

The Roxy Theatre realized a net operating profit of $130,519 for the year ending June 13, 1935, as against a loss of $59,341 for the same period last year, Howard S. Cullman, trustee of the Roxy, announced yesterday in a report which will be filed with Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

That the Government should try to shut out from the courts citizens who seek to recover taxes paid and damages incurred under a law declared invalid by the Supreme Court would have seemed incredible before the Age of Devalued Gold. Even now, when stomachs have grown far less delicate, it is too strong meat for the Senate.

On Washington Heights, the Gerard Development Corporation, represented by William L. Rosan, attorney, bought from the Morris Avenue Building Corporation the five-story building containing sixty-three apartments at 10-22 Fairview Avenue. The apartment has a frontage of 163 feet and was bought for all cash over a first mortgage of $172,000.

BUENOS AIRES, July 19. -- The Interior Ministry published today a decree signed by President Agustin P. Justo putting all newspaper correspondents and news agencies under heavy cash bonds and providing for strict control of all outgoing news by the Postoffice Department.

The rebound of industrial operations easily took precedence over all other occurrences in business this week, particularly because of the broadness of the increase when compared with the showing of a year ago, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The investment demand for stocks offset rather well yesterday the disposition of the market's professional following to claim profits. Failure of the share market to pursue its advance might be explained away on technical grounds. At any rate, stocks moved irregularly, closing steady and slightly lower.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The bulk sale provisions of the Federal Alcohol Administration Bill as reported out by the House Ways and Means Committee would force retail liquor stores out of business, officials of the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, Inc., here to fight the measure, declared today.
Would it not have a real educational value for the press to explain what part of big corporation salaries go to government and what part finally accrues to the person?

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Commenting on lobbying activities ascribed to the Association of American Railroads by Labor, organ of the standard railway unions, John J. Pelley, president of the association, declared today that formation of committees in the several States to present to the public and public officials the facts concerning the carriera was "altogether legitimate."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 19. -- The 325 members of a party entertained this week by Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Cox at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, filled the day with outdoor sports, a large group visiting the summit of Mount Washington, taking picnic luncheons.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 19. -Mrs. Henry White led with forty-nine prizes in the competitive classes at the Lenox Horticultural Society Flower Show, judging in which was completed today. Of these, thirty-one were firsts. Harris Fahnestock was second, taking thirty-one prizes, of which fourteen were firsts.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Senate action today in refusing to close the doors of the courts to all suits against the government to recover illegally collected processing taxes on agricultural commodities has raised a question as to the fate of President Roosevelt's measure, to bar gold clause suits.

The seafood, fruit and vegetable markets vied with each other in record-breaking 'receipts and cheaper prices yesterday, according to the City's Consumers' Food Guide, which is conducted under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 19. -- The irascibility of Russian newspapers over alleged military cooperation between Finland and Germany in connection with German naval armaments has led to new unrestrained attacks on Finnish foreign policy, which it is asserted, is aiming at territorial gains at the Soviet's expense.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 19. -- Licensing, allotment and processing tax provisions of the Agricultural Adjustment Act were held unconstitutional by Federal District Judge T.M. Kennerly in an opinion filed today in Brownsville. The court denied the Secretary of Agriculture an injunction to restrain a company from shipping citrus fruit.

Police Commissioner Valentine assigned John A. Lyons, Acting Deputy Chief Inspector, yesterday to head the department detail which will assist Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, in the forthcoming New York County racket investigation.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 19. -- Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School and Spring Lake and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange head a field of sixteen teams that will start tomorrow in the annual invitation doubles tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

The metropolitan district scored notable victory in the women's National A.A.U. swimming and diving championships at Oriental Pool, Alanhattan Beach, yesterday when Miss Elizabeth and Miss Erna Kompa stars of the Women's Swimming Association, finished one, two in the final of the 220-yard back stroke.

LONDON, July 19. -- Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, the Air Secretary, in a brief answer in the House of Commons yesterday did much to discount the evidence given recently before the British Arms Commission favoring national as against private arms factories.

MOSCOW, July 19. -- The secrecy that has thus far surrounded preparations for the flight of a Soviet airplane over the North Pole to San Francisco was relaxed just enough today to permit the giving of an unofficial opinion at the offices of the Northern Sea Route Administration that weather conditions made the flight unlikely for several days.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- A new batch of applications from over-the-counter securities dealers for registration with the SEC was made public today. Those from New York City follow (Symbols -- S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation):
PARIS, July 19. -- Crowds jammed into a mile-square area around the Place de l'Opera fought with policemen and Mobile Guards tonight.

Great hopes were raised when the new administration took the helm in Washington, and in several ways something has unquestionably been accomplished. I dismiss without hesitation a considerable part of the criticism and reaction which naturally must set in among a broad class of our suffering citizens, who still find themselves standing outside the promised paradise.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- A proposal to call a general strike of hosiery workers throughout the country on Sept. 1 was voted down this evening at the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers after more than eight hours of discussion.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 19. -- Primitive communications systems today carried to Ethiopia's furthest reaches Emperor Haile Sellassie's ringing defiance of Italy, stirring the nation to grim determination to defend its independence.

The Leder Tavern of 184 Third Avenue, described by the police as the headquarters of Cockeyed Louis Weiner, recently sentenced to five to ten years in Sing Sing for compulsory prostitution, lost yesterday an application to Supreme Court Justice Valentine to compel Police Commissioner Valentine to remove a patrolman who has been stationed in front of the place since last July.

BERLIN, July 19. -- Count Wolf von Helldorf, radical Nazi, violent anti-Semite and until late in March, 1933, the fighting leader of the Berlin Storm Troopers, who became famous for his mass arrests on the night of the Reichstag fire, was appointed Police President of Berlin today after a conference at which Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, presided.

Mayor F.H. La Guardia vigorously defended the New Deal at a luncheon of the Virginia Press Association in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday afternoon, after it-had been criticized by Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, editor of The News-Leader, Richmond, Va.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 19 (AP). -- Injuries were suffered by fifty-three persons in a brief but fierce hand-to-hand battle today between strikers and non-strikers at the Morrell Packing Plant.

Beside a well-kept grave at the edge of 'a winding road, bordered by tall, ancient trees, a score of men met late yesterday afternoon in Woodlawn Cemetery to pay tribute once again 2o John Purroy ! Mitchel, their friend and former political associate, and to remind New York City that Mayor Mitcho el's ideals of public service had set a high standard for all city officials .to observe.

Overcoming a number of serious obstacles, not the least of these being some rather inept pitching by the distinguished Vernon Gomez and the ponderous Walter Brown, who succeeded him, the Yankees managed to draw even with the Browns in the second engagement of the current series at the Stadium yesterday.

The present ordinance says that the "maximum" rates of fare for taxicabs shall be 20 cents for the first quarter of a mile and 5 cents for each succeeding quarter of a mile. So Mayor LA GUARDIA may run into difficulties when he tries to prevent cutthroat operators from seeking a lower rate. But he is right in principle.

Begun under difficulties, with gusts of wind blowing music from the stands of the orchestral players and with the scenery threatening more serious consequences on the stage, last night's repetition of Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Stadium had to be called off after about twenty minutes of the first act.

BERLIN, July 19. -- Adolf Hitler's Nazis struck at "reactionary" opposition on three fronts today. Jews, Catholic and Protestant churchmen and members of the Stahlhelm veterans' organization simultaneously felt the weight of Nazi wrath, with concentration camps, confiscation of property and threats of imprisonment the methods employed.

GENEVA, July 19. -- The League of Nations Secretariat issued a brief communique today making clear that a decision to hold the first Council meeting on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, as provided in its May 25 resolution, will not be taken definitely until the time limit expires on July 25.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Beginning Aug. 1, workers in Rexford G. Tugwell's rural resettlement administration, an important part of the work relief program, will do their chores in the luxury of the $3,000,000 McLean mansion on Massachusetts Avenue, it became known today.
SYRACUSE, July 19 (AP). -- In a thrilling ninth-inning comeback, the Chiefs again snatched victory from Newark tonight, 9 to 8, beating Ted Kleinhans, the league's leading pitcher.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP). -- The United Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions has cabled to the Emperor of Ethiopia a message conveying expressions of sympathy and confidence, in response to one from the Emperor through Fred L. Russell, senior representative of the board in Ethiopia, requesting "earnest prayers in this crisis."

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 19. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia won the Griswold Cup for the seventh time when she defeated Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., today, 5 and 4, in the final of the seventeenth annual Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournament.
When Giuseppe Lupo, a plasterer who came here from Italy fourteen years ago, was arrested on July 11, he told a plausible story to account for his possession of three counterfeit 50-cent pieces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 19. -- The Court of Appeals has reversed the Appellate Division which upheld a decision of Surrogate George A. Slater of Westchester County, who held that the two nephews of the late William H. Nelson of Mount Kisco, retired New York dairyman and trotting horse fancier, were not entitled to a share in the $600,000 Nelson estate, it was reported here today.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES dispatch on July 15, your Moscow correspondent. Harold Denny, states that the Soviet practice now is to buy machines from foreign countries, not in quantities but merely to serve as models. The Soviet copies them, without paying royalties because it does not have a patent convention with the United States.

ST. LOUIS, July 19. -- A pair of winning streaks met head-on today, and the more impressive one, owned by the world champion Cardinals, was shattered by the extraordinary Dodgers, who pay no attention to form or favorites.
Social agencies and people contributing to them must keep in mind not only those children who can be sent away to camps but also the much larger number who must remain in town.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- President Roosevelt's press conference, in the absence of news today, developed into a general conversation while 100 reporters lingered to laugh at the President's jokes and enjoy the White House cooling system.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

ATHENS, July 19. -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris's attempt to maintain himself as a neutral arbiter in the restoration plebiscite and to protect republican members of the Cabinet from the determination of General George Kondylis, Vice Premier and Minister of War, to make the government wholly monarchist before the plebiscite failed today under an attack of royalists, visibly strengthened by General Kondylis's return today from his Italian and Yugoslav visits.

LONDON, July 19. -- For the eighth time since the tennis musketeers of France claimed the Davis Cup at Germantown, Pa., in 1927, America's cup representatives rested their racquets tonight only two deep trenches removed from their ultimate goal -- regaining the emblem of world tennis supremacy.

For the first half of the year the William Wrigley Jr. Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $3,797,452, after depreciation, estimated Federal taxes ad other charges. The earnings equal $1.94 a share on 1,953,041 no-par shares of capital stock outstanding at the close of 1934, excluding shares held in the treasury.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 19 (AP). -- With a United States Wightman Cup team berth as one of the prizes, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Brookline and Mrs. Ethel Burkhart Arnold of Los Angeles will meet in the final of the Essex County Club's invitation tennis tournament tomorrow.

The striking caddies at the Dyker Beach Park golf course in Brooklyn "called" Park Commissioner Robert Moses's hand yesterday and found out that he was not bluffing. What started out Sunday as a strike for better pay has now apparently developed into a lock-out.

" SOS to the Rescue," by Karl Baarslag, a radio operator's inside story of the part played by radio in disasters at sea, published by the Oxford University Press, is to be issued shortly in Braille by the Clovernook Printing House for the Blind, Mount Healthy, Ohio.

The famous astronomer Sir NORMAN LOCKYER tells of meeting, when on a scientific mission in the Rocky Mountains, a French abbe, whose presence there gave him surprise. The abbe in explanation said that a few months before, being very ill and, as he thought, "already in the arms of the Bon Dieu," he was asked how he liked the beautiful world he had just left.

SEATTLE, July 19 (AP). -- The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs tonight elected Miss Charl O. Williams of Washington, D.C., president over Mrs. MacDonald Bowman, who was nominated for a third term, but did not seek reelection.

ITHACA, N. Y., July 19. -- The battle over the "gold dollar" versus the "commodity dollar" at the two-day conference on monetary policies in connection with the American Institute of Cooperation at Cornell University ended today with advocates of the two schools of thought each presenting additional arguments to bolster their causes.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- AAA officials were reluctant to comment on Judge Bryant's decision granting an injunction to a Texas ginner against collection of taxes under the Bankhead Cotton Act, before having read the decision in detail.

Savage lions will be thrown into the fray against the Italians by Ethiopia's fiercest warriors, the Galla tribesmen. Such, at least, is the report which has reached Istanbul. The lion is the national symbol of Ethiopia and its paws are presumably impervious to the burning chemicals with which Italy is planning to make the soil of Abyssinia too hot for the native barefoot warriors.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 19. -The Texas poloists rode into the final of the junior championship today at the Burnt Mills Club. They earned the right to face the Alken Knights Sunday for the crown by the slim margin of a single goal.

MOSCOW, July 19. -- Indications that the Soviet Union will endeavor to use the recently signed trade agreement with the United States as an entering wedge to get large bank credits there is given in an article on Soviet-American trade prospects in Economic Life, the journal of the Commissariat of Finance.

No doubt the League for Less Noise is doing good work, but a city ordinance would have the power to stop this nerve-racking, unnecessary nuisance by imposing a fine on using screeching, honking horns.

Washington dispatches report that the Ways and Means Committee is considering an excess profits tax as a possible substitute for the graduated corporation income tax proposed by President ROOSEVELT. Such a tax was levied during the war and the immediate post-war period, from 1917 to 1921.

Several diplomats are among the passengers on the French liner Ile de France, leaving today for Havre via Plymouth. The list includes Marc Peter, Swiss Minister to the United States; Justo Garrido, Spanish Minister to China, with Mrs. Garrido; Roger Gaucheron, First Secretary to the French Embassy in Washington, and J. Rosenthal, counselor to the Rumanian Legation in Washington.

PLATTSBURG BARRACKS, N.Y., July 19. -- The thrill that comes but once in a lifetime was experienced today by the 1,200 candidates attending this Summer's C.M.T.C. here, when they marched to Brown's farm, four miles southwest of Plattsburg, for their overnight bivouac, in a torrential downpour, accompanied by thunder and lightning.
From Bimini Island in the Bahamas, a short way off the Florida coast, comes another tale of big game fishing.

LONDON, July 19. -- Asserting the government had apparently given up all hope of preventing war or of putting an end to bombing of civilian populations by international agreement, the British Labor party tonight issued a manifesto stigmatizing the newly proposed measures for defense against air attack as "costly, ineffectual and alarmist" and "likely to create a general spirit of panic and war-mindedness which would be disastrous."

It was confidently said of Mr. DEWEY, before he was appointed special prosecutor, that if he were chosen he would make a thorough job of it. It was also claimed for him that "He knows his way about." By this was meant that he understood the intricacy of the relations between certain criminal activities and their protection by men with political influence.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- All written evidence bearing on the activities of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its numerous subsidiary units in twenty-six States against the "death-sentence" clause in the Utility Holding Company Bill was ordered destroyed when it became evident that a Senate investigation was certain.

BERLIN, July 19. -- The Boerse collapsed into total inactivity today under the influence of announcements by the Hapag and Lloyd Companies of drastic reductions in capital being planned. Both Hapag and Lloyd shares were quoted only on a limited cash market and they were rationed.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 19. -- Charles Campbell of the Argonaut Rowing Club of Toronto came up to expectations today by winning the single sculls championship of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at the sixty-third annual regatta on Lake Carnegie.

While ten policemen and a sergeant guarded the Home Relief Station at 285 Powell Street, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn against a repetition of the outbreak of the unemployed that occurred on Thursday evening, the Single Unemployed Protective League sent a delegation of twelve members to present demands for more relief to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

A new type of portable shower to be used in play streets, playgrounds and parks for cooling off sweltering children was demonstrated yesterday forenoon at the Fire Department's general repair shop, Queens Boulevard and Van Dam Street, Long Island City.

An odd reversal of wind direction at an altitude of more than eight miles, which may have a bearing on stratosphere flying of the future, was disclosed Thursday during a free-balloon observation at New York University, Dr. James H. Kimball, meteorologist of the United States Weather Bureau, said yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP). -- Industrial developments of the last ten days have vindicated General Charles G. Dawes's prosperity prophecy, Franklin Hobbs, business analyst, asserted today.

Institutional care was ordered yesterday by Justice Samuel D. Levy in Children's Court for seven Negro children their mother insisted they no longer belonged to her but rather to God after she entered the "kingdom" of Father Divine, Harlem "messiah." Six of the children, who range from 3 to 14, were in court.
PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP). -- The Pirates, aided by Arky Vaughan's homer in the ninth, downed Boston by 6 -- 5 today to make it the Braves' twelfth straight defeat.

NEWARK, July 19. -- Concluding three days of argument, Federal Judge Guy L. Fake held the processing tax under the AAA unconstitutional today on the ground that the act effects an unlawful delegation of powers. He granted a preliminary injunction restraining Charles V. Dully, Collector of Internal Revenue here, and Harry L. Maloney, collector at Camden, from enforcing collection of $870,116 in processing taxes claimed from ten concerns, whose suits were argued jointly.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Testimony asserting that A. Mitchell Palmer, former Attorney General, arranged to supply money to a fugitive who was wanted as a key witness in a Washington grand jury investigation of lobbying in connection with War Department contracts was given before the House Military Affairs Committee today.

Clarence H. Mackay and Dr. Joseph W. Hennessy have authorized the Joseph F. Trainor Company of this city to offer for sale a 100-acre tract of rolling land opposite Harbor Hill, the extensive Mackay estate, near Port Washington, L.I. The property to be sold is in the Westbury and Roslyn centres.
