Leaders of the forces opposing the re-election of Chase Mellen Jr. as Republican County Chairman made plans yesterday for a series of informal conferences to select a candidate to put in the field against Mr. Mellen.

Twenty-three years ago an American railroad, the St. Louis Southwestern, issued bonds payable at the option of the holder either in American dollars of the then current weight and fineness, or in Dutch guilders, French francs, or British pounds of equivalent value. The object of that provision was to make the bonds attractive to European buyers.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The first voluntary code under the new cooperative arrangement between the NRA and the Federal Trade Commission was agreed upon today by a committee representing the Wholesale Tobacco Distributors and officers of the Trade Practice Conference Division of the FTC.
LOS ANGELES, July 19. -- A demand that no governmental agency supersede the courts in power to rule finally on taxes was made by the American Bar Association at its convention here today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19. -Both new American international twelve-meter sloops were defeated today in the next to last session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week series.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 19 (AP). -- A Negro accused of a knife attack on a white woman was snatched from six deputies near here late today and lynched by a mob of masked white men.

William Bayard 0kie, in 40 W. 5th St. through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc.; William Mason Smith Jr., in 1,311 Lexington Av.; Thomas McCanee, in 1,435 Lexington Av. through Edgar Ellinger, Inc.; the Payson MeL. Merrill Co., brOker.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19. -Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner tonight at Wyndcote, their place in Main Street, for Mr. and Mrs. Edward Johnson of Baltimore and Watch Hill, R.I., who arrived today from Watch Hill with Mr. and Mrs. Robertson on the latter's yacht, Doubloon, to spend several days with them.
An 8-year-old girl was injured seriously at 6 o'clock last night when she fell from the roof of her home in the Bronx, and her father also was hurt in a fall when he went to her aid.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Exports from United Kingdom increased 9 per cent, and imports declined less than 1 per cent in the first half of 1935, as compared with a year ago, reports to the Commerce Department today revealed.

BOSTON, Mass., July 19. -- In what is believed to be the first decision of its kind in this country, Judge Samuel R. Cutler of the Chelsea District Court today fined the Western Union Telegraph Company $500 for contempt of court for accepting, transmitting and delivering messages protesting against the arrest of two defendants.

Nothing much ever happens to the drama in the middle of July, and next week is no great exception. Just two events, both on Monday night. In the first place, Benay Venuta, of the radio, will replace Ethel Merman in the cast of "Anything Goes" at the Alvin.

With the sale date on the $50,000,000 of tax anticipation notes of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania still officially unannounced awards of new State and municipal financing next week will total only $6,860,720, compared with this week's revised total of $44,759,945.

OTTAWA, July 19. -- The Tokyo announcement that Japan would after tomorrow impose a 50 per cent surtax on a selected list of Canadian goods appears to be the opening gun in a trade war, because the Canadian Government is not disposed to give way.
A demand for housing properties in Brooklyn was shown yesterday in sales of an apartment house and several dwellings.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Approximately 4,000 hogs were received here today, the smallest for any Friday within recent years. The weight of the arrivals is about the heaviest known at this season with the exception of 1926. New crop hogs weighing under 250 pounds were scarce and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundred weight to a top of $10.65, a new high level since September, 1930.

LAKE PLACID, July 19 (AP). -The Whiteface Mountain Memorial Highway, an eight-mile macadam road cut through solid Adirondack Mountain granite in one of the most difficult engineering feats in recent years, will be officially opened to traffic tomorrow.

LONDON, July 19. -- Although the rioting in Belfast died down today, the tension was still so great that Viscount Craigavon, Premier of Northern Ireland, visited 10 Downing Street, presumably to discuss the situation with Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin.

Only five racers were named overnight for the $5,000 added Yonkers Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, which will be the feature of the racing at Empire City today, but this small field includes the best performers remaining in the metropolitan area.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had revoked on May 28 last its approval of private wire connections between member firms and the Travelers Bank of Paris, which failed to open on Thursday morning. The revocation was attributed to a breach by the bank of the agreement with the Exchange which all non-members having wire connections with member firms are required to sign.

His Majesty's sloop Dundee arrived here early yesterday morning from Bermuda for a short visit in New York Harbor en route to Bar Harbor. Under command of Captain W.H.G. Fallowfield, the Dundee, which is stationed with the British West Indies squadron, carries a crew of ninety-six officers and men.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Expenditures for "recovery and relief" since July 1, 1933, together with outlays prior to that on account of the Reconstruction Corporation and for capital stock of Federal Land Banks, have exceeded $10,000,000,000.

A dignified, kindly, well-dressed old man with thinning gray hair and a professional manner roused Yorkville Court from its hot weather lethargy yesterday by quietly admitting to a record of three felony convictions and more than twenty arrests.

ST. PAUL, July 19. -- After an extended honeymoon, Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles, returned to golf today and fired a brilliant 67 to beat a par-shattering trio by ore shot in the first round of the $5,000 St. Paul open golf championship.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 19. -The annual outdoor frolics of the Harvard and Yale Clubs of New York resulted in a clean sweep for the Crimson graduates today as the former Cambridge athletes conquered the old Elis in baseball, golf and tennis at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Internal revenue collections broke all records for fourteen years during the fiscal year which closed June 30, the Treasury Department disclosed today in its report on receipts.

The sale of three commercial ships -- the Furness Red Cross liner Fort St. George and the Greek line ships Byron and Edison -- to Italian interests was announced here yesterday. The negotiations were not conducted in this country and the terms of the sale were not known here yesterday.

The New York Credit Men's Association has leased the entire fourteenth floor in the Mills Building, 354-360 Fourth Avenue, southwest corner of Twenty-sixth Street, in a deal arranged by M. L. Hess, Inc.; in conjunction with H. B. Eppstein. The association, which has been at 468-470 Fourth Avenue for the last ten years, will have 20,000 square feet of space at its new location.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- A special House committee left tonight to investigate the flood situation in up-State New York and Northern Pennsylvania.

OMAHA, July 19. -- Gus Sumnick, Douglas County farmer, who was Franklin D. Roosevelt's host in his Presidential campaign, has written to Washington to complain of a prospective increase of $5 an acre in his taxes due to the expense of a school to be established for a subsistence homestead in his district.

ATHENS, July 19 (AP). -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris's government fell to pieces today because of quarrels over restoration of the monarchy and resigned. Mr. Tsaldaris announced he expected to have another government ready tomorrow.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 19. -- Attacking the Democratic party's New Deal and its "puerile" leadership as no place for young men and women, three Young Democrats today formally resigned their positions with the organization and joined the Republican party.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 19. -- Patrolman Francis Feeney at night and Sergeant John Pflug during the day shift played laundryman today at Bronxville police headquarters.

The debenture holders' protective committee of McCrory Stores Corporation, of which Stanley A. Russell is chairman, has approved a plan of reorganization of the company sponsored by the preferred stockholders' committee and dated June 15, according to a letter sent to debenture holders by the committee.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The horse race that undoubtedly will settle the 3-year-old championship of the American turf for 1935 will be decided at Arlington Park tomorrow before a crowd of 40,000 spectators.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- A special House committee left tonight to investigate the flood situation in up-State New York and Northern Pennsylvania.

OMAHA, July 19. -- Gus Sumnick, Douglas County farmer, who was Franklin D. Roosevelt's host in his Presidential campaign, has written to Washington to complain of a prospective increase of $5 an acre in his taxes due to the expense of a school to be established for a subsistence homestead in his district.

ATHENS, July 19 (AP). -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris's government fell to pieces today because of quarrels over restoration of the monarchy and resigned. Mr. Tsaldaris announced he expected to have another government ready tomorrow.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 19. -- Attacking the Democratic party's New Deal and its "puerile" leadership as no place for young men and women, three Young Democrats today formally resigned their positions with the organization and joined the Republican party.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 19. -- Patrolman Francis Feeney at night and Sergeant John Pflug during the day shift played laundryman today at Bronxville police headquarters.

The debenture holders' protective committee of McCrory Stores Corporation, of which Stanley A. Russell is chairman, has approved a plan of reorganization of the company sponsored by the preferred stockholders' committee and dated June 15, according to a letter sent to debenture holders by the committee.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The horse race that undoubtedly will settle the 3-year-old championship of the American turf for 1935 will be decided at Arlington Park tomorrow before a crowd of 40,000 spectators.

CLEVELAND, July 20. -- Growing conditions in recent weeks have been favorable and the July crop report of the Department of Agriculture shows that prospects for nearly all local crops, including fruits, are better than in 1934. Harvesting of one of the best wheat crops on record has about been completed, and indications point to a local crop more than a third larger than the ten-year average.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- An assemblage of more than two hundred Summer colonists and guests was present at tonight's beach party and dance at the Maidstone Club.

Three attractive cruisers have been added to the fleet of boats moored in East Chester Bay belonging to members of the City Island Y.C. Former Commodore Charles F. Cafferty recently purchased the 52-foot Consolidated cruiser Ione and the 50-foot Yoho, both of which he has been using for Sound cruising.

ATLANTA, July 20 (AP). -- Mrs. Margaret H. Stuart, grandmother of Robert Stuart 3d, said today that he was a great-grandson of the Robert Stuart who at one time was John Jacob Astor's partner. Mrs. Stuart, who lives at an Atlanta hotel, declared, however, that "there is no family fortune now."

MAE West apparently is too much for the New England consciences of the high school students of Greenwich, Conn. In a recent poll of the likes and dislikes of 205 of the students of the Greenwich High School, no one plumped for Mae.

ARTHUR WALEY, Orientalist and translator of "The Tale of Genji," has brought out a new version of the Tao Te Ching. This handbook of the Taoist faith has been translated before, but always from the "scriptural" standpoint, explains Mr. Waley.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Continuing efforts to bolster the AAA against court attacks, administration officials today proposed legislation to validate contracts under which the government has agreed to pay crop-reducing farmers an additional $700,000,000.

A revival of the Congress of Industries, comprising some 140 small industries which had engaged in trade practice conference prior to the NIRA, will be launched within the next two weeks by its former leaders, Sol A. Herzog, New York lawyer, who had been counsel to the organization, revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The real issue for 1936, many Republican leaders believe, will be made by the administration in demanding revision of the Constitution to permit recovery policies heretofore regarded as forbidden. This is believed to be the course President Roosevelt will take next year if the Supreme Court decides the AAA, TVA and other administration acts are unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- After winning the first game of a double-header, 1 to 0, as Carl Fischer limited the Senators to a single hit, the White Sox dropped the second to Washington today, 9 to 2.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
More than 300 members of the Columbia Y.C. assembled yesterday at the new clubhouse on the former estate of Percy R. Pyne, 247th Street, Riverdale, for its sixty-ninth opening of the yachting season.
DES MOINES, July 20. -- Work relief was denied to able-bodied men in sixteen counties and the men were admonished to accept employment in the harvest fields.

ST. PAUL, July 20. -- Five months ago a youngster in the field of criminology walked into St. Paul's Public Safety Building, told police officials that the study of crime interested him, and said he'd like to watch a police force in action. Might he hang around the Public Safety Building as a sideline spectator? he inquired, with mild politeness.
PARIS, July 18. -- Instead of jogging along quietly as she used to do France since the war has been living in financial swoops and circles in a most disconcerting fashion.

Your comment on Senator Borah's guess that a Supreme Court member may be the Republican candidate for President next year brings to mind a story of the Old South. An aged Georgia darky stood one morning looking down at a small striped animal lying dead, with its mouth full of chicken feathers, at the roots of a lightning-struck tree.

THE men-of-war of the world have again steamed into the headlines. The Anglo-German naval agreement and the pending discussions among the great sea powers have focused international attention off the world's fighting fleets, and upon their component parts -- the heavily armored battleship, the carrier with her flight deck and her planes, the cruiser with rakish masts and powerful engines, the saucy destroyer and the submarine, the "assassin of the seas."

BUENOS AIRES, July 20. -- Yesterday's decree putting foreign news agencies and newspaper correspondents in Argentina under heavy cash bond was unanimously denounced in today's editorials here as an illegal usurpation by the federal government of powers specifically denied to it in the Constitution.
LONDON, July 20. -- Thousands of those tall and courteous policemen of whom London is so justly proud marched past King George today in a last great review of this Jubilee year.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20. -- Opposition of industrialists of the State of Sao Paulo continues to delay ratification of the commercial treaty between the United States and Brazil. The treaty was returned to Congress three days ago by the Finance Ministry and must be debated by the Finance Committee before it reaches the floor of Congress.

MR. PHIL STONG'S new opus is a short and pleasant tale straying over the pastures of light satire, farce and sentiment, bringing Iowa to Hollywood. You can read it in two hours in a hammock without strain on some Summer Sunday afternoon in the country just before dropping off in a doze.

Three Sundays ago the Music Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES published an interesting letter from Billy Artz, lamenting the unsuitability of the music that one hears at restaurants, hotels and on the radio during the dinner hour. He recommended charming dinner concert music for this period.

WHAT constitutes real oiliness in lubricants used for automobile engines is just now a controversy among automobile engineers on one side and the technical experts who do research work for oil companies on the other.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 20. -- Swept last night by the most severe lightning storm of the season, Camp Smith, with its encampment of 1,050 members of the New York National Guard, suffered only the inconvenience of its lighting and telephone system being out of commission for a short time.

DON BUDGE, the youthful redhead, gave our tennis tourists a good start in the inter-zone final round of the Davis Cup campaign. Chalk up another victory for California. Of Heiner Henkel, his victim, a kindly contributor from over the sea writes:

PHILADELPHIA. MOTOR cars carrying license plates of seven States stood the other day outside an old stone mill in Rose Valley which a little group of drama students has developed during the last twelve years into an institution in the American theatre.

Announcing that the Appellate Division, First Department, which covers New York and Bronx Counties, had cleared its calendar before the Summer recess, George T. Campbell, chief clerk, disclosed yesterday that the justices of the Appellate Division had ordered the Supreme Court in some counties to begin a drive this Fall to clear its calendar.

IN order to open the series of dance events which is to be given this Summer in the theatre of Bennington College, Tina Flade crossed the country from California to Vermont and gave last week her first recital in the East since her American debut in the Fall of 1933.

W.H. DAVIES has published fifty books, yet aside from his prose I should guess that his reputation is founded mainly on anthologies. His own volumes, so far as I know, have never had their day with the reading public.
Your recent "Farewell to Cellars," which must have been the emanation of an intellect of the masculine variety, needs corrections for the male's own piece of mind.

AIRSHIP experts from many States will gather in Akron July 25-26 to take part in a lighter-than-air craft forum, the first of its kind in America. The purpose of the conference is to review the present status of lighter-than-air from the engineering and scientific viewpoint, according to Dr. Theo Troller, director of the Daniel Guggenheim Airship Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- A decision that the government has no right to condemn property for housing purposes, handed down this week by the Circuit Court of Appeals at Cincinnati, affected directly only one Federal housing project in Louisville, and by implication only the area over which the court has jurisdiction.

THE factors composing this book combine to give a view of the tragic death of Czar Nicholas II and his family in, so to speak, three dimensions. Each one of these phases is authentic for its view-point, comprehensive, complete. The combination makes, therefore, a rounded account showing the flow of events that terminated inevitably in the tragedy, the national and personal background of the time and the detailed story of the event itself.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 20 (AP). -- A nationally unranked player today scored a startling upset by defeating Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan, ranked second among women tennis players of the country, to win the Essex County Club competition.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Americans who enlist within the territory or jurisdiction of the United States for service in the impending war between Ethiopia and Italy will violate a Federal statute that carries a fine of not more than $1,000 and imprisonment up to a maximum of three years.

Net earnings of the Paramount Publix Corporation in the first quarter of this year amounted to $2,411,414, after depreciation, Federal taxes and amortization. This amount is applicable to interest and preferred dividends on the securities of the newly reorganized company, subject to any additional provisions that may have to be made for reorganization expenses.

Representatives of the local musicians' union met last week at the law offices of former Magistrate Charles A. Oberwager, 11 West Forty-second Street, to discuss the situation created through the killing of a resolution by the Board of Education Thursday night that would have authorized an appropriation of $10,000 to help maintain the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concerts in the Lewisohn Stadium.

Issues of about a dozen companies gravitated from other markets to the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the first half of 1935 as the result of a gradual lowering of the Exchange's minimum requirements as to size of listed companies, and the influence of the Securities and Exchange Commission's uniform standards for permanent registration of securities on any national Exchange.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The Boerse was weak today. Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd again were in ordinary trading, with offers about 300,000 marks for each stock. Hamburg-American closed at 18, compared with 33 7/8 on Wednesday; North German Lloyd at 18 3/8, compared with 36 3/8 on Wednesday.

THE departmental spy, lost these many weeks, suddenly popped up from beneath the debris of the old Rialto the other day after the wreckers set off a walloping blast of dynamite. Unperturbed, he combed the dust and fragments of rock from his false mustache and sallied forth in quest of information relative to the new films looming on the horizon.

DIPLOMAT: Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. of Philadelphia, amateur boxer and World War veteran (he enlisted in the Marines and rose to the rank of major), was nominated by President Roosevelt last week for the post of Minister to Norway.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 20. -- In a petition to Congress the Southern Hosiery Manufacturers Association urged that pending legislation be scrutinized as to its constitutionality before any other factors are considered, according to a statement here today by Taylor R. Dur ham, secretary.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Civic, neighborhood and religious organizations in Chicago are protesting vigorously against the proposal of Mayor Kelly to establish what he terms a permanent fair in Burnham Park, the site of the late Century of Progress Exposition.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Nazi hooligans completely demolished the altar and furnishings of the Confessional Protestant Chapel at Trebbin, near Berlin, following a demonstration before the church presided over by a local Nazi leader and attended by Storm Troops, Hitler Youth and local party functionaries.

All the Stones and the Carrs and the Braggs are present at the celebration of the seventieth birthday of Sophia Stone, acknowledged head of the clan to which all these families belong. One of the Carrs has not been invited, but he is on hand just the same.
TIJUANA, Mexico, July 20 (AP). -- A ban on gambling here and in Agua Caliente, a fashionable resort, was ordered today by President Lazaro Cardenas.

LIMA will pay homage to one of its favorite saints next month at the colorful fiesta of Santa Rosa de Lima. In the capital city of Peru, where the memory of the young Dominican nun is held in reverence, a procession will be staged on Aug. 30 in accordance with a 300-year old custom.
PARIS. THE literary season is ended in France. Few are the publishers who dare to issue a book in July. What have these last two months given us?

VIENNA, July 20. -- The Hungarian legitimist newspaper Magyarsag of Budapest published yesterday an interview with the Austrian legitimist leader, Baron Wiesner, that is full of the usual optimistic claims of the monarchists of decreasing opposition to the Hapsburgs.

The trend of business continued along favorable lines last week in almost all sections of the country, the distribution of merchandise again attaining substantial proportions, while reports on industrial conditions indicated further gains, except in some divisions which are experiencing the usual seasonal gains.

THIS week will see formally opened at Saratoga Springs a complete plant of a modern spa, matching the best in Europe. It is an enterprise owned and operated by the State of New York in the Interest alike of the public health and the conservation of certain valuable natural resources -- the mineral waters peculiar to this region.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 18. -- Out of the depths of uncertainty and indecision supporters of the Tennessee Valley Authority this week flew on the wings of a court decision to a height of enthusiasm such as had not been experienced in this area since the first announcement of the President's program for the valley.

MANASQUAN, N.Y., July 20. -- "Monsters" of the sea are proving a serious problem to Saturday bathers at near-by beaches this Summer. Last Saturday a comparatively harmless and wounded hammerhead shark spoiled the bathing at Point Pleasant Beach.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- Featuring the entertaining here tonight was the dinner party given at Ochre Court by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet for a party of sixty in honor of their week-end guests.

Are the Columbia River salmon doomed? A writer in American Forests, leading conservationist organ, asks this disturbing question. One great dam has already been thrown across the river at Rock Island, two others -- the Bonneville Dam, 150 miles up the river from the sea, and the Grand Coulee Dam, 300 miles further up the river -- are now under construction.

IN 1727, William Gooch, a brigadier general in the British Army, became Governor of Virginia (to serve with credit and renown for twenty-two years) as deputy for the Earl of Orkney who held, as a sinecure and by royal favor, the official title and more than half the pay.

LONDON, July 20 (AP). -- Whether ex-King George of Greece is ready to fly back to Athens was debated here today. An airplane pilot said he was. The King's aide said he was not. The monarch could not be found for comment.

THE activities of Sir Leslie Hore-Belisha as British Minister of Transport have been so extensive and extreme that they have frequently been reported even in cabled dispatches to American newspapers. They have become a subject of controversy in Great Britain, being highly praised by many and severely criticized, even ridiculed, by others.

MARTHAS VINEYARD, Mass. -- Reflecting the steady growth of interest in the regatta of the Edgartown Yacht Club, this yachting event in Southeastern Massachusetts waters will cover two days this year, Friday and Saturday of this week.

MR. HUGHES brings to little ships the passion of a Romeo. He is thoroughly convinced that the one entirely satisfactory way of using life is to use it sailing about in a small boat. His favorite music is "the symphony of water sounds." He wishes there were something like the Carnegie Fund out of which boats would be provided for "worthy and deserving young men."

ALTHOUGH intended primarily for use in colleges, this volume by the Professor of Philosophy in the University of Indiana ought also to have, as he hopes it will, quite as much interest for those many general readers who are deeply disturbed by the looming menace of war in so many parts of the world and are ready to listen to suggestions looking toward a better organization of international interests.

The third day's program of the women's national swimming and diving championships turned into a water carnival for all concerned as storms broke over the Oriental Pool at Manhattan Beach yesterday and divided the two title events by more than an hour and a half.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 20. -- Newton D. Baker, co-chairman of the inter-racial Institute of Human Relations and former Secretary of War, expressed today the need for "the sober study of the problems of inter-cultural relations" during the present world unrest.

Dr. Miguel Lopez Pumarejo, Colombian Minister to Washington, was the guest of honor at a dinner at the Hotel St. Moritz last night in celebration of the 125th anniversary of the independence of the Colombian Republic. Consul General Gabriel Garces presided at the dinner, which was attended by several South American diplomats and notables.

The assets of the Code Authority for the Retail Solid Fuel Industry, Division 4, whose members are in the metropolitan area, will be dispensed through a receiver, according to a ruling made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer in granting an injunction sought by a member of the group.

A cruising radio car with two patrolmen proved a serviceable substitute for an ambulance and a physician in a sidewalk maternity case yesterday morning at 5:30 o'clock in front of 4,803 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- There is something about the feverish heat at the national capital that cannot be understood by the people of Louisiana, Iowa, Texas and the Plains States, where torrid Summer days are just another natural visitation.
STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The vacation season in the Poconos reached its peak during the past week-end with many entertaining events.

THE bad man, following the pioneer and the scout, contemporaneous with the cowboy and preceding that degenerate product of a mechanical age, the gangster, is one of the most picturesque types America has produced.

PROFESSOR FISHER has become familiar to many as an able and persistent advocate of monetary stability to be achieved by fixing the purchasing power of money in terms of goods as reflected in the cost-of-living index. In his Latest book, however, while still pursuing his main objective, he shifts the emphasis to another element of the problem which he has rather neglected in the past.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 20. -- A weakening in industrial activity was noted this week, largely due to the changed crop outlook in the Northwest, since reports of rust damage and extreme July heat damage have become alarming. Private surveys in the past two days indicate a small grain crop, especially wheat, which will run even lower than the more pessimistic second week of July estimates in this district.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Testimony regarding the activities of persons who have sought contracts from the War Department is being studied by members of the House Military Committee to see if it might be made the basis of criminal proceedings.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 20. -- While political observers pondered today the significance of coincidental visits of prominent Republicans to the home of Herbert Hoover, the former President and a group of friends spent the weekend at a Northern California resort section.

THE International Music Congress organized as an appendage of this year's "Maggio" was at the same time more comprehensive in scope than at the first festival, and more practical in character. It consisted of five separate sections: (1) Musical criticism; (2) Opera managers; (3) Radio art directors; (4) Cinema composers, technicians and critics; (5) The lyric stage and analogous problems.

BERLIN, July 20. -- A new Nazi "purge" of "reactionary" opposition, thus far bloodless, swept through Germany with increasing impetus today, its chief or threatened victims being Catholic clergymen, Jews and war veterans.

PAY IT WITH ISLANDS: Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois told the English last week how they might pay the war debt. Speaking in the Senate, he suggested that they transfer to us the Bahamas, Jamaica, the Bermudas and other islands near our shores, and that they abandon all claims to a canal across Nicaragua.

THE terrible rocks of the New England coast, the flat shores of the Great Lakes, the hot sands of the Gulf coast, even the sealing-ground of Me Aleutian Islands are constantly patrolled by the unbroken lines of the Coast Guardsmen, whose lives vary from a routine of unrelenting watchfulness to acts of desperate heroism.

THE Endless Furrow" is a class novel of the English soil and as such may have more meaning to an English reader than to an American. For the latter the social difference between a grocer and a tenant farmer does not exist and the struggles of a man to get back to the land merely on the basis of class seems a little difficult to understand.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 (Reuters). -- For the third time within a week disaster has struck down a giant airplane of the Royal Dutch Airlines, which operates a network of air routes in Europe and to the Far East.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 18. -- Mid-South cotton farmers, enjoying the benefits of controlled production and twelve-cent cotton, are going forward with their plans for marketing the 1935 crop, confident that Washington will find a way out of the difficulties raised by the adverse opinion in the AAA case in Boston.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- With a record-breaking number of laws abrogated in the last two years by the Supreme Court, government officials today counted five new tests that are marching toward the judicial proving ground.

A 26-year-old bride of less than a year was drowned yesterday at Palisades Interstate Park, near the New Jersey approach of the George Washington Bridge, when the heavy rains of the afternoon swept her 300 feet down a drain in which poverty had forced her to make her home.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, July 20. -- Armored ears were patrolling the streets of Lahore tonight after the Royal Scots Regiment had killed at least ten and wounded dozens by firing into a defiant mob of Moslem demonstrators this morning.

ROME, July 20. -- The immediate recall of Count Vinci, Italian Minister to Addis Ababa, was under serious consideration in Rome today as a reply to Emperor Haile Sellassie's speech Thursday in Parliament, the full text of which was received here only today.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 20. -- Seven world motor-boat competitive records were lowered on the Susquehanna River today in the closing events of the Havre de Grace Yacht Club's annual regatta.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Numerous visitors from the Virginias and Eastern and Middle Western cities will witness polo matches this afternoon on Greenbrier Field between the War Department's team and the Greenbrier Polo Club.

ONE of the many problems which confront the garden maker is whether he shall aim to have primarily a landscape picture or to grow a great variety of individually beautiful plants. It is the writer's conviction that it is possible to accomplish both purposes, and the results we have been able to achieve at Breeze Hill, Harrisburg, Pa., seem to offer rather conclusive testimony as to the correctness of this theory.

PARIS, July 20. -- Now that he has done to the best of his ability the task of trying to save the franc by a massive reduction in expenditures, Premier Pierre Laval hopes to give his time to the international situation, which interests him a great deal more.

SIGNIFICANT among the changes coming over the form of government laid down for us in 1787 is the shift in mental processes, or at least in public emphasis, which has made the once radical House of Representatives relatively conservative and the Senate, planned as an august balance wheel, radical by contrast.

Woman's hard-won alcoholic freedom was jeopardized recently by St. Louis barkeepers and Missouri temperance advocates. The barmen allege that feminine feet on the brass rail drive away male patrons who fear to be "mooched" into standing treat.

IN one of those many books of instruction and advice so dear to Elizabethan readers, Sir Thomas Smith established the formula for the making of a gentleman: "For whosoever studieth the laws of the Realm, who studieth in the Universities, who professeth liberall Sciences: and, to be short, who can live idely, and without manuall labor, and will beare the port, charge and countenance of a Gentleman, Bee shall bee called Master."

Although the number of buyers in the local market last week exceeded that for the corresponding period of 1934, stores were conservative and covered early Fall needs only, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. The decision against the processing tax forced buyers of manufactured cotton goods to place orders very carefully for future delivery.

At the end of June of last year the Third Reich had a purging -- the "blood purge." In that operation Chancellor Hitler directed the execution of several hundred members of the National Socialist party who had developed some ideas of their own. The "accidents" which occurred, such as the murder of former Chancellor von Schleicher, were regarded as unimportant beside the larger results which were accomplished.

A DOUBLE purpose, its authors believe, will be served by this book. It is their hope that with the growing interest in European affairs and the need for better and more accurate knowledge concerning European nations and their governments, the general reader who desires thus to inform himself will find in it the explanation and the analysis of present situations that will help him to clearer understanding.

LOCAL trade ran even or slightly ahead of a year ago in this area during the week and from some other centres came reports of impressive gains. Sales here ran to specials and hot-weather needs. Response to early furniture promotions was considered quite satisfactory.

The municipally owned Dyker Heights golf course near Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn had strike-breaking caddies yesterday. They were provided by the Park Department and were brought to the links from all parts of Brooklyn in department trucks.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Sluggish from almost seven months of great activity, Congress was resigned today to a possible session until Labor Day.

NEW HARTFORD, N.Y., July 20. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, in an address at a Republican garden party held at the home of Mrs. Alice D. Proctor, Republican vice chairman of Oneida County, attacked President Roosevelt today in connection with the Congressional inquiry into lobbying.

Pinto, foal of a half-wild range mare, was one of the most beautifully built horses ever seen by Bib Gunnison and his cowboys, so that from his birth there wasn't a hand who didn't yearn to ride the lovely sorrel-and-cream horse. But Pinto was high-spirited, he loved freedom and he could run faster than prairie fire, so that it took nearly three years of constant watching and five cowboys to rope him for training.

"I WANT a policeman!" When that call goes over the telephone wires to SPring 7-3100 it starts a lot of action for any individual, and just now Father Knickerbocker himself has asked for a policeman. It is odd that it should be so, but the individual probably will get quicker action in an emergency than the old gentleman with a peruke, for calls for held deal with simple problems.

LONDON, July 20. -- The select committee of the House of Lords on the bill for registration and regulation of osteopaths has ordered the bill to be reported to the House without amendment and has recommended it be not further proceeded with.

DURING the few weeks in which Sir Samuel Hoare has been Foreign Secretary international events of great importance have taken place. First there was the German naval treaty, which had reverberations throughout Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO. RECOGNITION of the work of Alexander Meiklejohn and his associates in creating a unique method of adult teaching in the San Francisco School of Social Studies is indicated by recent grants of money to the school from two New York foundations -- the Workers' Education Bureau and the Elmhirst Fund.

MR. MAUGHAM'S new book might be called a plan for novel in search of a hero. Or a cartoon for a stained glass window of sixteenth-century Spain. There have been more books on that land than there ever were castles. But this one is not like any other I know.

THE Fox-Twentieth Century merger which came to a head this week with the resignation of Winfield R. Sheehan, vice president and production chief of Fox, is regarded as a forerunner of momentous days in the cinema.

DURING a brief controversy in the columns of The New Republic between that admirable critic of Communist bent, Mr. Edmund Wilson, and the present writer, I recall the former inquiring with all candor: "But just who are the great modern Catholic thinkers and writers?
NEWPORT, R.I. -- Men and women golfers are to have the run of things in the Summer colony this week and there is every indication that the Newport Country Club will be a lively place.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- With the Burlington's twin Zephyrs each traveling better than 25,000 miles a month between Chicago and the Twin Cities and another Zephyr operating over 15,000 miles between Kansas City and Lincoln, the railroad world is watching operating costs of this new streamlined Diesel-electric powered service for guidance in making future investments in passenger-train equipment.

WARSAW, Poland, July 20. -- The Polish Ministry of Finance today ordered the custom offices in Danzig territory not to accept Danzig guilders in payment of duties for goods shipped to Poland by Danzig, but only Polish zlotys. Goods for The Free City's own use will be taxed in guilders.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Senatorial resentment was aroused today over reports the administration would insist on confirmation of four or five State works progress administrators in the face of opposition.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 20. -- Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster was the honored guest at a birthday dinner party which her father-in-law, Giraud Foster, gave tonight at Belle-Fontaine, Lenox. There were sixty guests at small tables on the terrace. The table decorations were zinnias and gladioluses. Mrs. Foster cut a birthday cake.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP). -- Behind Roy Mahaffey's six-hit pitching, the Athletics came back in the second game today to win, 5 to 2, and even a double-header after the Indians had overwhelmed them, 15 to 3, in the first encounter.

The full membership of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, Inc., will hold a mass meeting either on Thursday of this week or on Monday of next week to ratify the action of the executive committee which last week adopted a labor and fair trade practice agreement to replace the NRA rules in the millinery industry in this region.

There are many reasons why the House and Senate should quickly adjourn this session of the Seventy-fourth Congress. Chief among the reasons is the fact that more than twenty of our colleagues -- to be exact, twenty-six -- are now either in hospitals or at their homes suffering from heart trouble or a nervous breakdown.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- Governor Merriam's signing of the Red-wine-Martin bill prohibiting use of school houses to individuals and groups advocating the overthrow of the governments by violence brings to an end the campaign of powerful organizations and newspapers to give this State the most astringent laws in the Union limiting freedom of speech, 'press and assembly.

TORONTO, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- In a full dress rehearsal for the Hambletonian Stakes at Goshen, N.Y., Greyhound, owned by the Baker Stables of St. Charles, Ill., today won the feature stake event of the third day of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Thorncliffe track.
ALBANY, July 20 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, up-State WPA Administrator, warned cities, counties and communities today that those which neglect to file projects early may soon "be out of luck."

A 60-year-old woman was killed and a man, a passerby, was injured in a vain attempt to save her at 9 o'clock last night when they were struck by an automobile driven by a youth who had received his license yesterday. The accident occurred at East Tremont and Clinton Avenues, the Bronx, in a busy shopping district.

PARIS, July 18. -- Schiaparelli especially created the bridal gown for Lady Daphne Finch-Hatton, who was married to Whitney Straight yesterday at St. Margaret's Church, Westminster. One hundred and fifty dozen tiny orange blossoms of wax and countless silver paillettes were sewn on the gossamer mesh of the white silk veil.

A letter from Park Commissioner Robert Moses, announcing that plans are under way to provide play facilities in Riverside Park between Seventy-second and Seventy-ninth Streets for the children of the West Side below that area, was made public last night by Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer.

SEVERAL signals from the Orient were heard in New York during the past week on international short-wave channels. Conditions seemed to be especially favorable for transmission over the Great Circle route across the Arctic ice fields to Manhattan Island.

Considering that the decision of the United States Supreme Court holding corporate stock dividends non-taxable as income carried four dissenting opinions (Mark Eisner, Collector vs. M.H. Macomber, 252 U.S. 189), it is not surprising that the lower courts have difficulty in agreeing upon what constitutes tax-free stock dividends.

OUT of the darkness over the airport on the lakefront at New Orleans could be heard the drone of a plane. It was 9:20 o'clock. The green and red running lights of the big passenger liner were visible against the dark sky. It circled the port once to land down the wind in front of the floodlights.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 20 (Reuters). -- With war clouds rapidly massing around his country, Emperor Haile Sellassie hurled another challenge at Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy from his mountain capital today.

Substantial gains in both unit and dollar sales volume of electric household refrigerators are revealed for the first five months of this year, compared with the corresponding period of 1934, in a special report made public yesterday by the statistical division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

HAMMONTON, N.J., July 20. -- Three young girls lost their lives and three other persons were injured two of them seriously, near here tonight when two cars were in collision during a severe rainstorm.

PARIS, July 20. -- Offices of the Travelers Bank, an American firm here, were raided today by French judicial authorities. The action was taken in response to complaints of the bank's customers, scores of whom gathered today outside the offices, which have been unaccountably closed for three days.

PARENTS thumbing over private school catalogues this Summer or making the vexed decision between public school and private might pause a moment over a theory recently advanced by Morton Snyder, headmaster of Rye Country Day School.

Leading national Jewish organizations have associated themselves with the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee in a call for an emergency conference to be held tomorrow night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Efforts will be made to create a united anti-Nazi front of Jewish and non-Jewish organizations for a campaign to halt the attacks on Jews and other minority groups in Germany.
DETROIT, July 20. -- The doors of the world's largest hangar swung open this afternoon at the Detroit City Airport to admit the public to the All-American Aircraft Show.

THE big hump on the shoulder of Brazil jutting far out into the South Atlantic is only 1,200 miles from the African coast. On that hump of land a great race for supremacy in control of air contracts between Europe and America is being fought out.

INDUSTRIAL radio is more cheerful than it has been in seven lean years. The outlook for the 1935-36 season is rated as extremely bright. There seems to be plenty of business ahead, according to the trade barometers.

ELINOR AMES, whose name is not unknown to readers of etiquette columns, offers advice and counsel as to what is good and what is bad manners. She gives wise suggestions to mothers of young children. She devotes several chapters to the correct usages of engagement and wedding occasions.

THE rascally Lyle Long, manager for the Four States Syndicate, coveted the grazing lands of the Box C Ranch and its owner's daughter, Ruth Cameron, and so he set out to wreck that outfit. Old Dave Cameron was in a ticklish position, anyway -- in debt up to his ears and hardly knowing which way to turn.

An odd phase of the city's war against crime developed at City Hall when Mayor La Guardia was informed that the testimony of a city chemist had contributed substantially toward a conviction in the case of nine gangsters recently arrested in Mountain View, N.J.

EACH year seems to bring some new pest to add to the gardener's trials and tribulations. One of the worst is the Japanese beetle. It appeared several years ago near Philadelphia and has been spreading ever since. Now for the first time it is observed in many sections around New York.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 19. -- The public in Finland, as in other States around the Baltic, is beginning to realize that the newly-signed Anglo-German naval convention is bound to have far-reaching consequences upon the development of political events in the whole Baltic region.

Continuation of the present session of Congress until Aug. 15, a possibility indicated last week when the House tabled an adjournment resolution, would bring it into the ranks of the longest sessions. If adjourned at the expected date, it will have run 225 days, compared with the present average of 216 days for the 170 preceding sessions.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The driving stretch charge of William Woodward's Omaha, champion of the 3-year-olds, proved too much for the best that the West could muster against him at Arlington Park today as he went on to victory, a new track mark, a new money winning record for the season, and greater glory in the hearts of his admirers.

PARIS. THE Summer resort season has begun particularly early here this year, in spite of the fact that the Paris season -- which used to end abruptly the very day after the running of the Grand Prix on the last Sunday in June -- now continues well toward the middle of July.

THE State of Pennsylvania has initiated this season a novel project in trout fishing. At Spring Creek, not far from Bellefonte, its "fishermen's paradise" welcomed anglers between May 18 and June 15 and is host to sportsmen this month.
CLEVELAND, July 20. -- Meetings of the executive committee and board of trustees of the American Osteopathic Association were held today preliminary to the convention, which opens Monday morning.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of May 26 Clair Price in an article on John White, leader of Raleigh's first expedition to Virginia in 1587, mentions that White was not known before that period or after. Hakluyt mentions John White of Newton Kylmore as leading Raleigh's first expedition to Virginia in 1587 and returning to England on Oct. 24, 1590.
Even in these modern days there are plenty of adventures left within the realm of sport.

BARCELONA. -- Divorce in Spain is not accepted by the masses of the people, according to a survey by the newspaper La Vanguardia, despite the fact that laws making it legal became effective three years ago.

A DIDACTIC, professorial tone has always characterized the introductions to Mr. O'Brien's anthologies and now, in "The Short Story Case Book," he frankly assumes what is obviously a congenial role. His dry but sensible text is saturated with the atmosphere of the classroom and is directed specifically not toward the general public but toward teachers and writers of the short story.

TOKYO. -- Japan's trade with Canada has been selected for an experiment of great interest to the United States and other countries that sell more to Japan than they buy from her. The object is to find out whether the nation's purchasing power as a customer can be used as a lever to break down the tariffs, dumping duties and other obstacles it meets as a seller.

With the exception of government contracts for naval vessels, construction work now under way in the shipyards of the United States is limited almost exclusively to tankers. The American yards are building 25,911 tons of commercial work, according to Lloyd's Register, and 24,511 tons are tankers.

FOR the first time since President Wilson's illness the broad lawn north of the White House, separating the mansion from Pennsylvania Avenue, is closed to the public. Tourists streaming into Washington by the thousands daily find locked the great iron gates at the east end of the curving driveway where, ordinarily, the public walks at will and motor cars roll, bearing the tags of every State in the Union.

A young man dies of gas poisoning in his room in a London club, and Inspector David Blest is sent to investigate. It looks like suicide, but Blest suspects murder. He passes his suspicion on to his superior officer, and is told that he is growing too imaginative and that he needs a vacation.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 20. -- An alleged "gyp" gambling establishment that encouraged Nassau householders to strip their homes of furnishings by accepting them as collateral was raided at sunrise today by District Attorney Martin W. Littleton and county detectives.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20. -- Treasure Hall, black gelding owned by W.J. Benson of New York and driven by Rue Clark, trotted a mile in 2:10 1/2 before a thunderstorm ended the matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

What is an Englishman? asks Mr. HAROLD NICOLSON in an article reprinted in The Living Age from a broadcasting magazine. He had studied that pervasive character in many parts of the world. Look at the picture he sees in American eyes. The Englishman wears spats and an eyeglass.
CLEVELAND, July 18. -- This city is entering a campaign which may rival the memorable municipal fights of 1907 and 1921.

BOSTON, July 18. -- Industrial New England hailed with elation the 2-to-1 decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals here against the constitutionality of the processing tax. The almost universal expectation is that within the ninety-day period allowed by law the government will appeal to the Supreme Court, and that by the end of the year a final decision will be handed down against the tax.

The expectation that there would be an increase in medical social service work in New York City for a year or two after business recovered momentum was expressed yesterday by Mrs. William Armour. She is chairman of the woman's division of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

BOSTON, July 20. -- The Tigers wiped out most of the difference between first and second place in the American League standing today as they turned back the Red Sox for the third straight time, 6 to 5, but the "law of averages" continued to favor the Yankees.

DUMONT, N.J., July 20. -- Chauncey W. Johnson celebrated his 102d birthday today, with a game of checkers, an automobile drive, and visits from more than a score friends. He lives at 95 Washington Avenue, here, with his daughter, Mrs. F. Stearns Edick, and his granddaughter, Mrs. John R. Marshall, and his three great-grandchildren.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 20 (AP). -- A program designed to safeguard and expand the employment opportunities of incapacitated veterans was approved today by the Disabled American Veterans of the World War during the closing hours of their national convention.

The peaceful little town of Netherminster receives a visit from Inspector Pierce of Scotland Yard and Mr. Tolefree, private investigator. Pierce is convalescing after an attack of pneumonia and has come to Netherminster to rest and to revisit the scenes of his boyhood. Mr. Tolefree is there to see that Pierce does not overexert himself.

ANIMATING Elizabeth Jenkins's new novel is that curious, old-fashioned belief that woman is strictly and entirely responsible for the amatory destiny of man. Lily Macmillan, so at least we are led to infer, has "taken" Lionel Ackerly and thereby "destroyed" his wife's chance of happiness.

As Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the New York County racket investigation, proceeded yesterday with the organization of his staff, members of the Board of Aldermen were summoned to a special meeting to be held at noon on Thursday to approve salary schedules for the staff.

Because it is that far away from East Hampton. L.I., they have been calling the basin that opens between jetties to Gardiners Bay Three-Mile Harbor. Here is one of the really popular haunts of the small-boat skippers who, about this time every season, make their annual cruise out toward Montauk and explore all the famous old anchorages en route.

WHEN Hollywood became the world's screen capital and glamorous stars began applying make-up for the camera one of the most interesting industries in the world was inaugurated. Make-up today in all its branches, including the by-products of cosmetics and beauty preparations, has assumed undreamed-of proportions, resulting in the employment of thousands of workers and the manufacture of hundreds of commodities.

Charles Amandales, Dongan Hills, S.I., defending champion; John Murphy of Brooklyn and J.B. Sage of Manhattan each turned in a card of 36 -- 33 -- 69 to lead the qualifying round of the metropolitan public links championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

A total of 72,287 cases dropped from the relief rolls of New York City in the first six months of 1935 included more than 33,000 Home Relief cases removed because the beneficiaries had found jobs in private industry, the Home Relief Division reported yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

BERLIN, July 20 (AP). -- The text of the official announcement of the decree of the Ministry of Justice today warning Catholic priests to be careful in their comments from the pulpit tomorrow on the intensified Nazi campaign against "political Catholicism" follows:

AS conservative as Noah's Ark, this little book by an Englishman who describes himself as belonging to "the gentlest and humblest ranks of society, the back benches of the House of Commons," surveys the economic scene in a spirit as hopeful as Noah's company must have felt after the dove brought back the olive branch.

THIS book embodies an almost literal rendition of a series of lectures delivered at the Friday night services of the Brooklyn Jewish Centre during the seasons of 1932 and 1933. The series was intended by the distinguished rabbi of the centre to give a consistent interpretation of the basic teachings of Judaism.

JUST as there are fresh breezes in the sweltering months of July and August, so there are fresh style flashes to brighten fagged wardrobes. Get a new frock to go with that new face that the Summer sun has given you. A frock acquired at this season gives you pep, for it has the advance news of the incoming season.

UPWARD of 16,000 students are enrolled in the sessions of the two largest New York Summer schools. Most of them are teachers coming from nearly every State in the Union and from foreign countries (with the largest delegation from Canada), and the trend in their choice of subjects this year, more than ever before, reflects the economic, social and political interests of the times.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 20. -- Without committing themselves to endorsement of any individual, delegates of Young Republican Clubs throughout the eleven counties of the Fourth Judicial District at a "shirt-sleeves" conference at the Queensbury today considered the name of Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster of Elizabethtown, among others, as a possible candidate for Governor of New York State.

LONDON, July 20. -- There is some reason to believe that a subcommittee of the Cabinet has been holding highly important consultations on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis in the past three days. It is understood this committee has called before it key officials of the Admiralty, Colonial Office and Foreign Office to learn whether and to what extent British interests in East Africa, Egypt and the Sudan would be affected by an Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

MONTREAL, July 20. -- About forty planes from New York and near-by territory arrived here this afternoon on the Fourth International Good-Will Flight from Roosevelt Field. The number arriving at Cartierville Airport was below expectations.

Two alphabetical constituents of the New Deal were examined last week by two of our second-highest courts, with these results: TVA got off with a clean bill of constitutional health; AAA was found wanting.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 20. -- The Rev. Carl C. McIntire, Presbyterian pastor of Collingswood, who is being tried here for insubordination, today flatly denied that he had ever done anything to disturb the peace of the Presbyterian Church.

VACATIONISTS on Cape Cod this Summer find themselves entering their ancient haunts through portals magnificently new: the two tall bridges which the Federal Government has constructed over the Cape Cod Canal, one at Sagamore on the north, one at Bourne at the south.

RENO, Nev., July 20. -- Mrs. Edith Egbert Norton obtained a divorce here today from Henry Kittredge Norton, author, on grounds of cruelty. Agreement was reached on the custody of a daughter, Karlene, and her support.

An educational campaign directed at industries which are raising sharp objection to reciprocal trade pacts but which are benefiting greatly by the added foreign business obtained was started last week by export groups assisted by producers in such lines as automobiles, business machines, tractors, farm equipment, machine tool and heavy machinery.

The appointment of Captain Herman Lehmann as master of the Hapag Lloyd liner Albert Ballin was announced by the line Friday upon the arrival of the ship at her North River pier. Captain Lehmann has been with the line for thirty years and succeeds Captain Ernest Fuhr, who has retired.

A FIVE-FOOT shelf will soon be needed to contain the volumes of information about the ancient, lost continent of Mu which Mr. Churchward disseminates concerning the region, its civilization, the travels, migrations and activities of its people and what they believed and taught.

Dan McCarthy (Deafy Dan), one of the men who knew Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the days before repeal and who walked out of the courtroom in Syracuse at Flegenheimer's last trial, "is walking yet" as far as prosecution officials know, they said yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., July 18. -- The University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs is being criticized for inviting the American Liberty League to sponsor its round table on "The Constitution and the New Deal."

CLEVELAND, July 20. -- An apparent case of mistaken identity in a kidnapping was being investigated by police tonight. The victim was Robert G. Byers, 43, a sales counselor, of Columbus, who reported that he was abducted by three men under the impression that he was his brother, George Byers, a Columbus automobile distributer.

Thomas Hannaberry, veteran emergency man of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, had what he termed his "toughest" job in five years of service with the society yesterday morning when he was called upon to rescue a pigeon from the steeple of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- New mystery tonight surrounded the tarpaulin-wrapped body of a man, found floating in the Hudson River a week ago, following a report to police that he had at least three names and a police record.

WITH Summer rains making the plains and mountains of Eritrea and Northern Ethiopia a great morass of mud and sand, the armies of the Lion of Judah and Mussolini are feverishly preparing for the conflict that has been predicted as soon as physical conditions make a concerted Italian advance possible.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 20. -- The fate of two great California oil deposits rested in the balance of law and politics tonight, with partisans in one instance hinting of a possible scandal "greater than Teapot Dome."

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The net earnings of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the fiscal year which closed on June 30 were $41,288,582.88 as compared with $21,784,386.35 in the previous year, according to the annual report of the corporation made public by Chairman Jesse Jones.

An ancient castle, fully equipped with secret passages and presided over by an eccentric nobleman whose passion is the collecting of works of art, is the scene of this rather too complicated yarn. The attention of Scotland Yard is drawn to the vicinity of the castle because several persons have mysteriously disappeared from neighboring towns and villages.

IN concluding his engagement for the Summer at the Stadium concerts a week from tonight, Jose Iturbi again will appear as both soloist and conductor, playing the harpsichord in a Haydn concerto and the piano in Liszt's "Hungarian Fantasy."

THE woman who hides behind the nom de plume of "Xantippe" has, we are told, long been identified with radio as a writer and producer of programs. We can easily believe it, for she obviously dislikes sponsors, and sponsors are the persons who, if they are so inclined, can make life miserable for writers and producers of radio programs, and also for singers, instrumentalists and comedians.

LONDON. -- Observers of politics in Great Britain agree that the general election may come in the Fall of this year. Legally, of course, Prime Minister Baldwin could wait until the end of the quinquennial period of the present House of Commons -- that is, until October, 1936.

DES MOINES, July 20. -- Fourteen Iowa counties have removed all employables from their relief rolls in the last two weeks. The action, first taken in Harrison County. July 6, has been imitated in other counties almost every day since that time.

Establishment of a hosiery manufacturing industry in South Africa, which now imports 1,000,000 dozen pairs annually, will be completed within the next few months, J. Talerman, of Johannesburg, announced yesterday. Mr. Talerman, who has been active in the importation of American knit goods into South Africa, arrived last week from Johannesburg to place orders for $45,000 to $50,000 worth of American hosiery machinery which will be used in the production of full-fashioned hosiery.

General business conditions remained steady this month, although commodity prices showed a tendency to sag, according to the monthly report made public yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Thirteen years ago George Gershwin made a bet with one of his cronies that he would have a grand opera produced in ten years. He has lost the bet and he doesn't remember what the stakes were. But within four or five weeks he will have finished the opera that has been in his mind since 1922 and on which he has been working assiduously for a year and seven months.
OLD POINT COMFORT BEACH, Va. -- The oldest continuous parish in the United States, that of St. John's Episcopal Church at Hampton, will commemorate its 325th anniversary today.

DALLAS, July 20. -- Business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District has shown steady improvement during the last week, with favorable weather prevailing for the entire time over the area. Farmers are well up with work in their fields and, with the rush over, have taken time for visits to town.

This is a year when America might with special appropriateness and profit "check up" on its progress in democracy, for it is the hundredth anniversary of the first publication of DE TOCQUEVILLE'S "Democracy in America." France is preparing to celebrate the centenary of this work, which has had a powerful influence in furtherance of liberal political and social principles among the Western peoples.

PARIS, July 20. -- All through the night and until nearly noon today police officials of various depots in Paris questioned 1,500 demonstrators in yesterday's forbidden street protests against Premier Pierre Laval's economy decrees. Only eight persons who resisted the police, and eighteen foreigners, who will be expelled, were held.

THIS is an inspirational biography, the subject being, in Mr. Cate's words, "perhaps the most gifted statesman that the South gave to the nation from the close of the Civil War to the turn of the century, and the man to whom was due, more than to any other, the death of sectionalism and the healing of the wounds of the fratricidal war."

MISS HALBEISEN begins her excellent study of Harriet Prescott Spofford upon a duly apologetic note when in her preface she frankly admits that her subject belongs among "lesser names" of the nation's literature. Nevertheless, she feels that there is something to be said in defense of Mrs. Spofford as being worthy of a bi ography, now in the centennial year of her birth.

The growing difference in views on monetary policies held by United States business and financial men as against the theories expounded by the academic economists -- many of whom have served the present administration as financial advisers -- seems to have been accentuated by the Monetary Conference at Cornell University last week.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Home Owners Loan Corporation had instituted 568 foreclosure proceedings against delinquent borrowers by June 30. Loans outstanding totaled 880,378, with a face value of $2,657,639,111. Though the percentage of delinquent borrowers is small, when compared with the aggregate of individual loans, the number of foreclosures has increased sharply in recent months, with indications of further increases in the months ahead.

THE extreme artlessness of this novel deprives it of the essentials a tale of this kind should harbor to command critical consideration. It is the crudely told story of an Italian immigrant's life in America from the late 1880s until the book closes in the more immediate past, with the principal an unhappy, disillusioned old man virtually ruined by the ingratitude of his grasping wife and their two grown sons.

Additional contributions receive by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross brought its flood-relief fund up to a total of $12,922 yesterday, Douglas Gibbons, chairman of its disaster relief committee, announced at its headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue.

OTTAWA, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- Application by the Japanese Government of a 50 per cent surtax on Canadian imports entering Japan will be considered as a violation of the Anglo-Japanese treaty of 1911 to which Canada became a signatory in 1913, Prime Minister Bennett announced today.

SAN ANTONIO. WHAT the opening of the highway to Mexico, D.F., will mean in increased tourist travel and its attendant benefits is a topic constantly discussed not only in San Antonio but in Laredo, Fort Worth, Dallas, El Paso, and in fact almost everywhere in Texas.

DUBLIN, July 20. -- A sniper's shot at a land of Orangemen returning from the July 12 celebrations was the ostensible beginning of the grave outbreak of rioting that has turned Belfast into a city of turmoil and terror for the past nine days.

LAST week an attempt was made here to give some idea of the character and extent of the catalogues issued by American booksellers this Spring and early Summer. But this is far less than half the picture of the temptation, or problem, that confronts the average collector.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 20 (AP). -- An investigation was set in motion today by Governor Dave Sholtz to bring "the guilty ones to justice" for the lynching of a Negro. The victim, Rubin Stacey, 37, accused of slashing Mrs. Marion Jones, a white woman, with a penknife, was hanged yesterday within sight of her home.

The Dreyfus case was more than a symbol of personal animosity and intolerance perverting justice. It has illustrated also the way in which determined opposition to that perversion, working without self-interest of any kind, may yet halt disaster and compel at least some measure of restitution to the victim.

DURING the recent heat-waves in London cars were often parked at night down country lanes or in pleasant open spaces, with their occupants soundly asleep beside them or curled up inside, and tents were put up in gardens for children or adults to sleep in.

THE Group Theatre has spent about a month wondering darkly what to do with its three Clifford Odets plays -- close them, move them, leave them alone, change the casts or just simply sit down and rest. After a very late conference along about Thursday, the board of governors decided on the middle road.

With the blessing of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, representatives of 110 trade unions, Negro and white, moved yesterday to eradicate race prejudice and discrimination from the ranks of organized labor.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- Debating the EPIC plan to end poverty by "production use," Upton Sinclair, father of EPIC, and Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican, of New York, united here this afternoon in attacking the New Deal.
LONDON. THE attention paid to H.G. Wells's "The New America" is a striking tribute to his influence. Few living writers could count on obtaining so much publicity for a book so slender in bulk.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner gave a large dinner with dancing tonight at Red Top Farm, their home in Wickapogue Road, for Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Coulter, who have returned here after passing two years in England and on the Riviera.
PARIS, July 20. -- Only a few weeks ago in conversation with this correspondent, Premier Mussolini declared his government had not decided how far Italy would go in Ethiopia.
Nazi Germany flared up in the world's headlines last week with a series of events which recalled the first days of the Hitler regime.

BEGINNING Friday the American Women Composers' Conference will be held at Chautauqua, N.Y., continuing through Monday, July 29. Mrs. H.H.A. Beach's "Gaelic Symphony" and Mabel Daniel's "Pirate's Island" will be performed on Saturday by the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Albert Stoessel, who has been musical director of the Chautauqua Institution for twelve of the sixty-two years of its existence.

BELGRADE. -- The great Austrian Empress Maria Theresa must be among those turning in their graves at what is happening in post-war Europe to their carefully devised political schemes. For it was as a colonizer of Austria, anxious to preserve and extend the domination of Vienna, that she established throughout the old Austrian Empire little clusters of German peasants in the surrounding population of Slavs, Rumanians and Hungarians.

THE Lady of the Plaza has her bath back. After five long years of neglect and contumely, of arguing, of frustrated attempts that make the efforts of Sisyphus to roll his rock up hill look like mere child's play, the impossible has been accomplished.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 20 (Canadian Press). -- Oarsmen from the West Side Rowing Club of Buffalo, N.Y., today repeated their feat of last Wednesday by taking the senior eight-oared race from four Canadian and United States teams over a one-and-one-half-mile course in the feature event of the Rodeo Week regatta.

OMAHA, July 18. -- The Circuit Court of Appeals, in its decision at Boston, did more to alarm the Farm Belt over the danger which threatens New Deal farm relief than numerous tax injunction suits filed close at home.

LAST Saturday, the concluding Mozart performance at Glyndebourne marked the end of the season, so far as major events are concerned. A troupe of Russian dancers now delights holiday audiences at Covent Garden, and the concert halls are mainly occupied by students celebrating the end of the academic year.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during June at 74.6 per cent of capacity, on single shift basis, compared with 83.4 per cent during May this year and 72.7 per cent during June last year.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va. -- The Legislature started something which may not be finished for a long time when it is enacted a law requiring "for-hire" trucks from other States to have permits to operate over West Virginia roads.

ONLY now, when the magnificent exhibition of Italian masters from Cimabue to Tiepolo is coming to a close at the Petit Palais, and the show of nineteenth and twentieth century Italian art at the Jeu de Paume des Tuileries also drawing to an end, has the outside world come to appreciate the opportunity that has been at its disposal.

NO living religious thinker is quoted so often, especially by Catholic writers, as the emigre Russian Nicholas Berdyaev. There is his indubitable power as an interpreter of Christian doctrine in a fashion which is at the same time provocative and stimulating; again, he has the gift for using the terse apt phrase which revivifies and renders intelligible recondite religious knowledge usually considered outside the scope of laymen.

The Richard Cobden lecture for 1935 was delivered two months ago before the Royal Society of Arts in London by Senior MADERIAGA. He is well known for his association with the League of Nations, and afterward as a Spanish Ambassador. His theme was naturally the new world order which has been slowly in the act of creation.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Sixteen naval craft now on the ways in navy yards and private shipyards are scheduled for launching before Jan. 1. They include one aircraft carrier, twelve destroyers, two submarines and one gunboat.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 21. -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota has answered the Soviet note of July 1 with a denial of all of Moscow's charges of frontier violations by Japanese and Manchukuoan troops, which are described, he declared, as "either unfounded in fact or attempts to disguise the issue where the responsibility rests on the Soviet."

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- An assertion that utility companies were making a concerted and carefully planned court attack on most public power projects, financed by the PWA, was made today by Henry T. Hunt, general counsel of the Public Works Administration.

ALTHOUGH originally prepared and published for the purpose of persuading Britishers of the beauty and vacation attractiveness of their own land, this book, which is beguiling in text and lovely in illustration, ought to have a great deal of interest for those thousands of Americans who, the steamship lines assure newspaper readers, are now trekking in crowds across the Atlantic to vacation in England.

ATHENS, July 20. -- All Republican officers have been swept from the army, navy, police and constabulary by systematic purges and the only resistance to the Monarchists' progress is in the labor unions, the Communist party and in the Society of Cashiered Officers, all of whom are under close control.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- Award of fourteen three-year scholarships by the University of Pennsylvania Law School was announced today.

SECONDARY schools need college-trained teachers, but the mere possession of a degree does not meet the need. In recognition of this fact Mount Holyoke College will offer next term a fifth year of work, leading to the degree of Master of Arts in Education and designed especially for students who plan to teach in secondary schools.
