If the young girl growing up in the Western world of today feels at times confused and troubled by the complexities of the transitional age she has but to read this record of a young Japanese girl to feel that her own problems are comparatively simple ones.

LONDON, July 20. -- With Keith Brown, Yale captain, and Milton Green of Harvard setting the pace, track and field stars from the two American universities scored their eighth victory in twelve attempts over the combined teams of Oxford and Cambridge in today's international meet at White City.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 20. -- Single sculls supremacy was won today by Charles A. Campbell of the Argonaut Rowing Club, Toronto, who surprised 2,000 spectators along Lake Carnegie's shores by defeating Winthrop Rutherfurd in the feature event of the sixty-third annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen.

NO flower garden is satisfactory without some varieties of Sweet Alyssum, whether they are used in edging flower beds, have their individual places in a rock garden, or whether they trail from hanging baskets.
Arthur the Rat, for the last several years the bane of Columbia College freshmen who are forced to recite his epic adventures in a voice-recording test, is at last coming into his own.
The elevation of Dr. Sao-ke Alfred Sze from China's Minister to be her first Ambassador to the United States has come as part of a great contradiction.

The Yankees, trailing two games to nothing in their current series with the tail-end Browns, were deprived of a chance of squaring accounts in some measure with their annoying guests yesterday when a thunderstorm cracked down on the Stadium just as hostilities were about to begin.

WHAT with all the alarums and excursions in the film city -- the dramatic resignation of Winfield Sheehan, Mr. Churchill's neighboring prognostication that the near future is going to be bristling with mergers, and other such explosive items -- any attempt to set forth a Sabbath appraisal of the week's pictures comes within the general heading of playing a flute in a boiler factory.

Rapidly growing fear that voidance of the processing tax may substantially cut into crop reduction benefits to farmers and seriously affect rural buying power in some areas caused many retailers and jobbers, particularly those from the South and Southeast, to curtail their purchases in the local merchandise markets last week.

LONDON, July 19. -- Britain, and indeed the whole of Northern Europe, have been enjoying a remarkably prolonged spell of sunshine and fine weather. The result has been somewhat surprising in Britain at least. Britons are unused to it.

Showing a decided liking for the sloppy track, A.A. Baroni's Top Row, 4-year-old son of Peanuts and Too High, splashed his way home to an easy victory in the $5,000 added Yonkers Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth before a crowd of 10,000 at Empire City yesterday.

THE Welsh National Eisteddfod opens tomorrow in Carnarvon. Any lesser town would be submerged by this annual gathering of the clans, but Carnarvon has a castle big enough to tower above the clans like a rocky island in a flowing sea.

ADELAIDE, Australia, July 20. -- The worst dust storm in the history of Australia ended yesterday with rains in the settled areas and parts of the far north, where the weather had been persistently dry.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- With hotels and cottages filling rapidly, the White Mountain resorts now are starting definite programs of social and sports activities. The annual tennis championship for boys and girls is to be an important event of the coming week at Crawford Notch, where yesterday the annual White Mountain and New Hampshire State championships ended.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 20. -- With overcast clouds threatening rain, the 2,000 students of the citizens' military training camp paraded here today to honor the officers of the 305th Infantry who have trained them for the last two weeks.

Attempts to force through the present session of Congress a complete revision of the Federal Food and Drugs Act, as proposed in the Copeland bill, which passed the Senate in record time, will be strongly opposed by certain manufacturing and advertising interests when the measure comes up for hearing in Washington this week, it was learned yesterday.

OTTAWA. -- After 155 years of close if not always harmonious association, Canada and the United States are being drawn together as never before. One proof of the increasingly friendly relations was shown in the Conference on Canadian-American Affairs held recently at the university town Canton.

AERIAL mapping in the Dutch East Indies is far from a life of ease. At least that is the conviction of S.M. Burney of the Fairchild Aerial Surveys, who returned last week from an expedition to Sumatra. The terrain, which was photographed from the air with a five-lens camera, had not been mapped since 1883 and the maps of that date were found to be far from accurate.

HAVANA. -- Importers of American goods report considerable increase in sales throughout the island as a direct result of the agreement between the United States and Cuba which became effective Sept. 3, 1934, according to a survey made by the American Chamber of Commerce here.

The sinister education in idleness which millions of unemployed have received while on relief rolls is the greatest obstacle today to complete recovery from the depression, asserts Earnest Elmo Calkins in his article, "The Will to Recovery," in the August Current History.

THROUGH a loud-speaker the bus dispatcher booms, "Syracuse, Auburn, Rochester, Buffalo, 10:25"; then "Bridgeport, New Haven, Worcester, Providence, Boston, 10:33"; and, a little after, "All aboard for the Miami Special; no passenger stops."

A COURSE in fishing, in fly and bait-casting, was added recently to the physical education program at the Massachusetts State College. The course is part of a plan of individualized group instruction in the basic skills in sports which have "carry-over" value -- golf, tennis, swimming and archery, hiking and badminton.

The demand for better quality steel and iron in the last few years has definitely established molybdenum as one of the important alloys of these metals, it is said in metallurgical circles. World production of molybdenum in 1934 was estimated at more than 11,000,000 pounds, of which 9,400,000 pounds were produced in the United States.
CHICAGO, July 20. -- The Chicago Sunday Tribune, in a dispatch from its Washington bureau, tomorrow will say:

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The business week just closed was a most successful one, with prospects growing for a post-depression record in Fall wholesale and retail trade. The larger department stores reported sales substantially ahead of last year, with a dollar day feature drawing crowds and purchases that averaged close to the peak for this event.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., July 20. -- The greatest State-owned public playground in America, the Adirondacks, today celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the New York Forest Reserve with pageantry, oratory, a "synthetic forest fire" and an aquatic parade in the Fulton Chain of Lakes.

As between devaluation and deflation to scale down indebtedness, costs of living and production and attempts to restore "economic equilibrium," France has definitely decided upon deflation in the program announced last week by the Laval Ministry, in the opinion of bankers and economists.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 20. -- A dinner dance will be held here on Friday evening at the Westchester Embassy Club by the Eastern Westchester Maternal Health Committee. The divertissements will include programs by stage and screen celebrities.

ON Sept. 11, Longmans, Green Co. will publish a post-war Russian novel by Leonid Soboleff entitled "Romanoff." after the battleship which is at once the setting of many of the events described and a symbol of the state of Russia before the opening of the World War and after.

DETROIT, July 20. -- Automobile production held fairly steady this week, totaling 83,255 passenger cars and trucks in the United States and Canada, compared with 83,450 in the preceding week and 65,829 in the corresponding week last year, Cram's Reports, Inc., announced today.

THEY are still making silent pictures in Hollywood. In point of paradoxical fact every talkie is shot as a silent film for an appreciable extent of its footage. The sound comes in cans, precisely like peaches or tomatoes, and is added later, after the action has been photographed, by one of the most dexterous of the cinema's technical yogis, the person known as the sound "dubber."

A BOOKLET on New York's vacation lands has just been issued by the State Conservation Department. For the convenience of recreation seekers these playgrounds, extending from the wild stretches of 65,000-acre Allegany State Park to Long Island's modern resorts, are divided into twelve districts, each offering special attractions.
The situation that is developing with regard to Ethiopia must be of concern to every thoughtful American citizen. Some of the tragic features of such a war are these:

More than 7,000 persons attended a music festival last night at the Polo Grounds in which about 6,000 amateur musicians of the metropolitan area took part. The festival, given under the auspices of The New York Evening Journal, was for the benefit of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- The heat wave has had a detrimental effect upon trade during the past week, consumers having been already well supplied with Summer necessities for home, resort and camp life, but merchants continue drives upon some seasonable goods with varying results.

IN the essay with which Sir John Squire introduced the collection of drawings by Joseph Pennell which was published under the title "A London Reverie" he quoted G.K. Chesterton as saying that the statement "my aunt has tremendously changed" was a positive affirmation that she was still "my aunt."

Declaring that the amendment to the Sanitary Code proposed by the Municipal Department of Health which provides for the registration of toilet goods and proprietary medicines is "not one to protect public health but merely a move to obtain increased revenue," the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades Section of the New York Board of Trade opened an active campaign yesterday to defeat the measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 20. -- The foremost paddlers in the United States are gathered here to compete in the sixth annual national canoeing championships on Lake Carnegie tomorrow. Eighteen events are listed for the 800-meter course.

Activity in refunding high interest-bearing bond issues with proceeds obtained from new flotations having lower coupon rates showed no abatement last week. Definite plans for large redemptions in future months were disclosed, following successful refinancing, while proposals looking to refunding of other large blocks of bonds were advanced nearer to completion.

MOSCOW, July 20 (AP). -- All the property of workers' cooperative organizations which had been nationalized in the Russian Socialist Federation of Soviet Republics, comprising the bulk of the Soviet Union, today was ordered returned to the owners within one month.

RENO, July 20 (AP). -- Charles Levine, a Brooklyn junk dealer, who gained publicity as the first transatlantic airplane passenger, has established residence in Reno, presumably for divorce, it was learned today.
Luigi Pirandello, the dynamic Italian dramatist and story-teller who won the Nobel Prize for literature last year, came to the United States yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 20. -- Detectives said tonight that they had discovered the identity of a man found dead on the beach at Sands Point, L.I., on June 10. The body had a bullet wound in the head.

THE mellow appearance of a pine-sheathed wall in library or dining room can be closely simulated by new materials that are less expensive than selected knotty pine and much easier to install. Should the householder's taste incline to walls of shining modernity for the bath or powder room, this effect can be achieved for a moderate outlay.
NANKING -- Anti-Chinese policies in Siam, inspired by the growing nationalistic sentiment in that country, are to be met by China with economic, not military, weapons.

Partly as the result of the relative firmness of prices of most chemical products during the present season of comparative dullness, manufacturers here yesterday predicted a sharp increase in sales activity when the Fall buying season opens.

RUMOR grapevines around among the lonely cabins of the Ozarks that the "Federals" have come to drive every one away from the little clearings among the cedar brakes. The hill folk are to be ousted. They are to be forced away from their impoverished, rocky farms, where they have lived for generations, down to the richer land of the river valleys.

HONOLULU, July 20. -- America's research on islands lying along the future airline between the United States and Australia will advance Tuesday with the sailing of the yacht Kinkajou under Dr. Dana Coman of Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 20. -- The United States leads Germany by 1 -- 0 in the interzone final round of the Davis Cup competition by virtue of Donald Budge's victory over Heiner Henkel in four sets today. Rain prevented the playing of the match between Wilmer Allison and Baron Gottfried von Cramm. It will be held Monday.

Lightning killed four persons and injured four others at Brighton Beach yesterday afternoon during the severe thunderstorm that bombarded the metropolitan area, causing widespread but minor property damage, flooding streets and felling trees and telephone poles.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Increased vacation trips by motor were reported today by the American Automobile Association after a midyear survey of its 750 clubs and branches.

While buying was said to have been slightly under expectations in some divisions of the exhibit of Fall corset lines last week at the Hotel McAlpin, manufacturers' representatives expressed confidence yesterday that there will be a sharp pickup in sales activities this week.

CICELY COURTNEIDGE, probably the most famous of British comediennes and the wife of Jack Hulbert, passed through New York last week on her way to Hollywood to make her first American picture. It will be an experiment.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 20. -- Ray Billows concluded his sensational career in the New York State amateur golf tournament today by winning the championship.

FOR twenty-five years the author, as leader of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism and Professor of Homiletics at the Jewish Theological Seminary, has been expounding the thesis elaborated in this volume.

As guests of the Municipal Art Committee, more than 2,000 children are expected to participate in a choral concert at 12:30 P.M. on Wednesday at the City Hall in honor of Mayor La Guardia. This number will represent a selection from 180,000 members of children's choruses of the ERB, which have voluntarily taken advantage of the municipal musical activities arranged for them in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Richmond.
BROADCASTERS are making up their autumnal charts, and the present indication is that the air will be crowded with many old-timers continuing where they left off in the springtime.

TSINAN, Shantung, China, Sunday, July 21. -- Enormous devastation and huge loss of life are consequence of the diversion southward of the waters of the Yellow River, due to its breach of dikes near Linpuchi, in Southeastern Shantung Province, last week.

IT IS twenty years since kingdoms in Europe crashed. The lurid glare of propaganda has faded into the chill dawn of disillusion. Actors are back in the green room and the war paint has been wiped off their complexions.
ROME, July 20. -- The chief obstacles that Italy has met in carrying out her East African plans derive from the fact that Ethiopia is a member of the League of Nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20. -- Elated with the present tourist and vacation travel, the greatest movement of such travelers recorded on the Pacific Coast, officials of all shipping companies are turning to the next business in hand, which will be the handling of the annual harvest of agricultural products of California.

HOPES for home television soared with the recent announcement that "progress in the laboratories in the development of a new type of cable circuit known as 'coaxial' has reached a point where it is deemed advisable to carry out actual installation in the field in order to obtain experience with such practical problems as cannot be explored in the laboratories."

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- To enable the Coast Guard to cope more effectively with liquor smuggling, still one of its major law-enforcement problems, and to help it in its many other duties, President Roosevelt has approved a recommendation made by the Advisory Committee on Allotments for the Works Program for the allocation of $5,263,995 for the building of patrol boats and the reconditioning of shore stations.

A surprising number of names beginning with B were signed to 816 telegrams, all expressing opposition to the Public Utility Holding Company Bill, which were received June 27 and 28 by D.J. Driscoll, a Democratic Representative from Pennsylvania. Mr. Driscoll couldn't figure out why the B's among his constituents should be more wrought up than the general run.

LONDON, Sunday, July 21. -- Captain Joseph Chamberlain, elder son of Sir Austen Chamberlain, has been arrested by Wahabi officials of King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia, whose son, Crown Prince Saud, is now visiting London.

Open revolt against any extension of the Agricultural Adjustment Act was threatened here yesterday as food and grocery interests appealed for suspension of further legislation on the pending bill until the United States Supreme Court takes action on the constitutionality of the present measure.

MIDSUMMER in New York is not productive of large or numerous exhibitions, but events current include decided points of interest, even without reckoning shows in the Summer art colonies and near-by resorts.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- One thing Mussolini's pending invasion of the land of Emperor Haile Sellassie promises to accomplish is the use of the correct name of the country. It is Ethiopia, not Abyssinia, although the two have been used synonymously for centuries.

RAPID developments have been made in recent years in improved methods of producing healthy seedlings of vegetables and of annual and perennial flowering plants. These new methods are of vital interest to those who have had trouble with seed decay or wholesale death of young seedlings in the seed box or garden.

MANY flowers are emblematic to numerous people, but to the Passion Flower has been given a symbolism that interests the largest number. Most of the varieties are native to South America. There Passiflora caerula attracted the special interest of early Spanish missionaries..

NEW YORK STATE maintains 600 miles of trails inviting campers and hikers to mountainous and wooded seclusion. Here, amid the sighing of wind in pine trees, the babbling of mountain brooks and the chirping and singing of hidden birds, the city dweller for a brief spell forgets the tooting of taxicabs, the jangling of street-cars and the rattling roar of subways.

AUSTRIA has proclaimed a new deal for tourists. The government is seeing to it that travelers -- particularly American travelers -- are informed of the country's newest attractions as well as those honored by tradition. And it is smoothing the path.

IN an attempt to clarify city school practices in regard to teachers' health, the Federal Office of Education recently completed a nation-wide study on "The Welfare of the Teacher." Two of every three large cities in the United States, it was revealed, require teachers to submit a certificate of health before appointment, although few definite standards of health have been set up.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 20 (AP). -- The body of Robert Stuart 3d, 29, who died here penniless, lay today in a cemetery plot contributed by a church. His widow said that a New York bank held a $1,250,000 trust fund which ultimately would have been his.

After about a century of haphazard use for various institutional purposes. New York City's East River islands are about to be systematically developed, partly for park service, partly for occupation by modern hospitals and other institutions which will replace the hideous and antiquated firetraps now standing.

MANILA. -- General Emilio Aguinaldo is not meeting with much success in the opening stages of his campaign for the Presidency of the Philippine Commonwealth. His platform failed to arouse any degree of favorable comment in the Philippine press and apparently failed to attract certain groups for whose support he had hoped.

Non-boat owners and Corinthian members of the South Shore Power Squadron, the Long Island unit of the United States Power Squadrons, will be guests of the boat owners of the organization today on the occasion of the annual all-members' cruise and rendezvous at Zach's Bay, Jones Beach.

THIS first novel by a captain in the British Army arrives buttressed by a recommendation of the English Book Society and a pair of fine endorsements. One is from Frances Iles, who said: "I don't remember any novel more full of truly sick-making suspense."

A COMPARATIVE lack of tension at first nights and at social events of extreme dogginess has lately been evident in the East. Nothing has been crashed with an eclat worthy of record in the press. The barriers have been let down, democracy has gone rampant.

ZAGREB, July 20. -- The red, white and blue Croat banner banned six years ago by the Yugoslav dictatorship today waved over the Croat capital on the occasion of the fifty-sixth birthday of Dr. Vladimir Matchek, Croat Peasant leader. The Croat Nationalist parties seized the opportunity to demonstrate for a free Croatia and Croat racial feeling.
The writer is chairman of the legislative committee of the National Conference of Bituminous Coal Producers, a group of mine owners who are supporting H.R. 8479 -- the so-called Guffey-Snyder bill.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The sweeping denunciation of "political clericalism" leveled by General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, at Catholicism, has injected a fresh recrimination into the already highly acrimonious relations of the church and National Socialist State.

THE woman returning to this country after visiting Turkey, Germany, Russia and Italy, as this writer did -- after talking to women of nearly forty nations at the International Suffrage Conference at Istanbul -- might well conclude that the gains of women in their fight for equal rights have been greater than their losses.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Taking notice of some complaints of farm-labor shortages, the Agriculture Department said today that on July 1 the supply of farm labor throughout the United States was 95.7 per cent of normal and the demand 80.5 per cent of normal.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 20. -- Out of a massed attack that made par look ridiculous, Lighthorse Harry Cooper of Chicago made one of his most famous rides at Keller today to finish one stroke ahead of Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles at the half-way post in the $5,000 St. Paul open golf championship.

The new special investigator of Manhattan rackets, Thomas E. Dewey, submitted a budget for his inquiry last week calling for expenditures at an annual rate of more than $250,000, and the Board of Estimate gave its approval by appropriating the first instalment.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20. -- Caught in a northeast squall that loomed like a Texas twister, Long Island Sound's racing yachts went through thunder and lightning this afternoon and a 45-mile an hour blow in the last regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.

Here is a lovable successor to those two lively Sealyhams, Michael and Patsy, whose antics as told and illustrated by Dorothy and Marguerite Bryan have endeared them to many children of the picture-book age. Tammie was one of those determined Scottie puppies whose other name is persistence.
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- Lack of wind off the Speonk shore today marred the sailing in the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club's regatta on Moriches Bay.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., July 20. -- A gold "field" discovered here recently in a sandbank, and believed not worth working, may be of considerable value, it was disclosed here today. A study of the section near the bank is being made for a vein rich in the ore which experts think may be the source of nuggets found.

Sag Harbor, a convenient anchorage for yachtsmen cruising On the Peconics and toward Montauk, may get a $59,300 appropriation this year for dredging and annual maintenance funds of $5,000 as the result of a recommendation by Major Gem E.M. Markham, Chief of Engineers of the United States Army.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- The aborigines of Australia, probably the most primitive of the surviving races, are rapidly dying out, it is revealed by the report of The Commonwealth Statistician. Their numbers fell by 10 per cent last year. The figure of 54,800 is 5,200 below that which was returned in 1933 and is tragically lower than the population before the arrival of the first white settlers.

ST. LOUIS, July 20. -- A sharp gain in the industrial field in the Eighth Federal Reserve District is the feature of the business situation in the last week. Both big and heavy plants have quickened in a marked degree. In addition to a large car order received a week ago another has been received which promises to keep big plants busy for some time.

TO prevent barrel-like booms or "echoes," caused by radio sets being placed too close to the wall, "acoustic clarifiers" have been developed by the Philco Radio and Television Corporation. The unit is said to permit full bass reproduction without a tendency to boom.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 20. -- Common Pleas Judge J. Edward Knight refused citizenship yesterday to a man who was once convicted of murder, and in giving his decision declared that native criminals are a "sufficient problem" without complicating it by fortifying alien criminals with citizenship.

TWO Michigan playgrounds in primeval country have been opened to aerial tourists by the recent extension of plane services. They are Isle Royale in Lake Superior and the district around Newberry, which is but twenty minutes by plane from the new Two Hearted River Landing Field.

ONE of the best ways to keep dinner guests cool during the dog days is to give them something cool to look at. The pall of stillness that sometimes descends on a dinner party in hot weather, when even polite small talk is an effort, might be dissipated if there was an icy-looking centrepiece made up of some of the new glass or porcelain table decorations.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- A thunderstorm held up today's skirmish between the Giants and Cubs at Wrigley Field for close to an hour, but the downpour didn't provide enough interference to save our Giants from their second straight setback at the hands of Charley Grimm's clan.
The Red Queen gave a sigh of contentment, put down her newspaper, and fanned herself with it slowly. Alice could only wonder that any one should look so happy in such terrible weather.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 20 (AP). -- While rain-soaked passengers lined the rails, a lifeboat crew from the steamer City of Lowell fought an hour's battle with a tossing sea to save two youths from going down in their foundering sailboat in Long Island Sound last night.

BOSTON, July 20. -- Discovery, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's four-year-old champion and world record holder, today defeated P.A. Shaw's Gov. Sholtz by fifteen lengths to capture the $10,000 added Bunker Hill Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

Clergymen will preach today about the Italo-Ethiopian situation, and will offer prayers that war between the two countries may be averted. A few ministers will discuss the anti-Semitic riot in Germany. Almost every Protestant pulpit in the centre of Manhattan will have a guest preacher as the pastors with few exceptions are on their Summer vacations.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Indications of a near-agreement on important rates in the administration tax bill emerged tonight from the House Ways and Means Committee.

ALBANY, July 20. -- The need to plan for flood control came with a shock to New Yorkers in the section of the State which was devastated by the recent downpour. They have been in the habit of connecting floods with the Mississippi or the Ohio, and that floods should pour down the narrow New York valleys and swell tiny streams to destructive size is still almost inconceivable.

THE DRAPIER'S LETTERS" is one of Swift's great triumphs of pamphleteering as well as one of his great battles in the struggle against human oppression. Never did he batter more thrustingly against what he conceived of as injustice than in these onslaughts against Wood's patent to coin and circulate halfpence in Ireland; never any one, perhaps, more successfully aroused a nation to so unified a pitch of resistance.
CONFIDENT of bright prospects for radio sales, the RCA Manufacturing Company announced during the past week, "we are stepping up production 100 per cent over the year before, in anticipation."

MOUNT RUSKMORE. TOWERING above surrounding mountain peaks, the stone faces of George Washington and Thomas Jefferson look down upon the Black Hills of South Dakota. Rock is now being cleared away where the head of Theodore Roosevelt will be cut next in the mountainside, according to W.S. Tallman, superintendent of the Mr. Rushmore National Memorial.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Chairman Black announced today that the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee, complying with a request from William Ramsey, head of the Utility Consumers League of York, will call as a witness Tuesday Quay C. Aller, sales representative of Metropolitan Edison Company at York, Pa. Luther A. Coleman, manager of the Postal Telegraph Company at York, and J.E. Coble, manager of the York Western Union office, also have been asked to testify.

Despite the extremely warm weather, retail sales here improved last week and d artment store executives estimated that the total was equal to, if not slightly ahead of, the corresponding period in 1934. This showing was in contrast to that of the previous week, when volume slipped behind last year.
ISTANBUL, July 20. -- In Turkey, as everywhere else in the world, the Italo-Ethiopian dispute is today one of the chief topics of conversation.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20 (AP). -- After a conference today with State heath authorities, Floyd King, representative for Cole Brothers Circus and Clyde Beatty's wild animal exhibition, announced the cancellation of ten scheduled engagements in Virginia because of the infantile paralysis epidemic.

The American Institute of Steel Construction has begun a movement to improve standards of competition in the structural steel industry by voluntary action and education rather than by coercion. The new code will not be submitted to the Federal Trade Commission, since it is the consensus of the industry that no advantages would be gained by receiving sanction for non-enforceable rules.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP). -- Off to an early start with four runs, scored on three doubles and a single off Tony Freitas, the Phillies defeated the Reds, 9 to 3, today. The Phillies made seven doubles in all off the Cincinnati pitchers to even the series at one game each.

Production in the gold and platinum jewelry manufacturing trade was still paralyzed by the strike of 3,500 jewelry workers yesterday, it was reported by the International Jewelry Workers Union, Local 1, which called the strike on Thursday and threatened to extend it to Newark and Philadelphia.

I notice in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine an article by Dr. McBain, Professor of Constitutional Law, Columbia University, in which he sets forth the different contentions as to how the NRA may be resurrected. I think it unfortunate that the professor did not go further and give his own views.

ALBANY, July 20 (AP). -- State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews frowned tonight on a proposal by insurance companies that New York laborers exposed to silica and other dust hazards submit to compulsory, physical examination under threat of discharge after Sept. 1.

After being postponed four times, the case of the Morris Y.C. in Part 1, Special Term of the Bronx Supreme Court, was again deferred recently and in all likelihood the Summer recess will assure the members of the club at Pelham Bay Park of at least another season.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 20. -- As a further step in Princeton's program of adjusting the courses to the varying aptitudes of the students, McCormick Hall, the university's home of art and archaeology, is being remodeled this Summer to accommodate the new changes in the school's curriculum by increasing the study and research area 50 per cent.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The Reich Ministry of Justice issued instructions today to all prosecuting authorities to display the greatest energy in obtaining the chastisement of Catholic clergymen coming under the recent demand of General Hermann Goering, Prussian Premier and head of the secret State police, for stricter control of the Catholic Church.

TORONTO, July 20. -- Gold production in Canada in May reached a total of 269,238 ounces, valued at $9,409,599, according to a report just issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics at Ottawa. In April 245,697 ounces were produced and in May, 1934, the output was 261,125 ounces.

IN August, 1850, an emigrant train consisting of twenty wagons, fifty men, women and children, and a band of cattle left Independence, Mo., and started westward along the Santa Fe Trail. But they were not impelled by the gold-thirst that was then sending just such trains by the score along all the roads to the Western coast.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Production recovered in the week ended on July 13 from the sharp drop in the previous week caused by the July 4 holiday, but the rate of operations was below the June level, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of the domestic business situation.

Every so often a child wonder is brought forward and set before the public with attendant fanfare and adulation that are disproportionate to actual ability, but the latest prodigy to flash onto the athletic scene has won her place against the stiffest kind of competition and is already a fullfledged star.

The markets, except cotton, generally displayed a firm tone in yesterday's brief trading period during which the activity was slowed down in strict accordance with the season. The share market moved narrowly, with the price range held to limits of small fractions to 1 1/2 points; the closing was irregularly higher.
BOSTON, July 20. -- Mickey Cochrane has it all figured out how his Tigers are going to jump over the Yankees into the American League lead.

THE problem Dorothy Aldis has chosen, and dealt with in a charming manner, is the fairly universal one of becoming adjusted to newly acquired in-laws. There is no major tragedy involved, but the innumerable vicissitudes which beset a bride are amusingly and tenderly amplified, so that "Their Own Apartment" merits a star on the list of light Summer reading.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP). -- The Braves dropped both games of today's double-header with the Pirates, running their consecutive string of defeats to fourteen. The scores were 14 to 2 and 6 to 3.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Summer residents of Bar Harbor and the neighboring resorts are especially interested in maintaining the work of the Mount Desert Island Hospital, which serves the community the year round.

Following the recent ruling of the American Power Boat Association permitting increased power and superchargers, officials in charge of the thirty-second running of the Gold Cup championship at Bolton Landing, Lake George, Saturday predict a new record for the regatta.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20 (AP). -- After a conference today with State heath authorities, Floyd King, representative for Cole Brothers Circus and Clyde Beatty's wild animal exhibition, announced the cancellation of ten scheduled engagements in Virginia because of the infantile paralysis epidemic.

The American Institute of Steel Construction has begun a movement to improve standards of competition in the structural steel industry by voluntary action and education rather than by coercion. The new code will not be submitted to the Federal Trade Commission, since it is the consensus of the industry that no advantages would be gained by receiving sanction for non-enforceable rules.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP). -- Off to an early start with four runs, scored on three doubles and a single off Tony Freitas, the Phillies defeated the Reds, 9 to 3, today. The Phillies made seven doubles in all off the Cincinnati pitchers to even the series at one game each.

Production in the gold and platinum jewelry manufacturing trade was still paralyzed by the strike of 3,500 jewelry workers yesterday, it was reported by the International Jewelry Workers Union, Local 1, which called the strike on Thursday and threatened to extend it to Newark and Philadelphia.

ALBANY, July 20 (AP). -- State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews frowned tonight on a proposal by insurance companies that New York laborers exposed to silica and other dust hazards submit to compulsory, physical examination under threat of discharge after Sept. 1.

BEPORTS on the production and sale of motor vehicles during the first half of 1935 continue to show substantial gains over last year .... The total Ford domestic sales of 634,961 units was reached by the delivery of 100,882 vehicles in June, making that month the best June Since 1930 and the fourth consecutive month in which Ford sales have exceeded 100.000 units ....

Bandits held up Joseph Yovin of 32-50 Seventy-ninth Street, Jackson Heights, manager of the Crescent Theatre at 27-18 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, yesterday morning and escaped with a $400 payroll after tying Yovin and a 14-year-old boy in the office of the theatre.
M.E.M." of this city has written the editor of these columns as follows:
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Comments such as "tragic" and "regrettable" were heard on Capitol Hill today as legislators read dispatches telling of German Nazis harassing Catholics and Jews.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 20. -- A feud smoldering for years between two scientists who make Bermuda their base blazed into the open today with the assertion by Dr. Louis L. Mowbray, a world authority on ichthyology, that Dr. William Beebe, in taking the position that sharks would not attack human beings, "was moved solely by a desire for publicity."

SOUTHAMPTON -- Prominent women, headed by Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, in all the towns and villages at this end of Long Island, are taking an active interest in Southampton Hospital Week, which begins tomorrow and whose purpose is to raise $18,000 for the free service of the Southampton Hospital.

SCARCELY one of the surprisingly numerous posthumous volumes of Donn Byrne's stories has added anything ponderable to his reputation as an artist. The romantic fire of "Messer Marco Polo" and of "Changeling and Other Stories" has not been reflected in any of the works published since Donn Byrne's untimely death in 1928, and it seems increasingly clear that it will not be.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Sufficient time has elapsed since the Supreme Court invalidated the NIRA to make an appraisal of what has happened to wages, hours and fair trade practices which were the main props of the Codes of Fair Competition.

Few possess the conviction that the American system gave to the world an exact science of government. Our system was founded upon that moral law by which the universe is ordered. The American people must suffer until they turn again to leaders who know the nature and origin of our system.

NEW ORLEANS, July 20 (AP). -- The State administration whip of Senator Huey P. Long was felt today in New Orleans when it cracked down on the city administration of Mr. Long's enemy, Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, and cut off sixty-seven deputies sheriff.
During the past several days the Virgin Islands have again been in the news in a way second only to the time five years ago when President Hoover referred to them as an "effectual poorhouse."

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 20. -- Although showers interrupted play in the Northern New Jersey tennis championship, which got under way at the Westfield Tennis Club today, the field of fifty-eight practically was halved.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- A firm attitude has been taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission against modification of Form 18 for the permanent registration by foreign governments or their political subdivisions of bonds and other securities traded in on the Stock Exchanges.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- Two hundred sailors on thirty-eight Lake Yacht Racing Association craft participating in the Annual Freeman Cup cruise of 126 nautical miles on Lake Ontario from Sodus Point to Port of Rochester and then to Kingston, Ontario, tonight headed straight for trouble.

Lieut. Col. George W. Buckner, Commandant at West Point, is highly gratified with the success of his experiment in importing girl dance instructors to teach the United States Military Academy Cadets the ballroom arts and graces.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 20 (AP). -- Communistic activity in the Morrell packing plant strike here was alleged today as the situation quieted down after yesterday's riot in which fifty-four union and nonunion men were injured in a hand-to-hand battle.

EASTPORT, Me., July 20. -- A farmer today turned the tables on land speculators accused of trying to hold up the Federal Government for as much as $4,000 an acre on undeveloped land to be used as a site for a model village at the $86,000,000 Quoddy tidal power project.

The young man who is a guest at the home of David Pencoch when the trouble begins is William Williams, but Miss Ivy Pencoch has already begun to call him Billy. Williams is the managing director of The Share and Stock Corporation, Limited, but his title means next to nothing, for he is what the unimaginative British call a "nominee."

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange came almost to a standstill yesterday for prolonged intervals in the short session. Sales dropped to the lowest level since Aug. 18, 1934, amounting to $3,677,300, compared with $4,580,000 on the previous Saturday. With many traders away, few important price movements developed and the domestic list generally held within a narrow range.

LONDON. -- The British Government's hesitant attitude toward Italy's warlike moves in Africa, like her quick acceptance of the new German navy, has aroused curiosity both at home and abroad as to the present British foreign policy.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- Federal interest is involved in all streams of watersheds where human lives are lost and property is damaged during floods, Chairman Riley J. Wilson of the House of Representatives Flood Control Committee told members of the special Congressional committee investigating conditions in South Central New York, where floods a few days ago took a toll of forty-three lives and caused damage estimated at more than $25,000,000.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 20. -- Twenty of the more than sixty boats that started in the invitation regatta of the Bay Shore Yacht Club today dropped out before one leg of the 12-mile course was covered because of a storm that broke over the bay.

THE G Men, and an invaluable girl colleague, extend themselves as undercover agents in this squalid exposure of commercialized vice and crime during the momentous first year of repeal. One Eye Zigo, gangland big shot and boss bootlegger under prohibition, now refuses to abandon the liquor line for new fields of lawlessness, splitting over the issue, though still on friendly terms, with his partner, Rap Covani, killer, bandit and muscle man of the deadliest species.

KINNELON, N.J., July 20. -- Despite opposition by former Mayor Jerome T. Congleton of Newark, music and beer will be permitted here tomorrow at the German "waldfest" in the Nazi camp of the American National Socialist League.

THE useful life of an airplane frequently exceeds five years and there are at least 169 civilian airplanes now in service in the United States which were built in 1926 or before, according to the Bureau of Air Commerce. Studying the licensing records as of June 1, 1935, the bureau found that there were 8,733 civilian airplanes, of which 5,841 were licensed and 2,892 were unlicensed, but bore identification marks.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The tenth annual Lenox Horse Show is to be held at the Hanna Farm next Friday and Saturday, with the annual Horse Show ball at the Lenox Club on Saturday night. There will be forty-six classes in the show and most of the prizes will be cash.

Within an hour after police sent out an eight-State alarm yesterday for Mary Beno, 10 years old, as a missing child, she was found in a vacant top-floor apartment of the building at 205 Seventh Street, where her parents lived on the second floor.

A sharp break in Liverpool following the settlement of an extensive foreign short interest, besides two Texas court decisions declaring the Bankhead Act unconstitutional, kept trading unsettled on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday. Losses were about 12 to 20 points.
The Democrats at Washington have failed to heed the old proverb, "God helps those who help themselves." Having lived sheltered lives, the brain trusters know nothing of the value of hardship.

IN its stark realism this novel by the young Irish writer James Hanley attains to the proportions of major fiction. It is no book of mere Summer entertainment. There is something almost Greek in its simplicity of style, and something still more nearly Greek in its evocation of the feelings of pity and horror.

A vigorous campaign to retain their railroad scrap business, which in normal years amounts to $50,000,000, will be launched on Tuesday by scrap iron dealers, when they convene in Chicago to formulate a defense against the Eastman report to the carriers.

ST. LOUIS, July 20. -- Casey Stengel and his Dodgers kept their five-game winning streak intact today, out not through a second triumph over the champion Cardinals. Rain, one of those typical Midwest downpours, stopped the contest five minutes after it started.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Reports of black rust came thick and fast from the Northwest today, and while traders here were inclined to t fight any tendency of the wheat market to advance, the finish was at the top at net gains of 1 1/2 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel.

Thursday morning in Addis Ababa, Ethiopian leaders, including the Abuna (Egyptian head of the Ethiopian Church), priests and military officers, gathered in Parliament House, opposite the great palace. Five minutes before noon a pink silk veil dropped from the Emperor's box and Haile Sellassie, clad in khaki field uniform, rose from his throne and said:
The Museum of the City of New York announces that in the late Autumn or early Winter a new permanent costume alcove will be opened to the public.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace expressed the opinion today the United States could fill its own needs for pulpwood and paper, but questioned the advisability of "self-sufficiency" in this industry.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- From New England's textile capital last week came news that rocked the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, keystone of the government's farm recovery program, to its foundations. Two Federal judges of the three that compose the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Boston had held not only that the taxes levied on textile processing were invalid as taxes but that the law authorizing them was unconstitutional.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- Champions of yesteryear joined the issue with the younger generation of tennis players today as the annual invitation doubles tournament started on the turf courts of the Maidstone Club.

THE Legislatures of some forty-four States have been in session during the present year. Most of them have now adjourned. With the tremendous increase in motor transportation it was quite natural that numerous laws affecting the use of the highways should have been enacted by the various States.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., July 20. -- Forty-one airplanes, representing a cross-section of American flying, left the school field here this morning for the fourth annual International Good-Will Cruise to Montreal. They carried sixty-two passengers in addition to their pilots.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 20. -- The $1,000,000 Whiteface Mountain Memorial Highway was opened today in the presence of a large crowd when a white ribbon stretched across the road at the toll house was cut by Mrs. Frederick S. Greene, wife of the State Superintendent of Public Works.

A crusade of students into the Mexican State of Tabasco, recruited by foes of Tomas Garrido Canabal, master of Tabasco, was interrupted last week when machine-gunfire was directed at the invaders in Villa Hermosa. Thus Garrido Canabal, although he resigned as Minister of Agriculture in the shake-up some weeks ago that established President Lazara Cardenas's ascendancy over General Plutarco Elias Calles, has once again demonstrated the hold he has over his native Tabascans.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- four-hit pitching by Jack La Rocca enabled the Newark Bears to snap out of their extended losing streak as the Chiefs were thrashed, 11 to 0, before 3,000 fans tonight. It was Newark's first victory in fourteen starts and there was never any doubt as to the outcome, when the Bruins collected four runs off Flint Rhem in the first.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Building construction values last month showed an increase of 87.4 per cent over June, 1934, and a 10.4 per cent increase over May of this year as against a 20 per cent decrease from May to June during each of the four preceding years, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, stated today.

One of the most important titles of polo is to be decided at 4 o'clock this afternoon on Schley Field of the Burnt Mills Polo Club, Bedminster, N.J. At that hour Texas, with Cecil Smith, nine-goal star, will ride out to face the Aiken Knights, led by the nine-goal Winston Guest in the final round of the national junior championship.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 20. -- The worst uproar ever known to Wimbledon occurred today after rain had played havoc with the first day's matches between the United States and Germany in the Davis Cup interzone tennis final.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Discussion of the tariff consumed today in the Senate almost all of a four-hour session especially arranged to expedite progress on long-retarded amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Of a little more than passing interest, perhaps, was the disclosure made in last week's Federal Reserve report that the banks of the country, notably the New York institutions, in subscribing for the recent offering of $500,000,000 Treasury 1 3/8 per cent notes elected to pay for a large portion in cash.

Harry Wallace Cullin, a publicity man for almost fifty years, was killed at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon when he was struck by a truck and knocked down while crossing Seventh Avenue at Thirty-second Street. He was about 70 years old.

That American-bred dogs in a very large number of the breeds have made such progress and have become so well established that it is no longer necessary to make in portations to win top show honors is revealed in figures just compiled and released by the American Kennel Club.

LONDON, July 20. -- Competition between the Normandie and Queen Mary was ruled out today by high officials of Britain and France in speaking at a luncheon aboard the giant French liner in Cowes Roads.

LINCOLN, England, July 20 (AP). -- Viscountess Astor struck a personal note in a lecture to an assembly of teachers on birth control when she asserted her family would not have been so large if she had known what she knows now.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Judicial scrutiny of the New Deal resulted in decisions in three major test cases during the past week, marking considerable progress in the slow process of determining the constitutionality of the administration's program.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- four-hit pitching by Jack La Rocca enabled the Newark Bears to snap out of their extended losing streak as the Chiefs were thrashed, 11 to 0, before 3,000 fans tonight. It was Newark's first victory in fourteen starts and there was never any doubt as to the outcome, when the Bruins collected four runs off Flint Rhem in the first.

A crusade of students into the Mexican State of Tabasco, recruited by foes of Tomas Garrido Canabal, master of Tabasco, was interrupted last week when machine-gunfire was directed at the invaders in Villa Hermosa. Thus Garrido Canabal, although he resigned as Minister of Agriculture in the shake-up some weeks ago that established President Lazara Cardenas's ascendancy over General Plutarco Elias Calles, has once again demonstrated the hold he has over his native Tabascans.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 20. -- Gaining two pounds in the last thirty-six hours, Joe Randazza Jr., aged 3 years and 6 months, weighed tonight 137 pounds, one less than Leslie Bowles 3, of Ramsgate, England, present holder of the title of world's largest baby.

A week's consideration of the agreement between this country and Russia left foreign traders convinced yesterday that the trade pact was more of a gesture than anything else and that its chief value lies in establishing the principle of a Russian trade agreement divorced from the troublesome problem of Soviet debt negotiations.

SAN FRANCISCO. IN a year, or eighteen months at the outside, for construction is running far ahead of schedule, the giant bridge spanning San Francisco Bay will be completed and the ferries will slip into legend. Business, transportation and civic pride thus realize a long-cherished dream, but, for all of that, such realization is not without its sadness.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 20. -- The installation of nearly 200 park-o-meters on business streets here has started a controversy which has not yet settled the fate of the city's attempt to reduce traffic congestion and raise revenue. On Tuesday, the first day the meters were put in service, there was noticeably less traffic congestion, but few people paid the five-cent fee required by the city for parking use of the streets.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- A Congress, its ending overdue and pushing toward adjournment, is in certain respects easy game for marplots and professional lobbies. The closing hours of the Seventy-third Congress last June demonstrated anew this long-proved fact. Now that the Seventy-fourth Congress is moving into the same position, it will require complete Presidential command and a shower of good luck to prevent the same thing from happening.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The women's annual international invitation tournament, which opens tomorrow on the Hotel Champlain championship course to continue through Friday, inaugurates an important series of major golf events to continue through July and August on the principal courses in the Adirondacks and the Champlain Valley.

NEW ORLEANS, July 18. -- The political battle, admittedly one of elimination between Senator Huey P. Long and Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, reached a climax here this week when fifteen out of the seventeen "Old Regular" leaders met in caucus and decided to cast their lot with the senior Senator from Louisiana.

ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.J., July 20. -- A violent northwest wind and rain squalls forced many of the yachts to lower sails, capsized others and kept the Coast Guard rescue boats busy during the later races of the thirty-fourth annual Morgan Cup regatta today.

Houghton Mifflin has granted to the American Foundation for the Blind permission to reproduce in the form of "talking books" 300 copies each of "Years of Grace," by Margaret Ayer Barnes, and "Forty-two Years in the White House," by Irwin H. (Ike) Hoover.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 21 (AP). -- A procession of potential Republican Presidential timber began winding its way toward the home of former President Herbert Hoover here today with the arrival of Governor Harry W. Nice of Maryland.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- "For Sale or Rent" signs, "Apply to Uncle Sam," or their equivalent may soon be expected on vacant homes in many parts of the country. The government is being forced into the real estate business on an increasingly large scale by defaulting borrowers from the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 21. -- The Washington Canoe Club of Washington. D.C. won the sixth annual national canoeing team championship on Lake Carnegie today.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Although the Gold Discount Bank absorbs considerable superfluous money by selling notes, it cannot stem the inundation of cash deriving from Reich work-creation on credit. Therefore there are developing signs of slow inflation which is reflected in a rise in prices.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 21. -- President Livingston Farrand of Cornell University announced today that James Lynah, '05, of Savannah, Ga., prominent Cornell alumnus and retired motor corporation official, had been appointed Cornell's first director of athletics.

Cotton prices were generally lower last week on the decision of the Federal Circuit Court in Boston declaring the processing taxes unconstitutional, the restraining order issued by a Federal judge in Texas against the collection of the ginner's tax under the Bankhead act and an improvement in the outlook for the current crop.

LONDON, July 20. -- The feature of the financial situation in London is the remarkable rush of new security offerings. This week's issues alone exceeded 40,000,000, including 32,000,000 for financing the electrification of railways under a government guarantee.

NORTH WILDWOOD, N.J., July 21. -- Eight youths and ten girls, all between the ages of 17 and 23, were arrested here shortly before 3 o'clock this morning in a police raid on a high school fraternity house. The raid was the result of a complaint that noisy parties were held there regularly in the early morning hours.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW JERSEY, -- July 21. -- Two honest-to-goodness prairie dogs with beady eye and sharp claws turned up at a golf course here this morning and officials of the club immediately speeded the news to New York newspaper offices.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- In a few days it is expected that the closing chapter will be written on the Social Security Bill when the Senate decides to support or oppose the action of the House in defeating the Clark amendment, which would permit employers to maintain private pension plans.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 21. -- Clifford M. Grover's White Mist and Mrs. Charles E. Lucks Jr.'s Eel were selected as entries of the Barnegat Bay fleet in the Atlantic Coast championships of the International Star Class after finishing first and second in today's event.
DUBLIN, July 21. -- Sectarian riots in Belfast that led to the destruction of many homes of Catholics resulted in serious counter-sectarian outbreaks in the Irish Free State yesterday and today.

When tile Union Dime Savint,'s. Bank sold to the Lexington Management Corp., Ruth Rutenberg, president, tile northwest corner of Lexington Av. and 103d St., 100x30, at an indicated price of $25,000, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for that amount, due as per bond.
Because of failure of the House and Senate to agree on the Clark amendment to the Social Security Bill, the measure has again been sent to conference.

VIENNA, July 21. -- A remark interpreted as derogatory to Vice Chancellor Ernst von Starhemberg is believed to have brought a jail sentence of four and one-half months to Alfred Benesch of Barrhead, Alberta, Canada.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- Frank Parker of Spring Lake, N.J., and Martin Buxby of Miami, Fla., won the East Hampton invitation doubles tennis tournament today at the Maidstone Club.

NEW ORLEANS, July 20. -- Trading was slack in the cotton market here the past week. Not only was speculative interest lacking, but even scalping operations were limited by a scarcity of contracts. Fluctuations in prices were narrow, the extreme spread being a shade above a dollar a bale, or about 21 points.

MUNICH, July 21. -- The British Legion's delegation of five declined today to lay a wreath on the tablet in Feldherrn Halle to the memory of the Nazi insurgents killed in the unsuccessful revolt against the Bavarian Government in 1923.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 21 (AP). -- Snipers shot and killed Eddie Scarlett tonight, increasing to nine the deaths in rioting since the Orangemen's demonstration on July 12.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 21. -- Recently back from an extensive tour, during which he played polo in India and England, Michael Phipps, who starred at No. 1 on last season's Eastern four, gave an impressive performance in leading the well-mounted Long Island quartet to a 10-to-7 victory over Austin today in the weekly high-goal match at Bostwick Field.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- Lady Lindsay, wife of Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador at Washington, had luncheon guests at the Hedges today.

Led by Alderman Donald L. O'Toole, a committee of striking caddies at the city-owned Dyker Heights golf course near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, will call on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall today to protest against the employment of strike-breakers.

MOSCOW, July 21. -- The Tass (Soviet) News Agency reported tonight that many persons were killed in Meshed, Iran (Persia), in disorders resulting from a government decree that the people wear European style hats instead of native headgear.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 21. -- Need for Finland to refortify the Aland Islands' "strategically key position in the Baltic" was emphasized yesterday by the newspaper Ajan Suunta, chief organ of the Finnish Fascist and Nazi elements.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,448,232,080. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

KINNELON, N,J., July 21. -- More than 1,000 Nazi sympathizers, members of the American National Socialist League, took part today in a "waldfest" at their camp near here. No disorder was reported and seventy men in the uniform of the league, wearing swastika arm bands, took over the policing of the camp.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Pitou gave a luncheon today at the Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. William C. Durant, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Smith at Certosa, their place in Ox Pasture Road. Among other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Newton Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herbert 3d.

There is no possibility of a nation's finding itself so long as that nation has exaggerated values of itself, the Rt. Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Bishop of Ohio, said in a sermon yesterday morning as guest preacher at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Industrial activity during the first six months of this year was markedly greater than during the corresponding period of 1934, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The trend of business during June, the board finds, registered a slight improvement over the preceding month and remained considerably above the levels of the same month last year.

The weakness of Mr. Gubman's plea for cut rates on taxicabs is the fact that almost 7,000 New York cabs are driven by independent hackmen, and the majority of these drive used cars, in which their capital investment is much less than $500 and about one-half of what a lighter weight car would cost new.
The report of Irving L. Koch, examiner, recommending to the I.C.C. the reduction of railroad passenger fares, is well worth while.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP). -- Pinch-hitter Wes Ferrell's long home run smash in the ninth inning with two men on bases gave the Red Sox a 7-6 decision over the Tigers in the final game of the series today before 24,000 fans.

ATHENS, July 21. -- Reports of an imminent monarchial restoration by a surprise move which partly emanated from London circulated today and failed to evoke any signs from the Cabinet or Greece's armed forces that such an attempted overthrow of a "democratic and parliamentary government" would be seriously resisted.

The President certainly knows his onions -- meaning Congress. It always wants what the Countess in the play called a "bountiful answer that fits all questions." Mr. ROOSEVELT has found one for Congress in the present juncture. It is "propaganda by the very rich in order to escape taxation."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21. -- The "Old Seventh" Regiment of Manhattan observed "visitors' day" at Camp Smith today and about 4,000 invited guests spent the afternoon and evening with the members of the command of Colonel Ralph C. Tobin.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The CCC will virtually double its educational facilities to provide courses for about 500,000 at its camps next Winter, Robert Fechner, Director of Emergency Conservation Work, announced today.

An unorganized but widespread and stubborn consumers' strike has forced most of the restaurants of New York to abandon their effort to pass on increases in wholesale food costs, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, asserted yesterday.

THE strangest book off the month is "The Apple Is Bitten Again" (Dutton, $2), by Olive Moore. It is Olive Moore's pessimistic conviction that she is being eaten by worms before her time. The worms are the majority of the persons with whom she has contact. Her attack on them is fierce, but almost undoubtedly unavailing. Without ever trying, they will always hurt her more than she, with all her effort, can hurt them.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 21. -- The Yankee, an excursion steamboat plying between New London and Montauk Point, L.I., went on the rocks at the mouth of New London Harbor tonight in a dense fog. Coast Guard patrol boats took off the 110 passengers and twenty of the crew.

The joint national convention of the Sovereign Camp of the Woodmen of the World and of the Supreme Forest Woodmen Circle, opened last night with a memorial service in the Park Central Hotel. The service was conducted by the national officers in memory of the more than 6,000 members who died since the last national convention.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Thousands were turned away today as the biggest crowd in ten years at Wrigley Field watched the Cubs thrust back the Giants in both ends of their double-header to sweep the four-game series and make more precarious New York's hold on the National League lead.

ALBANY, July 21. -- The completion of studies of every city and village police and fire pension fund in New York State and the establishment of a permanent local actuarial consulting service was announced today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 21. -- Details have reached here of the meeting yesterday of General Enrique Penaranda, commander of the Bolivian Army, and General Jose Felix Estigarribia. Paraguayan commander, in the neutral Chaco zone.

LONDON, July 20. -- London's first impressions of Premier Laval's plans for balancing the French budget and attempting to restore financial stability have been wholly favorable. Although it is impossible to make an exact comparison between French and British taxes, the situation now facing France is, in a general sense, similar to that which Great Britain encountered in 1931.

The necessity for life to dominate nature if man is to progress was stressed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood of City Temple, London, in his sermon, "Life Is an Offensive -- But Against What?" at the Riverside Church.

The way of the modern world in its striving for wealth, power and mechanical perfection, with the resultant neglect of God, is the way of suicide, the Rev. George Gordon Cameron, pastor of Kent Road St. Vincent Church, Glasgow, Scotland, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Twelfth Street.

BERLIN, July 21. -- Following a week of noisy anti-Jewish demonstrations and acrimonious official discussion of the State's relations with German Catholicism and confessions in general, Berlin settled down to a tranquil Sunday today. There were no fresh outbreaks of Jew baiting and Catholic pulpit reactions to the government's vitriolic denunciation of "political Catholicism" also did not materialize.

A letter from Bolton Hall appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES states that tenement slums "exist because their owners are speculators holding their land out of proper use in the hope of getting higher prices for it."

PARIS, July 20. -- The budget decrees of the Laval Ministry have been generally well received, French public opinion evincing a natural satisfaction with the serious efforts being made to reduce State expenditures and balance the budget.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21. -- Despite their long session of Larchmont race week, thirty-six skippers brought out that many craft today for the Horse Shoe Harbor Yacht Club's invitation regatta.

WESTON, Conn., July 21. -- Franklin P. Adams, the New York columnist who writes as "F.P.A.," today emerged as the loser in his contest with the town of Weston to the extent of twenty-five feet of his front lawn and a large oak tree, of which he and Mrs. Adams are particularly fond.

Analyzing President Roosevelt's new tax proposals, the National Industrial Conference Board, in a statement made public yesterday, came to the conclusion that their purpose was "primarily to tax or penalize size or bigness, wherever and in whatever form it may be found."

ST. LOUIS, July 21. -- The Cardinals bounced back into their winning stride today and captured both games of a double-header from the Dodgers. The victors now are only one and a half games in back of the first-place Giants. The scores were 13 -- 7 and 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- A downward occupational trend among rural workers as a result of the disruption of their former status under the pressure of unemployment is shown in figures compiled from study conducted by the FERA and announced today by Corrington Gill, assistant Federal Emergency Relief Administrator in charge of research, statistics and finance.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 21. -- The famous Seventy-seventh Division from New York City will be well represented here for the next two weeks with three of the four regiments on active duty. The fourth regiment, the 305th Infantry, left yesterday after two weeks of train ing the students of the Citizens' Military Training Camp.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- An attack on President Roosevelt on the ground that he violated 1932 campaign pledges by building up a huge bureaucracy was made by the American Liberty League today in a pamphlet analyzing the growth of the Federal office-holding machine.
Despite overcast skies and cooler weather, nearly 1,800,000 men, women and children flocked from the city yesterday to the beaches and resorts of the metropolitan area.

DETROIT, July 21. -- Piloting his own plane here from Washington to visit the All-American Aircraft Show, Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics for the Department of Commerce, indicated today that the department's stringent regulations on Detroit's city airport would soon be alleviated.

The Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of Colgate-Rochester Baptist Divinity School, Rochester, N.Y., declared in a sermon yesterday morning that the relationship between the church and world movements is so close that it is the duty of every clergyman to help form opinions.

LIMA, Peru, July 21. -- The budget as drawn up by the Minister of Finance in cooperation with the financial committee of the Constituent Assembly has been approved by the Cabinet and promulgated by President Oscar R. Benavides. Revenue and expenditures are balanced at 131,313,490 soles.

Opening its sixth week of concerts tonight at New York University, the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, will play music ranging in character from the "Schwanda" polka and fugue to Cailliet's "Memories of Stephen Foster" and from Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor" overture to excerpts from Wagner's "Die Meistersinger." David C. Rosebrook will be cornet soloist.

LONDON, July 21. -- One match up on Germany as a result of Donald Budge's laborious victory over Heiner Henkel yesterday, the American Davis Cup team devoted the Sabbath to perfecting a putting touch on the greens of the Hurlingham club.
ST PAUL, Minn., July 21. -- Harry Cooper of Chicago finished his greatest scoring spree today to win the $5,000 St. Paul open championship with a record 72-hole total of 271 shots.

Love Powell, happy-faced Negro who sings as he polishes cars parked along West Forty-seventh Street, told the police at the nearby station house yesterday that he knew a lot about pigeons. So the police asked him to take charge of a black and gray speckled pigeon which a woman had seen limping in the street.

INDIAN POINT, N.Y., July 21. -- After registering a new unofficial world record of 50 miles an hour with his Class C craft at Havre de Grace yesterday, Lew Carlisle of East Islip, L.I., today won the Class C open event that featured the first annual outboard regatta of the Indian Point Yacht Club in the Hudson River.

She had been writing bits of local news about Steve Cline and the Snowdens, and Mr. and Mrs. Kenher and the Pauley place and folks around Oasis, and other bits about the crop prospects in the Ozark hills and how the tobacco was getting along.

Jack Wright of Manhattan and Mrs. Mollie Shapiro of the Bronx triumphed yesterday as match play in the metropolitan public links championship opened at Van Cortlandt Park. The players who had gained high qualifying positions in the round of medal play Saturday drew first-round byes, and consequently were idle.

Hee-haw, the striped hyena with the demoniac laugh, described by many as the most repellent inhabitant of the Central Park Zoo, became dean of the animals there yesterday, with all the rights and obligations thereunto belonging. It all happened when Robert J. Hurton, head keeper, reached back into his memory to determine which of the animals comes closest to his own thirty years of service at the zoo.
PITTSBURGH, July 21. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 41 per cent of capacity, against 36 per cent in the preceding week and 38 per cent in the last week of June.

BAYSIDE, L.I., July 21. -- E.S. White's Star Class boat Shucks crossed the finish line first today, giving the Westchester sailors a victory over Bayside, 18 1/4 to 17, in the first of a series of Long Island Sound team matches conducted by the Bayside Y.C.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 22. -- The Soviet Union's attempt to fly an airplane from Moscow to San Francisco by way of the North Pole is scheduled to start at 7 o'clock this morning (1 A.M. New York daylight saving time), the commandant of the airport at which the plane is poised announced early today.

ADDIS ABABA, July 21. -- A demonstration revealing the unity of Ethiopian Christians and Moslems in patriotic efforts was held today near Emperor Menelik's statue in the Place St. Ghiorghis where the Ethiopian youth organization has offices.

The trade war that has broken out between Japan and Canada seems so far to furnish a perfect illustration of the mutual folly of all such contests. The answer to the question regarding who started it depends partly upon one's point of view, and all the facts could not be known without a detailed investigation.

The statement of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the second quarter of this year, released today, shows a net income of $5,332,528 after deduction of interest and dividends on subsidiary companies' funded debt and preferred stock, depreciation and provision for income and other taxes.

Replying to resolutions by several members of the American Bankers Association urging the association to undertake a nation-wide public educational program, R.S. Hecht, president, said yesterday the A.B.A. was striving along eight different lines to promote better public understanding toward banks.

LONDON, July 21. -- "The purpose of this new Nazi campaign of vituperation and calumny against Jews is clearly discernible -- all is not going well with the Nazi program for the revival of internal prosperity," asserts the joint foreign committee of the Jewish Board of Deputies in a report read to the meeting of the "Jewish Parliament" in London today.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Trade reports indicate that business last week was the best for the period in recent years, some saying that the distribution of seasonal as well as general merchandise reached the best aggregate since about 1930. That the people have money and are more disposed to spend it is indicated by the increase in tourist travel, which is reflected in the increased buying of seasonal merchandise.

Track honors at the Panhellenic track and field championship meet held under the auspices of the Greek-American-Hermes A.C. and the Greek-American Institute of New York yesterday at Ulmer Park, Brooklyn, were shared by three runners, each taking a first and a second place.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay Hoguet of 59 East Eightieth Street, New York, have issued invitations to a debutante ball for their youngest daughter, Miss Anne R. Hoguet, at their Summer home, Council Grove, Stockbridge, on Saturday night, Aug. 31. Miss Hoguet's sisters, Mrs. William H. Hagen and Miss Louise R. Hoguet, also were introduced to society at Council Grove.

TRENTON, N.J., July 21. -- Nearly 1,000 buses and trucks carrying passengers were stopped and examined in New Jersey by inspectors of the State Public Utility Commission in a week-end drive against illegal and illegally operated vehicles carrying passengers.

The formation of a Refugee Economic Corporation with a capital of $10,000,000 to help refugees from Germany and other countries to settle in various parts of the world on an economically self-supporting basis was announced yesterday by Felix M. Warburg.

Speaker BYRNS, that amiable ancient now serving his fourteenth term, was 66 last Saturday. As the House was not to be in session on that day, Mr. LUDLOW of Indiana offered its congratulations Thursday. Mr. BYRNS was informed that he is "one of America's biggest assets," whose heart "keeps rhythm with the heartbeats of 125,000,000 people." He is "one of America's greatest statesmen."

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The sensational feature of the wheat crop situation comes from the Canadian and United States Northwest. Black rust and red stem rust are prevalent in most of the best wheat sections of Minnesota, South Dakota and North Dakota.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 21 (A). -- A Congressional committee investigating the flood damage in southern tier New York decided here tonight to recommend to Federal Relief Administrator Hopkins a fourfold program for immediate aid to stricken farms and communities.

About a dozen of the Summer theatres are braving the storms of mid-July to spend the week trying out new plays.
