Some of them are being done by Broadway managers, on an approval basis, and some are being done simply on speculation. Of the dozen, perhaps a couple will come to town later on in the year; so here, then, are the week's possibilities:

GENEVA, July 21. -- Deep in the conflict over Ethiopia there lie two Anglo-Italian protocols, made secretly in 1891. These are still unknown to the general public and apparently to many diplomats but they are of rising importance behind the scenes here and in London, Paris and Rome.

LONDON, July 21. -- Slowly, painfully and with many longing glances toward the better situations that might have been created under more favorable circumstances, the better-informed section of British opinion is reconciling itself to the view that war by Italy upon Ethiopia is inevitable.

PARIS, July 20. -- The lowering of the bank rate this week naturally affected market rates, but lenders were difficult to find because the mass exodus of gold in recent weeks has diminished the market's resources considerably. Not much gold has yet returned to the Bank of France.
LONDON, July 21. -- David Lloyd George's plan for "organizing prosperity" has been rejected in toto by the British Government.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The status of major legislation in Congress is as follows:

D.T. Richardson of Kelly, Richardson Co., Chicago, chairman of the municipal securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America, in a statement made public today, denounces a proposed amendment of the municipal section of the Bankruptcy Act introduced in Congress by Representative Wilcox of Florida, terming it a matter of great concern to investors in municipal bonds.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 21. -- Before the biggest throng that has watched a national junior polo game, the Aiken Knights of Long Island moved on to the championship by defeating Texas at the Burnt Mills Club today, 13 to 3.

With sugar, cocoa, cottonseed oil and rubber futures easier last week, the other markets for commodity futures showed strength in moderate trading, and good advances resulted. In the cash markets, all grains advanced, and lard, tin and silk rose to new high levels.

No evidence has yet been brought forward to substantiate in part Bolton Hall's contention that taxation of the rental value of the land upon which slum tenements exist can even in part abolish the tenement slums. The entire case put forward for the land-value or "economic rent" tax rests upon assumptions which are not borne out by facts.

The realization on the part of potential realty buyers that certain types of buildings have again become good investments has been a leading factor in the increasing amount of new construction in the five boroughs comprising the city, according to Myron L. Matthews in the current Dory Service Building Reports.

BOSTON, July 21. -- Thirty persons adrift in small craft were rescued by Coast Guard forces, five persons in a launch were almost run down by an ocean liner in the lower harbor, and a dozen coastwise and transatlantic vessels were delayed from a few hours to nearly a full day as one of the thickest fogs in years enshrouded this port area over the week-end.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Wheat traders of the world are watching weather and crop reports from the United States and Canada, as well as from the Argentine, Australia, Russia and European countries. Harvesting of wheat is on in North America and in some parts of Europe, and it will be only a few weeks before all the foreign countries, except those in the Southern Hemisphere, will be harvesting.

Seven health centre districts in New York City showed what was termed a "significant" rise in the birth rate last year compared with 1933, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Health. In view of the steady decline of the birth rate in the city as a whole, the increases were considered remarkable.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- NRA Code Authorities who are holding funds obtained through assessments against members of their respective industries have been requested by the National Recovery Administration to consult attorneys and take action through the courts to return the money, James L. O'Neill, acting NRA Administrator, stated today.

Mickey Walker will take the first step along the comeback trail tonight. The Rumson. N.J., fighter. one-time holder of the world's welterweight and the world's middleweight championships, will make his bid for recognition among the top-flight heavyweights when he faces John Anderson of Sweden in the feature bout of ten rounds at Dexter Park.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The Wagner-Connery National Labor Relations Act is hailed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in an editorial to appear in the August issue of The American Federationist, as marking "a new level in establishment of wage-earners' rights."
STEPHENVILLE, Texas, July 21. -- The only way to make a living is to work, and Congress can't do anything about it. thinks R.A. Clark, a janitor, who paid for his home during the depression.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 21 (2P). -- Newell P. Sherman confessed tonight that he drowned his young wife in fog-shrouded Lake Singletary, at Millbury, authorities announced, for the love of a 16-year-old girl who had rejected his attentions.

Police of Palisades Interstate Park opened a further investigation yesterday into the death of Mrs. Ottilie Stufmann Umbach, 26-year-old bride, drowned Saturday near the George Washington Bridge when a torrent of rain water swept her down a drain in which poverty had driven her and her husband to seek refuge.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP). -- Mel Harder pitched the Indians to a 6-to-4 victory over the Athletics today, but he had a narrow escape in the ninth inning. A barrage of hits scored all the Mack runs in the ninth and drove Harder off the mound. The box score:

Foreign exchanges showed a moderately firm undertone last week, the general list showing advances ranging from a fraction of a cent to 5 points. The only exception to the forward trend was a softness in the guilder and belga, which declined. Business was in good volume throughout the week.

Although the theatre's thoughts are still mainly in the country, it will pause for a time this evening to make a few changes along Broadway. Nothing world-shaking, to be certain, but even a ripple on Broadway, the week of July 22, is something.

Another world's record fell by the wayside as Miss Lenore Kight brought the women's national swimming and diving championships to a close in the Oriental Pool at Manhattan Beach yesterday by winning her third national title and breaking her second world's mark in the four days of the competition.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 21. -- There were many luncheon parties today in the Summer colony.

NEW LONDON, July 21. -- Massachusetts bridge players made a clean sweep of the three major events of the Southern New England contract championships when Frank T. Westcott and Dean Baker Jr. of North Attleboro, Mass., won the open pair championship for the Lewis Osborn Trophy with a score of 314 1/2 match points.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 21. -- Edwin Luchs of New York, seeded fourth, led the way into the semifinal round of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship today. The former University of Pennsylvania star won two matches in straight sets to move a round ahead of the field.

Declaring that the 1936 budget would be a "vital test" for the La Guardia administration, William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, urged the administration yesterday to announce plans to effect "real payroll economies," to draw the line against any additional city workers, to leave all vacancies unfilled, to refuse demands for restoration of pay cuts and to impose further pay cuts.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 21 (AP). -- Syracuse scored two one-run victories over Newark today, taking the second, 6 to 5, after winning, 4 to 3, in eleven innings of the first game.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 21. -- Princesse Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge of Paris will join her sister, Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds, at the Mount Washington Hotel on Tuesday for her annual visit.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 21. -- With Terence Preece and Thomas Hitchcock Jr. starring at the Nos. 2 and 3 positions, the Sands Point poloists routed Roslyn, 12 to 7, in the weekly high-goal match at the Sands Point Club today.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Prices of hogs on the Board of Trade last week were the highest in five years, at $10.65 a hundredweight. The make of lard is below the average, and stocks at the leading points are said to be decreasing. This has created a bullish feeling in the provision trade, the most pronounced in recent years.

A debut and a first performance were details of last night's orchestral concert in the Lewisohn Stadium, conducted by Jose Iturbi. The debut was made by Margaret Harshaw, contralto, the 1935 winner of the $1,000 Young Artists' Award of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

It is evident that European diplomacy does not yet admit that war between Italy and Ethiopia is "inevitable." Earnest negotiations are plainly afoot to prevent it. In this matter, France, after standing rather aloof for a tame, has been drawn into accord with Great Britain.

I wish to approve your editorial "Dilemma of Big Business," and to supplement it with further reasons why business, industry and the American taxpayer are justified in protesting to their respective Congressional representatives.

CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP). -- Curt Davis and Joe Bowman pitched the Phillies to two shutout victories over the Reds today, Davis taking the first, 4 to 0, over Paul Derringer, and Bowman the nightcap, 2 to 0. Bowman allowed five hits and Davis six.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- A prediction that Congress will remain in session until Nov. 1 and that "it is practically certain that the inflationary Patman Soldiers' Bonus and Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Refinancing Bills will be offered as amendments to the Tax Bill" was made today by Senator Borah.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- Federal statisticians have been charting this year the steadiest course for domestic prices as a whole since they started down the deflation trail in 1929.
MARCH FIELD, Riverside, Calif., July, 21 (AP). -- Fighting planes roared over the Far West today as the United States Army's first wing air force began manoeuvres to cover five States.

Although many of the out-of-town buyers operating in the wholesale markets here last week made generous purchases of Summer merchandise to fill in stocks depleted as the result of the heavy retail demand recently, or for special promotional events, interest generally was centred on the Fall lines, particularly in the apparel divisions.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reports that orders received in the first half of 1935 were 21 per cent higher than in the 1934 period, while sales billed were up 38 per cent. Orders on the books June 30 stood at $31,000,000, the same as a month before, but lower than at the end of previous months of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- What were described as "isolated incidents" of "a few minor utility officials," resorting to "scandalous and even dishonest methods" in opposing the Utility Bill were disowned today by the committee of public utility executives in a statement issued by its chairman, Philip H. Gadsden, who declared that the committee would continue to fight the Senate measure with its "death sentence."

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- A Senate committee reported today that "employment conditions existing on government construction work were in a deplorable state" and recommended new legislation to end abuses.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 21. -- Rejection of Secretary of Labor Perkins's proposal for arbitration of the strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's plant here "because it would spell ruination for the yard," was announced today by J.F. Metten, president of the company.

Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of rackets in New York County will get under way officially a week from today, but Henry H. Klein, an attorney, said yesterday he would make another effort in a taxpayer's suit to prevent what he holds to be a waste of public funds.

Negro college graduates were urged to lead the way in the movement for a new emancipation of their race by Dr. Charles H. Wesley, head of the Department of History at Howard University (Washington, D.C.), speaking yesterday afternoon at the fifteenth annual University Day forum held at St. James Presbyterian Church, 141st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

Stanley Bergerman, former producer at the Universal studios, announced here yesterday plans for the production of six feature pictures if satisfactory distribution arrangements can be worked out with a major film producing concern. Mr. Bergerman said that several well-known directors and writers had offered their services on a profit-sharing basis, a new departure in motion picture production.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 21. -- Shaded from the blistering heat by newspapers spread over their head or by umbrellas, nearly 2,000 devout Mormons and visitors gathered at the foot of Cumorah Hill, near Palmyra, today for exercises dedicating a monument to the Angel Moroni:

After maintaining its international headquarters at 21 State Street since 1915, the Swedish American Line will move to the midtown area. The company has leased two shop spaces on the ground floor and offices on the third floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

The independent committee for the protection of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad bondholders has sent a letter to the Interstate Commerce Commission asking that there be no hurried reorganization of the road in order that there may be a thorough and independent inquiry into the history of this company.

On their way back to Roosevelt Field from a good-will flight to Montreal, two Chinese fliers were detained last night by immigration officials after they landed at the Missisquoi Airport in Swanton, Vt., to clear customs.

Max Kraus, president of the Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association, said yesterday that despite assurances that Congress would remedy the evils disclosed by the Morro Castle disaster, it now appears that nothing will be done before Congress adjourns.

Bluefishing time is one of the most enjoyable phases of the salt water angler's season. From now on it can be expected that fishing news of the metropolitan area will be featured by many catches oil these sporting fish. Those who were out on Long Island's offshore grounds during the early part of the past week-end reported several good catches of five-pound fish.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 21. -- Shaded from the blistering heat by newspapers spread over their head or by umbrellas, nearly 2,000 devout Mormons and visitors gathered at the foot of Cumorah Hill, near Palmyra, today for exercises dedicating a monument to the Angel Moroni:

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Harvesting of the oats crop has made good progress, and while country offerings and sales were not large last week, sufficient selling pressure of futures developed to keep the price down close to the lowest of the season, 32 1/2 cents for December.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 21. -- Defending the sales tax enacted at his recommendation, Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey charged in an address tonight before a large gathering of the bitterest opponents of the levy that some retailers were deliberately sabotaging the program to increase the unpopularity of the tax.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 21. -- Clipper, owned by Clayton L. Banks of Nichols, won the ninth annual race from the Pequot Yacht Club to Cornfield Light and return, which was concluded here today.

Had a man driving one of those good old-fashioned Model Ts bobbed up on Daytona Beach last Winter and forthwith proceeded to run rings around Sir Malcolm Campbell's Bluebird, he could not have created greater consternation than did the Browns at the Stadium yesterday as they grabbed the final game of their series with the Yankees.

In The Atlantic for August Mr. ABRAHAM FLEXNER writes of "Private Fortunes and the Public Future." What he discusses is the effect on education and research of the proposed breaking up of great fortunes in this country. Mr. FLEXNER is no stodgy Tory. He does not believe in monopolistic exploitation of natural resources.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Hogs sold at $10.65 on last Friday, packers paying that price for top grades, an advance of 15 cents a hundredweight for the day. Furthermore, the price was $1.15 above the highest previous level paid on June 26. While desirable weights of hogs sold readily at the advance as the result of light receipts, heavy hogs failed to reach the top prices of the lighter weights.

LONDON, Monday, July 22 (AP). -- Ethiopia "badly needs money" with which to finance an apparently impending war with Italy and hopes to explore the possibilities of an American loan through J.P. Morgan, now in London, according to a statement by the new Ethiopian Minister here, Dr. Azaj Wargneh Martin, quoted in The London Daily Express.

Luigi Pirandello, the nervous, dynamic Italian playwright, whose works won him the Nobel Prize in literature in 1934, sat in his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday and talked of life, literature and Ethiopia.

BOGOTA, July 21. -- President Alfonso Lopez, in his message to Congress delivered last night, reveals that during the recent visit here of Miquel Lopez Pumarejo, Colombian Minister to Washington, a formula was drafted for a reciprocal commercial treaty which it is hoped will be acceptable to the United States. He also announced that Colombia and Japan are negotiating a commercial pact and that treaty discussions are being held with France.

NEW HAVEN, July 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.7, which compares with 81.6 the week before, 81.7 two weeks before, 81.6 three weeks before and 82 four weeks before.

HERE they go! The Giants against the Cardinals on the Western Front and the Yankees against the Tigers in the Bronx. That's a double order of heavy firing, and the campaign for a world series on a five-cent fare is the big target of attack

LONDON, July 19. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on July 17 at 67.4. This compares with 67.5 a fortnight before, 68.1 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

A drive by the police and railroad detectives yesterday against the sale of unused parts of railroad excursion tickets at the Pennsylvania Terminal resulted in the arrest of twenty-one men and eight women.

Arthur S. Tuttle, acting Stats director of the Federal Public Works Administration, announced yesterday the allocation of $44,553,060 for eighteen projects in New York City that will provide work for 15,000 persons. All but $300,000 of this is for city projects.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The stock market this week suffered a heavy decline in volume of trading but prices remained steady to firm until the Hapag-Lloyd financial reconstruction announcement depressed the whole list.

On the calendar of the House of Representatives is a bill proposing to create a new system of Federal regulation of the liquor traffic. Some system is necessary, since the Government is committed under the Twenty-first Amendment to aid the States in the enforcement of their own liquor laws and since the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, which previously performed this task with marked success, went down with the Supreme Court's NRA decision.
The list of the Cunard White Star liner Franconia, leaving today on a thirteen days' cruise to the Saguenay, Quebec and Newfoundland, includes:

BERLIN, July 20. -- The Laval Cabinet's decrees for balancing the French budget have been criticized here on the ground that they contain too many economies and not enough new taxation. It is remarked that former Chancellor Bruening, under similar conditions, reduced salaries, pensions and prices, but, unlike France, imposed new taxes to yield 3,000,000,000 marks.

BERLIN, July 21. -- Priests in Freiberg, Baden, defied today a stern warning against criticism from the pulpit of the Nazi drive to end "political Catholicism" as elsewhere in the tense Reich the Catholic clergy obeyed the government's edict.
CINCINNATI, July 22 (AP). -- The Braves ended a fifteen-game losing streak today by defeating the Reds, 4 to 2.

The "promised paradise," "Voter" should not forget, was not promised. Mr. Roosevelt was elected on a platform promising, definitely and unequivocally, such things as a sound currency, a balanced budget, withdrawal of the Federal Government from private enterprise, cessation to as great an extent as possible of Federal intervention, return to the States of their normal functions,

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 22. -- Opening day at Seabright carries the same connotation as the Ides of March to the tennis player who knows his tradition, and the inaugural round of the forty-eighth annual invitation tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club was productive of the usual harvest of anguish for the seeded array today.

Holders of public school teaching licenses were warned yesterday by the Board of Examiners that they might be dismissed without formal charges or trial if, in the opinion of their superiors, they failed to live up to standards of character, personality and good citizenship during the three years following their appointment to teaching posts.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 22 (AP). -- The Chicago division in the annual Mackinac Island yacht race sent the first four boats across the finish line tonight, while boats in the Detroit division bucked a strong wind sweeping east over the straits.

Despite rain which changed a drying-out track to sloppy, form prevailed at Empire City yesterday with Sir Quest, victor in the featured Katonah Purse, being the fourth consecutive winning favorite. This Arden Farms racer, which is a son of Sun Edwin and Question, surprised a good many by the manner in which he held on to score by a head at the end of five and one-half furlongs.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday an encouraging increase in industrial and commercial building in the State on the basis of building plans submitted last month to the Division of Engineering of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt conferred again today with Ferdinand Pecora, thereby causing a renewal of reports that the New York Supreme Court Justice would be designated soon as special counsel in the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of the American Telephone Telegraph Company.
A middle-aged merchant was the undoing last night of a hold-up man who had terrorized business men on the East Side for four months.
Sales of two corner parcels by financial institutions were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

BOSTON, July 22. -- Lost in the fog fifty miles off Chatham for several hours, rescued when a rift in the fog permitted him to sight the fishing schooner Rose Marie, and landed in Gloucester yesterday, Maurice Nickerson of Forest Hills, a member of the crew of the fishing schooner Reliance, took to the sea again in his dory and rowed from Gloucester to Boston rather than ask a loan to get home.

Colonel H. Murray Jacoby, former Ambassador Extraordinary to Ethiopia, announced yesterday that he had received a cablegram from Blatten Gueta Herouy, Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs, requesting him to inform the American press that "Rossari Heshla Tamanya," who has described herself here as an Ethiopian princess, was an "imposter and unknown in Ethiopia."

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The Dodgers won a wild eleven-inning game from the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, but they are talking about their accomplishment only in whispers. The score was 14 to 13 and a total of forty-two hits were smacked inside and outside the park, with Brooklyn making twenty-two of them.
Resumption of business in the credit market in the new week witnessed no change from the small state of the turnover involved, and steady array of quotations.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 22. -- Fourteen persons were injured, several seriously, in two automobile accidents on Route 29 and Watchung Avenue today. They were taken to Muhlenberg Hospital and after receiving treatment several were discharged.

TOKYO, July 22. -- War Minister Senjuro Hayashi carried forward on an enlarged scale today his policy of removing from key positions officers of the so-called "progressive" faction, who desire the army to play a political role and whose tendency to independent action had been noticeable in Manchuria and North China.

Leaders of the 215 striking caddies at the city-owned Dyker Heights golf course, in Brooklyn, laid their grievances before Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday through Alderman Donald k. O'Toole, who represents the district where they work.

Although the city is spending close to $9,000,000 for home relief this month, with 246,000 persons and families on the rolls of the Home Relief Bureau, the amount of relief cannot be considered adequate, Charlotte Carr, new director of the bureau, said yesterday when she assumed her duties.

The market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was dull and featureless yesterday. Sales amounted to $8,501,800, against $9,203,100 last Friday. Domestic corporation bonds presented a mixed undertone throughout the day and, with the exception of a few individual issues which were singled out for special movements, prices held within a narrow range.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 22. -- A 24-year-old youth serving a term of from twenty-five years to life in Sing Sing prison impressed Justice George H. Taylor Jr. in Supreme Court today by the neatness of his brief, offered in support of his writ of habeas corpus.

Proposals by the Consolidated Gas system to establish reduced electric rates in the city and to merge the New York Edison and the United Electric Light and. Power Companies were in effect handed back to the utility group by the Public Service Commission yesterday, with a request for revision.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Abandonment by Great Britain of the naval ratios written into the Washington treaty of 1922 and reaffirmed in the London treaty of 1930 occasioned disappointment here today but apparently no surprise.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 22. -- National Guardsmen began arriving late this afternoon and tonight had set up martial law in the city and county under an edict caused by a general strike which began this morning.

The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday for the second quarter of this year an increase in earnings compared with the corresponding period of 1934. The gain was said to be sufficiently large to offset the decline in the first quarter from that of last year, and to bring the total for the six months to about the same level as in the first half of 1934.

An audacious 4-year-old monkey named Mike, which escaped from his owners on Thursday and has been living a sort of civilized jungle life in loft buildings in the vicinity of Fulton and Greenwich Streets ever since, caused a commotion yesterday morning when the search that has been going on in a rather desultory fashion since his escape took on all the aspects of a concentrated monkey hunt.

PEORIA, Ill., Tuesday, July 23 (AP). -- Two buildings of the huge Hiram Walker distillery were wrecked and a third severely damaged by fire which followed a series of explosions in Rack House No. 3 late last night. Company officials said that the loss, in buildings and liquors, would aggregate $2,500,000.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Wheat made today a firm start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade. An early bulge of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish brought increased hedging pressure and also profit-taking, and the close was around the inside level with prices 1/2 cent a bushel lower to 1/2 cent higher, the latter on December.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Mahnkey of Forsyth, Mo., the rural reporter who makes notes on sugar sacks and whose beat for thirteen years included Oasis, a village of twenty-seven inhabitants fifteen miles from a railroad, made a suggestion yesterday evening.

A joint meeting of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee, held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night to create a united anti-Nazi front, was disrupted by series of fist fights among factions.

Allegations that the property of Primo Carnera is involved in the conspiracy on the part of Louis R. Soresi, Carnera's manager, and others to defraud not only the creditors of the Italian fighter but possibly Carnera himself were made in the Supreme Court yesterday by Theodore J. Skratt, a creditor, who won an application to Justice Lauer to extend a receivership to the money won by Carnera in the Joe Louis fight.

A meeting of the directors of the American Petroleum Institute has been called for Aug. 1 in this city, primarily to consider suggested changes in the petroleum marketing code, according to Axtell J. Byles, president. A meeting of the executive committee of the institute will be held here the day before.

Buddy, who for nineteen years served faithfully at Fort Wood, the military reservation on which stands the Statue of Liberty, and three other army mules bowed yesterday to what was inevitable -- mechanization.

PARIS, July 22. -- The Paris police learned today that B. Coles Neidecker, missing head of the closed Travellers Bank, had arrived in New York Sunday on the liner Britannic and ordered that an inquiry commission be sent to the United States.

During the last few days the Senate has spent much of its time debating a plan to clamp down restrictions on farm imports. The new AAA bill, as passed by the House, proposed to give the President power virtually to declare an embargo on such shipments. This was cut from the bill by a Senate committee; but Mr. LA FOLLETTE brought forward, and the Senate has now approved, an alternative proposal.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Renewed attacks by the German Government against Catholics and Jews brought a demand on the floor of the House today for a thorough boycotting of that country's products and for protests by the State Department.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Air express activities of all domestic airlines will be unified within sixty days if plans tentatively agreed upon are approved. Under the new set-up the Railway Express Agency will serve as exclusive pick-up and delivery agent, eliminating the Postal Telegraph Company from the field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 22. -- A novel marital situation appeared in Supreme Court here today when attorneys for two ex-wives of a retired American business man, now resident in Paris, argued before Justice George H. Taylor Jr. as to which had the first claim on the sequestered American property of the former husband.

With the exception of cotton goods, particularly the heavy styles, which carry a substantial amount of processing tax, Fall merchandise lines were bought in a fair way yesterday by visiting buyers. The retailers, most of them this week coming from the Middle West, covered their normal needs on coats, dresses, millinery and accessories, but definitely shied away from such items as sheets and pillowcases, towels,

THERE was a cloud in the sky at noon yesterday, and Mr. Gordon Stanley Cochrane paused in the operation of looping a tie around his shirt collar. He went to the window and surveyed weather conditions.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, director of the Regional Labor Board and chairman of the citizens' committee to promote decent wages in restaurants and hotels, minimized yesterday the warning by restaurant owners that they might be compelled to discharge 40,000 women employes because of the wage recently established by the Minimum Wage Board for women employes and minors.

All factors which previously have meant record markets were evident yesterday when the New York Furniture Exchange opened its week's showing of new Fall furniture styles. Prices were firm, with reports of impending advances; attendance, which exceeded 900, was the heaviest for any Fall market opening day in years, and the first day's purchase compared favorably with the mid-week orders placed at the last exhibition in May.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 22. -- Armed with a court order issued by Surrogate James A. Delehanty, Mrs. Mary Emma Calhoun, New York real estate operator, today visited the home here of Mrs. Charles L. Tiffany, and searched for silverware alleged to have been left her by her late mother, Mrs. Emma Wolfe of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

A Dictator does not have to give reasons for what he does. This leaves everybody free to make inferences and draw conclusions. These are naturally adverse to an all-powerful ruler when the steps which he takes lead to confusion and turbulence at home and suspicion and fear abroad.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 22 (AP). -- The Catholic-Protestant fight that began with the Orangemen's Day celebration of July 12 definitely became a religious battle today as it spread in the Irish Free State. Fires, window smashing, street fights and at least one strike were today's developments. Murder indictments were voted.

ALBANY, July 22. -- Crime and its many ramifications will be studied at a three-day conference here in October, Governor Lehman announced today. At the same time he gave out the names of a committee which will meet soon to prepare the program of topics to be discussed at this conference.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- New high levels for hog prices since September, 1930, were established today, with all interests competing for near-record small receipts for a Monday. Prices soared 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds and closed at the best figures.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. July 22 (AP). -- Mrs. Daniel J. McGoldrick of 596 Madison Street, Brooklyn, mother of Joseph McGoldrick, former Controller of New York City, was critically injured in a head-on automobile collision here today.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- The favored Frisky Matron captured the Belie Isle Purse, six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs today. The winner beat Exhibit by a neck, with Happy Go third, a length and a half further back.

The plan for refinancing of the bonds and other obligations of the township of North Bergen, N.J., submitted by the Seaboard Trust Company last April 5, has been protested by the committee for bondholders headed by Edwin H. Barker on the grounds that it does not preserve the rights of creditors and fails to recognize the maximum ability of the township to pay on account of the bonds now in default.

MOSCOW, July 22. -- The government of Outer Mongolia has rejected the Japanese-Manchukuoan demand of July 4, following border incidents, to be allowed to install a military mission with its own telegraph lines within Outer Mongolian territory, according to a dispatch from Ulan Bator by Tass, the Soviet official news agency.

-- A new issue of $8,500,000 first-mortgage 4 per cent Series B bonds of Associated Telephone Company, Ltd., due in 1965, will be offered today by an underwriting group headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., and including Paine, Webber Co., Mitchum Tully Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., at a price of 99 and accrued interest.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Scoring in every inning but the seventh and eighth, the White Sox moved within four games of the idle Yankees today as they turned back the Athletics, 12 to 3, in the opening game of the series.
NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- After losing fifteen of their last sixteen games on the road, the Newark Bears returned home tonight to blank the tail-end Albany Senators, 7 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt was represented today by Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, as being "firmly insistent" that the "principle" of the graduated corporation income tax be preserved in any tax measure passed at this session of Congress.

PIERRE, S.D., July 22. -- With South Dakota relief suspended tonight to force able-bodied men to seek employment in the harvest fields, the so-called "revolt" of relief clients was believed by officials to have been stemmed in six other Midwestern States.

Fifty-one residents of Chatham, Mass., have been portrayed as companions of Christ in a large mural depicting a modernized version of "The Last Supper," which will be unveiled in the First Congregational Church of Chatham on Aug. 3, it was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22. -- An account of how a giant iceberg lurked in the direct path of transatlantic liners at the height of this Summer's tourist season was given today by the Coast Guard.
LONDON, July 22. -- The British Government has definitely abandoned the ratio principle as the means of determining the proportionate naval strength of the world's marine powers.

The origin of the word "lobbyist" is not obscure. It means a person who frequents the lobby of a legislative house to strive to influence its members. Thus a lobbyist is a special kind of propagandist. He does not depend solely upon the printed word, the pamphlet, the letter, the telegram, but upon word of mouth and personal contact.

The application by Patrick J. Casey, a stockholder of Pathe Exchange, Inc., for an injunction to restrain the directors from putting into effect a reorganization plan dated Dec. 18, 1934, and from selling any part of the Pathe Company's 49 per cent interest in the stock of the du Pont Film Manufacturing Company was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lauer.

On July 2 various New York banks published their balance sheets as of June 29. The total deposits of ten of them amounted to $3,655,740,782 and of this amount $1,529,058,012 was invested in Federal bonds, or 41.83 per cent. Investment in State and municipal bonds amounted to $280,395,104, or 7.67 per cent, while real estate mortgages amounted to only $56,723,991, or 1.55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A sharp division of opinion among witnesses on the question whether the present Food and Drug Law was adequate arose today as hearings on the new Copeland legislation were resumed before a House Subcommittee on Interstate Commerce.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 22. -- Bellport's representatives gained the lead as competition opened today to select a crew to represent the South Bay Yacht Racing Association in the national junior sailing races at Stamford, Conn., on Aug. 26. Two contests, under the auspices of the Bay Shore Yacht Club, were staged.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 13 amounted to 317,045,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior. This was a decline of 2,194,000 barrels from the week before, comprising declines of 1,965,000 barrels in domestic and 229,000 in foreign crude.

Officials of the United States Polo Association announced last night the starting date for this year's open championship, the event which is bringing the Hurlingham team from London to play against the best of this country, The first game of the championship is to be held on the International Field of the Meadow Brook Club on Saturday, Sept. 7. Entries will close with the United States Polo Association on Monday, Aug. 26.
The Manhattan realty market was comparatively quiet yesterday, only a few deals being reported. Eight properties were bought in at foreclosure auctions.
Thunder showers checked rising temperatures intermittently yesterday and loosed torrents of rain that caused heavy floods in parts of Brooklyn and Queens and in Newark, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- In the eleven months from July 1, 1934, to June 1, 1935, the expenditures of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration were $767,195,306 from funds available of $918,045,135, leaving a balance on June 1 of $150,849,829.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 22. -- Denunciation of a son's treatment of his mother was contained in a decision by Judge Albert C. Baldwin of the Superior Court today, dismissing the claim of Spofford F. Wyckoff of Los Angeles and Stamford to ownership of the Wyckoff Pipe and Creosoting Company stock owned by Mrs. E. Anna Wyckoff Mitchell at the time of her death on March 28, 1933.

The French Government, through its financial attache here, made plain yesterday, that the new emergency 10 per cent tax on interest coupons of government or public institutional securities is not applicable to bonds issued in a foreign country and not listed on the Paris Bourse.

LONDON, July 22. -- The action of the Italian Government in suspending the clause stipulating that there must be 40 per cent gold coverage for notes has caused little surprise in financial quarters in London where for some days it has been impossible to deal in Italian currency for forward delivery.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 22 (AP). -- The lives of 25 persons on a transcontinental bus were endangered today when a passenger, apparently become deranged, suddenly seized the steering wheel and headed the speeding vehicle toward Donner Lake, in the high Sierras east of here.

Twenty-two-year-old Ide Lyman, the Danish-Canadian social worker who paddled her home-made canvas kayak out of Lachine, Quebec, on July 1 and landed Sunday morning at a boat club under the George Washington Bridge, spent yesterday afternoon having her complexion restored.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- When Joseph Winters was arraigned this morning before Judge Matthew D. Hartigan on a charge of breaking into a filling station while he was drunk, the young man's father, Joseph Winters Sr., recommended "a little good old-fashioned punishment" as more effective than a prison term.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 22. -- In as thrilling a finish as this competition has seen in its nine-year history, the representatives of the Westchester Country Club captured the Class A title in the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team tournament over the Green Meadow Golf Club course today.

LONDON, July 22. -- Under the influence of public opinion both within the country and outside of it the British attitude on the Ethiopian situation has distinctly stiffened -- stiffened, that is, toward Italy and in support of the League of Nations in resisting aggression against a member country.
PARIS, July 22. -- The rumored secret departure of B. Coles Neidecker for the United States and the condition of his Travelers Bank today remained a mystery to police and his friends.

PARIS, July 22. -- Considerable uneasiness over the possible consequences has been caused in Paris this evening by the decision of the British Cabinet, as reported here, to put the Italo-Ethiopian difference squarely up to the League of Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- A new invisible spot of red light which has a powerful retarding effect on the germination of seeds has been discovered by two government scientists.
BERLIN, July 22. -- The intensified National Socialist drives against Jews, Catholics, Protestants, "reactionaries," profiteers and others continued on an ever-widening front today.

A committee, consisting of Arnold Hanson of Hanson Hanson and Eugene A. Canalizo, has been formed on behalf of the minority stockholders in the Colon Oil Corporation, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch-Shell group. Mr. Hanson, in announcing the formation of the committee also disclosed that a suit has been instituted in Westchester courts by minority stockholders "to recover for mismanagement and waste."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 22. -- Important disclosures on one year of Nazi rule are made in the German emigre newspaper Neue Vorwaerts now published here. From official figures issued by the Reich, from June, 1933, to June, 1934, the journal says, 184 persons were killed in Germany "while attempting to escape."

KILUNG, Kiangsi, China, July 22 (AP). -- The venerable Lin Sen, President of China, today granted to his nephew and foster son, James Lin, the "right to make his own decision" in his recent marriage to Viola Brown, Columbus (Ohio) shopgirl.

ST. LOUIS, July 22. -- The Giants bogged down today at Sportsmans Park in more ways than one. On a field transformed into a quagmire by a morning of torrential rain, the pitching of the league leaders slumped badly and their attack was a harmless gesture as they met defeat in the first of six crucial games with the Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- An in tensified drive to reduce the relief rolls through "aggressive cooperation" with local officials in their attempts to place unemployed in farm and industrial jobs will be undertaken by the United States Reemployment Service, W.F. Persons, its chief, announced today.

The first firing in twelve years of the army's two sixteen-inch guns at Fort Tilden, Rockaway Beach, Queens, scheduled for today, has been "indefinitely postponed," because of political pressure brought to bear on the War Department in Washington.
An estate valued at less than $5,000 was left by Albert I. Sire, attorney and former owner of large real estate holdings here, according to his will, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Reflecting the increase in operations in the industry, which are about 15 points higher than a year ago, steel shares on the Stock Exchange were sharply higher yesterday. Many issues, including both common and preferred stocks of United States Steel, established new high levels for the year.

Over the week-end three more broadbill swordfish were added to the list of big-game fish captured off Montauk. One of these proved to be an unusual catch, and the total number of broadbill taken this season is now increased to six.

New York has once again proved to be more than a match for an octopus. It became known yesterday that the tiny baby cephalopod that arrived in town last Wednesday, minus five tentacles but otherwise apparently in the best of health, suddenly gave up the struggle Saturday afternoon.

BOMBAY, India, July 22 (AP). -- Unrest spread from Lahore to Punjab Province today as 5,000 Moslems, marching in protest against interference with their worship, clashed with policemen and State troops.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt was represented by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee as firmly insistent on passage of a graduated corporation tax at this session of Congress. The President conferred on neutrality legislation and NRA problems.

Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts Committee, said yesterday that $10,000 must be raised by public subscription within a week to support the remaining programs in the series at the Lewisohn Stadium. A minimum operating fund of $50,000 is required, and only four-fifths of that amount has been subscribed to date, she indicated.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP). -- After having had a conference with former President Herbert Hoover, Governor Harry W. Nice of Maryland today attacked the national administration as "totally insane."

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Investigation of charges that hundreds of unauthorized telegrams to members of Congress were filed in York, Pa., in opposition to the Wheeler-Rayburn Utility Holding Company Bill will be reported tomorrow by the Senate Lobby Committee.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 22. -- A tall, slim 17-year-old invader from Dunwoodie, Ted Hular, captured the senior caddie championship of the Westchester Golf Association in the annual tournament over the rolling 6,339-yard layout of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today with a score of 151.

Word is expected from Washington today or tomorrow on the identity of the agent to be detailed by the Treasury Department Intelligence Division for the next two years as chief investigator for Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the forthcoming New York County racket investigation.

Firm prices and an exceptionally heavy registration of buyers featured the opening of the Fall lamp show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. A total of 417 buyers, 25 per cent more than were registered on the opening day of the last Fall display, inspected the lines exhibited by 200 manufacturers.

LONDON, July 22. -- David Lloyd George accepted today the challenge implied in the government's rejection of his proposals for "organizing prosperity" and ending unemployment by raising a national loan of 200,000,000 to expend on work-producing projects.
ROME, July 22. -- Italy, increasingly concerned with the mobilization of an expeditionary force in East Africa, today decreed the temporary suspension of its 40 per cent gold coverage law.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, July 22 (AP). -- The picturesque Agua Caliente resort, largely paid for by American dollars lost in its palatial casino by film celebrities and thrill-seeking tourists, was padlocked today.
ATHENS, July 22. -- Premier Panavoti Tsaldaris considered today the royalist demand that Parliament be convoked to arrange for the immediate holding of a plebiscite on restoration of the monarchy.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- Just to have his hair trimmed by his favorite barber, John Capobianco, a Boston contractor, hired four taxis and an airplane.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 22. -- A brother and sister who had not seen each other for fourteen years were reunited yesterday when they met here at the grave of their mother in Bayview Cemetery.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 22. -- Mrs. J.S. Wemyss of the Lancaster Summer colony entertained her house guests, Mrs. Helen Renhan and Harry Rosiland, New York portrait painter, at the Mount Washington for tea yesterday. A large group gathered in the cocktail lounge following the tea concert to hear new songs by Tom Fletcher and his Negro singers.

The outlook for this heat-stricken Congress grows more depressing every day. To be told by the Administration leaders that they must keep on sweating and mopping and talking until Labor Day was bad enough. But now comes Senator BORAH with his Progressive and inflationist allies to announce that there is no hope of the session ending until November.
CHICAGO, July 22. -- Myrtle Wood, a 3-year-old filly owned by B. Combs, flashed to a new world record of 1:09 2-5 for six furlongs over Arlington Park's lightning fast track today in the fourth race.
PIERRE, S.D., July 22. -- All relief in South Dakota stopped tonight under orders issued through the office of M.A. Kennedy, State relief director, and his deputy, Philip Ketchum.
ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP). -- Flunking students are an expensive luxury to the public school systems of the United States, says Dr. Henry J. Gerling, St. Louis Superintendent of Instruction.

HANKOW, China, July 22 (AP). -- Showering of machine-gun bullets from a Japanese gunboat upon the American missionary school of Huping College at Yochow, Hunan Province, was reported by an American missionary arriving here today.

VIENNA, July 22. -- As a countermove to the government's preparations for a day of general mourning Thursday on the anniversary of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss's assassination, Nazis are scattering throughout Vienna aluminum coins bearing on one side the Nazi slogan, "

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Efforts of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation to obtain a loan of $2,300,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to aid in reorganizing the company have been turned down, it was reported today after a closed hearing in the chambers of Federal Judge William H. Holly.

Francisco Pardo de Zela, 18-year-old son of the Peruvian Consul General here, who had pleaded guilty to having had a loaded pistol in his hand on June 18 when he entered a jewelry shop at 271 1/2 Amsterdam Avenue, was freed yesterday in Special Sessions on a suspended sentence.

More than six months ago Mr. LLOYD GEORGE began to save Great Britain. He consulted every right-viewing expert he could find. Mighty plans came forth from his brain and the brains of his fellow-builders. He went on the stump, "He came back into public life with reluctance."

Combination restaurants, clinics and shelters for the unattached and transients on relief will be opened here, probably in September, it was disclosed yesterday, when a committee representing the American League of Ex-Service Men called at emergency relief headquarters to present a series of demands.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Authority to mint half-cent and one-mill coins to be put into general circulation throughout the country will be asked by Congress within a few days, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

ROME, July 22. -- Attacks upon Japan were made today in the Italian press, which questioned Japan's motives toward Italy in the dispute with Ethiopia. Japan has economic interests in Ethiopia and plans to establish a legation in Addis Ababa in December.

A proposal to merge the fair-trade practice bureaus of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc., and of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc., into one powerful organization was made yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the former group, to Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated association.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Asserting that "there's enough dirt to keep twenty committees busy," Chairman Black of the Senate Lobby investigators approved tonight the parallel House inquiry into the power company fight against the Utility Holding Company Bill.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 22. -- Dr. Russell M. Wright of Detroit today told the American Osteopathic Association convention that in an examination of 1,000 men between the ages of 16 and 30 only five disclosed perfect body posture, while 641 were definitely bad and 282 were extremely bad.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Deals in Stutz Motor Car Company stock will be aired tomorrow at hearings conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission in an investigation to determine if provisions of the Securities Act have been violated by the automobile company and half a dozen brokerage houses distributing Stutz stock in principal cities throughout the United States.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 22. -- Three of the members of the United States international chess team, who will go to Poland next month, were successful today in the first round of the annual Western championship, conducted by the American Chess Federation.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 22 (AP). -- A full confession that he drowned his wife to further his unwelcome wooing of a girl of 17 was attributed to Newell P. Sherman, 26, choir singer and Scoutmaster of Sutton, by Alfred Cenebella, Assistant District Attorney, today.

Noel Scaffa, private detective, sat in Federal court yesterday and heard a prosecutor accuse him of violating the law in connection with the recovery of jewelry stolen last January from Mrs. Margaret Hawkesworth Bell, former New York dancer, in the Miami Biltmore Hotel, Florida.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 22. --- The wheat crop in Kansas, Missouri and Oklahoma, with direct benefit payments at present market prices, is worth about $50,000,000 more than the 1934 crop.
A good many people must be wondering. It is now a week since the Brown Shirt pogrom in Berlin and no one as yet has come forward to prove that the real culprits are the Allies.

LONDON, July 22. -- The stock market opened the new three-week account quietly today, with prices dull in most departments. British Government issues were weak and British rails idle, although the dividend season will open in a few days.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- An international rubber combination which has clamped down on the export from 95 per cent of the ruling producing countries was blamed by Commerce Department officials today for steadily rising prices of that commodity.

ROME, July 22. -- Fascist troops and police were assigned today to guard against political demonstrations which, it was feared, would rise from the violent anti-Japanese campaign in the newspapers over the reported Japanese opposition to the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

A finding of accidental death was agreed upon yesterday by the prosecutor's office and the county physician of Bergen County, N.J., and the Palisades Interstate Park police, in the case of Mrs. Ottillie Staufmann Umbach, 26-year-old bride, who was drowned late Saturday afternoon when a torrent swept her down a 300-foot open drainage ditch near the Fort Lee, N.J., approach to the George Washington Bridge.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 22. -- Gus Kostas Paparipes, 55 years old, a frankfurter vendor, got angry at the neighborhood children for the last time tonight. He was chasing Victor Lali out of his store at 5 North Fifth Avenue when he dropped dead.

The Merchants Association filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday a table of rail rates charged for the transportation of automobiles between factories of the Middle West and the Atlantic seaboard and Gulf ports in support of the proposal of the Eastern railroads to increase the charges on this traffic to the Gulf.

" F.S." writes to THE TIMES: "America has just as competent and efficient engineers [as Europe has], who could devise a method to stop these terrible [auto] noises that endanger health and are a great nuisance by day and night."

BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- Five men from New York and Rhode Island who were convicted or pleaded guilty to robbing a mail truck in Fall River in January, received prison sentences today of twenty-five years each. They were Carl Rettich of Warwick, R.I.; Joseph Fisher of Providence; John "Sonny" McGlone, Thomas Duggan and Charles Harrigan of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 22. -- The Collier Trophy was presented today to Captain Albert F. Hegenberger of the Army Air Corps by President Roosevelt on behalf of the National Aeronautic Association.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 22. -- In scoring a brilliant and clean-cut victory today over Wilmer Allison of the American Davis Cup team, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany played tennis that stamps him as one of the greatest players in the world.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Like the Fat Boy in Pickwick, Senator Borah loves to make their flesh creep. This yearning had something to do with his terrifying suggestion yesterday that, so strong a fight will be made for bills involving 5 billions in inflationary currency Congress may not adjourn until Nov. 1.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- Though many had expected the Soviet trans-polar airplane to take off for San Francisco this morning, it is still under cover at some unnamed airport near Moscow, with the time of its departure as much of a mystery as ever.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22. -- The correspondents of the principal foreign newspapers and press associations are planning to leave Argentina or suspend news service from Argentina when the government's new decree putting correspondents under bond becomes effective.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP). -- Two full teams of seniors who gained fame on college gridirons last Fall, headed by four All-America selections, were named today to match power with the Chicago Bears of the National Football League under the lights at Soldier Field on Aug. 29, in the second annual all-star game.
Your description of the Virginia Press Association luncheon brings both joy and sadness.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- With applications for registration by 4,477 brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets on file, the Securities and Exchange Commission was confident today that its program for regulation, which will start Aug. 1, will prove effective.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 22. -- "Return to Folly," a comedy by Harlan Ware, with Leona Powers in the lead, was the offering tonight at the Red Barn Theatre, which started its fourth week of a ten-play season.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 22. -- President Jose Tejada Sorzano at a press conference today disclosed that Bolivia would ask the Buenos Aires peace conference for an intermission because of Paraguay's unwillingness to begin a study of the fundamental question of the Chaco conflict in view of possible political happenings in Bolivia on Aug. 15, when President Tejada's mandate expires.

Herman Strulesitz, 23-year-old proprietor of a small candy store at Fallsburgh, N.Y., who was held in $7,500 bail in Jefferson Market Court yesterday for a $1,590 payroll robbery, knows now that it is not prudent to go about talking of one's accomplishments. There may be a patrolman within earshot, one who is alert even if he is vacationing.

THE new novel by the new Lord Tweedsmuir, John Buchan, soon to take office as Governor General of Canada, is one of the prettiest examples of instinctive tact that I have ever seen. It has always been considered a news-worthy paradox that one of Great Britain's most obvious candidates for a pro-consulship should also be one of her two or three most popular writers of light adventure tales.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt's reciprocal tariff program, regarded by the administration as a principal step toward restoration of normal international relationships, was under heavy attack when the Senate recessed to night after a seven-hour debate on the amendments to the Agricultural AdJustment Administration Act.
ST. PAUL, July 22 (AP). -- The government today was enjoined by two Federal judges from collecting processing taxes from four companies.

The fourth and final new bill of the Fokine Ballet in its season at the Lewisohn Stadium opened last night before an audience whose numbers were kept small by the threatening weather. The program consisted of "Carnival," the Venusberg scene from "Tannhaeuser," and the Ravel "Bolero."

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The largest percentage increase in sales volume for any four-week period this year was reported today by Sears, Roebuck Co. Sales for the period from June 19 to July 16 amounted to $30,065,361, compared with $21,641,512 in the period ended June 18.

Which only two more full trading sessions before contracts for July cotton go off the board at noon on Thursday, an active demand for the near month steadied prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The government corner through control of virtually the entire domestic supply has compelled mills, having prices to fix, to pay an advancing premium over October until the squeeze widened the spread to 41 points in final dealings.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 22. -- Bringing stories of a "new wonderland" in Central New Guinea, H.G. Hides, Assistant Resident Magistrate, arrived with an expedition of thirty-eight men at Port Moresby on the southern coast of Papua today after traveling hundreds of miles through unexplored territory and filling in one of the last remaining blank spots on maps of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Borah's disclosure of efforts to tack $5,000,000,000 of inflation legislation onto the administration's Tax Bill brought quick notice today of opposition from Democratic leaders.

SCARSBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 22. -- As the fifth in his series of self-composed offerings at the Beechwood Theatre, Frederick Jackson presented here this evening an insistent little comedy, flavoring on French farce, entitled "Beginner's Luck." The cast was headed by Louise Prussing and William Post Jr.

The police thought for a time yesterday that they had found a clue that might lead to a solution of the $427,000 armored truck robbery that took place last August at the Rubel Ice Company's plant, Bay Nineteenth Street near Bath Avenue, Brooklyn.
Three men were drowned in the Hudson River yesterday, two of them suicides, according to the police. In each case the victim dropped into the river from a ferryboat. One was identified.

ROME, July 22. -- The Italian Government has decided temporarily to suspend the requirement of 40 per cent gold coverage of the note issue, fixed Dec. 21, 1927, under the decree stabilizing the lira at 92.76 to the pound sterling.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- For the second time in as many days a ninth-inning home run by Wesley Ferrell won a game for the Red Sox today. Dick Coffman of the Browns was the victim of Ferrell's batting prowess which made the final score 2 -- 1.

As long as American courts "continue to attack the problem of human behavior from the wrong end" they will fail to make progress in crime control, Judge Camille Kelley of the Juvenile Court at Memphis, Tenn., asserted yesterday. She spoke before a joint session of the Woodmen of the World and its auxiliary, the Woodmen Circle, opening an eleven-day convention at the Park Central Hotel.

After the usual series of rumors and evasions, without which a theatrical event is seldom preceded these days, there now comes official word that Ina Claire will again appear this season under the banner of the Theatre Guild -- the play selected for her brittle talents being "Love Is Not So Simple," by the Hungarian playwright, Ladislaus Fodor.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in fairly active trading, although some staples declined moderately. On the cash markets there were no declines, while gains occurred in cotton, corn and rubber and silk and tin rose to new high prices.

Net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the six months ended on June 30, 1935, amounted to $22,450,485, equivalent, after debenture dividends, to $1.74 a share on 11,051,662 shares of common stock, the average number outstanding in the period, according to a pamphlet report issued yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- Preparations for the annual village fair, which takes place on Friday afternoon, to be followed by a dance in the evening, are occupying all East Hampton this week. Mrs. Ellery S. James has organized her committee for the tea booth, which includes:

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Inspected hog slaughter for the current marketing year will be the smallest in twenty-five years, and present indications are that slaughter in the 1935-36 marketing year, which begins Oct. 1, will be even smaller, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Baden Catholics expect wholesale arrests in view of the announcement of Walter Koehler, Premier of Baden, that he was ready to "go the limit" against Catholic critics of the National Socialist party. It is believed, however, that few Catholics will challenge the Nazi edicts until after the conference of all Catholic Bishops at Fulda on Aug. 16.

Plans of the Duke-Price Power Company, Ltd., for refunding its $35,529,000 of first-mortgage 6 per cent bonds, due 1966, into a new issue carrying a lower rate of interest, are nearing completion, it was disclosed yesterday. All details of the operation have not as yet been determined, but it is understood that application will be made to the SEC soon.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 22 (AP). -- The House of Representatives committee investigating New York flood damage returned to Washington today to ask President Roosevelt to help speed up Federal reconstruction and relief in the flood zone by cutting red tape.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 22. -- J.E. White, general manager of The Terre Haute Star, announced tonight that the paper will "delay" its publication tomorrow morning because of the general strike The Star, a morning paper, has a circulation of about 26,000.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 22. -- The City Commission failed this afternoon in a last-minute effort to settle the strike of 4,600 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which today entered its eleventh week. The company proceeded with its plan to reopen the shipyard at 7:40 o'clock tomorrow morning in spite of the strike.
NEWPORT, July 22. -- Among the luncheon parties of today was one given by Mrs. Skirvin Adams at Beachmound. She and her sister, Mrs. George Mesta, will entertain again tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP). -- Wiley Post tuned up his monoplane today for a leisurely flight to Moscow and back, but whether his friend, Will Rogers, screen humorist, would accompany him remained a matter of conjecture.
PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP). -- Cy Blanton, Pirate rookie, ran his strikeouts for the season to ninety-one today as Pittsburgh won its fifth straight game by defeating the Phillies, 5 to 4.
MARION, Mass., July 22. -- American boats took first and second places today in the opening international thirty-square-meter match race conducted by the Beverly Yacht Club for the Roosevelt Bowl.

The hand-to-hand grapple for immediate possession of first place in the American League's 1935 pennant race between the Yankees and Tigers remained in something of a state of suspended animation yesterday when intermittent showers, that started upsetting things shortly after noon, caused a postponement at the Stadium of the opening clash of a four-game series.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 22 (AP). -- Fred Perry of England sat in the press box today as Baron Gottfried von Cramm played Wilmer Allison.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- The Indians celebrated Walter Johnson Day by defeating the Senators, 6 to 4, today, making fourteen hits and repulsing a ninth-inning attack by the losers.
TOKYO, July 22. -- The fiftieth anniversary of the death of Ulysses Simpson Grant will be commemorated tomorrow in services under the tree that General Grant planted when he visited Tokyo in 1878.

Albert Rasquin, an uncle of Almon G. Rasquin, Internal Revenue Colector for the First District, Brooklyn, died of gas poisoning late yesterday in his home at 140 Winfield Avenue, Jersey City. The police listed the death as accidental. Mr. Rasquin was 54 years old.
BERLIN, July 22. -- The Boerse displayed considerable nervousness today. The opening was weak but later recovery wiped out most of the losses and the close was somewhat firmer.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 17 shows increases for the week of $273,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $75,000,000 in other loans and investments, $174,000,000 in government deposits and $38,000,000 in net demand deposits and decreases of $145,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $16,000,000 in time deposits.
The defending champions met with varying fates yesterday as the fields in the men's and women's metropolitan public links golf championship were reduced to the finalists at Van Cortlandt Park.

Acrid smoke pouring from a fire in an elevator shaft at the forty-eighth floor in the fifty-story General Electric Building at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street forced Gerard Swope, the president of the company, and more than 300 other occupants of offices above the twenty-second floor to flee from the building at 4:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Daniel W. Bell, Acting Director of the Budget, were named today by Secretary Ickes to serve on an allotment subcommittee which will determine when cities shall receive interest rates on PWA loans below 4 per cent, the maximum and usual rate.

MALONE, N.Y., July 22 (AP). -- The general cordiality which marked the first income tax trial of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer will be absent tomorrow when he goes on trial again in Federal court here.
B. Coles Neidecker arrived here on Sunday under his own name aboard the Britannic, and recorded on his customs declaration that he intended to go to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A new and potentially glorious field for motion pictures is about to be opened by Music Guild Productions, a newcomer in the movie world. "Faust," the first of its projected pictures, will also be the first full-length opera to be done in color. Fragments of other operas and condensations have been attempted, operatic singers have appeared since the arrival of the talkies, and one or two highly successful films have been written around an opera.

Possibility of a Cabinet crisis in the Netherlands today over economy measures to be voted on by the Dutch Parliament provided the necessary spark yesterday for a general weakening in the foreign exchange markets with a sharp break in the price of the guilder.

A new and potentially glorious field for motion pictures is about to be opened by Music Guild Productions, a newcomer in the movie world. "Faust," the first of its projected pictures, will also be the first full-length opera to be done in color. Fragments of other operas and condensations have been attempted, operatic singers have appeared since the arrival of the talkies, and one or two highly successful films have been written around an opera.

Possibility of a Cabinet crisis in the Netherlands today over economy measures to be voted on by the Dutch Parliament provided the necessary spark yesterday for a general weakening in the foreign exchange markets with a sharp break in the price of the guilder.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Future activities of the National Recovery Administration were studied by President Roosevelt today in conference with Attorney General Cummings, Solicitor General Reed, James L. O'Neill, head of the NRA, and Howard Cheney, chairman of the Industrial Advisory Board.

Handing down a decision which may strike a blow at attorneys who demand what has been described as excessive fees in bankruptcy and reorganization cases, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals cut heavily yesterday into allowances granted by Federal Judge Inch in Brooklyn to trustees, attorneys, receivers and others in two reorganization and equity proceedings.

LONDON, July 22. -- With heavy bombers roaring overhead in night exercises the government obtained tonight a supplementary vote of 5,335,000 for expansion of the air force, with an increase of 12,000 men this year, outside of India. Of the new men 1,300 are to be pilots.

The preliminary annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for 1934 shows gross revenues of $83,975,089, a gain of $2,641,787, or 3.2 per cent over 1933, and sufficient to cover increased expenses and nearly enough to cover increased taxes.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 22. -- Displaying all the cool, quiet mastery that brought him into the Wimbledon final three weeks ago, Baron Gottfried von Cramm kept Germany in the running for Davis Cup honors today by defeating Wilmer Allison in three sparkling sets, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6-4.

TORONTO, July 22. -- Calumet Fingo, bay stallion owned by M. Schneider of Milwaukee, today won the Dominion Harness Horse Stake for the three-year-old pacers. Carrying a purse of $1,000 the event featured the grand circuit program at Thorncliffe Park.

In selling the largest number of cars for any six months in its history, the Chrysler Corporation made a net profit of $18,659,309, or $4.31 a share on its common stock in the first half of this year, it was announced yesterday by Walter P. Chrysler, president and chairman of the board.

Turning in a card of 32, 35 -- 67, five strokes under par, Ray Kilthau of Oakland and Charles Mayo Sr., veteran professional of the Lido Country Club, gained first honors yesterday in the Long Island Golf Association's weekly amateur-pro tournament at the Pomonok Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Western Pacific Railroad has reached a virtual agreement for reorganization with the bondholders, committee, and probably will file a plan soon with the Interstate Commerce Commission, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today.

MEXICO, D.F., July 23 (AP). -- A popular agrarian uprising forced Governor Manuel Lastra of the State of Tabasco out of office today and threatened the position of the Governor of Tamaulipas, Dr. Rafael Villarreal.

Fritz Lang, the German film director, has signed a long-term contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. His first American-made picture will be "Passport to Hell," an adaptation of a magazine story by James Warner Bellah. The cast has not been chosen yet.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 23. -- After a series of six races sailed yesterday and today over the Bay Shore Yacht Club course, a crew representing the Westhampton yacht squadron annexed the junior championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

Public offering will be made today by Edward B. Smith Co., Kidder, Peabody Co. and Lazard Freres Co., Inc., of $9,000,000 of fifteen-year 4 per cent debentures of the Armstrong Cork Company, priced at $100 and accrued interest to the date of delivery.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 23. -- A small group of employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation passed through a picket line a half mile long today to return to work as the company, in spite of the continuance of a strike now more than ten weeks old, opened the gates of its yard in a effort to resume operations.

DETROIT, July 23. -- As the trial of William Schweitzer, Florence and Loretta Jackson, sisters, and Jean Miller opened today before Judge John A. Boyne, repudiation of their confessions that they plotted to rob and murder Howard Carter Dickinson, New York attorney, was indicated.

Luigi Pirandello, Nobel Prize winner and dean of Italian playwrights, entertained a group of five American dramatists and writers yesterday afternoon in his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria and tried to give them his idea of art and artists.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 23. -- The forty-eight-hour general strike was called off tonight in an announcement by Thomas N. Taylor, organizer and special representative of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I, July 23. -- Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn gave a luncheon today at the Irving for a group of women members of the Garden Club of Southampton comprising the flower show committee who are working for the success of the twenty-eighth annual flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club and the Southampton Horticultural Society to be held Thursday and Friday in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

Aaron Greenspan, 29 years old, an attorney of 104-12 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Anthony Hoekstra in Rockaway Beach court, Queens, for violation of a municipal ordinance prohibiting bathing beyond lines of safety, said, "These men are all wrong, judge.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Signs of cooperation in an effort to effect adjournment of Congress with the adoption of the President's program by Aug. 23 are becoming apparent.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- With the ratio plan for limitation of navies definitely in the discard as the result of Great Britain's abandonment of that principle yesterday, officials here began today to study the possibility of finding a practical solution of the naval problem through application of the rule of "equality of security" for all nations.
BOSTON, July 23 (AP). -- Aided by a fourteen-hit attack on four pitchers, Ivy Paul Andrews, Browns' righthander, turned on his old mates today and registered a 7-2 victory over the Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The date when registration will be required of brokers and dealers who transact business in over-the counter markets was extended today from Aug. 1 to Oct. 1, by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mrs. Margaret Benson, 60 years old, of 30 Hudson Avenue, Guttenberg, N.J., received yesterday $5,000 of the $18,600 she saved out of her husband's salary in the last twenty-five years.
