Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Jersey City, made the award on the recent plea of Mrs. Benson's husband, Charles Benson, 59, for a receiver to take over the money.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 23. -- The American doubles team of Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn barely managed to win its all-important match in the Davis Cup interzone final round today, but only after a hair-raising, five-set struggle which brought it again to the edge of an utterly unexpected downfall.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 23. -- After being involved in a three-cornered tie in the annual thirty-six-hole Westchester Golf Association's caddie masters' tournament today at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club, John Skibik of Leewood captured the championship in a four-hole play-off.

Being President of a big country like China or Soviet Russia does not necessarily bring world-wide fame. When General CHIANG KAI-SHEK was head of the national government of China at Nanking he was very much in the news, but this was as a military man and as the real master of the government rather than in his official capacity.

ROME, July 23 (AP). -- A new mass attack against Great Britain was launched this afternoon in the Italian press, which announced "Italy will remember" Britain's reported decision to lift the arms embargo against Ethiopia, Editorial attacks on Japan's alleged expansionist policy in Africa continued.

Twenty amateur boxers making up the team of the Catholic Boys' Clubs of New York, in charge of Jack Britton, former welterweight champion, left Grand Central yesterday for Chicago, where they will meet the team of the Catholic Youth Organization at Wrigley Field next Wednesday.

Two claimants to the American agency of the Spanish Transatlantic Steamship Line will support their claims Friday in Federal court as the result of an injunction action brought by S. E.L. Maduro, 21 State Street, agent of the line since 1927.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation continued on a restricted basis in June, with new authorizations and commitments totaling $156,977,059.12, of which $50,000,000 represented an advance to the Commodity Credit Corporation to replace the cancellation of a similar amount previously authorized.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23. -- Another of the first-round games in the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club, which have been held up by the weather, was completed today when Stewart Iglehart's Long Island team finally managed to subdue John Fell's Camels by the margin of Pancho Echenique's extra-period goal, 7 -- 6.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ALBANY, July 23. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, addressing the Women's Republican Club of the town of Bethlehem, this afternoon demanded that Governor Lehman investigate the reign of the O'Connell brothers in Albany County.

BERLIN, July 23. -- The new National Socialist campaign against almost all non-Nazi elements among the German people is being accompanied by a new coordination wave which, in part at least, appears to be one of the purposes behind the campaign itself.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday decreased slightly in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. However, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Prices of hogs continued to advance in the market here today as the result of what the trade regards as a starvation run. Only 9,000 head arrived today, with 7,000 estimated for tomorrow. Prices were 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight higher with the top at $11, showing 15 cents above Monday's level and a new high since September, 1930.

The Countess of Granard, sister of Ogden Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, is one of the passengers due to arrive from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others coming on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg include:

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- A set of tax schedules estimated by the Treasury to yield $118,600,000 a year in additional inheritance and gift levies was tentatively selected today by Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee to be the basis for drafting that portion of President Roosevelt's tax program.

Conflicting price trends were evident in heavier bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Further progress was made by second-grade railroad liens and some of the more speculative industrial loans, but this trend was offset to some extent by a heavy undertone in many of the high-grade, or strictly investment issues.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, after reconsideration of cases involving coal rates to Atlantic City, Camden and other points in Southern New Jersey, announced today modified and adjusted freight rates to those destinations.

Amos R.E. Pinchot, prominent liberal, who supported President Roosevelt in 1932, asserted yesterday that he was "no longer gambler enough to support the New Deal." He made the statement in an open letter to Professor Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School, one of the President's close advisers.

A tentative school budget calling for appropriations of about $8,000000 more than the $134,000,000 granted this year will be turned over to the finance committee of the Board of Education today by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

TOKYO, July 23. -- In welcoming Britain's abandonment of the ratio principle for navies, which satisfied Japan's national dignity, the naval authorities intimate that Japan will not make any declaration stabilizing fleets at the strengths to be reached by 1942.

OMAHA, Neb., July 23 (AP). -- A "back-to-the-farm" movement which has brought increases in land prices of from 15 to 33 per cent over a year ago was looked upon today as indicating that prosperity is finding its way back to the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Federal Communications Commission, in joining the inquiry into the lobbying activities of the public utility groups against the Wheeler-Rayburn Holding Company Bill, directed eight communication companies today to supply specific information by Aug. 15 as to the extent of propaganda, whether unauthorized signatures were signed to telegrams to the President or Congress members, and the total of records, if any, which were destroyed.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -The House Interstate Commerce Committee approved today the administration bill for Federal regulation of motor trucks and buses.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 23. -- Mrs. T.R. Rudel of Plandome today scored an 85 to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament over the difficult Rock Spring Country Club course.

Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the taxicab problem, pledged yesterday a thorough inquiry into all phases of the cab industry to get data for legislation to end current abuses. Mr. Moran's committee will start active work late this week or early next.
The gold-bloc currencies were unsettled in the foreign exchange market yesterday, with sharp declines in the Italian lira and the Dutch guilder.

In a finish so close that many competent observers were unable to call the winner, Stocks captured the Croton Handicap yesterday at Empire City by a nose. A scantier margin and it would have been a dead heat with Cycle, which led from the head of the stretch until nipped at the wire by the rush of the Ascot Stable color-bearer.

ROME, July 23. -- The usual "well-informed circles" continue to state most emphatically that yesterday's decree authorizing the government to allow the Bank of Italy's gold reserve to fall below the statutory 40 per cent coverage of notes does not mean an inflation period is about to set in or that the lira is likely to be devalued.

BUENOS AIRES, July 23. -- An Argentine Senator was killed and the Minister of Agriculture and a member of the Chamber of Deputies were wounded when four revolver shots were fired in the Senate chamber this afternoon during a bitter debate about meat packers.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 23 (AP). -- As the result of the thrilling triumph scored by Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn in the doubles, America will enter the final phase of the Davis Cup interzone tie favored to win one of the two remaining singles matches tomorrow.

The squeeze in the July which compelled mills having unfilled contracts on raw cotton to pay a 40-point premium over October was again the feature of trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. While active mill covering sustained the near month here, Monday's 52-point premium in New Orleans crashed to only 16 points when July broke 43 points suddenly as delivery of a few hundred bales there found few buyers.

Steel stocks have advanced the last few days, apparently in the belief that the contra-seasonal rise in mill operations means the industry is at last entering an era of large production. For several years the nation's consumption of steel has been of starvation proportions, creating a vast backlog of unsatisfied needs.

Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Edison Electric Institute, utility trade association with offices at 420 Lexington Avenue, revealed yesterday that the institute had spent $181,749 to oppose the power and utility program of the Federal Government.

An attempt by two boys to drive away with a truck, of which the steering wheel had been locked when it was left in front of the Metropolitan Tobacco Company's office and warehouse at 69 Warren Street, Brooklyn, resulted last night in the wrecking of the vehicle and the arrest of John Ryan, 15 years old, of 309 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Pete DeCaprio of the Bronx and Mrs. George Rudnick of Manhattan gained the metropolitan public links golf titles as the four-day tournament at the Van Cortlandt Park course was concluded yesterday.
TSINAN, Shantung, China, July 23. -- Within ten days the northern half of Kiangsu Province will be flooded if the Yellow River continues to rise, in the opinion of Chinese river experts.

To get the services as chief investigator, in his forthcoming New York County racket inquiry, of the type of man he wants, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, is contemplating a substantial increase in the salary he originally offered, it was revealed yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- Paul Dean tossed the Giants out of first place in the National League race today at Sportsmans Park, but the Terrymen hammered their way back into the coveted position again and tonight still are half a game ahead of the Cardinals.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- The American Federation of Hosiery Workers gave to its executive board late today the power to take any action it saw fit in reaching a new working agreement with manufacturers at the expiration of the present contract on Sept. 1.

There was prolonged applause and loud cheers for Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday at a children's party in the Chaloner Theatre, Ninth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, when Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer, announced that the Park Department was going to provide them with play facilities in the new Riverside Park development.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Increases of 1.7 per cent in factory employment, or about 118,000 workers, and of 2.9 per cent, or $4,100,000, in weekly factory payrolls in June, as compared with May, were reported today by Secretary Perkins on the basis of reports from "representative establishments" in ninety manufacturing industries.

LONDON, July 24. -- The Labor party's motion to censure the government for its failure to deal adequately with derelict areas which "have become the industrial slums of industrial Great Britain" collapsed in the House of Commons tonight as all such motions have done.

BERLIN, July 23. -- There has been a lull today in the more violent aspects of the persecution that had so suddenly burst again upon the Jews of Germany. But it may be taken for granted that the lull is merely temporary.

The fiftieth anniversary of the death of General U.S. Grant was observed yesterday afternoon with memorial exercises on the plaza of Grant's Tomb at 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Representatives of patriotic organizations and of the nattional, State and city governments paid tribute to his memory and to five G.A.R. veterans present who had served in his troops.

Robert O. Ballou is discontinuing his own publishing business on Aug. 1 to join the staff of Robert M. McBride as chief editor. Mr. Ballou was one of the original members of the firm of Jonathan Cape Harrison Smith, Inc., and remained with that firm until 1932.

Alleging that constitutional and State rights of a mother have been violated, Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt will ask the Appellate Division today for permission to take to the Court of Appeals the Appellate Division's decision upholding the ruling of Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew that gave her only part custody of her 10-year-old daughter, Gloria.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 23. -- The ranks of the established array, which underwent so trying an ordeal on opening day, held firm against the challenge of the lower division and the sweltering humidity today in the second round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Prices of hogs at many points throughout the Midwest reached today the highest figure in nearly five years. The $11 hog reappeared on the Chicago livestock market for the first time since Sept. 22, 1930. This figure plus the $2.25 government processing tax made selected choice medium-weight hogs cost buyers $13.25.

BALTIMORE, July 23. -- The Maryland Casualty Company, the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company, the New Amsterdam Casualty Company and the Fidelity and Deposit Company registered substantial increases in premiums written in the first half of 1935, it developed today.

Mayor La Guardia struck back yesterday at persecution of American citizens by the German Government by establishing a policy of denying any special privileges to German citizens living in New York City. He said, "It is well known that American citizens of the Jewish faith have been discriminated against in Germany."

NEWPORT, July 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Pierpont Gilbert have selected Saturday evening, Sept. 7, for a dinner with music for young people at their home, Four Acres, in honor of Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, who is to be introduced to society at a dinner dance at the Muenchinger King on Aug. 14.

The five-day taste of freedom that Mike, a recalcitrant 4-yearold Rhesus monkey, found so sweet ended yesterday morning when he was captured on a tenth-floor window ledge of the Underwood-Elliott-Fisher Building at Greenwich and Vesey Streets after another wild chase through the modern jungle.

LONDON, July 23. -- Coincident with the concentration of Italian troops in East Africa, Great Britain is massing what naval experts rate as the strongest, fastest fleet ever assembled in the Mediterranean.

MALONE, N.Y., July 23. -- A hurt look twisted the usually blank features of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in Franklin County Court House today when Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant sent him to jail.

Incorporated Investors-Investments costing $40,126,132 had a market value on June 35 of $41,950,013. This compares with investments costing $35,990,859, with a market value of $34,488,075 on June 30, 1934. Net income for the quarter ended on June 30 from dividends and interest, after expenses and taxes, but exclusive of the net gain realized on sales of investment securities in the period, was $302,629.

SALEM, N.J., July 23. -- Abbott Worrall slept soundly last night and if he dreamed at all they were pleasant dreams which did not bother his slumber. An hour after dawn he awoke and looked out of the window over the East View Cemetery, of which he is the sole caretaker.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 23. -- The Bermuda cricket team defeated Providence today, 143 to 58. Providence used fifteen players against Bermuda's eleven, but the visitors had little difficulty in triumphing.

LONDON, July 23. -- The consensus in London's financial circles today was that Italy's reduction of the gold coverage of her currency supplies striking official evidence of the economic strain she has experienced in recent months -- a strain which is considered likely to increase if she undertakes an extensive war.

Revised gas rates filed by the Westchester Lighting Company bringing a saving estimated at $560,000 to Westchester consumers will be allowed to go into effect on Aug. 5 without approval or disapproval of the Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday.

Statistics from the president's annual report made yesterday by De E. Bradshaw of Omaha, Neb., to Woodmen of the World in convention at the Park Central Hotel revealed that the average age of 6,490 members who died in 1934 was 62.1 years. In 1914 it was 40 years.

High temperatures that were intensified by excessive humidity inflicted widespread discomfort again yesterday. Scattered and all too brief thundershowers in the afternoon and evening provided only momentary relief.

Judging of school teachers on the basis of weight, age and "loyalty" was termed "petty twaddle" in an address yesterday by Professor Roma Gans of Teachers College, Columbia University, before nearly 1,000 teachers and students attending the Summer session.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- President Roosevelt appointed Lawrence Cramer as Governor of the Virgin Islands, shifting the previous Governor, Paul M. Pearson and Judge T. Webber Wilson to other government jobs. He conferred on naval affairs with Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations.

Field Marshal Joseph V. McCarthy entered the Yankee dugout at the Stadium yesterday, glanced approvingly at a great crowd which later was found to total 62,516, glared at the common enemy and blazed both barrels into the Tigers.

Walter P. Chrysler announced yesterday that he was relinquishing the presidency of the Chrysler Corporation in favor of K.T. Keller, who has been vice president and general manager in charge of production of all Chrysler units. Mr. Chrysler has held the posts of chairman of the board and president since the formation of the company, in 1925.
ROME, July 23. -- The Italian press manifests surprised indignation at reports that the British Cabinet proposes to permit the sale of arms to Ethiopia and assumes a truculent tone toward Britain.

The net income of Remington Rand, Inc., for the three months ended on June 30 almost tripled that of the corresponding quarter of last year, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday by James H. Rand Jr., president and chairman.

" A flood in an area of fishing streams always raises the question of estimating the probable damage to fish life," states Conservation Commissioner Osborne in discussing fresh water conditions following the havoc wrought up-State by recent storms.

For just about three months Connecticut has been keeping the three hundredth anniversary of her birth. She has kept it quietly as becomes so great and ancient a gentlewoman. Town after town of old name exhibits its treasures and takes part in the festival.

Some who read Governor LEHMAN'S announcement that he intended to call a three-day conference in Albany in October on "crime, the criminal and society," may have been inclined to say to themselves, "What, another crime con-"ference? Haven't we had enough in-"vestigations and reports on that sub-"ject?

One man was killed and three other burned critically in an explosion that wrecked the 30-foot cabin cruiser Norman F. last night after the engine had been started as she was lying at her moorings about fifty feet off Gerrittsen Beach in Gerrittsen Basin near Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

PARIS, July 23. -- France will ask the United States Government for the extradition of B. Coles Neidecker, fugitive head of the Travelers Bank, which closed here last week, and for the detention of his two brothers, George and Aubrey, who are due at Norfolk, Va., on the ship of City of Newport News tomorrow.

Bertrand Coles Neidecker was taken into custody yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the New York police on a cable request from the Paris police, who wish to question him about his Travelers Bank in Paris, which closed its doors last week while he was on the way here from France.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Permanent organization of the Republican Grass Roots movement to carry it into every precinct in the Midwest is to be taken up the first week in August at a meeting of the Committee of Fifty to be held in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The section of the AAA measure passed by the Senate today which validates the rates of the processing taxes heretofore applied by the Secretary of Agriculture was aimed at meeting arguments that they had been fixed under an unconstitutional delegation of authority.

Announcement in the House of Commons by the First Lord of the Admiralty that Great Britain would henceforth disregard the naval quotas fixed by the Washington treaty came as no surprise. It naturally followed the action of Japan last December in giving the required notice of the nullifying of that treaty.

Secretary MORGENTHAU announces that, with the approval of the President, he will recommend to Congress the issuance of two new coins, a one-half-cent piece and a one-mill piece. The one-half-cent piece, he says, will be of copper, and slightly smaller than a penny, and the one-mill piece, equivalent to a tenth of a cent, will be of about the same size as the half-cent piece, but made of an aluminum alloy.

Miss Patricia Mallinson, daughter of the late Hiram R. Mallinson, silk manufacturer, is a member of the cast of "Why We Misbehave," which will be presented tonight by the Fortnightly Players at the Washington Theatre, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., it was announced yesterday.

It was something of a joke -- though really no laughing matter -- on the American students and instructors who arrived in Moscow to take part in the Summer school, to find on their arrival that there was no such animal.

Murdo Elder, 28 years old, who said he was a collector of 410 West Twentieth Street, and Ray Gray, 35, of 1,460 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to charges of fraudulent job fixing. Gray was one of the go-betweens for John Flaherty, now serving a Sing Sing term.

Complaining of the prolonged delay in getting United States Senate ratification of the sanitary convention signed May 24, between this country and Argentina, foreign trade groups yesterday appealed to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to bring the measure up for Senate consideration.

After reading a summary of Police Commissioner Valentine's report in which he states that minor crimes are on the increase, it is quite apparent that more policemen are needed. I understand that a plan for providing more officers is under way. Still, why not get the most out of the man power our department has at present?
MADRID, July 23. -- Public order is again the government's preoccupation. At today's Cabinet meeting that was the principal question discussed.

TRENTON, N.J., July 23. -- Authorities at the State prison here have refused to let Bruno Richard Hauptmann send out for publication the completed manuscript of his autobiography, "The Story of My Life," it was learned today following a visit to the Lindbergh kidnapper by his attorney, C. Lloyd Fisher.

Four indictments charging members of the notorious "rifle gang" recently rounded up by the police with assault, burglary and grand larceny were handed up to County Judge Charles Colden yesterday by the Queens County grand jury. Judge Colden said he would allow the five men named to plead today and that he would call a special term of the county court next week to expedite their trials.

SHANGHAI, July 23. -- The fact that Japan is prepared, if necessary, to resort to declared warfare against China in order to attain her aims on the Asiatic mainland was authoritatively divulged for the first time today when the official spokesman of the Japanese Embassy in Nanking revealed to this correspondent that Japan had placed a time limit on her patience.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 23. -- There's gold in the hills of Westchester, but there will be no gold rush, in the opinion of Peter Zodac, Yonkers mining engineer.

LONDON, July 23. -- All copies of "Junglemania," a travel book by Dr. Arthur Torrance, American medical explorer, have been withdrawn by London publishers following the discovery that it contained striking resemblances to a novel previously published by Owen Rutter, a British author.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 23. -- Five hundred and ninety-three Princeton students, or 25.4 per cent of the undergraduate body, are on the university honor roll for the academic year 1934-35, according to the list made public today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar.
Money market was at a standstill so far as business and rate variations were concerned. Demand was light, and quotations unchanged in all sections.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- Taking full advantage of the Dodgers' faulty defensive play, the Cubs today romped away with both ends of a double-header by 8 to 0 and 6 to 4.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 23. -- Colonel George H. Baird, Corps Area Citizens' Military Training Camp officer, with headquarters on Governors Island, made an inspection of the camp here yesterday and indicated his approval of the manner in which this year's instruction of 1,200 young men from New York and Northern New Jersey has been conducted.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,738,800 barrels, compared with 2,715,100 in the preceding week, a gain of 23,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 11,750 barrels in the daily average output in Texas was the most important change.

LONDON, July 23. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin insisted again today in unequivocal language that the foreign policy of his government would continue to be based upon the League of Nations. Addressing a deputation that had come to bring him the official results of the recent peace ballot, he said the government was still determined that international disputes should be settled "by peaceful means in accordance with the terms of the covenant."

ATHENS, July 23. -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris today expressed his approval of six conditions for restoration set forth by former King George to Mayor Kotzias of Athens during the letter's three-day conference with the former monarch in London.

CHARLOTTETOWN, P.E.I., July 23 (Canadian Press). -- Liberals under the leadership of the Hon. W.M. Lea made a clean sweep of the election in Prince Edward Island today, capturing all thirty seats of the Legislature and completely ousting the Conservative Government forces under Premier W.J.P. MacMillan.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- It was a big day at Arlington Park today for the Milky Way Farms, owned by Mrs. Ethel V. Mars of River Forest, Ill., when her color-bearers triumphed in three races. Alfred Robertson of New York rode all three horses to victory.

DANZIG, July 22. -- The conflict between Poland and Danzig's National Socialist government -- precipitated by Danzig's foreign exchange control -- took a sharp turn today when the Danzig Senate President, Arthur Greiser, delivered to the Polish Minister a formal note protesting the Polish customs decree.

Express elevator service in the General Electric Building at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street was partly restored yesterday after Monday's fire in an elevator shaft at the forty-eighth floor, which paralyzed all service above the twenty-second floor of the fifty-story skyscraper.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Mahnkey, winner of The Country Home award for her correspondence from the Oasis (Mo.) countryside, toured New York by automobile yesterday. This was a respite from the constant attention from the New York press to which she had responded gracefully since Sunday, when she arrived here.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 23. -- The three members of the United States international chess team were undefeated in their respective sections today after three rounds of the annual Western championship.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- After a battle of two weeks, the bill carrying amendments designed to protect the Agricultural Adjustment Administration against legal attacks and to extend its farm program was passed by the Senate today by a vote of 64 to 15.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $8,019,135, after all deductions, for the year ended on June 30, equal to $5.35 a share earned on 1,499,465 shares of no-par $6 dividend preferred stock.

BERLIN, July 23. -- The Boerse was generally livelier and firmer today, although nervous undercurrents were unmistakable and the trend turned irregular near the close. The market's consistent buoyancy caused by expectations of inflationary tendencies, received a fresh impetus from the 10 per cent slump in the lira, following Italy's reduction in her minimum of gold coverage.

OTTAWA, July 23 (Canadian Press). -- The seriousness of the rust scourge in the wheat fields of Canada was emphasized in a special report issued today in conjunction with the weekly crop report of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The political problem of the Virgin Islands, which reached the stage of a Senatorial inquiry, was solved in characteristic fashion by President Roosevelt today by a triple shift that took two of the principal Federal officials from the islands.

The share market was called upon to absorb considerable profit taking yesterday, with some of the selling coming from institutional sources as well as from professional operators. With the "inflationist" groups in the Senate and House endeavoring to gain some advantage before Congress adjourns, and with additional reports favorable to the trade outlook, the opportunity for the lightening of speculative holdings appeared made to order.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Charges that the Metropolitan Edison Company of York, Pa., a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, had "wholesaled" spurious and unauthorized messages to the Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies at York and that the companies had "retailed" them to members of Congress were laid before the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee today.

BERLIN, July 23. -- A new warning to the Reich Government to practice the greatest possible economy in view of Germany's rising indebtedness has been sounded by the German Economist, a periodical that follows Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's economic thought and sometimes enjoys direct inspiration from him.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Lawrence W. Cramer, new Governor of the Virgin Islands, was appointed Lieutenant Governor of St. Croix four years ago at the request of Paul N. Pearson, whom he is replacing.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Recent hints by Republican leaders that President Roosevelt should be impeached started a flood of political speeches in the House today. representative Fish, Republican, of New York, added to the Democratic feeling with a declaration that it would be foolish to impeach the President for acts for which the House, the Speaker and the Democratic leaders were "doubly to blame."

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- An agreement to seek immediate Presidential support, for a $40,000,000 appropriation for more than 800 army airplanes was reached today at a secret hearing of a House military subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The legislative cat-and-dog days are beginning here, and pet measures ranging from the foolish to the dangerous are coming from the committee hoppers. This is a natural condition. When a large majority of Congressional members and committees have nothing to do but to await the deliberations of a few, the time seems ripe for the production of favorite ideas in the hope they can be slipped over.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, July 23. -- The city of Matamoros in Tamaulipas, just across the border from Brownsville, remained in the hands of Mayor Rafael Munguia and his administration today, but it was generally conceded that when the 2,000 armed agrarians, now surrounding the city, decided to move in to make changes that the administration would no longer be able to hold out.

WARSAW, July 23. -- The protest by the Danzig Senate against the Polish decree forbidding the Free City's custom offices to tax goods imported into Poland via Danzig will be rejected by the Polish Government, it is learned here.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Allotments to New York City totaling $101,462,893 for WPA projects calculated to put 140,000 persons on jobs under the work relief program were recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments.

Samuel Untermyer sailed yesterday for Europe on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia for a vacation following a serious illness resulting from a cold. He said he would return on Aug. 22. He will land at Naples and go to Rome, where, he said, he might see the Pope, but would not see Mussolini.

Out of Broadway these mad, hot days come occasional rumblings denoting the slow but steady approach of Fall and "the season." Item one this morning, therefore, is hopeful. It concerns "Jubilee!" the Moss Hart-Cole Porter musical, and the future.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 23. -- Employing all modern war strategy, the 107th Infantry of the New York National Guard fought a theoretical battle all day today at Foxden, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Fox, on the Bronx River Parkway Extension eight miles east of here. At nightfall the regiment had attained its objective, which was occupation of a wooded hill near he east boundary of the estate.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 23. -- Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn won a terrific five-set battle from Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Kay Lund after they had saved two match points in the fourth set and three in the fifth, and the United States now leads Germany, 2 -- 1, in the interzone final of Davis Cup play.

Bequests totaling about $300,000 to philanthropic institutions and relatives were made in the will of Mrs. Roxana Atwater Wentworth Bowen, a descendant of early Colonial families. The estate approximates $1,000,000. The will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey beard argument yesterday and reserved decision on a motion made by the Securities and Exchange Commission for an order requiring J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, to appear and produce books and records before the commission in Washington in obedience to a subpoena.
BLUE RAPIDS, Kan., July 23. -- Man hunters of four States joined tonight in a search for three reported killers, one believed by some pursuers to be Alvin Karpis.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP). -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals has vacated the mandamus granted by the New Jersey District Court ordering Asbury Park to make provisions in its 1935 budget for part payment of defaulted bonds.

The 23-year-old robbery indictment that had been pending against Edward Hughes, Brooklyn pressman, since he escaped from a Coney Island court was dismissed yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn.

A review of the evidence under which Raymond J. Healey, self-styled the "American Hitler," was convicted of disorderly conduct, revealed yesterday that Healey had been planning a campaign of violence against Jews in this country. The review was published in The New York Law Journal in a decision by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky, who sentenced Healey to sixty days in the workhouse on June 12.

In view of the fact that THE NEW YORK TIMES has within the past year devoted so much space, both in its news columns and in its editorials, to the annual reports of the various city departments upon their appearance, your editorial of July 13, entitled "Telling Fusion's Story," which laments the paucity and later publication of these reports, is all the more surprising.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 23. -- This capital awoke today to a salvo of twenty-one shots from cannon on the hill of the Great Gibbi, the irregular reports of which announced in Ethiopian style the forty-fourth birthday of Emperor Haile Sellassie.

MARION, Mass., July 23. -- Driving through one of Buzzards Bay's famed smokey sou'westers, Erik Nilsson brought Lill-Singva home with a 7 minute and 42 second lead over Paul Dean's Fleetwing to win the second race for the President Franklin D. Roosevelt Trophy over a sixteen-and-one-quarter-mile triangular course today.

Grand jury testimony of Noel Scaffa was read at his trial yesterday in which he swore that on March 14 -- a week after the prosecution contends he recovered the $185,000 Bell jewelry -- he was in Miami making frantic efforts to trace the stolen gems.

Indictments charging murder in the first degree were returned yesterday by the Queens County Grand Jury against John Collins, alias Joseph Schwartz, 22 years old, of 415 First Avenue, and Fred Madjan, alias Magdan, 25, of 63-37 Eighty-fourth Street, West Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The first move to prevent bulk liquor sales to hotels and clubs under the proposed new Federal Alcohol Administration Act was rejected overwhelmingly in the House today, after members who sought to avoid injury to the cooperage industry warned that to do otherwise would be playing into the hands of the "whisky and bottling trust."

NEWARK, N.J., July 23. -After hearing a delegation of Newark city officials present arguments in favor of a reduction in the amount assessed against the city as its share of 1935 relief costs here, the State Relief Council deferred action today on its announced plan to stop paying rents for Newark families on relief.

HAVANA, July 23. -- Asserting that general elections on Dec. 15, as proposed by the government, would provide no solution for the national problems, the National Renovation party, headed by Dr. Carlos Saladrigas, former Secretary of Justice, today issued a manifesto charging that all revolutionary factions were being excluded from participation in the elections.

OTTAWA, July 23. -- The sweeping defeat today in Prince Edward Island of the Conservative government headed by Premier W.J.P. MacMillan left the Conservatives without control of a single Canadian Provincial Parliament.
William Gillette, who gave two generations of theatregoers their mental portrait of Sherlock Holmes, deserted his castle at Hadlyme, Conn., yesterday to pass his eightieth birthday here today.

Prices of commodity futures were irregular yesterday with trading moderate as a rule. On the cash markets corn and rye advanced, while wheat, flour, cotton and tin declined. Heavy sales of duty-free sugar at 3.20 cents a pound appeared to have cleared the market of offers at that level.
Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman, while visiting the Coney Island Court yesterday, heard Magistrate Thomas E. Casey assail persons who walked on the streets of Coney Island incompletely attired.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's Works Allotment Board approved a $200,000 survey of the flood areas in up-State New York and Pennsylvania today as the Federal Government moved in other ways to give relief to the sufferers and bring about flood control there.

Liquidation of the affairs of the Code Authority of the motion picture industry has been completed, according to a statement yesterday by John C. Flinn, its executive secretary. Members of the Code Authority voted to return its surplus funds, amounting to $23,873, to industry members who were in good standing on May 27, the date upon which operations of the code were terminated by the Supreme Court's NRA decision.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23. -- Apologizing because extreme poverty made it impossible for her to buy a stamp to mail a letter until her relief check arrived, Mrs. Daniel Fischer of 622 Hunterdon Street, this city, who has six children to support, returned today to Mrs. Hattie Randolph of Somerville $2,500 worth of bonds which Mrs. Fischer's 14-year-old son, Daniel Jr., picked up in Hillside last Friday.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP). -- The California-owned Ebony Lady today scored her second consecutive victory by capturing the Weymouth Purse, the one mile and 70-yard feature of the twelfth day of the Suffolk Downs meet. She romped home five lengths ahead of the Greentree Stable's Up and Up in the record-breaking time of 1:42 3-5 for the route.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Passage of the Tydings-McCormick bill to suppress attempts to incite members of the army and navy to disobedience, which was favored by the majority of the House Military Affairs Committee in a report made public today, would be using "a twelve-inch gun to kill a gnat," according to the minority report signed by Representatives Maverick of Texas and Kvale of Minnesota, opposing passage of the measure.

Three youths who took the advice of Horace Greeley, but made the mistake of starting West with three bicycles and $130 that did not belong to them, ended up in the Children's Society shelter last night charged with juvenile delinquency. They will be arraigned today in Children's Court.
Value of Dolla in Exeh-go. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follow, QuotaUon$ are in cents:

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Efforts of longs in July and September wheat in Minneapolis to take profits today disclosed a lack of support and both futures at the extreme lows were 5 cents a bushel under Monday's finish, the maximum decline permitted for one day under Exchange regulations.

BUENOS AIRES, July 23. -- It was learned today from a high official source that the government is much surprised by the wide outbreak of vigorous opposition and protest which has arisen against the recent decree establishing government control over foreign news agencies and newspaper correspondents.

PEORIA, Ill., July 23. -- The cause of the explosion and fire at the Hiram Walker distillery here last night, which is believed to have caused the death of one man who is still missing, injuries to sixty persons and the destruction of 6,000,000 gallons of whisky, was only partly explained today. The loss was put at $2,500,000.

HISTORICAL surveys of the accomplishments of female murderers -- one was recently published, "She Stands Accused" (Lippincott, $2.50), by Victor MacClure -- are bound to be marked by a certain monotony. They weren't very good at it in the old days. A majority of the more infamous murderesses, with a sense of their own limitations, which is only to be regretted, specialized in poisons.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse entertained members of her farm booth committee for next Friday's village fair at a tea today at her residence on Hunting Lane. This committee includes:

CHICAGO, July 23. -- How McCormick Co., and Kopald, Quinn Co., brokerage houses, sold 293,510 shares of common stock of Stutz Motor Car Company during January, February and March, 1934, when not more than 133,000 shares were oustanding at any one time, was told by investigators for the Securities and Exchange Commission here today.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Irritated by a remark attributed to Alfredo Salmaggi, New York musical promoter, that "just like spaghetti, grand opera comes from Italy, and belongs to Italians," Representative Hoeppel of California has introduced a bill "to protect the artistic and earning opportunities of American musicians, both vocal and instrumental, including orchestra conductors, in the United States of America."

The city of Bridgeport, Conn., will open bids next Wednesday for a new issue of $1,000,000 of current expense notes, dated Aug. 1, 1935, and maturing on June 1, 1936. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System reports for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $5,707,354 after taxes, depreciation, charges and minority interest. This was equal, after dividend requirements on 249,468 shares of $6 preferred stock, to $5.72 a share on 735,664 no-par common shares, compared with 6,940,819, or $7.40 a share on the common stock, in the preceding year.

A SIZZLING start for a steaming series. Johnny Allen, the clerk from behind a North Carolina hotel desk, against Schoolboy Rowe, the big buff from behind the firehouse at Eldorado, Ark. A sweltering day and a tremendous crowd. Threats of thunder alow and aloft.

Retail and wholesale failures increased during the week ended July 18, as compared with the previous week, and there was also a slight gain in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

With trading generally fair in volume, commodity futures moved over narrow ranges yesterday, with price changes about evenly divided between losses and gains. In the cash market, zinc and silk made new highs, while all the grains and cotton advanced.

TOKYO, July 24. -- War Minister Senjuro Hayashi told the newspapers today that on account of the necessity of defensive preparations against Russia, Japan's budget must be compiled on the principle of "armaments first" and that military expenditure would increase from now on.

The thirty-two-year-old Scandinavian liner United States, which operated between New York and Copenhagen until last November, has been sold to the Italian Government as a troop transport, it was announced yesterday. The price was not given.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the rackets investigation, announced yesterday the appointment of three $1-a-year men who will do various kinds of legal work for the experience and without official titles.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, July 24. -While agents of President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico conferred late today with Governor Rafael Villareal of the State of Tamaulipas in an effort to work out the present political revolution in that State, the old city of Matamoros, just across the Rio Grande River from Brownsville, was under martial law, with General Gabriel Cervera in charge.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- Asserting that they were convinced the President would make no promise for $1.29-an-ounce silver, some members of the "silver bloc" in the Senate prepared today to battle for wide-open trading in the white metal.

Foreclosure sales irlvolving eleven buildings were held by auctioneers in Manhattan yesterday. The improvements consisted of a business building, a dwelling and apartment houses. All were struck down to the plaintiffs in the proceedings.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 24. -- Athough business was resumed here today after forty-eight hours of a general strike, with martial law remaining in effect, two disturbing factors still threatened trouble in the strike-torn area.

Because of the hot weather the city's death rate rose slightly last week, according to Health Department statistics. Deaths totaled 1,361, which is at the rate of 9.3 for each 1,000 of population. Last year the rate was 8.9 and the average for the corresponding week since 1929 was 8.92.

The emergency staff of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey is to be discharged on July 31 for lack of funds. Authorities who are handling the PWA funds have given two reasons for their refusal, (1) the request for money was for a sum which would have given each man more than $1,128 a year, and (2) PWA allotments are for men taken from relief rolls.

Besides Jose Iturbi on Sunday and Jascha Heifetz on Aug. 5 and 6, as previously announced, soloists at the Stadium Concerts in the near future will include Ruggiero Ricci, boy violinist, and Harold Bauer, pianist, it was made known yesterday. Young Ricci will play on Aug. 11, this being his first New York appearance with orchestra since his debut here on Nov. 24, 1931.

Generally higher prices prevailed in the markets yesterday. The inclination of professional traders to claim profits was less insistent in the share market, which moved narrowly to an irregularly higher closing. The optimistic tone of the midweek reports on trade and industry may have occasioned the slowing down of profit-taking, but in any event the reports did contribute to the market's quiet strength.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 24. -- Reuben Fine and Isaac Kashdan of New York, in the first and second divisions, respectively, and Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., in the third, all had perfect scores after five rounds of the Western chess championship tournament today.

When CARDENAS was elected President of Mexico he was thought to be a man of mediocre ability, quite ready to be, as predecessors of his had been, a willing subordinate of the man behind the throne, CALLES. All the more surprising was it then, a few weeks ago, to see the President refusing to submit to the supposed all-powerful Dictator of Mexico.

Mayor La Guardia showed yesterday that he "could take it" by admitting that the criticism directed against him for his failure to fill three vacancies on the Municipal Art Commission had been justified.

Operations of the Packard Motor Car Company and subsidiaries in the quarter ended on June 30 resulted in a net profit of $1,500,622 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to 10 cents a share on 15,000,000 no-par capital shares.

HAVANA, July 24. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, head of the Republican party, who recently made a pact with the Liberal party to be the Presidential candidate of the two groups, this morning announced his withdrawal from this agreement.

BERLIN, July 24 (AP). -- Some church circles said ominously today that the next month almost certainly would bring further strict repressive measures, regardless of the German-Vatican concordat, or Chancellor Adolf Hitler's promises, to enable Nazi leaders to announce "complete liquidation" of the church question.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The second Deficiency Appropriation Bill, presumably the last of the regular supply measures to be offered at this session and carrying slightly more than $300,000,000 for government activities not cared for in prior legislation, was passed by the Senate today without a record vote.
LOS ANGELES, July 24. -- A tailless airplane, designed for the novice pilot with scant means, was displayed here today by Walde Waterman, who built the machine for the Department of Commerce.

There is a possibility, rather a remote one, to be sure, but a possibility nevertheless, that "As You Desire Me" may be revived for a series of special matinees. After all, the town is Pirandello conscious at the moment. The Italian author, attending "The Old Maid" on Tuesday, saw Judith Anderson, who appeared in "As You Desire Me" in 1931, and the matter came up in the course of the conversation.
Restoration of pay cuts in the 1936 city budget is a very slim possibility, Deputy Budget Director Leo J. McDermott said yesterday as hearings on the 1936 tentative budget opened.

Terms of the proposed merger of the Fox Film Corporation and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., upon which stockholders of the former will vote at a special meeting on Aug. 15, were disclosed yesterday when the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved the listing of preferred and common stocks of the combined concern.

The committee of arrangements of the New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday an unexpected call for transcripts of all records of member firms' expenditures for entertainment from March 21, 1933, to date. Officials of the Exchange said that the request was made as part of a general check-up and was not inspired by any outside authority.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24. -- More than 200 guests were present this evening at the dance given by the officers of Fort Adams. Lieut. Col. Samuel Turnbull and Lieutenant Thomas Hay were the committee in charge. Colonel Robert Arthur and Mrs. Arthur and Miss Jo Test, daughter of Lieut. Col. Frederick C. Test, commanding officer of the post, and Mrs. Test were on the receiving line.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 24. -- An investigation of the financial affairs of the town of Mount Pleasant, of which John D. Rockefeller Jr. is one of the largest taxpayers, was ordered today by Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr.

The police were called to Pier 18, at the foot of State Street, Brooklyn, and the sailing of the Norwegian freighter Marga was delayed from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. yesterday, when the crew of twenty men refused to work unless they were paid in American dollars instead of Norwegian currency.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Their nerves frayed by weeks of court and legislative troubles, Farm Administration officials were shocked today when they saw a classified advertisement published Sunday in the Joplin (Mo.) Globe.

ONE of the minor mysteries of life for this observer, who knows little about horses and not too much about mathematics, was how those gentlemen on the high chairs at Empire City and other race tracks arrive at those fancy figures they display on little slates. Purely as a mathematical problem, it held a lively lure.

The economic situation in Italy has been in many respects like that in Germany. Both countries have been enjoying an internal "boom" of a sort. In April the Italian index of general production was 106.8 per cent of the 1928 figure. This was partly owing to the activity in war industries, but not wholly so.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Thursday, July 25. -- Elsie Janis, radio entertainer and retired musical comedy star, was injured seriously, and Gilbert Wilson, her husband, also was hurt when their automobile crashed into a stalled truck parked without lights on the Saw Mill River Road near the estate of the late James Butler here at 9 o'clock last night.

PLATTSBURG BARRACKS, N.Y., July 24. -- A program for welcoming and entertaining graduates of the first Plattsburg Officers Training Camp in 1915, who will hold a reunion here next Monday, has been arranged tentatively by a committee and submitted to Colonel William B. Wallace, commanding the Twenty-sixth Infantry, for approval.

In the last year and a half or so every Conservative Provincial Government in Canada has been kicked out. Tuesday's election in Prince Edward Island was the last chapter of Tory local disaster. There was a straight contest between Conservatives and Liberals.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler have purchased a new issue of 1,000,000 tax-anticipation notes, dated July 15, 1935, and due Jan. 15, 1936, of Monroe County, N.Y., carrying an interest rate of 0.85 per cent. The notes are being reoffered to yield 0.625 per cent.

LONDON, July 24. -- "I have already expressed to the United States Ambassador the satisfaction of this government with the recent utterance of the American Secretary of State concerning the duties devolving on all signatories of the Kellogg pact," Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare told the House of Commons today.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the applications of five corporations for formal listing of their securities, most of which formerly had been admitted to unlisted trading.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Installation of a coaxial cable between New York and Philadelphia by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for experimental television and multiple telephone and telegraph service was authorized by the Federal Communications Commission today.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Representative Patton of Texas was indignant today when he heard his name had been brought into the Senate's utility lobby investigation and learned the circumstances.

Great Britain may hold the Davis Cup, emblematic of tennis supremacy, but cricket is a far more appealing sport than the net game in the eyes of England's youth. That was one of the chief impressions gained by members of the Lawrenceville School tennis squad of Lawrenceville, N.J., who returned yesterday aboard the French liner Champlain.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- In answer to a question today the President told his newspaper auditors he thought it would be "desirable" to have some neutrality law revision passed at this session, but not at the expense of prolonging the stay of Congress. If his leaders should assure the President that such would not be the case, then presumably committees would report certain neutrality bills with Mr. Roosevelt's imprimatur.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- Delegates to the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers today elected a new executive board of seventeen members, which will open negotiations tomorrow with hosiery manufacturers for a new working agreement to succeed the present one expiring on Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Proposals for a central government bank were denounced by Senator Glass as debate on the Omnibus Banking Bill finally began today in the Senate.

Alvin (Shipwreck) Kelly, flagpole sitter, hastened to New York by motor cycle early yesterday morning from Greenwich, Conn., to appear in Jefferson Market Court where his wife, Mrs. Carrie Bosh of 964 Amsterdam Avenue, was arraigned on a petit larceny charge.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, July 24 (AP). -- Unconfirmed reports received here today said General Juan Vicente Gomez, who for the last quarter century has held Venezuela in perhaps the tightest grip of any twentieth century dictator, was at the point of death.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24. -- Two Archbishops, twenty-two Bishops, including one from Brazil, sixty-one monsignors and several hundred priests will attend the consecration of the Most Rev. Thomas H. McLaughlin, Vicar-General of the Newark diocese, as titular Bishop of Nisa and Auxiliary Bishop of Newark, tomorrow morning in the unfinished Sacred Heart Cathedral here.

It is hardly the function of a Mayor to interpret an international treaty and then to act upon his own view of it. The State Department, or the President, would naturally have something to say about that. But there can scarcely be doubt that Mayor LA GUARDIA has hit upon a point worthy of attention in our treaty of amity and commerce with Germany.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., July 24. -- The former anti-Pearson factions here and in St. Croix are protesting the appointment of Lawrence W. Cramer to the Governorship of the Islands. They held a mass meeting tonight after Acting Governor Robert Herrick had denied them a permit for a parade this afternoon.

The 702 foreclosures by the HOLC, reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES today, constitute a small number compared to the 883,000 home owners who have obtained such loans from the Home Owners Loan Corporation. A question should be raised, however, in view of the outcome of other New Deal legislation, whether this is not merely a preliminary leak in the HOLC dike which will presently turn into a foreclosure flood.

In spite of the invalidation of the Steel Code, steel prices are said to be holding steady. With the increase in the demand for steel products many persons in the industry see little possibility of price shading in the near future. Following the abolition of the code some consumers were said to be holding off purchases on the theory that price concessions might be obtained.

ALBANY, July 24 (AP). -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, dismissed an appeal today of John F. McCarthy, Brooklyn school music teacher, from a ruling of the New York City Board of Examiners denying him a promotion license because he smoked in the school building after warnings by the principal.

Wallace G. Garland, former Yale honor student who studied higher economics under Professor Irving Fisher and induced the latter to invest some of his savings in a financial enterprise, surrendered to Federal authorities yesterday and was freed in bail of $5,000 on a charge of mail fraud.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 24. -- Although general opinion here is that Premier Colijn after his statement last night in the lower house has no other course but to offer his Cabinet's resignation to Queen Wilhelmina, the actual announcement of such resignation has not yet been made.

An inspection tour of Brooklyn parks and playgrounds, including the new Prospect Park Zoo, was conducted yesterday by the Park Association of New York City in cooperation with the Park Department and Brooklyn civic associations.
LHASA, Tibet, July 24. -- The search for Tibet's new Dalai Lama -- the unknown baby reposing in some humble manger or costly crib in this land of ancient mystery -- had officially begun today.

Establishing a new high record for any six-month period in the history of the company, the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation shows a consolidated net profit available for dividends of $7,256,517 for the first half of 1935, according to the financial statement to be given out today.

Active eleventh-hour covering of July obligations, strong stock and grain markets and a statement by Senator Bankhead that the loan on the 1935 crop cannot be less than 12 cents a pound, while it is hoped it may be 13 cents, caused a recovery of $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

The heat wave that has been playing havoc with life and property went into its twentieth day yesterday. The stifling weather caused two deaths and several prostrations and led to three drownings. The police feared a fourth drowning had occurred with the reported disappearance of a boy while wading in Jamaica Bay.

The Bostonian colt, Boston Brook, which was such a keen racer in Maryland last Spring, proved the most capable performer in yesterday's Stanwich Handicap at Empire City, and brought about a mild upset when he defeated Legionary.

Excessive humidity, Summer heat and the excitement of reviewing the inner workings of city institutions, all added to a steady round of activities since his arrivel in New York, forced Dr. Luigi Pirandello, Italian dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize, to abandon his tour of the city by noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- President Roosevelt expressed opposition to allowing corporations to obtain tax exemption for donations to charities. He expressed hope that some form of neutrality legislation would be passed at this Congressional session, and conferred with Senator Tydings and others on Virgin Islands problems.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, Polar explorer, arrived from Europe yesterday on the Champlain of the French Line en route to South America to join an expedition of the National Geographic Society to the Antarctic. After his return next March, Sir Hubert said, he will begin preparations for his second undersea exploration of the North Polar seas.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Senator Caraway and the "ladles of the House,." wives of Cabinet officers still in the city, and others from official and diplomatic circles were "honor guests" tonight at the fourth "sunset symphony" concert given at th Potomac River Watergate, near the Lincoln Membrial.

Despite the heat, which made traveling from showroom to showroom uncomfortable, out-of-town buyers continued to place a steady volume of business in the apparel markets this week. Individual orders were not outstandingly large, manufacturers reported, but the total was sizeable.

VIENNA, July 24. -- A two-day mourning demonstration in memory of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, organized by the government, began tonight with the burning of candles in the windows of homes from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M.

Alcohol still faces a vigorous foe in Mrs. Ella A. Boole, head of the World's Women's Christian Temperance Union, who will celebrate her seventy-sixth birthday tomorrow. As one of the field marshals in the prohibition fight, Mrs. Boole indicated yesterday that her birthday anniversary would find her no less busy than she is on other days of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Broader authority for the Secretary of Agriculture to make multiple seizures of foods, drugs and cosmetics without court order than is contained in the pending Copeland bill was proposed by Dr. Walter G. Campbell, chief of the Federal Food and Drug Administration, before a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee considering the measure.

Gunners and anglers will undoubtedly be interested in the sports program which New York State is sponsoring in conjunction with the celebration marking the fiftieth anniversary of the State's conservation activities.
PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP). -- The Pirates ran their string of victories to seven today by sweeping a double-header from the Phillies, 8 to 6 and 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Investigation of Nazi persecution of Jews and Catholics to ascertain if the United States is warranted in severing diplomatic relations with Germany was urged today by Senator William H. King of Utah.

Abe Feldman, East Side light heavyweight, earned a ten-round decision over John Henry Lewis of Phoenix, Ariz., before 3,000 spectators at the Coney Island Velodrome last night. Feldman weighed 180 1/2, Lewis 178. The loser was recognized on Tuesday as the leading contender for Bob Olin's crown.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing in its investigation of dealings in stock of the Stutz Motor Corporation was thrown into an uproar today when officials of McCormick Co., one of the firms under fire, refused to testify.

PARIS, July 24. -- Negotiations for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute continued at an impasse here today. A definite decision regarding the summoning of the League of Nations Council is expected tomorrow.

MEXICO, D.F., July 24. -Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico, told the Lions' convention here today that President Roosevelt had changed Pan-American sentiment from one of doubt and suspicion into one of perfect faith in the disinterested friendship of the United States.
The Bristol-Meyers Company declared an extra dividend of 10 cents a share on common stock.

American Negroes were urged to band together to arouse liberal opinion in this country and in leading European nations, particularly Britain and France, to prevent "Fascist, imperialist Italy" from causing another war, in an address last night by Dr. Willis N. Huggins.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H., July 24. -- Visitors in the White Mountains are planning a benefit tea and a recital by Mrs. Orton Bishop Brown of Berlin, who is chairman of the New Hampshire Children's Aid and Protective Society, for the Coos County branch of that charity.

CRUGERS, N.Y., July 24. -- A naked man, identifed later as a former inmate of two insane asylums, was shot fatally at 2:55 o'clock this morning by Burnett A. Ward while battering in the door of the Ward home on the Albany Post Road here with an ax and threatening to murder every one within.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 24. -- Members of the Summer colony filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players, under the direction of Felix Jacoves, opened their second production for this season with the presentation of "Sweet Salt," a Hungarian comedy by Ladislaus Aladar, adapted into English by Barre Dunbar.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- A compromise bill to extend air-mail contracts at existing rates, but allow the Interstate Commerce Commission to order higher rates where contractors could establish that rates were inadequate, was recommended to the Senate and House today by a conference committee which has been working over the differing air-mail legislation adopted by the two bodies.

A trust fund of $500 to provide Christmas presents annually for children in Harlem Hospital was listed among the bequests in the will of Dr. Walter P. Silleck, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. The estate was valued at "more than $20,000."

Land values are booming throughout Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wyoming, according to Federal Land Bank statements at Omaha, reported by The Associated Press. Sales are as much as 50 per cent higher than last year in some quarters. The bank people take it as a sign of recovery.

The New York Stock Exchange approved the listing yesterday of two of the smallest share issues in more than a decade when it admitted 146,314 shares of no-par capital stock of the Ruberoid Company and 162,355 shares of no-par common stock of the W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company, both of which heretofore have been traded on the New York Curb Exchange.

NEW ORLEANS, July 24 (AP). -Five of Louisiana's eight members of the House of Representatives today assailed Senator Huey P. Long in a statement branding him a "self-confessed traitor" to his party and predicting his downfall at the polls next January.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The House showed again today that it was ready to go home. Democrats and Republicans alike clapped and cheered a proposal by Representative Treadway, Republican of Massachusetts, that "we prepare for adjournment."

O.P. Van Sweringen has virtually completed a new plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, largest unit in his $2,000,000,000 railroad empire, it developed yesterday. If made effective, the plan would remove 12,000 miles of line from the state of bankruptcy into which they lapsed about two years ago.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 24. -- The Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, and Mrs. Paddock gave a large garden party at Buxton Hill, Williamstown, this afternoon in honor of Mrs. Robert E. Speer, who is spending the Summer at Lakeville, Conn., and Miss Ruth F. Woodsmall.
ALBANY, July 24. -- The officers of the joint legislative committees recently appointed to investigate several subjects were announced today by Senator Dunnigan, President pro tem of the Senate.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 24. -- Mrs. Van Deventer Crisp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club of Glen Head won the low gross honors in the regular one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association on the Sands Point course today.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Postmaster General Farley left Chicago at noon today with Mrs. Farley on his way to Hawaii for a vacation. Mr. Farley will make a political speech at San Francisco before departing for Hawaii and another at Los Angeles on his return, but he plans no further political activities on this trip.
Bill Meadows, a gray polo pony that has starred in many games on the army field at Governors Island, will be the guest of honor Sunday at a party in celebration of his twenty-third birthday.

Motorists taking week-end trips out of the city were advised yesterday by J.R. Crossley, vice-president of the Automobile Club of New York, to start their return journeys on Monday morning, rather than Sunday night. Such a practice, Mr. Crossley declared, would result in a definite drop in the number of week-end automobile accidents resulting from congested traffic on important through highways.

STOCKHOLM, July 24 (AP). -- A touring United States track and field team got away to a flying start in an international meet with the stars of ten other nations today, winning three events and placing second and third in two others.

Two of the 2,000 school children who came to City Hall yesterday to give a choral concert for Mayor La Guardia found the heat and the excitement too much for them, but they had the pleasure of riding to their homes in the Mayor's car after being treated for heat prostration.
MARION, Mass., July 24. -- The President Franklin D. Roosevelt Trophy for the thirty-square meter international yachting championship goes to Sweden for one year.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 24. -Jack Patroni, professional at Wykagyl, teamed with Archer U. Rodney of Quaker Ridge to win the best-ball pro-amateur event of the Westchester County Golf Association over the Quaker Ridge course today.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 24. -- Wilmer Allison carried the United States into the challenge round of Davis Cup competition against Great Britain by defeating Heiner Henkel, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, 11 -- 9, today and thus eliminating Germany.

Jesse Isidor Straus, United States Ambassador to France, is arriving today from Paris, on the Washington of the United States Lines, accompanied by Mrs. Straus and his sister, Mrs. Albert Hess. Others coming on the ship from the Channel ports and Hamburg include Miss Mildred Booth McKinney, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, tennis champion; Joe Kirkwood, golfer, and Paul W. Litchfield.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP). -- Chance Line, a cast-off from the Joseph E. Widener stable, and now owned by Mrs. Robert Pollard of Dallas, Texas, annexed the featured mile handicap race at Arlington Park today by a length over a good track.

Emboldened by Magistrate Kross's dismissal of disorderly conduct charges against fifty-two pickets arrested before The American Mercury's offices at 730 Fifth Avenue last Thursday, twenty-nine young women student pickets just after 6 P.M. last evening marched into the West Forty-seventh Street police station carrying banners and shouting.

In THE TIMES this morning opponents of the Clark amendment to the Social Security Bill, which permits the operation of private annuity plans, are reported as contending that if the funds of the private pension plans were invested in long-term securities and a depression occurred, "the impact of liquidation on the securities market would be so overwhelming as to create an almost unprecedented situation."

SUSQUEHANNA, Pa., July 24 (Nearly 90 in the shade). -- A large jumping worm, with a head at each end and the appearance of a small snake and a large caterpillar combined, crawled into the consciousness of this borough today and created a zoological mystery which few residents seem anxious to solve.

NORFOLK, Va., July 24. -- Aubrey and George Neidecker, Paris bankers, who were taken into custody early this morning as they debarked from the Baltimore Mail liner City of Newport News, were placed in the custody of New York authorities and are en route tonight for New York in the custody of Detective A.M.

With indications of further gains, production of steel ingots this week registered the third consecutive advance since the week of July 4, rising three points above last week's rate to 43 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age. All ground lost since the middle of May was thus recovered.

MALONE, N.Y., July 24. -- Perspiring farmer jurors mopped their faces in Franklin County Court House here today as the government, over defense objections, tried to get into the record at least a sketchy version of the background of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

The general strike which began in Terre Haute, Ind., on Monday morning collapsed in less time than the similar strike in San Francisco a year ago. It was prompted by a dispute between an enameling company and its employes over the question of union recognition.

The joint legislative committee investigating public utilities in this State is cooperating with investigators for Federal agencies who are checking up on the alleged lobbying of public utility companies against major features of the New Deal at Washington, it was indicated yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., July 24. -- James Crowley, Fordham football coach, came to this city today to answer charges of violation of the motor vehicle laws and remained to receive an official greeting and to play golf with the judge, Mayor John V. Hinchliffe and other admirers.

SHANGHAI, July 24. -- "The Japanese Army will not take drastic steps in China unless compelled to do so by the Chinese attitude, and conditions must become worse than at present before the army acts," stated Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, military attache of the Japanese Embassy today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- Asserting that the AAA amendments "went through the Senate in remarkably fine shape," Chester C. Davis, AAA Administrator, said today that government officials would meet soon to determine a course of action regarding the more than 350 processing tax suits now pending.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The bill for the regulation of interstate bus and truck operations under the Interstate Commerce Commission was favorably reported to the House today with a recommendation that it be speedily adopted. It is high on the list of "must" legislation.
Hostilities between the Yankees and Tigers were interrupted by a heavy downpour of rain at the Stadium yesterday, but unfortunately for the Yanks it did not pour long enough.

In their first legal skirmish in the fight to depose John E. Sheehy as Democratic leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District the forces of former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, contending for the leadership, sought yesterday to bar four voters from the lists of the district.

Fatal gun play in the Senate Chamber at Buenos Aires testifies to growing tension in Argentinian politics. The actual shooting was done by a spectator in the gallery, but it is charged that he was present in the capacity of bodyguard to one of the members of the Senate.

Forty-one students of the New York University School of Law have received prizes and honors for scholastic excellence during the last academic year, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Frank H. Sommer.
Henry C. Raven, who found the jungles of tropical Burma "cool," returned to his office at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday and doffed his coat in deference to the heat.

The first hearing on the constitutionality of the newly amended Public Enemy Law was heard yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn. The court reserved decision on the appeals of five defendants who were convicted on June 1 for violating the act, which also is known as the Brownell Law.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- "Cactus Jack" Garner's idea of a good fishing trip is to paddle his canoe and grin as he criticizes the way other anglers cast and handle their fish.

Supreme Court Justice Levy denied yesterday an application by the Bernstein Manufacturing Company in behalf of itself and other members of the cloak and suit industry to dissolve the Code Authority, headed by George W. Alger, and a plea for the appointment of a receiver for the Authority's property.

While spokesmen for local German-American organizations seethed with indignation yesterday at Mayor La Guardia's refusal of a city license to a German massage operator, the Mayor firmly stood his ground.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria arrived late yesterday from Southampton via Cherbourg with two stowaways who were put ashore at Cherbourg from the Aquitania, where they were detained until the Berengaria arrived there westbound.

The government's $50,000,000 National Youth Administration program was criticized yesterday as leading toward Federal control of the schools and as "setting the groundwork for a Fascist pattern of education in America" by Professor George D. Strayer of Teachers College, Columbia University.

When Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sheriff of 31-23 Eighty-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, went on vacation several weeks ago, they told their maid, Elizabeth Hanna of Corona, that she might have a vacation, too, but they suggested she drop in to "look around" once in a while.

LONDON, July 24. -- The Netherlands situation is being watched with keen interest in London, not only because of probable mixed effects upon British trade which the devaluation of the guilder would exert but principally because the depreciation of Netherlands currency to the approximate level of sterling would be generally welcomed here as a step toward what may be called a British solution of the world currency problem.
