ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 24. -- A note from the Italian Government was presented to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs here this morning regarding the dispute in the conciliation commission.

Four youths, under sentence to die in the electric chair for the murder of a patrolman last Jan. 18 in a Fifth Avenue luggage shop hold-up, were brought from the Sing Sing death house under heavy guard yesterday to testify before the New York County grand jury against an elderly man they accused of being their criminal mentor in hold-ups.
Delay in getting the new Federal WPA program under way has handicapped recreational work greatly in New York City this Summer, officials disclosed yesterday.

The volume of bankers' acceptances declined $31,469,314 in June, said the report of the American Acceptance Council for June 29, made public yesterday by Robert H. Bean, executive secretary. The total amounted to $343,285,933, a reduction of $190,907,315 from the total outstanding at the end of June, 1934.

PARIS, July 24. -- The mysterious disappearance of the contents of 310 cases containing armaments and the substitution therefor of sand and rocks is giving the Surete Nationale, secret State police, and customs authorities one of the most puzzling problems of that sort they have ever had to face.

The banking and brokerage assets of Bertrand Coles Neidecker in this city were tied up yesterday by the Attorney General of New York State on a judicial request cabled by a French magistrate from Paris.

Salvatore Spitale, one time ineffectual intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, and Salvatore Arcidiaco applied yesterday to the Appellate Division of the Court of Special Sessions for a certificate of reasonable doubt in their conviction under the Brownell Public Enemy Law.

District qualifying rounds for the Metropolitan Golf Association's first annual handicap championship will be held at three courses on Sept. 24, it as announced yesterday. The sixty-four competitors who qualify in the sectional tourneys will be eligible for match play at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, Oct. 2, 3 and 4.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 24. -- The United States swept into the Davis Cup challenge round today by capturing the last two singles matches from Germany, thereby winning the interzone final by four matches to one.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 24 (AP). -- Esther Magill, 17-year-old Whitinsville girl who has been called the "unconscious reason" for the murder of Mrs. Newell P. Sherman, 22, confessed by her husband, was questioned nearly four hours today by Alfred B. Cenedella, Assistant District Attorney, and State police.
Fifty years after writing the music of "There'll Be a Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight," Theodore A. Metz, the composer, who is 88 years old, has written a new song, "There's a Secret in My Heart."

Sailing dinghy racing will have a boom this week-end on Long Island Sound when the elimination trials are held to select an American team of two boats to meet the English pair in the international match in September.
BERLIN, July 24. -- The Boerse was quiet but generally firmer today, although profit-taking set in near the close. Because of the uncertain situation in Holland, caution was advised.

ROME, July 24. -- According to authoritative circles here, no official confirmation has yet been received of reports that the League of Nations Council will meet during the first week in August, and these reports are still referred to as "newspaper guesses."

TRENTON, July 24. -- Mrs. Harriet Chesebrough of Asbury Park applied to Chancery Court here today for an accounting of the $75,000,000 estate of her husband, Robert M. Chesebrough, petroleum jelly manufacturer, who died in 1910.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The anti-Semitic convulsion in Berlin, strictly following precedent as convulsions are apt to do in Germany, has now reached its second stage. That comprises abuse of foreign correspondents who have been telling the outside world what is going on.

At a recent meeting of the stockholders of the Bobbs Merrill Company, J.W. Fesler, Indianapolis attorney, was elected to the board of directors. For many years he was an intimate friend of the late W.C. Bobbs, long president of the company. At the annual meeting of the directors, Charles C. Kryter was elected chairman of the board, and D. Laurence Chambers was chosen president of the company.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- The special House investigating committee which visited the flooded sections of up-State New York and Pennsylvania last week asked the Federal Government today for $10,000,000 to rebuild highways and bridges.

PARIS, July 24. -- The foreign exchange market and the particular situation of the Dutch florin dominated the session of the Bourse today. The florin and other gold currencies were weak all day, while the dollar and the pound made sharp advances.

LONDON, July 24. -- The British Legion delegation, which with the blessing of the Prince of Wales spent ten days in Germany at the invitation of Reich ex-servicemen's organizations, returned to London today with the impression that in Germany there is a "genuine desire on all sides for a better understanding with the British."

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company yesterday bid in for $2,501,272 the greater part of the collateral securing loans to the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, a one-time Insull organization, in an auction in the Exchange Salesroom, 18 Vesey Street.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- President Roosevelt had one of the busiest days of his administration today, not excepting even those hectic periods that marked his first few months in the White House.
CHICAGO, July 24. -- Casey Stengel's crippled Dodgers suffered another double defeat today, to make it four straight games they have dropped to the confident Cubs in two days.

Domestic corporation bonds continued to rise irregularly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, carrying the combined average of domestic liens up .14 points, with the widest group advance scored by the industrial issues. The trading volume tapered off considerably, sales amounting to $8,692,000, compared with $11,197,900 on Tuesday.

TORONTO, July 24 (Canadian Press). -- Rosalind, bay filly owned by Gibson White of Lexington, Ky., and driven by Tom Berry, won the feature of the Grand Circuit meet at Thorncliffe Park today. In the stake for 2-year-old trotters, Rosalind took two straight heats.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- Producing rallies in the late innings, the Indians subdued Washington in both games of a doubleheader today, taking the first, 10 to 6, and the nightcap, 13 to 8.

The theme of pan-American amity and "inter-Americanism" that featured the day-long celebration here yesterday of the 152d anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator, was marred by a few discordant notes, one an incident that threw a meeting at the Roerich Museum last night into an uproar.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Consumer resistance to the high prices for fresh pork were effective today in checking the upturn in hogs which has been under way for over a week. Hogs generally sold 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower with some sales in the late trading regarded as showing losses of 25 cents.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 24. -- Disturbances today in several parts of the Camden area marked the second day's attempt of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation to resume operations at its plant here in spite of the continuance of its employes' strike, now in its eleventh week.
Large multi-family bildings in lro'oklyn changed hands yesterday in transactions in which investors and operators figured as principals.

SHANGHAI, July 24 (AP). -- A report today that 30,000 bodies of flood victims had been picked up in the Hankow area alone provided grim corroboration of reports of the heavy toll taken in Central China by the flood waters of the Hart and Yangtse Rivers, now receding.

ST. LOUIS, July 24. -- The Giants tonight are considering an appropriate testimonial for Pepper Martin. They owe him a debt of gratitude after the way he tossed them into a 4 to 2 triumph over the Cardinals today and increased their lead for the National League flag to a margin of one and one-half games.

Thomas Edward Crowley, a 34-year-old employe of an insurance adjuster, took the stand yesterday and identified himself as the "mysterious stranger" who on March 18 delivered the $185,000 Bell jewelry to Noel Scaffa, private detective, who is being tried in Federal court or perjury before a Federal grand jury.

KEESEVILLE, N.Y., July 24. -Amid the congratulations and well wishes of President Roosevelt, dignitaries of the Catholic Church and residents of the North Country, parishioners of the Immaculate Conception Church celebrated here today the centenary of the church, the 110th anniversary of the first mass celebrated here, and the silver anniversary of the ordination of the pastor, the Rev. John Joseph Bent.

CLEVELAND, July 24. -- On the eve of the B. F. Goodrich Company stockholders' meeting in New York the Akron Rubber ompany was reported to have purchased the large holdings of John R. Weed of Beverly Hills, Calif., one of the chief objections to the $45,000,000 refinancing program.

RKO Radio's screen transcription of H. Rider Haggard's novel "She," in which Helen Gahagan makes her film debut, will be presented this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Also in the cast are Randolph Scott, Helen Mack and Nigel Bruce.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- While Senate and House holding company conferees were engaged in a bitter wrangle over the insistence of two committee members that Administration power experts sit in on their secret meetings, the Senate Lobby Committee today continued its investigation of utilities propaganda with mysterious references to "a box wrapped in newspaper," said to have been delivered to a member of the House the day before the "death sentence" vote.

With the continued decline in the price of the Dutch guilder presaging a possible new crisis in the European gold bloc, financial circles centred their attention on the foreign exchange market yesterday. Wall Street was inclined to await developments before formulating definite plans, and, despite the serious consequences possible in foreign exchange, saw no attendant repercussions in other financial fields at this time.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The statement that Joseph Silverman Jr. supplied money to Frank Speicher, who could not be found when wanted as a grand jury witness at an inquiry last year into sales of army goods, was made today by Harold Schnuer, a New York lawyer, before the House Military Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Legislation affirming the neutrality status of the United States in the event of conflict between other nations was added to the Congressional program by President Roosevelt today, the only qualification being that he would not urge its enactment at this session of Congress if prospective debate on the issue should threaten to prolong the session unduly.

BERLIN, July 24. -- Ambassador William E. Dodd of the United States tonight addressed a delegation from the Steuben Society of New York and its host, the Carl Schurz Society of Berlin, at a dinner in the Kroll Opera House.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Overriding five attempts to limit further or prohibit bulk liquor sales under the new Alcohol Administration Act, the House today passed the control measure by a vote of 229 to 300 and sent it to the Senate.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 24. -The danger that lies in lurk for favorites on the turf of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today struck down the two players who defeated Miss Helen Jacobs in the finals here in 1933 and 1934, both o them members of the 1935 Wightman Cup squad.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Definite notice that the Senatorial investigation into the Virgin Islands was not concluded by the shake-up of administrative officials yesterday by President Roosevelt was given at the White House today by Senator Tydings, chairman of the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs.

An amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange providing for the creation of a new standing committee on management and personnel, to have jurisdiction over all employes of the Exchange, was ratified yesterday by the board of governors and, unless disapproved by members, will become effective on Aug. 7.

WARSAW, July 24. -- The press today appeals to the government to use all its authority to break Danzig's resistance against the Finance Minister's order forbidding Danzig customs officials to handle goods imported into Poland proper.

Several luncheons were given yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis. With Mrs. Howard Bayne were Mrs. Gurdon W. Wattles, Mrs. R. Draper Richards and Mrs. Francis T. Boyd. The guests of Mrs. Frederick K. Barbour included Mrs. Reginald Rowland, Mrs. Carlyle A. Bethel, Mrs. John Morgan Lee and Mrs. John Carrere.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Proposals that limited tax exemption be allowed on profits of corporations which contributed to charitable organizations were rejected by President Roosevelt today.

NORFOLK, Va., July 24 (AP). -The American Federation of Labor won its fight against the Virginian Railway when Judge Luther B. Way in Federal District Court today ruled that the railway should recognize an A.F. of L. union, rather than a Company union, as the representatives of the "back shop" employes.

Nelson Doubleday said on his return from Europe yesterday that the publishing firm of Doubleday, Doran probably would be able to bring out T.E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" in October. Mr. Doubleday returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from England, where he made arrangements with the late Colonel Lawrence's estate for the first popular publication of the work that covers his entire career as "Lawrence of Arabia."

NEWARK, N.J., July 25. -- At the impressive and centuries-old consecration ceremonies of the Roman Catholic Church Mgr. Thomas Henry McLaughlin, vicar general of the Diocese of Newark and a native of New York City, was elevated to the Episcopacy here today at the unfinished Cathedral of the Sacred Heart.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Federal Judge William H. Holly appointed today Irwin T. Gilruth, an attorney, and former Judge Charles A. McDonald as temporary trustees for the Public Utility Securities Corporation, key holding concern of the Harley L. Clarke utility system which is undergoing reorganization under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Mayor La Guardia's refusal of a trade license for a German citizen in New York on the ground of German discrimination against United States citizens has aroused considerable attention in Germany because it is feared that it may set a precedent that may have serious effects on German interests abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (.P).-Agents of the Department of Justice have saved the government $2,248,000 in the past six months by revealing "frauds" by mere who swore they suffered permanent injury from the World War in an attempt to collect from th government.

On formal complaint of the French Consul General, warrants were issued yesterday by United States Commissioner Garret W. Cotter for the arrest of Bertrand Coles Neidecker, 37 years old, who was taken into custody by the New York police on Tuesday, and for his two brothers, Aubrey, 35, and George, 40, who were taken into custody Wednesday by the police of Norfolk, Va.

Aug. 1 is the closing date for the book review contest sponsored by the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. A prize of $10 will be given by Mrs. Edward Fales Coward for the best review written by a merchant seaman of Hendrik W. Van Loon's book "Ships and How They Sailed the Seven Seas."

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission heard arguments today in a new fight between Northern and Southern soft-coal producers to obtain advantage in the New England coal market.

AKRON, Ohio, July 25. -- A controversy among three schools of airship construction developed today as airship experts from all parts of the country opened the lighter-than-air craft forum at the Daniel Guggenheim Airship Institute here.

Gains outnumbered declines on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Activity continued moderate. On the cash markets, oats, flour, cocoa, silk and rubber were stronger, while corn, rye, tin and cotton declined.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Joseph Mendelson, who, with Leon Sutterman, is charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with directing three market manipulations of Stutz Motor Car Company stock with resultant losses of more than $1,000,000 to investors, testified today in the hearings conducted in SEC offices here.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 25. -- The veterans Wilmer Allison and Johnny Van Ryn and "Freshman" Don Budge, the same scrapping trio that stampeded Germany in the interzone final, will carry America's colors against Great Britain in the sixth attempt of the United States to regain the coveted Davis Cup, prized amateur tennis trophy.

With the completion and dedication of the new group of buildings on the Saratoga State Reservation, this historic health resort becomes one of the great spas of the world and the first in America. This has been made possible, first of all, by bringing all the important spring properties under State authority, as well as the underground rights necessary to safeguard them.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 25. -- On the third anniversary of the organization of the Republican Militia, the principal cities of Chile witnessed yesterday public demonstrations and parades.
Referring to the recent discussion, concerning the ambiguity of classifying species of sharks, the following letter has been received from W.F. Baxter, secretary of the Beach Haven Tuna Club.

While being questioned early this morning in connection with the fatal stabbing of a white woman in St. Nicholas Park, a Negro, who said he was Oscar Wilson, 34 years old, with no home, was identified, according to the police, as the man who stabbed and killed Miss Leonora Rivera, 22, of 157 St. Nicholas Avenue, in Morningside Park at 120th Street July 15.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- Charles E. Small of York, Pa., wrote to his member of Congress today that he was not as dead as Senate lobby committee testimony would indicate.

MOSCOW, July 25 (AP). -- The seventh Communist International Congress, convening tonight in the presence of the Communist leader, Joseph Stalin, directed its opening fire against fascism, almost to the exclusion of its traditional demand for world revolution.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- Army engineers toured swiftly today toward making a flood prevention survey of up-State New York and Northern Pennsylvania, hard hit by recent storms, as President Roosevelt allotted $200,000 from the work relief fund to pay the cost.

Christian Klosset, 38 years old, of 639 Hart Street, Brooklyn, whose former residence was the scene of a "personal raid" by Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine more than a year ago, was arraigned again yesterday on a bookmaking charge in Gates Avenue court, Brooklyn.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., July 25.-Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.. third son of the President and Irs. Roosevelt, has become an employe of the National Grain Yeast Corporation here, of which his eldest brother, James, is president, it was learned today.

Domestic corporation bonds maintained a firm undertone on the Stock Exchange yesterday but the recent general advance appeared to be checked, at least temporarily, as prices fluctuated within a narrow range. Sales expanded to $10,197,700, compared with $8,692,000 on Wednesday.

PARIS, July 25. -- The recent renewal of anti-Semitic outbreaks in Berlin has revived uneasiness in national Olympic committees in regard to the status of Jewish athletes at the Olympic games in Berlin next year.
Deals in the Bronx indicated a continued demand for apartment houses yesterday when several multi-family buildings were purchased by operators.

Continuing to show large returns even through midsummer, bank clearings for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday increased 24.2 per cent from the same week a year ago. Last week the gain was 13.6 per cent.

VIENNA, July 25. -- Monarchist restoration propaganda in Austria received shard setbacks today in several quarters. Behind the setbacks are the unspoken hostility of Prince Ernst yon Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor, to Hapsburg restoration and the recent open intimations by the Little Entente States that they will resist it with every possible means.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 25. -- After seven rounds of the annual tournament for the Western championship being held under the auspices of the American Chess Federation, Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., recent winner of the Pacific Coast title and a member of the United States team picked to go to Poland, today is the only one of the thirty competing players who has won all of his seven games in the third division.

PITTSBURGH, July 25. -- Outwardly the coal crisis is just about the same as when a strike was thrice averted through extension of a truce at the last minute, but among miners the feeling is entirely different, and all signs point to a strike on midnight Wednesday.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Lacking pitching, batting power and inspiration, the Dodgers closed a disastrous Western campaign today by dropping their fifth straight to the Cubs, 4 to 2, giving Grimm's climbing team the series, five games to one.

TRENTON, July 25. -- Criticism of the manner in which funds of the State Board of Registration and Examination in Dentistry have been disbursed is contained in a report by State Auditor Walter R. Darby, made public today by Governor Hoffman.

In the obituary notice that appeared in THE TIMES a few days ago on G.W. Russell, I read with interest a quotation of Padraic Colum's appreciation of AE. There is also in J.B. Priestley's "Brief Diversions" (Cambridge, 1922) this very lovely epigram:
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Tentative provisions of the tax program being considered by the Ways and Means Committee, which approached a final draft today, include:

LONDON, July 25. -- David Lloyd George's "new deal" having gone temporarily into the discard, the public received the offer of another today at a cost of five shillings per copy, bearing the signatures of Sir Oliver Lodge, spiritualist; H.G. Wells, Professor Gilbert Murray, Sir Arthur Pugh, Laborite; the Archbishop of York and more than 100 other representatives of various schools of thought.

TO read "Feliciana" (Scribner, $2.50) is to spend a very quiet three hours with Mr. Stark Young. One will find the entertainment varied and genteel no end. The air Becomes heavy with the scent of red roses as one picks up the book, dried immortelles from overrun gardens lie about underfoot, the sun goes down into a rich dusk, but darkness is never complete, for there is always moonlight.

WITH a blue-grass background, E.C. (Easy) Smith has been picking winners the "Easy" way on the turf for more years than he cares to mention to complete strangers. Gray-haired, medium height, clean-shaven and thin-faced, he pulls the brim of his panama down to shade his eyes and picks six winners a day at Empire. He can't miss. He is one of the judges at the finish.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- James L. O'Neill, New York banker who was appointed Acting NRA Administrator on June 16 to succeed Donald R. Richberg, expects to resign by Aug. 1 to return to private business, he announced today. He has asked President Roosevelt to name a successor.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- The government moved on two fronts today to head off the soft coal strike, threatened for Aug. 1.

ROME, July 25. -- Premier Benito Mussolini in his capacity as Foreign Minister sent a telegram today to Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, declaring he was ready to resume the efforts that failed a fortnight ago in Scheveningen, Holland, to find a solution for the Ualual and other Italo-Ethiopian incidents.

The existence of a communistic campaign in the city's hospitals, both public and private, came to light yesterday when it was discovered that Bellevue Hospital had been flooded with a monthly mimeographed paper called X-ray. The four-page leaflet declares under its title head that it is "published by the Communist party workers at Bellevue Hospital."

The story of how disguised Federal agents laid a trap which led to the capture of Alfred Otto Wagner in an abandoned Brooklyn factory was told yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn before Judge Galston, where Wagner went on trial charged with violating the Lindbergh Kidnapping Law.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,467,000,000, a decrease of $11,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $6,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 25. -- Elsie Janis, after regaining consciousness this morning, exhibited such an "excellent frame of mind" that physicians at Grasslands Hospital expressed confidence for her complete recovery.

LONDON, July 25. -- Stocks were quiet on the London Stock Exchange today. British Government securities showed little change. British railway stocks were stimulated by the action of the London, Midland Scottish Company declaring an interim dividend of 2 per cent on the 4 per cent preference shares and 2 1/2 per cent on the 5 per cent preference issue.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- President Roosevelt nominated Charles West to be Under-Secretary of the Interior. He received a report on the condition of closed banks from J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the twelve months ended on June 30 shows gross income of $13,746,971, including stock dividends of $167,265, compared with $14,377,584 and $348,761, respectively, in the preceding year, and net income of $9,335,620, against $10,159,644.

MOSCOW, July 25. -- The Communist International in a remarkable change of front has decided to cast its lot with the more moderate elements in capitalistic countries in order to combat the growing menace of fascism.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Continued lack of aggressive outside buying counts heavily against the maintenance of bulges in the wheat market. While a sharp advance occurred early today in sympathy with an unexpected upturn of 5 cents a bushel in the July delivery in Minneapolis, the buying did not last long, and a reaction followed to below yesterday's finish.

The appointment of five legal assistants was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the investigation of rackets. Salaries of the five have not yet been fixed, but each will have the title of Deputy Assistant District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A fight by some House members for material changes in the pending Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill was in prospect today as the American Pharmaceutical Association threw its support behind an administration proposal to broaden the grounds for multiple seizure of misbranded products.

I read with interest the letter of Cyril Brown concerning the opportunities for utilities stockholders, but along with many other such holders I doubt whether any real opportunities exist as things are shaping themselves these days.

Fifth Avenue got a glimpse yesterday of fur fashions that will go swaggering down that thoroughfare when Winter comes, as two concerns held style reviews of new collections. Foremost Parisian designers were represented in the promenade of the manikins at I.J. Fox, while at Arnold Constable a formal showing was held on the remodeled sixth floor, with a salon especially decorated in gray, white and dubonnet, for the display of the more luxurious wraps.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H., July 25. -- At the Mount Washington Hotel, Bretton Woods, many riders were on the trails today and afterward enjoyed water sports in the swimming pool. Among these were Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Aguilera of Havana, who will depart this week for Europe; Mr. and Mrs. George Lane of Toronto, Mrs. W.G. Wunderley of Pittsburgh and Miss Peggy Sanderson.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25. -- Toward the dinner hour this evening the tournament committee at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club inspected the rain-soaked turf and reluctantly called off further play for the day after being thwarted by the elements in the morning and afternoon sessions.

Although member bank reserves increased $21,000,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to yesterday's report of the Federal Reserve System, the gain was offset by the increase in requirements, so that the excess of reserves over requirements held unchanged at approximately $2,340,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Rejection of any reciprocal trade agreement with Germany unless provision is made for religious and other guarantees of Americans resident in that country and for prevention of Nazi propagandizing in the United States was urged in the House today by Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A tax program estimated to bring to the government an added revenue of about $150,000,000 a year was tentatively decided upon today by Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee.

Reactionary tendencies, in varying degree, were manifested in the markets yesterday, particularly in the late trading. The share market, after coasting along most of the day, turned easier in the last hour to close irregularly lower; losses ranged from small fractions to 2 1/2 points.

The body of a man found in the North River off the West 129th Street pier on Wednesday night was identified yesterday as that of Dr. Arthur O. Nicholson, 47-year-old physician and surgeon, of 115 East Ninety-second Street. Dr. Nicholson had been missing since Monday.
TOKYO, Friday, July 26. -- The army has prepared a new five-year armaments plan to cost a total of 900,000,000 yen ($263,000,000) raised in annual instalments of 180,000,000 yen.

Final settlements before trading ceased in July obligations at noon yesterday caused a lively cotton market in the first two hours. After breaking 43 points here and exactly the same figure in New Orleans, activity subsided and comparatively little cotton changed hands the remainder of the session.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- In the same period when the President was revealing in various ways his disposition against "bigness" in business and his determination to press reform ahead of recovery measures, he appointed as the government's legal watchman of big business a man against whose selection Mr. Roosevelt's preceptors in these matters had strongly protested.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation earned 5 cents a share on 3,194,858 common shares for the second quarter of 1935, after quarterly dividend requirements on the preferred stock, Eugene G. Grace, president, announced yesterday. This compares with 56 cents a share earned on the common stock in the second quarter of 1934.

FORREST CITY, Ark., July 25 (AP). -- Senator Joseph T. Robinson denounced here tonight the political groups which, he said, had for their purpose the discrediting of the National Democratic administration and President Roosevelt, and charged that "they are united in a drive to seize control of the government."
YONKERS, N.Y., July 25 -- The authorities are looking for four men believed to have been trying to tamper with race horses at the Empire City track, it was revealed today.

PARIS, July 25. -- The crisis in florins monopolized attention in the Paris market again today and kept trading at a standstill. The florin finally closed at a slight gain from yesterday's price at 10.19 3/4 francs but still below the lower gold point. Forward discount Jumped to the record level of 12 francs, but this was interpreted here as a Dutch measure to check speculation.

BERLIN, July 25. -- About this time a year hence Berlin, as the scene of the eleventh world Olympics, expects to be "host to all the world." Not only Berlin but all Germany is looking forward to this and is preparing for it with a thoroughness and concentration such as few countries, if any, could manifest.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The differences which have existed between the Republican National Committee and the Senate and House campaign committees ever since Henry P. Fletcher was elected national chairman came to a climax today when the Congressional committees, dominated by Senator Hastings and Representative Bolton, severed all connection with the national committee as to policies and campaign funds.

Kempton Knott, leading rider of the current Empire City session, completed his third triple of the meeting yesterday, including the feature with William N. Adrian's Golden Way, through mud and a drizzle of rain. His first winner was James Butler's Caught in the fourth race, and his third, giving him three in a row, was the B.B. Stable's Law Maker in the nightcap.

Oscar H. Fogg, executive vice president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, was elected yesterday president of the Standard Gas Light Company, the New Amsterdam Gas Company and the East River Gas Company of Long Island City.

GREELEY, Col., July 25 (AP). -- A grudge nursed against peace officers during seventeen years of imprisonment was given by authorities tonight as the cause of Jack Printz's slaying of Policeman Lee Whitman last night, and his suicide early today when was trapped by a posse.

Billy Starkey, a cub Boy Scout and 12-year-old son of Staff Sergeant and Mrs. William Starkey, stationed at Fort Wood on Bedloe's Island, was inclined yesterday to minimize recommendations made to the headquarters of the Boy Scouts of America that a medal be awarded to him because he had saved a younger boy from drowning there Wednesday.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society's committee for raising funds opened yesterday a campaign to obtain the $10,000 needed to insure the deficits of the present season of symphony concerts, opera and ballet at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Stockholders of the B.F. Goodrich Company holding more than three-fourths of each class of stocks, the required amount under the company's charter, have approved the proposed financing plan which authorizes a mortgage under which $45,000,000 of bonds would be issued, $28,000,000 to be issued immediately, it was announced by the management at the special meeting of stockholders held here yesterday.

LONDON, July 25. -- A new railway that will fulfill Germany's prewar dream of direct railway communication between Berlin and Baghdad has been planned by Lord Glenconner, managing director of the British Oil Development Company, Ltd., in association with German and other financial interests.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision yesterday on an application by the New York Title and Mortgage Company for a stay of his order for the liquidation of the remaining assets of the company pending an appeal.

The Yankees' midsummer grapple with the Tigers for immediate possession of first place in the American League pennant race, which started so impressively last Tuesday when the McCarthy men wrenched the first game of a double-header from the Detroiters before a crowd of 63,000, terminated yesterday in a series of rain squalls that washed out the final engagement of the scheduled four-game series.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Charges of Navy Department dereliction in failing to force settlement of the strike at the Camden yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation and of violation by company officials of agreements with city officials were heard today by a House Labor subcommittee considering a resolution to investigate labor conditions in the shipbuilding industry.

Timothy J. Sullivan, Acting Aldermanic President, attacked the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday for setting up "arbitrary" qualifications for civil service applicants, which he said barred 90 per cent of those who wished to take examinations.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, in reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, earned a net profit of $388,002.88 for the twenty-one weeks ended on May 25, according to a consolidated report submitted yesterday afternoon to Federal Judge Bondy by the Irving Trust Company as trustee of the corporation.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 25. -- More than 100 horses are on the entry list for the Lenox two-day horse show at the Hanna Farm, starting tomorrow. The judges are Reginald W. Rives, Herbert L. Camp, Gerald S. Smith and Henry L. Bell.

As a proportionately heavy payer of city taxes, acquainted for years with many public school teachers, I feel impelled to write in behalf of the latter regarding the Board of Education's pamphlet on qualification tests.

Various proposals to revise the neutrality laws have been submitted to Congress, and the President thinks it would be a fine thing if some of them could be adopted, provided they did not provoke too long a debate. But the subject has become so complicated and difficult that any hasty and ill-considered legislation concerning it would be a mistake.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the twenty-eighth annual flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society, which opened this afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

The liner Manhattan, flagship of the United States Lines fleet, broke two of her records for the transatlantic crossing during her trip this week to Cobh and Plymouth, according to reports submitted yesterday by her master, Captain Giles C. Stedman, to the offices of the line at 1 Broadway.
BERLIN, July 25. -- The National Socialist drives against all non-Nazi elements in Germany continued today, and bulletins from various fronts detailed the following more important actions:

Sheriffs are county officers. County offices generally have long been regarded as a treasury of patronage for Tammany and its allies, who usually manage somehow to control them even when the fates are otherwise unkind. Four out of the five Sheriffs in New York City today are Democrats.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 25. -- Before this afternoon's torrential rain squalls made Lake George too rough for further tests, three of the five racing craft in motor boating's most expensive and extravagant annual classic for the Gold Cup skimmed over the new two-and-one-half-mile course in preparation for what promises to be an afternoon Saturday of record shattering.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe took under advisement yesterday fifty-three petitions for $3,221,328 in allowances from receivers, trustees, law firms and Others who participated in the receivership, bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings of the Paramount-Publix Corp.

Three-year-old Johnny Woods, who spent the first two years of his life undergoing scientific "conditioning" in the Child Development Institute at the Columbia Medical Centre, returned to the institute this week after a year of home life with six brothers and sisters, to receive treatment for a mastoid condition.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- While Attorney General Homer S. Cummings deplored today the suggestion that politics should enter into the affairs of the Federal Board of Parole, there were expressions of indignation at the enforced resignation from the board of Dr. Amy N. Stannard, penologist, to make room for Judge T. Webber Wilson, formerly of the Virgin Islands judiciary.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 25 (AP). -- Decrying "the abuse of the primary and independent petition system," David B. Costuma, New York City Commissioner of Elections, urged State voters today to exercise the same care in signing petitions "as in affixing signatures to personal checks."

With all financial centres inclined to await more definite developments in the Dutch politico-financial tangle, the foreign-exchange market assumed yesterday a much firmer tone, with the guilder regaining some of its previous losses.
Quotations for money, all classifications, remained steady and unchanged on a modest amount of business.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Packing houses in the United States continue to show the severe effects of the cattle shortage brought about by the government killing and the 1934 drought, The Chicago Federal Reserve Bank reported today that packing-house output in June fell contra-seasonally to the lowest level for any month since the bank began compiling records in January, 1923.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The value of stock and bond trading on the twenty-one national securities Exchanges totaled $1,276,682,055 in June, a decrease of 17.7 per cent from May, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Stock trading had a value of $987,345,680, a decrease of 18.7 par cent, and bond trading, valued at $289,246,470, was 13.8 per cent below the previous month.

The most notable current development in the educational field in this country is the adult education movement, Dean Ned H. Dearborn of New York University, division of general education, declared yesterday. Dr. Dearborn spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Administration Club of the university's School of Education Summer session.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Twenty-four craft were listed last night for the Bayside-Block Island race, which will start at noon today from off Little Neck Bay. The entries were announced at a dinner for skippers and crews given at the Bayside Yacht Club, Bayside, L.I.

PARIS, July 25. -- Marcel Regnier, Finance Minister, announced today at a Cabinet meeting that savings effected by the new decree laws had reduced the general budget from 47,000,000,000 francs to 36,000,000,000.

BERLIN, July 25. -- The property of the Stahlhelm units banned today in Western Mecklenburg was "provisionally seized and sequestered." Indications were that the Stahlhelm soon would be banned throughout the Reich, despite Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's reported promise to Franz Seldte, Minister of Labor and Stahlhelm leader, not to dissolve it.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 25. -- Federal conciliators sped efforts tonight to obtain an early settlement of the prolonged stamping mill dispute which led to union labor's general strike here this week. The conciliators were warned of a possible renewal of disorders when coal miners cease work for the weekend.

WARSAW, N.Y., July 25 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, charged tonight that the Roosevelt administration had dealt a "very severe blow" to the youth of the nation by blocking its path with "hundreds of New Deal edicts and regulations."

Large quantities of arsenic found in the vital organs of an unemployed Brooklyn musician who died last June 24 ostensibly from natural causes resulted yesterday in the arrest on homicide charges of the widow and a man with whom she was said to have been friendly.

Noel Scaffa, the private detective who is accused of having perjured himself last March before a Federal grand jury, which later indicted him for violation of the National Stolen Properties Act, offered no evidence yesterday in his own defense.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 25. -- Governor Lehman will speak here tomorrow when the seven new buildings which make up the $4,000,000 addition to the spa will be opened to the public. The State development, which is controlled by the Saratoga Springs Authority, embraces more than 1,000 acres and 163 mineral springs.

LONDON, July 25. -- The British Government announced today that it had decided "for the present," not to allow the export of arms either to Italy or to Ethiopia. The decision was made known by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare in the House of Commons in a brief statement in which he avoided any reference to the rights or wrongs of the Italo-Ethiopian quarrel.

OMAHA, July 25. -- A sharp reduction in Nebraska's August relief costs has been approved by the State Emergency Relief Commission. Discontinuation by Aug. 1 of all work relief in counties which are primarily agricultural, and by Aug. 16 in all other counties, with specified exceptions, will cut the month's appropriation to $744,000, nearly a half-million less than the July figure.

ST. PAUL., Minn., July 25. -- Black rust shrouded the Spring Wheat Belt so darkly today that observers forecast a 50 per cent reduction in the domestic crop of once bountiful promise. Increasing violence of the rust attack, with continued hot, humid weather, led competent authority to halve the original 273,000,000 bushels estimated from the great grain belt.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The new wealth tax bill, tentatively approved today by Ways and Means Democrats, virtually ignores two suggestions made by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Two of the Capitol's veteran political observers said today that Sept. 1 was the earliest possible date for Congress to adjourn if the present legislative program is to be enacted. They were Senators Norris and Capper.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Twenty-one State and city policemen, including one from New York City, have enrolled for the government's first crime school, which opens Monday, Attorney General Cummings announced today.
Engineering awards in the United States this week total $25,924,000, a 10 per cent increase over last week, The Engineering News Record reported yesterday.

Deposits of mutual savings banks in the United States for the first half of this year moved toward the peak figure reached on Jan. 1, 1932. With deposits of $9,870,051,120 on June 30, 1935, the total fell short only, $160,000,000 of the record, the report of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reveals.

LONDON, July 25. -- Russia has laid the keel of her sixtieth submarine and orders for ten more have been placed, according to a dispatch in The London Daily Telegraph. Four years ago the Russian Navy possessed only fifteen submarines, the majority of which were obsolete.

The Group Theatre, which has tried practically every combination of those Clifford Odets plays, has now decided on the last one. It will close "Awake and Sing!" and "Waiting for Lefty," at the Belasco, on Saturday night. On Monday the players will start their vacations, not together this time, but as individuals, and at the end of four or five weeks the Group will know better what its Fall plans are to be.

CANNES, July 25. -- The zeal of Hal F. Duberrier, a Chicago aviator, for the Ethiopian cause has now embroiled him in a quarrel with an Italian officer which is scheduled to be settled by a duel Monday or Tuesday.

Whether Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion, will fight Joe Louis or Max Beer in September is expected to be determined today by the German boxer, with the strong possibility that the Detroit heavyweight will be his opponent.

ROME, July 25. -- Rome heard tonight the refrain, "Ethiopia for us," shouted from 100,000 Fascist throats, as one of the greatest demonstrations in the capital's history gathered in Colonna and Venezia squares to roar approval of Benito Mussolini's African program.

BERLIN, July 25. -- The success of the National Socialist effort to eliminate women from shops and factories and send them back to the kitchen was attested today by figures issued by the German Labor Office.

STOCKHOLM, July 25 (AP). -- Picking up where they left off yesterday, athletes composing one of the three American touring track and field teams today carried off four firsts and a second as the two-day international meet closed.

It is now more than two years since the Public Service Commission began to take testimony on which to base temporary emergency electric rates for the metropolitan community. In the proceedings which followed, historic rules of rate-making were given scant consideration.

Father Gerard B. Donnelly, writing in the current number of the Catholic weekly America, takes issue with the Catholic Daughters of America for the resolution adopted at their Seattle convention on July 5 in which they attacked the motion-picture industry.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL TRAIN, COLIMA. Mexico, July 25. -- Following a riotous demonstration yesterday by a hundred women led by the wife of a local banker, demanding a speech by President Lazaro Cardenas regarding church privileges, the President received a delegation of Catholic women in his private car.
HAVANA, July 25. -- President Mendieta signed early this morning a decree reducing Cuban sugar exports for 1935 to the exact figure of the quota granted to Cuba by the United States for this period.

Paris had a saying about the late ARISTIDE BRIAND and RAYMOND POINCARE. It was to the effect that BRIAND read nothing and understood everything and POINCARE read everything and understood nothing. As a matter of fact, this epigram was neither true nor ben trovato.
PARIS, July 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- President Roosevelt today congratulated Lawson Little on his British amateur golf triumph and obtained from the burly Californian firsthand information about the treacherous winds that sweep the English courses.

E.F Hutton, a director of Zonite Products, reported an increase in his ownership of that company's capital stock by 27,598 shares in May to a total of 124,710 shares, according to summaries of the shareholding reports of officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed companies released yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
VIENNA, July 25. -- Vienna has been dominated all day by the execution of a scheme arranged by the government for recalling the tragic events of July 25, 1934.

American Cities Power and Light Corporation -- Six months ended June 30: Net cash income, $484,698 after all expenses and taxes, compared with $362,250 in the 1934 period. In addition, profits on sales of securities amounted to $306,561 after taxes, of which $265,800 was credited to earned surplus and the balance to reduction in book value of investments.

An interesting and important question is raised by President ROOSEVELT'S comment on the subject of gifts made by corporations to charitable causes. Such gifts have recently provided about one-fourth of all the funds raised in the United States for community chests.

Two of six men indicted last Spring for attempting to blackmail Mrs. George U. Harris of 17 East Seventieth Street for $5,000 by means of a bogus picture went on trial yesterday before General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi and a jury.

It is exactly such a situation as that covered in your editorial "The Crime Conference" which inspired the birth of the Boys' Anti-Crime Council of the University Settlement. Too much conference has been directed at the statute books, and not enough at practical steps for heading off the potential criminal.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Plans by which it was hoped to drive the Banking Bill to a final vote tomorrow were made in the Senate today after a five-hour session during which Title I, affecting Federal deposit insurance, was approved without change, Senator Glass completed an exposition of the bill, and Senator Nye urged his central bank proposal.

ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- Easier of mind than they have been for a fortnight, the Giants are speeding back to Harlem tonight, a joyous band humming over the rails after playing havoc with the Cardinal rush for the National League lead.

Construction of new airports and improvement of existing fields in twenty New York cities, involving expenditure of $5,672,000, was approved yesterday by the State Aviation Commission at a meeting at the Bar Association Building.

RYE. N.Y., July 25. -- A driving rain that swept over the course from Long Island Sound played havoc today with the eighteen-hole tournament of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Rye Country Club. Of it starting field of thirty-seven players only six returned cards, having played during the downpour.

PORTSMOUTH, England, July 25. -- While marines with fixed bayonets stood guard, ninety-three steel cases containing priceless treasures of Chinese art for the coming exhibition at Burlington House in London were unloaded from the cruiser Suffolk today.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- Jockey Wayne D. Wright provided most of the thrills at Arlington Park today, booting home three winners in three starts, two of them long shots.

GENEVA, July 25. -- Italy notified the League of Nations today, the first deadline set by the Council's resolution of May 25, of two previous messages to Ethiopia stating that Rome was ready to resume the session of the four arbitrators. She explained, however, that she made these offers conditional on Ethiopia's accepting the Italian boundary claims which had caused the deadlock.
The twenty-one-day heat wave that has caused discomfort and distress to the city's millions was broken yesterday by a series of gentle showers.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Although factories suffered no more than their usual seasonal reductions in production during June, they cut their employment and payrolls more than seasonally, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly business summary.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP). -- The Pirates ran their winning streak to eight straight today, turning back the Phillies, 9 to 8, with a three-run ninth inning rally. Pinch hitter Red Lucas ended the contest with a two-run single with the bases loaded.
The District Attorney's office in Kings County began yesterday an investigation of the charge that brutal treatment by two Kings County Hospital attendants had caused the death of an aged patient.

On the basis of the statements so far issued, the net operating income of the Class I railroads in June will be slightly below that for June of last year, while the gross revenues will show a small increase. The decline in net operating income is attributed to higher expenses under which the roads have been operating since the restoration of the wage reductions.

TORONTO, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- Calumet Evelyn, owned by the McConville brothers of Ogdensburg and handled by Vic Fleming, won the feature event on the closing day's Grand Circuit racing card at Thorncliffe Park today. She prevailed in three straight races.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25. -- A 27-year-old bank clerk from Buffalo, Erwin Konrad, today established himself as the outstanding sprint sculler on the continent by trouncing Toronto's sensational Argonaut pair, Charlie Campbell and Johnny Coulson, in the 440-yard senior dash that featured the opening program of the Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

ALBANY, July 25. -- Governor Lehman tonight urged that citizens of New York State respond more generously to the Red Cross appeal for funds to aid in the rehabilitation of homes in the southern section of the State which were damaged by floods early in the month.

The government has thrown up the sponge in its legal contest with Miss Marion A. Schwing of 216 Church Street, White Plains, champion of returning travelers, and henceforth the voyager may bring in $100 worth of foreign liquor free of customs duties and internal revenue taxes, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, July 25. -- Hannen Swaffer, Britain's Socialist writer No. 1, was presented to King George at a garden party at Buckingham Palace today when the entertainment of 10,000 guests brought the Silver Jubilee festivities to a close.

MALONE, N. Y., July 25. -- Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant committed four aides of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer to the county jail today "to be sure they will be available as witnesses" at Schultz's second trial for income tax evasion, which opened here Tuesday.

The General Motors Corporation's consolidated net income in the quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $52,219,467, or $1.17 a share on the approximately 42,670,800 average number of common shares outstanding in the period, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president.

The first step toward the feature event of the 1935 polo season will take place today when thirty-five carefully selected ponies, with a staff of sixteen grooms under the eyes of two of the players of the team, go aboard the S.S. American Trader in England and start the trip to the United States and the open championship which starts at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury on Sept. 7.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The new post of Under-Secretary of the Interior was filled by President Roosevelt today with the appointment of Charles West, the President's liaison man with Congress, who was active in the administration fight to preserve the "death-sentence" provision of the utility holding company bill.

The anti-Jewish rioting in Berlin's fashionable Kurfuerstendamm early last week was thoroughly planned by the Nazi party, according to Varian Fry, editor of The Living Age, who returned yesterday from the scene of the rioting on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.
Savings banks sold and leased buildings in the city yesterday. Two of the properties passing to new control will be altered.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Wholesale commodity prices declined slightly during the week ending July 20, the Bureau of Labor statistics index moving to 79.1 as compared with 79.2 the preceding week. A year ago it stood at 75.1.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- While prices of hogs dropped 10 to 15 cents a dundredweight today as a result of a continued slow demand for fresh pork, there was a better demand on the decline and part of the loss was recovered toward the close. The recession of 25 cents in the market in the last two days is said to have restricted country loadings and light arrivals are expected tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, July 25 (AP). -- Turning in a sparkling 68, four under par, Larry Sovic, a Syracuse attorney, led the field, including Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie and Jack Creavy of Albany, runner-up to Billows in the recent State amateur, in today's qualifying round of the Onondaga Club's annual invitation golf tournament.

Senator Huey Long of Louisiana made the definite announcement here yesterday that he would bolt President Roosevelt and the Democratic national convention in 1936 unless the President dropped his New Deal program and proceeded at once to carry out a program for redistribution of wealth.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 25. -- The Swedish sloop Lill-Singva added another victory to her laurels when she won the race of the American Thirty-Square-Meter Association from Marion to this port today. The invader, ably handled by Erik Nilsson and his crew, finished the twenty-one-mile race with a margin of 7 minutes 35 seconds over George Poor's Skjold VII.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Reports that General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff of the army, is to become military adviser to the first President of the Commonwealth Government of the Philippines and to direct the training and development of an insular defense army were heard in the capital today.

MONTREAL, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Bermuda eleven today defeated the McGill Cricket Club by six wickets in a one-day match. Batting first, Mc-Gill scored 166 runs and Bermuda replied with 170 runs for four wickets.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The "mysterious cigar box wrapped in newspaper," focus of the continued curiosity of the Senate Lobby Committee, played the leading role again today in the examination of Texas Power and Light Company officials.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A determined stand by House conferees on the AAA amendment bill in opposition to the Senate provision permitting suits for recovery of past processing tax collections was indicated today by Chairman Jones of the House Agricultural Committee in a statement saying that the provision must either be eliminated or modified "so as to avoid the abuses which it invites."

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, sailing today for Channel ports, will have on board the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman; David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America; J. David Stern, publisher of The Philadelphia Record and The New York Post; John F. Galvin, chairman of the Port of New York Authority; Leslie Howard, actor, accompanied by his wife and children, and Judge Learned Hand.

Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, was advised yesterday by the State Department that the German-American commercial treaty of 1925 was still in effect and that no complaints had been received that Americans have been discriminated against in Germany in violation of the provisions of the treaty.

Besieged by photographers and interviewers, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody arrived early yesterday aboard the United States liner Washington, fit, confident, determined to resist movie and professional offers and with definite views on America's chances in Davis Cup and Wightman Cup competition.

Approval of the entire set-up of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board, including a budget of approximately $375,000, was voted yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee at its offices, 132 West Thirty-first Street. Representatives of all the areas, into which the industry has been divided for administration purposes, were present, including delegates from Portland, Ore.; Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday a net operating profit of $371,591, after taxes and other charges, for the thirty-nine weeks ended on May 25, equivalent to $3.60 a share on 103,107 shares of cumulative preferred stock, entitled to cumulative dividends at the rate of $3.85 a year. This compares with a net operating loss of $528,836 for the corresponding period of last year.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

I am not a nudist and do not contemplate becoming one. However, in considering our present-day civilization in the light of present-day heat, I have come to the conclusion that the nudists are the only people using horse sense in the summertime.

The American steel industry's potential share in the $4,000,000,000 public works funds has been impaired, to the advantage of foreign producers, as a result of an order signed by a deputy administrator of the PWA dated May 25, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said after a meeting of the company's directors yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25. -- Despite bad weather the Newport Country Club clubhouse was the centre of attraction tonight for the men of the Summer colony and their golfing guests. The occasion was the annual golfing dinner marking the close of what had been a decidedly wet opening day of the ninth annual invitation tournament of the club.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Federal Judge William H. Holly today set noon on next Wednesday as the dead line for filing plans for the reorganization of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation, under Section 77-B of the amended Bankruptcy Act. The deadline was set by the court after a hearing lasting more than two hours in which the various litigants argued over the merits of a plan submitted on behalf of the stockholders.

Although outscored in two races on Little Neck Bay, junior skippers from yacht clubs on Manhasset Bay defeated Bayside sailors, 43 to 40, in the series of three events with meteor craft which ended yesterday,

TORONTO, July 25. -- Every single unemployed man in Ontario physically able to work will be stricken from the relief rolls on Aug. 1, and heads of families must accept farm work or be similarly cut off, Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn announced today following a Cabinet meeting.

Oswald W. Knauth, who was scheduled to retire as chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau on Aug. 1, will retain the chairmanship but will be succeeded as executive director by Miss Charlotte Carr, now director of the Home Relief Bureau, it was announced yesterday.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 25. -- The New York Shipbuilding Corporation stopped operations at its yard here today and shut down its power plant. The shipyard had reopened Monday despite of the continuance employes' strike, now in its eleventh week.

" The Arizonian," which RKO Radio halls as its successor to Edna Ferber's "Cimarron," opens this morning at the Roxy. Richard Dix has the starring role, supported by Margot Grahame, Preston Foster, Louis Calhern and James Bush.

Plans for increased activity in combating the spread of tuberculosis and social diseases were disclosed yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, at a hearing before Rufus E. McGahan, Budget Director, upon the Health Department request for a 1936 budget allowance $1,180,211 greater than that for 1935.

RYE, N.Y., July 25. -- It looks as if the regular, fulltime golfers in the district had better look to their laurels. Last week they were eclipsed by Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie billing clerk, and today most of them were put in the shade by George Herman (Babe) Ruth, one-time baseball hero.
BERLIN, July 25 (AP). -The Reichsbanks's statement as of July 23 shows the following canges in leichsmarks:

BUENOS AIRES, July 25. -- The Argentine Government has not given out any intimation or me reasons it had for issuing the decree establishing strict control over news agencies and newspaper correspondents, but President Augustin Justo's secretary, has published a statement indicating it will be enforced despite the most vigorous and widespread opposition made against any government measure in recent years.
LONDON, July 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Plans for elevating the standards of customers' men have been submitted to the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange by a special committee of members named in November, 1933, to study the subject, it was learned yesterday at the Exchange.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25. -- One of the most absurd duels in Argentine history was fought this morning when Federico Pinedo, Minister of Finance, and National Senator Leandro de la Torre deliberately fired into space -- each determined not to injure his opponent but going through the motions that Latin psychology considers "saved his honor."

Net profit of the National Cash Register Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $501,138 after depreciation, income taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to 31 cents a share on 1,627,000 shares of capital stock, and compares with $196,775, or 12 cents a share, in the previous quarter, and $722,130, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter ended on June 30, 1934.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- President Roosevelt outlined his foreign policy at his press conference, with special emphasis on remaining aloof from the Italo-Ethiopian situation. He reiterated objection to allowing public utilities to claim tax exemption for contributions to charities.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 26. -- C. Redner Richards, former stockbroker and former member of the New York Stock Exchange, committed suicide here late last night by hanging himself in the attic of his home. He left a note saying insurance on his life would have expired today.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 26. -Three youths, all under the age of 21, were held in the Bergen County jail without bail here today charged with being the masked bandits who held up five golfers on July 6 and shot one of them on the links of the Ridgewood Country Club.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama cheeks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The State and municipal bond market will continue dull next week, inasmuch as only $4,035,000 of new financing is scheduled to be done. This compares with this week's revised total of $7,818,720. The weekly average for the year to date, therefore, is further reduced, amounting to $23,400,813.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 26. -- G. Churchill Francis was general chairman of the Pittsfield Country Club women's golf tournament ball, which was held tonight, with more than 200 members and guests attending. Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Kittredg of Dalton had a dinner party of twenty at the club. The Country Club hobby show will be opened tomorrow.

With the first half of the year over, and favorable earnings statements out of the way, a few observers believe that the rise of the auto shares has ended, for the present at least. This view is based on the record of recent years, which shows that almost all of the earnings of the industry were registered in the first half of the year.

Though unemployment is still widespread and the relief rolls are near their peak, millions of Americans are able to earn money and to save it. The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday that deposits in such institutions increased by $112,000,000 during the first six months of 1935 and reached a total of $9,870,000,000.

Laden with a roll of paintings, illustrations and the manuscript of a new book, Rockwell Kent, artist and author, returned yesterday aboard the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland after a year's absence in Greenland.

The broadening of industrial operations, which started two weeks ago, contrary to all expectations for this period, has been further extended and rapidly is outstripping all records of the last few years, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

TORONTO, July 26 (Canadian Press). -- Because an inquiry disclosed "widespread bribery" in unlisted stock transactions, John M. Godfrey, Securities Commissioner, said today a general clean-up of the unlisted stock business here was under way.

The thirteenth man was arrested yesterday in the frauds through which the former Tammany district captain, John Flaherty, now serving four years in Sing Sing, obtained about $250,000 in the last five years from 100 aspirants for jobs in the Federal, State and city governments.

HAVANA, July 26. -- Military authorities took over this morning the Department of Public Works and detained Francisco Diaz, Acting Secretary, as well as thirty-five employes, including several bureau chiefs. All were lodged in Principe Fortress.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Indictments against five members of an alleged stock swindling ring, which operated principally in shares of Stutz Motors, will be sought as the result of evidence presented in the last four days at hearings here before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A sharp rally in Italian dollar bonds featured yesterday an otherwise dull bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Recoveries of 3 3/4 to 6 1/4 points ruled among the Italian issues, with the government 7s showing a gain of 6 1/4 points and corresponding advances in Italian Public Utility 7s, City of Milan 6 1/2s and City of Rome 6 1/2s.

THANKS to the recent activities of Herr Hitler and his henchmen, our amateur sports leaders now have that Olympic problem back in their laps again. Should we go in or stay out? They will have to make up their minds pretty soon.

An unidentified Negro was stabbed to death early yesterday morning and two other Negroes were cut while fleeing from a roller skating rink at 102d Street and West Drive, Central Park, where an altercation developed into a free-for-all fight. Detectives were unable to find the cause of the fight.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Despite mixed reaction to the President's stand in opposition to Federal exemption of profits taxes for corporation income contributed to charities, Mr. Roosevelt reaffirmed that position today.

The State Banking Department announced yesterday the successful completion of negotiations for a loan of $3,100,000 on the San Remo Apartments, Central Park West from Seventy-fourth to Seventy-fifth Street. The money will be used to pay a 5 per cent dividend to the depositors of the defunct Bank of United States.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Details of a plan to land a $10,000,000 army contract for motor trucks were placed before the House Military Affairs Committee today by Frank Speicher, a New York City tire salesman, who hid during the Spring and Summer last year to avoid appearance before a grand jury investigating army procurement.

The steel industry seems to be passing through a needless case of the jitters. Less than two weeks ago it announced, through the American Iron and Steel Institute, that increasing imports of steel in the first five months of this year deprived 3,900 workmen in the United States of full-time jobs.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP). -- Displaying a great drive in the stretch and rated perfectly at the hands of Apprentice Joey Wagner, the Greentree Stable's Nightmare had no trouble today in capturing the featured Gardner Purse, six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds, at Suffolk Dawns.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- The Cubs today defeated the Reds, 5 to 1, in the series opener, while their National League rivals, the Giants and Cards, were idle. The triumph gave the Cubs a full game over the Cards for second-place honors and left them only two and one-half games behind the Giants. It was their nineteenth victory in their last twenty-two games.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Broad general buying of wheat today on the Chicago Board of Trade carried all before it. Many operators heretofore skeptical regarding black rust damage in the American and Canadian Northwest became active buyers as a result of the sensational losses reported.

ROME, July 26. -- An invitation to Italy to participate in the meeting of the League of Nations Council that is to be held next week to discuss the Italo-Ethiopian situation was received by Rome late this evening almost simultaneously with news from Addis Ababa that the Ethiopian Government had rejected Premier Mussolini's suggestion that the Italo-Ethiopian conciliation commission resume its sittings.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- At the request of President Roosevelt, the bituminous operators and miners of the Appalachian fields today extended until Sept. 16 the wage and working agreement which would have expired on Aug. 1. The conference then adjourned subject to the call of the chairman, Duncan C. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Educational camps for women and girls, a relief activity started last year, are being re-established this Summer and carried on for periods ranging from six to eight weeks, Aubrey W. Williams, Acting Emergency Relief Administrator, announced today.

The continued investigation by State Attorney General John J. Bennett's Anti-Racket Bureau of the activities of the American Federation of Master Barbers resulted yesterday in the arrest of two more officials and four delegates of the organization on charges of coercion and conspiracy.

Having lived through a fifteen-day road schedule that was more difficult than had been expected, a succession of injuries that handicapped them seriously and a heat wave that prostrated one of their stars and narrowly missed another, the Giants rode triumphantly into New York last night. They are right where they want to be--at the head of the National League standings-and face a home stand that is eagerly anticipated.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -President Roosevelt accepted the resignation of James L. O'Neill, New York business man, who has headed the new NRA for two months. The resignation becomes effective Wednesday. The President said a successor would be named Monday or Tuesday.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses teamed up again yesterday to open two new park developments in Queens -- the first section of the new Interborough Parkway link to Brooklyn and a twenty-six-acre playfield in Alley Pond Park just south of Grand Central Parkway.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans totaling $3,500,000 were made available to flood districts in New York, Pennsylvania and other States today when President Roosevelt signed the Wagner-Sisson bill, designed to aid the hard-hit districts in up-State New York.

An anti-climactic disturbance was staged by about 500 Communist sympathizers in the vicinity of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station between 1 and 1:30 o'clock this morning while prisoners arrested at the riot on the liner Bremen earlier were being booked.

According to reports received from Montauk early yesterday, there is every prospect of good fishing over the week-end. Tuna, that have been in the vicinity in schools, are now taking the lures. Of the tuna that have been caught, the average weight is between forty and sixty pounds.

LONDON, July 26. -- It was made known officially today that the Cabinet's decision, announced by Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, yesterday in the House of Commons, not to issue export licenses "for the present" for munitions either for Italy or Ethiopia applied only until after the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations next week.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- Discovery, globe trotter of the American turf, goes sight-seeing again tomorrow, but it's an odds-on bet that he'll win the money while his rivals are seeing the sights.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- As a measure of economy, reducing Federal prison expense and congestion, President Roosevelt commuted the sentences of 151 alien convicts, including one woman, effective upon dates set for deportation to their homelands.

Forty-second Street is one of the most heavily traveled thoroughfares in this city. Counts of pedestrian traffic indicate that more than a million persons pass along the sidewalks in the Times Square section daily, and that an average of more than 6,000 pedestrians pass a given point on other blocks every hour.

Mrs. Lucille L. Harris, wife of George U. Harris, a member of the Stock Exchange, had testified in General Sessions yesterday against two men accused of having attempted to blackmail her of $5,000 last April 19 when one of the defendants, Ralph Picarelli, 26 years old, pleaded guilty to attempted extortion.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 26. -- The week-end entertaining began today in preparation for the score or more of dinner parties tomorrow night before the subscription dance to be given at the Clambake Club.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 26. -Eleven sailing dinghies, the elite of the lot afloat in the waters along the Atlantic seaboard, set out today off the Larchmont Yacht Club in the elimination trials to select a team of two to meet the two English boats that are coming to this country for an international match in September.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 26. -- New York captured four of the places in the finals of the annual Western championship of the American Chess Federation, in which eleven will compete as a result of the qualifying rounds which ended today. Boston will be represented by two, and Camden, N.J., Chicago, Milwaukee, Portland, Ore., and Toronto by one each. Those who qualified follow:

Noel C. Scaffa, private detective, was convicted yesterday of perjury. A jury, which began hearing evidence last Monday, arrived at its verdict after deliberating four hours. Scaffa will be sentenced on Aug. 13.

Early in September Doubleday, Doran will publish "Test Pilot," by the late Jimmy Collins, who died not long ago when an airplane he was testing for the government broke to pieces in midair. "Test Pilot" is a collection of pieces he wrote for various publications.
