GENEVA, July 26. -- Maxim M. Litvinoff of Russia, as president of the League of Nations Council, today convoked that body in extraordinary session on the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon gave a dinner and bridge tonight at The Shutters for Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Sage Jr., who are passing several days with them.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- President Roosevelt today was represented as still pressing Frank C. Walker, director of the Division of Applications and Information in the work-relief program to succeed James A. Farley as Postmaster General.
THE HAGUE, Holland, July 26. -Queen Wilhelmina named today Professor D.P. Aalberse to form a new government on the widest possible basis, and requested him to give his reply within the next few days.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A general definition of the administration's foreign policy was given orally by President Roosevelt today, with special reference to Ethiopia, in response to a question at his press conference as to what was being done to keep the United States out of war.

In line with its plan to have all interests represented in the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board, the United States Departments of Commerce and Labor will be invited to appoint members to serve on the organization's executive committee, it was announced yesterday by Alexander Printz, chairman of the board.

A further substantial rise in hog prices was largely responsible for a rise in The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to 123.6 on July 23 from 123 on July 16. Prices of hogs advanced to the highest level since the week ended on Sept. 16, 1930.

Despite the exceedingly warm weather, retail sales during the week were quite good and sales gains of about 6 to 8 per cent were registered over the corresponding week of last year, store executives reported yesterday.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 26. -Two experts from the United States Department of Agriculture arrived here at 5 P.M. today from Washington to investigate the cause and nature of the baffling illness that affected more than 100 World War veterans and a dozen attendants at the United States Veterans Hospital here last night, three hours after they had eaten supper.

STOCKHOLM, July 26 (AP). -- Jack Lovelock of New Zealand raced to victory over Gene Venzke of Penn and Eric Ny of Sweden in a 1,500-meter race at an international meet, in which touring American athletes gained three first places today.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 26 (AP). -- United States Senator Daniel O. Hastings, receiver for General Theatres Equipment, Inc., petitioned Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott today for permission to instruct the company's voting trustees to approve consolidation of Fox Film Corporation with Twentieth Century Pictures.

A bill to be known as the National Textile Act and establishing labor standards for that industry will be introduced in Congress next week by Representative Henry Ellenbogen, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, it was announced by the officers of the United Textile Workers who approved the measure at a meeting here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26. -- Wilfred Pike, secretary and general manager of the Opal Hosiery Mills, said today that only six of the company's employee were on strike, instead of 200, as announced at a convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers earlier in the week.

MOSCOW, July 26. -- World Communism's old slogan, "Turn imperialist war into civil war," which bound Communists in capitalist countries to turn on their own governments in case of war, has been shelved by the Communist International, now holding its seventh congress here.

Pleas of not guilty were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Nelson B. Clark, 62 years old, to two robbery indictments handed up several days ago. They followed testimony before the grand jury by four youthful inmates of the death house at Sing Sing that Clark was their mentor in a series of hold-ups which led to their murder of a patrolman last January.

Domestic producers of iron and steel are well able to compete with foreign makers without being given a 15 per cent price differential, C.T. Riotte, secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., charged yesterday in a letter sent to steel importing members of the organization.

SHANGHAI, July 26. -- The unyielding Japanese attitude toward China coupled with the fact that an Italo-Ethiopian conflict may soon absorb the interest of the rest of the world, thereby giving Japan an ever freer hand in the Far East, lends particular interest to the probable movements and attitude of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, asserted here today that he knew of no racial or religious reasons why the United States should consider withdrawal of its athletes from competition at the Olympic Games in Berlin next year.

HELSINGFORS, July 26 (AP). -- A United States track and field team, competing for the second day against athletes of Finland and Japan, today took four first places and one second on a track made soggy by a drizzling rain.

THE HOUSE OF DAWN" (Appleton-Century, $2) is cut so close to regulation pattern that it is worth a little wonder. One has the feeling, opening it, that it is fresh off a conveyor belt. In the short first chapter we are given a South American setting and a clue to buried Inca treasure. In the second chapter hero and heroine are introduced.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -Navy officials today declined comment on an assertion that neglect of technical advice caused destruction of the Macon, but pointed to an official report declaring that no one was to blame.

NEWARK, July 26. -- The Newark Bears and the Rochester Red Wings divided a double-header tonight before a gathering of 9,000. The Bears won the twilight game, 5 to 3, but the visitors captured the night fray, 1 to 0 after an eleven-inning battle.

After holding within limits of a few points for several hours yesterday under the lightest business of the year, trading on the Cotton Exchange was enlivened by short covering that followed the sharp rise in wheat. Buying orders, mostly in October, lifted the near month about $1 a bale and left the list at net gains of 8 to 15 points.
LOS ANGELES, July 26. -- Medical, dental and pharmaceutical care, ranging from major operations to the repair of false teeth, was made available free today to Los Angeles County's 400,000 unemployed.

The first normal Summer weather in three weeks brought a welcome relief to New York's millions yesterday. Compared with its twenty-one immediate predecessors, the day seemed ideally cool and comfortable.

More than 1,500 Columbia University Summer session students attended a conference on education in social conflict, held last night in the Horace Mann Auditorium of Teachers College, and heard four Teachers College professors urge teachers to take a more active part in the formation of a better economic and social life.

With $80,000,000 gold exported from Holland this week, due to the muddled monetary and political situation, the guilder jumped nervously yesterday in the foreign exchange market here. An additional $7,800,000 in gold was engaged in Amsterdam yesterday for interests in the United States, making $12,000,000 in the last two days.

EASTER POINT, Conn., July 26. -- Bobby Grant, former Connecticut amateur champion from Hartford, shot a sub-par round of golf today to win the medal for the first time in the sixteenth annual Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The observation that "public interest" will dictate administration of the Silver Purchase Act was President Roosevelt's reply today to the Senate silver bloc. His views on obtaining "our common objective of a wider monetary use of silver" were outlined politely but firmly in a letter to forty-six Senators who had asked him to pusue "enthusiastically" a policy that would lead to the goal set up by the act.

Police Commissioner Valentine and Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., chairman of a legislative committee appointed to investigate the taxicab industry, opposed before Supreme Court Justice Lauer yesterday an application by Earl W. Hagedone, taxicab owner, to compel the Police Department to license his reduced fare cab.

Cecil B. DeMille's new Paramount production, "The Crusades," will have its world premiere at the Astor Theatre on Wednesday night, Aug. 21. The film will be shown twice daily thereafter on a reserved-seat basis. Chief among the players are Loretta Young, Henry Wilcoxon, Ian Keith, Katherine DeMille and C. Aubrey Smith.
The New York Curb Exchange has removed from unlisted trading, for failure to maintain transfer facilities, Associated Telephone Utilities common stock, no par value.

A program for tightening of administration of the title and mortgage guaranty companies, of which twenty-four are being liquidated or rehabilitated, was made public yesterday afternoon by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

A cable reports that London is facing a pretty big season -- that is, if the plans of the managers, duly announced, mean anything. For example, take Mr. Cochran. Coming back from vacation next month, he hopes to launch what the cable -- and no doubt, Mr. Cochran, too -- calls "the biggest, most spectacular musical play he has ever produced." Also a new revue.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The possibility of a settlement soon of the strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's yards in Camden, N.J., was broached by President Roosevelt today. He said there should be definite developments looking to a solution within a few days.

A wild anti-Hitler demonstration by 2,000 Communists precipitated two near-riots last midnight and early this morning, the first one at the pier of the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen and the other outside the West Forty-seventh Street station, giving hundreds of policemen a lively battle before order was restored.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 26. -- In a letter to Colonel William B. Wallace, commander of the Plattsburg barracks, Bernard Sandler of New York commended the plan for a reunion of the members of the first officers' training camp, held here in 1915.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 26 (AP). -- Survivors of a movie barge tragedy off San Miguel Island yesterday told tonight of the death of Glenn Strong, film camera man, and the rescue of twenty-five persons in heavy seas.

The most successful meeting in the history of the Empire City Racing Association will come to a conclusion today with the East View Stakes for 2-year-olds as the featured event. Many persons congratulated James Butler yesterday the exodus began for Saratoga, where racing will begin on Monday.

Mrs. Mary Emma Calhoun of 147 East Sixtieth Street, a daughter of the late Christopher Wolfe, architect, and granddaughter of John Wolfe, banker, railroad operator and friend of J. Pierpont Morgan, obtained a summons from Magistrate Brough in the Tombs Court yesterday for her sister, Mrs. Maude Wolfe Cameron of 315 East Sixty-eighth Street.
BERLIN, July 27 (AP). -- A scathing warning that Germany will not permit "humiliation" was addressed to Mayor La Guardia today by the Angriff, organ of Dr. Josef Paul Goebbels, Propaganda Minister.
PARIS, July 26. -- Haile Sellassie, Emperor of Ethiopia, in an interview published today in the Paris-Soir declared he was confident the League of Nations would prevent war with Italy.

ALBANY, July 26. -- The Public Service Commission was made the target today of sharp attacks for its policy on rate reductions. The attacks were at a public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee investigating the public utilities.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Unaltered even by the transposition of a punctuation mark, the Omnibus Banking Bill making many changes in the present law was passed in the Senate today without a record vote in the form in which it had been unanimously reported by the Senate Banking Committee several weeks ago.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Declines in prices of hogs earlier in the week shut off country loadings and only 5,000 were received here today, of which 3,000 want direct to packers. Scarcely enough offerings were available to test the market. The latter was strong to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher early on scattered buying, but it quickly reacted and closed steadily to slightly lower, compared with Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Mrs. Oliver Grace Harriman, president of the National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, today presented to Speaker Byrns a petition advocating that lotteries in this country be legalized. She said that residents of New York State spent $14,000,000 last month on tickets for foreign lotteries and that the whole country has sent $3,000,000,000 abroad in the last two years in the pursuit of quick fortune through sweepstakes and similar ventures.

John H. Porter, 19-year-old student of 312 West Twentieth Street, was not without detailed legal advice when he was arrested at 6:45 o'clock last night in front of a school at 117 West Forty-sixth Street, charged with "obstructing the sidewalk by distributing circulars."

Public offerings of new bonds this week amounted to $35,900,000, consisting of two public utility, one industrial and four relatively small issues in the municipal classification. While the total is small compared with the $234,148,000 last week, it shows a substantial gain from the $5,112,000 in the corresponding week of last year.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 26. -- Bids for deepening the Barge Canal from Oneida Lake to Oak Orchard, a distance of about ten miles, and one of the largest contracts to be awarded in a group of seven, were opened today by Major Thomas F. Farrell, chief engineer of the Department of Public Works.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -Here are the main points in the Bank Bill which the Senate passed today and sent to conference with the House:
The New York Post announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with the Newspaper Guild, national organization of working newspaper men and women.

Ministers, missionaries and educational leaders will hear 100 inspirational addresses by outstanding clergymen of this and other countries at the fifty-fifth annual Northfield General Conference for Christian workers at East Northfield, Mass., which will open tonight and continue until Aug. 12.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Quick development of definite work relief projects for actors, artisans, writers and musicians was promised today with the appointment by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, of four technical assistants to direct "white collar" programs in the major arts.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -- Keg-makers charged today that Treasury liquor regulations had given an "absolute monopoly" to the glass bottle industry.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Presidential approval of an allotment of $4,657,251 of work relief funds for a long list of Works Progress Administration projects in New Jersey, was announced today by the Division of Applications and Information. These projects were among $5,813,234 worth recommended by the Advisory Committee on Allotments July 16.

LONDON, July 26. -- Stocks were more cheerful today on the London Stock Exchange with the resumption of investment buying of British Government issues. British railways were unaffected by two more dividend declarations.

Again Representative HUDDLESTON of Alabama is guilty of contumacy. A member of the House conference committee on the Utilities Bill, he objects to the presence in the conference room of two Federal legal experts while the committee is in executive session. Experts may be within call in the anteroom, but they musn't be admitted into the temple chamber.

Prices of most commodity futures were lower on the local markets yesterday, despite strength in wheat and cotton. On the cash markets, all the grains, cotton and tin advanced, while silk, rubber and printcloths were easier.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- A. spectacular air stunting exhibition ended today in the death of Duane Howard, 32 years old, a transport pilot and instructor at Sky Harbor Airport, near Northbrook, Ill., and his passenger, Virginia Thomas, 17 years old, of Berwyn, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia.

Two home runs by Heinie Manush, one of them in the seventh inning with the bases full, figured prominently in the 9-to-3 victory recorded by the Senators over the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday as the McCarthymen dropped from the American League leadership into second position.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, July 26. -- The conflict between Danzig's National Socialist Government and Poland over the foreign exchange and customs control questions, behind which lies the issue of whether Germany or Poland shall control the Free City, reached a complete deadlock today.

Special graduation exercises will be held for John Ulrich, 16-year-old boy of Brooklyn, at his bedside at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Centre by the East River, where he is putting up a fight against the ravages of leukemia, a serious blood disease.
Nobody was in a hurry yesterday to decide what to do with Bertrand Coles Neidecker and his brothers Aubrey and George, three Americans who are wanted by the French Government.

President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman have been invited to address the regular biennial convention of the Union of Democratic Clubs of Hew York State in Binghamton on Sept. 21, it was announced yesterday by the Democratic State Committee.

WHITE MOUNTANIS, N.H., July 26. -- Today, one of the season's clearest days, hundreds of visitors ascended Mount Washington by cogwheel railway, several special trains being sent up in addition to regular service. Others motored from Glen over the eight-mile motor road and the trails leading from Randolph, Pinkham Notch camps, Bretton Woods and Crawford Notch were used by many climbers.

Unemployed workers in June were estimated yesterday at 9,804,000 by the National Industrial Conference Board, whose monthly survey showed that this was an increase of 95,000, or 1 per cent, over May. The board further stated that the number of unemployed in June was 552,000, or 6 per cent, higher than in June, 1934.

Passenger traffic on eastbound ships in the transatlantic trade is setting at least one new record this season. Although total carryings are not up to the figures reported during the best years of the pre-depression period, the eastbound season has carried throughout July and bookings for August indicate that sailings will be heavier than for the corresponding month in several years.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The number of families on relief in the nation dropped 270,061 between May and June, and the cost of caring for the needy declined $18,483,581, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, stated today.

More than 10,000 children in 487 special classes passed the school year 1934-35 under the supervision of the Bureau for Children with Retarded Mental Development of the Board of Education. In its annual report, made public yesterday, the bureau further points out that it directed the activities of a psycho-educational clinic, which takes care of the more difficult cases of disabilities.

Now that the heat wave has -- for the nonce, at least -- been broken, and frayed dispositions somewhat mended, hopeful visionaires can look forward with a reasonable amount of assurance to the approach of Fall, cool weather and -- happy prospect! -- the new, temptingly suggested revue which will adorn the spacious stage of the French Casino.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 26. -- A "thinking" amplifier for dynamics was described today by Dr. John Hays Hammond Jr., radio engineer and scientist, as one of the most important parts of his new sound-reproducing system on which the Patent Office granted eighteen patents yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 26. -- In the presence of a great throng, Governor Lehman formally opened the new State-owned Saratoga Spa today. Standing in front of the steps leading to the new Hall of Springs, the Governor looked out across a green esplanade over a small lake reflecting the green arches of a mighty elm.

Postponed from Thursday night because of bad weather, Verdi's "La Traviata" was accorded the first of its two scheduled performances at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, with the second announced for tonight. An audience of about 5,200 applauded a cast almost entirely American, and one that had youth as a predisposing factor in its favor.

Many assert that the United States Supreme Court has usurped the power to invalidate an act of Congress. Of course, the unthinking and irresponsible among our people will be influenced by this argument; but those who take the trouble to think through the situation realize that there is nothing to the argument.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 26. -- The hull of the former America's Cup defender Enterprise, stored at the Herreshoff Manufacturing Company's yard at Bristol since the Fall of 1930, was sold today to Louis Lubchansky, a New London dealer in metals.

The list of the French liner Champlain, leaving today for Plymouth and Havre, includes Dana Pond, portrait painter; Mrs. Jacques Brugere, wife of the French Minister to Canada; Judge Maja Leon Berry, Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, Mrs. Alfred A. Knopf, Le Grand B. Cannon, Judge and Mrs. James E. Chenot, Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Frothingham, Gabriel de la Campa, Cuban consul general at Ottawa; John Reynolds and Miss Beatrice Mathieu.

Alfred Otto Wagner, the ex-convict who attempted to "chisel in" on important kidnapping cases by writing ransom notes, was sentenced to twenty years in a Federal prison by Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., July 26. -- After winning the medal yesterday with a magnificent 72, a performance that was obscured by Babe Ruth's 81, William J. Tobin of the Plandome Golf Club on Long Island had to win the last hole today in order to remain in the running in the Westchester Country Club invitation tournament.

BERLIN, July 26. -- A certain nervousness and apprehension are distinctly noticeable in Berlin tonight, but in recording the fact there is difficulty in ascribing it to any reasons that do not seem foolish. One reason would be that tomorrow is Saturday, a day memorable in the Nazi chronology for serious happenings. June 30 last year was a Saturday.

On the right-hand side of the page Congress is thinking up new taxes to soak Big Business. On the left-hand side of the page Big Business emits piercing outcries of warning against the Foreign Menace. On the right-hand side people quote untold billions to come out of the pockets of the rich; which glowing billions the quoters in their heart of hearts know to be remote.

While kneeling before the coffin of her father, a young woman and her uncle were shot, the latter fatally wounded, yesterday morning. Their assailant escaped. He was described as Alfred Ortiz, 35, a former business partner of the dead man, Martin Alfano, and a rejected suitor of his daughter.

BERLIN, July 26. -- The Vatican protested today in a formal note against recent anti-Catholic ordinances and declarations of the Reich Government and Nazi party functionaries. The note was presented at the Foreign Ministry by the Papal Nuncio, Archbishop Cesare Orsenigo.
Changes in amounts of listed securities as reported to the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange follow:

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A major Congressional battle was forecast today with the authoritative word that the Democratic drafters of the new Tax Bill, following President Roosevelt's expressed desire, would not include in it a proposed clause to let a corporation deduct up to 5 per cent of its taxable income for gifts to charities.

KINGSTON, Ont., July 26 (AP). -The Conewago of the Rochester Yacht Club, skippered by W.V. Castle, came through with a convincing victory in the eight-meter class to win the Commodore George H. Gooderham Cup as the Lake Yacht Racing Association regatta was concluded at the Kingston Yacht Club today.

AKRON, Ohio, July 26 (AP). -- Professor A.V. DeForest, a member of the eight-man commission appointed by Secretary Swanson to investigate the cause of the loss of the dirigible Macon, said today that the United States Navy was responsible for the crash.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 26. -- The Railroad Cooperative Building and Loan Association, 441 Lexington Avenue, New York, has become the Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, the State Banking Department announced today. This change was made under Section 197 of the Banking Law.

Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Jersey City today decided the officers and directors of the Great Western Sugar Company acted within their rights in the purchase for $9,000,000 of stock in the Cache la Poudre Corporation, an investment trust.
Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing is the editor of a new monthly magazine, Prison Life Stories, the first issue of which comes out today.
BERLIN, July 26. -- The Boerse was quiet and irregular today, due largely to uncertainty over the international currency situation.

Whether with entire sincerity or not, MUSSOLINI has been indicating a desire to arrive at a peaceful settlement with Ethiopia. He offered to revive the Conciliation Commission and to add a fifth member to it. But the Emperor of Ethiopia has apparently rejected this proffer.

BERLIN, July 26. -- In order to make his "new plan" of import control more effective, Economics Minister Hjalmal Schacht today issued a new order instructing German customs authorities to bar certain imports for which importers are unable to produce foreign exchange allotment certificates or appropriate substitute documents.

PARIS, July 26 (AP). -- Bigger and better figures will have a leading place in the 1936 fashion shows starting July 29, say designers. Busts and hips are being talked about and something faintly reminiscent of the old wasp waist was forecast as the dressmakers staged final fittings on manikins with well-rounded curves.

A more flexible working schedule than that followed under the NRA forty-hour week may be adopted gradually by the automobile industry in response to a request by workers for longer hours, so that they may earn more, according to a statement issued by Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association and of the Packard Motor Car Company.

LENOX, Mass., July 26. -- The Moreland Stables, owned by Miss Elmina and William Brewster of Durham, Conn., swept the thoroughbred hunter class at the opening of the two-day tenth annual Lenox Horse Show today.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Hoyt and Mr. and Mrs. Lindsley V. Dodge gave a party here tonight at the home of Mrs. Dodge prior to a dinner dance, arranged by the Eastern Westchester Maternal Health Committee for the benefit of the Maternal Health Centre of Port Chester, at the Westchester Embassy Club in Armonk, N.Y.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

To the visitor fresh from "the sticks" the New Yorker seems strange and improbable. Strangest of all is his easy acceptance of the chaotic crowds and his self-accommodation to them. He moves among them unaware of their threat to dwarf him, to blot out his individuality.

BOSTON, July 26. -- Colonel Edward Mandell House, adviser to two Presidents and prominent in the world of diplomacy, revealed today for the first time that the first draft of the League of Nations covenant was written at Magnolia. It was at the time he was spending the Summer at the cottage of the T. Jefferson Coolidge estate there.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26. -- Frank Parker's first venture in singles of the season on turf ended in the disappointment of a lost opportunity today in the semi-final round of the invitation fixture of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- The Marshall Field Co. merchandise express came back to this city today with orders exceeding $500,000 actually booked on its 3,455-mile trip through the South. Business in process of confirmation will probably boost the sales total by $100,000 more.

PARIS, July 26. -- Two American women, Mrs. Thomas J. Harris and Miss Charlotte M. Lockwood, were hurt in a motor accident this afternoon on the national road between Chalons-sur-Marne and Sainte Menehould. Their auto was in a collision with another at a crossroad.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The mysterious "box wrapped in newspaper." upon which for three days the Senate Lobby Committee's investigation has been centred, was a box of fifty five-cent cigars, "and may God strike me dead if that's not the whole truth," Representative Patton of Texas told the committee today.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 26 (Canadian Press). -- Johnny Coulson, who wants the diamond sculls as much as his towering club-mate, Charlie Campbell of the Toronto Argonauts, raced to a sparkling triumph today in the fifty-third Royal Canadian Henley's Association singles and qualified to face Campbell tomorrow for the senior championship.
The demonstrators on the liner Bremen handed out the following circular:

Donald A. Brown, for twelve years a teller in the Bowery Savings Bank branch at 130 Bowery, was found dead at 10:35 A.M. yesterday in the cellar of his home at 6,217 Avenue T, Brooklyn, from two self-inflicted bullet wounds. A shortage in his accounts had been discovered.

Mayor La Guardia supported his contention that the German Government discriminates against Americans yesterday by producing copies of five State Department press releases, each of which complained of discrimination against American holders of German bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A gloomy account of conditions in France in June, with volume of industry and trade remaining at a low level, accompanied by a "feeling of extreme nervousness" by the public on the monetary situation, was given today by the Commerce Department in its weekly report on business in our foreign markets.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A protest against the persecution of Jews in Germany was made to William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, today by a delegation representing a number of Jewish organizations who referred also to the "reign of terror" exercised against Catholics, Protestants and liberals by the Nazi government.

PEORIA, Ill., July 26. -- All Central Illinois cities tonight were called into a search for two bandits who escaped after a gun battle with police in a payroll robbery in the heart of Peoria about noon.

Despite an exchange of cablegrams and transatlantic telephone talks, Max Schmeling kept both the Twentieth Century Sporting Club and Madison Square Garden waiting yesterday while he angled for terms to decide whether he would fight Joe Louis or Max Baer here in September.

ALBANY, July 26. -- An appeal was made today to the Federal Government by Governor Lehman for a continuance of the use of CCC workers in the State's flooded area. In a telegram to Robert Fechner, director of the emergency conservation work, the Governor declared continued employment of the workers under the Soil Erosion Service is imperative.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The easy passage of the Banking Bill may obscure the fact that in this instance the Senate rejected noiselessly as major a New Deal tenet as the House, with sound and fury, did when it refused to vote the "death sentence" for holding companies.

" Ta-Ra-Ra-Boom-De-Ay," a popular song of the Nineties, made world famous by Lottie Collins, was composed by the late Henry J. Sayers, former minstrel manager and bandmaster, the Jerry Vogel Music Company, Inc., of 112 West Forty-fourth Street, informed THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday in a letter.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 26. -- First one and then a second of the five speed boats entered in tomorrow's thirty-second running of the famous Gold Cup classic came to grief tonight at the end of a hectic day to throw into more uncertainty the outcome of America's blue ribbon motor-boat event.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 26. -- A final spirited practice session today put America's Davis Cup warriors in fighting trim for tomorrow's big push when they encounter England's twin destroyers, Fred Perry and Bunny Austin, in the opening singles matches of the challenge round.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 26. -The twelfth annual regatta of the Edgartown Yacht Club opened today with two New York yachts, Prestige and Priscilla III, and the Swedish craft Lill-Singva scoring victories in the feature events. The races were sailed in a 12-knot northeast breeze under a fair sky, with a fleet of 152 boats on hand.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The increasing difficulty experienced by France and the other gold bloc countries in trying to stay on gold and the bloc's loss of $1,000,000,000 in gold within three months were recorded by the Federal Reserve Board today in its monthly bulletin.

MEXICO, D.F., July 26 (AP). -- Reports from the State of Chihuahua tonight said Governor Rodrigo Quevedo was confronted with the demands of a large group of agrarians who had arrived in the capital to lodge a protest with the National Revolutionary party headquarters against his administration.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The controversial order of Secretary Ickes permitting only a 15 per cent differential in buying material for the $4,000,000,000 work program is in conflict with an order by Rear Admiral Christian J. Peoples, U.S.N., chief government procurement agent, fixing a 25 per cent differential, it became known today.
Money market was dull and with only a light demand for funds the quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.

MALONE, N.Y., July 26. -- Abe (Bo) Weinberg and Moe Margolese, two of the four men in Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's beer legion who were jailed by Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant yesterday to assure their appearance as government witnesses, were released today after they had testified to practically nothing.
BAYSIDE, L.I., July 26. -- Nineteen out of twenty-four craft entered in the Bayside Yacht Club's race out around Block Island and back started this noon from the mouth of Little Neck Bay.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The confidential nature of the work involved caused Governor Lehman and the State Civil Service Board to exempt yesterday all positions to be filled under Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in New York City's racket inquiry, from civil service requirements.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP). -- The Tigers cleared all doubts about their status in the American League pennant race which had been left after their series with the Yankees by routing the Indians, 8 to 2, in the series opener today and taking first place.

At the midsummer season the news inevitably reveals a variety of deeds performed by lightning -- some tragic, some spectacular, some freakish. Within the past week or two lightning fires and lightning fatalities have been of normal hot-weather frequency.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Application for registration of $5,500,000 of 4 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures, due 1950, and 60,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Champion Coated Paper Company of Hamilton, Ohio, the commission announced today.

I have been interested in the plight of the building and construction industry since the advent of the depression, and your recent editorial on prefabricated housing has brought several thoughts to my mind.

PANAMA, R.P., July 27. -- No common cause has been found for suicides of American soldiers at Fort Clayton, according to a headquarter's report of the findings on the investigation of four cases of suicide and one of attempted suicide at Fort Clayton.

On receipt of a cablegram from Max Schmeling yesterday demanding new and better terms to fight Joe Louis here, Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club definitely broke off negotiations with the former heavyweight champion and turned his attention to getting another opponent for the Detroit Negro for Sept. 11.

RYE, N.Y., July 27. -- Young Charley Mayo Jr., bantamweight amateur golf champion of Long Island, added the Westchester Country Club invitation tournament honors to his list of 1935 conquests today when he defeated Fred Mayer, home club representative, 6 and 4, in the final eighteen-hole round.

SIR WILLIAM BEACH THOMAS, author of "Yeoman's England," has written a new book called "Village England" which will bring delight to every nature lover. In many respects Sir William is reminiscent of our own John Burroughs, who was no naturalist in the laboratory sense of the term, but wrote of the creatures of garden and woodland with the warmth and affection of a patient and observant friend.

IN a sense this book -- a group of stories and sketches collected from Stark Young's published work during the past seven or eight years -- forms a kind of footnote to his memorable novel, "So Red the Rose." This is perhaps its chief claim to significance.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Intimations come from the local meat-packing industry that several of the biggest concerns are seriously considering joining forces with those who, in legal battles, have been assailing the AAA processing taxes. The present attacking line includes a number of the smaller packers, millers, food products companies, cigar manufacturers and textile makers.
During its short life the League of Nations has faced many hard problems; none has presented more difficulties than the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, which the League Council must tackle this week.

A STATEMENT that was correctly quoted, yet misleading in its implications, was printed last week by THE TIMES, which gave some readers the impression that the Stadium concerts, because of an unexpected withdrawal by the city of a donation of $10,000, faced suspension.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- Advantages of unifying railroad terminals in four New York cities, and railroad facilities in other localities, are being studied by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal transportation coordinator.

DECISION of the Contest Board of the American Automobile Association to allow superchargers on racing cars at Indianapolis in 1936 has recentred attention on this mechanism after a lapse of five years. The decision made by the rules committee here last week also removes all restrictions on engine design.

NOW that the slump is receding and the stream of tourist traffic has returned to its normal volume, motoring, hiking and touring by air are proving more popular than ever. All three are now so well organized that European red tape and language troubles have lost their terrors.

HORNELL, N.Y., July 27. -- One of the most dramatic stories of the flood in Southern New York is told by R.H. Carter, an electrician, who probably was the last man to make the cross-State trip from Kingston, on the Hudson River, to Hornell, before the flood began.

In unusually heavy trading for a Saturday, the share market advanced briskly yesterday under the leadership of the steel and automotive issues to a substantially higher closing. Gains ranged from fractions to 2 3/4 points. On the Stock Exchange, trading aggregated 734,240 shares, the heaviest for a half-day period since June 22; the Saturday before business amounted to 429,000 shares.

Although the national swimming championships last week produced no startling times in the sprints or breast-stroke, the middle distance, back-stroke and diving events provided such a wealth of promising material that America's continued supremacy in international competition would seem to be fairly well assured.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y. -- Sailboat races are scheduled today, both morning and afternoon, at the Lake George Club. These events are held in connection with the Gold Cup Regatta, a three-day affair which they bring to a conclusion.

LONDON. IN November, 1933, it was announced that henceforth the King would offer every year a gold and a silver medal for poetry in the English language published in volume form within the empire by British citizens.

A proposal for the establishment of a Federal service to encourage tourist travel within the United States, which has been submitted both to the Senate and the House, has been received favorably by steamship operations and tourist agents.

According to a news dispatch, the New Jersey Planning Board is busy indicting the Little Red School House again. It is reported that educators are agreed that the attainment of satisfactory educational standards is all but impossible in small one-teacher rural schools.

The Federal Land Banks, which started operations before even the first post-war depression and went along for several years in normal competition with private lending institutions, have not been greatly harassed by borrowers who expect unbusinesslike concessions from an institution controlled by the government.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 27. -- The Delhi polo team moved into the second round of the Hempstead Cups tournament on Waterbury Field of the Meadow Brook Club today when it turned back Bethpage, 11 to 5, in a game marked by accidents.

THE Passion Play of Roquebrune, a half-deserted and crumbling hill-town on the French Riviera between Nice and Menton, has been running for 468 years without missing a performance. Only one performance of it is given each year, but in point of a record on this basis it is the world's longest-run play. It is 167 years older than the Oberammergau Passion Play.

THE judging of the model traveling coaches submitted by boys of New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the apprentice class competition of the Fisher Body 'Craftsman's Guild will begin next Thursday. Preliminary inspection by the judges will take place at the Manhattan warehouse at Fifty-second Street and Seventh Avenue, and final decisions will be made at the American Museum of Natural History.

In a highly vaulted chamber in the phantom court of the House of Hapsburg at Steenockerzeel, on the outskirts of Brussels, perhaps twoscore men and women talk in excited whispers. The wide red stripes on the trousers of some of the older men indicate their rank as generals of the former Austro-Hungarian Army.

Teachers College enjoyed all the excitement of an organized man-hunt on a small scale yesterday as search was made for a male teacher from the State of Nevada willing to serve on the committee of 100 which is making final arrangements for the annual men's steak dinner, to be held Saturday.

The figures collected by the Research Bureau of the Welfare Council of this city have the advantage that they cover practically all local relief expenditures, public and private, from whatever source obtained, and that they go back to the beginning of the depression. Consequently the charts published elsewhere in today's TIMES, based on these figures, give a clear picture of the trends in this great humanitarian venture.

Referring to William L. Laurence's article on the age of the earth in the July 21 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I notice that cosmogonists are very much concerned with taking their choice betwen the so-called short-time scale, ranging from one to ten billion years, and the long-time scale, ranging from 1,000,000,000,000 to 10,000,000,000,000 years for the age of our galaxy.

MOSCOW, July 27. -- A striking increase in the production of foodstuffs, together with a substantial drop in prices, was shown today in a survey published by the People's Commissariat for the Food Industry. It is asserted that average food prices in ten chief cities of the Soviet Union have declined 53 per cent in the past two years after rising steadily throughout the first Five-Year-Plan.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 27. -- The dawn, not the censor, stopped the Artists' Ball. But that does not mean that the scanty attire promised for the Beachcombers' twentieth annual event was not prevalent.

Hoping to end what they describe as an outstanding injustice of the Tariff Act, importers here yesterday pledged solid support to a measure introduced in both houses of Congress last week. The bill, reputed to be backed by the administration, would amend Section 516b of the Tariff Act, under which domestic interests are able to tie up liquidation of imported products through protesting against the rates assessed.

PROGRESS is reported on three routes in New Jersey. Road work on the by-pass at Somerville on Route 31, extending 1.83 miles, will be completed in September, but delay over the Jersey Central Railroad Bridge will hold up opening of the $300,000 improvement until next Spring.

MEN often do better than they plan or plan better than they do. This truism is well illustrated by the activities of governments, perhaps especially by the larger experimental and emergency activities of the United States Government as they apply to art.

With official reports indicating bumper crops throughout the country, the total pack of commercial canned vegetables and fruits this year is expected to reach the largest volume in the history of the industry, depending on the weather during the next three months, when the bulk of the pack will be made.

Now that the Columbia Y.C. is again operating from its base on the former Percy R. Pyne estate in Riverdale, its genial commodore, Dr. John A. Harriss, former Special Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of traffic in New York City, is making ambitious plans for the organization.

THE motor car has widened the scope of the vacationist in Berlin, making easily accessible famous dining places, old parks and hostels that once were reached only after a day of travel. Like most German cities, Berlin finds much of its pleasure in the out-of-doors, in beer gardens and parks.

FOUR advances in radio transmission for airmen have been registered at a Bureau of Air Commerce radio station at Pittsburgh, which is now undergoing practical service trials. This broadcast and radio range beacon station transmits voice and directional signals simultaneously.

GENEVA, July 27. -- The United States national group of the Permanent Court of Arbitration (World Court) has notified the League of Nations that it nominates to succeed Mineichiro Adachi on the court two Japanese -- Haruichi Nagaoka, former Ambassador to Paris, and Dr. Saburo Yamada, president of the Keijo Imperial University.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The influence of the New York State government was thrown here today against the bulk sale of whisky permitted in the new Liquor Control Bill passed by the House.

WITH the issuance of an executive order by the President doubling the number of CCC camps and extending the enrolment to 600,000, the CCC educational forces have quickened their pace to meet new demands.

THE very title of this book, its author remarks, would arouse a storm of protest in China today, where Confucianism is offensive to the new generation, and "to link 'Confucianism' with 'Modern China' is therefore an undeserved honor for Confucianism and an insult to modern China."

The ninth annual Summer championships of the American Bridge League which annually attract hundreds of contract bridge players from all over the country to the Convention Hall at Asbury Park, N.J., will begin on Monday, Aug. 5.

WOODSTOCK, N.Y. -- The colony, fully recovered from the temporary setback of the flood in the early part of the month, has resumed again its many social activities. The most prominent of these at the present time is the Woodstock Artists Association's third annual exhibition, which opened July 13 at the art gallery.

The improvement in prices of industrial shares during the week just completed, despite the intermittent waves of profit-taking, scarcely indicated that followers of the market have been greatly concerned with political developments in the nation's capital as they related to the financial scene.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP). -- The third place White Sox came to town today and battered their way through three of Manager Rogers Hornsby's pitchers for an 8-to-5 victory over the Browns, opening a short home stand.

MANILA. -- The candidacy of Bishop Gregorio Aglipay is furnishing much of the comic relief in the current Philippine pre-election campaign. It is a foregone conclusion that Manuel Quezon will be elected President of the forthcoming Commonwealth Government, but Bishop Aglipay's statements are a picturesque interpellation in what has been for years a cut-and-dried political system.

One of the world's most scenic lakes is in the making behind Boulder Dam in the Black Canyon on the Colorado, where the river forms a boundary between the States of Arizona and Nevada. Reaches of canyons that never have been visited by white men are being opened to easy approach as the water slowly backs up stream to make what is already the largest artificial lake anywhere.

EDMUND GOSSE put his finger (or rather, as those who knew him would say, his claw) on the trouble with Clare's poetry when he wrote apropos the poetry of Edmund Blunden, one of Clare's recent admirers and disciples: "That he is tinder the spell of John Clare is evident; and is curious, since Clare never boasted a disciple before.

PEIPING. -- New regulation promulgated by Yuan Liang, Mayor of Peiping, are designed to prevent the assigning of contiguous apartments to men and women who are not married. They stipulate that should an apartment house have two courtyards one shall be for men and the other for women.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 27. -- Victorious in their first two rounds of match play, Max Marston of Philadelphia and Bobby Grant of Wethersfield, Conn., tonight seemed headed straight for a meeting in the finals of the sixteenth annual Shenecossett men's invitation tournament.

With what ease and safety tenants may vacate a modern skyscraper where fire occurs was vividly demonstrated last week. Two thousand persons filed out in good order from the fifty-story office building of the General Electric Company at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street, at the top of which a restaurant was filled with flames and smoke due to electrical insulation trouble.

Assured that the Northeastern section of the United States, which normally furnishes close to 50 per cent of all home furnishings volume, is due to buy on a scale comparable with other parts of the country, manufacturers of furniture, rugs, lamps and other home wares items yesterday prepared for the largest Fall season since 1929.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Chief of Detectives Sullivan announced tonight that Lieutenant Otto Erianson and Assistant State's Attorney Charles S. Dougherty would leave immediately for New York to bring back Evelyn Smith, who was arrested there this afternoon in connection with the murder of Ervin Lang in Chicago early this month.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27. -- Speaking to the Yugoslav Senate today, Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch declared emphatically that Yugoslavia was opposed to any attempt at a Hapsburg restoration in Austria or Hungary and revealed that Austria had given satisfactory reassurances on the subject.

OTTAWA, July 25. -- This week found the Conservative party, for the first time since Canadian confederation, out of office in every Province of the Dominion. What is more, in one of them -- Prince Edward Island -- it was denied even the cold comfort of being in opposition in Tuesday's election, which achieved a record of choosing a Parliament made up entirely of Liberals.

Joseph Lewis quotes from Montesquieu against government interference in business, but Montesquieu quotes Libanius as saying that at "Athens a stranger who intermeddled in the assemblies of the people was punished with death." "This is because," he says, "in a democracy such a man usurped the rights of sovereignty."

Greatly encouraged by the sharp revival of retail trade during this month, with gains in many sections ranging up to 30 per cent, stores completed most of their initial Fall buying last week with expectations that volume in the final four months of the year would exceed earlier estimates of a 10 per cent rise.

So great has been the increase in interest this year that the American Kennel Club now is looking forward to having a total of 70,000 registrations by the end of the year, setting a new all-time record. This compares with the 60,200 registered last year and which is the present all-time mark.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- In an order issued today to all employes connected with the investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Chairman Walker of the telephone division of the Federal Communications Commission warned them to decline to accept any favors of gifts from company officials or employes.

The Quarterly Bulletin of the Department of Health, to be issued this week, contains the first complete directory of clinical laboratories in New York City to be published for four years, it was said yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

THE American worker doesn't want to overthrow the government, but unless the government sees to it that he gets his daily bread he may overthrow it "without realizing that he is doing so." This is John L. Spivak's conclusion, after a pretty thorough inspection of the trouble spots between the two oceans.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The proposal of the Treasury Department to renew coinage of pieces representing fractions of one cent revives a precedent set by this government over a period of seventy-five years, during which half-cents were a part of the standard coinage.

Credit and collection conditions in Latin-American countries showed substantial gains in the second quarter of this year, according to the report compiled for business concerns yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

HULBERT FOOTNER has assembled a good many ingredients familiar to a romantic adventure goulash, combined them with the hand of a skilled if uninspired chef and now serves up his dish to the public for $2 per plate for their delectation.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Bull fever in the wheat markets today resulted in an upturn that did not culminate until the May future here and all deliveries in Kansas City and Minneapolis had advanced 5 cents a bushel from Friday's finish, the maximum permitted or one day's upturn.

Paintings by five artists -- Morris Cantor, Harold Weston, Alice Stallnecht, Frederick Wight and Henry Varnum Poor, together with pottery by Mr. Poor -- will be the exhibition at the gallery of Ann Hamilton Sayre, at Wellfleet, on Cape Cod, beginning Sunday, Aug. 4, and continuing for three weeks.

RENO. ALTHOUGH in size not more than a small town and in economics no more than a provincial capital, Reno is significant to thousands of Americans. Increasingly, since an occasional daring individual came here in an older generation to obtain freedom, Reno has become associated with divorce.
For the second consecutive day New York's millions enjoyed somewhat cooler weather yesterday, a welcome relief to the previous three weeks of sweltering heat.

Stimulated by a sharp advance in wheat and a strong stock markets, further covering of October contracts on the Cotton Exchange yesterday improved near-month quotations 10 points, but efforts to take profits toward the close left the list unchanged to 10 points lower than on Friday.

QUEBEC. -- Celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of La Tuque, which came into being largely as the result of United States capital, is the highlight of the coming week's social activities for United States tourists to Quebec.

NOW that Lee Shubert has returned from his play-buying safari into the heart of Shaftesbury Avenue, Forty-fourth Street is becoming an active sort of place. A scout, prowling quietly over there of a Thursday, unearthed the following codicils to the Shubert plans for 1935-36.

OMAHA, July 25. -- The Corn Belt presents at this time a vastly changed appearance from that of a year ago. Then the prevailing hue was the brown of bare earth, dried pasture and meadow, or dusty roadside. Now it is the green of growing crops alternating with the yellow of the small grain harvest.

State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday the completion of the necessary legal requirements to enable War Department engineers to commence operation to straighten, widen and deepen the Harlem Ship Canal between the Hudson River and Broadway.

SAN FRANCISCO. -- California's experiment in lending money to veterans for home and farm purchase at low rates of interest and easy terms of repayment has been a complete success, according to the State Veterans Welfare Board.

Saratoga's thirty-day meeting, the high spot of the racing year to many thousands, will get under way tomorrow, and run until Aug. 31. During this time approximately $300,000 will be distributed to horsemen. President George H. Bull is authority for the statement that the up-State course has the brightest prospects in many years.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 27. -- Great Britain took an iron grip on the Davis Cup today for the third successive year by defeating the American team soundly and squarely in the first two matches of the challenge round.

American motor boat racing is being challenged by a vast and rapidly growing interest in Europe, according to Commodore Harry B. Greening of Hamilton, Ont., veteran officer of the American Power Boat Association and member of its racing commission and its international contest board.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 (AP). Survivors told today of the wreck of a movie barge from which twenty-six persons were flung into the ocean, one to die, during the filming of a sea picture.

WHEN Allaire West "blazed across his life like a rocket." Terry Willett was opening a river in South America to traffic by engineering a system of locks. He didn't care about opening the river so much as he did about finishing a job his father had begun.

ONCE again the tiny islands of St. Pierre et Miquelon sit in sad contemplation of the past's romantic glories. Theirs has always been the true gambler's life, with either nothing or plenty, and the wheel just now is down, definitely down.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27. -- After years of endeavor Gregory S. Mangin of Newark was rewarded today with his first leg on the Seabright bowl.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 25. -- When the front pages of the nation's newspapers blossomed forth last Monday with stories of a general strike in this city "On the Banks of the Wabash," the effect on the reader was as if an explosion had occurred without warning. But there were numerous preliminaries.

Merchandise lines in the average department store or specialty shop which will reach one of the three peak periods of the year during the month of August include fur coats, furniture, luggage and domestics, according to the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 27. -- Two Manhattan units of the New York National Guard, the 107th Infantry and the 244th Coast Artillery, completed today two weeks' Summer training at Camp Smith, here.
ST. LOUIS, July 27. -- Reports of plant additions and betterments were a significant feature of last week's business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District.

The favorable reporting of a House bill for the regulation of omnibuses and trucks, which repeats the provisions of a bill passed in the Senate, is seen by railway men as not only holding out hope for an improvement of competitive conditions in the field of transport, but as an augury of greater safety on the highways.

WITH the conclusion tonight of Jose Iturbi's series of concerts, the Lewisohn Stadium Summer series will enter upon its second period, the week bringing back Willem van Hoogstraten for his fourteenth consecutive Summer as one of the conductors at the Stadium.

Millions of men and women who have invested their savings in utility securities are asking the question: "Are these savings to be destroyed because a few minor utility officials have resorted to scandalous and even dishonest methods in opposing the Public Utilities Bill? Is the small utility investor to be penalized and the industry to be crippled because of isolated incidents of this kind?"

RADIO in this Summer season has developed a new vogue; there are standpatters on the air. Mindful that the productive hours at the microphone are measured by the clock and that there are only so many despite the demand, sponsors this year are carefully guarding their favored spots on the air by substitute talent while the star performers vacation.
HELENA, Mont., July 25. -- Marriages are nearly as prevalent in Montana as they were before the "gin marriage law" went into effect, July 1.

Serge Prokofieff, who is now in Russia, is at work on a new ballet, "Romeo and Juliet," which was commissioned by the Bolshoi Theatre of Moscow and which he has promised to deliver on Sept. 15, according to a letter received from the composer by E.F. Gottlieb in New York.

MR. FINNEY has entered a field of humor pretty well pre-empted by the late Thorne Smith, who established quite a business with a series of volumes in which statues came to life and animals talked and all sorts of persons cut all sorts of rowdy and bawdy capers.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- Dr. W. Montague Cobb of Howard and Western Reserve Universities said today an examination of Jesse Owens, Ohio State University track star, reveals that industry, training, incentive and outstanding courage rather than physical characteristics are responsible for the young Negro sprinter's accomplishments.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP). -- Robert C. Byers, 42, of Columbus, has thirty-six days in which to whet his appetite on workhouse fare for a dinner, the stakes in a publicity wager which he won through a kidnap hoax.

PITTSBURGH, July 26. -- Marking time while waiting for the next move in the soft coal situation, two operators here suggested that maybe, if no other solution is found, the industry may have to resort to a dictatorship, as baseball and the movie business have done.

Submission of voluntary agreements on fair trade practices to the Federal Trade Commission will probably be held off by the majority of industries for the next four to six weeks, until the commission announces its stand on the program drawn up by wholesale tobacco distributers, the first to be taken under consideration, it was indicated here yesterday.

HIKERS, campers and picnickers going into the fields and woods of the metropolitan area often run across snakes and to most city dwellers these reptiles constitute a feared and unknown factor. While most of the snakes to be encountered are harmless, a little knowledge of them, and a few precautions taken in advance, can do much to render excursions pleasanter and considerably safer.
In the light of recent decisions of Federal courts and occasional clashes between State and Federal powers, an understanding of our unique dual form of government becomes unusually important.

AT the outset Professor Knight proclaims the warning that he is under no illusion about the rank James Lane Allen, "the last champion of the Genteel Tradition," occupies in the Republic of Letters. As a writer, he frankly admits, he was never of the first class.

Mrs. Evelyn B. Smith, 46 years old, sought for more than two weeks on a charge by Chicago police that she murdered the son-in-law of a friend for a fee of $500, was arrested yesterday at 329 West Thirty-fourth Street and held by the police as a fugitive from justice.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- President Roosevelt for the next few weeks will hold bachelor hall in the White House, due to the closing down of the kitchen of the Executive Mansion while an entirely new electrical kitchen with latest equipment is being installed.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP). -- Black Highbrow, heavily favored gelding carrying the red and white colors of Mrs. Edward Haughton of Texas, accounted for the $3,500 added Bay State feature of six furlongs for 2-year-olds today at Suffolk Downs. A record throng estimated at more than 45,000 witnessed the races.

DETROIT, the city that first attacked the problem of handling traffic cases by establishing a separate court for them, has found the answer to another question that had the authorities stumped for some time. The question is, how can the gospel of safe driving be preached to the general public in such a manner as to draw and hold its interest.

Discussions as to the need for continued curtailment of cotton goods production were revived last week and a maintenance of the 25 per cent reduction program appears indicated for August at least, selling agents said yesterday. Many important mill executives are due here this week, primarily for a discussion on processing tax clauses, but it is also expected that they will take up the question of curtailment.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., July 27. -- The Rev. Dr. Paul E. Scherer, minister of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, New York City, made the opening address tonight at the fifty-fifth Northfield general conference of Christian workers convening here for two weeks under the chairmanship of the Rev. Dr. Paul Dwight Moody, son of the evangelist and founder of the Northfield Schools, Dwight L. Moody.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 27. -- Graduates of the first officers' training camp, held here in 1915, began gathering at the Plattsburg Barracks here this afternon and tonight for a reunion to mark the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the training regiment of 1,300 men sponsored by the late Major Gen. Leonard Wood.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Asheville's eighth annual Mountain Folk Festival and the thirteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Biltmore Forest Golf and County Club will feature the calendar here this week.

GENEVA, July 27. -- Maxim M. Litvinoff of Russia, as president of the League of Nations Council, today convoked it for 5 P.M. July 31 after receiving a puzzling telegram signed by Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy.

Encouraged by their conference with members of the Association of American Railroads last week, representatives of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel will resume their study of the Eastman recommendations to the carriers this week, Benjamin Schwartz, director general of the scrap organization, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP). -- The Athletics and Red Sox played well into the evening in dividing a double-header today. The Mackmen won the first game, 7 to 6, in fifteen innings, the visitors taking the second 2 to 0.

The article by "Old Timer" in a recent issue of THE TIMES, pointing out how very few of the motion-picture productions with historical backgrounds, or with particular social problems, are accurately handled, interested me.

ERNEST PASCAL, president of the Screen Writers Guild in Hollywood, has contributed a plaintive, but reasonably worded, appeal for recognition of the script writers. Setting forth the fact that members of his guild write more than 90 per cent of the pictures produced in this country and some of those turned out in London, he asks a few questions.

An experiment in the transmission of mail by airplane catapulted from the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen while at sea has established the fact that a passenger en route to Europe may be in communication with New York by mail within six days.

Some of the announced topics in the city's churches today deal with social and economic questions. Many visiting preachers, whose topics are unannounced, will be heard. At least four of the city's pastors will preach for the last time until after their vacations.

A steady to firm undertone ruled yesterday in quiet dealings in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover, $3,501,000, compared with $3,677,000 on the previous Saturday, was the smallest since Aug. 18, 1934, when transactions amounted to $3,473,300.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- After several lean years Federal revenues are rising again, though they still fall far short of balancing expenditures. Analysis of statistics, brought down to the end of the fiscal year, June 30, 1935, reveals not only this outstanding fact, but also that there have been important changes in the actual and relative amounts brought in by different forms of Federal taxation.

The average monthly number of cases on relief rolls rose from 321,170 for the last six months of 1934 to 351,481 for the first six months of 1935, with a $5,000,000 increase in cost for the latter period, it was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, chairman of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 27. -- Cantitoe, the twelve-meter sloop of the Cunningham-Johnson-Bedford syndicate, defeated Horace Havemeyer's Mouette and William Strawbridge's Mitena in the feature race of the Stamford Yacht Club's forty-third annual regatta today.

The apprehension and conviction of criminals, while of course of outstanding importance, is only one part of the crime problem. Juvenile delinquency, education, probation, the law enforcement agencies, criminal procedure in our courts, extradition, penal statutes, prison administration, parole and rehabilitation -- all are closely inter-related and must be taken into careful consideration in any comprehensive study of crime.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 27. -- The hundred or more veterans and dozen attendants at the United States Veterans Hospital here who became violently ill Thursday night a few hours after they had eaten supper had completely recovered today, much to the relief of many relatives who flocked to the hospital to visit them this afternoon.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company has contracted for the purchase of 250,000 additional barrels of gas oil and kerosene from the Soviet oil trust for shipment to the Near East. The price will be at the market at time of delivery. Products will be supplied for the rest of the year.

CAMPERS who depart for the deep woods this Summer laden with pound upon pound of equipment could take many lessons from the French-Canadian woodsmen and the Arizona natives, who manage to prepare comfortable meals in the wilderness with no cooking apparatus whatever.

EVEN from perfunctory newspaper accounts one can form an opinion of the typical dance marathon. It is, undeniably, a sordid and brutalizing affair, ruthlessly commercial and catering to the more degraded instincts.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., July 27. -This famous Fire Island -- silver sand-duned front yard for the Atlantic Ocean -- is suffering today the humiliation and anguish of proud plans gone astray and patriotic emotion unsated.

A NEW sort of secondary school, which requires no mathematics, Latin or modern foreign language and refuses to prepare pupils for colleges with the traditional entrance requirements, is scheduled to open this Fall at Short Hills, N.J.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27. -- Plans for the junior cruise of the Larchmont Yacht Club were announced tonight. It will start on Tuesday with a run across the Sound to Price's Bend. On Wednesday there will be a run to Stamford and on Thursday one back here.

Even without the specific request which is made by Dr. ARTHUR D. LITTLE, credit would be given to his Industrial Bulletin for an encouraging leading editorial on "Refrigerated Flies" -- and if for no other reason than that such high authority is needed to give its statements credibility.

I saw in your "In the Mailbag" column a letter concerning Marlene Dietrich's (or rather, Joseph von Sternberg's) picture, "The Devil Is a Woman." I sat through fifteen or twenty minutes of the picture and came to a very definite conclusion: That I was going to leave as soon as I could find my hat. I did.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27. -- Frank E. Campbell's sailing dinghy Confusion and Clair L. Farrand's Consternation were selected tonight to represent the North American Dinghy Association in the international match with two English boats which will be sent over here in September.

The main conclusion to be drawn from the work of the Brazil Coffee Producers Convention, which ended last week, is that Brazil has abandoned its severe crop-destruction program and will now try a moderate program in an effort to regain a larger volume on the world markets.

With no indication of a let-up in the attack on the Dutch currency, the guilder continued downward in the foreign exchange market here yesterday. Off 93 points for the week and 27 points for the day, the guilder closed at 67.10 cents.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 27. -- The baseball rivalry between the New York Athletic Club and the Penn A.C. was settled in an indecisive manner today when the umpire awarded the third and deciding game of the series to the Philadelphia team, 9 -- 0, following New York's refusal to accept a decision in the eighth inning.

For the New York County inquiry into criminal rackets, which opens tomorrow before a special grand jury, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey announced last week the selection of eight additional young men for his legal staff, all recent law school graduates from Harvard, Columbia, Yale, Fordham and New York Universities.

NEW ORLEANS, July 27 (AP). -- Arthur J. Romaguera, former chauffeur for Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, today returned a crayon portrait of President Roosevelt to the Old Regular political headquarters. He took it from the walls last night, because, he said, the ward leaders had turned to Senator Long "and you have no right to this picture."

BERLIN, July 27. -- Saturday, so often a day of sensational developments under the Nazi regime, has almost passed as this dispatch is written. Despite apprehensions so widely expressed yesterday, neither new instances of anti-Semitic violence on any considerable scale nor mass arrests for past excesses have marked it from other Saturdays, so far as is known.

MR. KIRSTEIN'S title is fair enough warning of the planned obscurity that fogs many of his poems. Yet the book repays the decoding exercise of reading it, from the prep school lines at the beginning to the ventures in revolutionary technique at the end.

An additional attachment against the funds of Bertrand Coles Neidecker, president of the Travelers Bank of Paris, which was officially declared bankrupt Thursday, was filed yesterday by General John F. O'Ryan on behalf of William D. Fulton, a creditor for about $10,000.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 27. -- Two sunburned men in their middle forties, wearing leather helmets, yellow pullovers, life preservers for safety and peering through spray-covered goggles, today on Lake George did what no other motor boat crew in the thirty-one-year history of the famous Gold Cup has been able to accomplish.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- The War Department granted today to the city of Bayonne, N.J., permission to construct about 10,400 linear feet of bulkhead and to dredge an entrance channel in it harbor.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27. -Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the White and Silver ball in behalf of the Southampton Country day school tonight in the Colonial Ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The annual flower show of the Warm Springs Valley Garden Club will be held on Wednesday at the Presbyterian Church in Warm Springs. The officers of the club have arranged a luncheon in the Colonial Room of the Homestead after cocktails at Oakley Farm, the home of Mrs. Tate B. Sterret, president, in honor of out-of-town visitors.

NATIONS have done much this year to eliminate delays at their border lines, once an irritation that dulled the edge of a pleasure trip. They have effected agreements with motorists which simplify international travel by car, granted special rates by rail and extended other favors.

PARIS, July 27. -- Archduke William of Hapsburg, grandnephew of the late Emperor Francis Joseph, was condemned by default today by a Paris court to five years' imprisonment and 2,000 francs fine for swindling. His "fiancee," Paule Couyba, who aided him and remained in France when Archduke William fled to Basle, Switzerland, received a three-year sentence which she will not have to serve as she was immediately paroled.

When taxes are imposed at rates which are so high as to make the payment of them burdensome, the taxpayer naturally seeks to ease his burden by limiting his taxable transactions by choosing the most favorable methods for the conduct of such transactions, or even by changing his form of business organization.
The Public Utility Holding Company Bill has been productive of more Congressional rows than an orange ribbon on the 17th of March. Last week it ran true to form.

The two months that have elapsed since the Supreme Court voided the National Industrial Recovery Act have not witnessed anything "remotely resembling a collapse of labor or fair trade practice standards in the needle trades," according to a report made yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., to a newly formed committee on maintenance of standards of the organization.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 27 (AP). -- Two young Kansas Democratic leaders who bolted in protest against "New Deal" spending returned from a tour tonight and asserted that dissension is sweeping the party.

SEVERAL of the recent novels about China, and Americans resident in China, have been outwardly more ambitious than this one; but few, if any, of them have made a more interesting and unobtrusive use of the Chinese background.

WHITE TOP MOUNTAIN, N.D., near Marion, Southwestern Virginia, will again echo with the sound of fiddle and banjo, fife and dulcimer on Aug. 16 and 17, when the folk musicians of many States come together in the fifth annual White Top Folk Festival.

The police made extensive preparations yesterday for trouble along the waterfront tomorrow when the teamsters' and longshoremen's unions resume their drive to organize non-union men moving freight to and from steamship piers.

The political machine that until recently governed Mexico under the control of General Plutarco Elias Calles is now being rapidly dismantled. The country is undergoing a political revolution, oddly, under the leadership of its President.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27. -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt took off by airplane this morning for the United States but he left behind a member of the Roosevelt family in his nephew, Kermit, Jr., who arrived yesterday aboard a cargo ship, accompanied by young McCormick Blair and Dr. D.A. Vernon.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- The Farm Adjustment Administration was reported today to be considering slashing the 1936 wheat acreage 15 to 18 per cent below the "base" acreage.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 27 (AP). -- The combined Harvard - Yale track and field team, which recently tied Cambridge-Oxford, had to be content with two first places in the Clyde Football Club's sports carnival, staged before 10,000 spectators today.

BERLIN, July 27. -- The German Government issued a semi-official declaration today through the official news service, asserting that Mayor La Guardia's action refusing a license as a masseur to a German citizen was a breach of the German-American treaty of commerce and friendship of 1925.

There is a good deal of criticism of obscene and vulgar movies. Many of them are bad enough. But a dozen of the worst obscene pictures cannot equal the damage that is done by such films as "The Mark of the Vampire."

MOSCOW, July 26. -- Even courage and adventure are being socialized in Soviet Russia.
