The projected 6,000-mile flight of Sigmund Levanevsky, Baidukoff and Victor Levchenko to San Francisco via the North Pole is to be very different in organization and conception from the individualistic exploits of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd.
A way station on Dr. Francis E. Townsend's high road to Utopia was opened yesterday in a bare second-floor office at 386 Fourth Avenue.

THE Metropolitan Museum, one of the standard-bearers of art during the Summer doldrums, is already looking forward to next season. Not that activity has noticeably lessened for the hot months: the exhibition of contemporary American painting has recently been changed and is one of the current local exhibitions which temporary New Yorkers should not miss and permanent New Yorkers who have not yet seen it should by all means visit.

BERLIN, June 29. BERLIN'S most representative stage, the Staatsschauspielhaus, finished its season on June 3 with the fiftieth sold-out performance of Scribe's "Das Glass Wasser," an unheard of seasonal number for any play at this house, which adheres rigidly to a repertory policy.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 27. -- After years of repeatedly bowing to American invaders, Canadian oarsmen held their heads high on the strength of a smashing international victory in the fifty-third Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Political problems are agitating Arizona, but they are problems of political economics rather than of personalities. Sentiment is strong that the only way to reduce taxation is by drastic cutting of State and local expenses. Of course Federal taxes are high, but the sums which the government is spending and will spend in Arizona will greatly exceed the amount paid in Federal taxes.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 27. -- A 22-year-old youth was fatally injured near here late this afternoon when the plane in which he was riding with a young companion went into a "flat" spin and crashed in an open field. The other youth saved himself by making a parachute jump a few hundred feet above the ground.

OLIVE MOORE apparently asks but one thing of life, and that is the privilege of making aphorisms about it. Apparently also she has been doing this over a period of some years, storing all in notebooks, now assembled under a title which is itself aphoristic.

LONG distance short-wave reception in the New York area has been above the average during the past week despite the torrid wave and humidity. Signals were intercepted from the far corners of the earth, with the Far East, Europe and Latin America clearly heard.

Somehow or other a fisherman with a fly rod is always keen to experiment. Every Fall the number of anglers who leave prejudice behind and go down to the sea for snapper blues with light rods is increasing. For they find that snappers, like bantamweight fighters, are scrappy enough per ounce to furnish real sport.

RUMSON, N.J., July 27. -- The United States Army polo quartet, teaming well and showing stronger individual play, routed Joseph M. Roebling's Harmony Hollow four today on the Herbert Memorial Field at the Rumson Country Club, 12 to 3.

SEVERAL species of gentians, generally considered difficult to cultivate, are now in bloom in the Thompson Memorial Rock Garden at the New York Botanical Garden. Because of their deep, true-blue color, interesting form and season of bloom -- when there is a dearth of flowers in the rock garden -- these plants deserve the attention of all gardeners who have suitable space for them.

RECENT news that Secretary Hull had informed the Italian Ambassador to the United States that he would view with grave misgiving any violation of Italy's signature of the Kellogg pact renouncing war as an instrument of national policy was received in Europe (outside Italy) with mild acclaim.
RICHMOND, July 27. -- Industrial news was the week's feature in the Fifth Reserve District, with six scattered localities being potential beneficiaries.

SHANGHAI. -- Two leprosariums will be opened for the care of patients in the Shanghai area before next Autumn, and the 2,000 or more known lepers now at large in this city of 3,500,000 people will at last be given proper care.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 27. -- Four Chicagoans, flying to Mackinac Island in Lake Michigan for a week-end holiday, were killed today when their rented plane crashed near the Curtiss-Wright Airport, ten miles northwest of Milwaukee. The pilot attempted a flat landing with the wind, went into a spin 400 feet up and was unable to right the craft.
ALONG a winding, narrow road out of Morgantown, in West Virginia, a wooden sign captures your eye. In black letters against a white background you read:

Proposed calls for future months rather than fixed redemption dates predominated in last week's announcements relating to bonds to be retired before maturity. Most of the definite calls were for municipal loans in small amounts, but several industrial issues were the largest separate redemptions.

Despite the warm weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area continued to make an encouraging showing last week and sales gains of 6 to 8 per cent over the corresponding week of 1934 were estimated by store executives. For the month as a whole, it is now expected that the increase over July of last year will range from 8 to 10 per cent.

TEXAS is celebrating this year the hundredth anniversary of the revolution which gave her freedom from Mexico. In recognition of the event the Naylor Company of San Antonio, which has already done excellent work in the publishing of local histories of various sorts, plans a Centennial Series of books about Texas and her history, of which this is the first volume.

Constructive forces continued to push the share market upward yesterday, leading equities advancing 1 to 3 points in the most active Saturday session on the New York Stock Exchange in more than a month.

Two gunners broke fifty straight targets in the skeet shoot over the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday. They were A.S. Bayles and W.A. Ketcham. In the shoot-off Bayles again broke all his birds, 25, and triumphed, Ketcham breaking 24.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Figures showing how the Treasury has managed the increasing public debt and, by refunding operations, extended the maturity of billions of its bonds and cut interest obligations were made public today by Secretary Morgenthau.

HALLIBURTON CARRIES ON: Richard Halliburton, who has spent years following eminent precedents to get material for lectures and books, turned up last week in the Swiss Alps. He was on an elephant and this time he was playing Hannibal.
LITTLE FALLS, Minn., July 27 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh left here late today after a 24-hour tour of the aviator's boyhood haunts.

PARIS. HATS are making a strong effort to play the stellar role in the dress ensemble for next Fall and Winter. They do everything they can to attract attention to the head and flatter the face. There have certainly never been so many feather trimmings within memory of woman.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 25. -- If success comes to a widely sponsored movement now under way, the State which has been the scene of the racial bitterness the Scottsboro case has called forth may become the site of one of the world's finest and most useful monuments to racial good-will.

ANOTHER step in the movement to centralize all motion-picture production, distribution and exhibition into four vast concerns was observed this week when it was revealed that physical acts have occurred toward merging the RKO-Radio and Paramount studios.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- More than 46,000 CCC workers are engaged in soil-erosion work, and 230 erosion-control camps are in operation in thirty States, CCC headquarters reported today.

I am very much interested in Linda Roberts's idea about converting Madison Square Garden into a cafe, Viennese style, where good concert music would vie with long, cool drinks and their accompaniment to lure our Summer visitors.

ALL air express activities in the United States are to be unified under the direction of the aeronautical division of the Railway Express Agency if active negotiations now under way are brought to a successful conclusion.

THE tenth annual group recently graduated by the Newark Museum apprentice class is ushered into a society where increasing emphasis is placed upon the relation of the museum to the public, according to Beatrice Winser, director of the museum.
LONDON. AMERICANS who motor through England this Summer will drive over the same roads that conquering Romans built to march their soldiers over centuries ago.

THE intellectuals for whom that book is best which sells the best are patronizing what Erasmus, had he lived in the twentieth century, would have called the New Learning. In "the glory that was Greece and the grandeur that was Rome" they seek to supplement scholarship by sensation, and, season by season, the renaissance is extended.

MONOTONOUS teletypes grind on, spewing forth yellowed pages covered with characters unintelligible to the uninitiated, but speaking a whole sentence to those who can decipher them. Quiet young men work about the Department of Commerce printers and their drawing boards. Detailed information gathered from the 250 observation points of the United States Weather Bureau is transferred to huge maps of North America, the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

Janitors, lords of the basement, are campaigning for Summer vacations and weekly days off such as ordinary folk enjoy. They have one ally, the Rev. Walter Carl Subke, pastor of the Greenwich Presbyterian Church, down in the Village, at Thirteenth Street.

AFTER ten years of tedious labor, archaeologists from the University of Chicago have completed the vast project of deciphering a series of hieroglyphics inscribed on the stone walls of an Egyptian temple dating from 1200 B.C.

With Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman present, the first session of the merged Essex Market and Tombs Courts was held yesterday morning in the Tombs Court. The second session will be held this morning in Essex Market.

THE bagpipers are at practice and nimble young feet are stepping again the pattern of the Highland Fling as Sydney prepares or a week of mod, or reunion. In no other part of the world except Scotland itself is the Scottish tongue used so widely or the ancient customs so dearly held as in Cape Breton.

WITH July the melon crop rides into the city. Pale gold honeydews and crinkled cantaloupes, all crated, are discharged from railroad lighters, but the big green watermelons come by truck as well as by rail.

Resolutions to be offered for adoption by 2,500 delegates from churches of the Disciples of Christ at the second world convention Aug. 7-12 in Leicester, England, will cite the Italo-Ethiopian conflict as demanding more intensive international steps to prevent war by settling disputes through arbitration.

NEW YORK held an exhibition of air-conditioning apparatus recently. It saw sprays, refrigerating machines, heaters, humidifiers and dehumidifiers, compressors, silencers, filters, ducts. Its respect for nature was heightened.

SPA: When Charles Evans Hughes was Governor of New York he appointed a commission charged with the task of buying up land and springs at Saratoga Springs for what was designed to be the most complete hydrotherapeutic plant in the country. On Friday the State reaped the fruit of the commission's labors.

OUR pampered and coddled citizenry who complain that their theatregoing is made excessively difficult by traffic snarls, the chicanery of box-office men and too many martinis, should feel a little abashed when they learn of the ordeals to which music-minded Missourians submit themselves to see the al fresco carnivals set up in their Municipal Theatre by Laurence Schwab.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Cash income to farmers from sales of farm products, plus rental and benefit payments through the AAA, amounted to $487,000,000 in June, compared with $451,000,000 in June, 1934, and $519,000,000 in May of this year, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today.

RECENT visitors to Europe are not surprised by the newest plan of Russian aviators to attempt a trans-polar flight. They are aware of many improvements in aviation on the continent, designed to aid the tourist and serve commerce.

COINCIDENT with the opening of negotiations for a trade-relations treaty between the United States and Austria, Vienna is preparing for her twenty-ninth International Fair, from Sept. 1 to 8. There will be displays of every type of hand-wrought and manufactured article -- motor cars, home appliances, building materials and the products that are peculiar to the tradesmen of Central Europe.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 27. -- "Geisha" will be presented tomorrow night in the outdoor theatre of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here for the benefit of the New York State flood sufferers. Miss Alice Wellman will sing the title role.

PARIS, July 26. -- Premier Pierre Laval has announced that he will himself attend the League of Nations Council that is going to have the disagreeable task o trying to find a way out of the dispute between Italy and Ethiopia.

ON calm reflection, which is possible only some hours after reading the last page of this book, you are likely to decide that there is something more to voodooism than sublimated showmanship. Among the authorities who know most about the subject there seems to be the least tendency to treat it lightly.

WOMEN whose jobs keep them tied to a desk in town except for a blessed August vacation want things just so when they make the annual break from the mundane life. The ideal is to travel light, yet include everything necessary for a smart outfit.

ROOFS reaching toward the sky, pier ends thrust into a dark tide, bus tops and park benches, ferryboats and front stoops -- that is where New York lives on these hot Summer nights. For three scorching months the city forgets it is a tense metropolis and takes to the leisurely ways of a small town.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Overriding the wishes of counsel both for the railroad and large institutional creditors, Federal Judge John P. Barnes ruled today that the proposed reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway must be completed by April 1, 1936. More than 100 creditors and investors were in the court room.

Another move by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to maintain peace between the Van Sweringen and the Taplin interests in the control of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway was disclosed yesterday in an order by the Interstate Commerce Commission which modified an agreement under which J. Crawford Biggs, former Solicitor General, was made trustee of the Van Sweringen holdings in the Wheeling.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Activities ranging from lawn teas to international hockey matches on the new ice of the Olympic Arena at Lake Placid are features of the week in the Adirondacks.

FORESEEING tremendous development in scheduled air transport operations between near-by cities and in commuting and suburban air service, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, the trade body of the aviation industry, has launched a nation-wide cooperative movement to hasten the construction of adequate marine terminals.

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 27. -- The first invitation races held by the Shinnecock Yacht Club of Quogue in four years attracted sixty-eight craft in eleven classes today. The events were sailed on Shinnecock Bay just east of the Hampton Bays Lighthouse.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Next Monday twenty-one men representing various city, county and State police organizations will arrive here to begin a three-month course of intensive training corresponding exactly to that given to the famous G-men of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice.

LOS ANGELES, July 27. -- Grave doubt of the constitutionality of the processing tax feature of the Agricultural Administration Act was expressed today in the opinion of four United States District Judges, who temporarily enjoined the Collector of Internal Revenue here from collecting processing taxes from eleven packing and milling concerns.

On the heels of his Grants' heartwarming triumphs in St. Louis, disaster came to Memphis Bill Terry from an unexpected quarter yesterday, annoying him greatly, but pleasing the majority of the 8,000 fans who gave him the usual Flatbush welcome at Ebbets Field.

VATICAN CITY, July 27. -- The Vatican note delivered to the German Government yesterday was said here to be similar to other protests against violations of the concordat between the Holy See and the Reich. The note condemned recent measures against Catholic organizations. It is generally believed that, although the relations between the Vatican and Germany are becoming increasingly strained, there is no immediate prospect of a rupture.

A NEW type of textbook, based on the theory that changing economic and social conditions should be reflected pictorially in the classroom, has been developed under the direction of the Society for Curriculum Study, a national organization of teachers and curriculum specialists.

BARCELONA. -- This city, Spain's traditional centre of turbulent action, is again under martial law. Back of the sudden action is the determination of the central government to break, if it can, the campaign of violence on the part of anarcho-syndical terrorists which was once more becoming active.

The riot on the liner Bremen is deplored by all, Children's Court Justice Jacob Panken, prominent Socialist leader, declared last night at the annual Socialist and labor picnic at Ulmer Park, Brooklyn. About 10,000 persons were present.

THE eyes of statesmen, financiers, economists and speculators throughout the world are fixed upon the sharp black upward line that describes the climbing value of silver. It is a line that sets off all the human emotions in many millions of people, most of whom know it only as a mysterious something that affects what they earn, what they buy and sell, and how, and for how much.

Aside from the new Tax Bill there are nine Administration measures which keep a weary and perspiring Congress going through the motions of debate and legislation as the dog days lengthen into August. Fortunately, from the point of view of those who hope for an adjournment at no greatly distant date, only one measure on the calendar is still so far from final action that it has been passed by neither branch.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Another clash between advocates of the dual and unified banking systems was held likely today when conferees begin discussion of the Omnibus Banking Bill passed by the Senate yesterday and by the House early in May.

WHEN darkness comes and day is done, the beauty of the garden need no longer be but a faint and ghostly thing with only the scent of lilies and mignonette to remind us that it is out there in the dusk.

The curiosity of a squad of customs agents attached to the Enforcement Bureau brought about the seizure yesterday of 1,000 bottles of Scotch whisky on the American West African freighter West Lashaway, which arrived on Friday night from Africa and the Cape Verde Islands.

ADDIS ABABA, July 27 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Sellassie authorized a written statement today to the effect that the problem of war or peace in Africa was now squarely up to the League of Nations. Ethiopia, he stated, was seeking a peaceful settlement.

THE financial plight of the Stadium concerts this Summer has been a deplorable one, and the failure of the ballet programs to pull them out of the hole is a particularly interesting, though not a surprising, aspect of the situation.

MALONE, N.Y., July 27. -- Rocco Di Larmi, swarthy associate of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, was held in contempt of court by Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant today for refusing to testify against his chief, who is on trial for income tax evasion.

THE world of science is watching with the keenest interest development of a modern controversy which promises to take its place along with the other historic controversies in the realms of philosophy and science.

NEWPORT, R.I., -- August in this city is to be the busiest month of the season -- principally a month for the debutantes. By the time it is half gone about ten young women will have made their bows to the social world at almost as many dances or other parties.
It is the Committee of the Stadium Concerts and not of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, as stated yesterday in THE TIMES which is organizing the campaign to raise $10,000.

MILWAUKEE, July 26. -- Storm clouds gathering over the Democratic party dim the heretofore unchallenged popularity of President Roosevelt in Wisconsin and aroused young Democrats have proposed a revolt in 1936.

Business in San Francisco continues to show steady increases over last year, according to the July Business Outlook, published by the Wells Fargo Bank and Union Trust Company of that city. Department store sales in June were about 12 per cent above June, 1934, the same rate of increase reported in May, but well above the degree of gain shown earlier in the year.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27. -- Summer residents had much to interest them this afternoon, dividing their time between the Newport Country Club, where the final match in the ninth annual invitation golf tournament of the club was played, and the estate of Mrs. Nicholas Brown on the southern harbor front, where the annual Boy Scout round-up for Newport County took place.

The communication of Harold R. Shurtleff interested me greatly because of my ownership of the files of The Sunday Dispatch of this city, containing the "History of the American Stage," by Charles Durang.

MELVIN VILLAGE, N.H., July 27 (AP). -- Francis Ouimet and Jess Sweetser, two former golf champions, in competition for the first time this season, went to unexpected defeats today in the opening rounds of match play in the Bald Peak Country Club's invitation tournament.

TOURISTS who find Paris too expensive -- and yet who wish to stay on in France -- often have found that Normandy is the answer to their problem. They quietly pack up and go down the Seine River to Caudebec-en-Caux. It is very near Havre and so on the direct way to the boat.

NEW YORKERS seeking an inexpensive but pleasant vacation in the outdoors are turning more and more to motor camping, and it is estimated that between 50,000 and 100,000 will spend two weeks or so "living on the road" this season.

MONKEY'S MONEY!" cried Robert-Marie Darby at that moment in which his fate seemed about to take its most bitter twist. "That's what life has given me. It mocks me instead of satisfying me, and everything it offers me is about as much good to me as a penny is to a monkey."

NEW ground is broken in this study of that old and much investigated subject of nutrition. For, although dozens of capable students have probed into its factors and studied its many phases, all of them worked on the basis of a three-meals-a-day schedule of intake of nourishment.

Vladimir Jabotinsky, president of the World Union of Zionist-Revisionists, characterized Palestine prosperity as false in a letter to the Zionist-Revisionists Organization of the United States and Canada and made public by the organization yesterday.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., July 27. -- An Animated Magazine will be published as a benefit for a group of charitable organizations. This has been arranged by a joint committee of South Kingston and Narragansett society members. The magazine will he edited by Harry Parsons Cross on Aug. 3 at the Narragansett home of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Noble, Casa Nostra.

AT this season of the year, when there is a bit of a lull in garden work in the open, or when excessive heat or too frequent rains make it impossible to do some of the things which are waiting for attention, the gardener may well use his spare time indoors in shaping plans for late Summer and Autumn activities.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Disclosures before the Senate and House lobby investigating committees, particularly the former, have, to say the very least, cast a deep shadow of suspicion over the recent great outpouring of public protest against President Roosevelt's Utility Holding Company Bill.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- With the approach of Aug. 1 Federal relief headquarters had no official figures available today on the number of persons actually put on jobs under the $4,000,000,000 work relief program, but some officials said that the number was "very small."

The wholesale market was abundantly supplied with green corn last week, particularly from New Jersey, and prices were consequently low, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.
ALL that our side won at Wimbledon yesterday was a pocketful of woe. Bunny Austin, the dapper broker from "the City," was just a trifle too good for Wilmer Allison from Texas, down by the Rio Grande.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., July 27. -- After capturing the qualifying medal with a 75, two over par for the stern 6,915-yard Timber Point Club course, David McCoy today won the annual Midsummer match play championship for members of the New York Athletic Club.

BALTIMORE, July 27. -- Governor Harry W. Nice, with twenty-three State and national political figures, sailed from here today for a weekend on the Chesapeake Bay aboard the Du Pont, flagship of the Maryland conservation fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- As a concession to a demand from many members of Congress for a Tax Bill that will yield more substantial revenues than the pending measure Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee decided today to start the proposed higher surtaxes on personal incomes at $50,000, instead of $150,000, the figure set earlier in the week.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- The coming week will be a gala one throughout the Summer colony, since the forty-fifth annual invitation tennis tournament opens tomorrow afternoon on the courts of the Meadow Club and continues throughout the week. This is one of the few major tournaments in the country that are still played on grass courts.

HOW time flies! Here it is practically the first of August and throughout the land are heard the muffled cries of those yet to go on vacation who are suddenly faced with the realization that they have put off to the ultimate minute the necessary restocking of their Summer wardrobes, with the result that restocking is difficult from depleted supplies. But all is not lost.

PARIS. ANOTHER star from the French cinema firmament will be shooting toward Hollywood this Autumn -- Simone Simon, that impish, delightful and wholly charming young lady whose Puck in "Lac-aux-Dames" was one of the most hauntingly beautiful creations which the screen has given us.

The confidence E.R. Bradley has had in Blue Larkspur's bay son, Bien Joli, was vindicated at Empire City yesterday when the youngster captured the featured $2,500 added East View Stakes before 15,000 persons. The margin was two lengths at the end of the short six furlongs, with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Parade Girl second, and C.V. Whitney's Triumphant third.

IT is the open season for furs, experts say, because of the reduction in prices. Be that as it may, every woman who sees the new fur coats between now and the time that the first cold blasts of wind remind her that she needs one will want an ombred Persian, a mink or a nutria, according to her requirements and pocketbook.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- An assertion that the "backbone of this terrible depression has been definitely broken" came tonight from Stewart McDonald, Acting Federal Housing Administrator.

HERALD HARBOR, Md., July 27. -- Amateur outboard records shivered somewhat but withstood assault in the running of the opening program of the eighth annual tri-city regatta today. Choppy waters and increasing wind were the two chief speed-reducing factors.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP). -- Four new witnesses in behalf of Tom Mooney were claimed by his attorney tonight as sympathizers gathered for tomorrow's observance of the 52-year-old convict's nineteenth anniversary behind bars.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- The government is going to lose little time getting rid of the 151 alien criminals President Roosevelt ordered deported.

THE war on mobs of racketeers who levy millions of dollars of tribute on business in New York City every year, a war that will centre attention on conditions even more sinister than those of ordinary crime, will begin tomorrow with the convening of the special grand jury and the swearing in of Thomas E. Dewey and his assistants as special prosecutors.

SOME one at the headquarters of WABC has a hobby of tabulating "most embarrassing moments" of announcers. The list includes Andre Baruch's tongue twisting announcement that a Marine Roof program was originating on the "Maroon roof," and Harry von Zell's reference to the former President as "Hoobert Herver."

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- A report that back-to-the-land movements during the depression years have proved a dismal failure for many, was made today by the Study of Population Redistribution, a Washington research organization operating under the auspices of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania.

HOW to reduce losses from forest fires has long been a problem to Canada, with its vast forest preserves and uncharted areas. These losses, averaging some $9,600,000 a year, do not take into consideration the injury done to soil or the change in the water level of streams.

DUBLIN, July 27. -- The dream of a united Ireland, cherished by every political party in the Free State, seems further from realization today than at any period since the country was partitioned, more than a decade ago. Recent sectarian riots in Belfast, with counter-anti-Protestant outbreaks in the South, have appreciably deepened the political estrangement between the Free State and Northern Ireland.

THOUGH the temples of its former grandeur are now for the most part memories, Coney Island springs to life each year, refurbishes its remaining gilded domes and gleaming minarets, and sets about the catchpenny business of trying to divert some of the millions who jostle gayly from subway to beach front, fugitives from the swelter of a great city.

ANGORA, Turkey, July 27 (AP). -- The tight military censorship was lifted long enough today to disclose the deaths of seven soldiers in the explosions of two munitions dumps of the Marmora Naval Base near Ismid yesterday and today.

Interest was aroused last week in underwriting houses by the resignation of Arthur Lehman, of Lehman Brothers, from the directorate of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation to comply with the Securities and Exchange Commission's recent Rule NB-2 which affected the marketing of a new issue of 250,000 shares of the company's convertible preference stock.

AT this season, when the failures of Spring can still be remembered and the bare spots of midsummer are all too apparent, a new stock of plants may be developed to repair these deficiencies for the next year. A few rows of hardy annuals, of biennial and perennial plants are a sure source of beauty, and many varieties of these may be started at once.

LONDON, July 26. -- There are three chief points of difference between the policy of "programs," which Great Britain is now suggesting to the maritime powers of the world, and the one based on ratios, born in Washington fourteen years ago and just discarded because Japan repudiates it.
The bodies of two men and two boys, recovered in the last few days from the waters about the city, were identified and claimed by relatives yesterday at the morgue.

MUKDEN. -- An organization of Manchurian cotton producers and brokers has drawn up a plan calling for the annual production of approximately 100,000 tons of raw cotton at the end of ten years. It is estimated that an area of 750,000 acres will be required.

FIFTY blind boys from New York City will be sent to Camp Lighthouse, Barnegat Bay, N.J., on Aug. 2 by the New York Association for the Blind. This marks the beginning of the season for boys at Camp Lighthouse, where forty-three blind girls, ranging in age from 5 to 17, have been vacationing during July.

Nazi Germany's current crusade against the Jews, Catholics and "reactionaries." which began July 15 on Kurfuerstendamm, Berlin's Fifth Avenue, spread last week to hundreds of cities, towns and villages through the Reich. It caused a stir beyond Germany's borders; in the United States -- and particularly in New York -- it led to counter-action and an outburst of rhetoric, both anti- and pro-Hitler.

LENOX, Mass., July 27. -- The Moreland stables of Durham, Conn., owned by Miss Elmina and William Brewster, who gained a clean sweep of the thoroughbred hunter class yesterday, today captured the champion hunter sweepstakes with Double Entry, a chestnut gelding.

BERLIN, July 27. -- Nazism's big offensive against reactionaries struck new terror into Jews and Steel Helmet war veterans today, but Catholics, heretofore under heavy fire, thought they discerned indications of an imminent truce.

BERLIN, July 27. -- The Nazi anti-Semites, under the leadership of Julius Streicher, now in the midst of a violent campaign to eliminate Jews from Germany's cultural and political life, have started plans to anti-Semitize the world and spread the poison of hatred against Jews everywhere.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler refused yesterday to change his stand requiring the liquidation of the New York Title and Mortgage Company. He denied the application of the corporation for a stay of liquidation pending appeal.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- This has been Herbert Hoover and G. O.P. week in California, with a succession of leading Republicans trekking to Palo Alto to talk things over with the party chief, and then continuing on to San Francisco to address enthusiastic meetings of New Deal critics at luncheon.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 27. -- The discovery of a revolutionary plot resulted today in the arrest of Juan Villa, navigation instructor in the military aviation school at Cali, according to a statement issued at the President's Palace this evening. The State police were said to have found in his room subversive propaganda and proclamations offering rewards to troops joining the projected revolt.
Mayor La Guardia, at Westport, Conn., would make no comment last night on Berlin dispatches saying that Germany considered her commercial treaty had been violated by him.

ROME, July 26. -- The decree issued this week authorizing the government to allow the gold reserves of the Bank of Italy to fall below the statutory 40 per cent of circulation is the first symptom that Italy is beginning to feel the strain of war preparation, coming at the end of a long period of economic depression.

DALLAS, Texas, July 26. -- Whether the crushing defeats suffered by the AAA in the courts will ultimately compel the abandonment of programs to restrict production and the substitution of international commercial policies designed to increase consumption is the important question stimulating political conjecture in all sections of Texas.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- The Cubs ran roughshod over the Reds today to win both games of a doubleheader, 9 to 8 and 12 to 1, and to reduce the Giants' League lead to a single game.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 27. -- In an atmosphere very different from the nerve-racking, funereal mood of last Summer, the Salzburg Festival opened tonight with a performance of "Tristan and Isolde," under the direction of Bruno Walter.

NORFOLK, Va., July 26. -- Lieut. Gov. James H. Price's announcement of his candidacy for Governor offers potentially the most serious threat to Senator Byrd's control of the State in a dozen years, but it is too soon yet to say how far this threat will go.

Offering of the new issue of 42,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock of the Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company, the registration statement for which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, is expected about the middle of August. This time affords ample allowance for the twenty-day period of grace required after filing.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- A spread ranging from 138.9 per cent to 386.9 per cent between domestic and residential electric power rates prevailing in the cities of New York as of Jan. 1 last, was disclosed today by the Federal Power Commission in its report on a survey of power rates in that State.

FOR visitors to Canada whose vacation period is limited the new bridge between St. Gregoire-de-Montmorency and the Island of Orleans, opened recently, offers a short cut to picturesque spots in and around Quebec.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- The Atlantic City Beach Patrol will stage its annual ocean-swimming contests next Friday off the foot of South Carolina Avenue, in view of the Boardwalk and Strand. On the following day the Atlantic City Swimming Club will hold its eighth annual races, with leading American athletes competing in a five-mile event for men and one-mile for women.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The forty-ninth annual Monmouth County horse show will be held on the Harding estate, Thornton Farm, Rumson, starting on Thursday and continuing until Saturday. Last year, and for several years previously, the show was staged at the Rumson Country Club.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Pittsfield horse show with fifty-eight classes will be held next Friday and Saturday at Holmesdale, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Weston. Robert W. McCracken is president and Ernest W. Nelson secretary and treasurer of the horse-show committee.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the city crime investigation, has received a confidential report on each of the veniremen from whom a special grand jury is to be chosen tomorrow before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in the County Court House.

The complaint of Hugh Sinclair a motion picture actor appearing in "Escape Me Never," that a composite photograph of him used for display purposes by the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company had presented him in "an undignified light" was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer.

DALLAS, July 27. -- Favorable weather during the last few weeks has resulted in improved agricultural conditions throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. Estimates indicate that crop production for this area will greatly exceed that of last year, particularly in feed.
IT will probably be news to many motorists and pedestrians that the Police Department's published regulations governing right turns on red read as follows:

DALLAS. -- Whether Texas should join those States now providing pensions for the aged and thus open the door to further social security legislation is a question which the electorate will decide on Nov. 24 when they vote on a proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for payments not exceeding $15 a month to all persons 65 years of age and over.

Two sisters, 18 and 20 years old, and a man, 25, were arrested yesterday by police of the East Sixty-seventh Street station as the source of counterfeit $20 Federal Reserve notes which have been passed in stores of the Yorkville area in recent weeks.

STOCKHOLM. IN a new volume of letters and reminiscences, the second of a series of three, Frida Uhl Strindberg unfolds the story of her brief marriage to the great Swedish dramatist as mostly a tempestuous battle of the ego in defense of personality.

The scandalous disorders created by avowed Communists at the sailing of the Bremen on Friday night can but react in creating a sympathy among thinking persons for those who were the intended object of the hostile demonstration. The ship, a bit of German territory, for the moment in our port and under our responsible care, was given every possible protection by the New York police.

The Communist raid on the liner Bremen early yesterday quickly became an international incident. Acting Secretary of State Wilbur J. Carr in Washington expressed regret at a press conference over the demonstration. No protest had been made by the German Embassy.

DETROIT, July 27. -- A jury of seven women and seven men was selected today to try William Schweitzer and three women for the murder on June 26 of Howard Carter Dickinson, New York lawyer and nephew of Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes.

LONDON, July 27 (AP). -- The assertion that United Stakes isolation will doom collective peace efforts is contained in a nonpartisan program of political action presented today by 153 leading British economists, publicists and writers.

In a few days a 400-ton steel shield, pushing through muck twenty feet below the Hudson River bed, will bump -- gently, it is hoped -- against a thirty-two-foot circular target. Engineers would like the shield to hit its mark "on the dime," but they will be satisfied with any margin of error smaller than a quarter.

PARIS, July 27. -- After several months of neglect because of France's internal problems and the all-absorbing Ethiopian affair, direct negotiations with Germany were resumed today when Premier Pierre Laval and Robert Koester, German Ambassador to Paris, had a long talk.

BOSTON, July 26. -- The Rhode Island by-election on Aug. 6 should furnish instructive political data for the nation. A Representative is to be chosen in the First Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused in January by the appointment of the Democratic incumbent, Francis B. Condon, to the Supreme Court.

Warning the House Committee on Labor that an absolute embargo on all imports of manufactured and semi-manufactured goods will result if the Connery Thirty-Hour Week Bill passes in its present form, the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., yesterday appealed to William P. Connery, committee chairman, to amend the bill to overcome the difficulty.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Thousands of homes will have to be acquired by the Home Owners Loan Corporation through foreclosure proceedings in the next year or two, Chairman Fahey declared today in commenting upon adverse publicity given to foreclosures already consummated.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- A favorable trend in industrial activity in the week ended on July 20 was noted by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of domestic business, released today. There was a sharp gain in steel ingot output, production of automobiles was maintained at about the same rate as in the preceding week and electric power production increased.

NO less than seven new films will find havens this week at the local cinema houses. Such a heavy bombardment tends to indicate that the screen is coming out of the Summer doldrums and may soon be providing Broadway moviegoers with a veritable abundance of new entertainment morsels.

EDGARTOWIN, Mass., July 27. -- The Edgartown Yacht Club started a fleet of 186 craft today to conclude its twelfth annual regatta. This established a new record for Southern Massachusetts yacht clubs, as it surpassed the club's total of 182 which sailed in 1933.

GLADSTONE, Mich. -Wages figured most prominently in the recent strike of more than 400 employes of the Northwestern Cooperage and Lumber Company, but the granting of the demand made by the workers that they receive their pay in checks rather than in the form of a credit slip from the company store marked a change of some import in this lumbering region.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- The Tigers maintained their victory pace today, subduing the Indians, 6 to 2. With the triumph they boosted their American League lead to two and one-half games over the Yankees, who lost to the Senators.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Conference committees, in which fewer than a dozen Senators and Representatives whip legislation into its final form, held the key today to most of President Roosevelt's Congressional program.

NOW that the Summer travel season is under way, the business of transporting the mails across international boundaries assumes new importance to the traveler. The American visitor in Istanbul, for instance, enlists the aid of the Turkish, Greek, Bulgarian, Yugoslav, Italian, Swiss, French and United States Governments to say, "Having a fine time -- wish you were here," to the folk back home (the postcard route from Turkey to America is that complicated).

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- When President Roosevelt announced last May the establishment of the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration, islanders, who for two years yearned to participate in the benefits of the New Deal, believed that their hopes were about to be realized.

LONDON, June 21. THE past fortnight in the theatre has been the busiest of the year. After the swift collapse of Mr. Priestley's "Duet in Floodlight," playgoers went to see Dame Sybil Thorndyke as the indomitable mother of a family in "Grief Goes Over," by Merton Hodge, whose "The Wind and the Rain" has been with us since we were young.

More than $22,000,000 in Soviet gold, to be sent here for final processing and left in this country for use in financing purchases and meeting other obligations, is due to be shipped to this country this year, according to reports in well-informed circles yesterday.

The committee on civic design of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, in its annual report made public yesterday, advocates the appointment of a "strong and fearless city planning board with adequate power and technical ability to actually plan New York."

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27. -- The publication of preliminary budget figures has moved the Chilean press to urge the government to keep down expenses at any sacrifice to balance the budget and avoid further taxation.
An explanation of the ambiguity in Article III of the Constitution is contained in a letter from Gouverneur Morris to Timothy Pickering.

GENEVA, July 26. -- A major dilemma confronting the League of Nations in the conflict over Ethiopia is whether it is better to be damned because it does or because it does not -- because, it attempts more than it is likely to succeed in doing or because it does not attempt enough.

THIS housekeeper's handy book is intended, the author says, for the special needs of the woman who does her own work or manages with one inexperienced helper. It is planned for the average household in average circumstances.

Pennsylvania fell back last year in its percentage of the country's production of finished steel, according to an analysis of capacity and production based on figures compiled by the American Iron and Steel Institute. One principal cause was the construction in recent years of new plans for rolling flat steel in States closer than Pennsylvania to many large consuming areas of such products -- the Detroit automobile district and the Ohio and Illinois industrial centres.

CHILDREN'S toys and furniture of long ago make a strong appeal to many collectors because of their human associations. Antique Noah's Arks and miniature four-poster beds have already reached the dignity of rarities.

PARIS, July 25. -- New touches of color will be added to Fall afternoon ensembles by matching velvet shoes and hats. For example, begonia velvet pumps and beret are shown with a pine-green broadcloth costume.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The appointment yesterday of former Representative West to the newly created post of Under-Secretary of the Interior has caused speculation as to whether he will continue as President Roosevelt's "contact man" with Congress.

Further expansion of industrial operations in various sections of the country, with a drop in unemployment, and reports of large expenditures for new plants and additions, were the most significant developments in last week's business trend.
HARTFORD, July 27. -- Hard liquor by the drink returned to Connecticut this week as the State Liquor Control Commission issued its first permits under the revised State law.

Disallowance of income tax deductions on corporations' philanthropic gifts, as proposed by President Roosevelt, "would undoubtedly result in the closing of many voluntary institutions," it was declared by Howard S. Cullman, in a letter to President Roosevelt, just made public.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 27. -- Thirty-nine Westchester County American Legion posts, in annual convention this afternoon at the New Rochelle Senior High School, spurned the recommendations of their nominating committee and elected most of the candidates advanced by an independent ticket.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H., July 27. -- Many annual patrons of the Mount Washington arrived today at Bretton Woods for the season. A lawn golf tournament was held there this afternoon, followed by tea and dancing. The cocktail lounge was thronged before dinner, parties being given to welcome newcomers and the Cave Grill supper dance was attended by a large group.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., July 27. -- Six cooks and waiters, all Negroes, in the dining car of the Royal Blue, new streamlined Baltimore Ohio Railroad train bound from Washington, D.C., for Jersey City, were scalded tonight when a steam tank exploded.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Representative Patton, Democrat of Texas, dropped his head on his desk today and wept.

A FOURFOLD program designed to aid local, State and national authorities in the prevention and control of crime has recently been announced by the Indiana University Institute of Criminal Law and Criminology. Studies in the causes of crime and in its prevention, training of personnel for criminal law administration, cooperation with public officials and improvement in the administration of criminal law are basic in the program.

In the enthusiasms of military adventuring the bookkeeper attract no attention. They are far in the background, dealing with figures and not glories. But, in the end, it is account books that decide how far armies can go; and now the bookkeepers of Italy and Japan are presenting balances that are disturbing to the adventurers.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 27. -- Alex Frankowski, 11 years old, of this village, was seriously injured here last night when he was struck by a car owned and operated by Walter P. Chrysler Jr. of Elm Point, Great Neck, son of the motor car manufacturer, the police of the Second Precinct reported.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Seven albums of President Roosevelt's stamp collection will be placed on exhibition in the National Museum, Aug. 4 to 31, for the golden jubilee convention of the American Philatelic Society.

WHEN all is said and done, the proof of the pudding is the author, and not the plot. J.C. Snaith is an old hand at the game, for he has produced a succession of novels of varying types. Some of his earlier works, such as "The Undefeated," "Araminta" and "The Sailor," have valiantly withstood the havoc of yearly Spring cleanings and still stand victorious on our bookshelves.

THE widow in question, a youngish millionairess described as "extremely pretty" despite "a hard, thin-lipped mouth and * * * the imperiousness of her large eyes," is so decidedly not one of the main characters of this novel that until you get somewhere near the end you wonder what she is doing in the title role.

RADIO is entering a new era, according to Ray V. Sutliffe, editor of Radio Retailing, who asserts "it is facing a sales boom as marked as that which started with the advent of the alternating current tube and dynamic loud-speaker." He justifies his prophecies on the new receiving sets already unveiled.

AN amusement park in the making is the cheerful setting for Clarence Budington Kelland's new book. A painfully shy youth of 27 who has spent all of his adult years at college, studying and tutoring, is unexpectedly shunted into the job of manager at Dreamland Park.

The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in June, which was issued in Washington Tuesday, compares as follows with preceding months and years, with the three-year average of 1923-25 taken as 100:

MANCHESTER, England, July 27, (Canadian Press). -- England made a good start before a crowd of 20,000 today in the fourth cricket test match against South Africa, the first innings closing for 357 runs. The Springboks in reply had scored three runs without loss when bad light stopped play for the day.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. MUSIC lovers by the thousand will journey to the laurel covered slopes of the Berkshire Hills early next month to join with members of the Berkshire Summer colonies in the Symphonic Festival.

ATHENS, July 27. -- Former King George and Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris have reached an agreement through Mayor Kostas Kotzias that in Greece's present divided condition direct consultation of the people's wishes by a plebiscite is preferable to a restoration by Parliament or by armed forces, as many monarchists openly demand.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 27. -- A report of interracial conditions in Mexico, dealing particularly with the church-State conflict there, will be given in Williamstown by a special commission representing the American Committee on the Rights of Religious Minorities next month.

WASHINGTON, July 26, -- Plans for its future activity will be presented in September to the Business Advisory and Planning Council of the Department of Commerce by a program and planning committee appointed at a meeting of the council in Washington on July 11, attended by about thirty members.

In The Spectator Mr. HECTOR BOLITHO laments the decay of letter-writing, the victory of the telephone and swift transit. He is a competent professional biographer. He has had great fun or excitement in hunting up material, old letters and other manuscripts, strange or stray information about his subjects.

GALLERIES which remain a open during the midsummer heat carry on gallantly. Among the exhibitions now current are a number which would deserve more than passing notice even in the busy days of the Fall or Winter season.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 27. -Only a handful of pickets stood today outside the entrance of the New York Shlpbufiding Corporation's plant, , scene of a strike which began nearly eleven weeks ago,

BOONTON, N.J., July 27. -- Nudists in steadily increasing numbers are basking in the sunshine of North Jersey, miles from civilization, seeking haven from the prying eyes of the law in States where nudism is frowned upon.

In an effort to draw up a plan which will protect the public in the purchase of drugs and at the same time be economical in administration, the Drug Institute of America next week will start the collection of data which will be the basis for voluntary action throughout the industry.

SOME sixteen months ago Fox Film executives decided to produce a modern version of Dante's "Inferno." When the script was finished the executives turned it over to Director Harry Lachman, bidding him to make it into a picture.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., July 27. -- Miss Elsie Janis, the actress, who is recovering from injuries received in an automobile accident three days ago, learned here today at Grasslands Hospital that pearls valued at $15,000, lost in the accident, had been recovered and turned over to an insurance company.

Managers and directors of the various regions of the American Power Boat Association were appointed during the week by George W. Sutton Jr., president of the organization, according to an announcement yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27. -- Nolen Richardson's home run with the bases empty in the fifth inning broke up a pitchers' battle between Tony Kaufmann and Marvin Duke today and gave the Bears a 2-to-1 victory in the final game of the series.

The Yankees spent a very trying afternoon at the Stadium yesterday, though what they were trying to do never became quite clear, at least so far as some 10,000 interested onlookers were able to make out. Perhaps it was the singular delivery of one Buck Newsom that befuddled the McCarthy men.

THERE was a time not long since when new recordings of the "Eroica" and "Unfinished" symphonies would have been deplored. But conditions have changed. For one thing, the catalogues have grown during the past few years and most of the urgent demands have been satisfied.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- The attention of criminologists has been directed once more to the Northwestern University Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory, where the "lie detector" has helped to bring another slayer to justice. He is Mills Redmond, 27 years old, and married, who is charged with the murder of Marion Cozo, 17 years old, on Dec. 1, last year.
ANNAPOLIS, July 27. -- President Roosevelt's guest tonight on a weekend cruise down Chesapeake Bay was J.R. McCarl, Controller General, one of the New Deal's sharpest thorns.

THERE is abundant evidence of good metabolism (to borrow a useful word from the Greek) in the recent activity in the Greek department at the Yale Library. According to three separate accounts in the current issue of The Yale University Library Gazette, the library has lately been enriched by gifts which add greatly to its prestige in the field of classical literature.
BERLIN, July 27. -- Are the events of the last two weeks in Germany a prelude to a new purge such as marked in red letters the closing days of June last year?

One of the fascinating features of yacht cruising is that a waterway never looks just the same year after year to the man at the wheel who is following his charts. During recent weeks several important changes in positions of buoys and lighted aids to navigation have been made by a United States Lighthouse Service that is busy year in and year out.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Carrying an impost of 135 pounds Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery today won the $10,000 added Arlington Handicap and lowered the track record for the mile and a quarter, set by Omaha just a week ago.

With the arrival of out-of-town buyers in the local merchandise markets last week very heavy purchases were made liberally in practically all lines, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
AFTER nearly three-quarters of a century of existence the Red Cross came into the news recently in ways which dramatically reflected the far-flung activities of this international humanitarian body.

The class of 1935 of Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken, six weeks after its graduation, June 8, has 60 per cent of its members employed in business and industry, according to a report made yesterday to Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the college, by N.H. Memory, alumni secretary and placement officer.

VIENNA, July 27 (AP). -- Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, standing on the platform at Belgrade from which the Hapsburg monarchy's declaration of war was read on July 28, 1914, reminded Yugoslavs today that dangers accompany any dreams Austrians may have for restoration of the Hapsburg dynasty.

Plans for a marriage of convenience which is expected to be one of the events of the social season may be announced any moment in Moscow. The notice will he given out by the Third Communist International or Comintern, now meeting in the Soviet capital.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The Senate Lobby Committee was disclosed tonight to be contemplating an extended inquiry into any relationships found to exist between members of Congress and lobbyists in general.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- While twenty-one picked officers headed here to attend the police-training course of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the National Rifle Association today announced another police school.

LONDON, July 27. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Fluctuations in foreign exchange were confined within narrow limits because of effective control of operations in the various centres. It is understood that French francs again were supported by the London control authorities.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Golfers are turning their attention to practice for the coming annual tournaments for men and women to be held at White Mountain resorts. A ringer tournament is starting at the Profile Golf Club, Franconia, which will end on Sept. 2.

Your editorial of July 14 in which you quote President Roosevelt's reference to "needless and unwieldy surpluses" and Mr. Gilbertson's letter published in your issue of July 17 illustrate the confusion of thought with reference to these matters on the part of persons unacquainted with accountancy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 27. -- The trial of the Rev. Carl C. McIntire, pastor of the Collingswood, N.J., Presbyterian Church, for alleged insubordination to the authority of the General Assembly of the church was finished here today.
After almost a full year of operation, during which time it has become the play mecca of the lower East Side, Roosevelt Playground is at last nearing completion.

The rights of the Roman Catholic Church in Germany will not be surrendered to Nazis, according to an opinion expressed yesterday in the leading editorial of The Catholic News, a weekly publication. The editorial compared Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's methods to those of Bismarck.

THE theatre season has vanished. Actors have departed for the country, agents have departed for Hollywood. Composers are in their ivory penthouses, rattling the keys over next Fall's flashy concertos. Critics are on their farms.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- No German protest over Mayor La Guardia's denial of a license to a German masseur has been filed with the State Department, and in the absence of such protest there was no official comment.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The issue of whether the Constitution permits the national government to take those measures it deems necessary to solve nation-wide economic and social problems is gradually being formulated for determination by the Supreme Court of the United States.

DETROIT, July 27. -- A housewives' war for lower meat prices left many men scratched and bruised in Hamtramck today, kept police scout cars dashing from one picketed butcher shop to another and sharply curtailed retail meat sales.

In order to eliminate the confusion due to the lack of uniformity in symbols, thirty national organizations and a number of independent experts have developed a graphical "dictionary" of drawings, which has been adopted by the American Standards Association.

In pushing his plans for war in Ethiopia, Benito Mussolini is carrying out an old European custom. During the last half of the nineteenth century the nations of Europe "scrambled" for Africa, each eager to get the largest, richest and most strategical share.

WHEN President Roosevelt came into office he chose Representative Lewis W. Douglas of Arizona to be Director of the Budget. It was announced that the position would have Cabinet rank. In the early months of the Roosevelt administration Mr. Douglas stood high in the councils of the New Deal.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 27. -- A.C. Simonson of New York gained the leadership, at least temporarily, in the Western chess championship tonight by holding A.W. Dake of Portland, Ore., to a draw in the third round of play.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The average member of Congress, who for the past six months has kept his nose to the grindstone, now is finding his burden easier. There has been a decline in important legislation awaiting disposal, and, further, the torrid Summer weather makes for general lethargy.

AN early September publication of the D. Appleton-Century Company will be "The Scandal of Sophie Dawes," by Marjorie Bowen. This is the same Sophie Dawes whose career was the subject of one of the chapters in Victor MacClure's book, "She Stands Accused," which was reviewed in our issue of July 14.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- The week brisk volume of trade at both wholesale and retail, with the wholesale preparing for the influx of between 26,000 and 28,000 buyers for the Interstate Merchants' Council and other trade gatherings here this week.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 27. -- Fourteen international Star Class yachts took part today in the first of a series of elimination races to select a crew to represent the Great South Bay in the North Atlantic championship races at Westhampton in September.

MADISON. Wis., July 27. -- stopped in Wisconsin to talk with Governor Philip La Follette after traveling by automobile through half the States, talking with all kinds of people. I had observed disillusion about President Roosevelt and had heard people high and low in the economic scale deploring the lack of clean-cut cleavage between those who think there must be drastic steps and those who wish to go slowly or stand still.

The total public unemployment relief bill in this city, covered by city, State and Federal funds, will be about $200,000,000 for 1935, a study revealed yesterday. Relief expenditures by private agencies will total about $4,000,000 for the year. Thus public agencies will have expended fifty times the sum of private agencies for relief purposes during 1935.

GATHERED into this interesting volume are extracts from the recent writings of thirty or more eminent men of ten different countries which voice their hopes and ideas for the new and different world into which they believe our old world is changing and merging.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- House Ways and Means Committee Democrats ended their preliminary work on the Tax Bill today, broadening it to dip into the incomes of more than 7,000 individual taxpayers by putting a higher surtax on incomes of $50,000.
ROME, July 27. -- Late this evening Italy had received no answer to her request that Addis Ababa say whether or not Ethiopia was willing to resurrect the conciliation commission.

ANY weekday morning from Monday to Friday, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street is one of the world's busiest crossroads, but at 9 A.M. on a midsummer Sunday, uptown or down, there is hardly a soul in sight.

I read with interest and some entertainment your editorial, "Excessive Speed." I say entertainment, because one cannot fail to be amused by this instance of history repeating itself "with modification." Are we not apt, in the occasional irritation caused by some observation or experience of reckless motor driving, to lose our sense of proportion and incidentally forget history?

NEWARK, N.J., July 27. -- Miss Cherry Mac, pacing mare owned by J.B. Gilligan, and Lulu J, trotting mare owned and driven by R.H. Brooks, were the outstanding performers at the matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

DURING the heat of Summer plants whose flowers or foliage suggest freshness and coolness are especially desirable in the garden. None do this more effectually than the shining white Moon Daisies. Known botanically as Chrysanthemum maximum, the Moon Daisies came originally from the Pyrenees.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 27. -- Great Britain practically assured herself of the Davis Cup for another year by winning the two singles matches today.

THE same Hollywood principle which dictates that the first scenes of motion pictures be photographed last applies also to prizefight sequences: the knockout comes first. After the knockout has been accomplished and recorded, to the wild cheering of the partisan extras, the cameras are set up again and the fighters go to work on the events building up to the tragedy which has happened already.

THE memory book of the traveler becomes less accurate with each passing season. While many customs of manner and dress have been carried along for centuries in foreign lands, the spirit of change is in the air, and what the traveler experienced a year ago may be passe by the time his successor takes up the trail this year.

IF Cliff Reid's case is typical, hectic is the only word which describes a film producer's life. Mr. Reid, who has "The Informer" to his credit, was in town last week and confessed, between conferences, consultations and calls from Hollywood, that in the last three years he has averaged twelve pictures a year for RKO-Radio, and that at the moment he is "shooting" three while preparing six others for the cameras.

A GOOD many familiar twists of crime and sex problem fiction are enlisted in this story, which hinges upon the murder of Dexter, New York blackmailer of frail society women, slain ostensibly by one of his numerous harassed victims during a soiree in the home of millionaire lawyer Lynton.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 27. -- Great Britain practically assured herself of the Davis Cup for another year by winning the two singles matches today.

THE same Hollywood principle which dictates that the first scenes of motion pictures be photographed last applies also to prizefight sequences: the knockout comes first. After the knockout has been accomplished and recorded, to the wild cheering of the partisan extras, the cameras are set up again and the fighters go to work on the events building up to the tragedy which has happened already.

LOUISVILLE. THE vast and fantastic Mammoth Cave in Kentucky, which has attracted hundreds of thousands of visitors, has been improved for this year's influx. New roads have been constructed above the surface, and in the cave itself 100 young CCC workers, laboring for two years with no machines other than wheelbarrows, have completed the longest cave tour in the world.

PLAYWRIGHTS and actors threw up their hands in horror when radio first bid for their talents, and then chopped the three-hour play to fit thirty or sixty minutes. Dramatists thought they would never recognize their own work, but the broadcasters asked for a chance to reveal a new sleight-of-hand in showmanship.

WHEN a young girl from country parsonage goes up to London to make her own way and lead her own life, her story always has interesting possibilities. Angela Menheniot was healthy and normal and looked like a Van Dyck painting.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 27. -- The 326th anniversary of the landing of Sir George Somers, Bermuda's first colonizer, will be celebrated tomorrow with special services in St. Peters Church, oldest British religious edifice in the New world. Canon A.T. Tucker, descendant of an early Bermuda family, will officiate at the services.

VARESE, Italy, July 27. -- With a terrific blast which shook villages and broke window panes in buildings for miles around, the Bickford-Smith munitions factory at Taino blew up this afternoon, taking an estimated toll of fifty lives.
College educations will be provided by the city for ten or twelve city firemen interested in the technical side of fire-fighting, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

WHEN Dr. Einzig sent the last pages of this book to the printer in April, the world had not been startled by the pious and disinterested proofs offered by Messrs. Myers and Newton, in a characteristically impartial organ of public opinion, that President Roosevelt was really to blame even before he entered office for the banking crisis of February and March, 1932.
PRACTICAL home improvement at low cost for the poor folk of the southern Appalachian region was recently demonstrated in novel fashion by the Foundation-Junior High School of Berea College, Kentucky.

ROME, July 27. -- Torn between the conflicting desires to steer clear of a general discussion of the Italo-Ethiopian question in Geneva and at the same time to avoid the appearance of deliberately throwing obstacles in the way of the League of Nations' efforts to find a solution, Premier Mussolini has replied to Maxim Litvinoff's invitation to attend Wednesday's Council meeting with what is at the same time an acceptance and a refusal.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 16 (by Mail). -- Dowager Queen Marie is nearing her sixtieth birthday.

THE Governors of six New England States have been invited to a conference that will have good music as one of its topics of discussion, in connection with the opening on Aug. 8 of the second Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Henry Hadley conducting, on the Hannah Farm near Stockbridge, Mass.

OF the particular Balkan crisis to a phase of which this book is devoted it has been said that "dozens of historians, scores of biographers, have trembled as they drew near and saw it blocking the pathway of their narrative." This was not the way it confronted Dr. Wirthwein.
College educations will be provided by the city for ten or twelve city firemen interested in the technical side of fire-fighting, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

WHEN Dr. Einzig sent the last pages of this book to the printer in April, the world had not been startled by the pious and disinterested proofs offered by Messrs. Myers and Newton, in a characteristically impartial organ of public opinion, that President Roosevelt was really to blame even before he entered office for the banking crisis of February and March, 1932.

LONDON, July 28. -- A suggestion that the League of Nations itself declare a "provisional protectorate over Ethiopia" was made in all seriousness tonight by Sir Hesketh Bell, former Governor of Uganda [British protectorate in East Africa] and for many years one of Britain's foremost experts on African problems.

THERE is much good in Richard A. Loederer's "Voodoo Fire in Haiti" (Doubleday, Doran $2.75). The pity is that he wrote his book with so many Sunday supplement first principles in mind. Some expert probably is responsible for that. The book reads as though Mr. Loederer had been given an impassioned talking to on What the Public Wants.

Markets for commodity futures were generally dull last week although prices advanced moderately. In the cash markets, all grains, lard, cocoa, sugar, zinc and silk were higher, while coffee, tin, cotton, print cloths and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The results of a survey of employment conditions in the metal trade industries were announced by the American Federation of Labor today to refute assertions made in a report last month by the National Industrial Conference Board that there was a shortage of skilled workers in those trades.

There appears to be no settlement in sight of the price war being waged in Brooklyn between domestic and foreign cement dealers, writes Wyron L. Matthews in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The domestic cement industry announced a price reduction at the wharf about two weeks ago which Mr. Matthews says was intended to pull in the horns of the foreign cement dealers operating in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Building activities throughout the nation are continuing their forward march back to normalcy which began in 1933, according to E.M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Employers.

Mrs. Theresa Horowitz, 70 years old, of the Hotel Beacon, Broadway and Seventy-fourth Street, died yesterday in Harlem Hospital of injuries received when she was struck Saturday night at Amsterdam Avenue and 140th Street by an automobile driven by Joseph Montouro, 30, of 1,422 Amsterdam Avenue.

LONDON, July 28. -- New evidence of Persian origin of Gothic architecture has been brought to London by Arthur Upham Pope who has just completed his fifth season's work in Iran (Persia) for the American Institute of Persian Art ad Archaeology.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Damage to the Spring wheat crop in the Northwest is estimated at from 25 to 50 per cent and in some instances assertions of 75 per cent are made. Early threshings in Minnesota and South Dakota, however, indicated that injury to durum has been slight, and the yield an acre about a good average bushel in weight.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 28. -- The members of the Plattsburg business and professional men's training camp of 1915, who are attending their first reunion here in twenty years, will be escorted at 10:30 tomorrow morning to the reviewing stand on the parade grounds to witness 1,200 Citizens Military Training Camp candidates display the results of their month's training under officers of the 26th, 389th and 390th Infantries.
This is to ask your readers to help me end the story of a boy named Sam, who lives in a tenement in New York. I know the first part of it well. Here it is -- just as it came to me out of Sam's life.

Connecticut goes at her tercentenary with a vim. If recollection does not err, there have been bigger and older Commonwealths, like New York and Massachusetts, which went much more sedately about their three-hundredth birthday. One reason was perhaps that the Empire State and the Bay State felt themselves too big and too important to go in for more than a dignified bit of commemoration.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 28. -- An announced plan of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation to obtain State police protection, if necessary to enable the shipyard to reopen this week was condemned today by the negotiating committee of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers.

Bill Terry today probably could repeat his classic query of a year ago, "Is Brooklyn still in the League?" without fear of stirring any great resentment in Flatbush, for yesterday at Ebbets Field a crowd of nearly 30,000 cheered him and big Giants as they whitewashed the Casey Stengel troupe in both ends of a double-header.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 28. -- More than 200 attended the Lenox horse show ball at the Lenox Club last night. It was the last of several days of entertainments for horse show judges and exhibitors. Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease was general chairman.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 28. -- The seventeenth annual departure ceremonies of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society were held here this evening at Maryknoll Seminary to bid farewell to sixteen priests and a brother, who set out after the services to missionary posts in the Orient.

IT turns out that the editor of Der Boxsport, the official organ of the German boxing authorities, had it right when he wrote: "However, Schmeling is not interested in facilitating Louis's rise to the championship." In short, a doesn't want to fight the Dark Destroyer from Detroit, and who can blame him?

Resorting to half measures at a time when something more emphatic seemed to be expected of them by a gathering of 22,000, including the distinguished gentleman golfer, Babe Ruth, the Yankees broke even with the Senators in their concluding double-header at the Stadium yesterday and so lost still more ground in their wayward pursuit of an American League pennant.

The Anchor Line has sent out questionnaires to the officers and some of the men on the ships of the fleet asking for suggestions to be incorporated in construction of new ships planned for the company's Indian service, it was learned yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 28. -- Orders from the Comintern (Communist International) to Communist parties in capitalist countries, including the United States, were made public here today.

Howard S. Cullman, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority and president of the Beekman Street Hospital, appeals to the city to support the voluntary hospitals of New York in caring for city cases in his annual report for 1934, sent to the directors of the institution today.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 28. -- Watchful waiting appears to have been the keynote in the moderate trading in the cotton market here last week. Advices from Washington were closely scanned with a view to arriving at some idea as to the government's policy on loans to farmers in the coming season.

The Capitol Theatre will cease presenting stage shows and, after Aug. 9, will limit its entire program to the screen, it was announced yesterday by its managing director, Major Edward Bowes.
