Among the holdings were the thirteen-story Hotel Bristol at 129-35 West Forty-eighth Street, the Seventy-second Street Playhouse at 346-50 East Seventy-second Street and a two-story taxpayer at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Fortieth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29. -- Justice of the Peace D. Wiley Travis of Peekskill pleaded before Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley this afternoon that he was a lover of dogs and had "leaned over backward" to save the life of King, pet police dog of Mrs. Marie Van Der Wee, who brought a Supreme Court action against Justice Travis based on her contention that he threatened to execute King.
David Rosoff, president of the Amtorg, Soviet trading agency in the United States, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie from Moscow. It is his first visit to this country.

ANGLETON, Texas, July 29. -- Three editors and three reporters of Houston newspapers were cited for contempt of court by Judge M.S. Munson here today. They must report in court on Thursday to defend themselves on charges of contempt of court because the newspapers printed testimony in the murder trial of Clyde Thompson, prison farm inmate, last week.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Alexander Smallens conducted a program of exceptionally effective compositions, which he interpreted with authority and fire, last night at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society in the Lewisohn Stadium. The compositions were Tchaikovsky's Fourth Symphony, Richard Strauss's "Don Juan" and the same composer's "Death and Transfiguration."

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Four New York real estate syndicates under the management of New York Investors, Inc., are fighting $289,284 in additional income taxes assessed on them by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, the records of the Board of Tax Appeals showed today.

In an attempt to arbitrate the question whether a 2-month-old boy shall be brought up as a Catholic or as a Jew, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn said yesterday that he would meet on Thursday with a Jewish rabbi, a Catholic priest and the parents of the child.

For the first time in its history the training ship Empire State has been visiting Cork, Ireland, and the enthusiastic welcome and cordial reception from the authorities and residents have been remarkable. The city itself has assumed all expenses for pilot fees, tugs and docking charges, and the cadets have been welcomed into the homes of the residents.

A committee for the common stockholders of the McCrory Stores Corporation will oppose the proposed plan of reorganization of that company at a hearing today before a special master in the Federal court here. This committee, of which Henry U. Harris of Harris, Upham Co. is chairman, is said to represent 175,000 of the 443,000 common shares outstanding.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Blanche Dunkel tonight identified Mrs. Evely Smith, rushed from New York by airplane, as the woman she had accused of the slaying of Ervin Lang.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of John Erskine and C. Paul Jennewein, sculptor, to the Municipal Art Commission, bringing its personnel to the required number of ten.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 29. -- After the failure of D.P. Aalberse to form a parliamentary Cabinet, Queen Wilhelmina requested former Premier Hendryk Colijn today to try to form an extra-parliamentary government on a broad basis.

With furniture and furs leading, August sales events in local department stores have gotten off to a good start, retail executives here reported yesterday. Gains of 25 per cent or more in fur volume were reported, with indications being that this percentage of gain would be bettered next month.

One hundred and fifty delegates from various local anti-Nazi groups met last night in the headquarters of the Anti-Nazi Federation of New York, 168 West Twenty-third Street, to frame a program of activity for the next several months. The delegates reported that they represented a total membership in their organizations of 139,000 persons.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29. -- James F. Fletcher, 75 years old, of 271 Hawthorne Avenue, Yonkers, who came to this country from Ireland in 1884, was not a citizen of the United States in the eyes of the State of New York until today, although he obtained his final citizen's papers in 1900.

Hymie Golden's wonderful crow Jake, who tired of quiet suburban life in East Setauket, L.I., after three patient months as guardian of the cash register in Mr. Golden's garage, was back home yesterday, wiser in the ways of the world after a taste of urban life.

PARIS, July 29. -- The sharp rise in the Dutch florin to slightly above its gold export point following the news of former Premier Colijn's recall by Queen Wilhelmina to form a new Dutch Cabinet dominated the French Bourse today just as the fall of the florin did last week.

MANCHESTER, England, July 29. -- Unless one team collapses another draw is in prospect in the fourth test cricket match between England and South Africa. One day remains to finish the encounter and practically two innings have to be played.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- A bill carrying President Roosevelt's "wealth-sharing" tax program, with an excess profits tax on corporations for which he did not ask, was introduced in the House today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee with an announcement that he would attempt to rush it through before the weekend adjournment.

With a thousand policemen and plainclothes men held in readiness for possible trouble along the waterfront as a result of the membership drive launched yesterday by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in cooperation with the International Longshoremen's Association, the first day of the campaign passed without disturbances.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Cook County adopted today the plan of A.C. Allyn Co. and Stifel, Nicolaus Co., investment houses, for carrying out a $48,000,000 refunding program, under which its defaults will be wiped out and its credit position improved.

A new technic of city planning is needed to eliminate colossal losses, assure their avoidance in the future and promote public health and opportunity for civic design, the annual report of the committee on civic design of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects declares.

COPENHAGEN, July 29. -- Fifty thousand farmers demonstrated today before the royal palace in Copenhagen for four hours in their effort to obtain better prices for their products and relief from their debts.

The National Power and Light Company reports for the twelve months ended on June 30 a consolidate net income of $6,161,245 after all deductions, equal, after preferred dividends, to 82 cents a share on 5,456,117 common shares, against $6,815,078, or 94 cents a share in the preceding twelve months.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- A Works Progress Administration project which would provide $718,840 for a year's employment of about 7,000 professional musicians and entertainers in Chicago was submitted to Washington for approval today by the Illinois WPA officials.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- New York City's claim for $764,143.75 re-imbursement of expenditures on sixty-six regiments which the city raised, equipped and furnished in the early days of the Civil War, was approved by the Senate today without a record vote and was sent to the House.

CLEVELAND, July 29. -- The Indians did a right-about-face today and walloped Alvin Crowder for a half dozen runs in the sixth inning to beat the Tigers, 6 to 5, for the first time in their last twelve attempts. The defeat cut the Tigers' league-leading margin to two and a half games over the idle Yankees.

A special Statutory Court, which was recently directed by the United States Supreme Court to review its findings in the Borden milk-rate case and base its decision on a proof of facts rather than on allegations contained in a complaint and answer, handed down an opinion yesterday, reaffirming its belief that Section 258q of the Milk Control Law of New York is constitutional.
Paul Kress of 1,094 Simpson Street, the Bronx, was brought forward yesterday by two fellow masseurs as "Mr. K," the German to whom a masseur's license was refused last week.

THE publication by Oxford University Press of H.W. Horwill's "Modern American Usage" ($3.25) is pretty full of significance. The English have long been amazed and amused at what the Americans have done to the English language, but for how long have they really wanted to know anything about it?

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Supplies of hogs continue far below normal for this season of the year, and while the demand here was not aggressive today, the market was strong to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher, compared with Friday. Some lightweight sows were quoted as much as 20 cents higher.

LONDON, July 29. -- The annual Malvern festival, by this time a veritable Baireuth for admirers of George Bernard Shaw, opened tonight with the English premiere of "The Simpleton of the Unexpected Isles." The play has been seen in New York.

Malnutrition born of five years of depression has rendered 135,000 children in the city's elementary schools too weak and undernourished to profit by attendance in regular classes, the Board of Education was informed yesterday in the annual report of its division of physically handicapped children.

Mrs. Mary Law Heide received a weekly allowance of $22.50 from her husband, Julius A. Heide Jr., son of a wealthy candy manufacturer, yesterday from Justice John Warren Hill in Domestic Relations Court. The payments for the support of Mrs. Heide and their daughter will start Saturday.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 29. -- What promises to be the outstanding sensation of the present festival took place tonight when Arturo Toscanini, returning after a considerable number of years to his first love, opera, conducted an astounding performance of Verdi's "Falstaff."
Following are the grand jurors chosen yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook to investigate organized crime and racketeering:

The Public Service Commission gave formal approval yesterday to new electric light and power schedules of the Consolidated Gas system. It is estimated that they will save consumers in this city about $7,000,000 a year.
News service dispatches from Berlin Monday that the Nazis would abate their campaign against the Jews, Catholics and "reactionaries" were not borne out by a survey yesterday of the German situation.
IV'lncent IV. Howard, in 319 E. 50th St.; Arthur J. Cohen, in 885 Park Av.; Potter, Hamilton Co., brokers.

Detective William Ford, 45 years old, of the Erie Railroad police, was shot and killed last night in a revolver battle with an unidentified man on the railroad right-of-way 1500 feet from the county road in Secaucus, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Strictures by Representative Goldsborough of Maryland upon the Senate subcommittee which drafted the Senate version of the Omnibus Banking Bill are resented by subcommitteemen, and his conclusion, voiced in a House speech yesterday, that "influences surrounded" the writing of the open market provision seems likely to bring a clash when the conferees meet tomorrow.

ADDIS ABABA, July 30. -- Shops here have shut their doors at the instigation of Bombay Armenian firms, who sent out clerks today to proclaim a hartal (cessation of all work) which is expected to last three days. Their object is to force a change in the policy of the Emperor, who has checked the exportation of silver, except through the Bank of Ethiopia, and pegged the thaler to sterling at about 13.50.
Prices moved in fairly narrow channels yesterday among bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange, the railroads and foreign list commanding the most attention.

BERLIN, July 30. -- While there are not lacking lone, even powerful, voices which deprecate and deplore the present anti-Semitic campaign in Germany, it is a mistake to assume on that account the campaign is waning or even being modified. Its outward aspect is being changed; that is all.

Mr. Sanford's "Showboat Revue" -- which is lower Tappan Zee's best Summer theatre -- will celebrate the advent of a new month by changing its bill a week from tonight. New songs, new dances and a new principal or so. Charles Kemper, the comedian, will remain on duty, however.

HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 30. -- With armed sentries guarding the road to the Navesink Lighthouse Station, the new "mystery ray," developed at the United States Signal Corps laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N.J., was tested for the first time under actual working conditions at the station early this morning, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Presidential support for efforts by the city of Newark to repurchase the army base, now under lease to the Mercur Corporation, was reported by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein today after a conference with Mr. Roosevelt.
A Catholic boycott of the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin is asked by The Commonweal, Catholic weekly, in an editorial in its Aug. 9 issue, to be published Monday.

MEXICO, D.F., July 30. -- Tomas Garrido Canabal, former Governor of Tabasco and later Federal Minister of Agriculture, invited foreign correspondents to visit Tabasco in his airplane to be convinced that he is not guilty of the charges hurled against him by political opponents following the clash a fortnight ago in which ten persons were killed and twenty wounded when Tabascans from the capital went home to vote.

The share market withstood a sizable amount of profit-taking yesterday without great difficulty. The movement to realize on gains, following the rapid bidding up of prices during the last few days, taxed the market at the outset, with the tape running about a minute behind at the end of the first half hour.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- A hint that the long-delayed work relief program finally was about to get underway was given by the Work Relief Allotment Committee today as it pared down the sum set aside for direct relief in August to $95,000,000.

Two youthful members of a band of five men and two women, held for a murder in Philadelphia last Thursday, were identified in Homicide Court yesterday as the participants in a liquor store hold-up in which a man was killed in Washington Heights last Wednesday.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 30. -- The failure of the American Davis Cup team became an utter rout on the centre court today when the British won two more singles engagements and thus made a clean sweep of all five matches in the challenge round.

The authorities of the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx have started a drive against visitors to the zoo with distorted senses of humor. Yesterday this campaign resulted in one man going to jail for two days because he threw a lighted cigar to the gorilla Sunday.

MILWAUKEE, July 30. -- First prize and the Western chess championship now rest definitely between Reuben Fine of New York, defending titleholder, and Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., who tonight drew in their encounter after a brief struggle.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- President Roosevelt received recommendations for allotment of $370,000,000 for work relief projects and approved several loans and grants. He conferred with Representative Celler of New York, calling his attention to an expression of sympathy for persecuted groups in Germany made public by the State Department.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- Until today the Yankees hadn't lost a ball game at Shibe Park this year. They had won all five played here. But they changed the order today.

LONDON, July 30. -- The horrors of the next war's gas attacks are vividly foreshadowed in the first of a series of six official handbooks that the newly formed Air Raid Precautions Department of the Home Office is issuing tomorrow.
PARIS, July 30. -- The wheat situation in France is approaching a critical stage for farmers, according to a recent bulletin of the Wheat Producers Association.

Members of the House Ways and Means Committee who drafted the proposed new taxes estimate that they will yield a total of $275,000,000 a year. This is an admission that, as a revenue and "budget-balancing" measure, the new bill is of negligible importance. For $275,000,000 would reduce the officially estimated deficit for the current fiscal year by less than one-sixteenth.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Adoption of an amendment clarifying paragraph (b) of Rule AN 8 which relates to the securities of issuers in bankruptcy was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Nearly 6,000 Germans and German-Americans, attending two protest meetings last night, booed Mayor La Guardia as "a Red and a Jew" and declared he had stirred up religious and racial hatreds.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- In the guarded phrases characteristic of diplomatic correspondence but with unmistakable meaning, the administration today expressed official sympathy for Jews undergoing persecution in Germany.
HANKOW, CHINA, July 30 (AP). -- A great pile of rude wooden coffins -- a veritable mountain of the dead -- is growing ever higher on the banks of the Yangtse River near here.

LOUISBURG, N.C., July 30 (AP). -- Govan Ward, 25-year-old Negro axe slayer of C.J. Stokes, Franklin County farmer, was lynched today by a mob which took him from officers and hanged him to a tree half a mile from the scene of the killing.

The first number of the new series of The Colophon -- A Quarterly for Bookmen -- will appear today in a different format from the original series which was published from 1980 through 1934 in twenty quarterly parts.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Stockholders of the Oliver Farm Equipment Company approved today a plan of reorganization that will wipe out preferred dividend arrears and provide for the issuance of one class of common stock in exchange for all shares outstanding.

GENEVA, July 30. -- A strong Italian effort to rush the League of Nations Council into reviving arbitration in some form began here with the arrival today of the two Italian members of the arbitral commission. The fact that they arrived before the Italian Council member, Baron Pompeo Aloisi, and that Count Luigi Aldrovandi-Marescotti then called on higher League officials, are considered significant of Rome's tactics.

Perhaps shuffle board and deck tennis are the most popular sports aboard ship, but the fisherman hasn't been crowded out of the picture yet. That is, not if others will follow the procedure adopted by Gouverneur Morris Phelps and Philip K. Crowe on a recent trip to Cuba.

VIENNA, July 30. -- Signs of widespread Communist activities in the Austrian Army were exposed today when the first special military court to be constituted under a law promulgated on the abolition of the Republican Constitution met to try eight army men on charges of incitement to mutiny.

David Higgins, 22 years old, of Kenilworth, N.J., was drowned yesterday at Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., as dangerous outward-racing sea currents, known as "sea pusses," endangered bathers along the Jersey coast, necessitating scores of rescues by life-saving corps at the various resorts.

IN one of Donald Ogden Stewart's plays an elderly man is made to explain his pre-eminence as a drinker by the line that he has stuck eternally at it and has never watched the clock. Reading R.L.G. Irving's "The Romance of Mountaineering" (Dutton, $5), one senses the same fanatical determination to make all the world of another sport, mountaineering.
Mayor La Guardia's 1936 budget request of $104,712 is reduced by $113 from his current budget of $104,825, schedules filed with R.E. McGahen, Budget Director, showed yesterday.

Protest against "the chain and syndicate store lobby directed toward destroying manufacturers' trade stabilization endeavors" will be lodged with members of Congress by members of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives in behalf of their organization, according to a resolution adopted at a meeting yesterday of the group at the offices of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., 225 West Thirty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Troubled by the growing payroll of his new resettlement administration, Rexford Guy Tugwell, the director, planned today to discharge 7,000 to 8,000 of his employes.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Disregarding in part President Roosevelt's advice to let no doubts as to constitutionality block the legislation, a House Ways and Means Subcommittee today handed the Guffey coal bill back to the full committee, without recommendation.
Thomas E. Dewey, the city's special prosecutor of racketeers, threatened last night to use the State's income tax laws, if necessary, to rid New York of organized crime.

Colonel Bill Terry, an exceedingly thorough man, thought he had taken every precaution as he marshalled his forces at the Polo Grounds yesterday in his scheme to entrench his Giants firmly in first place in the National League pennant race.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- An amendment providing leeway of six months within which to sue the government for damages resulting from abrogation of the gold clause in government securities was proposed to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Senator McAdoo.

NEWARK, N.J., July 30. -- Robert S. Greer of 843 Lake Street, a collector for the Prudential Insurance Company, was beaten by two men and robbed of $80 late today in a vacant house at 107 Beaumont Place, when he visited the house in response to a telephone call received in his office from a person who said he wanted to buy insurance and directed him to that address.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- American exports, including re-exports, amounted to $170,193,000 in June, compared with $165,456,000 in May, and $170,519,000 in June, 1934, the Commerce Department reported today, the analysis revealing that exports exceeded imports for the first time in three months.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP). -- The Browns, showing no favoritism to American League leaders, routed Schoolboy Rowe of the Tigers today to take the series opener, 8 to 6. Pete Fox, Tiger right fielder, and Julius Solters, Brown left fielder, got home runs.
That disturber of neighborhood friendships, the baby show, came to Washington Heights yesterday -- with variations.

A drop in the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 914, as against 1,032 in the previous week and 1,012 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Unless Howard C. Hopson, the dominating influence in the Associated Gas and Electric system, appears in Washington for examination by the Senate Lobby Committee tomorrow, or submits evidence that it is physically impossible for him to testify, the committee will formally request the Department of Justice to order a wide search for him.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Ways and Means minority report on the Administration Taw Bill read as follows:
LONDON, July 30. -- Professor Ivan Petrovich Pavlov, most famous of Russian scientists, announced today that he had proved that dogs possessed the same four fundamental temperaments as human beings.

The Procter Gamble Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a profit of $19,120,324 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. After setting aside $4,000,000 for materials and products price equalization, there was a net profit of $15,120,324 available for dividends, equal, after dividend requirements on the 8 and 5 per cent preferred stocks, to $2.23 a share on 6,325,087 no-par shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Replying to the radio address by Henry P. Fletcher of the Republican National Committee, challenging many New Deal measures as unconstitutional, Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic Senate leader, declared today that the Republican chairman was in effect criticizing leading members of his own party.

Harold Pfleger, 14-year-old Bronx boy who has undergone eighty-five blood transfusions and six operations in eight months, will leave New York Hospital on Saturday and return to his home, officials of the hospital announced last night.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP). -- Dart O'Mahoney, 22-year-old former Irish Free State soldier, tonight hurled Ed George out of the ring with a mighty heave to become the first undisputed heavyweight wrestling champion since Ed (Strangler) Lewis.

ALONG came Dazzy Vance of the dear old Brooklyn Dodgers, looking like a blond Zeppelin out for an airing. That's one thing about those Dodgers, they are a well-fed club. The story from the West was that cruel Casey Stengel had cut off their beer, right in the middle of the hot spell, too, merely because they were losing a flock of ball games.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30. -- The semi-final round brackets of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament were filled this evening at the Meadow Brook Club when three teams moved forward to join Ridge in this round. Houston, Long Island and Delhi were the winning teams in the last of the second-round matches.

As late as last year WALTER WILLIAMS, the journalist who became president of a university -- and one of the great State universities -- completed a six months' tour of the globe whose affairs had for half a century been his daily concern. He came to know the earth as widely and as intimately as the astronomer, SHAPLEY, born in the same State (Missouri) knows the stars in his night skies.

Mayor La Guardia and the supporters of Paul Kress, the German masseur unable to obtain a city license as a result of an order by the Mayor, remained deadlocked over the affair yesterday. The Mayor, before departing in the morning for Washington, insisted that he would not change his ruling, but prominent German-Americans remained hopeful.

The proposed plan of reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation was approved by five groups of creditors and investors and opposed by two other groups at a hearing yesterday morning before R.P. Stephenson, special master, in the Federal court, sitting in the Port Authority Building, Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 30. -- A complete upset of form on all fronts marked the quarter-final round today in the invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club, as one favorite after another succumbed to the vagaries of the innocent-looking but treacherous course.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Plans for a Senate recess from today until Thursday went awry when Senator Hastings, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, used an hour in a political speech today, thus interrupting debate on a pension bill which Senator Robinson, Democratic leader, sought to have passed.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $2,936,294 for the six months ended on June 30, after interest, depreciation and extraordinary expenses resulting from the low rate of activity at its Lake Superior ore properties.
Business in money was light and chiefly of a routine character. Quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.

A vagrant to whom Mrs. Leah Schotland, 88 years old, gave a dollar out of a window of her ground-floor apartment at 1,975 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, rang the bell a few minutes later, assaulted the aged woman and robbed her of two diamond rings.

It is certainly about time that something be done to reduce interest rates on home mortgages. Only a short time ago the savings banks were paying 4 1/2 per cent on deposits and charging 6 per cent. They have gradually reduced interest on deposits to 2 per cent, a reduction of 2 1/2 per cent, but have only passed on to the mortgagors one-fifth of this reduction, or one-half of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Plans were made today by which President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing bill, as broadened by the Ways and Means Committee, would be taken up in the House Thursday and rushed through that body before the end of the week.

BIG BAY, Mich., July 30. -- Many scores of congratulatory messages reminded Henry Ford of his seventy-second birthday today, although his Huron Mountain Club retreat is far from a telephone or telegraph wire.
PARIS, July 30. -- Premier Pierre Laval and Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, took the train together for Geneva tonight to attend tomorrow's Council meeting.
PARIS, July 30. -- The French and German Governments tonight reached a provisional understanding for settlement of the clearing agreement between them, which expires tomorrow night.
NEWARK, N.J., July 30. -- Newark gained a ten-inning decision over Montreal, 5 to 4, under the lights tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 30. -- Lloyd Nordstrom, Davenport, Iowa, who never had qualified before, today won the medal of the national public links golf championship by a one-shot margin. He had a 36-hole total of 145.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The index of prices paid to farmers for their products was 102 on July 1, fifteen points higher than a year ago but two points below the previous month, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

MOSCOW, July 30. -- A strike of "unprecedented scope" by seamen and dock workers on the Pacific Coast of the United States, beginning in September under Communist leadership, was predicted today in a speech of Samuel Darcy, American Communist party delegate, before the Comintern (Communist International) Congress, now meeting here.

The fact that the rise which has taken place in the stock market since March (with but few interruptions) has been without benefit of the pool operations of yesteryear may account for the orderliness in a day such as yesterday, when the urge to take profits was insistent.

With the second largest audience of the season to applaud it, the Fokine Ballet danced its farewell for the season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. Though some observers placed the attendance at 14,000, which would have been higher than that of the opening night, a more conservative estimate was of an audience between 11,000 and 12,000.

TRENTON, N.J., July 30. -- The city of Newark was notified today by the State Relief Council that it must pay the $760,344 due the council on monthly relief assessments since Jan. 1. Failure to pay this sum will result in the cancellation by the council of the payments of rents of Newark relief clients, aggregating about $1,500,000 annually.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, July 30. -In almost a flat calm T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour today sailed to victory in the Royal Victoria Yacht Club's international Gold Cup race, in which all eight of the Class J yachts competed.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Technicalities which have led Controller General McCarl to hold up more than $40,000,000 worth of work-relief funds for New York City threaten plans of General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for the city, for putting 100,000 needy on relief jobs during August.
LONDON, July 30. -- When Parliament adjourns Friday, it will be until Oct. 29, according to an announcement made by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin in the House of Commons today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- The opening round of play in the women's invitation tournament got under way at the Maidstone Club this morning and resulted in a sweeping procession for the favorites.
PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP). -- Running their winning streak to ten games, the Cubs downed the Pirates, 9 to 6, today.

The work of running down and punishing racketeers in this city has begun with promptness and vigor. The new grand jury was quickly drawn. If there was truth in the suspicion that the panel had been quietly infiltrated with some men not unfriendly to the underworld, that was at once disposed of by the examinations and eliminations conducted by Mr. DEWEY on the basis of a careful police checking of the records.

Miss Lucy H. Gillett, head of the nutrition bureau of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, defended yesterday the twenty-five-cents-a-day allowances for food by the Home Relief Bureau and private agencies, as sufficient for a proper diet.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The State Department received from the German Government today a most emphatic protest against the alleged insult to the German swastika emblem by a mob that tore a flag from the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen at its dock in New York last Friday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30. -- The Federal Government today threatened immediate action against radical forces that are agitating against maritime labor peace on the Pacific Coast and interfering with the mails.

After nine weeks in the music capitals of Europe as "a prospector for golden voices," Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will return to his desk in a few days, prepared to take up with his assistant general manager, Edward Ziegler, and some of his technical staff, details of the new season of grand opera that will open at the Metropolitan on Dec. 16.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30. -- Making the most of a fast start, Alvin Untermyer's Gold Foam scored in the hardest kind of drive by the scant margin of a head at the end of the six furlongs of the Seneca Stakes, feature today at the Spa. George Odom's hard-luck horse, Chancery, which has failed to triumph recently despite several powerful efforts, pressed the victor.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 30 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph Wilson Sutton, vicar of Trinity Chapel in New York City, tonight was elected Episcopal Bishop of Vermont by a special diocesan convention on the fourth ballot.

With trading restricted as the foreign exchange market awaited clarification of the financial and political situation in the Netherlands, the prices of all European currencies were narrow and uneven yesterday.

A 10-year-old boy and his 14-year-old girl playmate were killed yesterday morning in a head-on collision between the boy's bicycle and an automobile driven by a policeman on Tompkins Avenue near St. Mary's Avenue, Rosebank, S.I.
Mr. Dewey swings into action against the racketeers, and we may take it for granted that before he is through the future of "racket" a member in good standing of the English language will be assured.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- With President Roosevelt's approval, Senate and House conferees on the Social Security Bill worked out today a plan which the administration hopes will result in early enactment of the legislation. It has been tied up for more than a month in what appeared to be a hopeless disagreement between the two branches of Congress.
Housing properties in various parts of the city were in the realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Thousands of silver dollars were hurried into the Treasury Department today and stowed in newly completed vaults, as Secretary Morgenthau continued concentrating the government's silver holdings here.

The Hon. Calypso Baring Liddell, daughter of the late Baron Revelstoke and half-sister of Lorillard Suffern Tailer of Rumson, N.J., was admitted to the United States yesterday after appearing at Ellis Island before a special board of inquiry. Her four children also were admitted on a six-month visitors' visa.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30. -- A group of the season's debutantes and other young women of the Summer colony wore Greek, Russian, Bulgarian, Italian, Syrian and Persian costumes this afternoon as ushers and saleswomen at Heartsease, home of Mrs. Charles L. F. Robinson, on Kay Street, for the opening of a two-day sale in the interest of the International Students' Exchange.
CLEVELAND, July 30. -- Walter Johnson's career as pilot of the fifth place Indians depends on a conference at Detroit this week-end with Alva Bradley, president of the club.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -Mark Flanagan of Westhampton Beach annexed principal honors today in a Long Island Golf Association one-day handicap tournament at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- A government bureau office, knee-deep in rejection slips, was the scene conjured up here today by whimsical ones who listened to details of a proposed $500,000 project to aid unemployed poets.

Reports to date indicate that the Class I railroads, as a group, suffered a net loss of $3,400,000 in June, against a net income of $5, 869,000 in June, 1934. This would bring the net loss for the first half of 1935 to about $60,000,000, against a loss of $24,853,000 in the same period a year ago and a loss of $101,204,000 in the same period two years ago.
Davis Co., Inc., V. R. Davis, president, new export and import firm, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center,

BOSTON, July 30. -- Ebony Lady, black daughter of the famous Flying Ebony, finished two lengths before Bold Lover today in the Yannis Purse, one-mile feature for 3-year-olds and upward, to set a new track record of 1:38 1-5 at Suffolk Downs.

Aurelio Vasquez, 26 years old, a native of Puerto Rico, admitted in Special Sessions yesterday that the flat in which he lived at 75 East 119th Street had been the headquarters of a policy ring and declared that the rent of $21 a month had been paid by the Home Relief Bureau.

After a restful nap under the boardwalk and a cooling drink at a near-by bar, Joseph Revera, 27 years old, of 425 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, stood on the boardwalk at Rockaway Beach yesterday and watched six lifeguards, a police emergency squad and the crew of a police launch search for his "body" in the surf off Beach Sixty-sixth Street, Arverne.
MALONE, N.Y., July 30. -- This was a bad day for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who is on trial before Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant here for income tax evasion.

Three additional Thursday concerts by Creatore and the New York State Symphonic Band, composed of musicians from the ERB Concert Unit, are announced for Jones Beach, L.I. The first is scheduled for tomorrow afternoon and the others for Aug. 8 and 15.

Rome will not boycott Geneva. At one time it was feared that she would, since MUSSOLINI was represented as resolutely against submitting his controversy with Ethiopia to arbitration or inquiry by the League of Nations. Rather than do that, it was alleged, he would give notice of Italy's withdrawal from the League.

Fresh from his conquest at Bald Peak Sunday, the veteran George Voigt scored a dramatic triumph yesterday in the annual William Henry Beers memorial golf tournament on the Fox Hills course, Clifton, S.I.

The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and its subsidiaries report for the six months to June 30 total income of $691,187 and net income after expenses, taxes and charges of $254,474, including net security profits of a wholly owned subsidiary amounting to $131,773.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 30 (AP). -- When Great Britain completed its Davis Cup sweep today it marked the first time the United States had been whitewashed in the challenge round in twenty-four years.

May I not take exception to a dereliction that seems to crop up every once in a while in your columns? I refer to the omission, in printing the names of underworld characters, of the "monikers' by which they are known among their own set. For example, today you print the names of three "Dutch Schultz" aides, but in only one case do you give us, parenthetically, the nickname.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 30. -- As Great Britain completes the rout of the United States in the challenge round of Davis Cup play by winning the last two singles matches, the question arises: "Why did the American team lose?" With it comes another annual query, "What of next year?"

LONDON, July 30. -- The tendency remained firm on the London Stock Exchange today, although only a moderate amount of business was transacted. British Government stocks moved forward around midday as investment buying was resumed.

PARIS, July 30. -- Chanel is opening the Winter fashion season with a strong offensive against all period influence. Concentrate entirely on the present is her slogan. Every one of her models allows complete freedom of movement. She features asymmetrical design and cut, thus emphasizing the enveloping spiral movement that outlines without stressing the body lines.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday did little more than mark time pending announcement of the government's decision on next season's loan. With crop improvement a feature of the past month and a general tendency to anticipate an upward revision in yield estimates, operators seemed less inclined to furnish support.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 30. -- "The veterans who are gathering at Plattsburg symbolize the finest in American patriotism" and "they furnish a shining example for American youth," President Roosevelt wrote today in a greeting sent to the reunion of the regiment of 1915, the first to train at the Plattsburg citizens' military camp.

Mrs. Vincent Astor, Lady Beatrice Granard, Lady Dudley Ward and the Baron and Baroness John Dewar Forteviot are among the passengers sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Normandie. Others sailing are:
A general shake-up of the city's detective force was foreseen at police headquarters yesterday to take place between Aug. 1 and 15.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 30. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, promised a "bare-knuckle" fight by his party in the Fall campaign as he spoke here today on his "pep tour."

MOSCOW, July 30. -- Continued reports of bad weather -- from Canada, where tempests are raging, to Moscow, where fresh rains today again soaked the already soggy air field -- are still holding the Soviet plane that is ready to fly to San Francisco by way of the North Pole.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- On a small television screen built into a radio cabinet a group of chorus girls, an orchestra and Mickey Mouse performed this afternoon for an invited audience at the Television Laboratories, Inc., in Chestnut Hill.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (AP). -- Bennie Frey won his own ball game for the Reds today, connecting for a single to score the winning run to defeat the Cardinals, 6 to 5. The victory snapped the Reds' losing streak. Frey's winning blow came after two were out in the ninth.

The State Department is interested in the Moscow congress of the Communist International. It would like to know whether Comintern instructions to the Communist party in this country violate the spirit of the pledges given by the Soviet Government when it was recognized by Washington in 1933.

Keen competition was evident in the sale yesterday by the city of Lynn, Mass., of a new issue of $400,000 of temporary loan notes, due in equal amounts on July 1 and July 8, 1936. Award went to the First Boston Corporation, whose price was on a 0.41 per cent basis.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 30. -The first leg of the Larchmont Yacht Club's junior cruise ended with no finishers off this port today, due to a sudden and complete failure of the breeze that had taken the four racing craft from Larchmont to Lloyds Point Buoy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- On one of the finest days of tennis Southampton has known in years, Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, national clay court champion, was defeated, and Gregory Mangin of Newark, national indoor titleholder, escaped a similar fate by the margin of a net-cord volley today in the forty-eighth annual invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

MANCHESTER, England, July 30 (Canadian Press). -- South Africa maintained its advantage in the test cricket series with England by forcing a draw in the fourth match concluded today. Failure of the mother country to win the remaining match next month would result in the Springboks being declared victors in the international series as they are credited ,with the only victory to date, three games having been drawn.

Henry H. Heimann, formerly executive head of the Shipping Board of the Department of Commerce, has drafted a shipping bill for the department that is being considered as a substitute for the Copeland and Bland bills, the original administration legislation.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

BERLIN July 30. -- The Boerse was quiet and generally weaker today, due to the uncertainty of the international currency situation and the cessation of purchases from the blocked-mark account. Changes for the most part, however, were small and insignificant.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- A new attack on the processing taxes levied under the Agricultural Adjustment Act was opened today when the Quaker Oats Company filed suit in the Federal District Court challenging the legality of the act and seeking an injunction against further collections by the government.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- While bullish sentiment continues to predominate among wheat traders on the Board of Trade, they are not disposed to follow advances with buying orders. There also is a rather pronounced desire on the part of scattered longs to take profits on the bulges.

In the first month of operations since the scrapping of the Steel Code, employment in the industry was maintained last month at 98.9 per cent of the May level, despite a drop of 8.6 per cent in production in June, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Applications of eleven companies or bondholders' committees for registration of securities on the New York Stock Exchange were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows:

While the police said yesterday that a preliminary audit of the books of N. Miller, whose jewelry shop at 743 Fifth Avenue was robbed Monday, indicated that the loot taken was worth about $75,000, the owner, Nicolai Miller, who had hurriedly returned from a vacation in Virginia, asserted that the loss would be nearer $100,000.

In a legal opinion given to the Board of Estimate, Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, ruled that New York City could not borrow $6,000,000 from the Federal government under a twenty-five-year amortization plan to acquire title to property on which to build a westerly approach to the Triborough Bridge.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 (AP). -- Joe Hauser's home run in the seventh inning with one on, and an eighth-innning rally enabled Minneapolis to defeat the American Association All-Stars, 4 to 3, before 8,000 fans today.

Eight housing properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday. The largest parcel was a fifteen-story apartment structure at the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 101st Street.
More than 700 employes of the New York Central Railroad will go on the pension rolls today. The retiring employes, all of whom have reached the age of 70, live in nine States.
Your editorial "Savings," July 27, is perhaps encouraging and helpful. For the sake of accuracy, however, may I criticize some of your premises?
President Roosevelt's new plan for minting five-mill coins with holes in them, drew the ridicule of Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, in a statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Behind Fritz Ostermueller's four-hit pitching the Red Sox halted the Senators today, 11 -- 4, in the opener of their three-game series. Five Washington pitchers allowed thirteen hits.
Two bond issues totaling $24,000,000, publicly offered yesterday, found a ready market and the selling group books on each were closed by about noon.

OTTAWA, July 30 (Canadian Press). -- Frank Simmons, 77-year-old visitor from New York, was drowned here today when he fell into the Rideau River from a canoe. W.H. Brookins, with whom Mr. Simmons was staying, was rescued. He arrived here yesterday to visit Mr. Brookins, who retired four years ago.

WASHINGTO, July 30. -- Charges that Sterling Products, Inc., of New York City, whose net sales with twenty subsidiaries were reported as exceeding $28,000,000 in 1931, violated Section 7 of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act through acquisition on Sept, 17, 1934, of the capital stock of a competitor, the R.L. Watkins Company, Inc., were made today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Having completed the correction of proofs of her forthcoming book, "Gracious Lady: The Life of Sara Delano Roosevelt," Rita Halle Kleeman will sail today on the Normandie for a visit to France. The biography will be published in September by D. Appleton-Century Company.

Declaring that many applicants for city positions would not have "a Chinaman's chance" if they were allowed to take examinations without showing a background of education, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, defended his department's requirements yesterday in a letter to the Board of Aldermen.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Filing of suits by leading packers to enjoin the government from collecting the $2.25 a hundred pound processing tax on hogs failed to have any effect on the market here today. Prices opened weak to 10 cents a hundredweight lower and brought all interests in as buyers.

Unsettled and weak conditions prevailed in the commodity futures markets yesterday, with trading light in most instances. Copper alone showed slight gains. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, cocoa and silk declined, while oats and rubber advanced.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The amount of modernization credit and of mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration last week totaled $13,846,296, representing by far the largest volume of business done by the FHA since its establishment in June, 1934, Acting Administrator McDonald reported today.

Because of his absence from a Board of Estimate meeting yesterday Mayor La Guardia missed a resolution introduced by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx asking him to heed the patronage requests of Republican party leaders.

Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn declared last night that President Roosevelt, in a conversation yesterday morning, had expressed his sympathy with protests by American Jews against the treatment accorded their co-religionists in Germany.

BERLIN, July 30. -- The editor of the Berlin Tageblatt, Paul Scheffer, who made a reputation as a correspondent in Washington and Moscow before Adolf Hitler came into power, satirizes good naturedly in this morning's edition of his paper the American discovery that Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff's promises do not seem to apply to the activities of the Communist International.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- In honor of the visiting players who are competing this week in the women's invitation tennis tournament, a dinner dance will be given Saturday evening at the Maidstone Club. Mrs. Jesse Spalding is chairman of the tennis committee and Mrs. S. Kip Farrington Jr. chairman of the dinner committee.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc in the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,734,650 barrels, compared with 2,738,800 in the previous week, a decrease of 4,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 6,850 barrels in the daily average output of Louisiana was the most important change.

BERLIN, July 30. -- Nazi hotheads, deaf to party orders banning "direct action" against Jewish and Catholic "State enemies," hindered Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's efforts to curb extremist tactics in the Third Reich's anti "reactionary" drive today.

Arrangements have been made by the Hospitals Department to move about 500 child patients from the Children's Hospital for Mental Defectives on Randall's Island, to the vacant Parental School in Flushing on Aug. 25, Hospitals Commissioner S.S. Goldwater announced yesterday.
The text of the radio address by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the city racket inquiry, last night follows:

Temporary injunctions restraining the government from collecting processing taxes of more than $184,000 were obtained here yesterday in Federal court by seven corporations that have sued to test the constitutionality of the assessment provisions of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Four officials of Local 1 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union were arrested on warrants yesterday in their headquarters at 127 West Thirty-third Street on a coercion charge, made by Fred Cohen, the owner of a non-union tailoring plant at 89 Ridge Street.

The Rivoli Theatre, closed for the last two weeks, will reopen this morning with "Dante's Inferno," a Fox Film production. Though named after the Italian poet's masterpiece, the film has been bolstered with a modern story and such players as Spencer Tracy, Claire Trevor and Henry B. Walthall.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- The two finalists at Seabright failed to reach the semi-finals of the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today.

Prospects of improved business for the steel industry this Fall have been reflected in increases of 50 cents to $1 a ton in the price of steel scrap, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Iron Age. Steel operations have advanced 2 1/2 points this week to 46 per cent of capacity, the magazine estimates.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 31. -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's junior cruising fleet arrived at this port on its second run today, making excellent time from Price's Bend before a fresh westerly breeze. Zaida, sailed by R.N. Bavier Jr., nosed out Edlu, with Stanley Turner at the helm, by thirty seconds.

Popping home runs out of the arena with a reckless abandon rather painful to behold, the singularly inspired Phillies, who never seem to be getting anywhere yet on occasion play remarkably fine ball, closed their two-day stay at the Polo Grounds yesterday by tripping the Giants, 5 to 3.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

RYDE, Isle of Wight, July 31. -- King George, accompanied by the Duke and Duchess of York, went racing in his cutter Britannia today for the first time this season, participating in the race around the Isle of Wight for the Prince of Wales Cup in the Royal Thames Yacht Club regatta.

LONDON, July 31. -- The attention of financial London was drawn today to Italy's currency difficulties and the frozen British credits in Italy as a result of protests by Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, by deputations of the Mining Association of Great Britain and the British Coal Exporters Federation, who have asked the government to expedite overdue payments for coal shipped to Italy.

MOSCOW, July 31. -- Unfavorable weather, especially in Northern Canada, which has been delaying the flight of the Soviet plane from Moscow to San Francisco via the North Pole, is improving, according to reports today to the Northern Sea Route Administration, which is directing the flight.
PARIS, July 31. -- Picturesque ceremonies marked American Day in Lourdes today. Two hundred pilgrims from twenty-one States took part.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP). -- Prince Torch, at home in the sloppy going at Arlington Park today won the feature handicap event at seven furlongs by a length and a half.

LONDON, July 31. -- The ruler of Yemen, on the east shore of the Red Sea, the Zaidi Imam Yahya, has refused to give Italy permission to recruit laborers for military road building in Eritrea. He was said to have stressed that his sympathies were with Ethiopia.

Clarence D. Chamberlin, transatlantic flier, started operation of own airline yesterday. He has purchased a Curtiss-Condor powered with two liquid-cooled Conqueror engines from Eastern Air Lines and had its roomy cabin converted so that the biplane will carry twenty-eight persons, including pilot -- who is Chamberlin himself -- co-pilot and hostess.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 1. -- Fifty-five lives were lost in the sinking of the Soviet submarine B-3 in a collision in the course of the manoeuvres of the Red fleet in the Baltic Sea, according to a report of the Commissariat of Defense early today.

Brisk activity in home furnishings has continued to feature consumer response to August sales offerings, executives of local stores reported yesterday. Furniture was reported the most active of the home furnishings group, with draperies, sharing the buying to a smaller extent so far.

Four men were sentenced to prison yesterday by General Sessions Judge Koenig on their previous pleas of guilty to attempting to extort $5,000 from Mrs. George U. Harris, wife of a governor of the New York Stock Exchange, under threat to make public a faked photograph of her.

Resumption of heavy buying of stocks yesterday, following the irregularly lower opening, pushed the market into new high ground, more than a hundred issues reaching new top marks for the year and longer. The insistent demand raised the trading volume on the Stock Exchange to 1,908,000 shares, one of the largest daily totals of the year thus far.
TOKYO, July 31. -- Yosuke-Matsuoka, Japan's champion at Geneva when she left the League of Nations, is about to be appointed president of the South Manchuria Railway, according to the Nichi Nichi.

OTTAWA, July 31. -- National government for Canada was emphatically repudiated tonight by Mr. Mackenzie King in the first of a series of radio addresses in which the Liberal leader will expound his party's program for the coming general elections.

LONDON, July 31. -- Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, again refused today to take Parliament and the country into the confidence of the government concerning its future naval construction program.

Louis Jacoby, 58 years old, who conducts a check-cashing business in his cigar store at 62 West Twenty-sixth Street, in the needle trades district, was shot and beaten at 2:15 P.M. yesterday as he tried to prevent three armed robbers from getting into his barricaded rear office there.

The apparent unwillingness of Senate and House committees to consider or apply the intelligent, disinterested, sound advice of such authorities as Joseph H. Choate Jr. (late of the FACA), and Edward P. Mulrooney (presently of the ABC), particularly when supported by the opinion and experience of the entire wholesale and retail liquor trade, gives one pause for thought.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 31. -- Mrs. E.G. Richmond of the Cherry Valley Club scored a well-deserved victory today in the regular one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association when she holed the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course in 81 strokes.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 31. -- Mrs. Joseph J. Lawlor, No. 1 player of the Gedney Farm Golf Club, today won her first open match play tournament of the season by defeating Mrs. T.F.D. Haines of Mount Kisco, 5 and 3, in the final of the first annual invitation event of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Plans for providing electricity within eighteen months to 351,000 rural "prospects," including 247,000 farms, at a cost of about $238,249,000, were outlined today by Morris L. Cooke, Rural Electrification Administrator.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- On the theory that outdoor life builds better bodies, the government has agreed to spend more than $19,000,000 on sports fields within the next few months.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The question of fortifications in the Pacific was described as "an if-and-when problem" today by President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Navy Claude A. Swanson, but the Cabinet officer added that the establishment of bases must be "inevitably considered" if and when the Washington Naval Treaty expired.

Excluding $858,970 held in suspense, including interest thereon, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported a net income of $2,749,366 in the year ended June 30, equal to $3.69 a share on an average of about 745,085 no-par capital shares outstanding in that period. Including the amount in suspense, the earnings would be equal to $4.85 a share.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- Mrs. Henry R. Rea of Pittsburgh and Palm Beach has registered at the Gideon Putnam at the Saratoga spa for several weeks. Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kenny, Mrs. Daniel Meenan, Mr. and Mrs. Duncan McMartin of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Lewis of Philadelphia are also there.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Mrs Blanche Dunkel and Mrs. Evelyn Smith will be arraigned tomorrow afternoon on indictments charging them with the murder of Ervin Lang, Mrs. Dunkel's son-in-law. True bills were voted by the grand jury today and these will be returned in court before the arraignment.

The last whistle Blew yesterday for 700 veteran employes of the New York Central Railroad. With an aggregate of more than 24,000 years of service behind them, they turned in their cards at the railroad's terminals in nine States and two Canadian Provinces and retired on pension.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick issued temporary orders today restraining Walter J. Rothensies, Internal Revenue Collector here, from collecting AAA processing taxes from sixty-four firms. He renewed the orders in thirty cases which he had previously heard.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 31. -- The appointment of Richard F. Vaughan of Newton Centre, Mass., former hockey captain and assistant coach at Yale, as coach of the Princeton sextet was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the university council on athletics.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, former President of Cuba and now in exile as head of the Cuban Revolutionary Party, known as the "Autenticos," asserted last night that there can be no peaceful solution of the Cuban problem so long, as President Mendieta's government remains under the domination of Colonel Fulgencio Batista and the Cuban army.

Advisers of Paul Kress, the German masseur to whom Mayor La Guardia denied a city license, said yesterday that a decision would probably be made today on seeking a writ of mandamus against License Commissioner Paul Moss to compel him to issue the permit.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 31. -- Miss Helen Jacobs sailed for the United States aboard the Majestic today, but said she would be back next year for another crack at the All-England tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The report of the Ways and Means Committee majority on the administration tax bill read as follows :

VATICAN CITY, July 31. -- Pope Pius left the Vatican late this evening and motored to Castel Gandolfo, where he will spend the next two months enjoying the cooler atmosphere of the Albert Hills in the villa restored last year to its traditional use as the Summer residence of the Pontiffs.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--In the face of open opposition of President Roosevelt and on the eve of taking up of the Wealth-Sharing Tax Bill in the House, Democrats of the Ways and Means Committee decided today to offer an amendment to the measure, granting a limited tax exemption to corporations for contributions to charity.

The Board of Education took another step yesterday toward obtaining Federal funds for the construction of new buildings for Franklin K. Lane High School, Brooklyn; Andrew Jackson High School, Queens, and Public School 107, the Bronx.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 31. -- Jewelry valued at $100,000 was stolen Thursday night from the bedroom of Mrs. Wolcott Blair, who with her husband, a Chicago broker, has a Summer home at Brookville, L.I., Inspector Harold R. King of the Nassau County Police disclosed today.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- A team of Chicago amateur boxers defeated a contingent from New York, ten bouts to six, tonight in the first intercity boxing meet sponsored by the Catholic Youth Organization of America. The bouts were put on in Wrigley Field before 40,000 spectators.
No change was discernible in any section of the money market. Demand was light, and quotations maintained without variation from preceding session.

" Historic Opinions of the United States Supreme Court," edited by Ambrose Doskow, will be issued this month by the Vanguard Press. In this book are collected, with notes, the most important decisions of the nation's highest tribunal, from the epoch-making pronouncements of John Marshall to the decree that administered a death blow to the NRA.

Southern California Gas Company is notifying holders of its 5 per cent series first mortgage and refunding gold bonds, due in 1957, that it will redeem and pay them off on Sept. 1 at principal plus a premium of 4 per cent and accrued interest, at the Chase National Bank, trustee.
CHICAGO, July 31. -- The Middle Western States sweltered in a heat wave today which took a heavy toll in human life and caused extensive damage to farmers' crops.

An unusually heavy police detail of 100 detectives, 130 uniformed men and two police launches was on duty last night in and about the pier of the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland at West Forty-fourth Street to prevent any outbreak aboard the German liner such as occurred on the Bremen last Friday night.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., July 31. -- Disappearance last night of a new Northrop low-winged monoplane, designed as a speedy pursuit ship for the army, and taken for a test flight by Lieutenant Arthur H. Skaer Jr., was a mystery at army headquarters today.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 31. -- Premier Hendryk Colijn's new Cabinet is almost the same as that which resigned last week because of the opposition of Catholics, Laborites and Communists.

With the new Federal Works Progress Administration for this city completed and ready to function, General Hugh S. Johnson, in charge of work relief for the Federal Government in New York, announced yesterday that he was prepared to put to work every man who can be absorbed by projects now under way or approved.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- A new drive for adjournment of Congress, with the goal set at Aug. 20 to 23, was started today after a White House conference between President Roosevelt and Senator Robinson on the legislative situation.

The name of Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, means "the new flower," Dr. Marshall A. Howe, newly elected director of the New York Botanical Garden, said yesterday. Contrary to general belief, Dr. Howe said, Addis Ababa is a city of trees and many gardens, its direct sunlight and high elevation making it an excellent spot for flower growing.
Increased activity and higher levels in the stock list were transmitted to the bond market yesterday and prices advanced generally, with rails and utility issues again taking the initiative.

The directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, at a meeting yesterday, declared a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable on Aug. 30, to stock of record of Aug. 12. The last cash dividend on the common was 25 cents a share paid on April 30, 1932.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation, which is controlled by the Electric Bond and Share Company, records in its report for 1934 completion of the amortization of $859,081 costs resulting from the New Orleans street car strike of 1929 and 1930.

From a precarious footing on a narrow ledge more than 100 feet from the ground on the side of a Brooklyn building, an alert policeman performed a thrilling rescue yesterday of a window cleaner who was dangling from a cable of a scaffold from which another window cleaner had fallen to his death.

BOSTON, July 31. -- In a thrilling four-horse finish that brought the 21,000 assembled enthusiasts to their feet in noisy acclaim, Sergeant Byrne, golden chestnut sprinter from the Simonetti Stable, scored by a nose in the John Han cock Handicap, six-furlong feature of today's Suffolk Downs card.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The State Department began today the preparation of a reply to the German protest against the alleged insult to the German swastika emblem by a mob that tore a flag from the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen at its dock in New York last Friday night.
BERLIN, July 31. -- The municipal press and propaganda office today warned Jews not to come to Berlin. The warning read:

The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks has called attention to the deposits of such institutions reaching a total of $9,870,000,000, or within 2 per cent of the all-time high attained on Jan. 1, 1932. Among some of the causes for this increase were listed the higher prices prevailing for farm products, the mounting value of both rural and urban property, larger dividends from stocks and bigger payrolls.
Strength in other markets brought a recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and the list ended at gains of 11 to 16 points.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery, outstanding star of the handicap division, took the $3,000 added Wilson Stakes in stride today at the Spa, setting a new record for the event, and sending his winnings for the year to $64,840, second only to those of the 3-year-old champion Omaha.

Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, issued yesterday the first license in this State for the operation of private service bureaus, run for the convenience of motorists wishing to obtain automobile registration, driving and other permits authorized by the Motor Vehicle Department.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 (AP). -- Although their latest winning streak was snapped at eleven games, the Cubs narrowed the gap separating them from the Giants to one-half game today when they split a double-header with the Pirates while the league leaders were dropping a decision to the Phillies.

Democratic leaders of the Bronx gathered yesterday with Edward J. Flynn, party chief, and selected three men and a woman as organization candidates for the four new Municipal Court posts in the Bronx.
Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of Park Department zoos, is on the horns of a dilemma -- a dilemma having to do with horns.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Emil Fuchs, president of the Boston Braves since 1925, today forfeited his majority stock holdings to Charles F. Adams, vice president, and robbed baseball of one of its most colorful figures by returning to his legal profession.

MIAMI, Fla., July 31 (AP). -- More than 1,500 persons -- many crying that they were starving -- marched on Miami's City Hall today and gained their objective -- the City Commission's pledge to release funds immediately to relieve the welfare crisis.

BERLIN, July 31. -- The Boerse was almost totally inactive today, with no changes of importance resulting. Speculators appear to have withdrawn from the market entirely and the investing public shows little interest. The slight movements that are taking place indicate firmness.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 31. -- The annual flower show of the Warm Springs Valley Garden Club was held in the social hall of the Warm Springs Presbyterian Church at 3 o'clock this afternoon. It drew a record number of entries of unusual quality locally as well as from the Augusta (Ga.); Covington (Ky.) and Clifton Forge (Va.) clubs, which had been invited to exhibit as guests of the local club.

GENEVA, July 31. -- The special session of the League of Nations Council designed to avert hostilities between Italy and Ethiopia by continuing the conciliation procedure between them while other powers seek some compromise that would appease Premier Benito Mussolini's wrath began this afternoon.

Foreclosure sales in Manhattan yesterday included a large Second Avenue corner and various dwellings and flats in scattered sections of the borough. For the first time in several years an auction sale was held on the court house steps in the downtown Civic Centre.

Bertrand Coles Neidecker has asked Price Waterhouse Co., accountants, to seek permission of the French Government to make an audit of the books of his closed Travellers Bank in Paris. This was disclosed here yesterday at the offices of his attorneys, Coudert Brothers, 2 Rector Street.

At his press conference yesterday the President had some acid things to say about rich men who do not meekly hand over all they have to a Federal tax collector. He seemed to imply that there was something mean and unpatriotic about this. But he could not charge that it was unlawful All the large-scale evasion of taxes that has taken place has been in accordance with existing law.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- The Libby, McNeill Libby refunding bond offering, originally scheduled for today and then postponed, is now definitely scrapped, according to information received tonight from the intended underwriters.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- With one lone exception, the favored array came through to the quarter-finals of the women's invitation tennis tournament today on the turf courts of the Maidstone Club.

The opening phase of Thomas E. Dewey's investigation into organized crime, it was believed yesterday, will follow the course already charted by the "runaway" March grand jury which induced Governor Lehman to order a special inquiry into outlawry in Manhattan.

For the first time in the records of the Steamboat Inspection Service an American steamship company has been fined several hundred dollars on the complaint of one of its own officers charging violation of Federal statutes regarding working hours for officers and men.

MALONE, N.Y., Thursday, Aug. 1. -- The jury in Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's second trial for income tax evasion was locked up at 12:12 o'clock this morning after deliberating almost eight hours without reaching a verdict.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 29,429,387 shares, compared with 22,339,512 in the preceding month and 21,115,884 shares in July, 1934. The month was the second most active of the year and also since April, 1934.

The smallest amount of gold received for any month since September arrived here in July, principally because of the ending of shipments from France. The month's total of $7,322,100 contrasted with $235,779,200 in June and with $47,438,500 in July, 1934.

CHICAGO, July 31.--Walter J. Bauer, 38-year-old chemistry instructor and bridegroom of three weeks, died early today in Jackson Park Hospital from the effects of mutilations inflicted by a stranger who had kidnapped him from Ann Arbor, Mich.

Shirley Temple's new photoplay for Fox Films, "Curly Top," will be presented this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Also appearing with Mistress Temple are John Boles, Rochelle Hudson and Jane Darwell.

The consolidated report of the Commercial Credit Company for the first half of 1935, made public today, shows a net income from operations, credited to earned surplus, of $3,345,266 after charging off or providing reserves for all losses and doubtful items, Federal and other taxes.

A feature of the commodity futures markets yesterday was the weakness in coffee, which established a new seasonal low in the heaviest trading in more than a month. A further sharp break in Brazilian exchange rather than unfavorable trade news accounted for the break.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP). -- The first-place Tigers raised their lead over the idle second-place Yankees to three games today as they turned loose a thirteen-hit bombardment against the Browns to win, 9 to 3, evening the series.

An eight-hour meeting of stockholders of R. Hoe Co., Inc., ended in harmony yesterday, when the independent group of security holders, headed by Samuel Zirn, joined with the proxy committee appointed by the board of directors and unanimously elected a new board of eleven men.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Roosevelt administration was squarely behind the Senate lobby investigation today. An executive order, issued from the White House, was made public, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to make available to the Senate committee all income, excess profit and capital stock tax returns "to the extent necessary in the investigation of lobbying activities in connection with the so-called 'Holding Company Bill,' or any other matter or proposal affecting legislation."

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $4,430, 000 Territory of Hawaii bonds, due Sept. 1, 1939 to 1944. The price paid was 100.035 for $3,000,000 of the bonds as 1 3/4s and $1,430,000 as 1.70s, equivalent to an interest cost of 1.729 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Subsistence Homestead Division of the Department of Agriculture announced today that work would begin tomorrow on the site of the New Jersey homestead project near Hightstown, N.J.

How will Mr. ROOSEVELT'S proposed new fractional coins affect the chief purpose to which his administration was dedicated from the first? This, as we all know, is to raise the price level as the key to recovery.

SAN FRANCISCO, July, 31. -- Indictment of Sam D'Arcy, San Francisco Cummunist now attending the party's congress in Moscow, will be sought here before the Federal grand jury probably this week, authorities announced today. Before the congress yesterday he predicted a strike of "unprecedented scope" by seamen and dock workers on the Pacific Coast would be called in September.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- A plan for the reorganization and consolidation of the Missouri-Pacific Railroad Company and thirty subsidiaries was laid before the Interstate Commerce Commission today by O.P. Van Sweringen, with the approval of the road's board of directors.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- A resumption of operations on the bull side of wheat by local operators and the public, based on sensational crop-damage reports from the Spring wheat area, swept prices up sharply today. Minneapolis led, rising 5 cents from Tuesday's finish, the maximum permitted for one day's trading under Exchange regulations.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art asked yesterday for an increase of $36,194 in its 1936 budget to enlarge its staff, with the explanation that it now has only one watchman to guard valuable paintings and art works in three galleries.

New York banks are wondering whether the manufacturers of coin-sorting machines will come to their rescue with additional gadgets to prepare them for the proposed one-half and one-tenth cent coins. The handling of nickels and cents, always a trouble producer for the tellers and counters, is a toss-off compared to the trouble the banks face in the "chicken-feed" coins that will follow designs said to have been personally drawn for the Treasury by President Roosevelt.

A centre of attraction on the crowded passenger decks of the French liner Normandie yesterday before she sailed for Havre was Acee Blue Eagle, a full-blooded Creek Indian, 26 years old, who is head of the art department of Bacone College, attached to the University of Oklahoma, where he was graduated in 1932.

Willem van Hoogstraten returned to the Lewisohn Stadium last night as a conductor of the Summer concerts being played by an orchestra from the Philharmonic-Symphony. He was cordially welcomed by an audience of moderate size, about half that which assembled for the Fokine Ballet's farewell program the night before.

Junius Spencer Morgan, retired banker and first cousin of J.P. Morgan, left an estate appraised yesterday at $262,888 gross and $248,089 net. Only $1,362 was taxable in this State because Mr. Morgan was a resident of Princeton, N.J., when he died in Switzerland on Aug. 18, 1932.
