INDIANAPOLIS, July 31. -- A wave of upsets, the two greatest by a pair of unknowns from California, struck the national public links golf championship today, sweeping away every important favorite except Dave Mitchell, defending champion from Indianapolis, and Arthur Armstrong of Honolulu, whom he beat for the title a year ago.
The Summer theatre, as a tryout spot for next season's plays, appears to be slowly receding. Next week only seven of them will dare the new drama, the list running something like this:
NEWARK, N.J., July 31.--Newark and Toronto opened their series today by dividing a double-header. The Bears won the first game, 4 to 1, and the Maple Leafs took the second, 2 to 1.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
ROME, July 31. -- The government today decreed a monopoly of all purchases abroad of coal, copper, tin and nickel.
A 38-year-old American writer, H.L. Davis, now living in Mexico, has won the seventh $7,500 Harper prize novel contest with a first novel called "Honey in the Horn," to be published on Aug. 22.

Twelve of the twenty incorporated investment companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange had filed applications on Form 15 for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and seven more had signified their intention of filing when the deadline set by the Exchange arrived yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- All interests were buyers of hogs here today, and prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with the top moving up 15 cents to $11, at which figure it equaled the highest level of the season. Hogs weighing 250 to 300 pounds, which had been neglected for several days, led the upturn.

LONDON, July 31. -- A small boom developed in the Street Market here today after the London Stock Exchange had closed, with a flood of buying orders from Wall Street and British speculators eager for quick profits. Prices of the leading United States stocks soon went soaring, notably Chrysler, Western Union, United States Steel and New York Central issues.
LOS ANGELES, July 31 (AP). -- New records were established by both men and women contestants today in the fifty-fifth annual target meeting of the National Archery Association.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- President Roosevelt signed a bill raising half of the present army commissioned personnel one rank and extended the life of the National Labor Relations Board one month.

The United Gas Improvement Company, holding company with controlling interests in the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and other large utilities, reported an increase of $340,000, or 1.4 per cent in operating revenues, despite rate reductions of about $513,000, in the three months ended on June 30.

The dissolution of Richmond Co. and the organization of J.L. Richmond Co., Inc., to deal in utility, industrial and railroad securities at 111 Broadway was announced yesterday. Officers of the new company are James L. Richmond, president; Lester F. Tarbell, vice president; Lawrence M. Runkle, secretary, and E.M. Kohler, assistant treasurer.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 31. -- Miss Isabel Beckurts of Haverford, Pa., was the winner in the treasure hunt held at the Mountain View estate last evening. The event was followed by a Welsh rarebit party in the sun lounge of the Mountain View.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- A new effort to drive through the House tomorrow President Roosevelt's Utility Holding Companies Bill was reported as planned tonight by administration leaders.

TOKYO, July 31 (AP). -- The Home Office today banned sales of three American books, "Japan in Crisis," by Harry Emerson Wildes; "The Challenge Behind the Face of Japan," by Upton Close, and "The Far Eastern Front," by Edgar Snow, as "detrimental to public peace."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 31. -- The will of Colonel Henry Huddleston Rogers was filed for probate in the office of the Suffolk County Surrogate today, disposing of an estate not yet officially appraised, but estimated to be more than $15,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- New talk of compromise arose today from the Congressional controversy over excluding private pension plans from the administration's social security program.

CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP). -- A peace agreement drawn up by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, broke a two-month deadlock between striking unionists and officials of the Industrial Rayon Corporation today.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Retiring the last of the Federal bonds which can be used as collateral for national bank notes, the Treasury Department will start tomorrow paying off $74,901,580 in 2 per cent Panama Canal bonds.

A 16-year-old boy on his second offshore fishing trip experienced a thrill last Tuesday that has been denied to many anglers who have devoted years to the sport -- the capture of a marlin, most spectacular performer of big-game varieties. His prize weighed 101 pounds and was 7 feet 10 inches long.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 31. -- With one hundred and ten horses in sixty-one classes out of a total of three hundred and fifteen entries, the Pittsfield horse show, to be given Friday and Saturday at Holmesdale, the estate of Donald M. Weston, will be the largest show of the season in the Berkshires.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

A new Police Department safety campaign poster contrasting the deaths and injuries from automobile accidents with the A.E.F. losses in the World War was presented yesterday to Captain Hugo O. Wunsche of the East Fifty-first Street Station.

NEWPORT, July 31 -- Backgammon is proving so popular this Summer that a tournament has been arranged to take place at the Newport Clambake Club tomorrow night. It is expected there will be at least sixty players competing. George Henry Warren Jr. is chairman of the committee, the other members of which are William F. Whitehouse, C. Oliver O'Donnell, Kenneth Shaw Safe and Gustave J.S. White.

Declaring that any refund of processing taxes on goods which manufacturers are now selling to their customers is blocked by the existing law and the proposed AAA amendments, Gilbert Montague, legal adviser to a number of companies on processing tax questions, said yesterday that it was futile for mills to file claims or institute suits for recovery of levies on merchandise which they have sold to their trade.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Purchase of all oil properties and operating equipment of the Yount-Lee Oil Company, largest independent petroleum company in the South, by the Stanolind Oil and Gas Company was announced formally today.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31. -- After thirty Newark relief clients called at the City Hall asking that the city take care of rent payments due tomorrow, the City Commission voted this afternoon to meet, at least in part, the State Emergency Relief Administration's assessment.

PARIS, July 31. -- Rentes again forged ahead on the Bourse today, while stocks remained irregular. Month-end liquidation took place easily under the particularly favorable carry-over rate of 3 per cent, compared with 3 3/4 on July 15. Business was virtually nil in stocks. with only slight changes registered, except for the Credit Foncier, which lost 111 francs.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP). -- The Jury in the trial of William Lee Ferris and three former burlesque dancers heard testimony today that they killed Howard Carter Dickinson, New York attorney, to procure money to organize a "girl show."

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Since John N. Garner left the dais of the House to preside over the Senate the adjournment guessing average of Speakers has been very low. Mr. Garner is a shrewder judge of Congress than his two Democratic successors, and he is less inclined to guess without sound basis just to make a story for the newspaper men.
The demotion of twenty-three detectives from second to third grade status, with a reduction of $200 a year in salary, was announced yesterday by Assistant Chief Inspector Henry E. Bruckman.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the $7,000,000 a year reduction rates of the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system was "not enough." The same view was taken by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
WHEN Marse Joe McCarthy went off to Philadelphia with his Yankees he was still flourishing a rule book and asserting that President Will Harridge should be debited with an error.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 31. -- Diplomatically an external calm of an almost Chinese character is maintained as Emperor Haile Selassie awaits news of the League of Nations Council meeting. The Ethiopian delegation has full powers. but is in fairly regular correspondence with the Emperor whose policy remains clear and whose tactics may be briefly outlined.

Clarence H. Sniffen, 22 years old, a relief worker assigned as timekeeper in the Staten Island Board of Health and living at 56 Butler Place, Rosebank, was held yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. Police alleged that he had stolen about $6,000 in little more than three years from the pew and collection boxes of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Stapleton, S.I.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Two more blows were struck at the moribund Economy Act of 1938 today when President Roosevelt signed the Army Promotion Bill and the Senate concurred with the House in passing the McGill bill restoring full pension benefits to Spanish War veterans.

PARIS, July 31. -- The military silhouette is the inspiration for both cut and detail of superb tailor-made suits and dress afternoon coats by Creed. One cadet bolero suit in this collection has a dashing cape and a skirt cut tight as trousers, with braid down the sides in true Military fashion.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell made up for his generosity with hits today by driving two homers and accounting for four runs as the Red Sox defeated Washington, 6 to 4.

The New York Railways Corporation filed in Federal court yesterday its petition for reorganization under the amended bankruptcy laws, so that it might better carry out its pending plan to substitute buses for street cars on its entire network, as well as operate buses on four crosstown routes not now served by trolleys.

The House Ways and Means Committee practically abandoned a tax graduated in accordance with the total net earnings of corporations and adopted instead an "excess profits" tax, graduated in accordance with the rate of profit on the "adjusted declared value" of corporation capital stock.

IN "Lucy Gayheart" (Knopf, $2), Willa Cather has gone back to the scenes of her early and most fruitful memories -- to the Nebraska that constitutes what Stuart Sherman so reverently called her "own material." Yet, regrettably, she has trailed with her the later Cather manner -- the fragile, pastel quality of writing which, momentarily pleasing though it may be, renders "Death Comes for the Archbishop" and "Shadows on the Rock" so difficult to recollect.
ROME, July 31. -- Benito Mussolini's newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, renewed today demands for a "total solution" of Rome's quarrel with Addis Ababa.

LONDON, July 31. -- J.P. Morgan, who is here on his usual holiday, has been having his customary summertime talks with British bankers, but in addition he has paid a somewhat unusual visit to 10 Downing Street for a private talk with Stanley Baldwin, Prime Minister.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 31. -By drawing his last game in the eleventh round today, Reuben Fine of New York retained the Western chess championship.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Many members of the Garden Club of Southampton and their guests, as well as several members of the East Hampton Garden Club, attended the lecture on design and flower arrangements by John Taylor Arms, etcher, which was given this afternoon at Four Fountains under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton.

RUMSON, N.J., July 31. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, New Jersey State champion, today won the 54-hole medal play New Jersey Shore tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with a card of 239, eleven strokes better than the previous record for the event.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- The AAA announced today that a 15 per cent reduction in wheat acreage in 1936 would be required of farmers who signed contracts to adjust production.

EATONTOWN, N.J., July 31. -- Fort Hamilton's First Division polo squad gained the semi-finals of the Monmouth County Country Club 12-goal tournament today by defeating Gerald Balding's Harmony Hollow team of Rumson, 12 to 10.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- A severe attack on President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing tax program was begun by business and industrial representatives before the Senate Finance Comittee today in their first opportunity to discuss a definite measure designed to carry out the President's suggestions.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Many entries have been received for the eleventh annual horse show at the Riding Club of East Hampton on Saturday, Aug. 17. The entries will close on Aug. 7. Mrs. John Vernou Bouvier 3d and Miss Judith Hamlin are co-chairmen for the show.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 31. -- Articles of incorporation for the Little School of Englewood, naming Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh as a trustee, were filed here today in the office of County Clerk James W. Mercer.

The distinguished British seismologist, DAVID MILNE, once estimated that there must be at least 60,000 earthquakes, big and little, every year. It is certain that some 9,000 are felt -- most of them tremors and some of them formidable shocks. When, therefore, young REUBEN GREENSPAN tells us that there will be one on a given day, he is likely to be right.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The administration bill to put control of bus and truck transportation in the hands of the Interstate Commerce Commission went through the critical amending stage in the House today, emerging without substantial change, and is expected by leaders to pass early tomorrow.
CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP). -- The Reds defeated Paul Dean and the Cardinals, 4 to 3, in the tenth tonight before a season's record night crowd of 30,000 at Crosley Field.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 31.--Three veteran Freeport fishermen narrowly escaped death late yesterday afternoon in a marine hit-and-run accident which occurred in Jones Inlet near the mouth of Swift Creek, south of Freeport.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Investment Bankers Code Committee asked 3,200 registered security dealers today if they wanted to continue a national organization despite the fact that the anti-trust laws make creation of any "self-disciplining organization" to replace the NRA Code virtually impossible.

Joseph E. Widener, accompanied by P.A.B. Widener 2d and Mrs. Widener, are among the passengers arriving today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others coming on the ship from Germany, France and England include:

A conference committee representing the Senate and the House has before it an interesting question relating to the insurance of bank deposits. Existing law provides that all State banks covered by the Federal deposit insurance plan must become members of the Federal Reserve System by July 1, 1937.
City Marshal Charles A. Nack resigned a few days ago because of an investigation made into his office by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard, it was disclosed yesterday.

Sergeant John A. Johanson, with thirty years of army service behind him, finished his last tour of active duty at Castle Williams on Governors Island yesterday. In accordance with army tradition, he was to review his company at retreat last night to mark the end of his last "hitch," but that ceremony got tangled up in army red tape.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Sam Leslie's third homer of the year was more potent than Wally Berger's twenty-first circuit blow today and the Dodgers took the first game of a double-header, 5 to 3. But they returned to form in the nightcap by succumbing to their third shutout in their last four games, 4 to 0, with Freddy Frankhouse wielding the whitewash brush.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company failed to earn its preferentials during the fiscal year ended June 30, and therefore will not pay the city any interest on the municipal investment in the company's lines, according to a report filed in Federal court yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31. -- Jeremiah T. Mahoney, former Supreme Court Justice and present head of the Amateur Athletic Union, renewed tonight his objection to American participation in the 1936 Olympic Games at Berlin, because of German mistreatment of Jews.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Six months' grace for the filing of gold clause suits against the government was written into the gold-clause resolution today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and accepted for the administration by Senator Robinson, Democratic leader.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, hinted his disapproval today of the Nazi anti-Semitic campaign in so far as it disturbed business in Germany.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP). -- Mel Harder, Cleveland's hurler, who had hit only one home run in his seven-year major-league career, drove two circuit drives today, but, lost his game to the White Sox, 6 to 4.

MOSCOW, July 31. -- Resolutions that will embody orders of the Communist International [Comintern] to the constituent parties of other countries are being prepared for approval by the Moscow Congress, approaching the climax of its sessions.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 31. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's government -- hoping for peace with Italy but carefully keeping its powder dry -- told the world in ringing language today Ethiopia's independence was not for sale or barter.

Mrs. Marian Burke Wright, 27 years old, reported to be the bride of two months of a Watertown, N.Y., consulting" engineer, accompanied by her lawyer, Charles Hickey, surrendered at police headquarters yesterday on a grand larceny indictment.

A report that the provision to use 30 per cent of custom receipts to facilitate exports of surplus farm products had been restored to the Agricultural Act amendments by the conference between the two Houses of Congress brought a slight setback in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 1. -- Meeting the Norfolk Tars before opening their series with the Senators in Washington, the Yankees gained a decision over their Class B Piedmont League farm team today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- After losing two straight to the Red Sox, the Senators took the final game of the series today, 9 to 5, as Earl Whitehill scored his ninth victory of the season.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 1. -- This city today had two Mayors and two heads of the Police Department -- one of them a woman.

What is said to be a record in demolition work was made in clearing the Times Square block front between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets of the New York and Criterion Theatres, an office building and nine or ten six-story structures. Yesterday was the last of forty-four days required for the job, although the contract time called for fifty-nine calendar days.

Clearly mirroring improved conditions in the motion-picture industry, stocks and bonds of the major companies moved forward in the New York markets yesterday. Bonds of Paramount, R.-K.-O., Warner Brothers and B.F. Keith all closed a new high prices for the year, while in the stock list the securities of Keith-Albe-Orpheum, Paramount and Radio-Keith-Orpheum also attained new high marks for the year.

John Kearney of 402 East Seventy-fourth Street has won the George Lane Nichols Medal, it was announced yesterday by the Children's Aid Society. The medal is given each year for good sportsmanship, to a 12-year-old boy enrolled in one of the seven children's centres maintained by the society in tenement neighborhoods.

The Park Department announced yesterday a happy solution of the problem of what to call the new animals in the Prospect and Central Park zoos. Most of the older animals have acquired names -- usually the inspiration of the moment when some antic called for a newspaper story, but inspiration has been lacking in the case of the newer acquisitions.

Mayor La Guardia was angered yesterday over his discovery that school principals and assistant principals were charging the city $30 week for their presence at adult education classes in the public schools.

The North American Company and subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $11,570,539 after all deductions, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $1.13 a share on 8,602,991 no-par common shares, comparing with $10,713,049, or $1.05 a share, earned in the preceding fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The House today rejected for the second time the "death sentence" for utility holding companies, favored by President Roosevelt and passed by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Following is the text of the New York Police Department reports to the State Department on the Bremen flag incident, and a copy of a Communist circular also sent by the State Department to the German Embassy:
PARIS, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Seen from Berlin with German eyes the Danzig decision to break the customs union with Poland is nothing less than self-defense against a Polish attempt to rob Danzig of her sovereignty.

WARSAW, Aug. 1. -- The tariff and currency war between Poland and the Free City of Danzig developed into a political conflict today when Arthur Greiser, President of the Danzig Senate, issued a decree providing for duty-free importation of coal, pigs, butter, eggs, medicines and several other categories of goods.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- Georges Bonnet, Minister of Commerce, in a statement issued today, outlined in general terms the program by which the government designs to supplement the recent budgetary deflation by increasing credits and stimulating trade.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The testimony of E.P. Cramer before the Senate Lobby Committee in Washington was criticized today by his employer, the Thomas E. Edison Industries, Inc.

The Fox Film Corporation will be asked by the stockholders' committee to eliminate from its plan for merger with the Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., the feature providing for exchange of the Class B shares at twice the value allowed to the Class A shares, according to an announcement by Henry L. Sperling, counsel for the committee, after a meeting yesterday with officials and attorneys for the Fox Film Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The House Coinage Committee, which a year ago quickly agreed to gold dollar devaluation, kicked over the traces today on the Roosevelt-Morgenthau small coin plan.

After cutting short a vacation in Europe because of the illness of a daughter, Bernard M. Baruch, the financier, flew here yesterday from Quebec. He landed at the Newark Airport at 9:30 P.M. and left immediately for this city.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank, however, was at a new high for 1935.

ROME, Aug. 1. -- Italy is watching the developments in Geneva with the closest attention, but the proceedings there are still at such an early stage that it is considered too soon to make any forecast of their probable outcome. One cannot help noting, however, that official circles seem to be cheerful and confident that if Italy is firm enough the League will end by yielding to her viewpoint.

In the United States the rule of lawyers, if not of law, is universal. Legislatures and Congresses consist mainly of them. By their wisdom we live, if we can afford it. So it is with a shock, a sensation of blasphemy, that one reads in The Quarterly Review for July an article on "Barristers as Legislators."

CHERBOURG, France, Aug. 1. -- Dr. J. Bentley Squier and Dr. Eugene H. Pool of New York, passengers aboard the liner Berengaria, assisted in saving the life of a Portuguese sailor who had been rescued by the liner, it was learned when the ship put in here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The administration moved today to end the "dole" by providing direct relief funds for thirteen States for the first half of August only, instead of for the entire month. Co-incidentally, steps were taken to get the new work-relief program under way swiftly.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, accompanied by his wife, is going to his usual continental holiday resort, Aix-les-Bains, France, this coming weekend after the adjournment of the House of Commons Friday. He expects to spend the first half of the three months' Parliamentary recess there.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- For the first time since the Summer of 1930 the number of registered unemployed in Britain has fallen below 2,000,000, it became known tonight. At the same time it was announced that the note circulation of the Bank of England had reached a new high record for all time of 408,262,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 1. -- The gates flew open today for a wild rush of unknowns in the national public links golf championship as four comparatively long shots from coast to coast dashed past last year's champion and runner-up to enter the semi-finals.

In the last few years the belief has gained currency, and has unfortunately been acted on by important central banks, that the raising of the discount rate, in a real emergency, is a "futile" measure. That belief seems to be definitely discredited by recent events in France and Holland.

One fake job "fixer" received a three-month workhouse term from General Sessions Judge Collins yesterday, another was committed to the city reformatory and a third was freed on a suspended sentence, because the court considered him a victim, rather than a confederate, of the "arch fixer," John Flaherty, now serving a four-year Sing Sing term.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Legislative leaders were asked today to approve a plan by Governor Lehman to start at once on a $27,000,000 Federal-State highway construction program, designed to give employment to about 8,000 men.

Conspicuous traveling clothes no longer identify American men touring Europe, Frank L. Dorpols of Chicago, president of the National Association of Merchant Tailors, said here yesterday, following his return on the Rex from a six-month business and pleasure trip through England, France, Switzerland and Italy.

Prince Alexis Z. Mdivani had been a conspicuous figure in international society circles for more than a decade. The son of Prince Zachary Mdivani, he was one of five children, three sons and two daughters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Wholesale commodity prices increased slightly during the week ending July 27, the Bureau of Labor statistics index moving to 79.2, as compared with 79.1 for the preceding week and 74.7 a year ago. The index is based on the 1926 average as 100.

Opposition to the set-up proposed by the directors in the proposed plan of reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation, as expressed at a hearing yesterday by counsel for two investors' groups, failed apparently to make much impression on Robert P. Stephenson, special master.
GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- Harukazu, Nagaoka, former Japanese Ambassador to France, now strongly leads in the nominations for judge of the World Court to succeed the late Mineichiro Adachi.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Set in a new environment, the annual Monmouth County Horse Show began today on the Thornton farm, to continue through Saturday. While not far removed from the original location at the Rumson Country Club, this year's exhibition enjoys the advantages of a show ring more suitable to the saddle horses and an outside course demanding less of the hunters than the former long circuit of the polo field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Search for Mandeville Zenge, jilted suitor sought for questioning in the mutilation-slaying of Dr. Walter J. Bauer, was renewed today despite indications that he had leaped to his death in Lake Michigan.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe announced yesterday after a two-hour hearing that he would approve the plan submitted by the George E. Roosevelt bondholders' committee for the reorganization of the Ambassador Hotels in New York and Atlantic City.

Banks in this district suffered an accumulated net loss of more than $1,200,000,000 of funds in the first seven months of 1935, or more than they lost in the two preceding years, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York discloses in its Aug. 1 review of credit and business conditions.

A twenty-four-hour-a-day police guard was established yesterday over the Woolworth Building offices in which Thomas E. Dewey has set up headquarters for his investigation into racketeering and organized crime in Manhattan.

The city of Utica, N.Y., announced yesterday a new issue of $1,250,000 tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness for award on Aug. 9. The issue will be dated Aug. 12, 1935, and will be payable on Dec, 12, 1935.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Reaching Carl Fischer and Johnny Salveson for fourteen hits, including a homer and a double by Hale and three doubles and a single by Berger, the Indians won the final game of the series from the White Sox, 8 to 3, today.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Rumors current last week-end about an impending "purge" of National Socialist party elements practicing extortion upon well-to-do Jews received some confirmation today with the following official announcement:

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Reports indicating that mills in the United States had bought several cargoes of high-protein cash wheat in Canada for shipment to Buffalo more than offset sensational reports today of damage to the Spring crop and caused heavy selling of futures by commission houses that had been active buyers earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Despite President Roosevelt's insistence on tax legislation along lines set forth in his message of June 19, the administration will be satisfied with any revenue measure Congress may adopt and the Treasury Department will take no position on any bill designed to carry out his suggestions, Secretary Morgenthau told the Senate Finance Committee today.

In view of the possibility that the League Council may consider the matter of the boundary between Ethiopia and the Italian protectorates, it is significant to note that Count Bonin-Longare of Italy was one of the members of the subcommittee of the Sixth Assembly of the League of Nations which reported unanimously as follows on Ethiopia's application for admission to League membership in September, 1923:

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The evil spell which has been cast upon the efforts of the stable of William H. Gallagher at this track was dispelled today at Suffolk Downs when Candimate romped home four lengths in front. The victory, the first for the colors of the New York owner at this track, came in the Westfield, the mile feature of the twentieth day of racing here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 31, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,471,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $7,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- The State Department of Education today announced the list of candidates to whom have been awarded State tuition-paying scholarships at Cornell University as the result of competitive examinations conducted June 17-21.

Bank clearings for the twenty-two principal cities in the United States for the week ended Wednesday totaled $4,779,240,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents an increase of 5.9 per cent over the total of $4,513,069,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.

Higher prices for wheat, flour, livestock, meats and gasoline again carried The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices higher in the last week, the index rising to 125.0 on July 30 from 123.6 on the Tuesday previous. The rise in wheat and flour reflected the spread of rust, in gasoline the excellent consumption and in livestock and meat a continuation of the trend of recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Evidence was presented to the Senate lobby investigating committee today that a "whispering campaign" against President Roosevelt, designed to create an impression throughout the country that the President was "mentally and physically unsound," was suggested to a utilities corporation by Edward P. Cramer of Plainfield, N.J., an advertising man, employed by the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., of Orange, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- President Roosevelt in a strong statement supported the efforts of the League of Nations to effect a settlement in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis. He conferred with Secretary Roper on ship subsidy legislation; with Secretary Perkins on the Camden shipyard strike, and with Maine members of Congress on the question of placing quotas on imports of newsprint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The administration drive to push the $270,000,000 wealth-sharing Tax Bill through the House by Saturday night ran into a Republican filibuster today. This resulted in a waste of more than two hours after the measure was formally taken up for consideration, and may postpone a vote until Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Secretary Morgenthau's formal statement today before the Senate Finance Committee was as follows:
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 1 -- An official Italian delegation, headed by Premier Mussolini's son-in-law, Count Galeazzo Ciano, will attend the opening of the Grossglockner Road Saturday. This illustrates the strategical and political importance of the new road connecting Italy and Germany over the main chain of the Central Alps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- More than 150,000 of the 1,000,000 workers in railroad service in November, 1933, were working for a basic rate of 35 cents an hour or less, or its equivalent, and 110,000 rail employes worked more than forty-eight hours a week during selected payroll periods in 1933 and 1934, Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, stated today in announcing the completion of a wage and hour study.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The administration bill to place the bus and truck transportation systems of the country under a measure of Federal supervision comparable to that already exercised over the railroads was passed by the House today, 193 to 18.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrived yesterday on the first half of her one hundredth voyage and came in to a tightly guarded pier at West Forty-sixth Street where nearly 200 policemen and detectives were on duty to see that there was no recurrence of the anti-Nazi outburst of a week ago.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1. -- The three Soviet aviators now awaiting favorable weather reports before taking off on what they term the most dangerous and most daring flight ever made -- across the North Pole from Moscow to San Francisco --expressed today to the writer complete confidence in their success.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The fleet of junior sailors that participated in the three-day cruise of the Larchmont Yacht Club, sailed into port early this afternoon, concluding the event. The four boats left Stamford this morning and came home in a fairly strong southwest breeze.

A gain of $155,000,000 in member-bank reserves, bringing the total to a high record of $5,100,000,000, is shown by the weekly report of the Federal Reserve system, as of Wednesday. This increase raises the excess of member-bank reserves over requirements by $170,000,000 to a total of $2,510,000,000, compared with the record total recently established of $2,525,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The split between two rival groups of building trade unions within the American Federation of Labor was widened today when seven unions, upon the call of William Green, president of the federation, held a convention and designated J.W. Williams as president of the building trades department and Herbert Rivers as secretary.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- For the fourth time in its thirty-seven runnings, F. Ambrose Clark annexed the Beverwyck Steeplechase at the Spa when his Red Flash was first at the end of the two miles today in the presence of Governor and Mrs. Lehman.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- The government news service sent out from Nuremberg an interview with Professor Peter W. Dykema of Teachers College, Columbia University, in which he expressed profound admiration regarding conditions in Germany and the Hitler regime.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Reds slipped back to sixth place today as the Cardinals beat them, 7 to 5. Dizzy Dean, who failed to finish the game on the mound for St. Louis, was credited with the victory, his seventeenth of the season.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Timely long-distance hitting by Sam Leslie and Tony Cuccinello, coupled with inept base running by the Braves and a muffed fly by Wally Berger, enabled the Dodgers to take the final game of the short series today, 4 to 2, and regain fifth place as the Reds lost to the Cards.

The Actors' Equity Association, in all the dignity of its high office, has decided that Billy Rose's production, "Jumbo," is a circus. As such, it will be outside the Equity province, and Mr. Rose will be able to give two shows a day -- or more, for all of that.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Underlying and animating the effort to frighten a House majority today into reversing its position on the abolition clause for holding companies in the Utilities Bill was the same cynical philosophy which has generated other New Deal tactics. It is based on the belief, widely held in high administration quarters, that members of Congress have few real convictions, or, if they have, lack the courage of them.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., reports for the three months ended on June 30 a net loss of $85,809 after expenses, charges, reserves for depreciation and taxes. In the June quarter last year the net profit was $139,242, or 27 cents a share on the 512,631 capital shares outstanding.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- A split in the ranks of Presbyterian Fundamentalist became evident today with the announced resignation, "upon request," of the Rev. H. McAlister Griffiths as managing editor of the Fundamentalist organ "Christianity Today."

Acting as quietly as if he were conducting one of his own investigations, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, went to City Hall yesterday, was married to Mary Hillyer by Mayor La Guardia and left again before a single photographer had time to focus a camera.

Spurred on by reports of continuing improvement in the key industries, the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday in rather vigorous fashion, with buying orders directed mainly at the more speculative issues.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 1. -- The proceeds of the $76,000,000 ten-year loan issue that the Dominion Government plans to register with the United States Securities and exchange Commission will be used largely to refund the $50,000,000 bank credit obtained in New York a year ago.

The electorate of New York County in choosing William C. Dodge as District Attorney instead of Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., the Fusion candidate, paved the way for the necessity of spending $500,000 of the taxpayers' money on the Dewey racket investigation, Ben Howe asserted yesterday on his re-election as chairman of the City Fusion party.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 1. -- Three thousand troops from Wallamo, who arrived yesterday and camped west of Addis Ababa, struck camp early today on Emperor Haile Selassie's orders to avoid prying journalists and to lull panicky traders.

Despite the handicaps of a confused legislative program and the uncertainty over the entire AAA program, the National City Bank of New York in its August bank letter views seasonal recession as less evident than usual and optimism on the Fall outlook as having the upper hand.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Rain washed away the scheduled semi-final round of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, but the showers reached the North Shore too late to stop the practice match of Jock Whitney's Greentree team, which defeated a twenty-goal White four, 13 to 7.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Governor Lehman and Mrs. Lehman, who motored from the Executive Mansion at Albany, watched the racing from the Governor's box this afternoon. George H. Bull, president of the racing association, joined them.

KIRKSVILLE, Mo., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Letters received here today from Dr. Walter J. Bauer, declared he had just recovered from a slight heat stroke which caused him, in his "delirium," unjustly to suspect his bride of three weeks.

Engineering construction awards in the United States last month totaled $86,873,000, the second lowest monthly aggregate this year. The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday. Last June the figure was $110,161,000; in July, 1934, it was $118,000,000.
Housing properties in Manhattan attracted buyers in large numbers yesterday. Operators and investors led in the trading which extended from the Greenwich Village section to Washington Heights.
BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- No deliveries of arms and munitions to Italy or Ethiopia are being made by Germany, the Foreign Office said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Tigers battered three St. Louis pitchers for fourteen hits and a 6-to-3 triumph in the rubber game of their series today, choked off a drive by the Browns in the ninth and gained a half game over the idle Yankees.

Acting for the first time under the new Federal relief set-up, the Board of Estimate authorized the expenditure of $11,947,500 yesterday for relief in August, Almost all of this is for home relief, leaving the Federal Government to provide funds for work relief this month.

When the Seventy-fourth Congress met, the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations had before it for its consideration the International Copyright Convention of 1928, which had been transmitted by the President on Feb. 19, 1934, with the request that the advice and consent of the Senate to adherence thereto should be accorded.

The first session of the Police Department's training course for eligibles awaiting appointment to the force was held yesterday at the Police Academy, 72 Poplar Street, Brooklyn, with 164 men present of the 950 who have volunteered for study.
Six Manhattan parcels and thirteen in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Two scheduled Bronx offerings were withdrawn.

MALONE, N.Y., Aug. 1.--Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer was acquitted of income tax evasion charges here at 8:55 o'clock tonight after the jury had been out 28 hours and 23 minutes. It was his second trial.
GENEVA, Aug. 1.--The League of Nations Council, which is trying to solve the Ethiopian problem without resort to war, did not meet today. Even thus early it has reached what seems to be an impasse.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Prices of all commodity futures, except for hides, copper and silk, declined yesterday on the local markets. Coffee touched new low levels. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, butter and eggs advanced, while rye, oats, cocoa, cotton and Straits tin were lower.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 1. -- A contract party at the Mountain View, Whitefield, had thirty-five tables in play tonight, among though leading being Mrs. Harold E. Hewlett, Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Lappam, Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Randall, Mrs. Frank S. Dodge, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adams Lynde, all of the permanent colony.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. John E. Berwind gave a luncheon today at Minden, her country place, for Mrs. John Aspegren, who is spending a fortnight at the Irving. The engagement of Mrs. Aspegren's daughter, Miss Amy Aspegren, to Bruce F.E. Harvey, Mrs. Berwind's nephew, has been announced.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- The Boerse continued inactive today, although scattered signs of strength were noted again. Heavy industrials were firm but Rheinstahl, however, lost 1/4 point. Potashes were firmer by 1/4 to 3/4 point. Machine issues were stagnant.

Beset by a fairly heavy profit-taking movement, the share market closed yesterday irregularly lower, but not before the price-average reached new high ground for the year. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was nearly as great as on the day before, 1,888,000, against 1,908,020 shares.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--Continued easiness in the fresh pork market failed to affect the demand for hogs here today and prices for the latter advanced 10 cents a hundredweight generally, with some underweights showing as much as 25 cents above the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Missouri Pacific's present earnings do not allow it a very wide "margin of safety" over and above the financial obligations contemplated in the reorganization plan filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday by O.P. Van Sweringen, Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Many members of the Summer colony here attended the lawn fiesta of the Newport Art Association this afternoon. The grounds were gay with flags and gayly decorated booths, and many debutantes and young children of the colony assisted.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Gloria Vanderbilt, 11 years old, who had been spending a month with her mother, Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, at the Hamilton estate here, completed her stay at 10 o'clock today. Early this morning Gloria attended services at St. Philip and St. James Roman Catholic Church, accompanied by a private detective and her maid.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- With play in the singles at a standstill for the day, two teams gained the semi-finals of the doubles before rain washed out a part of this afternoon's program in the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- A thirty-day open season on ducks was promised to hunters today, but under the most rigid regulations ever imposed by the government in an effort to reduce the annual kill.

The directors of the American Petroleum Institute at a meeting yesterday received the tentative draft of a proposed voluntary code of fair practices for marketing petroleum products and voted to submit it to the petroleum industry for study and consideration. The committee for marketing then will resubmit the code to the directors of the institute for further consideration and action.

It is good to find a public man whose course is not always predictable, even by his close students and admirers. Last Saturday evening The Emporia Gazette quoted golden words: "'Quit and go home,' says Senator ARTHUR CAPPER." And ARTHUR CAPPER, "voic- "ing the sentiments of his people, cer "tainly said a mouthful"

W.C. Fields in "Man on the Flying Trapeze," a Paramount production with Mary Brian and Kathleen Howard, will move into the Capitol today for a week's stay. The stage show, featuring Lou Holtz, Belle Baker and others, has been held over from last week.

SEVERNA PARK, Md., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Otto L. Molter, 51, was shot to death in her home here tonight and her husband died several hours later of an apparently self-inflicted bullet wound in the head.

Cash income received by farmers in June was estimated at $438,000,000 against $483,000,000 in May, or with AAA payments at $487,000,000 against $519,000,000, according to The Annalist. The decline was much larger than the usual seasonal drop, and the seasonal adjusted index accordingly fell to a preliminary 60.0 from 64.0 in May or if AAA payments are included to 65.8 from 68.3.

Availing themselves of the preslent abundance of credit obtainable at low interest rates, corporations in July, through refunding operations, retired more bonds before maturity than in any month on record. The retirements were well diversified, with the principal ones in the oil, public utility, meat and packing industries.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP). --Notification that 2,500 transient workers and other persons on relief rolls have been assigned to the rehabilitation of debris-strewn farm lands in the New York flood zone was received by Governor Herbert H. Lehman from President Roosevelt today.

In a ceremony twenty feet below the bed of the Hudson, attended by newspaper reporters, sound camera men and the crew of a local broadcasting station, the new vehicular tunnel connecting Manhattan and Weehawken will be "officially holed through" early this afternoon.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 1. -- Prince Alexis Mdivani, former husband of the former Barbara Hutton, American heiress, was reported instantly killed today and a woman companion believed fatally injured when the automobile in which they were riding overturned at Albona, Gerona Province.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The largest cash premium realized by the government to date on "auction" bond sales resulted from the disposal of $106,483,000 worth of 2 7/8 per cent bonds during the first half of this week, Secretary Morgenthau revealed today.
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Following is the text of remarks on Ethiopia made by Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, before the House of Commons today:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- The trustees of the Berkshire Museum at Pittsfield, of whom Henry A. Francis is chairman, and Miss Laura M. Bragg, director, tonight gave a reception, for which 2,000 invitations were issued, to mark the opening of an exhibition of 134 oil paintings by twentieth century artists from the permanent collection of the Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Museum of American Art, New York.

BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- The future of the Boston Braves was no more settled today than it has been since the day dog-track furor put Judge Emil Fuchs in the limelight and stirred the wrath of Commissioner Landis and the National League.

The French Ambassador in Washington has conferred upon Julian Street the decoration of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor in tribute to his work as "the greatest present American author on wines and gastronomy." Mr. Street is the author of "Wines: Their Selection, Care and Service," which enjoyed wide popularity following the repeal of prohibition.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The indication that naval authorities will maintain a permanent naval air base here was made today when Lieut. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, in charge of the station, declared that authorization had been made for work projects on the naval reservations involving expenditures of $317,050.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Full confidence in Jefferson Caffery, Ambassador to Cuba, was expressed today by William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, to a delegation of liberals who called on him to request the Ambassador's removal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today named thirty-four representatives of business, labor, agriculture and educational institutions as a national advisory committee to the $50,000,000 national youth administration.

MOST literate people have met Clarence Day's Father (the capital is important), either in the already classical "God and My Father" or in the pages of The New Yorker. But familiarity in this case breeding anything but contempt, they will want to possess Mr. Day's "Life With Father" (Knopf, $2), which the Book of the Month Club is sending out for August.

WARSAW, Aug. 1. -- To encourage foreign automobile companies, especially American concerns, to establish assembling plants in Poland, the Polish Cabinet has decided to end the monopoly of an Italian company for motor-car construction in this country.

The New York Edison Company, Inc., was organized yesterday as a consolidation of the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company, pursuant to authority granted by the Public Service Commission on Tuesday. Officers were elected yesterday as follows:

Owners of certificates of the F issue of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company were notified yesterday that they would receive a dividend of 1 1/2 per cent on Aug. 15. The trustees, William J. Pedrick, Alexander Pfeiffer and William J. Schmitt were appointed only a few weeks ago by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to reorganize and administer the issue of $2,600,000.
The Park Department learned yesterday, greatly to its surprise, that if there is one thing New York has a surplus of it is shaving mugs.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP). --- The vanguard of 36,000 men of the First Army moved into Pine Camp today, starting the largest concentration of United States troops in peacetime history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Defending the New York police for their conduct in connection with the flag incident on the liner Bremen, William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, in a reply today to the German protest of last Monday, declared the incident was "in no sense due to neglect on the part of the American authorities."

Mayor La Guardia and Hospitals Commissioner S.S. Goldwater inspected two new city ambulances at City Hall yesterday and contrasted them with an older vehicle that has been in use for the last ten years.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP). -- It was birdie or no count today as sixteen of America's premier golf professionals met in the first round of a novel tourney -- a four-ball round-robin match play team event which will last through Sunday and 126 holes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Congress seems determined to expose the New Deal's farm processing taxes to court suits for recovery of the levies paid.

After a declining trend for two months, Dun's index number of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly in July to 171.511 on Aug. 1, an improvement of 0.03 per cent. The steadiness that marked the course of wholesale prices in July made wide recovery impossible, and the index was 0.9 per cent lower than on Jan. 1 and 2.9 per cent below the year's high level of 176.806 reached on March 1.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Stocks were quieter today than yesterday, although industrials continued active and strong. The heavy over-subscription of the new West Bromwich loan, together with the rapid success of the flotation by the Dun-success of the flotation by the City of Dundee, gave firmness to British Government stocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Changes made by the Senate Banking Committee in the administration's resolution to outlaw suits on gold payment obligations, so as to permit filing of actions within six months after the resolution is adopted, were accepted today by Attorney, General Cummings as "satisfactory."
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Britain decided today to offer, together with France, to guarantee Italian Somaliland and Eritrea against possible Ethiopian aggression.

In view of the fact that pool operations are banned by the Securities and Exchange Act, under Section 9, which prohibits manipulation of security issues on the Stock Exchange, it is quite difficult, at times, to explain the extraordinarily heavy trading which develops suddenly in many listed issues.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Lynn B. Hammond, Commissioner of Assessments for Glen Cove, opened the 1936 roll this morning for the inspection of taxpayers and announced there was little change this year. The total assessed valuation for 1935 was about $27,800,000 and the tentative total for next year is $27,773,638.

At the press conference where the President used some not too kind language about rich men who buy tax-exempt bonds, one of the correspondents asked him how that supply would be cut off. Mr. ROOSEVELT replied that he supposed a constitutional amendment would be necessary.

DWIGHT, Ill., Aug. 1. -- Dr. James H. Oughton, head of the Keeley Institute here, a hospital for the cure of alcoholism, was wounded fatally this afternoon when he was too slow in putting up his hands at the command of one of four robbers who invaded the business office of the hospital. Dr. Oughton, who was shot twice in the head, died two hours later in the Dwight Community Hospital.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and her sister, Lady Furness, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa accompanied by the latter's son Anthony. Others on the liner, leaving after midnight for Channel ports and Bremerhaven, include William S. Howell, first secretary of the American Embassy in Paris; Shells Barrett, motion picture actress, and Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw of New York. Others are:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- A strong declaration in support of League of Nations efforts to compose the differences between Italy and Ethiopia was made by President Roosevelt today in a statement expressing the hope that peace would be maintained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Trade Commission reported today that all divisions of the cotton textile industry operated at a loss during the last six months of 1934, the latest period for which statistics were available.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- German editorial opinion, which in the absence of something more precise must also be accepted as a reflection of inspired political views, is inclined to construe the session of the League of Nations council as a test of strength between Great Britain and France -- a test which threatens to relegate the Italo-Ethiopian conflict to a place of secondary importance.

Congress has put squarely up to the President the defense of one of the major reforms achieved by his Administration. It will be remembered that shortly after he entered office Mr. ROOSEVELT courageously took the lead in ridding the pension rolls of many ex-soldiers who had no moral right to be there, since they had suffered no injury or disability connected with war service.

NEWARK, Aug. 1. -- The Newark Bears defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 11 to 2, tonight to take the lead in their series. The first game of the scheduled double-header was postponed on account of rain, creating another twin bill for tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes late today issued an order restraining Carter H. Harrison, Collector of Internal Revenue, from enforcing collection of processing taxes on pork from the eighteen Chicago packing companies which had brought injunction proceedings. A similar order was issued for the Quaker Oats Company and Washburn-Crosby Company, Inc.

Staten Island political parties launched their campaign for the Fall elections last night by drawing up slates for offices. Three complete tickets were placed in the field, two of them to be contested in the Democratic primaries.

MINEOLA., L.I., Aug. 1. -- Henry Perl, 54 years old, of 378 Pine Street, Long Beach, L.I., police justice at Island Park, was arrested here this morning by Lieutenant Robert McLaren of District Attorney Martin W. Littleton's staff, charged with grand larceny.

One has but to see the uses to which the seven blocks between Houston and Canal, Chrystie and Forsyth Streets have been put, to be grateful to this city administration for the transformation that has been wrought in this blighted area. Not only has a strip of slum been redeemed, but it has been made into something far better than was dreamed when the property was first condemned for public development.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 1.--Interesting evidence of the close cooperation between Germany and Hungary is provided by the suppression from the Hungarian press of all accounts of Germany's anti-Semitic and anti-Catholic campaign and her labor difficulties.
A little group of serious thinkers created a disturbing oasis of quiet in the normal uproar of Heckscher Playground in Central Park near Fifty-ninth Street yesterday afternoon.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, metropolitan champion, who is regarded as the most improved player of the year in this district, today added another prize to the fine collection she has made by taking the Westchester-Fairfield one-day golf tourney low gross honors at the Innis Arden Country Club.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, Aug. 1. -- King George again was aboard his cutter Britannia in the Royal Thames Yacht Club's race for the big yachts today. T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour won, beating Astra, the second boat, by about five minutes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Justice Department is expected to reach out soon to protect the small-town bank, long victimized by America's 5,000 known bank robbers.

A finger has been laid on the vital spot in the shirt-sleeves-for-Summer controversy. One gentleman reminds us that men carry too many things in their pockets to go around without a coat. It is an argument that will evoke hearty support from those who know what untold sufferings follow upon merely discarding the vest in hot weather.

The Special Sessions Appellate Term handed down a majority decision yesterday confirming the recent conviction and workhouse sentences of three months imposed by Magistrate Perlman on Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco under the Brownell Public Enemy Law. Justices Hackenburg and McDonald -voted, without a written opinion, to elegy aeertlfieate of reasonable doubt' requested by Robert J. Fizsimmons, 'attorney for the defendants.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $10,228,390 in the week ended on July 31, the weekly report of the bank showed today. At the same time, deposits from chartered banks dropped $7,597,840.
The Dutch guilder resumed yesterday its decline in the foreign exchange market after having given a good account of itself on Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1. -- Striking back at a new "whispering campaign" against President Roosevelt, Postmaster General Farley told the Democratic County Committee today that "the President has the most strenuous job in the world, but he is equal to it."
Several apartment houses were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Bebest, owned by Mrs. Ernest McCown, trained by her husband, and ridden by her son, Darrell McCown, made a family affair of the one-mile feature at Arlington Park today, getting up to score by a head over H.H. Battle's Sis Agnes.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Citizens Military Training Camp students were hosts to 100 members of the Daughters of the American Revolution here today. After a review of the citizen soldiers, Miss Mabel Clay of Ocean City, the State regent of the organization, presented medals to the outstanding cadets in the camp.

Two men who sat in on a three-handed stud poker game in which William Boyd of 399 Park Avenue, member of a socially prominent family, lost $19,200 were arrested yesterday, after the North German Lloyd liner Europa arrived from Europe.

Interest rates charged for demand and time loans in July were unchanged from those prevailing in June. One-quarter of 1 per cent for call loans was posted daily on the New York Stock Exchange and three-quarters of 1 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange.

Dividends declared in July made the best showing for that month since 1931. Nearly all classes of industries voted larger dividends than a year ago. Declarations amounted to $172,504,763 for 785 companies, compared with $132,909,884 by 639 companies in July, 1934.

Steps designed to combat a revival of opposition to American participation in the 1936 Olympic Games at Berlin, growing out of the latest anti-Jewish and anti-Catholic activities in Germany, were taken yesterday by Avery Brundage, president of the American Olypmic Committee, according to The Associated Press.

Thirty-two makes of passenger cars and trucks will be exhibited at the National Automobile Show which will open in Grand Central Palace Nov. 2. This announcement was made by the Automobile Manufacturers Association yesterday, following a drawing by car manufacturers in Detroit for space.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 1. -- A law passed in the secret sessions of Congress authorizes the government to demonetize silver and prohibit trading in and the exportation of silver coins, according to the text of the law as published in the newspaper Tiempo today.

Port of New York Authority toll gate policemen who have occasionally been suspected by motorists of being practical jokers with a rather perverse sense of humor may be spared the entirely unfounded charge in the future.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- An apology for his recent reflections upon members of the Senate Banking subcommittee which wrote the Omnibus Banking Bill was made on the House floor today by Representative Goldsborough, thus ending a deadlock in the conference on the bill.

Edward Johnson, impresario of the Metropolitan Opera Association, returned on the Italian liner Rex yesterday after two months spent in Europe giving auditions, talking with European opera folk and members of the Metropolitan's company who are now abroad.

THIS would be a good time for the Giants to start a little winning streak. It's their turn. The Cardinals put on a sprint that carried them from away back to a neck-and-neck scramble with the Terry clan in St. Louis. The clamoring Cubs have come a long way forward in the past month. Except for one furious rally on the banks of the Mississippi, the Giants practically dawdled through July.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- William S. Meany Jr., dubbed "Wild Bill" since he purchased an airplane some time ago which he uses to get him around to various golf tournaments, had the laugh on his fellow golfers today.

At the special meeting here yesterday of stockholders of the Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company to take action on the refunding plan whereby new 5 per cent preferred stock would be issued and the present 7 per cent preferred retired, proxies for more than two-thirds of the common stock were held by the management to be voted in favor of the plan.

A tropical "twister" struck the Great South Bay fishing fleet while it was returning from the fishing grounds at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, capsizing several of the boats along with a score of other craft. Two men were drowned and about fifty persons were rescued from the bay and near-by waters by boats that had ridden out the sudden storm.

Not since March, 1931, has the total of new securities publicly offered here been larger for a month than it was in July. The flotations, nearly all for the purpose of refunding liens bearing higher interest, were principally large public utility and industrial bond issues.

ANGLETOWN, Texas, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Six Houston newspapermen today interposed a plea of legal privilege to publish a fair and impartial account of a public trial, as a defense against contempt of court charges in the murder hearing of a convict.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Suppressed and smoldering German unrest had as fuel for its fires tonight new warnings to faltering Nazis, new repressive measures directed against Jews, the Stahlhelm and "State enemies," an anti-Jewish demonstration near the Bayerischerplatz in Berlin and lurid newspaper extras.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL TRAIN NEAR URUAPAN, Michoacan, Mexico, Aug. 1. -- Speaking at the town of Commaja, State of Michoacan, President Lazaro Cardenas gave a signal Tuesday for the launching of a nation-wide campaign against alcoholism.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug, 1. -- Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles and Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif.,. gained the semi-final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today before rain intervened to force a cancellation of the other two quarter-finals.

This department's suggestion to anglers in search of a pure for boredom is an offshore trip for tuna. The school fish apparently are plentiful now along the Jersey coast and off Montauk, while in recent days a few catches have been made by boats from Bay Shore and Freeport.

Retail package deliveries made by the United Parcel Service showed an increase of 12 per cent for the week ended July 27, it was announced yesterday by officials of the service. The figure compares with a rise of 20 per cent for the previous week.

An agreement was reached yesterday in which Captain Eduardo Fano was acknowledged as the American agent of the Spanish Transatlantic Steamship Line. Two injunction suits, the first brought by S.E.L. Maduro and the second by Captain Fano, have been withdrawn and Captain Fano recognized as agent of the line, it was announced.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1. -- A drawl in his last game, held over from the eleventh and final round, enabled Isaac Kashdan of New York to finish third in the annual Western championship at the congress of the American Chess Federation, concluded today.

The optimism inherent in City Clerk Michael J. Cruise blossomed yesterday at a hearing on the Board of Aldermen's 1936 budget, when he assured Budget Director R.E. McGahen that the depression was over and that salary cuts should be restored for his staff.

Having succeeded in riding out a number of twisters of tropical proportions which for a time threatened to blast them loose from their moorings on top of the National League, the Giants came upon a haven of sunshine yesterday as the Braves hove into the Polo Grounds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Many operators on the Chicago Board of Trade expected today's private estimates on the wheat crop would reveal a calamity, especially in the Northwest, and when the figures were issued suggesting a prospective yield of 603,000,000 bushels they were construed as bearish.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A continued rise in industrial activity in Germany, as witnessed by higher production and a further drop in unemployment. was reported today by the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in American foreign markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Reports from the West that farm groups are organizing to fight protective tariffs for industry in retaliation for attacks made on the Agricultural Adjustment Act were termed by President Roosevelt today as symptomatic of the fact that farmers appreciate the benefits of the AAA program.

PANAMA, R.P., Aug. 2. -- A personal check of President Arias of Panama, offered as bail for the release of Nelson Rounsevell, publisher of The Panama American, charged with criminal libel, was refused by Canal Zone legal authorities tonight.

A committee for $224,040,000 of Missouri Pacific 5 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds prepared yesterday to attack the plan of reorganization for the railroad proposed by O.P. Van Sweringen, president of the Alleghany Corporation, majority stockholder in the 12,000-mile line.

TOKYO, Aug. 2. -- Ambassador Tsuneo Matsudaira, in a statement to the press as he arrived in Tokyo from London today after seven years' absence, gave the Japanese public a temperate review of their international position that has to be contrasted with the crisis and national emergency propaganda preached here since 1931.

Yesterday's TIMES carried an account of a jolly little party under the able tutelage of Senator Long at the Hotel New Yorker. The Senator is alleged to have directed the compounding and dispensation of some Ramos gin fizzes. And THE TIMES carried a recipe for this famous drink, purported to come from him.

A group organized by Conrad Glaser, together with Major Compson Satz, have bought the bus terminal at Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, Flushing, from William Henry Barnum Co. and the New York Trust Company. The deal was for cash above a $1,200,000 ten-year mortgage, Mr. Glaser reports.

EAST WINDSOR, Conn., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Howard Warner, 50-year-old cashier of the Broad Brook Bank and Trust Company, out-bluffed three robbers today, flatly refusing obey their orders to open the bank vault, and concealing from them the fact that a brief case in his hand contained $8,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- President Roosevelt expressed a view that private industry might provide enough re-employment that the work relief program would not have to absorb the full quota of 3,500,000 employable idle. He conferred with Representative Rankin on rural electrification, and with Jefferson Caffery and Sumner Welles on the state of Cuba.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 2. -- Countess Kurt von Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, was deeply affected when she learned today of the death of her former husband, Prince Alexis Mdivani. The news was broken to her at the railroad station at Warnemuende, Germany.

Following early firmness, the markets developed sagging tendencies during the later trading yesterday and closed lower on the day. The share market experienced another day of hesitancy as the professional following endeavored to arrive at some conclusion as to just how completely the price-rise had discounted business improvement and autumnal prospects.

Supreme Court Justice Lauer, in a decision yesterday, directed that the application of Earl W. Hagedone, a taxicab owner, to compel the Police Department to license his cut-rate cab he passed upon by a jury. The point to be determined, he said, is whether the imperfections of Hagedone's meter, as alleged by the police, is sufficient to justify the refusal of a license.

Bound for Warsaw, where they will represent the United States in the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation, five of the outstanding experts of this country -- four from New York and one from Portland, Ore. -- sailed yesterday for Poland on board the steamship Pulaski of the Gdynia America Line.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Greater use of advertising and more efficient personnel in freight traffic departments were recommended to the railroads today in a report submitted by Joseph B. Eastman, the transportation co-ordinator, to the regional co-ordinating committees of the country's railroads.

Budget increases for 1936 amounting to more than $10,000,000 have been requested by the forty-five city and county departments that had filed their schedules with Budget Director R.E. McGahen up to yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Plans for developing a second self-contained island prison off the Pacific Coast by converting McNeil Island in Puget Sound and two smaller islands near by into a model establishment were announced today by Attorney General Cummings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Not a race for champions, but a race for prospective champions, Arlington Park's Futurity will be decided tomorrow with the prospect of a field of 18. The race, at six furlongs, will close a highly successful thirty-day meeting of the Arlington Park Jockey Club, which for the first time in five years will show a profit, one that may reach $250,000.

The possibility that a reduction in Eastern railroad passenger fares may be forced through by the Interstate Commerce Commission in advance of hearings on the proposal developed yesterday when it became known that the leading passenger carriers had reached no agreement for a united stand.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 3. -- The Soviet's trans-Polar airplane took off on its risky flight to San Francisco at 6:03 this morning [12:03 A.M., New York daylight-saving time] from the military airdrome near the village of Sholkovo, twenty-five miles southeast of Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Talk of a compromise by conferees on AAA bill amendments emerged today amid conflicting reports from one quarter that the Senate changes had been accepted entirely and from another that they had not.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A letter from a utilities official calling E.P. Cramer's program for destroying the New Deal "very pertinent" started the Senate lobby committee on a drive today to fix responsibility for the recent whispering campaign against President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- Scoring four runs in a first inning that verged on the fantastic, the Dodgers today danced away with the opening game with the Phillies by the score of 8 to 3, insuring their retention of fifth place for another day, at least.

In spite of increasing difficulties in the financing of its work, the administration of the Children's Aid Society remains satisfied that the Federal Government has not assumed the care of dependent children during the depression, it was said yesterday in conjunction with the issuance of the organization's eighty-second annual report.

New York and other ports on the Atlantic seaboard have received a temporary setback in their efforts to win back the traffic in export automobiles, which has been diverted in recent years to the Gulf cities. The Interstate Commerce Commission, it was announced yesterday, has granted the request of Gulf port interests for suspension of proposed increases of rail rates on this traffic between the Middle West and the Gulf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Postponement of action on the President's wealth-tax program, in the interest of more mature consideration, until next January, when the budget will be under scrutiny, and exemption of "death-duty insurance" from the inheritance taxes proposed in the House bill were suggested before the Senate Finance Committee by Miss Catherine Curtis, representing Women Investors in America, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- President Roosevelt announced the appointment today of Thomas Riggs of New York City as a member of the Canadian Boundary Commission. Mr. Riggs, who is an engineer, was a member of the Canadian Boundary Survey in 1905.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A decision handed down by Federal Judge Luther B. Way in Norfolk recently, is being studied here by government officers who are preparing for the Supreme Court tests of the Wagner Labor Relations Law. Some officials believe the decision may have an important effect upon the controversy over the law's constitutionality.

While a cab driver crouched behind the wheel of his car in terror and hundreds of pedestrians scurried for shelter, a police sergeant and two patrolmen, fighting a twenty-minute revolver battle yesterday at Twenty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, killed an escaping robber trapped in the tonneau of the cab.

MALONE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The jury which acquitted Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer of charges of income tax evasion set forth its reasons today through a statement by Leon L. Chapin, the farmer and dairy products company official who served as its foreman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Mass production of safe, easily operated and inexpensive airplanes within a few years was predicted today by Eugene L. Vidal, chief of aviation activities in the Department of Commerce.

Realty trading in Manhattan showed a sharp upturn yesterday when brokers announced contracts for the sale of apartment houses in Harlem, the Washington Heights section and the Dyckman area. Added interest to the brisk market activity was lent by the leasing of two theatre properties in Fourteenth and East Houston Streets, and two multi-family buildings on the upper West Side.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Experience gained in medley swimming proved invaluable to 17-year-old Miss Johanna German of the Carnegie Library Club today as she thrashed her way to the lead after two events of the Decathlon competition in Zach's Bay.

Precautions vainly suggested by New York police officials before the anti-Nazi riot on the Hapag-Lloyd liner Bremen a week ago were followed scrupulously on the departure of the liner's sister ship, the Europa, early this morning. She sailed on time without the slightest disorder.
