Wreckers have taken forty-four days to demolish a Times Square blockfront comprising two theatres and half a score old-style office buildings. The contract called for fifty-nine days. The saving in time was effected by working fourteen hours a day in two shifts seven days a week.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 2 (AP). -- Justice Owen J. Roberts has denied to Mrs. Katherine McNider Drier, a relative by marriage of President Roosevelt, the right to sue the German Government for $600,000, it was disclosed today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Frank Parker of Spring Lake stands within one match of establishing a second successive leg on the Southampton Challenge Bowl. J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange is the last barrier to his progress on the Meadow Club courts.

HONGKONG, Aug. 2. -- While Shanghai at present is the nucleus for a new political party that favors abolishing the Kuomintang (nationalist party) and urging Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to assume an absolute military and civilian dictatorship, free of party and political trammels, another political party is in the making, which is expected formally to announce itself from Hongkong in mid-September.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Sam West's home run with Ray Pepper on base, hit off Vern Kennedy in the eighth, cashed in on Russ Van Atta's three innings of shut-out relief pitching today and gave the Browns a 10-to-8 triumph over the White Sox. Pepper had made a home run off Sam Jones in the fourth inning.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Al Moreau, brilliant American timber topper from Marksville, La., today equaled Percy Beard's world record of 14.2 seconds for the 110-meter high hurdles. Moreau continued his winning streak in a meet between a touring American track team and a picked Norwegian athletic array.

The "increasing" need of the schools for financial aid from the Federal Government without, however, Federal control of education, was stressed yesterday by speakers at a conference on long-term educational planning held at Teachers College, Columbia University.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- The semi-final brackets in the women's invitation singles were completed at the Maidstone Club today as Mrs. Ethel Burkhardt Arnold of California and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston won the two remaining quarterfinal matches.

Over-the-counter dealers in New York received yesterday a nine-page questionnaire from the Securities and Exchange Commission requesting data for the study the commission is directed by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to make of the feasibility of segregating the functions of brokers and dealers.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

No other possessive pronoun seems to be quite so personal, so absolute, as that which is applied to one's vacation. It is the all but universal question when persons meet, especially at this season, as to the when and where or how of it. There is not the same freedom even among friends to speak intimately and possessively about vocations, though they are the condition precedent of vacations.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 2. -- Over the leading Salzburg hotels float the Stars and Stripes and the Union Jack. This is symbolic, no doubt, but it scarcely tells the whole tale. For Salzburg is full this Summer as perhaps never before of foreigners from all parts of the world.

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- H.C. Hopson and the Associated Gas and Electric System, in which he is a prime mover, were subjected to sharp attack today at a public hearing conducted by the legislative committee investigating the public utilities. It was revealed that the committee has been seeking Mr. Hopson.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The State Tax Commission is in full accord with the sentiment expressed by Federal Judge Bryant, who criticized the acquittal of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, said today.

This evening will see just one closing, and a routine one it is, "The Yeomen of the Guard" will leave the Adelphi, to be followed, in the normal order of Gilbert and Sullivan, by "The Gondoliers" on Monday. "The Great Waltz" also will reopen at the Center Theatre on Monday, thus making an ambitious-time for a mid-August evening.

GENEVA, Aug. 2. -- The attitude to be taken by the Council of the League of Nations toward the Italo-Ethiopian dispute in its present stage was settled tonight among the delegations of France, Great Britain and Italy.
LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The ancient formula "Le Roy Le Veult" announced to the House of Lords today that the bill embodying India's new Federal Constitution had received the royal assent.

William Boyd of 399 Park Avenue, who lost $19,200 playing cards with two men on board the North German Lloyd liner Europa, refused yesterday in West Side Court to sign a complaint against them. The men were arrested Thursday night when the vessel arrived here from Europe

The Rev. Dr. Howard E. Mather, metropolitan, and national director of American Apostolic Missions, of Brooklyn, who was ordained in 1933 by Archbishop Gregory Lines of the American Catholic Church, and a man describing himself as Jerome S. Gottlieb, appeared yesterday on a conspiracy charge before Magistrate Mason in Flatbush Court. Decision was reserved until Aug. 115.
The Eastern grass court tennis championships will get under way today at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, with many noted women and men players among the entrants.

That racing on the metropolitan tracks made very favorable progress during the Spring meetings on Long Island and showed an increase in interest over last year is indicated in reports filed yesterday with the State Racing Commission by the Metropolitan Jockey Club, the Westchester Racing Association and the Queens County Jockey Club, which operate Jamaica, Belmont Park and Aqueduct respectively.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 2. -- Officials of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., here held a series of conferences today to determine the employment status of Edwin P. Cramer, who testified yesterday before the Senate Lobby Committee in Washington regarding a proposed whispering campaign against President Roosevelt.
CINCINNATI, Aug 2 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs suffered their first white-washing since July 5 today, young Gene Schott of the Cincinnati Reds blanking them, 8 to 0.

Two new provinces of the Roman Catholic Sisters of Mercy have been instituted in the United States, to be known as the Province of New York and the Province of Baltimore. The provincial house for New York is at Tarrytown. The mother provincial is the Rev. Mother Immaculata Murphy.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 2 (AP). -- A five-cornered fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor held the attention of voters today on the eve of Kentucky's primary election tomorrow.

Interest in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange subsided somewhat yesterday from the previous day and the market reflected an indifferent attitude on the part of traders. This resulted in a rather mixed undertone most of the day. The market seemed inclined to rest following the steady advance which has carried prices to the recent high levels.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The Newark Bears scored three runs in the seventh and final inning of a twilight game tonight to beat Toronto, 4 to 3. The second game of the scheduled double-header was called off on account of rain after the players and some 5,000 fans had waited an hour.

A sudden, freakish and shot-lived heat wave drove the Weather Bureau's mercury to a height of 90 degrees at 3:05 o'clock yesterday afternoon, thus placing the day, technically at least, in a triple tie for the second hottest of the year.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 2. -- After a day in which Frederick Von Nieda, Republican, and George E. Brunner, New Dealer, both went through the motions of being Mayor, an order was served on Mr. Brunner tonight restraining him temporarily from serving in that office.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2. -- The Communist International (Comintern) voted today to permit individual Communist parties more latitude in details of their work, but to retain control over essentials.
A slight, gray-haired man, with even his spectacles dripping ooze, popped out of a two-foot pipe seventy-five feet under the Hudson River at 12:18 P.M. yesterday.

Mr. ROOSEVELT showed his good sense in stating that he would take no procedures against the New Jersey advertising agent, hitherto unknown to fame, who claims to have furnished the original idea of a whispering campaign against the President. There is some evidence that men to whom he proposed his plan rejected it as "puerile."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- President Roosevelt at a press conference today predicted acceleration of employment on work-relief projects in September and October and absorption of 90 to 95 per cent of the employable idle by November.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Governor Earle has served "formal notice" that public utilities of Pennsylvania "will not be permitted to charge excessive rates."

The Italian liner Rex, leaving today with 1,003 passengers for Mediterranean ports, has on the passenger list Mrs. J. Kingdon Gould, Commander Ludovico Manzini, Italian Consul at San Francisco, and Mme. Manzini, Laurence Stallings and the following:

With characteristic bravado, Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who managed to convince a Federal jury of farmers at Malone, N.Y., that he was not an income-tax dodger, challenged Mayor La Guardia yesterday to try to keep him from returning to his old haunts in New York City.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP). -- A statement that the hold-up slaying of Howard Carter Dickinson was planned during a "strip poker" party in which he was a participant, was read into the record today in the murder trial of William Lee Ferris and three women co-defendants.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests, as well as many from East Hampton and Westhampton Beach, attended the dinner dance and entertainment for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children tonight at Canoe Place Inn.

A jury in General Sessions Judge Collins's court in half an hour yesterday convicted Luke F. Courtney, 38 years old, a suspended clerk in the Education Department, of a misdemeanor in making a "corrupt bargain" to have a man's name placed on the civil service eligible list for patrolmen in March, 1931.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- "We have faith in America, but give her time." This was the Marquess of Lothian's message here today to a class of teachers taking a vacation course. Lecturing on the history of America, Lord Lothian said many were pessimistic about the prospects of recovery in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the government had made a conditional threat to cancel its $50,000,000 naval contracts with the New York Shipbuilding Company of Camden, N.J., unless the company adopted some policy that would deliver the ordered ships and end the strike of 3,000 workers.

ADDI UGRI, Eritrea, July 12 (By Mail). -- At Addi Ugri, close to the Ethiopian frontier, the idea came to me that I should persist in my efforts to persuade the authorities to let me penetrate Ethiopia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Mandeville W. Zenge, 26-year-old Missourian, was arrested here today in connection with the death by mutilation of Dr. Walter J. Bauer, who last month married the young woman whom Zenge had courted for seven years.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The discovery of a new surgical method for curing Raynaud's disease and other disorders of the blood vessels was announced to the International Neurological Congress today by Professor Alfred Adson of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.

WARSAW, Aug. 2. -- A note demanding an explanation of Danzig's decree throwing the Free City's frontiers open to duty-free importation of many foreign products was sent today to Danzig's Senate President by the Polish High Commissioner.

The annual changes in personnel of educational institutions served by teachers provided by the Society of Jesus have been announced by the Very Rev. Edward C. Phillips, provincial of the Maryland-New York Province. His secretary, the Rev. Hugh S. Bihler, is to take up the study of psychology at the University of Prague, Czechoslovakia. In his absence the Rev. J.B. Murray will serve as secretary.
Fifty child performers took part in the annual circus in the roof garden of the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, yesterday.

The new regulations for the shooting of migratory waterfowl, announced in Washington on Thursday, aroused widespread discussion yesterday among sportsmen, conservationists and officials of various organizations interested in this highly controversial subject.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in the local markets yesterday. Rubber, silk and the metals recovered, while other staples continued to decline. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats, flour, cotton and coffee declined, while corn, silk and rubber gained and zinc made a new high.

Accelerated by the unexpected upturn in the pace of operations of some of the leading industries, far in advance of the usual period for expansion, more trends reached toward a higher level this week than was recorded at this time a year ago, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Marjorie Dunton's first showing in her new establishment -- formerly Augustabernard's house -- was a great success. She showed slim, youthful, wearable, modern clothes, featuring a variety of flattering ruffled neck and sleeve effects.

ANGLETON, Texas, Aug. 2 (AP). -Freedom of the press was presented as a privilege of the public as well as of newspapers in defense argunaents today at the hearing of siX Houston newspaper men cited for contempt of court in a murder trial. A ruling was set for 9 A. M. tomorTow.
There were not enough male dancing partners on a recent cruise ship. The passenger list consisted of 90 per cent women. Six hired "gigolos" were lost in the shuffle.
Mayor La Guardia made short shrift yesterday of the "demands" of a group from the Workers Unemployed Union who intercepted him on his way to City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A view that legislation to control utility holding companies, with a strong dissolution clause but without the arbitrary "death sentence" of the Senate bill, may still emerge from this session of Congress was expressed by Senator Wheeler today.

A pre-nuptial agreement whereby a Jewish man and a Catholic woman agreed that their children should be raised in the Catholic faith was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, who ruled against the father in his attempt to gain custody of his 2-month-old son.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Near-record small receipts of hogs, except for Saturday, kept many buyers out of the market here today, the fear being that a runaway market would be experienced if severe competition developed for the scant supplies. Prices advanced 5 to 10 cents, however, to a new high level since September, 1930, the top being lifted 10 cents to $11.20 a hundred pounds, while the day's average was 5 cents higher at $10.30.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area gave a good account of itself during the week, although reports indicated that sales in New Jersey still labored under the handicap of the sales tax there. The response to August sales offerings in local stores was good and a gain of around 10 per cent over a year ago for the week was estimated.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2. -- Foreign observers here said the enunciation of the new principle of the Communist International was of major importance, and of special significance in the light of the expected assembly next week, when the congress will formulate its program of action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Plans of the administration to lend Federal funds to private power companies to finance rural electrification programs were criticized today by Representative Rankin of Mississippi, a strong supporter of the Tennessee Valley Authority program.

While the conference agreement in Congress on an export bounty on surplus farm products was reported to be merely tentative, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved lower again yesterday under increased selling pressure. A quantity of contracts for March and May delivery came on the market, but buying of October by houses doing government business held up the near month and widened differences. May frequently sold 33 points under October.

Twice Magistrate Overton Harris, sitting in Tombs Court yesterday, was accused of unfairness, and in one of the cases an attorney, George Hiram Mann of 79 Wall Street, withdrew as defense counsel, declaring, "I don't think a lawyer can get a fair trial here."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan gave a large dinner at Bonniecrest this evening in honor of their guests, Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen and E. Victor Loew.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 2. -- Joe Coria, St. Paul picnic grounds policeman, and Frankie Strafaci, 18-year-old high school boy from the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, will battle it out for the national public links golf championship tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Charges that railroad reorganizations in process of arrangement with the Interstate Commerce Commission were designed to protect "corporate insiders" and to perpetuate control of the roads in the hands of those admittedly unable to run them successfully in the past were made today by Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee, in a letter to Balthasar H. Meyer, acting chairman of the I.C.C.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The House acted today to thwart any attempts by radical members to start a crusade for a more drastic "soak-the-rich" or "share-the-wealth" tax bill, by tentatively approving the Ways and Means proposal to start the new tax on net incomes above $50,000.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Rumors that Eleutherios Venizelos, former Premier of Greece, and his family were customers of B. Coles Neidecker and his bankrupt Travellers Bank were confirmed here today from an unimpeachable source.

The Van Raalte Company, Inc., declared yesterday an initial dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1. This is the first common dividend since incorporation of the company in 1919. Irving K. Hessberg, president, stated that this is not to be regarded as the inauguration of a regular dividend policy, although the directors will consider the company's earnings each quarter in connection with future declarations.

Childs Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first six months of the year a net loss of $22,470 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This contrasts with a net profit of $18,083, equivalent to 48 cents a share on 37,321 shares of $100 par, 7 per cent preferred stock in the first half of 1934.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Many parties were given today by the cottage colony. Mrs. Payne Whitney had as luncheon guests Mr. and Mrs. Fred Astaire, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Major Louis A. Beard and Arthur J. White.
Jimmy Save, the pantomimist, has accepted a long-term contract with the Hal Roach studios and will Journey to the West Coast late next month to begin work on his first production.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The second performance of the old-fashioned Georgia Minstrel and Revue, which is being given by members of the Westchester Country Club here and is under the direction of Ned Wayburn, attracted a large gathering this evening.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 21 shows the following changes in reiehsmarks:

A projected strike of white-collar and professional workers on relief projects if they receive a cut in pay under the regulations laid down by Congress would be too bad for the strikers, General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the Federal Works Progress Administration in New York, declared yesterday.

I have read with interest in THE TIMES about the joiner resolution introduced in Congress by Representative Dickstein of New York which would bar from the mails "any papers, pamphlets, books and writings of any kind which are designed, adapted or intended to cause racial or religious hatred, bigotry or intolerance."

Would it be ungrateful to raise the question, Why has the Long Island Railroad gone to the expense of erecting in the most congested area of its small and inadequate Manhattan station a crowd-gathering, news-flashing machine which projects upon a screen directly over the information booth items about such events as baseball games, crime, accidents and politics?

The Berlin bureau of The Associated Press yesterday transmitted to New York a denial by the German Propaganda Ministry of a Berlin Associated Press story of July 31 concerning police precautions against possible trouble there.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Frank B. Howe, director of the Federal Soil Conservation Service, stated today that machinery and equipment would be transferred to three TERA transient camps in the New York State flood area tomorrow with the aim of starting soil-erosion work by Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 2. -- Mayor J. Hampton Moore today indirectly accused the Federal Government of discrimination against Philadelphia in its allocation of Federal work relief funds and replied to what he termed "campaign misrepresentations" regarding the city's own attitude on relief.

The Columbia University Press, in recalling the experiences of the university in making the Columbia Encyclopedia, says that the life of an encyclopedia compiler is not devoid of humor. One writer, for example, was working on an article concerning a king of medieval times who ruled his land with the aid of a diet, or parliament.

Even the oversensitive Hitler Government must be satisfied with the answer of our State Department to its protest about the invasion of a German ship in this port by a gang of marauders. It was natural that this should have been resented in Germany, especially the disrespect shown by the mob for the German emblem.

SO Judge Fuchs goes back to the law. Too bad his Boston club wasn't in a contract bridge league. If that had been the case, the Judge would have had them right up there with E. Fuchs batting in the clean-up position. Baseball loses its wittiest magnate with the resignation of the Judge. A poor financier but a great fellow.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Denny Shute of Chicago and Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N.J., blazed through the soaking wet Inverness course today with a best ball of 62, nine under par, and forced Sam Parks, national open champion, and Ky Laffoon out of the lead in the round-robin match play tournament.

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan of the Bronx, President pro tem of the Senate, was the first legislative leader to reply to Governor Lehman's request for assurances that the next Legislature would pass an item in the budget for $3,000,000 for road construction.

Under orders sent out yesterday by Commodore John B. Shethar, arrangements were made for the American Yacht Club cruise, which will start from Rye, N.Y., on Aug. 11, and which, with three squadron runs, will take the fleet to the mouth of Long Island Sound, where the New York Yacht Club cruise then will get under way.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2. -- The Ox Ridge and Delhi quartets advanced into the final round of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today by downing the Houston riders and Long Island, respectively, in the semi-final round of the annual twelve-goal handicap event.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Scoring her third straight victory of the waning meeting, Chewawa, chestnut filly from the E.T. Burke Stable, triumphed today by three-quarters of a length in the Beaconsfield, the mile and a sixteenth feature of the program at Suffolk Downs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The House Rules Committee heard further testimony today that what Representative Patton of Texas received from a utility lobbyist was a box of cigars and nothing more.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A consent cease-and-desist order in the Federal Trade Commission's proceedings against manufacturers of rubber fire hose was announced today by the commission, closing a stormy chapter in the NRA history.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 2. -- Emergency precautionary measures to keep open the Addis Ababa Jibuti Railway line, this capital's only outlet to the world, were taken after two Italian subjects, natives of the Dodecanese Islands, were killed in an unexplained wreck.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The conquest of last year's winners, George T. Dunlap Jr. and E. Leonard Beard of Pomonok, was the high note during the first two rounds of the annual Winged Foot foursomes in memory of the late John G. Anderson on the east course today.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- Germany observed today the first anniversary of the death of President Paul von Hindenburg. The streets of Berlin and other cities were lined with half-staffed flags, draped with black crepe.

The continued improvement in steel scrap prices in the important centres is taken as an indication of a further improvement in steel operations in the near future. This week, quotations have been marked up from 50 cents to $1 a ton at several points, reflecting increased purchases by mill interests.

A ring of counterfeiters with headquarters near Kingston, N.Y., that specialized in printing and selling spurious one dollar bills at wholesale, was broken up yesterday by Federal Secret Service agents who made three arrests and seized plates, printing and photo-engraving equipment valued at thousands of dollars.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- The start of a campaign to restrict foreign correspondents, a new and wider definition of treason, and a statement from the Propaganda Ministry that it is "self-evident" that in Berlin and all Germany "there is complete order" marked the first anniversary today of Adolf Hitler's rise to supreme leadership after President Paul von Hindenburg's death.

GERONA, Spain, Aug. 2 (AP). -- A truck driver, who said he witnessed the accident that cost the life of Prince Alexis Mdivani, divorced husband of the former Barbara Hutton, said he was driving slowly along the Corsa-Figueras Road when the Prince's car flashed by at terrific speed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Education laws compelling school attendance to higher age levels have not only raised the general standards of literacy in the United States but have focused attention on deplorable environmental factors surrounding our youth, George H. Chatfield, director of the New York City Bureau of Attendance, declared here today.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Railway and Light Securities Company will be held in Boston on Aug. 20 at 10:30 A.M. to authorize not more than $4,000,000 of bonds, convertible into common stock, to be sold on terms the directors may determine.

The upward climb of stock prices in July lifted the total value of all equities listed on the New York Stock Exchange $2,686,022,655 to $38,913,092,273, according to a monthly tabulation released by the Exchange yesterday. Average price per share of all stocks on Aug. 1 was $29.76, compared with $27.78 at the beginning of July.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Sharp criticism of the administration at Washington for its handling of flood rehabilitation work in southern tier counties was made today by Representative Bert Lord, up-State New York Republican.

ROME, Aug. 2. -- The speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons yesterday served to distract Italian attention from Geneva today and focus it upon London, which is regarded here as the headquarters of all the efforts being made to thwart Premier Benito Mussolini's East African plans.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A 70-car coal train of the Port Reading Railroad struck an open switch here tonight at Rahway Avenue, overturning the engine and twelve cars and igniting an oil line which parallels the tracks. The engineer, two firemen and three hoboes leaped to safety.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The New Deal, in June, increased the number of government employes to the largest since the World War, according to the a report issued today by the Civil Service Commission. Most of the workers, the report said, were appointed without examination.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Maud Mason, 12-year-old resident of a Manchester slum, sat in the gallery of the House of Commons today and listened to members gravely discuss a jubilee school essay in which she had written:

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $39,654,550 in July, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The loan total at the end of the month was $768,934,748, compared with $808,589,298 at the close of June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Yankees bumped Irving (Bump) Hadley right out of the game at Griffith Stadium today in the opener of the series with the Senators, pounded Jack Russell for an additional flock of base hits and triumphed over the Griffmen when victory carried special significance.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The H.L. Herbert Cup for lightweight polo pony mounts, one of the most highly prized trophies in competition at the annual Monmouth County horse show, today was captured by the chestnut mare Maid of Ashalot, owned by J.B. Balding of Rumson.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Peace Chance and Red Rain will be severely tested in the two stake races on the first weekend of the Saratoga session tomorrow. The former is the Joseph E. Widener color-bearer which won the Belmont Stakes last year and is making a comeback.

BREMERHAVEN, Aug. 2. -- In a formal statement to the German official news agency, made on the arrival of the Bremen today, Commodore Ziegenbein flatly contradicted Berlin and Hamburg newspapers which had accused the New York police of failing to warn the ship's command that a Communist mob planned to attack the Bremen's flag and which also had accused the police of failing to take any protective measures.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Stocks on the London Stock Exchange continued cheerful today encouraged by favorable employment figures and by the success of the new 3 per cent Australian loan. Dealings in the Australian bonds started at a premium of 27s 7 d above the issue price and later the premium jumped to 32s 6d, when demand outran the supply.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- The Protestant clergy and laity organized in the confessional church to oppose Reich-bishop Ludwig Mueller's swastika policies discovered today that they are unquestionably included in the general purge of supposed opponents of the Hitler regime that is now going on throughout Germany.

The American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $5,911,340 for the twelve months ended on June 30, equal after full dividend requirements on 793,851 shares of $6 preferred stock to $1.17 a share earned on 978,444 shares of $5 preferred stock, comparing with $3,344,657, equal to $4.21 a share earned on 793,851 shares of $6 preferred stock, for the preceding year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Within the next few weeks, as Summer theatres, which operate for profit and the sale of new plays, are closing their doors for the season, Uncle Sam's new relief agencies in the five counties of the Ninth Judicial District will be starting a chain of community theatres.

Six artists on relief and assigned to the Park Department began work yesterday on a series of decorative murals on the walls of the Terrace Bridge arcade and restaurant just north of the Central Park Mall.

New bond financing in the New York market this week amounted to $49,825,000, an amount larger than last week and the same week last year. Of the total this week, $39,000,000 constituted new corporation issues, and the remainder new State and municipal bonds.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Constitutionality of the New York State Mortgage Commission was attacked on new grounds today in an action heard in Supreme Court here by Justice William F. Bleakley. The basic problem of constitutionality of the Mortgage Commission Act already is before the Court of Appeals on an appeal from a decision by Justice Bleakley in an action by Mrs. Anna Oberhammer in which he held the act constitutional.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 2. -- George E. Jeffers, 51 years old, of the town of Rowe, an unemployed laborer, was arrested this afternoon on a Federal warrant charging him with sending a threatening letter to President Roosevelt. He was seized in Rowe and brought here for arraignment tomorrow.

In a recent issue the Citizens Budget Committee voices complaint as to the salaries of certain civil employes as compared to the salaries of persons of similar rank in private employ. Unfair to all persons it discussed, the report was typical of that body.

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, Aug. 2. -- Three Catholic priests of Braunsberg, East Prussia, Fathers Hoppe and Schulz and Chaplain Sauermann were sentenced today to jail terms of four to eight months for slandering a police sergeant who was detailed to report a meeting of the local Catholic Labor Society.

The Park Department will begin Monday the "mining" of peat moss in its own private peat bog which was discovered on the fifty-acre Juniper Valley tract in Queens purchased last Spring from the estate of Arnold Rothstein, slain gambler.

With a roar which bystanders insisted sounded like that at Niagara Falls, a four-inch main carrying a full load of the New York Steam Company's live steam burst a few minutes after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and a column of the steam shot up 100 feet at the northwest corner of Rector and Washington Streets.
Excessive humidity oppressed the city's millions yesterday, spoiling what otherwise would have been a day of comfortable temperatures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Business activity in July was higher than a year ago, the Department of Commerce noted today in its weekly survey of the domestic trend. The relatively favorable tone of recent weeks was in contrast with the recession experienced about this time in 1934.

THE saga of the "Three Mesquiteers" has now attained to its fifth volume -- it may in time fill even a five-foot shelf if the industrious William Colt MacDonald keeps on turning out new chronicles as rapidly as he has produced the first five.

The political and monetary battle that lasted two weeks in the Netherlands has renewed interest here in Dutch affairs. Too much engaged in domestic entanglements to heed the situation in Holland, the average financial or business man has suddenly come to the realization that decisions in Amsterdam may have a far-reaching effect on the world monetary problem.

A WINDMILL-operated cradle set designed to function even without dry batteries, in regions where electric power is not available, has been developed by Eugene F. McDonald, president of Zenith Radio Corporation. He calls the new machine a "windmill radio," because a small windmill-driven electric generator keeps the set's storage batteries fully charged as long as there is a breeze to operate the device.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The recent riot on the Hapag-Lloyd liner Bremen in New York, during which a mob tore down the German swastika emblem and thereby caused an emphatic protest from the German Embassy to the State Department; has caused a general feeling of concern in the administration because of its broad implications.

A FIRST visit to Hollywood is dangerously narcotic and the journey back to reality cannot be accomplished in a single week. But when the reporter's reflexes are restored, and he begins to assemble his impressions of the city of the lotus eaters, there are high and important matters to be discussed with that air of sober authority which is the special gift of the visitor who has spent three weeks within the gates.
TOKYO, Aug. 3. -- "Dragged to it by the strong opinion of the army," as the newspaper Asahi puts it, the government issued today the following declaration on the Constitution:

The return of national speed boat racing to the waterways of New Jersey, on the North Shrewsbury, has resulted in a new enthusiasm among the yachtsmen at Red Bank over the sweepstakes regatta on Aug. 17 and 18. Between 35,000 and 50,000 spectators are expected for this event, which will attract the fastest single-motor craft of the country.

TOKYO. BECAUSE a French film, "La Bataille," is considered insulting to the imperial navy, Ambassador Naotake Sato has been instructed to communicate with the French Government, or alternatively, if he thinks better, with the producers of the film.

The Japanese Army has just completed a new "conquest" in Manchukuo -- this time not military but economic. After three years of free-for-all and often feverish Japanese trade promotions in the new State, it decided, in the words of Professor Kinzo Gorai of Waseda University, that "if this treasure-house is left open unconditionally, the vast resources acquired by bloodshed will be left to the depredations of rascals."

ADVERTISING has been subject to a considerable amount of criticism in recent years, from both within and without. The chorus of complaints from without has been increasing as intelligent leaders in the advertising world are well aware

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1. -- Eliminating himself voluntarily as a prospective candidate for Governor or any other office, Upton Sinclair has been succeeded in the practical political direction of left wing Democrats in California by State Senator Culbert L. Olson of Los Angeles.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 3. -- The second week of the Fifty-fifth Northfield General Conference of Christian Workers began today with the coming of Dr. T.Z. Koo of China, Dr. Adam Burner from Scotland, Dr. Albert Belden from London and Dr. Lynn Harold Hough from Drew Seminary. An international atmosphere is thus continued in Northfield as it was created under the leadership of Dwight L. Moody.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- President Roosevelt recently reverted to an old Presidential custom of picking non-career men for diplomatic posts when he named Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. of Pennsylvania to be Minister to Norway; Hugh Gladney Grant, former secretary to Senator Hugo Black of Alabama, to be Minister to Albania; Finley, Howard of Nebraska to be Minister to Paraguay, and Lester A. Walton, Negro journalist of New York, to be Minister to Liberia.

ELEVEN months of the year the tiny city of Salzburg thrives by attracting tourists interested in it as the birthplace of Mozart, or who are in search of mid-European "gemuetlichkeit" and the charm of peasant life. But during August Salzburg attracts other legions. Over night its narrow streets become filled with world celebrities.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is consternation among the writers. Those hardy perennials, the Westerns, are undergoing the first significant change in many years, and the authors, at least, fear the outcome. After having been constructed for years according to a rigid formula that has been eminently successful when adhered to without imagination or embellishment, now the word has gone forth that some of the producers of the horse operas want no more fights in saloons.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3. -- Intensive research to obtain further data on the cosmic ray will be undertaken this Summer by California Institute of Technology expeditions working in the Philippines, the Pacific Ocean, Texas and on Pikes Peak.

Net profit of $17,930,608 in the first half of this year was made by fifteen leading producers of steel, representing 58,714,700 tons of ingot capacity, or 86 per cent of the industry's total, according to the magazine Steel.

Several large issues of bonds of a diversified group of companies, called for redemption in future months before their maturity dates, featured announcements last week of new calls. Two large refundings, one for New York City and the other a public utility loan, in addition to several small amounts of municipal bonds, were added for August.
CALLANDER Ont., Aug. 3. -- Through their physician, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, the Dionne quintuplets today gave a message to the world. They said:

IN the courtyard of Dieppe's grand old thirteenth-century castle which looks down from the high cliff on the town and across the sea a monument has been erected to Jean Ribault, native of Dieppe, master mariner, explorer, Protestant, first to attempt to found a French colony in Florida.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3. -- A plentiful supply of salmon for the season was forecast when the North Wind of the Northland Transportation Company reached Seattle from Alaska. The vessel brought 100,000 cases, the largest single shipment to date.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Great Britain's determination to avert an Ethiopian war was clearly indicated by the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, Foreign Secretary, in Parliament on Thursday. Although addressing the House of Commons, the Foreign Secretary was definitely talking to Premier Mussolini when he said Great Britain was bound to carry out her obligations under the League of Nations.

CHATHAM, Mass., Aug. 3 (AP). -- A modern mural of Christ as a fisherman guest at a regular Wednesday night brown-bread and baked-bean supper of the First Congregational Church was unveiled in that edifice today.

IN point of passenger cars sold as compared with last year, the automobile industry has recorded nearly a 47 per cent increase for the initial half of this year. In figures, the improvement over the similar period of 1934 is shown as 1,461,940 units, against 995,555.

WARSAW, Aug. 3. -- Danzig's re fusal to withdraw the Senate's decree for the duty-free importation of foodstuffs and other products from East Prussia will be answered by Poland's retaliatory measures forthwith, it was announced here this afternoon.

COUNT ALBERT APPONYI'S popularity as Hungary's spokesman abroad, on the lecture platform and in the drawing room was due to many gifts. His interest in man, coupled with great charm, set both the exalted and the lowly at ease.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Harried national legislators took new courage this week with the prospect held out by their responsible leaders, of adjourning the present session of Congress by or soon after Aug. 20.
The House of Representatives, in which Democrats outnumber Republicans 322 to 102, visited a double defeat on the Democratic President last week under circumstances that were extraordinary.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1. -- Canada is hardening its heart toward the unemployed. Three Provincial governments have already cut able-bodied single men off the relief rolls, and Saskatchewan has applied the order also to heads of families. Others are preparing to follow, although in one of them, Quebec, nothing is likely to be done until the Provincial elections, due in a few months, are over.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 3. -- Charged with plotting the bombing on March 28 of the automobile of Judge W.A. Valentine during the insurgent strike at colleries of the Glen Alden Coal Company, Emerson P. Jennings, head of a printing concern in Wilkes-Barre and a civic leader, was ordered committed to Luzerne County jail by Judge John S. Fine late today in default of a bond of $15,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- A charge of murder will be filed against Mandeville W. Zenge, the young Missourian, held here in connection with the mutilation-slaying of Dr. Walter J. Bauer. This was decided today by Charles S. Daugherty, Assistant State's Attorney, after he had questioned the suspect for nearly thirty-six hours, an ordeal which left Zenge unmoved and his inquisitors on the verge of collapse.

Retail instalment sales are making steady gains in a wide variety of merchandise lines and all indications point to notably sharp increases for the Fall season. A.O. Dietz, president of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, said yesterday the outlook was excellent for credit sales of refrigerators, radios, washing machines and automobiles.

LONDON, July 13, 1935. THE international season was over and the Ballets Russes had taken possession of the Covent Garden Opera House for performances until the end of August. It was noon of a Saturday, when Londoners are presumed to be in the country for the week-end.

THE contradictions and sharp contrasts which distinguish, for the visitor, so much of Russian life are not lacking in the world of art under the Soviets. In the old established museums of Leningrad and Moscow there are startling innovations; in the circles of current creative activity, where radical changes might be most looked for, there may be utter conventionality.

The elimination of uncertainties surrounding the cotton textile industry and a renewed forward surge in buying are expected within the next ten days by both mill agents and buyers, it was indicated in the primary market yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Hundreds of visitors saw the first Saturday racing events at the clubhouse this afternoon.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Two boy pupils of the Nazareth Trade School of Farmingdale, who left the school without permission, were drowned here this afternoon in a water-filled sand pit of the Farmingdale Sand and Gravel Company.

THIS is the centennial year of Mark Twain's birth, and this little book, edited by his relative, Cyril Clemens, president of the International Mark Twain Society and author or editor of a number of volumes on Twain, gives it graceful recognition by making this collection of jokes, quips and anecdotes by or about him.
ROME, Aug. 2. -- The campaign that Italy is planning against Ethiopia differs from all previous colonial wars in that it will be fought by an army composed mostly of conscripts.

IN the memory of the reader this novel will readily -- perhaps too readily -- take an inconspicuous place with dozens of other books easily classified as American novels of the soil. "Seed of the Land" is a good story, sincere and well-written and, above all, interesting.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe added two games to his winning record today at the expense of the Indians. The Tigers took the first after twelve innings, 5 to 4, and the second, 7 to 3.

WITHIN recent months there have begun to appear on the walls of Federal buildings throughout the country murals that have social and artistic significance and represent a new phase in the relations of government and artist.

Of interest to Eastern sportsmen who annually journey to Canada for the wing shooting is the announcement from Fredericton that New Brunswick will have an open season on partridge this year, the dates being Oct. 1-15.
Occasionally the public gets a glimpse of the inner workings of practical politics; invariably, such glimpses are fascinating. There was one last week.

CHINA and Dalmatia are separated by the seven seas, but both are within the province of Ann Bridge -- who is a diplomat's wife and has been around. Diocletian's Palace and the ancient port of Ragusa are as familiar to her, apparently, as Peking, and she writes of them with an identical grace.

ART," Miss Cather has somewhere observed, "should simplify." It is a principle to which she has faithfully adhered, and in its practice she has grown increasingly adept. The principle is sound but hazardous. As applied to the novel, the point to which it can be carried without sacrifice of body is especially difficult to fix.

THE medal recently bestowed upon Miss Mabel Kittredge by Columbia University reminds us that she is responsible for a movement for social betterment that has spread to all large cities of the United States. In 1901 she started the Association of Housekeeping Centres, collecting the money to finance them and carrying them on practically alone -- most of the time with no secretarial assistance.

GENEVA, Aug. 3. -- In a public session of less than an hour duration this evening, the Council of the League of Nations set aside Ethiopia's plea for immediate consideration of the strained relations with Italy which threaten her existence.

A heavy increase in advance buying for Fall, prompted by the possibility of a scarcity in some lines and greatly delayed deliveries in others, was foreseen by leading retail executives here yesterday as country-wide retail sales continued to reveal gains far beyond expectations.

PALAMOS, Spain, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The body of Alexis Mdivani, youngest of the "marrying Princes" of ancient Georgia, was placed today in a placid little cemetery, a setting far from the glittering scenes in which he spent his life.

ADDIS ABABA, July 19 (By Wireless from London.) -- It is close to forty years since General Baratieri was defeated at Adowa, and Italy has never forgotten the disgrace. That, at least, was the view expressed by Emperor Haile Selassie at the extraordinary session of the Ethiopian Parliament on July 18.

RARE indeed will be the treat proffered to flower fanciers when the annual show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society opens next Friday afternoon for a three-day run at Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. In one of the most comprehensive exhibits devoted solely to one kind of flower ever held in New York there will be opportunity to view the beauties of the many new and interesting types of gladiolus.

Matthew Woll, acting president of the National Civic Federation, urged yesterday that a strong protest be made to the Soviet Government against "the persistent interference" of Moscow and the Communist International in the internal affairs of the United States, newly evidenced by the activities of the World Congress of the Third International.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- President Roosevelt's official contribution to the Geneva negotiations over the Italo-Ethiopian conflict is viewed in German official quarters as an extraordinary step and its real significance, it is pointed out, must be sought in the circumstance that only on rare occasions is the official voice of the United States made audible to the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A Presidential stamp collection will go on public display tomorrow in connection with a coming convention of the American Philatelic Society.

Champlain, paddled by his Indians in birch bark canoes, came from Montreal to the water that bears his name in 1609 and so discovered it, but Lake Champlain still remains to be discovered by the American fresh-water sailor, either by motor boat or small sailing craft.

CAMDEN, S.C., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Eight persons were killed and a ninth was believed dying of injuries today when a farmer's truck ran into a Seaboard Air Line train at a crossing near here and hurled some of its occupants beneath the train wheels.

Seventy-five Brooklyn youngsters, still in their teens, are so eager to learn about yachting and the principles and practice of handling large as well as small boats that they are paying ten cents a month for the fun of trying out the experiment of organizing and operating a new seafaring group.

The cooperation of householders in the Bronx in the control and eradication of mosquitos was asked yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice. He also outlined the work done by his department to that end during the first six months of 1935.

LENZBURG, Switzerland, July 25 (by Mail). -- Life will be injected anew into the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition by the middle of August, when preparations will be completed for my third attempt to cross Antarctica by air.
SUNDERLAND, England, Aug. 3 (AP). -- A man who said he believed he was an American was found wandering in a public park here today, his memory apparently lost.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The "Revenue Bill of 1935" was reported out last Tuesday by the House Ways and Means Committee. Compiled under pressure of haste, sharply criticized in a written report by a minority of the committee, the bill is designed to add annually $270,000,000 to revenue receipts under existing laws.

Launched in the House of Representatives as a routine measure which attracted little attention at the time, the McCormack bill, amending Section 516B of the Tariff Act, yesterday had become the storm centre of a battle between importers and domestic interests which will rival the contest preceding enactment of the reciprocal trade treaty measures of the administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Sales to collectors of special issue imperforate and ungummed postage stamps netted the government $1,663,717.66 between March 15 and June 15, according to final figures made public today at the Postoffice Department.

THE Kansas City Art Institute, in the 1935-36 prospectus at hand, expresses great satisfaction over Thomas Benton's having joined the faculty and welcomes his aid "in developing the kind of education that will prepare the young men and women of the region to live and work successfully, whether in the fine arts or the industrial or commercial arts."

Many people seem to be laboring under the misapprehension that the Constitution of the United States was finished in 1789. The fact of the matter is, of course, that the Constitution drawn and adopted at that time is replete with general and undefined terms.

OUTDOOR classes for children in poor health and home education for youngsters bound to their residences by physical handicaps have proved their value in the city's school program, says the recent annual report of the division of handicapped children to the Board of Education.

The straightening of the bend of the Harlem River Ship Canal at Spuyten Duyvil by the Federal Government is expected to begin the latter part of this month, thus reviving a project long deferred. Several minor contracts have been let and bids have been received by the United States Army engineers on other operations.

OMAHA, Aug. 1. -- Within a week the Farm Credit Administration in the Omaha Land Bank District expects to begin making loans on small grains sealed in farm bins. While these loans will not begin to approach in volume those of the 1933 corn loan, it is expected that they will offer a greatly desired accommodation, and that many farmers will avail themselves of the opportunity they offer.

Boston's outboard and inboard races on the Charles River basin next Saturday and Sunday are expected to attract the largest entry list in the East, according to Commodore Stanley W. Ferguson, who cooperated last month with the intercollegiate group in the races at Worcester.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The third-place Cardinals, back at home after a disastrous road tour, opened a three-game stand with Pittsburgh today by shutting out the Pirates, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Unchanged except for a single amendment, offered by friends, the $270,000,000 tax bill evolved by the Ways and Means Committee completed its trip through the House today, save for the formalities of the final vote which, by agreement, will be taken Monday.

A DECADE ago gladiolus enthusiasts were quite sure that the development of this handsome flower had progressed to the point where there was really little left to do, but the improvements of the last ten years have proved them wrong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A project described as the most elaborate State art program ever financed by a government will be undertaken with work relief millions under budgets for the drama, art, music, and writers' programs, now awaiting President Roosevelt's signature.

BERLIN. THE memoirs of Count Harry Kessler carry two subtitles: "Gesichter und Zeiten -- Volker und Vaterlander" (S. Fischer Verlag, Berlin). Count Kessler is one of the few great aristocrats of Germany -- or, for that matter, of any country -- who have occupied themselves intensively with art, who have been not merely art lovers but art connoisseurs in the finest sense of the word, endowed with a sureness of taste that transcends the personal.

Having obtained a substantial increase in one of the poorest months of the year, merchants are looking toward the Fall with renewed confidence, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Retailers, the buying office notes, have increased their six months' goal figures and, therefore, budgets in many instances have been increased proportionately.

A contract bridge foursome of Harold S. Vanderbilt, B. Jay Becket of Philadelphia, Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine will compete for the knockout team of four championship during the week of Summer championship play sponsored by the American Bridge League at the Convention Hall at Asbury Park, N.J., beginning tomorrow afternoon.

SHORT WAVES had their ups and downs during the past week. The strength of programs from the Daventry or "G" stations and those at Berlin, the "D" transmitters, is usually a good barometer of general short-wave conditions. Last week was notable because on several occasions the "D" and "G" stations Were almost inaudible, whereas on other days the strength and clarity passed the most sanguine expectations.

For the next four weeks frontline dispatches on the progress of the war against New York County racketeers are likely to be increasingly meager. The extraordinary grand jury which was sworn in last Monday to hear racket evidence now subsides into the background, adjourned until September.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The week's outstanding event in the Berkshires is to be the second annual Berkshire symphonic festival at the Dan R. Hanna Farm, with concerts Thursday night, Saturday afternoon and Sunday night by an orchestra of eighty-five pieces, Dr. Henry Hadley conducting.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Two small boys, members of a group of five who left a recreational camp in dissatisfaction early last Wednesday, were found dead near Cave Creek Dam today, victims of thirst, hunger and exhaustion.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Wholesale dry goods trade with the larger houses in July was about 7 per cent over 1934 and that for retail department stores around 9 per cent. Retail sales in the week just ended were ahead of 1934, although hampered by excessively hot weather.

ROME, Aug. 3. -- The Geneva resolutions were received in Rome without any particular enthusiasm. They are regarded not as the Italian victory the people here had been led to expect but rather as an adequate compromise in which Italy yielded some points in order to gain some others.
A NOTABLE: Shirley Temple, 6-year-old movie actress, arrived in Nonolulu last week on her vacation. Details:

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- For the influx of August visitors, resorts in the White Mountains are planning a round of social and sporting diversions. Today at the White Mountain Polo Ranch a match will be played between a visiting team and the local team, consisting of Lyle C. Phillips, Jasper Blandin, James Copley Robert and Teddy Poor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- A baby cried for milk its jobless father could not give it.

THE important and ever-popular barberry family adds a new variety this year in Berberis mentorensis. It is seldom that a really new hedge plant comes into existence, and while this is easily recognized as being a barberry it has many characteristics that differentiate it from the others in appearance and habit of growth.

SMOOTH writing, feverish pace, the luster of modernity, bright humor and an original turn of phrasing make Agnes Burke Hale's new book a thoroughly readable one. Its heroine, Vincent Hartell, is a sort of Doris Duke and Barbara Hutton rolled into one.

" Rookies" with college education are about to become more numerous in the New York Police Department, according to an analysis by the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the educational background of the 5,504 candidates who passed the last examination for patrolmen.
THE last sentence of this book evaluating Paul Elmer More's work in criticism states fairly well Mr. Shafer's attitude:

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 3. -- Lawrence Hanover Doc Parshall's speedy Hambletonian nominee, stepped up to win the American Stake for 3-year-old trotters today when Rockingham Park threw open its gates for a week of Grand Circuit racing.

A new nautical organization made its bow last week with the formation of the Beachwood Yacht and Country Club in Whitestone, and, judging from the present set-up of the outfit, Long Island Sound will have another enterprising unit close to the metropolitan area.

AT first the visitor has the impression that he is entering some sort of German Boy Scout encampment. Then he finds that the fire is no ordinary bonfire but a great pile of logs sending high into the night sky a wavering tongue of flame.

HALLE SELASSIE has informed the world that his empire is officially named, not Abyssinia, but Ethiopia. Yet the King of Kings and Lion of Judah would regard as lese-majeste any suggestion that he is by that same token a Negro. Anthropologists would agree with his racial estimate of himself, so far as "race" has any meaning.

PHLOX Columbia is the 1935 addition to the hardy phlox, among the most popular of all perennials. Few gardens are without this old-fashioned flower and its delicate fragrance. New varieties have strengthened interest in it periodically; Columbia now bids for a leading place among the more sought-after varieties.

OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 3. -- Because Professor Albert Einstein believed that the tide ran only relatively over the sand bars, which at low tide block the route from his home dock southward to the two bridges toward Long Island Sound, his sailboat ran aground recently and left the scientist stranded, it was learned today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The veteran George J. Voigt, former Walker Cup star, continued along the come-back trail today when he and his partner, Arthur Lynch, gained the final round in the Winged Foot Golf Club foursomes for the John G. Anderson Memorial Trophy.
Recent decisions on New Deal legislation by various Federal courts have aroused lay inquiry as to the relative places of such courts in the assertion of the judicial power of the national government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Senate Interstate Commerce Committee investigators disclosed today that they were "laying the groundwork" for public hearings in a wide inquiry into railroad financing by culling records of the New York banking house of Kuhn, Loeb Co.

AVOIDED for several years by well-informed transcontinental tourists and scorned by automobile club touring bureaus because of its antiquated surface and winding path, the famous National Highway, U.S. Route 40, which cuts across the southwest corner of Pennsylvania and the West Virginia panhandle, is staging a remarkable comeback.

HERE it is August. A bright new season is a month away, and the theatre is still groping for the corner that will take it from the heat waves and disasters of Summer. On paper, it would seem to be a pretty fair prospect, although at this time of year you can't tell what November will drop into the letter box.

FEW sports are more highly esteemed by their votaries on this littoral than the hunt for the sub rosa or the "sneak" preview. Ordinary previews are not to be mentioned in the same breath with it. These are on the theatre program, anyway; they come under the head of lagniappe, a quaint Hollywood custom, and every one is bidden to them, with free tickets for the elect.

EASTON, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP). -- A despondent mother took two children to death with her today, although she left more than $5,000 to provide for their future. The police said the woman, Mrs. Martha McKinley, a widow of 40, evidently collapsed as she fought through gas-filled rooms to the second floor where her sons, Austin, 12, and John, 14, slept.

BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- The newly organized Minute Women of 1936 are emulating the conduct of the Minute Men of 1776. They have assembled in that historic relic of Revolutionary times, the Old South Meeting House, to hear a repetition of the bitter protest of "taxation without representation" by a modern impersonator of Josiah Quincy.

THIS little book is intended to be in the nature of supplementary aid for persons who, although they may have had high school and even college education, did not learn during those years, or, at least, did not learn to apply the rules of good English speech, and who, therefore, in all their conversation permit telltale lapses from good usage to advertise their ignorance of cultivated English.

Underwriting and distributing houses and their attorneys are awaiting with interest the text of the address Judge John J. Burns, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, delivered on Thursday evening before the National Security Traders Association in Cincinnati.

TEN "ghost cars," fast, new emergency vehicles, are speeding over the highways of Nassau County as units of the intensified campaign now being waged by the county Police Department to reduce the hazards of automobile accidents. Since Jan. 1 more than 3,000 accidents have occurred in the county, from which more than 1,300 injuries and nearly 50 deaths have resulted.

NEW LONDON, N.H. -- Boat races and tennis matches are keeping busy those members of the Lake Sunapee colony who are rehearsing under Ned Wayburn for the "Show Boat Review of 1935." A chorus of fifty or sixty is put through the paces for the performances on Aug. 15, 16, 17.

VIENNA, Aug. 3. -- This week, the first of the Salzburg festival, practically coincides with several notable first anniversaries -- the assassination of Chancellor Dollfuss, the beginning of the Schuschnigg era and the execution of the Dollfuss assassin, Otto Planetta, a Nazi.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- From practically every one of the twenty-five States represented at the annual Fall session of the Interstate Merchants Council comes the same word -- "the farmer is buying again." The attendance at the council approximates 10,000 buyers, exceeding by 15 per cent that which marked the session of last year, when the world's fair was an added attraction.

Another era in the history of that peculiarly American institution, the bathtub, was reached a few days since when East Side tenants made formal demands for the installation of that former luxury.

NINETY years ago Americans found themselves agitated about a little known land on the Pacific Coast. That land was Oregon, to which the United States seemingly had some sort of title -- up to the forty-ninth parallel at least, and further if those who shouted "Fifty-four forty or fight!" had their way.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Aug. 1. -- The Eastern wing of the Republican party, through attacks on the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, is widening the split between Republicans of the agrarian West and those of the industrial East.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The annual children's sand modeling contest at Bailey's Beach will take place on Saturday, Aug. 24. Announcement was made today that the contest would be conducted along lines similar to past years. Beverley Bogert, one of the governors of the beach, will be manager.

ITALY of the Renaissance and modern times is, for the moment, conspicuous in the millinery picture. Out of the heavily gilded frames of the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth century portraits have stepped hats of all kinds and descriptions to grace the heads of women whose aims and ambitions would be highly bewildering to their original wearers, could they hear of them.

Strong protest was lodged yesterday by the drug and chemical section of the New York Board of Trade against a new ruling of the Department of Internal Revenue, which holds that vanity compacts, previously exempt, are now taxable, in addition to the cosmetics which they contain.

SCOTLAND relives the days of Bruce, Rob Roy and Bonnie Prince Charlie during this month and September, when its clansmen, in kilts, their bagpipes over their shoulders, hold their Highland gatherings and games.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 3. -- Clayton F. Smith, president of the Cook County Board, vetoed today the $48,000,000 bond refunding plan which had been adopted earlier last week by the board. Mr. Smith told _the commissioners the program did not promise to effect the interest savings sought by the county and would probably pave the way for further defaults.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- When the League of Nations Council opened its meeting on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute on Wednesday it was fully recognized here that the chief hope for avoiding a dangerous international explosion rested upon the shoulders of one man, Premier Pierre Laval.

From Moscow last week the United States learned interesting details about the strength and activities of this country's Communist party. The information did not come from the Soviet Government; it came from speeches made at the seventh congress of the Third or Communist International.

Were any of us capable and consummate enough in the art of selection to write each his individual adventure, how from a small helpless human animal he became a civilized adult, it would be a great and enthralling story.

Confident of an exceptionally good business this Fall, all branches of the floor-coverings industry are looking forward to tomorrow's formal opening of rug lines with greater optimism than has been displayed at any similar event in more than six years.

August brings renewed activity to American kennel affairs. Following the long midsummer vacation fanciers are keen for the competitions ahead and their charges should be the better after the good rest.
BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- The Jessie Woodrow Sayre Women's Democratic League, formed three weeks ago, has filed an application for a charter with the Secretary of State.

MISS HELEN HAYES, one of the foremost ladies of the theatre, whose microphone appearances in the past have been altogether too infrequent, will become a regular broadcaster this Fall, appearing in an original radio serial.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Ethiopia accepted today the League of Nations' formula to settle her quarrel with Italy. After hours of study Emperor Haile Selassie late this afternoon made this brief announcement:

TO his enemies President Roosevelt is a dangerous egocentric, a man of intermittent resolution and vacillation, an irresponsible comet against. our troubled national skies, He is swayed, according to this analysis, by the last man with whom he confers before the time arrives for a public decision.

Not a single Canadian Province now has a Conservative Government. In Prince Edward Island, the last to fall, not one Conservative was chosen to the Legislative Assembly. What is a Legislature without an Opposition ? One would think that the Liberals had nothing to do but to wait patiently for the Federal general elections.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The French press tonight treats the decisions reached at Geneva in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute as a personal victory for Premier Pierre Laval and as the best compromise that could have been expected under the circumstances.

Less than a fortnight before his fifteenth birthday, Harold Pfleger returned to his home yesterday after a grim siege, during which he received eighty-five blood transfusions and was operated on six times.

WHAT is the significance of the statement recently made that among the current crop of criminals arrested 19-year-old boys formed the largest age group? Is there an implication contained in these figures that this is a new phenomenon or that somehow it is a result of a too lenient attitude toward the youth of the present generation?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Refreshed from a vacation of three weeks in Hot Springs, Va., Secretary Hull returned to the State Department today determined to press forward with his reciprocal trade agreements program and more than ever convinced of its soundness.

From the moment this great little man appears on the platform, walking quickly, baton in hand, you feel that he is there purely for business. He bows graciously but inspires you with the idea that he does not want, or care for, the fuss which the public is obviously out to make of him.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 3. -- The wave of infantile paralysis cases in Virginia advanced today into the central part of the State, where eleven of thirteen new cases were reported. The thirteen cases today brought the total for three days to forty, and the aggregate since June 1 to 286.

WITH home furnishings and fur sales doing exceptionally well, August retail promotional events both here and in other cities throughout the country got off to an excellent start last week. Many merchants have been surprised by the strength of consumer demand, which substantially exceeded expectations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- Nominating papers were taken out today in behalf of Mrs. Bessie Dobson Altemus Eastman, chairman of the Republican women of Philadelphia County, as a Republican candidate for Recorder of Deeds. Mrs. Eastman is the widow of Major Nedom A. Eastman of the Marine Corps and the mother of Mrs. John Hay Whitney.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 2. -- A story of the successful rejuvenation of one of the old-time gold mines of Northwestern Ontario, bringing it to a point where a proiftable career appears certain, was revealed in the annual report of the Duport Mining Company, Ltd., operating the former Cameron Island mine in the Lake of the Woods area, as given at the annual meeting of shareholders in Port Arthur by Julian G. Cross, president.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Sun-tanned Frank X. Shields, back from Hollywood and the start of a career in motion pictures, made his tennis debut of the season in the Eastern grass court championship tournament at the Westchester Country Club today.

The most difficult problem that confronts Inspector Lecain of the Judiciary Police in this story of murder in Paris is the identity of the murdered man. When the body is found, Lecain recognizes it as that of Jean Holbein, a member of the Chamber of Deputies.

GLOUCESTER, Mass. -- Although the Summer folk will centre their attention on Marblehead during the coming week because of the midsummer yacht racing, the main event for the North Shore and surrounding resorts, many other affairs are scheduled for the Cape Ann sector in the same period.

With interest centred in the market for junior equities, trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was quiet and without any feature in yesterday's short session. The undertone was steady, with prices holding within a narrow range. A few of the second-grade and more speculative issues, taking their cue from the activity-and strength in the stock market, showed some life, but the main body of investment bonds recorded only minor fluctuations.

YREKA, Calif., Aug. 3. -- A mob of twenty-five to fifty masked men dragged C.L. Johnson, 24, from the county jail here early today and lynched him for the slaying of Chief of Police F.R. Dew of Dunsmuir.

SAN SALVADOR, July 31 (By Mail). -- An interesting experiment in civilization and education is being carried out at the agricultural school in Sonsonate with a boy Tarzan, who, when captured in the jungle, was without any language, although between seven and eight years old, and was human only in form.

ROME, Aug. 3. -- The newspaper Giornale d'Italia today printed a dispatch from Jibuti, French Somaliland, accusing Ethiopians of attacking three French Catholic missions in Ethiopia and sacking one of them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Renewing its war against foreign lottery operators, the Postoffice Department has recently issued fraud orders against 450 residents of foreign countries, the longest individual list ever issued by the department. Notwithstanding the close watch maintained at the border by customs officers and the vigilance of postoffice investigators, foreign lottery tickets find a wide sale in the United States.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 2. -- With the lumber strike finally settled in Oregon, the State is looking forward to substantial increases in construction activity for the late Summer and Fall months in both rural and urban districts.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Two members' games today filled in the afternoon between the semi-finals and tomorrow's final-round match of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at Meadow Brook.

TEXAS is giving a detachment of wanderers, known as "transients," a chance to earn an education. They range in age from 16 to 54 and in schooling from sixth grade to graduate-student status with degrees. It is an experiment which Texas thinks may develop a means of reducing the number of transients who are aimlessly roving by hitchhiking and by freight trains.
IN this book William Rose Benet has collected all of his poems which he would most like to see preserved, and to them has added something over a dozen pieces not before brought together in book form.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered at one time yesterday on reports that raw cotton had been removed from the proposed list for export subsidies, but favorable crop advices left quotations with a loss of 5 to a gain of 3 points on the day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 3. -- The smallest boy became the biggest man of the tourney today when 18-year-old Frankie Strafaci, Brooklyn high school student, stepped up before cheering thousands and was crowned champion of the public links golf players of the United States.

The zero hour for the American elm is at hand. Handicapped by delays, inadequate funds and restrictions which forbid the employment of trained scouts and tree climbers, the men in direct charge of the disease eradication work have struggled for the past month against almost insuperable obstacles.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Preparations reminiscent of wartime today occupied this military reservation, scene of the massing of regular army and National Guard troops for big army manoeuvres the last two weeks of this month.

IT is the thesis of this charmingly written book that with the passing of the idea of being a gentleman purely for the sake of being a gentleman something worth while has been lost to civilization. Neither democracies nor dictatorships are friendly to the gentleman.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The Summer seminar in Arabic and Islamic studies, the first of its kind ever held, which had been in progress at Princeton University for six weeks under the auspices of the American Council of Learned Societies, closed last week.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Championships and sweepstake competitions held the attention of a record attendance at the final session of the annual Monmouth County Horse Show, which came to a Close this evening on the new grounds at the Thornton Farm.

HIKERS who are spending their holidays trudging the roads and beauty spots of Europe this Summer are sleeping at specially provided shelters known as youth hostels at a cost of approximately 25 cents night.

Prince Abdul Kerim, who in early childhood lived amid the bizarre splendors of a royal court until his grandfather, Sultan Abdul Hamid II of Turkey, was deposed, shot and killed himself in a $3 room in the Hotel Cadillac, Forty-third Street and Broadway, early yesterday. He was 31 years old.

The appointment of E. Philip Rees to the newly created post of general manager of Furness, Withy Co., steamship operators, was announced yesterday. Mr. Rees has been with the company twenty years and for the last seven months has been assistant director of its American offices.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 3. -- All records were surpassed as the Eastern Yacht Club started a fleet of 378 yachts to open Marblehead's forty-third annual midsummer race week today.
