This number of starters in a single race eclipsed the Marblehead record of 209, the Eastern Yacht Club's record of 300 and the opening day record of 291, as well as the world's mark.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Hamtramck housewives, whose meat strike has progressed from hairpulling to jail-storming and forced more than half the butcher shops in that and other suburban centres to close, announced today that the movement is only the start of a "general strike against the high cost of living."

SKYTOP, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Ramoan Certainty, a Scottish terrier of the Brew Bricht Kennels, owned by Don Voorhees of Jericho, L.I., won first honors among 590 dogs in the tenth annual Lackawanna Kennel Club show today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3. -- Pennsylvania and Illinois entries carried off the major share of prizes in the abbreviated first day's program of the second annual Gold Cup Regatta before 20,000 persons on the Allegheny River at Oakmont today.

Patrons of the motion picture, no doubt, have already noticed a recent news item published in THE NEW YORK TIMES to the effect that the Turkish Government, through her Ambassador in Washington, contemplates censoring the pending film production of Franz Werfel's "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh."

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler signed an order yesterday requiring a detailed accounting of the $27,910,000 Series F-1 defaulted mortgage certificates sold by the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company following a depository agreement made with the American Trust Company on Feb. 21, 1927.

LONDON. -- While hope of a political solution of the difficulties between Italy and Ethiopia may not yet have been wholly abandoned, it is wise to give serious consideration to the military problem. To do so might be an aid to enlightenment in more than a military sense; for it is true to say, "If you wish for peace, understand war."

After two months of operations without the benefit of the NRA Petroleum Code, leading executives of the oil industry generally consider the outlook good. Gasoline prices are higher than when the NRA codes were invalidated by the Supreme Court at the end of May and, with the exception of some minor adjustments in one or two small producing areas, crude oil prices are unchanged.

The chief business of the House of Representatives last week was the President's tax-on-wealth program, which was set forth in a bill that contained a couple of ideas he hadn't thought of but still was a recognizable rendition of the suggestions he made to Congress in his June 19 message.

OLD timers must have a warm spot in their hearts for Schumann's piano quintet -- E flat, Opus 44. The various recordings of it can be used to measure the immense mechanical progress made during the last decade.

TORONTO, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Bermuda cricketers today lost the second match of their trip, bowing to the Toronto Cricket Club by seven wickets. Yesterday the visiting players were beaten by Ridley College at St. Catharines.

GENERALLY after a foreign radio official has been in New York for a day or two he is asked what he thinks of American broadcasting. That question was put to a veteran wireless man a few days ago, namely, Ernest Thomas Fisk, general manager of the Amalgamated Wireless Australasia, Ltd.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 3 (AP). -- In new and vigorous protect against the church situation in Germany, the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano accused the Nazi government today of "continued hostile spying" upon Catholic priests.

ALTHOUGH it is yet well on the vacation side of Labor Day, next season's announcements have already begun to accumulate in sufficient quantities to indicate that there is not going to be much chance for the dance audience to relax when activities once get under way.

Entry blanks have been sent out for the forty-fourth annual Middle States regatta to be held this season under the auspices of the Virginia Boat Club of Richmond, Va. The regatta will be staged as usual under the rules of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 3. -- Diversified sports events were on the day's program at White Mountain resorts, where a record number arrived on the New York express to spend August.

ONE windy night the chimney of a public bath-house in Hakodate was blown down and before morning a city of 200,000 inhabitants had been burned to ashes. In the great earthquake of 1923 fires broke out at 130 places in Tokyo, and the greater part of the capital became a blackened plain in which one could not even tell where the streets had run.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- More than 200 members and their guests attended a New England shore dinner served tonight on the golf course of the Wykagyl Country Club here. Dancing in the clubhouse followed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Factional feeling flamed out in arrests, embittered charges and hurried court hearings in Kentucky's primary election today. National Guard guns covered Harlan County.

NEW HAMPSHIRE'S Old Man of the Mountain rests the gaze of his great stone face on the hills, valleys, lakes and forests of his Granite State and sees more Summer people motoring, climbing, fishing, sailing, motor boating, canoeing, golfing and just loafing than in any other recent season.
Henry Hadley will conduct the three concerts of the second Berkshire Symphonic Festival, opening on Thursday at the Hanna Farm, near Stockbridge, Mass. An orchestra of eighty-five will participate.

WHILE there are many climbing plants with which to drape a trellis, porch, a stone wall or an old tree stump, or hide the bareness of a new house, none is more beautiful than the clematis -- and none is more rarely used.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Continued blows to form were administered before 15,000 persons today as the sensational Red Rain bowed to Postage Due in the United States Hotel Stakes and the favored Top Row brought up nine lengths back of Vicar in the historic Saratoga Handicap.

APE: Jane Penseroso, 7 years old, is a gorilla, resident in New York's Bronx Zoo. Like most caged anthropoids, she enjoys mimicking the humans who stare at her. Last week she watched with great interest as Michael Petrachione, one of the starers, lighted a cigar and puffed lustily.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1. -- Once again Maryland is pleased to have a Governor whom the nation's press is referring to as "Presidential timber." Twelve, eight and four years ago her knight-errant was unsuccessful but popular former Governor Albert C. Ritchie.

Much significance is seen in the action of the House of Representatives on Thursday and in several decisions reached by committees of both House and Senate. Most of the comment is political. Because the expressed desires of the Administration were overridden by Congress, and because the special appeals made by spokesmen for the President failed, it is argued that Mr. ROOSEVELT has been severely rebuffed and politically weakened.

FORT HANCOCK, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- After only three days of camp life, the 910 youths of the Citizens Military Training Camp Battalion here held a formal review and inspection this morning before a group of regular and reserve officers. When it was over they received high praise, and the company, composed mostly of New York City boys, narrowly won high prize for the day.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Cunard White Star liner Georgic arrived last night from England with a group of members of the British Medical Association bound for Melbourne, Australia, to attend the annual meeting of the organization there on Sept. 9. There are 112 in the party, including 30 wives and daughters of the physicians.

With the passing of the St. Paul's Cathedral Preservation Bill the doom of the familiar prophecy of MACAULAY, which pictured the New Zealander in the midst of a vast solitude taking his stand on a broken arch of London Bridge to sketch the ruins of St. Paul's, has been indefinitely postponed.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Hollyrood Perry, bay trotter owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of Newark, and Ironbound, a pacer from the stable of William Parkburst of Maplewood, captured the feature events of the weekly matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey today.

A dozen persons in a confectionery store at Decatur Avenue and Fordham Road, the Bronx, escaped injury about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a motor truck, out of control, crashed into the front of the store.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 3. -- Europe's second highest highway, the Gross Glockner Road, was thrown open to traffic today. Inhabitants of near-by mountain villages in their picturesque garb lined the road and enthusiastically cheered a long column of automobiles headed by President Wilhelm Miklas's.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Faybyan of Boston and Mrs. Ethel Burkhardt Arnold of California reached the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today and will meet for the Woodin Cup tomorrow at 3 o'clock.

THE theory is bruited about that Clarence Day's fiery and astounding Father will one day be regarded as a classic. Nonsense. He already is one. He has been for several years -- ever since magazines began to justify their existence by publishing some of the sketches in this book.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3. -- Walter Johnson, the Big Train of the major leagues, will learn tomorrow whether his career as manager of the Cleveland Indians has run its course.

THE name of John Buchan, who was recently appointed Governor General of Canada, is likely to arouse an automatic response in any one who reads or hears it. At the age of 60 he has something like forty books to his credit, and whether they be economic treatises, biographies, or novels, it is difficult to think of one that is less than quite-definitely good of its kind.
The spirit of depression which fastened itself upon the Braves many weeks ago became sort of contagious at the Polo Grounds yesterday when it seemed also to have enveloped the Giants.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Polo continues to be a leading interest of the colony here. Jay Kitchen Secor, captain of the 1935 Yale intercollegiate championship polo team, who has been playing for the Greenbrier Polo Club since the close of college, is just making his final appearance with the Greenbrier team.

A DINING ROOM, used only for an hour or two at a time, may be more vivid and individual in its decoration than a living room or library and so present a colorful background for diners. Perhaps this fact explains in part the revival of scenic wallpaper and the increasing vogue for hand-painted and photographic murals.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Foreign correspondents were placed in the same category with "State enemies" by Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, in a speech at Essen tonight. The speech was a warning delivered against every one deemed anti-Nazi.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The White Sox and Browns struggled for 2 hours 22 minutes today, with the second game of the series being called at the end of the tenth inning because of rain and darkness with the score tied at 7-all.

The search for 21-year-old Anne Sibley, a student at Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, and daughter of a Chicago lawyer, ended yesterday afternoon in a Coney Island sideshow, where she has been employed for several weeks as a "ballyhoo girl."

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- Enzel is introducing numerous new notes in Fall footwear. Sports oxfords, named Garmisch, after the 1936 Olympic games, are featured. These are adapted from Bavarian peasants' shoes.

After wallowing about at sea all night with a disabled engine, the skippers of motor boats ought to realize that the mechanical world is capricious. Some gas engines are, to put it kindly, temperamental. It is the theory of mechanical manuals that a machine in perfect condition will operate perfectly.

ONE begins this book with the natural assumption that its author and her artist husband, Charles and Cilette Ofaire, are French. But one does not read many pages until one knows they are not French and is puzzled by the question of their nationality.

PLACED end to end the roads and streets built with Federal public works highway funds in the two years ended last June 30 would just about encircle the earth at the equator. The exact mileage completed under the joint supervision of the Bureau of Public Roads and the forty-eight State highway departments was 24,600 miles.

BASED on the conviction that the story of California falls naturally into several distinct periods that evolve from one to another, with the thread of each continuing importantly in the fabric of the whole, Mr. Hanna's handbook of California's historical dates divides the four centuries which it covers into seven parts, each dealing with an epoch.

DALLAS, Aug. 3. -- While it is generally admitted that the Summer slump is here, most businesses in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District have been able to show gains over corresponding periods of last year, and some have felt little effect of the seasonal decline.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Midsummer finds social activities in full swing in the North Jersey resorts along the Attic from Bay Head to Atlantic Highlands. One of the outstanding events of the coming week will be the style revue Thursday afternoon at the Ross Fenton farm here for the benefit of the Fitkin Hospital.

Fifteen months before the next Presidential campaign will end, a whispering campaign was begun against the only candidate so far in sight. This custom of seeking to muddle the public mind by surreptitious detraction, slander or calumny of a party's banner bearer has been going on 107 years, in the old days more viciously than now.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- A new national broad jump record was established by Fritz Leichum today when he leaped 25 feet 4 3/4 inches in the annual German track and field championships for lightweight athletes. He surpassed the former mark by half an inch.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 3. -- Wisconsin's snarled tax situation showed signs of unraveling as a "peace conference" of the Senate, Assembly and administration reached an agreement today as to where increased revenues for the coming biennium are to come from, although leaving rates and other considerations for further negotiations.

SOMEWHERE off the Old Head of Kinsale, South Ireland, lies the Lusitania, torpedoed on May 7, 1915, with a loss of more than 1,000 lives. Outside of Kinsale Harbor bobs the Orphir, a reconverted lighthouse vessel, trying to locate the wreck.

Any sound fiscal policy now formulated for the Federal Government would be expected to give recognition to the need of additional taxes. Irrespective of what provision is made for extraordinary expenditures, additional tax burdens are unavoidable if the Federal budget is to be balanced.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3. -- The favorites swam true to form today when Edward Lee and Miss Susan Robertson, both representing New York clubs, scored easy triumphs in their respective ocean races.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Uncle Sam has won a $27,000,000 battle to make the Missouri River navigable, but the hoped-for stream of barge traffic between St. Louis and Kansas City has not materialized.

The series of factory stoppages in the coat and suit industry, due to a change in the method of determining and applying piecework prices, has impeded deliveries of August sales merchandise to a degree that may have an adverse reaction of far-reaching consequences, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., asserted yesterday.

DUBLIN, Aug. 2. -- The Dail Eireann has concluded an unusually turbulent session and the Deputies have returned to their constituencies until the end of October, but during the recess President Eamon de Valera and members of the Cabinet will be engaged upon an important constitutional task.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual ball to mark the close of the invitation tennis tournament which took place tonight in the Colonial Ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club.

Although the steel industry has not decided whether to continue the open-price system established under the NRA Steel Code, a decision must be reached before the end of this month, when the individual companies would normally file their prices for the fourth quarter with the American Iron and Steel Institute, according to steel executives.

No yachtsman, whether he pretends to be a fisherman or admits being interested only in sightseeing cruising, should let a Summer season go by without making Babylon a port of call. Here is a week-end harbor that should be on every one's itinerary who steers down the Narrows, on past Coney Island and heads into protected waters either at East Rockaway, at the Jones Beach Inlet or at Fire Island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Vernon Gomez picked one of the hottest days of the year here to snap out of his losing streak.

LONDON, July 5. SOME years ago a company of French actors, the Compagnie des Quinze won fame for themselves in London by their performances in two plays, both by Andre Obey, of which the first was "Noe" and the second "Le Viol de Lucrece." "Noe" has now been translated as "Noah" and appears under the direction of Michel Saint-Denis, with John Gielgud in the leading part.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Henry Fairfield Osborn Jr., associate of a New York City investment banking house, was appointed today as New York State director of the National Youth Administration. The NYA will carry out a $50,000,000 educational program in the nation for young people between the ages of 18 and 25.

FROM first page to last this book speaks with the genuine voice of the lighthouse. Mr. Sterling and those whom he has called to his aid know and love lighthouses and they write of them and of the men who make them what they are with affection, admiration and the interpreting spirit of intimate knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- No matter what happens the fundamentals of the Agricultural Adjustment program are written in the nation's agricultural policy for a long time to come. There are many reasons why I believe this is true. I will mention only four of them:

THE aviation unit of the Twenty-seventh Division, New York National Guard, will receive its first opportunity since its formation of working under full wartime conditions this month. Joining with the other troops of the Second Corps Area, the Twenty-seventh Division will "go to war" during the last two weeks in August in Northern New York along the St. Lawrence River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Treasury will spend nearly $2,000,000 in the next few months to safeguard its mounting hoard of gold and silver.

VIENNA, July 20, 1935. THE next few months ought to show to what extent the "resignation" of Richard Strauss from his official posts in the Nazi realm will affect the destinies of his protege, Clemens Krauss. It is an open secret that Krauss has not found the Berlin Staatsoper the bed of roses he anticipated.

It would perhaps surprise many to learn that in the jubilee ceremony in St. Paul's the only feature of the stately religious service not drawn from church ritual owed its existence to William Jennings Bryan.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 4. -- "What the Geneva agreement in the African dispute amounts to is further breathing space," The Sunday Times says editorially, "and one that in all circumstances, must be considered valuable.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Stolid Joe Louis came to the end of a three-week training siege tonight ready, to all appearances, to continue his devastating march through the heavyweight division at the expense of Chicago's King Levinsky next Wednesday night at Comiskey Park.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Lack of breeze spoiled the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club today. Of 89 craft that started, only 10 were able to finish, and they were the small Rainbows and Snipes, which had a course of but three miles to cover.

Throwing open the doors of a committee room shortly after 11 o'clock on the morning of Friday, July 12, Senator Black of Alabama, chairman of the Senate committee appointed to investigate the activities of the power lobby, announced to the waiting "boys" of the press that "the show was about to start."

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3. -- The Chaco peace conference has decided to ask the United States to help to determine whether Bolivia or Paraguay was responsible for the three-year war, which cost 100,000 lives. The conference will set up an international court of three members, composed of one leading jurist from Argentina, one from Brazil and one from the United States.

NORWICH, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, declared in a speech here in his home city today that the handling by State and Federal agencies of the relief of New York State flood sufferers "has been marked by the most complete breakdown which has been seen during any State or national emergency in many years."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Stung by yesterday's shut-out, the Cubs turned the full fury of their attack upon the Reds today, pounding four pitchers for seventeen hits and winning, 11 to 3.

Receipts, 7,904 packages. Market again rallied toward the wind-up with early, weak declines more than lost under a more general spread of confidence. Trade was taking hold in rather better shape and the position seemed pretty well supported at the higher rates though still nervous and unsettled under the surface.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- A police school for peace officers of the six counties surrounding Geneva was announced today by R.W. Morris, Chief of Police of Geneva, and James M. Williams, Professor of Sociology of Hobart College. The school, to be known as the Hobart College Police School, will open Oct. 1, and classes will be held several times a week for the ensuing eight weeks.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- German newspapers published today under banner headlines an account from the semi-official news agency of developments in the National Socialist campaign against Jews in Stettin which is reproduced below verbatim not because the developments themselves are so extraordinary or differ greatly except in detail from what is going on all over the country, but because the account is written with fresh, unwonted, revealing frankness.

KINGMAN, Ariz., Aug. 3 (AP). -- County Attorney Elmo Bollinger said today that he has filed criminal cases against eight residents of the isolated Short Creek community for allegedly living in a state of polygamy.

POPULARITY of radio's impromptu amateur hours and "vox populi" sidewalk interviews has the showmen and their professional troupes wondering if their art has become too formal, too natural. They look back to the days when a script in the hands of an announcer was unknown.

LONDON. AN official statement has just been issued of the Civil List pensions awarded during the financial year ended March 31 last. These subventions from the national treasury are given in recognition of services to literature, science or the arts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Federal entomologists are poised for a major drive against plant and insect infestations in the United States. Thanks to works relief grants of about $17,000,000, the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, during the current fiscal year, will war upon many pests that exact a heavy toll from American agriculture.

THE presence of Jascha Heifetz as soloist at two of the Stadium concerts this week -- tomorrow night and Tuesday night -- is expected to so prod the interest of many who have lagged in their support of the Summer series as to necessitate opening the gates as early as 6 o'clock on the evenings of performances.

Crooners songs and band music and toothpaste advertisements and bedtime stories were coming over the air in Harlem, much to the delight of the radio audience in the apartments and brownstone fronts near Fifth Avenue and 119th Street.

Generally I am opposed to the Federal assumption of State, municipal or private property rights, but the Federal Government would he fully justified in assuming all rights necessary to combat the insect pestilence, for insects take no note of boundary lines.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti. -- Aug. 15 is a notable day in Haitian history. On that date one year ago the last of the United States marines sailed away after military occupancy of the Afro-Latin republic for nineteen years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The gigantic Federal triangle, stretching from White House to Capitol, is an actuality at last -- a maze of classic columns, courts and corridors challenging explorers of the new Washington.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The second annual Sagamore horse show will start on Friday afternoon, continuing Saturday and Sunday on the enlarged horse show ring on the Hotel Sagamore grounds.

Diplomats from London, Paris, Moscow, Rome, Addis Ababa and other capitals labored in Geneva last week to find a temporary solution -- or breathing space -- for the Italo-Ethiopian dispute. At a private session of the League Council and in private talks in their hotel rooms they were unsuccessful.

NAOMI JACOB'S latest novel was written at Sirmione, on the southern shore of Lago di Garda in the north of Italy, where all the later events of the story take place. This drama of an Englishman's loss of honor during the war and of his recapturing it through his marriage to an Italian peasant girl and his subsequent life among her people has special if somewhat ironic interest at the present time.

PARIS, July 28. -- The general exodus to the mountains, beaches and spas has begun. Many Americans are in Vichy, including Mrs. Paul Dupuy and General and Comtesse de Chambrun, the latter the former Clara Longworth.

Mayor La Guardia's plan for giving a free college course in engineering to a carefully selected group of young "career" firemen was much discussed last week. In view of the many inquiries made concerning the plan, the Mayor gave this writer additional details as to the reasons for it.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- Denny Shute of Chicago and Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N.J., turned on the fireworks again today in the Inverness invitation four-ball golf matches, came in with a 64, seven under par, against Leo Diegel and Jimmy Thomson, and assumed the round-robin tournament lead.

This is a newspaper story, and all the newspaper men and women in it talk and act as though they were trying to live up to the picture presented in Hecht and Mac-Arthur's play, "The Front Page" And that is precisely what some of them are trying to do.

BY rail and steamship, by airplane and bus, in organized tours and in their own motor cars Americans are on the move. Reports covering thirty-two cities, recently assembled by the Department of Commerce, reveal at many important centres a striking gain in all types of travel.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 3. -- A parade and review were features of the military demonstration here this afternoon when 2,000 students of the Citizens Military Training Camp were hosts to thirty officers of the Military Training Camps Association. Each member of the Association represented his respective county in the State.

ANGLETON, Texas, Aug. 3. -- Three Houston newspaper editors and three reporters were found guilty of contempt of court by District Judge M.S. Munson here today for publishing testimony of a criminal trial against his orders. The editors were fined $100 each and the reporters $25 each.

Breaking 98 out of a possible 100 targets, R.H. Helsel won the High Scratch Cup at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. D.S. Wegg and M. Swanick each had 97, and in the shoot-off Wegg broke 25 straight to take the second trophy.
GENEVA, Aug. 3. -- The handling of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict by the League of Nation's Council thus far has left the main obstacles to its peaceful solution virtually unchanged.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Newark divided a double-header with Buffalo today, the Bears winning the first game, 6 to 3, while the visitors took the second, 9 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- President Roosevelt moved today to get the nation's vast land use and resettlement program under way by approving an allotment of $12,000,000 to the Forest Service for the purpose of taking land out of cultivation and developing it for other uses.

The letter entitled "Age and the Earth," written by Eric D. Bovet and published in THE TIMES, has interested me greatly. I fear that Mr. Bovet has misunderstood the conception of "age" as utilized by present-day astronomers and cosmogonists.

In answer to protests by white-collar workers against the wage cuts caused by the new Federal Works Progress Administration, General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator, yesterday provided one committee with the complete schedules, which showed that pay running as high as $175 a month was being given to persons in "superintendence" positions.

SOME eleven months ago these columns devoted themselves with considerable amiability to the daydreams of a visionary whose castle in Spain was located on the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. As he sat at his desk on the top floor of the Center Theatre the minarets and battlements of a fantastic wonderland floated out into the rarefied atmosphere of Sixth Avenue.

While the intense heat of last week retarded business activity temporarily in some sections of the country, particularly the agricultural areas, trade in general continued along favorable lines. Retail trade in many cities was partly aided by the demand for Summer wearing apparel, and, in some centres, including New York, an increase in buying activity was noted. All sections showed a substantial gain in sales over the corresponding week last year.

DETROIT, Aug. 3. -- The number of passenger cars and trucks manufactured in the United States and Canada this week was 69,415 as against 82,894 recorded for the week ended July 27, according to Cram's Reports, Inc., of this city. The current volume compares with 58,554 for this week of last year.

WESTHAMPTON. L.I., Aug. 3. -- The yacht racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club's regatta on Moriches Bay today was sailed in a moderate south-south-west wind. It held steady throughout but never was strong enough to send the craft around the longer course.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Lou Gregory, Olympic runner from the Millrose A.A. of New York, and Joe Wood of Amsterdam, Adirondack A.A.U. 10,000-meter champion, scored decisive victories today in the 5,000 and 10,000 meter road races, first two of a series of three week-end long-distance events attracting the cream of Central New York State runners.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- A waterfall, believed to be one of the highest in the world, was discovered recently in the Chirripo Mountains, according to a report of Penny Rogers, nephew of Will Rogers and pilot of the Costa Rica National Airways.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 3. -- Political prophets are looking to Rhode Island to give an indication on Tuesday of the country's answer to the question, "What is the opinion of voters on Roosevelt and the New Deal program?"

NEAR the rocky heights of Kings Mountain, in South Carolina, a gallant little army of backwoodsmen, recruited from Southern States, fought a heroic battle against the well-trained forces of the British and scored an admirable victory.

Warning that he would not permit any delay in the hearing on the reorganization plan for the Butterick Company, Federal Judge Knox granted yesterday permission to William Harris, a Newark lawyer representing 100 stockholders owning 10,000 shares to intervene in the proceedings.

BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- Flashing his speed before a crowd of 60,000, Time Supply, bay colt owned by Mrs. F.A. Carreaud, today negotiated the one mile and sixteenth route of the Puritan Handicap in 1:43 3-5 to set a new track mark for the distance at Suffolk Downs.

THE dog days are here and New Yorkers are quenching their thirst with a variety of cooling drinks. Every day the city's seven millions consume thousands of gallons of iced beverages. They sip at their own tables, in restaurants, sidewalk cafes and stands along the street.

THE ancient castle of El Morro, at the entrance to the harbor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, is the scene of the crime with which this story deals. The local manager of a tourist agency has arranged a moonlight treasure hunt within the limits ell the castle for the amusement of a party of tourists.

LIKE so many other things in human life, the covered bridge, just as it is about to sink down into oblivion, is finding itself to be, after all, a matter of very considerable interest This is the third book about it to appear within the last two or three years.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Three notable events are on the program of Vermont's Green Mountain resorts this week. The Woodhouse Trophy golf tournament will be held at the Burlington Country Club throughout the week; the Vermont State tennis tournament will start at Brattleboro on Saturday and continue through Aug. 16, and New England Leisure Institute, opened yesterday at Fletcher Farms, Proctorsville, will continue through Saturday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The fourth annual midsummer figure skating operetta, to be staged on the ice sheet of the Olympic Arena here on Friday and Saturday, is expected to exceed in beauty all of its predecessors.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 1. -- Rumblings of discontent in rural areas, which have been increasing in volume for several weeks, have added a new question mark to the prospect of the Tennessee Valley Authority and caused a shifting of the spotlight from the Authority's court-beset power enterprises to one of its original goals, the relief of the farmer from the destruction of fertile soil.

The new "NRA" for the men's clothing field in the form of a two-year agreement between manufacturers and workers, signed last week, should provide an excellent model for other industries anxious to establish "practical and sane labor relations," Charles D. Jaffee, president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, declared here yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Finals will be played tomorrow in the annual women's invitation tennis tournament, which began on Monday on the Maidstone Club courts. The annual tennis dinner dance at the Maidstone Club this evening offered as an added feature a mixed doubles ping pong tournament.

BERLIN. IN spite of severe contingent restrictions, the importation of American screen product into Germany has again become a remunerative transaction. Though production activity of American films in Germany fell below par and with Universal, one of the most active companies here, transplanting its producing staff in the less acrid soil of Vienna and Budapest, recent developments again make it a practical possibility.

The chiding of wealthy holders of tax-exempt securities at last week's White House press conference aroused considerable resentment in financial circles. That large amounts Of investment funds have sought refuge in tax-exempt securities should come as no surprise to any one who has paid even the slightest attention to the bond market.

HSINKING, capital of the new State of Manchukuo, is having a boom. Miles of newly made roads lined with more than 2,000 new American-style homes are noisy with the exhausts of American-made motor trucks and the rumble of wooden-wheeled Manchurian carts.

Today will end a world-wide celebration among Roman Catholics of the 700th anniversary of the canonization of St. Dominic. A solemn high mass in his honor will be celebrated at 11 o'clock this morning at the Dominican Church of St. Vincent Ferret, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, by Franciscan Friars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Some persons who obtained government aid to save their homes were declared today to be deliberately evading re-payment and resorting to threats of dire political consequences if the Home-Owners Loan Corporation forecloses on them.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Debutantes will be the centre of interest here the coming week. A parade of them is to be led by Miss Phyllis Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie. She is to be informally presented at a dinner with music at the Gillespie home on Wednesday evening.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- There is every indication that the gayety of last week will continue throughout the coming one, which will be featured by the annual horse show, under the auspices of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club, to be held next Saturday on the grounds of the clubhouse on the North Sea Road.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Splashing through mud and rain, Grand Slam, 31 to 1 in the wagering and left at the post, scored an upset victory today by winning the fourth running of the Arlington Futurity, climaxing the thirty-day meeting at Arlington Park.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 3. -- Political orators sped through the Blackstone Valley tonight in a final plea for support in Tuesday's special Congressional election that will test the New Deal and Democratic strength in Rhode Island.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- The National Socialist regime spends many millions of marks, including large sums of its already inadequate foreign exchange supply, annually in propaganda to create good-will toward it, explain its aims and convert its critics at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Bestirring itself after months of comparative quietude, the Republican National Committee today promised a vigorous anti-New Deal offensive in an effort to oust President Roosevelt and the Democratic party from power in 1936.

NEAR the modern village of Avebury in Wiltshire, England, excavators have recently uncovered ancient ruins pronounced by archaeologists to be of high importance. The work being done here is part of that larger job which will result in the restoration of some 4,000 monuments through the country which are considered to be not only of national but of international importance.

WITH work on the Pacific bases practically completed and the first of the giant Martin Clippers showing a gratifying turn of speed in the shake-down trials, realization of the dream of Pacific air service draws toward accomplishment in orderly fashion.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The interstate pistol match between National Guard teams of New York and New Jersey and the Luquer match, an annual contest for a trophy and medals offered by Colonel Thatcher P. Luquer, held at Camp Smith today, brought together the finest pistol shots in both States.

Although Johnny and Jimmy were as active a pair of bear cubs as you could find they had always heeded their mother's firm command not to go into the forest, until one day, discovering how much they had grown, they decided they were big enough to go, and went forthwith.

THE fairies of Ireland are undoubtedly a superior lot. Unlike their prototypes in Grimm's "Tales," or the opulent beings in the "Arabian Nights," they are rarely concerned with such material pleasures as gold or Jewels; they are bent on sheer adventure.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3. -- The Soviet transpolar airplane was forced to turn back this afternoon on its hoped-for nonstop flight from Moscow to San Francisco. It landed at 10:30 P.M. south of Leningrad at an airdrome where it had been instructed to land.

BORIS Z. SHUMIATSKY, president and general manager of the Soviet Motion Picture Industry, was in New York for a few days last week following a six-week visit in Hollywood. He granted a mass interview in the Soviet Consula' 7 East Sixty-first Street.

The sailing of the Italian liner Rex for Mediterranean ports with 1,000 passengers was delayed yesterday for two and a half hours because flood and fog in Pennsylvania held up five first-class passengers from Cincinnati.

LONDON, July 26 (By Mail). -- Were Mahan (Rear Admiral Alfred Thayer Mahan, American naval strategist and historian) alive today, he would hail current events as a vindication of his teaching, for the world is unquestionably reverting to the orthodox tenets of sea power. Every nation of maritime pretensions is expanding, or preparing to expand, its naval forces.

DARRYL ZANUCK is assuming the management of the former Fox lot with militant hand. Several stories have been abandoned as unworthy of the Twentieth Century-Fox program and a number of changes in personnel have been made.

Led by Harry Kasabach of Ann Arbor, Mich., winner of the title the last two years, three players gained the quarter-finals as competition started yesterday in the fifth annual Armenian national tennis singles championship at the Arrowhead Tennis Courts.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Efforts to advance the wheat market on the Board of Trade today by houses with Eastern connections had relatively little effect, although government buying in the December delivery caused a good rally early in the session. The bulge brought increased hedging pressure and toward the last some stop-loss orders were uncovered.

THE shadow of the forthcoming Presidential campaign grows long across the country. The party captains scurry about seeking likely issues before the day of preparation ends. What shall those issues be? There is at least one issue, and it is not new.

CLOSTER, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Reports that LeRoy S. Mead Post of the American Legion in this village of 2,500 progressive-minded souls would make a determined bid for the national convention of the American Legion in 1976 were confirmed here today by Joseph B. Pearman.

DANZIG, Aug. 3. -- A virtual trade war broke out today between Poland and Danzig, which under the Versailles treaty are combined in a customs union, when the Polish Government reinforced the border guard and proceeded exhaustively to search all trains leaving Danzig for Polish territory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- In lodging an informal Japanese protest against a cartoon of Emperor Hirohito that appeared in the August Vanity Fair magazine, Seijiro Yoshizawa, Counselor of the Japanese Embassy, called upon Eugene Dooman, chief Of the Japan section of the State Department's Division of Far Eastern Affairs.

A MILDLY pleasant, old-fashioned little story, "The Crystal Tree," belongs to the type which was known as hammock fiction in those bygone days when hammocks swayed and swung throughout the land. For heroine it has an entirely admirable and, of course, beautiful young girl, Quail Ashby, whose father's death had left her faced with an even more serious problem than the task of supporting herself.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, is erecting an imposing life-sized portrait statue in memory of the late General Harry H. Bandholtz, U.S.A., who in 1919, with a riding crop as his only weapon, is credited with having saved the treasures of the Hungarian National Museum.

The professional dignity of 700 teachers was cast to the wind last night when, without using knives or forks, they ate T-bone steaks weighing sixteen ounces each at the annual men's steak dinner of Teachers College, Columbia University.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Miss Patricia Maguire of Oak Park, Ill., is showing signs of awakening from a sleep that has continued for almost three and one-half years.

WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- New Zealand faces a native problem. The first gun of the new battle was fired by Sir Apirana Ngata, ex-Minister for Native Affairs, when he declared that the government must recognize the Maori king movement, which years ago the New Zealanders fought a long and bloody war to extinguish.

The crew of the Hapag Lloyd liner Europa took special pains to have their ship at top form when she arrived Thursday on the first leg of her 100th round trip in the transatlantic service. On their last eastbound voyage they started preparations for the century trip, several of the men building a large sign equipped with electric lights which they placed on the catapult or highest deck.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Boerse was somewhat more active today and showed firmness, but at the close the activity had disappeared. Heavy industrials were firm but quiet. Potashes suffered losses, Salzdetfurth dropping 1/2 point. Machines were inactive, with Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1/4 point, although virtually inactive. Electricals were firm.

Whether women can act quickly and effectively in emergencies is the question raised by the appointment of five girl telephone operators to the general switchboard at Police Headquarters. Commissioner Valentine proposes eventually to substitute girls for the patrolmen who have always been assigned to switchboard duty.

A banking group headed by J.P. Morgan Co. is seen in Wall Street as holding the key to the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific, which, operating 12,000 miles of line, is the largest railroad system in bankruptcy at this time. It is held that only a change in the bankruptcy law would alter the situation and that it does not appear Congress will change the law at this session.

THE story of the horse called Comanche and his part in the Battle of the Little Big Horn has been told before, although mainly in fragments and as parts of other narratives, and, because it is a moving story, it is well to have its factors all brought together into as much coherence and certitude as it is now possible to secure for them.

IN the little town of Bethlehem, N.H., up in the White Mountains, certain Jewish sufferers from hay fever and asthma established an institution for the poor of their race where they might come during their vacations to get surcease from their common affliction.

Challenging the government to uncover any evidence to substantiate charges of profiteering in the food industry, leading manufacturers and distributers of nationally known brands of groceries and allied products yesterday declared that the proposal for a Federal Trade Commission investigation along broad lines is a political move designed to harass the processors.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- For the second successive year Frank Parker of Spring Lake won the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today on the turf courts of the Meadow Club.
The following opinions are evoked by William J. Robinson's reprobation of so-called horror films in last Sunday's TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The 145th anniversary of the founding of the United States Coast Guard in the administration of George Washington on Aug. 4, 1790, win be observed tomorrow with celebrations by all units of the service.

WORK by American artists, old and new, is plentifully on view in the galleries that have braved the Summer heat to remain open. And diversity, if one may make an Irish bull, is rather the keynote of the exhibitions. The excellent shows of contemporary Americans at Milch's and Rehn's have already been reviewed in these columns and are herewith again recommended.

THIS is the day of the cynic and the pessimist. They no longer sit in the dust by the roadside, uttering jeremiads while the unheeding throng passes them by. They have stepped forth as traffic police to halt the movement of progress.

CANADA is rushing to completion her transcontinental airway so that by the Summer of 1936 European mail will be less than three and one-half days from Montreal and less than five days from Vancouver. A high government official told your correspondent that with the trans-Canada airway in operation and fast modern planes flying its route Canada will receive much of the European mail for the Asiatic Continent.

I was very much interested in THE NEW YORK TIMES comment on the absence of a cellar in the Fouilhoux model small house. For some reason the poor, helpless cellar, which provides the most accommodation for the least money in the average house, seems to be the pet target of all who would design a more efficient home, or lower its cost.
TRENTON, Aug. 3. -- Governor Hoffman says that thirty-five States have accepted his invitation to send representatives to Trenton for a conference Oct. 11 and 12 on interstate crime compacts.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Two nuns, members of the Brooklyn community of Sisters of Mercy, were drowned in Hart's Cove here this morning when they stepped into a deep hole while wading at the private beach of the Sisters of Mercy villa.

Setting up of a psychological testing council, or sampling jury of consumers, to aid merchandise executives in determining in advance the probable reaction of customers to new items, was suggested here yesterday by the divisional merchandise manager of a leading local store, as an essential in the development of more scientific retailing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A 9-year-old boy from Charlotte, N.C., who was hungry and tired, was discovered today to have eaten at the White House Thursday night.

Edward D. Cunningham, veteran coach of rowing in Worcester, Mass., announces that the first national women's rowing regatta will be held on Lake Quinsigamond Aug. 24. This is an event of more than passing interest, for there has been much agitation for women's races to be held in conjunction with the men's national regatta, notably in 1933, when they were held in California.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- Woodsmen in the upper peninsula of Michigan do not have to read the agricultural journals in order to get an idea how the farmers in the Corn Belt and other sections of the country are faring.

A HUNDRED and one years ago Jacques Cartier sailed out of St. Malo, his birthplace, to make his first voyage to the New World. The adventure culminated in the discovery of the Gulf of St. Lawrence.After penetrating the Gulf a short distance he concluded that he had made a sufficiently momentous discovery for one year, and he returned home to prepare for a fresh start.

Community Chests and Councils, Inc., an association of community chests representing 417 cities, has issued a bulletin on "Trends in Community Chest Giving" in which are quoted figures estimating that at least $70,000,000 will be raised for charity through private philanthropy this year.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The Red Sox made a habit of coming from behind today and whipped the Athletics, 5 to 4, scoring two runs in the eleventh.

HARTFORD, Aug. 1. -- Gains in employment rolls and man-hours over a year ago and a continuing increase in June and July instead of the usual Summer slump is reported by the Manufacturers Association of Hartford County on the basis of statistics collected from its members.
A new forum on current economic and political problems to be held at New York University under the division of general education was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn.

To the accompaniment of the heaviest trading for a Saturday since Nay 12, 1934, the share market moved higher yesterday under the leadership of utility issues. On the Stock Exchange, trading exceeded 1,000,000 shares, compared with 734,000 the week before. News of the action of the House in defying the administration's wishes in the matter of corporation gifts to charities did not become generally known until after the market's closing.

THE business of serving meals and running a house goes right on through the Summer for many housewives. Attractive new tableware and labor-saving gadgets have been designed to add a midsummer fillip to their tasks.

THREE generations of farm dwellers: those who pioneer, those who carry on and those who break away, are depicted in Miss Blake's novel of physical and spiritual sowing and reaping in the Norwegian communities of the Middle West.
John M. Richardson, seeded No. 1, defaulted to 0wen Davis as play began in the annual men's Staten Island singles tennis championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3. -- A five-year suspension of foreign debt payments by Brazil is foreseen by banking and financial circles here, as a result of the decline in the nation's foreign trade.

The 1935 Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, successor of the Williamstown Institute of Politics, which was discontinued in 1933, will open at Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., on Sunday, Aug. 25, and continue in session for six days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Representatives of union seamen from the Pacific Coast, after a meeting today with representatives of the ship owners and the Labor Department, refused to give the word that would release five ships tied up at San Francisco and Vancouver.

EASTBOURNE, England, Aug. 3. -- The combined tennis forces of Yale and Harvard got away to a fine start today in their quest of the Bernon S. Prentice international intercollegiate trophy, winning eight of the eleven opening singles and doubles matches from the Oxford-Cambridge netmen.

A strike of 700 motion-picture machine operators in 150 theatres of the RKO, Loew's and Skouras circuits in the city loomed yesterday members of the Motion-Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, protested against a pay cut of about 41 per cent ordered by the exhibitors.

LAURIUM, Mich., Aug. 3. -- This Northern Michigan mining community, which gave to football's hall of fame the great George Gipp of Notre Dame fifteen years ago, paid tribute to his memory today at the dedication of a memorial park and monument.

WITH the formal opening of the Advanced School of Education this Fall, Teachers College will take a significant step forward in the training of graduate students. Patterned along the lines of the Ecole Normale Superieure of France, this school is ultimately expected to equip educators as expertly as West Point and Annapolis equip officers for the army and navy.

SOME one rings your doorbell. At the threshold you confront a scared-looking individual armed with pencil and trailing a long sheet of paper, who begins asking questions of a rather personal nature: "How many rooms, occupants and servants are there in your house?
Brooklyn's scenic Shore Road, where in other years the mansions of the wealthy of the old village of New Utrecht overlooked the Narrows, is today the centre of a widespread park project.

JOLIET, Aug. 3. -- In one of the simplest but most audacious escapes in the history of the Joliet penitentiary, Henry J. (Midget) Fernekes, notorious gunman and bank robber, walked calmly out of that institution today where he was serving a sentence of ten years to life for bank robbery.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- Showing a radical reversal of yesterday's form, the Phillies outpitched and outplayed Casey Stengel's Dodgers today to win both ends of a double-header. The scores were 2 to 1 and 5 to 1, and in both games the Flatbush boys failed to get a run across until the ninth inning.

HERE is Shufflin' Joe Louis getting ready to fire away at Kingfish Levinsky, the furious fish-monger of the Michigan Lake front, and it's the only big brawl in sight. What became of those famous pugilists of a year ago? It's a queer tale altogether.

A committee of the Colonial Y.C. this week is busy completing arrangements for the annual Bear Mountain cruiser race, which will be held on Sunday, Sept. 15. This fixture, now several years old, is held for the Jules Heilner Trophy and is a seventy-two-mile grind up the Hudson -- around the committee boat anchored between Iona Island and Bear Mountain Bridge and then back to New York.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Federal Works Progress Administrator, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses were deadlocked yesterday over the question who should issue orders to WPA workers provided for park projects.
The Citizens Budget Commission issued a statement yesterday declaring again that the general level of city salaries exceeded those in private industry and was "wholly indefensible" at this time.

About 20,000 whites and Negroes marched through the streets of Harlem yesterday afternoon in two separate parades, and then joined in a mass meeting in the square at 141st Street and Edgecombe Avenue, in a protest against war in general and Italian aggression in particular.
The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club strengthened its lead in the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association competition by defeating the Brooklyn C.C. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug 3. -- The first Canadian issue since the establishment of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the second such foreign issue, was filed today with the SEC.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- The body of John Pershing Heiner, a second cousin of General Pershing, was found hanging in a closet of his bedroom in a Locust Street apartment here today. Other occupants of the apartment house said he had been a successful stock broker who lost more that $750,000 in the market collapse of 1929 and had appeared morose lately.

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 3. -- John Henry Kirby, veteran Democrat of this city, is chairman of a new organization, the Southern Committee to Uphold the Constitution, which has just been started with a membership extending over the sixteen Southern States.

SCIENCE is the modern Scheherazade. Her imagination is incomparable. When she rests for a moment from work in her laboratories, leans against a microscope, gazes into the future and begins to tell what she is doing and going to do, novelists and poets and dramatists and even just plain liars can all hide their heads in shame.

An embargo on shipments of American war materials to warring nations is advocated by the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. In a statement issued by Dr. Ivan Lee Holt, president of the council, the committee asks also for legislation banning loans and credits to nations at war and providing that Americans "doing business with or traveling in nations at war do so at their own risk."

THE continued growth and spread of the Summer theatres that now function throughout New England, New York, New Jersey and are beginning to assert themselves in other States, may very well indicate what course the American professional theatre will have to take if it is to re-establish itself land command the attention and respect that it enjoyed before the cinema replaced it in the affection of the masses.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The Philadelphia Board of Trade telegraphed today to President Roosevelt protesting against his reported instructions to the Navy Department in connection with efforts to settle the strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's plant here, now twelve weeks old.

A total of $11,383,140 new State and municipal bond issues was reported approved by the voters of 123 communities in thirty-two States in July, compared with $4,558,000 in June. In July, 1934, a total of $1,807,500 was approved, compared with $27,836,852 in July, 1933, and with $1,618,000 in July, 1932.

THE 1935 Fisher Body Craftsman's a Guild competition in miniature coach making closed last Thursday and judging of the models submitted by boys from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania began on Friday at the American Museum of Natural History.

DESIGN WORKSHOP'S Summer session is now in progress (continuing until Sept. 1) aboard the old ship Herbert in Gloucester Harbor, Gloucester, Mass. The New York headquarters, where classes are conducted in the Autumn, Winter and Spring months, is at 69 Bank Street.
The large department stores in the leading cities of the country are maintaining hours and wage schedules set up under the NRA codes, according to a survey made this past week.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 4. -- The Home Office has prohibited sale in Japan of the August number of Vanity Fair, containing a caricature of Emperor Hirohito, and the copies in bookstores have been confiscated by the police.

ALREADY the city's leading hotels are filling up for Ireland's greatest social and sporting event of the year -- the Dublin Horse Show. And this year's fixture promises to equal, if not excel, the splendor of previous shows.

MAX BRAND writes some of the roughest, wildest, most preposterous tales of Western rough life -- the life of outlaws and such, particularly -- and does it with unsurpassed aplomb. For he is a facile story teller and somehow he makes his fictions realistic.

LEADERS who like to experience "the fearful thrill of danger" at second hand, together with that smaller number who crave it at first hand, should both get a good deal out of Mr. Irving's contribution to the literature of mountain climbing.

THE author of this book, a British writer, five years ago published a volume called "A Realist Looks at Democracy," in which he severely criticized the existing democratic system. In it, he says in his preface, he was endeavoring to destroy the shams and illusions on which "conventional democratic thought and practice are based."

Operations of the Household Finance Corporation and subsidiaries in the first six months of this year resulted in a net profit of $2,234,687 after interest, Federal taxes and other charges. If applied directly to preference stock, the earnings would equal $10.50 a share on 212,701 shares of $3 cumulative participating preference stock of $50 par.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Wolff gave a party in the Homestead Club last evening for more than sixty-five guests. Those present included:

FOUR of the seven first-run cinema temples in the midtown area will have new tenants this week. Which tends to indicate, somehow, that after a week of feverish activity, during which eight new films went on exhibition, the pace is beginning to slacken a bit.

TODAY there will be parades in this town and a great sprinkling of Swiss costumes among the watchers and marchers. A two-day celebration will mark the ninetieth anniversary of the settlement here of a small colony of emigrants from the canton of Glarus, Switzerland.

THE sun swims up through an ocean of muggy and stagnant air. People who have been sleeping uncovered in ill-ventilated city bedrooms wake up in a perspiration. The New York subways fairly steam. Air-cooled theatres, restaurants and stores do a good, if not rushing, business.
A concerted drive against Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and his agent, lieutenants and henchmen will be made by the police, it was learned yesterday.

Backed by large government subsidies, aircraft factories in Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy are busily at work on huge flying boats aimed at catching up in the race for over-ocean trade routes of the air which the American system, Pan American Airways, now dominates.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The attention of several foreign governments was directed today to the position of their nationals who are serving as press correspondents in Germany. Diplomats communicated with their Foreign Offices after conferring among themselves about the correspondents' personal safety and attacks upon them in the Nazi press.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 3. -- With one superb performance Miss Lenore Kight of the Carnegie Library Club bounded back into the picture today as the women's decathlon swimming competition continued on the sun-flooded waters of Zach's Bay.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The attention of several foreign governments was directed today to the position of their nationals who are serving as press correspondents in Germany. Diplomats communicated with their Foreign Offices after conferring among themselves about the correspondents' personal safety and attacks upon them in the Nazi press.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 3. -- With one superb performance Miss Lenore Kight of the Carnegie Library Club bounded back into the picture today as the women's decathlon swimming competition continued on the sun-flooded waters of Zach's Bay.

The army, with substantial assistance from Borough President Harvey and Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr., came to the rescue last night of more than 150 men, women and children who were forced to vacate two four-story brick apartment houses At 11-46 and 11-48 Forty-fourth Drive, Long Island City, because the Queens Building Department had found them no longer safe for occupancy.

BAY HEAD, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Smooth seas and an extremely light northeasterly breeze attracted a large fleet today in the annual regatta of the Bay Head Yacht Club, which held the weekly championship events of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

ROBERT O. BALLOU has discontinued his own publishing business and has joined the staff of Robert M. McBride Co. as chief editor. Mr. Ballou was one of the original members of the firm of Jonathan Cape Harrison Smith, Inc., when it was founded in 1929, and he remained with that firm until it was discontinued in 1932.

SYDNEY. -- Where government enterprise has failed, private wealth is now seeking the opportunity to develop North Australia, the great empty spaces of which are a weakness of which the country is uncomfortably aware.

Late events in Berlin and Moscow make a person wonder how far the new physics of EINSTEIN, PLANCK, MILLIKAN and SHAPLEY have made things easier for HITLER and STALIN. The art of riding two horses at the same time has been practiced by politicians of all times and all climes.

MANILA. -- Governor General Frank Murphy recently completed two years in office as Chief Executive of the Philippine Islands. They have been dramatic years because of the passing of the Tydings-McDuffie act, the drafting of the Philippine Constitution and the holding of a national plebiscite.
There is much in the press these days about peace. I believe in peace, but I am a pacifist with the accent on the fist. Some wars are necessary; some others very likely will be.

Featured by active consumer response to August home furnishing and fur promotions, retail trade here forged ahead last week. Estimates placed the increase for the period at 10 per cent or more over last year for local stores, with smaller gains for the Northern New Jersey area, where the sales tax continued to affect volume adversely.

READERS who are already acquainted with Joseph C. Lincoln's stories of Cape Cod -- and this, by now, must include the greater part of the novel-reading public -- will need small introduction to this one. It will be sufficient to say that "Storm Signals" is in Mr. Lincoln's usual vein and that, as far as action goes, it is one of the best yarns he has yet given us.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 3 (AP). -- A crack transcontinental airliner was wrecked today in an emergency landing in a scrub tree forest twenty miles east of here, but the nine passengers escaped unhurt and the two pilots received only cuts and bruises.

The production of electric power in the United States now stands at the threshold of unprecedented records, after following a much better than seasonal course for the last two months. Electric output already has surpassed all previously recorded levels for the Summer period, and in the final week of July exceeded by 5.83 per cent the previous midsummer peak, set in 1929.

THE dream of a pastoral paradise -- what city dweller has not been enticed by its false charms? Even those who have been born on farms will, after a few years in the city, remember only the swimming and fishing, the stealing of fruit, the privilege of going barefoot, or the simple pleasures of a visit to town.

PARIS. IS Paris on the verge of a passementerie period? A great many style signs point in that direction; they started early last Summer with those ruffled bodices of Vionnet's, fitted by wheels within wheels of complicated needlework.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Senator McNary today looked over the seventeen major bills awaiting final action and predicted that at least seven would be scrapped to permit an adjournment by Aug. 20 at the latest.

WHAT ecstasy can this country offer a Roman comparable to that which generations of traveling Americans have found in, say, the Coliseum by moonlight? Do the Spanish houses of Palm Beach make the child of a former Spanish King feel homesick?

Mayor La Guardia's recent appointments of three men to the Municipal Art Commission call attention to a body which probably does more work and more important work in proportion to its annual appropriations and the size of its paid staff than any other city agency.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- More than 100 officers of the First Army Corps arrived here today to swell the number already preparing for the coming army manoeuvres to over 1,300 officers and soldiers of the regular army.

If the city carries out its contemplated program of public works under Federal loans and grants its borrowing capacity will be cut to a margin insufficient for imperative public needs, William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

Fifty-five eminent British physicians and surgeons on their way from England to Australia to hold the annual meeting of the British Medical Association half-way around the world in the interest of the scientific unity of the empire, visited the Grasslands Hospital at Valhalla, N.Y., yesterday and admitted they had a thrill.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- Reports for the last week indicate an increasing stagnation of business, unwillingness of manufacturers to take risks and a decrease in the granting of credits for purely industrial purposes. The confusion in Geneva, Nazi dissensions, the rapid rise of prices, the admission by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht that economic tension exists and, finally, foreign reactions to the anti-Jewish campaign served to depress sentiment.
PARIS, Aug. 4. -- The necessity for military preparedness was the topic of official speeches delivered today both in France and in Belgium.

The late President Paul von Hindenburg of Germany was extolled yesterday as "Germany's greatest historic figure" at a service in his honor at the Evangelical Lutheran Zion Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street. Dr. Gustav Albert Mueller, acting Consul General of Germany, and members of his staff participated in the exercises.

Home Owners Loan Corporation and Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation bonds have greater security than direct government issues, according to a bulletin issued by C.F. Childs Co., specialists in government bonds. In addition to being guaranteed by the United States, these bonds are backed by collateral in the form of actual mortgages on homes and banks, the bulletin says.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Fearful that they cannot control Congress or even hold it in session once the Tax Bill has been disposed of, administration leaders will redouble their efforts this week to push the remainder of President Roosevelt's legislative program over the "hump" toward final enactment.

This country's desire to show Japan that our fighting planes could attack the Japanese Empire was responsible for the recent flights of American planes over areas of the Pacific, the Rev. Dr. Robert L. Tucker, pastor of the Indianola Methodist Episcopal Church of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday.

Employers of building trades labor on construction projects in New York City will probably pay approximately $1,000,000 during the year 1936 for unemployment insurance, Myron L. Matthews points out in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

If one is minded to glance back over the stock record for August since the turn of the century, it will be discovered that the month has usually been characterized by a rising share market; it is at this season that followers of stocks seek to "discount" autumnal improvement in business and, if possible, to anticipate what is thought to lie ahead in the Winter and even Spring months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Work relief officials here are understood to be indignant at Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner, who has denied the sole right of General Johnson, New York Works Progress Administrator, to issue orders to WPA workers on park projects.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- Winning two games in one day from the Phillies was beyond the powers of the Dodgers, even though Casey Stengel shifted his line-up so radically that Jimmy Bucher became an outfielder, Danny Taylor and Frenchie Bordagaray were benched and Joe Stripp went back to third base.

On the eve of the war between the United States and Spain a group of diplomatic representatives of several European countries went to the White House to express to the President their apprehension and, without offense, to propose their good offices in trying to avert a conflict.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4. -- Gar Wood Jr., 17-year-old son of the famous Michigan motor boat speed king, upheld the family name when he won the William Randolph Hearst Gold Cup in the second annual two-day outboard regatta which closed today at Oakmont.

KEANSBURG, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Five Dartmouth College students arrested this afternoon for parading along the boardwalk attired only in bathing trunks learned by hard labor today that this community strictly enforces its ordinance prohibiting the wearing of scanty apparel on the streets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Hedging pressure in wheat by millers and purchases of cash wheat, oats and rye had a lowering influence on prices here last week, with declines to new low levels for the week and to the lowest prices in oats for the season. Corn was erratic, with support by local traders who bought futures on every weak spot, but profit-taking resulted in sharp price recessions after every bulge.

Six American forestry experts who sailed on the Europa Saturday for Germany to study the problems of scientific forestry received grants from the Oberlaender Trust of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

The Stedman committee for $244,000,000 Missouri Pacific Railroad bonds, which is opposing the plan of reorganization for the railroad proposed by O.P. Van Sweringen, president of the Alleghany Corporation, fired its opening gun with an announcement issued for publication today condemning the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Unless a change is made in the eligibility rule which stipulates that the young men's group of the CCC shall be from families on relief, officials admitted tonight that the corps will not fill its quota of 600,000 by Aug. 31, the date set in their plans.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- Rumblings of what may be a new purge of "State enemies" in the Nazi Reich were sounded today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels. As the Propaganda Minister issued his warning, speculation was aroused by the announcement of the resignation of former Field Marshal August von Mackensen from honorary membership in the Steel Helmet organization, the group of war veterans against whom the government's campaign against "State enemies" has recently been turned.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. Ethel Burkhardt Arnold of Los Angeles established her first leg on the most valuable tennis trophy in American today and at the same time pretty well clinched a singles berth for herself on the Wightman Cup team.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week continued to be dominated by the Holland guilder. However, some of the nervousness and tension of the preceding week had disappeared with the formation of another Colijn Cabinet, with the result that the guilder closed at an advance of 80 points, at 67.90 cents, compared with a loss of 93 points in the preceding week.

Communism and Christianity have many fundamental aims in common and should work together for the welfare of mankind, John Haynes Holmes declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the services of the Community Church at The Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Reflecting crop and livestock conditions, the Association of American Railroads reported that the Western railways had a drop of 77.4 per cent in net operating income in May. This was in contrast to results in the East, where a gain of 4.8 per cent was recorded, and in the South, where the gain was 32.3 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Wholesalers, retailers and manufacturers in all leading lines held their gains last week and developed fair enlargement, especially as compared with a year ago. When all conditions are taken into consideration, particularly that of crops, the business situation is held especially gratifying.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Behind the four-hit pitching of Tommy Bridges the Tigers blanked the Indians today, to sweep the three-game series and score their fifteenth victory in twenty starts this season against Walter Johnson's charges.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- William S. Meany Jr., the intrepid aviator-golfer, and his brilliant partner, Bobby Grant of Wethersfield, Conn., today won the John G. Anderson memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club by defeating the veteran George J. Voigt and Arthur Lynch, 2 and 1, in the final round.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Miss Virginia Latrobe of New York and Baltimore gave a tea at her cottage this afternoon.
Clarence Streit's dispatch from Geneva on July 21 speaks of the Anglo-Italian protocols of 1891 as having been made in secrecy, and this "secrecy" is much emphasized by the headline.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Templeton, the team which is to defend its open polo title against the British and American challengers next month, rode today for the first time this season in its regular championship line-up. Facing Pete Bostwick's Aiken Knights in the regular weekly game at Bostwick Field, Templeton gave away three goals on handicap and lost by that margin to a side that rode well and earned its victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the fiscal year ended June 30 made a profit of $4,716,409 after paying all operating expenses and allowing for losses in nineteen closed banks, Leo T. Crowley, corporation chairman, asserted in his annual report today.

ATHENS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The newspaper Anexartitos said today former King George of Greece, disappointed at not being able to return to the throne under present conditions, was seeking a reconciliation with former Premier Eleutherios Venizelos, now in exile under a death sentence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Rudolph Ganz, composer-conductor, former leader of the St. Louis Symphony and present director of the Chicago Musical College, made his debut here tonight as guest conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra in its seventh "sunset" concert at the Watergate in the Potomac.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Swimming's greatest sister act staged its fanciest exhibition today in the glistening green waters of Zach's Bay as the Kompa sisters unfurled the most dazzling performance of their brief aquatic careers. Erna broke one world's record and one American mark, but ahead of her in this two-ply shot at existing figures was her sister Elizabeth.
Have you ever considered the dangers of vacationing? Here we are hardly settled in a country house at Westhampton and we find ourselves smack dab up against a problem.
WASHINGTON Aug. 4 (AP). -- Strong political pressure for a twelve-cent loan to help peg 1935 cotton crop prices descended today upon farm administration officials.

Travel men predict that new records for August tourist traffic, domestic and foreign, will be established this year. Basing their predictions on the volume of advance bookings and the manner in which ships have continued their heavy carryings far beyond the normal period, they maintain that the movement of travelers away from home combined with the return of groups who have been away will set a new high mark this month for the post-war years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor will begin holding its quarterly meeting at Atlantic City tomorrow, in order to complete the report which it will submit to the annual convention scheduled for Oct. 7.
