CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Mandeville W. Zenge, Missouri farm boy, and Mrs. Louise Schaffer Bauer, who, before her marriage, jilted him after he had purchased a wedding ring for her, met tonight in the State's Attorney's office.

An ambulance of the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, was telescoped in a collision yesterday with another automobile at Liberty Avenue and 158th Street, Jamaica. A passenger in the automobile was injured.
PARIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- An American track team of ten athletes today captured first places in all but three of fourteen events in competition with French and Italian stars.

Commodity futures were mixed in tone throughout last week, with trading light as a rule. The breakfast-table commodities and hides were weak, while most other staples advanced moderately. In the cash markets, all the grains except flour, coffee, cocoa, cotton, wooltops and hides declined, while lard, pork, rubber and zinc advanced.

GENEVA, Aug. 4. -- Yesterday's postponement by the League of Nations of the Ethiopian problem serves to bring out one factor in it that is important for Ethiopia and may become more so for all the nations concerned. It is already giving the British Government some uneasiness as Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's recent speech indicated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Irregularity in the price of live hogs, which advanced to $11.20, the highest in almost seven years, had an unsettling effect on the market here last week for lard and hog products generally, and shorts in lard futures were frightened into covering, while holders of contracts took profits.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 4. -- General Fortunato Zuazua, who says he is the Governor-elect of the State of Nuevo Leon, made a statement today charging former President Plutarco Elias Calles with trying to dictate the result of last Sunday's election in favor of Plutarco Elias Calles Jr., the former President's son.

LINCROFT, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Commoner Crown, 5-year-old gray gelding owned and ridden by Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N.J., won the hunter championship of the first Lincroft charity horse show, which was held today at Lincroft Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kaiser.

Anne Sibley, 21-year-old daughter of a Chicago lawyer, who left college on an escapade that led to a circus career, remained yesterday at her job with a side-show on the main street of Coney Island and held attention as the leading attraction of the day.

Possibly no machinery in the interest of world welfare has ever proved so entirely ineffective as a Geneva conference. To begin with, no more impressive or effective setting could be devised for the application and working out of the theory that might makes right than is staged by this august assemblage of the powers of earth, with its pomp and circumstance, its foofaraw and medicine-making.

Characterizing the present age as one that has seen the paralysis of the "love principle," the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood of London said yesterday morning at the Riverside Church that this fact presented to mankind a "supreme test."

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The 2,000 students of the Citizens Military Training Camp ended their Summer training with a reception and parade for 1,000 visitors. Mothers and fathers came by bus and auto to see how their sons had lived for the last four weeks. At noon the visitors stormed the mess halls to eat with the citizen soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Yankee machine went into reverse at Griffith Stadium today, just when it seemed perfectly tuned for a steady run. As a consequence, the McCarthymen dropped the third and last game of their series with the Senators, skidding back to a position four and a half games in the wake of the Tigers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- The Mayor's job appears to be growing in popularity in Philadelphia. A check of the records in the County Commissioners' office discloses that thirty candidates are seeking the Republican nomination for Mayor and eighteen others are running for the Democratic nomination.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 46 per cent of capacity, an advance of three points in a week and comparing with the revised estimate of 39 per cent for each of the last two weeks of June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- In a formal statement issued tonight, Senator Barbour of New Jersey condemned the "Wealth-Sharing" Tax Bill from beginning to end, and stated his intention of opposing it to the last ditch when it reaches the Senate.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Further light has been thrown upon the oft-debated intentions of the framers of the Constitution of the United States, through the original notes of John Lansing Jr., later Chancellor of New York, taken on the debates in the Constitutional convention, which have been discovered by Professor Joseph R. Strayer, of the department of history of Princeton University.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer will return to his haunts in Harlem and the Bronx within a week or two, police officials predicted yesterday, to draw the line of battle on which he expects to meet the Police Department's threat to remove him from active racketeering.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Those who, to ease their conscience or for some other reason, send money to the State "conscience fund" are not thus relieved of responsibility when it comes to paying income taxes, Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, said today.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES for July 30, under the caption "Metten Charges Denied, Camden Mayor Says Strikers Were Warned Aginst Reds," there is an alleged quotation by Mayor Frederick Von Nieda of Camden, N.J., as follows:

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 3. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.9, which compares with 82.6 the week before, 81.7 two weeks before, 81.6 three weeks before and 81.7 four weeks before. The present average is the highest of the year to date and the highest since the week ending Oct. 12, 1930.

Cotton futures declined last week 21 to 26 points on the New York Cotton Exchange under the influence of uncertainty whether the government would make a fixed-price loan on the new crop. Prices fluctuated in a narrow range as conflicting rumors reached the market, but lack of authentic information prevented any sharp changes.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on July 31 at 68.1. This compares with 67.4 a fortnight before, 67.5 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Timely hitting in last-inning rallies enabled the Cardinals to capture both ends of a doubleheader with the Pirates today before 17,000 fans. The world champions scored, 4 to 3, in the ten-inning opener and took the nightcap, 6 to 5.

The Aug. 1 vote in the House on the instruction to House conferees to accept the Senate bill provisions for abolition of "unnecessary" utilities holding companies represents an interesting analysis as far as New York State is concerned.

Twenty streamlined motor coaches of the most modern type will be put in operation on the Fifty-seventh Street and Seventy-second Street crosstown lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company within the next few days, John A. Ritchie, president of the company, announced yesterday.
Random notes of a ramble through the Catskills while on recent furlough:

PEEKSKILL N.Y. Aug. 4. -- More than 11,000 visitors were at Camp Smith today to witness the review of the Ninety-third Brigade of Manhattan by Governor Herbert H. Lehman. Governor Lehman was the guest for the day of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 3. -- The political crisis is over, but the difficulties remain virtually unchanged, in the general opinion here, so confidence in the guilder is less strong than before. Even Premier Colijn admits that only the hurried solution of the Cabinet crisis averted devaluation, which means that even a drastic technical defense and a strong technical position of the Bank of The Netherlands will be insufficient to save the guilder if confidence really disappears.

Several hundred clergy and laymen of the Syrian Orthodox Church in New York, Boston and Detroit turned out yesterday morning to greet Archbishop Theodosios Abourjely of Tyre and Sidon, patriarchal delegate sent here by Alexander III, Patriarch of Antioch and all the least and supreme head of the Syrian Orthodox Church, when he arrived on the liner Byron of the Greek Line at Pier 3, Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The foreign exchange market once more is settling down to something approaching normal conditions. With the formation of a new Dutch Cabinet another crisis in the gold bloc appears to have been surmounted. Fundamentally, however, conditions in the gold countries remain unchanged.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The fast and comfortable modes of transportation for the present generation are likely to decrease the span of life, Dr. William H. Vail, the third oldest living graduate of Princeton University, said here today as he celebrated his ninetieth birthday at his home, 141 Second Avenue, East Orange, with relatives and friends.

Mayor Angelo Rizzo of Mulberry Street is a largish man, and he has enough difficulty trying to sleep these humid nights without having to listen to the excited shoptalk of the Double-X Pigeon Club in convention on the sidewalk. But he made no complaint, because the flying stock of the pigeon club members was having an important test flight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Farmers and the grain trade in general have been greatly disappointed by the unexpected deterioration in the Spring wheat sections of the United States and Canada, and present indications are that there will be another scarcity of Spring wheat in the United States as the result of heat, drought and black-stem rust.

YREKA, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Citizen posses scoured the wooded hills of Northern California today for a second police-slayer suspect as District Attorney Davis blamed "apathy of the Supreme Court of the United States" and other Federal tribunals for the mob hanging of Clyde L. Johnson.

Only one of the eight divisions of the hosiery industry -- the wool bundle group -- has voted to enter into a voluntary agreement for retention of NRA labor and fair practice standards, it was made known here yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- The Maidstone Club stands were thronged today for the playing of the final round of the tenth annual women's invitation tournament for the gold cup donated by the late William H. Woodin.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Boston's largest baseball crowd of the season, 40,000, saw the Red Sox and Athletics divide a double-header today, Boston taking the first, 7 to 6, in ten innings, and Philadelphia the second, 4 to 3, in eight innings. The nightcap was cut short because of the local 6:30 P.M. Sunday curfew.

The twenty-seven families evicted Saturday afternoon from two Long Island City apartment houses because the Queens Building Department had found them unsafe for occupancy were hunting for new homes yesterday with assurance from the Home Relief Bureau that the first month's rent would be guaranteed for those unable to pay.

Frederick A. Tuttle, who was chief of the inspection division at Ellis Island when he retired in 1933, will be arraigned before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard today to plead to four indictments charging him with naturalization and immigration frauds.

The world premiere of Max Reinhardt's screen edition of "A Mid-summer Night's Dream," produced by Warner Brothers, will take place at the Hollywood Theatre here on the evening of Oct. 9. The film will be shown on a reserved-seat, two-a-day basis.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, and other members of the British delegation to the League Council returned by air this evening. Mr. Eden flew in a private plane from Paris to Lympne, where he will stay with Sir Philip Sassoon until Tuesday, when he is to report to Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan has been asked by the West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., to suspend construction of the extension of the West Side elevated express highway, from Canal Street to the Battery. In a letter made public yesterday the civic organization asserts that to continue the work at this time might result in waste of tax funds and damage to business interests in lower Manhattan.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 4. -- It was a busy day in the Marblehead 43d annual race week today as three clubs held racing off the harbor. The feature event was the annual junior regatta of the Pleon Yacht Club which brought to the line a fleet of 176 craft to break another Marblehead record, 115 boats having been the previous high total for this event.

ONE day at the Empire meeting there was a book reviewer at the track and in his pocket he was carrying a small volume of Tennyson. Rather odd; what? Not the visit of a book reviewer at a track. Such things happen now and then. Even the Pinkertons are not always on the alert. But the presence of a volume of Tennyson on the turf was absolutely astonishing.
FULTON, Mo., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Five convicts, one a killer, were at large tonight while officers unsuccessfully sought them over a wide area of Central Missouri.

A stolen automobile that was being driven from the scene of an accident at 104th Street and Madison Avenue shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon with two policemen in pursuit firing their pistols in the air crashed into a taxicab near the home of Mayor La Guardia, causing injuries to six other persons.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The foreign exchange market again was the centre of interest this week, and events turned out as expected. The recovery of the guilder caused great relief here, as there was some anxiety concerning it a week ago.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The detention of Carroll Dunham Smith, 63-year-old manufacturer of Essex Fells, and his son, De Veaux Smith, by police in Seattle Saturday night was termed an "unfortunate incident" by Carroll Dunham Smith Jr. at his home here today.

Several dwelling transactions and cancellation by the Commerce and Navigation Board of New Jersey of a riparian grant on the Passaic River were the leading features over the week-end in New Jersey transactions.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Until the early hours of this morning this Fire Island community waited, with the patience that characterizes life where the kerosene lamp and the bicycle are the most modern improvements tolerated, for the opening and dedication of the town's new $2,600 jail.

Five bungalows and an unoccupied three-story frame hotel were destroyed last night in a fire that swept through a Summer bungalow colony on the shores of lower New York Bay at the foot of Arbutus Avenue, Huguenot Park, on the south shore of Staten Island.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 5 (AP). -- While the Foreign Office awaited today the report of Ambassador Hirosi Saito from Washington, Japanese newspapers criticized the embassy at Washington for alleged failure in its duty in permitting the publication in America of "such indignities to the Japanese sovereign" as the caricature of Emperor Hirohito in the August issue of the magazine Vanity Fair, now banned in Japan.

There's quite a bit going on this evening, when you consider that it is still only early August. In the first place, "The Great Waltz," by Johann Strauss Sr. and Jr., and Moss Hart, will reopen at the Center Theatre after a vacation. A limited engagement, they call it, with Marie Burke, Guy Robertson, H. Reeves-Smith and all the rest present. . . .

While world consumption of United States cotton in the season just ended amounted to only about 11,314,000 bales, compared with 13,680,000 in the previous season, world consumption of foreign growths aggregated approximately 14,150,000 bales, against only 11,792,000 the season before, according to a report issued today by the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

Although there were fewer buyers in the wholesale markets here last week, the demand for Fall merchandise continued fairly active in various divisions. Buyers made substantial purchases of young men's and boys' clothing and accessories for back-to-school promotions, and there was also a lively call for girls' dresses and coats for August sales events.

HENRY DWIGHT SEDGWICK'S "In Praise of Gentlemen" (Little, Brown, $.2) might well qualify for the title of most exasperating book of the year. Any one who attacks it is in danger of being written down as no gentleman, yet it is full of subtle distortions and gratuitous assumptions, and it should, therefore, be attacked. The gentleman, says Mr. Sedgwick, is the product of privilege and property; hence he is anathema to democrats and humanitarians.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,334,433,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The question is being asked whether the American public is wine-minded. The average American citizen wants wine and likes wine, but is prevented from obtaining it on account of prohibitive prices and the many restrictions and red tape that make it so difficult to procure.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Cubs and Reds divided a double-header today, Cincinnati enjoying one big inning to clinch the first, 5 to 1, but dropping the second, 4 to 3.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Pope Pius was represented today as convinced that Italy must and will use force to obtain possession of Ethiopia, contrary to his fundamental belief that colonization should be achieved peacefully.

In the Riverdale residential area in the westerly Bronx section a plot 50 by 129 feet on Netherlands Avenue has been purchased by George A. Gottlieb. He is having plans prepared to erect a dwelling on the property. The plot is situated 183 feet north of 230th Street. Edgar J. Johnson was the broker in the sale.
ADOWA, Ethiopia (by mail). -- I was received by the Crown Prince Seyoum, ruler over this part of Ethiopia.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2. -- While occasional periods of activity developed on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange last week, trading as a whole was moderate. A general desire to await developments in Congress, uncertainty over the loan policy of the government for the new season and a general betterment of crop views were the main influences.

KRONSTADT, U.S.S.R., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The bodies of fifty-five officers and men of the Soviet Baltic fleet and students in Red naval schools who lost their lives when the submarine B-3 was rammed and sunk in the Gulf of Finland on July 25 were buried today in a single grave.

Now that August is rounding the corner, the Summer theatre situation is less out of hand. Several of the rural playhouses have closed their doors, and the current week is the final one for a few more. The list of new plays being tried out for New York managers is the smallest in some weeks, reading, as it does, like this:
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4. -- Entertaining afloat and in the open was popular here today.

Columbia University will shortly publish a new encyclopedia in one volume. It is said to be the first to be prepared and published by an American university. It is three inches thick, contains 2,000 pages, 52,753 separate articles and 5,000,000 words. Its editor, Dr. CLARKE F. ANSLEY, announces that it was prepared for "every man except the specialist."
BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- Eleven appointments and the promotion of thirty-three members of the faculty at Boston University were announced today by Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president.

With the 43-year-old infant of the diamond, Rabbit Maranville, putting on a merry sort of divertissement that added to the royal good humor of a crowd of 20,000, the top and the bottom of the National League concluded their immediate business at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a double-header that did not disturb either of the circuit's extremities.
Evolution does not mean moral progress, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., said yesterday in the fifth of a series of sermons at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 4. -- Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., added $500 to his prize collection today as he and Johnny Revolta, 23-year-old Milwaukee star, won the first annual Inverness invitational four-ball tournament.

Reporting the largest gross income and total volume of business for any like period in its history, the Phillips Petroleum Company, in its half-year statement made public today, shows gross income of $42,294,612, compared with $38,265,473 for the first six months of 1934.
PAWHUSKA, Okla., Aug. 4. -- The income of the Osage Indians, "richest people in the world," has begun to climb again after hitting a low mark in 1933.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- With the 2-year-old situation thoroughly confused by the racing in the West as well as by that here, the forthcoming week also holds the threat of upsetting the placid calm which has ruled in the 3-year-old ranks since Omaha so thoroughly dominated his opposition from the Kentucky Derby on.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation established headquarters here today to extend financial aid to property owners in flood-stricken Southern Tier New York communities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- A bill for regulation of national commerce which will provide "an American program of industrial construction" and which "will be constitutional," will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow by Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming, who announced its main outlines today.
A bright sun brought renewed tropical weather to the city yesterday and sent more than 2,000,000 men, women and children to beaches in the metropolitan area.

FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The romantic Indian scouts of the United States Army -- descendants of the same tribe ruled by such mighty chieftains as Geronimo, Mangus Colorado and Cochise -- were headed for oblivion today.

Characterizing the World War as the most idiotic and senseless thing that man ever did, the Rev. Dr. Robert H. Dolliver warned in his sermon at the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street, yesterday morning, that all signs pointed to another outbreak in Europe within the next few weeks.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- Bankruptcies in Germany numbered 227 in July, against 222 in June. Railroad Corporation carloadings fell slightly in June, but were 8 per cent higher than in June, 1934. While operating revenue of the railroad was 108,000,000 marks higher in the first half of 1935 than in the 1934 period and covered operating expenses, the corporation's contribution to the Reich and its fixed charges were not earned.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- The week-end barrage of official speeches and pronouncements is significant because it reveals Nazi spokesmen of varying ranks and calibre in a fighting mood rarely witnessed in recent months.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Never trailing and flashing a well-organized attack that gained momentum as the match progressed, the Sands Point polo four vanquished Greentree, 12 to 6, today before 1,500 fans in the weekly high-goal game at the Sands Point Club.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The Newark Bears completed their home stay today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Buffalo Bisons. The scores were 6 to 3 and 5 to 0. During their two weeks at Ruppert Stadium the Bears won twelve out of sixteen contests.

When Congress enacts a Tax Law which is confiscatory the public can grin and bear it. But when it enacts a tax which is in violation of an implied if not an expressed agreement, then there is just cause to complain.
A number of Catholic churches in the city celebrated yesterday with solemn high masses the feast days of two saints, St. Ignatius Loyola and St. Dominic.

One hundred emissaries of the Park Department sallied forth in search of antique shaving mugs to give away as prizes in the great Barber Shop Song Contest on the Central Park Mall next month. In the space of five hours no less than 8,000 specimens of the cup that beautified and cheered without intoxicating were run down, gilt scrolls and mottoes and all.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 4. -- As the radio service will be closed this afternoon it will be impossible to report comment on the League Council's decision, but there is far greater optimism here since the official report of Gaston Jeze's, Ethiopia's League delegate, was received today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Frank Parker of Spring Lake, N.J., fresh from his triumph in the Southampton invitation tournament, hurdled the first obstacle in defense of his Eastern grass court tennis championship today at the Westchester Country Club by defeating Thomas Flynn of Bayside, L.I., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, before a capacity crowd.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Big-hearted Uncle Sam's program of feeding, bedding and bathing the American hobo drew the ire today of the rovers' old enemy, the railroad detective.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 4. -- Steve O'Neill, coach of the Indians, tonight was named manager of the team as Walter Johnson resigned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The House Military Committee was disclosed today to have promised aid to Frank Speicher, key witness in its investigation of War Department business deals, in any legal proceedings that may arise from the inquiry.

Twenty-one years ago this morning it there appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES an interview of the night before with Professor SAMUEL T. DUTTON of Teachers College, Columbia University. In it, with singular prescience, he stated that we should see in the process of the war the most wholesale and comprehensive form of the reversion of civilized man to barbarism that the world had ever known.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Two men were killed and two injured today when two airplanes dropping down to a landing at Stinson Airport in suburban La Grange collided and plummeted 100 feet to the ground.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- If the government's efforts to promote recovery succeed, the French economic system will become better adapted to the conditions resulting from the world depression, and industry and trade will be in a better position to meet foreign competition, in the opinion of financial observers here.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., Aug. 4. -- The tournament ball was held at the Wyantenuck Country Club last night, with more than 300 present. It was the principal social activity of the gayest week-end of the Summer in Great Barrington. Mrs. Frederick A. Pearson was general chairman.

BRIELLE, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The drive against gambling and other law violations along the Jersey Coast, launched recently by Sheriff Howard Height of Monmouth County, received a surprise impetus last night when a score of detectives from Prosecutor T. Raymond Bazley's office swooped down the coast and raided three resorts.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Higher prices for pork, beef and mutton last week, with hogs up to $11.20 a hundred pounds, the highest price in almost seven years, gave the farmers, packers, butchers and consumers something new to think about as to supplies, both present and future.

The latest addition to the hymnody of Old New York, an opus entitled "Oh, the East Side Ain't the East Side Any More," has been registered at the Copyright Bureau at Washington by none other than Wireless Louis Zeltner, former Alderman, head of the East Side Wireless News Association and a singer of songs from Suffolk Street.

Three children were killed and six others, three of whom are less than 10 years old, were seriously injured during the week-end in the metropolitan area by automobiles whose drivers, losing control of their cars, ran up on the sidewalks.
MOSCOW, Aug. 4. -- There was no effort in Soviet circles to disguise the disappointment over the failure of the flight from Moscow to San Francisco via the North Pole.

Although Australia has very substantial secondary industries -- her workers are almost equally divided between primary and secondary industries -- she is dependent for her national income -- that is, her income from outside -- almost entirely upon the proceeds of the sales of her primary products abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- A possibility developed tonight that Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, might be called before the House committee investigating utility lobbying to disclose the part he is said to have played in urging the "death sentence" for utility holding companies.

The glowing personality of Jesus is lost in the man of today, the Right Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Ohio, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Filing of ten new registration statements under the Securities Act last week was announced by the SEC today for a total of $31,736,034.66. Most of the contemplated issues are for commercial and industrial purposes.

Mr. MCNARY, the Republican leader in the Senate, is convinced that if Congress is to adjourn by Aug. 20 no fewer than seven bills on the President's list will have to be postponed until the next session. He mentions them by name, though he might have left some of them out and put others in. In his main contention there is a good deal of force on the basis of the parliamentary situation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4. -- Although the Communist party is eager to unite with the more moderate elements in capitalist countries to combat Fascism, such a union would be only a marriage de convenance, to be abandoned when the Communists believe the time ripe to strike for the creation of Soviet governments in other countries.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Rain-swollen streams gushed through Westmoreland County today in the wake of week-end storms that lashed Western Pennsylvania, causing two deaths and thousands of dollars' worth of damage to property and crops.

Concrete evidence of favorable turns in public opinion regarding banking institutions is found in the reports of 96 per cent of more than 300 clearing houses throughout the United States which responded to a survey conducted by Banking, the monthly publication of the American Bankers Association.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Decorations of the Order of the Purple Heart, awarded for bravery in action, in that their recipients fought on after being wounded, were pinned upon seventeen New Jersey World War veterans at Camp Hoffman here today.

An appeal to the athletic authorities of the United States to move to have the Olympic Games of 1936 transferred from Berlin as a protest against the religious persecutions in Germany is contained in an editorial in today's issue of The Christian Century, Chicago, one of the most influential Protestant journals in the country.

MILL NECK, L.I., Aug. 4. -- This incorporated village, which has no unemployed, is better off than nearby Oyster Bay in that respect. Further, Mill Neck has devised a scheme for coping with its neighbor's relief problem.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston gave a large beach luncheon today for Miss Lesley Bogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert of New York and Anglesea, Newport, who is visiting Miss Margaret Van Horn Wagner at Red Top Farm.

"The church has a far higher mission than merely becoming the political lobbyist for pet theories of socialism," the Rev. Ralph E. Stewart, pastor of the Hildreth Baptist Church, Columbus, Ohio, declared yesterday afternoon in a sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Harry Kasabach, the defending champion from Ann Arbor, Mich., advanced to the semi-finals in the Armenian General Athletic Union tennis tournament yesterday at the Arrowhead courts. The titleholder registered an easy straight-set victory over Ed Zarmanian of Brooklyn, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, in the quarter-final.

Eugene C. Gibney, who until his death was head of the Bureau of Extension Activities of the Board of Education, misappropriated about $41,000 over an eight-year period, Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday in a report from Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

Howard C. Hopson, missing witness, who has been sought for weeks by the Senate Lobby Committee, won a victory yesterday in his fight to prevent the Federal Government from inspecting records of five corporations, all subsidiaries of the National Public Utilities Investing Corporation, of which he is president.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

A story of the strange influence of two necklaces worth $100,000 in the life of a quiet Negro porter who was haunted by fears so great that he kept the jewels hidden in a bureau drawer at his home for more than four years, was unfolded yesterday at police headquarters.

A suggestion of a joint meeting of the British Medical Association and of the American Medical Association in the interest of international harmony was received here yesterday with a hearty chorus of approval by a party of fifty-five eminent British physicians and surgeons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- President Roosevelt pledged his support to a compromise oil-control measure and indicated that he would send a message to Congress on it. He nominated Ernest G. Draper of New York to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce and received Joseph Grew, Ambassador to Japan.
MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 5. -- When tuna are not hitting in the offshore waters and sharks happen to be showing on the surface, a handy man to have aboard is an expert harpoon tosser.

Paul Kress, the German to whom Mayor La Guardia denied a masseur's license on the ground that Germany has discriminated against American citizens, announced yesterday that he would return to his homeland tomorrow night on the Hapag Lloyd liner Hamburg.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The narrow escapes from defeat experienced by Wilmer Hines of Columbia, S.C., and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., furnished the highlights of the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today as most of the ranking players in the men's singles indulged in a day of rest.
Mayor La Guardia was urged to eliminate the luxuries of government from the 1936 budget yesterday unless he wished to face a revolt against his administration.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A communication from Francis L. Baker, president of the Eastview Civic League, complaining in behalf of the league that inmates of the Westchester County Poorhouse at Eastview were wandering on public highways near the institution, and demanding that the Board of Supervisors of Westchester take action to confine the 700 inmates to the grounds of the poorhouse, was read at the August meeting of the board today.
Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the investigation into the city's organized crime, announced yesterday that he had appointed Mrs. Eunice Hunton Carter, Negro lawyer, a member of his staff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Ernest Gallaudet Draper of New York City was appointed by President Roosevelt today as Assistant Secretary of Commerce to fill the position vacated by the transfer of John Dickinson to the position of Assistant Attorney General.

No change was apparent in any igible for purchase or rediscount section of the money market, the by Federal Reserve Banks. Rates demand for fuz{ds running to small quoted are for discount at purchase: lines, while quotations remained Bid. asked. steady.

MIDDLEBURG, N.Y., Aug 5 (AP). -- Continuing his attack on State and national Democratic administrations, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, declared today that Governor Lehman "is losing ground in the public mind" because he "is taking orders from Washington."

TOKYO, Aug. 5. -- Domestic reasons resulting from the present state of national sentiment in Japan, which made a display of energy necessary, were hinted at by Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, today in a statement regarding the protest over the cartoon of Emperor Hirohito in Vanity Fair.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange continued to mark time yesterday pending a decision on the loans to be made to producers for the new season. After fluctuating within a range of a few points the list ended 3 points higher to 7 points lower than on Saturday.

George Cukor, the director, has signed a contract with Irving Thalberg to direct one picture a year for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. His first assignment under the new arrangement will be to direct Norma Shearer in a film transcription of "Romeo and Juliet," which is scheduled to enter production soon.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 5. -- The Ethiopian Government received no official notice of the League of Nations Council resolutions until 12:20 this afternoon, although the message was dispatched at 9 o'clock last night. After a speedy conference at Gibbi Palace between the Emperor and his Minister of Foreign Affairs and foreign advisers, the following communique of approval was issued:

The Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $1,924,810, after all charges, depreciation, taxes and a reserve of $900,000 for a possible future decline in the market value of inventories.

As public utility and petroleum issues vied for leadership in the share market yesterday, other groups maintained a steady to firm tone most of the day; the closing, on the average, was slightly easier. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,735,000 shares.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $3,832,061, equal to nearly 44 cents a share on 8,738,695 common shares, compared with $6,241,627, or more than 71 cents a share, in the preceding twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Aug 5. -- The bill to put the bus and truck transportation systems under authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission, one of the measures on the administration's "must" list, was completed by Congress today and sent to President Roosevelt for signature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- President Roosevelt was challenged by Senator Long today to speak on the same platform in a political debate either in Louisiana or elsewhere in territory over which the Louisianan is said to extend his influence.

Passage of the new tax bill by the House of Representatives was so surely indicated that the immense majority for the measure on yesterday's roll-call was no surprise. Chief interest centred in the question whether there would be any break in party lines. Would Republican Representatives vote for a bill which their party leaders denounce?

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- A cloudburst and an amazingly feeble brand of Boston pitching came as balm to soothe the wounds of the crippled Yankees at Fenway Park today, and the McCarthymen downed Joe Cronin's Red Sox, 10 to 2, to cut down by half a game the lead of the Tigers in the pennant race.

In crowded cities chivalry is no more and the horse is felt to be a nuisance, a delayer of traffic, a slowpoke. In New York the horse-drawn vehicle, always welcome to timorous pedestrians, is getting rarer. In London, according to the report of its Traffic Advisory Commission, from 1924 to 1933 vehicle traffic rose 29 per cent, horse traffic fell 61 per cent.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5. -- The Indians played heads-up baseball for their new pilot, Steve O'Neill, today, defeating the White Sox, 4 to 2. Ralph Winegarner, one of the Tribe's rookie hurlers, held the White Sox to seven hits.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Louise Schaffer Bauer was in technical custody of the police in a hotel tonight while prosecutors prepared for the arraignment in Felony Court tomorrow of her former suitor, Mandeville W. Zenge, who is charged with the mutilation-murder of Dr. Walter J. Bauer, her husband.

Bricklayers and members of other building trades unions employed on Works Progress Administration projects were reported yesterday to have walked out on their jobs as a protest against the reduced wage scales ordered by General S. Hugh Johnson, Works Progress Administrator.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 5 (AP). -- American athletes took five first places and three seconds while Finnish competitors collected three firsts and five seconds in a divided track meet held in the towns of Oulu and Joensuu today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5. -- That run-off primary election will be needed Sept. 7 to determine the choice of Kentucky Democrats for the Gubernatorial nomination appeared certain tonight on the basis of incomplete returns from Saturday's primary election.

ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- James N. Noonan, Albany lawyer who was with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer when the latter surrendered last November in the office of Federal Commissioner Lester T. Hubbard, was notified immediately by his client of the service of the Supreme Court order.

Under an agreement made last week in behalf of creditors of the closed Travelers' Bank in Paris, Bertrand Coles Neidecker and his brother, George W. Neidecker, as partners in Neidecker et Cie., who conducted the Travelers Bank, made an assignment yesterday to former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan, who represented several of the creditors in attachment suits brought here recently to tie up the assets of the Neidecker brothers.

STEPHEN FRANCIS O'NEILL is the new manager of the Cleveland Indians. Now there should be harmony on that club. In the words of the great Sir Toby Belch, here's a stout fellow who can "rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver." He has a mellifluous voice, a contagious breath.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 5. -- That Boston has gone gambling mad, with Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island joining the craze, seems well established by a glance at the season's betting figures, which reached an all-time single day's high on Saturday.
Wandering into the Polo Grounds yesterday in their customary carefree manner, the Dodgers received two shakings which, if they did them no serious harm, certainly did them no great good.

The lure of a soloist attracted to the Lewisohn Stadium last night the largest audience to date of the Summer concerts there, about 15,500 persons crowding the stands and field for the first of Jascha Heifetz's two appearances with the orchestra of Philharmonic-Symphony players.

Frederick A. Tuttle, principal defendant in the case built up by Samuel H. Kaufman, special assistant to the Attorney General, in the latter's investigation of an immigration racket, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Henry H. Goddard.

While prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were not disturbed to any great extent yesterday, there was considerably less interest on the part of traders. Transactions dropped to $7,713,400, compared with $9,163,800 on last Friday.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Edward S. Evans, Detroit manufacturer whose twenty-eight-day trip around the world established a new record in 1926, announced today that his two sons would participate in the next Harmsworth race in a "hydra-foil" boat which they believe the fastest water craft ever constructed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Through Commissioner Claude R. Porter and Oliver E. Sweet, director of its Bureau of Finance, the Interstate Commerce Commission began today the examination of the plan for the reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company presented by officers of the corporation.

For more than eighty years the Children's Aid Society has carried on its varied activities in behalf of underprivileged children in New York. And it still carries its burden of relief on its own voluntary shoulders like St. CHRISTOPHER, though, as his burden, its burden has grown heavier and heavier in the midstream of need.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Dr. H.M. Parshall of Urbana, Ohio, leading driver on the Grand Circuit last season, today gained his second straight major victory at Rockingham Park.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The conflict between the National Socialist State and the Catholic Church reached the stage of open declarations of war today when both sides issued fiery proclamations calling upon their followers to rally to the battle.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania has invited bankers to submit bids on Aug. 13 for a new issue of $50,000,000 tax-anticipation notes, dated Sept. 5, 1935, and maturing on May 31, 1937. Bidders are asked to name the interest rate on the notes not to exceed 4 1/2 per cent or, as an alternative, may quote a discount with no interest.

The report of the Department of Agriculture giving the condition and indicated yield of the current crop, which will be published on Aug. 8, is expected to show a substantial increase over the private estimates of around 10,500,000 bales a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A Presidential veto of the bill passed by Congress restoring benefits to veterans of the Spanish-American War which were cut in the Economy Act of 1933 was indicated at the White House today by officials who conferred with President Roosevelt.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 5.--Work was started today on the factory site at the 1,270-acre Jersey Homesteads Development, four miles southwest of Hightstown, the first of the self-contained community units to be established in the East by the Suburban Resettlement Administration, of which Rexford G. Tugwell is director.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Improved earnings for the Middle West Utili ties Company as well as for its subsidiaries were reported today by Daniel C. Green, trustee for the parent concern, which once was the keystone of the fallen Insull system.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 5. -- The Long Island Golf Association's regular weekly amateur-pro tournament at the Lido Country Club today appeared to be in the nature of a benefit for the two Mayos, Charles Sr., pro at the club, and his son, Charles Jr., present Long Island amateur champion, until the very last returns were posted.

COWES, England, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The fleet, dark-hulled Endeavour, T.O.M. Sopwith's unsuccessful America's Cup contender, scored a handy victory in the Class J yacht race today at the opening of the Cowes regatta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- An informal conversation today between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Hirosi Saito, Ambassador of Japan, apparently brought to a close international complications caused by publication of a cartoon in Vanity Fair satirizing Emperor Hirohito.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Tom Whittlesey maintained his perfect record in the Great South Bay Star Class elimination series by sailing his Argo home today at the head of a fleet of twelve in the third trial held over an eight-mile course in a brisk northwest breeze off the Babylon Yacht Club.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5. -- American Communists discussing American problems took a prominent part in today's session of the Communist International Congress. Earl Browder presided and William Z. Foster and Gil Green, head of the American branch of the League of Communist Youth, were among the chief speakers.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Orville Jorgens held the Braves to three hits as the Phillies bombarded Brown and Benton for a 9-1 triumph today in the first game of the series.
The Grace Line has taken for its first uptown passenger office a ground-floor shop in the Palazzo d'Italla, Rockefeller Center. The main office is in 10 Hanover Square.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Harassed Detroit butchers want the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to explain existing meat prices to the army of women whose buying strike has cost them thousands of dollars in spoilage and lost sales.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- The Bourse had an almost lifeless session today, with rentes making further slight progress and stocks holding even. Suez Canal issues again proved the exception with a heavy loss of 325 francs, thus continuing their sharp decline of last week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Starvation receipts of hogs and reports of a better movement of fresh pork resulted today in general buying of hogs here, with prices lifted 10 to 35 cents. The top of $11.35 a hundred pounds, exclusive of the processing the equaled the best level of September, 1930, while, including the tax of $2.25, it was the highest since October, 1926.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Another bill was added to the administration list facing Congress today when President Roosevelt gave his support to a compromise petroleum-control measure submitted to him by spokesmen for heretofore widely separated groups.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Aug. 5 (AP). -Francis Bolton Mallory, Hollywood editor and former husband of Nancy Carroll, who is honeymooning in Mexico with his shy, 14-year-old bride, Carlota Labato, has requested immigration authorities for permission to remain in the country for another six months.

Advances were scored yesterday in most of the local commodity futures markets. Sugar and cocoa eased moderately in quiet trading, and hides, coffee and silk futures were higher. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, eggs, lard, hides and silk advanced, while corn and cocoa declined.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 5 (AP). -- The yawl Belisarius, owned and sailed by Charles B. Rockwell Jr. of the Bristol, R.I., Yacht Club in Class A, and John Parkinson's sloop Praxilla of the Beverly Yacht Club in Class B today were declared winners of the centennial race around Block Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Senator James P. Pope of Idaho, member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and author of a joint resolution for this country's membership in the League of Nations, will sail for Europe Aug. 13 to confer if possible with Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin of Britain, Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, Premier Pierre Laval of France and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- About 72,000 "white collar" workers will be hired from local relief rolls under the work relief program to carry out three census projects under Commerce Department supervision, Secretary Roper announced today.

Buddy Baer, brother of the former heavyweight champion, was matched yesterday to fight Jack Doyle, the Irish heavyweight, at the Madison Square Garden bowl Aug. 22. James J. Johnston, promoter for the Garden, clinched the match and the formal signing of the contracts will take place today in his office.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Governor Lehman said at his press conference tonight that Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, was "trying to inject politics" into the New York flood relief situation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5. -- The Soviet railways are keeping up their remarkable gain in freight car loadings, which began almost immediately after L.M. Kaganovich took hold of this, the weakest link in the Soviet's industrial and defense system, on his appointment as Commissar of Transportation last February.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A warning that, unless the conferees on the Utilities Holding Company Bill reached a compromise which left some "teeth" in the measure, passage at this session of Congress might be blocked, was voiced today By Senator Wheeler, co-author of the original measure and leader in the fight for elimination of "unnecessary" holding companies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The House Military Committee was disclosed today to have promised aid to Frank Speicher, key witness in its investigation of War Department business deals, in any legal proceedings that may arise from the inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Senators slashed a full game off Philadelphia's hold on sixth place today by defeating the Athletics, 10 to 7, as Whitehill scored his tenth victory of the year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Operators on the Board of Trade who were talking bearish on wheat at the close of last week were much less confident of their position today. An effort to reinstate recently sold out lines disclosed a lack of aggressive selling both here and in the Northwest.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Cubs dropped four games behind the league-leading Giants today, losing to Cincinnati, 3 to 1, in the last game they have scheduled here this season. The victory gave the the Reds three out of five for the series and left the Cubs only two games ahead of the third place Cardinals.

ATHENS, Aug. 5. -- Civil disorders of a revolutionary character broke out in Heraclion, Crete, today and marked the culmination of a wave of general strikes protesting against the movement for a monarchist restoration. Five police officers and twelve soldiers were wounded during the street fighting.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The annual athletic review of the 2,000 youths at the Citizens Military Training Camp here was held today. Major Leonard Boyd of the Sixteenth Infantry, executive officer of the C.M.T.C., presented awards to the following men:

The six-story apartment house at 11-19 Hillside Avenue, in the Dykman section of Manhattan, has been purchased by Charles Walzer operator, through Schack Schack. The building, on a plot 125 by 200 feet, contains 285 rooms arranged in ninety suites, and is reported to have an annual rental roll of about $60,000.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation doubled yesterday the annual dividend rate on the common stock by declaring a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, equivalent to $2 a year. At the same time an extra dividend of 25 cents a share was declared.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Many new arrivals were in the clubhouse this afternoon for the second week of racing. Mr. and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, who anchored their yacht in the Hudson below Albany, are here enjoying the racing. They played golf at the Saratoga Golf Club with Edward Fish and John R. Fell Jr. this morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The tax-the-wealthy bill, designed to produce upward of $250,000,000 in new revenue, was passed by the House today by a vote of 282 to 96 and sent to the Senate.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 5 (By Wireless).--Our great ancestor, King Solomon, expressed the opinion that a wise man should roll his tongue seven times around his mouth before voicing his thoughts, and this maxim forms today the beginning of wisdom for a statesman.

Dr. PAUL JOSEPH GOEBBELS is back on the front page. Perhaps it would be exaggeration to say that it is a pleasure to meet him again, but omitting the pleasure, the reappearance of the Nazi Minister of Propaganda in the headlines is a fact to be noted.

To but few now in active politics will the name of FRANK HITCHCOCK, who died in Arizona yesterday, carry vivid memories. But in his day he was a leading actor on the political stage in this country. The chief office which he held for a brief period was that of Postmaster General.

Seeking to prevent issuance of a new American Federation of Labor charter to Charles Herbert, poultry racketeer, Acting Markets Commissioner Carl W. Kimball disclosed yesterday that Herbert was trying to organize a new poultry union after being ousted last Wednesday from Poultry Schochtim Union 440.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 5. -- Between fifteen and twenty thousand persons are expected to invade Salzburg within the next day or two after their trips over the Gross-glockner Road. The vanguard can already be seen dashing from one hotel to another in a more or less fruitless search for accommodations.

Next week will see at least two events in the Times Square district -- a matter of some consequence when you stop to consider that it will be the middle of August. The month's only opening will take place on Wednesday evening, when "Smile at Me" will test the water at the Fulton Theatre.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Consummation of the reorganization program whereby the elevators formerly operated by the Rosenbaum Grain Company were to be transferred to a new concern managed by the Norris Grain Company was delayed today by last-minute objections on the part of bondholders.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 5. -- In the last of three broadcasts to the Canadian electorate MacKenzie King tonight declared the Liberal party's policy looked to recovery before reform. He ridiculed Prime Minister Bennett's belief that reform would automatically produce recovery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Large-scale security sales during June by Y.P. Morgan Co., Alfred P. Sloan Jr., John J. Raskob and others prominent in financial circles were disclosed today when the Securities and Exchange Commission made public reports on stock transactions and holdings filed with it between July 1 and 10.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Little is heard from the subcommittee of Congress which, with Norman H. Davis and other representatives of the State Department, has for several weeks been discussing neutrality legislation. The silence is in inverse proportion to the detonations which conceivably could come from this group.

JOHN L. SPIVAK, whose "America Faces the Barricades" (Covici-Friede, $2.50) is an honest attempt to get at the facts of the industrial plight of the United States in this year of grace, used to be a first-rate tabloid reporter. He has a happy faculty of asking outrageously leading questions in such a debonair and insinuating way that his victim is usually perturbed and nonplused into telling him what he wants to know.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The $249,000,000 PWA low-cost housing and slum clearance program is being impeded and delayed by high appraisals which other government agencies have put on property in areas the PWA wishes the acquire.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5. -- Thirty-two women golfers, their goal the "Queen of the West" crown, battled their way into the match play round of the women's Western tournament today -- shunting the rest of the field of 120 into the lower flights which have no bearing on the title.

Federal agricultural policies have dealt a severe blow to American cotton in the British textile market, with losses of cargos to American ships operating from the South Atlantic and Gulf ports, according to George M. Massey, American representative of the Manchester Ship Canal Company.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Mawry O'Connor, Branch Brook professional, and Byron Nelson, Ridgewood sharpshooter, carded 70s over the par 71 Monmouth County Country Club course to lead the field in the New Jersey P.G.A. tournament today.

The faithful met again last night at Fifty-fourth Street's Adelphi Theatre, where Lodewick Vroom's Gilbert and Sullivan seminar moved on to a week of "The Gondoliers." It should be obvious from that pair of statements that the occasion produced no very intense surprises either for those who have looked in on Mr. Vroom's offerings of recent weeks, or even for those who remember the Milton Aborn productions from which these are directly descended.

An exhibition commemorating the 250th anniversary of the births in 1685 of Johann Sebastian Bach and George Frederick Handel will open today at the New York Public Library. The display will be in the smaller exhibition room on the first floor near the Fifth Avenue entrance and will continue until after Labor Day.

Ten Manhattan properties and six in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The offerings included various apartment houses of six stories or less, in addition to several dwellings and business structures.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Senate lobby committee tonight planned a deep-cut investigation of what it termed the recent "whispering" campaign against President Roosevelt.
ELKTON, Md., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Billboards advertising Elkton's two "marrying ministers" came down in a hurry as a new town ordinance outlawing them went into effect today.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 5. -- Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer was served today with an order directing him to appear before Supreme Court Justice William H. Black in New York on Thursday for examination in connection with his State income tax for the years 1929, 1930 and 1931.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Moving with unexpected speed the State opened today the trial of Mrs. Blanche Dunkel and Mrs. Evelyn Smith for murder of Mrs. Dunkel's son-in-law, Ervin Lang, 28-year-old grocery clerk, before Acting Chief Justice Cornelius J. Harrington of the Criminal Court.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 5. -- An indication of how strained relations between the Holy See and Germany have become was given today by the Pope, who expressed the opinion that difficult times were ahead in an address delivered to fifty German boys belonging to the Catholic Action movement of Trier archdiocese whom he received in his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Millions of Londoners flocked home tonight bronzed by the Summer sun after the most brilliant August bank holiday any of them could remember.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- A loss of 408,089 was reported today by Cunard White Star, Ltd., in its first annual statement since the merging of the two former rival companies.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug. 5. -Great Britain's polo invasion of America started this morning when thirty-four ponies of the Hurlingham team, seventeen grooms, including their own farrier, and two of the players arrived aboard the American Merchant liner American Trader.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -The hundreds of contract bridge players who have convened here for the week of play for the American Bridge League's Summer championships believe in solid comfort.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- A survey of Federal agencies in New Jersey, as the basis of a report to President Roosevelt to determine the effects of the national administration's recovery program, was launched here today by Peter Grimm, recently appointed assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

With Fall prices up an average of 5 to 7 per cent yesterday, rug manufacturers were talking of another advance of approximately the same size, to be put into effect late next month or early in October. At practically all showrooms where Fall lines of rugs and carpets were displayed in the industry's formal opening of the new season's lines,

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Members of the Newport Art Association will show a collection of about forty paintings, as well as a number of etchings, in the Guild Hall Galleries here from Aug. 15 to Sept. 4, inclusive.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5. -- New York's entry in the Union Printers International Baseball Tournament scored two victories today to become a favorite to annex the title. The New Yorkers trounced Washington, defending champion, 8 to 6, in the first contest, and then beat Chicago 10 to 4.

The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad expects to have a plan of reorganization ready by September, it was said at the company's office yesterday. No comment was offered as to whether the company would have recourse to the Bankruptcy Law to put the plan through, although if the precedent followed by the Western Pacific, owner of one-half of the control of the Rio Grande, is followed, this step will be taken.

The General Electric Company will offer at public auction tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. through Adrian H. Mueller Son, at 18 Vesey Street, 390 shares of $100 par-common stock of Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and 691 shares of $100 par-common stock of Commonwealth Edison Company.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The major political parties had mobilized all their forces tonight for the showdown at tomorrow's special First District Congressional election on President Roosevelt's New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- About 27,600,000 acres in "rented or contracted" land, or about one-twelfth of the cultivated land in the United States, have been shifted from "surplus basic crops" this year under 1935 adjustment contracts and are now being used largely to produce forage crops of vegetables, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Taking his first match without the loss of a game, Robert Harmon of Los Angeles, seeded No. 1 in the junior singles, eliminated Don Cramer, Plymouth, Ind., today as the national junior and boys' tennis championships opened on the courts of Culver Military Academy.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 5. -- Marblehead race week's second major event was held under very poor racing conditions today. The larger craft sailed through two hard rain and thunder squalls and the smaller boats had to weather one. Although there was plenty of warning of what was to happen, the boats again turned out in droves, 333 competing.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 5. -- As a prelude to the twentieth annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, thirty-one boats sailed today in an invitation event conducted by the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club. It marked the club's thirty-fifth anniversary.

EASTBOURNE, England, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Yale doubles team of Edward Mansfield and George Stevens outlasted its British rivals in a three-hour struggle today for the decisive point which gave the combined Yale-Harvard forces victory over the Oxford-Cambridge team and possession of the Bernon S. Prentice International Intercollegiate Cup.

Reorders on fur coats proved a feature of the business reaching this market yesterday, with the resident offices here reporting the volume as the best for several years. Additional volume in cloth coats proved somewhat spotty in accord with the varied results retailers are obtaining on cloth coat offerings throughout the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 5. -- General Hugh S. Johnson took time out today from his duties as New York Works Progress Administrator and made a flying and unsolicited visit to the session of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in the Hotel Ambassador here.
PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Owing to causes as yet unexplained, France's painstakingly perfected stratospheric airplane crashed today near Toussus le Noble and was destroyed by flames.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Growth of sentiment hostile to President Roosevelt and the New Deal were reported to the Republican Grass Roots Committee of fifty from ten Midwestern States gathering here today for a two-day session.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 5. -- Applications by several Americans of wealth and social prominence for permission to purchase real property in this British colony were published in the local press during the past week.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 5 (AP). -Former Supreme Court Justice John E. Mack, counsel to the New York State Utilities Investigating Committee, labeled as "praise" today a charge of the Associated Gas and Electric Company that his committee was seeking "passage of drastic Federal utility legislation."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Although a stiff breeze blew across the rolling 6,440-yard course of the Lawrence Farms Golf Club today, causing well-hit shots to deflect out of bounds, Joe Donate and Fred Pagano of the Amawalk Club shot a 67, five under par, to win the pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P.G.A.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -Another slaughter of favorites took place today, the general collapse of form carrying down C.V. Whitney's Today, which was attempting a come-back to competition after casting a shoe in the Kentucky Derby.

The first continuous assembly plant ever built for the production of Diesel-electric locomotives is being constructed by the General Motors Corporation at the McCook, Illinois factory of the Electro-Motive Corporation, a General Motors subsidiary.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 5.--Carded and combed yarn spinners from all parts of the country representing 3,000,000 spindles met here today and passed a resolution concerning the cotton processing tax.

The proposed order setting minimum wage schedules for women and minors in hotels and restaurants in the State was criticized yesterday as "unfair and unscientific" by attorneys for the hotel industry at the first of a series of public hearings before Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

Thomas F. Manville Jr., only son and heir to a large part of the estate of the founder of Johns-Manville, Inc., was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for a separation by his fourth wife, the former Marcelle Edwards, a show girl. The papers were served on Manville at the office of his attorneys, the law firm headed by George W. Olvany, former Tammany leader.

ROME, Aug. 5. -- The partial nature of the success scored by Italy in Geneva was emphasized today by half-hearted press comment. All the newspapers underline the fact that the League Council's deliberations recognized the justice of the thesis Italy set forth, but the tone of their remarks was in a minor key and they were completely lacking in the paeans of joy they are in the habit of singing on the slightest provocation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--Merger of the Inland Steel Company and Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc., Chicago steel concerns, was approved tonight by the boards of directors of the two companies. Combined assets of the two companies will be $116,705,502.

Charging the Actors Equity Association with making "non-cooperative rulings" which may serve "increasingly to encircle the problem of theatrical production with mounting difficulties from the point of view of capital and labor," the League of New York Theatres, representing most of the producing managers, has submitted a brief to the members of the Equity council strongly protesting against a recent ruling of the council requiring pay for rehearsals.

ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- Governor Lehman presided today at a preliminary meeting of the Advisory Committee which is to map a program for the crime conference next October. It was an executive session, with thirty of the thirty-four members of the committee attending.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 5. -- The two biggest demonstrations Puerto Rico has seen in a decade, one for and one against Governor Blanton Winship, were held today on the Governor's return from Washington after receiving an allotment of $42,500,000 for island reconstruction work.

An informed public opinion is a necessary antecedent to attempts at improvement by legislation. Otherwise even a good law may be ignored or thwarted, or by a tacit universal agreement honored in the breach. Prohibition failed, not because the objective of the law was bad in itself, but because there had not been a prior development of a genuine public sanction.

A new issue of $20,000,000 first mortgage sinking fund 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series A, due on Sept. 1, 1955, of the Cudahy Packing Company, will be offered to the public today at 100 flat. The offering is being made by a banking group including Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.,

PITTSBORO, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Bodie Bates, a Negro accused of attempting to attack a 22-year-old white woman of Pittsboro Saturday night, was lynched by a mob which stormed the Calhoun County jail last night. The body was found swinging from a rope under a Yalobusha River bridge.

It may of interest to some of your readers to learn of a tense battle that has been fermenting for some weeks now between President James E. Finegan of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Timothy J. Sullivan, vice chairman of the Board of Aldermen, over the so-called "highbrow" requirements set for applicants for Market Supervisor.

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- Given a strong stretch ride by Bert Wimmer, Hoosiers Pride, gelded brown son of Blondin, galloped home a half-length in front in the Lenox Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature of today's card at Suffolk Downs. The winner was an outsider at 9-1.

Slavery in Ethiopia, an issue in the international disputes involving that country, gradually is disappearing under a policy of systematic abolition, according to Gordon MacCreagh, author of "The Last of Free Africa," which Appleton-Century is issuing in a new edition.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5. -- The State Supreme Court denied a petition brought by Tom Mooney today offering $1,000,000 bail for temporary release from prison so he might aid at the taking of depositions in the East on his habeas corpus application.

Your today's editorial on the above subject furnishes ample food for reflection and profitable study to sanitarians, agriculturists, social economists and, above all, to the rulers of countries who, in order to acquire strips of land or commercial advantages, are only too ready to sacrifice the flower of their youth instead of making life more happy to them on the land they already own.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 31 showed decreases for the week of $211,000,000 in total loans and investments and $27,000,000 in net demand deposits, and an increase of $166,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

In one of the most severe criticisms yet leveled against the administration's pending inheritance and income tax legislation, Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, charges that the bill as now drawn will force changes in control of great industries and bankrupt large estates.

Simon Lake's quest for the half-legendary gold of the British ship Hussar, which sank in 1780 in the East River off what is now 132d Street, was resumed again yesterday in the swift tide rips and currents of the Hell Gate vicinity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- As a means of reviving the tabled resolution authorizing the Treasury to mint sub-penny coins, Secretary Morgenthau may compromise with the House Coinage Committee and drop the provisions for broad discretionary powers contained in the original draft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Reaching complete agreement on the long-contested amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration Act, Senate and House conferees today retained the Senate provision permitting suits for recovery of illegally collected processing taxes, but decided that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue must first rule if the taxes have been passed on to the consumer.

Three spectacular fires in widely scattered communities of the metropolitan area late last night and early this morning caused hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of damage and threatened to spread into residential districts until checked by fire-fighting forces.

Three spectacular fires in widely scattered communities of the metropolitan area late last night and early this morning caused hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of damage and threatened to spread into residential districts until checked by fire-fighting forces.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Because of delay in transmission of the police report on the circumstances of the death of Helmuth von Gerlach, noted German pacifist exile, who died here suddenly Friday, an autopsy could not be performed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Impressed by arguments that the Guffey Coal Bill is unconstitutional because of the penalty tax for non-compliance with its provisions, the Ways and Means Committee seems likely to report the bill to the House without recommendation, according to Chairman Doughton.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey sat from 10:30 A.M. yesterday until 8:30 o'clock last night in the Woolworth Building hearing arguments for and against allowances of $309,184 in fees to lawyers and others in connection with the reorganization of the Republic Gas Corporation under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5.--E.P. Cramer of Plainfield, N.J., an assistant in the advertising department of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., here, was dismissed by the concern today. Notice of Mr. Cramer's discharge was made public in a statement from Charles Edison, president of the organization.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 5. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green, who is to open formally the Navy Relief Society Ball on the evening of Aug. 31, has taken a box at the ball for his guests.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5.--E.P. Cramer of Plainfield, N.J., an assistant in the advertising department of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., here, was dismissed by the concern today. Notice of Mr. Cramer's discharge was made public in a statement from Charles Edison, president of the organization.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 5. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green, who is to open formally the Navy Relief Society Ball on the evening of Aug. 31, has taken a box at the ball for his guests.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Joe Louis, undefeated young Negro heavyweight who will meet King Levinsky in a ten-round bout here Wednesday night at Comiskey Park, was a prohibitive favorite today to continue his string of victories at the expense of Levinsky.

Fresh northwest winds swept over the city yesterday, reducing the temperature from Sunday's tropical 90 degrees to an average of 76, two degrees above normal. The day's high was 81, recorded at 3:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, said today that he would devote his third year as coordinator to obtaining action on recommendations for improving the condition of the railroads and their service that have been made by his staff.

As a result of a warning by Charles H. Tuttle, attorney for a group of merchandise creditors, that the entire plan for reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation would have to be dropped unless the matter of landlord claims was settled, attorneys for various objecting landlords agreed yesterday to fix the total of their claims so that a reserve could be set up against it.

Negotiations between officials of the Motion Picture Operators Local 306 and officials of the RKO and Loew's theatres over wage reductions ordered by the two circuits resulted in a deadlock last night.

TO write a successful satire that is also a successful fantasy must be the most difficult of auctorial feats. If the analogies between the fantastic and the human become too pat and mechanical, the obviousness of the parallels kills interest in the satire. If, on the other hand, the fantasy becomes too completely divorced from human meaning, it will carry no conviction that it is important to read.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 6. -- The Lenox art room in the old Academy of Lenox, built in 1803, was opened this afternoon with a preview of etchings, drawings for etchings and lithographs in honor of the board of governors and associate members.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6. -- The third and final day of the Eastern Yacht Club's part of Marblehead race week found many groups not racing because of a northeast storm. However, 206 yachts competed and the Q Class had the only casualty.

Bail of $2,500 was set by Magistrate Lindau in Yorkville Court yesterday for James Hinton, Negro porter, from whose pocket police recovered two pearl necklaces, missing four years and valued at $100,000. His wife, Ethel, was held in $1,000 bail.
FREE CITY OF DANZIG, Aug. 6 (AP). -The customs war between Danzig and Poland went into full swing today, with reprisals for emergency measures from both sides developing gradually to a clinlax.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Business activity was reported by the Commerce Department today to have shown resistance to Summer slump influences in July.

COPIAGUE, L.I., Aug. 6. -- The training at artificial respiration that Richard Nehring, 15 years old, received last Winter with the Bronxville (N.Y.) Boy Scout troop resulted in saving the life of Nelly Biandi, 11 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julio Biandi of Copaigue, at the beach here this afternoon.

Park employes of the State of Illinois took steps here yesterday to protect their interest in a benefit and annuity fund, $128,000 of which is represented in the face value of bonds of the defunct Chicago Joint-Stock Land Bank.
