WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The menace of a strike of all marine unions on the Pacific Coast when the present agreement expires on Sept. 30, predicted at a meeting of the Communist International in Moscow last week, was averted today when the two unions broke away from the "united front" cemented by Harry Bridges, radical San Francisco longshoremen's leader, and agreed to release the steamship Point Clear, tied up at San Francisco.

Prices of most commodity futures were irregular in the markets here yesterday. Sugar, cottonseed oil and some of the metals had a firmer tone. Trading generally was fairly brisk. On the cash markets rye, lard, cotton and silk advanced. while wheat, corn, oats, flour and rubber were easier.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Mrs. A.S. Phillips of the Westchester Country Club today won the low gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Rye Country Club. There were 104 players in the field.

Paul W. Kress, who was denied a masseur's license by the Mayor on the ground that Germany has discriminated against American citizens, denied in a speech last night that in returning to his native Germany he is "running away from a fight."

Salary increases and provision for additional workers totaling $112,060 were asked yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, for the personnel of his department at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 6. -- The Legion of Valor of the United States, composed of persons who have won the Distinguished Service Cross or Congressional Medal of Honor, condemned the "academic freedom" resolution of the National Education Association today and demanded that recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States be abrogated.

Before the Senate Finance Committee yesterday Mr. ROBERT H. JACKSON, counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue, gave precious testimony in behalf of righteousness. The poor are taxed much too much, the rich much too little. The former are to be relieved by plucking the latter.

The appointment of a commission of ten lawyers headed by State Senator John J. McNaboe to investigate racketeering in guaranteed mortgage certificates was announced yesterday by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at its office at 29 Broadway.

A stronger tendency on the part of retailers to anticipate their ready-to-wear requirements for a longer period in advance than has been the case for the last several years was reported yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Apparel Trade Executives held at the offices here of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The Democrats of Westchester County, at their annual convention in the Grace Church parish house here tonight, named a complete county ticket for the Fall elections. Miss Ruth Taylor, incumbent Republican Commissioner of Public Welfare, was endorsed for re-election.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Robert Harman of Los Angeles, favorite in the national junior tennis championship, pounded his way through two easy matches today to enter the fourth round. Robert Riggs of Los Angeles and Don Leavens of Milwaukee, next in the seeded list, also advanced.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The annual yearling and thoroughbred sales began at Saratoga tonight with the dispersal of the Inverness Farm yearlings, mares and the stallion Flying Ebony.

The article "Charm of Brooklyn's Shore Road Being Revived as Park Project," in the second news section of today's TIMES, gives an excellent pen-picture of this development and also revives historical memories. One portion of this project, however, is missing -- but possibly it was inadvertently overlooked.
Timothy J. Sullivan, impressively arrayed in five city titles, including that of Acting Mayor, presided over a special meeting of the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 6 (AP). -- E.J. Baker's Greyhound, reputed to be the best 3-year-old trotter in training, today showed the New England light harness fans why he is a 1-2 favorite for next week's $40,000 Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, N.Y. This gelded son of Peter the Great competed against six Grand Circuit rivals and swept all three heats.

GENEVA, Aug. 6. -- Gaston Jeze, representing Ethiopia, sent a note today to Alessandro Lessona, Italian Under-Secretary for Colonies, inviting Italy to instruct her arbitrators to meet Ethiopia's arbitrators without delay to name a fifth arbitrator in accordance with the League of Nations Council's resolution of Aug. 3. In this move lies a hint of possible difficulties on this point.

Wallace Beery and Lionel Barrymore have been chosen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to head the cast of its film production of Eugene O'Neill's play "Ah, Wilderness!" in which George M. Cohan appeared last season under the auspices of the Theatre Guild.

The daily average production of gross crude oil in the United States last week amounted to 2,634,350 barrels, compared with 2,734,650 in the previous week, a decline of 100,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 61,600 and 25,150 barrels in the daily average output of Texas and Oklahoma, respectively, were the most important changes.

MUNICH, Aug. 6. -- The Government News Agency announced tonight as an example of Jewish "insolence" the case of the president of the Jewish Community House in Fischach, near Augsburg, Hugo Della, who had been forced to stand in the centre of the market place holding an anti-Jewish placard over his head while a Storm Troop leader made an anti-Semitic speech to the populace.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The appointment of Viscount Cranborne as Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was announced tonight and thus the Foreign Office will in the future be represented in Parliament by four Ministers -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary; Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs; Lord Cranborne and Earl Stanhope, Under-Secretary in the House of Lords.

"ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- Up-State hotel men and restaurant representatives voiced a demand today for a differential in their favor against the minimum wages proposed for New York City as they appeared at a hearing conducted by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, on the question of minimum wages proposed for 60,000 women and minors employed in the hotels and restaurants.

The body of Prince Abdul Kerim of the deposed royal house of Turkey, who shot and killed himself early last Saturday, was claimed at Bellevue Morgue yesterday by George C. Apostle, an undertaker, who removed it to his establishment at 455 West Forty-third Street.

Directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., yesterday declared a dividend of 15 cents a share on the common capital stock, payable on Sept. 16 to stock of record of Aug. 23. The company paid a dividend of 115 cents a share on March 15, making payment for this year 30 cents, compared with 60 cents in 1934.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Prominent arrivals to enjoy the races and a visit to the new Saratoga Spa are Governor George H. Earle and Mrs. Earle of Philadelphia. They have leased a cottage at the United States Hotel and will be joined Thursday by the Governor's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Victor C. Mather of Avonwood Cottage, Haverford, Pa.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 6. -- The Ethiopian National Red Cross Society was inaugurated this afternoon by Emperor Haile Selassie in a canvas pavilion, hung inside with dark red velvet, which had been erected near the Ras Makonnen Bridge.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- With twenty-five Star Class yachts competing for the Commodore George A. Corry trophy and ninety-nine other craft of miscellaneous types turning out, the Great South Bay's twentieth annual race week got off to a flying start today at the Babylon Yacht Club.

Unless reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation is effected within the next year, the company is likely to suffer serious loss of revenue, James B. Simpson, Operating manager, representing the Irving Trust Company, trustee, testified yesterday at a hearing before Robert P. Stephenson, special master, in his offices at 29 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson ordered the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company today to show cause on Sept. 17 why an order should not be entered requiring the road to submit a plan of reorganization to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Nov. 1.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6. -- The present overtures of the Comintern (Communist International) to more moderate Left elements in the capitalist world for formation of a united front against fascism has for its purpose establishment of a "united front" of governments wherever possible, which, in turn, would be merely stepping stones toward completely Soviet governments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Contrasting by inference the spirit of solidarity among the twenty-one New World nations that had brought about peace in the Chaco between Bolivia and Paraguay with international wrangling "in another part of the world," Secretary of State Hull said today that the way now was open to banish war eternally from this hemisphere.

Expansion of employment service for "white-collar" workers is indicated in the announcement of a lease to the New York State Employment Service of the State Department of Labor, of an additional floor in the Lexington Tower Building, 369 Lexington Avenue.

ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 6. -- Official reports stated today that complete order had been restored in Crete, thanks to the energy of General Bakopoulos, commander-in-chief of the military forces of the island. The general revolutionary strike was reported at an end.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The big test will confront Joe Louis, the sensational young Negro heavyweight from Detroit, tomorrow night. Louis, whose rise to the top ranks of the heavyweight division in the short space of thirteen months has been the wonder of modern boxing, will face King Levinsky, the eccentric but durable Chicagoan, in a ten-round bout at Comiskey Park.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The stock markets reopened quietly but cheerfully today after a holiday since last Friday. Outstanding in the operations was the continued activity of industrials, the better sentiment being helped by strength in the United States markets over the week-end.
It is quite possible that the Dodgers meant the Giants no serious harm as they concluded their two-day sojourn on the Harlem yesterday, but they fairly burned up the Terrymen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Republicans here were jubilant tonight over the victory won by Charles F. Risk, Republican candidate in the Rhode Island Congressional election.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6. -- The Casino Theatre, under the auspices of the Actor Managers, Inc., this evening presented Laurette Taylor in her own comedy, "At Marian's." Several informal early dinner parties preceded the performance. Those who entertained box parties were Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss and Mrs. Walter Belknap James, Mrs. Joseph Benjamin Long, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Maxim Karolik, Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly and Mrs. Moses Taylor.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation, in its report for the year ended on May 31, shows a net profit of $179,568, as against a net loss of $59,000 in the previous fiscal year. The $179,568 equals about 64 cents a share, contrasted with a loss of 22 cents a share in 1933-34.

There were eighty-eight new cases of infantile paralysis reported in the city last week. While this is a sharp increase over the previous week, the cases are scattered and Health Department officials are not alarmed. Dr. Charles F. Bolduan, Director of Public Health Education, pointed out that infantile paralysis always increases during the Summer, and the number of new cases is far below the corresponding week of 1931, when there were 591 New cases.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was devoted largely to the secondary and lower grade issues. Although the averages for representative bonds eased moderately, the price structure of the higher grade investment issues was not disturbed appreciably.

Justice Riegelman in Kings County Supreme Court yesterday signed a permanent injunction against J. Frank Brooks and J. Frank Brooks Co., Inc., at 32 Broadway from engaging in further sale of securities in this State. The court also appointed Louis Lorence of 60 Wall Street as receiver for both Brooks and the corporation.

PEIPING, Wednesday, Aug. 7. -- Tao Shang-ming, former Chinese inspector, who called at the Japanese Embassy here, is being "detained at the embassy for investigation" in connection with the murder of a Chinese colonel in the demilitarized zone and the wounding of a Japanese sergeant of the railway guard.

Although the supply of important new State and municipal bond issues is relatively scarce now because of the seasonal influence and a general lack of interest by investors, prospects for a substantial pick-up next month are bright. A total of more than $23,000,000 in various new State and municipal loans already is reported in bond circles as a possibility, subject, of course, to the approval of voters.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Bob Smith held the Phillies to three hits today and the Braves triumphed by 4 -- 0.

Cleto Locatelli, one of the leading contenders for the lightweight title, fought his way to a well-earned decision over Harry Dublinsky of Chicago in ten rounds at the Coney Island Velodrome last night. A crowd of 6,000 saw the contest, which was filled with action from the first round to the last.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee said tonight, after committee investigators, armed with a subpoena, had journeyed to the Virginia estate of Patrick J. Hurley in search of H.C. Hopson:

The strike of skilled workers against their $93.50 monthly "security wage" on Works Progress Administration projects continued to spread yesterday as more bricklayers, plasterers and ironworkers quit their jobs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 6. -- Announcement was made here this afternoon by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, president and publisher of The Chattanooga Times, of the appointment of Julian LaRose Harris as executive editor of that newspaper.

Three robbers calmly drew up beside a car stopped on a traffic light at Prospect Avenue and 156th Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, held up the two occupants and made away with a bank bag containing $46,250 in cash and checks which belonged to Krasne Brothers, wholesale grocers, of 581 Austin Place, the Bronx.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer criticized and denied yesterday an application for an examination before trial of Howard C. Hopson, executive of the Associated Gas and Electric System, who is being sought by the Congressional committee investigating lobbying on the utility "death sentence" bill.

The lopsidedness of our income-tax structure has frequently been commented upon by tax authorities. It is not merely the new bill that is a "soak-the-rich" measure; our taxes even in their present form are primarily such. Their class nature is evident from the briefest scrutiny of returns for 1932.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Wednesday, Aug. 7. -- President Roosevelt and his New Deal program took a sharp setback in the special Congressional election held yesterday, when the Democratic candidate in the First District race was defeated by his Republican opponent.

Mrs. George Simmons, who is the wife of a Marshall, Mo., farmer, but who looked more like a guest at a Long Island garden party, declared before the Women's National Republican Club yesterday that President Roosevelt, aware or unaware, was following the Moscow pattern of government and would turn this nation into a Communistic State.

A new record for the season of Summer concerts was set at the Lewisohn Stadium last night when the second appearance of Jascha Heifetz as soloist with the orchestra from the Philharmonic-Symphony attracted in excess of 17,000 persons.

A new issue of $399,000 school bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1934, and payable Aug. 1, 1943 to 1954, of Sioux Falls (S.D.) Independent School District has been awarded to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago and Justus F. Lowe Company of Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The Guffey bill, which is sticking hard in the Ways and Means Committee of the House and standing as a high barrier to the adjournment of Congress, has grown from a legislative midget to a giant in a few months. When it was introduced it was regarded as an interesting political gesture by the new Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania toward his constituents.

Seventeen Manhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. The largest parcels were an eighteen-story office building at 32-34 Broadway and a twelve-story apartment house at 103-09 East Eighty-sixth Street.
The councils of the Actors Equity Association and the Chorus Equity Association decided yesterday to permit their members to appear in Sunday performances in this State.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 . -- The statement made by Robert H. Jackson, counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, at the Senate Finance Committee's tax hearing today was as follows:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Sixteen of the nation's leading women golfers, representing eight States, went into the second round of the Western championship with victories at the Westwood Country Club today.

Contracts for railway equipment exceeding $2,000,000 in value have been awarded to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company by the Board of Transportation of New York City, calling for accessories for new subway cars ordered for city-operated lines.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y, Aug. 6. -- The first double winner of the Saratoga meeting was returned when the Howe Stable's Kate, a 5-year-old mare by Westwick, captured the Ticonderoga Purse of a mile today at the Spa. It was a four-horse race, but for almost six furlongs it was a keen contest with George D. Widener's Chicstraw forcing the pace.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 6. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes of Washington ended a month's sojourn at the Mount Washington today and departed for Buffalo. They will cruise the Great Lakes to Duluth, motoring thence to the Yellowstone Park and later visiting the Canadian Rockies.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 6. -- Referring to a recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES in which he was represented as emerging as Mexico's "strong man" in succession to General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President Emilio Portes Gil today issued the following statement:

What is all this noise about the Kress case? I was kept for ten months in solitary confinement in a Nazi prison for no other reason than voicing "silently" in my notebook pacifistic opinions. I was tried and acquitted by the People's Court in Berlin. Did the German press get excited about my rights to be tried earlier as a foreigner?

JOHNSON CITY, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, charged tonight that the Roosevelt administration was attempting to "Sovietize" the nation by appeals to "the emotions and to class prejudices."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- "I was thrilled by the oratory I heard," Senator Glass, chief conferee, said with a smile as he emerged from the conference on the Banking Bill today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The question whether the Securities and Exchange Commission will force large corporations to divulge salaries paid to executives received new attention today when the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey filed a registration statement for a $4,350,000 stock issue without making public any of the company's salaries.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Lancashire and Yorkshire, cricket rivals for years, fought a stern battle in the county cricket championship during the past three days, the White Rose emerging victorious by seven wickets. The match was a personal triumph for William Bowes, Yorkshire fast bowler, who captured twelve wickets for 99 runs.

BOLTON LANDING, Lake George, Aug. 6. -- Mrs. James L. Hand of New York gave a tea in honor of the tennis committee for the annual Sagamore tennis tournament to be held on Aug. 14-15. Paul Martin of Troy, defending champion in the men's singles, and Philip Maguire of Saratoga Springs, winner of the boys' singles in the Sagamore junior tournament on Sunday, were guests of honor.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Florence Jackson, one of three women companions of William Lee Ferris, on trial with him for the slaying of Howard Carter Dickinson, New York lawyer, testified today that Ferris sought in vain for "some papers" in the lawyer's pockets after Mr. Dickinson had been shot to death in Rouge Park here June 26.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Faced with demands in Congress for cancellation of the Boy Scout Jamboree here this month because of the danger of infantile paralysis infection, Surgeon General Cumming reported today that evidence of the disease had virtually disappeared from the Northern Virginia area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A new record for recent times in American exports of iron and steel was established in June, when 289,867 gross tons was shipped, as compared with 286,599 in May and 219,406 in June, 1934, the Department of Commerce reported today.

IT would be a dreadful shock to the followers of the fancy if Kingfish Levinsky, the furious fishmonger, fought a whale of a fight and left Shufflin' Joe Louis as flat as a flounder on the Chicago canvas.

HAILE SELASSIE begins a presentation of Ethiopia's case in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES with a reference to "our great ancestor, King SOLOMON." A little further on the Emperor of Ethiopia reminds the Italian invader of what happened to GOLIATH of the mighty armaments at the hand of DAVID and his slingshot.

All of Great Britain's invading polo squad was at its training quarters last night, the Burnt Mills Polo Club in Bedminster, N.J. Yesterday morning, Captains P.B. Sanger and Humphrey Guinness, and Eric Tyrell-Martin arrived in the Cunard-White Star liner Majestic and immediately joined their team-mates, Captains M.P. Ansell and H.C. Walford, who had arrived Monday with the team's ponies.
The Park Department began yesterday to mail out to more than 300 clubs, fraternal organizations and social groups in the metropolitan area an elaborate brochure on its barber-shop quartet contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Senators gained another full game on Philadelphia in their battle to grab sixth place in the American League today, making fourteen hits to score their second successive victory over the Athletics, 11 to 2.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The contract bridge team of Howard Schenken, Miss Ruth Sherman, Louis H. Watson and Miss Helen Bonwit of New York won the Shepard G. Barclay Trophy for mixed teams of four at the Convention Hall here this afternoon.

BASLE, Switzerland, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Led by Eulace Peacock, Negro athlete from Temple University who equaled the listed world record of 10.3 seconds for the 100-meter dash, touring American track and field athletes dominated an international meet today. They captured twelve of thirteen events.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Pressure or no pressure, two Congressional committees today were taking their time about authorizing the issuance of midget coins which the President has designed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Missing since July 14, Howard C. Hopson, dominant influence in the Associated Gas and Electric System and key witness of one phase of the Congressional inquiries into lobbying against the Utility Holding Company Bill, was in Washington last night, the House investigating committee learned with surprise today.
BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- Charles F. Adams and George Preston Marshall today laid the groundwork of a deal to turn over the Boston Braves to new interests.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- Vera Borea's new collection is the best she has shown for several seasons. Her suits, jackets and long redingotes are semi-fitted, with leg-o'-mutton sleeves and a widening shoulder line. Sports suits are unusually cut in soft colored tweeds and are worn with darker crepe shirts.

DUBLIN, Aug. 6. -- Dublin's great horse show opened today with a record entry of more than 2,000 of the country's finest bloodstock, and every promise that this will be one of the best exhibitions in many years.

Magistrate Kross dismissed charges of disorderly conduct against some fifty persons who had been picketing the offices of The American Mercury. In your correspondence columns and in some newspaper reports since that incident there has been a suggestion that so-called "mass picketing" is unlawful.

Anne Sibley, 21-year-old daughter of a Chicago lawyer, who left college to become a barker and performer in a side show in Coney Island, ended her career yesterday afternoon by returning home with her mother.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 6. -- With Johnny Fell accounting for five of his team's six goals and playing a fine all-around game at the No. 2 position, the Blue quartet conquered J.C. (Cocie) Rathborne's White Team, 6 to 3, in a high-goal members' match on Belmont Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Streams swollen by torrential overnight rain flooded large areas of Western Wisconsin and Southeastern Minnesota today.

Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic for a brief vacation. He was accompanied by his daughter, Henrietta. Mrs. Bingham remained in England.

At the time when Mark Twain was editing a Western newspaper a merchant in the town wrote him asking whether a spider in his morning newspaper was an omen of good or ill fortune. The reply, one of the bits in "Mark Twain Wit and Wisdom," was characteristic: "Finding a spider in your paper did not mean either good luck or bad for you.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The continued subnormal movement of hogs to market, with the output of fresh pork so limited that even the curtailed demand has been sufficient to more than absorb all offerings, sent prices of hogs soaring 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- A revised Ship Subsidy Bill, designed chiefly to meet objections found by President Roosevelt in earlier ones, was introduced today by Senator Copeland.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- The popular unrest, which hitherto had confined itself to protest meetings over Premier Pierre Laval's deflationary program, has taken a violent turn in the last two days in several places in France, and today after a serious riot the Brest naval arsenal had to be closed.

DUBLIN, Aug. 6. -- The Abbey Theatre, with newly decorated foyer and many other improvements, reopened last night with a production of Rutherford Mayne's sturdy, thought-provoking drama on land division in Ireland, called "Bridgehead."

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- A physical siege in the county building was ended tonight when eight men, swinging sledge hammers, battered down a door and ejected Otto F. Aken from the County Superintendent of Schools' office, where he had barricaded himself against his rival, Noble J. Puffer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Before the gaudy stage curtain of dilapidated Washington Auditorium, to which they have just moved, upstairs in the stars' dressing rooms and in tiny metal chambers which workmen are noisily completing, administrators of the Work Relief drama, art, music and writers' projects are pushing forward their plans, confident that President Roosevelt will approve an allotment of $27,215,217 for the program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Millions of dollars in securities have been given away by a few score industrialists, including John D. Rockefeller Jr., during the four months ending June 30, according to reports made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

John C. Judge, Brooklyn attorney and former chairman of the Kings County Criminal Bar Association, was indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn, charged with violating provisions of the Home Owners Loan Corporation Act.

Two Brooklyn detectives returned from London on the Majestic yesterday with a jaunty, custom-tailored prisoner who has just finished a term in Brixton Prison in England and now faces a charge of swindling a Chinese-American restaurateur of $23,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The Boerse was unsteady and limited in its activity today. Heavy industrials were quiet, showing some strength only at the close. Potash issues were unchanged, except that Aschesleben lost a half point. Machine shares were slightly stronger at the opening, but finished weak and inactive. Chemical securities were stagnant.

The members of the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition are gathering from the corners of the earth and heading for Montevideo, where they will board the motor ship Wyatt Earp, which will take them to their base on Dundee Island.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- Count Wolf von Helldorf, Berlin's Brown Shirt police president; Reich Commissar Lappert, municipal dictator of Berlin, and the Nazi party chief for Berlin, Artur Goerlitzer, had a long conference today, it was announced tonight, and decided who in the future would be allowed to move to Berlin and who receive a concession to carry on business here.

Reflecting both the heavy gains in retail trade throughout the country this Summer and the active start of the Fall season in the major wholesale markets here, the arrivals of buyers in this city during July set a record for this period, according to data compiled yesterday and based on the buyers' arrival listing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A happy prospective bridegroom had his marriage blown out of his hand yesterday, although only temporarily, when he carelessly dropped the $10 bill with which he was going to pay for his marriage license.

Protection for stated periods of time against the termination of the processing tax by a Supreme Court decision was assured to buyers of cotton goods yesterday, when the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York unanimously endorsed a clause for inclusion in contracts recommended by its industrial recovery committee.

Three depositors of the closed Travellers' Bank of Paris filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday against Bertrand Coles Neidecker and George W. Neidecker, brothers and co-partners of the bank, who were arrested here last week at the request of the French authorities.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

More than 26,000 workers will be added to payrolls as a result of loans to industry made by, or with the cooperation of, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to Edward J. Noble, president of Life Savers, Inc., and a member of the Industrial Advisory Committee of the New York Reserve Bank, which passes upon such loans.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug, 6. -- The will of Gwendolyn Dows, society woman and wife of David Dows, former Sheriff of Nassau County, was filed here today for probate with Surrogate Leon E.D. Howell. Mrs. Dows died at the New York Hospital, Manhattan, on July 30 last.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- The Rev. Howard W. Diller, rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church of Pottsville, Pa., notified a Philadelphia tourist agency today that a permit to enter Mexico for a week's visit as a tourist had been denied him "because he was a Protestant clergyman."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Mrs. Henry Lorillard Cammann and her sister, Miss Louise B. Willard, gave a dinner tonight at Lougret Lodge, their home at North Sea, for Mrs. Raymond Lesher and Mrs. Henry Warner Slocum, who are visiting them.

Paul Coze, Commissioner of the Boy Scouts of France, who will be chief of the French contingent at the jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America in Washington, D.C., Aug. 21 to 30, arrived yesterday on the Ile de France. A group of French Girl Scout leaders also was on board, coming here to tour the country and to visit President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, recrowned queen of tennis, returned home from New York today and announced that she has decided to play in the national championships at Forest Hills two weeks hence. Smartly attired in a black silk ensemble, she was greeted at Berkeley Station by her husband, Frederick J. Moody Jr.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- The State Tax Commission refused point blank today to give Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer a week's respite from the order to appear in court in New York Thursday to give testimony regarding his assets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A promise of a vote on the veterans' bonus early next session was put out by Senate leaders today in their double effort to protect the Wealth-Sharing Tax Bill from extraneous amendments and to force early adjournment of the present session of Congress.

One of the interesting developments of the current salt-water fishing season has been the revival of weakfishing in Jamaica Bay. Ten or fifteen years ago the bay yielded great numbers of weaks, but pollution and shrimping operations that reduced the amount of natural food changed the picture.
The waters from Montauk to Atlantic City were teeming yesterday with minnows, weakfish and one whale, according to the day's unusual catch of fish stories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The possible effect of proposed inheritance taxes on the fortune of Henry Ford was outlined to the Senate Finance Committee today as follows by Robert H. Jackson, counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Congressional attempts to frame legislation authorizing issuance of fractional coins for sales taxes have led to entirely unexpected obstacles, it was learned today. It is still a question whether the legislation will be passed at this session.

The safety of American passenger ships and the treatment accorded visitors to Italy have been made the objects of attack by organized campaigns of propaganda, it was charged here yesterday. The recurrence of marine accidents aboard American ships last Winter and the condition of Italy's international relations have been used as the basis of the attacks, it was said.
Purchasing of housing properties for investment was reported in three boroughs of the city yesterday, a continuance of the activity apparent the preceding day.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 6. -- Today's convention of the late Marshal Josef Pilsudski's Polish Legion at Cracow, held every year to commemorate the beginning of the legion's march against Russia on Aug. 6, 1914, was made the occasion of great manifestations to honor the memory of the Marshal and of an enthusiastic welcome to his successor in the Polish Army, Inspector General Edward Rydz-Smigly.

ROME, Aug. 6. -- The ink is hardly dry yet on the Geneva resolutions regarding the East African dispute, and Premier Mussolini is already announcing again to the whole world that he laughs at interference, from whatever quarter it may come, and that he intends to go ahead and solve Italy's difficulties with Ethiopia in his own way, which is equivalent to saying by force of arms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The policy of the Roosevelt administration to shift the burden of depression expenditures through taxation from the lower income groups to the well-to-do propertied class "in proportion to their ability to pay" was expounded in detail for the first time today before the Senate Finance Committee considering the $250,000,000 House bill, by Robert H. Jackson, counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Steel ingot production in the United States in July showed not only a large gain over the corresponding month of last year, but actually exceeded the output for June, contrary to the seasonal trend, according to the monthly tabulation of the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Sixty-one detectives will be demoted and forty-nine promoted this morning in the most extensive shake-up of the detective division of the Police Department in many years.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6. -- Reports that the Federal relief grant to New Jersey for August had been reduced to $3,000,000 and that the State Emergency Relief Administration would be ordered to abandon all work projects caused Governor Harold G. Hoffman to issue a statement today assailing any such action as a move that would throw 8,000 persons out of work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Roy Henshaw, who makes a habit of beating the Pirates, scored again for the Cubs, 2 to 1, today. A pair of errors on a freak play gave Chicago the victory that cut a full game from the Giants' leading margin.

Failures declined in both the manufacturing and retail divisions in the week ended Aug. 1, as compared with the previous week, while in the wholesale branch the number of defaults remained unchanged, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detail summary is as follows:
Designating petitions were filed with the Board of Elections yesterday on behalf of about twenty candidates who seek election this Fall to the Assembly and the Board of Aldermen.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The propaganda barrage against Jews, Catholics, Protestants, conservatives, Reds and other real or far-fetched opponents of the Nazi regime that is being laid down by the powers that be in Berlin continued today with emphasis on the Communists. Other categories of alleged enemies of the State could sit back temporarily and get their breath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Interviews with the bearers of 355 names signed to telegrams sent from Warren, Pennsylvania, urging abolition of the holding company dissolution clause in the Utility Bill showed that the names of 180 were used without authorization, a report by J.C. Willever, first vice president of the Western Union, revealed today.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The Marquess of Linlithgow, an able young Conservative with an impressive record of public service behind him, was appointed tonight to the supremely difficult post of Viceroy of India in succession to the Earl of Willingdon, whose five-year term will expire next April.

Participants in the recent riot aboard the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen and organizers of anti-Nazi demonstrations continued their protests yesterday against the treatment of American seamen both here and abroad.

"Jubilee," the Cole Porter-Moss Hart tribute to the sundry manifestations of Noel Coward, will arrive in New York at 8:30 o'clock on the evening of Oct. 5, which is a Saturday. It hasn't yet decided on the theatre, but there is a good deal of talk about the Imperial and one or two others; the decision will be made later on.

One out of every three married couples in the United States, the Census Bureau now tells us, is childless. n 1930 the percentage of couples without children stood at 31.9, but is now slightly higher. Of the 23,400,000 couples in 1930, 7,400,000 had no children, 5,300,000 had one child, 4,200,000 had two and the rest three or more.

Offering no alibis for her recent defeat at Wimbledon and with high praise for Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, her conqueror, Miss Helen Jacobs returned yesterday aboard the White Star Cunard liner Majestic, ready for further combat on the courts. Accompanying her were members of the British Wightman Cup team.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- An authoritative source expressed the belief today that fear of losing the 1936 Olympic Games because of the campaign against Jews and "political Catholicism" lay behind Nazi attempts to obstruct foreign correspondents.
Designating petitions were filed with the Board of Elections yesterday on behalf of about twenty candidates who seek election this Fall to the Assembly and the Board of Aldermen.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- During July the number registered of unemployed in Great Britain fell below 2,000,000 for the first time in five years, the Ministry of Labor officially announced tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The suggestion that insured mortgages of the Federal Housing Administration be marketed to the general public was made today by leading bankers who met at luncheon at the Essex Club with Peter Grimm, recently appointed assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

Due to yesterday's high registration the number of buyers reported in the market during the week showed a sharp gain in comparison with the figures for the preceding week, although the total was somewhat less than in the corresponding week last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 6. -- A war veterans' heaven, fostered by the fear of the administration that another "Hoover bonus march" might descend upon Washington, and directed by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, has sprung up seven miles from this city.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 6. -- An injunction suit to restrain Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and other motion picture companies from continuing an alleged conspiracy to deprive three St. Louis houses of first-run films was filed by the government in Federal court today.

The Jersey City Commission received yesterday a preliminary report on a proposal for the construction of an elevated airport, 150 feet high, at the Jersey end of the Holland Tunnel. The report was made by Alexander Simpson, former State Senator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- More than 550,000 persons are now employed on work relief jobs under the new $4,000,000,000 program, relief officials said today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean, serving in a relief role, won his eighteenth victory of the season and the fifth in a row for the world champions by knocking a home run with two on the bases in the tenth inning of the Cardinals' series opener today with the Reds.

The completion of a 16-year survey on the meteorological phenomena in the city, with particular emphasis on fog and other conditions of low visibility, is being held up by Dr. James H. Kimball of the United States Weather Bureau as a result of lack of funds from the Works Progress Administration, it became known yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Reaching Cecil Spittler for all their runs in the fifth inning of the nightcap, the Red Wings captured a 7-to-2 decision today for an even break with Newark. The Bears won the first, 10 to 2, behind heavy hitting.

Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, appointed to prosecute racketeers before a special grand jury, announced yesterday that he had selected Wayne Merrick, a former agent of the Department of Justice, as chief investigator on his staff.

Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, appointed to prosecute racketeers before a special grand jury, announced yesterday that he had selected Wayne Merrick, a former agent of the Department of Justice, as chief investigator on his staff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Financial difficulties of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company were attributed in large measure by its president today to provisions in its mortgages requiring it to replace equipment "not needed in the operation of the railroad," and to "the incubus of the accumulated interest on the adjustment mortgage."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor will appeal to President Roosevelt to step into the mediation proceedings between Italy and Ethiopia and use all the influence at his command to prevent the threatened war. This was announced by William Green, president of the A.F. of L., after today's session of the council meeting here.

The sixth annual Gladiolus Show, sponsored by the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society and the Rockefeller Center Gardens of the Nations, will be held Friday, Saturday and Sunday in Horticultural Hall at Rockefeller Center. Entries will be judged Friday at 2 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- President Roosevelt met with the Advisory Committee on Allotments and with the National Emergency Council, and had lunch with Jesse Isidor Straus, Ambassador to France.

What is virtually a religious civil war has broken out in Germany. Our Berlin correspondent quotes from posters and proclamations issued by both sides. The Nazi invective is directed not against the Catholic Church by name, but against those "traitors" who would make use of an ecclesiastical body for political purposes.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight he had received a survey from the State Highway Department showing that in fourteen counties of the recent flood area, 543 town and county bridges were destroyed. He estimated the replacement cost at $2,500,000.

Bankers who have lately returned from abroad are not sanguine about the prospects of an early move toward currency stabilization. While the French are eager for stabilization, the British continue cold. France, it is suggested, would welcome a general move toward stabilization as a cover to some moderate devaluation of the franc.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Shouting that they would stay until their demands were met, about 1,000 relief workers swarmed through the Wyandotte County Court house tonight in protest against a two-thirds cut in work relief payments and other grievances.

Pointing out that the administration's tax bill, which recently passed the House of Representatives, would establish a radically new principle in our form of government, W.S. Farish, chairman, and W.C. Teagle, president, of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declared yesterday in a letter to stockholders that the bill "accepts the new theory that the government's power to raise revenues can be availed of to regulate business."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- House and Senate oil leaders tossed almost identical bills into the Congressional mill today in speedy response to a Presidential endorsement of oil legislation at this session.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7. -- Miss Eva Shorb of Massillon, Ohio, 17-year-old high school girl, furnished the fireworks today in the second round of the women's Western golf championship at the Westwood Country Club.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The market on the London Stock Exchange was quieter in tone today compared with yesterday, and generally remained firm, a factor being the announcement that the unemployment rolls in July had gone below the 2,000,000 mark.

A plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, which has been in bankruptcy for two years, was expected in Wall Street yesterday to be forthcoming as a result of an order entered by Judge James H. Wilkerson in Federal Court in Chicago on Tuesday.

HAVANA, Aug. 7. -- The resignation of the entire governing body of the ABC, revolutionary organization, formation of a new "emergency directing cell," and complete reorganization of the once powerful political body were revealed today in reports published by Havana newspapers.

Irregularity continued to characterize the share market yesterday as profit-taking and switching operations occurred in some volume. The demand appeared to carry out the time-honored idea of rotation, the merchandising, and at times the amusement, automotive and metal shares, being favored at the expense of the railway and utility issues.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Assent of the Prudential Insurance Company to the reorganization plan presented by the present management of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company and approval of the plan by insurance companies and fiduciary corporations representing $61,410,600 of the carrier's securities, were announced today as the Interstate Commerce Commission's first hearing on the plan was adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Reviving reports of differences between the New Deal and the Roper Business Advisory Council, the resignation ou Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, was disclosed today because of the pressure of "other obligations."

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, addressed the Tompkins County Development Association, at a luncheon today, on the Federal land conservation and agricultural readjustment program and urged the approval of the members for the land plans of the administration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Upsetting the Chicago defense with a myriad of bunts while Cy Blanton hurled scoreless ball, the Pirates shut out the Cubs, 6 to 0, today. They handed Larry French his first starting defeat in ten weeks as they dropped the second-place club three and one-half games back of the idle Giants.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 7. -- Rhode Island seemed proud of its place in the political spotlight as the result of its repudiation of President Roosevelt's New Deal program in yesterday's special Congressional election, when Charles F. Risk, Republican, received 48,023 votes, against 35,054 for Antonio Prince, his Democratic opponent.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- Joe Cronin hit a home run out of Fenway Park today to deprive the Yankees of a twin victory and, as a result, the McCarthy men emerged from a double-header with the Red Sox without change in their position back of the Tigers. They still are four games off the pace.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Support for Governor Hoffman on the sales-tax issue weakened in his own party here today.

A group of Harlem housewives who have learned that beet tops are as tasty as collards and that brown bread at less cost for a loaf is as nourishing as white cashed in yesterday on their skill in lending elasticity to their food dollars. Winners in a city-wide contest under the sponsorship of the Department of Health, they received checks of from $5 to $15 at the district centre, 108 West 136th Street.

The mystery of the Sciurus carolianensis -- in other words, the black member of the squirrel family -- has been finally solved at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Officials and other employes, pressed by the public for information on the jet black rodent that has been seen of late scurrying about a section set aside for a bird and wild flower sanctuary, cleared the mystery, but not without outside help.

Actual construction of the new Sixth Avenue subway will be started about Oct. 1, when ground will be broken for the first section, extending from Forty-ninth to Thirty-ninth Street, it was indicated yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

The new issue of $5,400,000 Public Service Company of New Hampshire 4 per cent refunding bonds probably will reach the investment market in the latter part of the week of Aug. 19. Application was filed with the SEC on Aug. 2. The sale will be on a competitive basis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Yesterday's election results in Rhode Island caused great jubilation among Republicans here today. Democrats as a rule, however, laughed at assertions that the Republican victory in one Congressional district indicated a national trend against the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- A bill to provide a national textile commission of seven members with broad powers to regulate and license the textile industry in all its divisions was introduced today by Representative Ellenbogen of Pennsylvania, who said he was certain that the bill was constitutional.
The cost of city government is increasing "like a snowball rolling down hill," the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday in the seventh of a series of pamphlets on city expenditures.

Crosby Gaige has once more changed his plans and dates for the Merivale-Cooper "Othello" and "Macbeth." Last announced to open here on Sept. 23, the plays have been set back to Oct. 7 on Broadway, where their run is now described as "limited."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- John Hamilton, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, said today that he interpreted the Rhode Island election as a "repudiation of the policies of President Roosevelt."

David Alper, a strapping young man of 25, strode into his home at 525 Union Avenue, the Bronx, just before 8 o'clock last night and reviewed the rather bewildering events that had turned him overnight from an ordinary collector for a downtown jewelry company into a champion of the rights of man.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Captain Fred G. French and E.M. Cook of Philadelphia captured the Derrick J. Wernher Trophy for men's pairs here this afternoon at the Summer championships of the American Bridge League.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Mrs. Blanche Dunkel and Mrs. Evelyn Smith were found guilty today by Acting Chief Justice Harrington of the Cook County Criminal Court of the murder of Mrs. Dunkel's son-in-law, Ervin Lang, 28-year-old grocery clerk. Judge Harrington, who has heard the evidence without a jury, said that he would fix the sentences tomorrow afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7 (AP). -- An estate valued at $9,037,847.26, mostly in stocks and bonds, was left by Percy A. Rockefeller, nephew of John D. Rockefeller, according to the inventory filed today.

The Aktieselskapet Actium Corporation of Norway yesterday remitted in New York the $5,040,000 balance due on its purchase for $6,300,000 in cash the German gold bonds with a face value of $21,000,000 held by the bankruptcy estate of the International Match Corporation.
Interstate Department Stores. Inc., including company's own departments and excluding groceries and leased departments -- Sales:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- President Roosevelt placed seven government lending agencies under the Budget Bureau as regards their administrative expenses, laid down rules for loans under the rural electrification program and signed a bill liberalizing the District of Columbia divorce laws.

Three robbers who held up two employes of Krasne Brothers, Bronx wholesale grocers, Tuesday afternoon and made away with a canvas bank bag containing $46,250 in cash and checks, yesterday returned the checks, totaling $44,600. They were mailed to the company's offices at 581 Austin Place, the Bronx, from Station H, a branch postoffice in 102d Street, near Amsterdam Avenue.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Forty-four yearlings were disposed of in the sales paddock tonight for a total of $39,900, an approximate average of $907 per head. The best prices were received for sons of Gallant Fox and the Belair Stud lot.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, replied yesterday to the theatrical managers and producers who have, in the last few days, publicly criticized Equity for its recent rulings on Sunday performances and pay for rehearsals.

SALEM, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow, attired in widow's garments, confessed tonight to Prosecutor W.A.W. Grier that she and Norman Driscoll, a neighbor and childhood sweetheart, had planned the murder of her husband, Harry, 34 years old.

Dr. RALPH WILLARD freezes his tubercular monkey, Jekal, with the aid of carbon-dioxide snow, liquid air and a refrigerator. Probably the "block of ice" to which Jekal was reduced is not to be taken too literally. Still, he is dead so far as the tests show -- dead for 120 hours, or five days.
The budget of the Board of Education for 1936, as drawn by its committee on finance and budget and adopted tentatively by the board, is $140,625,000, an increase of $7,215,000 over the 1935 estimate.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
DALLAS, Aug. 7. -- Striking women garment workers stripped four women naked, partly disrobed six others and chased them through the streets, spanking and scratching them in wild rioting today.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- According to latest information British, French and Italian conversations here on the Ethiopian affair will not take place before Aug. 16. French circles already are taking pains to make clear that it will not be a conference properly speaking, but a simple diplomatic conversation which will not bind the parties to the extent that a formal conference would.

George A. Helme, former president of the American Snuff Company and of the George W. Helme Tobacco Company, left an estate valued at $4,652,401.98 at the time of his death on April 29, 1931, an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogates' Court by the executors shows.

Engagement of the American Ballet, of which George Balanchine is director, to take over the dance features and divertissements of the Metropolitan Opera in succession to the traditional opera ballet, was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager of the opera association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Duffy Copyright Bill, over which artistic wars have waged for two years, was passed today by the Senate.

Lawyers for Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco, who are serving three-month workhouse terms as public enemies under the Brownell Law, took a new step in the Appellate Term of Special Sessions yesterday in an effort to set aside the recent conviction of the pair by Magistrate Nathan L. Perlman.

The 1,501 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $43,026,061,990 par value as of Aug. 1, had a total market value of $39,457,462,834, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of July 1, there were 1,513 issues, aggregating $43,511,242,590 par value, which had a total market value of $39,864,332,759.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Members of the Summer colony filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players, under the direction of Felix Jacoves, opened their third production for this season, "Your Young Men," a new comedy by William Wallace Vosburgh.

The annual music memory contest of the Goldman Band was held in conjunction with last night's concert at Central Park Mall. Many listeners praticipated, turning in slips with the titles of compositions entered on them after the band had played passages from twenty-five works that have figured on its programs this Summer.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Treasury, is sailing Saturday on the Empress of Britain for Quebec, en route to China, where he will examine financial conditions with a view to recommending what aid, if any, this country can render to China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Renewed threats of action against German vessels entering New York and other ports were made today by a New York delegation of seamen and anti-Nazi organizations when they left the State Department after having urged unsuccessfully aggressive government action to obtain the release of Lawrence B. Simpson, an American seaman, under arrest in Germany.

Pig iron production in July, according to The Iron Age, totaled 1,520,263 tons, compared with 1,552,514 tons in June. The daily rate last month, at 49,041 tons, was 5.2 per cent below the June average of 51,750 tons. However, ninety-five furnaces were in blast Aug. 1, a net gain of four over the number active July 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- An acute shortage of hogs, arrivals here today of only 7,000 head setting a new all-time record low for a Wednesday, and general buying by all interests lifted prices generally 25 to 35 cents above Tuesday's level to a new high price since 1930.

YORKLYN, Del. Aug. 7. -- Joseph F. Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, today broke 499 sixteen-yard clay targets to win the twelfth annual renewal of the Marshall marathon of trapdom, the 500-target world's amateur championship.

The latest of the cruelties, and they are many, inflicted upon helpless but sincere white-collar relief workers in this city is the ruling, just effective, whereby for two weeks from tomorrow the thousands of persons on work-relief projects will be without pay.

July purchases by the Russian Government in this country amounted to $8,500,000, it was announced yesterday by the Amtorg Trading Corporation. The figure is the largest for any month since 1931, when the Soviet began curtailing commitments in this country.

Hundreds of eases of liquor purchased abroad by Americans who believed the price they paid would be used in figuring the amount of liquor they would be permitted to bring into this country under the $100 exemption clause provided in the Tariff Act for personal effects are being abandoned on steamship piers by disillusioned tourists, according to information from customs officials yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Four States were advised by the Treasury today that their use of sales-tax tokens was believed to clash with the Federal Government's exclusive right to coin money.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- While new rioting flared up and was gradually being supressed in the naval arsenal at Brest today, the salary cuts of Premier Pierre Laval's decree laws led today to postponement of the liner Champlain's sailing from Havre, for which 800 passengers, mostly Americans, had booked passage.

Samuel Kaplan, a clerk in the offices of the Prudential Collateral Company at 1,119 Sixth Avenue, was standing alone behind the counter watching the noon crowds crossing Sixth Avenue and Forty-third Street yesterday when a lanky young man with the gait of a Westerner approached with a smiling "Howdy do."

Departmental estimates for 1936 were submitted yesterday by the Registers of New York, Bronx, Kings and Queens Counties and by the Commissioners of Records of New York, Bronx and Kings Counties at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen at 253 Broadway.

WARSAW, Aug. 7. -- A provisional settlement of the Polish-Danzig customs conflict was reached today after the Free City's Senate declared its readiness to submit to Poland's demand and withdraw its decree for duty-free importation of foreign goods.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 7. -- J.H. (Jock) Whitney's Greentree quartet, entered in the national open polo championship at Meadow Brook next month, today conquered a thirty-goal White team, 12 to 9, in a thrilling match at Greentree Field. George H. (Pete) Bostwick, Thomas Hitchcock Jr., Gerald Balding and Whitney proved a well-balanced twenty-six-goal combination which should go far in the championship.
Under the first important hedging pressure of the new-crop season, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday and closed unchanged to 12 points lower than Tuesday.
The landslide in Rhode Island spoke for itself so loudly that even the most light-hearted of the New Dealers will have difficulty in misunderstanding it.

Excluding operations incident to bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings, Paramount Pictures, Inc., shows for the first quarter of this year estimated net earnings of $1,472,000 after Federal taxes, foreign exchange adjustments, reserve for losses of Paramount Broadway Corporation, and interest on new debentures of Paramount Pictures, Inc.

In a letter to the membership yesterday, the tax committee of the Textile Fabrics Association definitely rejected the 120-day protection clause of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants and suggested that converters purchase gray goods only with full protection against an adverse court decision on the AAA.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The First Congressional District of Rhode Island, which was strongly in favor last Autumn of permitting the President to work out his New Deal policies without hindrance, has overwhelmingly changed its mind. The entire State of Rhode Island has turned against public works in particular as a relief and recovery device.

Liquidation of the McCrory Stores Corporation at present, even under the best possible conditions, would leave a balance of only $243,192 to meet interest charges of $2,500,000, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing before Robert P. Stephenson, special master, at 29 Broadway, on the preferred stockholders' plan for reorganization of the company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Joe Louis bombed King Levinsky out of the picture tonight and at the same time entrenched himself more firmly as the leading candidate for a chance at the world's heavyweight championship, now held by James J. Braddock.

Installation of the "electric eye," a device which takes a motion picture of the finish of a horse race and simultaneously records the time of the contest to within a hundredth of a second, has been recommended for all tracks in New York State effective Oct. 1, according to announcement made yesterday by the State Racing Commission, of which Herbert Bayard Swope is chairman.

Nineteen yachts were entered yesterday for the American Yacht Club's cruise, which starts on Sunday morning from off Rye, N.Y., and as many more tentative entries have been named for the three divisions. Officials of the club expect this cruise, the third annual one, to eclipse the others.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Joe Louis weighed in at 198 1/2 and King Levinsky at 197 3/4, his lightest fighting weight in five years, today for their heavyweight match at Comiskey Park tonight. Joe Triner, chairman of the Illinois State Athletic Commission, officiated at the weighing-in.
A REMARKABLE fellow, this Wesley Cheek Ferrell. In later days the graybeards will be sitting in the shade of some grand stand looking at a fine young pitcher and muttering:

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Aside from the loss of a set by Sidney B. Wood Jr. to Martin Buxby of Miami, Fla., the play today in the Eastern grass court championships was barren of unlooked-for developments as the stage was set for one of the best days of tennis offered in recent years at the Westchester Country Club.

With the composer at the piano in lieu of the orchestra for which he had prepared his score, "The Tents of the Arabs," an opera by Paul Tietjens, was presented in the form of a public rehearsal at the McMillin Theatre last night. The performance was given in connection with the music festival this week at Columbia University.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 7. -- State police and local authorities are investigating a mysterious attack on John White, 21 years old, and his sister, Margaret, children of John E. White, an undertaker, of 107 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, who were brutally beaten in their Summer home here yesterday by a gang of seven thugs.

All that remains of the Czechoslovakian film "Ecstasy," which a jury of middle-aged business men found last June to be "obscene," is an expensive pile of ashes -- a little mound that may be the subject of heated argument in a Court of Claims.

Viewing the recovery in steel output as the beginning of a "long pull out of hard times," The Iron Age in its weekly summary says production has risen to 47 per cent of capacity, thus marking the fifth consecutive weekly advance.

Doubleday, Doran Co. reported yesterday that they had received from Harry Hansen, literary critic, the complete manuscript of the O. Henry Prize Stories for 1935. The book, which will be published this Fall, will contain short stories by Stephen Vincent Benet, Kay Boyle, Louis Paul, Josephine Johnson, Thomas Wolfe, Mackinlay Kantor, Dorothy McCleary and others.
QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Fire swept the interior of the navy's newest cruiser, the 10,000-ton Quincy, today at her dock, where she was being made ready for a trial run.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- W.W. Porter, former head of a number of investment houses, surrendered today to Federal authorities on charges of using the mails to defraud, and was released after posting a $5,000 bond. Warren Canaday, Assistant United States Attorney, estimated a shortage of $1,700,000 in the accounts of the Porter companies with investors.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The New Orleans Cotton Exchange, in its annual report given out today laid the loss of foreign cotton markets to the government cotton program.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Harold Halsted gave twenty-six Star Class rivals a sailing lesson in his defending champion Chuckle II today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7. -- New York's entry in the union printers' international baseball tournament became an outstanding favorite to win the title, now held by Washington, by halting Boston, 8 to 7, in ten innings today.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Aug. 7. -- Transport after transport laden with Italian troops and war supplies is passing through the Suez Canal en route to East Africa, official figures disclosed today.

If Governor LEHMAN waited till he came to every bridge before he crossed it he would need a long time to undo the damage by recent up-State floods. No less than 543 town and county bridges were wrecked. To help repair them the Governor wants to use a part of the Federal emergency funds allocated to New York highways.

SIMLA, India, Aug. 7. -- The news of the Marquess of Linlithgow's appointment as Viceroy had a friendly reception throughout India even from India Congress newspapers, which admit "a worse choice could have been made."

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Rain-swoolen rivers poured waters over towns, farms and roads in Western and Central West Virginia tonight, claiming one life and causing untold damage and suffering.

Conflicting price trends characterized the market for domestic corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Individual groups were singled out for special unconnected movements. The trading pace slowed down slightly, transactions amounting to $8,703,300, compared with $9,056,900 on Tuesday.

Reporting an increase of more than $300,000 in net profits for the first twenty-four weeks of 1935, with continuing business improvement, directors of the Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester declared yesterday an increase in dividends to holders of common stock.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Tourist business is booming in New York State this Summer. By rail, highway, air and water, thousands of persons are "on the go" throughout the most populous State in the nation, the largest number since the pre-depression days.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- Little Nymph, courageous filly from the stable of Percy M. Pike, scored an upset in the juvenile ranks at Suffolk Downs today when she disposed of Black Highbrow by a nose after a thrilling stretch drive in the Faneuil Hall Stakes, a six-furlong sprint.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Further improvements in trade and earnings were reported today by Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co., leading mail order and department store chain organizations of this country.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30 a consolidated net profit of $3,367,453 after depreciation, depletion, interest, amortization, Federal taxes and minority interests. This is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to 26 cents a share on 5,632,136 no-par common shares, excluding 366,795 shares held in the treasury.

Police radio cars were rushed to the West Side Court yesterday afternoon when sympathizers of seven men on trial as participants in the riots at the pier of the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen on July 27 started a noisy demonstration in the court room.

CAMP CHIEF OURAY, Col., Aug. 7. -- Dr. C.W. Hosphouer, Coroner, was notified tonight that searchers had found the broken body of William Brode, 15 years old, at the bottom of treacherous Lindbergh Peak, from which he fell more than twenty-four hours ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals won their sixth consecutive victory today, 4 to 2, by an early assault on Gen Schott of the Reds, who was knocked out in the second inning. Don Brennan baffled the Red Birds for the remaining six and two-third innings, but the damage already was done.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7. -- The condition of Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, who is gravely ill here with lobar pneumonia, was somewhat improved this evening after reaching a low ebb this afternoon. Dr. Adolph S. Rumreich, American Embassy physician, who is attending Mr. Filene, said his condition was more hopeful, though distinctly serious.

A new issue of $5,500,000 of 4 per cent collateral trust notes of the Kresge Foundation, due July 1, 1945, is being placed on the market today by a banking group headed by Blyth Co. at 100 and accrued interest. Associated with Blyth Co. are Merrill, Lynch Co., Cassatt Co.; White, Weld Co.; Hemphill, Noyes Co.; Kidder, Peabody Co. and the First of Michigan Corporation.

Commodity futures were highly erratic yesterday both as to changes in price and volume, with the third turnabout in coffee within three days the feature in fairly heavy trading. Sugar and copper were the only other staples to advance. In the cash markets wheat, corn, rye and lard advanced, while cotton, rubber, silk, cocoa and tin declined.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Navy Department has given the New York Shipbuilding Company of Camden, N.J., until tomorrow noon to agree to arbitration of the shipyard workers' strike, or to have the contracts assumed by the government, it was reported today after President Roosevelt had referred to the Navy Department inquiries raised at a press conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Material changes in the $250,000,000 tax bill passed by the House were indicated as imminent today by members of the Senate Finance Committee as the Treasury Department joined organized business in attacking various provisions as contrary either to the interests of recovery or principles laid down by President Roosevelt in his tax message.
BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Reports of anti-Jewish violence and mass meetings marked the Nazi drive against "non-Aryans" tonight. In small towns the drive against the Jews continued unabated.

For the first time in five years the number of the unemployed in Great Britain has fallen below 2,000,000. The gains in employment, which have been slow but, on the whole, steady, have been brought about largely by the recovery of private industry. There have been no vast or unusual Government expenditures on public works in order to create jobs.

ALLENHURST, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP). -- The salaries of officers of the United Piece Dye Works in Lodi were withheld today by a Chancery Court temporary injunction after a stockholder had charged that "lack of aggressiveness" by officers and payment of excessive salaries and bonuses to executives had caused the corporation to lose more than $6,000,000 in the last three years.

DOVER, N.J., Aug. 7. -- While members of local Socialist organizations paraded outside with banners and placards carrying the legend "Down with the sales tax!" Governor Hoffman speaking to a group of 200 Rotarians and Kiwanians at a dinner in Elite Hall here tonight defended the tax and struck back at the people of New Jersey who opposed it.

P.L TRAVERS is an Irish girl with something of the glancing wit and irreverence of Isabel Paterson. Last year she jumbled her memories of all the governesses she had had in Australia, where she was born, and in the British Isles, where she was brought up, and out of these memories emerged Mary Poppins, who slid upstairs and did other odd tricks to keep her childish charges in an eternal state of amusement.

Some 270 skilled laborers working on various Works Progress Administration projects walked off the jobs yesterday, marking the first organized step in what threatened to be a widespread strike against the Federal work relief wage schedule.

From one point of view, the slightly more than $100,000,000 of working capital loans approved by the Federal Reserve Banks under Section 13b in the last year does not appear large. It tends to support the contention that demand was not very large for business credit that was not being met by the banks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The top level has apparently been reached by prices of high-grade Spring wheat. It was reported today that some choice Canadian grain had been bought at $1.32 a bushel c.i.f. Buffalo, duty paid, a figure which corresponded to the highest grade of heavy No. 1 dark Northern officially quoted in the Minneapolis market.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt luck held once more when the filly Good Gamble today added the Saranac Handicap to her Acorn Stakes and other victories, in a manner to impress observers. Leading from start to finish of the featured mile test, she scored by two lengths, with Jockey Sammy Renick having little more to do than sit still.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7. -- Suspension of foreign debt payments by Brazil within a few weeks is predicted today by the newspaper A Noite. According to this report, quiet negotiations are now taking place between the government and foreign bankers' representatives for a suitable formula to effect the suspension.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Following long discussion of the Gold Suit Bill, in which it was sharply denounced as unconstitutional, unjust and immoral and declared an attempt to back the administration in a program of repudiation of its gold pledges, the Senate agreed today to limit debate tomorrow on the measure.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 7. -- Hugh Paul's speedy little Astra won the Royal Yacht Squadron's race today, gaining four points in the first of three events for the Jubilee Cup, a silver trophy commemorating the King's jubilee.

A thorough purge of racketeering in the ranks of organized labor in New York City became a practical certainty yesterday as the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in session at Atlantic City, announced that it would offer the federation's complete cooperation and active assistance to Thomas E. Dewey, who is conducting an investigation of all racketeering in the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Patrick J. Hurley and Joseph P. Tumulty, both former high government officials, received a total of $209,000 in the last few years for representing various clients in connection with legislation pending before Congress, the Senate Lobby Committee brought out today.

Strict precautions were taken by the police last night to prevent any disturbance at the sailing at midnight of the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg from Pier 84, North River. The ship had 625 passengers.

Members of the British Wightman Cup tennis team, who arrived on Tuesday to participate in the annual women's net classic for that trophy, engaged in an informal practice session yesterday on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Bids for construction of thirteen of the twenty-four vessels to be built under the 1935 naval expansion program were opened at the Navy Department in the presence of Secretary Swanson, high ranking naval officers and shipbuilding representatives.
Mayor La Guardia is being guarded by an additional detail of six plain-clothes detectives assigned to follow him between City Hall and his home, it was learned last night.

Mr. Carson's letter dated July 25, 1935, deserves an answer. Unfortunately, this cannot reach him until those little birds are almost too old. We have successfully nurtured several nestlings of different species from time to time. All the birds we have raised took angleworms.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Highways of the West are throbbing with motor-tourist traffic that may outdistance the peak of the pre-depression era.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford and Sir Robert Throckmorton are among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Others coming on the ship are John M. Franklin, vice president of the United States Lines, and Mrs. Franklin, and:

Gas rates in the Bronx and Queens will soon be reduced by the Consolidated Gas Company with an annual saving of $590,000 to consumers, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, announced yesterday.

In an Associated Press dispatch from Rochester, N.Y., I read that the time is "opportune" to effect the release of Paul Redfern; also that an American aviator had been picked as one of two men to set out for the interior of Dutch Guiana to search for Redfern.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 7. -- A former Canadian ace now playing from the Plandome Golf Club, Mrs. T.R.
