Rudel, today captured the low gross prize in a one-day eighteen-hole medal handicap tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association. She returned a fine 79 over the difficult links of the Nassau Country Club.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 7. -- The Boston Yacht Club's day in Marblehead race week brought out a fleet exceeding the Eastern Yacht Club's mark of 333 boats today when 352 yachts sailed from port. The largest group, the Indians, numbered 24, while the Stars and Triangles had twenty-one each.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 7. -- Wiley Post, round-the-world flier, and Will Rogers, his companion on a "vacation trip," landed in the bay here at 5:30 P.M. (9:30 P.M. Eastern daylight time) today to complete a flight from Seattle in eight and one-quarter hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Specifications designed to assure the largest possible expenditure on direct wages to labor were laid down by President Roosevelt today in an executive order establishing regulations for the proposed lending of $100,000,000 for rural electrification projects.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- A prediction that disaster would befall the Democratic party in elections throughout the country, as it did in Rhode Island, was made by former Governer Ely today, unless, he said, President Roosevelt "announces that he is through with reform and is giving his attention to recovery, and unless he gets rid of those of Socialistic tendencies and brings into his Cabinet the real Democrats of the nation."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The first two weeks' wholesale market in local history will draw to a successful close Saturday with more buyers here that any time since 1929 and with orders in all lines from 15 to 40 per cent in excess of last year.

CULVER, Ind., Aug, 7 (AP). -- The first upset in the national junior and boys' tennis championships was recorded today as Robert Underwood of Los Angeles, unseeded, defeated Edgar Weller, Austin, Texas, seeded No. 4, by 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, in their fourth-round match.

At a meeting yesterday of 1,400 members of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, at Odd Fellows Hall, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, definite strike action was postponed until Saturday, when the recently imposed 41 per cent wage cut on the $2.12 hourly scale ordered by the Loew's and R.-K.-O. circuits goes into effect.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 7. -- The Chilean government's recently announced plan to limit automobile imports through restrictions on foreign currency drafts has caused importers of foreign cars, principally importers of American cars, to put pressure on diplomatic representatives for action.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- The Molyneux opening revealed an utterly simple daytime and a super-glamorous evening mode. Day skirts are definitely shorter and some waistlines are lowered almost to the hip bones in loose bodices that are tucked into the skirts like sweaters.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MASSILLON, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Flood waters, the worst in the State since 1913, swept over East Central Ohio today, taking three lives, forcing hundreds of families to vacate their homes and causing heavy damage to property and crops.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- About 1,500 youths of German descent, who have gathered from fifty countries, including the United States, to spend the Summer in Germany as guests of the Hitler Youth organizations, were sent forth from Nuremberg today to serve as missionaries of National Socialist anti-Semitism in their native lands.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Executives of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation were in session this evening to determine what stand they would take in the face of the Navy Department's ultimatum on the shipyard strike here. They gave no hint as to the reply they would make.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -- "Your Young Men," a new comedy by William Wallace Vosburgh, had its premiere tonight at Parrish Memorial Hall, with the Hampton Players. Felix Jacoves was the director, in the absence of Henry C. Potter and George Haight, founders of the group, who are in Hollywood.

As one of your readers permit me to thank you for the good reporting of the interview with Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan, who said: "I believe that a day will come when our own singers will be looked for over there."

The testimony of ROBERT H. JACKSON, counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, before the Senate Finance Committee is the ablest and most detailed presentation yet made in defense of the Administration's tax measure. At the same time, however, it is clearly an ex parte statement.

Laurence Stallings, newspaper man, novelist and playwright, motion-picture writer and editor, is en route to Ethiopia to write and photograph for the North American Newspaper Alliance the story of the ominous events that are expected to occur there when the rainy season ends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Declaring Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank of New York, guilty of fraudulently evading income taxes in 1929 and 1930, the Board of Tax Appeals decided today in a civil proceeding that he must pay about $1,100,000 in taxes and penalties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Four thousand World War veterans have been shipped south from Washington since last October to camps established for them in Florida and South Carolina by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- A Jewish girl who had a fair chance of a place on the Olympic team was excluded from last week's German field sports championships, one of the most important contests in preparation for the Olympics, it was revealed today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7. -- The annual flower show was opened at the Casino this afternoon by Governor Theodore Francis Green, who came especially from Providence to attend and to be guest of honor at the annual luncheon given by the show committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- George Preston Marshall, who may head a new Boston Braves set-up, went on the stage at 16 and has been a showman ever since.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7. -- "It was easier for D.L. Moody to preach a sermon in his day than it is for ministers today," said the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean of Drew Seminars, today to 300 ministers who gathered as a part of the Northfield General Conference, which is in its second week of meetings.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The masculinity of American Girl Scouts would be too much for the French, said Mlle. Marise Fischbacher, a commissioner of the Federation Francaise des Eclaireuses, Girl Scout organization of France, in an interview today at Camp Andre, National Girl Scout camp, which she and ten other foreign Scouts are visiting until tomorrow.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 7. -- In one of the most spectacular mountain rescues in West Coast history, a group of United States park rangers today crawled down the steep slant of Half Dome, a sheer granite mountain known to tourists the world over, where a misstep would have meant a 2,000-foot fall to death, and rescued a Massachusetts girl and her injured man companion.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 7. -- With the demobilization today of the 2,000 students of the Citizens Military Training Corps here, the appointments of the officers in the Reserve Corps were announced. A board comprising Alfred P. Walker of the Signal Corps Reserve and Lieutenants William Collins and Charles Royce of the Sixteenth Infantry conducted the examination of the blue, or fourth year, men.

After a twenty-three-hour rest in a hotel in Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday, Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer slipped out of that city at 11 o'clock last night and was believed to be heading for New York City.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 7. -- Beethoven's "Fidelio" is not a popular opera in the ordinary sense of the word, but the wealth of all the Indies would have been insufficient to procure a solitary ticket for this evening's performance of it at the Festspielhaus.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Indians and the White Sox split a double-header today, Cleveland winning the first game, 5 to 2, and the Sox taking the second, 2 to 1.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 7. -- A growing war fever in Ethiopia is giving chiefs a difficult time in restraining hot-blooded warriors, eager to start for the frontier of Italian colonies, reports today from outlying districts disclosed.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The Foreign Office revealed today that on July 26 urgent representations were made to Premier Mussolini through Ambassador Ping Grandi in London against continuous assaults in the Italian press on the British Government.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Many parties preceded and followed today's racing events. Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton entertained at a luncheon for Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, Mrs. Chauncey Olcott, Mrs. William A. Prime, Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Benjamin, Morris S. Tremaine, John M. Clancy and John Curtis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- President Roosevelt today signed a bill greatly liberalizing divorce laws in the District of Columbia. A thirty-five-year-old statute which had permitted divorce only on the ground of infidelity was amended by the measure, passed by Congress only after warm debate.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission held a two-hour session yesterday at which it heard the testimony of former Controller Frank J. Prial and several of its own examiners, and reserved decision on whether or not to order a new examination to fill the post of director of concessions in the Park Department.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Edwin P. Cramer of 501 West Seventh Street, here, who appeared before the Senate Lobby Investigation Committee in Washington last Thursday in regard to the "whispering campaign" against President Roosevelt, received today acknowledgment of an apology he telegraphed to the President Sunday night.

Girl Scouts eager to earn their merit badges in cooking descended upon the modest little corn patch on the eleventh floor of the RCA Building in Radio Center at noon yesterday, stripped it of ripe ears of golden bantam, and held an outdoor roast in the Spanish patio of the Garden of the Nations.

Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions yesterday gave approval to the release from the penitentiary today of Thomas Patrick Morris, fake claimant to a share of the Wendel estate, on the indeterminate sentence of not more than three years that Judge Koenig imposed a little more than two years ago.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Gibson White's speedy fillies, Rosalind and Rosette, trotted one-two in the National Stake for 2-year-olds at Rockingham Park to gain the major parts of the $4,016 purse.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has purchased $43,950,000 worth of preferred stock in banks in Northern New Jersey, and has lent $92,870,000 to banks, building and loan associations, mortgage companies, insurance companies, and industry, of which $75,970,000 has been repaid, according to a report made to Peter Grimm, assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, by Daniel J. Mahoney, manager of the New York Loan Agency of the RFC.
ROME, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Italy's primary hopes of profit in Ethiopia are based on development of products that would affect its trade with North and South America -- cotton and coffee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The House Military Committee heard evidence today that Joseph Silverman Jr. fostered a plan to divide a big War Department contract among leading automobile manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Italy will be unable to obtain credits from the Export-Import Bank for munitions purchasing purposes, it was learned today in connection with several applications filed with the bank by American exporters for short-term credits to finance cotton shipments to the Italian textile industry.

DELHI, India, Aug. 7. -- The legendary mountain pass over the lower and southern Baltoro range in Kashmir is believed to have been rediscovered by Lieutenant James Waller of the Royal Artillery, leader of a recent expedition to the Karakoram Mountains.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 7. -- On being brought to the shore of Mirror Lake, after spending the night on Half Dome, I could not decide whether I wanted first to drink, bathe, eat or rest. I never knew the ground could feel so good.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Three months after the government decided to keep pace with Germany's rearmament in aviation, the Air Ministry has now completed its plans for a vast expansion of the British air force, to be finished by the end of March, 1937.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The Boerse was quiet today, with evidences of firmness. Toward the close the market fell, however. Heavy industrials were stagnant. Machine issues were firm in a limited market, Berlin-Karisruhe gaining 1 1/2 points at the opening.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Negotiating the Sands Point Club course in 72 and 71 and aided by a six-stroke allowance each time, Harvey W. Shaffer and J.J. Dowling of the Meadow Brook Club today won the Long Island Golf Association's annual club pairs' best ball championship by a one-stroke margin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- In a new step toward correlation of government activities, the administrative expenditures of seven special New Deal lending agencies were put under the supervision of the Bureau of the Budget today by President Roosevelt.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Florence Jackson, former burlesque dancer, made the direct charge from the witness stand today that William Lee Ferris shot Howard Carter Dickinson, New York lawyer, on the night of June 26. The woman, with her sister, Loretta, and Jean Miller, are accused jointly with Ferris of slaying Dickinson in a hold-up plot.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 7. -- The first Turkish Charge d'Affaires in Ethiopia since the World War is expected to arrive this evening on a train that is also bringing a number of Egyptians and Syrians who hope to receive commissions in the Ethiopian Army.

In the special election in the First Rhode Island Congress District on Tuesday the prime issue between the Democratic and the Republican candidates for Congress was the New Deal. Mr. PRINCE, the Democratic nominee, closed his last campaign address by saying that his opponent, Judge RISK, "is against the Roosevelt program, lock, stock and barrel":

Reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City showed a decline of $44,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by their condition statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- "Conditional acceptance" of President Roosevelt's ultimatum to the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., was reported today when a voluminous reply from the company was delivered at the offices of Assistant Secretary Henry L. Roosevelt of the Navy Department.

The total sales of hotels in the principal cities of various sections of the country showed an increase of 13 per cent in July as compared with the corresponding period last year and the gain was practically the same as in previous months of 1935, according to a report issued yesterday by Horwath Horwath, hotel accountants.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The Corinthian Yacht Club took charge of race week today and started another record fleet for American waters of 357 boats. The fleet started in real Marblehead racing weather with a light easterly wind, which gave the home skippers an advantage.

Two hours after Raymond Pierce, 23 years old, a garage attendant of Cross Corners, N.Y., near Peekskill, was found murdered yesterday near there, two young men were picked up on the Bowery near Park Row as his murderers. The capture, shortly before midnight, was the result of cooperation between the new "Scotland Yard" division of the State police and city detectives.

City Hall shook off some of its Summer calm yesterday when a booming voice and a heavy tread signaled the advent of Peter .J. McGuinness, long known as the most ardent admirer of his native Greenpoint that the world has ever seen.

Both the Senate and House committees having the question in charge are reported to be reluctant to recommend the measure permitting the Treasury to coin half-cent and one-mill pieces, as it has requested. The Treasury itself ought now to drop the proposal. It is being urged in order to enable a handful of States that have adopted particularly bad sales taxes to make these taxes work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Here are the major provisions of the Social Security Bill, as reported out of conference today:

Proponents of the plan to reorganize the McCrory Stores Corporation under section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, completed presentation of testimony last night before Robert P. Stephenson, Federal special master, in his offices at 29 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The bill to close the doors of the courts soon to suits against the government which are based on dollar devaluation was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 53 to 24. The measure was returned to the House for action on changes made since it went through that body in mid-July.

A clause to be attached to all future purchases of cotton merchandise by retailers, in view of the possible invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act by the United States Supreme Court, was adopted yesterday by a committee of representatives of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Association of Buying Offices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A 1935 cotton crop of 11,798,000 bales, an increase of 2,162,000 bales over last year, was predicted today in the year's first cotton report of the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Ever since the outlines of the Wealth-Tax Bill were made clear, the Ford Motor Company to many has seemed best to exemplify the argument that the inheritance levies of the measure will be destructive in instances where an estate is largely an industry.
A 420-pound swordfish, third largest broadbill ever brought to the Montauk Yacht Club and the ninth rod-and-reel catch of the current season, was hung on the club dock at midnight Wednesday.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Although all of New Jersey's luminaries turned out for the first round of the State open championship today, it remained for a comparatively unknown youth to turn in the day's best score over the magnificent Monmouth County Country Club course.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 8. -- On an upland at the Dan R. Hanna farm west of Mahkeenac Lake the second annual Berkshire symphonic festival opened tonight with an outdoor concert by an orchestra of eighty-five musicians conducted by Dr. Henry Hadley.
In the course of his statement on the Administration's tax measure before the Senate Finance Committee ROBERT H. JACKSON, the Treasury expert, suggested a rather remarkable basis for rate fixing:

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers and to consumers last month continued to run ahead of the same month of last year, although there was a moderate seasonal decline compared with June, according to monthly figures issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Senator Black, chairman of the Senate Lobby Committee, predicted tonight that the power industry's fight against the Utilities Bill "will be known as the '$5,000,000 lobby'."

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today owing to end-of-the-account influences. Virtually the only feature was the continued strength in British funds on investment buying and Continental demand because of renewed fears regarding the outlook for Continental gold currencies.
Joseph Presser has returned to the realty brokerage business after an absence of two and one-half years. He will operate as the Joseph Presser Realty Management Co., at 430 E. 138th St., the Bronx.
ROME, Aug. 8. -- Seven Italians, including a Cabinet Minister and a famous explorer, were killed last night in an airplane crash on the Egyptian desert while on an inspection flight to Eritrea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A Republican suggestion that States "defy the bureaucrats in Washington" and issue their own sales tax tokens accompanied a renewed Treasury drive today to obtain small-coin legislation from an apparently hostile house.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- Mike Jacobs, who aided the Sporting Club of Illinois in the promotion of the bout between Joe Louis and King Levinsky last night, revealed today that he has signed Louis to meet Max Baer in September.

A 5 per cent increase in the price of all Amoskeag cotton-textile products will become effective today, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan Co., distributers for Amoskeag, in endorsing the processing-tax clause recommended by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants "as being fair and equitable.'' Amoskeag will use this clause in future orders when customers request one.

A shipment of rare reptiles, including ten sea snakes from the Indian Ocean and waters of the Malay Archipelago, arrived yesterday at the Staten Island Zoo, West New Brighton. The sea snake is considered one of the most deadly reptiles known to man.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The Boerse was inactive and slightly weaker today, with a tendency toward unexpected breaks in individual stocks. The Reich Institute for Business Research issued a report indicating that many stocks were above their real value.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit during the week ended Aug. 7, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,476,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and of $13,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- An issue of about $100,000,000 in 2 7/8 per cent bonds of 1955-60 will be sold on "auction" next Monday and will be the last Treasury long-term financing this month, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Eulace Peacock, Temple University's Negro star, again led the way as America's touring track and field athletes scored a near clean sweep against foreign opposition today.

With the news of the day bearing on trade and industry reassuring in character, although not unqualifiedly so, profit-taking in the share market was met without much difficulty and the closing was higher, on the average. Railway issues pointed higher, as did the merchandising and most of the automotive and steel stocks; a number of preferred issues made wide gains.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- In a return to the spirited bidding of pre-depression days, forty-eight yearlings passed through the sales ring tonight, bringing a grand total of $160,100. This made an average of $3,335 per head, a figure unheard of in recent years.
ROME, Aug. 8. -- Anglo-Franco-Italian negotiations about Ethiopia are to begin Aug. 16 in Paris. Italy will participate in them without any particular enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Regulation by the Interstate Commerce Commission of bus and truck carriers in interstate and foreign commerce, as provided by a bill awaiting President Roosevelt's signature, will probably require 500 additional employes and an additional appropriation of $1,000,000 a year, it was estimated at the commission today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Acting because of the infantile paralysis epidemic in Virginia and other near-by localities, President Roosevelt canceled the Boy Scout jamboree scheduled to start here Aug. 21. He conferred with various officials on work relief and other administrative matters.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 8. -- Most British missionaries and British-protected Swedes and Danes, numbering about 150 working outside of Addis Ababa, have now been advised by the British Legation of steps to be taken in the event of trouble. All steps have the approval of the Emperor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- Sentences of 180 years each in prison were imposed today on Mrs. Blanche Dunkel, 44 years old, and Mrs. Evelyn Smith, 46, for the murder of Mrs. Dunkel's son-in-law, Ervin Lang, 28-year-old grocery clerk. The sentences were imposed by Chief Justice Cornelius J. Harrington of the Cook County Criminal Court, who found the women guilty yesterday, after hearing the case without a jury.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Theodore A. Lightner of New York and B. Jay Becker of Philadelphia led a field of twenty-eight contract bridge pairs here this afternoon in the first three sessions in the sixth annual competition for the Waldemar von Zedtwitz Gold Cup for master pairs.
The text of General Hugh S. Johnson's speech on the strike against Works Progress Administration projects, which he read over the radio last night, follows:

DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Jean Miller declared on the witness stand today that she had nothing to do with the slaying of Howard Carter Dickinson or the robbery plot which preceded it. The robbery netted $134.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Lawrence Hanover, with Hugh M. Parshall in the sulky, today gained a two-out-of-three victory over six trotting rivals at Rockingham Park in the final rehearsal for next week's $40,000 Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Senator Vandenberg's address before the senator today on the administration Tax Bill was as follows:

POINT O'WOODS, L.I., Aug. 8. -- With the class thrown into utter confusion by the fouling and capsizing of a mark, Harry Meislahn and Reeves Bowden sailed the Star boat Sunbeam to victory in today's race of the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy competition, but Harold Halsted kept the series lead by adroit handling of Chuckle II under difficulties.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A promise of five weeks of grand opera for Chicago during the 1935 season, at top prices of $3 per seat, was made tonight by the Chicago City Opera Company.

Adam H. Davidson of Dallas, Texas, objected yesterday in a statement issued here, to what he called the "incomplete and probably misleading" announcement of the Federal Trade Commission in Washington that he had "received a commission of $1,000,000 for procuring gas options in the Louisiana and Mississippi natural gas fields and acquiring franchises for the distribution of gas by the Southern Natural Gas Corporation in Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia."
BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- An authoritative source said today there was a possibility of serious deficiencies in some German food supplies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Continuing their recent rise, wholesale commodity prices advanced a bit in the week ending Aug. 3, bringing the Bureau of Labor statistics index to 79.6, as compared with 79.2 the previous week and 75.1 a year ago. The index uses 1926 prices as 100.

For the third consecutive week there was a marked increase in the volume of goods sold and in production of silk and rayon fabrics, according to a report issued yesterday by the research and planning division of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

Twenty thousand persons filled Madison Square Garden last night when a mass meeting under the auspices of the anti-Nazi Federation denounced Hitlerism and fascism and demanded that the United States withdraw from the 1936 Olympic Games to be held in Berlin. The names of prominent Nazi leaders were hissed and the name of Mussolini was booed.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The unusual proposal that Communists ally themselves with churchmen for a fight to overthrow the Nazi regime was presented today to the seventh congress of the Third International.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, Chief of the Army Air Corps, was retired from active service today at his own request, thus terminating the controversy in which he had long been involved with the House Military Affairs Committee and closing the career of the pioneer aviation officer of the army, who has been an active flier for twenty-six years.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Worcestershire, aided by masterful bowling by R. Howorth and R.T. Perks, defeated Gloucestershire by eight wickets in the game concluded today in county cricket competition. Howorth took six wickets for 15 runs and Perks for 33.

" The Old Maid," which has passed up its two Saturday performances since early July, Pulitzer Prize or no Pulitzer Prize, will resume them tomorrow. In sum, those week-end vacations for the cast will take the place of a layoff prior to the Autumn tour.

The Atlas Corporation, in issuing its semi-annual report showing its condition as of June 30, announced yesterday that the directors had declared a dividend of 30 cents a share on the common stock, the first distribution ever made on the issue.

New York will have begun a real revolution when the new ballet in the modern Russian manner supplants the old classic ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House next season. EDWARD JOHNSON, now in Mr. GATTI-CASAZZA'S place, makes the announcement.

Blessed Martin de Porres, Negro lay brother of the Dominican Order, who lived in Lima, Peru, 1579-1639, where he ministered to the needs of the sick and the poor and extended his mercies even to rats, has become the subject of prayers on the part of thousands of Roman Catholics in the United States who want him canonized as a Roman Catholic saint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Official announcement was made today that because of "generally unsettled" conditions the Export-Import Bank would take no action on the applications by American exporters for credits to finance cotton shipments to Italy.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 8. -- James E. Cuff, 64, one of this city's most widely known citizens, a former postmaster and friend of Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, died of a fractured skull in the Albany Memorial Hospital at 5:30 A.M. today after an automobile accident at East Greenbush, near Rensselaer, N.Y., shortly after midnight.

OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 8. -- In connection with the tercentenary celebration which is being held in Old Lyme this week, the craftsmen of the town have arranged a special exhibition in the famous old Peck Tavern, dating from 1675, now the headquarters of the Old Lyme Guild.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer slept late yesterday morning in his hotel room at Bridgeport, Conn., ignoring an order for his appearance in Supreme Court here. He was permitted to do so for the time being, but officials of the State Department of Taxation and Finance hinted that his slumber might cost him three times the $36,937.18 they are trying to collect from him -- or more than $100,000.

A former headmaster of Rugby School, Dr. A.A. DAVID, now Bishop of Liverpool, in a "Speech Day" address made a fresh attempt at describing or defining an "educated man" -- almost as hard to define, says The Morning Post, as a gentleman. His definition is unique in that it relates chiefly to one's attitude toward work and leisure:

The Government's first estimate of the new cotton crop, made public precisely at noon yesterday, was awaited with even more than the usual interest which attends this August forecast. AAA is under heavy fire in the courts. New England is disturbed by the processing tax.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 8 (AP).--Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt arrived in England today and announced with flashing eyes:
Claude V. Allnutt, 56 years old, a vice president of the Irving Trust Company, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping 122 feet from the George Washington Bridge.

The government's first estimate on the season's cotton crop, indicating a yield of 11,798,000 bales, or 2,600,000 larger than promised on Aug. 1 last year, was 300,000 to 400,000 bales more than had been generally looked for, and prices on the Cotton Exchange broke nearly $2 a bale at one time yesterday.

In a statement issued yesterday James Marshall, a member of the Board of Education, characterized as "the most important item" in the 1936 budget of the board a request for $103,000 for enlarging the scope of the Bureau of Reference, Research and Statistics.

May I, through your columns, advise those who are anxious to know if pigeon cotes are to be built in Central Park this Summer, that the Park Department has definitely decided not to build them? This is indeed bad news for all who are interested in the pigeons. Those of us who try to feed them daily know too well that it means cruel suffering and hardship for them again next Winter.

Grudgingly the legislators at Washington make small concessions in the interest of a better, fairer and more constructive air mail act. Approval by both Houses of the conference report on the McKellar-Mead bill permits the transcontinental lines to retain their coastal routes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Billy Herman's hitting and Tex Carleton's relief pitching combined to bring the challenging Cubs from behind and defeat the Pirates, 9 to 5, today. The triumph moved the Chicagoans within two games of the leading Giants, who dropped both ends of a doubleheader at Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A Congressional investigation into circumstances accompanying consideration of the Copeland Food and Drugs Bill at this session of Congress, and of the Tugwell bill at the last session, and also into the trade practices of industries affected by the Copeland measure, was urged today by J.B. Matthews of Consumers Research, Inc.

The $200,000 flood-control survey of up-State New York was ready to go today, pending formal notice from Washington that the necessary appropriation had been approved, Captain Lester F. Rhodes, veteran of army flood-control projects in the Mississippi Valley, told The Associated Press.

Every time some distinguished jurist is compelled to lay aside his judicial robe by reason of his having attained the age at which retirement is compulsory, we are accustomed to lament his passing, and to wonder at the wisdom of a rule which, in one fell swoop cuts off from us an individual full of years and learning, and apparently at the peak of his intellectual power.

Of 2,180 papers turned in at the twelfth annual Music Memory Contest, held in conjunction with Wednesday night's concert by the Goldman Band at Central Park Mall, two were rated a perfect score and one 97 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Federal taxes and penalties of about $653,000 have been levied against the Empire Power Corporation of New York for alleged fraud against the government in respect to taxes and for alleged aid to its stockholders in tax-dodging.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

NOW Shufflin' Joe Louis is well along the trail on the big game hunt. Baer next. If the Harlequin of Hollywood is knocked out of the way, Shufflin' Joe will be in the clear for a heavyweight title bout with Jersey James Braddock.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Rochester split even with Newark in two pitching duels today. The Bears won the first game behind Ted Kleinhans's five-hit pitching, 2 to 1, with the Red Wings taking the second, 3 to 2, in ten innings, as Weiland checked the visitors with five hits also.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works filed yesterday in the United States District Court in Philadelphia a plan of reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, providing for the conversion into new securities of all its outstanding issues except the first-mortgage bonds.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses attended an open-air dance in Harlem last night to make a surprise announcement of plans for the development of a major recreation centre for that section of the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--After hearing a final attack by organized business on the excess profits tax provisions of the House Tax Bill, the Senate Finance Committee closed its hearings today and will begin tomorrow to draft its own bill, with hopes of introducing it on Monday.
Apartment and business properties were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.
STANLEY, Wis., Aug. 8. -- Three persons were burned to death this morning in a fire which destroyed a two-story frame farm house near this place.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The league-trailing Browns split a double-header with the Indians today by taking the nightcap, 9 to 5, after feeble hurling cost them the opener, 14 to 8.
CAMILLUS, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Cooperative action by agriculturists to bring electricity to the farms of New York State was urged today by Governor Lehman.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The wheat market continued today to fluctuate erratically, reflecting conflicting views. General evening-up was active for the government report to be issued late tomorrow.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The Tigers lengthened their lead over the Yankees to five games today as they defeated the White Sox, 5 to 2, in the first of a four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Asserting that his activities in no way affected interstate commerce, Robert W. Lyons, counsel for several chain store systems, refused today to submit to questioning by the special House committee investigating chain store activities, and declined to recognize the committee subpoena calling for his presence.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- The Giants dropped both ends of a double-header to Jimmy Wilson's Phillies at Baker Bowl today, saw their pennant lead cut and stood helpless while their two pitching aces were harshly treated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 8.--The possibility of a nationwide strike among WPA workers was expressed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, here tonight at the close of the day's session of the meeting of the executive council of the organization.
ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Flood waters raging down the Muskingum River valley approached their crest here tonight and threatened to tear away levees protecting the city.
PARIS, Aug. 8.--Five persons were killed and 200 wounded today in serious rioting by naval workers at Toulon, and a state of siege was declared in the city.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8. -- Miss Margaret Russell of Detroit, Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky.; Mrs. D.T. Atwood of Chicago and Miss Marion Leachman of San Francisco won their way to the semi-finals of the women's Western golf tournament at the Westwood Country Club today.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Developments in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute lent strength today to the growing belief that Emperor Haile Selassie is turning to the Orient for munitions the rest of the world thus far has denied him.

TOKYO, Aug. 8. -- Ambassador Tsuneo Matsudaira's return from London has given the press an opportunity for speculations on the future of Anglo-Japanese relations which, though devoid of official foundation, have some interest as political weather signs.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Aug. 3 showed a rise of 13 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase compares with a gain of 12 per cent for the previous week. For the four weeks ended Aug. 3, the rise in deliveries, made for about 250 stores in the metropolitan and suburban areas, was also 13 per cent.

Unsettlement of the market for United States Government loans was the feature of bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Trading in the Federal issues expanded sharply and sales reached $3,350,700, compared with $700,000 on Wednesday.
LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

PANAMA, Aug. 8. -- Present conditions in the United States and its relations with Latin America were discussed by Leo R. Sack, United States Minister to Costa Rica, in an address before the Spanish-American Study Centre here today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -- One of the unique events of the season in behalf of philanthropy took place here tonight when the first in a series of melodramas for the benefit of the William Carey Camp of the Boys Club of New York at Jamesport, L.I., was presented on board the showboat Periwinkle in the canal near Canoe Place Inn.

PARIS, Aug. 8. -- Schiaparelli's is the most exciting of the Winter couture collections seen to date. It is regal when it comes to the matter of fabrics and colors; royal purples flash and crown-patterned prints are prominent. On the other hand, the daytime, silhouette is simple and democratic.
Overpowering heat left deaths, prostrations and shattered temperature records in the Middle West yesterday.

Publication of some of the facts about bonus-marchers in Washington, or on their way there, who were transported to several camps in South Carolina and Florida, led the Federal Emergency Relief Administration to state its policy in the matter. If this had been done earlier, and more frankly, it would have prevented suspicions about a plan of which the public was left in pretty dense ignorance.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The secret police announced today the suppression of the National Socialist Front Fighters League [Steel Helmet] in Berlin and the Provinces of Brandenburg and Pomerania for reasons of "public safety, quiet and order."
Manhattan remodeling projects reported yesterday included conversion of a West Fifteenth Street loft structure into apartments and alteration of a Murray Hill house owned by J.P. Morgan.

Justice John C. Madigan of the City Court decided yesterday that the United Steel Works of Duesseldorf, Germany (Vereinigte Stahlwerke Aktiengesellschaft), must make good the principal and interest of its bonds, despite the decree of the German Government in 1933 which placed them in virtual default.

Sol Waitzman, a retail fish dealer, who testified at the trial of Joseph (Socks) Lanza and twenty-seven other defendants accused of operating a trust in the fresh-water fish market, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on four counts alleging perjury.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- Stopping here on their way to their Summer home, Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, and Mrs. Knox were guests of honor at a luncheon for forty given by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons, the latter Republican National Committeewoman for Rhode Island, at their home, Winter Cottage, today.

Attendants at the bird house in the Zoological Gardens in the Bronx are on their mettle now that they have humming birds to care for once again. Three of the species, raised in Venezuela, were brought to the gardens three weeks ago by way of a Bronx express subway train.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 (AP).--Advising Anna, a recent purchase from the stable of Jack Howard, today captured the Mayor's Purse, mile feature of the Suffolk Downs program, in the fast time of 1:38.3 in her first outing under the colors of Mrs. Floyd West.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--With receipts of hogs this week setting a new all-time low record, officials of the Union Stock Yards and Transit Company ordered the closing today of half the hogs pens at the stock yards as an economy measure.

Mrs. Michael Capezza, 37 years old, of 116 East Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, mother of four children, was accused by the police yesterday of having trained her 13-year-old son and other boys to be robbers.

Prices of domestic staples on the local commodity futures markets were unsettled yesterday by the cotton report, but other futures continued to advance moderately in light trading. In the cash markets, wheat, corn and rye declined with cotton, while lard, printcloths and rubber advanced.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Two eighteen-knot former Canadian Pacific liners, the Melita and Minnedosa, of 15,183 tons each, have just been added to the fleet that Italy is accumulating to transport troops and supplies to East Africa.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 8. -- With the International Union Printers baseball title virtually in its grasp, New York collapsed today, lost a double header to Detroit and was eliminated from the tournament.

CAMP CHIEF OURAY, Colo., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Daring mountain climbers recovered the body of 15-year-old William Brode of Memphis tonight in a "chimney" rock carved by glaciers along the jagged granite slope of two-mile-high Lindbergh Peak.
Visitors to the branches of the city's circulating library complain of a shortage of books. Insufficient money has been appropriated over the past several years.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada decreased by $17,533,276 in the week ended on Aug. 7, the bank reported today. Deposits from chartered banks rose $16,038,203. Note circulation went up slightly and reserves held in sterling and United States funds declined.

Budgetary increases of $157,522 were asked by four District Attorneys yesterday at a hearing before Rufus E. McGahen, Budget Director, on the 1936 estimates. An exception was made by the District Attorney of Richmond County in the presentation of a schedule showing a decrease of $4.50.

Shipments of $17,040,500 gold from Holland arrived here yesterday, virtually completing the current movement from that country, which started on July 25. Of the day's receipts, $11,200,000 was consigned to the Guaranty Trust Company.

James M. Washburne, who dropped from a position as head of the Martha Washington candy chain in Manhattan with an annual income of $50,000 to peddling sweets from a Times Square curbstone, is well on the way on the return journey of a round trip between riches and ruin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A new attempt to force the President's "must" Guffey Coal Bill out of a deadlocked committee was planned today by House New Deal chiefs.
Eleven properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions in Manhattan yesterday. Seven Bronx parcels also were taken over by the mortgage holders.

Mayor La Guardia, amused by newspaper stories about the six detectives assigned to guard him against violence at the hands of cranks, disclosed yesterday that the detail had been returned to other duties.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 8. -- Chilean circles in touch with the Chaco peace negotiations report that efforts are being made to find a way to give Bolivia an outlet to the sea, at least for her oil. South America is looking principally to Chile and Argentina to make the settlement broad enough to include some such concessions, since they are the guardians of the ocean gateways.

The excess of reserves over legal requirements of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System reached a new high level of $2,550,000,000 on Wednesday, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report, published yesterday. The latest figure of excess reserves compares with a total of $2,510,000,000 the week before and with a previous high record of $2,525,000,000 reached in June.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 8. -- The resolutions recently adopted by the League of Nations permit the resumption of arbitration between Ethiopia and Italy, but the arbitration is being confined to questions of fact concerning the Ualual incident. The basis of the conflict remains untouched and the conflict continues.

What the Republicans say about the Rhode Island election is discolored by hope. Is what conservative Democrats like former Governor ELY, Senator GERRY and Senator WALSH say to be disregarded because they never qualified for Mr. FARLEY'S degree F.R.B.C.? These men know the New England situation.

DANZIG, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The custom disagreement between Poland and the Free City of Danzig, threatening serious international complications, was settled amicably today with the signing of a four-point accord by representatives of the two governments.
Former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick accepted yesterday the Republican and Fusion designations for District Attorney of Kings County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--The old clash over the principles and theory of the defunct NRA flared again in the Senate today so swiftly that debate, begun on the Welsh bill to impose NRA wages and hours in connection with government contracts, was sidetracked until tomorrow.

A young couple and their two children, 2 and 4 years old, were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of vagrancy when they were found sleeping in a hallway at 647 St. Mary's Street, the Bronx. They told Magistrate Katz in Bronx magistrates court that they had been sleeping in hallways for the last two weeks.
" As long as Fred Perry and Bunny Austin are on the team, Great Britain will retain the Davis Cup."
The money market was dull. The little business reported covered routine requirements, all of which was done at prevailing quotations.

A judgment in the suit brought by stockholders of the National City Bank and its subsidiary, the National City Company, to compel the former directors to account for funds alleged to have been lost because of their imprudent acts was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday, disclosing the sums to be paid by the various directors named in the suit and the awards to the attorneys who appeared for plaintiffs for fees and disbursements.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The highest levels for hogs since August, 1929, were established in the early trading here today, when fairly general buying sent prices up 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight to a top of $12.05, exclusive of the processing tax of $2.25.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Confronted by a serious defection in his own party from the State sales tax, Governor Hoffman prepared here today for a two-day series of conferences with Republican leaders in an effort to stem the tide of opposition to the levy which he proposed and secured with the aid of Democratic votes in the Legislature.

Recently there has appeared in the advertising columns of the New York newspapers announcement of proposed or perhaps already effective reduction in rates by the public utility companies (gas and electric). In these announcements the impression is undoubtedly carried away by the reading public that the action was an unsolicited and voluntary act on the part of these companies.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N Y., Aug. 8. -- The phenomenal string of successes scored this season by the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt racers was continued today in the eighteenth running of the Schuylerville Stakes when his Parade Girl led a band of eight other juvenile fillies over the five-and-one-half furlong route.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Reiterating his confident prediction that the government would have 3,500,000 persons at work under its new program by Nov. 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, recalled today that 550,000 workers already were enrolled and "on the job."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--The old clash over the principles and theory of the defunct NRA flared again in the Senate today so swiftly that debate, begun on the Welsh bill to impose NRA wages and hours in connection with government contracts, was sidetracked until tomorrow.

A young couple and their two children, 2 and 4 years old, were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of vagrancy when they were found sleeping in a hallway at 647 St. Mary's Street, the Bronx. They told Magistrate Katz in Bronx magistrates court that they had been sleeping in hallways for the last two weeks.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 8. -- The Mount Washington Hotel management sponsored today a recital for the benefit of the New Hampshire Children's Aid and Protective Society, followed by tea and dancing, with Mrs. Orton Bishop Brown of Berlin, daughter of the Confederate general, John B. Gordon of Atlanta, as the artist.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg, Bremen, Boulogne and Southampton. Among her passengers are a group of sixty-five piano teachers from Midwestern States who have been on a tour of the leading music centres of Germany and another group of thirty-four German students who will spend two weeks in the East.

The report of the Department of Agriculture putting the indicated yield of the current cotton crop at 11,798,000 bales generally was considered bearish, but the decline was held in check by the uncertainty concerning the policy of the government toward a loan on the present crop.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The desirability of holding Anglo-French naval conversations in the Autumn has just been discussed in Paris by Captain V.H. Danckwerts, assistant director of plans at the British Admiralty, who returned tonight after several days' informal meetings with French naval experts.

With 770 men already on strike, the building trades unions yesterday pushed forward plans by which, their officials calculated, between 10,000 and 15,000 men would be called off Works Progress Administration jobs.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's lead-off production for the 1935-36 season, "China Seas," starring Clark Gable, Jean Harlow and Wallace Beery, opens this morning at the Capitol. The Capitol's new policy of presenting motion pictures exclusively goes into effect today.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Steady rainfall held up the "flying vacation" plans of Will Rogers and Wiley Post today.

The six players to represent the United States in the thirteenth annual Wightman Cup matches were named at the meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Wightman Cup Committee yesterday. The competition will be held at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, on Friday and Saturday of next week.
PARIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 8. -- Workers employed on a WPA project at League Island Navy Yard, the only Federal works improvement under way here, went on strike late today in protest against the wage rates allowed by the government, ranging from $55 to $94 a month.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 8. -- Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee crossed the line first in an exciting finish of the race for big yachts today, although Hugh Paul's smaller Astra, three minutes behind, won on her time allowance, thereby securing the coveted Silver Jubilee Cup for the most points scored during the three days' racing.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Three members' polo matches were played at the Meadow Brook Club today, with the White team of Alan Corey, Michael and Ben Phipps and Raymond Guest staging a strong finish to down the Blue riders, 9 to 7, in a high-goal match on Belmont Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Boy Scout jamboree, which was to have brought 30,000 youths from all parts of the world to this city August 21-30, was canceled tonight by President Roosevelt because of the prevalence of infantile paralysis in Virginia within 100 miles of Washington.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The season's most impressive gathering of the country's tennis elect paraded before packed stands at the Westchester Country Club today and the net results in the Eastern grass court championships provided a program that promises to bring out an even larger crowd tomorrow afternoon.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- A large week-end throng has begun to arrive here for the Saratoga Special, to be run Saturday.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Three youthful stars from the Pacific Coast and one from Florida, all seeded, today reached the semi-final round of the national junior singles tennis championship.

The American Woolen Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries, except Textile Realty Company, had a net profit of $501,015 in the half-year ended on June 30, after depreciation, taxes, inventory adjustments, interest and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.31 a share on 383,215 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value, and contrasts with a net loss of $585,020 for the first half of 1934.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A decision to report out a liquor control bill closely following the administration's recommendations was voted tonight by the Senate Finance Committee. The report is expected to be filed tomorrow.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- John Royal, vice president and program director of the National Broadcasting Company, at a reception tendered to him by directors of the German radio today, declared in favor of increasingly intimate cooperation between American and German radio systems. The official German News Service quotes him as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Conferees on President Roosevelt's Social Security Bill, tied up in conference since June 19, reached an agreement today and the House quickly approved the report, including elimination of the Clark amendment permitting continuance of private industrial pension systems.

For the first week of August, bank clearings were much higher than a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Aug. 7 was $5,596,320,000, compared with $4,086,541,000 a year ago, an increase of 36.9 per cent. In the preceding week this year, the increase was only 5.9 per cent.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 8. -- Combining an effective long game with a superb display of chipping and putting, Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Greenwich today fashioned a sparkling 83 over the 6,528-yard layout of the Wee Burn Club to win the low gross prize in an 18-hole medal handicap tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

B.W. Dyer Co., sugar trading house, have made a plea to the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange to terminate the eighteen-month suspension of the firm ordered on Jan. 23 last in connection with the "squeeze" in December, 1934, sugar contracts, it was ascertained in trade circles yesterday.
Purchase of a farm tract in Hunterdon County featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Three members' polo matches were played at the Meadow Brook Club today, with the White team of Alan Corey, Michael and Ben Phipps and Raymond Guest staging a strong finish to down the Blue riders, 9 to 7, in a high-goal match on Belmont Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Boy Scout jamboree, which was to have brought 30,000 youths from all parts of the world to this city August 21-30, was canceled tonight by President Roosevelt because of the prevalence of infantile paralysis in Virginia within 100 miles of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- In an effort to determine the part which lawyers played in bringing about the defeat of the dissolution clause in the Public Utility Holding Company Bill, the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee has sent questionnaires to more than 100 of the country's best known lawyers.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Faced with the twin problems of the rising price of pork and the growing surplus of cotton in the country, officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration were apparently proceeding today with their corn-hog and cotton programs, regardless of criticism outside of the capital.

Among 10,000 gladioli, both the "most beautiful" and the "most unusual" specimens, were displayed yesterday by one floriculturist at the opening of the sixth annual show sponsored by the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society and the Gardens of the Nations in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in July aggregated $26,172,566,175, a rise of 7.6 per cent from the preceding month, and the heaviest turnover for any month since January, 1932, except for an approximate business volume in March.
Lord SADEN-POWELL, the world Chief Scout, in discussing "the good of a Jamboree," thinking of the great camp of Scouts planned,,for this month in Washington, said: ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The deadlock which has long held up the Guffey-Snyder bill for control of the bituminous coal industry was broken in the Ways and Means Committee today, and the committee is expected to bring in a favorable report Monday.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- Not only has calm returned to the French ports, but after the serious rioting at Toulon and Brest the majority of arsenal workers at those cities and at Cherbourg and Lorient set themselves to show today that they did not intend to express dissatisfaction with salary cuts by street fighting of a revolutionary character.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R. Aug. 9. -- The fifteenth International Physiological Congress opened this morning in the central hall of the former Tauride Palace, now Uritsky Palace, after one of the early Bolshevik leaders who was assassinated in the Summer of 1918.
Money market was at a stand-still. Activity in stocks was without effect so far as any broad inquiries for funds were concerned. Quotations were carried forward without change.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt, commenting on the rising tide of defections from WPA projects in various parts of the country, declared today that these were not strikes but merely the return of men to their homes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt's Social Security Bill, designed to make the American people secure "against the major hazards and vicissitudes of life," and the keystone of his whole program for social reform, ended its long course through Congress today when the Senate ratified the conference report on the measure without a record vote.

Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner New York from a six-week vacation. He was met at Quarantine by Rudolph Leitner, Counselor of the German Embassy in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Robert W. Lyons, counsel for several large chain store systems, continued today to refuse to answer questions about anti-legislative operations in various States and demanded that he be put under subpoena by a special House committee investigating "super-lobbies'' and chain store practices.

HUNTINGTON, Ind., Aug. 9. -- Violators of minor traffic rules of the city hereafter must wear the "scarlet letter" of their shame for thirty days or pay a fine, according to a new plan worked out by R.C. Forst, Chief of Police.

Count Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, Belgian Ambassador to the United States, is sailing today for Brussels on the French liner Ile de France. Others leaving on the ship for Havre via Plymouth, include:
SEATTLE, Aug. 9. -- Despite hints of possible protests, a Japanese 'mikado" and "an Ethiopian emperor'' were burlesqued together today in a "fox hunt" staged for fun.

With the race followers up in Saratoga, the fight fans out in Chicago and August being what it is, the best that can be said of night life hereabouts during the past week is that it has been like a flagpole sitter -- conspicuous but pretty dull. One or two routine openings, a new face here or there and the rest of it biding its time.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 9. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, refused tonight to comment officially on the strikes of WPA workers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson, after a conference with attorneys on the proposed reorganization plan of theBaldwin Locomotive Works, assigned the reorganization matter to Howard Benton Lewis, former United States Attorney, as special master.

Inspired by the presence of John (Blondy) Ryan, the famous sparkplug of the 1933 Giant model, the enfeebled Yankees took a couple of deep breaths at the Stadium yesterday and forthwith revealed immediate signs of a swift recovery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- A gradual change in the type of money in the nation's pocketbooks, marked by increased use of silver and Federal Reserve currency, was reflected in the Treasury's monthly circulation statement for July made public today.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange broadened yesterday in an advancing trend, with the volume the heaviest since June 20. Transactions amounted to $13,914,000, compared with $11,519,700 on Thursday.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Jack Forrester, a dyed-in-the-wool Scot who still retains his "burr" despite a long residence in this country, stepped out in front at the New Jersey State open golf championship today by holing the difficult Monmouth County Country Club course in 70 strokes, one under par figures.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- More than 4,000 persons were thrilled by the glamour of the fourth annual midsummer ice show at the Olympic Arena tonight as the best skaters of the United States and Canada joined in an extravaganza equal in variety of group, the most finished Winter comedy and solo work to any of productions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Congressional approval of voluntary State compacts to conserve petroleum reserves was recommended by President Roosevelt in a message sent to the Capitol today. One such compact, which six States have ratified, already exists, and the President urged Congress to give its consent, as required by the Constitution, presumably before the present session adjourns.
President Roosevelt banned yesterday the use of Federal money to provide home relief for striking Works Progress Administration relief workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Social Security Bill which went to President Roosevelt today is divided, in its essential provisions, into two parts, one dealing with the long-range plan of President Roosevelt for insuring Americans against "major hazards of our economic mechanism," and the other carrying special and immediate aid to the States in caring for dependent unemployables.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., and Mrs. Philip T. Atwood of Chicago will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the women's Western golf tournament.

Although Turtle's Comet as it swirled round the sun gradually lost its cohesive force, astronomers do not know just how long ago, and may not now have even a nucleus, it is still providing an annual free display of fireworks to dwellers on earth.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- Premier Pierre Laval set a precedent in centralizing the government today when he met prefects from all departments in France in a conference over the application of his deflation decrees. Addressing them, he told them that if the Premier had called them into a conference it was because France was in an exceptional situation.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- Silently, under cover of a painstaking news suppression system, the campaign against orthodox Protestantism in Germany continues while the brunt of the government's outburst of fury against the clergy and churches is borne by Catholics.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley upheld today the action of Justice of the Peace D. Wiley Travis of Peekskill who had ordered King, the pet German Shepherd dog of Mrs. Marie van der Wee of Peekskill, put to death as a dangerous animal.

Albert Nahoum, 35-year-old father of four children, who says that his hands were crippled as the result of shoveling snow for the city last Winter, began a suit yesterday to compel the city to increase his home relief allowance, which now amounts to approximately $60.50 a month.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 9. -After reviewing the solid historical foundation for the power of the Supreme Court to declare laws invalid, and discounting as unfounded expressed fears for our form of constitutional government, C. O'Conor Goolrick, president of the Virginia Bar Association, jolted many members of the traditionally conservative group here today with a spirited defense of the New Deal.

MADRID, Aug. 9. -- The government ruled valid today the claim of Edmondo Quatrocchi, American sculptor, to approximately $520,000 worth of property in Madrid for which he assertedly paid the equivalent of $485 in 1931.

Stone Webster, Inc., reports total income of $815,792 for the year ended on June 30, compared with, $690,617 in the preceding year. Net earnings after expenses and taxes were $87,219, contrasted with a net loss of $119,786 the year before.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9. -- The new attitude of the League of Communist Youth (Komsomol), which now encourages members to cooperate with and even join bourgeois youth organizations, including religious ones, .in an effort to create an anti-Fascist united front, was explained by Gil Green, American, and Mr. Chemodanoff, of the committee of the Communist Youth International, in speeches before the Communist International Congress here.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Employment in factories in the State declined 0.5 per cent and payrolls dropped 1.2 per cent from the middle of June to the middle of July, it was reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner. Average changes for this period are decreases of 1.2 per cent in employment and 1.5 per cent in payrolls.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The unwillingness of the father of a 14-year-old-boy, crippled by infantile paralysis, to have the youth undergo an operation that might possibly "restore him to his rightful place in society" caused Children's Court Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester County to reveal today that he is considering issuing a court order to compel the operation.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hubbard Allen of the Huntington Bay colony here gave a supper dance tonight at their country home to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hubbard Allen.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 9. -- A fete entitled "A Night in Cuba" was given tonight at the Sands Point Bath Club here. Among the tropical decorations which embellished the Casino and pool decks of the club were flowers and plants contributed by Mrs. Christian R. Holmes from her near-by estate.

GOVE HAMBIDGE'S charming book-length essay on "backyard farming," "Enchanted Acre" (Whittlesey House, $2.50), is both a warning and a revelation. Mr. Hambidge addresses himself not to cultists who, for the most part, talk a good deal about the joys of country life as they sit under the ailanthus trees in New York backyards, but more to those whose itch for the soil is an incurable disease.

Strong condemnation of police tactics used in breaking up the Harlem riot on March 19 is expressed in the second report of Mayor La Guardia's investigating committee, made public without comment by the Mayor yesterday.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 9 (AP). -- For the third straight year the national junior singles tennis championship will go to California. A certain victory for California in the final was assured today when two Los Angeles youngsters, Bob Riggs and Joe Hunt, emerged victorious in the semi-finals.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- Under the lead of British funds, securities were again cheerful and mostly higher today on the London Stock Exchange. Old consols were in most demand among the British funds, strengthening further on renewed investment support and fresh Continental buying.

The speech of General JOHNSON urging the unions to abandon the WPA strike was courageous, eloquent and sympathetic in tone. He pointed to the practical folly involved in men who had not previously been allowed to earn more than $60 a month under the old work-relief program striking against an offer of $93.50 a month under the new one.
Several flats and business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Speedy action for the reorganization of the $13,000,000 issue of defaulted guaranteed-mortgage certificates known as B-K, and sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, was promised as the result of a conference yesterday of attorneys for certificate holders.

One of the most drastic changes in the recently announced waterfowl gunning regulations for the coming season was that which prohibited shooting over baited premises -- areas where individuals or groups put out food. The United States Bureau of Biological Survey, in a bulletin issued yesterday, explained the reasons for the outlawing of the practice.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Reichs-bank's statement as of Aug. 7 shows the following changes in reiehsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- A single Boy Scout wandered today through the vast camp set up to house the World Scout Jamboree which President Roosevelt called off yesterday. He was Alford Hoffner Jr., 15, of Springfield, Pa.

Humidity figures during July were the highest for the period in eight years, with the average for the month being 72 per cent, 8 per cent higher than the normal of 64, according to a report issued yesterday by David R. Morris, in charge of the Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 9. -- S. Morris Crothers of Philadelphia broke 175 straight targets to annex the Auburn Heights special, featuring the third day's events of the T. Clarence Marshall trapshooting classic today.

The hopes entertained in the hearts of the Republicans of the country and the fears that may be felt by the Democrats on account of the outcome of the recent elections in a Congressional district in Rhode Island, considering it as an indication and as a sample of what may be the outcome of the general election of 1936, are both exaggerated and misleading.

For the time being, the flow of gold to this country from the goldbloc nations appears to have halted. All of the metal engaged in Holland during the recent attack on the guilder, $28,834,600, has now been received and the only gold now on the way here is $900,000 coming from India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- After four days of arguments, conferees on the Banking Bill today reported considerable headway in composing differences. Final agreement early next week was regarded as probable.

DENVER, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Veteran mountain men praised the daring of 15-year-old Robert Henderson of Omaha as the whole story of his efforts to aid William Brode, 15, after his plunge from a cliff at Lindbergh Peak, was disclosed today with the arrival of the Brode boy's body here.

HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Premier honors went to the standard poodle, ch. Edelweis du Labory of Salmagundi, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Griess of Hamilton, Mass., in the first dog show of the South Shore Kennel Club conducted today in highly successful fashion amid splendid weather conditions.

DETROIT, Aug. (AP). -- Hank Greenberg smashed his thirty-first home run of the season over the scoreboard with Gehringer on base in the fifth inning today to give the Tigers their winning margin over the White Sox. The score was 4 to 3.

SIMLA, India, Aug. 9. -- Italy's policy toward Ethiopia is denounced throughout India, especially by the native-owned newspapers, which are scathing in their comments. The underlying attitude is an indictment of European policy and a cynical contempt for the expansionist aims of the Christian nations.
IT was about high noon yesterday that Connie Mack, baseball's venerable but far-from-antiquated thin man, eased himself into a comfortable seat and remarked:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Beginning what is expected to be a series of sweeping modifications to the $250,000,000 tax bill passed recently by the House, the Senate Finance Committee voted 11 to 8 today to strike from the measure the drastic inheritance tax provisions which the Ways and Means Committee had estimated would yield $86,000,000 a year.
ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Ohio resurveyed tonight the damage from its most disastrous flood in twenty-two years and set the total at about $5,000,000.

Further gains in retail trade in the metropolitan area were noted this week. Estimates yesterday indicated that sales volume of leading department stores ranged from 10 to 12 per cent above the figures for the corresponding period last year, or somewhat better than the increase for July.

The advance in the share market was resumed with full vigor yesterday as the demand from investment land professional trading sources easily overcame the profit-taking and "distributing" movements. The buying enthusiasm was hardly to be ascribed to any particular development in the day's news but rather to the continued encouraging showing by trade and industry.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 9. -- This community wad in a furor this morning when a 32-foot fish, weighing nearly six tons, was found in the fish traps of a fishing company, two miles southwest of the Fire Island lighthouse. The fish, which was taken from the traps after a five-hour struggle by members of the 50-foot fishing derrick Sunrise, was said to be a whale-shark.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Traders and commission houses here today construed the government's report on the wheat, corn and oats crops as about in line with expectations. The indicated yield of all wheat was only 5,000,000 bushels above the average of the private returns, although the figures on the Winter variety were somewhat larger than looked for.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- The St. Louis Cardinals rode into second place in the National League today, displacing the Cubs, when the Cards walloped the Chicagoans, 3 to 1, behind the six-hit pitching of Paul Dean.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Aug. 9. -- With the crops of tall kaoliang (a type of millet) for shelter, the hordes of bandits that roam Manchuria are indulging in a series of outbreaks unparalleled in this region for daring and savagery.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H., Aug. 9. -- A water carnival on Lake Gloriette attracted a large gathering of young people who engaged in canoe tilting, races, diving exhibitions and boat races before a throng gathered at the boathouse. Ross Allen and his orchestra played and many parties followed In the Boar's Head Grill.

Disillusioned over the rewards of a professional criminal's career, two Peekskill youths paced separate cells of the Westchester County jail last night, charged with the murder of a motorist whose kindness, they admitted, they had repaid with death.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 9. -- In a day of wholesale disqualifications and weather reminiscent of Long Island Sound, Harry Meislahn and Reeves Bowden sailed their Star boat Sunbeam into a commanding lead in the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy series this afternoon.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 10. -- Draft of a bill for control of the automobile industry was approved by the Cabinet yesterday for presentation to the Diet at its January session.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Those ninth-inning rallies in which the Giants specialize paid dividends today when the league leaders narrowly averted the humiliation of taking three straight on the chin from the lowly Phillies.

Because of the offering of a new issue of $50,000,000 tax-anticipation notes by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania next Tuesday, new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week shows a substantial increase over recent weeks.

TOULON, France, Aug. 9. -- Though the arsenal and shipyard workers called a halt to the rioting that had caused deaths and injuries yesterday, this city today swarmed with thousands of soldiers, its streets resembling an armed camp.

The directors of Corporation, at a meeting yesterday, elected T. Rieber, formerly vice president in charge of marine and export activities, chairman to succeed the late Judge C. B. Ames. Mr. Rieber will continue in charge of marine and export activities in connection with his duties as chairman.

The McCrory Stores Corporation has current assets of $9,154,912, or $1,031,550 more than was listed in the reorganization plan proposed for the corporation under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, according to testimony at the continued hearing yesterday before Robert Stephenson, special master, at 29 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt selected today three members of the arbitration board that will adjudicate the dispute involving the shipyard workers employed by the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., who have been on strike since May 13.
