Terms of the arbitration plan and names of the arbitrators will probably be announced tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- One of the most spectacular finishes seen in the Chicago racing district this season occurred in the featured Flamingo Purse at Lincoln Fields today when L.E. Komorous's Top Dog won the three-quarter sprint by one and a half lengths.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Bisons defeated the Newark Bears in both halves of a double bill tonight by scores of 7 to 2 and 14 to 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- As City Treasurer Hadley, one of the thirty-odd candidates for the Republican Mayoralty nomination, opened his campaign today with a pledge of "action" instead of promises, President Judge Brown of the Municipal Court busied himself trying to make peace among Republican factions.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Complaint of a tourist home owner that descendants of the Pilgrims had no right to regulate historic Plymouth Rock was the cause tonight for a ruling that the ancient stone belonged to all American citizens.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- The Boerse was quiet and weak today, complete stagnation developing near the closing of the session. Heavy industrials were slightly lower, Vereinigtestahl losing a half-point. Machine issues fell, Schwarzkopf receding 5/8 point.

Following Thursday's unexpectedly large government crop estimate and the sharp decline in the market, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed more resistance yesterday, led by October contracts, which recovered a quarter cent at one time.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Five Negro convicts were dead today, victims of the heat, which prostrated eight others at the Angola State penal farm yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Buset and trucks engaged in interstate commerce were placed today under Federal regulation similar to that exercised over railroads, when President Roosevelt signed the Motor Carrier Act.

GERONA, Spain, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Physicians said today that Baroness Maud von Thyssen would be blind in one eye as a result of the automobile crash last week in which Prince Alexis Mdivani was killed. Her doctors expressed "the utmost confidence" that she would recover. They said the left eye was also badly injured.

A national guide book for the United States is the biggest relief project the WPA has in mind for authors and allied trades. The work is to be in five regional volumes and will'go exhaustively into geographical and historical background, but avill not neglect museums, statues and restaurants.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Can Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery win with 139 pounds, a pound more than the greatest impost ever shouldered by Man o' War, and what juvenile of half a dozen potential champions will capture the famous Saratoga Special, are the two main problems which will face racegoers at this historic plant tomorrow.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- An Eastern Air Lines plane, with a woman and five men as passengers and a pilot and co-pilot, bumped to a safe landing here this morning despite a crippled landing gear, while firemen, policemen and two ambulance surgeons stood anxiously by ready for any emergency.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- Miss Lucy T. Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurance Saunders, was the second debutante of the season tonight. She was presented at a dinner dance given by her parents at their Summer home, Plaisance. About 150 guests were present, many of them of the younger set.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Two Governors watched today's racing events. Governor Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island, accompanied by his police escort, motored here to inspect the Saratoga Spa. He took the mineral baths at the Roosevelt Baths this morning and enjoyed the races this afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9. -- The Pan American Airways Clipper hopped off from Alameda airport for Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, and Midway and Wake Islands at 3 o'clock this afternoon (7 P.M. Eastern daylight saving time) on a train dispatcher's schedule.

The resignation of Dr. ELMER D. MERRILL as director of the New York Botanical Garden and the appointment of Dr. MARSHALL A. HOWE in his place call attention to an institution which is of far greater value to the community than its name implies. Open-air beds and greenhouses in which botanists may study plants scientifically would seem to have no strong claim upon the public's interest in times like these.

There is no evidence that farmers are dissatisfied either with higher prices for their products or with Government subsidies, but elsewhere criticism of AAA continues to increase. The most recent cause of dissatisfaction is the present situation in the market for meats.

An estimated production of 256,200 passenger cars and trucks in July by members of the Automobile Manufacturers' Association was reported yesterday. The only large producer not a member of the association is the Ford Motor Company, which, according to a previous report, manufactured 95,463 units in July.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Soil Conservation Service disclosed today that it now controls all crops for five years on 12,061 farms.

A move by the Municipal Art Committee, recently established by Mayor La Guardia, to alleviate regulations pertaining to legitimate theatres in this city so that bar might perhaps be set up in play-houses and smoking permitted in certain parts of theatres was revealed yesterday by Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association and a member of the subcommittee of the Mayor's organization which is conducting the incipient campaign.
ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Severe criticism of the prison wards of Bellevue in Manhattan is made in a report on New York City hospitals by John L. Schoenfeld of the Commission of Correction.
Apartment house deals in the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.
A total of $40,693,000 in new boned issues was publicly offered in the New York market this week, compared With $49,825,000 last week and only $17,925,000 in the corresponding time last year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The yearlings from Arthur B. Hancock's Claiborne and Ellerslie studs were disposed of tonight for a total of $118,950 before the best group of buyers to turn out since the sales began early in the week.

Plans for the campaign of former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican and Fusion designee for District Attorney of Kings County, will be prepared next week after Mr. McGoldrick returns from a visit to his mother in Massachusetts, John R. Crews, Republican leader of Kings County, announced yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- The drawing this afternoon in connection with the annual invitation golf tournament for the Maidstone Bowl was followed by the president's reception at the Maidstone Club. Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Myrick received the visiting players. Several hundred Summer colonists were present.

Most commodity futures advanced in quiet trading yesterday on the local markets. The only declines occurred in the metals group. In the cash markets wheat, corn and silk advanced and cotton and tin declined.

Announcing the designation of a full slate of candidates for the coming election, the Communist party formally, set forth yesterday a policy of employing the local campaign for advancement of the "united front" and "labor party" program enunciated at the Comintern in Moscow by American Communist leaders.

Passenger ships owned by the Italian Line which were taken over by the Italian Government for service as troop ships have been turned back to the company and no more of the line's passenger fleet will be commandeered, it was announced here yesterday.

Mr. HIPPOLYTE ROSSE, a dashing chevalier of industry on the West African circuit, has been sent to jail by an unsympathetic Paris court as a swindler. From the native point of view there was no swindling in at least one of his businesses. He sent out hunters for lions and buffaloes.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The ultimate goal of Nazi statecraft is to eliminate the Jews from Germany. Julius Streicher, editor of the Stuermet, and other anti-Semitic leaders leave no doubt as to that. A reading of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's biography, which is a sort of bible of the Nazi movement, shows that he, too, would celebrate the day when not a Jew is left in Germany.

The Maine Central Railroad announced yesterday a plan for refunding $20,000,000 of first and refunding-mortgage bonds due on Dec. 1 and $2,961,000 collateral-trust 6 per cent bonds due in 1959, the latter being callable now at par. E.S. French, president, said acceptance of the plan was an alternative to "action under the bankruptcy law or other judicial proceedings."

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The fifth annual Economics Conference for Engineers will open here tomorrow at the Engineering Camp of the Stevens Institute of Technology, with an attendance of about 125 engineering graduates of twenty or more colleges and universities.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- It was officially announced today that at the end of July the total number of registered unemployed in Germany had dropped to 1,754,000. This compares with the record high of 6,013,000 at the end of January, 1933 -- beginning the year 1 of the National Socialist epoch -- which is used as the standard of comparison to measure National Socialist achievements.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- A dark-horse contract bridge team with an ocelot named Ossie for a mascot eliminated the top-seeded foursome of Harold S. Vanderbilt, B. Jay Becker, Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine by the narrow margin of 160 points here this afternoon in the first knockout round in the national challenge team-of-four contest for the City of Asbury Park trophy.

With two out in the ninth inning and the tying run on second base, Signor Anthony Cuccinello hit the most emphatic of his six home runs of the year to give Casey Stengel's Dodgers a last-minute 6-to-5 triumph over the Braves at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Tom Noonan, "bishop of Chinatown," left his residuary estate, valued at "more than $10,000," to the Rescue Society Mission of 5 Doyers Street, of which he was superintendent, it became known yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. Mr. Noonan died on July 25 last.

It seems to me that your editorial characterization of the late Frank H. Hitchcock. while recognizing his exceptional abilities and public service, is stretched beyond 'he line of fairness. A more or less intimate contact with General Hitchcock over a period of years impressed me particularly with his high moral plane as well as his mastery of political organization and his adeptness in political strategy.

Freekled faced, tousle haired, shirtless, and tough, Herby Kaplan, 10 years old, hitched up his trousers and told the story yesterday of how he and Jakey Sussman broke a forty-year record for the Henry Street Settlement. It wasn't, he admitted, premeditated, for he and Jakey of the cherubic smile got themselves thorougly misplaced somewhere in the wilds around White Plains, shortly before lunch time, during a picnic on the Felix Warburg estate on Thursday.

If not exactly at hand, the end is in sight for Broadway's leading musical comedy success, "Anything Goes!" The show, with the company now playing at the Alvin, is expected to begin its road tour in Philadelphia on Nov. 4, and thereafter journey to Washington on Nov. 18; Pittsburgh, Nov. 25, and Chicago, Dec. 2.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 9. -- The best racing of Cowes week was seen today as the Royal Yacht Squadron's regatta neared its finish.
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 9. -- The Securities Exchange Commission was attacked by Oklahoma oil royalties dealers today in a suit charging the act creating the commission was unconstitutional.

No political dictum has been more steadily drummed into the ears of the public than the assertion that Republicans cannot hope to win elections. unless they have an acknowledged national leader and a platform uniting the party. Rhode Island had something to say 'about this on Tuesday.

William H. (Bill) Houghton might have been a successful executive had not his employers in 1904 decided that he was fitted particularly to track down a man who had vanished with the concern's secret formula for waterproofing cloth.

Mrs. Sarah Henkin, 48-year-old sister of Irving Berlin, song writer, jumped to her death at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon from the roof of a four-story apartment house at 591 Williams Avenue, near Livonia Avenue, Brooklyn. She lived with her husband on the third floor.

I see where Governor Harry Nice of Maryland, after a brief visit with former President Hoover, declared that the Roosevelt administration is "totally insane." Governor Nice further told the members of the Union League in Sail Francisco that he wanted a "return to national sanity."
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 9. -- In view of the crisis with Italy, especial interest is being shown here in the construction of a new road between Addis Ababa and Kurmuk in the Sudan.

With wholesale markets thronged with buyers and wider increases being recorded for retail sales, as industrial operations broadened and farmers buying power expanded, recovery took a firmer grip on most divisions of trade this week, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Governor Lehman today ordered Civilian Conservation Corps men put to work on Southern New York farms to help flood-stricken farmers rehabilitate their lands, salvage any remaining crops and get fields in shape for next year's planting.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Governor Hoffman held a series of conferences with Republican leaders at his residence here today. After the meetings the Governor said that, despite bitter primary fights in some counties, he "had not struck a case yet where the Republicans won't get together in the general election."

A group of about seventy-five youngsters ranging in ages from 8 to 16 years took exception last night to speeches being made by corner orators at Jackson Square Park, Eighth Avenue and Horatio Street, and after some mild heckling unleashed a barrage of ripe fruit and vegetables.

In the opinion of Edward J. O'Brien, editor of compilations of short stories, the English-reading public is now more interested in the American short story than in the home product. The English short story, Mr. O'Brien says, "is dozing in pleasant backwaters."

If such terms as "bindlestiff" and "riding the rods" appear in academic theses or Phi Beta Kappa essays during ensuing terms in institutions of higher learning, it may be the result of one collegian's experience during the vacation season.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The second-day fleet of the Corinthian acht Club's part in Marblehead race week decreased to 348 starters today. The yachts again experienced ideal Marblehead racing conditions, with a moderate easterly wind freshening during the day.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- The Bourse ended the week today with an extremely dull session in which trading was reduced to an absolute minimum. Faced with a week-end in which the popular reaction to the decree laws and the rioting in French ports can be ascertained, investors preferred today to stay away from the Bourse.

RED BANK, N. J., Aug. 9. -- While Governor Hoffman and United States Senator W. Warren Barbour were conferring in Sea Girt today with Republican leaders in an effort to iron out the opposition within their party to the sales tax before the Fall election, Assemblyman Theron McCampbell, bitter opponent of the tax, aroused the community here this evening by staging a spectacular "test" demonstration against the tax.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The thirty-hour-week proposal was passed by the Senate two years ago, but died in the House. In advancing it today as a substitute for the Walsh bill, Senator Clark contended that it would "write into law what the (Walsh) bill leaves to the discretion of some bureaucrats."

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- There were hardly sufficient hogs on sale today to establish a market, buyers refused to bid up for the limited offerings, fearing to create a runaway affair, and sales were steady to 10 cents a hundred weight lower, compared with Thursday.

SALEM, N.H., Aug.9 (AP). -- Bertha C. Hanover, with Henry Thomas handling the reins, returned to top form and swept two of the three heats in the free-for-all trot that featured today's Grand Circuit program at Rockingham Park.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 9. -A war of words raged in this old Cape Cod town tonight over the issue of free speech.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Keen competition was the keynote of the second annual Sagamore horse show, which opened today in the ring at the Hotel Sagamore, where hundreds of cottagers, guests and visitors assembled.

Religious services will be conducted at 3:45 o'clock this afternoon and again tomorrow afternoon on a wharf at the foot of John Street, on the East River, commemorating the 175th anniversary of the arrival here of the first group of Methodist Episcopal immigrants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- A decline of about 123,000,000 bushels in the indicated wheat crop between July 1 and Aug. 1 and an increase of about 227,000,000 bushels in corn for the same period were estimated today by the Crop Reporting Bureau of the Department of Agriculture.

The city won a partial victory yesterday in its suit against Herman Blume, Municipal Court stenographer, who was absent from duty for eleven years doing private work but collected $34,963 salary and paid substitutes during that period. Supreme Court Justice Valente, who heard the suit for the entire amount, ruled that the city could not collect for the period barred by the six-year statute of limitation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Increased business caution in Japan, accompanied, however, by some encouraging trends such as less unemployment and a gain of 17 per cent in exports for the first half of 1935 as compared with 1934 and a 16 per cent rise in imports, was reported today by the Commerce Department's weekly survey of conditions in our foreign markets.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The star of one of America's leading Davis Cup hopefuls lost luster today while the dimmed effulgence of another was revivified in the Eastern tennis championship at the Westchester Country Club.

David O. Selznick, president of the recently organized David O. Selznick Productions, Inc., announced yesterday that his first production as a unit producer under the United Artists releasing banner would be a screen version of Frances Hodgson Burnett's "Little Lord Fauntleroy."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Fresh from his triumph in the Rhode Island open championship, T. Suffern Tailer, former metropolitan amateur titleholder, turned in a 71 today to win the medal in the Maidstone Club's annual invitation golf tourney.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9. -- Lou N. Bloom, president of the Northeastern Ohio division of the Amateur Athletic Union, said today he would summon Jesse Owens, fleet Ohio State track and field star, to appear before the division Board of Directors either tomorrow or Sunday to defend his amateur standing.

When the Grace liner Santa Barbara sails from New York today for Guayaquil, Ecuador, it will carry among its passengers Captain Eric E. Loch, leader of the 1935-36 Andes-Amazon Expedition, and four of his aides. The purpose of the expedition, which is under the auspices of the Museum of the American Indian (Heye Foundation), is to establish contact with the Ssabela Indians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9, -- President Roosevelt approved today the sentence of dismissal from the army of Colonel Alexander E. Williams of the Quartermaster Corps. The dismissal will become effective Monday.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Loretta Jackson testified today that Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea "raved and swore" to make her and three other defendants confess to the slaying of Howard Carter Dickinson.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Marjorie Edwards, a promising 12-year-old California violinist, gave a recital at the Hanna Farm tonight. Although she has been playing in recital in her native State (she was born in Oakland) for six or seven years, this was her first out-of-doors concert anywhere. The audience was very enthusiastic.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Catholics in the St. Paul Archdiocese today were ordered by Archbishop John Gregory Murray to spurn and renounce membership and employment in any organization cooperating with birth control movements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Black-Connery Thirty-Hour Week Bill was offered in the Senate today as a substitute for the administration sponsored Walsh Government Contract Bill, which imposes NRA wages and hours on government contractors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Metropolitan New York has more retail beer dealers than any State with the single exception of the Empire State itself, reporting one out of every eleven in the country. This was disclosed today by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- The mode chez Lucien Lelong is luxurious in the extreme. Specially woven stiff satin brocades, chiffon velvets, epingle velvets and star-dust failles make trailing evening gowns and enormously wide floor-length capes that are ecclesiastical in character.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Wilcox Air Base Bill authorizing the establishment of an elaborate air-defense system will be signed by President Roosevelt, he said today, but his approval of the bill will not represent a commitment to proceed with the indefinite expenditures involved in the program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Waterman W. Porter, 48 years old, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of using the mails in a scheme to defraud more than 2,000 persons who put $1,700,000 in three investment concerns he operated.

ST, LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP). -- His word picture of a new Mark Twain -- the American humorist as the social charmer of Vienna at the turn of the century -- today won for C.E. Carpenter, Geneva, Switzerland, the eighth annual essay award of the International Mark Twain Society.

The Citizens Budget Commission, contrary to the statement of John Hughes, in his communication to THE TIMES took full consideration of city messengers receiving as low as $1,200 annually, in its recent report showing city salaries far in excess of those paid in private employment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt soon will have a new $5,000-cook stove in the White House kitchen. The stove, already built, is a shining stainless steel and chrome plate electric unit, about the length of an ordinary railroad box car, with ranges, ovens, frying kettle, griddle and stock kettle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt signed the Bus and Truck Regulation Bill, recommended in a message that Congress approve State compacts for oil conservation, backed up Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, in his stand on work relief "strikers," and announced the selection of three members of an arbitration board for the Camden shipbuilding strike.

The Goodyear Tire and rubber Company and subsidiaries earned in the half year a net profit of $2,404,778 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, subsidiary dividends and other charges, according to the financial report made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Civilian Conservation Corps jobs have gone a-begging and the recruiting program is off schedule by months.
TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 10. -- How Frank H. Hitchcock kept Europe from scrapping the Monroe Doctrine, a story he did not want revealed until after his death, is disclosed now by his friends.

THIS reprint of a famous book has been eagerly awaited. The original has long been out of print, and copies sell at a premium. No work has taken its place. With a scope far wider than its title indicates, it deals not merely with the fur trade, but with the physical geography and geology of the Far West, the fauna and flora, the Indian tribes and the struggles for mastery between red man and white.

TO say that "Land Under England" is an unusual book is sheer understatement. It is so unusual, it departs so far into the eerie realms of the imagination, that at times it comes perilously close to alienating the will-to-believe.
VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 10 (Canadian Press). -- The Rev. Bernard Hubbard, "glacier priest," will leave for Alaska tomorrow to investigate another scientific theory.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- As far as Berlin is concerned, there is still nobody home in higher governmental circles. But that does not imply any cessation of political activity -merely its transfer.

The writer has been a close observer of the fortunes of lighter-than-air craft since the United States first took them up. The airship has shown itself to be practical, The Graf Zeppelin has plodded on through the years and hung up a remarkable record.
TOKYO, -- Envoys of Japan throughout the world have been launched upon a campaign to correct erroneous information about Japan found in foreign textbooks, museums and encyclopedias.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Modern turf history was made today before 25,000 persons, including the Governors of New York and Pennsylvania, when Discovery carried 139 pounds to a smashing victory in the Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap and Red Rain and Coldstream ran the first dead heat in the Saratoga Special since its inauguration in 1901.

ON BOARD SCHOONER MORRISSEY, Aug. 9. -- From New York to Brigus, Nfld., we had a splendid run. The Morrissey made a record of just one week to the hour. Our stay was short, just long enough to pick tip extra boats and camping outfits.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8. -- A strike of 2,600 tiff miners in the Ozark foothills less than seventy-five miles from St. Louis, the first such in the entire history of the region, reveals an economic plight of workers only casually known hitherto to the outside world.

SYDNEY. AFTER a fashion recalling the famous Oklahoma land rush, fifteen business sites in the new township of Tennant's Creek, a gold field in the northern territory of Australia, recently were granted to those who were first to peg the four corners of the block they preferred and fleetest in the subsequent race to the warden's office with their application.

Safety is the basis for all successful traffic regulation, according to Colonel Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner, who expressed this opinion yesterday following an aerial survey of motor vehicles in the city's streets.

The conveyor system of mass production, which has become a by-word of the new mechanization since Henry Ford began using it for putting motors into buggies, is now to be applied to the Diesel engine, younger but bigger brother of the gasoline motor.

Plans to bring relics of early American Methodism to the archives of the Old John Street Church, 44 John Street, and restore Wesley chapel in the basement, fitting the entire edifice as a shrine for Methodists the world over to visit, were announced yesterday afternoon by the pastor, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Fencing in faultless style, with his owner in the saddle, the big brown gelding Brian Boru this afternoon won the Meadow Brook Masters Trophy, one of the prized awards in the seventh annual horse show on the grounds of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Surgeons today removed a goitre from the throat of Mrs. Amelita Galli-Curci, famous diva, at Henrotin Hospital, while she sang tones and scales so that they could study how the operation might affect her voice.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP). -Relief agencies assisting residents of the flood-stricken Muskingum Valley faced new problems tonight as a severe rain storm hit Massillon, filling streets with water and again swelling streams which had somewhat subsided.

Dr. Hernan Romero of Chile was elected secretary of the Pan-American Medical Association, at the recent "Floating Congress" of the association, it was announced here yesterday by the Chile-American Association, Inc., of 225 Broadway.

Gifford C. Ewing in THE NEW YORK TIMES writes so plausibly in defense of the little red schoolhouse that it is quite possible other readers will share his misapprehension of what the New Jersey State Planning Board has in mind.

David Alper, the youth Who insisted on an elevator ride although he was coatless in a building that required front elevator passengers to wear coats, walked out of Jefferson Market Court yesterday like a vindicated champion.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- In a rail-down breeze today at the American Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta, the Norwegian-built 12-meter Cantitoe scored a decisive victory over the two new international twelves of this country.

HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- A committee of twenty-one representatives of Cuban industry, agriculture, commerce, labor and press, headed by Jose Manuel Casanova, president of the Cuban Social and Economic Union, departed this afternoon on a Pan American Airways plane for Miami en route to Washington.

Are men as wary, cool, suspicious and mean about women as Mrs. MARGARET CULKIN BANNING, a distinguished Western novelist, paints them in Harper's Magazine? "They Raise Their Hat" is the ironical title of her article. At least many of them do; of those that don't it should be charitably supposed that, dedicate to wind and sun, they scorn to crown their brains.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10. -The first of three special concerts by the Vienna Philharmonic, to be broadcast on successive Sundays from Salzburg to America, will be given at the Mozarteum tomorrow under the direction of Felix von Weingartner, who will conduct Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony, which he gave at the first orchestral concert in the current Salzburg festival two weeks ago.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10. -The two-week training period of the 2,200 New York City National Guardsmen of the Ninety-third Brigade, was completed here at Camp Smith today when the members of the "Old Sixty-ninth" of Manhattan and the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn were mustered out and paid off.

IT would be unfair to Dr. Ralph Willard, described as "a dark, intense young research chemist," to judge him and his work by the dispatches that came from Holywood last week. The doctor froze a tubercular monkey, Jakal, so the story runs -- froze him stiff as a board.

A specimen group of 100 large corporations in the United States, representing twenty-four industries, is owned by 4,678,470 investors who hold an average of 113.88 shares each, according to a study by the stockholders' department of the General Foods Corporation, given out yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Litigation instituted by Mrs. Marie L. Van Der Wee of Peekskill to save the life of her 4-year-old German shepherd dog King will be carried to the United States Supreme Court on appeal and to Governor Lehman for pardon, if necessary, it was stated today by Everett Frooks, her counsel.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8. -- Kentucky's free-for-all primary, with three Republicans and five Democrats seeking their respective party nominations for Governor, resulted in Circuit Judge King Swope of Lexington winning Republican honors overwhelmingly, but no Democrat emerged from the scramble with a clear majority.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Assemblyman Theron McCampbell of Monmouth County continued his "potato test" demonstration against the New Jersey Sales Tax Act here today by selling 925 100-pound bags of potatoes at 25 cents a bag with no sales tax asked or accepted.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 8. -- Spurred on by prospects of a bumper crop with satisfactory prices, Midsouth merchants, bankers and business men are making preparations for the most active Fall business in years. Weather conditions have been all that could be desired.

SANTO DOMINGO, D.R. -- Customs collections on imports into the Dominican Republic so far this year have continued approximately the same as for 1934, the best year since 1930. Last year's collections totaled $3,165,000 and the first six months of this year indicate that that level will be maintained unless there are unexpected declines between now and December.

PORTSMOUTH, R.I., Aug. 10. -- For the second successive day the immaculately groomed and impressively performing standard poodle Ch, Edelweis du Labory of Salmagundi, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Griess of Hamilton, Mass., gained the best in show award today in the thirty-first annual Rhode Island Kennel Club show on Mrs. Moses Taylor's picturesque Glen Farm.

" Petroleum, The Story of an American Industry" is the title of a 95-page pamphlet issued last week by the American Petroleum Institute. The purpose of the book, it is explained, "is to tell in simple terms of the operations and services involved in the transformation of a natural resource into useful products."

COLONIAL craftsmen are for the most part held in greater esteem now than in the days when they were designing and producing. As examples of their pottery, furniture and silver come to be definitely identified, and details of their lives are disclosed, many of these early artisans have ceased to be merely names and have become as interesting as their craft work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- With Dizzy Dean pitching masterful ball in the pinches for his nineteenth victory, the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 4 to 2, today for their eighth straight triumph.

POLAND SPRING, Me. -- Under the auspices of the Maine State Golf Association a one-day pro-amateur tournament will be held on Aug. 29 on the Poland Spring Golf Course. The ladies' championship for the Emily Rockwood Cup will be played from Aug. 5 to 9.
Before I leave America, after a month's visit, may I, a Rumanian journalist, offer my impressions of Four country to your readers.

LONDON. IN every profession success brings its own penalties. There is one in particular that falls upon popular authors. They are plagued by communications from utter strangers, who are not content to express admiration for their work -- that, by itself, might be as grateful incense in a writers' nostrils -- but attempt in addition to impose a burdensome tax upon their generosity.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- A dinner-dance was given tonight at the Westchester Country Club here in honor of the players who participated in the Eastern grass court tennis tournament which ended today. Joseph E. Higgins was chairman of the entertainment committee, E.W. Moon Jr., of the tennis committee, and Francis W. Hopkins was in charge of arrangements for the dance.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 10. -Pennsylvania's Health Department notified Virginia today that its 3,000 National Guardsmen will be barred from manoeuvres at the Mount Gretna and Indiantown Gap Reservation because of the infantile paralysis outbreak in the South.

YONKERS, Aug. 10. -- Parents of 5-year-old Helen Vasko of Hastingson-Hudson, whose eye was removed by court order two years ago, may be called upon next week by the Westchester County Children's Court to convince Anthony Spiak that he should permit his crippled son to be operated upon.

THOSE who complain that the rock garden in Summer lacks color are not acquainted with alpine members of the Campanula family. These dwarf Harebells are easy-going, with delightful dispositions and make charming guests.

Tomas Garrido y Canabal has been called the Huey Long of Mexico. He ruled the State of Tabasco by fascist technic, owing his life to a bullet-proof vest, off which bullets on occasion have harmlessly bounced. For a few months the exdictator was a member of the Cabinet of President Lazaro Cardenas as Secretary of Agriculture.

SHANGHAI. -- Japan's latest activities in North China have had the incidental but important effect of revealing China's growing strength and national unity, in the opinion of Dr. Hu Shih, one of the world's greatest living philosophers and leader of the Chinese literary renaissance.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- Again there is a feeling of nervousness such as from time to time pervades Berlin, sometimes with the subsequent justification notable in a large class of the population.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 10 (AP). -- J. Ross Jones, chief of police here for thirteen years and a World War veteran, died in a hospital here this morning several hours after suffering a mysterious bullet wound in a hotel room.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Preservation of historic sites, buildings and other milestones along the paths traveled by the men and women who created a nation on this continent has been declared for the first time to be a national policy and provision has been made by Congress to rescue and restore for the inspiration and benefit of the American people such significant reminders of their heroic past.

WITH Connecticut's celebration of her 300th birthday now at its height, visitors from all over the country are daily crossing the borders of "the great little State," where colonists adopted the first written Constitution in the world formulating the functions of government in detail.

Cabin-class passenger ships, such as the Manhattan and Washington of the United States Lines, are not as large or fast as express ships and are not concerned by the trans-Atlantic records of the luxury class craft. The crews of the cabin ships get an occasional thrill, however, when they find upon completion of a crossing that the ship has improved upon her best previous record.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 10. -Breaking 145 out of 150 clay birds, Frank Storms of Goshen, N.Y., Joseph F. Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, and H.C. Jones of East Alton, Ill., divided the honors in the Marshall Handicap featuring today's final events in the T. Clarence Marshall trapshooting tournament.

MARGOT GRAHAME, the 24-year-old English actress who played in "The Informer" and "The Arizonian" and who has just completed her third American film, "The Three Musketeers," has only one fault to find with Hollywood.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 10. -Byron Nelson, a 24-year-old Texas-born youngster, who is assistant professional at the Ridgewood Club, distinguished himself today when he won the New Jersey State open championship from one of the finest fields ever to play in the event and on one of the most exacting golf courses in the East.
JACKSON, N.H., Aug. 10. -- Social activities at Wentworth Hall included a buffet dinner last night, a water carnival at Wildcat River pool and a bridge tournament.
PARIS, Aug. 10. -- In the Winter collections now being shown in Paris no one has more successfully adapted the Italian primitive influence to the evening mode than Mme. Lanvin.

Federal legislation, based on existing constitutional statutes such as the Wilson act, the Webb-Kenyon act or the Ashurst-Sumners act, could be easily contrived to stamp out child labor or to establish maximum working hours, in conjunction with State laws, Mortimer Fischel, attorney, who was responsible for the introduction of the Ashurst-Sumners bill, said here yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 10. -- It is sufficient to think of the 300,000 men whom Premier Mussolini has mobilized for service in East Africa to realize how thorough Italy's preparations are. The Premier obviously is leaving nothing to chance.
The decision of Miss Virginia Van Wie to forego the defense of her women's national golf championship this month came as something of a surprise.

Underneath an interesting article around the recent tour of the Abbey Players in the United States there is an additional article about the affairs of the Abbey Theatre in Dublin. After mentioning the dispute between me and the Abbey Theatre over the head of "The Silver Tassie," the article goes on to say: "One of the first fruits of the reconstituted Abbey Theatre Board will be a production of 'The Silver Tassie' in August.

Confidence that the Dodgers will perform deeds not accomplished by any other club in the circuit never is misplaced. Yesterday they achieved the distinction of presenting Huck Betts of the Braves with his first 1935 victory.

Bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange in yesterday's short session was characterized by a continued advance in second-grade issues and those with convertible features. Transactions were fairly heavy for a Saturday, amounting to $5,456,400, compared with $3,432,400 a week before.

THESE little books are not very important, but if one is not discouraged by the series title Sunny Books and the unattractive cardboard container one will find six slender volumes that have some elements of appeal to 5 and 6 year olds. "Grasshopper Green," written and illustrated by John Rae, is the best of the six.
MANILA. -- Moves are already under way to amend the newly adopted Philippine Constitution. The Legislature is now considering the propriety of such a procedure.

It was with interest that I read the letter of Edward J. Carson in THE TIMES. Several years ago I attempted to raise a baby wild bird that had lost its mother, and the experience of giving it a "respectable bringing up" proved to be one of the most unusual adventures I have ever enjoyed.

MUKDEN, Manchuria. -- The agricultural population of this new empire faces one of the worst years in its history. Floods last year, lack of in this Spring, widespread and continuing banditry and a slack export market all combine to foretell acute poverty, even famine.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- First actual work under the Federal Worksl Progress Administration was sched-

With preliminary hearings on the 1936 city budget already under way and with a possible addition of $260,000,000 to the city's funded debt through works projects approved, pending or under consideration, the financial status of New York is coming again under close scrutiny.

About 1,500 boys and girls of he Yorkville area on the East Side vied yesterday afternoon for prizes in games and baby contests in the first annual Children's Day under auspices of the Yorkville Men's Club of the Home Thrift Association, Inc., a settlement house.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 10 -- Championing an expanded public works program, Secretary Ickes today asserted that many Western cities had rejected more liberal terms from Harry L. Hopkins's Works Progress Administration because they preferred to pay prevailing wages.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- The reinstatement of 120 policemen and twenty-eight firemen, discharged on Dec. 31, 1931, by Major Lemuel B. Schofield, then Director of Public Safety, was ordered today by Judge Harry S. McDevitt.

After a successful visit to Canada, during which they won nine games, drew three and lost four, the cricketers of the Bermuda Athletic Association returned yesterday to Livingston, S.I., to play the first of a series of three matches which will wind up their tour here.

Reports on consumer response to August sales of fur-trimmed coats to date indicate a slight decrease from the corresponding period of last year, according to a telegraphic survey made by the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

The opening of play in the two-day tournament being staged at Central Park to determine the New York representatives for the national public parks tennis championships at New Orleans Aug. 19 saw all the favorites gain the semi-final round in both the men's and women's divisions yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 9. -- The elements that compose France's internal structure are changing fast.

About eighteen years ago I became an American citizen, as have many others of different nationalities. Before a Federal judge we all had to swear solemnly that we would uphold the Constitution of the United States and forever renounce allegiance to all foreign sovereigns and their governments.

A JOB lot of the troubles that assail almost any traveler on the long road from the cradle to the grave is collected here by John Rathbone Oliver out of his own intimate knowledge of the lives of ordinary people.

THE virtues and faults of radio as an entertainment and cultural medium are frankly discussed in the first issue of "Radio Review," a pamphlet published monthly by the Women's National Radio Committee, an organization representing approximately 17,000,000 clubwomen, which for some time has been turning a critical searchlight on current radio programs.

CUTTING flowers for exhibition in local shows in late Summer or early Fall, or for use in the house in bouquets, involves the question of when and how to cut them, for many thoughtless gardeners defeat the entire season's work by a failure to carry out the process at the right time and in the proper manner.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 10. -- Old Lyme, Stonington and Colchester headed the list of nine towns in this vicinity which held tercentenary celebrations today.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 10 (Reuters). -- Trouble is again brewing in Siam, which in recent months has seen both the crushing of a revolt and the abdication of its King. The latest outbreak of disaffection has been in the Siamese army, and while reports of disorders in Bangkok are unconfirmed, it is thought in Malay that developments in the near future are not unlikely.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The possibility of closing the Suez Canal to Italy as a method of blocking that country's proposed war on Ethiopia already has been thought of by the British and French as a last resort should sanctions of that magnitude become imperative.

AS a Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States Louis D. Brandeis could probably not write and publish a book like his famous "Other People's Money" (recently reissued and selling in a 15-cent edition), nor could he expatiate, off the bench, on "The Curse of Bigness" as he does in the earlier sections of the present selection.

On the day before the Federal Works Progress Administration swung into the New York City work-relief picture, General Hugh S. Johnson met with a group of newspaper men to go over details of the forthcoming program. One of the significant questions put to him was: "Has the wage problem for work relief been settled satisfactorily?"

Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago newspaper publisher whose name has been advanced as a possible candidate for the Republican nomination for President in 1936, will make his first major political address in New York State at Batavia on Aug. 21.

DR. CORLETT, who is now professor emeritus after long service on the medical faculty of Western Reserve University, has here made an impressively compre hensive collection of about all that is known of the medical knowledge and practices and the medicine-men of the native American tribes from the Arctic to Tierra del Fuego and from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

The State Department expects to have complete information on the proceedings of the Moscow congress of the Communist International at its close to determine whether the Soviet pledge of noninterference in internal American affairs has been violated, William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, said in a letter made public yesterday.
With membership rosters on the increase, four yacht clubs of the metropolitan area are making preparations to provide better accommodations for their skippers and guests.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated assets on June 30, 1935, equaled $70.66 a share on the $3 convertible preferred stock, and 66 cents a share on the common stock, with securities owned in subsidiary and associated companies carried at their underlying asset values.

THE Hollywood field-gunners will lay down a barrage of six openings this week along the local film sector. The cannonading will get under way on Wednesday with new photoplays at the Rivoli and the Strand.

THE tall, thin, distinguished-looking, elderly gentleman pulled up a chair, removed his Panama hat and was just about to speak when he was rather rudely warned that it was too early to take up the subject of the Lafayette football team -- his perennial topic -- and, anyway, his misinformation on past seasons was a good guide to the worth of his football confidences.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Controversy over the proposal to change the name of the Department of the Interior to the Department of Conservation was further enlivened today by an exchange of letters. Secretary Ickes accused officials of the Society of American Foresters of "misrepresentation" or inability to understand the "plain English" of the proposed legislation, and the latter, insisting on their own interpretation of the measure, accused him of never having read it.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Naming committees to report on a program and resolutions, a joint conference of New York State and Federal officials and representatives of flood-stricken southern tier cities and villages swung into action today to chart a course designed to speed rehabilitation and prevent recurrence of the disaster that caused forty-three deaths and a property damage estimated at $2,900,000.

The merchant fleets of most of the important commercial nations of the world were reduced during the past year, according to the annual edition of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday. The nations as a whole own 64,885,972 tons, a decrease during the year of 690,640 tons from the total of 65,576,612 tons reported in June, 1934, the report showed.

MR. BLUMENFELD is a journalist who could never have been anything else. As a free lance in New York, he saw a convent on fire and sold the story for $5, so in dulging in "the first genuine honest-to-God dinner in a month." Gordon Bennett picked up the paper, declared that the story was a "masterpiece of reporting," and Blumenfeld was a made man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The Senate Finance Committee today broadened the base of the House Tax Bill to carry into effect President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing program and turned it into a device for raising $450,000,000 annually in new revenue from all classes of citizens from relief workers to the richest in the land.

THINGS are looking up for the air lines in spite of the pounding they have taken. Flying 4,993,328 miles and carrying 73,896 passengers, the scheduled line in the United States set all-time monthly records in June, Eugene L. Vidal, Director of Air Commerce, reported last week.

DETROIT, Aug. 9. -- While wholesale hog prices soared to a new high level not reached since 1925 the plans of housewives in various areas of Greater Detroit to continue the meat boycott and strike, instituted during the last week in July, were being broadened.

FOLLOWING Jascha Heifetz in the succession of soloists engaged for the final fortnight of the Summer concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium, Ruggiero Ricci, the boy violinist, will play Lalo's "Symphonic Espagnole" under the baton of Willem van Hoogstraten as the feature of tonight's symphony program.

Influenced by a recovery in Liverpool, strong stock and wheat markets and continued high temperatures in the South, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied again yesterday and ended at gains of 1 to 7 points.

Leading professional golfers of the metropolitan district will strive for qualifying places for the national P.G.A. championship when they compete Wednesday at the Pomonok Country Club at Flushing, L.I. A field of thirty-five is scheduled to start here in quest of the title now held by Paul Runyan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10, -- Filing of an application for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of an issue of $50,000,000 twenty-eight-year 4 per cent secured bonds of the Pennsylvania Company, to be used entirely for refunding purposes, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

THE dog-days hang heavily over London's Strand, the cable from that point declaims; but if there are only two openings this week, there is a deal of activity and preparation for events in the offing. Very briefly, the two openings: Mr. Shaw's "Man and Superman," commencing tomorrow night as the first of a Shavian series at the Cambridge Theatre; and on Wednesday at the Alhambra, the comedy called "Tulip Time," postponed from last week.

WITH the publication of the fifteenth volume of this monumental work, Professor Seligman and Dr. Johnson have completed the most ambitious editorial task that American scholarship, aided by foreign collaboration, has yet essayed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- Aside from labor troubles, the trend in industry and distribution in this district is satisfactory for a usually quiet Summer month. Bank clearings well above last year's figures continue to reflect the greater steel production, the harvesting of large crops, an easy money market and liberal expenditures, not only of public funds, but of private income for necessities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation and member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has been made chairman of a new division of the commission that will administer the provisions of the Motor Carrier Act approved yesterday by President Roosevelt, the commission announced today.

CARTAGENA. VISITORS to the 402-year-old "heroic city" of the Spanish Main are seeing for the first time this season a gaping hole in an inner wall of the House of the Inquisition which tells a grim story.

DO artists, then, never take vacations? The city slumbers, but the woods and seashores are full of an enkindling stir. Activity, the traveler perceives, has but changed, for a time, its habitat. This has nothing whatever to do with the leopard's changing his spots.

Arrangements have been made for a reprint of the booklet which was recently issued by the Concert Unit of the Works Progress Administration as a record of the compositions played by the orchestras under that unit from Sept. 15, 1934, to June 15, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Reflecting the continued increase in Federal employment, a report recently issued by the Civil Service Commission showed that the New Deal has added more than 150,000 employes to the Federal payroll. Most of these were appointed without examination.

Light-harness horsemen of the Western world will meet at the famous Good Time Park in Goshen this week for the annual Grand Circuit meeting which will get under way tomorrow afternoon and continue through Friday.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 10. -- The second concert of the Berkshire Music Festival was a matinee given this afternoon by Dr. Henry Hadley and an orchestra of eighty-five pieces at the Hanna Farm Arena. The weather was perfect and the attendance exceeded that of the first night, when 3,000 were present.
ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 10 (Reuters). -- Seven Ethiopian armies comprising more than 600,000 warriors will be flung into attack by Emperor Haile Selassie in the event of war with Italy.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- This is Newport's tennis week, and the members of the Summer colony are entering upon what promises to be the most active week of any season in several years. There will be a ball every night except Tuesday.

STANFORD, N.Y. -- In appreciation of the speed with which flood-damaged highways leading from New York City to this village were restored, State Commissioner of Highways E.P. Brandt will he presented with a key to this village by Mayor James Churchill at exercises in the public square on Aug. 25.

The Walsh bill, calling for NRA hours and wages in the manufacture of all goods for Federal use, will result in the creation of monopolies for the supply of materials to the government, Gilbert H. Montague, New York lawyer, declared here yesterday.

Antoine and Julius Huehn, both of whom have been engaged for the Metropolitan, are among other outstanding singers of the festival. Miss Antoine will sing the role of Maria Malibran in the Simon and Bennett opera of that name, first given at the Juilliard theatre last Winter.

SIX days before the date set for his execution, Robert Westland decides that he does not want to die in the electric chair. A jury of his peers has found him guilty of murdering his wife, ad the evidence against him has been so conclusive that he has despaired of ever being able to prove his innocence.

To most of us the normal life would be tranquil and secure. During periods of great upheaval we long for some mystical return to average good living. But it would not be difficult to show that throughout the history of this democracy the periods of relaxation have been the abnormal ones.

UNION BEACH, N.J., Aug. 10. -A shrapnel shell, found on the beach three weeks ago by small boys and discarded in a waste-paper container several days ago, exploded here this afternoon, injuring three persons, one seriously, when a beach attendant set fire to the papers in the container.

TWO numbers of the Index of Twentieth Century Artists, published by the College Art Association, come to hand simultaneously. These issues (June and July) deal with Joseph Pennell, author, illustrator and graver, who takes up the entire first number, the bibliography being concluded in the second; and in the July issue are also treated the works of Charles Demuth, George Pearse Ennis, Emil Kolzhauer and John Whorf.

WHEELING, W. Va., Aug. 10. -- The nickels in the conductors' change carriers clinked a little more merrily today. The last instalment is paid and the street car line now belongs to the workers themselves.
New York is to have "noiseless" days and nights in the near future, if Mayor La Guardia has his way.

THE title of this piece is not, as one might be inclined to assume, a quotation from that old collegiate ditty about "sometimes I wish there were more." Mr. James Lafayette Hutchison has subtitled his slim little novel "A Nocturne."
The purpose of this correspondence is to acquaint the people of the great atrocity they are -- maybe unconsciously -- committing.

The title of this story refers to a miraculous jewel known as the "Horn of Wandarra." It was found in Africa, stolen from the finder and brought to America, where it found its way into the collection of Peter Carmody, the elderly roue who is murdered in the first chapter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Developments at conferences of chiefs of local and international unions of Pacific Coast marine workers, steamship owners and officers of the Department of Labor in the last few days indicate the possibility of a grave crisis on the Pacific Coast when present agreements expire on Sept. 30.
PANAMA, R.P. -- President Velasco Ibarra of Ecuador is apparently attempting to calm the rather disturbed political situation in anticipation of the meeting of Congress.

RADIO'S amateur hours are springboards leading into widely divergent channels. Some who make the leap find current that whirl them into professional realms; many are lost in the ethereal sea soon after the dive, according to the records kept by the broadcasters.

Depicting the history of man in fifteen hieroglyphs, a massive stone screen nears completion in Rockefeller Center and soon will be revealed to the public, according to an announcement yesterday. The screen is over the Fiftieth Street entrance of the new International Building.

THE great destruction industry is again in full career -obliterating block after block of buildings in this city. With bar and sledge it belabors Broadway. Here it razes the pleasure dome the Kublai Khan of the theatre decreed in the Roaring Forties; there it batters down the playhouse he built at Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street.

For the princes and peoples of India there now opens a new chapter of far-reaching significance. The King-Emperor has given the royal assent to an act passed by the British Parliament whereby his Indian Empire is brought for the first time within a comprehensive and, to some extent, a representative constitution.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10. -- Changes in the divorce laws to provide automatic collection of alimony and severer punishment or fathers who fail to provide for their children will soon be adopted, it was announced today by Nikolai V. Krylenko, Commissar for Justice in the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic, the largest unit in the U.S.S.R.

PARIS. -- French believers in the existence of a lost continent, Atlantis, have been greatly encouraged by the announcement that the French ship Ampere has discovered a submerged peak in the Atlantic in the region where they think the lost continent had been.

SO numerous and patterned to an accepted, scholastic form have been most of the biographies of Giacomo Count Leopardi that the later appraisals of his life or work seem tainted with plagiarism. Successive translators of his verse and prose have also played true to the same form, varied only by individual ambitions to excel predecessors.

WITH the strong possibility that this season will bring the greatest influx of American tourists to Canada since 1929, the Dominion's recreation centres are launching ambitious programs as special attractions for the traveler from below the border.

THE next forward stride of air travel is to be in the direction of making journeys by night comfortable even beyond the degree of other modernized modes of transportation. The present vintage of high-speed airplanes, cruising at or near 200 miles an hour, have made it possible to span the continent between the close of one business day and the opening of the next.

RUSON, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Overcoming a handicap of two goals conceded to the Second Carps Area riders from Governors Island, the Monmouth County Country Club tied the count at 6 -- 6 at the end of the first half and continued a sustained drive to win the second match of the 16-goal tournament by the score of 9 to 8 today on Herbert Memorial Field at the Rumson Country Club.

The largest peacetime field manoeuvres in American history will start at the end of this week when 55,600 soldiers from twelve States will be concentrated in three areas in New York State, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.

A certain lack of reverence in foreigners for sacred persons and institutions in distant countries is a perennial source of international misunderstandings. And that is particularly true where Americans, in their moated grange isolated by two wide oceans, are in the position of being the "foreigners" concerned.

ONCE again George F. Johnson, veteran shoemaker at Endicott, in the valley of the Susquehanna, has anticipated in practice a theory that the nation is now discussing. Long before the present share-the-wealth orators had come to flower Mr. Johnson was quietly disposing of his fortune.

SINCE the recent political crisis which ended the reign of General Plutarco Calles as the power behind the cactus throne there has been speculation throughout the world concerning the personality of the man who is today the master of Mexico: President Lazaro Cardenas.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- Helplessly trapped an in interurban passenger car, five persons were killed in a collision today and a score were injured, several critically.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -Decreasing expenditures for education were shown in the 1933-34 school statistics issued today by the office of education.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP). -- If the Selectmen of this ancient town, in whose harbor the Pilgrims drafted the historic Mayflower compact, imagined the current agitation over free speech died with their refusal of a permit for an anti-war meeting, they learned differently tonight.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, minister of City Temple, London, will conclude this morning a series of sermons he has been preaching at Riverside Church. This evening he will preach at 7:30 o'clock at a vesper service in the quadrangle at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

With their gadgets galore and their fascinating new-fangled accessories, several thirty and forty-foot pleasure yachts cruising on Eastern waterways provide an amazing revelation of what a skipper with time and patience and, of course, with money -- can do with unusual and extraordinary equipment.

THE Five Mavericks (some of whose exploits have been recorded in two earlier tall tales by Stone Cody) rode down into Mexico to rob a thief of a muletrain of silver. They had learned that the Mexican bandit El Lobo was systematically looting the ore trains of the Bar Bullion Mine.

WHEN Mr. Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, returned recently from Europe, he made with an air of sorrow rather than anger certain observations of facts which had been repeatedly stressed in these columns.

AMONG the anatomists of small-town American life Thyra Samter Winslow has already secured for herself an extremely solid place. Successive volumes of short stories, cool, ironic, biting, have testified that she knows how dull and mean-spirited the provinces can be, and that a later experience of cities has kept her memories intact.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- Today is the final day of the Sagamore horse show, which has been attracting crowds since Friday. Among the exhibitors are Senator Walter H. Goodrich of East Haven, Conn.; Roger Young of Bronxville, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of New York City; William Brewster and Miss Elmina Brewster of New Haven, Conn.; Miss Phebe Warren of Troy; Alfred E. Heller of Brant Lake, and Charles H. Turtle of New York City.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. l0. -- Leaders of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers announced late today that the terms under which the New York Shipbuilding Corporation had agreed to arbitrate the thirteen-week strike at the shipyard here were unacceptable to the union.

RIGHT now a subject of absorbing interest to gardeners is the arrangement of flowers. In the Summer flower shows the winners are not always those who grow the most beautiful blooms. It is often observed that the clever folk who know how to display them also carry off prizes.

MANY a Summer vacationist visiting New England pauses for a brief stay at Plymouth, on whose sandy sea coast a small band of Pilgrims landed one cold December day in 1620. Invariably, the tourist finds Plymouth a simple but satisfying historical shrine.

DORIS HUMPHREY and Charles Weidman took their concert group to Bennington College, Bennington, Vt., last week for the second performance in the Summer series there, and found such an extensive audience awaiting them that the little college theatre was packed to the doors, and enough people were turned away to have filled the hall several times over.

THERE is something peculiarly romantic about owning an island, even a humble island in home waters with nothing but its isolation to distinguish it in any way. Haot, however -- presumably an invention of Mr. Camborne's -was such an island as most of us only dream of.

ROME, Aug. 10. -- A government spokesman announced tonight the Bank of Italy's discount rate would be increased by decree Monday from 3 1/2 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent, and insisted this banking manoeuvre did not mean any inflationary policy.
ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Jack Rutherfurd's flashy blue Duster established itself today as a Gold Cup contender to be reckoned with in any regatta.

CONSIDER the silhouette. The early Autumn brings one that will make girls sit up and take notice. Its slimness tells the story of bosom, waist and hips, and yet it is not bare-faced revelation. Within the confines of the outline there is plenty of ease of motion.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The new $500,000 clubhouse at Bethpage State Park. Long Island's inland Jones Beach, was formally opened today at ceremonies following a meeting of the State Council of Parks.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Determined to obtain for Sergeant Bernard J. Early of New Haven the credit given to Sergeant Alvin C. York of Pall Mall, Tenn., for annihilating a German machine-gun battalion, the Connecticut Department of the American Legion today adopted a resolution calling on Congress to award the Congressional Medal to the Connecticut veteran.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Ray Pepper's tenth-ining single scoring Julius Solters gave the Browns a 6-to-5 victory over the Indians today after they overcame a two-run lead to tie the score in the ninth.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 10. -More than 700 veterans of the Seventy-eighth Division assembled here today for their annual reunion to commemorate their wartime mobilization days at the camp. During the day the veterans renewed old acquaintances, exhibited their sharpshooting at the rifle range and participated in a series of athletic and social events.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- If the Senate Finance Committee's proposed dip into the lower income brackets should become law, it would create an anomalous situation whereby some of the persons on relief would be turning money back to the government in the form of income tax.

INCREASINGLY popular this season among tourists visiting Russia are the Soviet steamers from London to Leningrad. On board them absence of formality is the rule and a lack of conscious effort to entertain passengers during their five days at sea.

WESTBURY, L.I., -- Aug. 10. -- Two members' games, in which some of the men who will be in the national championship played, formed today's polo at the Meadow Brook Club. In one of these, a team of Whites, including Jimmy Curtis, Ben Phipps, Barney Balding and Dunbar Bostwick, defeated a Blue team of Charley Wrightsman, Dr. John Richards, Robert E. Strawbridge and Cocie Rathborne, 10 to 4.

Mamaroneck has not one but several spots to drop a hook and spend a night or a week-end, especially when a wind is blowing off the Westchester shore and a skipper wisely elects to get in a lee along the north side of Long Island Sound.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 10. -- Poland's Foreign Minister, Josef Beck, accompanied by Secretary General Count Lubiensky, arrived today for a four-day official visit which in advance has caused unusually widespread comments in Polish, German and Russian newspapers as signifying a remarkable political event.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The Boerse was slightly stronger today and somewhat more active than on the two preceding days. Heavy industrials were firm, Mannesmann gaining 5/8 point. Machines were stronger, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1 point. Chemicals were generally inactive.

AL G. BARNES, proprietor and manager of the famous circus that bore his name, who through many years gave pleasure and entertainment to numberless thousands all over this country, died a year or so ago at the date ranch of Dave Robeson in Indio, near the southeastern border of California.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8. -- After "standing by" since May awaiting an invitation to go to Washington for the final negotiation of a reciprocal Canadian-American trade treaty, a number of leading Canadian Government tariff experts have packed fishing kits and gone on holiday.

Further gains in retail trade in the metropolitan area and a sharp increase in the number of buyers' arrivals here featured local business developments last week. Increases of 10 to 12 per cent over a year ago in the sales volume of department stores was estimated by retail executives.

HIGHWAY safety has become a paramount issue in American motoring. Automobile manufacturers and allied branches of the industry are engaged in a nation-wide effort to make all who drive motor cars safety conscious.

The Social Security Bill which has gone to the President for signature is a measure of great historic importance. In addition to its sections dealing with assistance to dependent and crippled children, mothers, the indigent disabled and the blind, it provides for the first time in our history for nationwide old-age assistance, old-age pensions and unemployment insurance.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 10. -Charles Francis Risk, who, as the Republican candidate for the House of Representatives in the special Congressional election here this week, came to grips with President Roosevelt's New Deal and won easily, has his bag packed and ready to carry on his fight against the Washington administration's policies at the present session.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Next week's chief event here is the annual horse show on Saturday on the grounds of the Riding Club on Pantigo Lane from 9 A.M. until 6:30 P.M. Mrs. John Vernou Bouvier 3d and Miss Judith Hamlin head the active horse show committee this year.

The haste with which the pending Federal tax program has been initiated negatives the presumption that it was planned with any degree of deliberation either as to its scheme of operation or as to its legality.

Only one Presbyterian church building has been lost in the United States since 1929 through foreclosure proceedings, the Rev. Dr. A.B. Keeler, secretary of building aid funds of the board of national missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., said yesterday.

THE section of Route 23A between Palenville and Haines Falls, which has been closed because of damage by last month's floods, was opened to traffic last week, it is reported by the Automobile Club of New York. This highway is the direct connection between Route 9W and Haines Falls, Tannersville, Onteora Park, Hunter and other resorts in the mountains.

LEADING artists of the West Coast and Middle-Western States, and artists born in these sections but now working in other parts of the United States, are represented in the recently opened exhibition at the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Centre.

Mrs. Vera Brown, 35 years old, of 500 South Forty-seventh Street,West Philadelphia, died of a heart attack and Arthur O'Brien, 39, of 428 Ninth Street, Brooklyn, was stricken by the same ailment early yesterday while both were passengers on the fishing boat Sachem en route to Atlantic City from Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Visitors to Bar Harbor will today have a final chance to visit the beautiful gardens of its private estates. Mrs. John T. Dorrance will again open the gardens of Kenarden Lodge. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee, Mrs. John Markoe, Mrs, Edward Porter May, Miss Mary Roberts Coles, and Mr. and Mrs. George S. Munson will open their estates.

VANCOUVER. -- Canada is watching the progress of the Alberta health-insurance scheme, the first adopted in the Dominion. Under legislation recently passed, the youngest of the Provinces will be divided into medical districts with populations of 20,000, these being regarded as sufficiently large to form an administrative unit, employing a full-time curative and preventive health service.

PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 10. -- The world's first solar tower for taking motion pictures of physical and chemical changes in the sun is being built here by an amateur astronomer whose work has won high commendation from Science.

George F. Crouch last week began a movement to change the deed of gift and the allotment of the Gold Cup, America's oldest and most famous motor boating trophy, to the new international 4-liter or 225-cubic-inch class.

A fall down a vertical drain-pipe from the roof of a six-story apartment building at 296 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was the result of the curiosity exhibited yesterday morning by a small white poodle dog.

A study of the "Conquest of Pestilence" in New York City, including a graph indicating the trend toward a lower death rate and showing dramatically the toll of cholera in 1832, 1849 and 1854, was made public yesterday through the office of Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

Nathalia Crane, whose first book of verse, "The Janitor's Boy," was published when she was 9 years old, will celebrate her twenty-second birthday today with a party of young friends at her home, 36 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights.

FURTHER sharp improvement again featured retail trade last week, both here and out of town. Locally, the gain was placed at 10 to 12 per cent above volume for the corresponding period last year. Home furnishings and furs made a notably good showing.

AMOY, China, Aug. 10 (AP). -- A tale of desolation and suffering among survivors of typhoon-wrecked Chuanchow was brought here today by an American missionary, the first foreigner to communicate with the outside world since the disaster.

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP). -A 21-year-old Ohio State University student, Dexter Woodford of Akron, was crowned national amateur five-mile swimming champion today. He topped a field of thirty-one at Lake Ariel, dethroning Eddie Lee of the New York A.C., who held the title for five years.

DESPITE all that has been said and written in recent years on the marked advantage of planting new lawns in the Fall, by far the greater number are still planted in the Spring. While there is yet plenty of time to sow lawn seed -- growth will be better when danger of scorching midday suns is lessened and nights grow somewhat cooler -- it is none too early to get the ground ready.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges blanked the Chicago White Sox today, 4 to 0, as the Detroit Tigers marked up their eighth straight victory. A crowd of 25,000 saw the game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Despite the many attempts of partisan opponents, and some Washington writers, to dramatize President Roosevelt's troubles with his new Congress, the record fails to show more than one major defeat at this session.

Porters, not the wives of fish mongers, are said to have been historically responsible for the extraordinary language, in name synonomous with Billingsgate Fish Market, next to the ancient Custom House, in Thames Street, London.

More than 100 craft, inboard and outboard, will participate next Saturday and Sunday in the National Sweepstakes Regatta at Red Bank on the North Shrewsbury -- a regatta that will be second in importance this season only to last month's Gold Cup event on Lake George.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10. -- Miss Marion Miley, 21-year-old Lexington (Ky.) girl, today won the women's Western golf championship.

ATHENS, Ala., Aug. 10 (AP). -Cheers for the Roosevelt administration echoed today as Representative Arthur Mitchell, Democrat of Illinois, only Negro member of Congress, declared that it had devoted its energies toward helping the common man.

Officials of the New York Botanical Garden and the Park Department conferred yesterday to arrange the details of the $144,000 WPA project which the Federal Government has approved for alterations and repairs to the garden.

How formidable an adversary the Nazi regime faces in its present struggle against the followers of the Catholic church in Germany is partly indicated by statistics. A third of the nation's population belongs to the Roman Catholic faith, probably a third of its school children and students receive tuition from Catholic teachers, about 100,000 priests and nuns are engaged in religious activities, and hundreds of millions of marks are invested in church properties.

KINGSTREE, S.C., Aug. 10. -- One of the strangest of New Deal undertakings is in progress here, where 200 to 250 World War veterans are "engaged" in the construction of a golf course for this little community of about 3,000 persons, half of whom are Negroes.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10. -- Moscow representatives of American industries are discussing with much interest a newly issued decree decentralizing to a large extent the purchase by the Soviet Union of goods from abroad.

WALL STREET, too long on pigeons, is trying to get rid of them by refusing aid, comfort and food. Some of them may stay away, but the pigeon population is not likely to be decreased by any such gentle means. The birds are a hardy race of vagrants. They have been on their own for centur/es in this town and be/ong to nobody.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- One of the major grass court titles in tennis fell to an unranked player today as Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye carried off the Eastern championship at the Westchester Country Club.
