Because it is the custom among male Americans to wear a derby for informal evening parties, while Englishmen put on a bowler, there has grown up a popular indoor sport in this country. It is called the American Language.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Business was sustained at a generally favorable level in the week ended on Aug. 3, the Department of Commerce reported today ill its weekly survey of the domestic situation.

BECAUSE of the shortage of box-office names, there are indications abroad that some of the studios may jump the producers' agreement and conduct talent raids. Facing this fear, Metro has decided to make a test case of Myrna Loy's controversy and fight any attempt of the star to break her contract or go to another lot.
MUSIC is the backbone of broadcasting. No one seems to have ever disputed that fact.

Anticipating the most active consumer demand for merchandise in five years, retail buyers thronged the major wholesale markets in various sections of the country last week, making heavy purchases of Fall and Winter lines. In the large trading centres where special buying events were in session, the attendance of retailers was the largest in years and, in some instances, purchases compared favorably with the 1928 and 1929 totals.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The Red Sox climbed to within half a game of third place today by defeating Washington, 9 to 8, in the series opener, while the White Sox were being shut out by Detroit.

Just now we are hearing a lot about "too much Federal" and "not enough State" control. Being a Republican, and one of the vanishing Americans, I wish to point out certain facts to the committee of the whole.

LENZBURG, Switzerland, Aug. 10 (By Wireless). -- There is a refrain that runs through the conversation when one is talking with Lincoln Ellsworth about his plans for his coming exploratory flight across Antarctica. It comes as he answers questions in his quiet, soft voice. It is a sort of refrain; just this -"No one knows."

MADRID. -- The death 300 years ago of Fray Felix Lope de Vega is being remembered wherever the Spanish tongue is spoken, because his plays still are regarded as the finest ever written in that language. Spain's greatest dramatist was a contemporary of another countryman who gained literary immortality -- Cervantes -- as well as of Shakespeare.
PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Premier Pierre Laval, warning that the Republic's life is "at stake," sought today to stir all forces into action in support of his emergency recovery program.
Final prizes in eighty-seven classes of gladioli were awarded yesterday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, where the sixth annual gladiolus show is being held.
A recent article in THE TIMES states that when crops are abundant the country is prosperous, that business success is dependent on successful agriculture.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 10. -- Ed O'Brien of Syracuse University today was an easy winner in the 400-meter final at an international meet in which American track stars competed with athletes from Northern European countries.

HONOLULU, Aug. 10. -- Welcomed by Postmaster General James A. Farley, who arose long before daylight this morning to motor to Pearl Harbor, the Pan American Clipper arrived at 5:42 A.M. [12:12 P.M. New York time] today on its third experimental cruise across the Pacific Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -Senate and House conference committee members moved for peaceful Congressional acceptance of the Farm Adjustment Bill today by opening wider the doors of the courts to suits for recovery of processing taxes.

Signing of the Motor Carrier Act by President Roosevelt marked the culmination of five years effort by the railroads to obtain a law that would apply to commercial highway traffic regulations comparable to those under which the railways operate.

THE doctor has a financial stake in the accidents due to automobiles. Often enough the victim is cared for by the physician closest to the scene of the accident. Whether he will or not, the situation of the physician is such that he must give medical and surgical attention without regard to the possibilities of financial reimbursement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 10. -Aiming to give unemployed teachers of New England additional training, a FERA project which will pay students $18 weekly, as well as transportation expenses from all parts of New England, will be officially opened here on Monday.

There seems to be no small resentment in Washington at the keen and active interest which so many Americans are taking in the new taxes proposed by their Government. Particularly in the Senate has the matter stirred up a lot of dust and heat. But why complain when taxes produce the very kind of spirit in citizens which they are intended to create?

IN the early days of the World War, when it was found that rifle and pistol bullets were as futile against marauding airplanes as filed artillery fire was impractical, some bright soul was inspired by necessity to do something about it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Disclaiming that the action was prompted by strikes and protests against the WPA security wage scale, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, increased today wages paid to Iowa needy under the $4,800,000,000 work relief program.

Reporting on a ten-year study of 1,561 Manhattan babies, Dr. Harry Bakwin, New York University pediatrician, recommended yesterday the extension of baby health clinics in New York. He said that proper health supervision in the first weeks of life was of "crucial importance" for infants' normal development and should aid their health in later life.

WHEN William Boyce Thompson was near the height of his career he remarked to his daughter Margaret: "Money gives you elbowroom; it gives you space so you can move around without knocking against the other fellow."

The smallest State in the Union provided last week the biggest piece of political news we have had in months. Rhode Island elected a Congressman to fill a vacancy. The voters had a choice between Antonio Prince, Democrat and 100-per-cent Roosevelt supporter, and Charles F. Risk, Republican, who campaigned on an anti-New Deal platform. They chose the Republican, 48,023 to 35,054.

WASHINGTON. COMMUNICATIONS in foreign languages received by the White House from other countries have increased, on the average, about two and a half times over the number recorded during the Hoover administration. The increase reflects world interest in the New Deal and the place of President Roosevelt as an international figure.

Ever since the recent unanimous NRA decision of the Supreme Court we have been hearing and reading so many demands for another amendment to the Constitution of a prohibitive nature that the friends of that venerable document must fervently pray, "God save the Constitution."
CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Plans for reunion of the three greater branches of the Methodist Church in America will be considered at a joint session of three official commissions on Monday in Evanston, Ill.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- The British policy for the coming week's conference in Paris with the French and Italians is to negotiate for peace in Africa before Premier Benito Mussolini's war against Ethiopia begins.

Discrepancies between Senate and House versions of several New Deal measures are being subjected to the adjusting processes of Congressional conference committees. Such committees are not required in foreign Parliaments, largely because in bicameral Legislatures abroad the two chambers are generally not co-equal.

I HAVE been visiting England for more than fifty years, having come here first at the unobserving age of 3. I have spent part of each of the last eight years here. Thus I see the England of today in the light of the England of the past. My personal view of her people is somewhat like that which one takes of an old acquaintance who hag been through many troubles.

GENEVA, Aug. 10. -- "How is the League standing the strain of the Italo-Ethiopian crisis?" is a frequent question by Summer visitors. Judging by the number of these visitors, which seems to be greater than in several years, the League is standing the strain fairly well.

MR. ROBERT FAHERTY has written a tender, sentimental and wistful tale, which somehow gets itself inextricably involved in a complicated plot about a jail warden who is something of a homely philosopher and humanitarian poet at heart, and his motley assortment of charges -- some of whom also get caught up in the plot -- down in some Southern town.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 10. -- Maine Democrats, who nearly four years ago surprised the State and the rest of the country by electing a Governor and two members of Congress and then repeated the performance two years later, appeared today to be heading into difficulties and Republicans predict they will recapture the State next year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The American Federation of Labor is ready to step in, if invited, to give any assistance possible toward an amicable settlement of Works Progress Administration strikes in New York or elsewhere.

THE turnover of headliners in our national drama is enormous. The waste of leading men, prima donnas, ingenues and first comedians is startling. It seems to be "amateur night" always in the politics of a republic. Notables come on with the band playing, only to disappear without any music at all, and where they go no man knoweth.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- An eighteen-inch putt that slipped by the cup at the twentieth green forced Gene Homans, former metropolitan champion, to bow to T. Suffern Tailer in the Maidstone invitation golf tourney today. Tailer, winner of the Rhode Island open crown earlier in the week and yesterday's medalist over this seaside course with a 71, gained the semi-final as a result of his triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Congressional completion of the Social Security Bill was hailed by Secretary Perkins today as "one of the most forward-looking pieces of legislation in the interest of wage earners" in the nation's history. She was chairman of the Committee on Economic Security, which submitted recommendations for the measure.
The exuberant spirit of John (Blondy) Ryan continued to work like a charm for our suddenly revivified Yankees yesterday.

STRATOSPHERE expeditions, whether in airplanes or balloons, have so far been having a bad year. For months a Piccard balloon flight has been announced as going any day from near Warsaw, Poland. The National Geographic Society-Army Air Corps balloon expedition from Rapid City, S.D., sustained something of a setback when the balloon collapsed an hour before the take-off time and three hours after it had been inflated.

MIDSUMMER brings the meatless menu into favor. Now is the season when near-by garden acres yield hugely and New Yorkers eat more fresh vegetables, native grown, than at any other time. Stores of produce from New Jersey, Long Island and the home-State mainland are whisked into the city overnight.

The sharp advance in share prices was continued yesterday as leading issues rose fractionally to a point or more in the heaviest trading for a Saturday since Feb. 24, 1934. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,210,000 shares; 115 issues reached new high marks for the year and longer.

ANY plant which has eight new and tested varieties to offer within one year is pretty certain to be a worthy garden subject. So it is with the hardy asters. We Americans are so accustomed to their Fall beauty along the roadsides that we do not always give them their justly deserved place in our gardens.

SEEKING an "intelligent and equalized" basis for motor vehicle taxation, Professor John S. Worley three years ago undertook a study of conditions in Michigan for the State University's Department of Engineering Research.

The RKO, Loew's and Skouras circuits of motion picture theatres yesterday rescinded for one week a 41 per cent pay cut ordered for motion picture machine operators and a strike projected by Local 306 of the operators' union was called off.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 9. -- While Washington may regard Senator Huey Long's anti-Roosevelt tirades as a good show for the galleries and most of the country may be getting pretty tired of him, the Louisiana dictator is getting down to business in his campaign for delegates to "stop Roosevelt" in the Democratic convention.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea described William Lee Ferris as "worse than a rattlesnake" today as closing arguments were begun in the trial of the 26-year-old hotel hanger-on and his three women companions for the murder of Howard Carter Dickinson.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Marblehead's forty-second annual Summer race festival closed today with the Corinthian Yacht Club's regatta in which there were 336 starters, lifting the grand total for the seven days to 2,332.

IN a stud poker game in Poplar Station young Clay Borden ("Baby-face" his enemies called him) won more than a thousand dollars and collected the money in spite of an ugly gunman who tried to cheat him out of it. He intended to take his winnings home to Texas and pay off the mortgage on his father's ranch.

TORONTO, Aug. 10. -- Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., had a net profit of $334,522 in the second quarter, compared with $237,920 in the previous quarter and $366,092 in the second quarter a year ago. Gross operating profit was $528,024, against $529,403 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- When the National Labor Relations Board is ready to act under the new powers conveyed by the Wagner Law one of its first cases will be that of a complaint by the local Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants' Union against the Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers' Union, with headquarters in this city.

WOODSTOCK, N.Y. -- The merriest affair on the village social calendar for the month is the annual Country Fair for the benefit of the Woodstock Library. It will be held on the library lawn Wednesday, Aug. 21, and will supply entertainment besides displaying a large number of booths showing rural products.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colonies in Southampton, East Hampton and Westhampton attended the annual horse show held today in the grounds of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP). -- A new law to prohibit discrimination against Negroes or any other persons "because of race, creed or color" will become effective in Pennsylvania on Sept. 1.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 10 (AP). -- The sloop of war Philadelphia, her hull pierced by cannon balls in the Battle of Valcour Island nearly 160 years ago, has been raised from the bottom of Lake Champlain near here today.

WHEN England set out after markets, who foresaw the result or imagined the problems that were being created for future generations to unravel or bungle? Mothering -- or is it fathering? -- a brood of embryo nations involves all the ordinary domestic difficulties and responsibilities raised to the nth power.

While the Chadbourne plan for a five-year marketing agreement of sugar will terminate officially on Sept. 1, the world sugar situation has been so far ameliorated that no large producing country is expected to engage in untrammeled expansion, and the coast is said to be clear for the formulation of another international agreement late this year or in 1936.

MANY are bald but few are chosen for the screen's representation of the bald-headed rows in the Temples of Burlycue. Simple baldness, in other words, is not enough to get a man a job before the cameras as an admirer of the strip-tease artistes, the baggy-pantalooned sons of Comus, the single and the double meaning, and the non-precision ballets of burlesque.

The experience of the Federal Reserve Banks in the last year in making loans of working capital to industry has shown that, while a considerable demand for such credit exists, it is not nearly so large as had been supposed. It seems doubtful, on the basis of the Reserve System's records, bankers say, whether unsatisfied demand for working-capital loans is sufficient to justify the establishment of a proposed permanent government-owned corporation to handle the loans.

PARIS, Aug. 8. -- The first week of the Winter openings shows several distinct period influences. The fashions of the Nineties are by far the strongest, but these remind one rather of "Aunt Sapphira" than "Diamond Lil."

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The formation of a new regiment of medium artillery in the New Jersey National Guard, with a resultant wide shifting of the State military organizations, has been recommended to Governor Hoffman by Major John J. Toffey, head of the State National Guard and commanding officer of the Forty-fourth Division.

LAST Spring there was some talk of looking into the hospitals for the mentally deranged to find out whether sane people had been unlawfully locked up. Nothing much came of that. But a year or so before William Seabrook had been conducting a rather enthusiastically approving investigation of his own.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- A weary Congress turned down the home stretch today, hoping to reach the adjournment goal next Saturday but more optimistic over the prospect of ending the grueling session the following week.

A CATTLE war is the subject of Alan LeMay's latest novel -- a war that raged all the way from-Mexico to Montana. There had been bad blood for years between the King-Gordon partnership that had developed with the great cattle trails and Ben Thorpe, that unscrupulous cattle baron whose power was steadily growing, largely by means of rustling and cheating smaller men out of their holdings.

It is a bad name that ST. PAUL, quoting "a prophet of their own," gave to the Cretans in his letter to TITUS, whom he left in that charming island to "set in order the things that were wanting." In that same letter he described the qualifications of a leader among them, saying that he should not be a "striker," using the word in its literal sense ("non percussorem," as the Vulgate has it).

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Encouraged by the results of rate cuts on Western and Southern lines, government and railroad officials are considering a general reduction of passenger fares to stimulate rail travel.

THE philosophers and the scientists are to hold an International Congress of Scientific Philosophy from Sept. 15 to 23 in Paris. It is not likely that the proceedings will make the front page of any newspaper, in these days of Ethiopta's conflict with Italy and Hitler's activities.

Two events last week evidenced the sustained recovery of investment trusts. One was a continued rise in holdings of the Lehman Corporation that carried the asset value of its shares beyond $100 for the first time since its organization in 1929.

A series of skeletons by which ethnologists and archaeologists may be able to fill in the "blank" years of ancient Athens in the centuries before Christ are nosy on the way from Greece to the American Museum of Natural History.

MEN-OF-WAR with swift heels, towering masts steel-bolted sides and heavy guns are sliding down shipbuilding ways in half a dozen countries. Welding torches are sputtering; draftsmen are fairing the sweet curves of underwater hulls; great cranes swing slabs of armor plate, and riveting hammers chirrup a metallic cacophony as the world's leading sea powers build up their fighting fleets.

IN the sprawling, haphazardly built palace, or "Gebbi," at Addis Ababa lives the man who is today the storm centre of the Ethiopian crisis. He is medium-sized, dark, with a black beard and the slight, sensitive features that characterize his proud Amharic race.

A small field took part in the August registered shoot over the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday, and it ended in a tie between T.H. Lewis and E.L. Rowland, at 96. Lewis then broke 25 straight in the shoot-off and took the trophy.

SAARBRUECKEN. -- The outstanding impression, gained during a brief visit to the Saar Territory about five months after its reincorporation in the German Reich on March 1, is that there still exists a "Saar Problem," with the difference that it has been removed from the sphere of international politics and has now become a purely German internal question.

BERLIN. COLIN ROSS is Germany's best writer of travel books. This because of the brilliant lucidity of his style, the keenness of his observations, his essential psychological sensitiveness, which enables him to understand the nature of alien races to an amazing degree, and because of his quite extraordinary vitality and physical endurance.

The trout fishing in the Willowemoc and Beaverkill in Sullivan County has been superior to that usually found in August, due to a spell of cool weather and normal water levels, according to reports forwarded to this column.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Measures for increasing economic cooperation between the United States and Cuba, with particular reference to the reciprocal trade agreement and the Costigan-Jones Sugar Act, will be considered in conferences here next week between a commission of twenty members representing the Cuban Social Economic Union and officials anti experts of the United States Government.

DETROIT, Aug. 10. -- The second consecutive drop in weekly automobile and truck production in the United States and Canada was reported today by Cram's Reports, Inc. Only 48,067 units were turned out last week, compared with 69,415 in the preceding week and 62,894 in the seven days ended July 27.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 10. -- Reliable military sources said late today that an attempt to assassinate President Lazaro Cardenas had been frustrated by the arrest of five men, who are being held incomunicado at police headquarters.

IT is surprising these days to find our old-time friend the daylily still blooming in gardens and show grounds long after its usual season is past. The explanation is that the plant breeders during the last few years have added many new varieties, greatly extending the period of bloom, and therefore the usefulness, of this easily grown and satisfactory flower.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Roger A. Young of Bronxville and William Brewster and Miss Elmina Brewster of Durham, Conn., carried away a number of ribbons and trophies today at the second session of the second annual Sagamore horse show, which will be concluded tomorrow.

A MEASURE of considerable importance for the future development of Italian amusement arts and industries has been adopted with the recent creation of a so-called Ispettorato del Teatro, or Theatrical Inspectorate, organized at the initiative of Mussolini's son-in-law, Propaganda Minister Galeazzo Ciano, as a department of his bureau, which was elevated some days ago to the dignity of a Ministry.

KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Twelve-year-old Miss Lillian Marsh Chambers of Katonah showed her bay gelding Jack Tar at the second annual Mount Holly horse show today and experienced remarkable success, four blue ribbons being credited to her during the course of the program.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10. -Nearly eighty events are marked on the calendar of tercentenary observance for next week, which will be the busiest since the anniversary celebration began last April.

THE recent executive order creating the National Youth Administration provides for the administration of important phases of public education by an agency in the central government. It states that there shall be a national advisory committee, an executive committee and an executive director.

VILLA HERMOSA, Mexico, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Tomas Garrido y Canabal, his fifteen-year-old dictatorship of Tabasco State definitely at an end, left today by airplane for Guatemala en route to Puerto Rico, where he intends to live permanently in exile.
BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- Will Italy really bludgeon her way into Ethiopia a month hence, despite her solemn obligations to a fellow-member of the League of Nations under the League Covenant?
MR. BUCKLEY has been keeping a diary of his inner life for sixty-five years and now, at the age of 85, he has made a book out of selections from it to depict his evolution from youth to old age.

LENINGRAD, Aug. 10. -- It is curiously fitting that the first world physiological congress to be held in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which is a land of paradoxes, has itself a paradoxical aspect.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- Premier Pierre Laval received Bejirond Tecle Hawariate, Ethiopian Minister to Paris, today for a discussion of the Ethiopian trouble. Their talk does not seem to have covered next week's meeting here of British, French and Italian diplomats.

GLASGOW, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Opening the Scottish soccer season with a bang, the Glasgow Rangers today trounced Arbroath, newcomer to first division football, 6 -- 0. Third Lanark, which was promoted with Arbroath at the end of the 1934-35 season, went down before St. Johnstone, 3 -- 1.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- A tremendous crowd, estimated by officials at 70,000, today helped lower the curtain on Suffolk Downs' inaugural twenty-eight-day meeting. This huge throng, which shattered all horse racing attendance records for this section, poured $721,565 through the mutuel windows.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Slim Rosie, 3-year-old filly owned by Aarons and Well of Chicago, today captured the Crete Handicap at six furlongs, the feature at Lincoln Fields.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- As the Summer season draws to a close, activities in Pennsylvania's picturesque playgrounds, the Poconos, are becoming intensified. All sections of the county are aiding in preparations for the annual show of the Pocono Mountains Horse Show Association, which will be held in the Arena in the Clouds on Friday and Saturday, Aug. 23 and 24, for the benefit of the Monroe County General Hospital.

While the announcement that seventeen false fire alarms were made in a recent twenty-four-hour period has turned public attention once more to this recurrent nuisance, fire authorities say this is not an excessive number in a city the size of New York, where forty calls a day were not unusual a year or more ago.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 10. -- Winfield Sheehan, motion picture director, and Maria Jeritza, the opera singer, obtained a license to wed here today and said that they would be married Monday at the Old Mission.

PROBABLY in every generation there will be an author moving in an orbit so individually his own as to defy all the measuring instruments of watchers of the literary skies. Such a one is E.R. Eddison, who will be remembered for his strange romance, "The Worm Ouroborus," and who now presents us with "Mistress of Mistresses," so extraordinary and eerie a romance that ordinary and realistic terms are quite inadequate to its description.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10. -The gayest event of the Summer season in the social life of the clubs in this area was a dinner dance at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, Greenwich, tonight. Dancing was on an outdoor marine terrace.

PARIS. THERE are decidedly two sides to the Paris textile question this season, Reversible materials of all descriptions smartly turn the other cheek. Some of them contrast only in color; others in surface; still others in color, texture and medium.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10. -The Brazilian-British thawing agreement was attacked today by a minority member of Congress, who said the agreement was badly injuring Brazilian industry. He asserted that by accepting the agreement Brazil encouraged the importation of products competing with national industries and that those products were from a country selling more to Brazil than she buys from her.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Republican grass roots in the Middle West will sprout a prairie harvest of anti-New Deal votes if the ambitious plans of the grass rooters work out as they hope. A committee of fifty, named by the June conference at Springfield, Ill., met this week in Chicago and drafted a program of action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The Japanese Embassy called the attention of the State Department late today to a reported "fox hunt" burlesque in Seattle in which a "Mikado" was described as pulling an "Ethiopian Emperor" in a jinrikisha.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 10. -While that threadbare term, "the idle rich," may still apply to women in a stratum of society that was untouched by the depression, it fails to describe this Summer many members of the North Shore estate colonies who work from dawn to dusk in business.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Hollyrood Perry, bay gelding trotter, and Edwin, 3-year-old trotting colt, won the feature events of the weekly matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity numbered the same as the preceding week but were for smaller amounts of bonds. Those posted for this month were municipal issues, while those for future months, which comprised most of the redemptions announced, were principally public utility bonds.

" The franc is saved!" proclaimed the principal newspapers of Paris Friday morning. "From now on the great financial danger has been set aside," said Premier Laval. Such was the attitude of government and press two days ago when the Premier announced the second part of his program for the economic rehabilitation of France.

LESS than ten years ago, when Europe was abominably anxious about its economic conditions -- it has not yet escaped from that anxiety -- an Englishman looked at America with amaze ment touched with a pardonable envy. In mean minds, which exist here and there among most peoples, there was jealousy and irritation.

A large delegation of philatelists from this city and the metropolitan area will leave for Washington today and tomorrow to attend the annual convention of the American Philatelic Society, the largest organization of its kind in the country, which will be opened officially on Tuesday.

More than 10,000 officials, civic workers and citizens participated in three ground-breaking ceremonies for Staten Island's South shore boardwalk yesterday afternoon. Borough President Joseph A. Palma hailed the project as the realization of a twenty-year dream and he gave sole credit to Mayor La Guardia.
Disorder growing out of a protest over the dismissal of an I.R.T. employe resulted yesterday in the arrest of five of the worker's colleagues at the Grand Central subway station.
MORE JOBS: Great Britain, Italy and Germany reported optimistic statistics last week.

MORE and more people are being won over to the charms of a house near some small town in the country as a place to spend their Summers -- an old house which one can do over, bring out its ancient charm, enjoy its mellow quiet, invite one's friends to share, over quiet week-ends amid hills and open spaces, books and open fires.

THIS little book is not so much the recollections of its author's childhood in Wales as it is a translation into adult terms of the Welsh country and the Welsh spirit as experienced by a child and revived in later years through recollection.

Scenting a new type of tariff attack, importers yesterday lined up in a general drive to prevent passage of the Walsh-McCormack bill providing for the licensing of all importers and dealers in foreign watches and watch movements. Fear of the precedent which passage of a licensing law would create has drawn importers in every branch of business into the fight behind those concerned only with watches.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The annual Lake Placid Horse Show will command attention from members of the Lake Placid colony on next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -The Newark Bears exacted a full measure of revenge for a double defeat suffered yesterday when they subdued Buffalo tonight by scores of 8 to 4 and 16 to 4.
AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 10 (AP). -Thousands of employables on Texas relief rolls looked today to whitening fields of cotton for jobs paying wages higher than relief grants.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10. -- It is evident now Soviet imports from the United States this year will be at least $30,000,000 -- the same figure fixed on by Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, and William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, in the recently signed trade agreement as the minimum amount Russia was willing to buy from the United States annually.

IT is in itself an achievement for the daughter of a well-known English novelist, herself the author of twelve books, to maintain the illusion that authors and liter ary scenes are good material. Possibly Miss Frankau chose this background in order to express her contempt for the London author-publisher-reviewer fraternity; and this she does thoroughly.

FOR its seventh season of traveling exhibitions (1935-86) the College Art Association has prepared a schedule described as "wider in scope than ever before." The prospectus at hand lists sixty-five offerings -- twenty exhibitions composed primarily or exclusively of oils, six entirely or largely of water-colors, five altogether or in the main of sculpture.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. '10. -Good business continues for steel makers in this district and production schedules slightly in excess of 50 per cent of capacity are assured for next week. Current output and activity is much higher than is usually the case at this season.

The fallacy in Robert H. Jackson's argument regarding taxation of the rich is in the evasion of responsibility. The real question is the responsibility of wealth management, not the bare ownership of wealth. The transfer of wealth management by arbitrary manipulation of credit and tax-exempt bonds leads to the question whether political management is better than private business management.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 10. -- The preliminary sixth international university athletic championships began here today with the participation of more than a thousand athletes from all parts of the world. The only American participant, however, was Knapp, a swimmer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Profit-taking by commission houses and scattered liquidation in grains developed on the Board of Trade today after a firm start. The markets never showed a disposition to rally after they had turned downward, wheat breaking around 3 cents a bushel from the early top.

Construing President Roosevelt's ban on the use of Federal money for home relief for striking Works Progress Administration employes as a "work or starve" order, George Meany, labor leader, declared yesterday that the union members would not submit to it.

MARY PICKFORD'S first novel recounts the romance of a poor girl who rose to dizzy heights of fame as star of a musical review, and became the sweetheart of the creme de la creme of Paris. Aside from that bare outline, there doesn't seem to be anything autobiographical in the novel.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 10. -- The climax of the Fifty-fifth Northfield General Conference, founded by Dwight L. Moody, will be reached tomorrow, the closing day, when Dr. John R. Mott, world traveler and Christian missionary, will address 3,000 persons in the auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Military "Disaffection' Bill -- the first measure of its kind ever seriously considered in this country in peacetime, and termed by its opponents a "real threat to the freedom of the press," has passed the Senate without dissent and has won the majority support of the House Committee on Military Affairs.

The plan for reorganizing the assets of defaulted mortgage companies by separate issues rather than by "bureaucratic control" received additional support yesterday when counsel for groups of certificate holders filed applications in the Supreme Court here favoring the appointment of trustees by the court.

WHEN the history of the Summer theatre is eventually written -- and there is no particular reason why it shouldn't be, considering the stir it has made -- a good, fat chapter should be given to the shire of Long Island for two reasons.

The heavy buying of stocks in the last fortnight has not only brought the average level of prices to the highest mark since November, 1931, to the gratification of recent buyers and to those holding investments frozen since 1929, but has wrought considerable improvement in the mechanical end of trading.

It seems safe to say that any one who read "Once a Wilderness" will want to follow the subsequent fortunes of the Mark family as chronicled in "Second Growth." In the earlier volume Mr. Pound portrayed with remarkable vividness an era in American life -- an era whose passing nearly every native American has found occasion, during the past few years, to regret.
BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- Clint Ferguson of Waban, Mass., carried off the major honors in the Central New England Association outboard races on the Charles River Basin today.

THE ruthless directness, frequent brutality and sharp staccato beat of so much of our modern fiction are noticeably absent from this delicately wrought novel of a day that is past but whose memory lives. A thing of fantasy, fragile and exquisite as a piece of rare old lace, its characters are many of them haunting shadows rather than human beings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Farmers this year have more money to spend than in four years past. The total for this year will exceed $7,250,000,000. Of this, $6,700,000,000 will be from sales of crops and livestock and AAA rental and benefit payments, according to government estimates; the remainder, from supplementary sources such as part-time employment, boarders and tourists, and the hiring out of horses and tractors.

ON the far-off tables and buffets of Continental Europe may be felt the effect of the New Deal's vast power development program in the Pacific Northwest. Engineers who are throwing steel and concrete barriers across the Columbia River at Bonneville, Ore., and Grand Coulee, Wash., fear that the mammoth dams and hydroelectric development may destroy one of the world's chief supplies of chinook salmon.

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- Observers all over New England, irrespective of party, are pretty well agreed as to the meaning of the Rhode Island vote of last Tuesday. Primarily it was a rebuke to the administration and the New Deal. In minor degree it spells encouragement for the opposition.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Theodore A. Lightner of New York and B. Jay Becket of Philadelphia won the Waldemar von Zedtwitz Gold Cup for masters' contract bridge pairs here this afternoon in the annual Summer championships of the American Bridge League.

Further growth of voluntary chain and group merchandising was predicted yesterday by John Block, president of the Association of Buying Offices, who in reply to recent criticism of central office buying practices, said that these offices today play a vital role in providing "the independently operated store with some of the advantages of the multi-unit chain."

Some Republican critics of the Roosevelt Administration are making use of a graphic illustration in order to emphasize the enormous spending now under way in Washington. They point out that from 1789 to 1913 the Federal Government spent a total of about $24,000,000,000.

SEATTLE, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Claude Myrick, who says he is "The Ragtime Kid" of Robert W. Service's famous poem, "The Shooting of Dan McGrew," will be among the early day trail blazers of the Alaska-Yukon country here next Friday for the annual international sourdough stampede.
ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The sports and social calendar in this section for this week is featured by the thirteenth annual men's invitation golf tournament at the Biltmore Forest Country Club.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- North Jersey shore colonists turn with interest this week to Red Bank, where the National Motor Boat Sweepstakes Regatta will be held on Saturday and Sunday. Preparations are being made to entertain a large spectator fleet.

THE nursery rhyme which declares that when a man marries his trouble begins might have been chosen as the theme of this story of life among the music-hall performers of England, for young Fred Clifford is nearly destroyed by his wife, and only regains self-confidence and prestige when he divorces her.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 10 (AP). -- The defeat of Angel Child, heavily played favorits in the featured 2:13 trot, by American Hanover, the second choice, marked the closing day's racing of the Grand Circuit meeting at Rockingham Park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Federal marshals raided an office at 1,427 I Street, N.W., bearing signs adverising the "Grand National Treasure Hunt" today and arrested Philip Schoenberg, who was said to be the manager, and his assistant, Albert Little. They were later released on $2,000 bond each.

Although the cancellation of the Boy Scout Jamboree scheduled in Washington from Aug. 21 to 30 was given wide publicity in this country and abroad, $4,853.10 in Jamboree registration fees were received yesterday at the national offices of the Boy Scouts of America, 2 Park Avenue.
New York City was selected as the proving ground for President Roosevelt's $4,000,000,000 work-relief program; it became last week the battleground as well.
PARIS, Aug. 10. -- The helicopter principle applied to a small dirigible was demonstrated this morning at an aviation field near Toussusle-Noble by the veteran balloonist, Broutelle.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 8. -- Black Hill Park beetles are threatening the national forests of the Rocky Mountain region. Already thousands of acres of prime timber have been destroyed and the woodland beauty of Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks in Wyoming and the Rocky Mountain National Park and three government forests in Colorado have been threatened.

SARATOGA this August is very much alive, what with the races carrying on the old tradition and the new spa staging an up-to-date show which suggests a Mediterranean bathing beach -though the spar blue water is contained in a mechanically filtered pool.

SEATTLE, Aug. 10. -- The Japanese Consulate disclosed today that a telegram had been sent to the Japanese Embassy at Washington regarding yesterday's "Mikado" episode in which a man dressed to represent the Emperor of Japan appeared at a coyote hunt pulling a jinrikisha containing a man costumed to represent the Emperor of Ethiopia.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 10. -- This resort's hotels are experiencing the busiest Summer since 1929, if tax payments this week can be taken as evidence of improving conditions.

HOLLYWOOD. A HUSH has invaded Old Lyme, Westport, the timbered manors contiguous to the border of the Nutmeg State and sundry other haunts of the literati that once resounded with the crash of midnight typing. The seasonal shift of the clerkly to the atelier of Hollywood has been afoot for quite a while.
Those who wanted Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer back in New York City last week after his acquittal on Federal income tax charges in an up-State court were:

Caissons included in the foundations of New York's lofty buildings have been gaining frequent mention in the news. With them the tower of Trinity Church has been bolstered up, and although the spire leans eighteen inches it is safe.
A new Nemesis is on the trail of Oklahoma's bad men.

The net income of the New Jersey Zinc Company in the first six months of this year amounted to $2,174,213 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges. This equals $1.11 a share on 1,963,264 shares of $25 par stock. In the first half of 1934 the net in-! come was $2,086,511, or $1.06 a! share.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Sewell Cup day at the Seaside Park Yacht Club saw the traditionally large entry lists which have featured this event for thirty-five years compete as Mary Ann took the historic trophy today in a championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The town of Plainfield is to celebrate its 150th anniversary with a three-day program starting next Friday with sports, baseball and community singing. On Saturday the feature will be a pageant in five episodes and nineteen scenes entitled "The Village That Is Set on a Hill."

More than 1,000 buyers are expected to attend the National Domestics and Linen Show which opens tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker. Fall bedspreads, sheets and pillowcases, blankets and linens will be displayed by seventy-six manufacturers.

THE tide of tourist traffic Europe-bound is still running strong into August this year, far beyond the normal swell. Travel agencies predict a record lengthening season for post-war years, pointing to numerous bookings well into September by Americans at the large English and Continental hotels, and to advance westbound steamship reservations by many tourists who are prolonging their stay in Europe into late Summer or early Fall.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 10. -- Champions from the country's two extremes -- the Atlantic seaboard and the Pacific Coast -- were crowned today on the courts of Culver Military Academy as the national junior and boys' tennis tournament came to a close.

Under the protective shadow of the General Sherman monument at Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue a small band of men make a last stand against a mechanical world. Reminiscent of a more leisurely age, the venerable hackmen who line the entrance to the park slowly are thinning in ranks.

Rhymes that deal with such matters as getting up and going to bed, new shoes, birthday parties, cutting out paper dolls, pets, games and gardens. There is no poetry in the verses, but as "rhythmic expressions of the everyday experiences of child life," as Miss Hill calls them in the introduction, they will doubtless be useful in nursery school and kindergartens.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- Miss Jane Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope of this city and New York, made her debut tonight at a ball given by her parents at their Summer home, The Waves.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- The Giants divided a double-header with Jimmy Wilson's Phillies before a gathering of 15,000 at Baker Bowl today. In the opener the Phils, guilty of six errors, presented the Giants with a 6-3 victory, while in the nightcap they trounced the Terrymen, 6 to 1.

Perpetuation of Negro spirituals and folk music is the purpose of a new art foundation established in Pasadena, Calif., by George Garner, the Negro tenor. Bantu tribal songs from the West Indies, native African chants and war calls, as well as old plantation songs of them American Negro, are included in its collection.

Gains averaging from 10 to 15 per cent are predicted for Fall by leading merchants in a survey just completed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. In announcing the results yesterday, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association, declared that if the forecasts are realized, "retailers will experience the best Fall since 1931, with beneficial effects on all lines of business."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP). -Catcher Ernie Lombardi did all the run-getting today as the Reds blanked the Pirates, 2 -- 0, in a game which gave Paul Derringer his fifteenth victory of the season.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Resorts in the White Mountains have arranged entertainments for their guests, whose numbers have been increased by an influx from seashore resorts.

More than 1,000 buyers are expected to attend the National Domestics and Linen Show which opens tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker. Fall bedspreads, sheets and pillowcases, blankets and linens will be displayed by seventy-six manufacturers.

ANOTHER section of the recent bequest by Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Museum of Modern Art has been opened to the public with the rearrangement of three of the galleries on the third floor of the museum. The additional material in the current Summer exhibition includes a score of water-colors by ten artists and drawings by another.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The power industry challenged President Roosevelt tonight to make a 1936 campaign issue of the Utilities Bill and holding company abolition.

THE University of Southern California's School of Government has turned its attention in a large way to the education of public officials. It has enrolled more than 4,000 students -- many of them being Mayors, policemen, city clerks and engineers -- in courses that consider the business of government a field for scientific research and trained efficiency.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 10. -Harry Meislahn and Reeve Bowden carried off the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy in the Star Class boat Sunbeam today, although the defending champion, Harold Halsted's Chuckle II, finished first in the final race of the series.

The Department of Agriculture's estimate of 11,798,000 bales for this year's cotton crop, which is 2,162,000 in excess of the 1934 yield, brought forth more than the usual amount of comment when it was published on Thursday, mainly because of the keen interest in the crop restriction program of the government and its efforts to maintain prices through loans to farmers.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- Any attempt to appraise the motives that impelled the Nazi regime to intensify its drives against German Catholicism and its hounding of Jews must first take cognizance of the fundamental principles underlying the National Socialist philosophy as incorporated in the totalitarian State.

FOR a year now Billy Rose, the minute mahout of Times Square, has been darkly hinting that he was about to touch the fuse to a musical circus, "Jumbo," reverently named for the most fabulous peanut consumer in zoological history.

IT was just a month ago that this column was announcing an excursion of the Theatre Union executive board to Cape Cod, that lustrous theatrical nursery. The board wanted to think things out up there -- wanted, specifically, to decide what the first play of their new season would be, assuming that it wouldn't be "Strike Song."
WASHINGTON (NANA). -- Will an elaborate six-course dinner swing twice as many Congressional votes as a simple supper of three courses?

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 10. --Declaring that the notes of James Madison on the Constitutional Convention underwent many alterations after the convention, Professor Edward S. Corwin, chairman of the Princeton Department of Politics, intimated here that the newly discovered Lansing notes might be a much more reliable record of the proceedings.

Gains averaging from 10 to 15 per cent are predicted for Fall by leading merchants in a survey just completed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. In announcing the results yesterday, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association, declared that if the forecasts are realized, "retailers will experience the best Fall since 1931, with beneficial effects on all lines of business."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The veteran Charlie Root pitched the Cubs to a 3-to-2 triumph over the Cardinals today before 23,500, the largest crowd to turn out for a single game at Wrigley Field this season.

The first of two free concerts marking the close of the Summer session of the New York University Department of Musical Education will be given at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Auditorium, 37 West Fourth Street. It will be an orchestral program played by the Symphonic Orchestral Society, conducted by John Warren Erb, with Andrea Johannsen, soprano, and Engelbert Brenner, oboist, as soloists.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- After another extra-hole battle, T. Suffern Tailer of Newport extended his winning streak by capturing the fourth annual Maidstone invitation golf tourney final in pouring rain this afternoon.

Anent your editorial "Who Are the Ethiopians?" in which you perhaps correctly imagined that the Emperor of Ethiopia will count it lese-majeste to be regarded as a Negro, may I beg to remind you that most well-read and intelligent people seem apparently to forget that the word Negro is a term used by Europeans and Americans to define peoples of darker hue, especially those of African descent?

There is just one question that I would raise in relation to Francis M. FieldMcNally's informative letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 8, on the care and feeding of homeless fledglings. Mr. FieldMcNally says, "We have never been successful in restoring birds to nests. The parent birds seem to have no use for the offspring when human being intervene."

It would be profitless to discuss in minute detail the changes which the Senate Finance Committee proposes to make in the Tax Bill as it passed the House. There is as yet no certainty that the Senate will adopt them. There is bound to be a hot fight in the Senate against some of the new taxes, as planned.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Three World War veterans, returning home from the State American Legion convention at Hartford, lost their lives today in a collision involving a bus, a truck and a private automobile. Nineteen other persons were hurt, one critically.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 11. -- A virtually nation-wide rise in city home and apartment rental rates is expected this Fall, according to a summary of residential conditions just issued by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis.

There is great need for a gospel of gladness to assume as important a place as our gospels of repentance, grace and righteousness, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson said yesterday in his sermon at the North Presbyterian Church, 525 West 155th Street.

Having read with interest General Johnson's defense of the "security wage" program in today's TIMES, I write in rejoinder to his reasoning. The security wage may be more than the average earnings of skilled labor during these past few years. But the attempt to argue that employers will not use the hourly rate as a lever to reduce is refuted by facts.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP). -Featuring the renewal of the $40,000 Hambletonian Wednesday, the five-day Grand Circuit meeting will open at Good Time Park tomorrow with the largest 2-year-old field of the year named for the $1,000 Village Farm pacing stake.

The review by the Department of Health of the conquests of pestilences that once walked in darkness in this city -- the darkness of our ignorance of their causes -- tells in graphs and bare statistics a story of stirring significance. SHELLEY in his poetic catalogue of Promethean achievements listed the "hidden power of herbs" and the springs of which disease drank and slept.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Japanese consular authorities have made an unsuccessful attempt to have suppressed the August issue of the American periodical, Vanity Fair, within the International Settlement here, it was learned today.

Having won Saturday's game after a close race against time, the cricketers of the Bermuda Athletic Association yesterday took on another eleven from the ranks of clubs in the New York and Metropolitan District Association at the Staten Island Club at Livingston.

The Second Brigade of the First Division, stationed at Fort Ontario, Oswego, N.Y., started yesterday its movement to Pine Camp, near Watertown, N.Y., where, commencing next Saturday, 36,000 soldiers are to take part in two weeks of the most extensive field manoeuvres ever held in this country.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The Greentree quartet of G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, Tommy Hitchcock, Gerald Balding and John Hay(Jock) Whitney rode to a 10-6 decision over Old Westbury in the weekly highgoal polo game at the Sands Point Club today.

In a special dispatch from New Brunswick, N.J., THE TIMES reports an economic program sponsored by Robert Wood Johnson as suggesting "we should have minimum wages high enough for the people to buy what they produce."

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Hans von Tschammer und Osten, Leader (meaning ruler) of German Sports, made a speech yesterday at the meet in Budapest in which, speaking as the German authority on all matters pertaining to the coming Olympics, he said:

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- John Trumpy's Merigale scored its second straight victory today in the fleet championship series for International Star Class Sloops on Barnegat Bay. Cliff Grover's White Mist took second, with Paul Soeffing's Pagan in third place.

SOAK the rich? The rich were soaked long ago. They were soaked to a fare-you-well by Harry Lehr, who was, at the bright dawn of our great century, the clown, the veritable Maxie Baer, of New York's famous Four Hundred. Harry's widow, Elizabeth Drexel Lehr, tells all about the soaking in "'King Lehr' and the Gilded Age" (Lippincott, $3), which is one of the saddest books I have ever read.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 11. -- The Derby Polo Club of Buffalo, which yesterday defeated the Greenbrier four in the first game of a two-match series, again met the local team on Greenbrier Field this afternoon. A capacity audience witnessed the play.

Five men, operating in a cool and business-like manner, overpowered the night watchman in one of Brooklyn's tallest office buildings late Saturday night and looted the safes of three corporations of an undetermined but probably large amount of cash.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 11. -Threats of organized labor to strike on Works Progress Administration jobs in this area are not expected to interfere with the program.
ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 11. -- Emperor Halle Selassie indicated tonight Ethiopia was willing to cede part of its territory to Italy in exchange for an outlet to the sea and financial assistance.
BEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug. 11. -Great Britain's polo visitors today convinced a crowd of 8,000 gathered around Schley Field at the Burnt Mills Polo Club, that they are a good team.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor investigating racketeering, is expected to announce the appointment of Jacob J. Rosenblum, an Assistant United States Attorney, as a member of his legal staff this afternoon. The appointment would be in line with Mr. Dewey's intention to make an intensive investigation of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, alleged overlord of the Harlem policy racket.

HARWICH, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP). -The general store which Cyrenus S. Hunt never bothered to equip with lights because he closed it at sundown every day for sixty-seven years was empty tonight -- closed permanently.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Scarcity of top grades of hogs, with a sharp demand from packers, boosted prices 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds on Thursday to a level of $12.05, the highest in six years. There were only 7,500 hogs received on that day, which was too small a run for the demand from small packers and shippers, who wanted light and medium weights for fresh-meat trade.

The United States Lines service to Cobh, Liverpool, Manchester and Belfast has completed its first year of operation with a record of increasing freight and passenger traffic and prospects of continued activity, it was announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 10. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 80 as the average for 1926, is 83.1, which compares with 82.9 the week before, 82.6 two weeks before, 81.7 three weeks before and 81.6 four weeks before.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- The French Government is pursuing steadily the economic reconstruction program. After having balanced the budget through rigorous cuts in expenditure, a series of orders in council were issued this week in an effort to reduce the cost of living, protect savings and stimulate business by means of a new public works plan.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Despite the cloudbursts and a extremely rainy season, campers have increased this year at the twenty-seven public campsites maintained by the Conservation Department in the Adirondack and Catskill Forest Preserve, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne said today.

The Columbia University Press reports that so far as can be learned the earliest printed book was the "Diamond Sutra," a Buddhist scripture printed in China in the year 868. The book was brought out by Wang Chieh. Only a single copy of this precious work is known to exist.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 11 (AP). -Gene Venzke of Pennsylvania was badly beaten in the finals of two events in an international track meet today, finishing third in both the 800 and 1,500 meter runs.

New York City maintained the rating of the safest large city in the nation from Jan. 1 to Aug. 1, according to a report on the Police Department Safety Drive made to Mayor La Guardia by Commissioner Valentine.

The Rev. Fred R. Isacksen, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Ketchikan, Alaska, guest preacher yesterday at the John Street Methodist Church, criticized ministers today as "fat and content" and declared that communism was gaining throughout the world because it was based on a definite plan.

Passengers due today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen include Selby Munsie, member of the Australian Senate, and Mrs. Munsie; Baron George von Sedlitz and Carlos Alves de Souza, counselor of the Brazilian Legation in Mexico City. Others aboard are:

Standing committee appointments by the Bar Association of the City of New York for the coming year were announced yesterday by Charles H. Strong, the secretary. The elective officers were also announced. The standing committees are appointed by Clarence J. Shearn, president.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- After waiting two hours in perfectly flat conditions, a fresh easterly breeze came in this afternoon to give eleven Interclub Class boats a race in their Bermuda trophy series and Lou Pearson a victory with Emil Mosbacher's Susan.
MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 11 (AP). -Authorities planned swift prosecution today of seven men seized for an alleged attempt to assassinate President Lazaro Cardenas.

A man in hip boots stood in the glinting rapids of the Beaverkill River, casting a fly to an aldershaded pool. Fifteen yards downstream a 10-year-old boy, barefoot and wearing only khaki trunks, sat on a rock on the edge of the stream, gripping a 5-and-10cent store rod, from which hung a line and worm-baited hook.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- The Havas News Agency reported tonight from Addis Ababa that Emperor Haile Selassie had announced Ethiopia was willing to cede part of her territory to Italy in exchange for an outlet to the sea and financial assistance.

The street now known as John Street was early in the seventeenth century a "lane" that by the end of the century had grown into a street bearing the name by which it had been christened when a lane -- "Golden Hill." One wonders why so alluring a name was relinquished for the common name which has been given to saint and sinner alike.
Modern society has killed man's conscience and has substituted itself for "the small voice of God," the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge said yesterday morning at high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- George H. Bull, president of the racing association, was host at a large luncheon today at the Saratoga Golf clubhouse. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. Morris S. Tremaine, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Playford, Mr. and Mrs. Robert McMullen, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Vassar, Mr. and Mrs. Henry McComb Bangs and Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Birckhead.

Four thousand followers of Father Divine, Negro evangelist, journeyed to Brooklyn yesterday to assist their leader in a parade and demonstration in front of the tent of a rival evangelist, "Prophet" K. Costonie, on a vacant lot at Pacific Street, between Rochester and Utica Avenues.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- The disturbances which broke out this week at various French ports did not have a great influence on the stock market. These riots really were of a political character and were instigated by minority agitators who wanted to make use of the discontent following the pay cuts.
Although their season is definitely waning, the Summer theatres of several States have mustered ten new plays for production this week, in addition to the usual list of established successes.

The upward progression of share prices in the latter part of the week just completed, wherein the stock average was lifted to the highest level since late in 1931, demonstrated that the investment faith in the market as a barometer for trade and industry has not been shaken.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- Clint Ferguson, Waban, Mass.; Fred Jacoby Jr., North Bergen, N.J., and Bob Grabau, Kenmore, N.Y., shared leading honors on the Charles River Basin today as the two-day Central New England Regatta Association outboard racing came to an end.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- A Winter wheat crop of 432,000,000 bushels, in round numbers, as indicated by the United States forecast, is 26,000,000 bushels less than indicated by the government's estimate on July 1, and 25,000,000 bushels in excess of last year's harvest, which was the smallest in recent years.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- Leaping into the open sea on the Fishing Banks, 200 miles east of here, from the deck of a trawler, a Boston man was rescued today under circumstances which for a time furnished a mystery for the Coast Guard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The statement from Herbert Hoover projecting a "momentous" constitutional issue into the 1936 campaign was interpreted here by some as foretelling his own candidacy.

Preaching the sixth in his series of sermons on "The Liturgy and Life" at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R. I., declared that the lives of Christians in the common acceptance of the term were not likely to be happy.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11. -- Trading in the cotton market here was rather sluggish in the early part of last week, because of the traders' desire to await the government estimate of the indicated crop based on conditions existing on Aug. 1. After the estimate for a crop of 11,798,000 bales was released, trading became more active.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- New stock corporations formed in the State in July totaled 1,435 as against 1,472 for July of last year. The July figures were 100 less than the June total. July capitalization, however, amounting to $18,083,318, exceeded that of the corresponding month last year by nearly $3,000,000 and that of June of this year by more than $3,500,000.

EDMUND BURKE said you cannot indict a whole people, but somebody indicted a whole sex at Asbury Park the other day. The occasion was the Summer championship bridge tournament at which, for the first time, a betting syndicate made a book on the men players.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- The unsettled weather today made home luncheon parties popular. Among those who entertained were Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Roger W. Cutler, Mrs. Herbert C. Pell, Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie, Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas, Mrs. Bedford Davie and Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon Jr.

A new issue of $76,000,000 tenyear 2 1/2 per cent bonds of the government of the Dominion of Canada will be offered to the public today at 97 3/4 and accrued interest. This issue marks the first Canadian Government financing and the second foreign government loan in the American market since the passage of the Securities Act.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP). -Graham McNamee of New York and Tom Manning of Cleveland, radio announcers of the National Broadcasting Company, and Mrs. Betty Searles of Akron were injured today during the running of the National Soap Box Derby, a contest for boys.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 11. -- The sixth international university championships were formally opened today by Regent Nicholas Horthy in the presence of members of the cabinet and the diplomatic corps and international sports celebrities.

A showdown between the striking Works Progress Administration workers and Administrator Hugh S. Johnson will be reached today. Union leaders predicted that they would complete the task of calling an estimated 10,000 to 15,000 men off projects and General Johnson stood ready to cut them off the payrolls at the end of the day.

Plant expansion and reconstruction work to cost $50,000,000 has been authorized by the General Motors Corporation, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, announced yesterday in issuing the company's report for the first six months of the year. The building program, Mr. Sloan skid, was being undertaken because of the "more assured outlook for profitable development."

Another lot of surprising Dodger doings was put on display for fewer than 5,000 fans who summoned sufficient enthusiasm to congregate at Ebbets Field yesterday. As Item No. 1, the Stengel troupe downed the Braves in both ends of a double-header, 7 to 5 and 3 to 2, and reascended into fifth place.

Forced down by motor trouble and finding no other place available, the pilot of an excursion plane from Floyd Bennett Field landed safely with eight passengers on a concrete automobile parking space at Manhattan Beach at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Harvesting of Spring wheat in Minnesota, the Dakotas, and in southern sections of Western Canada, reveals disap pointing yields because of unusually high temperatures, lack of sufficient rainfall and spreading of black stem rust.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- In the absence from the capital today of most of the political leaders who were taking a day of rest from Congressional problems bearing on early adjournment, Herbert Hoover's demand for clarification of the Roosevelt administration's intentions regarding amendment of the Constitution brought little reaction here.

The greatly increased income tax burdens to which residents of New York State would be subjected if the tax bill agreed on by the Senate Finance Committee should be enacted into law, and the New York State rates should be maintained as enacted last February, are shown in the following table, with amounts in dollars:

The Adelphi Theatre's stepchildren of Gilbert and Sullivan will offer a double bill up there this evening -- the usual double bill of "H.M.S. Pinafore" and "Trial by Jury." Having gone through a fair share of the more popular Savoy operas, they will begin next week to repeat them.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The elaborate report on short-term borrowing by Germany, published by the Bureau of Statistics at the beginning of this week, is regarded in financial circles as a new mystification since it entirely evades the throwing of any light on the real magnitude of the debt.

SARTOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Important decisions will be made this week affecting Omaha and Discovery, the two outstanding racers on the American turf today. The former is a doubtful starter in the $25,000 Travers here on Saturday, while Discovery's owner waits upon the announcement of weights before deciding whether to ship his star to Pawtucket, R.I., for the $25,000 Narragansett Special on Aug. 21.

The pulmotor which for a couple of days had the Yankees breathing with a grand defiance went out of commission completely at the Stadium yesterday, to leave the McCarthymen without any wind whatsoever.

BOLTON LANDING, Lake George, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The gayest social affair of the season here was the horse show ball held last evening in the French Village Grill of the Hotel Sagamore. Mrs. Caleb Lodge McKee entertained at the ball for her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Esterbrook of Columbus, Ohio.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Militant farmers have organized to fight the program of regimenting producers of the nation through the New Deal's Agricultural Adjustment Act. Tomorrow they will start a nation-wide organization with headquarters in Chicago to protect farmers from "the further loss of their individual rights."

ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The wineries and the fruit pantries in the State will have a far greater supply of grapes, apples and peaches this year than they had last, if tentative production forecasts are borne out.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Former President Herbert Hoover in a statement issued today declared:
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Pirates and Reds divided a doubleheader today, Pittsburgh winning the first 5 -- 4, and Cincinnati the second, 4 -- 3.

Postponement of consideration of the Federal Tax Bill until the next Congress was urged yesterday by James Lee Loomis, president of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn. Mr. Loomis is also chairman of the standing committee on Federal taxation of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

Although prices were mixed last week in the local commodity futures markets, the undertone was firm, reflecting in part the strength in security markets. The volume of business was comparatively small because of the lack of interest on the part of the public.

Recent requests by groups of employes in various departments of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's system for shorter work weeks and vacations with pay, it was disclosed yesterday, have been turned down by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver.

The organization of the Grover Cleveland Memorial Committee, which will undertake the erection of the monument to the former President authorized in June by a joint Congressional resolution, was announced yesterday.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 11. -Assemblyman Theron McCampbell of Monmouth County, who has been conducting a "potatoe test" demonstration against the State sales tax here for the last several days, notified J. H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, today that he would not file any tax returns on the more than seven hundred 100-pound bags of potatoes he sold to residents at 25 cents bag.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 11. -Ray Ruddy, the distinguished water polo player, made his seasonal debut in championship swimming competition today and demonstrated once more that he is the kingpin of the local distance natators.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 47 per cent of capacity, representing a rise of one point in a week. The monthly report shows an average of 39.44 per cent in July, against 40.31 in June and 46.70 in the first half of the year.

AURORA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Dr. William Ernest Weld, Professor of Economics and dean of the college at the University of Rochester since 1929, will become the president of Wells College on the retirement in June, 1936, of Dr. Kerr Duncan MacMillan, head of the institution since 1913, according to an announcement today by the board of trustees.

IT was in a baseball dugout that the discussion started. Ival Goodman was the first of the Cincinnati players to make 100 hits this season. Ival. Odd names some of these fellows come up with, There was Euel Moore, pitcher with the Phillies, now a Giant.

Death was described as the "most dynamic force in life" in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, minister of City Temple, London, ending a series of five sermons at Riverside Church.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- The first increase in the number of births in five years was recorded in the first half of this year, figures made public today by the State Department of Health indicated. There is a definite sign of change in the sustained decreases in the birth and death total rates.

LENINGRAD, Aug. 11. -- The belief that to cure disease the microbe must be found and eliminated was challenged by Professor A. D. Speransky of the Soviet Institute of Medicine before the International Physiological Congress here today.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- Although British markets generally have slackened greatly over the holidays, there has been a surprising degree of activity in securities and, considering the season, an unusual interest in gilt-edge issues. A loan of 1,670,000 for the Trinidad Government was offered this week on a 3 per cent basis and it appears that there will be no closed season for new capital issues this year.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 11. -Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice had her largest concert of the Summer at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, yesterday afternoon. One hundred and fifty guests heard the Russian Cathedral Quartet sing four groups of songs.
Housing deals in three boroughs Were included in the urban realty transactions reported yesterday.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Aug. 11. -The newe $2,600 Fire Island jail was opened at 2:38 o'clock this morning to the strains of "Sweet Adeline." It was sung by 300 men and women who jammed the one-storied brick structure for an official dedication that could not be held last week because Police Marshal Clarence (Babe) Morriss had mislaid the key.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Aug. 11. -- A plan originating in Guatemala to call a conference of the Presidents of five Central American republics has been reported here and in other capitals. It concerns a proposal for a commercial and economic union of the countries.

Reflections on last week's distressing event in Rhode Island and Providence Plantations pour from all parts of the country, perhaps in the pious hope of concentrating Mr. ROOSEVELT'S attention for a moment on a matter that swam into his ken in the morning papers of last Wednesday.

In his first appearance with orchestra in New York since his sensational debut as a boy of 8 six years ago Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, played Lalo's "Symphonic Espagnol" with the accompaniment of the ensemble from the Philharmonic-Symphony at the Stadium last night.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 11. -- Repudiation of the Roosevelt administration in the 1936 election and collapse of the New England cotton textile industry unless the processing tax on cotton is abrogated were predicted today by Lincoln Baylies, spokesman for the Northern cotton manufacturers.
Will political convention history repeat itself? The question is being debated by those giving thought as to who the Republican nominee for President will be in 1936.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- Overcoming a 2,530-point lead piled up against them by a DixieNew York contract bridge team the New York foursome of H. Huber Boscowitz, A. Mitchell Barnes, Charles Lochridge and John Rau fought their way into the finals of the knockout team-offour championship of the American Bridge League here tonight by a margin of a mere sixty points.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Grain traders who believe that conditions in the United States and Canada are such as to create increased speculative buying support and higher prices are greatly disappointed by the erratic action during the week. They bought on every piece of bullish news, and advanced prices, but when the buying ceased selling movements developed, and prices receded more readily than they had advanced.

The La Guardia administration will send no definitive unification plan to the Tralisit Commission, to be used as the basis for public hearings, unless it is able to arrive at an "understanding" with the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company similar to that already existing with the B.M.T., it was indicated yesterday.

The Works Progress Administration projects which employ about 100,000 relief workers in New York are threatened by a skilled workers' strike in protest against the "security wage" scale. This strike, if successful, may paralyze the entire WPA program, with the result that all now employed will be thrown back upon the relief rolls, and 250,000 more who are expected to receive future work will be compelled to continue accepting home relief.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -With the height of the Summer rush still a few weeks off, hotels in this city are experiencing, almost without exception, the busiest season in the last five-year period.

MANILA, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Threats of election violence having been subdued by an Interior Department warning, candidates are laying their foundations for the commonwealth Presidential campaign, which will end at the ballot boxes Sept. 17.
