CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Pressure on grain futures here last week, mainly from tired holders and hedgers, prevented many bulges in prices from holding, and unloading at the last carried prices to virtually the lowest of the week on all grains. There were net losses on wheat futures of 1/4 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, May leading the decline.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP). -The Bisons took both games from Newark today, 5 to 4 and 16 to 5, to register their second double-barreled triumph in three days and gain a four-out-of-six margin in the series.
VIENNA, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Significant hints were dropped in several quarters today that Austria and Germany might shake hands and call off their bitter two-year-old quarrel.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

The salary cost of the administrative staff of the Board of Education has increased 197 per cent since 1918, the Citizens Budget Commission declared in a statement yesterday. The commission said that overmanning and grossly excessive salaries were the rule throughout the administrative force.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 11. -- Opposition Senators Carlos Aroyo Del Rio and Pablo Hanibal Vela were elected president and vice president of Senate, respectively, yesterday. The Lower House elected Guillermo Ramos and Ricardo de Hierro, supporters of the government, to corresponding positions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Pullman, Inc., and its sleeping-car affiliate, the Pullman Company, reported declines in earnings today, each showing deficits in current operations.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11. -- Stocks and bonds of newsprint companies operating in the Dominion were firmer and more active on the Canadian exchanges last week and the improved trend is believed here to reflect a feeling of encouragement with regard to the industry's outlook for next year.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The newly created Newark police emergency squad saved the life of a baby boy born to a 15-year-old mother here this morning, after working over the child for more than an hour with an inhalator.

Negroes and Italians in Jersey City turned the streets into a battlefield yesterday afternoon and fought out their differences over the Italian-Ethiopian dispute with a bitter hand-to-hand combat under the elevated railroad tracks on Railroad Avenue between Coles and Monmouth Streets.

YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 11. -- Not waiting to learn the identity nor the mission of strangers who ventured near his isolated home at 9 Mildred Street, Anthony Spiak, who is resisting efforts to have his crippled son operated upon, drove away visitors this afternoon with a barrage of stones and a brandishing of sticks.

Foreign exchanges were mixed in their trend against the dollar last week. The pound and the Scandinavians showed an upward swing, but the French franc, the belga, guilder and the Swiss unit declined. German marks and the lira registered slight gains.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The strike in France, which was accompanied by considerable rioting and disorder, resulted this week in renewed nervousness here in the foreign exchanges, although compared with the experience of the recent Dutch crisis the market is described as "tranquil."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Oats specialists who worked last season on the belief that the smallest crop in about fifty years should result in prices advancing materially were so badly disappointed that they are going slowly on the selling side, despite the large oats crop, which, however, is not up to early expectations, serious damage having resulted from too much rain and high temperatures at the critical growing period.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- The farewell appearance of the Giants at Baker Bowl this season was sad indeed -- for the league leaders. Bucky Walters, a reformed infielder, held them powerless before a gathering of 5,000 as the Phillies made the Giants absorb their third shut-out of the season.

A list of makers of unnecessary noise is in the possession of the League for Less Noise, Inc., of 580 Fifth Avenue, it was learned yesterday, and will be regarded as a collection of public enemies in the league's drive for a quieter city.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 11 (AP). -Two young fellows clad only in trunks and tennis shoes went determinedly on with their Tarzanesque existence in the wilds of the Olympic peninsula today, the fifth of their scheduled thirty-day undertaking on a $200 bet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The national income paid out in 1934 is estimated to have increased by more than $5,000,000,000 over 1933, in an article by Robert R. Nathan, chief of the Bureau of Economic Research of the Department of Commerce, appearing in the August number of the department's Survey of Current Business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- All the political ingenuity of administration leaders of both Houses of Congress will be brought into play this week to return the pending tax bill to limits suggested by President Roosevelt in his message of June 19 and to adjourn the present session by Aug. 24 at the very latest.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 11. -- Bretton Woods celebrated the gayest week-end of the season at the Mount Washington.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The thirteen-week strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's plant here was no nearer solution today as spokesmen for both sides indicated an unwillingness to arbitrate beyond certain limits, already announced.

Although operations in the steel industry advanced another point last week to 48 per cent of capacity, the magazine Steel says that new commitments were in lighter volume and that steel makers believe the current rate represents a peak in the rise under way since the first week in July.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- This writer has just returned from Rome and he feels it is high time that public opinion was placed in possession of the full truth of the gravity of the issues now pending between Britain and Italy, of which the Ethiopian incident is only the outward sign.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- Earl Browder, American Communist leader, published today a tentative program for a proposed workers and farmers party in the United States and said Communists in America would urge government confiscation and operation of idle mills and factories.
Industrial and housing properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

MARION, Va., Aug. 11. -- Prominent persons in American music, art, literature and folklore are expected to take part in the annual White Top Folk Festival to be held on White Top Mountain near Marion, Southwestern Virginia, on Friday and Saturday, and allied events at Marion and Wytheville, Va., on Wednesday and Thursday.

A return to the art of dining, ruined during prohibition, is closing the doors of many restaurants to waitresses, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, declared yesterday. Mr. Henkel thinks a good meal is served better by a trained man.

ABBEVILLE, S.C., Aug. 11 (AP). -- National Guard troops with fixed bayonets guarded from threatened violence tonight eleven Negroes imprisoned here on charges of assaulting and attempting to kill Jim Strickland, 40, a white man of Calhoun Falls.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 11. -Construction has been started on the auditorium of the Paper Mill Playhouse, Brookstde Drive, Short Hills. The first unit, comprising offices and workshops, was completed in the Spring. The auditorium, remodeled from one of the old buildings, will be of steel and brick construction, with sand-finished walls and large deep windows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Thirteen registration statements involving issues of $118,585,000, of which $118,435,000 represented new issues, have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced today. They include ten commercial and industrial issues totaling $41,435,000.

The principal feature in the cotton market last week was publication of the first government estimate of the 1935 domestic cotton crop. The report, indicating a crop about 400,000 bales above expectations, brought a moderate decline and was followed by more activity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Details of the offering of $100,000,000 2 7/8 per cent Treasury bonds announced last week were given today by Secretary Morgenthau and tenders for the issue were invited.

Premier LAVAL has called upon all the Prefects of France to use all their power to enforce the decrees which he has issued by authority of Parliament. He was naturally disturbed, and perhaps unduly alarmed, by the rioting which took place in several French seaports.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- George Lauder's Class M sloop Windward today led the fleet of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., on its first cruise run here.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- President Albert Lebrun addressed what he called a "supreme appeal to the nation" to cease violent opposition to the government's deflationary program in an address this afternoon at the dedication of the memorial to war dead at Metz.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Behind the four-hit pitching of Elden Auker, the Tigers downed the White Sox by a score of 4 to 1 today, sweeping the four-game series and running their string of consecutive victories to nine.

BIARRITZ, France, Aug. 11 (AP). -- American athletes again triumphed over an aggregation of French track and field stars today, but Roger Normand, French hopeful, wrested two of the thirteen first places from the visitors.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The Morelands Stables of Miss Elmina and William Brewster of Durham, Conn., annexed the first four places in the hunters stake today in the final session of the second annual Sagamore Horse Show.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- A proposal to provide public bathing facilities in the Central Park lakes will be placed before the Park Association of New York City by Nathan Straus Jr., former president of the association, when he returns to New York early next Monday after several weeks in Europe on a mission of inquiry for Mayor La Guardia.

Last week's report of the Federal Reserve System showed that excess reserves of the member banks have reached $2,550,000,000, the highest mark on record. Yet bank loans continue at a low level. The weekly reports of member banks in ninety-one leading cities show an average of $4,433,000,000 outstanding during July in loans other than those made on security collateral.

DOVER, N.H., Aug. 11 (AP). -Smedley D. Butler, former chief of the marines, told 4,000 Veterans of Foreign Wars at their annual convention here today that "the United States is rapidly drifting toward another war through the medium of a dictatorship."
BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler warned foes at home and abroad today that the German nation was prepared to fight.

A drive similar to that which resulted in the ousting of W. Kingsland Macy as Republican State Chairman has been begun against Chase Mellen Jr., Republican County Chairman, by the conservative leaders of the party here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -Establishment in the isolated Rat Islands off Alaska of a Federal penal colony where prisoners would shift for themselves without guard rule has been recommended to Attorney General Cummings.

The Rev. William V. Adams of the Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street, that "a correction of our thought and practice at the point of worship will correct many of the difficulties in our lives."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The lumber industry has now reached a "reasonable balance" between production and consumption, according to a report of the special lumber survey committee of the Department of Commerce, and no further general stock reduction is recommended.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Darkness ended the second half of a double-header today between the Browns and the Indians, with the teams deadlocked at 7 -- all after eleven innings. The Indians punished four pitchers to win the opener, 10 to 7.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The new system of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, for selling promissory notes through the Gold Discount Bank has materially affected the month-end demand for money. The commercial banks which want cash may now obtain part of it by selling their holdings of notes instead of rediscounting them at the Reichsbank.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- In defiance of warnings, the Council of Brethren, made up of clergymen opposed to the Nazi Protestant Church program, has sent out a letter informing all Protestant ministers that "a new and possibly the most severe struggle yet experienced lies ahead."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- A revival of business in all leading lines, indicated by reports covering virtually all parts of the Middle West, the West, the Southwest and extending to most sections of the country, has created the best feeling in recent years.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- German paganism and the national church movement have been making steady headway under the beneficent influence of the State's campaign against the stubborn independence of the Christian churches.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- Earl Browder, American Communist leader, told of plans to broaden the appeal of the American Communist party to American farmers, in order to induce them to join a united-front workers and farmers party, in another address before the Communist International Congress here.

The Fifth Avenue Playhouse will reopen on Friday as the Cinema de Paris, when "Prenez Garde a la Peinture," a film of provincial life in France based on a story by Rene Fauchois, will have its American premiere. The house will devote itself exclusively to showing Frenchproduced photoplays, and lists among future attractions Rene Clair's "Le Dernier Milliardaire" and "Maria Chapdelaine," the film that was awarded the Grand Prix of France.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- A group of neighboring Storm Trooper organizations paraded Munich streets in 500 trucks today, flaunting streamers denouncing Jews and referring to "Catholic foreign exchange smugglers." The demonstration occurred after handbills had been distributed calling the population to witness the parade and to hoist flags.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 11. -Many conditions of today's depression were foreseen three-quarters of a century ago by Lord Thomas Babington Macaulay.

I was interested in Francis Brown's article "Sparring Begins for the Issue of 1936" in last Sunday's TIMES. According to him, politicians are afraid of issues and avoid them whenever possible, and now the party leaders are busy searching for vote bait, being careful not to raise any real issue.

BEAUMONT, Texas, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Johnnie Godwin, 31, acting Police Chief of Orange, Texas, died today of a bullet wound suffered in a fight with two motor-car theft suspects -- just seventy-five days after the slaying of his predecessor, Ed J. O'Reilly.

RYE, N.Y.. Aug. 11. -- In one of the most dramatic finals seen here in years, Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta toppled the giant Frank Shields of New York and Hollywood today to win the Eastern grass court tennis championship on the rain-soaked turf of the Westchester Country Club.

There is but one effective answer to the striking union craftsmen. Science will ultimately eliminate all so-called craftsmanship from building construction, except for repair work and improvements on existing structures.

Yesterday was Father's Day at the beaches of the metropolitan area. With a sigh of relief from the responsibilities of watching youngsters play in the surf, he set out from shore in a boat and spent the day fishing.

With consumer buying expanding steadily in all sections of the country, out-of-town buyers arrived in large numbers in the wholesale markets here last week to purchase supplies to fill in depleted stocks, but mainly to make commitments in anticipation of an early and active demand for Fall merchandise in the stores.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP). -- The third chief of police to be shot down in Northern California in recent weeks was killed early today by bullets from a prowler's pistol.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The use of the taxing power to level great fortunes; as proposed by President Roosevelt, was defended tonight by Dr. Charles A. Beard, historian, at the fifth annual economic conference for engineers in session at the Stevens engineering camp here.

BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 11. -- A series of more than forty robberies in homes in surrounding towns, which have been puzzling the police for the last three months, apparently was solved today, according to the police, with the arrest of five brothers, the sons of Mr. and Mrs. James Furman of Montville, N.J.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,308,350,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- With 35,000 fans in the stands, Washington and Boston divided a double-header today, the Senators taking the first game, 4 to 2, and the Red Sox the final, 5 to 4.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- A Red Mrs. Grundyvitch, who ordered a park closed because it contained reproductions of nude Greek statues, received a stinging rebuke today from the newspaper Pravda, which made clear that the Communist party would not tolerate such prudery.

LENINGRAD, Aug. 11. -- The theory that science has no country but is the universal patrimony of humanity is well exemplified in the Leningrad Physiological Congress, where the leading research workers of more than thirty nations are assembled for the mutual communication of their separate investigations, discoveries and theories.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 11. -- The first international gastroenterological congress decided to form a permanent society when it concluded its session here today. Professor Pierre Duval of Paris was elected president and it was decided that the next Congress would be held in Paris in September, 1937.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 12. -- Mrs. James Graham Parsons and her son, James Graham Parsons Jr., were guests of honor at a dinner which Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ivison Parsons gave tonight at their Stockbridge villa. Others in the company included the Rev. Edmund Randolph Laine, Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis, Mrs. John Clarkson Potter and Mr. and Mrs. Ramsey Hoguet.

A goodly representation of Broadway's more serious sector will undoubtedly find itself this evening under the stars of Schenectady, N.Y., on the campus of Union College, beholding the premiere performance of Don Marquis's "Master of the Revels."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A possibility that FERA veterans' camps, spread from Kingstree, S.C., south to the Florida keys, might be eliminated and their personnel be transferred to CCC camps became evident today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Playing in his first American tournament of the year, Roderick Menzel of Czechoslovakia defeated Wilbur Hess, national intercollegiate champion from Texas, today as the annual Newport invitation tennis fixture started on the turf courts of the Casino.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- In answer to a complaint today concerning the unwillingness of White Plains Hospital to send an ambulance in response to the urgent call of a local family, Miss Elizabeth Russell, superintendent, said this afternoon that the institution's one ambulance cannot be used as a "jitney," and can be sent out only on calls from police or physicians.

SEATTLE, Aug. 12. -- Mayor Charles L. Smith today expressed to Issaku Okamoto, Japanese Consul, his regrets that during the Capitol Hills fox hunt Friday Emperor Hirohito of Japan had been depicted drawing a jinrikisha bearing Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 12. -- The text of the address delivered today by Emperor Haile Selassie to his Crown Council follows:

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 12. -- Stormy Weather, the American-owned, Bermudian-rigged yawl which triumphed in the recent transatlantic race from Newport, R.I., to Bergen, Norway, won the famous Fastnet Cup race of the Royal Ocean Racing Club today on time allowance.

The purpose of this letter is to give especial attention to what will happen to many widows and orphan children in America immediately after the death of the husband and father if the act now being rewritten is made a law.

Salary increases amounting to $124,228 for the judges and employes of the County Courts of Kings, Queens, Bronx and Richmond are sought in the 1936 budget requests of those courts, it was brought out yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.
TORONTO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Newark Bears crept closer to the Toronto Maple Leafs and fifth place in the International League tonight by defeating the Leafs, 5 -- 3, in a floodlight contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Charges that Secretary Dern had exceeded his legal authority in preventing construction of the projected Fifty-seventh Street Bridge in New York City and that in so doing he has "thwarted the will of Congress" were made before the Senate Commerce Committee today by the Rudolph Schroeder, counsel for North River Bridge Company.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Edward D. Searle, who won the 1934 title with a shot that came within seventeen inches of the pin, today virtually assured himself of a second championship in the fourth annual hole-in-one tourney of The New York World Telegram on a specially constructed hole at the Salisbury Country Club.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 12. -- The Robert E. Lee Week Committee, which, is sponsor of the annual Lee festival in memory of the Confederate general the week of Aug. 25, has sent invitations to the Governors of Southern States and their staffs to be present at the many festivities arranged for the occasion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported tonight that the dollar value of department store sales in July was 14 per cent greater than for July of last year.

LAST June, when the spate of farm novels threatened to swell to Niagara proportions, I fled to the country to escape fiction about the country. I was sick of novels of the soil written to illustrate the Saving Habit and the contrasted Spendthrift Habit, as shown by two sets of yokels who conveniently lived their lives in counterpoint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Guffey-Snyder bill, embracing President Roosevelt's plans to stabilize the bituminous coal industry by setting up a commission for administering a regulatory code, was reported favorably by the Ways and Means Committee today, but only by the margin of a single vote.
Sir William Wiseman, banker, and Fred Perry, British tennis player and world's amateur champion, are among the passengers arriving today on the Cunard-White Star liner Berengaria. Others aboard are:

With all-wool blankets up 20 per cent since March, linens 10 per cent and sheets and pillowcases 5 per cent, the 150 buyers who attended the opening of the National Domestics and Linen Show yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker found the wholesale markets extremely firm.

Your front page this morning is surely good evidence that we are living in strange times for a country so progressive in all material things as ours. Schultz is freed. The assistant to the president of a great corporation actually entertains and considers a "whispering" campaign against the President to the effect that he is mentally and physically unsound.

Mr. HOOVER was much more belligerent than is usual with him in his statement attacking the President. No doubt he speaks his honest convictions, whether personally or as the nominal leader of his party, but when he pictures Mr. ROOSEVELT as resolved to break up the Constitution and destroy all our liberties, he is not convincing.

With more cotton being ginned daily as picking increases, hedging operations are becoming more evident on the Cotton Exchange. Pressure on October caused a loss of 15 points yesterday and carried all later months below the 11-cent level. Mill price-fixing orders developed resistance and fluctuations held within narrow limits throughout the session.

The run of common history always brings any Gilbert and Sullivan troupe to the usual double bill -- "H.M.S. Pinafore" and "Trial by Jury" -- a point that the amiable proceedings at the Adelphi Theatre reached last evening. And all right, too.
Highways and railroads, particularly in the Summer-resort region in up-State New York, will be crowded with troop movements this coming week-end, army officers announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, with increased business. particularly the industrials, where iron, coal and steel were outstanding for strength. Internationals were bought on activity in Wall Street, which is expected to continue.

The share market was bid up rapidly at the outset yesterday as further optimistic reports on industry and trade found reflection in heavy investment buying; foreign participation is reported to be increasing substantially. However, the opportunity to claim profits proved to be tempting, and during the afternoon the market was concerned mainly with endeavoring to hold part of the earlier gains; the closing was irregularly higher than on Saturday.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- It was officially announced today that Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler had received Franz Seldte, Reich Minister of Labor and commander of the moribund National Socialist German Front Fighters League (Steel Helmet) to discuss the future of that once most important German war veterans' organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Aug. 7 shows decreases for the week of $16,000,000 in total loans and investments and $62,000, 000 in net demand deposits, and an increase of $22,000,000 in time deposits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- An early statement by President Roosevelt on how he feels on the chief issues before the country, including possible constitutional changes, was predicted today in inner administration circles.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 12. -- Federal authorities tonight began an investigation of charges of misappropriation of $226,228 from the funds of the National Central Bank, one of the city's oldest banks. The shortage, according to a statement issued by the president of the bank and confirmed by Bernard J. Flynn, Federal District Attorney, was due to a defalcation and misappropriation by Harry H. Hahn, until ten days ago cashier and vice president.

WHAT, again! Those Giants had the National League pennant all wrapped up last year and then let loose. It was a catastrophe that draped the territory along the Harlem River in deep gloom and left the Polo Grounds a lonely scene of desolation when there was sound of revelry by day in Detroit and St. Louis.

TRENTON, Aug. 12. -- Elimination of townships, extensive consolidation of boroughs and cities, and, in some instances, the merger of counties, were steps proposed today by the State Planning Board to supplant the present multiple system of government which it held to be the stumbling block in the way of real economy in administration, and the establishment of effective spending control.
Dr. William Reid Blair, director of the Bronx Zoo, appeared in a new role yesterday -- that of long-distance dietitian to a baby walrus (odobaenus rosmarus).
The first railroad to report for July, the Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, showed yesterday a deficit for the month. Its statement follows:

SINGAPORE, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- "I am not banished, but am a keen supporter of the government and the Premier," declared Luang Pradit, Siamese Minister of Interior, often described as Siam's "mystery man," when he arrived today from Bangkok.

Mrs. Clara Fargo Thomas, American mural painter, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after three months in London. In that time she had a three-week exhibition of fourteen panel paintings depicting beautiful women from ancient to modern times. Mrs.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 12. -- A throng of enthusiasts followed the exhibition golf match at the Bretton Woods Golf Club today between Miss Elizabeth Gordon of Providence and Miss Helen Waterhouse of Cowesett, R.I., playing against the Rhode Island amateur woman golf champion, Mrs. Frederick Davis, and Miss Betty Waterhouse.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Miss Dorothy Schieffelin gave a luncheon, followed by bridge, today at the Beach Club for Miss Laura T. Worthington, who is visiting her.

The Twentieth Century-Fox cameras will start turning today at the Eastern Service Studios in Astoria on the sequences in which Paul Whiteman and band and Ramona will be seen in "Thanks a Million," a musical satire which is to be produced by Darryl F. Zanuck.

The directors of the Colon Oil Corporation, in a letter to stock-holders, assert that the present financial condition of the company has not been brought about by mismanagement but by conditions over which the directors have had no control

CLEVELAND Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP). -- George H. Bender, in a statement issued by his office late today asserted that the Ohio General Code "orders the Governor of the State of Ohio to call a special election without regard to politics or economies."

CLINTON, Conn., Aug. 12. -- After drifting all day in fog, the fleet of the American Yacht Club's cruise swept into Duck Island Roads tonight when a southwest breeze sprang up and gave the craft momentum. It was a long, tedious run of thirty-one miles from Port Jefferson, L.I.

British and American women tennis players started sharpening their weapons for the forthcoming Wightman Cup matches on adjoining courts yesterday at Forest Hills, where the thirteenth test in the series will be staged on Friday and Saturday.

Catching motorists who neglect to observe traffic rules is too serious an avocation to be given up just because unsympathetic people have called him names, Henry Lipkin, 19 years old, of 60 West 176th Street, the Bronx, has decided. "Names," the red-haired youth murmured yesterday, "can never hurt me."

The culture of poisonous plants is the hobby of a mystery story writer on the Doubleday, Doran list. Abe Merritt, author of "Creep, Shadow!" and other tales, has a Long Island garden which contains such poison plants as the deadly nightshade, the wolf's bane, the monk's hood and the datura.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The colors of Willis Sharpe Kilmer, one of the best-known breeders in this country, were carried to victory by Ned Reigh in the Troy Claiming Stakes today. Mr. Kilmer is the owner of Sun Beau, world's largest money-winning thoroughbred, but he was not present for the triumph, his second of the meeting.

Charles Morton Parker, president of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, who died in Los Angeles Sept. 26, 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,942,404 gross and $1,898,008 net, of which $1,744,289 was in securities.

More than 1,000 inquiries and offers from prospective buyers have been received by the State Mortgage Commission since it announced two weeks ago a list of properties for sale. Members of the commission said yesterday that the number of brokers and investors continually to be found in the sales department was "evidence of the optimism now prevailing in realty circles.

The International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $1,068,996 for the first quarter of 1935, against a loss of $1,218,543 for the same period in 1934 on a comparative basis. The company now excludes the International Hydro-Electric System and its subsidiaries from its consolidated returns.

GUTTENBERG, N.J., Aug. 12. -- William Buntz Jr., 6 years old, of 124 Twenty-fifth Street, here, set out from his home early this morning on a tricycle to "see the world." After an exciting day, during which he was royally entertained by the Hoboken police, the boy was returned to his anxious mother late in the afternoon, convinced that the world is a rather big place for a youthful explorer.

Strength in second-grade railroad and selected public utility issues featured trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The market for strictly high-grade investments remained dull as prices continued firm in undertone. Transactions amounted to $10,779,600, against $13,914,400 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Former President Hoover's statement in Chicago, asking that President Roosevelt definitely state the changes which he desires made in the Constitution, was filed away by the White House today among the topics which the President will probably discuss in speeches after Congress adjourns.

Leonard Del Genio, Harlem lightweight, received the decision over Abe Wasserman of the Bronx in the feature bout of ten rounds at Dyckman Oval last night. A crowd of 2,500 persons saw the contest, which was bitterly fought. The going was always close, and many in the gathering disagreed with the decision.

An unprecedented period of big-game fishing activity at Montauk, during which a number of records were shattered, was climaxed on Sunday with the capture of a 117-pound white marlin, believed to be the largest of that species ever brought to the dock of the Montauk Yacht Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Nation-wide walkouts of Works Progress Administration workers similar to the strikes in New York and Philadelphia were predicted here tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as he recommended in the name of the Federation's council that all WPA building and construction projects be transferred to the PWA, which pays the rate of wages prevailing in each community.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Sales of United States savings bonds increased in July after declining in June and the total maturity value of "baby bonds" outstanding reached $152,471,459.85 on July 31. The cash value was $114,353,594.89.

Two former officials of the Concord Casualty and Surety Company, which was at 90 John Street when it was taken over for liquidation by the State Insurance Department in April, 1934, were indicted by the New York County grand jury yesterday in connection with alleged mismanagement of its funds.

Few recent public announcements have been more gratifying than the Mayor's declaration of warfare against city noise. After a polite "educational campaign" next month, the first really active step will be taken Oct. 1, when a month of "noiseless nights" will be ushered in, to be followed by "noiseless days."

Doesn't it become more and more obvious that by some means or other a group of individuals have worried their way into official Washington in order that they may better carry on their efforts toward that new social order described as "State capitalism" Whether Hr. Jackson personally is of this group, I do not know.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 12. -- Certainly an extraordinary conjunction of lucky stars seems to be regulating the destinies of Salzburg this Summer. It is almost incredible how everything, even the weather, apparently is combining to make this a year of years and to raise the festival to an unprecedented level.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- President Roosevelt signed the Wilcox Military Air Base Bill and the Second Deficiency Bill, allotted $18,373,233 in WPA money to New York City, received a delegation of Cuban traders and conferred with Speaker Byrns and Senator Robinson on legislation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Economic cooperation between the United States and Cuba as exemplified in the reciprocal trade agreement and the Costigan-Jones Sugar Act were praised and held up as an example to the rest of the world in felicitations exchanged today by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull with Jose Manuel Casanova, president of the Social-Economic Union of Cuba.

The American Ballet last night gave the first of two performances at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience which, according to the official estimate, numbered 5,000. Though this may seem rather m small crowd in view of the company's recent publicity in connection with its forthcoming appearances with the Metropolitan Opera Company, it is probably to be accounted for by the fact that the program offered nothing new.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Aug. 12. -- A friendly boxing bout, staged in a vacant lot here last Tuesday to determine the neighborhood championship, brought a 19-year-old youth into court in New Brunswick today on a technical charge of manslaughter following the death last night of his 16-year-old opponent.

Paul W. Chapman, former president of the United States Lines will re-enter the shipping field if the Federal Government looks favorably upon his plan for the construction of two large transatlantic liners, it became known yesterday.
Former President Herbert Hoover maintained an official silence yesterday as he arrived in New York City after his sharp attack on the Roosevelt policies issued en route in Chicago.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Georgia Public Service Commission today lost its fight before a three-judge Federal court to prevent the Interstate Commerce Commission from putting into effect railroad freight rates higher than those prescribed by the Georgia commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- General liquidation by longs developed today in all grain pits on the Board of Trade and disclosed a lack of support, and the finish was around the bottom. New low levels for the season were established in December and May corn and all deliveries of oats and rye, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.

A substitute plan for reorganizing the McCrory Stores Corporation was offered yesterday at the continued hearings before Robert P. Stephenson, special master, at 29 Broadway. The new plan was advanced, not in opposition to the reorganization proposed by the preferred stockholders' protective committee, but as a possible substitute, some of the provisions of which would be somewhat more liberal to the debenture holders.
The Committee on Stock List of the New York Stock Exchange has received applications for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 from the following listed companies:
Philip Le Boutillier, owner of the Fastnet Cup winner Stormy Weather, has been an active participant in yacht racing for many years, usually sailing his own boat.

IRONWOOD, Mich., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Representative Frank E. Hook declared today that if any one tries to use the fact that his father and three of his brothers had received government relief "as a club over my head, I'll just fight all the harder."
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The former Barbara Hutton will receive about $400,000 from the estate of her divorced husband, Prince Alexis Mdivani, killed in a Spanish motor car crash on Aug. 1.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 12. -- "Thy People," a problem drama by Ernesta Beaux, was presented tonight for the first time on any stage at the Red Barn Theatre. The old story of Ruth and Naomi is retold in modern, almost melodramatic, form and the almost insurmountable difficulty of keeping the promise of Ruth, "Thy people shall be my people," is revealed in a way that fascinated the audience.

With a twenty-two-run attack in the seventh and final inning, the baseball team of the City Hall reporters crushed a nine ostensibly representing Mayor La Guardia's office yesterday afternoon at the Yankee Stadium. The score was 36 to 9.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Federal Judge Johnson J. Hayes reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on writs of habeas corpus under which the Neidecker brothers hoped to win their release from extradition proceedings.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12. -- Thousands of officials of collective farms arrested in connection with irregularities in the 1932 and 1933 harvests are affected by a widespread amnesty issued by the Central Executive Committee. Those in prison or under sentence are paroled and the prosecution of others has been halted, with court records wiped clean.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- A sample plane the like of which officials hope thousands of Americans soon may be able to buy cheaply and fly safely landed in Washington today after a 2,655-mile trip from the Pacific Coast.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth P. O'Brien reserved decision yesterday on Henry H. Klein's latest effort to block Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of organized crime by tying up the funds for the inquiry in litigation.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Play began today in the annual women's singles tennis tournament for the Maidstone Club championship. Seeded players are Miss Katharine Barker, last year's winner; Miss Mary Mitchell, Mrs. Jesse Spalding, Mrs. John L. Weeks, Mrs. Robert E. McCormick, Miss Helen Tuohy, Mrs. J. Kirkland Weeks, Mrs. Clinton Gilbert and Miss Marion Tuohy.

The city of Euclid, Ohio, has invited bids for a new issue of $2,019, 768 refunding bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1934, and maturing on Oct. 1, 1939 to 1947. The bonds are to carry a 4 1/2 per cent coupon. Award will be made on Aug. 27.

"Taxpayer," in his letter about the New York Public Library, writes that "insufficient money has been appropriated [for books] over the past several years." Perhaps he and the two or three million readers who use the central and branch libraries would be interested in the actual figures.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Governor Earle telegraphed Secretary Dern today asking that all regular army and National Guard troops from Virginia and the District of Columbia be excluded from the Third Corps. Area manoeuvres in Pennsylvania.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP). -- With plans almost completed and the prospect "good" for the first party to be in the field along the Chemung River near here by Wednesday, Captain Lester Rhodes threw his flood control survey machinery into high speed today on receipt of news from Washington that a $200,000 allotment had been formally approved.
"Political Observer" criticizes the new liquor bill now pending, which would permit the shipment of whisky in bulk, but does not know or overlooks the fundamental issues involved.

We read in one column that the Park and Department is setting up in every borough a "progress thermometer." The machine will show at a glance how fast the Park Department is nearing its goal of 203 new play areas to be completed by next Summer. Seventy-three of these are already in use.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Jumping away in front with a three-run attack in the first inning, the Pirates reached four Cincinnati hurlers for fourteen hits today as they turned back the Reds, 7 to 4. The victory gave the Pirates the series, three games to two.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Between 400 and 500 friends, members of the Summer colony and their tennis week guests, assembled at the Newport Country Club tonight to meet the fourth of the season's debutantes, Miss Aerielle Frazer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Washington Frazer of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and to dance in a silver garden illuminated with moonlight effect.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- National Socialism's attacks this Summer on Catholics and Protestants and the counter-offensives by the two confessions have finally forced Germany again into one of those nationwide religious conflicts that have furnished the bitterest chapters in its sanguinary history.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The Institute of American Meat Packers, trade association of the packing industry, whose members produce 90 per cent of all meat sold in the United States, issued the following announcement tonight in reply to Secretary Wallace's statement:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Backing up his recent assertion that he would push ahead with the Work Relief program in New York City despite the WPA strike, President Roosevelt today allotted an additional $25,934,527 for WPA projects there.

Strength predominated yesterday in most of the local commodity futures markets, although coffee and cottonseed oil fell slightly and tin futures were depressed. In the cash markets all grains except oats declined, as did coffee, cotton and tin, but gains appeared in printcloths, pork, cocoa, rubber and silk.

Chase Mellen Jr., Republican county chairman, ridiculed yesterday declarations that Charles D. Hilles, national committeeman, and Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, had joined a movement to remove him from his position.

General Hayashi, the War Minister of Japan, began on July 16 his vigorous measures for removing the army from the political field, into which it had forced itself from 1931 onward under the nationalistic General Sadao Araki, General Hayashi's predecessor.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- There will be no economic need to shorten the work-week when business conditions return to normal because of technological changes in the methods of production, Dr. Bradford F. Kimball declared in a study he made for Dr. Warren W. Coxe of the research division of the State Department of Education on "Changes in the Occupational Pattern of New York State."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The terms of the Navy Department's proposal that President Roosevelt name an arbitration board to decide the dispute between the New York Shipbuilding Corporation and its employes, which has tied up construction of seven naval vessels for thirteen weeks, were announced by Secretary Perkins today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- Judge Raymond MacNeille, who two weeks ago declined overtures from Republican party leaders aimed at making him a "compromise" candidate for the party's mayoralty nomination, consented today to the filing of nominating petitions.

The Blue Ridge Corporation, the Pacific Eastern Corporation and the Shenandoah Corporation made public yesterday their statements for June 30 showing increases in the net asset values of their securities. All are investment companies affiliated with the Atlas Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- When the Senate shouldered aside the Black Thirty-Hour Week Bill today in favor of imposing NRA Code wages and hours on industries dealing with the government, it acted amid cries of "discrimination."

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, and Joe Cronin, manager of the Red Sox, today were fined $100 apiece by William Harridge, president of the American League, for allowing "stalling" tactics in the New York-Boston game at Boston Aug. 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Welsh bill to require compliance with the hours and wage provisions and child and convict labor prohibitions of the defunct NRA codes as a condition to all government contracts, Federal loans to industry and grants in aid to States was passed today by the Senate without a record vote.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Aug. 12 (Reuters). -- "If Italy becomes seriously involved in Ethiopia and is seriously crippled there by a long conflict a very serious position may be created in Europe," declared General Jan Christiaan Smuts, South African Minister of Justice, in an interview today in which he broke the official silence as to the attitude of the South African Government toward the possibility of war in Ethiopia.

William M. Henry, who was technical director of the Olympics at Los Angeles in 1932 and now is a consultant for the games in Germany next year, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after spending four weeks in Berlin making a survey of the prospects for 1936.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 11. -- Four men have made a profit already of more than 1,000,000 [the Australian pound is quoted at about $3.97] from the sale and flotation of Emperor Gold Mines, Ltd, in the Fiji Islands. Behind this spectacular coup lies a mining romance which has engrossed Australians for months.

JERUSAL.I, Aug. 12. -- Interest in what the Mohammedan attitude may be in event of war between Italy and Ethiopia cen- tres here on the forthcoming visit to Palestine of Emir Ibn AbdulAziz Ibn Saud, son of Ibn Saud, the ruler of Saudi Arabia.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Mainbocher's utterly modern collection is designed to enhance the charm and chic of the typically 1936 woman. Skirts are wider than elsewhere, with a restrained circular cut giving fullness below the hips. They are slightly shorter for daytime.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Prices of hogs were on the upgrade again today, with all interests buyers. Sales showed 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight above those on Friday, with the top at $12.15, up 15 cents to a new high mark for the season. The day's average was $11.15, up 15 cents.

The recommendation of Nathan Straus, minister without portfolio, on a survey of the housing conditions in the city of London, that New York follow London's example and convert the lakes in Central Park into public bathing pavilions, was characterized yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses as "absurd, impractical and impossible."

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Aug. 12. -- The release of hormones into the blood stream by stimulation of the nerves can affect distant organs, Dr. Horsley Gantt of Baltimore told the International Physiological Congress today.

The strike of 10,000 or more skilled workmen on Works Progress Administration projects failed to develop yesterday. Figures announced at Administrator Hugh S. Johnson's office, although disputed by the union leaders, showed that only 656 men were out, 461 fewer than last Friday evening.

TOKYO, Aug. 12. -- Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau, was mortally wounded with a saber, as he sat at his desk in the War Office this morning by a lieutenant colonel, whose name was withheld. He died soon afterward.
Apartment house and taxpayer deals were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Sergeant Alvin C. York's old company commander says the Connecticut American Legion's request for Congress to give credit to Sergeant Bernard J. Early of New Haven for the annihilation of a German machine gun battalion now attributed to York is "unwarranted."

YONKER, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Science, through the mediation of a court .of justice, won a victory here today when Anthony Spiak, father of 14-year-old Henry Spiak, who was deprived of the use of his legs by infantile paralysis, agreed leave his son's fate in the hands of the Westchester County Children's Court.

Although President Roosevelt, because of the prevalence of infantile paralysis, canceled the Boy Scout Jamboree that was to open in Washington Aug. 21, several scouting contingents are on ships bound for the United States, having sailed before the President's decision was announced last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Seeking to prevent possible airplane crashes into the government's stores of high explosives, President Roosevelt today prohibited civil aircraft from flying over twenty-four army and navy arsenals, ordnance reservations and ammunition depots.

The eleven prisoners arrested during the Italian-Negro clash Sunday night on Railroad Avenue, Jersey City, were arraigned in court yesterday. Three Negroes, charged with carrying concealed weapons, were held without bail for action of the Hudson County grand jury; one Italian and one Negro were held under $1,000 bail each on atrocious assault-and-battery charges and two Italians and four Negroes were held under $500 bail each as material witnesses.

Of the innumerable supplementary themes of the daily press there is none, no, not even the graphically preconceived, prediction defying, next World War, nor the charmingly intimate history of the Dionne infants, that intrigues me so delectably as the question who will be the candidates for President next year, and, correlatively, which of them will be elected.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP). -- M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, said today in a letter to stockholders that Republic and the Corrigan, Mc. Kinney Steel Companies would proceed immediately to complete their merger. A stockholders' meeting set for Thursday would be postponed pending completion of details for the merger.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Bob Bavier Jr. and his crew of Larchmont hopefuls got the jump today as the twelfth annual championship series of the Junior Yacht Racing Association began at the Pequot Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Howard C. Hopson, who, according to the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee, is the "master mind" of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, has been found by agents of the House Committee on Rules and will be a witness before that committee when it convenes at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

DETROIT, Aug. 12. -- Joe Louis, who says it was "just one of those things" when he missed calling his knockouts of Primo Camera and King Levinsky by one round each, is going into training before telling the world when he believes he'll put Maxie Baer away next month -- but the brown bomber is none the less confident he can turn that trick.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 12. -- Although Emperor Haile Selassie has not yet expressed his views about the use of the 1906 treaty as a basis for the three-power negotiations about Ethiopia in Paris, it has been possible this week-end to gauge the Ethiopian viewpoint more clearly.

With buyers' arrivals numerous and mail orders larger, the week in the major apparel and accessory markets opened actively here yesterday. While cloth coats have suffered from the competition of furs so far in the August promotional events, the former merchandise met renewed interest yesterday and the indications are that the next two weeks will see an increase in this business.

Fifteen properties, including eight in Manhattan and seven in the Bronx, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan offerings included seven flats of five or six stories, in addition to a dwelling. Three savings banks and a mortgage firm were among the plaintiffs.

ROME, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Militant Italy pushed her mobilized forces close to the October goal of a million manpower today. Orders for mobilization of 500,000 men for war games that will begin in Northern Italy in the Brenner Pass area on Aug. 24 gave no date for the men to return to their homes.

Adoption by the city of an ordinance prohibiting motor trucks more than thirty feet long from entering the downtown food market section of Manhattan was urged upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday. The recommendation was made by a fact-finding committee on food trucking, of which Dr. John A. Harriss is chairman.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Old-fashioned diplomacy will try to do what Geneva's open negotiations have so far failed to accomplish when Anthony Eden of Great Britain, accompanied by Sir Robert Vansittart and Alexander Hamilton Thompson, arrives here tomorrow for preliminary conversations on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A statement showing how about $1,500,000,000 could be saved by the government this year in expenditures was placed before the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Jockey Alfred Robertson, Western rider for the C.V. Whitney stable, scored a triple with successive mounts at Lincoln Fields today.

Columbia College will experiment this Fall with a modified "house" plan in its dormitory system, similar to that used at Harvard, it was learned yesterday. A group of fourteen students has been selected to live in a special section of Hartley Hall with a member of the faculty as adviser.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Twenty-one more companies have applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of securities on national securities Exchanges. Those on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges follow:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Bids for the proposed transpacific air mail service to operate once a week each way from San Francisco by way of Honolulu and Manila to Canton, China, were invited by the Postoffice Department today.

It was foreseen that there would be a bitter cry in Congress against the proposal of the Senate Finance Committee to lower the exemptions in the matter of income taxes. But it was not foreseen that the Senate Finance Committee itself would so quickly turn tail and run away.

A six-story apartment house for forty-seven families is to be built at 712-26 Ocean Parkway, northwest corner of Parkville Avenue, according to plans filed in Brooklyn yesterday. The estimated cost is $125,000. Cohn Brothers, architects, designed the structure for the Paqueen Building Corporation of 26 Court Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Plans for the merger of the Methodist Episcopal Church (Northern), the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant churches probably will be completed this week at a meeting in Evanston, according to Bishop W.N. Ainsworth of Macon, Ga., chairman of the College of Bishops of the Southern Church.

With the earlier tournaments out of the way, the polo players are turning this month to preparations for the national championship and the defense of the title against the visiting Hurlingham team from London. The various open championship teams are drawing plans for practice matches and games will be held each day this week except Friday.
Several flats and business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Favorites were beaten in two of the three events on the opening day of the Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Eight proposals for constitutional amendments to sanction social legislation reposed today among forty, collecting dust in Congressional pigeonholes.

Two theatres at Columbus Circle were the targets of bombers at 3:10 o'clock this morning. The bombing gang, driving past the theatres in a brown-colored sedan, threw explosives at the fronts of the theatres despite groups of taxi chauffeurs and other persons standing about in the streets.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The success of Advising Anna, 5-year-old daughter of Blondin, since she joined the stable of Mrs. Floyd West continued today when she won the Roger Williams Handicap, a mile event for 3-year-olds and upward, feature of the opening program of Narragansett Park's thirty-day midsummer meeting.
HAVANA, Aug. 12. -- Cuba quietly commemorated today the second anniversary of the downfall of the dictator Gerardo Machado.
CRESTON, Iowa, Aug. 12. -- Carol Lynn Rowe, 20 months' old daughter of Dr. and Mrs. K.W. Rowe, has a vocabulary of more than 600 -- words.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- A dazzling 64, eight under par, by Henry Dobbs and Herman Rama of Fresh Meadow topped a near record field in the Long Lsland Golf Association's amateur-pro best-ball tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

A genial but impoverished traveler, who in the last eighteen months has visited most of the United States, is rapidly endearing himself to the officials of the Irving Trust Company, even though his generous nature has compelled them to adopt a form letter that informs recipients of his bounty that his intentions are better than the checks he writes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP). -- A controversy grew warmer tonight over Governor Martin L. Davey's indecision on the question of calling a special election to fill the vacancy in the House caused by the death of Representative at Large Charles V. Truax Friday, in Washington.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The possibility of restoring prosperity through government spending was debated here today at the Economics Conference for Engineers at the Stevens Institute engineering camp.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12. -- Air France plans to inaugurate passenger service from Paris to Buenos Aires in January, according to an announcement here today by the company's famous flier, Jean Mermoz.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Of thirty-five cities covered in a report made today by State Auditor Walter R. Darby, Port Republic, Atlantic County, is the only one having no net debt, while Asbury Park ranks highest in percentage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- If the 1933 hog slaughter under AAA auspices had not taken place, consumers would now be paying higher prices for pork than they are, Secretary Wallace said today in reply to what he termed packers' propaganda against processing taxes.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Aug. 12. -- The passage of Italian reinforcements through the Suez Canal bound for Eritrea continues on a large scale, with transports appearing here daily.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The opening of the nineteenth invitation tennis tournament at the Newport Casino this morning drew a large gallery.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12. -- The amateur standing of Jesse Owens, Ohio State track and field star, remained unchanged tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- By bearing constantly in mind the fact that, with the exception of certain Democratic conservatives and Senator La Follette, few members of Congress want to pass before 1937 a tax bill which is more than a political gesture, readers of the Washington news during the next week or two can better understand such gyrations as that of the Senate Finance Committee today, and those to follow on the floor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- In a sudden reversal of its action of Saturday, the Senate Finance Committee late today revised the pending tax bill to conform more closely to President Roosevelt's ideas of redistributing wealth. The revamping reduced the prospective yield in new revenue from $450,000,000 annually to a bare $250,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- With fresh suits added daily to the fight against AAA, government lawyers predicted today that the processing taxes will face more than 1,000 legal attacks by midweek.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Forty-nine yearlings passed under the hammer tonight at the sales ring and brought a total of $72,700, an average of approximately $1,484 per head. Most of them were from the breeding farms of Willis Sharpe Kilmer, with the best prices being received for his yearlings.

Retail prices again declined during July, continuing the trend toward lower levels which has been in evidence since April, 1934, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. With the composite index at 85.2, prices on Aug. 1 were the lowest since September, 1933.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Deputy State Tax Commissioner Grimm, in charge of sales tax collections, said today that he would advise Commissioner J. H. Thayer Martin against prosecution of Assemblyman Theron McCampbell of Monmouth County for his recent public sale of potatoes without collecting the levy from the consumers.

While the statement issued by the United States Office of Education covers reports from only forty-one of the forty-eight States, it is to be assumed that the averages would be fairly representative of all. As compared with the biennium 1931-32, that for 1933-34 showed a decrease of 18.3 per cent in current expenses (reduced from $1,171,903,899 to $957,693,673); of 68.4 per cent in capital outlay and of 9.6 per cent in interest payments.

The dollar was weaker yesterday in the foreign exchange market, dropping 5 points to 99.96 per cent of gold parity. The franc advanced 7/8% point to 6.63 3/8 cents at the close, which was also the high mark for the day. Other members of the gold-bloc trio, the guilder and the Swiss franc, were up 8 points and 3 points respectively.

It is a sad picture of the state of commercial aviation in Europe that HENRI BOUCHEE presents to the Air Transport Cooperation Committee of the League of Nations. Instead of stimulating the development of fast machines, subsidies have dulled enterprise.
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Seventy yachts, fifty-one of them racing, made the run of the American Yacht Club here today from Duck Island, west of the mouth of the Connecticut River.

The other evening at dinner one of the men present described the efficient work being done at East Hampton in the elimination of ragweed and the resulting relief to hay fever victims. Among those present was a physician who specializes in hay fever treatment. The next day I received the following letter which may interest your readers:

HONGKONG, Aug. 13. -- The political stage in Southwest China with Canton as its centre may soon witness momentous developnents precipitated by the resignation of Wang Ching-wei as Premier and of other Nanking officials.

TOKYO, Aug. 13. -- Lieut. Gen. Kiyoshi Imai, Director of the Personnel Bureau of the War Office, was appointed today to succeed Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, Director of Military Affairs, who was murdered yesterday.

A budget estimate of $7,171,152 for 1936, an increase over 1935 of $1,084,743, was submitted yesterday by Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- The appearance of Enrique Maier of Spain on the centre court in his American debut was the most interesting development of a day of long and arduous competition in the Newport invitation tennis tournament today as the ranking elect came through two rounds at the Casino.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- The markets on the London Stock Exchange today were cheerful but less active, except among the industrials. Demand was keen for iron and steel issues, stimulated by output figures for July. Company reports and expectations of dividends helped motor securities.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Boerse was fiym and quiet today. Heavy industrials were friendly but not particularly active. HarDener gained point. Machine issues were firm and quiet, although Berlin-Karlsruhe last A. Chemical securities were passive.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Although several thousand spectators viewing the second day's session of the fourth annual hole-in-one tournament failed to see any of the 164 players who competed today better Edward D. Searle's shot within 8 1/2 inches of the 148-yard hole at the Salisbury Links, there were numerous thrills provided.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Mike Cestone, a Montclair letter carrier, and Eric Lenaeus, former assistant professional to Craig Wood, co-medalists yesterday, today entered the semi-finals of the first annual New Jersey State public links golf championship at the Forest Hill Field Club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- St. Bernard, which was runner-up to Omaha in the Arlington classic, proved his fitness for the Travers when he won the Kenner Stakes at a mile and three-sixteenths today over a track rated as good, but not considered to be to his liking.

The advance in the share market yesterday was concerned mainly with the public-utility and railway groups. With little in the day's news to draw attention to these issues, it may be assumed that with other sections of the stock list lately encountering active profit-taking, the firming up of the market involved speculative exploration in hitherto comparatively neglected territory -- that is, neglected during the recent sharp climb in stock prices.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Aug. 13 (AP). -- In one of the strangest races on record, the yacht Astra won in the Royal Yacht Club regatta off Spithead today -- against a blank field. A burst of stiff breezes for which yachtsmen were praying at Cowes all last week caused the confusion that saw Astra sail off alone and gain the victory after completing the first round.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- A general population census to cost $16,000,000 in Work Relief funds was recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments. The recommendation followed a declaration of the Census Bureau that "extensive changes in national welfare" and "unprecedented movements of population" have rendered the census of 1930 obsolete.

The Rev. John Dorn, 35-year-old rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Thirty-sixth Street and Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, Queens, lost his right eye in Flower Hospital yesterday as the result of injuries he received shortly after midnight when he was set upon and beaten by two unidentified men at Seventieth Street and the West Drive, Central Park.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Aug. 13.--Captain John J. Daisey, commander of the Manasquan Beach station of the Coast Guard, dived twice into the heavy surf here this afternoon and rescued swimmers who were being carried out to sea by outward racing currents, locally known as "sea pusses."
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP). -- William Lee Ferris and three former burlesque house dancers were convicted by a jury here today of the $134 hold-up murder of Howard C. Dickinson.

Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, who was wrestling yesterday with the problem of getting the type of lawyer he wants to assist him in his crime investigation at salaries he can afford to pay, pointed to one incident of the day with pride and satisfaction.

At a meeting in City Hall within sight of the dingy old postoffice building that blocks the view of Lower Broadway, the Municipal Art Commission approved yesterday a plan for the restoration of the park to its appearance of 100 years ago.

Baseball's high spot of the 1935 campaign to date will rush swiftly to its climax this afternoon when, with scarcely any prelusive gestures whatsoever, the Giants, in opening their final long home stand of the season at the Polo Grounds, start fighting with their most profoundly respected foemen -- the Cardinals of St. Louis.

The number of skilled laborers on strike on Works Progress Administration projects dwindled yesterday, while plans were made to test President Roosevelt's "work or starve order" by having a striking bricklayer apply for home relief.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 13 (AP). -- France, fearing the League of Nations may fail to settle the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, is taking the utmost precautions to protect her interests in this colony.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. (AP). -- Leaders of three branches of Methodism today completed preliminary negotiations for the proposed merger of the Methodist Episcopal Church North, the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant Church.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 13. -- During July 11,000 Bolivian soldiers were demobilized and left the Chaco former war zone, according to an official announcement. Besides these, more than a thousand sick and wounded have left hospitals for home as recovered.

Price changes and activity were mixed yesterday in the market here for commodity futures, but no movements were important. Outside features were the heaviness in London of spot silver, which fell to the April level, and in silver futures in Montreal. In the cash markets, cotton, wheat, flour, rye, oats, tin and rubber were depressed, while corn, lard and silk advanced.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Asserting that "this is not the time for rocking-chair citizenship," Governor Harold G. Hoffman contended tonight in an address at the fifth annual economic conference for engineers at the camp of Stevens Institute here that "the American system of government is threatened with the loss of its stability and strength because of shortsighted financial policies."

As the pound sterling, continuing its slow advance, rose yesterday to the highest mark since last Nov. 30, the price of silver here and in London declined to the lowest levels in four months and the price of gold in London fell to a fresh bottom mark for this year.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- The Bourse continued its progress today along the entire list but the volume of trading, however was reduced from that of yesterday and the gains were relatively moderate. Rentes consolidated their previous advances and in some cases gained slightly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- An income-tax deficiency of $727,659 has been levied against the American Waterworks and Electric Company of New York, holding company for a large number of power, water and traction companies, records of the Board of Tax Appeals revealed today.

The presence of seven detectives, two city agents and three reporters caused such acrimonious debate at a special meeting of the Shochtim yesterday afternoon at the Great Central Hall, 96 Clinton Street, that some persons left in disorder.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- In testifying before the House Lobby Committee today, H.C. Hopson was asked by Chairman O'Connor to state his income from management fees for the last two years or the last year.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Miss Joan Earle of Bellport, 1933-34 women's champion, led by 4 points today at the end of three of a series of five races sponsored by the Great South Bay Racing Association for the Henry Morgan Bowl, symbolic of the women's championship of the bay.

The national income in 1934, according to the Department of Commerce, was $49,440,000,000, an increase of 11 per cent over that in 1933. Some readers will be puzzled to see that this income is placed at only $44,431,000,000 in 1933, compared with $47,964,000,000 in 1932, whereas the common impression is that 1933 was a better year than 1932, and that 1934 income would compare more favorably with 1932 than these figures show.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 18. -- Dr. Gebhard Mosl, a naturalized Canadian of German extraction, is under arrest here and awaiting trial for "having made utterances against the government that are punishable under the Reich law of Dec. 20, 1984."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Swift enactment of the Tax Bill, perfected in certain aspects now under fire and yet in a form more in keeping with President Roosevelt's recommendations than either the Senate or House drafts, was freely predicted today as the Senate prepared to open debate tomorrow.

The American Cyanamid Company has made arrangements to borrow privately about $9,000,000 with which it is paying off all its funded and bank debts and those of its subsidiaries, it was announced yesterday.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the previous week. The total was also above the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 1,109, as against 1,027 in the preceding week and 1,079 in the same period last year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Many of the best-known personages in the racing colony have extended their cooperation toward making a success of the dinner dance of the Saratoga Golf Club, according to an announcement here today by Mrs. Seth W. Morton, chairman of the entertainment committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -Senator Connally of Texas introduced a three-point substitute for the Thomas' Oil Regulation Bill today.

Proponents of the new common stockholders' reorganization plan for the McCrory Stores Corporation yesterday offered, as a move to expedite reorganization, to pay $500,000 in cash to the United Stores Corporation as profit for its settlement of landlord claims against the McCrory company.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13. -- The Yankees turned back the Indians, 8 to 2, today before 5,000 fans at League Park.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- William H.J. Ely, New Jersey Works Progress Administrator, opened the WPA program in the State today by authorizing work on fifty-seven projects. The projects, involving an expenditure of $1,424,479.30, of which $1,218,769 will be provided by Federal funds, with the remainder supplied by sponsors, will provide employment for 3,217 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 . -- The Senate Lobby Investigating Committee today began an investigation of the House Rules Committee, which is also investigating lobbies, particularly the power lobby, against the Wheeler-Rayburn bill containing a "death sentence" clause on holding companies.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 13. -- Three employes and an official of a stock brokerage concern were arrested today in connection with the $226,000 shortage at the National Central Bank.
Notes on a week-end jaunt to the Jersey coast in search of bluefish:

Fun is fun the world around, Mrs. Philip L. McMahon has discovered from a tour of the globe to see how the nations play. As unofficial observer for the National Recreation Association, she found it interpreted as surf-riding in Hawaii, kite flying in Japan, polo in India and grand opera in Italy -- but it all adds up to the same thing, she said yesterday in her room at the Barbizon Plaza.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 13. -Governor Lehman and his official party narrowly escaped a serious accident early tonight while motoring to Kingston for the opening session of the annual New York State Police Conference at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Starting promptly at 9 A.M. with Dave Kanter of Southern Parkway, Charles Mayo Jr. of the Lido Country Club carded 35, 38 -- 73 to take low-gross honors in the Iong Island Golf Association's one-day handicap tournament at the Woodmere Club today.

The American Child Health Association, of which former President Herbert Hoover was honorary president, voted to discontinue its activities at a meeting yesterday at its headquarters in the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center.

Mayor La Guardia at noon today will formally start the task of removing the Manhattan extension of the Brooklyn Bridge, the unsightly viaduct which extends over Park Row into City Hall Park. The Mayor will operate a paving breaker to start the work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade drifted aimlessly to lower levels today, with little evidence of aggressive buying except for a brief period early in wheat. All rallies in this grain ran into selling, both hedging and liquidation, and the close was at the bottom, with net losses 7/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

STONEVILLE, Miss., Aug. 13 (AP). -- Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, told a gathering of cotton farmers and business men today that a complete loss of foreign markets was to be preferred to "selling out our cotton farmers and the fertility of our farms for a 5 or 6 cent price."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The Athletics fell on four St. Louis hurlers today to gain a 14-to-1 victory over the Browns.

DETROIT, Aug. 13. -- Temperature regulation and air conditioning are being installed in machine shops and foundries at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge factory. The installation already includes 200,000 cubic feet of buildings and soon will be extended to 75,000 more cubic feet.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Aug. 13. -- On a warrant sworn out by his wife Frank E. White, 57 years old, an undertaker of 107 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested here today by the State police as the man who had employed seven thugs to "beat up" his son and daughter last Tuesday.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Aug. 13. -- Much interest was aroused in Russian circles of the International Physiological Congress today by a paper read by a young American scientist, Donald Marquis of Yale, which throws further light on Professor Ivan Pavlov's theory of conditioned reflexes.

Good rains over a large part of several cotton-growing States where moisture was needed depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. For the first time since early in June, all new crop months fell below the eleven-cent level, although a steady trade demand for October developed at each point of recession as mills fixed prices. The market met cotton on all rallies and closed with losses of 14 to 18 points on the day.
