A two-unit eighty-pound noise meter, mounted on a bright yellow truck, accompanied by two limousines filled with reporters, cameramen, acoustical sound engineers, publicity men, a secretary and a camp follower, went on a motor odyssey through the crowded streets of New York yesterday, registering the raucous decibel.

The Broadway theatre district teemed last night with pickets who massed before motion picture houses in a union labor war and with more than 175 policemen concentrated in the area to guard against a repetition of the bomb throwing which early yesterday morning endangered two Columbus Circle theatres.

ROME, Aug. 13. -- Grave doubts that any positive result capable of averting war in East Africa will issue from the Anglo-Franco-Italian negotiations in Paris continue to be entertained by public opinion here. A principal reason is that Italy has expended an enormous amount of money and energy on preparations for war and expects to get something substantial in return.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 13. -- Controlling interest in Arthur D. Little, Inc., an industrial research firm, has been left in trust for the benefit of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, under Dr. Little's will, filed for probate today.

Here to defend the national championship which has been in his possession for the past two years, Fred Perry, Great Britain's tennis ace, arrived from Southampton yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. He was emphatic in stating that he would not turn professional.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from California on the Santa Paula of the Grace Line was former Governor Charles S. Whitman. After denying that he had any Presidential aspirations, he said that, in his opinion, the Republican party would be "very wise" if its next candidate for the White House were not chosen from the Atlantic seaboard.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,656,850 barrels, compared with 2,634,350 in the preceding week, an increase of 22,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 35,400 barrels in the dally average output of California was the most important change.

You published a dispatch from Annapolis, that a letter written in 1857 by Lord Macaulay to H.S. Randall, in which he foresaw the present economic and political conditions of this country, had recently been discovered. Evidently the person who came upon this prophetic document did not take the trouble to see if it had ever been published, but if he had he would have found it in the 1875 edition of Macaulay's letters.

The midsummer handicap committee meeting of the United States Polo Association announced its findings yesterday and, while several interesting changes were made, the majority of the more highly ranked players were left where they had been.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Judge James H. Wilkerson in Federal court today overruled a motion of defendants to dismiss the suit brought by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to collect $14,000,000 from stockholders of the old Central Republic Bank and Trust Company to make up for an alleged deficiency in repayment of the so-called $90,000,000 Dawes loans.

An increase in retail failures, with declines in the wholesale and manufacturing classifications, featured business defaults for the week ended Aug. 8, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The retail embarrassments numbered 145, against 121 in the preceding week.

Something of what it means to isolate oneself more than 100 miles from any other human being for months at a time is disclosed in the sections of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic diary published in the current American Magazine.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Engineering experts for the elimination of factory noises have been retained by James Roosevelt, eldest son of President Roosevelt, to stop the annoyance of residents in the vicinity of the National Grain Yeast Corporation here, of which he is president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Announcement that striking shipyard workers at Camden, N.J., would not accept the Navy Department's arbitration proposal was made here today by the union committee, which appeared before the House subcommittee investigating the three months' strike against the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Major Gen. Milton A. Reckord, commander of the Twenty-ninth Division, National Guard, withdrew today authority previously granted Virginia and District of Columbia guardsmen to train at the Maryland National Guard camp at Cascade.

Reluctant as we are in this country to face problems before they become acute, there is one now lurking under the surface which might be met half way. If we need social security insurance, we need equally, before conditions get much worse, automobile disability insurance for those in the lower income brackets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- New Deal power policies were projected as a 1936 campaign issue today during a five-hour Republican filibuster in the House against holding the world power conference in the United States next year.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- New York State's deficit June 30 was $97,029,788.31, it was disclosed today at the office of Controller Morris S. Tremaine. The figures were given out with the explanation that the cause of the deficit was a falling off in revenues from the estimates.

Arthur Tullman, 40 years old, of 61 Mangin Street, a solicitor of funds for the Gates of Mercy Centre at 53 Lewis Street, was held in $1,000 bail yesterday for hearing Aug. 16 by Magistrate Brodsky in West Side Court on a charge of petit larceny.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 13. -- The Bretton Woods colony turned out en masse today to watch a Scotch foursome at the Mount Washington, in which the Rhode Island woman champion, Mrs. Frederick Davis, and Le Baron C. Anthony, Miss Elizabeth Gordon and S. Reed Anthony, also Miss Helen Waterhouse and E.L. Behr, Miss Betty Waterhouse and W. Ross Harper were paired.

The reluctance of the Securities and Exchange Commission to comment for publication upon the steps that it may use to run down pool operators occasioned no surprise yesterday in Wall Street, where it has been rumored frequently that the SEC was investigating transactions in this or that issue.

Partisans in four of the five boroughs in the city will battle for control of the party machinery at the Fall primary, it was indicated last night. The time for filing designating petitions expired at midnight.

TURIN, Italy, Aug. 13. -- Rescue workers, troops and policemen who were rushed with supplies today to the flooded Piedmont area from the city of Alessandria said they could compute no definite toll of the dead until daylight. Scores of injured received emergency treatment at hospitals and first-aid stations and others, made homeless by the flood, spent the night in makeshift shelters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The last major accomplishment of the Economy Act of 1933, which represented the pledge of the President to cut the expenses of government 25 per cent, disappeared today when Mr. Roosevelt signed a bill restoring $46,000,000 annually in pensions to veterans of the Spanish-American War, the Philippine Insurrection and the Boxer Rebellion.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Earl Whitehill, veteran southpaw, pitched the Senators to a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers in ten innings today as the league leaders dropped a game of their margin to the Yankees.

TO the select company of old maestros among the detectives of fiction add the refulgent name of Rex Stout's Nero Wolfe. He is fat and placid, he distrusts firearms, he spends four hours a day raising orchids and has bribed me to review a book about him by sending me one, he eschews industrial espionage, and his consumption of properly chilled beer is prodigious.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The Red Sox climbed into third place in the American League by dropping the White Sox into fourth with a fourteen-hit attack against John Whitehead and Jack Salveson that produced a 9-to-5 victory.
HARRISBURG, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Governor Earle decided tonight that about fifteen Philadelphia magistrates would be prosecuted on charges of misconduct in office.

The report of B.F. Goodrich Company and its subsidiaries for the first six months of 1935, issued yesterday, shows net profits of $1,553,040 after all charges and reserves. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 45 cents a share on the 1,156,101 common shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Aside from its action today relative to H.C. Hopson's appearance before the House lobby committee, the Senate lobby committee heard John F. MacLane of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, a New York law firm, describe the organization of the drive against the Wheeler-Rayburn bill by utilities companies which later formed the committee of public utility executives headed by Philip H. Gadsden.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- A plea of "not guilty" was entered by Mandeville W. Zenge, 26-year-old farmer of Canton, Mo., in Criminal Court today to the indictment charging him with the mutilation murder of Professor Walter J. Bauer, who married Zenge's fiancee.

Five armed men, their leader masked, entered the branch office of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company at 1,408 Bedford Avenue, near St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly after 10 o'clock yesterday morning and escaped with $2,089.

TURIN, Italy, Aug. 13 (Reuters). -- About 1,000 persons are believed to have been drowned by floods which burst over the town of Ovada, Piedmont Province, today as the result of the collapse of the 100-foot-high dam at the end of Lake Orticella, used in connection with an electrical power scheme.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 13. -- Invitations have been issued for the Old White Fancy Dress Ball in the Cameo Room at the Greenbrier on Aug. 23. The event will be a feature of Old White Week, commencing Sunday, to celebrate the establishment of this resort as a spa. The committee has offered prizes for the most elaborate, most striking Continental, most outstanding Oriental, most ludicrous and most beautiful period costumes.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Angriff, the Nazi party's official afternoon organ in Berlin, carries today bitter front-page editorial criticism of the United States as the home of lynching and strike riots. The Nazi editors' ire was aroused by a report of the resolution by the Massachusetts House of Representatives condemning Nazi religious persecution.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The Public Service Corporation and its subsidiaries and the Prudential Insurance Company of America were among several large property owners that filed appeals with the Essex County Tax Board today, seeking reductions in assessments imposed by the City Tax Board.

Darryl F. Zanuck's Twentieth Century screen transcription of Jack London's "Call of the Wild" will have its premiere this morning at the Rivoli. The film was directed by William Wellman from a screen play by Gene Fowler and Leonard Praskins, and has as its principal players Clark Gable, Loretta Young and Jack Oakie.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 13. -- The one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Piping Rock Club today saw the largest turnout of the year as 107 players teed off. Playing around the smart course under ideal conditions until the wind rose in the afternoon, there were only thirty-nine who failed to return cards and the scoring was uniformly good.

Miss Virginia Seigh, 23 years old, of 1,323 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn, private secretary to Arthur Reisman, owner of a chain of beauty shops, was shot and killed shortly after 2 o'clock this morning on the lawn of the Reisman home at 14-37 Utopia Parkway, in the residential Whitestone district of Queens.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schcy will give a dinner on Friday evening and take their guests to the ballet led by Edwin Strawbridge and Lisa Parnova at the John Drew Memorial Theatre.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Mrs. Joseph F. Stillman gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at Mayfair Cottage, her home in Pond Lane. The party included her daughter, Mrs. C. Gordon Hutchinson, wife of Captain Hutchinson of Fort Meade, S.D.; who is spending the season with her; Mr. and Mrs. Louis du Pont Irving, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pendleton Rogers, Dr. Alfred Stillman 2d, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Wright and Miss Eleanor Mellon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Relief workers who would "like to be in pictures" may get their wish.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- President Roosevelt signed a bill restoring pensions to Spanish War veterans, and allotted more than $103,000,000 in work relief funds to various States.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Occupying the wickets from noon until 5:30 P.M., with one hour out for lunch, the cricketers of the Bermuda Athletic Association, due to sail for home tomorrow, ran up the record score of their North American tour in the ninth and final match against an eleven of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today.

Thirty passengers in a Queens bus were terrorized yesterday during a wild ride of six blocks as an obviously intoxicated man held the jagged end of a broken beer bottle at the head of the driver and commanded him to drive off his route.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 13. -- Jimmy Rousmaniere and his crew from the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, Marshall Hornblower and George Lindsay Jr. took two steps forward toward winning the championship of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- The Daily Mail announces that Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, the Air Minister, in behalf of the Air Council, has accepted from Viscount Rothermere, chief proprietor of The Daily Mail, a new type of airplane asserted to be the best and fastest in its class in the world. It has been named Britain I.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 13. -- At Ormeland, Williamstown, this afternoon Mrs. William Warren Tracy entertained the Richmond Garden Club at a garden party. Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, president of the club, presided at the tea table, and her guest, Mrs. Louis E. Laflin of Lake Forest, Ill., read a paper on interesting gardens she has visited.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman announced yesterday afternoon in her apartment at 1,088 Park Avenue that she had obtained permission from Borough President Samuel Levy to erect a booth in Times Square and conduct a poll on legalizing lotteries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -The State Department received a Midwest protest today against trade treaties providing wheat reduction in this country without a return reduction by the foreign party to the treaty.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 13. -- One of the entrants in the open championship, playing with its regular line-up, rode through six periods of practice polo today. Several members of other teams also were in action.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- A rush to file nominating petitions, characterized by veteran politicians as the greatest pre-primary marathon in the city's history, ended late this afternoon when thirty candidates had recorded their intention of running for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Exports increased in June to all grand divisions except Asia and Northern North America, as compared with the same month last year, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports increased from all grand divisions except Asia.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 13. -- The six members of the American track and field team left Finland this afternoon, taking an airplane for Oslo. During their three weeks' sojourn here the Americans appeared in ten meets against the best of Finnish and Japanese athletes.

LEADVILLE, Colo., Aug. 13. -- Hunters of buried treasure and souvenir seekers have almost demolished the rude cabin of Elizabeth "Baby Doe" Tabor on Fryer Hill. Windows have been broken, the door hangs only on one hinge and the floors and ceiling have been torn away, apparently by tourists who believed the widow of H.A.W. Tabor, one-time Colorado silver king, might have hidden a portion of the Tabor millions there.

Every one seems to be taking up repertory these days, the latest in point of time being Helen Hayes. Unless something happens between now and then, the Fall will find her giving "Caesar and Cleopatra," "Mary of Scotland" and an unidentified new play.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Amid tall green pines and clean khaki uniforms, Governor Lehman paid his first visit to the camps of the Boy Scouts of Greater New York at Ten Mile River, Sullivan County, today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Higher taxes on personal holding companies to guard against evasions of increased surtaxes on individual incomes were disclosed today to have been written into the new Tax Bill by the Senate Finance Committee.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Over a track that should be fast, the Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-olds will be trotted tomorrow on the mile circuit of Good Time Park. Nine of the world's fastest steppers will take the word from Starter Steve Phillips for the first heat at about 3 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The House today approved the conference report covering only part of the Agricultural Adjustment Act amendments, but embracing the controversial provision permitting processors, wholesalers and retailers to file claims for processing tax rebates, under limited conditions, if this feature of the original act should be held invalid by the Supreme Court. The vote was 174 to 40.

A decision on the pay of waitresses and minor employes in restaurants will not be made for another ten days, it was announced last night by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews after the final public hearing on the establishment of a minimum wage, held at 80 Centre Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -Cottonseed crushed in the cotton year which ended July 31 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 3,549,383 tons, compared with 4,156,911 the previous year. Cottonseed on hand at mills July 31 totaled 91,119 tons, compared with 222,761 a year ago.
Your editorial "Lagging Work Relief" prompts me to say a word relative to the lack of preparedness at Washington for this tremendous task.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a small family luncheon at Chetwode today. Their guests included Mr. Astor's mother, Mrs. Enzo Fiermonte, and Mr. Fiermonte; Mr. Astor's aunt, Mrs. Lorillard Spencer, and Mrs. Astor's mother, Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows.

Scarcity of bids for United States Government bonds of near-by maturity resulted in fairly substantial declines in that list on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Losses spread over virtually the entire group, including the guaranteed as well as the direct obligations, with prices at the end of the day showing declines ranging from 1-32 to 9-32 point.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Nomination of Lawrence W. Cramer to succeed Dr. Paul M. Pearson as Governor of the Virgin Islands was confirmed without roll-call by the Senate this evening after debate which was almost entirely eulogistic of his character, intelligence and ability.

Decision to make a study of the advisability of recommending the adoption of net terms to their respective organizations was reached yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives, held at the offices of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- A vivid picture of the severity of the regime which rules the Alcatraz Island Federal prison is given by William H. Ambrose, one-time Chicago gangster, who has just left the island to be deported. He declares that Alcatraz prison is "one tough joint."

RENO, Nev., Aug. 13. -- Suit for divorce was brought here today by Mrs. Priscilla Baldwin Morgah against Thomas Archer Morgan, on ground of cruelty. She asks restoration of her maiden name of Baldwin.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- With Governor Lehman sounding the keynote in New York State's determined war against organized crime, police officials and State lawmakers gathered her tonight at the opening of the annual State police conference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Both packers and consumers are feeling the effect of the shortage in the supply of hogs. Fresh pork loins advanced 1 cent a pound wholesale today to a level of 19 to 29 1/2 cents, the outside figure showing an advance of 23 cents a pound from the low point in 1933.

George W. Egbert, Acting Superintendent of Banks, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday against 720 persons and brokerage concerns holding 82,458 shares of stock in the Bank of United States. The complaint contends that in certain cases ownership of the shares was transferred to clerks, minors and others in an effort to escape liability for a stockholder's assessment of $25 a share levied by the Superintendent of Banks in July, 1932.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 13. -- Australia is cursed by a "soft-job complex," in the opinion of the Rev. William Thomson, who has resigned the directorship of the Victorian Presbyterian Boy Farm Training movement. The movement was begun in 1931 and at first applicants for employment proved satisfactory, but in the last eighteen months there has been difficulty in finding boys for farm work.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 13 (AP). -Canada's carry-over of wheat at the end of the crop year, July 31, was 203,231,288 bushels, it was announced today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Last year it was 193,990,281 bushels and the year before 211,740,188.

Whether there is to be peace or war between Italy and Ethiopia must be decided in a few days. The affair is rapidly approaching a crisis. If a solution is to be found at all it must be found quickly. On Friday the three-Power conference will begin its sessions.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Striking employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation tonight rejected the arbitration plan under which the Navy and Labor Departments sought settlement of the strike, now in its fourteenth week, at the company's Camden plant.
Former President Herbert Hoover, during his stay here, is sounding out opinion among influential Republicans on the 1936 political outlook and the role he may play, it was learned yesterday.

Dorothy Pawlowsky of 12 West Fifty-fifth Street, who said she had been employed as a maid by Countess Marie Ann von Wurmbrand-Stuppach, the former Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., objected in the Supreme Court yesterday to a motion by her former attorneys, Oberwager Oberwager, for permission to withdraw as her counsel in a breach of promise action against John George Brody, an attorney.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP). -- Archie B. Smith, son of the president of Pathe News, Inc., of New York, was killed today and his two youthful companions were injured critically when their automobile left the road, plowed 600 feet across a field and crashed into a house.

Martin and Osa Johnson sailed from Brooklyn last evening for an eighteen-month expedition into the jungle of British North Borneo to make sound and color films there. They left at 6:30 aboard the Rotterdam Lloyd freighter Kota Pinang from Pier 3, Forty-third Street and the Upper Bay, Brooklyn.

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 13. -- After a suitable period of devotion to the classics, the Mohawk Drama Festival at Union College has mounted a new play by Don Marquis, "Master of the Revels," which was acted this evening under the open sky and against the hum of August crickets.

BLANEY, S.C., Aug. 13. -- When the Federal Relief Administration took veterans off the streets of Washington to avert another "Hoover Bonus march," the net result so far as it concerns the productive labor of 265 of them concentrated in a camp near here has been the construction for themselves of an "old-fashioned swimming hole."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Mrs. Marie Van Der Wee, whose pet German shepherd dog King has been ordered destroyed by the courts after being adjudged a dangerous animal for nipping an attorney's trousers, appealed today to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to save her pet.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- With arrival today in Paris of the British delegation to the three-power conference on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, there seemed to be a growing conviction that whatever happened Ethiopia must expect to lose out. The best thing for all concerned, it appears to be accepted, is to circumscribe that loss as much as possible and above all to avoid a catastrophic European conflagration.

The American Steamship Owners Association, comprising most of the American ship lines operating in the foreign trades, has applied to Senator Copeland for an opportunity to express the views of the shipping industry on the shipping-aid bill which is now in the hands of the Senate Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- An agreement to pay Norman H. Davis $150,000 for heading an international protective committee on Kreuger Toll securities was disclosed today in testimony made public by the Securities Commission.

The principle of graduated rates of tax on corporate income is a "highly objectionable departure from sound standards of Federal income tax legislation heretofore followed by this country," Clarence Francis, executive vice president of the General Foods Corporation, said in a letter sent yesterday to its stockholders.
It must be this news from Moscow about common fronts that has inspired HUEY LONG. He lets it be known that he will go in with virtually anybody to make a common front against FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT.
The Securities and Exchange Commission was upheld yesterday in the United States District Court here in the first decision involving a test of the constitutionality of the Securities Act of 1934.

Lionel J. Noah, president of the American Woolen Company, and other officers and directors of the corporation were sued yesterday in the Supreme Court here by Albert Lautman, owner of 100 shares of preferred stock, in behalf of himself and other stockholders for an accounting of alleged excessive salaries and unjustified bonuses which the executive officers are asserted to have received.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Changed to suit the wishes of the administration, the bill to replace with a permanent structure the Federal Alcohol Administration, which died with the NRA, was passed in the Senate today without a roll-call.

Story, a monthly magazine devoted entirely to short fictional stories, plans immediate expansion and will move today into greatly increased quarters of its own at 432 Fourth Avenue. Founded in Vienna five years ago by Whit Burnett and Martha Foley, who will continue as editors with sole editorial charge and the same policy, the magazine has been published for two and one-half years at Modern Library and Random House offices, 20 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A construction permit for the highest-powered short-wave telegraph transmitter in the Western Hemisphere, and possibly in the world, has been granted to RCA Communications, it was learned yesterday from RCA engineers here. Designed for about 200 kilowatts output power, the apparatus is now under installation at Rocky Point, L.I., and will be ready for operation by Nov. 16.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Senator Long has told Senatorial colleagues that he intends to run for President in 1936 and defeat President Roosevelt if he has to wreck the Democratic party to do it. He has privately said that his plan is roughly as follows:

It is fifty-five years since WILLIAM WATSON "commenced poet" in "The Prince's Quest." He was but an imitator of good models. He found himself in "Wordsworth's Grave," unless it be thought that even there he recalls the elegiac, contemplative MATTHEW ARNOLD.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 13. -- The "king of the Rumanian bandits," Mihai Coroiu, succeeded in escaping yesterday from a jail at Botosani. Together with his guard he drove off in a motor car, presumably to rejoin members of his band.

BOSTON, Aug. 13. -- Governor James M. Curley sent a strongly worded letter today to the German Consul General here, Baron Kurt von Tippelskirch, in reply to a protest the Consul General had made against a resolution adopted yesterday by the Massachusetts House of Representatives denouncing religious persecution in Germany.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 13. -- Apparently the romance of Juan Ignacio Pombo and Miss Maria Elena Rivero of Mexico has crashed since Pombo started his flight from Spain in May with the reported purpose of proposing marriage.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- Referring in optimistic terms to the world business revival, Jean Tannery, Governor of the Bank of France, probably the most conservative of all banking institutions in a statement today told the French people the time was now propitious to bring out their hoarded funds.

Suit to restrain stockholders of the Fox Film Corporation from voting tomorrow on a plan of reorganization of that company and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Best Co. reported yesterday for the six months ended on July 31 a net profit of $426,830 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after semi-annual dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, to $1.40 a share on 300,000 no-par common shares.

Millions of dollars are spent each year by the city for physical training, health education and gymnasiums. Hundreds of teachers devote their entire time to this branch. Yet very few of our young men and women know how to walk properly.

J.F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, advised security holders yesterday that the company had filed with Senator Black, chairman of the special investigating committee, a sworn statement putting the expenditures in connection with the Wheeler-Rayburn bill at $49,865.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- A suggestion that American sportsmen should give "serious consideration" to the question of withdrawing from participation in the Berlin Olympic Games next year was made to the Senate today by Senator Peter G. Gerry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The "microbe hunters" of the Public Health Service have received 45 acres on which to grow their own white mice, rabbits and guinea pigs and search for life-saving serums.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 13. -The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, rejected today all bids made on its $50,000,000 issue of tax-anticipation notes. The action followed failure of any large investment banking house to submit a bid. Total bids of $14,780,000 were made by fourteen banks and investment firms.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- That a battle-royal for the New York State women's championship is in prospect was manifest today when a triple tie in the qualifying round resulted on the Hotel Champlain Golf Club course, one of the pioneer links of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13, -- The vicinity of The Washington Post Building, in the downtown section, was rocked by an explosion today when a short circuit blew up a transformer housed below the level of the sidewalk in front of the building.
TORONTO, Aug. 13 Canadian Press). -- Toronto was completely routed tonight as Newark bettered its chances in the International League race by a 10-to-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The most revealing statement which can be made about the lending Tax Bill is that, with few exceptions, members of Congress wish the President had not brought it up at this session. Democrats cannot present it as a real budget balancer, and its pretensions as the symbol of a new economic philosophy have been clouded by tinkering in the Senate and the House.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 (AP). -Gray-haired, paralyzed John MacDonald, key witness at the trial of Thomas J. Mooney for the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing, asserted under oath today that he never saw Mooney before viewing him in a San Francisco jail cell after the bombing.
After stiffening their nerves with drinks, two gunmen held up the Claremont Inn at Riverside Drive and 124th Street shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and escaped with a $3,000 payroll.

The Department of Health reported yesterday a decrease in births last week as compared with the same week in 1934. For the seven days ended Aug. 10 there were recorded 1,898 births, a rate of 13 per 1,000 population, while a year ago births totaled 2,041, for a rate of 14.2.

MIDWAY ISLAND (by Pan American Airways), Aug. 13 (AP). -Completing the second stage of its 4,922-mile flight from Alameda, Calif., to Wake Island, the Pan American Airways' Clipper seaplane arrived here today 8 hours and 52 minutes after leaving Honolulu.

DUBLIN, Aug. 13. -- The first production here of Sean O'Casey's "The Silver Tassie" packed the Abbey Theatre to capacity last night. There were fears that the production might evoke riotous scenes reminiscent of the days when Synge's "Playboy of the Western World" was played, but the gallery was made up mainly of intellectuals and university students and applauded even the most lurid passages of O'Casey's tragicomedy of the European war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The Navy Department and the Public Works Administration, it was disclosed today, have sided with the War Department and the Port of New York Authority in seeking to block the proposed construction of a bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The government has been "making money" in a big way out of its power to issue currency and "regulate the value thereof."

THE Hambletonian means nothing in the life of the city dweller, the troglodyte of the teeming turrets. But to the farmer in the dell -- and the farmers on a thousand hills -- the Hambletonian is the great sports event of the year. The harness horse and all its ways are truly rural.

FAIRVIEW, Mich., Aug. 13 (AP). -Former Senator James A. Reed, Missouri Democrat, predicted today that if the Republican party adopted a good platform and nominated a good candidate it could defeat President Roosevelt in 1936.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President and a hard-riding polo player at Harvard, was arrested at about 3:30 P.M. today on a charge of speeding 54 miles an hour after a motorcycle patrolman had followed him for half a mile while he was driving alone from the Roosevelt estate at Hyde Park, N.Y., to New York City.

HAMPTON BEACH, N.H., Aug. 14. -- A campaign in support of Colonel Frank Knox, Manchester, N.H., and Chicago publisher, for the Republican Presidential nomination next year was begun here today. At an outing of the Rockingham County Republican Club Governor H. Styles Bridges and George H. Moses, former Senator, in public speeches proposed that this State's delegation to the national convention support Colonel Knox.

ALESSANDRIA, Italy, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Fascist troops and regular army soldiers sloshed through forty-three square miles of tragic mud tonight, fighting a peacetime battle to relieve hundreds of inhabitants marooned by the Lake Orsiglieto flood.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Greyhound, 2:02 1/4, gray gelding owned by E.J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., and driven by Sep Palin, today proved himself one of the greatest light harness horses of all time, when he won the tenth Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-old trotters in two straight heats.
Two newcomers to national P.G.A. championship competition will be among the nine representatives from the metropolitan sector when the local contingent leaves for Oklahoma City in October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The new Air Mail Act, setting forth revised regulations for the handling of mails by private carriers on postoffice contracts and placing supervision over contractors in the hands of the Interstate Commerce Commission, was signed by President Roosevelt late today.

Professor MOLEY continues in his recently adopted role of candid friend instead of undiscriminating eulogist of the Roosevelt Administration. In this week's issue of Today he announces a political discovery all his own. It is that the surprising Democratic upset in Rhode Island was caused by "the unfortunate speeches of at least two Cabinet members" on the tariff.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14. -- The Garden Club of East Hampton held a roadside and conservation meeting at Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse's Play House this afternoon. Mrs. Ellery James presided. The members visited the new nature trail. Mrs. E. Lawrence Jones spoke on the conservation of wild flowers and Edward Gorman of the local high school faculty spoke on nature work of school children.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- In its heaviest transactions since the silver program began, the Treasury bought today more than 25,500,000 ounces of silver.

TOKYO, Aug. 14. -- By shocking the military conscience, the assassination on Monday of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, Director of Military Affairs in the War Office, has strengthened the hands of War Minister Senjuro Hayashi in his efforts to stamp out sectional agitations in the army.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Senate passed without debate today the Connally Oil Regulation Bill.

Your editorial "If A Escapes, Hit B," supplements effectively your longer analysis of Mr. Jackson's very clever statement on the pending Internal Revenue Bill. The statement itself was very much of a non sequitur.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The most important stake victory of the season for Willis Sharpe Kilmer was scored today when his homebred filly, Alberta, captured the fifty-sixth running of the Alabama Stakes, oldest event for 3-year-old fillies in this country.

Under the caption "Liquor in Bulk" Henry Leeds seems to question and criticize the unprejudiced authoritative testimony of Joseph H. Choate Jr., Edward P. Mulrooney and Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, given before the Senate committee in opposition to bulk sales.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Denying the petition of John W. Schlegel, a Trenton butcher, for an injunction to restrain the State from enforcing the Retail Sales Tax Law, Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan reserved today until a final hearing consideration of the act's constitutionality.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 14. -- The rescue of a man and his son from a burning boat off the New Jersey coast twenty-five years ago brought a $10,000 reward today to the Rev. Francis X. Langan, 59-year-old pastor of St. James' Roman Catholic Church in Woodbridge.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14. -- From 1918 to 1934, the State Planning Board reported today, New Jersey gained 1,900 manufacturing plants, with an increase of about 6,000 in employes.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- When his mates in the Mississippi Valley League were handing out nick-names they picked a good one for Odell Hale, otherwise known as "Bad News," who plays third base for Steve O'Neill's Indians. He was all of that and more to the Yankees' fading pennant hopes at League Park today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 14. -- With the firing of a gun at 6 P.M., when the flagship Jameroy dropped anchor down in the mouth of the Thames River here, the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise was inaugurated officially. There was a meeting of the yacht owners with Commodore Junius S. Morgan on the flagship, which is under charter, and instructions were given.

GENEVA, Aug. 14. -- The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations has asked Britain and France as mandataries for Palestine and Syria, respectively, to explain at its next session "the reasons why imports of products from a State that has ceased to be a member of the League of Nations are admitted on an equal footing with the products of States that are members of the League."
Former President Herbert Hoover delayed his departure from New York yesterday as he conferred with more Republican leaders. The former President now plans to start for California this afternoon.

The Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the New York and Queens Gas Company will file today with the Public Service Commission their new schedules of gas rates, bringing their charges in line with the prevailing rate of $1.15 a thousand cubic feel and making that rate uniform throughout the city.
LYON, France, Aug. 14. -- America's touring track and field athletes conceded big handicaps to French and Italian rivals today and still emerged victors in eleven of the twelve events.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- Frank Shields came back with another stirring exhibition of hitting power today to meet successfully the exacting requirements of repulsing one of the most indomitable fighters on the tennis courts in the Newport invitation tournament.

Nathan Straus Jr. suggests that the Central Park lakes, following the lead of Hyde Park in London, ought to be used for bathing and swimming. But has Mr. Straus ever gone swimming in a Central Park lake?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A fight between the Senate and the House for the possession of Howard C. Hopson as a witness in their respective investigations of lobbying against the Utility Holding Company Bill was on tonight after the Senate had cited the "master mind" of the Associated Gas and Electric System to appear before it tomorrow and show cause why he should not be adjudged in contempt.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Two policemen persuaded William Moritz, 35 years old, to lay down his gun last night after he had held them at bay for two hours when they tried to stop Moritz's attempt to commit suicide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- However time and the event may disprove the soundness of these attitudes, it can be written down as a fact that Herbert Hoover's militant activity is worrying the Republicans, and Huey P. Long's publicly "confidential" plans for 1936 are not worrying the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A compulsory production control system for potatoes, along the lines of that in effect for cotton and tobacco, was approved today by the House and sent to the Senate for concurrence in a minor technical amendment.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 14. -- Large pay-offs in the first race and the daily double stole the spotlight from the Aquidneck Claiming Stakes, six-furlong feature for 3-year-olds and upward, which was won by Mrs. A.M. Creech's Cant Remember at Narragansett Park today.

WEATHER clear, track fast. At high noon of a sizzling day citizens were pouring down over the cliffs into the back entrance of the Polo Grounds or scurrying along under the shade of the Eighth Avenue elevated to the main entrance. Cars seemed to be parked as far north as Yonkers. A sweltering day, a boiling crowd and a feverish feud. Giants vs. Cardinals, two games.

ROME, Aug. 14. -- An editorial on the Italo-Ethiopian controversy printed in The Times of London this morning was made the occasion for another heated attack by Italian newspapers against what is here termed the bullying attitude of the British press and "those who inspired it."

Aroused by an assault and robbery of an elderly man, the latest in a series of crimes committed in the public parks, the city marshaled its forces yesterday for a campaign to make all park areas safe by night as well as day.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of another relatively small stock issue when they sanctioned the admission of 287,000 shares of $10-par common stock of the Sutherland Paper Company.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's big bat and three faltering St. Louis pitchers told the story of the Athletics' 8-to-2 victory over the Browns today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- World-wide gains in the international movement of arms, munitions and the raw materials of war were disclosed today in a survey of the statistics of the United States and other nations.

It threatened to rain at Ebbets Field yesterday, and Charles Johann Grimm, vice president and manager of the invading Cubs, wishes the threat had been carried out. For Casey Stengel's Dodgers slapped the Bruins about rudely and beat them twice, 9 to 5 and 3 to 2, while 7,000 noisily voiced complete approval.

"Alice Adams," adapted by RKO-Radio from the novel by Booth Tarkington and starring Katharine Hepburn, will be presented today at the Radio City Music Hall. Others in the cast are Fred Stone, the veteran stage actor; Fred MacMurray, Evelyn Venable and Frank Albertson.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14. -- The government refused to be interpellated at this afternoon's session of the Chamber of Deputies on the decree putting news agencies and newspaper correspondents under heavy cash bond and establishing a strict censorship of outgoing news.

Programs from a central studio in Cleveland are being sent on a commercial basis over electric light wires to a "few subscribers" in the Lakewood section of the city, it was learned yesterday from a representative of the North American Company of 60 Broadway, New York, which, under its subsidiary, Wired Radio, Inc., has been experimenting with this type of entertainment dissemination for several years.

With some members pressing for additional appropriations and others deploring the increases, the Board of Education at a meeting last night adopted a budget for 1936 totaling $141,434,071.57, an increase of $8,023,617.60 over 1935.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 14. -- Devoting most of the time to futile waiting for wind, Jimmy Rousmaniere and his crew from the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club protected a slim lead in the championship series of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today.

French dressmakers are not backing up the French Government in its efforts to ward off trouble in Ethiopia. On the one hand, M. LAVAL is valiantly striving to find a peace formula. On the other hand, Rue de la Paix and its environs stress the military theme.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Edward D. Searle of the Dunwoodie Golf Club, Yonkers, today captured the annual hole-in-one tourney sponsored by The World-Telegram at the Salisbury Club. It was his second successive victory in the event.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton met this morning at Minden, the country place of Mrs. John E. Berwind in Bridgehampton. Mrs. Henry E. Coe, the president, presided. A members' competition in design and flower arrangements was judged by popular vote based on qualities of proportion, balance, color and originality, as discussed in a recent lecture by John Taylor Arms.
TORONTO, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Newark took a double header from Toronto, 3-0, and 12-1, tonight to move into a tie with the Maple Leafs for fifth place.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 14. -- An anniversary dinner was given tonight at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, at which Dr. and Mrs. William P. Healey of New York observed Mrs. Healey's birthday and Mr. and Mrs. Elmer L. Rice of Sanford, Me., their wedding anniversary, which they have celebrated together here during the last three years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The text of the Senate Finance Committee report on the revised Tax Bill is as follows:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 14. -- Australia will send a trade and good-will mission to the United States. It was hoped the United States would send a mission to Australia, but Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons, who has returned after a visit to Washington, is convinced the first move must come from the Commonwealth.

VIENNA, Aug. 14. -- The clerical Weltblatt, whose information from Berlin is believed to be mostly from reliable diplomatic sources, reported tonight that Berlin expected the proclamation of an army dictatorship within the next few weeks.
The Giants plucked a lot of feathers out of an enraged Cardinal yesterday but it did not enable them to subdue the troublesome Red Bird of St. Louis as completely as they had hoped.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie has dispatched 60,000 troops to positions behind Ethiopia's eastern borders, in preparation for a quick southward drive on Italian Somaliland if Italy should invade his kingdom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- When the Social Security Board is named by President Roosevelt in a few days it will face the enormous task of administering an act designed to protect the American wage-earner "against the major hazards and vicissitudes of life."

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The New York State Police Conference, in convention here today, discussed the Miller-Strong bill to create a bureau in the Attorney General's office which would supervise all police forces in the State. The bill was defeated by the last Legislature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana will report tomorrow to the New York Stock Exchange consolidated net profits of $13,191,166 in the first six months of 1935, equal to 87 cents a share on the 15,215,677 shares outstanding on June 30.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 14 (AP). -- W.J. Walters, president of the Johnson Johnson International Company, made a successful plea for clemency in City Court today in behalf of his 23-year-old son, Walter, who has twice run into difficulty with the law in Connecticut since he left his New Brunswick home to try life "on his own."

The directors of the Consolidated Oil Corporation voted yesterday to defer the issuance of the bonds recently authorized by the stockholders. H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, who made the announcement, stated that this action had been taken because of the improvement in earnings and the better cash position of the corporation.

Commodity futures generally were higher in fairly active trading yesterday. Silk futures were a feature and reached the highest level since mid-October, 1933, in the most active trading since Dec. 28, last. In the cash market raw sugar, corn, lard, rubber and cotton were higher, while tin, wheat and oats were lower.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The markets on the London Stock Exchange are generally firm and active today, although there was some profit-taking among the industrials. British funds were again easier under the influence of the Ethiopian news and selling of options. Dealings in the new Trinidad 3 per cent loan started today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Reaching the highest level since the third week of February and advancing for the sixth consecutive week, steel ingot production is now at 49 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age reported yesterday in its weekly summary. The gain for the week was 2 points.

Requests for comparatively small budgetary increases for 1936 marked the schedules submitted yesterday by the Armory Board, the National Guard and Naval Militia, the Board of Assessors and the Board of Child Welfare at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

BEAVER, Okla., Aug. 14 (AP). -- The burden of a cattle rustling conviction placed on Jim Herron forty-two years ago has grown too heavy for the hardy old plainsman of a livelier day in "no man's land." He escaped from the Sheriff then, but now, 70 years old and blind, he has returned here to settle the account

Three men who were being deported yesterday aided in the rescue of a sailor in the Hudson River. The three, all warrant cases based on illegal entry, were being transported from the detention rooms on Ellis Island to Pier 60, North River, from which the United States liner Manhattan was to sail at noon.

The pace of wholesale buying activity in women's apparel and accessory lines has been well maintained thus far this week, with considerable attention given by retailers to the question of deliveries. However, comment was heard in the wholesale markets that the current increase in retail trade has somewhat outstripped the gain in wholesale orders placed to date for the early Fall.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14. -- "In war operations parachutists who know foreign languages will be more useful to soldiers that those who do not." This is revealed in today's Komsomolskaya Pravda, newspaper of Moscow's Young Communist organization.

OTTAWA, Aug. 14. -- After effecting a partial reconstruction of his Cabinet, involving the swearing in of four Ministers, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett today obtained dissolution of Parliament. He announced that a general election would be held Oct. 14.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel of Queens Valley and Miss Ann Weeks of Rockaway Hunt accounted for honors in the one-day medal tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association today. The same pair triumphed in last week's association event.

The Union Health Centre, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has leased the twenty-fifth floor, 15,000 square feet, in 275 Seventh Avenue. The structure, the twenty-six-story Lef-court Clothing Centre, is on the block front between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets.

Creation of a new standing committee on foreign business and selection of members of the recently established committee on management and personnel was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange following a meeting of its board of governors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Bullish and bearish influences were about evenly balanced today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, prices fluctuating erratically within a moderate range. An early bulge was followed by a dip to a new low level on the current downturn, with a rally later, the rise in cotton having some effect.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Kenneth A. Morrison, 47 years old, Assistant Controller of the Chicago Park District, was found mysteriously slain in the rear seat of his automobile at daybreak today on the near northwest side.
Mayor La Guardia and General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for this city, pledged full cooperation yesterday in putting the Federal works program into operation in New York City.

Franklin D. Mooney was elected chairman of the board of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indian Steamship Lines and subsidiaries at a meeting of the directors yesterday afternoon. He succeeds H.H. Raymond, who retired in June because of ill health.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A five-run attack against Ray Phelps in the seventh gave the Red Sox a second straight victory over the White Sox, 7 to 1, today and extended the Chicagoans' dismal August showing to one victory, a tie and twelve defeats.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, was introduced to society at a dinner given by her mother at the Muenchinger-King tonight.

Thomas Ryan, 65 years old, of 994 Columbus Avenue, who first got into trouble with the police in 1897 and has since run up a record of forty-five arrests and thirty-seven convictions, was nosed out yesterday in his race in the wrong direction by one William Fine.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The State of California today began its efforts to refute an elderly man's sworn testimony that he perjured himself in 1917 in identifying Thomas J. Mooney, San Quentin life term prisoner, as the man who timed the Preparedness Day parade bomb which killed ten people in San Francisco.

BURNT MILLS, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Hurlingham four of London, British poloists who came to America for the national open next month, won their second American exhibition game today, defeating Burnt Mills, 8 to 4.

The work of tabulating the petitions of the several hundred candidates for nomination to public office was completed yesterday morning by the staff of the Board of Elections. The time for filing designating petitions expired at midnight Tuesday.

The first definite step toward the creation of an active nation-wide organization to combat what is termed "Italy's deliberate violation of the code of international ethics" and to aid Ethiopia in preserving her political and territorial sovereignty by peaceful means was taken yesterday at a meeting of the Provisional Committee on the Ethiopian Crisis.

The draw made yesterday for the Wightman Cup tennis matches, which will get under way tomorrow at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, revealed that Miss Helen Jacobs, the national champion from Berkeley, Calif., again has been named the No. 1 player of the American team which will oppose the British women.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- Official Germany appears to be determined to return to the Gothic letter form that makes so many editions of the German classics practically unintelligible to foreigners who know German but are unfamiliar with this type.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14 (AP). -- George H. Bender, defeated Republican candidate for Ohio Representative at Large last year, asserted today the visit of Governor Davey to the White House was an effort "to shake down the administration" for $15,000,000 in public works funds.

LENINGRAD, Aug. 14. -- Dr. C.H. Best of Toronto, co-discoverer of the insulin treatment for diabetes, told the International Physiological Congress today of experiments that resulted in his recent discovery of the equivalent of a new vitamin of great importance in the treatment of diabetes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- In a sudden change in policy brought on by drought and high domestic wheat prices, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration pushed up today the acreage of wheat allowed to be planted under the 1936 program to 95 per cent of the base acreage, instead of the 85 per cent established two weeks ago.

Mass picketing by members of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union yesterday resulted in fifty-nine arrests on charges of disorderly conduct or unlawful assembly in the Broadway district. The police continued, without success, to seek the men who threw bombs at two theatres early Tuesday.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and ten other oil companies for judgment declaring invalid the section of the New York City sales tax prescribing the method by which the sales tax on gasoline is to be computed and directing that the tax be fixed on payments made by customers with the State and Federal levies included.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Former President Hoover is expected to hold a number of important conferences with Republican leaders from the Central West in Chicago on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- President Roosevelt signed the Social Secu-rity and Air Mail Bills and conferred with Governor Davey of Ohio on relief matters.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- An "immediate, fair, impartial and fearless" investigation of Philadelphia's twenty-eight magistrates was ordered today by President Judge Harry S. McDevitt of Common Pleas Court 1 in a special charge to the August grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Hope that there will be no recurrence of unpleasant incidents to lead to misunderstandings between the United States and Japan was expressed by Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, in a call today on William Phillips, Under Secretary of State.

The plans of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel have always provided for two single-way tubes. When the first of these was recently "holed through" the Port of New York Authority announced that it would be used for two-way vehicles, because work on the second must be deferred.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Frank Sobrero, Santa Clara halfback, and Bill Shepherd of Western Maryland, the nation's leading scorer last year, were injured today as the college all-stars of 1934 went through a scrimmage for their football game on Aug. 29 against the Chicago Bears of the National Football League.

The possibility that the Securities and Exchange Commission may recommend to Congress in January complete segregation of the functions of broker and dealer continues to cause much anxious conjecture in Wall Street. Perhaps 90 per cent of all brokerage firms, including members of the Stock and the Curb Exchanges, eke out their living by operations as dealers, and in many cases the very existence of a firm depends upon this business.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- An informal mixed doubles tennis tournament was started at the Casino this afternoon. Mrs. Barger Wallach, former national champion and a member of the tennis committee of the Casino, organized the matches, with some of the players in the invitation tournament taking part.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 14. -- Senators and Representatives from Fairfield County, meeting here today, approved a proposed expenditure of $20,000,000 for construction of the Merritt Parkway from the New York State line near Glenville across Fairfield County to the New Haven County line at Devon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Adjustments will be made automatically and promptly under the bill signed yesterday by President Roosevelt restoring $46,000,000 annually in payments to veterans of the Spanish-American War, the Philippine Insurrection and the Boxer Rebellion, General Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, stated today.
With the arrival of bluefish in the waters around Fishers Island and Plum Island, there has been a marked increase in activity among boatmen and anglers along the Connecticut shore.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 14. -- Hans von Tschammer und Osten, German Sport Leader, lectured privately yesterday to Hungarian political and sporting notables in the German legation on Germany's preparation for the Olympics.

Myrna Loy, film star of "The Thin Man" and other pictures, climaxed her salary disagreement with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday by announcing that she had terminated her contract with the company. Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, replied with a statement from his New York office in which he declared the studio will make a legal effort to force Miss Loy to abide by the terms of her contract.

After prices on the Cotton Exchange had declined into new low ground yesterday, a violent advance of $2 a bale resulted from a confident assertion by Senator Bankhead that a 12-cent loan would be announced as soon as the amendments to the agricultural bill had been passed.

James E. Stephens, 44 years old, a Negro of 103 West 137th Street, who for the last five years has been Tammany Assemblyman for the "Little Africa" section of Harlem, and his brother, Alexander W. Stephens, 38, an insurance broker of 201 West 135th Street, were arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on two grand larceny indictments charging job fixing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio declined today to call a special election to choose a successor to the late Charles V. Truax as Representative at Large despite court action aimed at forcing such an election. The Governor said that he would resist moves for a vote now, since a special election would cost the State about $500,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- A series of trials against Jews charged with money smuggling and violation of the foreign exchange laws similar to recent action against Catholic monks and nuns was foreshadowed in the prosecution of an "Aryan" employe of a fugitive Jewish importer of eggs and venison.

A thunderstorm that broke over the city at 8 o'clock last night pelted the baked pavements and rooftops with huge raindrops and caused a six-degree drop in temperature. The mercury fell to 74 degrees from 80 at 7 o'clock.
Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, is returning today from Europe on the French liner Champlain, with his family. Others aboard include:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The possibility that the United States may establish one or more naval bases in the Aleutian Islands after existing treaties expire was seen today in the recent decision of President Roosevelt to include the Islands, which stretch westward 1,200 miles off the Alaskan Coast, in a list of strategic points over which civil airplanes must not fly.

It now appears that Jack Haley, instead of Eddie Cantor, will be the star of the new Porter-Crouse-Howard musical show which Vinton Freedley has been planning for this Fall. Mr. Cantor, at least, will not be in it. The delay in starting his new film, plus the producer's natural desire to get the show to Broadway before the season is far gone, sent Mr. Freedley looking for a substitute.
Mr. ROOSEVELT'S signing on Tuesday of the bill restoring Spanish-American War pensions makes timely a brief resume of the Government's position in this matter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A fight to restore charges of undue legislative activity to the complaint in which the Federal Trade Commission alleges unfair competition in the suppression of counter ice cream freezers was started today. The complaint is drawn against the International Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers and six of the country's largest dairy companies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Social Security Bill, providing a broad program of unemployment insurance and old-age pensions, and counted upon to benefit some 30,000,000 persons, became law today when it was signed by President Roosevelt in the presence of those chiefly responsible for putting it through Congress.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in its statement for the six months ended on June 30 reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $10,338,242 after all charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade's figures for July:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Pirates won both ends of a double-header from the Phillies today, taking the first, 8 to 1, and the second, 7 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Senator McCarran asserted today that the Works Progress Administration planned to issue soon an administrative order establishing the "prevailing wage principle" for the $4,000,000,000 Work Relief program.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Details of the property settlement made by Lawrence Tibbett when he divorced his first wife in 193l were made public today for the first time, over the stage and screen singer's protest.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but weakened near the close. Heavy industrial issues were friendly. Machine shares were inactive, Berlin-Karlsruhe losing a half point. Chemical securities became stabilized, with the Farbens rise coming to a halt.

Mr. GEORGE LANSBURY, leader of the Labor party, perhaps as a humorous revenge for the weakness in numbers of His Majesty's Opposition, has been harrowing the feelings of Conservatives, Liberals and Mr. LLOYD GEORGE'S little posse alike by giving notice of his party's resolve to set up its candidate at the next election in Speaker FITZROY'S constituency in Northamptonshire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- James D. Preston, for thirty-five years superintendent of the Senate press gallery and for three years librarian of the Senate, resigned the latter post today to become on Monday assistant to the administrative secretary of the newly established National Archives.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Although the British Foreign Office is not yet officially informed of Ethiopia's new protest to the League against the arms embargo, this action is considered by official quarters in London as fully justified.

A 17-year-old high school student who never had been in trouble before was revealed by the police yesterday as the tipster who helped armed bandits rob his 23-year-old sister of a $2,000 payroll in a B.M.T. subway train two months ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Soundings to ascertain national sentiment on a constitutional amendment to broaden the powers of the Federal Government have been undertaken by Democratic strategists.
Apartment house deals continued to mark the realty trading reported yesterday in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

The plan for reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation that was offered by a committee of holders of preferred stock that was dominated by the United Stores Corporation was disapproved yesterday by R.P. Stephenson, special master.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Mike Cestone, 31-year-old Montclair letter carrier, today won the first annual New Jersey State public links golf championship.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Viscountess Astor, the American-born Member of Parliament who has done some plain talking of late about birth control, said today that her increased mail from America led her to believe some people misunderstood her.

Seven Manhattan parcels and five in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Banks were plaintiffs in all of the Manhattan actions, all of which involved tenement structures. The plaintiffs and holdings in the Bronx were more varied.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 14. -- Official efforts in the last two days to pin down Emperor Haile Selassie to a definition of his attitude toward the negotiations by Britain, France and Italy have failed.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Braves, deeply entrenched in the National League cellar, celebrated their homecoming today by defeating the Reds, 8 to 1 and 11 to 5. Boston played errorless ball.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- I cannot tell you how happy I am. My Voice is free again, unbridled after years of struggle with the "potato."

Operations of the United Carbon Company and subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a net profit of $937,969 after taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This is equivalent to $2.36 a share on 397,885 no-par shares of common stock outstanding.

The formation of an organization known as the American Wild Life Institute to assist government and private conservation agencies in protecting wild life and restoring its natural habitat wherever possible was announced yesterday afternoon by Thomas H. Beck, president of the Crowell Publishing Company.
A drive against violators of the city 2 per cent sales tax which is expected to bring upward of $1,000,000 into the city treasury was revealed yesterday by the Finance Department.

A sharp increase in group insurance written in July made the total of new life insurance production for the month 30.2 per cent greater than in July last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -Government trade observers regard the sustained advance in shipments abroad of office equipment as an important indicator of improving economic conditions in most foreign countries despite international tensions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The report of the Finance Committee minority on the Senate Tax Bill, signed by Senators Hastings and Metcalf, reads as follows:

TILFORD, Surrey, England, Aug. 14. -- Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, former Laborite Chancellor of the Exchequer, broke a lifetime rule tonight and gave an interview in which he said Europe was on the brink of a new world war "too terrible to contemplate."

The share market maintained a fairly steady tone during most of yesterday's trading. Mild rallies occurred at times in the utility, petroleum, electrical and railway issues and in some of the stocks of the "beverage" group, but as a rule these were short-lived although they did enable several issues to reach, momentarily, new high marks for the year.

A letter to THE TIMES signed "G.C." says the home relief he has been existing on amounted to only $2.15 a week. But strange as it may seem, he rejects a government job at $93.50 a month. The ground of the rejection is that the private employers who now offer him nothing will use the $93.50 rate as a lever to reduce wages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Dr. Emery E. Olson, dean of the School of Government of the University of Southern California, will come to Washington on or about Sept. 1 to join the staff of American University. He has been named Professor of Public Administration and director of the "In Service" training division of the university's School of Public Affairs.

Haggard and semi-hysterical at her plight, Mrs. Etta Reisman, 35 years old, wife of the proprietor of a chain of beauty shops, admitted yesterday that she had shot and killed her husband's secretary, Virginia Seigh, 23, in a fit of jealousy shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday morning on the lawn of the Reisman home at 14-37 Utopia Parkway, Robinswood, Queens.

A seaman who, through the offices of Mrs. JANET ROPER of the Seamen's Institute of New York, had been found for his mother after they had been lost to each other for years said that he liked to think that he had two mothers and always bought the same anniversary present for each.

With the executors of the estate of John H. McCooey filing a check for $20,000 with the State Tax Department to cover inheritance levies, it was learned yesterday that the late Brooklyn Democratic leader left a net estate of about $650,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- Three of the highest officials in Germany of the Catholic Brothers of Mercy order and seven nuns of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd went on trial in Berlin today on charges of violating German foreign exchange regulations.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The pennant-chasing Tigers went on a batting rampage today, hammering three Washington pitchers for seventeen hits and taking the second game of the series, 18 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Congressional consent for creation of an Interstate Sanitation District land of an Interstate Sanitation Commission, to cope with the pollution of New York Harbor and adjacent waters, would be authorized by a joint resolution approved by the Senate today and paralleled by a measure pending on the House calendar.

Major General Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area with headquarters at Governors Island, and Commanding General of the First Army, now gathering for extensive field manoeuvres at Pine Camp, N.Y., may be selected as the next Chief of Staff of the Army to succeed General Douglas MacArthur, it was reported yesterday.

Judge Cornelius F. Collins of General Sessions handed down a decision yesterday sustaining the right of Victor House, as a special Assistant District Attorney, to present the evidence to the July, 1934, grand jury on which indictments, alleging financial irregularities, were handed up against twenty-seven former officers and directors of four defunct title mortgage companies.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, head of the State Education Department, today fixed Aug. 28 as the date to hear the appeal of Miss Rose Freistater, a rejected New York City school teacher, from a decision of the Board of Examiners which decreed that she could not receive a license because she was too fat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Seventeen educational Summer camps in eleven States for 1,280 needy unemployed women have been authorized, others are under consideration, and still others will be approved if requested by State relief officials, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today two amendments to its regulations issued under the Securities Act of 1933. One applies to railways and railway holding companies and the other to companies whose properties are leased to their owners.

The State of Maryland will offer for sale on Oct. 9 an issue of $1,500,000 of 3 per cent emergency bonds dated Oct. 15, 1935, and maturing from 1938 to 1950, according to advices received in bond circles yesterday. The issue will be the second instalment of an original authorization of $8,500,000, of which $5,500,000 was sold in April.
BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The "big four" remained intact after the first two rounds of the annual New York State women's invitation championship today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A conference between Navy and Labor Department officials and leaders of the Camden, N.J., shipyard strike ended late tonight with what Secretary of Labor Perkins termed "a clearer understanding on many disputed points."

MOSCOW, Aug. 14. -- Georgi Dimitroff, Bulgarian Red and an outstanding figure of the Communist International Congress here, laughed away the fears of some party leaders that the united front and the fight for democratic rights might wean away workers from the fight for proletarian dictatorship or that the united front might create "democratic illusions in the minds of the masses."

A new issue of $5,500,000 of 4 3/4 per cent debentures of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company of Hamilton, Ohio, known previously as the Champion Coated Paper Company, will be placed on the market today by W.E. Hutton Co., Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Replacement of Buildings dating hack to 1856, now housing a third of the Government Printing Office, with a modern plant consistent with the main building, completed in 1930, will begin at once under the second Deficiency Act approved Monday by President Roosevelt.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- The clearing of ground for the formal three-power conference to save Ethiopia from the disasters of a war with Italy and the League of Nations from a dilemma that is likely to wreck it as a vital institution, whichever horn it may choose, began here today when Premier Pierre Laval received the British delegates at the Quai d'Orsay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- An effort to block action on the Tax Bill at this session, begun with a sharp attack from the Republican side, was overwhelmingly defeated today by the Senate. By a vote of 55 to 19, a motion by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan to recommit the measure to the Finance Committee for further study was rejected.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Bobby Grant of Wethersfield captured the one-day thirty-six-hole William Rice Hochster Memorial golf tourney at the Quaker Ridge course today. Grant turned in a 72, 74 -- 146.

Archibald Palmer, an attorney who has appeared in many actions in Federal court as a self-avowed champion of oppressed groups, complained yesterday to Judge Murray Hulbert that Referee Peter B. Olney, sitting as a special master in reorganization proceedings, had called him "a rat."
Henry H. Klein lost his second attempt yesterday to block Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of organized crime as a needless waste of taxpayers' money. He said he would continue his fight.
GENEVA, Aug. 14. -- The League of Nations gave out today a moving appeal to the Council from Ethiopia against refusals to sell arms to her wherever she has sought them.

Striking Works Progress Administration workers will not receive relief from the city administration, Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday. It was the first official intimation of the course the city will pursue.

PEABODY, Mass., Aug. 14. -- Attacking nine automobiles carrying executives and office employes of the Danvers Bleachery, 500 striking textile workers from the Pequot Mills in Salem and the bleachery here smashed the windows and dented the bodies of the cars, which they tried to overturn after forcing the doors open.

Mayor La Guardia extended his anti-noise campaign to his own office at City Hall yesterday, installing a noise measuring device there, without the knowledge of his staff, to test the number of decibels which hover around his sanctum.

When the President first announced his new tax program on June 19 the one recommendation which was publicly approved by both Republicans and Democrats, conservatives and radicals, was that for a constitutional amendment terminating the issuance by Federal, State and local governments of tax-free bonds.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- At a luncheon of the National Trade Union Club today David Lloyd George, Liberal party leader, made a bid for Labor party support for his now almost forgotten "new deal." His hearers showed little interest in his economic theories but warmed to his criticism of the government's foreign policy, the results of which he said were now manifesting themselves in the Italo-Ethiopian situation.
