WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Some supporters of the Omnibus Banking Bill expressed fears today that the measure would die in conference before this Congressional session ends.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, economic dictator of the Third Reich, took a hand today in the fight against mounting prices by ordering price supervising offices to prevent "every unjustified rise."

When the names of forty-eight prisoners in a raid at dawn yesterday on a suspected gambling place at 83 Mulberry Street were called out later before Magistrate Stern in the Tombs Court thirty-one of them, for whom a total of $15,500 in bail had been provided, were discovered to have sent substitutes to stand trial.

The AAA policies of President Roosevelt's administration are driving American business men into the cotton business in Brazil because of cheaper production costs there, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, cousin of the President, asserted last night.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 14. -- After completing a hazardous journey into a hitherto unknown part of the interior of the island of Papua, Assistant Resident Magistrate H.G. Hides presented an engrossing 30,000-word report to the Federal Government today, greatly amplifying reports of his discoveries published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on July 23.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, declared here today that there had been more improvement in police work in the last century than in any other phase of public service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- An impression was current at the Capitol today that Congress might adjourn as soon as the Tax Bill was disposed of, and some estimates from trustworthy sources set the date as early as next Tuesday night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- A record number of primary contests in Westchester County was made evident today by petitions filed with the Election Bureau before the deadline last night. The contests, mostly for positions on party committees, number 107, said to be the largest since the Bull Moose insurgency.
the managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange approved yesterday the following amendment to trade rules applying to sugar, effective Aug. 23:

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Desirable hogs continued in active demand here today and while heavy butchers and lard types were disposed to drag, the market was quoted as steady to as much as 10 cents higher, with four loads averaging 197 to 208 pounds, selling at $12.20 a hundredweight, exclusive of the processing tax, to equal the outside level paid on Tuesday for a selected lot.

Enlargement of the lending powers of the Mortgage Certificate Loan Corporation through amendment of the charter was announced yesterday by Thomas W. Streeter, president. The concern is now permitted to make loans on mortgage certificates or bonds guaranteed by corporations, organized under the Banking Law, for which the Superintendent of Banks has been appointed rehabilitator or liquidator, and to make rehabilitation loans on the properties underlying such securities.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the city will readvertise in the near future for bids on fire hose needed by the Fire Department and, in the event that identical bids are received, will turn the matter over to the Attorney General of the United States for prosecution.

Max Klein, 50 years old, a jewelry salesman, who was indicted a year ago on his story of being robbed of $13,000 in diamonds in the Hotel Astor, was exonerated yesterday of a grand larceny charge by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions.

Annual gross revenues of $30,000,000 might suffice to meet the charges and depreciation of the Baldwin Locomotive Works required by the recapitalization plan it has filed under the terms of the bankruptcy law, George H. Houston, president, said yesterday.
HAMBURG, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP). -- A former Broadway revue dancer confessed today, authorities said, that she had slain her husband in a struggle for his pistol after he struck her.

An outdoor library will be established within the next week in Bryant Park, it became known yesterday. Plans for the service are now being worked out by officials of the Recreation Division of the Park Department and the Extension Division of the New York Public Library.

Henry Lipkin, the 19-year-old Bronx youth whose dislike of negligent motorists has led him to pass some of his time each day noting the license numbers of automobiles that violate traffic rules, will have a day in court to press his charges, it was decided yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- President Roosevelt, at his press conference today indicated that the matter was in the hands of the Labor and Navy Departments and that he was expecting an agreement on arbitration.

A 17-year-old volunteer worker in the Bellevue Hospital eye clinic was run down and killed yesterday at First Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street by a hearse on its way to the morgue to get the body of another automobile victim.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Alfred Esdaile, managing director of the Prince of Wales Theatre, bought the Piccadilly Theatre today for more than 100,000. He cabled Mae West an offer of $35,000 for a two weeks' engagement for the opening of the theatre next month.
PARIS, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- The "United Methodist Church" was agreed upon today as a name for the proposed reunion of the Methodist Episcopal Church (Northern), the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant Church.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A new basic treaty and supplemental agreements with Panama under which the United States will no longer guarantee the republic's independence or have the right to intervene to preserve order in Panama City and Colon, if the Panaman authorities prove inadequate, have been virtually concluded after months of negotiations.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15. -- One of the unusual artistic events of the season took place here this afternoon when an exhibition of paintings and sketches by a group of Southampton artists opened with a reception and tea at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng in Halsey's Neck Lane.

It would be difficult to imagine a more fantastic situation than now exists with respect to silver. So far as monetary reserves are concerned, the United States already has in its possession a large enough supply of what the world regards as a better metal -- gold -to support with ample coverage four times the amount of currency now outstanding.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Madge Watson, sought for questioning in the killing of Kenneth A. Morrison; Assistant Controller of the Chicago Park District, was detained tonight at Danville at the request of the Chicago police.

The directors of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 70 cents a share on the common stock, placing the stock on an annual dividend basis of $2.80 a share against $2 previously paid.

Disposal by gift in June of 2,104,000 common shares of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company reduced the holdings of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in this company to less than 10 per cent of its 31,154,279 outstanding shares. Since he is neither an officer nor a director of the concern, he will no longer be required under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to report monthly changes in his shareholdings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The AAA reported today that practically complete returns disclosed that 171,691 growers voted in referenda where growers of four types of tobacco approved crop adjustment programs for next year. Referenda were held for producers of burley, fire-cured, dark air-cured and cigar filler and binder tobacco.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 15. -- An increase in State control of local government financing was reported here today by Norman F. Titus, director of research of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The conference report on the bill carrying amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act was adopted in both branches of Congress today, completing Capitol action and heading this long controverted measure toward the White House.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Secretary Morgenthau expressed satisfaction today with this week's sale of Treasury bonds on an "auction" basis, although both the prices bid and the amounts bid for declined sharply.

All commodity futures except metals and hides advanced sharply in active trading on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets gains were made in cotton, wheat, corn, rye, flour, lard, coffee, cocoa, silk and rubber. Tin declined.

Plans for a "prompt and sweeping investigation" into mortgage certificate "racketeering" were made at the first meeting yesterday of the special commission appointed by the Federal Bar Association to inquire into reports of improper practices in this field.

The baseball market at Ebbets Field was distinctly bearish yesterday, those Chicago Bruins bouncing back from the double disaster of the previous day to take the third encounter of their series with the Dodgers by 11 to 3.

I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, returned from a five-week trip to Europe yesterday convinced that the outcome of the Italian-Ethiopian situation will have a profound effect on world economic conditions in the next few years.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 15 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Government's deposits with the Bank of Canada were increased $3,014,892 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly report of the bank showed today. Notes in circulation declined $1,000,231, while reserves in United States funds increased $2,695,336.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. gave away $27,300,000 worth of stock in the Socony-Vacuum Corporation on June 28, nine days after President Roosevelt had asked Congress to impose inheritance taxes and increase existing gift and estate taxes, the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today.
WINNIPEG, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press). -- The council of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange announced today that trading in two new futures, October and December, would be started tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Transfer of about 52,000 jobless from the "dole" to Work Relief jobs in the last week, bringing the total number on work jobs over the nation to 602,000, was reported today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator. Of this number 133,000 are on WPA jobs, 442,000 are in the CCC and 27,000 on Federal projects.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and $10,000,000 above the corresponding week in 1934.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Bobby Brown hurled two-hit ball to shut out the Reds today and win his first game of the season for the Braves. He ran the lowly Braves' winning streak to three straight games. The score was 8-0.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- True to form, the four seeded players, Mrs. Marian Turpie Lake, Miss Sylva Annenberg, Miss Charlotte Glutting and Miss Marjorie Harrison, advanced to the semi-final stage in the annual New York State women's invitation championship at the Hotel Champlain Golf Club today.

Officials of the recently formed Interstate Sanitation Commission comprising New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, met yesterday to formulate a comprehensive plan for purifying bordering waters and protecting sewage disposal in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A decision by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to finance construction of streamline trains which railroads can buy on the instalment plan," was announced today by Chairman Jones.

The problem of educating descendants of the Acadians who were deported from Canada in the eighteenth century and settled in the French colony which is now Louisiana, is proving a serious problem to the school authorities of that State, according to Essae M. Culver, secretary of the Louisiana State Library Commission.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 15. -- Complete returns from Tuesday's election showed that Ohio voters genersJly sanctioned bond issues for poorly conditioned public schools. Proposals to issue bonds for new buildings and to provide additional operating funds were defeated.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Numerous guests, many prominent in society, are arriving for the running of the Travers on Saturday.

The security markets moved lower yesterday as commodities showed some improvement. Stocks held fairly steady during most of the day under the leadership of petroleum and, at times, the automotive and mining shares, but encountered a flurry of selling just before the closing so that final prices were irregularly lower on the day.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Julius Streicher, National Socialist party district head of Nuremberg, leader of the anti-Semitic wing of the party and organizer of the anti-Jewish boycott in 1933, invaded Berlin tonight.

Higher hosiery and fabric prices loomed up yesterday as a consequence of the sharp advance in raw silk and rising quotations on synthetic fibers. Raw silk was quoted yesterday at the highest prices since the pre-NRA boom of 1933 and a rise of about 5 cents a pound is momentarily expected to be announced on acetate yarns.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. 3fleet trade conditions and wholesale prices in lqew York.

Although Maxwell Anderson's recent play included a dramatic meeting between Queen Mary of Scotland and Queen Elizabeth of England, no such meeting ever took place, according to Stefan Zweig's new biography, "Mary Queen of Scotland and the Isles," which will be released within the next fortnight.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Sources close to army staff headquarters tonight labeled as "baseless" rumors that a girl had died as the result of an attack by soldiers, and blamed communistic elements for starting a "whispering campaign" against next week's army manoeuvres.
Nervousness over a producers' loan caused frequent and irregular fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday with gains of 1 to 19 points being recorded at the close.

Six-story apartment houses were included in the foreclosed realty bought in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday. Four Manhattan parcels and three in the Bronx were offered. One scheduled Manhattan sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

The uptrend in bank clearings has slackened in pace, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday was $4,545,189,000, compared with $4,239,802,000 a year ago, an increase of 7.2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- A sharp reduction in hedging pressure incident to an improvement in sales of flour, with strength in the wheat market in Liverpool, was largely responsible today for a firmer market for wheat on the Board of Trade.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Flood Control Council for Central-Southern New York swung into action today to assure fifteen southern tier counties against a recurrence of the damaging floods of early July, electing officers and discussing a flood-control program.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Aug. 15. -- The Soviet Government tonight honored the International Physiological Congress with an elaborate dinner in Catherine the Great's Palace at Tsarkoe Selo, now called "Detskoe Selo," twenty miles from Leningrad.

The Giants and Cardinals spent two hours and thirty-three minutes tossing a lot of things at each other in the third encounter of their important struggle on the Harlem yesterday, but two tosses settled the encounter. Both were unfurled by the invaders, each strayed considerably from its desired line of flight and they gave Colonel Bill Terry's men the game, 5 to 4, while 10,000 onlookers bellowed approval.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP). -Tommy Bridges, aided by a timely pinch single in the eighth by Charley Gehringer, scored his eighteenth victory of the season today as the Tigers trned back the Senator, 6to 3.
ROME, Aug. 15. -- Italy looks to the Paris negotiations without the slightest confidence that they will result in a peaceful solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- New $1 silver certificates are being printed by the Treasury and will be put into circulation soon, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

TIRANA, Albania, Aug. 15. -- General Leon de Ghilardi, inspector general of the Albanian Army, was assassinated today, together with his chauffeur, near Avlona. Six revolver shots were fired into each. The shooting took place while they were riding in the general's automobile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- FERA camps in the South to which some 3,500 jobless war veterans were quietly sent, partly because of the administration's fear of another bonus march, will be broken up by Nov. 1 and the able-bodied veterans in them will be transferred to CCC camps and work-relief jobs, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, announced today.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Miss Betty Pietsch, this year's finalist in the metropolitan championship, today won her first one-day golf tournament of the season, capturing the Westchester-Fairfield event over the Hudson River Country Club course.

Among the business leases announced yesterday was one by the Crossroads Club, Inc., a luncheon and advertising club, for the penthouse occupying the twentieth floor of 247 Park Avenue. The lease, for a long term kt an sggregate rental of about $75,000, was negotiated by i Wm. A. White Sons.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15. -- The first exchange exhibition between the Newport Art Association and East Hampton artists opened today, to continue through Sept. 4. Newport artists have sent some sixty paintings and twenty-five etchings, which are being shown in the Guild Hall's three art galleries here.

The one undoubted major improvement made by the Senate Finance Committee in the Tax Bill is that abolishing the proposed inheritance tax entirely and substituting instead a higher estate tax designed to raise the same additional revenue. The old estate tax rates reached a maximum of 60 per cent; the new reach a maximum of 70 per cent.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Two full brothers, one 3 and the other 4, finished one-two in the thirty-third running of the Catskill Stakes, feature today at the Spa, marking the first time in many seasons such a double has been brought off. The colts were George Odom's Chancery and Chancing, both sons of Chancel Play from Courtly.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 15. -- A throng attended the annual water sports tonight at the indoor swimming pool at the Mount Washington Hotel. Among those having pool-side seats were Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucigne, Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace, Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds, Mrs. Amy C. Shepard, Joseph F. Duffy, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lee Judd, Mrs. James A. Thomas, Louis A. Hamilton, Dr. Stewart Lee Jeffrey, and many others.
l[rs. Iathryn S. Clark, in 115 E. 53d St., { completing the renting of this building; Brett Wyckoff, Inc., brokers.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Supported by a trio of homers by Manager Joe Cronin, Bill Werber and Dusty Cooke, which accounted for all the Boston runs, Lefty Grove pitched the Red Sox to their third straight victory over the White Sox, 3 to 1, today.

Summer school will end today for 52,000 adults who, during the last two months, have been attending the free classes of the Adult Education Project of the Board of Education and the WPA in 165 centres, including fifteen public school buildings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP). -- A.C. Gilbert, New Haven toy manufacturer and member of the American Olympic Committee, expressed the opinion today that the United States should have full representation at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin.

LONDON, Friday, Aug 16 (AP). -- A Reuters dispatch from Peiping reported today that Gareth Jones, British journalist and former secretary to David Lloyd George, who was captured by bandits near Kalgen, Chahar Province, Inner Mongolia, a fortnight ago, had been killed by his captors.

Yesterday's statement of the' twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year..
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The race for the medal in the annual Green Meadow invitation tournament today produced the best golf that has been played in the qualifying round for eight years.
Referring to that bit of news given yesterday by Mrs. E.D. Campbell, English stylist, may I put in a word or two?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A seven-hour exciting search for Howard C. Hopson which led through fashionable cocktail rooms, hotel corridors and swimming pools and will probably cost the government about $15 for food and drinks added new color to the career of Chesley W. Jurney, Senate sergeant-at-arms and former Texas sheriff.

OSLO, Aug. 15. -- Gordon Dunn, crack weight man of the San Francisco Olympic Club, barely missed a new world's record today when he won the discus throw in a track and field meet in which athletes from the United States, Norway and Sweden participated.

Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, will return today on the French liner Champlain. Also on the liner, due early this morning from Havre and Southampton, are Jacques Brugnon and Andre Martin-Legeay, French tennis players, and the following:

More than 100 crime suspects, hold-up men, fugitives and parole violators were sifted out yesterday as 700 derelicts swept up Wednesday night in the drive to wipe out crime in the public parks were milled through the magistrates' courts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Eastman Railroad Reorganization Bill, designed to reduce burdensome capital structures and the resultant fixed charges, and to prevent blocking of reorganization plans by recalcitrant minorities, was rushed through the House today without a dissenting voice.

The attitude of the United States in the Ethiopian-Italian dispute rests "squarely upon the principles declared in the Pact of Paris," a communication from the State Department yesterday advised Mrs. Arthur Brin, president of the National Council of Jewish Women.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Emphasis to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's cotton problem was given today when the Department of Commerce made public figures showing that exports of United States cotton for the 1934-35 season, August to July inclusive, were 36 per cent below the previous season in volume and 23 per cent in value.

My chief objection to the NRA was that it made a hopeless attempt to stimulate business by raising prices instead of decreasing prices, the only natural and logical method. The principle applies to taxi fares as well as to anything else.

As stockholders of the Fox Film Company overwhelmingly approved yesterday the proposed reorganization and merger with Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin in Brooklyn reserved decision on two injunction actions to restrain consummation of the plans.

Anxious to set at rest reports that Sir William Watson, English poet, who died Tuesday at the age of 77, had vilified a prominent Englishwoman in one of his many poems, Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, editor and author, of 327 Lexington Avenue, last night issued a statement denying that "The Woman With a Serpent's Tongue" had been inspired by Lady Asquith.
It is still the Summer, but also there is no reasonable law against making a few plans for next season, wherefore these forward-looking bulletins:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15. -- Held to one hit for six innings by Willis Hudlin today, the Yankees swung into action, bunched five timely blows and downed the Indians in the third game of their series, 3 to 1.

The decision of the Park Department as announced recently through the columns of your paper by Miss Kobbe, that no dovecotes will be erected in the city parks, is no surprise to one who feeds the birds daily. The Park Commission has plenty of money for our monkeys, lions, reptiles and other specimens of wild life, but not a cent for our native birds.

MURDEN, Manchuria, Aug. 15. -- Sounding a pessimistic note regarding North China, Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, who has just returned from a conference in Dairen of the Kwangtung Army staff, said today the attitude of the Japanese Army toward the recent murder of a Japanese at Lanchow would not be defined until the identity and connections of the criminals were established.
Monogram's screen transcription of Mrs. Gene Stratton-Porter's "The Keeper of the Bees," featuring Neil Hamilton, Betty Furness and Edith Fellows, opens this morning at the Roxy.

Officials of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange are giving earnest attention to the prospect of a tight situation in the old No. 1 sugar contract within the next fortnight, and, if the situation seems to warrant it, may cause the appointment of the control committee provided for by vote of the members on July 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Looking toward fulfillment of another important task before the adjournment of Congress, the House moved today to bring up for consideration tomorrow the Guffey-Snyder bill for the control of the bituminous coal industry, described in a committee report as necessary to "remedy evils which seriously endanger" the industry and the well-being of "many people."

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Details of two expense-paid trips to California, made by John MacDonald to testify in Tom Mooney's behalf, were revealed here today as MacDonald continued his testimony before a referee named by the California Supreme Court.

FRANKFORT-ON-THE-MAIN, Germany, Aug. 15. -- Sir Basil Blackett, British Treasury expert and a director of the Bank of England, was fatally injured when his automobile was hit by a train at noon today, and he died in the Marburg Hospital this afternoon.
GILMER, Texas, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Four persons died early today in a tri-motored ship of the Delta Airlines, which crashed and burned after circling a cotton field in a vain attempt to land safely.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System reached a new high record of $2,670,000,000 on Wednesday, compared with $2,550,000,000 a week before, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report published yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Bishops and laymen representing the three principal branches of the Methodist Church tonight were near agreement on a constitution by which, if adopted, their organizations would be merged into a unified church.
NEWPORT, Aug. 15. -Entertaining in honor clothe season's dbuantes this week continued tonight, when there were two large parties for two young women.

The provision in the Copeland Shipping Bill, now in the hands of the Senate Commerce Committee, which would bar men associated with ship lines within the last two years from membership on the proposed Maritime Authority, was attacked yesterday by shipping operators.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 15. -The final program in the dance festival sponsored by the Bennington school of the dance at Bennington College took place tonight in the Vermont State Armory here when Martha Graham and a supporting group of thirty-six dancers presented a new three-part composition entitled "Panorama."
Small housing parcels made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 15. -- Polo came back to the beautiful field of the Piping Rock Club today as Aurora and the Hurricanes, the latter with one substitute, rode through six fast periods before a crowd of 3,000 parked along the side boards.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Whether Joseph P. Kennedy is to remain more than a few weeks longer as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission largely depends, it is learned authoritatively today, upon whether a utilities law is enacted at this session of Congress for administration by the SEC, and in what he considers workable form.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Without a quiver in her stretches of canvas, H.S. Vanderbilt's Class M racing sloop Prestige led the New York Yacht Club fleet here today from New London on the first squadron run of the organization's annual cruise.

THE visitor wanted to talk about Shufflin' Joe Louis, but that topic is getting pretty well worn from constant usage. All the laudatory adjectives and phrases have been tossed around so much that they are getting thin in the middle and frayed around the edges.

With Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago not scheduled to defend the title, ninety-four contestants will start in the qualifying round of the women's national amateur golf championship at the Interlachen Country Club, Hopkins, Minn., on Monday, Aug. 26.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15. -- Mr. Ercole, Italian delegate to the seventh congress of the Communist International, told the meeting today that the clashing interests of Britain and the United States in the Far East had brought on a deep and dangerous division in the capitalistic world.

GENEVA, Aug. 15. -- Numerous public works have been constructed in Ethiopia since the world depression began without unemployment as a spur, according to Ethiopia's reply to the League of Nation's inquiry as to what each country has been doing to relieve unemployment by public works.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Repeal and lower fares have given the two principal American passenger ships nearer capacity transatlantic loads than are being carried by the Normandie, the French queen of the seas.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The Milky Way Farm of Mars. Ethel Mars again was the high bidder at the yearling sales tonight where fifty-four head passed through the ring, bringing a total of $69,350. This made for an average of approximately $1,284.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- In a rush for speedy adjournment of Congress the $250,000,000 Tax Bill was passed in the Senate late today by a vote of 57 to 22.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -President Roosevelt appointed an inter-departmental committee today to coordinate the government's health activities, allotted more than $14,000,000 in work relief funds, and late tonight left for a week-end at Hyde Park.
Sale of a suburban holding featured the apartment house deals reported yesterday.

A Big Ten, consisting of a galaxy of five major league stars from the nineteenth century and as many more from modern times, will form the foundation for an official baseball hall of fame in the National Baseball Museum, now located at Cooperstown, N.Y., the game's birthplace.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- If the prospect of a peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian difficulties depended on the developments of today and yesterday the task might as well be given up now as hopeless. But they do not.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15. -With the Greentree-Long Island match, scheduled for Manhasset today, postponed for the second successive day, the two teams journeyed to the Meadow Brook Club this evening and engaged the Templeton quartet in a round-robin on Belmont Field.

GOSHEH, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Two world's records were set during today's Grand Circuit program by Thomas Berry when he drove Paul Bowser's 4-year-old filly Tara, by Volomite -- Sweet Fern, to a three-straight-heat victory in the Progressive Stake for trotters with a record faster than 2:04. The times were 2:00, 2:01 and 2:02.

The American Machine and Foundry Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $507,105, including dividends received from the International Cigar Machinery Company and $50,079 representing the proportionate share of the latter company's earnings in excess of the six-month dividend requirements.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The New York State Police Conference, in convention here, unanimously decided to submit a definite program of crime reduction and better police service to the Crime Commission appointed by Governor Lehman, which will hold its first sessions in October.

TORONTO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Leafs tonight turned back Newark, 9 -- 2, in a game played under arc lights. Barnes limited the Bears to six hits and shut them out until the eighth, when they scored both their runs.
The litigation which always follows the filing of primary designating petitions with the Board of Elections began yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers, driving toward their second straight American League pennant, are not likely to find double-headers, with their heavy toll on pitching staffs, a stumbling-block in the path to the world series.

Fenner Beane, members of the New York Stock Exchange and of leading commodity exchanges throughout the country, announced yesterday that, beginning next Tuesday margins would be required of all customers on all new commodity transactions.

WEINSBERG, Germany, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, wealthy American draft dodger, made a new offer of surrender today to the United States Government. His stipulations are that "first the case be taken out of the hands of the military authorities and, secondly, my family be permitted to reside permanently in the United States."

The management of the Hotel New Yorker announced yesterday that it had refused to permit the Association of German-American Technologists to fly the Nazi swastika flag in a private dining room at a dinner during a three-day convention scheduled to be held from Aug. 31 to Sept. 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is technically "insolvent" in the sense that its remaining liquid assets will no longer cover its liabilities, the corporation's monthly statement for July, made public today, shows.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 15. -The longest and most successful season in the five years of excavating the Agora, or Athenian market place, by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens was reported today by Dr. T. Leslie Shear of Princeton, field director of the expedition which has just returned.

The Republicans of New York State, by-recapturing the Assembly from the Democrats, can serve notice on the people of the nation that the tide is turning against President Roosevelt in his home State, F. Trubee Davison asserted yesterday.

Aaron Rabinowitz, real estate expert and member of the State Housing Board, testified before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday that the Federal Government was planning to spend $50,000,000 on low-rent apartment house construction in New York City. An announcement to that effect is expected soon, he said.

Who would have guessed that the liquid notes issuing from the throat of GALLI-CURCI had to pass a formidable obstruction on their way? For fifteen years, says the prima donna, she has been singing "around" a goiter in her throat, which surgery has now removed.
The salt-water fishing season is at its height and the coming weekend should witness another banner outpouring of devotees of the sport.

The thirteenth team match between the United States and Great Britain for the Wightman Cup will get under way in the stadium at the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills this afternoon with two singles and one doubles match scheduled.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Lucille Horan, former showgirl, will plead "self defense, justifiable homicide and temporary insanity," at her trial for the killing of her husband, Frank Horan, her attorney Samuel Fleischmann, announced this afternoon. He added:

HARRAR, Ethiopia, Aug. 15 (Reuters). -- Traveling by rail and road from Addis Ababa to Harrar and Diredawa, this correspondent observed signs of intense military preparations with a view to repelling the advance of the Italian army, which is expected within five or six weeks.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15. -- A serious impasse has arisen in the Chaco peace conference over the exchange and repatriation of war prisoners. Paraguay is willing to exchange prisoners, grade for grade and man for man. Bolivia, however, insists upon the immediate release of all prisoners on the ground that the war has terminated.

The budgetary estimates of the Borough President of Brooklyn for 1936, while showing an increase of $61,975 over 1935, reflected "substantial savings" when examined yesterday by Rufus E. McGahen, budget director.

Regarding Harry A. Lesser's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES criticizing that part of the economic program offered by Robert Wood Johnson which proposes "minimum wages high enough for the people to buy what they produce," I take exception to his interpretation.

The effect of eliminating the tax-exempt feature of United States Government securities, while leaving State and municipal issues with their tax-exempt features unchanged, would be to increase the cost of Federal financing, but otherwise would make little difference, it was explained in banking circles here.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The news of Sir Basil Blackett's death in Germany came as a shock today, not only to the "City" but to the wider public, which had come to regard him as one of the most progressive of British business men.

A new advande of 0.7 point carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 127.1 on Tuesday, last, the highest point reached by the index since June, 1930. The rise, as in the case of other recent weeks, was due primarily to advances in livestock and meats, as the effects of the drought last year continued to be felt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Following is a comparison of the tax bills passed by the Senate and the House:

OLIVER LA FARGE, grandson of John La Farge, is, by vocation, an anthropologist, a specialist in the Indians of Central America, Mexico and our own Southwestern States. Most of his fiction, including the Pulitzer prize-winning "Laughing Boy," consists of anthropological material accurately observed and set forth in a prose that is sensitive both to an alien Indian psychology and to the hues of tropic or desert.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- With actual work on relief projects under the Works Progress Administration in New Jersey scheduled to begin tomorrow, William H.J. Ely, State administrator, approved today another twelve projects, at a cost to the WPA of $35,006 and to the sponsors of $6,609.

Thomas E. Dewey, who has declared his intention of investigating corruption among the leaders of organized labor in his investigation into racketeering, issued a statement yesterday explaining that he was not interested in incidental acts of violence growing out of labor conflict between employers and legitimate unions.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15. -- There is a more solid basis for the cheerfulness of business sentiment than the impressive and important fact that stock market quotations have been advancing for five consecutive months, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, Cleveland Trust Company vice president, said in the bank's business bulletin today.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The markets on the London Stock Exchange became more quiet today as a result of profit-taking, although industrials continued generally firm. The markets were pleased with the Board of Trade returns. Further weakness in British funds was also partly responsible for the slackening of business.

An appeal to President Roosevelt to preserve the prevailing rate for union workers on Works Progress Administration jobs -- the object of the WPA strike -- was decided upon yesterday by the unions' strike committee.

Reduced rates for gas supplies by the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the New York and Queens Gas Company were approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The new rates, which resulted from negotiations between the commission and the Consolidated Gas Company system, become effective Sept. 1 and represent an annual saving of about $590,000 to consumers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -Sharp increases in the farm products and foods groups helped raise the wholesale commodity price index of the Bureafi of Labor Statistics during the week ending Aug. l0 so that it stood at S0.1, as compared with 79.6 the previous week and 75.4 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- President Roosevelt does not intend to mention the question of constitutional revision to the country on the Western trip upon which he will start soon, some of his closest political advisers said today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta today added another notable conquest to his string for the season as he gained the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament with Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 15. -- Another Italo-Ethiopian incident is reported in the Harrar neighborhood, this time by the Ethiopians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A return to open silver trading in the United States was voted today by the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -President Roosevelt's right-hand "contact man," who keeps him posted on what Congress is doing, was denounced today by the House Republican leader as a "lobbyist."

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The Ard Righ Hunter Stable's chestnut gelding Campanile scored his third victory in as many tries in the Deer Hill Challenge Cup event for middle and heavyweight hunters at the Cohasset Horse Show on the estate of Mrs. Hugh Bancroft today to retire the cup and provide the feature of the first day of the exhibition.

SALZBURG, Aug. 15. -- It has been announced officially that Dusolina Giannini will appear as Mistress Ford in Saturday night's performance of "Falstaff," her throat ailment being cured. As a matter of fact, without Giannini's cooperation Saturday's "Falstaff" probably would have to be canceled, since Maria Caniglia, who replaced her in performances of Verdi's opera, has gone to fill engagements in Italy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 15. -- Belated returns today from Tuesday's State-wide balloting added to the majority whereby the voters of California rejected three bond propositions submitted to them by the recent Legislature and added much speculation as to the future financing of 'projects for building and enlarging State institutions such as asylums and prisons which are overcrowded.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Serious inadequacy in Britain's anti-aircraft defenses due to the ineffectiveness of searchlights was revealed in night "air raids" over important naval and military centres in the Portsmouth area tonight and in the two preceding nights.

ANDREW CARNEGIE once declared that it was a disgrace to a man to "die rich." He certainly lived up to his own principle, giving away in his lifetime many millions of dollars. If the taxes on gifts proposed in the pending bill in Washington had been in effect when he was making his large benefactions, they would have been reduced by nearly one-half.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15. -- The reactionary circles of American finance capital that are attacking President Roosevelt and his New Deal are the real force behind fascism in the United States, and, inferentially at least, the true target of the American Communist party in its fight for an anti-Fascist united front, Georgi Dimitroff told the Communist International congress in his concluding speech, published today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Settlement of the strike which has tied up construction of seven naval vessels at the New York Shipbuilding Company yard at Camden for thirteen weeks appeared closer tonight after the first day of conferences between all parties concerned.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 15. -- A three-clay celebration of the sesquicentennial of the Baptist Church at East Poultney, Vt., will open tomorrow evening with a dinner on the village green at which Governor Charles M. Smith of Vermont will be the guest of honor.

A group of five Chicago banks, headed by the First National Bank of Chicago, received yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,500,000 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Chicago Board of Education on a bid of 102.1876. The bonds are to mature on Jan. 1, 1955 and are callable on Jan. 1, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Here are excerpts from the Ways and Means Committee majority and minority reports on the Guffey-Snyder Bituminous Coal Control Bill and from the reports of three members filing supplementary views:

Made cocky by the Rhode Island election and knowing the value of advertising, Ohio Republicans saw a chance for a good game of brag. The seat of the one Buckeye Congressman at Large is vacant. It must be filled at once, Governor DAVEY. If you won't issue the call for a speedy election, and you won't because you are afraid to, we'll hale you into court and make you do your duty.

James A. Moffett, Federal Housing Administrator, who set aside his work as vice president of the Standard Oil Company of California to accept the government post, announced yesterday that the organization of the FHA was complete and that he felt free to leave Washington and return to private business.

PLATTSBURG, Mo., Aug. 15 (AP). -- One thousand angry farmers, uttering threats, tearing clothes and swinging fists, surrounded Henry Dillingham, United States marshal, and three aides today on the courthouse lawn and forcibly prevented the foreclosure sale of a farm.

Ignoring threats of criminal and civil action against him, Magistrate Hulon Capshaw held without bail in the Essex Market Court yesterday a prisoner charged with felonious assault who had been freed by a Supreme Court order under $2,500 bail.
Sir Basil Blackett Entered British Treasury at 21. Sir Basil Blackett was one of the leading financiers of Great Britain and was regarded as a world authority in the field of economics.
Edward F. Hutton, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, and Mrs. Hutton, the former Mrs. Marjorie Post Close, have been separated for several months, it was disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The four convicted slayers of Howard Carter Dickinson stood before Judge John A. Boyne in a packed courtroom today and were sentenced to life imprisonment.

Samuel H. Kress, chairman of the board of S.H. Kress Co., five-and-ten-cent stores, was revealed yesterday as the purchaser of Duccio's famous painting, "The Calling of St. Peter and St. Andrew," from Clarence H. Mackay. The price was reported to have been about $250,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The first month following the introduction of what is generally known as the billion-mark export subsidy plan, special levies for which became effective June 15, produced a considerable improvement in the German foreign balance according to figures issued today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 15. -- Jimmy Rousmaniere, perennial runner-up from the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, today came through narrowly to win the championship of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

United States Senator Huey P. Long, whose Presidential candidacy was launched in Washington recently by anonymous friends, bobbed up here yesterday to accept the nomination with qualifications and reservations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A resolution intended to discourage United States participation in the Olympic Games to be held in Germany next year was introduced today by Representative Celler of New York. It would prohibit the use of public or semi-public funds to defray expenses of American nationals seeking to compete in the events.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- The market for hogs was somewhat unsettled today, with packing sows, which now constitute about half of the receipts, advancing 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight, while increased offerings of hogs averaging less than 180 pounds each resulted in declines of 10 to 15 cents in the underweights.

If New York succeeds in extending its public library facilities to readers out in the open, under the trees in the parks, as is definitely proposed for Bryant Park, it may soon be that California can no longer boast that more books are read under her skies than in any other State. Books in that State are conveyed to forest camps, to boxcar libraries on side-tracks, to fruit gatherers and even to mountain settlements.

Eighty-three artists and art teachers employed by the Works Progress Administration in designing and executing murals in public buildings throughout the city and in teaching art in settlement houses were arrested at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon after they staged a demonstration in front of the WPA office at 137 East Fifty-seventh Street demanding their pay for the last two weeks.

Alfred E. Smith, renting agent of the Prospect Park Zoo, is mighty pleased at the response to his appeal to various ones of the United States for native animals to populate the barren cages in Brooklyn and in the Central Park Zoo in Manhattan.

Revocation of the private detective license of William M. Tivoli, head of the Aster Detective Service, 10 West Sixty-first Street, was announced yesterday by Miss Grace A. Reavy, Chief of the Division of Licenses, Department of State.

The city campaign against delinquent sales tax payers has resulted in the collection of $682,000 with at least as much more in prospect, Milton Solomon, Deputy Controller, said yesterday. Usually, he explained, delinquents pay their tax plus the penalty when they are called in for an explanation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- In what some thought was an attempt to make peace with labor unions which have supported WPA strikes, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, ruled today that union labor might be supplied to work relief contractors from lists furnished by "recognized unions" of union workers on relief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Marion Caskie of Mobile, Ala., was appointed by President Roosevelt today a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of Patrick J. Farrell last December.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP). -- A training school reaching thousands of parents and children throughout New York State, providing employment for hundreds of teachers and fitting a large number of other young women to earn a livelihood, is proposed under an emergency nursery school and parent-education project sent to Washington today by the State Works Progress Administration.

Joseph B. Weaver, director of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection Service, declared yesterday that American ships were operated under antiquated laws, many of which were a century old, and urged that safety at sea be sought by the training of ships' personnel.

Drivers of automobiles bearing registration plates of the State of Georgia will be stopped and questioned by the police to determine whether they are bona fide residents of the State, according to an order issued to local police yesterday by Carroll E. Mealey, Deputy Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -Bryan Grant, Atlanta's little tennis giant, today took a beating in the semi-finals of the Casino tennis tournament from tall, wiry and redhaired Don Budge of Oakland, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Senate passed the Pittman resolution to investigate the operations of the Silver Purchase Act; heard eulogies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post, and passed a bill to buy Post's Winnie Mae plane for the Smithsonian; passed many minor bills and recessed at 6:03 P.M. until noon Monday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Former President Hoover spent today in Chicago on his way from New York to his home in Palo Alto. He left late tonight on the Chicago North Western Overland Limited after a series of meetings with friends which were declared to have little political significance.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- A break of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in fresh pork loins had a depressing effect on the prices of hogs here today and the latter market was weak to as much as 15 cents a hundredweight lower, with lightweight grassy hogs showing the most loss.

The efforts of some 500 Communists to hold a meeting at the intersection of Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, in the face of police opposition drew more than 2,000 onlookers last night, finally necessitating the use of reserves. In several melees between the police and the crowd four men and a woman were arrested for disorderly conduct.
ROGERS, Ark., Aug. 6 (AP). -- This little Northwest Arkansas town, where Will Rogers was married twenty-seven years ago, heard with grief today of his death.

BIRCHALL'S Paris dispatch yesterday showed that France, England and Italy have begun "to talk business." To put it brutally, what is MUSSOLINI'S lowest asking price; what is the highest bid that France and England will make? Can they satisfy Italy at Ethiopia's expense?

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The Boerse was quiet and firm today. Heavy industrials were inactive. Potash issues were mixed, Westergeln gaining 1 point and Asches-Leben losing 3/4 point. Chemical shares were active, with I.G. Farben slightly weaker but variable. Electrical securities were inactive.

On the night of July 29, 1926, THE NEW YORK TIMES received a query from Will Rogers, who was then in London as an unofficial ambassador of good-will, asking if the newspaper would pay the cable tolls on a brief message.

DUBLIN, Aug. 16. -- Former President Cosgrave, who is on vacation at Connemara, said: "I am deeply grieved to hear of the death of Will Rogers. He was a brave and intelligent man who kept strictly to the moral code in all his work. His charity was perhaps his outstanding feature.

Plans of a six-story apartment house for the northwest corner of Perry Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard were filed yesterday with the Bronx Department of Buildings. The structure, designed by Charles Kreymborg, architect, is estimated to cost $175,000.
STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 16. -- A Wuerttemberg Catholic priest was sentenced to nine months' imprisonment today, and another priest was arrested on the same type of political charges.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16. -- Word that his father had crashed was communicated to Will Rogers Jr., 22-year-old son of the humorist, as he was working as a wiper in the engine room of the Tanker H.M. Storey. Young Rogers began work on the vessel only a few days ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Speaker Byrns said today he had a premonition that trouble would come to Will Rogers on the Alaskan flight:

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Aug. l6. -President Roosevelt returned to Hyde Park House today for a brief period of quiet contemplation before undertaking the direction of strategy designed to bring the current session of Congress to a satisfactory conclusion from the administration standpoint.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A semifinal conference of Democratic leaders to make arrangements for a prompt adjournment of Congress was called tonight by President Roosevelt for Sunday night.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that the average hourly wages of its employes had been increased 5 per cent, and that the basic work week would be forty hours, in conformity with the general practice of the metal-working industries.

Reports have been published that serious epidemics of dysentery, malaria, typhoid and other tropical diseases have broken out among the Italian troops sent to Africa and that thousands of soldiers are being shipped back to Italy, under cover of night, as the result of the havoc brought about by these diseases.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
Business and residential parcels were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Mrs. Cecille Canle, 26 years old, of 366 Tenth Avenue, Paterson, N.J., who with her 3-year-old daughter, Marylin, was found early yesterday morning in a dazed condition sitting on a bench at Morningside Avenue and ll6th Street, died at 7:30 P.M. in Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A charge that President Roosevelt and Governor Davey "have apparently conspired to deprive the people of the whole State of Ohio of their right to elect a Representative to the second session of this Congress" was made today by Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A determined drive to adjourn Congress by Tuesday night, with Thursday as the latest alternate date, was started today following formal commitment of the Wealth-Tax Bill to conference and a conference agreement on the Eccles Banking Bill.

A poll for a national tree conducted last year by the National Life Conservation Society resulted in a victory for the sequoia and not the pine, Mrs. Charles Cyrus Marshall, founder and president of the society, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Howard C. Hopson, who now admits that he was the guiding influence of the $900,000 lobby that the Associated Gas and Electric Company waged against the Wheeler-Rayburn bill, was forced to state before the Senate lobby inquiry committee today that the company had not hesitated to use the advertising columns of newspapers as a club to minimize unfavorable publicity.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 16. -Nearly 100 race drivers, who, in frail motor boats of assorted sizes, shapes and designs, are capable of doing fifty, sixty, seventy or even eighty miles an hour, were still arriving with their autos and trailers until long past dark tonight for the annual national sweepstakes regatta, which has helped to stamp Red Bank as a conspicuous motorboat racing centre in the East.
Various housing properties were included in the continuance of Bronx real estate activity reported yesterday.

Reports from Washington that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration would announce next week changes in the off-shore sugar quotas for 1934 and 1935, all of which would be applied to 1935 instead of being made retroactive, increased yesterday the danger of a "squeeze" in No. 1 sugar contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and spurred officials of that organization to further activity.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 16. -With twenty countries entered and represented by picked players, the sixth biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation was started auspiciously today, with the colors of the various nationalities waving proudly atop the Army Officers' Casino.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- Upon request of the executive secretary in the office of Governor Martin L. Davey, the Secretary of State, George S. Myers, today prepared a form of proclamation for filling the vacancy caused by the death of Charles V. Truax, Representative at Large from Ohio.

Employes of the Works Progress Administration complained yesterday to Hugh S. Johnson, their administrator, that they had not received their pay checks for the first two weeks of August. He replied that some of them would have to wait as long as six days before they would get paid.
" Sunny Youth," a new Soviet film, will have its American premiere today at the Acme Theatre, on Union Square.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Young Vernon Kennedy outlasted Wesley Ferrell in a marathon mound duel today and the White Sox ended their seven-game losing streak with a fourteen-inning victory over the Red Sox, 4 to 3.

MARTIGNY, Switzerland, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Dr. W. Beran Wolfe, New York psychiatrist, of 24 East Eightieth Street, was killed and his companion, Mrs. Marion Hilliard Blodgett of 66 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, was seriously injured when an automobile Dr. Wolfe was driving last night struck and killed a cyclist and crashed into a tree.

Mr. LA GUARDIA literally took the first crack at the Brooklyn Bridge extension over Park low when he ceremonially applied a pneumatic hammer to that venerable structure. Removal of the bridge spur, said the Mayor, was essential to the general plan for the restoration and beautification of City Hall Park.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Wiley Post died Just as he wished to die.
Among the passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia are:

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Sales taxes, although introduced as temporary measures, will tend to become permanent despite their unfairness, Carl Shoup, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, declared today at the fifth annual economics conference for engineers at Stevens Camp.

The possibility of a will contest involving the $5,000 estate of an inmate of the City Home for Dependents on Welfare Island arose yesterday when it was revealed that a nephew of the late Stephen Mahan, aged testator, had disclosed such an intention when making inquiries in the clerk's office of the Surrogate's Court.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bealle Davis gave a dinner and bridge tonight at Fondamere. Their guests were Major and Mrs. John A. Warner, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon, Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson and Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Morris, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Richardson at the Crossways; Mr. and Mrs. J. Couper Lord and Mr. and Mrs. G. Faber Downey Jr.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -Almost forgotten in the furore over who had spent how much in opposing it, the ban against utility holding companies was drawn up today by House and Senate conferees, debated to a draw and laid aside until Monday.

ALDERSHOT, England, Aug. 16. -- Britain's new light machine gun, originally constructed in Czechoslovakia but now to be made at the Royal Small Arms Factory at Enfield, England, under the name "Bren," is among the newest implements of warfare that will be tested out by the troops new assembling here for the annual collective training of the regular army.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- To the general conferences of its three main divisions a constitution for a united Methodist Church of 20,000,000 constituent members was tendered today.
RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Cecil Smith's Texas quartet won the Rumson Country Club's 16-goal polo tournament today after a hardfouht battle with the Monmouth County C.C. team. The score was 6 to 4.

Wiley Post literally climbed to the heights of international fame from the comparative obscurity of the barren plains, of Texas and Oklahoma. He overcame many obstacles, physical and financial, before he emerged, like a character from a Jules Verne fantasy, as one of the great aerial pioneers of the world.

VIENNA, Aug. 16. -- An addition to the collection of reports relating to the German "blood purge" of June 30, 1934, was published in this week's issue of Sturm Ueber Oesterreich, organ of the Catholic Oestmark group, headed by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg.

Will Rogers had what it takes to tickle the national funny bone. His wry countenance, with its occasionally wistful expression, was comical to see, and his consciously cultivated drawl lent a rustic savor to his sophisticated quips. Most important of all, he had the knack of translating into trenchant phrases the inchoate thoughts of masses of "average" Americans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -Cotton consumed in July was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 391,771 bales of lint and 62,137 bales of linters, compared with 385,946 and 61,905 during June this year, and 359,951 and 63,484 during July last year.
Jimmy Rogers, youngest son of Will Rogers, received the news of his father's death from an official of the Hotel Gotham, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, where he is staying.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Harry L. Hopkins's new order gave permission for employment of union labor exclusively, whether on relief rolls or not, on all work-relief projects carried out under contract.

While the advance in retail distribution was less marked this week than last, activity continued pronounced in the wholesale markets as buyers hastened to replenish depleted inventories on a rising market and released long-postponed orders as delivery delays grew imminent, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16. -- Johnny Allen lost his temper at League Park today, and the Yanks dropped a three-run lead, then rounded out an exciting afternoon by presenting their farewell game to the Indians, 8 to 5. They also missed a chance to gain on the Tigers, who were beaten by the Senators.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP). -Army transport officers wrestled tonight with the problem of an ever-increasing flow of civilian tourists that threatened to jam highways through Central and Northern New York and interrupt the largest peace-time movement of troops in the nation's history.
The plan to build a $45,000,000 city electric power plant as a yardstick to bring about general reduction in electric rates was revived yesterday by the La Guardia administration.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -Slowly, running before a soft breeze that hauled about, the New York Yacht Club fleet straggled in here tonight on its cruise to the eastward.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- A new exodus of German Jews who now see before them only economic ruin and a return to the ghetto, if not worse, appeared inevitable today as business, governmental and Jewish circles carefully appraised the significance and effect of the antiSemitic demonstration led by Julius Streicher in Berlin last night.

Playing on the basis of "a home run or no count," the Dodgers subdued the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday to win, 2 to 1. A victory in the final today would give the Flat-bush boys four out of five against the ambitious pennant contenders from Chicago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- With the spirit of youth, Amos Alonzo Stagg, grand old man of American football, started the seventy-fourth year of his life today, keen-eyed, happy and full of energy.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 16. -The first performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "H.M.S. Pinafore" on a water stage attracted 15,000 persons to Jones Beach tonight. Most of the audience came early, filling the 7,000 free seats by 6:30 P.M. Holders of the 3,000 reserved seats arrived before the overture, which was played at 9 P.M.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 16. -Horses owned by Miss Cynthia Myers of Cleveland predominated today during the opening session of the sixth annual Lake Placid show, which will continue through Sunday. Her gray mare Silver Dare won the novice saddle and mare and gelding events.
Henry M. Ferguson is in the office of Munds, Winslow Potter in the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose about $2 a bale yesterday after confident assertions had been made by two more Southern Senators that a 12-cent producers' loan would be announced soon. Aggressive speculative and trade buying carried October to 11.60 cents a pound, or $4 a bale above the low quotations made on Wednesday.

In its account of the proposed memorial to Grover Cleveland THE TIMES published the names of the citizens' committee, with Colonel William Graham Rice, who was Cleveland's secretary when Cleveland was first elected President, as the probable chairman.

THE Cardinals had lost two out of three to the Giants and Manager Frisch was seated on his Westchester piazza in a new easy chair, trying to take things easy and get his breath before leading his River Rowdies against Colonel Bill Terry's men again.
Dizzy Dean, elongated ace of the Cardinals, is still tops when the heat is on and the chips are down.

Ford has scads of money. He made it selling automobiles to people. Without people to sell to, he could not have made his money. Therefore the people are entitled to get it back through confiscatory governmental taxes.

The general advance in commodity futures was maintained yesterday and all staples were firmer, with the exception of rubber and sugar. In the cash markets, wheat, frye, oats, cotton, lard, silk, tin, coffee and cocoa advanced, while corn and rubber declined.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- A Senate investigation of the effect of the government's silver-purchase program was ordered today with hearings to begin "immediately."

Five persons, including two 8-year-old children, were injured about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a privately owned automobile and a police radio car crashed at Grand and Mott Streets in the midst of a neighborhood Italian celebration.

Opposition to passage in the House of the Duffy Copyright Bill as amended in the Senate by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, providing for copyright registration of models and designs applicable to merchandise sold in retail stores, was expressed yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, through its counsel, Irving C. Fox.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Merritt (Sugar) Cain, whose 1935 hurling achievements have been anything but astonishing, today set a new American League strike-out record for the year by fanning thirteen batters, and the Browns defeated the Athletics, 7 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- In the face of the most serious party schism which has yet confronted any of President Roosevelt's projects for industrial reform, the Guffey-Snyder Coal Bill was manoeuvred by House leaders tonight into a position for final action on Monday.
Since coming events cast their shadows before them to the point of eclipsing this seasonal interlude, today's first dispatch will look to the future. Something like this:

TOKYO, Japan, Aug. 16 (AP). -- One of the most imposing arrays of mermen ever assembled for dual competition in the history of speed swimming finished training today for the three-day American-Japan aquatic meet beginning tomorrow night in the Meiji Shrine pool. The meet is expected to reveal definitely the championship trend for the Olympic Games in Berlin next year.

MAYSVILLE, Mo., Aug. 16. -- A crowd of about 200 farmers blocked a farm foreclosure sale here today and beat J. Lyman Andrews of St. Joseph, mortgage trustee, and a companion, forcing them to leave town.
ROME, Aug. 16. -- With the opening of the three-power negotiations in Paris, the centre of interest in the Italo-Ethiopian controversy has shifted from the Italian to the French capital.

Lewis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday temporary workmen's compensation rates for the dust disease, silicosis, one of the occupational ills covered by an amendment to the Compensation Act passed at the last session of the Legislature.
MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 16. -- A wave of shock and deep regret spread over this city on receipt of the news of the deaths of Will Rogers and Wiley Post. Both were greatly admired in Mexico.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Jessie Spicer, 14 years old, of 444 East Fifty-eighth Street, decided that Sultan would be a good name for the male llama because he is so "superior looking." James Buckley, 12, of Sharon, Conn., who was in town for a visit to the dentist, selected Toothbrush for one of the zebras.

NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 16. -Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa of New York introduced their eldest daughter, Miss Elena L. Villa, tonight at a large ball, held at Fairholme, their Summer home on Ochre Point, long the Summer residence of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel.

Second-grade railroad bonds and public utility issues assumed yesterday the leadership in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government loans again lost ground but on a reduced trading volume. Total bond transactions on the Exchange amounted to $12,310,900, compared with $13,963,600 on Thursday.

MONTREAL, Aug. 16 (AP). -- A home run inside the park by Fresco Thompson with the bases full climaxed a five-run attack by the Montreal Royals in the fifth inning tonight and gave them a 5-4 victory over the Newark Bears in the opener of a four-game series.

VIENNA, Aug. 16. -- There is no foreign telephonic communication with Albania and a rigid censorship preventing reliable news makes it impossible, forty-eight hours after the assassination of Inspector General Leon de Ghilardi, to obtain the true circumstances of the killing and its repercussions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A bill authorizing expenditure of up to $25,000 to buy the Winnie Mae, Wiley Post's famous plane in which he set the present round-the-world record and made experiments in stratosphere flying, was passed unanimously today by the Senate and House.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- Throughout the day and until late this evening, with only an interval for luncheon, Premier Pierre Laval, Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy have been in conference at the Quai d'Orsay over the Italo-Ethiopian problem in an effort to avert a war, with its resultant repercussions in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Registration applications filed with the SEC by over-the-counter dealers on Form 1-M between July 26 and Aug. 10 included the following New York City dealers:

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 16. -- To Miss Miriam Winslow went top laurels today at the Cohasset horse show, the daughter of Sidney Winslow taking blue ribbons with her Hob Nob and Nob Girl in the pair saddle pony class, and with Hob Nob in the event for saddle ponies 14.2 hands and under.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 16. -- With a view to amplifying statements issued recently by certain government departments, and correcting possible misconceptions in the foreign press regarding the status of the foreign debt and the Mexican army, President Lazaro Cardenas has given the following exclusive statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 16. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt passed last night at the Mountain View House, Whitefield, on the way from Campobello, N.B., to Hyde Park, N.Y. She drove her own car. She dined last evening at the Mountain View with Mr. and Mrs. Henry Parish, Mrs. Van H. Dodge and Mr. and Mrs. Frank Schuyler Dodge.

Writing under the caption "The New Deal and the Old," Mr. McHugh of Philadelphia criticizes a recent speech made by Governor Nice of Maryland, and his expressed wish for a return to "National Sanity" -- a wish which I am sure every American will re-echo.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Securities on the London Stock Exchange developed jumpy nerves this afternoon because of the international situation and heavy selling developed just before the closing of the market. British Government stocks were weak all day, the war loan ending five shillings down.

Surf casters on the Jersey shore have had indifferent luck with bluefish so far this season. A party of New Yorkers visited Ortley Beach, near Seaside Heights, on Thursday and failed to hook a blue, but six fish were caught by other anglers casting from the same stretch of beach.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Hearst, who have recently come from California, will pass the week-end here with Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice. They will arrive tomorrow at Montauk on a yacht. Other week-end house guests of Mr. and Mrs. Rice will be Mr. and Mrs. John Carney and Charles Tucker of New York.

New bond financing this week amounted to $102,884,000, the largest since the mark of $234,148,000, in the week ended on July 19. This week's total compares with $40,693,000 last week and only $989,000 in the corresponding week of 1934.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 . -- The National Red Cross was compiling today a remarkable honor roll, the good deeds of Will Rogers. It ran like this:

Italians in the lower East Side witnessed scenes reminiscent of their native country yesterday when the feast of Saint Roch (San Rocco) was celebrated in Roosevelt Street with the color and pageantry of the old world.

It is not only the aviators who bow their heads to pay a tribute to the memory of WILEY POST. There can be no doubt that the public as well is deeply affected. For he was not just one of hundreds who now cleave the skies in the routine service of an age that but yesterday learned the way of an eagle in the air.

PALMER, Alaska, Aug. 16. -- Will Rogers dropped into the Matanuska Valley at 3:15 P.M. Wednesday with a wisecrack on his lips. He pronounced the colony "Fine! Fine!" after a ninety-minute examination, and flew off with a departing wisecrack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- All foreigners coming to the United States on business, regardless of how brief their stay, must, under a rule of years' standing, pay a tax on income earned while here, the Internal Revenue Bureau said today.

Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, declared yesterday he thought some of the money devoted to public works should be allocated as subsidies to private industry, as a means of unemployment relief. Mr. Deutsch returned with his wife and two daughters after a six weeks' vacation abroad.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 16. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, tonight attacked the recent statement by officials of the United States Department of Commerce to the effect that "labor is receiving a larger portion of total income today than it did in 1929."

Fourteen universities have already adopted for use the two-volume "History of Western Civilization" by Harry Elmer Barnes. Harcourt, Brace Co., who will publish this work on Sept. 12, also report that the book is arousing much interest among booksellers.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 16. -By defeating Miss Charlotte Glutting on the nineteenth hole of the Hotel Champlain course, Miss Sylva Annenberg today reached the final round of the women's New York State invitation golf championship for the second year in succession.

The ambulance fleet of the city hospitals was augmented yesterday when twelve new vehicles were placed on display at the grounds of Bellevue Hospital, facing the East River between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets. They were officially inspected by Joseph Le Ray, chief of transportation of the Department of Hospitals.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Par held no terrors for the amateur-professional teams in the one-day golf tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at Hudson River today as seventeen best-ball teams, half the field, cracked the standard figure of 70.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Long Jim Barnes of Crescent, former British and United States open champion, and Jimmy Hines, recent winner of the Long Island open title, today won the first best-ball tournament of the newly formed Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the Salisbury golf links.

EAST POULTNEY, Vt., Aug. 16. A three-day celebration of the sesquicentennial of the Poultney Baptist Church was opened tonight on the village green with an open-air dinner. About 150 persons attended.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- British and foreign military authorities here said today that an Italo-Ethiopian war was likely to break out between the first and third weeks of September.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 16. -- Governor George H. Earle today urged the American Legion at its State convention here to ignore anti-Red drives in this country and follow "the path of liberalism" in order to "block the attempt of organized wealth to deliver us into fascism and dictatorship."

After reading Jim Tully's "Ladies in the Parlor," Magistrate Jonah Goldstein decided in Yorkville Court yesterday that the book was indecent and held the defendant corporation, Greenberg Publishers, Inc., for trial in Special Sessions.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, Aug. 16. -- Will Rogers, beloved humorist, and Wiley Post, master aviator, were crushed to death last night when a shiny, new airplane motor faltered and became an engine of tragedy near this outpost of civilization.
