SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Just short of $100,000 was bid tonight for forty-nine yearlings which passed through the sales ring before one of the most responsive gatherings of the Spa season. With the town filling up for the Travers and other stakes, there was little surprise when the total of $99,350 was announced. This made for an average of $2,028.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -What the world has missed in the sudden death of Jesse Irving M. Brewer, eccentric, who died on the eve of a proposed announcement to the world of his solution of the problem of perpetual motion, may never be known.

Reports reaching New York from London yesterday disclosed that unfavorable comment had been occasioned in British journalistic circles by the action of the United States Government in compelling Sir Percival Phillips, special correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, to pay an income tax during his recent visit to this country.

An accumulation of $66,916 interest on a $1,100,000 loan extended to the Alleghany Corporation by J.P. Morgan Co. is disclosed in the corporation's statement for June 30. Under a reorganization plan proposed by the corporation, the bankers agreed to take new $2.50 prior preferred stock in settlement of the debt.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The New York Yacht Club fleet arrived at its clubhouse here on the annual cruise late this afternoon. There was much entertaining in honor of members of the fleet tonight.

The Van Sweringen interests have arranged to surmount another financial hurdle soon with an offer to extend for three years $14,988,000 of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railway 6 per cent notes which will mature on Oct. 1. The I.C.C. sanctioned the plan yesterday.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Four heats were necessary before McGregor Guy, owned by Michael Schneider of Milwaukee, earned the decision in the free-for-all trot, one of the two feature events on the getaway Grand Circuit program at Good Time Park today. Harry McKay held the reins.
Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio moved formally yesterday to defy Republican demands for a special State-wide election this year for Representative at Large to test New Deal sentiment in the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Unanimous agreement on every feature of the hotly contested bill to change the nation's banking laws was reached by Senate and House conferees late today and arrangements were made to hurry this highly important measure through both branches of Congress early next week.

New State and municipal financing officially scheduled for next week amounts to $13,655,258, compared with a revised total of $79,847,713 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $24,372,318.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -The cotton carry-over at the end of the cotton year, July 31, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have been 7,208,570 bales, compared with 7,743,695 a year ago and 8,164,634 two years ago.

He came to hold such a place in the public mind, that of his passing from the stage it might be said, as it was by Dr. JOHNSON of GARRICK'S, that it will "eclipse the gayety of nations."
BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- After winning the first three games of the series the Braves reverted to their usual form today and dropped a double-header to the Reds, 3 to 1, and 4 to 3.

WAKE ISLAND, Saturday, Aug. 17. -- American aerial pioneering of a trade route to the Orient was completed today with the conclusion of the first flight over the 1,191 miles of open ocean from Midway Island. The Pan American Clipper landed in the lagoon at 12:29 P.M. (9:29 P.M. Friday in New York).

This year's national polo championship, starting at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury on Sept. 7, will become in addition to the title competition, the proving ground for an international match as it was announced yesterday that England's official challenge for 1936 had arrived at the offices of the United States Polo Association.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The historic Travers, oldest stake now renewed in this country, will be run at the Spa tomorrow for the sixty-sixth time, with every probability that E.O. Shaffer's St. Bernard will go to the post a definite favorite.

Miss Helen Jacobs, women's national tennis champion, met with her first singles defeat at Forest Hills since 1931 yesterday as America's hopes of retaining the Wightman Cup suffered a severe setback in the loss of both the opening singles matches.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 16. -Percy M. Pike's Opera Bouffe won the fifth and C.C. Hastings's Center Lane the sixth race today at Narragansett Park, the two events featuring an all-claiming program. The purses in each were $1,200, the other six being $1,000.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 16. -- Intercession by President Roosevelt himself today appeared likely to give freedom to Lloyd Whiteleather, 29, of Ripon, Calif., arrested here last night after he was found hiding beneath the observation platform on the President's special train.

SEATTLE, Aug. 16. -- Will Rogers and Wiley Post were killed last night when the motor of their plane failed and the craft plunged into a small stream fifteen miles south of Point Barrow, Alaska, the office of the Army Signal Corps, which maintains the only system of communication with Barrow, was notified today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A good showing by mid-Summer trade, aided by hot weather and a 15 per cent rise in tourist traffic, with retailers buying with more confidence despite some decline in Western crop prospects, was reported from Canada in this week's survey of business conditions in our foreign markets, made by the Commerce Department.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Reuters News Agency today reported from Peiping the murder by Chinese bandits of Gareth Jones, British newspaper correspondent.

The airplane which Wiley Post was flying with Will Rogers was built for him at the Union Air Terminal, Los Angeles. It was a special craft for his projected trip with Mrs. Post to Siberia and Moscow by way of Alaska and the Bering Strait.

MAYSVILLE, Okla., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Old friends who bore the news of Wiley Post's death to his mother and father were greeted today with this statement: "This is the news we've been dreading for years."

Early losses were retrieved yesterday by the share market in the late trading, and the continuation of the rally through to the close resulted in generally higher prices on the day. Public utility and railway issues showed the best strength throughout, with more than seventy issues of these and other groups establishing new high marks for the year.

The police were criticized from two quarters yesterday as they continued the round-up of hoboes intended to halt crime in the public parks. Yorkville Court again was the centre of activity in the drive, with Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein sentencing forty-nine men to jail.

A record-breaking number of entries has been received for the national amateur golf championship that will be held at The Country Club, Cleveland, during the week of Sept. 9, John G. Jackson, chairman of the U.S.G.A. championship committee, announced yesterday.

Foreign dispatches reporting the purchase here by a banking group headed by Lazard Freres of London of the entire block of 400,000 ordinary shares of the General Electric Company, Ltd., owned by the International General Electric Company, at the current London market price of about 61s 6d a share, or about 1,200,000 ($5,960,000), were described authoritatively here yesterday as correct.

EAST LYME, Conn., Aug. 16. -East Lyme welcomed to a historic pageant this evening her citizens and several thousand visitors as the climax of a program in observance of the tercentenary of Connecticut.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16. -- The $3,500 prize open golf tournament at the Acacia Country Club today was chiefly a lot of fun as far as Babe Ruth, former home-run king of baseball, was concerned. Ruth turned in an informal score of 43, 42 -- 85 for the eighteen-hole opener and was in trouble almost as much as out of it.

CLIFF HAVEN, N.J., Aug. 16. -Speaking from the same platform where President McKinley made his famous "the Constitution follows the flag" proclamation, Governor Lehman tonight addressed a large audience at the Catholic Summer School of America, making an eloquent plea for the enlightenment of the youth of the country as a means of controlling crime.

The New York City school budget for 1936 as adopted by the Board of Education shows an increase of a little less than 6 per cent over the 1935 budget and yet does not include provision for many "desirable" items -that is, for activities which are recognized as well within the scope of the public school in its most efficient service to the community through its children.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, informed the German radio public once again during an address at the opening of the Berlin radio exhibition this morning that the German radio was a "political radio with a conscious tendency."

The proposed elimination of waterfront property at Ninety-sixth Street and East River to make way for the construction of the Triborough Bridge caused the Maritime Association yesterday to write to the Board of Estimate warning that the area involved was an important factor in the movement of waterborne commerce and its elimination would be harmful.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16. -- The estate of. Will Rogers was conservatively estimated at $3,000,000 today in financial circles here.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The seventh-place Senators reached three Detroit pitchers for sixteen hits today, seven of them for extra bases, to beat the Tigers, 8 to 1, and gain an even break in their series.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 17. -- Officials decline to comment on the British proposals for a naval conference, but leading newspapers, which undoubtedly reflect the navy's attitude, foreshadow refusal by Japan to participate in the main conference if, as is suspected, Britain's proposal consists only of a plan combining qualitative reduction with declarations of construction programs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- National banks throughout the country showed increases in deposits, but decreases in loans and rediscounts, for the four months between March and June 29, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, revealed today.

If there is a thread of continuity running through the long session of Congress that now nears an end, it is supplied by the new Farm Bill. Snow covered Capitol Hill, and the session was barely two days old, when the Administration let it be known that it would ask for far-reaching amendments to the basic act creating AAA.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 16. -- Harry Frederickson, Oklahoma City oil man and close friend of Wiley Post, revealed tonight that the famous flier and Will Rogers were on a leisurely flight around the world at the time of their fatal Alaskan crash.

Lindbergh, technical adviser to the line, who is in Maine, and local officials of Pan American Airways were in touch yesterday with Mrs. Will Rogers and Mrs. Wiley Post to offer the facilities of Pacific Alaska Airways, a subsidiary, Juan T. Trippe, president of the parent company, said last night.

High temperatures checked retail sales expansion in the metropolitan area during the early part of the week. Some improvement was shown during the latter portion, but it is estimated that the total sales for the week of leading department stores will either show a much smaller gain than was the case last week or an even break with the figures for the same period a year ago.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 16. -- No newspapers published in the area in which Associated Gas and Electric Company operates have been more vigorous and outspoken in their denunciation of its methods than the Gannett newspapers, it was declared today by Frank E. Gannett, publisher.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 16. -Anthony Shomilak, 13 years old, tried to interest his step-sister and another girl in a new idea he had for a game of "cops and robbers" this afternoon. But the girls chose to play "house" in the rear yard of the Shomilak home at 127 West Fifteenth Street.

It cost Mrs. Ruby Schinasi of 346 West Eighty-ninth Street, widow of Leon Schinasi, cigarette manufacturer, an average of $30,000 a year to support each of her two children, Solomon, 8 years old, and Betty, 6, according to an accounting filed yesterday by her as their general guardian in Surrogate's Court.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16. -- ExPresident Marcelo Alvear formally denied today that the Radical party was in any way associated with the plot for disturbing public order that has been persistently rumored in the last few days. Mr. Alvear is the Radical party's national chairman.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, recrowned queen of the world's tennis courts, will not play in the national championships at Forest Hills, she announced today.

Buddy, a 5-year-old wire-haired fox terrier, has been assured of a comfortable home and an income of $20 a week for the rest of his life by the bequest of his former master, Percy Jacobs, who died on July 18 at 31-44 Thirtieth Street, Long Island City.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Leading grain markets developed a much firmer undertone today as traders viewed the general news as more favorable to holders than for some time. In addition to a sharp upturn in Liverpool and reports of continued dry weather in Argentina, temperatures as low as 20 degrees above zero were reported in Northern Saskatchewan and Alberta, causing, it was said, heavy damage to the new wheat crop.

PONCA CITY, Okla., Aug. 16 (AP). -- "I wish to God I had been with him when he crashed," Mrs. Wiley Post, widow of the flier, exclaimed here today as she received word of her husband's death in Alaska.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- An increase of less than 1 per cent in the number of men employed in the construction industry in July as compared to June was noted today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, who reported on a survey of 1,400 contractors who report to Dr. E.B. Patton of the Labor Division of Statistics and Information.

Probably never has the death of a single person not a high government official or one active in the financial or business world had such wide repercussions in the financial community as did the death yesterday of Will Rogers. No sooner had the report of his death been flashed to Wall Street than the stock of Fox Film dropped more than a point.

The Atlantic Refining Company and subsidiaries had a net profit of $255,378 for the first h of this year, after expenses, taxes, depreciation, depletion, interest and other charges, according to the pamphlet report that will be made public today.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., Aug. 16. -- Torn by grief, Mrs. Will Rogers, her daughter Mary and her sister, Miss Theba Blake, left their place today for New York City, en route to the Rogers home in California.

With silver purchases by the United States Treasury in London reduced yesterday, the yound sterling declined. In the last few days heavy buying for the government in Washington has necessitated large purchases of sterling exchange, forcing the pound up to the highest price since last November.

County Judge Thomas Downs of Queens was sued in the New York Supreme Court yesterday by Lorenzo C. Carlino, a lawyer, for $50,000 damages. The lawyer charged that Judge Downs, after finding him guilty of contempt of court in a trial, and fining him $250, had knocked him down and kicked him at the St. Albans Golf Club in Queens.

St. John's University has rejected an offer to play basketball next February with a visiting team of Y.M.C.A. boys from Mexico, D.F., James Ambrose Freeman, director of athletics, announced yesterday.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Two of golf's inseparable companions, Tommy Goodwin, Westchester amateur champion, and his clubmate, Richard Chapman of Winged Foot, are slated to clash in the semi-final round of the annual Green Meadow invitation tourney tomorrow.

A letter from Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar-General of the Archdiocese of New York, to the clergy will be read tomorrow at every mass in all the churches of the archdiocese, giving details of the National Eucharistic Congress to be held in Cleveland, Ohio, Sept. 23-26.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The popularity which Will Rogers enjoyed in Great Britain may be measured to some extent by the way the news of his death and that of his companion Wiley Post swept all other news off the front pages of London's evening papers, but still more so by the depth of feeling shown in the tributes of his many friends here.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Mary Zuk, leader of the housewives buying strike which has harassed Detroit butchers for four successive week-ends, today said a delegation leaving for Washington tonight would demand abolition of AAA processing taxes.

The New Life Movement in China, fathered by Chiang Kai-shek, "to give new life to a nation whose people have long been accustomed to the habits or disorderliness, dullness, weakness and vulgar manner," is showing its effects. The movement, set forth in a series of precepts or laws, had its inception in February, 1934, in Nanchang, the provincial capital of Kiangsi, where headquarters are maintained by a national organization formed in support.

Communist and American Federation of Labor groups joined yesterday in a Union Square demonstration against the Works Progress Administration. Hugh S. Johnson, WPA administrator, was the chief object of denunciation.

Generally regarded as the most successful held, the National Linen and Domestics Show closed yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, with all previous attendance records broken and with substantial orders having been placed. More than 1,000 buyers, the largest number since the shows were inaugurated several years ago, visited the exhibits of seventy-six manufacturers and covered their Fall requirements in a substantial manner.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- A full program will entertain week-end visitors at the White Mountains resorts, where today is marked by exhibition golf matches at Maplewood Club, Mountain View, Whitefield, the Waumbek at Jefferson, the Bretton Woods Golf Club and the Bethlehem Country Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- A masquerade supper dance arranged by younger members of the Summer colony was held at the Beach Club tonight. Proceeds will be donated to the Southampton Hospital. Henry Herman Harjes headed the group in charge of the arrangements, which included Mrs. Harjes, Miss Katherine Blake, Mrs. Rogers C. Dunn, Miss Mildred Nicoll and Miss Rita Mitchell.

The police here continued yesterday to stop and check persons driving automobiles with Georgia license plates, following a request by the Motor Vehicle Bureau in Albany. At the same time Paul Doyal, chairman of the Georgia Revenue Commission, issued a denial in Atlanta that Georgia was conducting a "mail order license plate business," according to The Associated Press.

FROM Morley College for Working Men and Women in London comes the announcement, signed by Ralph Vaughan Williams, chairman of committee, and sponsored by a distinguished group of musicians of England and America, of a projected memorial to the late Gustav Holst, one of the leading figures among modern composers.
BERGEN, Norway, Aug. 17. -- Our happiness over our arrival here is dimmed by thoughts of the death of Wiley Post and Will Rogers and by sympathy for their families.

Despite the fact that he staged a successful disappearing act for a month, Howard Colwell Hopson is no magician. He cannot be in two places at once. That shortcoming gave rise to excitement and comedy in Washington last week; upon Mr. Hopson's return from his month-long disappearance a Senate committee and a House committee struggled with all their might and dignity to get simultaneous possession of him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Journeying eastward, with an unseasonable dark top-coat over his arm, on what was described as a routine business visit, former President Hoover prefaced a series of private political conferences last week by trying to draw fire from the administration Democrats on the question of changes in the Constitution.

BUENOS AIRES. -- The National Cotton Board has inaugurated a vast plan of government aid to cotton growers to help them improve the already favorable position which Argentine cotton has won in European markets. The plan includes the colonization of government lands, indemnity for the destruction of poor-quality plantings, bonuses for the production of pedigreed seed under government supervision, and bounties for fields devoted to improving the standard type of Chaco cotton.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 16. -- Open attacks on President Roosevelt's administration this week by Minnesota's Farmer-Labor Governor, Floyd B. Olson, are the latest in a series of incidents which have aroused speculation over the status of the working arrangement that existed from 1932 to 1934 between the "regular" faction of the local Democratic party and this State's third party.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Department of Justice men said today that George Barrett, 48, would stand trial in Indianapolis for killing Nelson B. Klein, 37, Cincinnati "G-man." Barrett will be taken there as soon as his wounds permit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- If the Republican voters in the next eight months show that they sincerely desire Senator Borah as their standard-bearer, he will seek the nomination aggressively and make a number of speeches in advance of the first real primary test in Ohio in May, it was learned today.

A special meeting of the State Chamber of Commerce will be held at noon on Tuesday to take formal action in regard to "the wasteful expenditures of Federal funds and the futility of the Tax Bill now before Congress." The meeting, called by Thomas I. Parkinson president of the chamber, in response to a demand from members, will be held in the great hall at 65 Liberty Street, headquarters of the chamber.

A vast expansion in the dramatic activities of the work-relief administration -- activities that already have provided to hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers their first acquaintance with the stage -- is planned under the new Federal WPA set-up.

Six of the sixteen recognized American outboard motor boat speed records have been broken this season, according to new tables figured last week by the National Outboard Association. Amateur drivers have made four of the new marks, two in competition and two in time trials, and the professional racers have set two.

SEATTLE, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Technical Staff Sergeant Stanley R. Morgan, the Signal Corps man at Point Barrow who recovered the bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post, will visit the United States this Fall for the first time since he and Mrs. Morgan entered the barren lands of Northern Alaska seven years ago.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 17. -- That the good in a fair wind can be undone by a foul tide was clearly demonstrated today on the cruise of the New York Yacht Club here from Newport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- A Democratic Representative from the farm belt, Clarence Cannon of Missouri, charged today that packers organized the Detroit housewives' "strike" against high meat prices "as a part of their campaign against the processing tax."

The grief-stricken family of Will Rogers gathered here last night and prepared to leave for California by train tomorrow afternoon for the funeral of the comedian, killed with Wiley Post in an airplane crash in Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Official War Department figures show that 1,221 United States soldiers died in hospitals as a result of gas poisoning during the World War. In addition, it was estimated today that about 200 died on the battlefield as the result of gas.

ALL the year round New York buys foodstuffs in the streets, but Summer is the peak season for trading at the curbs. At fixed pushcart stands, or from itinerant peddlers, housewives shop for bargains in melons and peaches, in cucumbers and carrots and new green corn.

WHEN the first link of the Pan-American Highway. connecting the Texas city of Laredo with the capital of Mexico, is thrown open to regular traffic, it will lead Mexico into a new era. Elderly Americans who remember our own railroad-building decades would have a very good idea of the reason why.

The recent flare-up in the WPA projects indicates the difficulties that confront government officials in dealing with unemployment. Consideration should be given beforehand to the common grounds which would be approved by the various groups involved in any program of relief.

TESTING can determine the growing power of any seed. The amateur gardener who has seeds gathered from his own plants last season, or seeds left over from a previous planting, may determine for himself whether or not his seeds are worth planting.

EAST MACHIAS, Me., Aug. 17. -- Nearly a thousand men and women of this wood manufacturing centre as well as hundreds of vacationists from the Hadley Lake Summer colony were battling for their homes late tonight as a forest fire swept toward the village.
CANADA, which every American vacationist is said to visit sooner or later, is not content to rest on her laurels, but is busily engaged in providing fresh lures for sportsman and tourist.

The President's signature last week of the bill restoring Spanish-American War pensions will have a direct effect on the Treasury's position during the current fiscal year. Expenditures for veterans' relief are already running ahead of those a year ago. The bill approved by the President will add an estimated $46,000,000 to the Government's outlay for this purpose.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, Aug. 17. -- The World Alliance for International Friendship Through Churches, meeting near here, declared in a resolution on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, unanimously adopted today:

EAST POULTNEY, Vt., Aug. 17. -- Residents of this historic little village and scores of distinguished guests from all sections of the United States tonight relived early days of this part of Vermont as a pageant, "Green Mountain Days," featured the second day of the sesquicentennial celebration of the Baptist church here.

PORTLAND, ME. MAINE -- State of mountains, lakes and rugged seashore -- is this season enjoying a gain in patronage from Summer vacationists conservatively estimated by old-timers in the resort field at 25 to 40 per cent over last year.

THE bulk of action in this fast-moving adventure novel transpires either aboard the Simplon-Orient Express, eastward bound, or at the places where the train halts and the impromptu tumultuous events which mark the course of the journey. M. Bordier, a minor Parisian journalist, is ordered by his editor to entrain hurriedly for Sofia, imminent revolution and war in the Balkans threatening a crisis like that of 1914.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Postponement of passage of new tax legislation until the next session of Congress is understood to have been urged in a report submitted to President Roosevelt by the Commerce Department Business Advisory Council.

Once a place of milling crowds, the overhead extension of the Manhattan terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge is now being torn down. Its fate is linked with the rehabilitation of City Hall Park incident to the proposed demolitation of the old General Postoffice and the clearing of the vista of the Civic Centre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- In the face of very little opposition, the Guffey-Snyder Bituminous Coal Control Bill was rushed through the amending stage in the House today with only one important modification.

BERLIN, Aug. l7. -- The past fortnight has witnessed a series of manifestations in various parts of the Reich which, if accepted at their face value, might create impression abroad that opponents of the Hitler regime are now boldly venturing out into the open.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. l7. -- After waiting an hour and a half in almost complete calm, a light but steady breeze came out of the south-southwest today to give seventy-eight craft in a dozen classes a race in the Huguenot Yacht Club's thirty-ninth annual regatta.

The current report of the Foreign Policy Association is devoted to a study of England's progress toward industrial recovery. As a dispatch to THE TIMES reported recently, the number of unemployed has declined to less than 2,000,000, compared with nearly 3,000,000 in January, 1933.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17. -- A huge plaza here was jammed this afternoon with thousands of men and women who cheered the speakers of the Leftist parties as they energetically denounced what they described as the reactionary and anti-democratic tendencies of the Justo government and warned of imminent danger of a Fascist dictatorship.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With horse shows, tennis tournaments and theatricals on the wane as Summer diversions, bridge parties for charity have become quite the vogue among the colonists of the North Jersey shore. One of the outstanding events of this kind will be staged at the Monmouth Beach Club on Wednesday as a benefit for the Monmouth Memorial Hospital at Long Branch.

Events in the world market for silver last week appeared to indicate that the silver policy of the United States was fast approaching a situation which might necessitate a radical change in it. The United States Treasury was disclosed as in the position of supporting the rapidly declining price of silver in a foreign market at a cost running as high as $16,800,000 a day.

The strike called by the New York building trades unions, which last week-end posed a big question mark over the entire national work-relief program, failed to materialize with sufficient intensity to stop a single project.

In 1912 Louis D. Brandeis, now justice of the United States Supreme Court, declared that "a large part of our people have learned that efficiency in business does not grow indefinitely with the size of business."

FOR thirty years Jessica Blanche Peixotto has been a member of the faculty of the University of California, first as a lecturer in sociology, but advancing to the position in 1918 of Professor of Social Economics. Recently she became professor emeritus.

A SIGNAL device designed to warn motorists automatically on approaching dangerous zones is reported from Baltimore by Charles Adler Jr., laboratory research worker. According to Mr. Adler, it has been tested on private cars and commercial vehicles with successful results.

LONDON. DISAPPOINTMENT is the prevailing note of most of the reviews of Jessie Conrad's "Joseph Conrad and his Circle" (Jarrolds). Thus, her claim to "the most intimate acquaintance with that complex mind of any person who knew him" is pronounced, by The Times to be only partially true.

IN the manoeuvres and deliberations which have accompanied the Tax Bill now before Congress, Robert M. La Follette, Senator from Wisconsin, has had a major part. It was he with his liberal colleagues who last June signed the Senatorial round-robin demanding the passage of tax legislation at this session.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17. -- Lincoln Ellsworth and Mrs. Ellsworth arrived here from Europe today on the Graf Zeppelin. They will spend three weeks in Matto Grosso exploring the jungle and hunting.

Leading pulpits in Manhattan will today be occupied by clergymen from Great Britain, three churches having as their guest preachers Presbyterian pastors in Glasgow. Others of the visiting ministers will be from England, and still others will be from Canada.

PALMA, Aug. 2. THE Chopin Festivals held every Summer in the Island of Majorca are attracting increasing international attention, both for their musical interest and, still more probably, for the unspoiled charm of their background. This year's commemoration, the fifth of the series, brought to the "golden isle" considerable numbers of peninsular and foreign music lovers and tourists to swell the large crowd of Mallorquines who attended the three days' celebrations.

SALZBURG, Aug. 17. -- Dusolina Giannini made her belated entry in the Salzburg Festival this evening, singing the part of Mistress Ford in Toscanini's production "Falstaff." Only here and there did her voice show lingering traces of her recent cold, and these might easily have escaped casual notice.

A LITTLE more than a year ago a small two-place biplane was scooting about the heavens above Oakland Airport. Observers noted two interesting things about it. First, it had the quietest power plant they had ever seen and heard.

THE COLOPHON, new series, does not contain an original print as one of its features, and its text is less fully illustrated than heretofore. The articles are no longer manufactured at separate printing establishments but are all set up, in uniform type and on the same paper, by the Pynson Printers.
RETICENT hints may have stolen from time to time into these columns, to the effect that the traveler does not search in vain for art in the summery American countryside and at the seashore.

HUNGARY celebrates this month the festival of St. Stephen, who was the first to wear the holy Hungarian crown and who converted the population to Christianity some nine centuries ago. Considered one the greatest statesmen of the nation, he adapted Western European principles of government to the needs of his liberty-loving Hungarians and organized the country on a solid foundation.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 16. -- Citizens of States adjacent to Virginia appear considerably more excited over the abnormal prevalence of infantile paralysis here than the Virginians themselves. Except in Albemarle County and the City of Charlottesville, where there have been 109 cases since July 1, or slightly more than one-fourth of the total for the entire State, there has been no terribly alarming concentration of the disease.
ROME, Aug. 17. -- The Italian press publishes today under dateline of Jibuti, French Somaliland, a report of a new incident on the frontier of Ethiopia and French Somaliland.

The disappointing volume in August cloth coat sales has not dampened the enthusiasm of retailers as to general retail business, which is maintaining a better pace than for the same month last year, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

It is stated in Washington, on behalf of the President, that he does not intend in his coming trip through the West to take up at all the question of amending the Constitution. One reason given for this decision is that he does not believe that the public at present is taking real interest in the subject.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Members' polo at the Meadow Brook Club filled in today's program, leading to the most active Sunday of the Long Island season. Six of the teams entered in next month's championship will be in action on three fields tomorrow.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Army Signal Corps men, serving every important point in Alaska and linking them with the outside world by radio, rose to the occasion when the Rogers-Post airplane tragedy caused an almost unprecedented flow of private and press messages.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H. -- The coming week will be so full of activity at Lake Sunapee that people will have to budget their time if they expect to take in everything. New Londoners are likely to be awakened on Tuesday morning by some one who comes to tag them for the new London Hospital, for that is the annual tag day for that institution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The government is now in the real estate business as a home owner, but only on a modest scale, which permits operations in a careful manner. It got into this business much against its will, when the Home Owners Loan Corporation was forced to institute 910 foreclosure proceedings.
THE annual exhibition of Southern Vermont Artists will open to the public in Manchester Aug. 25, following a private view and reception the day before. Henry E. Schnakenberg reports:

IMPORTANT questions for the future in regard to legal differences arising out of the operation of transport airplanes which, it is believed, will have increasing bearing as the oceans as well as the continents come to be spanned regularly by scheduled aircraft services, will come before the tenth meeting of the Comite International Technique d'Experts Juridiques Aeriens, commonly known as the Citeja, scheduled for The Hague about Sept. 20.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 16. -- Senator Huey P. Long's recent announcement that he would be a candidate for President in 1936 was being taken with a smile in Louisiana, not only by his opponents, but by his political allies as well.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Close finishes featured the opening of the Stone Harbor Yacht Club's first annual sailboat regatta today. Skippers from Island Heights, Raritan Bay and South Jersey combined to make the first day's races interesting and entertaining to the thousands of residents and visitors lining the course.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 17. -Consistently outplaying her opponent, Miss Marjorie Harrison of Ausable Forks, N.Y., this afternoon after taking a two-hole lead on the first eighteen, Miss Sylva Annenberg of Lakeville today gained a second leg on the women's New York State invitation golf championship trophy.

Centralized buying, handled through the Amtorg Trading Corporation, will still control 90 per cent of the orders placed by the Soviet in this country, despite announcement last week that home organizations in Russia will be permitted to buy direct from abroad.

BATH alone, among the English resorts, can claim more glamour than Brighton, and not even Bath can claim more history. The fate of the two places has been very different, and Brighton's the less enviable; for where the great watering place withered away in genteel dowdiness, the great seaside town has not perished but grown vulgar.

Conclusion of "compensation" dollar agreements, similar to those concluded by a number of Latin-American countries with Germany and Japan, was urged yesterday necessary to the preservation of this country's markets for finished goods in South America, by Joseph D. Bohan, export manager of the Centaur Co., and chairman of the foreign trade section of the Proprietary Association.

RUPERT HUGHES has presented in "The Man Without a Home" a more than usually fascinating bit of historical research. Or, rather, it would have seemed a fascinating bit of research if it had been cast in any other form than fiction.

BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- The protest of the German Consul General against the resolution adopted by the Massachusetts House of Representatives last Monday, together with the replies of the Governor and the Speaker, constitute an incident and not an issue.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 17. -- Alaska is stunned by the catastrophe at Point Barrow.

DETROIT, Aug. 17, -- At a critical moment in a crucial ball game today at Navin Field, 'Jack Saltzgaver faltered and the Yanks lost the decision, and a chance to cut a slice from the lead the Tigers hold in the pennant race.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Smashing over all their six runs in the second inning and giving Bobby Smith errorless support, the Braves defeated the Reds, 6 to 1, today, and carried off the six-game series, 4 to 2.

IT is generally conceded that in the ambitious farm-relief program represented by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration President Roosevelt and his farm experts have by the tail a large and extremely troublesome bull; that they might like to let go, but if they did the problem would immediately arise of how the bull would behave.
